title: Rows and Rows of Corpses, and Voices Choked With Sobs
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 31 - Ahmed Madi Hussein paced back and forth furiously in front of Nouman Hospital, dressed in a gray dishdasha but barefoot. Clutching his cellphone, he punched out a call, and when one of his sons answered tears began running down his cheeks.

title: A Sad Day, Too, for Architecture
description: SITTING safely in Washington, I am watching harrowing footage shot from helicopters above the Ninth Ward of New Orleans, submerged under 14 feet of water when the Mississippi thundered through the breached levee at the Industrial Canal and destroyed everything in its swirling waters.

title: Comic Improv Competition as a Festival of Putdowns
description: MTV's crass, crackling summertime hit, "Nick Cannon Presents Wild 'N Out," tries hard to develop some new streetwise talent, some new ways of luring young minds into the innovation of improv comedy. But its greatest achievement is harnessing the unstoppable energy of Nick Cannon. As host and producer, Mr. Cannon provides some solidity to a wiggy half-hour of jive talk and insult-trading, and each episode demonstrates that no one has the moves like he does.

title: Elaine Stritch: Heart, Soul and Plenty of Leg
description: SHORTLY after 10 o'clock at the Carlyle hotel one recent evening, Elaine Stritch finished her final run-through of the day and, still carrying on a conversation with her musical director, disappeared into the next room. Six straight hours of rehearsing her forthcoming solo cabaret, "Elaine Stritch at Home at the Carlyle," hadn't made a dent in her gorgeously gravelly voice. Or her audacity.

title: JetBlue Conducting Reviews For Creative and Media Work
description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it had placed in review the creative and media parts of its account, with spending estimated at $25 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 29 about a briefing for financial analysts by Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, regarding the company's growth prospects recounted one remark incorrectly. (An article in Sunday Business this week about investing in Microsoft repeated the error.) Mr. Ballmer said he had asked Microsoft employees generally -- not its executives -- whether they were buying the company's stock, and had found no takers. A Microsoft spokesman brought the error to a reporter's attention on Sunday.

title: Neck Deep in Rules, Before Getting a Toe Wet
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J. - NO jumping off the high dive at the town pool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRICKNER, RABBI BALFOUR
description: BRICKNER--Rabbi Balfour. Survived by his loving partner Marcia Soltes, his sons Adam and Rabbi Barnett, his sister Joy Rabinowitz and his four grandchildren, Alexander, Eve, Eli and Hasina. Services Thursday, 11AM, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68 St, N.Y. Contributions may be made in his memory to the National Offices of Planned Parenthood and/or the Rabbi Balfour Brickner Early Childhood Center at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, in Manhattan.

title: Drivers Fear Gasoline Shortages as Prices Climb
description: Drivers continued to line up outside gasoline stations in some parts of the United States today for a second straight day as fears about fuel shortages drove up prices.

title: Fields Casts Her Past as a Preview
description: C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president and Democratic mayoral candidate, released her first television advertisement yesterday, just two weeks before the Sept. 13 primary election. The 30-second ad, "Imagine," will begin appearing on cable channels tomorrow before moving to broadcast networks, and the Fields campaign said it would run through the rest of the campaign. The campaign would not provide a figure for how much television time Ms. Fields had purchased to present the ad, but her campaign manager, Chung Seto, said it was a "competitive buy" relative to the other candidates.

title: Iran to set up a 'love fund' with oil revenue
Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMMERMAN, JOHN WILLIAM
description: ZIMMERMAN--John William. 40, on June 13, 2005 after a brief encounter with Hodgkin's lymphoma. In accordance with his wishes, a memorial Eucharist will be celebrated on September 15 at 7 PM at St. Luke-in-the-Fields, Hudson Street at Grove Street. Reception to follow.

title: Parents, Teachers and the Crisis in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel and Pakistan hold first high-level meeting
Intricate Flood Protection Long a Focus of Dispute
description: The 17th Street levee that gave way and led to the flooding of New Orleans was part of an intricate, aging system of barriers and pumps that was so chronically underfinanced that senior regional officials of the Army Corps of Engineers complained about it publicly for years.

title: Administration Steps Up Actions, Adding Troops and Dispatching Medical Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - The Bush administration stepped up the federal response on Wednesday to the devastation from Hurricane Katrina, deploying thousands more National Guard and active-duty troops to the Gulf Coast to help with rescue and relief missions, authorizing the release of oil from the nation's strategic reserve to blunt the economic effects of the storm and dispatching food, water and medical supplies to the region.

title: Roundup: Tri-Nations rivals suffer at half back
Waiting for a Leader
description: George W. Bush gave one of the worst speeches of his life yesterday, especially given the level of national distress and the need for words of consolation and wisdom. In what seems to be a ritual in this administration, the president appeared a day later than he was needed. He then read an address of a quality more appropriate for an Arbor Day celebration: a long laundry list of pounds of ice, generators and blankets delivered to the stricken Gulf Coast. He advised the public that anybody who wanted to help should send cash, grinned, and promised that everything would work out in the end.

title: These Kids Today: A Bit Pop, a Bit Punk
description: Onstage at the MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night, Hilary Duff listed her favorite acts. "Morrissey," she began uncertainly, "Rancid, A.F.I., the Murderers." She stopped short and feigned frustration. "Ugh! I always get that one wrong," she said. She meant the Killers, not the Murderers. Her boyfriend, Joel Madden from the teen-friendly punk band Good Charlotte, was standing next to her. He pretended to be embarrassed by this faux faux pas.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Suspect In Hariri Case Freed
description: Lebanese authorities released a former pro-Syrian member of Parliament, Nasser Qandil, a day after he was detained at the request of the United Nations team investigating the killing of Rafik Hariri, a former prime minister, in a car bombing in February. The authorities continued to question three former security chiefs as well as the head of Lebanon's presidential guard, all of whom have close ties to Syria and were also named by the United Nations investigators as suspects in the February killing. Hassan M. Fattah (NYT)

title: In Hawaii
A mother's goodbye lesson
President Bushs Remarks Thursday
description: President BushAs remarks after meeting with former Presidents Clinton and Bush regarding hurricane relief, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, BLANCHE
description: SCHWARTZ -- Blanche. On August 30, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving aunt of Sandra Katz, Pherne Karp, Florence Tanner and Fred Gasthalter. She will be deeply missed by her grandnieces and nephews. Service Thursday, 9:30 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Teenager Uses Upset of Roddick to Motivate
description: It figures that Sania Mirza would find inspiration in the first-round upset of Andy Roddick by Luxembourg's Gilles Muller. Mirza, like Muller, knows how it feels to carry a racket bag sagging with the weight of a country's expectations.

title: Balfour Brickner, Activist Reform Rabbi, Dies at 78
description: Rabbi Balfour Brickner, a voice of Reform Judaism on issues like race and abortion and the rabbi emeritus of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Fort Lee, N.J., and Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Bolton Makes His Case at U.N. for a New Focus for Aid Projects
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 31 - John R. Bolton, the American ambassador here, came under fire and fired back on Wednesday over hundreds of changes he is seeking to a pivotal document on aid for the developing world and change at the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWNSTONE, CECILY
description: BROWNSTONE--Cecily. Died peacefully August 30, 2005, at the age of 96, after a long, distinguished career as a food writer. As Associated Press Food Editor, she was one of the most widely distributed food journalists in America.

title: Officials Struggle to Reverse a Growing Sense of Anarchy
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 1 - National Guard troops moved in force into this storm-ravaged city today as state and local officials struggled to reverse a growing sense of anarchy sparked by reports of armed looters, bodies floating untended in stagnant floodwaters, and food and water supplies dwindling for thousands of trapped and desperate residents.

description: Central Florida at South Carolina

title: Paris to skip Tlcom offer
Ken Germann, Who Led Columbia Athletics, Dies at 84
description: Ken Germann, a former football star and later athletic director at Columbia, and for 14 years the commissioner of the Southern Conference, died Aug. 24 in Glen Ellen, Va. He was 84.

title: Citizen Navy in a Flotilla, Eager to Save
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 - Guy T. Williams is usually to be found behind his desk downtown, where he is the president of the Gulf Coast Bank and Trust Company. But nothing is usual in New Orleans, and on Wednesday Mr. Williams was paddling his canoe in a submerged residential area between downtown and the overflowing Lake Pontchartrain, exploring flooded homes not yet reached by rescue teams.

title: Blood supply to brain is linked to dementia
Paid Notice: Deaths   SQUAIRE, LAWRENCE
description: SQUAIRE--Lawrence. On August 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Anthony and Barbara Squire, Andrew Squire and Ilya Speranza, Michael and Roseann Squire and Lori and Kenneth Einhorn. Loving grandfather of Jason, Sarah, Harry, Molly, Emma, Corey and Abby. He served as a Japanese interpreter on the USS Missouri during WWII. Services Thursday, 11:45 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Knesset lets Egyptians patrol border of Gaza
British Engineer and Translator Kidnapped in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 1 - A British engineer and his translator were kidnapped by gunmen when their convoy was ambushed on a highway in western Afghanistan, a local police official said today.

title: New contacts at WTO
Little Applauded in Life, a Recluse Goes on Display
description: Eileen Gray designed classics like the voluptuous Bibendum Chair (below left); an occasional table (center) that allowed a person to eat breakfast in bed without dropping crumbs on the sheets; and sensual modernist houses like E.1027, a hideaway for herself and Jean Badovici, an architectural critic. Still, she spent most of her life having her work ignored and did not become world famous until shortly before she died, in 1976. An exhibition opening on Sept. 17 at the Design Museum in London (designmuseum.org) will showcase her work, focusing attention on a designer whom the museum director, Alice Rawsthorn, described as "an independent outsider, a woman working in a man's world," who was "shy and reticent to the point of reclusiveness." ELAINE LOUIE CURRENTS: MODERN DESIGN

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Saint-Gobain Makes Bid for BPB
description: Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, Europe's biggest distributor of building materials, confirmed its bid of 3.68 billion ($6.62 billion) for BPB of Britain, the world's leading supplier of gypsum used to make plaster for walls and ceilings. Saint-Gobain, based near Paris, made formal its bid of 720 pence a share in an offer document that was posted Wednesday. BPB shareholders have an initial 30 days to consider the approach, which the French company first put forward on Aug. 3. Saint-Gobain's chairman, Jean-Louis Beffa, made a hostile bid after BPB rebuffed three offers for a merger, which would create the No.1 supplier of building interiors.

title: How to Make Phone Calls Without a Telephone
description: Internet telephone service is well on its way into the mainstream.

title: Arroyo allies cut impeachment case
4 Men in California Accused of Plotting Terrorist Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - Four men were indicted in Southern California on Wednesday in what federal authorities described as a terrorist plot hatched inside a prison to attack synagogues, American military installations and Israeli officials.

title: A Kitchen Pro's Personal Picks
description: Nyack, N.Y. - WHEN it comes to great kitchens, everyone's an expert. But when you're paid to be one, the stakes get more interesting.

title: A Baby Step Toward Wi-Fi Photos
description: EVERY now and then, someone combines two technologies into a single new product, and the result is a triumphant new category that changes the industry. Clock + radio. Cellphone + camera. Music player + hard drive.

title: Currencies: Revised U.S. GDP pushes dollar lower
Looks Normal at Shea, Except for the Standings
description: THREE astronauts were talking baseball. One tennis star was slugging a ground-rule double in batting practice. There were eight drums on the sideline for Taiwanese Night.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Where World-Class Sports Are Played
description: Now that Mayor Michael Bloomberg's dream of holding the Olympic Games in a grandiose stadium on the West Side of Manhattan has been dashed, it may be a good time to note that the city already has a world-class athletic site. It is doing just fine in the oft-dismissed borough of Queens, a reluctant second-choice venue for the Olympic stadium. The facility is the National Tennis Center, the host of the United States Open tennis championships this week and next in Flushing Meadows, which is attracting players from more than 60 countries. While most New York sports fans are focusing on the Yankees and the Mets, the tennis center and the Open are the truest measure of the city's global sporting prominence.

title: Fashion Veteran at 24: New York's New Star?
description: IT is something of a Fashion Week tradition to gauge which newcomer will generate the most buzz, which up-and-coming designer will whet the appetite of retailers with the presentation of mere sketches. For the New York shows, which begin Sept. 8, a leading contender is Brian Reyes, a designer who held jobs for Ralph Lauren, Michael Kors and Oscar de la Renta before branching out on his own at the age of 24.

title: AFTER THE HURRICANE
description: THE RESCUERS -- Dozens of rescue teams from the Federal Emergency Management Agency are searching for the living in the wreckage of the Gulf Coast. In places like Pass Christian, Miss., they are mostly finding the dead. PAGE A20

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Weak Support For Transport Bond Act
description: A City Council poll of 640 New York City residents found that 60 percent supported a $2.9 billion transportation bond act that will be on the ballot in November, which may not be sufficient to overcome opposition to the measure in other parts of the state, said Councilman John C. Liu, left, of Queens, the chairman of the Transportation Committee. A $3.8 billion bond measure was defeated in 2000 even though 73 percent of city voters favored it. While 64 percent of those in the recent poll agreed that more money was needed for subways and buses, only 31 percent said they believed the Metropolitan Transportation Authority would use the money effectively. The poll was conducted by telephone from July 25 to Aug. 8. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Entr'acte: The Western world through Eastern eyes
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about plans to close Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington and merge it with the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., misstated the location of the naval hospital. It is about three miles northwest of Walter Reed, not northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MESSENGER, DAVID C.
description: MESSENGER--David C. Retired partner and friend. Trained as a lawyer as well as a CPA, Dave had a facile mind and a gift of persuasion that was a joy to behold, especially when applied to tax agents. On a personal level, he was a skillful storyteller with an inexhaustive supply of jokes. Dave was a partner with our firm for many years who kept in touch after retirement. We will be missing that now, but hope that he has found peace from the illnesses that plagued him. Our sincerest sympathy is extended to Dave's wife Bobbi, his two sons & many grandchildren. The Partners and staff of H.J. Behrman & Co.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: The New College Mixer
description: Swarthmore, Pa. - WHETHER they know it or not, the 75 students moving this week into Alice Paul Hall, the sleek new dormitory alongside Parrish Lawn here at Swarthmore College, are being manipulated at nearly every turn into developing a social life.

title: Television Finds Covering Area Hit by Storm Is Like Working in a War Zone
description: After struggling with enormous logistical problems trying to cover the calamity caused by Hurricane Katrina, television news organizations moved yesterday onto what one executive called a "war footing."

title: A Sharp Increase in Reports of Planes Flying Too Close
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - The number of reported cases in the New York area in which low-altitude aircraft flew too close to each other for safety is more than six times as high as the number reported for years, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday.

title: 76 Arrested Protesting N.Y.U. Cutoff of Student Union
description: The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the secretary-treasurer of the United Auto Workers and a state senator were among nearly 80 people who were arrested yesterday during a protest of New York University's decision to end dealings with a union of graduate student teaching and research assistants.

title: Qaeda Claims Responsibility for London Bombing
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 - The Arabic news channel Al Jazeera broadcast a video late today drawing direct links for the first time between Al Qaeda and the July 7 bombings in London that claimed 56 lives in the city's worst peacetime attack.

title: Nurcholish Madjid, 66, Advocate of Moderate Islam, Dies
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 31 - Nurcholish Madjid, a prominent Muslim scholar in Indonesia who was instrumental in persuading President Suharto to step down, died here on Monday. He was 66. The cause was liver and kidney failure, according to Pondok Hospital in Jakarta.

title: First the Sticker Shock, Then On to the Shock Jock
description: Fans of Howard Stern, who is moving to Sirius satellite radio in January after getting a $500 million deal, may want to consider a new "wearable" player from Sirius so they don't miss a minute of him.

title: Ancient Yank Outduels Young Mariner
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 31 - Every game is a test for Randy Johnson, a challenge to live up to his younger self, to meet the Yankees' expectations and to pitch like an ace again. But this one, on some level, must have seemed more personal.

title: Jets Not Counting Martin's Carries...Yet
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 30 - Curtis Martin and the Jets' coaching staff have fielded numerous questions from the news media about Martin's preseason workload. But does it really matter how many carries he gets in four meaningless games?

title: The Sensitive Case of E-Mail
description: Case Can Matter With E-Mail

title: Curing Health Costs: Let the Sick Suffer
description: The word in Tennessee is that Gov. Phil Bredesen, a Democrat, has presidential aspirations. I find that interesting. Perhaps he can run on the success he's had throwing sick people off of Medicaid.

title: After Decades, Nations Focus on Rights Abuses
description: BUENOS AIRES - After years of inertia, governments throughout Latin America have recently shown surprising vigor in prosecuting human rights violations that occurred, in some cases, 30 years ago or more. Chile, for instance, has offered reparations to torture victims and forced the army to apologize for its abuses, while the Supreme Court in Argentina in June declared unconstitutional a pair of amnesty laws from the 1980's.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Growth of 3.9% in 2nd Quarter
description: The Brazilian economy expanded 3.9 percent in the second quarter, compared with a year earlier, as a surge in exports of products like iron, sugar and trucks more than offset a decline in domestic demand. The figure was faster than the 2.8 percent growth reported in the first quarter, according to the government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAXBERG, LAURENCE
description: WAXBERG--Laurence 64, on August 29, 2005. Survived by his beloved Judy, devoted children Ira and Akiko Waxberg, and Allison and Marc Milgrom. An accomplished Teacher, Advertising Art Director and Artist. Services Friday, 11:30am, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Revised Birthday Suit
description: WHEN Amy Rueckl, a 24-year-old graduate student in San Diego, tells friends that she loves being "totally bald," she is not referring to her head. For the past two years Ms. Rueckl has visited La Jolla Spa MD in California for laser treatments to remove all the hair from her pubic area.

title: In Chimpanzee DNA, Signs of Y Chromosome's Evolution
description: Scientists have decoded the chimp genome and compared it with that of humans, a major step toward defining what makes people human and developing a deep insight into the evolution of human sexual behavior.

title: Higher Death Toll Seen; Police Ordered to Stop Looters
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 - Chaos gripped New Orleans on Wednesday as looters ran wild, food and water supplies dwindled, bodies floated in the floodwaters, the evacuation of the Superdome began and officials said there was no choice but to abandon the city devastated by Hurricane Katrina, perhaps for months.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Netanyahu Calls For West Bank Expansion
description: A day after announcing his campaign to unseat Prime Minister Ariel Sharon as leader of the Likud Party, Benjamin Netanyahu traveled to the West Bank and urged the immediate construction of more homes for Jewish settlers in an extremely contentious area just east of Jerusalem. He said Mr. Sharon's withdrawal of settlers from the Gaza Strip had raised expectations that Israel would also pull back in the West Bank and in East Jerusalem. Mr. Sharon "has created a precedent that will lead to the division of Jerusalem," Mr. Netanyahu said in Maale Adumim, just east of Jerusalem. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about increased efforts by advertisers and agencies to reach Hispanic consumers, misidentified the satellite radio company with which S TV made a sponsorship deal. It was XM, not Sirius.

title: Google Earth mapping service draws complaint from Seoul
Why Verizon's Computer Operator Talks So Much
description: As I've written many times, I have a love-hate relationship with my Verizon Wireless account. I love the fact that I can get a signal just about anywhere I travel.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,874 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Premier To Meet With Kashmiri Separatists
description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and an umbrella group of separatist leaders from the Indian-administered side of Kashmir will hold their first talks, both sides said, a significant turning point in the troubled half-century-long history of the disputed Himalayan territory. The group, known as the All Parties Hurriyat Conference, recently met with President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since independence from British rule in 1947, two of them over Kashmir, which they both claim. The province has been battered by what India says is a Pakistan-backed armed insurgency since 1989. The talks are scheduled for Monday in New Delhi. Mr. Singh has repeatedly said he would not entertain any proposal to give up Indian territory. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: A niche of Vietnam resistant to change
State Audit Details Problems at Westchester Hospital
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 1 - Mismanagement, sloppy accounting practices and wasteful spending at Westchester Medical Center, the premier hospital in the Hudson Valley, contributed to a $207 million operating loss from 2001 to 2004, a New York State audit has found.

title: Bush sees parallels toWorld War II
Briefs: Terror suspects used marriage to stay in U.S.
Apple Is Accused of Violating Software Patent
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 - Creative Technology, a maker of portable music players, has accused Apple Computer of violating a newly granted software patent covering the way users navigate music selections.

title: A French citadel?
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Production Falls 1.1%
description: Industrial production in July fell twice as much as economists expected, adding to evidence that growth may be slowing in Japan, the world's second-largest economy. Production fell a seasonally adjusted 1.1 percent from June, when the increase was 1.6 percent, the trade ministry said in a report from Tokyo. The median forecast in a Bloomberg survey of 37 economists was for a 0.5 percent drop. The decline was led by makers of electronic parts and transportation equipment. The yen slid for a fourth day on concern that the economy's recovery might falter as exports slump and surging oil prices slow economic growth around the world.

title: A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandelson says Europe must let China textiles in
Millions Said to Be Lacking Phone Service of Any Kind
description: Efforts to get food, water and electricity to the hundreds of thousands of survivors of Hurricane Katrina have been hampered by a lack of an essential tool: the ability of aid groups, utilities and even the phone companies to communicate with one another.

title: 950 Die in Stampede on Baghdad Bridge
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 31 - More than 950 people were killed and hundreds more injured Wednesday morning when rumors of a suicide bomber provoked a frenzied stampede in a procession of Shiite pilgrims as they crossed a bridge in northern Baghdad, government and hospital officials said.

title: People: Art Garfunkel, Bruce Lee, Charlize Theron
Taped Up and Ready to Impress Coughlin
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 30 - Giants wide receiver Mark Jones wraps thin strips of tape around his thumbs, pinkies and index fingers before he plays football. He says the ritual is not a superstition, and he says it does not necessarily help him catch the ball.

title: U.S. and China Fail to Reach Deal on Textile Shipments
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 1 - United States and Chinese trade negotiators failed to reach an agreement on textile shipments in a brief meeting today in Beijing, and the American team flew home, leaving it very unlikely that the two sides will come to terms before President Hu Jintao meets President Bush next week.

title: Longtime Tory Seeks to Lead Party, With Eye on 10 Downing
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 - Could a 65-year-old politician with a liking for beer, cigars, suede shoes and cricket -- along with business links to Big Tobacco -- become Britain's next prime minister?

title: And We're Just Helping Out at the Newspaper
description: And We're Just Helping Out At the Newspaper

title: Sitting Down to Dinner on a 9/11 Anniversary
description: Richard Karz's documentary "9/11/03: A Day in the Life of New York," filmed entirely on the second anniversary of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, intercuts clips from events occurring around New York City that day with scenes from a formal dinner and discussion that night in the landmark Surrogate's Courthouse. The discussion, which focused on the aftermath of the attacks, was moderated by John Sexton, president of New York University, and attended by news media, business and government leaders ranging from the hip-hop entrepreneur Russell Simmons to the assistant secretary of defense for homeland defense, Paul McHale, and the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

title: Amusement Park Worker Dies After Being Pinned Under Ride
description: A North Babylon teenager who spent the summer working at the Adventureland amusement park in Farmingdale, N.Y., died early yesterday after being run over on Tuesday night by a car on the roller coaster he was operating.

title: A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis: Netanyahu makes political gamble
Goodbye, Therapist. Hello, Anxiety?
description: WHEN it came time to schedule a new round of appointments with his therapist of six months, Tom Dietzler took out his pocket calendar, affected the harried expression of a man whose life was terribly overbooked, and began chattering about obligations that he knew didn't exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERMAN, RUTH
description: SHERMAN -- Ruth. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with profound sorrow the passing of Ruth Sherman, longtime member and mother of our Executive Director Susan Polansky. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Building's Sale Threatens Times Sq. Tavern
description: The rumors began lazily drifting about in the August heat. Customers wandered into McHale's pub near Times Square, surprised. "We heard you guys were closed," they exclaimed.

title: Schrder, in survival bid, goes on attack
News Analysis: Hard NewTest for President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - Not since he sat in a Florida classroom as the World Trade Center burned a thousand miles away has President Bush faced a test quite like the one he returned to Washington to confront this afternoon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged With Lewdness On Subway
description: A co-founder and chef of two popular raw-food restaurants in Manhattan was arrested yesterday, accused by the police of exposing himself to a woman in a subway train on Aug. 19. The man, Daniel Hoyt, 43, of East 10th Street, was charged with public lewdness. The police said Mr. Hoyt exposed himself to a 22-year-old woman aboard an R Train near Cortlandt Street. The woman, whom the police did not identify, took a picture of the man with her cellular phone, the police said. Mr. Hoyt and Tolentin Chan founded the Quintessence restaurants on East 10th Street in the East Village and Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side.

title: Stocks: Retreat in oil price comforts U.S. investors
India's mini-multinationals make waves in Western markets
News Analysis: Roh strikes at Korea's regional politics
A Little Shoe Therapy Never Hurt
description: THIS time of year, knowing that the comforting rituals of autumn are just around the corner is the only thing that gives me strength to go on. No matter how distant the date may seem, every year I remain unshaken in my conviction that the first day of school will arrive to send certain late-sleeping members of my family scurrying back to the forced productivity of math class.

title: Parents, Teachers and the Crisis in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a poll on Americans' views on the teaching of creationism misstated the margin of error of findings taken from a smaller sample of respondents who were asked about religion and politics, government financing of religious charities and gays in the military. It was 3.5 percentage points, not 2.5.

title: Textile Talks With China Seen at Impasse
description: BEIJING, Aug. 31 - Talks to curb China's surging textile exports to the United States will continue Thursday, after two days of negotiations here ended at an apparent impasse.

title: New Breed of Trainers Are Proving Fat Is Fit
description: ONE evening four years ago Jennifer Thompson decided at the last minute to go to a cycling class at New York Sports Club. She had just joined the gym and was unfamiliar with the instructors at the Cobble Hill branch in Brooklyn, so she was surprised when an overweight woman hopped on the bike at the head of the room.

title: Israel and Pakistan Hold 'Historic' First Meeting
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 - The foreign ministers of Israel and Pakistan met publicly for the first time today, a diplomatic breakthrough brokered by Turkey that appeared to be a first payoff for the Israeli pullout from the occupied Gaza Strip.

title: A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: State Dept. Official Urges Inclusive Tack on 9/11
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - With the approaching anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes sent a message on Wednesday to American ambassadors that they should attend interfaith services on that date or make some other gesture noting "that this is not just about us" but about other countries.

title: Real-Time, All-the-Time Computer Backup, So You Can Just Work
description: Correction Appended

title: Utility Workers Come From Afar to Help Their Brethren Start Restoring Service
description: Convoys of utility trucks and reinforcement workers from as far away as Massachusetts and Ohio are arriving in the gulf states to help restore electricity to the estimated 1.6 million household and business customers still without power in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMPBELL, FATHER JOHN ''JAC''
description: CAMPBELL -- Father John "Jac", of Boston, August 29, 2005. Father John "Jac" Campbell of the Paulist Fathers died after a long illness on Monday August 29 at his residence at the Paulist Center in Boston. Fr. Jac was the loving son of the late Bertha (Walsh) and John P. Campbell, and devoted brother of the late David, all of Somerville. Fr. Jac was ordained a Paulist Priest in 1969. He served in many pastorates and campus ministries; at UC Berkeley; Austin, Texas; Greensboro, NC, and Seattle, WA. In Seattle in 1987, Jac created the now world-wide program or reconciliation called Landings. He was the friend and adopted brother of many, especially of those in recovery. Fr. Jac's vigil will be held on Friday, September 2, from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm, with prayers and sharing at 7:30 at the Paulist Center, 5 Park St, Boston. Relatives and friends kindly invited. His Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11AM on Saturday, September 3 at the Paulist Center. Memorial donations in memory of Father Jac may be made to Landings-International and/or to the Paulist Fathers, 5 Park St, Boston, MA 02108. Boston Harborside Home, JS Waterman and Sons Waring-Langone, 580 Commercial St, Boston. 617536-4110.

title: Soccer: Spurs lead last-day buying spree
School Siege Leader Calls Russia Unwitting Ally
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31 - Shamil Basayev, the Chechen rebel leader and mastermind of the siege last year at School No.1 in Beslan, said Wednesday that Russia's special services had helped make the assault possible by allowing the terrorists safe passage toward the school in an attempt to ambush them.

title: Martnez and Mets Take a Big Step Back
description: Ryan Howard, the 260-pound behemoth who plays first base for the Philadelphia Phillies, took a big cut at Pedro Martnez's sailing fastball and missed. It was a huge third strike. Martnez pumped his fist and headed toward the dugout. Then he stopped.

title: Digital convergence still elusive
Gas Prices Surge as Supply Drops
description: For the first time since the 1970's, gasoline lines reappeared yesterday in some corners of the country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Prices Surge and Spot Shortages Appear As Hurricane's Effects Reach Gas Pumps Days after Hurricane Katrina dealt a devastating blow to the nation's largest energy hub, the worst-case possibility was quickly becoming a reality: gasoline prices surging well above $3 a gallon, consumer complaints of price gouging and service stations in a handful of locations running out of gas. The White House said it would release emergency oil stockpiles to meet shortages and would relax environmental standards nationwide. [Page A1.]

title: Rows and Rows of Corpses, and Voices Choked With Sobs
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 31 - Ahmed Madi Hussein paced back and forth furiously in front of Nouman Hospital, dressed in a gray dishdasha but barefoot. Clutching his cellphone, he punched out a call, and when one of his sons answered tears began running down his cheeks.

title: Fuel prices? Europeans have other concerns
Sears to Sell Card Unit to Morgan
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 31 - J.P. Morgan Chase has agreed to purchase the credit card business of Sears Canada for 2.4 billion Canadian dollars in cash and the assumption of 1.1 billion Canadian dollars in debt.

title: Plot twists in Italy's banking takeover drama
The West's fear of Islamism backfires
MySpace: A site with 26 million 'friends'
Graffanino Is Feeling Right at Home With Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 - Tony Graffanino placed calls to his former teammates Mike Sweeney, Matt Stairs and Joe McEwing as the Kansas City Royals were plummeting to 19 consecutive losses earlier this month. Graffanino cared enough to check on his friends, but he was also relieved to no longer be losing with them.

title: Senate Panel Plans Hearing Into Reports on Terrorist
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - The Senate Judiciary Committee announced Wednesday that it was investigating reports from two military officers that a highly classified Pentagon intelligence program identified the Sept. 11 ringleader as a potential terrorist more than a year before the attacks.

title: Twins vie to take over leadership of Poland
Rethinking Roddick's Mojo After First-Round Defeat
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it would make changes to a campaign about Andy Roddick losing and finding his "mojo" after his first-round defeat at the United States Open tennis tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, EMANUEL
description: LEVENTHAL--Emanuel. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Emanuel Leventhal, MD, a former member of Beth Israel's Department of Radiology for more than thirty years. To his wife Sheila, their children and all who loved him, we extend ourheartfelt condolences. David J. Shulkin, MD President and CEO Stephen P. Haveson, MD President, Medical Board and President, Doctors Alumni Association Michael M. Abiri, MD Chairman, Department of Radiology

title: Unsafe Paris buildings targeted
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) CHILDREN OF BESLAN -- A year ago today, masked Chechen terrorists stormed a school in Beslan, Russia, and took more than a thousand children, teachers and parents hostage. The terrorists' political demands were not granted, and three days later the siege ended with more than 300 dead, at least half of them children. A dozen young survivors of the tragedy, including Atzamas(above left) and Zarina, are interviewed in this documentary.

title: The Blind Trusting Their Stride
description: It was a beautiful day for a run in Central Park. The sun glistened on the surface of the reservoir, the baseball fields seethed with players in bright jerseys and cool air rustled the trees shading the six-mile loop. But on a summer afternoon of color and light, Nooria Nodrat, in training for the New York City Marathon, saw only black.

title: Google Dips Into the World of Print Advertising
description: Google, which built a lucrative business in online advertising, has found a new medium for its ad sales: print.

title: F.D.A. Approves Drug Meant to Help Short Children Grow
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 - The Food and Drug Administration gave approval Wednesday to Increlex, the first new drug in 30 years for the treatment of abnormally short stature in children.

title: Crisp New England Autumns for Sale
description: A HUMILIATING story in a new memoir, "The Tender Bar" by J.R. Moehringer, illustrates the signal importance of the elegant button-down shirt.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Profit Flat at Telephone Company
description: The China Telecom Corporation, the nation's biggest fixed-line phone operator, posted flat profit in the first half as revenue growth stalled because of competition from cellphone companies. Net income was 14.7 billion yuan ($1.8 billion), or 0.18 yuan a share, a marginal change from 14.7 billion yuan, or 0.19 yuan, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. First-half sales rose to 84 billion yuan from 80.22 billion yuan. The chairman, Wang Xiaochu, 47, is counting on getting a nationwide wireless license to raise earnings as more Chinese opt for mobile phone services. Revenue from local fixed-line calls, which makes up 51 percent of China Telecom's business, rose 0.7 percent, the company said. To counter competition from mobile phone operators like China Unicom and China Mobile (Hong Kong), China Telecom offers a cordless phone service known as Little Smart in northern cities like Tianjin and Chengde that lets users make calls within cities. Still, China Telecom, which is based in Beijing, will slow investment in Little Smart as the company moves closer to securing a mobile phone license, Mr. Wang said.

title: Furniture, Some of It Sat Upon, in Chelsea
description: Furnished Quarters, which rents out furnished apartments in various cities, is selling new and slightly used furniture and some antiques in Chelsea. Hundreds of items -- sofas, chairs, dining tables, beds, end tables -- are priced as much as 75 percent below retail. Leather Thayer Coggin chairs, $2,800 new, are $1,199, and Sealy queen-size sofa beds, normally $1,400, are $699. The sale, through September, is at a temporary storefront at 26 West 25th Street. Hours vary, so it's wise to call ahead: (212)989-5216. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?

title: Survivors worry about the missing
But, Ma, I Saw It on 'The O.C.'
description: THE new season of the Fox melodrama "The O.C." is days away, but teenagers needn't wait to shop a new line of bohemian Southern California fashions inspired by that hit show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COX, RALEIGH CHAFFEE
description: COX--Raleigh Chaffee. In New York City on August 29th. She graduated with a BA in both Math & Economics from Wellesley College in 1957. She came to Wall Street from the National Foreign Trade Council, and joined the Bank of New York in the investment advisory department. Later, she started an investment advisory department for Franklin National Bank. She went to Blythe in 1972, and was the first woman ever hired on the sales side. During this time she was also president of the Junior League, involved in both the society and culture of New York. She married Thomas R. Cox III in 1972. They had two children, Amanda Raleigh (1976) and Samuel Riggs (1978). While raising her family in Brooklyn, she renovated multiple brownstones and tenements, planted street trees and was an active supporter of the Big Apple Circus and served on the board of Goddard Riverside. She moved to Greenwich, CT in 1986; was president of the Daffodil Society, an avid soccer mom, ran the Indian Harbor Yacht Club Junior Sailing program, and was president of the US International 420 Class Association. For the past 8 years she lived in New York City, and worked as an antiques appraiser for her beloved Tepper Galleries. She was truly a Super Mom and loved by all who knew her. She is survived by her children, Amanda and Sam. A memorial service in her honor will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Sunday, September 18th at 2pm. Donations can be made in her name to Goddard Riverside at 212.873.4448, or the Big Apple Circus at 212.268.2500 ext.128.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Mayor Names Five To Cabinet
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago announced the appointment of five new cabinet members in his administration, a day after apologizing and saying he should have done more to prevent corruption in city government. Three of the newly appointed department heads replace people who were fired or have resigned since May in a growing scandal involving bribery and political influence in city hiring. New leaders were appointed to two of the three city departments where federal agents have seized records in recent months. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: When Trees Are Bending, Windows Needn't Break
description: A translucent, PVC-coated, snap-on panel can protect windows during hurricanes, not only from windborne coconuts but from "pressurization and wind-driven water damage," said Mike George, a marketing manager for the product, Fabric-Shield. The convenience of the shields and their price -- $8 to $12 a square foot installed -- encourage homeowners to invest in protection, said Eric Stafford, a building code consultant to the state of Florida, adding, "I tell people about this product all the time." Fabric-Shield meets the Florida hurricane code, but not those of Broward and Dade Counties. Waynedalton.com or (850)475-6001. LINDA LEE CURRENTS: STORM SHIELDS

title: Taking Fashion to the Streets
description: TIERED skirts, glass beads, supersize shades and curly-toed slippers fit for Scheherazade: the jumble of wares massed inside the stalls at the Howard Street market in downtown Manhattan left Rachel Cohen giddy. Pawing though an assortment of crazily embroidered peasant skirts last week, Ms. Cohen, a 27-year-old physiotherapist from Jerusalem, said her forays into such bazaars are usually desultory, a mix of shopping and plenty of unfocused roaming. But Howard Street was different.

title: Ruling on Campaign Money Muddies New Jersey Race
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31 - The New Jersey governor's race remained mired in the minutiae of insurance law Wednesday, after a state agency released a complex ruling that failed to resolve questions about the legality of millions of dollars in campaign contributions that Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican nominee, has made to himself and other candidates.

title: Prescription for Injustice
description: THE current push by some pharmacists for a right not to fill certain prescriptions awakens memories of 1954, when my father was dying of cancer. I was a graduate student in New York, but I returned to my home in New Haven, Conn., to be with him. As the end drew near, his suffering became intense, the pain harder and harder to control. He was being cared for by an extraordinary doctor: Seymour Lipsky, then chief of hematology at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Dr. Lipsky did not have a private practice, but he had volunteered to take care of my father, telling us to call him whenever we felt we needed him. When we called, he came to the house.

title: Reaching for Success but Not Too Much of It
description: While high-tech start-ups in a hurry to expand get most of the ink, an increasing number of entrepreneurs are choosing another path: slow growth or no growth.

title: European Union Calls for Common Rules on Deporting Illegals
description: The European Commission today asked European nations to adopt common rules across the Continent governing the return of illegal immigrants and failed asylum seekers to their home countries.

title: Lawsuit Delays Takeover of 4 Private Bus Lines
description: A plan by the Bloomberg administration to have the Metropolitan Transportation Authority take over four private bus companies has become bogged down in litigation.

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter column on Monday, about the prominent role of women in the debate over the Iraq war, incorrectly summarized comments by President Bush about Cindy Sheehan's protest. He said that an immediate withdrawal of American troops, as advocated by such protests, would weaken the United States and embolden terrorists. He did not say that protesters like Ms. Sheehan were themselves weakening the United States and emboldening terrorists.

title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Educators Offer Classrooms to Many Displaced Students
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a pop music listing in Weekend on Friday about a concert tonight at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park misstated Bruce Hornsby's role in the concert. His band, Bruce Hornsby and the Noisemakers, is sharing the bill with Bob Weir's band, Ratdog; he does not tour as the pianist in Ratdog. The listing also misstated the time of the concert, the price of admission and the telephone number for information. Doors open at 4:30 and the concert begins at 6 p.m., not 3 p.m. Tickets are $39.50, not $40, and the information number is (212)307-7171.

title: In City of Skyscrapers, Which Is the Mightiest of the High?
description: Happy 75th birthday, Chrysler Building. New Yorkers in the know think you're the best.

title: Funds in brief: Hedge fund executive criticizes German rules
For Its Motorists, Only Parts of Rome Prove to Be Eternal
description: ROME, Aug. 28 - As a salami salesman, Giorgetti Mincello, 49, has driven his little scooter over the bumpy roads of Rome the equivalent of two-thirds around the equator in the last year. So he considers himself an expert on one atmospheric bit of Roman history that he believes would be better left in the past.

title: Wall of Water Set a Record
description: Hurricane Katrina's storm surge -- the wall of water it pushed ashore when it struck the Gulf Coast on Monday -- was the highest ever measured in the United States, scientists said yesterday.

title: The Opportunity Cost of Economics Education
description: SHORTLY after I began teaching, more than 30 years ago, three friends in different cities independently sent me the same New Yorker cartoon depicting a woman introducing a man to a friend at a party. "Mary, I'd like you to meet Marty Thorndecker," she began. "He's an economist, but he's really very nice."

title: Corrections
description: An article on August 30 about efforts to privatize Japan's postal savings system misstated a remark by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi about opponents of the plan. He said they are like reactionaries who insist that the Sun revolves around the Earth, not that the Earth revolves around the Sun.

title: Loved Ones Turn to Web for Searches in Flood Zone
description: The age-old tools when searching for a missing loved one, a flier and Scotch tape, would seem to be useless this time, and people desperate for word from sons, daughters, parents or friends are turning to a different kind of lamppost.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a Critic's Notebook article about characters played by more than one actor misidentified the red-haired actress on the left in a collage of three of the eight people who played the heroine in the film "Palindromes." She is Hannah Freiman; Rachel Corr, who also played the role, was not shown.

title: News Analysis:Musharraf gains in local elections
The Storm After the Storm
description: Hurricanes come in two waves. First comes the rainstorm, and then comes what the historian John Barry calls the "human storm" -- the recriminations, the political conflict and the battle over compensation. Floods wash away the surface of society, the settled way things have been done. They expose the underlying power structures, the injustices, the patterns of corruption and the unacknowledged inequalities. When you look back over the meteorological turbulence in this nation's history, it's striking how often political turbulence followed.

title: Jews and Catholics must work together
Jailed Russian Oil Tycoon Says He Plans to Run for Parliament
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31 - Prison has done little to silence Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon who received a nine-year sentence three months ago. He has published jailhouse treatises, granted interviews and issued regular statements through his lawyers. Now he plans to run for Parliament.

title: A Distribution System Brought to Its Knees
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 - As ports remained closed from Louisiana to Florida on Wednesday, some 300 barges containing grains and other products were left homeless.

title: The Horror of Beslan, Through Its Youngest Survivors
description: There is no narrator. The voices are those of children 10 or younger. A dark-haired girl with beautiful eyes cries as she recalls the order to throw away all mobile phones: "There was one girl, her mobile rang. She hadn't thrown it away, so they shot her."

title: N.B.A. Prepares to Relocate Hornets in Aftermath of Hurricane
description: Playing sporting events in New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina is such a daunting prospect that the National Basketball Association is bracing to relocate its local franchise for the entire coming season.

title: The Pitch: A Series About Wacky Terrorists
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 - Here are a few highlights from the hottest Hollywood script you will most likely never see produced on a television or movie screen:

title: Turkey rebuffs EU pressure on Cyprus
Police and Owners Begin toChallenge Looters
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 - In a city shut down for business, the Rite Aid at Oak and South Carrollton was wide open on Wednesday. Someone had stolen a forklift, driven it four blocks, peeled up the security gate and smashed through the front door.

title: Taking a new look at Japan
Last puff for the French-made Gauloise
Corrections
description: The White House Letter column on Monday, about the prominent role of women in the debate over the Iraq war, incorrectly summarized comments by President Bush about Cindy Sheehan's protest. He said that an immediate withdrawal of American troops, as advocated by such protests, would weaken the United States and embolden terrorists. He did not say that protesters like Ms. Sheehan were themselves weakening the United States and emboldening terrorists. (Go to Article)

title: Searching for the Living, but Mostly Finding the Dead
description: PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss., Aug. 31 - Dave Bernzweig saw them as soon as he peered inside the small brick house: two more lost souls, wedged among the soaked ruins of their belongings. He recorded the location of the bodies, between the front door and the flowered couch, then moved across the street, where another victim of Hurricane Katrina lay.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jets Pass On West Side Deal
description: The Jets formally notified the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday that the team would not buy development rights at the West Side railyards for a stadium that would be used for football and trade shows. After nearly five years of effort, the $2.2 billion project suffered a potentially fatal setback in June when state legislative leaders refused to approve the stadium, which had been opposed by some neighborhood and civic groups. The team is negotiating to build a stadium in New Jersey that would also house the Giants, while also exploring the possibility of building its own home in Queens. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: At Stake in Court: Using the Patriot Act to Get Library Records
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 31 - It was a hearing where the name of the client was never disclosed, the subject of the federal inquiry remained unidentified and the context for the exercise was kept top secret.

title: Suspension Gives Sheffield's Knee Some Rest
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 31 - Gary Sheffield returned to the Yankees on Wednesday after serving his one-game suspension for a confrontation with Umpire C. B. Bucknor in June. Sheffield took the day off to rest his right knee, which has been an issue since the All-Star Game break.

title: Agassi Is Back to Being Great U.S. Hope
description: An American tennis idol, former United States Open champion and star of a memorable American Express commercial walked off the court and signed oversized balls for adoring young fans yesterday.

title: Defiant Khodorkovsky running for Parliament
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "This recovery will take years."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVENPORT, WILLIAM (GERALD)
description: DAVENPORT--William (Gerald) on August 20, 2005. Beloved husband of Edith, devoted father of David and Dexter. Loving father-in-law of Monica Azare and devoted grandfather of David Cole. A humanitarian and community activist, his 40 year professional career started with the New York City Mission Society where he was the Society's principal manager with Camp Minisink. He then served over 20 years with the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (RBF) where he was a program officer and director of the New York City programs. Later in his career he worked at the Harlem Urban Development Corporation and then retired as a senior officer of Phipps Houses. In retirement, he cofounded Gerall-Stan Associates, a Management Consulting firm. Gerald was acitve on numerous boards. He was also a proud member of Salem United Methodist Church in Harlem and an active member of Phi Beta Sigma Inc. Gerald earned both a Bachelors degree in sociology and a Masters degree in social work from Howard University. He was a native of Mt. Vernon, NY. A memorial service will be held later.

title: World Briefing: Middle East; Asia; Africa
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Pirro Endorsed By Erie County Republican
description: The Republican leader of Erie County, Robert Davis, endorsed Jeanine F. Pirro yesterday for the party's nomination to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton next year. Mr. Davis said he chose Ms. Pirro over her leading rival, Ed Cox, because she was "dynamic and exciting and can expose Hillary Clinton's broken promises." He predicted that Mrs. Clinton, who did unusually well in some upstate Republican strongholds in 2000, would have a harder time next year because of her first-term record. "She said she would create tens of thousands of jobs; where are they?" Mr. Davis said. Rodney Capel, the state Democratic Party's executive director, said, "It's bad timing for the G.O.P. smear campaign, since Senator Clinton just delivered thousands of jobs to the western New York area by keeping local bases from closing." Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

title: Ferrer and Bloomberg Increase Campaign Attacks on Each Other
description: As the Democratic primary campaign enters its final weeks, Fernando Ferrer is moving more aggressively to take on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, just as polls show that his strategy of lying low throughout the contest has left him barely budging and in danger of being forced into a runoff.

title: Iraqis bury victims of Baghdad stampede
On The Street: Then
description: IN the waning years of the 1980's, hipsters of every persuasion turned their backs on the age of excess, adopting a variant of ashcan chic. The more spirited among them took to the streets tricked out in ensembles that suggested a cross between punker and Cabbage Patch doll, their funky bandanas, trucker hats, embroidered T-shirts and shredded jeans meant to send a clear message that they were dancing on the razor's edge.

title: A Hard Drive Can't Be Too Big (or Too Small, Either, It Seems)
description: The explosion in digital cameras and camcorders, the popularity of music and video downloading and the spread of the multiple-computer household have made additional digital storage space a necessity. Fortunately the price of storage has plummeted in the last few years. According to the NPD Group, a market research firm, prices have gone from about $300 for a 100-gigabyte hard drive in 2002 to about $150 this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANNISKI, JUDE T.
description: WANNISKI--Jude T. Age 69 of Morristown, NJ on August 29, 2005 at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Survived by mother Constance and wife Patricia. Devoted father of Matthew, daughter Jennifer Harlan, and Andrew. Also survived by brother Terence, sister Ruth Necco and one granddaughter. Mass of Christian Burial at 10 AM on Saturday September 3, 2005. Interment, private. Hours of visitation Friday September 2, 2005, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown, NJ. Donations made to New Jersey Chapter Parkinson Disease Association, PO Box 214, Elizabeth, NJ 07207

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEUER, JAMES H.
description: SCHEUER--James H. August 29, 2005, age 85, peacefully at home in Washington. Member of the U.S. House of Representatives from 1964-1972 and 1974-1992. He is survived by his adored and adoring wife, Emily Malino Scheuer, and his loving children, Laura, Elizabeth (PeterJoseph), James (Lorna Payabyab), and John (Robin Lawson). He will be missed and remembered by his grandchildren: Damella and Laurella Dotan; Eleanor, Nicholas, Anna, and Katherine Joseph; James William and David Scheuer; and Sarah and Thomas "Buster" Scheuer. He is also survived by numerous siblings, cousins, nephews and nieces, all of whose lives he touched in many ways. Adoring family man, dedicated public servant, musician extraordinaire, lifelong supporter of Israel. He loved desserts, good jokes, family sing-alongs, horse-back riding, and Hopewell. His legacy inspires us, and we will miss him immensely. Funeral services will be private, and a memorial service will be held at a later date. The family will be receiving visitors from 4-8pm on Wednesday and from 123pm on Thursday at 4730 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, NY; and from 6-9pm on Thursday at 610 West End Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to: Swarthmore College, 500 College Avenue, Swarthmore, PA 19081.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about the theft of a pair of ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in "The Wizard of Oz" misstated the location of the museum from which they were stolen. It is in Grand Rapids, Minn., not Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: Gay Cable's Like Straight, Except for Nervous Jokes
description: The striking thing about Logo, a new gay cable channel owned by Viacom, is how much it looks like the rest of cable television. It has movies, a wedding makeover show, travel tips, a reality show about a young guy starting his own business, and lots of sexy music videos and raunchy comedy routines.

title: Ex-minister seeks post in Britain's opposition
Administration Steps Up Actions, Adding Troops and Dispatching Medical Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - The Bush administration stepped up the federal response on Wednesday to the devastation from Hurricane Katrina, deploying thousands more National Guard and active-duty troops to the Gulf Coast to help with rescue and relief missions, authorizing the release of oil from the nation's strategic reserve to blunt the economic effects of the storm and dispatching food, water and medical supplies to the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, RUTH FISHER
description: SIEGEL--Ruth Fisher. Age 78. Died at home in New York City on August 30, 2005 after a short, fearless battle with lung cancer. She is survived by her daughter Dorian Siegel Held, her son Jeffrey J. Siegel and daughter-in-law Debragh Siegel, grandchildren Isaac Held, Alison and Michael Novara, Jill and Jamie Drummond, four great grandchildren, Phoebe and Madeline Drummond, and Benjamin and Charlotte Novara; and her sister Marilyn Helen Fisher. She was the daughter of dearly departed Mollie (Bogner) and Nathan Fisher, and brother of Allen M. Fisher. Ruth was a travel agent for many years and traveling the world was her passion. Services Thursday, 11:15AM at The Riverside, 180 West 76 St, (Amsterdam Avenue), New York, N.Y. Burial immediately after service at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing (Queens), N.Y. Heartfelt thanks to Calvary Hospital Hospice.

title: Baghdad stampede kills nearly 850
Why Ralph Fiennes is never just a guy
Paid Notice: Deaths   WINSTON, LABELLE
description: WINSTON -- LaBelle. Died peacefully at home on August 31, 2005 at age 97. Devoted wife for more than 60 years of the late Benjamin Winston. Adored mother of Roger and Dale Winston, Jane and Peter Endler, Betty and Ken Weisberger. Loving grandmother of Peter and Kerri Winston, Drew, Jodi and great grandson Jacob Weisberger, Matthew Weisberger and Michael Winston.

title: Lengthy Practices Prepare Court Nominee for His Senate Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - As "murder boards" go, this one was murder. Not only did the final practice for the confirmation hearings of Judge John G. Roberts Jr., the Supreme Court nominee, last all day on Tuesday in Room 350 of the Eisenhower Executive Office Building.

title: Some Assembly Required, But It Comes With a Mallet
description: Tables weighing up to 350 pounds that can be dismantled in minutes? So say the owners of Bottega Montana, a furniture company in Lima, Mont., that has introduced a collection of tables that knock together -- and come apart -- with a hand-turned mallet. The company is applying for a patent. The collection includes a coffee table ($7,600), right, that is made with white oak and black walnut and is 4 feet long, 30 inches wide and 19 inches high. Other pieces include a dining table and an end table with a chessboard surface. The tables "work in a modern or traditional setting," said Francesco Gillia, above left, who owns the company with his brother, Marco, right. They make only 80 pieces a year. Information: (406)276-3325 or bottegamontana.com. KATHRYN HARRIS CURRENTS: FURNITURE

title: Arts, Briefly; Video Music Awards Attract Fewer Viewers This Year
description: Whether viewers' attention was elsewhere because of Hurricane Katrina or for other reasons, the ratings for Sunday's Video Music Awards on MTV were down significantly from past years. The special, with Diddy, left, as host, brought in an audience of 8.01 million, a big drop from last year's 10.32 million. The 2002 event, at which Eminem and his "Without Me" video were the big winners, stands as the award show's most-watched broadcast, with 11.95 million viewers. Despite this year's drop, Sunday's show was No. 1 on cable for the week in all adult demographics. On the network side, CBS won its 13th week in a row in total viewers and tied with Fox among 18- to 49-year-olds. Tuesday's Nielsen's estimates indicated a continuation of CBS's streak. Its lineup of an "NCIS" rerun (9.55 million), "Big Brother" (8.49 million) and "Rock Star: INXS" (6.72 million) didn't win every hour, but the combination easily beat all network competition among total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

title: Pakistan's President Consolidates Power in Local Elections
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 1 - Allies of President Pervez Musharraf scored major gains in two rounds of local government elections, a development likely to further consolidate the Pakistani leader's grip on power ahead of the general election in 2007, analysts here say.

title: The Mohawk Becomes, Well, Cute
description: A YEAR ago Alex Kamnitsis, 27, an executive assistant at a film production company in Manhattan, adopted a hair style he calls a modern version of the Mohawk. He was looking to make a statement: despite his corporate trappings he is a person with a little edge. This summer, when he asked his stylist at the Oscar Bond salon in SoHo for the same cut, closely buzzed along the sides and a strip of long hair on top, Mr. Kamnitsis discovered that the Mohawk, like so many other badges of anarchy, had gone mainstream.

title: Ex-Pepsi Executive Named ConAgra Chief
description: ConAgra Foods said yesterday that it had hired Gary M. Rodkin, the former head of North American operations at PepsiCo, to succeed Bruce C. Rohde as chief executive and president.

title: Official Quits on Pill Delay at the F.D.A.
description: The director of the Food and Drug Administration's office of women's health resigned yesterday to protest the agency's decision last week to further delay approving over-the-counter sales of the morning-after pill.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD ZVI
description: SHEPPS--Howard Zvi. September 1, 1953-July 9, 1992 Birth dates are for remembering. Happy Birthday

title: Mourners to mark anniversary of Beslan tragedy
A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: Future Face of New Orleans Has an Uncertain Look for Now
description: The impulse to rebuild follows any catastrophe within hours, relief drawn on a future account when there is little comfort in the present.

title: Lives and Homes Strewn on an Abandoned Street
description: PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss., Aug. 31 - On Henderson Avenue, the houses were all out of order, scattered like pool balls on the broad green lawns.

title: Review Planned of State Efforts to Curb Fraud in Medicaid
description: After elected officials questioned whether New York State has been effectively fighting fraud in its Medicaid program, federal officials said yesterday that they plan to conduct a review of the state's Medicaid prosecution unit this fall.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Summer Hits
description: In a slow week for music sales, Hilary Duff's "Most Wanted" (Hollywood) remains at the top of the Billboard album chart for the second week in a row after selling 101,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Some long-running summer hits occupy most of the top positions on the chart. The 19th volume of the pop compilation series "Now That's What I Call Music!" is at No. 2, Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam) holds strong at No. 3 in its 20th week of release, and the Black Eyed Peas' "Monkey Business" (A&M/Interscope) is at No. 4. The only new album in the Top 10 is "Harlem: Diary of a Summer" (Koch) by Jim Jones, a member of the hip-hop collective the Diplomats. Further down the chart, "Crazy Frog Presents Crazy Hits" (Next Plateau/Universal) by Crazy Frog -- the animated amphibian that began as a cellphone ring tone and swept the British singles charts this year -- enters the American charts this week at No. 19. BEN SISARIO

title: Better Late Than Never to Fix Latino Promotion
description: Major League Baseball could have done far better in its attempt to honor the greatest Hispanic ballplayers than its flawed Latino Legends promotion.

title: Cracks in the Guggenheim Get High-Tech Attention
description: It may not be as disappointing as finding the Trevi Fountain obscured by construction platforms and heavy plastic, or the Arc de Triomphe. Still, tourists and New Yorkers alike are bound to be frustrated by the scaffolding that began to rise this week around the Guggenheim Museum, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Briefs: MasterCard plans IPO
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ex-Firefighter Said to Offer Bribe to Aid Son
description: Correction Appended

title: 10,000 Patients and Staff Members Await Evacuation From Barely Functional Hospitals
description: It is daunting what the 600 patients and staff members trapped by a moat of filthy water inside Charity Hospital in New Orleans have been doing without.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Physical Culture; No Arms, But Really Warm Hugs
description: OF all the seasons, autumn can be the most fickle. With the arrival of in-between weather -- warmer than winter but spiked with rain and frigid breezes -- an insulated vest comes in handy, particularly for those who prefer to exercise outside.

title: A woodpecker and its secrets
Speed limits lowered as pollution builds up
On Auto Dealer Lots, a Shift Away From Gas-Guzzling Vehicles
description: SYLVANIA, Ohio, Aug. 31 - Michelle Rable was in the middle of car shopping on Wednesday morning when she stopped to fill up her Pontiac Aztec, a sport utility vehicle, with gas -- at $3.09 a gallon.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Translator Charged In Gang Inquiry
description: A Chinese-language translator who worked for the F.B.I. was charged yesterday with warning his cousin last year not to speak with two gang members because their phones were tapped, federal authorities said. The translator, Jimmy Zheng of Sewell, N.J., had been helping investigators translate wiretaps of members of a gang operating in Chinatown and in Flushing, Queens, prosecutors said. They said Mr. Zheng did not tell the F.B.I. that he had socialized with several gang members, including the leader, Lim Shang. Mr. Zheng was arraigned yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan and charged with obstruction of justice. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Guy Adopts a Bar and Tells About It
description: The Tender Bar By J.R. Moehringer 370 pages. Hyperion. $23.95.

title: The Neighborhood Started Looking Up Once the Soybeans Moved Out
description: A couple of old soybean silos in a former harbor area of Copenhagen, below left, have been converted into the luxury Gemini Residence by the Dutch architectural firm of MVRDV. Its principals, Winy Maas, Jacob van Rijs and Nathalie de Vries, achieved fame with a colorful housing block built on stilts over the Ij inlet in Amsterdam and for their minimalist Lloyd Hotel, which opened in Amsterdam last September.

title: Banished Whistle-Blowers
description: The Bush administration is making no secret of its determination to punish whistle-blowers and other federal workers who object to the doctoring of facts that clash with policy and spin. The blatant retaliation includes the Army general sidelined for questioning the administration's projections about needed troop strength in Iraq, the Medicare expert muted when he tried to inform Congress about the true cost of the new prescription subsidies and the White House specialist on climate change who was booted after complaining that global warming statistics were being massaged by political tacticians.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the Shakespeare authorship controversy misidentified the daughter of Edward de Vere who failed to marry William Herbert, one of the two earls to whom the first Shakespeare Folio was dedicated. She was Bridget, not Susan.

title: Too Busy Slaying Aliens to Take Calls? Here's Your Game Boy
description: More and more people are using their cellphones to play games, but Nintendo is betting that game lovers won't mind carrying a separate cellphone-size device if it's hip.

title: Chechen claims he tricked Russians
A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: To Seduce Next Year's Gardeners, Some Blossoms Unfold Early
description: Plant fashionistas can get a sneak preview of some of next year's hottest picks at six garden centers between Philadelphia and Virginia Beach, Va., and open to the public on either Sept. 22 or Sept. 24. (Information: easternperformancetrials.org.) The event, being held for the first time, will introduce unusual flowers, shrubs and vegetables, including the deeply hued container-friendly Bourbon clematis, top; the Brigadoon hypericum, above; and the Angel Robe hydrangea, left. Nothing will be for sale. The organizer is Garden Centers of America, a trade group. (Home gardeners are not required to register to get into the centers.)

title: Where to Help
description: Following are organizations and groups that the Federal Emergency Management Agency says are collecting donations or offers of help:

title: A City in Ruins: Americans Open Their Hearts (10 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Elaine Stritch: Heart, Soul and Plenty of Leg
description: SHORTLY after 10 o'clock at the Carlyle hotel one recent evening, Elaine Stritch finished her final run-through of the day and, still carrying on a conversation with her musical director, disappeared into the next room. Six straight hours of rehearsing her forthcoming solo cabaret, "Elaine Stritch at Home at the Carlyle," hadn't made a dent in her gorgeously gravelly voice. Or her audacity.

title: INDECISION
Parents, Teachers and the Crisis in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, GERALD
description: VOGEL--Gerald. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our devoted member. We extend our condolences to his family. Services will be held at Temple Sinai on Thursday, September 1, 2005 at 10 A.M. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Charles Berman, President

title: Hazards Contained in Waters Are Not as Toxic as Feared
description: Although the water that now covers much of New Orleans is a fetid broth of sewage, with gasoline from gas stations, solvents from dry cleaners and chemicals from household cleaners mixed in, it could have been a great deal worse, experts said yesterday.

title: Talk of Muller's Triumph Dominates the Day's Action
description: For one day, the subdued attracted more attention than the glitter, the gangly was more compelling than the glamorous. On the afternoon after Gilles Muller stunned the prince of tennis, Andy Roddick, in the first round of the United States Open on Tuesday night, Muller, the best player in Luxembourg's history, even overshadowed the princess of the game, Maria Sharapova.

title: New York and Illinois
description: THE United States Open is well under way -- and so is the shopping. In addition to world class competition, the National Tennis Center is home to a 3,000-square-foot Polo Ralph Lauren shop, below. The store is equipped with large plasma screens, so you needn't miss a swing just because you have a yen for a cable-knit sweater dress.

title: France Drafts Plans to Limit Takeovers by Foreigners
description: PARIS, Aug. 31 - After recent vocal efforts by France and the United States to defend flagship companies from foreign bidders, French officials on Wednesday started sketching plans to protect companies deemed strategic. But officials left unclear how the plans would pass muster with European regulators or assuage skittish investors.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about the filmmaker Henry Jaglom misstated the studio that released his 1971 movie, "A Safe Place." It was Columbia, not Universal.

title: Mohawks Ask Pataki to Approve a Catskill Casino That Was Stalled 5 Years Ago
