description: In what supporters see as a last-ditch attempt to bring an Indian casino to the Catskills, the St. Regis Mohawks and a gambling company are reviving plans to build a $500 million Las Vegas-style gambling operation at the Monticello racetrack.

title: A Digital Camera That Acts More Like a Film One
description: Serious amateur photographers who switch to digital single-lens reflex cameras are sometimes disappointed to find that their lenses don't behave as they did with film. That is because the light sensors on most digital S.L.R.'s are considerably smaller than a frame of 35-millimeter film. This changes the lenses' field of view and also makes it more difficult to highlight a subject by making the background go out of focus.

title: Suspected Muslim militants set off 10 bombs
MasterCard Pursuing Plan to Offer Shares to Public
description: MasterCard Inc., the world's second-largest credit card brand, announced plans yesterday to pursue an initial public offering that could value the company at more than $10 billion.

title: U.S. Alters Rules for War Crime Trials
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - Pentagon officials announced procedural changes Wednesday to the military commissions created by the Bush administration to try terrorism suspects on war crimes charges at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Democratic Candidates Propose Low-Dose Cures for Fiscal Ills
description: New York City has been through a jarring fiscal ride over the last four years, veering from a severe budget crisis to recent relative prosperity. Ahead could be more hard times: a projected $4.5 billion deficit for the coming fiscal year. Yet the four Democratic mayoral candidates have, for the most part, avoided addressing how they would bridge this gap.

title: Tying Down the Roof
description: ON Tuesday night, Reed Kroloff, the dean of the architecture school at Tulane University in New Orleans, was holed up in a hotel in Houston, wondering whether his century-old Victorian house in New Orleans had withstood Hurricane Katrina. It was not a pretty thought.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel Approves Egyptian Troops On Gaza Border
description: By a vote of 53 to 28, Israel's Parliament approved a plan for 750 Egyptian soldiers to patrol along the border with the Gaza Strip, a move that clears the way for the withdrawal of the last Israeli soldiers from Gaza. The agreement allows Egypt to beef up its security presence on its side of the frontier, a stretch of eight miles, with the aim of preventing weapons smuggling into Gaza. Some Israeli politicians called for the military to remain, but Defense Minister Shaul Mofaz said keeping troops there "defies military logic and will risk the lives" of the soldiers. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Superdome: Haven QuicklyBecomes an Ordeal
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 - The sick and the disabled were the first to be led out. But late Wednesday afternoon, as the slow evacuation of the Superdome began, it was not always easy to distinguish them from the rest of the 20,000 or more storm refugees who had steeped for days in the arena's sickening heat and stench, unbathed, exhausted and hungry.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about proposed efficiency standards for home furnaces misidentified the chemical company that joined an environmental group in urging the federal Energy Department to adopt stronger rules. It was Dow, not DuPont.

title: The Choice Is More Than Clear When It Comes to Glass
description: THIS season's fashionable kitchen-and-bath material is glass, which is pushing aside granite, stainless steel and concrete for countertops, walls and floors. It comes in many forms and finishes, offering rooms without much natural light a reflective surface or one that allows light to pass through. There are even new fake-glass tiles, made of acrylic.

title: Congress Prepares $10 Billion Aid Package
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - Congressional leaders were preparing to rush through an aid package of about $10 billion requested by the White House for the Gulf Coast region today as President Bush made plans to visit the areas devastated by Hurricane Katrina.

title: State Audit Details Problems at Westchester Hospital
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 1 - Mismanagement, sloppy accounting practices and wasteful spending at Westchester Medical Center, the premier hospital in the Hudson Valley, contributed to a $207 million operating loss from 2001 to 2004, a New York State audit has found.

title: F.D.A. Clears Flu Vaccine Made by Glaxo
description: A flu shot from GlaxoSmithKline was approved by American regulators yesterday and the Chiron Corporation's Liverpool vaccine plant, shut last year because of contamination, moved closer to being opened as officials work to avoid another shortage.

title: A Heartthrob Who's as Friendly as He Is Feral
description: The rise of emo has created lots of unlikely new sex symbols over the last few years. Gerard Way, from My Chemical Romance, makes fans scream by stalking the stage in a tight bulletproof vest as black as his hair. And Adam Lazzara, from Taking Back Sunday, has a flamboyant, preening style; it's no insult to call him a first-rate poseur.

title: Comic Improv Competition as a Festival of Putdowns
description: MTV's crass, crackling summertime hit, "Nick Cannon Presents Wild 'N Out," tries hard to develop some new streetwise talent, some new ways of luring young minds into the innovation of improv comedy. But its greatest achievement is harnessing the unstoppable energy of Nick Cannon. As host and producer, Mr. Cannon provides some solidity to a wiggy half-hour of jive talk and insult-trading, and each episode demonstrates that no one has the moves like he does.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Convicted Of Killing Roommate
description: Christopher Schloss, 37, of Tampa, Fla., was convicted on Tuesday of the April 1994 slaying of his roommate in Springfield Gardens, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Schloss was found guilty of second-degree murder for killing Omar Langshaw, 26, prosecutors said. Mr. Brown said that while the two men were driving in a van, Mr. Schloss shot Mr. Langshaw in the leg and demanded that he turn over a briefcase. When he refused, Mr. Brown said, Mr. Schloss shot him again, shoved him from the van and shot him three more times. Mr. Schloss faces a sentence of 25 years to life in state prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JERROLD MI CHAEL
description: SCHWARTZ -- Jerrold Mi chael. With deepest love and affection we announce his death on August 30, 2005. Best friend and husband of Renee; beloved father of Robin Adelman (Barry), Richard Schwartz and the late Nancy Schwartz Schreier; adored grandfather of Lindsay, Travis, Amanda, Kathryn, Danielle, Jacquelyn and Brandon; devoted brother of Frances Pernick. Funeral services will be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, Thursday at 11 AM.

title: Inquiry Into Commissions at Bayou
description: Over the last two and a half years, Bayou Securities, the brokerage unit of the Bayou Group, the Connecticut hedge fund firm at the center of a growing investigation, generated $51.5 million in revenue executing trades for its four affiliated hedge funds, according to two people who have seen financial statements the firm filed with its regulators.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Is Shot And Killed
description: A 16-year-old boy was shot and killed yesterday afternoon in front of an apartment building in the Rockaways, the police said. The boy and a 22-year-old man, identified by his family as Lamarr Clark, were walking in front of 439 Beach 54th Street when a gunman fired at them and then fled on a bicycle. The boy was struck in the head and was pronounced dead at the scene shortly afterward, the police said. Mr. Clark was shot in the left leg and was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was in stable condition. Bobbie Hargrove, the mother of Mr. Clark and the godmother of the dead boy, said the two victims were headed to her apartment when they were attacked. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Iran's nuclear program
Youth Is Served, but Nadal Serves a Bit Better
description: If the teenagers had curfews, they would have broken them. Rafael Nadal, 19, and 18-year-old Scoville Jenkins played a second-round match at the United States Open last night that was so chock full of drama, it could not be contained in one day. A one-hour rain delay before the start of the match was followed by two and a half hours of riveting tennis that ended with Jenkins limping to the net to congratulate Nadal, the French Open champion, on his 6-4, 7-5, 6-4 victory.

title: Tradersin Philippines on a roll
Ernesta Drinker Ballard, 85, Horticulturist and Feminist, Dies
description: Ernesta Drinker Ballard, who saved the Philadelphia Flower Show and transformed it from a horticultural beauty show into a spectacular international educational event, died Aug. 11 at the Cathedral Village retirement community in Philadelphia. She was 85 and formerly lived in the Chestnut Hill area of Philadelphia.

title: Bridge; Europe's Young Experts Glitter In Its Ninth University Tourney
description: The United States has some excellent junior players, as highlighted by last month's overtime victory in the World Youth Teams Championship in Sydney, Australia. But more future experts seem to be rising through the ranks in Europe.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Katrinas React to Katrina

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about a Guidant Corporation panel on product safety misspelled the surname of one of its members. He is Dr. John P. DiMarco, not DiMar.

title: Paris Assesses Unsafe Buildings After Fires That Killed Africans
description: PARIS, Aug. 31 - Under public pressure after two fires killed 24 African immigrants here in the last week, the French authorities pushed ahead Wednesday with an inventory of the city's most dilapidated buildings, preparing to evacuate those deemed unsafe.

title: Jobless levels are down in Germany and France
Interpublic Loses Bank of America Account
description: THE troubled Interpublic Group of Companies was dealt a serious blow yesterday when one of its largest clients, the Bank of America Corporation, dismissed Interpublic and shifted its consolidated account, with total spending estimated at $600 million, to the Omnicom Group.

title: Can You Save a Hard Drive?
description: Correction Appended

title: Life in the Bottom 80 Percent
description: Economic growth isn't what it used to be. In 2004, the economy grew a solid 3.8 percent. But for the fifth straight year, median household income was basically flat, at $44,389 in 2004, the Census Bureau said Tuesday. That's the longest stretch of income stagnation on record.

title: Europe, With Other Woes, Takes Gas Prices in Stride
description: FRANKFURT, Aug. 31 - Tiziano Colombo, an engineer from Milan, hit the road this summer, driving with his wife and in-laws in a rented van through Austria, Germany, Belgium, Holland and France.

title: Rookie Realizes a Dream While Coping With a Nightmare
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 31 - Washington Nationals relief pitcher Jason Bergmann scans the list of incoming calls on his cellphone until he reaches the one he might never erase.

title: From Fantasy to Life
description: Marcel Dzama's twisted fairy-tale world comes to life.

title: Beach Erosion
description: Since a Frenchman named Louis Rard introduced the two-piece bathing suit nearly 60 years ago, bikinis have become smaller and smaller. Ever skimpier swimwear has influenced personal grooming, prompting women to remove more and more body hair.

title: Feigned Emotion
description: The Neuberger Museum's exhibit establishes that staged, people-based photography is becoming the Pre-Raphaelite painting of our time.

title: New York, Then and Now
description: Douglas Levere's project at the Museum of the City of New York is a feat of photographic craftsmanship and offers a great perspective of New York's changing landscape.

title: Preserving Summer
description: With these stylish ways to save and display the season's treasures, from beach finds to vacation photographs, it can be an endless summer after all.

title: Disaster Talk
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Milkshake, a Dead Banker and a Verdict in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 1 - A life of housemaids, black-tie balls and country homes that ended with a senior Merrill Lynch banker lying beaten to death on his bedroom floor produced a guilty verdict Thursday night and a life sentence for his 41-year-old American wife.

title: Exploring the Long Island of Pre-Expressway Days
description: RICH FIEDLER paid for college by harpooning swordfish with his father, a lifelong commercial fisherman in Greenport, N.Y., just as his father had been before him. They made a good living and loved the seagoing life. Those low-tech days have waned, said Mr. Fiedler, now 60, as he greeted visitors to the Main Street art gallery that bears his name. "The swordfish industry went down the tubes with long-lining," he lamented. "Greenport is a tourist area, not really a fishing town any more."

title: 36 Hours in Ocean City, Md.
description: OCEAN City, the 130-year-old honkytonk town "down the ocean," is undergoing a transformation. The 10-mile-long peninsula between the Atlantic and Isle of Wight and Assawoman Bays, an infamous destination for hormonal teenagers and beloved by blue-collar families as an inexpensive seashore getaway, is going upscale. There are still more tattoo parlors, miniature golf courses and dive bars than you can count, and Route 1 (a k a Coastal Highway and Philadelphia Avenue) is still used as a drag strip by muscle cars and road-rocket motorcycles. But merchants are also starting to cater to an influx of high-end condominium buyers who want flavored martinis and $100 tasting menus. Nevertheless, Ocean City's main attraction remains the endless diversions that appeal to all - sport fishing, parasailing, arcades, skateboard parks and miles of wide, sandy public beaches.

title: Government Saw Flood Risk but Not Levee Failure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - When Michael D. Brown, director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, returned in January from a tour of the tsunami devastation in Asia, he urgently gathered his aides to prepare for a similar catastrophe at home.

title: Bloomberg Democrats Are a Primary Force
description: Most New Yorkers are Democrats. And half of them, a recent poll suggests, would re-elect the city's Republican mayor. So come Primary Day, what are these Bloomberg Democrats to do?

title: Scientists Wrestle With a Very, Very Big Wrinkle in Time
description: "A Sound of Thunder," by Ray Bradbury, is a short, elegant science-fiction parable about the dangers of going back in time and messing up the course of evolution. "A Sound of Thunder," a scrap of late-summer damaged goods from Warner Brothers ostensibly based on Mr. Bradbury's tale, offers a somewhat different lesson. Directed by Peter Hyams from a script credited to (or perhaps blamed on) Gregory Poirier, Thomas Dean Donnelly and Joshua Oppenheimer, it illustrates the dangers of turning a lean, elegant short story into a loud, noisy, incoherent B movie.

title: Middelhoff's 2nd act: Revamping Karstadt
Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Wandering in a Forest of Poses
description: PURCHASE, N.Y. - THE exhibition "Acting Out: Invented Melodrama in Contemporary Photography," which opens Sunday at the Neuberger Museum of Art on the campus of the State University of New York here, is a modest but focused effort that brings back old memories and differences. Specifically, it recalls a point in the early 1980's when Douglas Crimp, a pioneering art critic, lamented in an essay the growing popularity of postmodernism's cutting-edge strategy, appropriation.

title: Audit Finds Fiscal Mess at Hospital in Westchester
description: Correction Appended

title: People: Karisma Kapoor, Jerry Hall, Judy Garland
Digging for the global truths
New School Year, New Controversy in France
description: Public schools reopened, but last year's uproar over a ban of Muslim head scarves that threatened to provoke a confrontation between the government and Muslim activists was not repeated.

title: Corzine Loan Becomes a Senate Complaint
description: TRENTON, Sept. 1 - The Senate Ethics Committee received a formal complaint on Thursday that Senator Jon S. Corzine had violated Congressional financial disclosure rules by failing to report that he had given a $470,000 mortgage to the head of a major state employees union. He was dating the union leader at the time.

title: Muslim Leaders Confront Terror Threat Within Islam
description: After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, American Muslim leaders insisted that the terrorism had nothing to do with Islam. They cited Central Intelligence Agency reports showing that Latin Americans were responsible for more terrorist incidents than Muslims. They blamed Israel or American foreign policy, and their organizations focused on campaigns to convince non-Muslim Americans that Islam was a religion of peace.

title: Correction: From Paul Krugman
description: In describing the results of the ballot study by the group led by the Miami Herald, I relied on the HeraldAs own report, which listed only three hypothetical statewide recounts, two of which went to Al Gore. There was, however, a fourth recount, which would have gone to George W. Bush. In this case, the two stricter-standard recounts went to Mr. Bush.

title: A Multiple-Minority Comic, Happily Drubbing the Right
description: Equal parts inspired clown, committed advocate and ferocious Republican-baiter, the comedian Margaret Cho explains why she chose "Assassin" as the title of her latest tour. "I wanted a name that would drive the right crazy," chortles the Korean-American, whose very existence -- she is also outspokenly liberal, feminist and bisexual -- is probably sufficient to accomplish that particular goal.

title: Clothing Logjam Continues
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 1 - Peter Mandelson, the European Union's top trade official, continued to grapple Thursday with six nations in his group as well as China in an effort to defuse a dispute over a tide of Chinese textile imports.

title: In Spurrier's Debut, Gamecocks Get the Party Started Off Right
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 1 - Tailgating around Williams-Brice Stadium began early Thursday, a workday that turned into a party well before the University of South Carolina's football season kicked off. This was the celebration of a beginning, and a continuation of the victory dance that started in November, when Steve Spurrier was introduced as the team's coach.

title: Actor, director, character, doppelgnger
News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Liberty Gets an Early Vacation
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 1 - The Liberty limped into the W.N.B.A. playoffs, and left in pretty much the same fashion.

title: Intel Sharply Rebuts A.M.D.'s Antitrust Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 - In a sharp rebuttal to an antitrust lawsuit, the Intel Corporation on Thursday denied any wrongdoing and characterized Advanced Micro Devices, its rival and accuser, as a victim of its own mistakes.

title: Talks Fail; U.S. Expands Quotas on Chinese Fabrics
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 1 - The United States imposed quotas on imports of bras and certain expensive fabrics from China after American and Chinese trade negotiators failed to reach a deal in a brief meeting in Beijing on Thursday.

title: STORM AND CRISIS
description: A STRICKEN CITY -- The scenes from New Orleans were chilling: an elderly woman dead in a wheelchair outside the Convention Center. Corpses rotting in the streets. Angry crowds chanting to television cameras, "We're dying!" PAGE A15

title: Bush's Remarks in New Orleans
description: PRESIDENT BUSH: Listen, I want to thank the governor of Louisiana and the mayor of New Orleans, Senator Landrieu, Senator Vitter and Congressman Jefferson, Congressman Jindal and General Blum.

title: History, Heard From the Inside
description: FOR Hank Jones, the last 60 years of jazz is not best explained by records. The entire period seems to be retained in his own head: a labor history of all the jam-session, studio, one-night and concert-hall gigs he has played since moving to New York in 1944.

title: The Listings: Sept. 2 -- Sept. 8; RILO KILEY
description: A lot of indie rock bands depend on a certain disarray -- almost but not quite falling apart -- for their frisson. The Los Angeles band Rilo Kiley, led by the charismatic singer-songwriter Jenny Lewis, above, and the songwriter-guitarist Blake Sennett, isn't one of them. With each outing, this group grows more confident, lately narrowing a panoply of styles to a blend of show-tuney pop and bold country soul, the preciousness of both tempered by brash, intimate lyrics. Interpreting her band's songs with nuance and sometimes heartbreaking vulnerability, Ms. Lewis makes no effort to conform to unschooled indie faltering. She goes for it, and her vocals on tunes like the wrenching other-woman vignette "Does He Love You?" on the 2004 album "More Adventurous" (Brute/Beaute) make one hope the band will consider doing a covers record, one that darkly reimagines radio hits by Linda Ronstadt and Crystal Gayle. Of course, Rilo Kiley has a lot to say on its own. "It's a Hit" ruefully compares wartime troop deployment with the mindless shaking of salt, and the torchy "I Never" captures Patsy Cline-esque longing. Perhaps opening for the pop phenom Coldplay, as Rilo Kiley will this week at Madison Square Garden, is a portent of the fame that awaits this band. When Coldplay's earnest master of generalization, Chris Martin, sings on his latest hit "birds come flying from the underground," one suspects he is perhaps talking about the kind of joy transmitted by bands like his show's opening act. (Tuesday and Wednesday, 7:30 p.m., Madison Square Garden, 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue, (212)465-6741; $40.50.) LAURA SINAGRA

title: When work just traps people in poverty
At Track, Weld and Bruno Discuss a Horse Race
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1 - William F. Weld's quest for the Republican nomination for governor of New York took him on Thursday to the clubhouse at Saratoga, which, each summer, becomes the unofficial headquarters of State Senator Joseph. L. Bruno, the leader of the Senate's Republican majority.

title: New York Places, Then and Now
description: The Museum of the City of New York is showing 50 cityscapes from Berenice Abbott's 1939 book "Changing New York," each paired with a picture shot from the same perspective between 1997 and 2003 by the commercial photographer Douglas Levere. His view of Union Square is above; on Page 28 is Abbott's shot, which includes the old S. Klein department store.

title: Juror Says Her Guilty Vote Was Coerced in Terror Trial
description: A juror in the trial of Lynne F. Stewart, the defense lawyer convicted in February of aiding terrorism, wrote to the judge six weeks after the verdict to say she cast her guilty vote "only as a result of the fear and intimidation I was made to feel for my life" during deliberations.

title: Doctors Blame Taser Stun Gun for Fibrillation
description: A shock from a Taser stun gun caused a teenager in Chicago to go into ventricular fibrillation, a usually fatal heart disturbance, according to a letter published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: The Listings: Sept. 2 -- Sept. 8; 'CAPRICCIO'
description: Are words or music more important to opera? The question might not seem worth pondering for an entire evening if it had not been so charmingly woven through Strauss's final opera. The composer called it a "conversation piece for music," but "Capriccio," which opens the New York City Opera's new season on Wednesday, is actually a brilliant piece of meta-opera: music that spins around itself, music through which Strauss bid loving farewell to the genre in which he had been unsurpassed. Strauss and Clemens Krauss wrote the slyly ironic libretto that centers on Countess Madeleine, who is being courted by a composer and a poet. The two suitors team up to create what the audience soon realizes is the very opera being performed before its eyes. The work opens with a lush string sextet and includes some of the most sublime soprano writing in the Strauss literature. Pamela Armstrong, who shined last season in "La Rondine," returns as Madeleine in this new production directed by Stephen Lawless (computer rendering of the set above). Ryan MacPherson plays the composer Flamand, and Mel Ulrich is the poet Olivier. There is even a role for "a young ballerina" and City Opera has recruited Ashley Bouder, a principal dancer at the City Ballet. George Manahan conducts. (Wednesday night at 6:30, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500, $45 to $110.) JEREMY EICHLER

title: A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarke aims quick blast at Blair and Iraq policy
Baghdad and Philadelphia
description: Iraq has provoked some pretty odd utterances from the Bush administration over the years. High among them are President Bush's tortured comparisons between the vigorous debates and political compromises that produced America's Constitution in 1787 and the stillborn constitutional discussions between representatives of Iraq's alienated Sunni Arab minority and the dominant majority coalition of Shiites and Kurds.

title: Conservation? It's Such a 70's Idea
description: WHERE are the plans for energy conservation? They are needed now.

title: Joseph Rotblat, 96, Dies; Resisted Nuclear Weapons
description: Sir Joseph Rotblat, a physicist who was the only scientist to quit working on developing the atomic bomb for moral reasons and who won the Nobel Peace Prize a half-century later for his worldwide campaign to eliminate nuclear weapons, died Wednesday night in London. He was 96.

title: Burning Man
description: HALF pickup truck, half pig, the glowing blue roadhog turns left onto the bustling esplanade, its bemused expression as hard to decipher as its owner's intentions. Kandy-kolored glowstick bicycles veer to avoid it, as do a half-dozen pedal-powered muffins and cupcakes. A convertible Cadillac spacecraft idles at the side of the bustling ring road, its passengers haranguing passersby from atop its beer-keg booster rockets.

title: Commissioner Starts Search to Find New Home for Saints
description: By The Associated Press

title: Judge Dismisses Disclosure Suit Brought by S.E.C. Against Siebel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - A federal district judge in Manhattan has dismissed a lawsuit against Siebel Systems brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of the agency's effort to eliminate the selective disclosure of financial information by public companies.

title: A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lorenzen and Palmer Make Their Final Bids
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 1 - The Giants were pleased to win their preseason finale, and even more pleased to avoid serious injuries.

title: Seven Nominees for Tennis Hall of Fame
description: The former United States Open champions Patrick Rafter and Gabriela Sabatini are among seven nominees for induction into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I.

title: Anxious Liberal Groups Try to Rally Opposition Against Supreme Court Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - It was an anxious August for liberal interest groups battling the nomination of Judge John G. Roberts Jr. to the Supreme Court.

title: Israel and Pakistan hold talks in Turkey
Storm Erased Most of Set of Barrier Islands
description: The Chandeleur Islands, a narrow string of sandy barriers in the Gulf of Mexico about 70 miles east of New Orleans, were virtually destroyed by Hurricane Katrina, according to federal researchers who flew over the area yesterday.

title: Mets Put Up Fight Far Too Late Against the Phillies
description: The 98-mile-an-hour fastball had barely left Billy Wagner's hand when it zipped past a startled David Wright.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Bystander's Shooting
description: A 12-year-old boy was struck by a stray bullet yesterday during an early-morning argument between two men in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. Jason Lindsey, 20, of 818 Macon Street, was charged with assault and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. About 1 a.m., Mr. Lindsay began arguing with another man in front of 820 Macon Street, the police said, and fired several shots from a pistol. The man was not hit, but one bullet struck the boy, who was walking nearby. Officers spotted Mr. Lindsay fleeing, the police said, and arrested him in his building. The boy, who was not identified, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was listed in stable condition.

title: Briefly: Competition hurts Carrefour net
Storm Notes: Carriers cancel flights
While Iraq grieves over stampede, squabbling subsides
Girl Crushed by S.U.V. at Harlem Gas Station
description: A 3-year-old girl was crushed to death in her stroller yesterday when it was wedged between a Lincoln Navigator and a minivan waiting in line at a busy gas station in East Harlem, the police and witnesses said.

title: Gulf Oil Operations Remain in Disarray
description: The Gulf of Mexico, the nation's largest energy center, was still reeling yesterday, four days after Hurricane Katrina, crippling gasoline supplies in some pockets of the country. In the face of the turmoil, the government stepped up its release of strategic oil stocks to refiners.

title: Unending Civil Conflict Makes Life Grim in Indian State
description: IMPHAL, India - A garland of red hibiscus adorned the dead man's portrait, and provisions for the afterlife were laid out for the mourners to see: new slippers and towel, a white undershirt, dessert plates piled high with bananas and sugar-cane candy.

title: Mississippi's Morning After
description: Hattiesburg, Miss. - THE TV news folk love hurricanes. You can see it in the bright lights of their eyes, as they muster crews to travel south, as CNN's Anderson Cooper lashes himself to yet another building, the better to show the viewers at home the terrible truth of the wind. If the wind is slow or uncooperative, then they look for flying awnings, or 70-foot-high BP signs sticking out of motel roofs. Great stuff. Lots of water is good, too, up to our ankles, up to our knees. With Hurricane Katrina, there was some ABC guy in New Orleans using himself as a human measuring stick. Tuesday night he was knee-high in water on Canal Street. Wednesday he was chest-high. Soon, if we are lucky, he will disappear altogether.

title: Interpublic Picks Up Credit Suisse Account
description: A day after the Interpublic Group of Companies learned that it would lose Bank of America as a client, two Interpublic agencies said they had been awarded the assignment to create campaigns for another large financial services marketer, Credit Suisse. The account, with spending estimated at $100 million, had been handled for the last four years by Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas.

title: Convoy Hit in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 1 - A British engineer and his interpreter were kidnapped, and three members of their armed escort were killed Wednesday when their convoy was ambushed in western Afghanistan, a local police official said Thursday.

title: Billion-Dollar Baby Dot-Coms? Uh-Oh, Not Again
description: JIM BREYER, a top Silicon Valley venture capitalist, knows that the $12.2 million his firm paid for a modest stake in Facebook, an online service immensely popular with the college set, is a lot of money.

title: Local Officials Criticize Federal Government Over Response
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 1 - Despair, privation and violent lawlessness grew so extreme in New Orleans on Thursday that the flooded city's mayor issued a "desperate SOS" and other local officials, describing the security situation as horrific, lambasted the federal government as responding too slowly to the disaster.

title: Hitachi to Introduce Tiny Drive
description: In the race to make ever-smaller disk drives for hand-held consumer appliances, Hitachi Ltd. will announce today that it has matched Seagate Technologies with what it says is the smallest drive on the market, a one-inch-diameter hard drive that holds eight gigabytes of data.

title: He's Just Like James Bond, Only Trickier and Stockier
description: Jason Statham is the unlikeliest of high-octane action heroes. He is a stocky, ordinary-looking Englishman who doesn't come off all that swift. But as the ex-Special Forces operative Frank Martin, the impeccably dressed, blank-faced professional driver in "The Transporter" and now "Transporter 2" with more tricks -- and lives -- than James Bond, he's struck gold with a franchise-spawning role. The part allows for the exhibition of some impressive martial-arts skills (he performs almost all his own stunts) while requiring very little in the acting department.

title: Hartford Libraries Watch as U.S. Makes Demands
description: Librarians in Connecticut say they are closely following a federal case in a Bridgeport courthouse involving a demand for library records, both to learn more about the identity of the people at the center of the case and to underscore their concerns about such orders.

title: Victory Over Harsh Press Law in Zimbabwe
description: A court handed a rare victory to journalists in a long-running legal battle with the government, acquitting a reporter for the banned newspaper The Daily News of charges that he had worked without a license required by the Media and Information Commission.

title: Spanning the Gulf
description: Fairhope, Ala. - IN camouflage, rifle at his side, all through the night the National Guardsman leans against the Humvee at the entrance to my block, checking identifications of passers-by. I live along hurricane-smashed Mobile Bay, across from the city of Mobile, and some boats are beached nearby. I realize that this citizen-soldier, who also bears the Iraq war on his shoulders, is here to keep order, but like the armed guardsman pacing in front of the jam-packed local gas station, he seems menacing. When I return home, I show him my driver's license. "Have a good one," he says, waving me on. Finally, I relax.

title: Sponsors Try Their Backhands
description: Correction Appended

title: A Flush Mideast Is Ready to Deal
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 - Thanks to the surge in crude oil prices, Middle Eastern companies, governments and many families in the region have found themselves flush with cash, igniting a flurry of deal making and investment in Europe, Asia and the United States.

title: Latino Art, and Beyond Category
description: At its most vapid, talk about contemporary art is marketing talk, hem-length talk, trend talk. Painting is back. Pleasure is in. Like that. And because trends are cyclical, there's always a "new" to talk about, even though it's old.

title: West, Northwest, Southwest, South and Washington
description: WEST

title: F.B.I. Abandons Disputed Test for Bullets From Crime Scenes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - F.B.I. scientists said Thursday that they would abandon a controversial bullet-matching technique that had been used in thousands of investigations.

description: To the Editor:

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,876 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Nineteen Die as Minibus Falls Off Cliff in South Africa
description: Nineteen people died in northern Limpopo Province when their overloaded minibus taxi rolled off a cliff on a mountainous stretch of a major highway.

title: In Brief: A record price asked for Scottish castle
Children's Events
description: Theater

title: Other Views: Arab News, Miami Herald, The Guardian
A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers; A Question of Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina misstated the day that President Bush returned to Washington from his vacation to meet with a task force coordinating disaster response. It was Wednesday, not Tuesday.

title: Astrodome a Step Up From the New Orleans Chaos
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1 - Refugees from New Orleans arrived Thursday at the Houston Astrodome, finding a roof, dry cots, air-conditioning and hot food. But after accepting 11, 500 refugees, a Red Cross spokeswoman said, the Astrodome was deemed full and people were being diverted to other shelters in the area Thursday night.

title: Hotel Watch: No frills, but low cost at sea
Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Held After Wife's Death
description: A Queens man, Luis Jara-Coello, 31, surrendered to the police yesterday after officers discovered the body of his wife, Fany Lucia Calderon, 29, in her apartment on 67th Street in Woodside, the police said. She had been stabbed several times, the police said. Mr. Jara-Coello turned himself in to the 108th Detective Squad. The police said that Ms. Calderon's murder was still under investigation. Mr. Jara-Coello was held on an immigration-related warrant, the police said.

title: U.S. Sues Bayou; Fraud Cited
description: Federal prosecutors sued the Bayou funds yesterday, saying the hedge fund company and securities firm run by Samuel Israel III directed a years-long fraud that attracted more than $300 million from investors.

title: A World of Dreams, Not All Deferred
description: A World of Dreams, Not All Deferred

title: Gunmen Open Fire on Two Sunni Mosques in Southern Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 2 - Gunmen opened fire on worshippers at two Sunni mosques in southern Iraq this morning, killing one and wounding four, as imams across the country devoted their weekly sermons to the nearly 1,000 victims of Wednesday's deadly stampede in Baghdad.

title: Unexpected Stone Age Find in South Africa
description: Serendipity struck scientists touring a visitors center under construction at the Cradle of Humankind World Heritage Site, a complex area of caves north of Johannesburg that are home to the highest concentration of remains of mankind's earliest known ancestors.

title: We're Waiting, Snyder Tells Morgenthau
description: Leslie Crocker Snyder, the former judge who is waging a primary battle for the post of Manhattan district attorney, unveiled her fourth advertisement on Wednesday night, tweaking the incumbent, Robert M. Morgenthau, for refusing to debate her on television. The commercial, which is running on Time Warner Cable stations, is called "Don't Hold Your Breath"; a spokesman for her campaign declined to say how much it cost.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey Rebuffs Europeans On Cyprus
description: Foreign Minister Abdullah Gul of Turkey resisted pressure from the European Union on Cyprus, saying Turkey would recognize the island's government only after a full settlement on its reunification. His comments came as the bloc grapples with whether Turkey's refusal to recognize Cyprus, a fellow member, should be an obstacle to opening membership talks with Turkey as scheduled on Oct. 3. The European Union is considering a political declaration, as early as this week, to ease political sensitivities over Turkey within Europe and pave the way for negotiations to begin on time. While it is expected to stop short of demanding that Turkey grant Cyprus diplomatic recognition, it would underline that Turkey must grant all the bloc's members, Cyprus included, commercial relations by opening Turkish ports and airports to trade from them. Mr. Gul said this week that that obligation was incumbent only on a full member of the bloc. Graham Bowley (IHT)

title: A Day for (Slightly) Older Women to Shine
description: Sesil Karatantcheva sprayed tennis balls the same way she talks -- boldly, without always thinking -- until she fell uncharacteristically silent, muted by the maturity and precision of third-seeded Amlie Mauresmo.

title: New French plan: No labor overhaul
Exploring the Long Island of Pre-Expressway Days
description: RICH FIEDLER paid for college by harpooning swordfish with his father, a lifelong commercial fisherman in Greenport, N.Y., just as his father had been before him. They made a good living and loved the seagoing life. Those low-tech days have waned, said Mr. Fiedler, now 60, as he greeted visitors to the Main Street art gallery that bears his name. "The swordfish industry went down the tubes with long-lining," he lamented. "Greenport is a tourist area, not really a fishing town any more."

title: Novartis, betting on vaccines, buys Chiron
Top Executive in Germany Again Faces Ruling Heirs
description: ESSEN, Germany, Aug. 31 - Thomas Middelhoff insists that he was not looking for redemption. Nor, he says, was he itching for a bigger challenge, another chief executive's title, or to see his name back in print.

title: In Hunt for Life's Necessities, Rumors Fly and Lines Crawl
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 1 - Emile Ozerden drove 70 miles Wednesday night on a tip that there was gas in Mobile, only to discover that the stations with gas had no power to pump it. When she finally found fuel, in Biloxi, she couldn't wait -- the line was too long, and she feared she would miss curfew here.

title: Lawmakers Lose Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - Representative Gene Taylor, Democrat of Mississippi, raised his family in the house that he and his wife, Margaret, own in Bay St. Louis.

title: Agassi Plays Cards Wisely Against Barrage of Aces
description: As Andre Agassi shuffles, pigeon-toed, from corner to corner, his conservative cap plopped unrakishly on his bald head, it is difficult to imagine just how much is racing through his mind. It might look straightforward when the points are as short and the serves as big as they were yesterday in the second round of the United States Open with Ivo Karlovic looming on the other side of the net, but Agassi is constantly updating his massive tennis memory, looking for fresh angles and new escape routes.

title: Rotting Food, Dirty Water And Heat Add to Problems
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 1 - The National Guard went out on Thursday to pick up the chicken.

title: If Sharon leaves Likud behind
A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A list on Aug. 19 with an article on swimming holes included a location where swimming is prohibited. Bash Bish Falls State Park, near South Egremont, Mass., does not allow swimming above or below the falls.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: European Commission Seeks Faster Repatriation of Some Migrants
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 1 - The European Commission asked European nations on Thursday to institute common rules across the Continent governing the return of illegal immigrants and failed asylum seekers to their home countries.

title: Revisiting the Estes Rocket
description: This was the last week of summer vacation for my kids. I thought it might be a good chance to help my eight-year-old son try out a Christmas present he's been harboring all year long, waiting for a clear day and warm weather: an Estes rocket.

title: A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers (14 Letters)
description: Correction Appended

title: Legion of the Lost: The True Experience of an American in the French Foreign Legion
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Economy Adds 169,000 Jobs, but Storm's Impact Not Yet Felt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - The nation's pace of job creation remained strong in the weeks before Hurricane Katrina as the unemployment rate edged down to its lowest level in five years, the government reported today.

title: Oil Retreats as I.E.A. Agrees to Release Emergency Stocks
description: Oil and wholesale gasoline prices fell today, retreating from this week's surge, as the International Energy Association said its members would release emergency oil stocks to the United States and progress was reported in restoring oil pipelines, refineries and a critical import terminal.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Sports Briefing column on Saturday about the vote that resulted in softball's being ousted from the Olympic program (52-52, with one abstention) referred incorrectly to Jim Easton, a United States delegate to the International Olympic Committee. He recused himself before the voting process because his company manufactures equipment used by the sport; he did not abstain from the vote. (The I.O.C. never released the name of the person who abstained.)

title: Cameras Captured a Disaster but Now Focus on Suffering
description: A woman in a wheelchair, her face and body covered by a plaid blanket, dead, and left next to a wall of the New Orleans convention center like a discarded supermarket cart. There were many other appalling images from Hurricane Katrina on Thursday, but that one was a turning point: after three days of flood scenes, television shifted from recording a devastating natural disaster to exposing human failures.

title: Escaping Depression? Just Dance Blues Away
description: Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers made 10 musicals together, from "Flying Down to Rio" in 1933, when they didn't yet get star billing, to "The Barkleys of Broadway" in 1949, a full decade after the ninth and a kind of coda to the rest.

title: Stocks: Rising gasoline prices bring out the bears
R. L. Burnside, 78, Master of Raw Mississippi Blues, Dies
description: R.L. Burnside, a blues singer and guitarist who found fame only in his gray years, when his music was embraced by young rock fans and remixed with electronic beats, died yesterday at a hospital in Memphis. He was 78 and lived near Holly Springs, Miss.

title: Sharpton and Union Leader Weigh Whether to Make a Joint Endorsement of Ferrer
description: With less than two weeks before the Democratic mayoral primary, Al Sharpton and Dennis Rivera, leader of the influential health care workers' union, 1199/S.E.I.U., are weighing whether to endorse Fernando Ferrer or skip an endorsement in the primary altogether.

title: Airlines to Fly Up to 25,000 Refugees Out of New Orleans
description: The nation's airlines today began an operation intended to fly up to 25,000 refugees out of New Orleans, under an emergency plan put into effect for the first time by the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Philip Bowring: Cheating great expectations
Progress reported in Lebanon murder investigation
Theater Is to Be Renamed for a Dying Playwright
description: "I have a robust imagination, but I never imagined anything like this."

title: Beware: Voters Could Sway This Election
description: ONE at a time, the five major candidates for mayor, including the incumbent, paraded before an audience Wednesday evening to take questions and present themselves as the worthiest in the realm. Had they only expressed hope for world peace, their event at City Hall might have faintly resembled the final round of the Miss America pageant.

title: 4 Highly Placed Lebanese Are Charged in Killing of Former Premier
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates Sept. 1 - A Lebanese prosecutor charged a security chief and three former security officials on Thursday with murder in the killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, the most significant step in the investigation of the Feb. 14 bombing.

title: Switzerland names 2 blacklisted airlines
Agassi's Run No Surprise to Lendl
description: ANDRE AGASSI endured another round yesterday, in his 20th consecutive late summer in the big city, playing in a third decade on the men's tennis tour. At age 35, in the twilight of greatness, the wise old man of the United States Open continued a remarkable career rewrite, one that only contrarians in the habit of hitting crosscourt could have foreseen a decade ago.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WHERE ARE THEY NOW? -- In this special, Stacy London and Clinton Kelly (right), the outspoken hosts of "What Not to Wear," revisit four past fashionmakeover subjects. Left on their own, have they remained fabulous? Heaven help them if they haven't.

title: Producers, at least, are smiling
Holiday on Monday; Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Federal Court Thows Out Suit Brought by Correction Officer
description: NEWARK, Sept. 1 - A federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a former Union County correction officer's claim that the county had illegally dismissed him in retaliation for testimony against fellow corrections officers.

title: Momoya
description: If I have this right, Italian was the new Japanese and Mexican is the new Italian, unless you consider Italian a kind of timeless player who advances and retreats but always looms large on the field. In that case Mexican is the new Japanese, and any way you slice it, Japanese has been cast as a faded culinary empire, at least here in New York.

title: The Whale According to Welles (a Long Island Tale)
description: Tony Walton was just a young art student when Orson Welles came to London in 1955, bringing with him an enormous ego, an even bigger reputation and a play as large as, well, a sizable sea mammal.

title: Wide Open Spaces, Within and Between the Frames
description: Like the starship Enterprise, museum curators are supposed to go where no curator has gone before. They can do this with relative ease in temporary exhibitions and also with acquisitions. But the meat of their job lies elsewhere: curators must find unexplored planets in a very familiar galaxy, the artworks in the museum's permanent collection. Like orchestra conductors working with the classical repertory, curators must discover new worlds within existing artworks and till familiar terrain for fresh interpretations.

title: Bush Says Results of Aid Efforts Were 'Not Acceptable'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - President Bush toured New Orleans today, seeing from the air and on the ground what flooding has done to one of America's most elegant cities, and he vowed that the city and the lives of the people who call it home would be rebuilt.

title: Fats Domino Among Missing Musicians
description: Several prominent New Orleans musicians, including Fats Domino, one of the great figures of Louisiana rhythm and blues since the 1950's, are unaccounted for in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

title: President Fox Cites Gains in Mexican Democracy and Economy
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 - Five years after his historic election triumph, President Vicente Fox made a case in a speech to Mexico's Congress on Thursday night that he had laid the cornerstones for Mexico's democracy, made the government more transparent and stabilized the country's volatile economy.

title: Homes of 2 Daimler executives raided
Letter from Warsaw: Belarussians hoping to rock toward change
A House Divided
description: OUTSIDE, it was a picture of autumnal beauty: The cool wind whipped across the front yard, stirring the burnished yellow and orange leaves blanketing the ground. But I was indoors, deep in the basement of my mother-in-law's farmhouse in upstate New York, toiling alongside her housekeeper, imported from the city for the weekend. As I scraped old contact paper from a kitchen cabinet drawer, I knew that I would not look back on this day with fondness.

title: Meanwhile: The bean that mitigates life's daily grind
Great Plains, Pure Golf
description: FROM up on the first tee, the course stretches out and across in a stirring panorama. The fairway, full of ripples and hollows and mounds, bordered by golden fescue and gnarly, craggy sand traps, beckons even as it menaces. There are no developments, no McMansions in sight -- just land and sky and golfers, some of whom have made a long pilgrimage to get to this special place.

title: A Killer on the Campus, a Class Clown on the Trail
description: The latest bit of damaged goods offered up in the Miramax clearance sale, "Underclassman" plays like the longest episode of "21 Jump Street" ever made. It seems to have been conceived to help its star, Nick Cannon, make the transition from television tweener heartthrob to big-screen action hero. Mr. Cannon, whose idea the whole thing apparently was, has a loose, quick-talking charm -- he was delightful in Charles Stone III's "Drumline" -- but in this picture he tries on a series of secondhand movie star identities, trying so hard to be the next Will Smith or Eddie Murphy that his own personality all but dissolves.

title: The Role of a Pharmacist
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 28 Charged In Cigarette Smuggling
description: The police have arrested 28 men -- many of them Jordanian nationals -- accused of selling untaxed and sometimes counterfeit-label cigarettes to store owners in the Bronx, Yonkers and Manhattan, the police said yesterday. The scheme involved buying cigarettes from Suffolk County's Shinnecock and Poospatuck reservations, where they are not taxed, and from cigarette counterfeiters based in China, and reselling them to bodegas for half the cost of legitimately taxed cigarettes, the police said. The enterprise is believed to have generated approximately $10 million in profits since the investigation began in 2003, the police said. Approximately $500,000 was sent to unknown recipients in Amman, Jordan, by way of crew members of Royal Jordanian Airlines, according to the Bronx district attorney's office. Those arrested are charged collectively with 1,237 counts of money laundering, possession of forged instruments, trademark counterfeiting and other offenses. Investigators seized or bought, through undercover officers, more than 15,000 cartons of cigarettes and seized more than $700,000, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: They Saw It Coming
description: Lenox, Mass. - THE deaths caused by Hurricane Katrina are heart-rending. The suffering of survivors is wrenching. Property destruction is shocking. But perhaps the most agonizing part is that much of what happened in New Orleans this week might have been avoided.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Rare Beatles Items in London Pop Auction

title: Fire Dept. Defends Policy on Hiring

title: Where Goldfish Smoke and Sushi Spin
description: "Mind Game," an animated feature playing for a week as part of the Museum of Modern Art's Japanese anime series, is certainly something to see. It may, for that matter, be too much for the eye or the mind to take in all at once. Combining inky, hand-drawn animation with flashes of live-action imagery (in particular, sudden glimpses of the real faces of the voice actors), it is a sometimes enthralling, sometimes exhausting tour de force, complete with smoking goldfish, spinning sushi and a detour through the streets of Osaka into cartoon heaven.

title: An affair, a milkshake and a guilty verdict
Around the World
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cadbury to Sell Beverages Division
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the world's third-largest maker of soft drinks, plans to sell its European beverages unit and use the proceeds to reduce about 4.3 billion ($7.8 billion) of debt. The business, which makes Orangina and Schweppes and accounts for 10 percent of sales, may fetch at least 1 billion, according to Richard Workman, an Oriel Securities analyst in London. The Goldman Sachs Group is advising the London-based Cadbury, a company spokeswoman, Katie Macdonald-Smith, said. Cadbury's chief executive, Todd Stitzer, is focusing on faster-growing businesses, like United States beverages.

title: Tongue-Tied on Bilingual Education
description: Education researchers have been seething since the Education Department's research arm announced that it would not publish a long-awaited, federally commissioned report on bilingual education. The department denies any political motive, noting that peer reviewers described the study as terminally flawed. But given the politically charged nature of the issue, the administration would be wise to make this controversy go away. It could accomplish that by quickly conveying ownership of the study to the researchers, who could then publish it privately and let the public judge the work for itself.

title: INSIDE
description: Theater to Be Renamed For a Dying Playwright August Wilson, a two-time winner of the Pulitzer Prize for drama, will receive one of the great honors in American theater next month. His name will be affixed to the marquee of a Broadway theater, the Virginia Theater on West 52nd Street.

title: Al Jazeera Video Links London Bombings to Al Qaeda
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 - Osama bin Laden's chief lieutenant praised the July 7 bombings in London in a videotape that also featured a statement from a man who closely resembled one of the bombers. The tape, broadcast on Al Jazeera, also said Al Qaeda would carry out more attacks.

description: An article yesterday about the impact of Hurricane Katrina on schools and colleges misstated the name and composition of an association of research universities that has urged its members to help displaced students. It is the Association of American Universities, not the American Association of Universities. Two of its 62 members are in Canada; they are not all in the United States.

title: From Margins of Society to Center of the Tragedy
description: The scenes of floating corpses, scavengers fighting for food and desperate throngs seeking any way out of New Orleans have been tragic enough. But for many African-American leaders, there is a growing outrage that many of those still stuck at the center of this tragedy were people who for generations had been pushed to the margins of society.

title: A Reprieve for Reality in New Crop of Films
description: Penguins versus grizzly bears: the battle for the hearts, minds and dollars of American moviegoers waged by the emperor penguins of Antarctica against the grizzly bears of Alaska in two widely praised summer documentaries has something to tell us about our appetite for reality.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Rules Against Preservationists
description: Landmark West, a preservation group fighting to obtain landmark status for 2 Columbus Circle, suffered a setback yesterday, when Justice Michael D. Stallman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled against the group's petition to block the Museum of Arts and Design from buying the building. Landmark West had accused the museum, currently known as the American Craft Museum, of improperly trying to influence the commission. The judge also dismissed the group's claim that the city should have to pass special legislation to sell the building. Landmark West said it would appeal the ruling. A spokeswoman for the Museum of Arts and Design, Cheri Fein, said it planned to proceed with the purchase. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

The game was more about auditioning players for the remaining open roster spots and starting positions than it was about the final score.

With these stylish ways to save and display the season's treasures, from beach finds to vacation photographs, it can be an endless summer after all. LESLIE LAND

title: A Can't-Do Government
description: Before 9/11 the Federal Emergency Management Agency listed the three most likely catastrophic disasters facing America: a terrorist attack on New York, a major earthquake in San Francisco and a hurricane strike on New Orleans. "The New Orleans hurricane scenario," The Houston Chronicle wrote in December 2001, "may be the deadliest of all." It described a potential catastrophe very much like the one now happening.

A horrified family telling tales of pirates commandeering rescue boats at gunpoint. Corpses left rotting in broad daylight. Angry crowds chanting for the television cameras, "We're dying!" or simply "Help!"

In the face of the turmoil, the government stepped up its release of strategic oil stocks to refiners. [Page C1.]

title: Dining: A delicious discovery in the Basque region
Guillermo Toledo
description: Mr. Toledo, who as a rakish department-store salesman is the antihero of Alex de la Iglesia's black comedy "El Crimen Perfecto," may just be beginning to register on the radar of American filmgoers: he was last seen here as a cuckolded lover in the musical sex farce "The Other Side of the Bed," in 2003. But Mr. Toledo, 35, above, has been a household name in Spain since appearing on the wildly popular sitcom "Siete Vidas" ("Seven Lives") from 1999 to 2002. In addition to his Spanish feature film work, Mr. Toledo has become known for his outspoken criticism of the conservative People's Party. When he served as a host of the 2003 Goya Awards (where he was also a nominee for best new actor), Mr. Toledo turned the ceremony into a group protest against the impending war in Iraq, much to the dismay of the Spanish Ministry of Culture. He is also a founding member of the Madrid-based theater collective Animalario, which toured the country last year with "Alejandro y Ana," a play spoofing the nuptials of the daughter of the former prime minister, Jos Mara Aznar (who lost his job when his party was voted out last year just after the terrorist attacks on Madrid). Now, two years after his controversial appearance as host of the Goya Awards, Mr. Toledo finds himself nominated again, this time for best actor for his role in "El Crimen Perfecto." In a recent interview with a Spanish film magazine, he linked that film's implicit critique of consumerism to his own political beliefs: "We need more black humor and less fear," he said, adding later, "We need to be wilder, cruder. We need to lash out at a social structure that doesn't work." (Sunshine Cinema, 143 East Houston Street, Lower East Side, (212)330-8182.) DANA STEVENS Critic's Choice

description: ONLY two years ago, Fred Wilpon mused that he would like to see his team play meaningful games.

title: Israel Halts Plan to Add Homes Near West Bank Settlement
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 3 - Israel has bowed to the United States and frozen a much-criticized plan to add 3,500 new housing units near a large West Bank settlement called Maale Adumim, according to Ehud Olmert, a close ally of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his vice prime minister.

title: Art Ahead: Linger for a While, Look and Tell the Story
description: The Accidental Masterpiece On the Art of Life and Vice Versa By Michael Kimmelman Illustrated. 246 pages. Penguin Press. $24.95.

title: Woman Is Killed in Second Fatality of Week at L.I. Amusement Park
description: Two days after a teenager was run over as he operated a roller coaster at Adventureland amusement park in Farmingdale, N.Y., a woman was killed at the park yesterday when she was thrown from a spinning ride and sent crashing into a car in a nearby parking lot, the Suffolk County police said.

title: The Man-Made Disaster
description: The situation in New Orleans, which had seemed as bad as it could get, became considerably worse yesterday with reports of what seemed like a total breakdown of organized society. Americans who had been humbled by failures in Iraq saw that the authorities could not quickly cope with a natural disaster at home. People died for lack of water, medical care or timely rescues -- particularly the old and the young -- and victims were almost invariably poor and black. The city's police chief spoke of rapes, beatings and marauding mobs. The pictures were equally heartbreaking and maddening. Disaster planners were well aware that New Orleans could be flooded by the combined effects of a hurricane and broken levees, yet somehow the government was unable to immediately rise to the occasion.

title: Leviathan, Thy Bounty Made Nantucket Shine
description: Around 1690, legend has it, a group of men standing on a bluff on Nantucket, the windswept island 24 miles south of Cape Cod, saw a pod of whales offshore. Pointing to the whales, one man reportedly said, "There is a green pasture where our children's grandchildren will go for bread."

title: Education Law Is Loosened for Failing Chicago Schools
description: Moving once again to ease the requirements of the nation's tough new education law, Secretary of Education Margaret Spellings announced yesterday that she would allow the Chicago Public Schools to run federally financed tutoring programs for students at low-performing schools, despite Chicago's failure to meet academic goals.

title: Hotbed of Protest: In St. Petersburg, It's the Downtown Mall
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 1 - A man with a bullhorn stood inside a corral of metal barricades, leading protesters in a chant: "Business is a privilege! Free speech is a right!" The police handcuffed a young man who had been violating a noise ordinance by beating a drum, and the chants turned to "Let him go!" Four men dressed largely in black taunted officers with a Nazi salute.

description: "We're just a bunch of rats. That's how they've been treating us."

description: Not to be confused with the works of photographic appropriators like Sherrie Levine and Richard Prince, rephotography is a specialized genre that entails finding the exact spot where an old photograph was taken and shooting the scene again. Demanding professionals use equipment similar to what was used to make the old photograph, and try to mimic exactly the framing, time of day and other salient aspects of the original picture.

This is not a complete list: shoot me, but I've left out the reverent editions of old television shows that now seem to be a DVD staple, and there are at least a couple of obvious candidates that are not included here because review copies were not available, including "Rebel Samurai," a four-film collection of Japanese swordplay movies due from Criterion on Oct. 4; a reissue from Universal of 10 Alfred Hitchcock titles, also Oct. 4; and an intimidatingly titled "The Complete Monty Python's Flying Circus 16-Ton Megaset," arriving from A&E Home Video on Sept. 27.

And the world of contemporary art is flooded by work that is either about being young and immature or is deliberately made to look as if it had been created by young and immature people -- or both.

An additional 2,000 jobs would be transferred to the technology companies, primarily to I.B.M. ABN did not say where the jobs would be cut. title: Arts, Briefly; Hurricane in Prime Time
description: CBS, NBC and ABC each broadcast a news special devoted to Hurricane Katrina on Wednesday night. On CBS, "48 Hours" was broadcast first, at 8 p.m., drawing 8.21 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. "Dateline," on NBC at 9 p.m., brought in 11.8 million. And at 10 p.m., an ABC News special drew an audience of 9.22 million. Over all, NBC was No. 1 in total viewers and tied with CBS in the 18-to-49 demographic. On Sunday night, both "The 4400" and "The Dead Zone" concluded their seasons on USA. "The Dead Zone," starring Anthony Michael Hall, attracted 3.32 million viewers. "The 4400" drew 3.67 million, a huge drop from its first season finale last summer, which brought in 6.1 million viewers. Both USA series finished in basic cable's top 15 shows of last week among 18-to-49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

title: The Listings: Sept. 2 -- Sept. 8; 'BIRTH OF A CULTURE: 60'S AND 70'S SURF PHOTOGRAPHY BY LeROY GRANNIS'
description: The problem with photographing athletics is that while movement is of the essence in sports, photographs don't move. Surfing doubles the problem. Both the athletes and the playing field are moving quite speedily. What a surfing photographer like LeRoy Grannis wants is to freeze the moment at an instant of maximum tension: the towering wave just before it crashes from a sheer glassy green wall into frothy chaos; the surfer, an escape artist, scooting along just ahead of the angry white water that threatens to engulf him and take him down. The rider falling like Icarus (above in a photograph from 1966), diving away from his board so as not to be hit by it in the ensuing turbulence, is a good motif, too. Of course, the ocean itself is an eternally photogenic subject, and man against the sea an enduring mythic theme. All these elements plus romantic nostalgia combine in new, big color prints of images that Mr. Grannis shot in the 60's and 70's. Born in 1917, Mr. Grannis started surfing in the 60's and shortly thereafter took up photography, which earned him major awards for his work for surfing magazines and eventual initiation into the International Surfing Hall of Fame. (Bonni Benrubi, 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan, (212)888-6007, through Oct. 1.) KEN JOHNSON

Pervez Musharraf, scored major gains in the first two rounds of local government elections, a development likely to further consolidate General Musharraf's grip on power ahead of the general elections scheduled for 2007, political analysts say.

title: 36 Hours in Ocean City, Md.
description: OCEAN City, the 130-year-old honkytonk town "down the ocean," is undergoing a transformation. The 10-mile-long peninsula between the Atlantic and Isle of Wight and Assawoman Bays, an infamous destination for hormonal teenagers and beloved by blue-collar families as an inexpensive seashore getaway, is going upscale. There are still more tattoo parlors, miniature golf courses and dive bars than you can count, and Route 1 (aka Coastal Highway and Philadelphia Avenue) is still used as a drag strip by muscle cars and road-rocket motorcycles. But merchants are also starting to cater to an influx of high-end condominium buyers who want flavored martinis and $100 tasting menus. Nevertheless, Ocean City's main attraction remains the endless diversions that appeal to all -- sport fishing, parasailing, arcades, skateboard parks and miles of wide, sandy public beaches. ALICIA AULT

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Science Times on Aug. 23 about the Citadel in Erbil, Iraq, one of the world's oldest continuously inhabited sites, misidentified the group that seized power in what is now northern Iraq in the 13th century A.D. It was the Mongols, not the Ottomans (as the article said) or the Moguls (as the chart said). The article also misstated the timing of the takeover; it was about 1,600 years after Alexander the Great defeated the Persians on the plain west of Erbil, not about a millennium afterward.

title: Jan Moor-Jankowski Is Dead at 81; Used Chimps, Kindly, in Science
description: Jan Moor-Jankowski, a scientist known for groundbreaking immunology work with chimpanzees and whose life was defined by many impassioned battles, from fighting Nazis in his native Poland to defending press freedoms to exposing animal abuse, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: For the Trump-Deprived
description: IT is impossible to read Donald Trump's blog without hearing his voice and picturing him typing away in his Turnbull & Asser pajamas, sleep still in his eyes. Otherwise, "The Trump Blog" (what else?) seems a lot like most other blogs. Which is to say, lightweight and highly egocentric.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 2 - The Liberty searched all season for consistency. When it finally found some, it did not survive much past a mid-August injury to one of its best players, Ann Wauters.

description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 2 - United Nations diplomats vowed to keep negotiating next week on a pivotal document for an approaching summit meeting, but a dispute sharpened Friday over American amendments that are seen as diluting the meeting's central theme of increasing development aid.

title: Katrina's Assault on Washington
description: Do not be misled by Congress's approval of $10.5 billion in relief for the Hurricane Katrina victims. That's prompted by the graphic shock of the news coverage from New Orleans and the region, where the devastation catapults daily, in heartbreaking contrast with the slo-mo bumblings of government.

title: Short-term oil fixes, long-term uncertainty
Sagaponack Passes Measure to Incorporate
description: SAGAPONACK, N.Y., Sept. 2 - Residents of Sagaponack voted overwhelmingly on Friday night to become a village, winning what had been a battle to preserve their seaside community's traditional boundaries.

title: Utilities Restoring Some Service, but Large Gaps Remain
description: The major electric utilities in the storm-damaged Gulf Coast region have restored power to some areas less directly affected by Hurricane Katrina and to numerous hospitals, some key oil operations and to the main airport of New Orleans.

title: Meeting School Siege Victims' Kin, Putin Deflects Blame From Kremlin
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 - Facing unusually public and personal criticism, President Vladimir V. Putin met Friday with relatives of the victims of the school siege a year ago in Beslan and promised the thorough accounting of the circumstances surrounding it that they have been demanding for months.

title: Siblings Share Psychodramas Within a Psychodrama
description: Childlike whimsy turns sour in "The Eisteddfod," Lally Katz's darkly self-indulgent, deeply muddled new play. It's about a pair of shut-in orphans of indeterminate age, Abalone (Luke Mullins) and Gerture (Jessamy Dyer), who kill time by role-playing the parts of their late mother and father, of a schoolteacher with an imaginary class and of a brutal, womanizing cad named Ian.

title: Less 'Germany Inc.' - more openness

description: Set against the daily cadence of drama in the city, an emergency call from a Grand Street apartment on Monday night was routine enough. An elderly woman, suffering from Alzheimer's disease, was threatening to hurt herself, possibly with a knife. So her neighbors called for help.

title: Currencies: Fear of a Fed pause on rates hits dollar
Cats and Rats, and the Cats Are Losing
description: A BROKEN bottle of a man sat on the hot sidewalk Thursday afternoon, lips wet from the beer he had just tossed under a car. With leaden hand he stroked the head of an abandoned baby bird in his lap, and it was a tossup as to which of the two looked more lost. But for now he would have to do as the sentry for the awful apartment building behind him, 305 West 150th Street.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Unexpected Stone Age Find
description: Serendipity struck scientists touring a visitors center under construction at the Cradle of Humankind World Heritage Site, a complex area of caves north of Johannesburg that are home to the highest concentration of remains of mankind's earliest known ancestors. While being shown a retail area under construction, archaeologists spotted a trove of Stone Age tools and artifacts lying in a seam of gravel unearthed just 20 inches below the surface. The discovery, which filled three boxes with stone axes, knives, cleavers and other tools said to be between 500,000 and 1.8 million years old, was a "huge surprise to all of us," said Rob King, the chief executive of Maropeng Africa, the company that will manage the visitors center, which is scheduled to open in December. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Twins' Faith in Liriano Could Finally Pay Off
description: In November 2003, Francisco Liriano was an afterthought in the trade that sent catcher A. J. Pierzynski to the Giants and pitcher Joe Nathan to the Twins. Liriano was coming off an injury-plagued season, and San Francisco included him and pitcher Boof Bonser, another minor leaguer, in the trade.

title: Gunmen Open Fire on Sunni Worshipers in Southern Iraq, Killing One
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 2 - Gunmen opened fire on worshipers at two Sunni mosques in southern Iraq on Friday morning, killing one and wounding four, as imams across the country devoted their weekly sermons to the nearly 1,000 victims of Wednesday's deadly stampede in Baghdad.

title: Hurricane News Coverage Affects Mayoral Primary
description: With just 10 days before the Democratic primary, there is no more important time than now for the candidates to get their faces and platforms out in front of voters.

title: Group Files Lawsuit to Prevent The Closing of Fort Monmouth
description: A coalition of state and local elected officials, as well as soldiers, unions and defense contractors in New Jersey, filed a federal lawsuit yesterday that seeks to keep Fort Monmouth from being closed based on a recommendation by the Base Closure and Realignment Commission.

title: Storms Beneath the Calm
description: The drummer Brian Blade's band, Fellowship, is an open book of serene and sweeping emotion; just about all the pieces in its repertory suggest hymns or the neo-bucolic sound of early Pat Metheny records. But below the thematic surface of the music, which is paved by the pianist Jon Cowherd, the guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel and the saxophonists Myron Walden and Chris Cheek, there is sweat and churning.

title: Miller Seeks Big Exemption From Limits on Spending

title: War Strategy Without Politics (No Budget Cuts)
description: Military commanders in the real world, I suspect, would love to transfer to one of the make-believe armies of Advance Wars: Dual Strike, the turn-based strategy game by Intelligent Systems. Weapons systems never malfunction, there are no cost overruns and soldiers line up to take over for fallen comrades. Intelligence is accurate and never skewed for political ends, and unlike the morally ambiguous wars of history, in Dual Strike the fight is against an aggressive, unscrupulous enemy pursuing world conquest. It is a military paradise.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: After Strong First-Quarter Earnings, Air France-KLM Raises Its Outlook Air France-KLM raised its profit forecast yesterday after first-quarter operating earnings soared, helped by efforts to cut costs as airlines grapple with high oil prices. The airline said buoyant traffic figures recently and oil market hedging contracts pointed to a marked improvement in the second quarter and "significantly higher" full-year operating profits. Operating profit rose to 223 million euros ($279.9 million). Analysts had forecast 197.1 million euros. Net profit for the three months through June was 112 million euros, just ahead of consensus at 110.4 million. Shares in the merged French-Dutch airline rose as much as 5 percent to 13.98 euros, before closing 2.5 percent higher, at 13.62 euros. (Reuters)

description: WANNISKI--Jude. Jude's passionate respect for the wisdom of the marketplace, whether financial or political, his brillance and cogency in explaining and interpreting the markets' meaning, and his unfailing insistence on understanding the view through the eyes of the underdog, the unpopular, and even the hated, informed us for over 25 years. We will miss him sorely and extend our love and sad condolences to Patricia and his children. Richard Gilder, David Howe, and the Partners and employees of Gilder Gagnon Howe & Co.
