The headliner arrived to the "Also Sprach Zarathustra" fanfare; there were smoke machines, explosions, sing-alongs, confetti, lighters held aloft and, of course, the Wave. The lead singer shouted "New Jersey!" on any plausible occasion and proudly announced that it was the biggest show the band had ever played in America.

title: Parties Provide Lists of Witnesses for Roberts Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - Preparing for battle next week on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge John G. Roberts Jr., Democrats released a list of witnesses on Friday that includes John W. Dean III, former counsel to the Nixon administration.

description: ROSEMONT, Ill., Sept. 2 - American Muslims met with Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes on Friday at an Islamic convention here to offer advice and assistance as she began an initiative to improve the flagging image of the United States among Muslims overseas.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Getty Faces New Charges
description: Two months before the chief antiquities curator of the J. Paul Getty Trust is to stand trial in Rome on charges of conspiring to receive illegally exported artworks, a newly revealed series of letters and photographs shows that the curator, Marion True, maintained close ties to dealers suspected of selling stolen art, The Los Angeles Times reported yesterday. Letters indicated the dealers were offering objects "which appear to be from illegal excavations," and photographs showed the artifacts "in an unrestored state" that suggested they were recently looted, according to a confidential 2001 memo from the Getty's lawyer Richard Martin, a copy of which was obtained by The Los Angeles Times. In a statement, the Getty responded: "The Times's story is based on privileged documents that have been stolen from the Getty. The Getty provided all of the materials that were requested and did not provide materials that were not requested." Italian authorities have identified 42 objects, including some of the Getty's most prized antiquities, as stolen and have demanded their return. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: The Bra Wars
description: The Bush administration, ignoring the lesson offered by a similarly ill-advised move across the Atlantic, has announced more restrictions on imports of bras and some fabrics made in China. The European Union has shown quite ably just how ridiculous this strategy is. Some 80 million garments have been held up in European ports because of complaints by European textile manufacturers about the flood of cheaper Chinese-made goods since the World Trade Organization abolished the quota system on Jan. 1. Most of those shipments have already been paid for, but arrived after E.U. quotas went into effect. The E.U.'s trade chief, Peter Mandelson, has asked the group's member nations to let the bras and other items in. He recently warned that not doing so could lead to "severe economic pain for many smaller retailers and medium-sized businesses." European officials and China are still negotiating over the quota issue.

title: In Hard Times for Airlines, No Soft Touch
description: Soon after the September 2001 attacks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, asked a Fed colleague, Edward M. Gramlich, to become chairman of the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, created by Congress to oversee $10 billion in loan guarantees to help the struggling industry.

title: At Least Yankees Get Some Rest In Ugly Loss
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 2 - The public-address announcer was still talking, but Jorge DePaula threw a pitch anyway. Bobby Kielty doubled to the right-field corner. The Yankees did not want to be here anymore, in the sixth inning of a dreary blowout, and the Oakland Athletics still had hitting to do.

He is Ted Bartles, not Barltes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: New School Year, New Controversy
description: Public schools reopened, but last year's uproar over a ban of Muslim head scarves that threatened to provoke a confrontation between the government and Muslim activists was not repeated. "The tension is mostly behind us," Philippe Guittet, a teachers' union leader, told Le Figaro. But there has been some controversy over a new law that requires primary school pupils to memorize the words of the national anthem, "La Marseillaise," whose lyrics call for the "impure blood" of France's enemies to irrigate its fields. "How can you talk about impure blood, and teach pupils tolerance at the same time?" Jean-Luc Villeneuve, another teachers' union leader, said in a televised debate. Guy Geoffroy, a conservative member of Parliament, accused him of "trying to guillotine the Marseillaise." John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: First Estimate Puts Storm's Economic Toll at $100 Billion
description: A risk management firm yesterday offered the first estimate of economic losses from Hurricane Katrina -- $100 billion -- and said that private insurance would probably cover less than a quarter of that. Federal money and charitable contributions may need to do the rest.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 19 Die As Minibus Falls Off Cliff
description: Nineteen people died in northern Limpopo Province when their overloaded minibus taxi rolled off a cliff on a mountainous stretch of a major highway. The police said the minibus, built for 16 passengers, was carrying 26 when its driver stopped in the predawn hours to relieve himself by the side of the highway and the vehicle rolled down the road, over a bridge and off a cliff. Often-horrific accidents involving poorly maintained minibus taxis and their unregulated drivers are a staple of road life in southern Africa. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Muslim Voyagers in a Distant Land (the West)
description: BARCELONA - For well over 1,000 years, from the Moorish conquest of Spain to the postwar addiction to Mideast oil, Europe has been engaged with the Muslim world. Yet remarkably, over much of this period, Europe has paid little heed to how it was viewed in the eyes of Muslims.

title: Egypt's Premier Hurries Up to Make Change Slowly
description: CAIRO - ARAB leaders are not generally known for being accountable to the public, and do not often make an effort to explain their actions.

title: Spot Shortages of Gas Reported Around Country
description: Less than a week after Hurricane Katrina severely disrupted energy supplies, spot gasoline shortages were reported yesterday at service stations in New York City and across the country heading into the three-day Labor Day weekend.

title: Doubles' Jeopardy Is Focus of Lawsuit
description: America's most accomplished doubles team turned the National Tennis Center into a court of public opinion yesterday. Their chosen sport was on trial.

title: A Democratic Candidate for Mayor
description: Michael Bloomberg, a Republican, is far ahead in the polls right now, but New York is overwhelmingly Democratic, and the winner of this month's Democratic primary could well become the next mayor. He or she needs to be qualified for that critical post. It's also important that the party's nominee challenge Mr. Bloomberg to defend his policies, answer for his mistakes and chart his plans.

title: European Brewers Accused of Fixing Prices
description: The European Commission accused European brewers, including Heineken and Royal Grolsch of Holland and InBev of Belgium, of dividing the Dutch beer market among themselves and fixing prices artificially high during the late 1990's, Jonathan Todd, the spokesman for Europe's competition commission, said. "Competitors agreed on prices, allocated customers, discussed the conditions with individual customers and shared market information. These practices affected the price of beer," he said. The brewers will have a chance to reply and have a hearing, before the commission makes a final decision. If found guilty, the companies face fines of up to 10 percent of their global annual sales. InBev declined comment on the case and the other two brewers could not be reached for comment after business hours. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Teenage Upstart From Serbia Can Exhale After Upset
description: On Tuesday, as the Serbian teenager Novak Djokovic lay on the blue hard court in the heat in the first round -- his breathing labored, his face twisted in pain and his fresher and healthier opponent, Gael Monfils, watching from across the net -- it was difficult to imagine that his first United States Open was going to last much longer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALDOR, MAJOR GENERAL JEROME N.
description: WALDOR -- Major General Jerome N., USAF Ret., of South Orange, NJ on September 2, 2005. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Marc, Matthew and Peter. Loving brother of the late Mickey. Adored grandfather of five grandchildren and three step - grandchildren. Funeral services at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ, Sunday, September 4th at 10AM. Bernheim - Apter Kreitzman 1-800-938-6372

title: Leader of Federal Effort Feels the Heat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - On Thursday night, Michael D. Brown, the federal government's point man for managing the response to Hurricane Katrina, made a remarkable confession on live television.

title: 1 Dead, 1 Hurt in Small-Plane Crash
description: A single-engine Cessna plane crashed last night a quarter-mile east of Teterboro Airport in South Hackensack, N.J., killing one person on board and injuring the other, in the fourth plane accident involving the airport this year, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTTENBERG, IRA M.
description: ROTTENBERG--Ira M. age 75 of Paramus, N.J. raised in Manhattan, on September 1, 2005 at his home with his family at his side. Survived by his loving wife of 49 years, Enid (nee Bergel) of Providence, R.I., his children and their spouses, Mark and Elise Rottenberg, Hank and Ilene Rottenberg, and Beth and Scott Rappoport, his brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Barbara Rottenberg, and seven adored grandchildren, Jason, Haley, Rachel, Matthew, Jackie, David and Jared, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant H.S. and Lowell (Mass) Textile Institute, a Lieutenant in the U.S. Coast Guard, who served in the Korean War, was a Past Commander of Post 669 of the Jewish War Veterans, was a longtime devoted member of the Jewish Community Center of Paramus and spent his life working in the textile industry.

title: Europe's response: An odd mixture
REMAINS SILENT
Corrections
description: An article on July 28 about efforts to preserve Namibia's endangered cheetah population referred incorrectly to the role of Tristan Boehme. He is a shareholder in Okonjima, a lodge that donates a share of its proceeds to AfriCat, a nonprofit foundation dedicated to preserving Africa's large cats, not a shareholder in AfriCat itself.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the way the Kurds had secured most of what they wanted in the new Iraqi constitution misstated the number of Kurds killed in the 1980's by Saddam Hussein and his forces. It was hundreds of thousands, not hundreds.

title: Federal Aid Is Offered to Schools
description: Education Secretary Margaret Spellings telephoned the Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama state school superintendents and other top Gulf Coast educators yesterday, offering broad federal assistance to stricken schools and universities.

title: In the Land of Asphalt, Spiking on the River
description: The late-August stop on what has become a grueling year-round professional tour is the Legends of Poker at the Bicycle Casino in Bell Gardens, about 11 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. (Many readers may not know that poker is legal in California.) With a million-dollar event being offered almost every week somewhere in Europe, the Caribbean, the United States or Australia, tournament specialists (and the high-stakes cash players who follow the tour like oversize, ravenous pilot fish) have to make tricky decisions about where to fly next. Last week the choice was quite clear.

title: Corrections
description: A listing yesterday of groups collecting donations for hurricane victims misstated the phone number for United Jewish Communities. It is (877) 277-2477.

title: African Insurer Offers to Buy Skandia
description: LONDON, Sept. 2 - Old Mutual, the largest insurer in Africa, has offered to buy Skandia for 44.9 billion kronor ($6.1 billion) to enter Scandinavia and increase sales in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALTER, HARRIET R.
description: PALTER--Harriet R. Passed on September 1, at age 80, after a courageous four-and-ahalf year battle with lung cancer. She is survived by her husband Buddy, after a beautiful life together of 59 years and seven months, and her two sons, Scott and Steven, also her brother and sister-inlaw, Marvin and Faye Rubin. Services private, family only.

title: French Police Evict 140 Africans Squatting in Unsafe Buildings
description: PARIS, Sept. 2 - In dawn raids that marked the beginning of a wider sweep of buildings regarded as unsafe, the police on Friday evicted 140 West Africans who had been squatting in two run-down buildings in poor sections of Paris.

title: Across U.S., Outrage at Response
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - There was anger: David Vitter, Louisiana's freshman Republican senator, gave the federal government an F on Friday for its handling of the whirlwind after the storm. And Representative Elijah E. Cummings, Democrat of Maryland and the former chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, declared, "We cannot allow it to be said that the difference between those who lived and those who died" amounted to "nothing more than poverty, age or skin color."

title: Amid Inquiry, City Puts Hold on Contract for Arts Group
description: City officials said yesterday that they would not complete a $216,000 contract with a students' performing arts training group founded by Lenora B. Fulani, an official of the Independence Party, as long as the state is investigating the group over allegations of financial improprieties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORCELAIN, HARRIET BAUM
description: PORCELAIN--Harriet Baum. On September 2, 2005. Wife of Cecil (Cy) Porcelain. Mother of Glenn (Barbie) Porcelain, Tina (James) Greene, Lois (Dan Reed) Porcelain. Grandmother of Tani (Yoel), Michael A., Alex M., David A., Jonathan E., Andrea and Rachel. Sister of Lawrence (Harriet), Reuben (Sandy), Monroe and Ronald (Rita) Baum. Graveside services will be held on Sunday, September 4 at 2:30 PM at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions to: Yeshivat Lev Ha Torah, 16-01 Morlot Avenue, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410. Shiva will be observed at 2909 Fallstaff Road, Apt 38, Baltimore, MD (21209) and 44 Remsen Road, Great Neck, NY (11024). Information: Sol Levinson & Brothers, Inc.

title: Grim Triage for Ailing and Dying at a Makeshift Airport Hospital
description: KENNER, La., Sept. 2 - Some were being given water by soldiers. Some had small spasms as they lay on their stretchers. Some psychiatric patients chewed their lower lips or babbled quietly. Some tried to wander out the doors where buses dropped off more patients. Some were dying; one corpse in a wheelchair, not far from the Delta counter, lay covered by a blue blanket.

title: In Chicago, Honoring Athletes of Improv
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2 - It seemed like a bad joke.

title: An Economy Raised on Pork
description: Cambridge, Mass. - THE old work-force compact is in shreds. Paychecks that rose with productivity gains through the middle decades of the 20th century no longer do so. Since the early 1970's, national product per person has grown more than 75 percent, but the median wage of male workers has risen barely two cents, adjusted for inflation, from $15.24 in 1973 to just $15.26 last year. Family incomes are up only because wives have gone into paid work and everyone's putting in more hours. Job loss often means loss of health insurance and a tax-advantaged pension.

title: Finally, a Wi-Fi camera  but wait
Characters Who Cavort in and Out of the Anime and Human Worlds
description: Animating anime might seem a redundant proposition: anime is already the animated-film version of Japanese manga comics. But the choreographer and dancer Kiyoko Kashiwagi, Japan-born and New York-based, has taken the animation process one step further in her Anime Dance Theater, currently ensconced for a two-weekend run at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens.

title: The Times's Editorial Board Endorses Ferrer for Primary
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Democrat who is making his third run for mayor, has received the endorsement of The New York Times editorial page today in the four-way Democratic primary race that ends on Sept. 13.

description: Nell I. Mondy, a Cornell biochemist who extolled the nutritional benefits of the potato to consumers worldwide and pushed hard to dispel its reputation as a weighty clump of empty calories, died on Aug. 25 at Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, N.Y. She was 83.

She will partner world champion Sabine Auken for one session in a forthcoming tournament. The male prizewinner was Thomas Bessis, who played for cole Polytechnique of Paris, which finished second, behind Lodz University of Poland.

title: Two Black Coaches Are the Face of Mostly White Washington
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 28 - Television viewers in the Seattle area have been shown a series of appealing commercials this summer featuring the University of Washington's two most prominent athletic figures -- Tyrone Willingham, the football coach, and Lorenzo Romar, the men's basketball coach. The lighthearted 30-second spots are intended to pump up ticket sales for the football season that begins Saturday. Intrinsically, they provide a bigger message.

title: Ethnic and Religious Tension on the Thailand-Malaysia Border
description: BANGKOK, Sept. 2 - Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said Friday that a group of Thai Muslims who crossed into Malaysia complaining that their safety was threatened by Thai security forces included "separatist militants" trying to spread the bloody insurgency in Thailand's southern provinces.

description: Boeing halted production yesterday as 18,000 machinists went on strike, dealing a setback to the company just as worldwide orders had begun to pick up and it was gaining ground against Airbus.

description: TO the traditional three R's -- readin', 'riting and 'rithmetic -- you can now add a fourth, at least at some of the nation's universities: riches.

Francis, who said doctors were pulled in so many directions that delays were often unavoidable. He is director of the Office of Health Disparities at the New York Academy of Medicine; his term as president of the American College of Physicians ended in April.

title: The Desperate Cry Out for Loved Ones Still Lost
description: BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 2 - Amber Wyrick sat alone in a temporary office set up by the Harrison County coroner, wiping at tears. Five days after the storm, she had yet to hear word about her 1-year-old son, Danny, who was with his father when Hurricane Katrina hit. His house was gone.

title: British Muslims disown Qaeda tape on bombing
Misery in New Orleans: The Anguish of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Indictments and Statistics All Overwhelmed by Tragedy Down South
description: WITH each passing day -- sometimes, it seemed, each hour -- the news grew worse. After Hurricane Katrina missed a head-on collision with New Orleans, there was hope that the storm's 175 m.p.h. winds might not have had a chance to do as much damage as feared. But then came reports of breached levees, beached oil rigs, widespread flooding -- and, perversely, fires. Estimated death tolls rose from dozens to hundreds; Mayor Ray Nagin said perhaps 1,000 people or more had perished in New Orleans alone, even before the looting and gunplay erupted.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Trial For Omagh Suspect
description: A Belfast magistrate ruled that a 36-year-old electrician would be the first person to stand trial on murder charges in the 1998 car-bomb attack in Omagh that killed 29 people and wounded hundreds. Prosecutors said evidence would show that the man, Sean Hoey, was involved in making explosives used by the Real I.R.A., an Irish Republican Army splinter group. Victims and their families have criticized the slow pace and frequent missteps of the police investigations into the bombing. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) SHARK TALE -- (2004). You know the filmmakers are going for the grown-ups in the audience when a fish that looks like Martin Scorsese turns up. In this animated undersea comedy, Oscar, an ordinary-guy fish (the voice of Will Smith), lets his friends believe that he saved himself from a shark attack, when in fact the attacker just happened to kill himself by colliding with an anchor. The shark is survived by his mob-boss father (Robert De Niro) and a misfit vegetarian brother (Jack Black), shown above with Oscar on his back. Mr. Smith's character has two love interests (Rene Zellweger and Angelina Jolie).

title: Tennessee and the Sick
description: To the Editor:

title: Thanks to Guards, Iraq Oil Pipeline Is Up and Running, On and Off
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 2 - Saboteurs shut down Iraqi crude oil exports to Turkey for virtually all of the past year, but the oil is flowing again after Iraq's government put in place elaborate new security measures and decided to move its product in what is essentially a clandestine operation.

title: Brussels to lend China funds for airport work
In New Jersey Governor's Race, Personal Finances Are Shaping the Debate
description: TRENTON, Sept. 2 - Given the many burdens and growing expenses of daily life in New Jersey, this year's race for governor was expected to focus on concrete issues like suburban sprawl, the spiraling cost of health care and the state's property taxes.

title: Personal Business; Paper or Online? Many Bank Customers Still Pick the Old Way
description: Even though Kathy Posner lives atop a mall on Chicago's Magnificent Mile shopping boulevard, she can count the number of times she has visited a retail store this summer on one hand.

title: Connecticut Librarians See Lack of Oversight as Biggest Danger in Antiterror Law
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 2 - Despite their concerns about the privacy of their patrons, librarians in Connecticut say they have turned over information sought by law enforcement authorities -- but usually when investigators are able to produce ample legal documentation obtained with a judge's consent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: SILVERSTEIN--Joseph. Died August 29 at the age of 93 in Jupiter, Florida. He was one of Wall Street's greatest arbitrageurs, most prominently with Ladenburg, Thallman & Co. Joe and his previously deceased wife, Bea, formerly lived in Harrison, NY and in Palm Beach, Florida. He was a loving husband, father, nephew, cousin and friend. A great golfer and a fine person. He is survived by his only son, Mark, of Lee, New Hampshire and numerous cousins, and will be remembered for a long and good life. May he rest in peace. The Leet and Hamburg Families

title: Off the charts: Across U.S., shrinking paychecks
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It really makes us look very much like Bangladesh or Baghdad. I'm 84 years old. I've been around a long time, but I've never seen anything like this."

title: How democratic is the new left?
A Quest for Carpets Reveals the Persian Past and the Soul
description: ATHENS, Sept. 1 - Brian Murphy propped his big black glasses up on his forehead, his eyes a few inches from one of the first carpets he ever bought. Rosaki the cat had left a fine coat of white fur on the rug, a Turkoman that was otherwise a rusty red. But Mr. Murphy focused on a little scar of stitching a few shades off the original.

title: In First Response to Crisis, Bush Strikes Off-Key Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - From the moment he walked out of the Oval Office toward his helicopter on Friday morning until he left New Orleans at the end of the day, President Bush's task was to erase the hardening impression that his administration had failed to act with sufficient urgency to address the suffering of tens of thousands of people.

title: In Contrast to Rival, Clinton Has Her Man Stand by Her
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 2 - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton brought her husband along to the New York State Fair on Friday, drawing a sharp contrast with her likeliest Republican rival in next year's Senate race, who has mostly kept her scandal-plagued husband out of public view since announcing her candidacy.

title: Military Dealt With Combination of Obstacles Before Reaching Victims
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - As thousands of National Guard soldiers entered New Orleans on Friday to help restore order and deliver emergency supplies, Pentagon and Guard officials said the military's response had been slowed by a combination of physical obstacles created by the storm compounded by a cumbersome bureaucratic process for sending federal forces to assist in natural disasters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKIN, MYRA
description: BARKIN--Myra. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Sr. Rabbi Jerome Seiler, MD, President

title: Israel to Freeze Growth of West Bank Settlement, Official Says
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 3 - Israel has bowed to the United States and frozen a much-criticized plan to add 3,500 housing units near a large West Bank settlement, Maale Adumim, according to Ehud Olmert, Israel's deputy prime minister and a close ally of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Victory Over Harsh Press Law
description: A court handed a rare victory to journalists in a long-running legal battle with the government, acquitting a reporter for the banned newspaper The Daily News of charges that he had worked without a license required by the Media and Information Commission. The Daily News, once Zimbabwe's most popular paper and a frequent government critic, was shut down in 2003 in part because the government said its journalists lacked proper licensing. The acquitted reporter, Kevin Jakachira, argued that he had applied for a license but never received a response. The judge said that the state's evidence against him was "confused and unreliable." As many as 45 journalists could have faced similar charges had he been convicted, Mr. Jakachira said. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Other Views: The Age, Asahi Shimbun, Chicago Tribune
Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the dateline of a letter yesterday by Sandra Miller, about vulnerable people in New Orleans, misstated her home state. It is Arkansas, not Arizona.

title: Bank of Japan deputy upbeat on end of deflation
Newcomer Is Struggling to Lead a City in Ruins
description: He has been camped out for days on the 27th floor of a structurally damaged and powerless hotel in New Orleans, sending runners to communicate with the few staff members who remain in an increasingly futile effort to run some semblance of a municipal government.

title: Kite Hill
Before Hurricane Katrina
description: The flood on the Mississippi River in 1927 and other events eerily foreshadowed today's devastation in New Orleans.

title: Tanzania at 15 M.P.H.
description: THE sun is sinking, the air is cooling and our legs are pumping up and down, powering us toward a horizon unbroken by a cellphone tower, a house or even a fence. I'm looking over the bicycle's handlebars at the veld unfurling in front of me - the baobab trees in bloom, the hawks circling, a miniskyline of anthills rising in the distance, thinking that 15 miles per hour is about the perfect pace to soak this all up.

title: Through Andalusia, in Search of Gazpacho
description: SPAIN is a matrix of themed routes - rutas as they are known in Spanish - carefully mapped out for those looking to follow a lead. There is the Catholic pilgrimage route of Santiago de Compostela, the Ruta del Quijote, trailing Cervantes's beloved character from windmill to windmill in La Mancha, and, in season, there is even a Strawberry Train.

title: A Woman Scorned, Then Empowered
description: Keyshia Cole

title: Water Buffalo? Swamps? This Is Japan?
description: SAY Okinawa, and the word conjures up one of the last major battles of World War II and the enduring presence of American troops in Japan. But Okinawa is so much more: a chain of hundreds of islands stretching some 600 miles southwest of mainland Japan into the East China Sea (also called the Ryuku Islands), home to a distinctive subtropical culture and nature that few foreigners - and not many Japanese for that matter - have ever seen.

title: Nice
description: WHY GO NOW Sun-baked Mediterranean coastline and palm-planted boulevards notwithstanding, Nice, the fifth-largest city in France, has had a somewhat iffy reputation of late, thanks to an elevated crime rate, political corruption and a mayor formerly aligned with the far-right National Front party. There was, for many, the sense that the best days of Henri Matisse's former home were far behind it. Key attractions like the century-old Russian Orthodox Cathdrale de St. Nicolas (1) and the two-century-old oceanfront boardwalk, the English-built Promenade des Anglais, nostalgically recalled the bygone time when Czarist aristocrats and British royals wintered in the area. The city's most glorious Jazz Age hotel, the Palais de la Mditerrane, (2) sat desolate and abandoned along the seaside.

title: Giving Them What They Want
description: After three decades in the TV business, Leslie Moonves, the chairman of CBS and the person most responsible for taking the network from last place to first in the ratings, has figured out a few things about what people want to see when they turn on their televisions. ''Americans do not like dark,'' Moonves told me last May, before a scheduling meeting to select CBS's fall 2005 lineup. Moonves, who was wearing a gray suit, white shirt and diagonally striped maroon and navy tie, was in a wood-paneled corner office on the 35th floor of Black Rock, the longtime home of CBS on 52nd Street in Manhattan. The office used to belong to William S. Paley, the legendary tycoon who personified CBS for more than 60 years. Truman Capote once remarked that Paley ''looks like a man who has just swallowed an entire human being,'' and Moonves has that same sort of aggressive vigor -- an almost palpable appetite and enthusiasm for the complications and constant challenges of network TV.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about film piracy included incorrect revenue data supplied by the Motion Picture Association of America. Hollywood's global revenue in 2004 was $44.8 billion, not $84 billion. Of the total, $21 billion, not $55.6 billion, came from sales of DVD's and videos.

title: Paper in Every Guise Imaginable
description: 'Paperworks'

title: Two Robbery Suspects Escape From Police Station in Midtown
description: A man and a woman arrested in connection with a robbery yesterday morning escaped from a Midtown Manhattan police station hours later and were still at large last night, the Police Department said.

title: 'Matisse the Master'
The Rolling Stones Get What They Need
description: SOMETIMES clichs are underrated. The Rolling Stones embrace them wholeheartedly on "A Bigger Bang" (Virgin), their first album of new songs since 1997, and they're better off for it.

title: The Naked and the Dead
description: When the performance artists Delia Bajo and Brainard Carey fell in love in 1999, they say, they gave up everything to explore their newfound happiness. "It was a little irresponsible," Ms. Bajo said recently, sipping tea in a pastry shop near P.S. 122 on the Lower East Side. "We stayed in bed all day, rejoicing in the sensuality of life. It was euphoric." Ms. Bajo, 32, who had studied ballet, and Mr. Carey, 38, a former gallery owner, soon began sharing their feelings with others in interactive, multidisciplinary projects, presented under the name Praxis, at places like the Whitney Biennial and the Dublin Fringe Festival. In neo-"happenings," they offered audience members and passersby hugs, foot washings, prayers and, on one occasion, marijuana; that event also featured a John-and-Yoko-like couple frolicking naked on a bed.

title: A Reunion at the Corner, On Peter Falk Place
description: IT was a slick event calculated to generate publicity for a new Hollywood movie, but when the old-time Ossining crowd came out to mingle with Peter Falk, their famous former neighbor, the occasion turned into a sweet trip down the village's Memory Lane.

title: At a Big-Easy Outpost, a Somber Soundtrack
description: THE fried green tomatoes, crowned with shrimp remoulade, were as divine as ever. Bowls of succulent andouille gumbo were set steaming on tables.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: This is the slow moment in the world of classical performance: the festivals have all packed up, and the main concert season for the most part has not yet gotten under way. There are, of course, a few organizations that see an opportunity here, not least among them the NEW YORK CITY OPERA, which is beating all the other major organizations to the punch -- and giving itself a few weeks virtually clear of competition -- by opening its season on Wednesday.

title: When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: Shakespeare Doubters
description: To the Editor:

title: At Campaign Headquarters, Glitter and a Salsa Beat
description: Nothing about Ruben Gonzalez's block of East 108th Street near Third Avenue suggests a run for City Hall. The street, which is peppered with vacant lots and abandoned buildings, and punctuated by a fire hydrant spouting graceful arcs of water, ends, eloquently, at Poor Richard's Playground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, GLEN G.
description: ALTMAN--Glen G., age 74, died in New York on September 1, 2005. Loving and devoted wife, mother and grandmother, she is survived by daughter Tracy altman Warner, son-in-law Greg Warner, grand - daughters Haley, Amanda and Brooke Warner, step-daughters Virginia Aaron and Patricia Falkenberg and much loved dogs Max and Minu. Glen lived in New York for over 50 years and was married to Edwin J. Altman for 40 of those years. She missed him desperately following his passing in June 2003. Glen will be well remembered as beautiful, elegant, wise, generous and strong of will. Glen held a Masters in English Literature and loved poetry, classics and philosophy. She taught as a professor of English Lit for some time and subsequently ran a family jewelry business, M.B. Altman Sons. She will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. "Be Thou my vision, O Lord of my Heart; Nought all else to me, save that Thou art-Thou my best thought, by day or by night, Waking or sleeping, Thy presence my Light." Hymn 339. Funeral services on Wednesday, September 7th at 1 p.m. at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue between 91st and 92nd Streets. Viewing will precede at 12:30 p.m. in the chapel. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to The Central Park Conservancy 'Adopt-A-Bench' program, in memory of Glen Altman, 14 East 60th St., New York, NY 10022.

title: When Carpenter Ants Take Up Residence
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, carpenter ants will not eat your house. They might, however, move some of it out of their way.

title: Alison Mathis and Robert Wollin
description: Alison Leigh Mathis, the daughter of Marylin Mathis and Mark J. Mathis of Bethesda, Md., was married last evening to Robert Jason Wollin, the son of Joan Wollin of Fort Lee, N.J., and Lonnie E. Wollin of Secaucus, N.J. Rabbi Susan Shankman officiated at the Willard hotel in Washington.

title: All Her Life Has Been A Mystery
description: ALAFAIR BURKE's interest in crime dates to her move to Wichita, Kan., at the age of 8. Her family and the B.T.K. serial killer arrived in Wichita about the same time. "People were talking about it and talking about it a lot," said Ms. Burke, whose third mystery novel, "Close Case," was published by Henry Holt in July.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: IN THE PROVINCE OF SAINTS. By Thomas O'Malley. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) If the neighboring farmer's hired man "had touched a drop at all," the teenage hero of "In the Province of Saints" recalls, "he'd be singing -- some familiar Irish song about rebels or emigration and the never never of coming back; songs about the loss of land, the loss of love, but most of all, songs about . . . longing for Ireland." O'Malley's beautifully written first novel also sings many of those songs. Set in rural southeastern Ireland in the late 1970's, it tells the coming-of-age story of Michael McDonagh. Michael roams the fields and rivers when he is not caring for his mother, who is ill with cancer, while his father leaves for Boston to find work and then drinks up his earnings. There is much talk of rain, and ghosts, and the smell of dung, and the reader feels the claustrophobia and hopelessness that coexist with the wild beauty of the land. As Michael grows up, he comes to terms with his family's secrets, both personal and political. In the end we know that he, too, will leave Ireland for good. A familiar Irish song, but the words will break your heart.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ASHER, NORMA HAYIM
description: ASHER--Norma Hayim. 81, of NYC and Boca Raton, FL. Born Norma Keats and married 48 years to the late Alvin Hayim. Graduated University of Pennsylvania. Survived by her husband of eight years, Leonard Asher of Short Hills, NJ, her brother, Ira Keats of Yardley, PA, three children Stuart Hayim of Great Neck, Scott Hayim of St. Louis and Nancy Sagon of Amherst, NH, and 10 grandchildren. Norma had life time involvement in various charitable causes and was a patron and past board member of the Boca Raton Museum of Art.

title: Syria Kills Militants
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Sept. 3 - Syrian security forces killed five militants late Friday in clashes in the turbulent town of Hama, the official Syrian news agency Sana reported Saturday.

title: DataBank; In a Wrenching Week, the Markets Held Strong
description: Investors bid up the shares of companies that stand to benefit from Hurricane Katrina, with oil, construction, and engineering stocks helping to lead the three major stock market indexes higher for the week.

title: Lower Prices? Check
description: To the Editor:

title: An Excruciating Excess of Reality
description: DURING a scene in the fifth episode of VH1's new reality series "Breaking Bonaduce," Danny Bonaduce, the former child star from "The Partridge Family," is playing with his 10-year-old daughter, Isabella. "Daddy, what happened to your wrists?" she asks, looking at bandages he is wearing. As she swings in and out of the frame, Mr. Bonaduce lies to her. "Oh, it's nothing," he says with a slight grimace. "Daddy's just not a very handy guy when it comes to installing windows."

title: 'The Sugar Mile': Poet at the Bar
description: THE SUGAR MILE By Glyn Maxwell. 140 pp. Houghton Mifflin Company. $23.

title: A City Beyond the Reach of Empathy
description: EAST BOOTHBAY, ME. - WHO can write about New Orleans now? Tell us what it's like there. Bring us near to what people are experiencing, to their loss, to what will survive. People who are close should write that. Only they're in the city, or they're on a bus, or they're seeking shelter. We don't know where they are.

title: Jacqueline Flug and David Kronenberg
description: Jacqueline Paige Flug, a daughter of Justice Phyllis Orlikoff Flug and Dr. Arthur Flug of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married last evening to David Ian Kronenberg, a son of Norma and Irving Kronenberg of Stockbridge, Mass. Rabbi Richard A. Marker officiated at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: With Poetry and Power, Henin-Hardenne Overwhelms
description: Justine Henin-Hardenne has an awesome array of shots, blending power, cunning and grace as well as anybody not named Roger Federer. Her game flows like haiku, so it should not be a surprise that in the manner of lyrical poets everywhere, she sometimes struggles to create a facile result.

title: More Bad News
description: To the Editor:

title: Father and Son, 5, Share a Journey and a Memory
description: WHENEVER I told someone I was taking my 5-year-old son, Dean, on the overnight train to Chicago, I heard the same words in response: "He'll remember it for the rest of his life."

title: Marking 9/11, Coast to Coast in Myriad Ways
description: Four years after terrorist attacks destroyed the World Trade Center and killed nearly 3,000 people, Sept. 11, has come to represent different things to different people. Around the country, towns and cities have planned events to mark the occasion not only with solemnity but also with life-affirming celebrations, including concerts, motorcycle rides and fitness runs.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about The Encyclopedia of New England, which will be published Sept. 28, misstated the number of New England states besides Connecticut. There are five, not four.

title: Caroline Nolan and Jonathan Carpenter
description: Caroline Susan Nolan and Jonathan James Carpenter were married yesterday evening at St. Michael's Church in Upton Warren, England. The Rev. Roger Antell, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Attacks Kill 19 Iraqi Soldiers and Policemen
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 3 - Insurgents staged a series of attacks on Iraqi police and army patrols and checkpoints north of Baghdad on Saturday, killing 19 people and wounding at least six in some of the worst guerrilla violence the country has seen in weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: First Rival Campaigning For Leader Ends in Egypt Egypt's first multicandidate campaign for the presidency ends today, the first in which opposition forces could publicly challenge the ruling party's monopoly on power. There was never any real prospect of ousting President Hosni Mubarak. But the 19-day campaign season was an end in itself. PAGE 14

title: The Vanished Paintings and the Tortured Quest
description: Yvonne Limn is an artist whose dramatic, mostly abstract paintings are often inspired by Xochimilco, Mexico, her hometown. Her work was exhibited last November at Casa del Sol, the South Bronx community center, and she left 20 of her pieces there during a visit home last fall, assuming they would be safe.

title: William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice of Supreme Court, Is Dead at 80
description: William H. Rehnquist, who died Saturday at the age of 80 almost a year after learning he had thyroid cancer, helped lead a conservative revolution on the Supreme Court during 19 notably successful years as chief justice of the United States.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SECRET LIFE OF THE LONELY DOLL: The Search for Dare Wright, by Jean Nathan. (Picador, $15.) A children's book called "The Lonely Doll," published in 1957, engendered a vast cult following. Its author, Dare Wright (1914-2001), not only styled her heroine, a blond doll named Edith, after herself, but also illustrated the book and its sequels with melancholy black-and-white photographs. In this biography, Nathan explores the disparity between Wright's glamorous facade and her turbulent interior: a miserable woman, Wright was locked in a suffocating relationship with her mother. Our reviewer, M. G. Lord, called Nathan's book "exhaustively reported" and "gracefully written."

title: Toll Is Also Exacted on Gulf Region's Historical and Cultural Treasures
description: The hurricane and the flood that followed took their toll on the cultural riches of New Orleans and the cities in its orbit.

title: Girl-Watching, Tanning and (of Course) Lifesaving
description: WHITE PLAINS - THERE are a few things Kyle Belluscio counts as perks in his job as a lifeguard at Saxon Woods Pool.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FOSTER, COL. RAFE ROBERT
description: FOSTER--Col. Rafe Robert. Our brilliant sweet and beautiful boy, forever. We love you always. Your loving family

title: Literary Letters, Lost in Cyberspace
description: Back in the 20th century, when publishers had three-martini lunches and young women fresh out of Bryn Mawr became secretaries, not editors, it was often lamented that the telephone might put an end to literary biography. In lieu of letters, writers could just as easily gab on the phone, leaving no trace.

title: Atop Kite Hill
description: IT'S early evening in Prospect Park, and three men from Barbados are relaxing on Kite Hill. Officially there's no such hill in the park, but regulars know the place, a hillock in the Long Meadow where on weekday evenings and weekends men from the neighborhood fly homemade kites.

title: $100 And Under: Fall's Best
description: This fall luxury has hit new heights, with clothing and accessories toting price tags of epic weight. Nonetheless, smart shoppers can still unearth treasures of substance -- a bright October-weight pea jacket at a lottery-low price, a luscious cashmere cardigan with crystal buttons, even a pleasingly heavy 22-karat gold pendant on a leather necklace -- all for less than $100. Here are 10 of the season's best buys that still have the power to surprise.

title: Rescuer in Mirror Is Closer Than He Appears
description: TARRYTOWN - THERE is no breakdown lane on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Depending which way you're going and what time it is, there are three, or four, lanes of traffic moving at 60 to 70 miles an hour. Just beyond them and a four-foot-high railing, there is the Hudson River, 157 feet straight down.

title: 'He's Being a Bully,' Little Wal-Mart Cries
description: Wal-Mart makes no apologies about dominating the American retail landscape and resists fiercely whenever anyone tries to put pesky things like zoning or labor laws in the way of its expansion.

title: An Olfactory Education
description: I GREW up on a farm in Castelsarrazin, a village of 300 in the southwest of France. One of my earliest memories is waking up and smelling whatever my grandmother was cooking.

title: When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: STEALING GOD'S THUNDER: Benjamin Franklin's Lightning Rod and the Invention of America. By Philip Dray. (Random House, $25.95.) In the 1740's, electricity was as much a parlor trick as an object of serious investigation; one scientist liked to hang an orphan from the ceiling with silk and invite ladies to draw sparks from his nose with a charged glass tube. Through experiments slightly less baroque, Franklin became convinced electricity was a fluid that could have either a positive or negative balance, like a checking account. He refined devices for storing electrical charges, which he named "batteries" for their resemblance to rows of guns, and in 1750 he designed an experiment to show that lightning was a form of electricity. He designed another two years later, which involved flying a kite. But maybe you've heard of the kite. Having noticed that lightning preferred to run through metal, Franklin put up the world's first lightning rods that summer, and Dray tells how the rod slowly displaced an earlier, ineffectual means of protection, the ringing of church bells during thunderstorms. Dray offers no startling discoveries or bold reinterpretations, but his prose is elegant, Franklin is charming and the science is easy: Do lightning rods attract extra lightning? Should they be pointed or blunt? Do they cause earthquakes? Franklin's curiosity about smallpox, botany, wood-burning stoves, musical glass disks, mesmerism, fossils and ballooning make cameo appearances.

title: Tamara York and David Lowin
description: IF love at first sight is like a lightning bolt, then the courtship of Tamara York and David Lowin, who married last Sunday in Teaneck, N.J., was more like the slow rumble of distant thunder. Their journey to marriage lasted nine years, survived two breakups and spanned three cities.

title: French Quarter Becomes Oasis of Wary Calm
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 - Marty Montgomery stood on his second-floor balcony on Friday night, playing blues on his harmonica into empty French Quarter streets that have never seemed so dark, so desolate -- or so threatening.

title: When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: The Breaking Point
description: Another consequence of reaching "peak oil" is the debate it will surely provoke in the United States over whether we should avert the coming crisis by drilling in pristine lands and waters long considered off limits or by engaging in conservation and development of alternative fuel sources. Oil companies will argue that we have to save jobs and save the economy by squeezing those last drops from every forest and coastline. Environmentalists will have to go beyond aesthetic or ecological arguments and prove that job creation and economic growth come during times of great technological innovation.

title: Boss to Workers: A Dollar for You, and $431 for Me
description: Ben Cohen's dusty vow that no Ben & Jerry's executive would make more than seven times the lowliest worker's wage seems a surreal joke now. Across corporate America today, bosses might be more likely to intone magnanimously, "I will never earn more than 400 times as much."

title: Small Stifles the Athletics in Stunning Fashion
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 3 - The Yankees are not designed for players like Aaron Small. In the world of the principal owner George Steinbrenner, Yankees players have lavish contracts, proven track records and supreme confidence. If a player like Small gets a chance, something must be wrong.

title: Pilot Killed in Crash Is Identified
description: The pilot of a single-engine Cessna who was killed when the plane crashed Friday night near Teterboro Airport in South Hackensack, N.J., has been identified by the police.

title: Here Comes Miss America, and Why Not to Staten Island?
description: As Miss America sashays her way out of Atlantic City this year, pageant aficionados around the country are agog with discussion of which city might serve as host of the contest after 84 years on the Jersey Shore. Thoughts on the pageant's official online bulletin board turned to Las Vegas, Orlando and Nashville (just "a short drive to Chattanooga to see one of the best aquariums in the nation").

title: A Primary in Greenburgh
description: Is Paul Feiner your guy, or isn't he?

title: Braced Once More for a Last Picture Show
description: As the red curtain closes and the lights go up on the 2 p.m. showing of the low-budget dramedy "King of the Corner," the lean, bespectacled figure of Peter Elson is revealed, sitting in the front row. The audience members, all four of them, shuffle toward the exits, unaware that they are passing the man who is trying to keep the New Metro Twin alive.

title: Final evacuation of New Orleans completed
Chief Justice Rehnquist Dies at 80
description: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Sept. 4 - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist died Saturday night of the thyroid cancer he had battled for nearly a year, opening a second Supreme Court vacancy just days before Senate confirmation hearings were to begin to fill the seat being vacated by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.

title: Field Guide to Judging a Show by Its Title
description: THIS time of year, the titles of oncoming art exhibitions blare from magazine covers and museum posters, amplified by megawatt names, weighty epochal allusions, clever colloquialisms or restrained, status-reeking factuality. (Can you say "2006 Whitney Biennial"?)

title: Curry Hill: Indian Summer
description: The last days of summer are a good time to add warmth to the diet, Indian style. These restaurants are in the neighborhood known as Curry Hill, which radiates out from Lexington Avenue and 28th Street.

title: The Breaking Point
description: Peter Maass (Aug. 21) uses the Saudi Arabian oil situation to highlight the entrenched interests, secrecy, unpredictability and vulnerability of the system that feeds our oil addiction. Maybe we should use $60 and $70 fill-ups at the pump as personal wake-up calls to start doing what Congress and the executive branch seem incapable of doing: reducing consumption through improved efficiency and conservation efforts. Along the way, we would apparently reduce the profits available to finance terrorism and repression. That seems like a good bargain.

title: As Rates Climb, the Short-Term C.D. Is Standing Taller
description: ATTENTION, prudent savers. You can now risk a peek at your financial statements.

title: The Boys of Summer
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. - IN 1970, the summer I was 13, aliens arrived on my street. They came in VW Bugs of every color -- yellow, white, blue, lime-green. They came unshaven, with long hair and torn jeans. They were against the war. They listened to FM radio. They were mysterious, full of secrets and private jokes. They smelled strange, like sweat and smoke and clothes that needed washing.

title: On the Gulf Coast, Only Remnants
description: There were stoops without homes, bridges without roads, family photos without families. As people across the Gulf Coast searched the debris for what remained of their towns and their possessions, they found nothing whole, only pieces.

title: Early Pangs of Empty Nest Syndrome When the Children Leave Home for College
description: Since Sarah Ripp began pining over the prospect that her daughter, Emily, was going away to college, her husband has taken to calling her "the weeping willow."

title: Hoping to Buttress Sharon, U.S. Urges Allies' Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - The Bush administration, hoping to strengthen Prime Minister Ariel Sharon in the Israeli turmoil after the Gaza withdrawal, is urging allies of the United States to refrain from pressing Israel to make new concessions to Palestinians, senior American officials said this week.

title: Karen Raksis and Rob Grader
description: Dr. Karen Rachel Raksis and Rob Grader are to be married today at the de Seversky Center, a mansion on the campus of the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y. Curt Collier, the leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, is to officiate.

title: President Bush: 'He Honored America With a Lifetime of Service'
description: Our nation is saddened today by the news that Chief Justice William Rehnquist passed away last night.

title: Social Lubricant
description: Dove Body Nourishers Intensive Firming Lotion "Fat or Fabulous?" asked a line on the cover of a recent issue of People magazine, underneath a small photograph of some of the "Dove Girls." These are the young women appearing on billboards and other advertising on behalf of Dove Body Nourishers Intensive Firming Lotion and related products; they are not the ultrathin fashion-model types common to advertising, and they are dressed only in underwear. They have become a minor sensation, sparking opinion articles in major publications (including a New York Times editorial) and showing up as guests on the "Today" show. This is a rare thing and pretty clearly a publicity bonanza for the Dove brand.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Defining Himself by Dance

title: Auditions: The Do's, the Don'ts, the Sheer Terror
description: BETSY HEAD, an actress and a director, was on the A train in April 2004, traveling to yet another acting tryout, when she suddenly thought: "I want to direct another show just so I can watch people audition. I wonder if other people want to see auditions." She has her answer. "The Audition," which Ms. Head, 26, calls "reality theater," had a sold-out four-day run last fall; its second production starts Wednesday at the Wings Theater in the West Village.

title: Giants Settle on Quarterbacks, and Palmer Is Odd Man Out
description: Jesse Palmer, who parlayed his place as the Giants' backup quarterback into television stardom on "The Bachelor," was dumped by the Giants yesterday as the team trimmed its roster to 53 players.

title: The SAT Results Within the Results
description: As more New Jersey high school students take the SAT tests, the disparity in scores by race and income has become even more pointed.

title: The Week Ahead: Sept. 4 - Sept. 10
description: THEATER

title: Editors' Choice
Paid Notice: Memorials   WOODSIDE, LYNDON
description: WOODSIDE--Lyndon. Westchester Choral Society deeply misses our beloved leader/ teacher/friend of 38 years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WOLDAR, JEROME
description: WOLDAR--Jerome. The Jewish Chapel Fund of the United States Military Academy mourns the loss of our past Vice President, Major General USAF (Ret.) Jerome Woldar, a founding member and great benefactor of the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund. Jerry was always available for any assignment that would benefit the West Point cadets. We will miss his invaluable guidance, great sense of humor and positive leadership. Lt. Col. Andrew Lotwin, USA (Ret.) Vice President, West Point Jewish Chapel Fund

title: Connecticut Team Helping Storm Victims
description: The state has sent a team of emergency medical personnel, trained to respond to disasters, to the areas hit by Hurricane Katrina. A strike team arrived last Sunday at a staging site in Aniston, Ala., said Michael J. Purcaro, a spokesman for the 150-member Connecticut Disaster Medical Assistance Team, based at Brainard Airport in Hartford.

title: Zen Rock Garden
description: What you see here looks more like a lovely garden than a vehicle for the display of 10 stone sculptures by Isamu Noguchi, one of the 20th century's best-known artists. And that, paradoxically, is what makes the art look so good.

title: The Breaking Point
description: When Sadad al-Husseini says that we can't keep offsetting depletion (we need to add a Saudi Arabia every couple of years), why doesn't Peter Maass ask him why we can't? We have obviously been doing it throughout the history of the oil industry. And Maass mentions James Schlesinger as a respected figure (true) but doesn't point out that in 1979, Schlesinger said that world oil production had nearly peaked, that it was geologically impossible to expand it.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; ART
description: Labor Day, the annual nadir of the art season, is at least a chance to ponder the art we mostly speed by to get to the blockbuster shows when the year starts humming. The other day I turned left at the top of the steps in the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM, into the long hallway that usually funnels the tourists toward Impressionist paintings (it is temporarily shut at the end), and suddenly caught sight of a classic HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON photograph, his cubistic masterpiece shot from inside a bullring in Valencia, Spain, in 1933.

title: Updating the Subway
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, criticized for its sluggish response to the possibility of terrorist attacks, has now swung into high gear with plans for a security update of the subways and proposals for cellphone service at more than half of the city's subway platforms. In this insecure age, improvements like these make sense, assuming they work as advertised.

title: Vanessa Cho and Matthew Simmons
description: Vanessa Cho, a daughter of Suke Cho and Young Rin Cho of Kobe, Japan, is to be married today to Matthew Simmons, a son of Maryanne Ellison Simmons and Ted Simmons of Wildwood, Mo. The Rev. Thomas F. Dowling, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at the home of the bride's sister in Healdsburg, Calif.

title: With Blazing Speed and Flapping Jaws, Receivers Loom Large
description: Some of them have big egos, but they also make big plays. The wide-receiver position in today's N.F.L. is loaded with talented players, some with neon personalities and many with game-changing abilities.

title: Where the A B C's Are Subsidized by B-I-N-G-O
description: Msgr. John Servididio was dismayed to inform the parents at St. Joseph parochial school on Staten Island that tuition had to go up this year, by 11 percent, more than triple the rate of inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENFELD, MARILYN
description: ROSENFELD - Marilyn on September 1, 2005. Beloved wife of the late George, loving mother of Gale, and mother-in-law of Bruce Federman, adoring grandmother of Jordan and Sam, dear sister of Murray Grob. Service Sunday 12:45pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Judy Valente and Charles Reynard
description: Judy Valente and Charles Granville Reynard were married yesterday at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church in Chicago. The Rev. Dominic Grassi performed the ceremony.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; DANCE
description: There are ebbs and there are flows, and right now in New York dance we're still in the late-summer ebb. Looking up that dry desert gully, we can see signs of the onrushing torrent that will mean the start of the fall season. In the meantime, down south (but only 90 miles down south), there is the annual LIVE ARTS/PHILLY FRINGE festival (through Sept. 17), which brings an interesting clutch of dance attractions along with its offerings in other fields. It should amuse Philadelphians and any New Yorkers who feel like venturing there. Most of the performers are local, especially on the Fringe side, but there is a nice sprinkling of New York, national and international artists as well. Philadelphia Live Arts Festival/Philly Fringe, various days, times and theaters, (215)413-1318 or www.livearts-fringe.org.

title: Judge Ruth Levine Sussman Dies at 46; Led a Domestic Violence Court
description: Judge Ruth Levine Sussman, an acting New York State Supreme Court justice who organized and headed the state system's first Integrated Domestic Violence Court, in the Bronx, died on Aug. 26 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 46.

title: Violence in Haiti: Politics and Policies (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting the Creeps on a Treasured Island
description: MEGAN TAYLOR, a National Park Service ranger, saw something eerie last winter in Fort Jay, on Governors Island. In the grassy courtyard stand two weathered metal rocking horses -- remnants from the post-World War I era, when the star-shaped fort was home to Army and Coast Guard families -- and as Ms. Taylor watched, a bizarre thing happened.

title: Their Hearts and Minds?
description: With its bitter echoes of Vietnam, the expression "hearts and minds" is one that many Americans understandably use ironically rather than seriously. But if the last three years have demonstrated anything, it is that hearts and minds are essential to defeating the insurgencies that United States forces face in Iraq and, increasingly, again in Afghanistan. Whatever you think about the Iraq war, or the fight against Islamic terrorism more broadly, the move among American policymakers away from military solutions and toward political ones can only be a good thing.

title: Ironing Out the Wrinkles
description: Terrell Owens had been sent into his pump-up-the-volume exile. Another wide receiver had been lost for the season with a torn Achilles' tendon. One defensive lineman was holding out in a contract dispute. Another had been shot in the stomach during a robbery attempt. One running back had held out because he was unhappy with his contract. Another had such a bad knee that he would eventually have season-ending surgery.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: A Homegrown Musician

title: School of Indie Rock
description: The predawn gig at CBGB may still be a prerequisite, but aspiring rockers and established musicians now have a more academic avenue for mastering club and career strategy: Indie Night School, a series of panel talks on topics that include booking a show, finding a label and getting reviewed. It's sort of like getting an M.B.A. -- a master's of band administration.

title: Taliban Killed an Engineer Abducted in Afghanistan, Britain Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 3 - A British engineer who was abducted in Afghanistan three days ago has been killed by the Taliban, the British government said Saturday in a statement released in Kabul.

title: Machine Dreams
description: Matt Bai (Aug. 21) has prematurely written an obituary for political parties. Parties have survived since Martin Van Buren's time because they have evolved and adapted, and they will continue to do so.

title: Storm Will Have a Long-Term Emotional Effect on Some, Experts Say
description: Once the hard work of physical survival is complete, another kind of flood will begin, carrying with it remembered images of bloated bodies, rotting sewage and neighbors ragged with hunger, some turning desperate.

title: The Ghost in the Darkroom
description: IT is not a place you would normally expect to find a curator preparing for a major photography show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But a few summers ago, Pierre Apraxine was camped out on the third floor of a rambling town house on West 73rd Street near Central Park, the headquarters of the American Society for Psychical Research, a 120-year-old repository of the paranormal whose founders included the philosopher William James.

title: Havana via Woodbridge: Legal Cuban Cigars
description: RIDGEWOOD - THE group of men emerges every Thursday evening, stealing a few moments to head up to the second-floor balcony of the Tobacco Shop in Ridgewood. Once there, the several members of this close-knit smoking club that includes a chiropractor and a printing-company owner relax, some in leather wingback chairs, others leaning on the balcony railing. Their easy conversation and steady laughter are punctuated with short pauses to draw on Pinar cigars, made with imported Cuban tobacco. They savor the richness of a product that is typically considered contraband.

title: Want to Party With Stars? Pay Up
description: LOS ANGELES - AT 1:30 on a summer Sunday afternoon, high above Sunset Boulevard in the Hollywood Hills, an invitation-only pool party was just getting under way. On the patio guests drank Red Bull mimosas while others floated in the black-tiled pool or dipped their heads under artificial waterfalls. A few blond women in bikini tops and shorts sucked on Charms pops as they danced in Candies heels around a makeshift D.J. booth; Missy Elliott was in rotation.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article on Aug. 21 about maritime activity on the north shore of Staten Island incorrectly described the operations of the Moran and McAllister tugboat companies. They own fewer than half of the tugs based there, not most of them, and they are among the nation's major tug companies, but not the last two. The article also referred incorrectly to Caddell Dry Dock and Repair Company. It is not New York's last full-service shipyard. GMD Shipyard in the Brooklyn Navy Yard is also full-service.

title: Violence in Haiti: Politics and Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Terrace Plagued by Falling Objects
description: Q. I live in a co-op in Queens and have an apartment with a very large terrace. My problem is that since I have lived here (more than seven years), things have been falling onto my terrace. This is a 42-story building, and I am on the sixth floor. The other day someone dropped a full can of soda from one of the higher floors. and it hit like a hand grenade. What is the building's legal obligation to protect us? Matthew Schultz, Queens

title: Students' New Test Subject: Their Breath
description: IN West Islip, a few girls taped flasks of liquor to the inside of their legs, which were hidden under their prom dresses. In Rockville Centre, three students went to a 10 a.m. class with whiskey in Snapple bottles.

title: Where's the Party? In the Suite Filled With Blake's Fans
description: The James Blake cheering section, which spread to almost every corner of Arthur Ashe Stadium yesterday, started on the beer-soaked balcony of Suite 236.

title: Driving Is a Hard Bargain
description: As gasoline prices hit record highs, travelers who rent cars are feeling a double whammy as many rental car companies have also raised their prices, and the cost of renting a car this fall will remain higher than it was last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MOSES, ANITA
description: MOSES--Anita. Known to everyone as "Granny." Devoted wife to the late Bernard Moses; beloved mother to Susan Zises and Wynne Weinreb and Scott Beaton, stepmother to Eric Moses and Robert Moses. Fun-loving grandmother to Lara Zises, Samantha Cohen, Justin Zises, Kye Beaton and Khynna Beaton; great-Granny to Lily, Simon and Oliver. Graveside funeral Sunday, at 1 PM.

title: For Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Opulent but Savory
description: Louis/Dressner, a New York importer, champions understated wines from French and Italian boutiques that reflect their home vineyards with little manipulation in the cellars. They contrast with the opulent style favored by the powerful critic Robert M. Parker Jr. The Olga Raffault 2003 Poplinire, an herbal red Chinon from the Loire ($17), and Cascina degli Ulivi's savory 2004 white Gavi ($15) are typical examples.

title: Water Buffalo? Swamps? This Is Japan?
description: SAY Okinawa, and the word conjures up one of the last major battles of World War II and the enduring presence of American troops in Japan. But Okinawa is so much more: a chain of hundreds of islands stretching some 600 miles southwest of mainland Japan into the East China Sea (also called the Ryuku Islands), home to a distinctive subtropical culture and nature that few foreigners -- and not many Japanese for that matter -- have ever seen.

title: Sarah Levinson and Matthew Rothman
description: Sarah Kate Levinson is to be married this evening to Matthew Robert Rothman. Rabbi Eliezer Havivi is to perform the ceremony at the vacation home of the bride's family in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

title: One More Thing To Worry About
description: IT may be a bad time to bring this up, but there is probably never a good time. People hate it when you tell them there is trouble ahead.

title: With Mayor on Roll and Minds on Katrina, Rivals Hone Tactics in Last Push
description: The four major Democratic candidates for mayor of New York, entering their final full week of campaigning today, find themselves struggling anew to interest voters in anti-Bloomberg messages that have been dampened by the mayor's popularity, his relentless advertising, and now the heartbreak after Hurricane Katrina.

title: Schumacher and Ferrari Are Seeing an Era End
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 3 - When asked in an interview here in the summer of 1998 about his ambitions for Ferrari, Michael Schumacher said that he wanted not only to win the Formula One title but also to create a Ferrari era.

title: Connect the Dots. Find the Fees.
description: TO many investors, the collapse of the Bayou Group -- a hedge fund company and brokerage firm run by Samuel Israel III -- may seem like just another financial mishap, and a calamity only for those who had the bad luck to invest with Mr. Israel or to be steered his way by advisers they were wrong to trust.

title: What Happens to a Race Deferred
description: WASHINGTON - THE white people got out. Most of them, anyway. If television and newspaper images can be deemed a statistical sample, it was mostly black people who were left behind. Poor black people, growing more hungry, sick and frightened by the hour as faraway officials counseled patience and warned that rescues take time.

title: Jennifer Sandford and John Cummings
description: Jennifer Susan Sandford and John William Cummings were married yesterday at the Tournament Players Club at Jasna Polana in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. David Mertz, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: On Moral Grounds, Some Judges Are Opting Out of Abortion Cases
description: MEMPHIS - A pregnant teenager went to the grand and imposing county courthouse here early in the summer, saying she wanted an abortion. The circuit court judge refused to hear the case, and he announced that he would recuse himself from any others like it.

title: As Anxiety Over Storm Increases, Bush Tries to Quell Political Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - Faced with one of the worst political crises of his administration, President Bush abruptly overhauled his September schedule on Saturday as the White House scrambled to gain control of a situation that Republicans said threatened to undermine Mr. Bush's second-term agenda and the party's long-term ambitions.

title: Inside the List
description: ELLIS'S ISLAND: Bret Easton Ellis made his first appearance on the Times best-seller list almost exactly 20 years ago, in September 1985, when his first novel, "Less Than Zero," made its debut on the hardcover fiction list at No. 13 -- right between "Hold the Dream," by Barbara Taylor Bradford, and "The Class," by Erich Segal. Before this week, Ellis's only other appearance on the Times list came in 1991, when "American Psycho," published as a softcover original, spent three weeks on the paperback fiction list. The Times Book Review, as it happens, gave that novel the kind of advance publicity no amount of money can buy, publishing an essay by Roger Rosenblatt -- under the headline "Snuff This Book! Will Bret Easton Ellis Get Away With Murder?" -- arguing that "American Psycho" shouldn't be published at all. (Fifteen months later, also in the Book Review, John Irving called Rosenblatt's essay "prissy enough to please Jesse Helms.") Ellis's fifth novel, "Lunar Park," enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 13. In an interview on the "Today" show, Ellis told Katie Couric that his novel is "an homage to Stephen King and all the books I liked like that when I was a boy. . . . I wanted to write a haunted house book, a genre book, a supernatural thriller." He also told Couric that, when he reread "American Psycho" recently, even he was "shocked by it. . . . I had to steel myself at times."

title: Nickelodeon Heads (Further) South
description: The fate of the highly successful "Dora the Explorer" preschool empire -- more than $3 billion in retail sales to date -- is about to rest on the slender shoulders of Dora's cousin, Diego. New episodes of "Dora" are on hold, save for a few hourlong specials, while the creative team works on "Go, Diego, Go!," the franchise's first spin-off. And they're working hard.

title: West of the Moon
description: BASKING RIDGE - THIS restaurant's name may sound like an address. But as the alert reader will notice, 3 West is not at 3 West Anything. The reality is more interesting.

title: The No. 1 Network of Never-Were-Land
description: ON a recent episode of that Zen parable masquerading as a trashy E! reality series, "Gastineau Girls," Lisa Gastineau was heard to remark, "It's not about what you do -- it's about what you don't do." In truth, she was advising her daughter on how to get men to give her expensive jewelry, but her larger point was well taken, and one that's worth applying to the cable network disseminating it: What, exactly, does E! do or not do these days?

title: An Earlier Appearance
description: To the Editor:

title: Director/Hooligan
description: When a film with a challenging topic is turned down by Hollywood studios for distribution, its producers and filmmakers usually bite their lips and walk away. But not when it's directed by a former soccer hooligan.

title: Sideways
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Lake Is Deep, and the Accent French
description: IMAGINE a region offering many of Maine's charms -- tranquillity, natural beauty, folksy art -- but only 90 minutes' drive from a major city. That is what Montrealers enjoy in the string of pearly lake hamlets known as the Eastern Townships, 30 miles north of the Vermont border. (From New York, they're about the same drive time as the mid-Maine coast, seven hours, or the same fly-and-drive time as flying to Maine via Portland, two and a half hours.)

title: Updating the Subway
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, criticized for its sluggish response to the possibility of terrorist attacks, has now swung into high gear with plans for a security update of the subways and proposals for cellphone service at more than half of the city's subway platforms. In this insecure age, improvements like these make sense, assuming they work as advertised.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DENNING, ROBERT
description: DENNING--Robert. The Associates of deEvia.com are deeply saddened by the death of Robert Denning, a legend in interior design. He was partner for many years of our late founder Edgar de Evia, photographer, artist and author. David McJonathan-Swarm President

title: Movies
description: SAMURAI I (1955) Saturday at 8 a.m. and 2 p.m. on IFC The first installment in Hiroshi Inagaki's samurai trilogy is about a 17th-century bad boy, Takezo (Toshiro Mifune), who leaves his home village with a close friend to become a warrior and returns to marry Oko (Mitsuko Mito, above right, with Mifune), the friend's abandoned fiance. Women have always thrown themselves at Takezo. The film, also known as "Miyamoto Musashi," received the Oscar for best foreign film. The exposition in the subtitles isn't the subtlest of all time -- "You are engaged to me, aren't you?" Matahachi (Rentaro Mikuni) says to Oko -- but Jun Yasumoto's cinematography of the Japanese countryside and battles in the rain is gorgeous.

title: The Newest Indians
description: Jack Hitt's earnest report on new tribal allegiances would have been whimsical except for its startling implications (Aug. 21). If "racial identity" is a matter of "ethnic shopping" and can be assumed like a fashion statement, what does it mean for race-based government programs? Any affirmative-action policy may now be built on sand.

title: John Madden Is More Than a Commentator. He's a Brand.
description: For most of us, the summer solstice occurs in late June, but for John Madden, it begins the second he steps on training-camp grass. This is what his body clock is set for, what his biorhythms tell him is right. Early last month, that initial landing was at Soldier Field in Chicago, where the Bears were practicing.

title: A Memorable Cab Ride and Other Journeys Into the Heart of the City
description: THE PROPHET OF ZONGO STREET By Mohammed Naseehu Ali Amistad ($22.95, hardcover)

title: What's Next at the Open? An Eight-Foot Racket?
description: At the United States Open, if one is of a certain age (quite young) and wishes to be seen as stylish and in-the-know, no accessory is more necessary than an enormous, unwieldy tennis ball.

title: Between Franchise and Player, the Label Drives a Wedge
description: A person who everyone agrees is a prized catch is threatening to leave. If you are a wishy-washy suitor, you pony up a ring, but refuse to commit to a date. If you are a National Football League general manager, you offer as a grand gesture the franchise player tag.

title: Is a Hedge Fund Shakeout Coming Soon? This Insider Thinks So
description: OF all the sectors of the financial universe, the hedge fund world is probably the most secretive and almost certainly the most alluring.
