Open only to institutions and the wealthy, hedge funds offer sophisticated models of risk, access to the best financial minds and the chance for outsized returns. According to Van Hedge Advisors, hedge fund assets have topped a trillion dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSE, HOWARD
description: ROSE--Howard. 81, on August 30, 2005. Loving father of Elizabeth Rose-Boitnott and Charles Alan Rose. Father-in law and dear friend to Gina Savoca Rose and Dennis Boitnott. Loving son of Etta and Isadore Rose. Loving brother to Joan Shepherd and her husband Robert. Grandfather of Jason (20) and Hannah (15) Boitnott; Lily (17), Joseph (15), Logan (11), James (7), Antonio (5) and Molly (2) Rose. Joins his beloved granddaughter Mia Rose, (who died of leukemia at age 13), in heaven. Husband and lifelong friend of Judith Rose. Good friend and first cousin to Simeon and Herbert Brinberg. Nephew of Samuel and David Rose, and Rebecca Klein. B.S. in Architecture, University of Illinois. Licensed Professional Engineer, State of New York. Builder and developer. Former partner of William Rechler, Walter Gross, and Thomas Manno, builders and developers of Vanderbilt Industrial Park, Smithtown L.I. Broadway Producer: "Stardust" 1987. Founding Member The Mill River Club, Oyster Bay, N.Y. (the first integrated golf club on Long Island). Member, The New York Friars Club. WWII Veteran Army Air Corps, Air Transport Command - European Theatre. Avid aviator and world traveler. Contributions to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society in memory of Howard Rose and Mia Rose. Funeral today, 11am Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Interest-Only Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: Under the Radar in Brooklyn
description: ARE the city and state doing enough to protect home buyers in the midst of one of the biggest building and condo booms in years?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVERSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: SILVERSTEIN--Joseph. Died August 29 at the age of 93 in Jupiter, Florida. He was one of Wall Street's greatest arbitrageurs, most prominently with Ladenburg, Thallman & Co. Joe and his previously deceased wife, Bea, formerly lived in Harrison, NY and in Palm Beach, Florida. He was a loving husband, father, nephew, cousin and friend. A great golfer and a fine person. He is survived by his only son, Mark, of Lee, New Hampshire and numerous cousins, and will be remembered for a long and good life. May he rest in peace. The Leet and Hamburg Families

title: Deceit of the Raven
description: It began with apes. In the 1960's and 70's, scientists taught captive chimps to use words and documented wild ones using tools and planning hunting expeditions. Then other smart mammals -- monkeys, elephants and porpoises among them -- also proved to have surprisingly "human" mental powers. And in the last few years, the circle has expanded to still other mammals and beyond.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; THEATER
description: Fidel Castro is not a figure generally associated with smooching, but in EDUARDO MACHADO'S new play, "KISSING FIDEL," a Cuban-American in a forgiving mood announces to his surprised -- indeed, disgusted -- family that he plans to head back to the homeland to give the cigar-chomping Cuban dictator a benevolent embrace. Plans for this quixotic journey are announced by the estranged family misfit, a novelist, at the funeral of the clan's matriarch in Miami. Mr. Machado, in his second year as artistic director of the Intar Theater, dedicated to producing the work of Hispanic playwrights, opens the season with this world premiere. Previews begin Sept. 6 at the Kirk Theater on Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212)279-4200.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: New Brunswick: Ready for Its Close-Up
description: Jason Francisco, an assistant professor of photography at Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University, said he had the photographer Aaron Siskind's "Harlem Document" series of the 1930's in mind when he enlisted two photographers to help him document the city of New Brunswick for a yearlong project that began last August.

title: Man Who Killed Dogs Given 2-Year Jail Term
description: Brannon Chandler, who was accused of killing five young dogs and seriously injuring another in Seymour last January, pleaded guilty to six counts of animal cruelty and was sentenced to two years in jail last Monday in Derby Superior Court.

title: A Wise Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys in Love . . . With Each Other
description: Correction Appended

title: Dealing With Dealers
description: I live in a gentrifying neighborhood. Someone on the block is dealing drugs that, I recently learned, are less benign than I'd assumed; he's dealing crystal meth. I believe that the drug laws are overly punitive, and I've never had a problem with the dealer. But I would like to see the block cleaned up and the drug traffic gone. What's the morality of narcking on the neighbors? Anonymous, Brooklyn If your local drug dealer is merely unsightly, do nothing. This is not to endorse dealing crystal meth but to assert that the war on drugs does more harm than the drug use it seeks to suppress.

title: DATEBOOK
description: REYKJAVIK - The Iceland Airwaves festival will present local and international rock artists throughout downtown Reykjavik from Oct. 19 to 23. Icelandic favorites like the quirky electronic group Gus Gus will be joined by an eclectic roster, including the Norwegian pop singer Annie (below), the brother-sister indie-rock duo known as the Fiery Furnaces, and even Juliette Lewis and her band, the Licks. Shows will be presented around town; pubs and bars will be hosts to D.J. parties and other events.

title: Bottling Nostalgia, Along With the Soda
description: IN the days when milk was delivered to most people's doors, so was locally bottled soda. It was often dropped off in wooden crates and the delivery driver would return for the empties.

title: N.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: Correction Appended

title: Are Isolated Center Pawns a Weakness or an Advantage?
description: At the 106th Annual United States Open Championship, held in Phoenix from Aug. 6 to 14, Joel Benjamin of the United States and Vadim Milov of Switzerland tied for first place with 8-1 scores. Benjamin got the trophy on tiebreak points.

title: Passing Strange
description: When school busing to achieve racial balance was a big issue in 1985, John Roberts, arguing for judicial restraint, wrote to a fellow Reagan White House aide, "It strikes me as more than passing strange for us to tell Congress it cannot pass a law preventing courts from ordering busing when our own Justice Department invariably urges this policy on the courts."

title: Swimming With Don Quixote
description: AHAB had his white whale, Monty Python its holy grail. I, too, have embarked on an epic quest: a search for the perfect swimming pool.

title: A Place to Grow and to Downsize
description: ON a sultry, late-summer afternoon, shortly before school was about to begin again, the members of one Eastchester family set off in different directions.

title: What Looks Like Grass But Spreads Like a Weed?
description: THE number of children playing too many sports on too few athletic fields in Westchester may finally have reached critical mass. At least, that is an inference to be made from the increasingly rapid spread of artificial turf -- which at about $800,000 a field was once out of the reach of most county schools.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HALF, ROBERT
description: HALF--Robert. Forever in our hearts, always in our thoughts. We miss and love you so very much. Peggy, Nancy, Maxine

title: East of New Orleans, Heavy Damage, Lost Lives and Pleas for Help
description: CHALMETTE, La., Sept 3 - St. Bernard Parish, just to the east of New Orleans and surrounded by water -- more island than peninsula since Hurricane Katrina -- is nearly empty now, the vast majority of its 68,000 residents scattered to who knows where.

title: The Heart of Rock 'n' Roll Is in Wildwood
description: WILDWOOD - DICK RICHARDS was just happy to be at the Shore in the summer of 1954. Mr. Richards, a drummer from just west of Philadelphia, and his six band mates were booked from Memorial Day to Labor Day at the HofBrau, one of the biggest clubs on the Atlantic Avenue strip here.

title: Old Memo From Roberts the Young Lawyer Shows a Caustic Side
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - When he was a young lawyer in the Justice Department in 1982, John G. Roberts Jr. wrote a memorandum that contained an unusually caustic assessment of a prominent black lobbying group called TransAfrica, according to documents released Saturday.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; FILM
description: The Toronto International Film Festival has become Hollywood's vehicle of choice for a first peek at the fall films (JODIE FOSTER'S "FLIGHT PLAN," scheduled to open Sept. 23, is having its press junket in town), and this year the auction block will be full of films financed by Hollywood's new wave of post-dotcom, pay-as-you-go producers, including DAVID SACKS and SIDNEY KIMMEL. Among the 109 films to have their premieres at the festival, which opens on Thursday and runs through Sept. 17, will be "HARSH TIMES," the first foray into directing by DAVID AYER, who wrote the powerful drama "Training Day"; MARTIN SCORSESE's much-anticipated documentary "NO DIRECTION HOME: BOB DYLAN," and TOMMY LEE JONES's directorial debut, "THE THREE BURIALS OF MELQUIADES ESTRADA," in which he also stars.

title: Congressmen Tell North Korea to End Standoff
description: BEIJING, Sept. 3 - Two members of Congress returning on Saturday from a visit to North Korea warned the country's government that an American public traumatized by Hurricane Katrina was in no mood for any more lengthy negotiations over North Korea's nuclear program.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FELL, JUDITH
description: FELL--Judith. On August 29, 2005 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Barry Okun, daughter of Red and the late Babs Fell, sister of David (Amy) and Happy (Adair) Fell, aunt of Lauren and Sarah Fell. Friend to too many to name. We will miss Judy's wit, intelligence, and fearless honesty. Memorial service on Wednesday, September 7, 2005, 11 AM, Congregation Beth Elohim, 247 Garfield Place (corner of 8th Ave), Brooklyn, N.Y. Memorial donations in Judy's name to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden or the National Council of Jewish Women-New York Section. $(6$)FELL--Judith. NCJW NY Section staff and members mourn the loss of our courageous colleague and friend. Her strength of character and spirit will be missed. Our condolences to Barry and the Fell and Okun families. Natalie Katz, President Judith R. Golub, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MCLERNAN, JAMES J.
description: McLERNAN--James J. Died August 24, 2005, Miami Beach, FL. He left behind his beloved sister, Margaret Barry, and the late John McLernan. Cherished uncle of six nieces and nephews. Memorial service will be held at Our Lady of Good Counsel, Staten Island, NY, September 10, 2005, 12 noon. A second service will be held in Key West, FL, November 16, 2005. Visit www.jamesmclernan.com

title: Amanda Goldstein and Scott Spitzer
description: Amanda Mikael Goldstein, a daughter of Wendy and Howard Goldstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Scott Howard Spitzer, the son of Jane and Michael Spitzer of Bethlehem, Pa. Rabbi Elliot Holin officiated at the Knowlton Mansion in Philadelphia.

title: Federer's Latest Victim Has Nothing but Praise
description: Tomas Berdych bounced out of his chair at the end of every changeover yesterday and skipped to his side of the court. A 19-year-old from the Czech Republic, he was playing so well it seemed he could hardly wait to hit his next shot.

title: Community Forestry Bids to Preserve Scenic West
description: OVANDO, Mont. - When the Plum Creek Timber Company decided to sell its 88,000 acres in the mountain-ringed Blackfoot Valley near here in 2003, ranchers, conservationists and other locals worried that a crop of new houses would sprout. Dependent on the forest and mountains to make a living and for hunting and fishing, they formed a nonprofit group mostly made up of area residents to buy the land.

title: A Rare Niche: New Homes for Rent
description: WHEN James and Jeanette Greco set out with the help of classified advertisements to find homes for rent near Port Jefferson in Suffolk County, they quickly learned to spot the rentals on most streets even before they saw the house number. "It's usually the worst house on the block," Mr. Greco said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SEYMOUR, LYNNE WEIL
description: SEYMOUR--Lynne Weil Of Needham, Ma. Formerly of NY. Daughter of Marjorie (Weingart) and the late Richard L. Weil. Sister of Barbara Gummere and Lonnie Weil. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Three-Bedroom Co-op at the Imperial House $2,900,000

title: Chirac Hospitalized
description: PARIS, Sept. 3 - President Jacques Chirac was hospitalized late on Friday after suffering unspecified vascular trouble, and is expected to remain in the hospital for a week, his office said Saturday.

title: 'Can't Stop Won't Stop': A Nation of Millions
description: CAN'T STOP WON'T STOP A History of the Hip-Hop Generation. By Jeff Chang. Illustrated. 546 pp. St. Martin's Press. $27.95.

title: 9 Afghans Killed Ahead of Election; Taliban Are Blamed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 4 - Another election candidate and eight other people were killed in Afghanistan in several attacks, officials said today, blaming Taliban militants.

title: 'Ghost Town': Gothic Gotham
description: GHOST TOWN Tales of Manhattan Then and Now. By Patrick McGrath. 243 pp. Bloomsbury. $16.95.

title: Hotel QT in New York City
description: THE BASICS -- Andr Balazs created the Mercer Hotel in SoHo, the Standard hotels in Los Angeles and the groovy Sunset Beach on Shelter Island. Hotel QT, on a busy block just around the corner from Times Square, is an attempt by Mr. Balazs to reach a less-affluent crowd; some rooms are under $200 a night. His touches -- walls covered with pages from On the QT, a scandal sheet that flourished in the 1950's, and an indoor pool adjacent to the lobby bar -- have created a lot of buzz since the hotel opened in February. But buzz doesn't guarantee a pleasant stay.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MESSINGER, EDNA HELLER
description: MESSINGER--Edna Heller. Brooklyn, died on September 1, at 92. Beloved mother of Susan Avner and Dr. Eli Messinger, mother-in-law of Dr. Sandy Avner, Barbara Barnes and Ruth Messinger. Cherished grandmother of David, Marc, Daniel, Miriam, Adam and Benjie. Loving great-grandmother to ten. Widow of Benjamin Messinger. Services Tuesday, September 6, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, at 91 St, Manhattan

title: Lilah Fisher and Jeffrey Wise
description: Lilah Hilliard Fisher and Jeffrey Roland Wise, actors in New York, are to be married today in Holderness, N.H. James Diamond, a Universal Life Church minister, will perform the ceremony at the Chocorua Island Chapel, of which the bride's father is a trustee.

title: Erin Leib and David Lisitza
description: Erin Dana Leib, the daughter of Naomi R. Leib and Dr. Martin L. Leib of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married on Thursday evening to David Lisitza, a son of Nessa Lisitza and Bernard Lisitza of Northbrook, Ill. Rabbi Jonathan I. Rosenblatt officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan, with Rabbi James Jacobson-Maisels taking part.

title: Quitting? What to Know Before You Go
description: Q. You're thinking about leaving your job, but first you want to explore your company's postemployment benefits. Should you ask your boss about them?

title: The Meaning of Hard Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Says Palestinian Pleaded Guilty to Assisting Attackers
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 - A prominent member of the Palestinian parliament, Husam Khader, pleaded guilty today in an Israeli military court to charges of assisting an armed Palestinian faction that has carried out many attacks against Israel, the military said.

title: Correction
description: A capsule guide on Aug 21 with an article about vacations for nontraditional families referred imprecisely to the price of safaris to Kenya being offered by Gay 2Afrika, a tour operator. Nine-day safaris start at $2,490; that is not the sole price.

title: When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: $10 Dance Back at City Center
description: There was plenty of hoopla last year -- and also a bit of grumbling -- when City Center inaugurated its bargain-priced Fall for Dance Festival. The $10-a-night event offered 30 companies, classical to far out, in six eclectic shows meant to bring together audiences and performers who might not otherwise cross paths.

title: Violence in Haiti: Politics and Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicole Gade and Nathan Brill
description: Nicole Mary Ferrante Gade, a daughter of Dr. Marie Ferrante Gade and Dr. Ronald Gade of Sands Point, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nathan Arthur Brill, the son of Mary and Arthur Brill of Kalamazoo, Mich. Msgr. Brendan Reardon performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: The End of the Fabled Insider Deal
description: THE residents at the Sheffield, a 50-story apartment building near Central Park, believed their King Midas moment had finally arrived. Their building had just been sold for $418 million, and the new owners wanted to convert the rental building into a luxury condominium.

title: If You Can Make It Here ...
description: MILWAUKEE - MATTHEW S. LEVATICH hovers intently over the shiny red-and-chrome Harley-Davidson motorcycle parked near his office. He is annoyed. A reporter has questioned the American purity of Harley cycles and Mr. Levatich, as the vice president in charge of procurement, is defending the faith. He is slowly circling an employee's bike, identifying the source of each visible part.

title: What the Beatles Knew
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cineaste as a Peekskill 'Everyman'
description: PEEKSKILL - ADAM MATALON caused quite a stir at his bank here not long ago when he cashed a check bearing the notation, "for sex and camping." No, the note was not what it seemed. Mr. Matalon, president of Chatsby Films in Peekskill, was withdrawing money in aid of a comedy he is producing and directing called "Sex and Camping."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KOONS, TILGHMAN B. (SKIP)
description: KOONS--Tilghman B. (Skip). A celebration of the life of Tilghman B. (Skip) Koons, who died July 7, will be held at 4PM, Friday September 9 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave and 51 St.

title: Drawn to Trouble
description: When you first see the art of Marcel Dzama, you may feel you are looking at illustrations from some quaintly antique children's book. He specializes in pen-and-ink drawings in which pale, slender women routinely meet up with rabbits and talking trees. Yet Dzama isn't making art for children.

title: Bush Pledges More Troops as Evacuation Grows
description: Correction Appended

title: Anxiety in Iraq as Guardsmen Head Home to Uncertainties
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 3 - Capt. Terrence P. Ryan has made a career out of helping Americans dig out from storms up and down the Gulf Coast. But now, with his own house underwater, he is stuck at Camp Victory in Iraq waiting for a flight home.

title: New Member of Supreme Court Brings More Than Just One Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - "Every time a new justice comes to the Supreme Court, it's a different court," Justice Byron R. White liked to say, and he had reason to know. During a tenure of 31 years, he saw the arrival of 13 new colleagues. Each one, he said, made the court "a new instrument."

title: Giving Them What They Want
description: After three decades in the TV business, Leslie Moonves, the chairman of CBS and the person most responsible for taking the network from last place to first in the ratings, has figured out a few things about what people want to see when they turn on their televisions. "Americans do not like dark," Moonves told me last May, before a scheduling meeting to select CBS's fall 2005 lineup. Moonves, who was wearing a gray suit, white shirt and diagonally striped maroon and navy tie, was in a wood-paneled corner office on the 35th floor of Black Rock, the longtime home of CBS on 52nd Street in Manhattan. The office used to belong to William S. Paley, the legendary tycoon who personified CBS for more than 60 years. Truman Capote once remarked that Paley "looks like a man who has just swallowed an entire human being," and Moonves has that same sort of aggressive vigor -- an almost palpable appetite and enthusiasm for the complications and constant challenges of network TV.

title: The Newest Indians
description: Hitt might have mentioned that DNA testing may be used to determine whether someone has an Indian background. This would put an end to "wannabes."

title: The Breaking Point
description: A perspective rarely heard in our dialogue on oil concerns the permanent loss of this finite resource by treating it as a "fuel." The best use of petroleum is as a "material." The computer hardware on which I am composing this note and an infinite number of goods we have come to rely on are petroleum products. Most of those products can be recycled. When petroleum is used as fuel instead of as material, it is gone forever.

title: Songs That Hit A Political Note
description: CLASSICAL composers have a history of writing music that is also political protest. There is, for instance, Mozart, whose opera "Le Nozze di Figaro" offered a biting critique of the French aristocracy, and Beethoven, whose opera "Fidelio" is even more explicit in its critique of tyranny and especially Napoleon.

title: Match That Keeps Giving
description: Lindsay Davenport is winning with ease at the Open and won again, 6-3, 6-2, in the third round against the Spaniard Anabel Medina Garrigues last night.

title: Luring Fashionistas Uptown
description: EXACTLY two weeks before the start of the New York Spring Collections, otherwise known as Fashion Week, Malcolm Harris, a 37-year-old designer, was inching toward the debut of a solo line that he is calling Mal Sirrah (his own name, written backward) and describing an unanticipated stumbling block: his new neighborhood.

title: Moving to Houston in Order to Move On
description: Moving to Houston In Order to Move On

title: Lowriders
description: Women continue to experiment with the lowered-waist silhouette. They mostly flirt with the 1920's flapper but some styles suggest the dresses Botticelli put on his goddesses. Below, a Botticellian dress with both a high bust line and a dropped waist. ON THE STREET

title: Sometimes, It's Not the Tuition. It's the Textbooks.
description: AS the school year begins, soaring tuition isn't the only financial matter on college students' minds. Many are also trying relentlessly to get a break on the rapidly climbing cost of textbooks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FINN, HETTY WELLS
description: FINN--Hetty Wells. Born April 13, 1912, Rockville Centre, NY to Jeanette Robinson Wells and Pierson L. Wells, died August 27, 2005, Ashland, Oregon. Married Dr. Frederick W. Finn 1935. They had four children, five grand children and seven great grandchildren. She is survived by her daughter, Virginia Finn Blechman of Ashland, Oregon and son, Frederick Wells Finn of Olympia, Washington. Her husband and sons, James Webster Finn and Lawrence Lee Finn proceeded her in death. Graduated from South Side HS and Sweet Briar College with honors, majoring in Chemistry. Served the First Presbyterian Church, Greenwich, Ct. for 50 years in numerous capacities including Elder, Deacon and Chair of the Finance Committee. Member of the Board of Directors of the Greenwich Academy and Co-Chair of the Brunswick School Annual Giving, Volunteer Greenwich Hospital with 2900+ hours. Most of all she will be remembered as a loving and giving daughter, sister, mother, grandmother, great grandmother and friend. At her home there was always "room at the inn". Contributions in her name may be made to a charity of your choice. Funeral information: Fred D. Knapp of Greenwich, Ct., 203-869-0315.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: Three Men and a Woman
description: ANGELINA and I are in an art gallery that doubles as a dance club. A D.J. stands on a sheet of plywood over milk crates playing house music with a heavy bass line. It's still afternoon but already there are a few office workers here loosening their ties, putting their earrings back in.

title: Antony Finds His Voice
description: One morning in early July, I sat next to Antony, of Antony and the Johnsons, in Studio 4 of the BBC's radio center in Maida Vale, a quiet neighborhood of London. Down below us, the Johnsons -- the small, rotating-member chamber ensemble that regularly accompanies Antony -- were chatting and tuning up, getting ready to record a few songs for Radio 1. Antony had his laptop open, and he was watching a video of his recent appearance on "Later," an influential British TV music program whose host is Jools Holland, who used to be in the band Squeeze. I watched over his shoulder. There on the screen was Antony, in the long brunette hair extensions he has been wearing lately, the straight Karen Carpenter hair framing his gentle, full-moon face. He sang from the piano in his signature high quaver -- "Hope there's someone/Who'll take care of me/When I die; will I go?/Hope there's someone/Who'll set my heart free. . . . "

title: Legislative Agenda Turned Upside Down by Hurricane
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - Congress returns in full force on Tuesday to confront a legislative agenda turned on its head by the devastation resulting from Hurricane Katrina and a rise in gasoline prices accelerated by the storm.

title: Political Science
description: When Donald Kennedy, a biologist and editor of the eminent journal Science, was asked what had led so many American scientists to feel that George W. Bush's administration is anti-science, he isolated a familiar pair of culprits: climate change and stem cells. These represent, he said, "two solid issues in which there is a real difference between a strong consensus in the science community and the response of the administration to that consensus." Both issues have in fact riled scientists since the early days of the administration, and both continue to have broad repercussions. In March 2001, the White House abruptly withdrew its support for the Kyoto Protocol on climate change, and the U.S. withdrawal was still a locus of debate at this summer's G8 summit in Scotland. And the administration's decision to limit federal funds for embryonic-stem-cell research four years ago -- a move that many scientists worry has severely hampered one of the most fruitful avenues of biomedical inquiry to come along in decades -- resulted in a shift in the dynamics of financing, from the federal government to the states and private institutions. In November 2004, Californians voted to allocate $3 billion for stem-cell research in what was widely characterized as a "scientific secession."

title: Bad Boys III: A Week With Nothing but Trouble
description: LAST winter, in the face of Jason Giambi's reported grand jury testimony on his steroids use, the Yankees quietly explored the possibility of terminating his contract. That they decided to eschew that move was based at least in part on the difficulty they saw in winning an inevitable grievance.

title: London's Art Scene's Edge Moves Again
description: THE Young British Artists who made Hoxton in East London one of the city's trendiest spots have become Middle-Aged British Artists, and the area has grown up too. Now, young artists, galleries and nighttime scenes are popping up in nearby cheaper spots, including Bethnal Green, a mile east of Hoxton and three miles northeast of the city center.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOODMAN, NAOMI ASCHER
description: GOODMAN--Naomi Ascher. Activist, poet and friend to many, died suddenly while swimming near her house in East Hampton, NY. Born August 26, 1920, she was a lifelong pacifist. Ms. Goodman was the co-author of "The Good Book Cookbook," coeditor of "The Challenge of Shalom." She was married to Percival Goodman, noted modern architect who died in 1989. She is survived by her children Joel Goodman and Rachel Goodman, her grandchildren Amos Goodman, Bear Goodman and Iris Tilley, and great-grandchild Mia Goodman. She is also survived by her brother Robert N. Ascher and Margaret Beach. Funeral services will be held at 11:15 am, Monday, at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam, NYC.

title: The Truth About Summer
description: IF I seem unduly cautious and a bit skittish during the summer, it has far less to do with the endless articles citing the surge in emergency room activity than with my own history of summer horrors.

title: Corrections

She was Doe Avedon, not Claire Trevor. This correction was delayed by mishandling at The Times.

title: More Hotels for a Comeback City
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. - FOR years, there were just a few hotels in this capital city. They took in visitors during the city's good times and bad, hanging on during its bleaker years like children on a roller coaster ride.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; TELEVISION
description: It's hard to pinpoint precisely what went wrong with "THE O.C." in its second season. Among the culprits were flavorless plots, flat new characters who failed to grab the audience's interest and too many guest appearances by indie rock bands. Whatever the reasons, Season 3 is starting (FOX, Thursday at 8 p.m.), and Ryan (BENJAMIN McKENZIE), Seth (ADAM BRODY), Summer (RACHEL BILSON) and Marissa (MISCHA BARTON) will be seniors in high school -- and JOSH SCHWARTZ, the show's executive producer, will try to lure back the zeitgeist. The teen soap's first order of business: sort out the fact that Marissa shot Ryan's brother, Trey (LOGAN MARSHALL-GREEN), in the final moments of the May season finale.

We can all enumerate the many differences between a natural catastrophe and a terrorist attack. But character doesn't change: it is immutable, and it is destiny.

title: Everybody Into the Pool (and Dance)
description: WHEN Nomie Lafrance first saw the deserted 50,000-square-foot McCarren Park swimming pool, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 1996, it had been closed for 13 years. The concrete floor was cracked, littered with broken glass, graffiti and weeds. Seeing a public facility in such wretched disrepair, Ms. Lafrance, who lives nearby, had a strong emotional response. "This is superb," she thought.

title: Takatsu's Debut With Mets Becomes a Forgettable One
description: MIAMI, Sept. 3 - When he pitched in Japan, Shingo Takatsu earned the nickname Mr. Zero because he did not allow a run in 10 championship series games. Then, before last season, he bolted for the United States, signing with the Chicago White Sox and emerging as the team's closer and as a cult figure.

title: Israel Says Palestinian Pleaded Guilty to Assisting Attackers
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 - A prominent member of the Palestinian parliament, Husam Khader, pleaded guilty today in an Israeli military court to charges of assisting an armed Palestinian faction that has carried out many attacks against Israel, the military said.

title: Correction

The two smaller pictures were of sculptures by Frank Bender; the large picture was of a sculpture by Gloria Nusse, as the article said.

description: "Panhandle" is one of those geographic terms, like "tundra" or "mud flats," that are not well suited to selling real estate. It smacks of homelessness, or kitchen drudgery. As a signifier of mystery and romance, it vastly underachieves.

title: Allan Bloom and the Conservative Mind
description: CONSERVATIVES in 1987 may still have been basking in Ronald Reagan's "morning in America," but nothing prepared their movement, or the academic and publishing worlds, for the wildfire success of Allan Bloom's "Closing of the American Mind: How Higher Education Has Failed Democracy and Impoverished the Souls of Today's Students." Amid a furor recalling that over William F. Buckley Jr.'s "God and Man at Yale" in 1951, Bloom indicted liberal academics for betraying liberal education. His attack sold more than a million copies.

title: Comings and Goings
description: CRUISE WEST is introducing three- and four-night trips to Glacier Bay National Park in Alaska next year. The Spirit of Alaska and the Spirit of Glacier Bay will sail round trip from Juneau with stops at Skagway and Haines; the four-night cruise also visits Icy Strait. The cruises will be offered from May through August with prices starting at $1,349 a person, double occupancy. Information: (888) 851-3360 or www.cruisewest.com. CONTINENTAL AIRLINES is adding a third destination in Puerto Rico (after San Juan and Aquadilla) with daily nonstop service between Newark Liberty Airport and Ponce, on the south coast, starting Nov. 17. The flights from Newark are overnight, leaving at 11:55 p.m. The return leaves at 6:15 a.m. Information: (800) 525-0280 or www.continental.com. The SMALL LUXURY HOTELS OF THE WORLD group is now selling gift certificates on its Web site, www.slh.com, redeemable at any of its 350 member hotels. The certificates come in amounts of 100, 500 and 1,000 dollars, euros or British pounds. MARJORIE CONNELLY

She will be missed and remembered by her grandchildren Beth and Armin, Libby and Matt, Marnie and Shir and Lauren and David and her great grandchildren Harrison, Sophie, Max, Kiya, Parker, Grace and Zachary, all of whose lives she touched in many ways. We will not grieve but find strength in what remains behind.

title: Introduction
description: Our cover article on the coming oil crisis drew a strong response. Readers emphasized the need to explore alternative sources of energy. And what about the oil in Iraq? The report on Native Americans and wannabes prompted many to raise the issue of choosing your own ethnicity.

title: Why the Internet Isn't the Death of the Post Office
description: MILLIONS of people now rent their movies the Netflix way. They fill out a wish list from the 50,000 titles on the company's Web site and receive the first few DVD's in the mail; when they mail each one back, the next one on the list is sent.

title: For Cleaner Courts in Brooklyn
description: Two critical contests on the Sept. 13 Democratic primary ballot in Brooklyn -- for district attorney and for a Surrogate's Court judgeship -- offer voters a chance to register their disgust with the cozy clubhouse-courthouse ties that lie at the heart of the borough's judicial patronage and corruption scandal, and the undue influence of Clarence Norman's local Democratic machine. Together, these races amount to a referendum on cleaning up the local political and justice system.

title: Quizzing Judge Roberts
description: One Supreme Court justice can make a huge difference in what kind of nation America is. Consider Sandra Day O'Connor, who in a series of 5-to-4 decisions cast the deciding vote holding: (1) that the federal government has broad power under the Clean Air Act to fight air pollution; (2) that states cannot impose new restrictions on abortion rights; (3) that courthouses cannot post the Ten Commandments; and (4) that the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law is constitutional. John Roberts, the appeals court judge who is President Bush's nominee to replace Justice O'Connor, could have an equally powerful influence. As far as we know right now, he could wipe away all of these rulings and many more.

title: Louise Li and Thomas Chew
description: Louise Li and Thomas Chew are to be married this afternoon in New York. George T. Chew, the bridegroom's uncle and a judge of the United States Immigration Court in New York, is to officiate at the Torch Club, an event space for alumni of New York University.

title: Iraq to Put Hussein on Trial in 6 Weeks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 4 - The trial of Saddam Hussein will begin in six weeks, the Iraqi government said today, and he and seven aides face a special tribunal on charges of massacring almost 150 residents from the town of Dujail, the scene of a failed assassination attempt against Mr. Hussein 23 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KNIPE, ANDY
description: KNIPE--Andy. The Board of Directors and staff of The ALS Association, Greater New York Chapter, are deeply saddened by the loss of our esteemed Board member, Andy Knipe. In his valiant struggle against ALS, Andy, much like his hero Lou Gehrig, never complained or despaired. For those who worked alongside him and were deeply stirred by his courage, he will remain a symbol of hope for many others who are equally afflicted. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his devoted wife Laura and family. Alan Griffith, Chairman John Ernst, Chair Emeritus Dorine Gordon, President Jackie Reinhard, Exec. Dir.

title: Tokyo on the Hudson
description: "ANYONE attempting a history of Japanese film is at something of a disadvantage in that so little Japanese film is left," writes the critic Donald Richie in his essential study "A Hundred Years of Japanese Film." The devastating earthquake of 1923, the fire bombing of major cities during World War II and the physical destruction of hundreds of films deemed "feudal" by the postwar Allied occupation forces are among the reasons Mr. Richie cites for the destruction of Japan's film heritage. Only 10 percent of all Japanese films made before 1945 survive, he estimates.

But the possible collapse of the Bayou Group, a $400 million Stamford firm being investigated by federal and state authorities, has turned a spotlight onto the insular universe of Connecticut hedge funds.

title: When Worlds Collide
description: ROEBLING - THESE days Father Joseph Chereches, the 84-year-old Romanian Orthodox priest who has served the tiny parish of SS. Michael and Gabriel here for the last 20 years, spends much of his time in the network of vegetable gardens in small plots given over to his cultivation by his neighbors. He lovingly tends the tomatoes, bean plants native to Romania, and stands of the popular Romanian herb lovage. He bends his sturdy 5-foot-4-inch frame to tear away a dead leaf or pluck a bean pod that has been nibbled by rabbits in much the same way he did decades ago growing up on a farm in the village of Milas in northern Romania.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SONTAG, HOWARD

title: For U.S., a Counterfeiting Problem in China Is Old and Very Real
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 30 - New problems come and go between China and the United States, but when leaders of the two countries meet in Washington shortly, protection of intellectual property will be on the agenda -- as it has been for years.

title: Rich Gay, Poor Gay

title: U.S. Allies, And Others, Send Offers Of Assistance
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Sept. 3 - The images of destruction, suffering and death from Hurricane Katrina circulating around the world have evoked both disbelief that such a powerful country could be so overwhelmed by a natural disaster and an outpouring of sympathy and assistance.

title: Bob Schroeder, He's Not Dead Yet
description: Say one thing for the would-be New Jersey governor Bob Schroeder: he doesn't give up easily.

title: Jets Rally Around One and Bid Farewell to Others
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 3 - It was an oddly emotional day at Jets camp as 19 roster cuts were announced and the team continued to rally around a player hit hard by the news coming from New Orleans, his hometown.

title: In a Romantic Comedy, Looking for Mr. or Ms. Right
description: STONY POINT - NO one is going to leave the theater after "Maybe Baby, It's You" with a new understanding of the human condition -- or even of the battle of the sexes. But a lot of people will leave smiling.

title: The Tappan Zee's Stealth Pit Crew
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. - THERE is no breakdown lane on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Depending which way you're going and what time it is, there are three, or four, lanes of traffic moving at 60 to 70 miles an hour. Just beyond them and a four-foot-high railing, there is the Hudson River, 157 feet straight down. And New Jersey drivers think they have problems on the Turnpike and the Parkway.

title: On the Air, on Their Own: Iraqi Women Find a Forum
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - The two radio hosts, Majda and Majid, a chattering woman-and-man team, said the subject for the next hour would be childbearing and motherhood, from the first flush of pregnancy to the tribulations of labor.

title: New Haven Students Get Bus Bracelets
description: When the school year opened in New Haven, the approximately 3,200 kindergarten and first-grade students who ride school buses were given yellow bracelets identifying which bus they were supposed take and what time they were supposed to be met at their stop.

title: The Prologue, and Maybe the Coda
description: I CALLED my home in New Orleans Wednesday to listen to the phone ring. I didn't call for messages, knowing that without power the answering machine had not taken any. I called to connect to my home. No neighbors remained to talk to. The few who had remained through the storm and through the first part of the week had finally gone. Listening to the ring, imagining it echoing through the silent house, its sound waves caressing so much that I loved and so much of my life, I was reluctant to hang up. It seemed as if hanging up meant abandoning my home and my city, as if I were holding onto it, and hanging up meant letting it all go.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHERMAN, LEONARD
description: SHERMAN--Leonard. description: IN the four years since Sept. 11, Muslims on Long Island say, they have been waging jihad. And they are saddened, but not surprised, when non-Muslims misunderstand what that means.

title: The Judges Were Right
description: ADAM SUPRENANT, the winemaker at Osprey's Dominion, is like a big-hearted chef who doles out an extra helping. His penchant for ample quantities of generous flavors may help explain why this estate, in Peconic on the North Fork, was recently declared winery of the year.

title: Nasty Hurricanes? Don't Forget Bob
description: To the Editor:

title: All Work, All the Time
description: HALEDON - JUST a few minutes' drive from the skeletal remains of Paterson's industrial past is a well-kept 12-room Victorian whose most conspicuous feature is a second-floor balcony. Were this lovely house on the market today, some real estate agent would tout the balcony's view of Garrett Mountain in the distance. It seems like a fine place to loll away a quiet summer evening, cocktail in hand.

title: Homeland Security Chief Defends Federal Response
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - Michael Chertoff, secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, gave his most detailed explanation to date for the troubled federal response to Hurricane Katrina on Saturday, saying the storm was particularly unpredictable and that the government had not expected large sections of the levees protecting New Orleans to fail.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GARFIELD, FRANCES
description: GARFIELD--Frances. Died August 29 at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Irving William Garfield. Mother of Nina Joan (Alfred) Mattikow of Greenwich, CT, Alan (Marion) Garfield of Manhattan and Southampton and Ronald (Lily) Garfield of Aspen, Colorado. Grandmother of James and April Mattikow, Stacy and Jeffrey Young, David Garfield, Spencer and Tara Garfield, Jason Garfield, Oliver Garfield and Parker Chenoweth. Great-grandmother of Jordyn Bari Young, Ian Davis Mattikow, Sydney Rae Garfield and Daniel Jay Garfield. Grandmother and GreatGrandmother to her extended family, Sheree, Marc, Max, Danielle and Sam Holliday, Erin, Richard and Troy Hellberg, Robyn, Richard, Stephen and Addison Berniker. A consummate New Yorker, she lived a privileged life and availed herself of the rich cultural life of the city. Even as diminished eyesight in her last years forced her to give up her voracious reading habit and twice weekly bridge games, she continued to attend theater, concerts, ballet and museum exhibits. A fiercely independent woman she lived life to the fullest and was always full of life. The family requests that donations in her memory be made to Macular Degeneration Research, 22512 Gateway Center Drive, Clarksburg, MD 20871.

description: DINGLE, Ireland - Everyone knows that it's a long way to Tipperary. But how far is An Daingean?

description: ALL week we've been watching the immersion of a great old city. We imagine another city, less peculiar, will arise in its place. But I have this feeling it will never be quite the same nontoxic gumbo again.

title: Letters
description: Our cover article on the coming oil crisis drew a strong response. Readers emphasized the need to explore alternative sources of energy. And what about the oil in Iraq? The report on Native Americans and wannabes prompted many to raise the issue of choosing your own ethnicity.

description: The wait for ballplayers to develop in the minor leagues has long been likened to baking bread, ripening fruit and percolating coffee. A balanced breakfast, perhaps, but one that after all these years still gives baseball folks heartburn.

description: The stress of contention is over for most of the drivers in Nascar's premier series. After 24 races, beginning in February with the Daytona 500, a majority of the 10-car field for the Chase for the Nextel Cup has been set.

title: For Surrogate's Court in Manhattan
description: The problem of patronage isn't nearly as severe in Manhattan's Surrogate Court as it is in its Brooklyn counterpart, or, for that matter, in Queens. But even in Manhattan, more can be done to avoid the impression that well-connected lawyers have an unfair edge in the competition for fees for acting as executors, guardians and estate administrators.

title: Taking Root in Memories
description: BETWEEN the ages of 6 and 11, I played in an enchanted place guarded by a giant copper beech tree. Its branches rose over the eaves of a rambling house full of hidden corners. Its leaves rustled above a backyard that still slopes and meanders in my memory, past a wisteria-shaded arbor to a tangle of raspberry bushes, beyond a glittering goldfish pond to a dark sweep of hemlocks.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the listed at price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: 'Seize the Fire'
description: At 5.50 on the morning of 21 October 1805, just as dawn was coming up, the look-outs high on the mainmasts of the British fleet spied the enemy, about twelve miles away downwind. They had been tracking them for a day and a night, the body of their force kept carefully over the horizon, not only to prevent the French and Spanish taking fright and running from battle, but to remain upwind, 'keeping the weather gage', holding the trump card with which they would control and direct the battle to come. All night long, British frigates, stationed between the two fleets, had been burning pairs of blue lights, every hour on the hour, as pre-arranged. It was the agreed signal that the enemy was standing to the south, just as was wanted, straight into the jaws of the British guns.

title: School Monitor
description: Q: Children who return to school this week will be returning to segregated schools, with one system for whites and an inferior one for minorities. Or so you argue in your new book, "The Shame of the Nation."

title: 'The People's Tycoon': Driven
description: THE PEOPLE'S TYCOON Henry Ford and the American Century. By Steven Watts. Illustrated. 614 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: In This Beach Town, There's Noticeably Less Fun, and the Homeowners Couldn't Be Happier
description: BELMAR, N.J., Sept. 1 - The beer-stained tabletop beside a rental house on Avenue A sits unused these days. Earlier this summer, it was used by countless college students and young graduates playing beer-pong, a drinking game involving Ping-Pong balls and plastic cups.

description: BAAFULOTO, Gambia, Aug. 29 - The foreigners who would descend on this village from time to time were an odd bunch indeed.

In 2001, when the Jewish Museum of Florida produced and mounted "The Art of Hatred" to explore the issues of discrimination, anti-Semitism and stereotypes, only a few bold museums would show the degenerate art.

title: Jill Soloway: To Tell the Truth
description: HOLLYWOOD - "SOME of you guys are going to boo, but I'm going to say it anyway. I don't like dogs," Jill Soloway declared. She shut her eyes and winced like a schoolyard weakling expecting a punch.

title: Nice
description: WHY GO NOW -- Sun-baked Mediterranean coastline and palm-planted boulevards notwithstanding, Nice, the fifth-largest city in France, has had a somewhat iffy reputation of late, thanks to an elevated crime rate, political corruption and a mayor formerly aligned with the far-right National Front party. There was, for many, the sense that the best days of Henri Matisse's former home were far behind it. Key attractions like the century-old Russian Orthodox Cathdrale de St. Nicolas and the two-century-old oceanfront boardwalk, the English-built Promenade des Anglais, nostalgically recalled the bygone time when Czarist aristocrats and British royals wintered in the area. The city's most glorious Jazz Age hotel, the Palais de la Mditerrane, sat desolate and abandoned along the seaside.

title: Thai With a Twist (and a Crowd) in Mystic
description: RICE SPICE NOODLES is a new Thai restaurant on Route 1 just outside the Mystic train station. It is so tiny, you may miss it. But arrive much past 5 p.m., when the restaurant opens, and you can spot it easily by the clutch of people waiting outside. Rice Spice has been discovered.

title: Iraq to Put Hussein on Trial in 6 Weeks

Born and educated in France, Mr. Crosnier brought his Gallic-inspired culinary ideas to the United States, ultimately serving as the executive chef at Stonehenge in Ridgefield, Conn., before taking over Capriccio last year.

title: Riding Roughshod
description: FOR hikers and birders looking to escape the crowds and cacophony of modern life, Labor Day weekend seems like the perfect time to visit the Fishkill Ridge Conservation Area, a 2,600-acre nature preserve on Mount Beacon and the adjacent Fishkill Ridge. The rugged hills, with their chestnut oak forests and rocky outcrops, provide habitat for such rare fauna as bald eagles, peregrine falcons, timber rattlesnakes and Eastern fence lizards. Sadly, the preserve also has attracted a pernicious invasive species: all-terrain vehicles.

title: UP FRONT
description: This week we present more evidence of how the publishing industry is caught in a tug of war between corporatization and disorganization. The question at hand is what will become of writers' correspondence now that typewritten letters have been eclipsed by e-mail messages. The answer, it turns out, is anyone's guess. E-mail correspondence has created technical, legal and practical headaches unimaginable only a few years ago. In interviews with people across the book business, Rachel Donadio, a writer and editor at the Book Review, discovered that few publishing houses have established policies for archiving their e-mail messages, and not all editors and writers take the time or effort to save theirs. Random House, for instance, "does not have in place a distinct corporate policy for archiving electronic author-publisher correspondence, and we have yet to establish a central electronic archive for housing publishing material," a company spokesman told Donadio. The New Yorker, meanwhile, routinely purges its e-mail messages. Technology experts might caution employees to delete old e-mail correspondence to avoid overwhelming the server, and libel lawyers might advise a similar policy, lest messages be used against a company in court, but what's good news for the corporation is bad news for historians concerned about the future of biography. To find out whether you'll ever read the collected e-mail correspondence of Jonathan Franzen, Rick Moody, Margaret Atwood, Zadie Smith or Salman Rushdie, turn to Page 14. The Editors

title: Why Is This Man Smiling?
description: PHILIP ROTH does not look or act like a man who has just been canonized. He is still among us, and there is still a gleam in his eye. He still tosses off jokes with a rimshot quickness and gift for mimicry that would have guaranteed him -- had the writing career ever fizzled -- top billing as a stand-up act in Vegas. He used to have a great routine, for example, about why Jewish couples keep their sex manuals in the credenza.

title: Blake Continues His Turnaround by Defeating No. 2 Nadal
description: It was a performance that not only a mother could love: full of huge, bold forehands and deep first volleys, of astonishing defense and sportsmanlike behavior. But after James Blake put the finishing but hardly delicate touches on one of the most remarkable upsets of the tennis season, it was not the shot-making and court coverage that made the deepest impression on his mother as she watched from the stands on this crystalline late-summer Saturday at the United States Open.

Their lawsuit over the mess is now headed into a second month, having been mediated by seven judges in three courthouses so far.

description: FISHKIN--Ruth. Died on August 30, 2005, age 97. Preceeded in death by her husband Sidney L. Beloved mother of Arthur F. and wife Jane Paul. Great grandmother to Henry P. and Jeanne Marie, Grant Alexander and Alena Ann, and Sara Janah.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KENNEDY, EUGENE M.
description: KENNEDY--Eugene M. 88, of Westport, MA and Providence, RI, on August 27, 2005. He is survived by his wife, Mary, sons Eugene of NY and John of Geneva, Switzerland, daughters Mary Ellen of Larchmont and Barbara of Scarsdale, and their families. An alumnus of Georgetown and the University of Scranton, he began a lifelong career in the textile machinery business in 1942 at Whitin Machine Works in Whitinsville, MA, retiring in 1985 as president of Whitin Roberts Co. in Charlotte, NC. He was a former president of the American Textile Machinery Association and the Charlotte Textile Club, a director of the North Carolina Textile Association, groundbreaking chairman of Discovery Place in Charlotte, and a past trustee of Old Sturbridge Village. Known as Gene, Dad, Bompa or Uncle Gene, he was devoted to his friends and large extended family who will miss his engaging stories and wry smile.

title: Chirac in good health, doctors say
Before the Sopranos, There Were the Lenape
description: Talk to New Jersey schoolchildren and they can probably tell you that the American Indians who lived here before the colonies existed were known as the Lenape. But the history of these natives, who at one time numbered nearly 10,000, is less well known. We don't know who they were or where they went.

"I'm completely without creativity," she continued, handing me a quarter of a peach she'd doused with crunched peppercorns. "I was cracking pepper earlier and just had to try it with a peach," she said.

description: ON this Labor Day weekend, here's something to think about: New York City's middle class is shrinking. Once a solidly middle-class place, New York has become a city of rich and poor.

title: An Assembly Endorsement
description: The success of the last legislative session in Albany was a vivid example of the power of a frustrated electorate. After a relentless drumbeat of criticism about dysfunctional government, lawmakers responded, as if to make the pounding in their heads go away. The challenge now, of course, is to make the fix-Albany mantra go in one ear and stay there.

title: BEYOND PASS-FAIL
description: When, say, a high school teacher hands out an assignment, it will probably be completed, although the consequences for a delinquent student may not be especially dire if it isn't. But if a federal judge assigns someone to write a paper -- well, that's another matter.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: UTAH SPA SPECIAL -- The Red Mountain Spa in St. George, Utah (about two hours northeast of Las Vegas), specializes in outdoor adventures among stunning red-rock cliffs. From Sept. 8 to Dec. 18, the spa is offering a Fall Playground Package, which starts at $229 a person (normally $265), double occupancy, plus 3.27 percent tax, and includes a $100 resort credit for spa services or special permit hikes. A four-night minimum stay is required. To make reservations, call (800) 407-3002 or go to www.redmountainspa.com. BACK TO THE BEACH For a chance to relax by the water well past Labor Day, consider packages offered by the Crowne Plaza Redondo Beach in California. Bikes at the Beach includes buffet breakfast for two and a half-day bike rental for $199 a night plus 12.1 percent tax (until Dec. 30). With another package, Never on Sunday, guests whose stay includes a Sunday night pay for two nights and receive the Sunday free, also until Dec. 30. The charge is $239 a night plus tax. For details: (800) 368-9760; www.crowneplaza.com/redondobeach.

title: Do You Know What It Means to Lose New Orleans?
description: LA JOLLA, CALIF. - WHAT do people really know about New Orleans?

title: Nine Years in the Life
description: When "Rent" opened in 1996, the mostly unknown actors playing the show's young East Villagers were about the same age as their characters. When six of the eight original stars repeated their roles this year for Chris Columbus's film adaptation, they were playing characters now a decade younger than themselves. "I just believe that had I cast 19- and 21-year-olds in this picture, they wouldn't have brought the emotional weight and resonance that this cast does to these particular roles," Mr. Columbus said. As to why two of the three original female stars, Daphne Rubin-Vega and Fredi Walker-Browne -- two of the three oldest among the eight -- were not invited back for the film, which is to open on Nov. 23, Mr. Columbus said, "I take the film director's Fifth Amendment on that." Here's a look at how the original eight have fared, and how some of them felt about recreating their "Rent" roles -- or not.

title: In Manhattan, Poor Make 2 for Each Dollar to the Rich
description: Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue is only about 60 blocks from the Wagner Houses in East Harlem, but they might as well be light years apart. They epitomize the highest- and lowest-earning census tracts in Manhattan, where the disparity between rich and poor is now greater than in any other county in the country.

title: When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Riding in the Shadows of Saints' by Jana Richman
description: Riding in the Shadows of Saints: A Woman's Story of Motorcycling the Mormon Trail By Jana Richman Crown, 299 pp., $24.95

title: San Antonio Welcomes Saints, but for How Long?
description: SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 3 - As the New Orleans Saints continued their journey as their city's most fortunate refugees, delivered far from Hurricane Katrina's wreckage by a charter flight and housed in a gleaming convention hotel, they could only begin to grasp the coincidences that enveloped their arrival.

title: A Wall Wants Its Greatness Back
description: Point Pleasant Beach - THE Great Wall has come down -- or, at least, part of it.

title: Paperback Row
Noticing Details, Like Opportunity's Knock
description: AFTER Lisa J. Dolan was laid off as an investigator for a law firm in 1996, reconstruction became her focus -- reconstruction of her career, and reconstruction as the theme of the product she would offer in going into business for herself.

title: Shlemiel! Shlemozzle! And Cue the Soprano.
description: LOS ANGELES - SHORTLY before the first onstage rehearsal for the Los Angeles Opera's production of Jacques Offenbach's "Grand Duchess," its director handed out thick packets labeled "Revisions." The singers groaned. The opera had been good enough for 138 years. Did it really need last-minute changes?

title: Life in the Slow Lane
description: ELEANOR STERMAN stepped gingerly onto East 23rd Street, edging along the sidewalk, cane in hand, toward her daily lunch spot. About five feet tall with a crown of white hair, Mrs. Sterman moved steadily westward as taxis sped past toward the F.D.R. Drive and roaring buses disgorged crowds of people who darted around her left and right. Her reading glasses dangled from a cord around her neck, and her tan nylon pocketbook was slung over her shoulder. Her cane jabbed the ground with each step, another few inches closer to her destination.

title: A Dream Ride, Complete With a Gym and a Spa
description: WELCOME to "Extreme Makeover: Commuter Edition." Tonight we're going to explore ways to transform a shabby 30-year-old rail car into a comfortable and attractive place to spend your time as you're whisked into Manhattan.

title: The 9 Habits of Highly Creative Directors
description: ON the sixth day of rehearsal for "Miracle Brothers," a new musical set in 17th-century Brazil, the director, Tina Landau, was talking to her cast about the television show "Miami Vice."

title: Two Gardeners Quite Contrary, And a Plot Unfinished
description: Hastings-on-Hudson - EVERYONE knows Westchester is prized real estate, but the experiences of Helen Barolini, a widow who lives alone in an apartment here, have lent that adage new meaning.

title: Sideways
description: To the Editor:

title: 14 killed in apartment fire near Paris
When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 9 of Arts & Leisure today about the forthcoming film "Brokeback Mountain" misstates the reason it was not included in the Cannes or New York Film Festivals. The film was not submitted to either festival.

title: When Faith and Science Cross Paths
description: To the Editor:

title: Deena Emera and Sherief Meleis
description: Deena Emera, the daughter of Randa and Tarek Emera of Greenbrae, Calif., was married yesterday in Manhattan to Sherief Mahmoud Meleis, a son of Afaf and Mahmoud Meleis of Philadelphia. Omar Lopez, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Ladies Pavilion in Central Park.

title: When a Stroll Becomes Trespassing (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, HERBERT
description: COHEN--Herbert. Bronx native, 65, died after a long and difficult struggle with hydrocephalus. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Cecilia Collins Cohen, and is survived by his adoring children, Dorothy and Emily Cohen. In addition to being a devoted husband and father, Herb was above all a teacher. He served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Ankara, Turkey, a city he returned to twenty years later as a Fulbright Scholar. Herb earned a PhD at the University of Iowa. He enjoyed a twenty-five year career at Arizona State University where his passion for teaching and education inspired countless students, including his daughters, to become teachers. Though friends and family deeply mourn his loss, all are comforted that Herb finally has rejoined the wife and dogs he so greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Hospice of the Valley.

title: China Observes Date of Japan's Surrender
description: BEIJING, Sept. 3 - China commemorated the 60th anniversary of Japan's World War II defeat on Saturday, saying "the just had prevailed against the evil" back then but denying any military ambitions today.

title: Local Star Boosts Tennis Attendance
description: GOOD weather and enthusiastic fan support last week for both Lindsay Davenport and James Blake, a Fairfield High graduate, helped to set attendance records for the Pilot Pen Tennis tournament in New Haven, which drew more than 100,000 fans.

title: Can't Find a Sure Bet? It May Be Time to Spread the Risk
description: WHEN equities are stuck in a rut, as they appear to be now, investors tend to say they are in a stock picker's market. Even if the major indexes are going nowhere, good ideas backed by big bets are supposed to make a portfolio fat.

title: 'Can't Stop Won't Stop'
The Supply Side vs. the Other Side
description: Jude Wanniski, the political economist, journalist and polemicist who coined the term "supply-side economics," died last week -- on the same day that the Census Bureau reported that the poverty rate rose and the median income of Americans fell, even as the economy grew.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 4, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Katrina's Shock to the System
description: DRIVERS waiting in line for hours, and occasionally in vain, to fill up their tanks. Gasoline prices shooting up 50 percent or more overnight. The president urging everyone to curtail driving and conserve energy at home. Dark rumors of hoarding and market manipulation starting to spread. Economists warning that soaring energy costs will certainly slow economic growth -- and maybe snuff it out completely.

title: Plum Island's Fate? Possibilities Abound
description: SIX years ago, when the United States Department of Agriculture broached the possibility of upgrading the research laboratories at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center to study lethal diseases transmitted by animals, most elected officials recoiled and many residents said the risk of deadly viruses' escaping was too great.

title: The Missing Condoms
description: Uganda became Africa's leader in fighting AIDS by waging an all-fronts war. In 1991, 15 percent of Uganda's adults were infected with the virus. Ten years later the figure was 5 percent. Ugandan officials achieved this drop by bringing the disease out into the open and encouraging people to protect themselves. President Yoweri Museveni called the fight "a patriotic duty." The government and a network of citizens' groups promoted abstinence, faithfulness and consistent condom use.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WANTZ, DIANA D.
description: WANTZ--Diana D. The Board of Directors of 950 Park Avenue notes with sadness the death of Diana D. Wantz on August 26th. A longtime resident and Board member, she will be missed for her good judgment, business acumen, and sense of style. Our thoughts are with her daughter Diana, and her son David.

title: A Blue-Ribbon Recovery At Fairgrounds In Hebron
description: DESPITE the efforts of vandals who burned down the main building and drove a dump truck into several others last winter, the Hebron Harvest Fair, one of the state's largest agricultural festivals, will open Thursday through Sunday, as it has for the last 33 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a class at the University of Connecticut in Torrington that features appearances by famous writers living in Litchfield County included an erroneous listing among the participants. Rebecca Miller, a screenwriter and author (who is a daughter of the playwright Arthur Miller), is not part of the program.

title: Millions of Fish Die Because of Oxygen Loss
description: A shortage of oxygen in state waters has killed millions of bunker fish over the last several weeks, officials said. Richard Harris, a scientist and the director of Harbor Watch/River Watch in Westport, which monitors waterways for the State Department of Environmental Protection, said the condition, known as hypoxia, had killed several million bunker fish at the estuary of the Norwalk River.

title: The Breaking Point
description: That Peter Maass could write an article on oil without any mention of the current war in Iraq is stunning. Saudi Arabia notwithstanding, a number of oil-industry observers have called Iraq (with proved reserves of more than 100 million barrels, and perhaps that many yet to be found) the big prize. The Bush administration has failed, thus far, to pay for its Iraq adventure by exploiting this oil resource, but long-term plans are another matter.

title: All About A, And Don't Forget Z
description: "All Star Alphabet," a Sesame Street home video produced by Sony Wonder and Chatsby Films of Peekskill, is scheduled for release in the coming week. Set in a mall, it stars Stephen Colbert, of "The Daily Show," and Nicole Sullivan, of "The King of Queens."

title: The Sub Fight Below the Surface
description: WHEN supporters of the submarine base in Groton fought to keep it open after the Pentagon recommended in May that it close, they attacked on several fronts. They developed detailed briefing books that showed that the region would be devastated economically, that environmental cleanup costs would be enormous, and that the base did not get a fair shake in the Pentagon review.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HELLER, RICHARD, ESQ.
description: HELLER--Richard, Esq. Died on Friday, September 2, 2005. He is survived by his loving wife, Jean Nathan Heller; three children, Bette Heller, Nancy Heller & Evan Krichevsky, Paul & Katharine Burdsall Heller; and four grandchildren, Aliza & Jared Krichevsky, Kyle & Melanie Heller, who are celebrating his long and wonderful life. He was predeceased by a sister, Frances Cahen, and survived by a sister, Phillis Rosenthal. Funeral at Larchmont Temple, Sunday, September 4, at 10 AM. Donations to Anatol & Arthur Charitable Foundation, c/o Dr. Dan Costin, 2 Longview Ave, Ste. 201, White Plains, NY 10601 or Visions, 500 Greenwich St., NY, NY 10013. $(6$)HELLER -- Richard. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member of over 50 years, Richard Heller. We send our sincere condolences to his wife, Jean, and the entire family in their time of sorrow. Steven M. Slaven, President Thomas W. Brock, Secretary

title: Navy Turns to Halliburton for Help on Damaged Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - Facing extensive damage by Hurricane Katrina to naval installations in Mississippi, the Navy turned immediately to the Halliburton Company's KBR subsidiary for tasks like restoring electricity, repairing roofs and clearing debris at bases that are urgently needed for response efforts.

title: For the Whole Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Speculation Grows About Minority or Woman Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - With a second vacancy to fill on the Supreme Court, President Bush is much more likely to turn to a Hispanic candidate like Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales or another minority lawyer or a woman to be his nominee, Republicans and former White House officials said today.

title: His Madeleine, the Cherry Lime Rickey
description: HERB PREMINGER, a courteous, soft-eyed man who lives on East 17th Street in Midwood, Brooklyn, has managed well during his professional life as a marketing writer. But for nearly three decades, his overwhelming passion has been for his work as an amateur historian of the vanished New York candy store.

title: Rosewood Hotels to Offer Guests G.P.S. Guidance
description: Starting this month, Rosewood Hotels & Resorts will offer a high-tech option for finding local attractions: the NaviGuide program. Concierge desks will provide hand-held Global Positioning System devices at three Rosewood properties -- the Carlyle in New York City, and the Mansion on Turtle Creek and Hotel Crescent Court, both in Dallas.

title: Baby Squirrels: A Mystery Solved
description: To the Editor:

title: With Agassi, Experience Trumps a Youthful Heart
description: Tomas Berdych bounced out of his chair at the end of every changeover yesterday and skipped to his side of the court. A 19-year-old from the Czech Republic, he was playing so well it seemed he could hardly wait to hit his next shot.

title: The Peoples Tycoon
Robert Barry Writes A Walk-In Dictionary
description: MONTCLAIR - SEVERAL weeks ago, the internationally renowned conceptual artist Robert Barry was given a rare opportunity: to install an exhibition of his latest work in New Jersey, the state where he has lived for more than 30 years. It wasn't that art museums and commercial galleries in the state weren't aware of his reputation, but rather that he had somehow been overlooked.

title: U.S. Stops Mexico and Gains a Berth
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3 - In most of the United States, what happened here was lost amid the opening weekend of college football and the final major championship of the year in tennis, the United States Open.

title: Pass the Brush: 6 Artists, 1 Vision
description: "ISN'T that where Osama bin Laden is hiding?" an acquaintance asked after I told him that I was reviewing an exhibition of Pakistani contemporary art. I nodded, thinking how news events can color an entire nation in the eyes of the world. It must be exasperating for those who live there, knowing the greater richness and diversity of the society as a whole.

title: Standing Apart by Working Together
description: "ISN'T that where Osama bin Laden is hiding?" an acquaintance remarked after I told him that I was reviewing an exhibition of Pakistani contemporary art. I remembered thinking how news events can color an entire nation in the eyes of the world. It must be exasperating for those who live there, knowing the greater richness and diversity of the society as a whole.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 4 -- Sept. 10; POP/JAZZ
description: Fans of prolific, maverick, self-guided musicians have a tough choice on Tuesday night, when the songwriter JANDEK plays an exceedingly rare live date at ANTHOLOGY FILM ARCHIVES and the Japanese noise improviser MERZBOW headlines the KNITTING FACTORY. Both have released dozens of albums since the 1970's; both have devoted followers who enjoy music that others would consider an endurance test. Where Merzbow has made himself loud and ubiquitous, Jandek has made himself scarce.

title: Tanzania at 15 M.P.H.
description: THE sun is sinking, the air is cooling and our legs are pumping up and down, powering us toward a horizon unbroken by a cellphone tower, a house or even a fence. I'm looking over the bicycle's handlebars at the veld unfurling in front of me -- the baobab trees in bloom, the hawks circling, a miniskyline of anthills rising in the distance, thinking that 15 miles per hour is about the perfect pace to soak this all up.

title: To Live and Ride in L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES - LIFE is good for Rocket, the urban horse. He lives in a wooded neighborhood in one of the most exclusive sections of Los Angeles, Sullivan Canyon, nestled between the Pacific Ocean and the 405 freeway and oblivious to the traffic, sprawl and shopping enclaves around him.

title: Weis Gets His Irish Up, at Expense of Wannstedt's Pitt
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 - Notre Dame 42, Pittsburgh 21

title: The Breaking Point
description: According to your article, the Saudi royal family is supplying funds to institutions "that have fanned the fires of Islamic radicalism." This couldn't possibly be the same Saudi royal family that vacations in Crawford, Tex., and has cookouts with the president, could it? What am I missing here?

title: Not All Swings Are Created Equal
description: Like much of the equipment in Playground 70 on West 70th Street, one of three city playgrounds designed for maximum accessibility, the JennSwing was created with disabled children in mind. The large red plastic contraption, shaped like a reclining bucket seat, has raised sides and two sets of elaborate straps.

description: Correction Appended

description: Correction Appended

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I will never again tell people that help is on the way. It's not coming."
