description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - President Bush said today that he would move quickly to choose a successor to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, whose death gives him a second opportunity to nominate a member of the United States Supreme Court and try to solidify the court's conservative orientation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 9 of Arts & Leisure today about the forthcoming film "Brokeback Mountain" misstates the reason it was not included in the Cannes or New York Film Festivals. The film was not submitted to either festival. (Go to Article)

title: Is That a Smile On Mr. Codey's Face?
description: Being the governor of New Jersey is such a good job that two people are spending staggering amounts of their own money to land it. Neither one, however, seems to be able to get people to like him.

title: NOTED
description: Identity 2005, a convention for companies in the identity-theft-protection business scheduled for later this month in Dana Point, Calif., has announced its keynote speakers.

title: 9 Afghans Killed Ahead of Election; Taliban Are Blamed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 4 - Another election candidate and eight other people were killed in Afghanistan in several attacks, officials said today, blaming Taliban militants.

title: Week 1 of the U.S. Open
description: The first week of play at the United States Open produced some dramatic surprises.

title: A Painter's Progress
description: Images from "Matisse the Master," by Hilary Spurling, show the mature work of a 20th-century master.

title: More Check In, Check Out Reviews
description: A slide show of recently reviewed hotels.

title: Japan's Yaeyama Islands
description: The islands are so spiritually independent that Japanese tourists from the mainland often say visiting is more exotic than going abroad.

title: 'Can't Stop Won't Stop': A Nation of Millions
description: Hip-hop has had 30 years to seep into the national bloodstream, and our cultural guardians have spent much of that time trying to fit the form into musical narratives that stretch from jazz and the blues to rhythm and blues, soul music, funk and rock 'n' roll. Most of these have been well-intentioned efforts -- and, almost without exception, they've gotten the story half-wrong: with hindsight, hip-hop's grab-bag, collage-driven aesthetic looks more like a radical break with the blues-based idioms that dominated popular music in the previous century.

title: For One Teenager, the Party's Over
description: It comes nowhere near capturing the wise, subtle tone of the book it's based on, but "Speak," the story of a teenage girl trying to cope with having been date-raped, is still an effective treatment of a difficult subject, thanks almost entirely to the performance of Kristen Stewart as the young victim.

title: Jockeying for Position Down on the Ranch
description: Watching tonight's episode of "Wildfire" on ABC Family, you'd be hard pressed to figure out that Kris Furillo is the central character.

title: A Heightened Demand for Online Video
description: In the days after Hurricane Katrina landed on the Gulf Coast, the number of visitors watching online video at CNN's Web site surged to record highs. The number of times video was watched last Monday dwarfed an ordinary day's viewing. It also tripled CNN.com's previous record, set on the day of the London subway bombings in July.

title: Hurricane Response Becomes Issue in Mayor's Race
description: Outrage over the federal government's response to Hurricane Katrina has worked its way into New York City's mayoral campaign in recent days, with some of the Democratic candidates using the crisis as a vehicle for broader assertions that Republicans have neglected the poor.

title: Egyptians Are Said to Find Links in 3 Sinai Attacks
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4 - Investigators say they have concluded that three recent attacks in the Sinai Peninsula were all linked -- including the bombings at Taba in October and Sharm el Sheik in July and a smaller attack in August on peacekeepers in the Sinai.

title: Taiwan airline cleared for flights over mainland
Nepal Communists declare cease-fire
Bush might nominate longtime confidant to court
An Austrian 'What if,' With Airplanes, Boats and Neon
description: LINZ, Austria, Sept. 4 - Austrian history did not include a division into two states after World War II, an extensive Allied airlift to a blockaded Vienna, or reunification after the cold war. But to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Austrian State Treaty, which made the nation officially neutral and effectively part of the Western bloc, a multimedia performance on Saturday night on the banks of the Danube River presented this alternate history on a grand scale.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: ABC News Sued Over bin Laden Images

To a Friend in Need, Giambi Proves a Friend Indeed

description: Correction Appended

The Death Of the Chief Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricane Forces New Orleans Newspaper to Face a Daunting Set of Obstacles
description: Jim Amoss, the editor of The Times-Picayune, faced an ugly decision on Tuesday morning. About 240 employees and some members of their families, including one 6-month-old baby, had spent the night in the corridors of the newspaper building at 3800 Howard Avenue in New Orleans, just over a mile northwest of the Superdome.

title: The Pope's Daughter
If Autumn Comes, Can Changes of the Mind Be Far Behind?
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 31 - The Canadian literary critic Northrop Frye might have had a grand time with our Labor Day, if he had put his mind to it. Today, though no season's boundary is being passed, one cultural archetype gives way to another. And Frye cherished archetypes. In his classic book "Anatomy of Criticism" (1957), he argued that all of literature could be divided into four categories, each associated with a particular season that characterizes the work's style, story and structure: to every genre there is a season. Spring is the season of comedy, summer the season of the romance, autumn the season of tragedy and winter the season of satire.

title: The Schrder-Merkel Debate: Experts Say the Conservative Still Leads the Chancellor
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 4 - Germany's conservative leader, Angela Merkel, on Sunday accused Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of saddling the country with record high unemployment and a faltering economy as they met in a televised debate two weeks before the election. Most polls predict that voters will make Mrs. Merkel the first woman in German history to serve as chancellor.

title: A Russian Church Founded to Preserve a Religion Celebrates 75 Years
description: Correction Appended

title: Supreme Court Short List
description: When President Bush was preparing for a possible Supreme Court vacancy last spring, White House officials put together a list of nearly a dozen potential candidates. The names were mostly those of sitting federal appeals court judges, all of whom could be described as conservative, although each would have brought a different political and philosophical profile to the confirmation process.

title: 4 Palestinians Killed in Blast of Home Linked to Hamas
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 5 - Four Palestinians were killed and more than a dozen wounded on today when a powerful explosion destroyed the home of a family closely linked to the Islamic faction Hamas in Gaza City, Palestinian hospital and security officials said.

title: With an Early Practice, Venus Williams Makes a Statement
description: Venus Williams arrived fashionably early for her morning practice session today, as if thumbing her nose at the critics who have suggested her commitment to tennis has suffered as a result of her outside interests.

title: Murdoch's Company Said to Seek Buyout of Partner
description: The News Corporation is in talks to buy out the minority partner in its growing outdoor advertising business in Central and Eastern Europe for an undisclosed sum, a person involved in the venture said on Friday. Since 1999, the media conglomerate's News Outdoor unit has been building a presence in advertising venues like billboards and bus shelters in eight countries that it refers to as "emerging Europe."

title: No Primary. Uh, Probably.
description: City election officials are not sleeping well these days. There's a little thing about a possible last-minute election to worry about.

title: 'Entourage' Chillingly Realistic, Insiders Say
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 - He's down, he's out and now, after a failed coup attempt -- code name "tsetse fly" -- he's last seen trying to save his career while working out of a coffee shop. That is where the HBO series "Entourage" left Ari Gold, the conniving talent agent played with lip-smacking relish by Jeremy Piven, as its second season ended Sunday night.

title: Reporters Turn From Deference to Outrage
description: When even Fox News will not give Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld more than half the screen for his first appearance in the Hurricane Katrina disaster zone, it is clear that television is having a major mood swing.

title: Placing Products, Advertisers Find Room at the Inn
description: The protagonist of Anita Shreve's forthcoming novel "A Wedding in December" is an innkeeper, so, along with garden-variety publicity for the book -- national advertising, book tour, television interviews -- her publisher added another product-placement destination: a bookshelf at the Gillum House Bed & Breakfast in Shinnston, W.Va.

description: A top Ukrainian official said that he had resigned because of widespread corruption in the government of President Viktor Yushchenko.

description: North Mississippi Allstars "Electric Blue Watermelon" (ATO/Sony)

title: New Orleans Police Kill 4 in Shootout
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4 - New Orleans police officers yesterday shot and killed four people and wounded two others who had fired at officers escorting a convoy of contractors across a bridge, the authorities said.

title: Ruth L. Sussman, a State Supreme Court Justice, Dies at 46
description: Ruth Levine Sussman, an acting New York State Supreme Court justice who organized and headed the state system's first Integrated Domestic Violence Court, in the Bronx, died on Aug. 26 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 46.

Arts, Briefly; Video Awards a Big Draw
description: The Aug. 28 broadcast of MTV's Video Music Awards, with Diddy, below, as host, was cable's top-rated show last month. Its audience of 8.01 million, according to Nielsen's estimates, easily beat the No. 2 program of the month, a Nascar Nextel Cup race on TNT on Aug. 21 (6.87 million). Among the Top 20 programs in total viewers were eight episodes of WWE Monday night wrestling, currently on Spike TV but moving to USA in October. In the 18-to-34 demographic, four episodes of MTV's "Real World" ranked in the top six for the month. MTV won that age group in prime time in August, but for the whole day Adult Swim took first place. Among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds in prime time, TNT led the other advertiser-supported cable channels: all four of its original episodes of "The Closer" made the month's Top 20 in total viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Bush Promises to Move Quickly on Chief Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - President Bush said Sunday that he would act quickly to replace Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, whose death late Saturday opened a second vacancy on the Supreme Court and a new front in the ideological battle over the judiciary.

title: Amid Criticism of Federal Efforts, Charges of Racism Are Lodged
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 4 - The devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina became a rallying cry for African-American religious and political leaders here in President Bush's former hometown on Sunday, with pleas for charity mixed with a seething anger at the response to the crisis.

title: For Victims, News About Home Can Come From Strangers Online

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Injured In Shooting Dies
description: A man who was shot in the neck late last month in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section died on Friday at Brookdale Hospital, the police said. The man, Shawaun Shaw, 20, of Brooklyn, and another man were shot on Aug. 24 in a dispute at an apartment complex on Lott Avenue. Eugene Maxwell Jr., 28, also of Brooklyn, was arrested on Friday and charged with assault and attempted murder in the shooting. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: White House Enacts a Plan to Ease Political Damage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - Under the command of President Bush's two senior political advisers, the White House rolled out a plan this weekend to contain the political damage from the administration's response to Hurricane Katrina.

title: Bush picks John Roberts to be chief justice, replacing Rehnquist
Flood Book in High Demand
description: A book about the deadly 1927 flood along the MississippiRiver has become a strong online seller since HurricaneKatrina devastated the Gulf Coast, The AssociatedPress reported. "Rising Tide: The Great MississippiFlood of 1927 and How it Changed America" had risen toNo. 11 on Amazon.com's best-seller list by yesterday afternoon.The book, by a New Orleans resident, John M. Barry, describes the history and politics behind a floodthat killed 1,000 people and displaced 900,000 from Louisianato Illinois. The book's publisher, Simon & Schuster,began to see increased demand last week, and said itwould print an additional 10,000 paperback copies.

title: Return of Former Communists Stirs Up Afghan Elections
description: KHOST, Afghanistan, Aug. 31 - The outriders decorated their motorbikes with sunflowers, and at every stop people tossed flowers at their convoy and offered prayers.

title: Who's a Looter? In Storm's Aftermath, Pictures Kick Up a Different Kind of Tempest
description: Two news photographs ricocheted through the Internet last week and set off a debate about race and the news media in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

title: The Hurricane and Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUNTER, KAREN (NEE SPILKE)
description: HUNTER -- Karen (nee Spilke). Died instantly on September 2, 2005 when the plane she was piloting crashed near Teterboro Airport. Dr. Hunter, a clinical psychologist, had a successful practice in Brooklyn Heights. She was a graduate of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, Antioch College and the Union Theological Seminary before obtaining her Ph.D. She is survived by her beloved daughter, Irene Hunter, of San Diego and New York, and her mother, Marilyn Spilke, of Ardsley-onHudson, her brother Ken Spilke, of Seattle, and her sister Sandy Dea-Jue, of Dobbs Ferry. She will be sorely missed by her family, many friends and patients. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to a charity of your choice. Funeral services will be held today, 10 AM at Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Who Will Care for the National Parks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Painting that hints at past turbulence
The Pendulum of Reporting on Katrina
description: Correction Appended

title: Using Advantage, or Abusing It? Questions on Miller's Bid Persist
description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, called a news conference last week to criticize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority over one of his pet peeves: government waste at taxpayer expense. But Mr. Miller, who is running for mayor, found himself fending off pointed questions from reporters about his own campaign spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNIPE, ANDREW T.
description: KNIPE--Andrew T. There is a saying, "Adversity doesn't build character, it reveals character." This perfectly captures the spirit of our friend and work mate, Andrew T. Knipe, who passed away Saturday after a long battle with ALS, a neurological ailment also know as Lou Gehrig's disease. He was 38. After being diagnosed in 2000, Andy pursued a tireless schedule of speeches, videos and fund-raising efforts for research and patient care. He was always optimistic and positive. Never down or self pitying, he made a point of trying to make sure his friends and family were okay. A remarkable soul. Andy joined the BBDO advertising agency after winning the prestigious Rich Martel Award. He created awardwinning and acclaimed work for many of our clients, including Pepsi, HBO, FedEx and the NJ Devils. At the agency's annual meeting several months ago, Andy was recognized with the Founder's Award. The outpouring of emotion for him as he accepted was overwhelming. Over the past few weeks as Andy's condition worsened, scores of BBDOers reached out to him with hospital visits, notes and emails. He felt our love and support. His brother, Rich, wrote a note to Andy's friends at BBDO the other day: "I would like everyone to please see this as Andy getting out of jail. He was wrongfully accused but served a five year sentence gracefully, productively and with dignity. Although we will all miss him, none of us will miss what that relentless disease did to him. Andrew told many of us that when he dreamt at night, he was always well. Walking, talking and without pain. Now his dreams have become a continual reality." Goodbye from your family at BBDO, Andy, we'll miss you.

title: Just Acting Neighborly, But Finding Itself Full Up
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 4 - Strained by an influx of evacuees without equal in modern American history, Texas struggled on Sunday to house about a quarter-million victims of Hurricane Katrina in shelters and hotel rooms and began organizing an emergency airlift to divert thousands more to other states.

title: Elder Statesman Agassi Reaches U.S. Open Quarterfinals
description: For anyone who recalls the light but steady rain that wreaked havoc on the schedule and competitive integrity of the 2003 United States Open, this year's tournament has been a welcome change. Too hot and humid for comfort in the early days, the temperature has dropped and the skies over the National Tennis Center were again close to cloudless today.

title: Briefly: Putin fires commander of the Russian Navy
Standards of Swing, Tossed Around
description: Capitalizing on the unpretentious strengths of last year's "Magic Hour," Wynton Marsalis has made another small-group record that doesn't mess around. But "Live at the House of Tribes" goes quite a bit further. It's a close, slightly rough-sounding recording, with unerasable audience hollers and claps and talking. The concert was a fund-raiser at a small community theater in the East Village, one of Mr. Marsalis's favorite cultural centers in New York; there were about 50 people in the audience, which made that room crowded on Dec. 15, 2002.

title: Briefly: Floods and landslides from typhoon kill scores
On a Hot and Restless Day, a Hydrant and a Wrench Turn a Block Into a Water Park
description: It was noon one recent weekday in the South Bronx and playing conditions were perfect: 90 degrees, no breeze and a sidewalk like a stovetop. The players -- a roster of men who were hot, bored and mischievous -- lined up behind a fire hydrant on St. Ann's Avenue near 138th Street and shouted in Spanish for a big wrench.

title: Mets End Four-Game Skid
description: MIAMI, Sept. 4 - The first two games of this trip tested Manager Willie Randolph's tactics. He started Victor Zambrano on Friday night, and that did not turn out so well. On Saturday night, Randolph called on a reliever with a funky delivery, Shingo Takatsu, who swiftly turned a two-run Mets lead into a one-run deficit.

title: U.S. Needs a Few More Good Men in Quest for World Cup
description: About 30 minutes after the United States knocked off its archrival, Mexico, 2-0, on Saturday night to clinch its fifth consecutive World Cup berth, midfielder Steve Ralston was talking about a message his coach, Bruce Arena, had delivered.

title: The Price of Fame
description: Fernando Ferrer has spent millions of dollars on his mayoral campaign. It looks as if he'll have to pay about $14,000 more.

title: Arts, Briefly; New CD's This Week
description: The Rolling Stones lead the charge with "A Bigger Bang" (Virgin), boasting 16 tracks ranging from the political "Sweet Neo Con" to the ballad "This Room Is Empty," sung by Keith Richards. Another notable release this week will be Sarah McLachlan's "Bloom" (Arista), featuring dance floor-friendly makeovers of songs from throughout her career remixed by Talvin Singh, Sly & Robbie, Thievery Corporation and others. Joan Baez's "Bowery Songs" (KOCH), recorded live in New York last year, which includes her versions of songs by artists like Steve Earle, Natalie Merchant and Bob Dylan, and "Warnings/Promises" (Capitol), the fifth full-length release from the Scottish band Idlewild, will also be released. So, too, will the North Mississippi Allstars' "Electric Blue Watermelon" (Ato); "Amber Highlights" (Infernal) by Greg Dulli, the former Afghan Whigs frontman; and "Voice" (Sanctuary) by the British chanteuse Alison Moyet, who tackles songs by the likes of Elvis Costello, Bert Bacharach and George Gershwin. GRANTJAMES VARJAS

title: Andruw Jones Quiets Critics While Keeping the Braves in the Race
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 4 - Andruw Jones's six Gold Glove awards have never been enough to deflect the scorn brought by unmet expectations. He was supposed to do more. He was supposed to live up to those two home runs he bashed into the October night sky in Game 1 of the 1996 World Series at Yankee Stadium when he was 19 years old.

title: Flaming Psyches
description: Part art fair, part counterculture sleepover camp, the Burning Man festival in Black Rock Desert, Nev., is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year. The 2005 art theme was "Psyche: The Conscious, the Subconscious and the Unconscious." The Bureau of Land Management estimated that about 35,000 people attended the festival, which ends on Monday.

title: Elections in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid the Ruins, Worshipers Pause to Pray and Receive Messages of Hope
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 4 - As the service started at Mount Zion First Baptist Church, the choir, 30 members strong in flowing green robes, broke into a gospel song that rocked the walls and had parishioners on their feet, swaying and waving their arms in the air. At that moment, a gray-haired man in a black-and-white plaid shirt, tan cargo shorts and black running shoes bounded out of his pew, trying to stifle sobs, and headed outside.

title: Storm Notes: EU and NATO aid asked
Motor racing: Montoya wins while Raikkonen's hopes disintegrate
STORM AND CRISIS
description: ROADBLOCKS FOR MEDICAL AID -- A medical team trying to provide assistance had a hard time doing it in the confusion and bedlam after Hurricane Katrina. PAGE A12

title: Insurgents launch attack on Iraqi Interior Ministry
Theories Created Equal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt's Election Panel to Ignore Court Order on Poll Monitors
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4 - The Egyptian electoral commission said late Saturday night that it would not abide by a court ruling authorizing nongovernmental organizations to monitor the coming election for president, a decision that effectively places the commission above the law and calls into question the integrity of the vote scheduled to take place on Wednesday.

title: The Sister Act Was Anything but Dramatic
description: THE matches are never going to be as compelling as the plot twists and career swings of the Williams family pendulum. No conspiratorial accusations intended, but it seems to be Venus's turn again.

title: In the tsunami region, disbelief at U.S. woes
Chief Justice William Rehnquist
description: Supreme Court justices often evolve in their time on the court, but William Rehnquist held on to his conservative views while the court moved toward him. Chief Justice Rehnquist, who died last weekend, served for 33 years, more than half as chief justice, and in that time he won many victories. But on the biggest issues, he was farther right than the majority of his colleagues. In the end, he never managed to make the Rehnquist court his own.

title: U.S. Appears to Have Avoided Massive Oil Supply Problems
description: As Americans began heading home from the Labor Day weekend, gasoline stations today continued to report spot shortages, but the country appeared, at least as of this afternoon, to have avoided the massive supply problems that some had feared.

title: In Tale of Two Families, a Chasm Between Haves and Have-Nots
description: KENNER, La., Sept. 4 - It was moving day for the families of Gaynell Porretto and Tracy Jackson, the first page of the next chapter in their Hurricane Katrina horror stories.

title: Roundup: Lebedeva captures $1 million jackpot
Robert Denning, 78, Champion of Lavish Dcor, Is Dead
description: Robert Denning, an interior decorator whose lush interpretations of French Victorian dcor became an emblem of corporate-raider tastes in the 1980's, died on Aug. 26 at his home in New York. He was 78.

title: Jockeying for Position Down on the Ranch
description: Watching tonight's episode of "Wildfire" on ABC Family, you'd be hard pressed to figure out that Kris Furillo is the central character.

title: William H. Rehnquist, Architect of Conservative Court, Dies at 80
description: William H. Rehnquist, who died Saturday at the age of 80, almost a year after learning he had thyroid cancer, helped lead a conservative revolution on the Supreme Court during 19 years as chief justice of the United States.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Hallmark) SUPERNOVA -- Zebras are stampeding, dolphins are beaching themselves and fireballs are vaporizing the Western United States. The world is going toend in seven days, just after the sun explodes, and the only person behaving sensibly is a Nobel Prize-winning scientist (Peter Fonda) who heads to a tropical island. However, an astrophysicist (Luke Perry), a government agent (Tia Carrere) and a reporter (Emma Samms, above, with Mr. Fonda) may be able to make a difference.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Saturday about the rivalry between the national soccer teams of the United States and Mexico misstated the number of games they played in the first 50 years of their rivalry, which began in 1934. It was 27, not 25.

description: ZAZULIA--Daniel J. Age 78. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Father of Beth and Todd and grandfather of six.

title: MATCH POINTS
description: Jarkko Nieminen became the first Finnish player in the Open era to advance to the fourth round of the Open with a 6-3, 7-6 (5), 3-6, 6-3 victory over Max Mirnyi. Fernando Verdasco of Spain dispatched Novak Djokovic, 6-1, 4-6, 6-7 (2), 6-4, 6-4, to reach the Round of 16 for the first time in a Grand Slam event. . Nicolas Kiefer, a former Open juniors champion, beat Arnaud Clment, 6-4, 6-7 (5), 6-4, 6-1. David Nalbandian defeated Fernando Gonzalez, 7-5, 6-3, 6-0, in the last match of the day. Karen Crouse

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TYRRELL, WILFRED L.
description: TYRRELL--Wilfred L. Of West Bay Shore, LI, suddenly on September 2, 2005. Beloved husband of Dorothy Tyrrell. Devoted father of Thomas Tyrrell, Timothy and his wife Tara Tyrrell, Rev. Wilfred L. Tyrrell, Jr., S.A. and Doreen Tyrrell. Loving brother of Gerald and his wife Callie Tyrrell and the late Dennis Tyrrell. Cherished grandfather of Justin, Timothy and Ryan Tyrrell. Dear brotherin-law of Irene Farrington. Adored uncle to many nieces and nephews. Wilfred was a proud United States Navy Veteran and retired member of the American Stock Exchange. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy.) Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11 am, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, LI. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Bay Shore, LI. Visiting Sunday & Monday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations in Wilfred's name may be made to the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement, Graymoor, Garrison, NY 10524 or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis TN 38105.

title: Who Will Care for the National Parks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Boom May Continue After Storm, Experts Say
description: Hurricane Katrina destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes, threw at least a million people out of work, disrupted supply lines for businesses and brought misery to untold numbers. Will it also put an end to the housing boom?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWHOUSE, HELAINE L.
description: NEWHOUSE -- Helaine L. Died peacefully, at home, on September 3, 2005. Wife of the late Ross M. Newhouse. Mother of Jeff, Jill and John. Grandmother of Ross P. and Karly Newhouse and Alex Denzler. Companion of Samuel L. Apter for over a quarter of a century. Motherin-law of Barbara Newhouse, Karen Newhouse and Thomas Denzler. Life long friend of Louis Kaufman. Funeral services Tuesday, September 6, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81 Street).

title: Who Will Care for the National Parks?
description: To the Editor:

title: UN members dig in their heels in aid dispute with U.S.
MATCH POINTS
description: Top-seeded Roger Federer's march through the draw looked as if it might take a slight detour when he fell behind, 1-4, in the second-set tie breaker against his boyhood doubles partner, Olivier Rochus of Belgium. But with some timely first serves and swing volleys, Federer went on to take the tie breaker, 8-6, and the match, 6-3, 7-6 (6), 6-2. Federer, the defending champion, will face Nicolas Kiefer of Germany in the fourth round. Christopher Clarey

title: Sports of The Times; A Dirge Now, Please, for Sorrow and Shame
description: THE only pro football team nicknamed for an upbeat spiritual needs a new song. Until now, "When the Saints Go Marchin' In" fit the franchise ever since it joined the National Football League in 1967, but in the days since Hurricane Katrina smashed the levees, maybe you've heard Louis Armstrong's wonderfully sad and scratchy voice singing, "Do you know what it means to miss New Orleans?"

title: His Service Is Vintage, and Some Say the Approach Is, Too
description: For three decades, Robert M. Morgenthau has been the immovable Mount Rushmore of New York law enforcement, complete with beaky profile and granite reputation.

title: High-definition TVs flock to a debutantes' ball
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hurricane Forces New Orleans Newspaper To Face a Daunting Set of Obstacles After the hurricane, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans had to report the biggest story in its history with no electricity, no phone access and no home. With its readers scattered across the South, the paper turned its affiliated Web site, www.nola.com, into a release valve for the accumulating tales of misery from the city, providing news, crucial information and a missing persons forum that now contains more than 17,000 posts. [C1.]

title: CRITICS' CHOICE: NEW CD'S
description: Against Me! "Searching for a Former Clarity" (Fat Wreck Chords)

title: The Dynamic Virtues of Small-Hall Beethoven
description: It usually doesn't take long to hear what makes Bargemusic the perfect chamber music hall, and on Saturday evening that moment occurred when the violinist Mark Peskanov, the cellist Sophie Shao and the pianist Niklas Sivelov began the slow second movement of Beethoven's "Ghost" Trio in D (Op. 70, No. 1). The musicians had just roared through the opening movement with an uncommon ferocity, but having arrived at the slow movement, they pulled back, producing a tightly controlled, intensely focused pianissimo.

title: A Lovely Evening Fades Away With Venus, Not Serena, Rising
description: They switched on the lights at Arthur Ashe Stadium as the sunshine of another gorgeous September afternoon slowly gave ground to the shadows, but the atmosphere in this all-Williams tennis match bore scant resemblance to the bulb-flashing, electrically charged ambiance of their United States Open night finals past.

title: Next Up, Crossover Convertible Coupes
description: MY country cousins used to keep pets of every description, from beetles to burros, on their farm in North Carolina. Their mother tolerated all of these creatures -- except for an opossum.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot
description: A 23-year-old man was fatally shot in front of a three-story apartment building in the Prospect Lefferts Gardens section last night, the police said. The man, who was identified by his relatives as Winfield Jaston, was shot once in the head during a dispute about 10 p.m. outside 23 Winthrop Street, between Flatbush and Bedford Avenues, the relatives said. An aunt of the victim, Altagrace Louis, said her nephew, who lived nearby, had lost an eye after being shot last year. "Maybe the same people were trying to kill him," she said at the scene of last night's shooting. The police said they were still investigating and would not discuss the case. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: A Corner of Kyrgyzstan Has a Cure-All: Let Them Eat Clay
description: NARYN, Kyrgyzstan - High in the Tien Shan Mountains, about 100 miles from the Chinese border on a midsummer day, two Kyrgyz women scoured a sandpit for choice clay. Plucking a clump of dusty earth as if picking fruit from a tree, the younger of the two popped a sample in her mouth, letting the dirt melt on her tongue like a lozenge.

title: In the tsunami region, disbelief over U.S. woes
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Officers Are Suspended
description: Two police officers were suspended after two robbery suspects escaped on Saturday from a station house on West 54th Street, a Police Department spokesman said yesterday. The two police officers, Jose Crillo and Sgt. Jean Martin, his supervisor at the Midtown North station, were suspended without pay pending an internal investigation, the authorities said. The police said that one of the robbery suspects, Tracey Herman, 30, somehow got out of handcuffs as she stood in the station's processing area. Ms. Herman then released the other suspect, Pedro Martinez, 22, from a holding cell, the police said. The two had been arrested hours earlier in connection with the robbery of a man at an automated teller machine near the station house, the police said. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: New Orleans Begins a Search for Its Dead; Violence Persists
description: Correction Appended

title: News Was Surprising to Colleagues on Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - The Supreme Court, having already weathered months of uncertainty about Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's health and ability to remain on the job, now faces a contingency that no one expected: two vacancies with less than a month to go before the opening of the new term.

title: Antidoping Agency Seeks Test for EPO That Is Definitive
description: When a drug test for the banned blood booster EPO was developed by French scientists in 2000, it was hailed as a revolution. For the first time, a potent performance-enhancing drug, which had been abused with impunity in sports like cycling and distance running for nearly a decade, could be detected.

title: INSIDE
description: Hussein Trial to Begin Oct. 19 The Iraqi government said the trial of Saddam Hussein would begin in six weeks, when he and aides face charges of killing almost 150 residents of Dujail after an assassination attempt there in 1982. PAGE A6

title: Working Hard at Nothing All Day
description: Paris - THOREAU deplored the supremacy of work in this way: "It would be glorious to see mankind at leisure for once. It is nothing but work, work, work." Fortunately, there is one day a year in which one celebrates work without going there: Labor Day.

title: WB Network Moves to Attract an Older Audience
description: Correction Appended

title: Chernobyl's After-Effects Not as Dire as Predicted, Report Says
description: Nearly 20 years after the huge nuclear accident in Chernobyl, a new scientific report has found that its after-effects on health and the environment have proved not so dire as scientists had been previously predicted.

title: Indonesian Jet Crash Kills All 117 Aboard
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Sept. 5 - An Indonesian 737 airliner carrying 109 adults, three babies and five crew members crashed soon after takeoff from the northern city of Medan on Monday, slammed into a village and burst into flames.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GORMAN, CLIFF
description: GORMAN--Cliff Oct 13, 1936--Sept 5, 2002 As before and always, to you my love I give my heart. Gayle

title: Redemption in the Bayou
description: People keep making bets against nature, and in the end nature usually wins. This is as true in the rainforests of Central America, where clear-cutting has led to disastrous floods, as it is in the steep California canyons, where people have no business building houses.

Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a meeting between the foreign ministers of Israel and Pakistan described incompletely the state of diplomatic relations between Israel and predominantly Muslim states. It has full diplomatic relations with 10 of the states -- including Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan and Azerbaijan -- not just Jordan, Egypt, Mauritania and Turkey.

Paid Notice: Deaths   PALTER, HARRIET R.
description: PALTER--Harriet R. June 1, 1925-September 1, 2005. Last night, in my arms, you left us to begin a new journey. There never was another like you. 59 years and 7 months we lived, worked and loved together. You were always there for me and I for you. God love you and protect you till eternity. Harriet, as a youngster, was a championship horseback rider, attended the Dalton School, graduated from Miss Semple's classes. She attended NYU and Cornell and later, after her boys were grown, joined me in business and became the color stylist for Bruno Magli Women's Shoes in America. Always a great friend to all; kind, compassionate and helpful. Truly one of a kind. Godspeed and rest in peace, your Buddy. If you wish to make a donation, please send it to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for research on lung cancer. Services are private.

title: Iraq's Kurdish Leader Issues Broadside Against Arab Countries
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 5 - Iraq's Kurdish president, Jalal Talabani, issued a bitter rhetorical broadside against other Arab countries today, saying they had insulted Iraq by not sending diplomats to Baghdad and had not sent condolence letters about the stampede last week in which almost 1,000 Shiite pilgrims were killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITAN, GEORDIE
description: LEVITAN - Geordie. Died peacefully September, 3, 2005, surrounded by her family after a long, courageous battle with cancer. She was the beloved daughter of George and Florence Levitan, mother of Brooke, partner of Warren and sister of Carol, Barbara and Joanne. She was a friend to too many to name, and loved by all who knew her. She will be greatly missed for her beauty, generosity, spirit, wit, fearlessness and honesty. Her service will be held on Tuesday, September 6, 2005, at 10 am, at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd, Larchmont, NY 10538.

title: They're Always on Hand, Not Lending Their Support
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a bachelor and a Democratic mayoral candidate, has attracted the unwavering attention of at least one young woman in this campaign.

title: Inc. Magazine Turns a 9,000-Word Spotlight on Itself
description: A certain type of publication fancies itself engaged in glorious battle and writes about its windmill-tilting with a military diarist's introspection. Inc. magazine, however, with its "how he did it" business success stories and its target readership of cuff-linked entrepreneurs, is not such a publication.

title: With Chirac ailing, Sarkozy campaigns
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Nobody's coming to get us. The secretary has promised. Everybody's promised. They've had press conferences. I'm sick of the press conferences. For God sakes, shut up and send us somebody."

title: Chinese president postpones visit
News analysis: Who do you believe, Lance or France?
Rescuers, Going Door to Door, Find Stubbornness and Silence
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4 - The boat pulled up to the living room window on Read Boulevard early Sunday afternoon, and a volunteer rescuer, Stanley Patrick, began yelling: "Mr. Robert! Mr. Robert! Can you hear me?"

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Younger Vick Begins Tenure With a Victory
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 4 - The much-anticipated and long-delayed beginning of the Marcus Vick era at Virginia Tech arrived Sunday night against North Carolina State at Carter-Finley Stadium.

title: Fox Says U.S. Shares Blame For Problems Along Border
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 4 - President Vicente Fox responded over the weekend to criticism from American authorities about a recent surge in violence and illegal immigration along the border, saying that the United States shares responsibility for the problems and should work harder with Mexico to fix them.

title: Indonesian Plane Crash Kills 104 on Board and 39 on Ground
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 5 - An Indonesian Boeing 737 passenger plane crashed into a crowded neighborhood shortly after takeoff in the northern city of Medan today, killing 104 people aboard and 39 on the ground.

title: The Death of the Chief Justice (2 Letters)

title: Soccer: Ukraine and U.S. head to Germany
LOOKING AHEAD
description: EUROPE HAS ISSUES, TOO -- The European community will open its annual summit with China in Beijing today and with India in New Delhi on Wednesday to consider economic issues with the two Asian giants. The indefatigable British prime minister, Tony Blair, is expected to attend both. Elsewhere, Russian President Vladimir V. Putin plans to meet with Chancellor Gerhard Schrder in Berlin on Thursday. On other fronts, the European Union is expected to propose a new tariff on bananas tomorrow, and the International Monetary Fund will take up the question of Zimbabwe's arrears on Friday. The economically crippled African nation somehow came up with a $120 million payment last week, and though it still owes $174 million, the payment may have been enough to ward off expulsion from the I.M.F. for now.

title: A Major Backfire in Japan Deflates Vodafone's One-Size-Fits-All Strategy
description: TOKYO - Yoko Yakushiji's biggest complaint with her Vodafone cellphone was not just the lack of functions, the expensive bills or the poor signal. It was not even the delays in receiving text messages.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Cite Man At March
description: The authorities detained and cited a man yesterday afternoon during a march protesting the federal government's slow response to the Hurricane Katrina disaster, the police said. Participants in the protest, which was organized by the group World Can't Wait, said about 100 people marched from West 13th Street and Seventh Avenue to Washington Square Park and on to Union Square. Near West 14th Street and Broadway, as marchers overflowed from the sidewalk into the street, witnesses said one man lying down in the road refused a police order to move and had to be lifted by the officers. The man, whose name was not released by the police, was detained and issued a summons for obstructing a roadway, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: The Mountains Called, and New Yorkers Answered
description: DIVINE CORNERS, N.Y., Sept. 3 - It doesn't take much to get the circle up and running. Every morning, shortly after the children have been mercifully spirited away to day camp, Deborah Goldman or Bonnie Keller or perhaps Agi Gruenbaum will drag a rickety folding chair to the shade of the giant white pine, pull out her latest embroidery project and before long, the circle -- a jagged amoeba is more like it -- will come to life with a dozen or more women who make Ganz Bungalows their summer home.

title: Complications for Both Sides in the Battle for the Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - Advocacy groups on the left and the right scrambled Sunday to adjust to what had suddenly become a far more complicated struggle over judicial nominations with the death of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist.

China and Europe Fail to Resolve Dispute Over Textiles
description: BEIJING, Monday, Sept. 5 - China and the European Union failed to resolve a festering dispute over garment shipments after talks in Beijing on Sunday, one day before British Prime Minister Tony Blair is to arrive to lead a summit here.

title: Sculptor Throws a Curve With Slugger's Head
description: When you sculpture heads, as Daniel Edwards does, you never expect an artistic gift like the news that Ted Williams's head had been removed and frozen, along with his separated trunk, at a cryonics laboratory in Arizona.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a meeting between the foreign ministers of Israel and Pakistan described incompletely the state of diplomatic relations between Israel and predominantly Muslim states. It has full diplomatic relations with 10 of the states - including Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan and Azerbaijan - not just Jordan, Egypt, Mauritania and Turkey. (Go to Article)

title: Texas Way Station Offers a First Serving of Hope
description: ORANGE, Tex., Sept. 4 - One after another, the westward-bound buses pull off Interstate 10 and all but collapse at the Texas Travel Information Center here. Their doors sigh open to release the fetid smell of a devastated New Orleans: of urine and waste and mud; of days spent on rooftops, on bridge overpasses, in dark and dangerous concrete behemoths.

description: Number Seventeen is a design studio in New York City. OP-ART: NUMBER SEVENTEEN

title: College Football: Notre Dame rolls over Pitt in battle of new coaches
Grounded Vilma Moves Into His Second Season
description: The legendary running back eyed the young linebacker warily. When Marcus Allen was running toward Canton, first as a Los Angeles Raider and later as a Kansas City Chief, he sized up players like the Jets' Jonathan Vilma in the snap of a football. He could read them faster than the first line of a TV commercial script.

title: Palestinian Legislator Pleads Guilty to Assisting Militant Group
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 - A prominent member of the Palestinian parliament, Husam Khader, pleaded guilty on Sunday in an Israeli military court to charges of assisting an armed Palestinian faction that has carried out many attacks against Israel, the military said.

title: On the Gulf Coast, a Chance to Inspire Is Slipping Away
description: WASHINGTON - When President Bush toured the flattened Point Cadet neighborhood in Biloxi, Miss., to survey the damage from Hurricane Katrina, he was almost literally walking in the footsteps of another president, Richard M. Nixon. In 1969, Mr. Nixon had come to Gulfport, only 10 miles away, in the wake of the terror of Hurricane Camille.

title: Blast Kills Four and Riots Continue in Gaza
description: Four Palestinians were killed and more than a dozen wounded when an explosion destroyed the home of a family closely linked to the Islamic faction Hamas in Gaza City, Palestinian officials said. Neighborhood residents said the blast was apparently caused by explosives that detonated accidentally inside the home.

title: Putin Replaces Navy Chief
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4 - President Vladimir V. Putin shuffled the Russian Navy's high command on Sunday, a move expected after the accident in August in which seven sailors aboard a mini-submarine were saved with other countries' help.

title: Amid Difficulties, Leaders of Labor See Opportunity
description: As they have on past Labor Days, the nation's union leaders are vowing to reverse labor's decline, but that goal is made more difficult this year by the schism in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and by the likelihood that striking mechanics at Northwest Airlines will suffer a bruising defeat.

title: Who Will Care for the National Parks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploiting the Gender Gap
description: Carlsbad, Calif. - NOTHING disturbs working women more than the statistics often mentioned on Labor Day showing that they are paid only 76 cents to men's dollar for the same work. If that were the whole story, it should disturb all of us; like many men, I have two daughters and a wife in the work force.

title: Iraqis set trial datefor Saddam as Oct. 19
Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, ROBERTA
description: SILVERMAN--Roberta. On our birthday. Everyday. Very great love. Barry

title: Standards Of Swing, Tossed Around
description: Capitalizing on the unpretentious strengths of last year's "Magic Hour," Wynton Marsalis has made another small-group record that doesn't mess around. But "Live at the House of Tribes" goes quite a bit further. It's a close, slightly rough-sounding recording, with unerasable audience hollers and claps and talking. The concert was a fund-raiser at a small community theater in the East Village, one of Mr. Marsalis's favorite cultural centers in New York; there were about 50 people in the audience, which made that room crowded on Dec. 15, 2002.

title: In Boat Haven, Soaring Fuel Costs Bring Subtle Changes
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 3 - The necklace of lakes and waterways that surround and flow through this city are giant playgrounds at this time of year as Seattle's short season of sun is ending.

title: Palestinian legislator admits helping attackers

description: FLYNN--Nancy. 9/5/074/15/05. I'll be looking for you in Bergdorf's today. Happy Birthday. Nancy Cristy

title: Mosques Fight Militancy in the Netherlands
description: Three Amsterdam mosques have adopted a code of conduct to fight radicalism, promote democratic values and encourage Muslim clerics to use Dutch. In exchange, the government has pledged to fight discrimination of Muslims.

title: Afghan and U.S. Forces Mount Operation in Southern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 5 - Afghan and American forces mounted an operation into a remote mountainous district of southern Afghanistan in pursuit of a group of insurgents and killed 13 suspected Taliban and detained over 40 people, Afghan and American officials said today.

title: Referee says he played by the rules
With Textbooks, Students Show How Smart They Are
description: IT is easy to hate textbook publishers in September.

title: An Inferno of Vehicles Expands a City's Circle of Suffering
description: ROME, Sept. 4 - On a remarkably pleasant night in early August, Patrizia Dolcini, a 44-year-old hotel worker, was jolted from her sleep by a series of violent explosions just outside her first-floor bedroom window in one of Rome's most upscale areas.

title: Software Strives to Spot Plagiarism Before Publication
description: After a series of damaging newspaper scandals involving plagiarism in recent years, a new piece of software looks to help editors stop wrongdoers before their articles go to print.

title: Excerpts From Eight Decisions That Helped Shape Doctrines
description: In his 33-year tenure on the Supreme Court, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist used the power of judicial review to translate many of his long-held positions into binding precedent. These included an enhanced role for the states and a shrinking of the role of the federal courts by taking them out of the business of running prisons, schools and other institutions of government.

title: Iran Rejects an Ultimatum From Europe
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 4 - Iran on Sunday rejected a call by Europe to halt its nuclear program in two weeks or face possible Security Council penalties, and said it would not give in to what it called bullying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAKEMAN, EDITH HUGHES
description: BLAKEMAN--Edith Hughes. Died peacefully on September 3, 2005, at Long Beach Memorial Center. She adored, and was adored by, Royal, her devoted husband for over 60 years, her caring daughter Carol, who was born at Long Beach Medical Center, her loving granddaughter Jamie Forrest, whose success in business made her very happy, and wonderful son-in-law Rev. Stephen Shick. She will be missed by numerous nephews, nieces and cousins. She was proud of her service in WWII as a parachute rigger in the Coast Guard. She enjoyed a good joke and a good book. She loved flowers and the Mets and she loved to sing. She knew the lyrics of almost every standard song. The song is ended but the melody lingers on, "Dream a Little Dream of Me." Private service.

title: Chaotic Week Leaves Bush Team on Defensive
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - Perhaps not since Richard M. Nixon faced Vietnam-era tumult abroad and at home has an American president had to meet quite the combination of foreign war, domestic tribulations and political division that President Bush now confronts, from the Persian Gulf to the Gulf Coast to Capitol Hill.

title: Police Truck Jumps Curb and Hits Restaurant
description: A police emergency-service truck responding to a call for help yesterday swerved, jumped the curb and plowed into a sidewalk restaurant in Murray Hill in Manhattan, demolishing a large sidewalk planter and pushing two customers and their server up against a wall in a tangle of chairs, tables, plants and soil, according to the police and witnesses.

title: In America's Cup, it's brand that counts at the finish line
Medical Team From Georgia, Trying to Provide Help, Hits Roadblocks Along the Way
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4 - Dr. Jeffrey Orledge and his medical team provided care in New York City after the 2001 terrorist attacks and in Florida last year after Hurricane Ivan. None of that prepared them for the bedlam of the past week, he said on Sunday.

title: Serve Doesn't Protect Dent When He Needs It in a Five-Set Loss to Hewitt
description: Taylor Dent is a serve-and-volley specialist, which even in the best of times is challenging, like being an illusionist in a world of computer graphic artists. Yesterday at the United States Open, Dent might as well have been a magician working with mirrors but no smoke.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEIDELMAN, PHYLLIS
description: SEIDELMAN--Phyllis, Sept. 5, 2001. Dear mother, it's 4 years and we miss you terribly. Love, Ca, Richard & William

title: Not Even Web Retailers Will Be Exempt From the Aftereffects of Katrina
description: AS the Gulf Coast reels from Katrina's devastation, online businesses are struggling to gauge the impact of the possible loss of half a million prospective customers for weeks or months.

title: A Day On
description: Labor Day is a holiday with a declining constituency. Yes, many of us take the day off and consider ourselves entitled to do so, and union members still parade down the main thoroughfares of major cities with politicians leading the way. But it is really a non-labor day, a moment to wonder where the summer went and how the school year will go, to think about the punctuation of our lives. Most years, that feels good enough. But not this year. The summer came to an abrupt end with Hurricane Katrina and the huge destruction along the Gulf Coast.

title: Young Driver Wins and Honors Those in Need
description: FONTANA, Calif., Sept. 4 - Twenty-year-old Kyle Busch became the youngest driver to win a Nascar Nextel Cup race on Sunday night.

description: As his Notre Dame players celebrated with their band and their fans at Heinz Field after Saturday night's 42-21 victory over host Pittsburgh, Charlie Weis might have been expected to stop, gaze and savor his impressive debut as a college football head coach.

description: Bobby Bowden and Joe Paterno are in the twilight of their coaching careers, the end much closer than the beginning.

He is Asadullah Khalid, not Gul Agha Shirzai, Mr. Khalid's predecessor.

title: 15 dead in Paris blaze
Red, White, Blue and Kodachrome
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - Americans are accustomed to looking at the Depression in black and white. But a more vibrant nation appears in an exhibition of 70 color photographs that opens Thursday at the Library of Congress here. Culled from a collection of little-known color images made by photographers from the federal Farm Security Administration and the Office of War Information, the prints bring alive everyday rural life between 1939 and 1943.

description: A vibrant show of photographs that opens Thursday at the Library of Congress brings alive everyday rural life between 1939 and 1943.

title: Conqueror in a War of Virtual Worlds
description: Warner Brothers Interactive Entertainment wanted to make a big splash in the video game world back in March when it introduced Matrix Online, a massively multiplayer online game based on the once-hot film franchise. The game made a big splash all right, like a belly flop.

title: Through Shakespeare, Lessons of Life and Devotion
description: In a fifth-grade classroom in a poor and dangerous part of Los Angeles, Hobart Boulevard Elementary School pupils (mostly Latino and Asian) are doing "Hamlet." They are so good at it that at one point Sir Ian McKellen, who has played Hamlet, Macbeth, Iago, Richard II and Richard III, drops in to watch, to do a little recitation of his own and to praise them.

title: Stunning News of a Tumor Serendipitously Discovered
description: Everything went well at my annual checkup last year until the final few minutes.

title: Bush Has Staunch Defender Amid Critics on Gulf Coast
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 5 - The Bush administration has been stung by criticism of its handling of Hurricane Katrina by anguished Louisiana officials and by nervous Republicans from across the country, but it has one stalwart defender right in the heart of the devastated region -- Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi.

title: Floodwaters recede as levee closed
In Throes of a Diaspora, Two Families Bind
description: CUMMING, Ga., Sept. 4 - Their 4-year-old daughter, Laurel, had complained of missing only two things, Leslie and Jaime Mixon said, since the family evacuated their Louisiana home two days before the storm hit: a playmate and the contents of her dress-up chest, especially a Cinderella costume and a cardboard sword.

title: The Stones' old tricks still work
Hurricane Expected to Cost Government Up to $100 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - The federal government's costs related to Hurricane Katrina could easily approach $100 billion, many times as much as for any other natural disaster or the $21 billion allocated for New York City after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Kosovo President Says He Has Lung Cancer, Raising Doubt Over Talks
description: The president of the United Nations-administered province of Kosovo, Ibrahim Rugova, said yesterday that he was suffering from lung cancer, putting in doubt his participation in negotiations on the future of the region scheduled to begin this fall.

title: You are judged by the company you keep
Bush and the Lightning Nomination
description: To the Editor:

title: Corzine and Forrester Test Campaign Themes, and Bounce a Baby or Two
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5 - After weeks of increasingly hostile engagement in the news media and over the airwaves, United States Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester on Monday plunged into the street-level politics of zeppoles and hot dogs, hand-squeezing and baby-bouncing, testing the themes that they hope will propel them to victory in November in the race to be New Jersey's next governor.

title: Citigroup to sell 230 billion in bonds
Japan elections fixate on 'reform'

description: Hurricane Katrina has been the big leveler in more than the physical sense. Small banks, big stores and international manufacturers were all hit, and all are trying to figure out how to help customers and employees. Like the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have scattered to temporary homes and shelters throughout the South, businesses are also part of the diaspora.

description: COHEN--Herb. Always in our hearts. Your loving sister Judy, her husband Joe and son Paul

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBITZ, JESSE S.
description: LUBITZ--Jesse S., on September 4. Forever loving devoted husband of the late Frances, his childhood sweetheart. Beloved father of Peter, daughter-in-law Heidi. Smitten and adoring grandfather of Harry, George, Audrey and Jack. Treasured friend of many. All will sorely miss him. Services on Tuesday, 11:45, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Class War Runs Through It
description: MISSOULA, MONT. - JAMES COX KENNEDY, the head of Cox Enterprises, the Atlanta media company, was just doing what lots of modern media moguls do when he bought nearly 4,000 acres in Montana's Ruby Valley: transforming remote Western ranchland into a private hunting and fishing retreat, and doing some commendable habitat conservation and restoration work in the process.

title: Vanished, Under Force of Time and an Inconstant Earth
description: Nothing lasts forever.

title: Traumatized by 9/11, Fired Over Drug Rule
description: If anyone seemed an able candidate for the harrowing recovery work at ground zero, it was Firefighter Tom Kelly, a former marine and sandhog who had spent most of his 14-year career pulling people out of fires and accidents.

title: Daniel Ruge, 88, Dies; Cared for Reagan After Shooting
description: Dr. Daniel A. Ruge, the White House physician who made crucial decisions in the care of President Ronald Reagan after he was shot in 1981, died Aug. 30 in Denver. He was 88.

title: Arnold Weinstein, 78, a Poet and Collaborator on Operas, Is Dead
description: Arnold Weinstein, the poet, playwright and librettist who wrote works performed on and off Broadway, taught playwriting at Yale and Columbia, and collaborated with composers from William Bolcom to Henry Threadgill to Philip Glass, died Sunday at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Blake Brings Momentum and Perspective to Match With Agassi
description: Mats Wilander once gave a young James Blake a few pointers on picking up momentum. More than a decade later, the courtship that the Swedish tennis legend facilitated appears to be in full bloom.

title: Union Organizers at Poultry Plants in South Find Newly Sympathetic Ears
description: MORRISTOWN, Tenn. - Hour after hour, Antonia Lopez Paz said, her supervisor at the Koch Foods poultry plant here told women on the deboning line that production demands were so great that they could not go to the bathroom.

title: Asia Adjusting Energy Policies in Move to Curb Demand
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 5 - Governments across Asia are overhauling energy policies in response to high world prices for gasoline and diesel, cutting subsidies and raising local prices in moves that could curb demand and help bring down global prices in the months ahead.

title: Reared in a Pub, by Hector, Ajax and Achilles
description: DENVER - It's 1974, and an 8-year-old boy who is growing up without a father walks into a pub in Manhasset, on Long Island, where his uncle is bartending.

title: Many Helping Hands Offered to Louisiana Orchestra's Players
description: From spare harp strings to violin repairs to a place to live and practice, offers of help from around the country are pouring in to the musicians of the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Indonesian Jet Crashes on Takeoff in Sumatra, Killing 143
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 5 - An Indonesian passenger plane crashed into a crowded neighborhood shortly after takeoff in the northern city of Medan on Monday, killing 104 people aboard and 39 on the ground.

title: Fans' Tough Choice: Agassi or Blake
description: The fist-pumping specter of Jimmy Connors returned to the National Tennis Center as Andre Agassi and James Blake followed the trail into the final eight that Connors blazed on the hardcourts here with more sound, fury and difficulty in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRAIER, ADAM
description: FRAIER - Adam. Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the tragic passing of Adam Fraier, beloved son of Mark, our ritual coordinator, and Sarita Fraier, and dear brother of Rachel. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President

title: STORM AND CRISIS
description: TINIEST SURVIVORS -- Woman's Hospital of Baton Rouge was the clearinghouse for 121 babies rescued from Orleans and Jefferson Parishes last week. Nearly all of the babies were newborns and most were premature. The hospital had not established contact with parents of about 10 of them. PAGE A24

description: AHH, autumn. No more crowded airports, chronically overbooked hotels or highways clogged by minivans filled with vacationers. Is it any wonder that business travelers look forward to the end of summer?

title: A Hospital Takes in the Tiniest of Survivors
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 5 - Jazmyn Anderson yawned and flexed her tiny, rail-thin arms. Weighing 1 pound 41/2 ounces, she is one of the tiniest and frailest of Hurricane Katrina's survivors, airlifted here to Woman's Hospital of Baton Rouge last week from a New Orleans hospital as part of a chaotic evacuation of newborns.

title: Last-Minute Pardon for Electric Toyotas
description: In 1996, General Motors hired Chelsea Sexton to help sell its outside-the-box new electric vehicle, the EV1. One of 13 "E.V. specialists," Ms. Sexton soon became enamored of a car that is still considered the most energy-efficient vehicle to be produced by an American manufacturer.

Like the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have scattered to temporary homes and shelters throughout the South, businesses are also part of the diaspora.

Saints to Play Relocated Game Against Giants on a Monday
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5 - The New Orleans Saints, whose season was thrown into chaos by Hurricane Katrina, will play their relocated home opener at Giants Stadium on Monday, Sept. 19, the N.F.L. announced Monday. The game will begin at 7:30 p.m. and be televised, with the Washington-Dallas game kicking off as scheduled at 9 p.m.

title: Scientists Comb a Ruined Coastline for Clues and Lessons
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 2 - The six-seater Cessna was flying low and slow along the Gulf Coast. Two coastal researchers, straining against their seatbelts, were leaning out a gaping hole where the port side door had been removed, photographing overwashed sand, piles of seagrass and new inlets, the marks left on the region's barrier islands by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Protectionism doesn't work

description: At least 12 more people could be indicted in the government's investigation of questionable tax shelters sold by the accounting firm KPMG, a federal prosecutor said this afternoon.

title: Bush Makes Return Visit; Two Levees Secured
description: As criticism raged over the federal government's response to Hurricane Katrina, President Bush returned to the region yesterday, and Army engineers patched up two levees that had been breached by the storm and cautiously began pumping water out of New Orleans.

title: Roth, still evolving, gets canonized anyway
Residents of a Parish Encountering Lost Dreams
description: METAIRIE, La., Sept. 5 - They parked the van at the water's edge, some three blocks from the house, and plunged into the swamp. Knee-deep, Nils Breckoff dumped his cellphone into a blue plastic tub and hoisted it onto his shoulder. At thigh level, Heather Spicer hesitated, watching her boyfriend's waist disappear a few steps ahead.

title: Business Aviation Show Moved
description: BUSINESS AVIATION SHOW MOVED -- The National Business Aviation Association's annual convention and trade show, which had been scheduled for New Orleans for mid-November, has been relocated to Orlando, Fla., for Nov. 9-13. Last year, the corporate aviation trade show, held in Las Vegas, drew more than 31,000 participants, a record. Orlando was able to accommodate the relocated convention on short notice at the Orange County Convention Center; corporate aircraft will be displayed at nearby Orlando Executive Airport.

title: Dental Health: After a Caesarean Birth, Watch Your Child's Mouth
description: Babies born by Caesarean section appear to be more prone to infection with cavity-causing bacteria than those who pass through the mother's birth canal, new research suggests.

title: Her Hometown Destroyed, a Traveler Turns to a Blog

"I can work pretty much anywhere as long as I bring my laptop," she says on her personal blog, at prncess674.blogspot.com. "I can be ready in 30 minutes to go anywhere, literally anywhere!"

title: Challengers See a Conflict Over Plea Deal and Donations
description: The candidates challenging Charles J. Hynes for Brooklyn district attorney called yesterday for an investigation into some campaign contributions collected by him, based on reports that the district attorney's re-election organization accepted money from people connected to the family of a driver who received a plea-bargain sentence in a fatal 2001 car crash.

title: Katrina and the Gas Pump
description: In Katrina's wake, gasoline prices are rising faster than oil prices -- an odd, but explicable, phenomenon. Enough crude oil is being produced to meet global demand, but the ability of the Gulf Coast's many refineries to turn the oil into gasoline has been devastated, as has the ability to transport the gasoline that does become available. Those supply bottlenecks are chiefly responsible for this past week's higher prices at the pump.

title: Emotions Flare as Coria Beats Massu in Five Sets
description: The fourth-round match yesterday between Nicolas Massu and Guillermo Coria lasted longer than any other at this United States Open. Coria dispatched Massu, 6-4, 2-6, 6-7 (5), 6-2, 6-2, in 4 hours 32 minutes, and it can safely be said the match did not end a minute too soon.

title: Arts, Briefly; Daytime Drama
description: For the week that ended Aug. 26, ABC's daytime drama lineup -- "All My Children," "One Life to Live" and "General Hospital" -- was No. 1 in Nielsen's estimates among women 18 to 49. That was the 33rd week in a row that ABC won the demographic advertisers target on network television during the day, its longest run since June 2000. The ABC soap opera schedule drew an average of 1.1 million 18-to-49-year-old women, with "General Hospital" leading the lineup with an average of 1.2 million viewers. In total viewers for the week, CBS led the rankings, as it usually does, with an average audience of 4.06 million for its daytime dramas. ABC brought in 3.1 million total viewers, and NBC delivered 2.71 million. But NBC, for both that week and for the season, ranks the highest among women 18 to 34. Its two soap operas, "Days of Our Lives" and "Passions," were Nos. 1 and 2, respectively, in the younger age group. KATE AURTHUR

title: John Roberts's Rapid Ascension
description: President Bush surprised many with his swift decision to nominate Judge John Roberts Jr. to be the next chief justice of the United States. If Mr. Bush thought Mr. Roberts had already impressed both the public and the Senate with his intelligence and sincerity, he figured correctly. But if he regards the judge as a known commodity whose confirmation should be a shoo-in, he is wrong. The Senate did not have enough information to make an informed judgment about Mr. Roberts when he was the nominee for just one of the nine seats on the court. Now it simply becomes more important than ever that he be questioned thoroughly about his views.

Gentleman of the Court
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - IN October 1971, the White House tapped Assistant Attorney General William H. Rehnquist to respond to my critique of someone at the top of its short list for one of the two vacancies created by the nearly simultaneous resignations of two justices. I found his tepid apologia underwhelming. Yet within two months, when Mr. Rehnquist took the Supreme Court seat once marked for the target of my critique, I began to see how foolish it would have been to measure him by his defense of a candidate about whom he probably felt lukewarm. While it may be too soon to assess the chief justice's enduring impact, it is not too soon to reflect on why so many who served with him as colleagues, worked for him as law clerks or appeared before him as advocates are already prepared to render a verdict of greatness and to tell the world how deeply his passing is mourned.

title: Leader Says Other Arabs Are Insensitive to Iraq's Plight

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACNAIR, SUSAN
description: MacNAIR--Susan. 1939-2005 The soul of generosity, kindness and warmth, Susan MacNair died on August 31, 2005 after an extended illness. Sue spent most of her adult life in the theatre and film worlds, working closely with such giants as Mike Nichols, Nora Ephron, Edward Vilella, Lauren Bacall and the late Michael Bennett. She served in various production capacities on Mike Nichols' DEATH AND THE MAIDEN, SOCIAL SECURITY and HURLYBURLY, and on the Michael Bennett musicals, SEESAW, A CHORUS LINE and BALLROOM, winning a Tony nomination as a producer of BALLROOM. Her film credits include Monte Hellman's TWO-LANE BLACKTOP and Mike Nichols' SILKWOOD, HEARTBURN, REGARDING HENRY, GILDA RADNER, POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE and WORKING GIRL. Sue had an adventurous spirit and loved more than anything to cook for and travel with her husband, Artie Sicardi. Her family and friends will miss her deeply and wonder how, without Sue's help and guidance, they will know what restaurants to eat at in Rome, where to stay in Maine, where to find the best cheese, pastries, lobsters, bagels, lox and unconditional emotional support. Sue is survived by, her husband, Artie, and Artie's family-Artie, Jr., Drew, Laurie, Melanie and Cody--her mother, Hilda MacNair, and her brother, Duke MacNair, and Duke's family -his wife, Gayle, his son, J.D., and J.D.'s son, Houston. The family will have a private funeral with a memorial service to be announced at a future date. At Sue and Artie's request, please send any gift to Columbia University Lung Cancer Research Fund, in care of Mark B. Stoopler, M.D., 161 Ft. Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032.

Their thrashing, splashing and grunting reverberates all through the night.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Blast Kills Four And Riots Continue
description: Four Palestinians were killed and more than a dozen wounded when an explosion destroyed the home of a family closely linked to the Islamic faction Hamas in Gaza City, Palestinian officials said. Neighborhood residents said the blast was apparently caused by explosives that detonated accidentally inside the home. Also, in the southern city of Khan Yunis, hundreds of unemployed Palestinians demanding jobs clashed for a second day with Palestinian security forces. More than a dozen were injured, including demonstrators and policemen, witnesses said. Since Israel's withdrawal of Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip last month, growing numbers of Palestinians are calling on the Palestinian Authority to provide jobs and restore order. Greg Myre (NYT)

description: ALTMAN--Glen G., age 74, died in New York on September 1, 2005. Loving and devoted wife, mother and grandmother, she is survived by daughter Tracy altman Warner, son-in-law Greg Warner, grand - daughters Haley, Amanda and Brooke Warner, step-daughters Virginia Aaron and Patricia Falkenberg and much loved dogs Max and Minu. Glen lived in New York for over 50 years and was married to Edwin J. Altman for 40 of those years. She missed him desperately following his passing in June 2003. Glen will be well remembered as beautiful, elegant, wise, generous and strong of will. Glen held a Masters in English Literature and loved poetry, classics and philosophy. She taught as a professor of English Lit for some time and subsequently ran a family jewelry business, M.B. Altman Sons. She will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. "Be Thou my vision, O Lord of my Heart; Nought all else to me, save that Thou art-Thou my best thought, by day or by night, Waking or sleeping, Thy presence my Light." Hymn 339. Funeral services on Wednesday, September 7th at 1 p.m. at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue between 91st and 92nd Streets. Viewing will precede at 12:30 p.m. in the chapel. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to The Central Park Conservancy 'Adopt-A-Bench' program, in memory of Glen Altman, 14 East 60th St., New York, NY 10022.

title: Through Shakespeare, Lessons of Life and Devotion
description: In a fifth-grade classroom in a poor and dangerous part of Los Angeles, Hobart Boulevard Elementary School pupils (mostly Latino and Asian) are doing "Hamlet." They are so good at it that at one point Sir Ian McKellen, who has played Hamlet, Macbeth, Iago, Richard II and Richard III, drops in to watch, to do a little recitation of his own and to praise them.

title: Salvaging a New Orleans suburb
Destruction on Peninsula Illustrates Danger of Living at Earth's Edge
description: VENICE, La., Sept. 5 - Before Hurricane Katrina, people around here took pride in living at what they called the end of the world: far from New Orleans in miles and in spirit, at the bottom of a narrow peninsula that juts into the Gulf of Mexico as if in dare.

title: Arts, Briefly; Virgin' Transported Out of Top Spot
description: Audiences were in the mood for a visceral, martial-arts action film during Labor Day weekend: the action sequel "Transporter 2" (Fox), in which Jason Statham, right, reprises his role as an ex-Special Forces operative who foils a kidnapping, opened with a record-breaking $20.2 million in estimated four-day ticket sales, the best Labor Day opening ever (besting "Jeepers Creepers 2" which took in $18.3 million two years ago). "The original 'Transporter' was a huge hit on DVD, and that may have helped propel these strong grosses," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, which tracks box-office sales. "The 40-Year-Old Virgin" (Universal) dropped to No. 2 in its third week but is still holding well with a four-day estimate of $16.6 million, bringing its cumulative sales to $71.9 million. The critically acclaimed international thriller "The Constant Gardener" (Focus Features), directed by Fernando Meirelles ("City of God") and starring Ralph Fiennes and Rachel Weisz, opened impressively at No. 3 with $10.8 million. Holdovers rounded out the top five: "Red Eye" (DreamWorks) took in $9.3 million (bringing its cumulative sales to $45.4 million) and "The Brothers Grimm" (Miramax) collected $7.9 million (cumulative sales: $27.6 million). Over all, the box office is up 15 percent from last weekend. CATHERINE BILLEY

By making a feature film about two young Palestinians who volunteer to become suicide bombers, he risked being accused either of glorifying terrorism or of betraying resistance to the Israeli occupation.
