title: Arts, Briefly; Marvel Launches Film Slate
description: Marvel Enterprises Inc., which has a library of more than 5,000 characters, announced that a $525 million financing deal would make possible the production of 10 films, based on its stable of comic book properties, over the next seven years. In recognition of its newly expanded film production focus, the company will change its name to Marvel Entertainment Inc. The properties for the 10 films to be announced today are Captain America, above; Nick Fury; the Avengers; Black Panther; Ant-Man; Cloak & Dagger; Dr. Strange; Hawkeye; Power Pack; and Shang-Chi. Each film is expected to carry a budget of up to $165 million and a rating no more restrictive than PG-13. Summer 2008 will bring the first theatrical release (it is too early to say which one), followed by two releases each year. Paramount Pictures will be the sole distributor and marketing partner for each film. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: When Auditors Go Astray, What Director Dares Say So?
description: Is the big accounting business too important to be left to the accountants? Or, put another way, why should all the safeguards put in place for normal companies not apply to auditors?

title: Mexican President Haggles Over Pemex Reform
description: President Vicente Fox, right, has vetoed a bill to lighten the heavy tax burden on Petrleos Mexicanos, the state-owned oil monopoly. The president is sending it back to Congress this week with proposed changes. Pemex, as the company is known, pays about two-thirds of its revenue in taxes and accounts for about a third of all government spending. The bill would give Pemex as much as $2.3 billion more money next year for investment. The oil monopoly badly needs more money for exploration as its reserves are dwindling. Although Mr. Fox has supported the basic outline of the reform, his administration, along with state governments, objected to the final version of the bill, arguing that it would strip both the federal government and the states of too much revenue too quickly. Mexico is the second-largest foreign supplier of crude oil to the United States. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT) BUSINESS BRIEFS

title: Hedge Fund Managers Tried to Get Into Movie Business
description: As state and federal authorities pore through documents for Bayou Management, the hedge fund sued by the United States government last week for defrauding investors of at least $300 million, a separate trail indicates that its top managers, operating out of the Bayou offices, were trying to get into the movie business.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - President Bush and Congressional leaders vowed today to find out what went wrong in the federal response to Hurricane Katrina, with Mr. Bush declaring that "bureaucracy's not going to stand in the way of getting the job done for the people." And as Congress reconvened, there were predictions that federal spending on relief would be astronomical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, RENEE ABIKZIR
description: WEISS--Renee Abikzir. Renee Abikzir Weiss was born March 30, 1928 in Alexandria, Egypt to Bechor Abikzir and Jeanne Charbit. She came to the U.S. in 1955. She married Samuel Weiss, the owner of Samuel Weiss & Company (NYC), in 1965. After Samuel passed away, Renee continued to operate SW&C until her death on September 4, 2005 from complications of breast cancer. Renee is survived by her brother, Felix Abikzir of Toronto and her sister, Celine Arenson of Lincoln, NE. She is also survived by the following nieces and nephews: Clem Abikzir and Jeannette (Abikzir) Riber of Toronto; James Arenson of Cedar Rapids, IA, Lucy Arenson Bowers and George Arenson of Lincoln, NE; Bruce Arenson and John Arenson of Naperville, IL, and many grand nieces and grand nephews. Services Tuesday, September 6, 2005, 11AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City. Interment at King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Mosques Fight Militancy
description: Three Amsterdam mosques have adopted a code of conduct to fight radicalism, promote democratic values and encourage Muslim clerics to use Dutch. In exchange, the government has pledged to fight discrimination of Muslims. The mosques began work on the code after the murder in November of the filmmaker Theo van Gogh by a man of Moroccan origin. Mosques that adopt the code will consult with the family of a potential militant, but if such actions do not lead to a change in behavior, the mosques pledge to report the person to the Dutch authorities. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: U.S. Military Attacks Insurgents in Western Iraq

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Arrested In Clinic Shooting
description: A man wanted in connection with the shooting of a woman at a kidney dialysis center in Long Island City was arrested on Monday night after an officer spotted the suspect at a Manhattan subway station, the police said. The police said the man, Wilfred Alston, 64, opened fire at the Western Queens Dialysis Center about 6 p.m., striking Eva Rashid, 41, in the torso. She was listed in stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center yesterday evening, the police said. About five hours after the shooting, Officer Steven Broda saw a man matching a description of the gunman on a video monitor at 40th Street and Eighth Avenue, and he and two other officers arrested Mr. Alston, the police said. Charges were pending yesterday. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Casino Authority Chief Resigns
description: The director of New Jersey's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, Curtis Bashaw, submitted his resignation yesterday. Mr. Bashaw, appointed to the $137,500 a year job last year by former Gov. James E. McGreevey, said he was returning to his business as a real estate developer in Cape May, where he has restored several hotels, including Congress Hall. The authority, in addition to overseeing the redevelopment of Atlantic City, distributes revenue from casino taxes to economic development projects around the state. Mr. Bashaw's resignation is effective Sept. 30. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Kennedy Center Honorees
description: Tony Bennett, Robert Redford, Tina Turner, Suzanne Farrell, below, and Julie Harris were named yesterday to receive this year's Kennedy Center Honors in the performing arts. "We honor five extraordinary American artists whose unique and abundant contributions to our culture have transformed our lives," said Stephen A. Schwarzman, chairman of the center. "Tony Bennett is a brilliant musician and singer's singer whom even the great Frank Sinatra called the best there is; Suzanne Farrell's profound artistry has inspired the creation of masterpieces and is teaching ballet to a new generation; for half a century, the enchanting Julie Harris has been one of this country's most acclaimed and revered actors; Robert Redford is an actor-director whose extraordinary support of independent film has had an immeasurable impact on filmmakers and audiences alike; and Tina Turner's sizzling talent and indomitable spirit has made her one of the world's best-loved entertainers." The honors, in their 28th year, have evolved into a weekend celebration of culture and the arts with receptions at the White House and the State Department. The presentation of the awards for lifetime achievement is to take place at the center on Dec. 4 and be broadcast on CBS later that month. JOHN FILES

title: Next Move in the Mideast (2 Letters)

title: A Zoo With Organic Residents
description: For the school lunchbox, an excursion or a snack with milk, there is a cookie worth considering: Snackimals, excellent animal crackers from Barbara's Bakery in California. They come in wheat-free oat, vanilla and chocolate chip flavors. The ingredients are organic and the cookies come in reclosable 7 1/2-ounce sacks as well as single-serving pouches with 2 1/8 ounces. The camels, elephants, bears and tigers are nondairy, vegan and kosher. The cookies are sold in natural and health food stores for around $4 for the big package, 89 cents for the small. FOOD STUFF

title: Apple Unveils Cellphone Music Player and Smaller IPod
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 - Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple Computer, attempted today to extend his dominance of the digital music marketplace, introducing a cellphone music player in partnership with Motorola and Cingular, as well as a smaller iPod dubbed the Nano.

title: Next Move in the Mideast

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Posts Sharply Higher Profit
description: AXA, Europe's second-largest insurer after Allianz, said profit increased 31 percent in the first half of the year as rising share prices helped sales of life policies and savings plans pegged to market performance. Net income rose to 2.27 billion euros ($2.83 billion) from 1.73 billion euros a year earlier, the company said.

title: Act on volatility, Stiglitz urges Asia
Same Sex Marriage Wins Vote in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 - California lawmakers on Tuesday became the first in the country to legalize same-sex marriage, with the State Assembly narrowly approving a bill that defines marriage as between "two persons" instead of between a man and a woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWIFT, RUTH
description: SWIFT--Ruth. The Board and members of Reuth are deeply saddened by the death of our dear, longtime friend, Ruth Swift. Her refined and gentle manner coupled with her passionate support of our cause and activities will be sorely missed. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ursula Merkin, Chair Rosa Strygler, President

title: Composition of a Comet Poses a Puzzle for Scientists
description: Although comets form at the frigid edges of the solar system, they appear somehow to contain minerals that form only in the presence of liquid water, and at much warmer temperatures, scientists are reporting today.

title: Wines That Say 'Yes' to Cassoulet and Braised Duck
description: LANGUEDOC, the region in southwestern France, got its name from the Medieval French spoken there, the langue d'oc, or the language of oc.

title: Pressure Is on Gordon in Chase
description: Jeff Gordon, the four-time Nascar champion, is running out of time. The field for the Chase for the Nextel Cup will be set after the Chevy Rock & Roll 400 at Richmond International Raceway on Saturday night. Gordon trails Jamie McMurray by 30 points and Ryan Newman by 29 in the battle for the 10th and final spot in the Chase. The pressure falls on the entire team, including Robbie Loomis, who replaced Ray Evernham as crew chief in 2000 and helped Gordon to his fourth title in 2001. Gordon's decline has led to speculation about Loomis's future with the team. "If it's up to me, yeah, I'd love to have him as my crew chief," Gordon said yesterday during a teleconference. "He's trying to decide right now what his plans are. It has nothing to do with our performance this year." Viv Bernstein

title: Born Into Popular Music, Weaned on Opera
description: The pop singer and songwriter Rufus Wainwright knows that many of his fans are surprised to learn that he is an avowed opera buff. Yet the term "buff" does not tell the half of it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: As Pump Prices for Gasoline Begin to Fall, Some Step Up Calls for Government Action Gasoline prices at the pump fell for the first time since Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast, suggesting that fuel costs, while still high, are leveling off. But even as the surge in prices appeared to be easing, policy makers and consumer groups nationwide increased calls for a host of government interventions to punish profiteers, reduce gas taxes and institute price caps. [Page C1.]

Asian states move to curb demand for oil

The Tablecloths Are White, and So Are Most Faces
description: WITH summer drawing to a close New York diners will soon begin their fall migration back to the city's top restaurants. But if they fly to pattern, only a few blacks, at most, will join the flock.

title: Saudis Kill Top Militant, Ending Skirmish With a Qaeda Cell
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 6 - Saudi security forces finally overwhelmed a cell of militants holed up in a house in the Persian Gulf city of Dammam on Tuesday, ending a three-day siege. The bloody firefight was the latest in a string of confrontations between militants and security forces throughout the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVENSON, PAUL
description: LEVENSON--Paul. The family of Paul Levenson mourns his passing on September 6, 2005 after a valiant battle with cancer. He was an incredible husband and father, and a loving son, brother, cousin and friend. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in Paul's name to Montefiore Women's Center. Att: April Grossman, 3320 Rochambeau Ave, Bronx, NY 10467.

title: Autopsy Says Lineman Had Heart Disease
description: Heart disease caused the death of San Francisco 49ers offensive lineman Thomas Herrion after an exhibition game against the Broncos, the Denver medical examiner's office said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran Nuclear Weapon Years Off, British Researchers Say
description: A leading British research institute said that Iran was at least five years away from producing sufficient material for "a single nuclear weapon," and that it could make one only if it chose to ignore international reaction and "throw caution to the wind." The researchers, at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, said the conclusions had been based on public sources of information. "Nevertheless," the institute's director, John Chipman, said, "there remains a good deal that cannot be known for certain from the outside." The new report broadly concurs with one completed in May by American intelligence agencies, which concluded that Iran was not expected to build a nuclear weapon before the next decade.

title: Bush Promises to Seek Answers to Failures of Hurricane Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - Under relentless political fire over the federal response to Hurricane Katrina, President Bush on Tuesday tried to steer the public debate toward progress in the region, promising to investigate earlier stumbles, as anxious lawmakers returned to the Capitol pledging inquiries of their own and aid money for the storm victims.

title: Endesa rejects Gas Natural bid
Second thoughts for Armstrong?
Addicted to oil; Serb illusions
Stocks: Service sector data help Wall St. turn positive
Chirac's Illness Remains a Mystery, Despite Official Details
description: PARIS, Sept. 6 - After a series of minimalist medical bulletins describing President Jacques Chirac's stay in a Paris hospital, it is still a public mystery what kind of neurological malady has befallen him, although French military doctors at this point certainly know the diagnosis, independent experts said.

title: In Asia, Low Fuel Prices and Subsidies Lose Ground
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 5 - Governments across Asia are overhauling energy policies in response to high world prices for gasoline and diesel, cutting subsidies and raising local prices in moves that could curb demand and help bring down global prices in the months ahead.

title: Miller Suffers a Setback Over Expenses
description: In a setback for the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, the New York City Campaign Finance Board ruled yesterday that a part of the expenses that his mayoral campaign hoped would be exempt from campaign spending limits would indeed count against those restrictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANZ, SAMUEL
description: FRANZ--Samuel. We mourn the tragic passing of Sam and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Marilyn, sons Marc (Laurie), Peter (Marcy) and Eric (Aviva), grandchildren and sister, Sydelle. Sam was truly a family man, funny, warm, loving and kind. We will love and miss him always. Ellen and George, Lisa and Andy, Nancy and Rick

title: Lethal Fire Heightens Egyptians' Anger at Government
description: BENI SUEF, Egypt, Sept. 6 - When a candle used as a prop was tipped over in a small one-room theater here on Monday night, the place was packed -- 200 people were inside -- and the side exit had been bolted shut. Fire blasted through the room, chewing through the ceiling, carpeting and paper decorations, killing 32 people, some of whom never got out of their seats, and injuring 60 others.

title: Haunted by Hesitation
description: WASHINGTON - It took a while, but the president finally figured out a response to the destruction of New Orleans.

title: Officials Try to Assess Damage to Barrier Islands Off New Orleans
description: BATON ROUGE, Sept. 7 - The barrier islands that guard and beautify coastal Louisiana have suffered noticeable damage due to Hurricane Katrina, but officials say it could have been significantly worse.

How to Make Cheese Feel at Home
description: "Cheese: A Connoisseur's Guide to the World's Best" by Max McCalman and David Gibbons (Clarkson Potter, $32.50) is an explorer's guide to the cream of the crop. This authoritative volume offers profiles, with alluring photographs, of nearly 180 cheeses from 13 countries; particularly tempting rarities come from Switzerland and the United States. The book offers advice on how to evaluate cheeses, using all senses except hearing; how to buy and store them, with sound counsel to purchase just enough for immediate consumption because the home refrigerator provides an "inhospitable" environment for most cheeses; and how to pair cheeses with wines. FOOD STUFF

description: IT happened one fateful night in Bette's young and thus far elegant life, that set piece of affront and appeasement played time and again in New York's better restaurants.

title: A Tutor Half a World Away, but as Close as a Keyboard
description: COCHIN, India - A few minutes before 7 on a recent morning, Greeshma Salin swiveled her chair to face the computer, slipped on her headset and said in faintly accented English, "Hello, Daniela." Seconds later she heard the response, "Hello, Greeshma."

description: MORAN--John J., 88, retired Vice President and Treasurer of Heublein, Inc. died Saturday, August 27, 2005. The funeral will be Friday, September 9, 2005, at The DillonBaxter Funeral Home, 1276 Berlin Tpke. of Wethersfield, CT. Donations: McLean Foundation, 75 Great Pond Road, Simsbury, CT. 06070.

description: Mats Wilander once gave a young James Blake a few pointers on picking up momentum. More than a decade later, the courtship facilitated by Wilander is in full bloom.

Hussein Confessed to Massacre Order, Iraqi President Says
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 6 - The deposed Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein has confessed to crimes in meetings with investigators for the special tribunal that will try him later this year, President Jalal Talabani said in a televised interview Tuesday night. But a lawyer for Mr. Hussein's family dismissed the statement as a "fabrication."

title: Parental Supervision Required
description: Philadelphia - IN 1989, when I was 13 and living in Cincinnati, I waged a one-girl campaign to persuade my mother and father to let me attend Groton School in Massachusetts. Despite my parents' ambivalence about boarding school, they ultimately acquiesced, I went, and I received a very good education -- not all of it academic. More than a decade later, I couldn't resist setting my first novel at a boarding school. Now at readings, I'm asked if I'd send my own child away to school, and I say no.

title: Gas Prices at Pumps Show Signs of Easing
description: Gasoline prices at the pump inched lower yesterday for the first time since Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast last week, suggesting that fuel costs, while still high, are leveling off and may not lead to as severe an energy shock as once feared.

title: CALENDAR
description: Oysters for Future Chefs

title: 60 + New Restaurants
description: The meatpacking district is expanding. Hotel restaurants show tremendous vitality. There will be more sushi than ever. This is a snapshot of New York's new restaurant scene for this fall and beyond. The count of new restaurants is more than 60. Most are at new sites, not replacing failures, and they will add more than 5,000 seats to a city that already has at least a million.

title: Retailers Say Europe Gave Incentives to Win China Deal
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 6 - Leading European retailers accused the European Union on Tuesday of granting some textile-producing nations special incentives to win their backing in negotiations with China to unblock piles of garments impounded at Europe's borders.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: WPP Buys Hong Kong Agency
description: The WPP Group, the second-largest advertising company after Omnicom, has bought iPR Asia Ltd. of Hong Kong as part of its plans to increase total 2005 sales in that city, China and Taiwan to $400 million, the chief executive, Martin Sorrell, said. The companies did not release terms of the deal.

title: Saddam should be executed "20 times a day," Iraqi president says
Our Choice for Public Advocate
description: The office of the public advocate is an enigma in New York City government. Created in the City Charter revision of 1990, it lacks real power and a mandate, beyond a vague description of the public advocate as an "ombudsman" who monitors city services. The advocate is nonetheless the second-highest-ranking city official and the first in line to succeed the mayor, albeit temporarily, in an emergency. There is no template for doing the job, but New Yorkers should expect their public advocate to be experienced, independent and resourceful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIES, RICHARD A.

title: United Seeks to Revive Itself, While Delta Cuts Back Further
description: Two of the nation's troubled airlines moved in opposite directions today in dealing with their financial health, as United offered a plan that it hoped would lead it out of bankruptcy, while Delta took steps that could precede its own bankruptcy filing.

description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; TV's Ho-Hum Labor Day
description: In Nielsen's estimates for Labor Day, ABC won among adults 18 to 49, CBS led by a sliver in total viewers and the two networks tied in households. On the slow holiday night, ABC's primetime hours were given over to a broadcast of a college football game, Florida State's low-scoring victory over Miami. CBS's Monday lineup was all repeats, and drew an average of 9.65 million viewers. It featured the most-watched program of the night, the 9:30 p.m. rerun of "Two and a Half Men," which delivered an audience of 11.22 million. During the 9 p.m. hour, Fox broadcast the second episode of its new drama, "Prison Break," which attracted an audience of 10.5 million to its premiere last week. This Monday, 8.47 million viewers watched the jailbreak adventure series. KATE AURTHUR

title: Urban Evacuees Find Themselves Among Rural Mountains
description: CASS, Ark., Sept. 5 - Lovers of the rural life in the Ozark Mountains of northwestern Arkansas would no doubt appreciate Baptist Vista Encampment, a rustic summer retreat on a long, winding dirt road here. But for the 150 hurricane evacuees who arrived just before dark on Monday, having been told almost nothing about where they were going or how long they would stay, the emotions were more complicated.

title: Remembering Help Received After Sept. 11, New York Sends Officers to Louisiana
description: HARAHAN, La., Sept. 6 - Some New York City police officers who arrived here over the last few days were serving on the front lines of a national crisis for a second time. They had been there, too, when the attack on the World Trade Center, a man-made disaster, took the lives of 23 members of their department.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Boy Hurt In Fall
description: A 3-year-old boy suffered serious injuries yesterday after he fell out of a third-story window and a first-floor awning broke his fall, the police and the boy's father said. The boy fell shortly after 1 p.m. from his apartment at 80-38 138th Street. The window did not appear to have a window guard. He was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, and was listed in serious condition yesterday. "It's a complete accident," said Tom Lyons, the boy's father. "Thank God he hit the awning." He said the boy's mother had left him alone for a moment to speak with her doctor on the phone. "Next thing she knows, she hears a scream," he said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: President Bush's Remarks at the Funeral of Chief Justice Rehnquist
description: PRESIDENT BUSH: Jim and Janet and Nancy; members of the Rehnquist family; colleagues of the Chief Justice. This afternoon the people of the United States mourn the passing of the leader of a branch of the government, the eight Justices of the Court pay final homage to their Chief and friend, and a loving family bids farewell to a kind and gentle soul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORTON, MARTIN S.
description: NORTON--Martin S. His family at A La Vieille Russie mourns his loss profoundly. We will miss his sense of humor, wise counsel, warmth, generosity and sincere friendship over more than 60 years. We join many others in sending love and sincerest condolences to his family. Peter, Paul, and Mark Schaffer

title: The Nine Candidates for Manhattan Borough President and What They Have to Say
description: The Manhattan borough president's race has drawn a large field of candidates for the Democratic primary, nine in all. In their campaigns many of the candidates have tried to appeal to certain slices of the electorate to build enough of a base to obtain victory, since only a plurality of the vote is needed, and since there is no provision for a runoff, a candidate can theoretically win with a small percentage of the vote. Following are the candidates running in the primary.

description: LONDON, Sept. 6 - A leading British research institute said Tuesday that Iran was at least five years away from producing sufficient material for "a single nuclear weapon," and that it could make one only if it chose to ignore international reaction and "throw caution to the wind."

title: Horace W. Davenport, 92, Dies; Pioneered Ulcer Treatments
description: Horace W. Davenport, a physiologist and educator at the University of Michigan who laid a foundation for more effective ulcer treatments by revealing how gastric acid works in digestion without consuming the stomach itself, died Aug. 29 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 92. The cause was complications of pneumonia, his family said.

title: Lines for Gas Are Harbinger of Shattered Coast's Recovery
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 6 - It would be absurd to look at the ruins along the coast of Mississippi and say that things are getting back to normal.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the Notre Dame student who was one of the earliest to sound the alarm about the potential threat to New Orleans from Hurricane Katrina misstated the name of his dog. It is Robbie, not Becky. A correction in this space yesterday misspelled the student's given name. He is Brendan Loy, not Brendon.

title: Off the Menu
description: GABRIELLA'S A larger version of this Upper West Side Mexican mainstay is to open in January. The original restaurant at 93rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue closed last week; its branch at 75th and Amsterdam Avenue closed in May: 688 Columbus Avenue (93rd Street). The Double Seven Sasha Petraske's cocktails at this new lounge are designed to complement the chocolates by Debauve & Gallais that are served alongside: 418 West 14th Street; (212)981-9099.

title: Bush Asks for $51.8 Billion in Relief Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - President Bush asked Congress today to approve an additional $51.8 billion to help the Gulf Coast region recover from the catastrophic hurricane and floods, and Congressional leaders promised quick action to get aid to those who need it.

title: Agreement, and Argument, on Gubernatorial Debates
description: TRENTON, Sept. 6 - Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester said on Tuesday that they had agreed to several debates this fall in their contentious race for governor.

title: Auriemma Not Likely to Leave
description: Geno Auriemma's generous contract with the University of Connecticut would make it difficult for him to leave the university to coach the W.N.B.A.'s Phoenix Mercury, according to a person close to the UConn program. Seth Sulka, the Mercury's general manager, said Monday that he expected to talk to Auriemma in the next few days to discuss the job opening.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the outlook for New Orleans restaurants after the hurricane omitted part of the Web site for the Southern Foodways Alliance, which is among the groups working on a job bank for displaced workers. It is www.southernfoodways.com.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the Notre Dame student who was one of the earliest to sound the alarm about the potential threat to New Orleans from Hurricane Katrina misstated the name of his dog. It is Robbie, not Becky. A correction in this space yesterday misspelled the student's given name. He is Brendan Loy, not Brendon.

title: Yankees Fall to Dreaded Devil Rays
description: As much as the Yankees would like to see the bigger picture, as optimistic as they might be about their playoff chances with three weeks left in the season, the $200 million team from the Bronx might have to cite a last-place team from Florida as one reason their season did not go according to plan.

title: Feasting On Summer's Last Herbs
description: THE incredible abundance of herbs that appears at the end of summer finds its way to all of us, not just to gardeners. For once, herbs are plentiful, good and inexpensive at farmers' markets. And these days even supermarkets have bunches of locally grown specimens.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KEMPNER, NAN S.

title: Osama and Katrina
description: On the day after 9/11, I was in Jerusalem and was interviewed by Israeli TV. The reporter asked me, "Do you think the Bush administration is up to responding to this attack?" As best I can recall, I answered: "Absolutely. One thing I can assure you about these guys is that they know how to pull the trigger."

title: Rivals End Dispute Over Radio Tag Patents

title: The Ancestors Knew Good Pork
description: Rich pork from heirloom Berkshire pigs, often called Kurobuta, is luscious when hot from the grill or frying pan. And when lightly smoked, the ham makes a superb addition to a plate of charcuterie or a simple sandwich made with dark or rye bread with lashings of good mustard. Consider it for weekend breakfasts with eggs or, once the weather cools, warmed on a bed of tender lentils with a splash of green sauce or tucked among the sausages, bacon and sauerkraut in a choucroute garnie. Fairway sells it boneless, $11.16 a pound, or on the bone, $9.96 a pound, sliced or unsliced. There is a 10 percent discount for whole hams, 10 to 12 pounds with bone, 8 to 10 pounds boneless. description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 6 - Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden trudged into a conference room Tuesday with bags under his eyes, slippers on his feet and a serious question.

title: Going Modern While Looking Colonial
description: CHESTER, N.J. - This borough of 1,600 people in western Morris County is about 45 miles from Manhattan and a world away. It has Colonial roots and a rural small-town character, and it wants to stay that way.

title: Car Bomb Kills 16 Iraqis at Basra Restaurant
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 7 - A taxi packed with explosives detonated outside a crowded restaurant this evening in the southern city of Basra, killing 16 Iraqis and injuring two dozen, hours after a bomb killed four American contractors in the same city.

title: E-retailers can't avoid storm fallout
Barbara Bush Calls Evacuees Better Off
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - As President Bush battled criticism over the response to Hurricane Katrina, his mother declared it a success for evacuees who "were underprivileged anyway," saying on Monday that many of the poor people she had seen while touring a Houston relocation site were faring better than before the storm hit.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Federer Finds Dents in His Armor
description: Nicolas Kiefer, who has faced Roger Federer enough lately to know, said that when it came to tennis and Federer, "We're on earth, but he's playing on a different planet."

title: Morgan Director Resigns, a Sign That a Reorganization Is Likely
description: Michael A. Miles, a Morgan Stanley director with close ties to the former chief executive, Philip J. Purcell, has resigned from the board, the bank said yesterday.

title: Skip the City: He'll Take New Jersey
description: HOW many New Yorkers making their way along the walkways and bike paths that line the Hudson River look out over the water to Weehawken or Tenafly and are inspired, suddenly, to think about food? However physically close, New Jersey is galaxies away in the provincial culinary imagination of the Manhattanite, an imagination that has made little room for the possibility of someone like Nicholas Harary and his ginger-plum pork belly.

Are Devil Rays Tired of Their Manager?

U.S. to Widen Inquiry of KPMG Tax Shelters
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they planned to file new charges and name as many as a dozen new defendants in their investigation of questionable tax shelters sold by the accounting firm KPMG.

title: Briefly: Israel expands plans for West Bank housing
Putting Down New Roots on More Solid Ground
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 6 - In her 19 years, all spent living in downtown New Orleans, Chavon Allen had never ventured farther than her bus fare would allow, and that was one trip last year to Baton Rouge. But now that she has seen Houston, she is planning to stay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, HERB
description: COHEN--Herb. Always in our hearts. Your loving sister Judy, her husband Joe and son Paul

title: A Screenwriter Shoots His Own Unproduced Scripts, With a Gun
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 - In the dim light of a shooting range, a figure clad in black baggy trousers and a black T-shirt is carefully loading a .45-caliber pistol. He adjusts his glasses, plants his feet and aims straight ahead.

title: A Standout Teacher Who Also Stands Out
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va. - MS. RAY stayed. Twenty-three years, Irene Ray has been teaching at Huntington High, in this small city near the Kentucky border, and once again she was back, for another first day of school. "They changed the hall-pass system again," she said, leafing through a stack of first-day memos with titles like "Asbestos Notification Form." It was 7:15, and she was rushing. "They're going back to the way they did it five years ago."

title: Katrina's world
Congress clears Arroyo of charges
Federal Agencies Struggle to Send Aid and Benefits to Victims
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 7 - The lines for public assistance here are so long that the Salvation Army and other charities have begun feeding people twice a day - lunch and dinner - while they wait, as day turns into night, to apply for food stamps.

title: In Baton Rouge, a Tingeof Evacuee Backlash
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 6 - Last week came the rumors -- of riots at Wal-Marts, of break-ins at homes, of drug gangs from New Orleans roaming the streets of its more sedate neighbor 75 miles up Interstate 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRINELL, RICHARD, MD.
description: GRINELL--Richard, MD. On September 5, 2005. Podiatrist for over 60 years. Beloved husband of Joan. Dear father of Barbara and Sheila. Cherished grandfather of Michael. Loving brother of Herbert. Services Wednesday 2 PM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to a charity of choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the WB Network's efforts to attract somewhat older viewers misstated its losses. Analysts estimate them to be $25 million to $50 million for 2004, with a similar number projected for 2005. (The estimates of $650 million to $750 million for each year are for revenues.)

title: 'Dr. Death' Inquiry Resumes in Australia
description: Only days after being shut down, an inquiry was revived into allegations that Jayant Patel, an American-trained surgeon, was responsible for the deaths of more than 80 patients in Queensland. The state premier appointed a new head of the inquiry under pressure from the victims' relatives. The previous head was disqualified after a state court ruled last Friday that he was biased against hospital officials. Dr. Patel, called "Dr. Death," had been hired without health officials checking on his background. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Giants' Manning Says Elbow Is Fine After Passing a Test
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 6 - He has the most scrutinized elbow this side of Yankee Stadium, and on Tuesday, Giants quarterback Eli Manning had a pitch count, too. Manning threw about 70 passes in his first practice since spraining his right elbow Aug. 20.

title: New Orleans rescue efforts gain ground
Film director's dictum for opera: Hit the notes and get the laughs
Briefly: MasterCard faulted in U.K.
Gonzales Is Mentioned in Supreme Court Remarks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - President Bush said Tuesday that his list of candidates to replace Justice Sandra Day O'Connor was "wide open," and he jokingly but pointedly singled out Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.

title: Other Views: Sydney Morning Herald, Moscow Times, New Straits Times
Blog of a 'weather nerd' gave early warning of Katrina
The Perils of Casinos That Float
description: BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 6 - Bernie Burkholder, dressed in scuffed tennis shoes, shorts and a dirty shirt, could have been any other shell-shocked survivor of Hurricane Katrina, desperate to find enough gas to motor out of town. Mr. Burkholder stood by a badly damaged hotel here in the coastal town of Biloxi, siphoning gas from a barrel into a pair of five-gallon plastic jugs.

description: Correction Appended

title: Microsoft Eyes a Business Niche
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it planned to announce today a new strategy for selling software to medium-size business, including a revamped collection of programs that would handle specific jobs. The new software programs will be released starting this fall and through next year.

title: Observance
description: When Pamela Chisholm speaks of redemption during the morning prayer service at the Bowery Mission Women's Center, her words carry authority. For 15 years she was homeless, a drug addict and a prostitute. She is now the spiritual leader of the community she entered at the lowest point of her life.

description: Recent Lease

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Criticized On Hiring
description: A federal monitor has found that Chicago has not complied with a 1983 consent decree banning the use of political patronage in hiring, firing and promotions. The monitor, Noelle C. Brennan, who was appointed by a federal judge last month, said in a preliminary report filed in Federal District Court that she had found improper political influence in hiring and promotions and that Mayor Richard M. Daley's office of intergovernmental affairs had substantial involvement in hiring and promotion decisions, the report said. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

description: An article yesterday about the illness of President Jacques Chirac of France and the political infighting that has ensued misstated the date he entered the hospital. It was late on Friday, not Saturday. (Go to Article)

description: It was an annual tradition that most everyone in the Bronx neighborhood had eagerly awaited: the end-of-summer barbecue, when neighbors pooled their money to buy shrimp, lobsters and steaks.

title: Arafat's Former Security Chief Is Killed by Gunmen in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Sept. 7 - Dozens of masked gunmen dragged a former Gaza security chief from his home early on Wednesday and killed him in the street, underlining the internal rivalries and factional turmoil in Gaza the week before Israeli troops are preparing to pull out of the territory.

title: Gotti Was 'a Street Boss,' Prosecutors Say in Closing
description: John A. Gotti, the prince of the Gambino crime family, ordered the 1992 kidnapping of the Guardian Angels founder, Curtis Sliwa, because he regarded himself as "the street boss of his own government," a federal prosecutor said yesterday in his closing argument in Mr. Gotti's racketeering trial.

description: The Giants will give their season-ticket holders and an unknown number of Saints fans the first chance to buy tickets for the Sept. 19 game. The game was moved to the Meadowlands from flood-ravaged New Orleans.

title: Navy Pilots Who Rescued Victims Are Reprimanded
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 6 - Two Navy helicopter pilots and their crews returned from New Orleans on Aug. 30 expecting to be greeted as lifesavers after ferrying more than 100 hurricane victims to safety.

description: The United States attorney for Connecticut warned residents yesterday that a nationwide "jury duty scam" had found its way to their state.

description: Lenora B. Fulani, a leading member of the Independence Party, will try to insert herself into the mayoral race this morning with a news conference at which she and other minority leaders will pledge support for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: The Squeezing of Lawyer-Client Privilege
description: In its agreement with the government that headed off an indictment, the accounting firm KPMG promised not to try to use "any claim of privilege" to keep information from prosecutors.

title: Northwest Suspends New York-Tokyo Flights, Citing Fuel Costs
description: Northwest Airlines said today that it would indefinitely suspend its daily flight from New York to Tokyo, attributing its decision to the record high cost of jet fuel.

title: Shock Waves From the Storm

title: Pain Now, but Gain May Lie Ahead for Gulf Utility
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 6 - The oft-noted gap between Wall Street and Main Street -- or in this case, Canal Street -- was on vivid display Tuesday.

title: Showmanship Yields to Elegance
description: SOMETIMES the best way to move forward is to revisit the past. Sometimes the loudest statements are the quietest ones, made without undue fuss, in precise gestures. At his new restaurant, Perry St., Jean-Georges Vongerichten circles back, shuts up and cooks, electing earnestness over irony, controlled flourishes over cluttered frippery. In doing so he gives fresh currency to his stature as one of the most talented chefs at work in this country. He also gives his doubters, who had grown legion, reason to believe.

title: E.P.A. to Bar Data From Pesticide Studies Involving Children and Pregnant Women
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - Researchers will no longer be allowed to include children and pregnant women in studies examining the effects of pesticides to help set federal standards, according to the first regulations for human testing of pesticides that the Environmental Protection Agency plans to propose.

title: Egypt Votes in Contested Race for President, a First
description: CAIRO, Sept. 7 - Egyptians voted today in the nation's first multicandidate race for president, and while the country has clearly not yet shaken off decades of one-man, one party rule, the streets were calm, protestors were allowed to block city traffic and voters could cast a ballot for someone other than Hosni Mubarak.

title: At Least He Wasn't Playing in the Schoolyard
description: At Least He Wasn't Playing In the Schoolyard

title: This Song Goes Out to You, Big Easy
description: When Nick Spitzer heard the order for everyone to evacuate New Orleans two Sundays ago, he left his wife and children long enough to drive to his radio studio in the city's French Quarter. There he grabbed several family snapshots, his Rolodex and the master recording of the next episode of his weekly show, "American Routes." Then, on impulse, he reached for a copy of the Fats Domino song "Walking to New Orleans."

title: Bob Denver Is Dead at 70; Star of 'Gilligan's Island'
description: Correction Appended

title: Monk, Coltrane and the missing link in the history of jazz
Miller Stresses Schools, Subways and Taxes
description: A week before the Sept. 13 primary, Gifford Miller's mayoral campaign yesterday began running its fourth television advertisement. Mr. Miller is expected to spend nearly $1 million for time on broadcast and cable channels. The ad revisits the issue of smaller class size -- the theme of a previous ad -- but also highlights Mr. Miller's plans to repair the subway system and give tax credits to working families.

title: A city for shoppers in the A380's home
Why Japan Seems Content to Be Run by One Party
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6 - The Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan nearly continuously for half a century, appears headed for another victory in the general election on Sunday -- a big one, if polls are correct.

title: Everyday Grapes, In Their Sweet Season
description: Late-harvest grapes, which yield dessert wines, are usually picked brown and shriveled; as they lose moisture, their sugars become concentrated. But late-harvest Thompson seedless grapes, the workhorse green table variety, are still mighty pretty and have a delicate sweetness. These Thompsons, available from Marian Farms in the San Joaquin Valley in California, are the kind that are dried for raisins, so they are smaller than most table grapes. Some of their green is beginning to hint of gold. They will be available at least until the end of the month and are $2.99 a pound at Agata & Valentina, Balducci's and Whole Foods. FOOD STUFF

title: Challenges ahead for Toyota hybrids

description: Lance Armstrong may not be retired after all.

description: "This is a whole new beginning, a whole new start. I mean, why pass up a good opportunity, to go back to something that you know has problems?"

title: Pierre Omidyar's Perfect Store Turns 10
description: Over Labor Day weekend 10 years ago, a programmer named Pierre Omidyar took a chance on an odd little Web site called AuctionWeb. Most of Silicon Valley spent the summer of 1995 dreaming up ways to use a newfangled technology called the Internet. This was his: an auction site that let anyone list an item or place a bid. He wrote the code in his spare bedroom and posted it on his personal home page, which had a whimsical domain name: www.ebay.com.

World Briefing | Europe: France: First Step In Fire Charges
description: Four girls have been placed under judicial investigation on suspicion of starting a fire that killed 17 people in a Paris high-rise apartment block. Under French law, a judicial investigation is the first step toward bringing formal charges. The girls, between 15 and 18, have admitted to starting a fire in a mailbox. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALVIN, JOSEPH
description: GALVIN--Joseph. September 6, 2005. Devoted husband of Margaret (nee Dell'Aquila). Beloved father of Anthony, Kerri and Lori; loving brother of John, Michael and the late Thomas. The family will receive visitors on Wednesday 7-9PM and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 at the Clark Assoc. Funeral Home, 4 Woodsbridge Road, Katonah, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10AM at St. Patrick's RC Church, Bedford, N.Y. Entombment Ferncliff Mausoleum. In lieu of flowers, memorials to the American Cancer Society, would be deeply appreciated.

description: Representative Charles B. Rangel and Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College at Columbia University, urged the Bloomberg administration and the teachers' union yesterday to create pay incentives of $10,000 a year or more to entice educators to work in some of city's lowest-performing schools.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 - That the turn onto Exit 246B of Interstate 10 was under 12 feet of water was of no matter to the amphibious troop carrier, as with the marines on the vehicle, an amtrac, designed to storm beaches.

title: Challengers Look for an Angle on One of the Mayor's Strengths
description: When it comes to housing policy, all four Democratic candidates for mayor argue that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has not done enough, and that what little he has done has catered too much to the middle class.

title: An Outsider, Out of the Shadows
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 31 - The mystery of S.E. Hinton begins with her genderless name. Her most famous book, "The Outsiders," about teenage gangs and alienated youth in Tulsa during the 1960's, transformed young-adult fiction from a genre mostly about prom queens, football players and high school crushes to one that portrayed a darker, truer adolescent world. Since it was published in 1967, the novel has sold 14 million copies, 400,000 of them last year alone.

description: J.&W. Seligman & Company, a New York investment firm, sued the state's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, yesterday, asserting that he had overstepped his authority in his investigation of improper trading in Seligman's mutual funds.

title: Arts, Briefly
New Energy Infuses Ancient Languedoc
description: SOME call it magic. Others say it's romance or simply a hyperactive imagination. But wine, unlike any other beverage, has the special power of summoning up a precise corner of the world with every sip. Whether the rolling hills and valleys of Piedmont in a glass of Barolo, the vineyards slanting toward the Rhine at hysterically steep angles in a good Rheingau or pastoral Mendocino County in a dry, minerally gewrztraminer from the Anderson Valley, pictures and places waft up from wine like the proverbial aromas of fruits and earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSE, HOWARD
description: ROSE--Howard. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved and esteemed member, Howard Rose. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Services were held. Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec Dir Freddie Roman, Dean

title: Palestinians Struggle With Renewed Lawlessness in Gaza
description: GAZA, Sept. 7 - With Israel preparing to withdraw troops from the Gaza Strip within days, the Palestinian Authority struggled today to cope with renewed lawlessness that included the predawn assassination of Moussa Arafat, a presidential security adviser and a cousin of Yasir Arafat's.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Electric Utility Rejects Bid From Gas Supplier
description: The board of the Spanish power producer Endesa yesterday rejected a hostile bid of 22.6 billion euros ($28.3 billion) from Gas Natural SDG, Spain's largest natural gas supplier, as too low. "The economic terms of the offer are manifestly insufficient and in no way reflect the real value of the company," Endesa said. Rafael Villaseca, the chief executive of Gas Natural, said earlier that his company would not raise its offer.

Times, Sports Illustrated, Time, Inc. & Esquire. He also authored & illustrated several children's books. He is survived by his daughter Katrina Bettina Charmatz. Her two children, Brooke and Hunter, loving husband of 14 years, Peter, brother, John, and cuddly confidant, Bear, regret they are unable to attend (and, besides, they aren't on the guest list). Please join us to celebrate her life at 5:30 PM on Wednesday, September 14th at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Her garden is still flourishing so please do not send flowers.

Even the television cameras gave up on him during his most recent triumph, a five-set, well-past-midnight victory over Richard Gasquet that sent him into today's quarterfinals.

title: A Defender of Independent Courts
description: Today's funeral service for Chief Justice William Rehnquist and the imminent start of hearings in the Senate on Judge John Roberts Jr., the nominee to succeed him on the Supreme Court, provide a moment to honor one of the vital but less celebrated hallmarks of Chief Justice Rehnquist's 33-year service on the court: his proud record of defending the independence of the federal judiciary against attacks by politicians.

title: Barbara Bush strikes again

description: PARIS, Sept. 6 - The crew members of a Cypriot airliner that crashed Aug. 14 near Athens became confused by a series of alarms as the plane climbed, failing to recognize that the cabin was not pressurizing until they grew mentally disoriented because of lack of oxygen and lost consciousness, according to several people connected with the investigation into the crash.

Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Parents Charged In Sons' Deaths
description: The parents of two small boys who were scalded to death in a Yonkers apartment last July have been indicted on eight counts stemming from the deaths, Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, announced yesterday. The boys, Elijaha Santana, 3, and his half brother, David Maldonado Jr., 20 months, died on July 29 while they were trapped in a bathroom as hot water poured from a tub. Ms. Pirro said the father of one of the boys, David Maldonado, locked them in the bathroom. As they screamed and struggled to survive, she said, the boy's mother, Luz P. Arroyo, was in a drunken sleep nearby. Mr. Maldonado was charged with manslaughter, and Ms. Arroyo was charged with criminally negligent homicide. Both were also charged with endangering the welfare of a child. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

description: Nobody really wants to relive high school or serve on jury duty. It is more satisfying to watch "The O.C." or "Law & Order."

description: KEMPNER--Nan S. A Memorial Service will be held for family and friends at 10 A.M. Friday, September 23, 2005, at Christie's, 20 Rockefeller Plaza, West 49th Street, New York, NY

title: Internet Pioneer Leaving MCI to Join Google
description: With a billion users and counting, the Internet hardly needs an evangelist.

title: Level of Bacteria Is Found Unsafe
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Tests of water covering New Orleans showed excessive levels of E. coli bacteria and lead, federal officials said Wednesday, providing the first confirmation that the floodwaters caused by Hurricane Katrina are posing health risks for emergency response workers and residents who have remained in the city.

title: Where 80 Is Young, All Friends Are Old Friends
description: Ulster Heights, N.Y. - IT is, in a sense, not entirely surprising that the few remaining Catskill bungalow colonies to have held out against the influx of Orthodox Jews would be made up of Holocaust survivors. As colony after colony has yielded to the Hasidic men who pay hard cash, places like Silver Gate, Pleasant Valley and Four Seasons Lodge have held on -- their residents, well into their 80's and 90's, determined to enjoy summers alongside others who have lived through the unimaginable.

title: The Last Team With the Expos Nickname Will Play Its Final Game

Paid Notice: Deaths   LOBELL, HELEN S.
description: LOBELL--Helen S. Loving wife of Jack. Beloved mother of Charles and Donna Lobell, Richard and Nancy Lobell, Marilyn & Richard Trownsell, devoted grandmother of six and beloved great grandmother of six. She will always be loved and never forgotten.

title: On Election Eve, Brooklyn Party Leader Is on Trial
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MONTANA, RICHARD
description: MONTANA--Richard. On September 6, 2005. Beloved husband of Lucy. Devoted father of Lori and Rick and his wife Julie. Cherished grandfather of Kirk, Darcy & Luca. Loving brother of Carmine and his wife Pat and Angelo and his wife Barbara. Loving brother-in-law of Susan and Bob Bermack. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday, 7:00-9:00 P.M and Friday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:009:00 P.M. Mass of Christian burial on Saturday, 9:00 A.M. St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOULD, LUCIA
description: GOULD--Lucia. September 4, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Harry Edward Gould, Sr. Loving mother of Harry Edward, Jr. & his wife Barbara, Peter John and his wife Cynthia and Robert Jay and his wife Edie. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra and her husband Eldon Scott, Trip, the late Katharine, Brandon, Loren, Evan and Noel. Cherished great-grandmother of Eldon III (Cub) and Bisbee. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Thursday, September 8, 10AM at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: For Beach Plums, It Takes Two
description: For Beach Plums, It Takes Two

title: Our Moral Culture Was Breached, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Avoid the Heartless
description: Law enforcement agencies have identified numerous fraudulent schemes related to Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath -- many soliciting "relief funds" illegally or luring victims to fake Web sites in the guise of legitimate charities, where credit card information is stolen or viruses are installed on users' machines.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Agreement Reached on Chinese Textiles
description: European Union countries agreed to back Brussels on the deal it negotiated with Beijing to end the trade dispute that has stranded millions of unlicensed Chinese-made textile products at European ports. The approval of all 25 member countries was necessary to ratify the agreement, which was reached Monday in Beijing. The deal allows the estimated 80 million items to flow into Europe; China has agreed to reduced textiles quotas for 2006. Graham Bowley (IHT)

title: The Rehnquist Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Ericsson in China
Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 29 about the closing of Mississippi's casinos as Hurricane Katrina approached misspelled the surname of the general manager of the Treasure Bay Casino, who said the casinos were built to withstand a Category 3 hurricane. She is Susan Varnes, not Barnes.

title: With Sand and Pines as Muses
description: CHARLES MILITE built his 3,000-square-foot cedar-shingle house for $850,000. It was designed by James D'Auria, an architect with offices in Manhattan and Amagansett, N.Y. (James D'Auria Associates, 631-907-3300).

title: Jets Help Fill in a Hole in Their Offensive Line
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 7 - It can be eerily quiet in Montana, especially when you are an N.F.L. free agent whose phone is not ringing.

title: New Orleans Officials GrappleWith How to Pull Out Residents
description: Correction Appended

title: A Laptop That Wields Its Power Sparingly
description: Ask travelers with laptops to share their biggest complaints about mobile computing, and they're likely to talk about their inability to manage power use as well as short battery life. Sharp's new M4000 WideNote, which went on sale this week for $1,800, tries to solve both problems. The computer has a battery that runs for six hours under optimal conditions. It also includes a button on one side that puts the computer into one of three mobile-power modes and software that gives detailed control over the machine's power settings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALEM, DR. ROBERT
description: HALEM--Dr. Robert, on September 6, 2005 in Coral Springs, Florida, beloved husband of Christine, cherished father of Alexandra Levine and her husband Mark, and Elizabeth, devoted brother of Henry & his wife Sandra, son-in-law of Kathleen Giamelle & brotherin-law of Louis Giamelle and his wife Denise, loving uncle of Jessica and Christopher. Dr. Halem helped countless patients during his 30 year psychiatric practice in New York City. Service Monday September 19, 2 PM, "The Riverside", 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Amy Strong Memorial Fund for Melanoma Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, ADA 'HONEY.'
description: FRANK--Ada 'Honey.' Beloved mother to Marilyn and Susan; beloved sister of Ruth Marins; beloved grandmother to Billy, Brian, Sharon, Michael, Michelle, Scott, Jeff and Felice. Beloved great grandmother to Nicholas, Ryan, Alex, Hailey, Kyle, Matthew, Madison, Sarah and David. May you rest in peace. Services being held on Friday, September 9, at 12:30, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: Basra Bombs Kill 16 Iraqis and 4 U.S. Contractors
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 7 - A taxi packed with explosives blew up outside a crowded restaurant on Wednesday evening in the southern city of Basra, killing 16 Iraqis and wounding two dozen others, hours after a bomb killed 4 American contractors in the same city.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Africa, Asia
description: EUROPE

title: Seeking Justice, of Gods or the Politicians
description: In the history of humankind, there has rarely been a disaster like the New Orleans flood without a theodicy to go along with it. The word "theodicy," coined in the 18th century by the philosopher Gottfried Leibniz, derives from Greek roots invoking the "justice of the gods." A theodicy is an attempt to show that such justice exists, to prove that we really do live in what Leibniz insisted was the "best of all possible worlds."

title: Supply fears subside and oil price slips
Prudential of U.K. gains approval for China firm
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the financial impact of Hurricane Katrina on the federal budget omitted the last three words of a quotation from Thomas S. Kahn, staff director for Democrats on the House Budget Committee. He said, "Democrats think this is the worst possible time to be cutting taxes for those at the very top and cutting the social safety net for those at the very bottom, adding $35 billion to the deficit."

title: Canada's Central Bank Raises Lending Rate a Quarter-Point
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 7 - Despite growing uncertainty about Canada's economic direction, the Bank of Canada raised its main lending rate by one quarter of a percentage point, to 2.75 percent, on Wednesday.

title: Superdome Had an Hour ofFuel Before Panic
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 7 - A 750-gallon fuel tank was all that stood between J. Douglas Thornton and a deadly panic inside the Superdome.

title: Inside the Editing Room, Where Movies Are Built
description: "For my vision of the cinema," Orson Welles once said, "editing is not simply one aspect. It is the aspect." According to "Edge Codes.com," a wonderfully informative (if oddly titled) new documentary, what was true for Welles's cinema is true for the medium as a whole. Like "Visions of Light," Arnold Glassman and Todd McCarthy's 1993 exploration of the craft and history of cinematography, this film, directed -- and edited -- by Alex Shuper, examines a central component of the art that is often neglected or taken for granted. In the process it illuminates the essence of motion pictures.

title: Virus Ravaging India's Poor Stirs Call for Counterattack
description: LUCKNOW, India, Sept. 7 - Government ministers descended on this storied North Indian state capital on Wednesday to kick off an ambitious rural health initiative. The city's roads were freshly tarred, and banners hung along the main boulevard to welcome its chief guest: former President Bill Clinton.

title: Base Closing Request Granted, but Connecticut Fight Lingers
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 7 - A federal judge on Wednesday granted the state's request to stop an independent commission from including in its final report to President Bush a recommendation to remove fighter jets from the Air National Guard base at Bradley International Airport.

title: The Arts, Briefly; 'Big Brother' Lends CBS A Helping Hand
description: CBS's "Big Brother" led Tuesday's slow primetime in adults 18 to 49, and lifted the network to the top for the night in that demographic and in total viewers. An estimated 8.07 million viewers watched the two cliques in the "Big Brother" house, the Sovereign Two (once six) and the Nerd Herd, continue to scrape and fight for the $500,000 prize, which will be awarded during the Sept. 20 finale. At 8 p.m., both NBC's "Dateline" and CBS's "48 Hours" broadcast specials about Hurricane Katrina, drawing audiences of 7.09 million and 7.91 million, respectively. Over all, NBC took second place in total viewers -- despite the poor performances of both "Tommy Lee Goes to College" (4.18 million) and a repeat of "The Office" (3.2 million) -- as "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" at 10 p.m. was the night's most popular show (8.32 million). Fox was No. 2 among 18-to-49-year-olds, with reruns of "House" (6.26 million) and the previous night's "Prison Break" (6.27 million) both attracting solid audiences. KATE AURTHUR

title: Ukrainian Leader Fires His Government
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8 - President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine dismissed his prime minister and the rest of the cabinet today as internal divisions and accusations of corruption splintered the political coalition that led last year's popular uprising against his predecessor's autocratic government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARISER, MARILYN
description: PARISER--Marilyn, September 6, 2005. Beloved wife of Dr. Sanford; loving mother of Howard and his wife Mary, Paul and his wife Erin, and Evan and his wife Nataly; proud grandmother of Andrew, Spencer, Sheldon, Ariel, Ali and Rachel. Beloved sister-in-law of Lenore and Marshall Lesser. She enjoyed a fulfulling life by her husband's side for 56 loving years. Her three sons were a source of great pride, and she was devoted to her grandchildren. She was a brilliant and strong and charitable woman who passed peacefully after defying the odds. She's at peace now. She was one of a kind, and will never be forgotten by her family and the many people who knew and loved her. In lieu of flowers, she would want memorials to be sent to Hadassah or the ASCO Foundation. Funeral Service Thursday 12 noon Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, 914-381-1809. Interment New Montefiore.

title: U.N. Chief Admits Oil-for-Food Missteps
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7 - Secretary General Kofi Annan said Wednesday that he took personal responsibility for the management failures highlighted in a damning new report on the oil-for-food program, and he urged adoption of fundamental changes in the way the United Nations is run.

title: A Guide to Backing Up
description: In my last two e-mail newsletters, I shared the tale of my nasty Dell hard drive crash, and my efforts to recover the data I lost. And for two weeks, the number one reaction from readers has been, "O.K., you've scared me into getting a backup system in place. So what backup system should I put in place?"

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Farmers Struggle to Cope With Damage Left in the Wake of Hurricane Katrina Two weeks from the beginning of harvest season, there is a mounting sense of alarm over a potential financial disaster in the farm community. Farmers who rely on the Mississippi River to move their corn, soybeans and wheat to export markets cannot be certain that the Port of New Orleans, badly damaged by Hurricane Katrina, will reopen anytime soon. The storm also left farmers reeling from numerous other problems, including a lack of electricity to restore chicken and dairy plants to service, and a shortage of diesel fuel needed for trucks to save stranded cattle. [Page A1.]

title: Eulogies for Rehnquist Recall a Man of Many Interests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - With soaring song and fond stories, family and friends recalled Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist on Wednesday not as the cerebral public conservative who helped transform the Supreme Court but as the private man who loved history, singing and cards and showed "how a wise man looks at the law and a good man looks at life," as President Bush put it in his eulogy.

title: On The Street: Then
description: AT the tail end of the 1980's, fashion's last notorious age of excess, it was sometimes hard to differentiate between a style-conscious Manhattanite marching off to lunch and a beefy linebacker. In those waning days of gridiron chic, devout fashion followers persisted in wearing the aggressively sharp-shouldered suits espoused on the runways nearly a decade earlier by fashion pacesetters like Claude Montana, Thierry Mugler and Giorgio Armani.

title: BMW to join hybrid effort
Downloading Harry Potter
description: Harry Potter has conquered another medium. Apple Computer and the Random House Audio Publishing Group said yesterday that the entire series of Harry Potter audiobooks, read by Jim Dale, are now available as a digital download at Apple's iTunes site. The six audiobooks, previously available only on CD or tape, can be purchased individually for $32.95 to $49.95 each, or the entire 95-hour digital box set is available for $295. Apple said that the collection also includes a full-color digital booklet and "previously unreleased readings from author J.K. Rowling." Random House has sold more than 5 million copies of audiobooks in the Harry Potter series. EDWARD WYATT

title: Gotti's Lawyer Tries to Turn Jury Against Mob Turncoats
description: In closing arguments yesterday, the defense lawyer for John A. Gotti, the prince of the Gambino crime family, tore into the government's account of the 1992 shooting of Curtis Sliwa, founder of the Guardian Angels, excoriating the prosecution's witnesses as self-serving liars who had fabricated their story of the attack.

title: Shaking Possibility Out of the Great Web Tree
description: AM I the only person who ever began the day vowing to pick up all the fallen pears from the driveway but ended up spending the afternoon in front of a computer, engrossed in an article that detailed the finer points of how and when to pick tree fruit?

title: Take-Two Slips in 3rd Quarter
description: Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game maker, said yesterday that its loss widened after retailers pulled Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas because of hidden sex scenes.

title: At hospital, isolation and chaos
New Field House Gives St. John's a Selling Point
description: Norm Roberts knows some of what rival coaches have been telling recruits about St. John's: don't go there; their facilities are third rate.

title: U.S. Solheim Cup Team Just Wants to Have Fun
description: CARMEL, Ind., Sept. 7 - The motor home came equipped with plush leather seats, but the golfers barely used them.
