TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Jack Straw: Shift Europe's boundary
Surviving the Worst of Times
description: If you go to NewOrleansProducts.com and order a Mardi Gras poster, you will be taken through the standard ordering process, but you might have to wait awhile for delivery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARSCH, PHYLLIS
description: KARSCH--Phyllis. The National Women's Division of Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of our good friend Roxanne Palin, a Vice President of our New York Chapter. To Roxanne and her husband, Dean, to Mrs. Karsch's son, Michael, and his wife Erica Karsch, who serves on the board of the New York Chapter, to her grandchildren Amanda, Ben and Danielle Palin and Samuel Karsch, and to all the family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean National Women's Division Linda Altman, President Judy R. Rosenberg, Chairwoman Executive Committee Janet Hershaft, President New York Chapter

title: Arguing the Purposes of the World Trade Center Site
description: THE boundaries of hallowed ground at the World Trade Center site -- that inviolate territory where the survivors of 9/11 want nothing more or less than a fitting memorial -- seem to have expanded.

title: Sharapova Is Next for the Resurgent Clijsters
description: The door was ajar for Kim Clijsters after her defiant three-set comeback victory over Venus Williams in the quarterfinals of the United States Open. But Clijsters is not the type to kick open a door and announce, with fanfare, that she has arrived.

title: Match, Set, Burn: This Is No Genteel Afternoon Game
description: AFTER decades of teaching aerobics and training individual clients, Debbie Bowyer is sick of going to the gym. And she suspects she is not alone. "People are getting tired of the club atmosphere," said Ms. Bowyer, 51, who exercises nearly every day and teaches at a Y.M.C.A. near her home in Williamston, S.C. "I'm bored with machines. I'm bored with classes."

title: Roundup: Los Angeles plans bid for 2016 Games
World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Top Aide Replaced
description: President Viktor Yushchenko appointed a new chief of staff, Oleh Rybachuk. The previous chief, Oleksandr Zinchenko, resigned Saturday to protest what he called top-level government corruption. Ukrainians rallied to support Mr. Yushchenko last year, but polls show many are disappointed with the government, which came to power on anti-corruption promises. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Drying Out, New Orleans Fears a Blaze
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 - The sky dawned azure here on Wednesday. Gone was a black shroud of smoke that has left fire officials worried that this city will begin to dry out only to have fires complete the devastation that a flood could not finish.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Plane Had Wrong Fuel Gauge
description: The Tunisian airplane that crashed near Sicily last month and killed 16 people had run out of fuel, but the pilot could not tell because the plane had an improper gauge designed for another plane, an investigation showed. Italian officials banned the airline, Tuninter, a subsidiary of Tunisair, from operating in Italy. Officials also called for an inspection of all fuel gauges on planes built by Avions de Transport Rgional, a French and Italian joint venture. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROWE, JOHN JAY, JR.
description: ROWE--John Jay, Jr. Died Sunday, August 28 at his home in Amagansett at the age of four score and seven. He and his wife, Diana Cutler, were married in 1941 and spent many years summering in the Devon Colony until he retired and became a full time resident. His family of five children and eight grandchildren will cherish the legacy that he created. Born in Cincinnati, he was the youngest son of Grace Probasco Rowe and John Jay Rowe. He attended Cincinnati Country Day School, Middlesex and Harvard, Class of 1940. He served his country in W.W. II as an Army Captain and spent his career at Procter & Gamble. Best known to the locals as the creator of "Ferryland"--John Rowe was a friend to all; he opened his door and knowledge, wit and a youthful spirit poured out. Our hearts are at half-mast but his wishes were resolute, "Let no moaning be, as I put out to sea." The memorial service will be on Saturday, October 8, at Spring Grove Cemetery, Cincinnati, Ohio, in the Norman Chapel 10:30 AM.

title: An Island for Sinners and Saints
description: ALTHOUGH I have lived in New York for almost two decades, I had not until recently visited the Miracle Mile in Manhasset, N.Y., a stretch of stores along Northern Boulevard anchored by the Americana Manhasset mall. Everything I knew about the Mile was limited to information gleaned from the 1980 Billy Joel song "It's Still Rock and Roll to Me." It was presumably a thoroughfare on which a person might cruise after equipping one's car with whitewall tires.

title: Rocking the Baby Products Cradle
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Investigation of Oracle Is Requested
description: The South Korean fair trade commission was asked to investigate the Oracle Corporation, the world's third-largest software maker, a commission official said. The Tmax Soft Company, a software maker, asked the commission, which investigates antitrust matters, to look into Oracle because of questions about the bundling of some products, a commission spokesman, Kim Joo Hyok, said. Mr. Kim said the commission would decide whether to pursue an investigation after studying Tmax Soft's complaint and a response from Oracle, which is based in Redwood City, Calif.

title: Leave the Standing in Line to Them (Better Yet: No Stuffing of the Cab)
description: The Container Store has a solution for harried shoppers who don't have the time or the energy to fill a shopping cart and stand in line: it is giving them scanning devices that record pricing bar codes as they cruise the aisles, selecting the store's organizing and storage products. Someone else rounds up the purchases and packages them for delivery the same day ($15). The shopper provides charge-card information when signing out a scanner and signs a credit slip before leaving. The service, called Go Shop, is offered at only one store -- the one in New York: 629 Sixth Avenue (18th Street); (212)366-4200. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Schwarzenegger to Veto Same-Sex Marriage Bill
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 - Less than 24 hours after California lawmakers narrowly passed the country's first same-sex marriage bill, a spokeswoman for Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Wednesday that he would veto it "out of respect for the will of the people."

title: Independent courts
Epic Match Had It All, Except for the Black Hat
description: JAMES BLAKE was already expressing his great respect for Andre Agassi. And that was long before they played one of the most memorable night matches ever held at the United States Open.

title: A Gull's Wing for Flying Fingers
description: A new keyboard from Microsoft is designed for the millions of finger-stressed computer users worldwide. The Natural Ergonomic Keyboard 4000, released this week, splits the keys into two sections as it bubbles up and out in a convex gullwing design. Dan Odell, Microsoft's hardware ergonomist, said the unusual shape put the keys closer to the fingers, reducing reach and unnecessary motion while encouraging a more natural and comfortable typing position.

title: Glaxo to Acquire Canadian Vaccine Maker for $1.4 Billion
description: Hoping to become a major supplier of flu shots to the United States, GlaxoSmithKline said yesterday that it would pay $1.4 billion to acquire ID Biomedical, a Canadian vaccine maker.

title: The Rehnquist Court
description: To the Editor:

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: For the Younger Set, A Trip to the 20th Century
description: "Kids are born Modernists," said Rob Forbes, the founder of Design Within Reach, whose catalog put modern furnishings into millions of mailboxes. "They know instinctively that form and function go together like the fingers on their two hands." In late October, the company will issue its first children's catalog, DWR Jax. It will include, top, the solid foam Grand Prix sofa ($298), rocking chair ($198) and pouf ($258), and a white cardboard playhouse ($110), inset, that can be decorated with decals ($58) or crayons. Also available will be cribs and changing tables from ducduc, a new SoHo firm, and children's classics like the 1962 Trisse table ($365) and stool ($249) by Nanna Ditzel. "Our products will emphasize interactivity and imagination," Mr. Forbes said; dwr.com or (800)944-2233. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: CHILDREN'S FURNISHINGS

title: Checking In at Home, Even From Afar
description: For some, the problem with being on the road is the anxiety that things might be amiss at home. Are the cats behaving? Is the baby sitter keeping the peace? Are interlopers helping themselves to your Scotch -- and your stereo?

title: U.S. Open: Agassi overcomes Blake in thriller
Learning Tool or Toy? You Might Say It's a Draw
description: Upgraded for the third time, the Pixter Multi-Media System, an electronic coloring book and digital video player, is Fisher-Price's latest effort to compete with rivals like Leapster and V.Smile in hand-held devices for children.

title: Jacob Marinsky, 87, Dies; Isolated Promethium Ions
description: Jacob A. Marinsky, a chemist who helped discover promethium, No.61 in the periodic table and one of several elements isolated during work on the Manhattan Project, died Sept. 1 at his home in Buffalo, where he taught at the State University of New York. He was 87. The cause was multiple myeloma, his family said.

title: Berger to Pay $50,000 Fine for Taking Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Samuel R. Berger, national security adviser to President Bill Clinton, was ordered today to pay a higher-than-expected fine of $50,000 but received no jail time for removing and destroying copies of classified documents from the National Archives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, MARK CROSS
description: WILLIAMS--Mark Cross, age 38, in July in Amsterdam, Holland. Beloved son of the late Eileen Westlake Williams and the late Joseph Cross Williams of Monmouth County, NJ. Beloved brother of Robert Greenhut, Gail Williams Bennett and Henry Williams. Beloved ward of Margo Hamilton. A generous and inspiring friend to many in West Palm Beach, FL, New York City and Stockholm, Sweden. Private family services are planned.

title: Swiss Focus on 4 in Oil-for-Food Case
description: Switzerland has frozen the assets of four people it is investigating on suspicion of money laundering and bribery in connection with the United Nations' scandal-ridden oil-for-food program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a state audit that uncovered mismanagement, sloppy accounting practices and wasteful spending at Westchester Medical Center misstated the location of a bankrupt hospital acquired by the medical center. The hospital, Ellenville Regional, is in Ulster County, not Sullivan County.

title: Researchers Say Human Brain Is Still Evolving
description: Two genes involved in determining the size of the human brain have undergone substantial evolution in the last 60,000 years, researchers say, suggesting that the brain is still undergoing rapid evolution.

title: Caesarean sections linked to tooth decay
The Arts, Briefly
description: Cream Plays the Garden

title: No Quick Fixes
description: Washington - IN the aftermath of the Department of Homeland Security's mangled response to Hurricane Katrina, a bipartisan consensus is rapidly forming around one key idea: the Federal Emergency Management Agency failed because it is no longer an independent entity. Had FEMA not been swallowed up by the huge and lumbering Department of Homeland Security in 2003 -- were it still a nimble independent agency reporting directly to the president -- it would have been prepared to handle the catastrophe.

title: U.N. Report Cites U.S. and Japan as the 'Least Generous Donors'
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7 - A week before world leaders gather here to set a course for combating global poverty, a United Nations report released on Wednesday names the United States and Japan as among "the least generous donors" and says American and European trade policies are hypocritical and contribute to impoverishing African farmers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILL, LAWRENCE D.
description: HILL -- Lawrence D. The Board of Directors of The City College Fund expresses its deepest sympathy to his devoted wife and fellow Board member, Thelma Goodrich-Hill and family. Herbert Robinson, Chair Frank Sciame, President

title: Davenport Loses Time, and Pierce Gains Some
description: Lindsay Davenport stood rooted to the court, watching helplessly as Elena Dementieva's backhand sailed behind her on match point.

title: Other views: Daily Star, The Hindu, The Independent
Free-speech case can't hide progress
Gas Supply Falls to Lowest Point in 5 Years
description: The nation's gasoline inventories fell to their lowest levels in almost five years last week, the government said today, quantifying for the first time Hurricane Katrina's impact on the nation's energy supplies and production.

title: Corrections
description: A Square Feet article in Business Day yesterday about United States retailers that have opened stores in Canada misstated the name of an electronics company acquired by Best Buy. It is Future Shop, not Future Shock.

title: Eutelsat registersfor an IPO
For Many, Relief Is Delivered by the Most Traditional of Rescue Groups
description: As government officials and relief organizations in the South scrambled to harbor evacuees from areas hit hardest by Hurricane Katrina, the oldest, most traditional rescue groups most people know came to life -- families.

title: Prices Seen Stabilizing, but Only for Drivers
description: Gasoline prices appeared to stabilize yesterday as companies restored more oil production and refining capacity, and the government projected that prices would drop well below $3 a gallon by the end of the year.

title: 2 U.S. airlines take major steps for survival
A director's portrait of suicide bombers
Congress Approves New Storm Aid, and Bush Pledges to Expedite It
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - President Bush said today that he would work with Congress to "cut through the red tape" and get federal aid as fast as possible to people whose lives had been disrupted by wind and flood along the Gulf Coast, and Congress responded this evening by rushing through an additional $51.8 billion in federal assistance.

title: Physical Culture; Run, Spot, Run (But Be Careful)
description: MOST runners wouldn't dream of hitting the road without the proper shoes, clothes and nutrition to power them through their workouts. But people often drag dogs along without giving their needs a second thought.

title: Japans Banks Try Something New: Lending
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8 A Japan crossed a milestone in its slow economic recovery Thursday when the government said lending by banks increased in August for the first time since it started tracking lending activity seven years ago.

title: I.R.S. Donations Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - The Internal Revenue Service will announce a plan on Thursday in which companies will be allowed to set up programs so employees can donate some of their time off to a charity providing disaster aid.

title: New York Leads Suit Over Appliances' Energy Standards
description: New York State, along with 14 other states and New York City, sued the United States Department of Energy yesterday for failing to comply with a federal law requiring tougher efficiency standards for 22 home appliances.

title: Blair urges closer India-Europe links
New Angel to Keep Met Opera on the Air
description: The Metropolitan Opera's radio broadcasts, which have spread the gospel of opera for more than seven decades but were threatened by a lack of financing, have won a temporary reprieve.

title: Corrections

description: Nobody really wants to relive high school or serve on jury duty. It is more satisfying to watch "The O.C." or "Law & Order."

World Briefing | Europe: France: President To Be Released In Days
description: French President Jacques Chirac is "in very good condition" and will leave the hospital in the next few days, according to a government spokesman. Medical specialists contacted by news agencies have said that Mr. Chirac's eyesight was probably affected by a small blood clot in the retinal artery. John Tagliabue (NYT)

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,885 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Dorothy Fields Forever: A Centennial Tribute at the Algonquin
description: He says and she says. Watching Mark Nadler and KT Sullivan interpret the life and song lyrics of Dorothy Fields in their zesty centennial tribute, "A Fine Romance," is as entertaining as observing a fabulously zany tennis game. While one player rushes the net with a ferocious eagerness, the other hangs back and relies on long, floating overhead shots; put the two together and you have a manual on how to play the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, EVERETT ARNOLD
description: EISENBERG--Everett Arnold Everett Eisenberg was born to Dr. David and Birdie Eisenberg on October 30, 1916 in Astoria, NY, and died on September 4, 2005 in Delray Beach, FL. He graduated from City College in 1937 at a time when it was considered the "common man's Harvard." Awarded a scholarship, he went on to attend Harvard Law and graduated in 1940. His reverence for Harvard was deep, reinforcing his conviction that mankind is capable of profound good. Less than a year after graduation, and ten days before the attack on Pearl Harbor, he began his airforce training. For his service in the Pacific arena, he received the Bronze Star, the Distinguished Flying Cross and a citation from General MacArthur. Following the war, his love of flying led him to serve as traffic manager for Empire Airlines. Ultimately, he returned to the practice of law, becoming legal counsel to the Foreign Press Association. Always driven by his concern for humanitarian causes throughout the world, his exemplary international career as a corporate lawyer was often combined with his pursuit of equality and justice on a global scale. Most notably, he successfully argued one of the first of many cases arising from the Iran hostage situation before the World Court at the Hague. Everett's lifetime of varied experience reflects a curious and extremely facile mind. His passions were expressed on land by a competitive game of tennis; on sea as a skilled sailor; and in air as a private pilot. His incisive intellect and wit were a testament to a many-faceted personality. A fabulous raconteur, he held any audience spellbound. In simple words, he was a man larger than life. As such, he took the phrase "go forth and multiply" seriously. He is predeceased by his brother, Dr. Sanford H. Eisenberg, and his brother-in-law, Dr. Harold Diner. Four years ago, he lost the true love of his life, Viviane Eisenberg, the former Viviane Tubiana, past prima donna of Le Theatre National de L'Opera Comique. Additionally, two other mates have played important roles: the mother of his daughters, Hermione Sakolsky, and his current soul-mate, Kay Peck. Everett is lovingly remembered by his children, Amy Thor and Deborah HowlandMurray, son-in-law David Murray and his younger sister, Sydelle Diner. He was thrilled by his role as grandpa to seven grandchildren and 73/4 great grandchildren. A global cadre of nieces, nephews and cousins will miss him dearly. In his memory, and with regard to his respect for individual free will, contributions may be made to any cause that promotes the ideals by which he lived. Had he survived, he would surely have lent his help to the victims of Hurricane Katrina, and to do so would also be a fitting memorial. A memorial service will be held at 3PM on October 2, 2005 at the Astoria Center of Israel, 27-35 Crescent St, Long Island City, NY.

title: In Her Hands, Felt Is Fashionable
description: Spannum, the Netherlands - CLAUDY JONGSTRA, a Dutch textile designer who works in felt, used to spend her free time beekeeping. "If you stay very calm," she said one afternoon last month, her green eyes saucer-wide, "you can handle the bees with your bare hands."

title: Good Price, Lots of Space, and God Is in the Details
description: AURORA, N.Y. - God's former home is on the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, FREDERICK M., M.D.
description: WEISSMAN--Frederick M., M.D. Died on 4 September 2005, in his home, at the age of 91. Dr. Weissman is survived by his beloved partner of nearly forty years, Elizabeth Eberhardt. He was the son of the late Nathan Weissman and Carrie Weissman-Wolfson, and the grandson of the late David and Esther Berlinberg. Dr. Weissman is also survived by his cousin Phyllis Rosenberg. Prior to WWII, he graduated from the University of South Carolina with a BSc. in Chemistry. In devotion to his alma mater, Dr. Weissman donated two academic chairs to the university. The first chair was the Weissman chair in chemical ecology. In honor of his grandparents, the second was the Berlinberg chair in real estate at the College of Business Administration. During World War II, he served with distinction in a U.S. Army Air Forces Intelligence operation in Germany. Following the war, Dr. Weissman received his medical degree from the University of Geneva, his specialty was neurology. He served as a neurologist at several New York City Hospitals, and a medical officer in the US Air Force Reserves. Dr. Weissman authored several scientific articles in the field of neurology. A private service was held on 6 September 2005 at the Har Nebo cemetery in Philadelphia.

title: Maybe It Is Time to Fix Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chinese University Removes a Topic From the Closet
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 7 - As the class got under way, the diminutive teacher standing before an overcrowded lecture hall in this city's most exclusive university handed out a survey. The first of several multiple-choice questions asked students what their feelings would be if they encountered two male lovers: total acceptance, reluctant acceptance, rejection or disgust?

title: Out of the Oceans, Inspiration for New Forms of Life
description: The sculptor Michele Oka Doner based 10 Steuben Glass designs on ocean life, from microscopic cells to coral formations, left. The pieces, called the Reef Collection, will arrive at the Steuben store, 667 Madison Avenue (61st Street), on Oct. 19 (and will be available by phone after Oct. 1: 646-497-3714). Ms. Oka Doner's Radiant Disc Table ($23,000), center, has a glass top that resembles a slice of jellyfish and bronze legs shaped like driftwood. Her Ocean Reef Bowl ($23,000), right, is engraved with patterns of algae cells and rests on a bronze coral base. The Steuben commission is Ms. Oka Doner's first major venture in glass. During her 40-year career, she has specialized in metalwork; her large-scale installations include thousands of bronze marine creatures embedded in the floor of the Miami International Airport, and she also makes chairs, candlesticks and spoons (micheleokadoner.com). She chose aquatic motifs for Steuben, she said, partly because the globules formed during glassblowing remind her of water foaming and bubbling. EVE M. KAHN CURRENTS: GLASSMAKING

title: 2 Airlines Race Against Bankruptcy
description: TWO airlines in crisis -- Delta and Northwest -- took steps yesterday aimed at gaining some breathing room in their attempts to avoid seeking bankruptcy protection.

Abbas Vows to Find Palestinian Killers of Security Aide
description: GAZA, Sept. 7 - The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, pledged Wednesday to track down the Palestinian gunmen who had assassinated his security adviser, a killing that delivered a new challenge to his leadership just days before Israeli troops are to leave the Gaza Strip.

title: A Summons to Tradition
description: SOME people, no doubt, will find a disconcerting, even distasteful, incongruity between the scenes of devastation along the Gulf Coast and images of designer catwalks that will begin emanating from New York tomorrow as the spring 2006 collections begin. But the fashion industry's unwritten law that its shows must go on sometimes results in a poignant, if inadvertent, connection to events beyond the borders of Bryant Park, in this case the planned installation next week of a great Southern tradition, a sewing circle, amid the racks of decadently priced merchandise at Jeffrey New York.

title: Online, Feisty Critics
description: LAST week Rebecca Fok fired a blast at Jessica Simpson. Ms. Fok, 19, who was reared in Hong Kong and lives in London, writes under the name Harrods Girl on the blog I am Fashion, heaping praise and, by turns, tirades on the haughty world of style.

title: Research clarifies true chronic fatigue
National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Petitions To Oust Mayor
description: Opponents of Mayor James E. West of Spokane, who is accused of abusing his office in a sex scandal, said they had gathered the required 12,600 petition signatures to put a recall vote on the November ballot. The organizers of the recall campaign, Citizens for Integrity in Government, said they had about 12,700 signatures and planned to collect 5,000 more as a cushion. It took 11 days to reach their goal after the State Supreme Court ruled last month that the petition could proceed. Mayor West, 54, is accused of offering city jobs to men he met in gay chat rooms. He denies doing anything illegal, and has vowed to fight the recall. David Carrillo Pealoza (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HART GREEN, ALEX
description: HART GREEN--Alex. Died peacefully on September 4, 2005, in Sarasota, FL. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Adele Morgan; his children, Anne Smithers and Barbara Fauth; and four grandchildren, Lindsay and Jennifer Fauth, Amelie and Philippe de Richemont. He is also survived by a brother, Patrick Hart Green. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to a local hospice or Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. A memorial service at Brick Church will be announced at a later date.

title: Journey Leads Warner Back to Giants Stadium
description: Kurt Warner is so characteristically gung-ho about his new opportunity as Arizona's starting quarterback that he said he did not even stop to think that Sunday's game against the Giants will represent the third consecutive year he has played the opening game at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, PATRICIA BURRAGE
description: YOUNG--Patricia Burrage. Of New York City, September 3, 2005. Devoted mother of Missy Rosengarten of Carmel, N.Y., Julie O'Connor of Swampscott, MA., Steven Young of Rutland, VT. and Chris Young of Carmel, N.Y. Sister to June Jenkins and Anne Alford, both of Fort Worth, Texas; former wife of the late Robert F. Young of Hastings-On-Hudson, N.Y. Survived by 8 grandchildren, many loving nieces, nephews and countless cherished friends. Memorial Service at The Colony Club, 564 Park Avenue, New York on Monday, September 12 at 11 AM. Donations in her memory to Putnam County Humane Society, PO Box 297, Carmel, N.Y. 10512.

title: Microsoft Sues to Keep Data Secret
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 7 - Microsoft said on Wednesday that it had filed a new lawsuit against the European Commission, challenging the commission's order that it divulge technical information that rivals need to create programs that work well with Microsoft software.

title: Out of the Spy's Stocking and Into the Wash
description: ALBANY, Sept. 2 - The spy had made a daring foray behind enemy lines for a rendezvous with a highly placed agent and was rewarded with a trove of military secrets. But his escape plan fizzled, forcing him to try to return on foot through enemy territory. Just short of the border to safety, he was caught, unmasked and eventually executed.

title: Players in Wheelchairs Get Their Own Open
description: Growing up in Paris, Michael Jeremiasz loved to play sports. He began skiing at age 2. At 5, he was playing tennis. He also enjoyed basketball and swimming.

title: The Modern Acquires a 'Lost' Matisse
description: A rich and hypnotic interior by Matisse whose whereabouts had been unknown to scholars in recent decades has been purchased for the Museum of Modern Art by its new president, Marie-Jose Kravis, and her husband, the financier Henry Kravis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the economic effects of Hurricane Katrina referred incorrectly to the wages of idled workers at McDonald's, because of misinformation supplied by the company. McDonald's continued to pay the workers; it did not stop paying them after the storm hit.

title: Katrina's Silver Lining
description: As a colleague of mine says, every crisis is an opportunity. And sure enough, Hurricane Katrina has given us an amazing chance to do something serious about urban poverty.

title: A Life of Cards Began With a Missed Slam at 15
description: Alan Truscott, who died on Sunday after 41 years as the bridge columnist of The New York Times, found out about bridge at Whitgift School in Croydon, London, when he was 15. He instructed three friends to read a book, and the next Thursday they had their initial game. On the first deal his partner opened one spade. He responded three clubs, a strong jump shift, and his partner passed. His partner hadn't read far enough into the book. To make matters worse, Truscott won 12 tricks and was furious at the missed slam. But 12 years later this friend had represented England and Truscott had played for Britain in a European championship.

title: Senate Democrats Pushing for Roberts's Legal Memos
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee renewed their push on Wednesday for access to legal memorandums written by Judge John G. Roberts Jr., sending a pointed letter of complaint to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, who controls the records and who is himself a potential Supreme Court candidate.

title: Liability Issue: Wind or Water?
description: Even with the full extent of the losses caused by Hurricane Katrina still unknown, a battle over what insurance companies will cover is taking shape around one pivotal question: How much of the damage was due to strong winds and how much due to flooding?

description: Texas Instruments succeeded in transforming itself from the best-known maker of calculators to the largest seller of chips for cellphones. Now it wants to repeat that success in the market for video chips.

description: The higher the price of gasoline goes, the less Lynn Reeves values her privacy on the long drives back and forth to work.

description: NAVAL AIR STATION NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 7 - Even if it was not clear to anyone else in the government, the Marines had figured they would be needed when Hurricane Katrina struck.

description: EBay is in preliminary discussions to acquire Skype Technologies, the Internet telephone company that has been the object of much merger speculation of late, for $2 billion to $3 billion, two people involved in the negotiations said today.

description: The rivalry between Notre Dame and Army was once one of the most popular and prestigious in college football. It waned in the second half of the 20th century, and the teams have met just twice in the last 20 years, most recently in 1998.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SWIFT, REBBETZIN RUTH
description: SWIFT--Rebbetzin Ruth. Congregation Ahavath Torah deeply mourns the loss of our beloved Rebbetzin Ruth Swift. For decades, Rebbetzin Swift stood by the side of her esteemed husband, the late Rabbi Isaac Swift, of blessed memory, as together they built our community. During the years following Rabbi Swift's demise, Rebbetzin Swift continued her extraordinary work within our community and beyond. She visited the ill, comforted the bereaved, counseled those in need, established Sabbath hospitality rooms at Englewood Hospital, developed a network to visit the homebound, and aided those around her in countless other ways. She helped make us who we are as a community and always modeled who we could be. We will miss her deeply and extend our deepest sympathy to her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Rabbi Shmuel Goldin Kenneth Eckstein, President Englewood, NJ

title: Zimbabwe's Blood Supplies Low
description: Zimbabwe's blood supplies have dwindled after a recent state campaign that ousted at least 700,000 peasants from their homes, the newspaper The Herald reported. A combination of school holidays, a fuel shortage and the forced migration of regular blood donors has effectively left the nation without blood for transfusions. Zimbabwe's medical system has been in collapse, with most doctors and nurses having left the country and medicines in short supply, since the nation's economy began falling apart in 2000. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Eco-Deco, for a Greener House
description: IT'S getting easier to be green, at least at home. If you thought "ecofriendly" design was only for the Birkenstock set, it may be time to take a second look. Some new furnishings and paints are as stylish as a pair of Jimmy Choos.

title: Man Stabs a Baby Girl in Her Stroller
description: A man with a knife walked up to a nanny pushing a 10-month-old girl in a stroller in Washington Heights last evening and plunged a knife into the baby's stomach, critically injuring her, the police said.

title: Bernard S. Meyer Is Dead at 89; Served on New York's Top Court
description: Bernard S. Meyer, a former judge of the New York State Court of Appeals who led an investigation in 1975 into the state's handling of crimes arising from the Attica prison revolt four years earlier, died on Saturday in Valley Stream, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Deepest Thoughts on a World Tour
description: IN 1916, on a troop ship from Australia, a pair of soldiers stuffed a piece of paper in a bottle. "Two young men, soldiers on our way to the Front," they had written on it, "would like the person or persons finding this note to write to us as we are very lonely." Like so many bottle-borne missives, it was an attempt to call out to strangers in unknown places. And the attempt was not entirely in vain. According to an Australian newspaper account, the bottle and its note were found on the coast of Tasmania by a passing priest -- nearly four decades later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGDOROWITZ, SOPHIE
description: WIGDOROWITZ--Sophie. Died in Florida, 2 months short of 100th birthday. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and greatgrandmother. Service Friday, September 9, at 11:30 A.M., Plaza Chapel at 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Deposed Head of Australian Inquiry Ties Surgeon to 13 Deaths
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 7 - In a report sent to the Australian Parliament on Wednesday, the former chairman of an inquiry into the activities of an American-trained surgeon at a rural Australian hospital says that the doctor was responsible for the deaths of 13 patients.

title: To Beat the Blurs, a Camera With a Trick
description: Like most new small digital cameras, the DiMAGE X1 from Konica Minolta has a big L.C.D. screen -- 2.5 inches diagonally. That leaves no room for a viewfinder that lets you brace the camera against your face, and if you hold it away to see what you're shooting on the screen, the camera is unsteady. But an antishake system stabilizes the eight-megapixel image sensor and the lightweight zoom lens when the camera moves, allowing sharp photos even at shutter speeds slow enough for candlelight.

title: A Nose for Hot Spots, in Three Assorted Flavors
description: Although miniature Wi-Fi detectors you can stow like a pack of gum have been available for some time, the proliferation of laptops and personal digital assistants that can sniff out wireless networks on their own have made them little more than novelties. But the $99 AG225H from Zyxel, which is scheduled to go on sale this month at zyxel.com and CompUSA, has a few tricks up its sleeve.

title: Restarting Pumps RequiredPluck and Luck
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 - Late Monday night, with a whoosh and a thunderous rumble, the first pumps kicked in at Pumping Station 6, New Orleans's largest, and began draining water out of this sunken city and into Lake Pontchartrain.

Productivity vs. Low Skill

title: An Elusive Rock Enigma Sings, but Doesn't Speak
description: Some of the most coveted tickets in New York on Tuesday night were for the 200 seats at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village, where Jandek was playing his New York debut. Jandek conceals his offstage name, which is probably Sterling R. Smith. He has released 42 albums of his morose, irregular, antimelodic and sometimes bleakly riveting songs since 1978 on his own label, Corwood Industries, selling them via a post-office box in Houston. A documentary about him, "Jandek on Corwood," appeared in 2004, and until last year he had not performed in public. His New York show was only his fourth live concert, after appearances in England, Scotland and Texas.

title: Chertoff Draws Fire On Briefing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary who has been the Bush administration's point man in fielding criticism of the hurricane relief effort, came under fire Wednesday from some Congressional Democrats for private remarks about the conditions faced by storm survivors that struck the lawmakers as insensitive.

title: Shelters for Pets Fill With Furry Survivors
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 7 - Peter, a yellow cockatiel, came through the door of the Houston animal shelter from New Orleans perched on his owner's finger. With pets barred from the bus trip, Lola, a green parrot, made it hidden inside her owner's bra. And the Great Dane? Well, no one is quite sure about him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: State Airline to Buy Planes From Airbus
description: India has cleared the purchase of 43 aircraft from the European maker Airbus for the government-owned domestic airline, Indian Airlines. The value of the deal is $2.2 billion, the prime minister, Manmohan Singh, said. The airline's aging fleet is facing competition from younger private airlines like Jet Airways and Air Sahara. The government said it had secured a concession from Airbus. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Deal for Rest of Asian Paper Venture
description: Norske Skogindustrier will buy the stake it does not already own in an Asian paper joint venture from Abitibi-Consolidated for $600 million to overtake its partner as the world's biggest newsprint maker. The deal for the PanAsia Paper Company will be financed by a sale of 4 billion kroner ($615 million) in new shares, Norske Skog said.

title: No Strangers to the Blues
description: The tragedy in New Orleans did not occur in a vacuum. There is no way, even in the face of a storm as violent as Katrina, that a great American city should have been reduced to little more than a sewage pit overnight.

title: Fears over Endesa bid

It is in Baton Rouge, not St. Gabriel. (Go to Article)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMINSKI, EDA
description: KAMINSKI--Eda, born in Zavoya, Poland. She survived the brutal concentration camps of Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen. Her life in America was marked by he devotion to her family and her commitment to many charitable organizations, among them Bikur Cholim, Emunah, Krakow Society and Young Israel of Kew Garden Hills. Predeceased by her loving husband Reuven Kaminski, she will be deeply mourned by her daughter Anita Epstein (Noel), son Harvey Kaminski (Helene), grandchildren Stephanie, Pamela, Frances, Philip and great-grandchildren Tessa, Lilah, Jake and Max. The funeral will be held at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, Queens on September 8 at 1PM. You were the best mother in the world. Your loving family.

title: Finding Love in the Material World And Making It Into a Teacup
description: Can everyday objects bring more love into our lives? An exhibition at Felissimo Design House, 10 West 56 Street, through Sept. 28, attempts to answer that question with pieces by young designers who entered an international contest called Love/Why?, sponsored by Unesco and the Felissimo Group, a Japanese retailer. Tamar Meshulam of Israel won the $10,000 grand prize for her tabletop game Master Peace, top, which encourages interaction and collaborative storytelling among people of different cultures. A finalist, Alon Meron, also from Israel, made dishes, left, melding unlikely partners: white porcelain and yellow rubber. Objects by more than 50 professional designers are also on display: Kenneth Cobonpue's Barrel of Love stool, right, has a top made of rattan poles, some engraved with messages of love. TIM MCKEOUGH CURRENTS: YOUNG DESIGNERS

title: Cricket: A brilliant Ashes, and not just for English fans

description: Michel Abreu defected from Cuba 18 months ago with endless expectations. He figured he would gain residency status in Mexico, perform in a tryout camp for 30 major league teams and sign a lucrative contract to play first base in the United States.

Metro Briefing | New York: Shandaken: More Delays For Watershed Plan
description: Belleayre Resorts at Catskill Park, the largest project ever proposed for New York City's watershed, will have to submit to additional hearings that will delay the project indefinitely, according to a ruling yesterday by a New York State administrative law judge, Richard R. Wissler, who said that 12 sensitive environmental issues had not been adequately examined. The proposed development includes two hotels, two 18-hole golf courses and hundreds of housing units on 1,960 acres in Shandaken and Middletown. Daniel Ruzow, a lawyer representing the developer, Crossroads Ventures, said that the project was "still proceeding." Anthony DePalma (NYT)

Saving Hemingway's Cuban legacy
Seafood Industries Devastated by Hurricane
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 8 - Louisiana officials said today that the commercial and recreational seafood industries along the coastline were devastated by Hurricane Katrina, and they estimated that the economic impact could reach $1.6 billion over the next 12 months. And that is not counting the loss of a trademark of bayou culture.

title: Vice President Cheney in Mississippi
description: Obviously, we're down here today to -- (inaudible) -- look at all of the activities that are under way, to get some idea, obviously, the extent of the damage, but also an opportunity to meet with the folks who are doing something about it. I had some great meetings with the mayors of the local communities here, with state officials, with military, with police and law enforcement, and federal officials as well. (Inaudible) -- Secretary Chertoff, I've got Attorney General Gonzales with us and so forth, too.

title: A Band Whose Leader Is Proud to Be Humble
description: Chris Martin was onstage at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, humbly explaining how honored he was that his little band, Coldplay, had filled such a big venue. "We can't rely on fireworks and smoke and mirrors," he said, although by "can't" he seemed to mean "don't need to." Which undermined the humility more than a little.

title: Maybe It Is Time to Fix Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINGER, NANCY
description: SINGER--Nancy, age 83, of Watchung, NJ formerly of Whitestone, NY died Sunday, September 4, 2005. Survived by husband, Norman Singer; son Donald Singer of College Point, NY; daughter Lucie Longworth of Millburn, NJ; three grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. Memorial services, Tuesday September 13 at 11:00AM at Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd, Watchung, NJ. Call 908-756-0017 for further information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVENSON, PAUL
description: LEVENSON--Paul. The Board of Directors and staff of the Christopher D. Smithers Foundation expresses its deepest sympathy and condolences on the passing of Paul Levenson, a devoted friend and brilliant counselor who gave of himself with great compassion and dignity and who was steadfast in his belief of justice and the legal system. He will be sorely missed and always remembered. Adele Smithers-Fornaci President

title: Microsoft sues the EU a 2nd time
Shelters Grow Empty as Apartments Open Up
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 7 - In a stunning turnaround for some of the most besieged victims of Hurricane Katrina, the Astrodome population dwindled to about 3,000 on Wednesday from an estimated 15,000 over the weekend, with many people seizing on local job opportunities and inexpensive housing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, ABRAHAM CHAIM (HY)
description: LEVY -- Abraham Chaim (Hy), 80, of Brooklyn and Boca Raton, Florida, after a short, gallant struggle with ALS, at home in Brooklyn. Born in Jerusalem, Hy immigrated to the United States at age 12 along with his parents and six sisters. A peaceful and peace-loving man, Hy served his nations proudly in times of crisis, in the US Army in World War II and in the Israeli War of Independence. Hy was married for almost 54 rich and productive years to Mildred (Glaser). Hy was active in the Bnai Brith. Young Israel of Bedford Bay, and served for many years as the president of Kings Bay II cooperative apartments. At age 40 Hy became a proud college graduate, after entering the teaching force in the New York City public school system, where he used his skilled hands and generous heart in making industrial arts a favorite class for young people in the South Bronx and Coney Island. After retirement, Hy and Mildred moved to Florida, where they continued to give, and to benefit from the people around them. They volunteered at the West Boca hospital, and sang in the Yiddish Folk Chorus of Palm Beach County. He was a lifelong athlete, reaching the semi-pro ranks as a soccer player and excelling at tennis. Hy's proudest accomplishment was his work as a founding member of Congregation Torah Ohr in Boca Raton. Hy's proudest connections were to his family. His memory will be a blessing to Efrat Frayda Levy and Dan Bernstein, to Steven & Beena Levy, to Rachel Levy, Jaime Levy, Dara Levy-Bernstein, Jacob Levy, Meirav LevyBernstein, Revital LevyBernstein. He will also be remembered with great love by Yona Linder, Zipporah Kessel, Shoshana and Jack Yarmosky, Pnina Engel, and Miriam and Hal Rein, by many nephews and nieces, and by countless friends. Funeral services will be held Thursday September 8th at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave (at Ave L) Brooklyn, at 1:15 PM. Shiva will be observed at the Levy home in Brooklyn. Donations in Hy's Memory can be made to Congregation Torah Ohr.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a mortuary set up in St. Gabriel, La., for victims of Hurricane Katrina referred incorrectly in some copies to the only long-term treatment facility for Hansen's disease, or leprosy, in the continental United States. It is in Baton Rouge, not St. Gabriel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIDGWAY, THOMAS JR.
description: RIDGWAY--Thomas Jr., 91. Beloved husband of Jane Pope Akers Ridgway, died of a heart attack at their summer home in Newport on Monday, September 5, 2005. Mrs. Ridgway is the daughter of the late John Russell Pope, the architect of the West Building of the National Gallery and the Jefferson Memorial in Washington, DC among others. Mr. Ridgway was born on May 9, 1914 in Philadelphia, PA. to Thomas Ridgway Sr, a well known Philadelphia attorney, and Edith F. Ridgway. Mr. Ridgway has Pennsylvania ancestry; he was directly descended from General "Mad" Anthony Wayne, of the American Revolution. Thomas grew up in Philadelphia and graduated from the Episcopal Academy in Philadelphia. Mr. Ridgway served as an Aviator in the US Army Air Force during World War II. As a pilot he transported planes to China for General Chennault's American Volunteer Group, flying "over the hump" as a member of the Flying Tigers. Thomas Ridgway was twice the Junior Tennis Champion of New England, and tennis remained a lifelong interest. Mr. Ridgway was a member of the Knickerbock Club in New York, The Spouting Rock Beach Association and the Clambake Club of Newport. He is survived by hie wife Jane Pope Akers Ridgway & a daughter Ellery Akers. A funeral service will be held Saturday, September 10, 2005 at 11:00AM in the Christ Chapel at Episcopal Academy, 376 North Latches Lane, Merion, PA. followed by a private burial. A Memorial service will be held in St. Columbia Berkley Memorial Chapel, Vaucluse Ave, Middletown, RI at a date to be announced. For information, contact Memorial Funeral Home, 375 Broadway, Newport, RI 02940. Donations in his memory may be made to The Episcopal Academy, c/o Meg Hollinger, 376 North Latches Lane, Merion, PA. 19066.

title: In economic growth, lots of company
Baseball:Greatest ever in the clutch?
STORM AND CRISIS
description: ACTION IN CAPITAL -- The Bush administration requested $51.8 billion in new relief money in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, while Democrats and Republicans in Congress unleashed a burst of attacks on the administration's response. PAGE A21

title: Maybe It Is Time to Fix Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We are kind of shocked they didn't beat us."

title: The Embattled Leader of a Storm-Battered State Immersed in Crisis
description: Correction Appended

title: Yushchenko dismisses government amid growing crisis
Yahoo Role Documented in Chinese Trial
description: BEIJING, Sept. 7 - Yahoo, the Internet search company, provided information last year that helped authorities in China convict a Chinese journalist for leaking state secrets to a foreign Web site, court documents show.

title: Yankees Get the Details Right and Finally Beat the Devil Rays
description: Jonny Gomes took the subway to Yankee Stadium from Manhattan yesterday, and as he was arriving at the station near the ballpark, he bumped into a reporter who questioned him about the secret to the Devil Rays' success against the Yankees this season.

title: Wheelchair Tennis: The Basics
description: Wheelchair tennis makes its competitive debut at the United States Open today. While the rules are similar to the ones used by able-bodied athletes, wheelchair players are allowed two bounces. Esther Vergeer of the Netherlands demonstrates the style and strategy of play. By BEDEL SAGET

title: Medical Records Say Arafat Died From a Stroke
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRIPPEN, DAVIS A.
description: CRIPPEN--Davis A. Died suddenly on September 2 at the age of 75. He is survived by his wife Cynthia, his sons Alex and Tom, and his grandchildren Daniel and Eli. A service will be held at 3 PM on Saturday, September 17 at Christ Church, 416 Valentine Avenue, Sparkill, NY. He loved books and the opera. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Piermont Library Building Fund, 153 Hudson Terrace, Piermont, NY 10968, or the the Metropolitan Opera in NYC.

title: What is lost, archaeologists try to find
Bring Out Your Pork
description: Fair warning to the suffering Gulf Coast masses: Congress is already talking of concocting "economic stimulus" and "job creation" packages as hurricane recovery tools. That sounds useful, but unfortunately those terms usually signal that the House and the Senate are about to use the crisis of the moment to roll out wasteful tax cuts for the well-off and pork barrel outlays for hometown voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SESAN, IRWIN
description: SESAN--Irwin. 76 years old, died on September 6, 2005. Beloved husband of Lolly. Devoted father of Robin Sesan and Michael and Sheila Sesan. Cherished grandfather of Sarah and Alex Robins and Tyler and Jordan Sesan. Dear brother of Roz Ruder. Services Thursday, 11:30 A.M. at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd, Woodbury, NY 11797.

title: After 210 Years, Jim Beam Discovers the Power of TV
description: JIM BEAM and its maker are finally clambering aboard the increasingly crowded bandwagon of liquor brands being advertised on television.

title: People: Tony Bennett, Suzanne Farrell, Robert Redford
Key rates
description: In percent

title: Displaying a supernatural medium
It's a small park: Hong Kong Disneyland faces overcrowding
Candidates Are Armed With Data but Stretch It to Hurt the Mayor and One Another
description: The candidates in the Democratic debate last night came armed with data to make their cases that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg deserved to be fired and that they were the ones to solve a number of city ills he has failed to fix.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the impact of rising gasoline prices on commuters, businesses and services in New York misstated the position of the League of Mutual Taxi Owners, which has asked city regulators for permission to add a $1 fuel surcharge to fares. It wants the surcharge to go to all cabdrivers, not just owners of medallions.

title: Debate Clock Clips Answers, And Drama
description: The four major Democratic mayoral candidates used a televised debate last night to try to chip away at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's unusual popularity with Democrats, portraying him as ill-equipped to handle a natural disaster, growing poverty, the need for affordable housing, and other concerns of voters.

title: Offers Pour In, But the U.S. Is Unprepared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Generous offers of aid for Hurricane Katrina victims are pouring in from scores of nations, but in many cases the United States is unprepared to receive the goods.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Clean Air Measure Approved
description: A plan to reduce pollution from diesel garbage trucks, transit buses and school buses was signed into law yesterday by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey. In a Nov. 8 ballot referendum, voters will choose whether to finance the proposal with part of the state Corporate Business Tax. If the financing is approved, the money will be used to retrofit vehicles over the next 10 years to reduce emissions.

title: Kitchens for Neatniks
description: Q. Are kitchen materials like copper and marble more trouble than they're worth?

title: Three Automakers Plan Alliance to Develop a Hybrid Car
description: BMW, the world's largest luxury carmaker, will join General Motors and DaimlerChrysler to develop fuel-saving gasoline-electric power systems to try to catch up with the hybrid leader, Toyota.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article and a caption yesterday about Maria Sharapova's victory over Nadia Petrova in the quarterfinals of the United States Open misstated Sharapova's world ranking in some copies. She is No.2, although she is seeded No.1 in the Open. (Lindsay Davenport regained the No.1 ranking just before the tournament.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Escapees Captured
description: A man and a woman who escaped from the Midtown North station house on Saturday after their arrest on robbery charges have been captured, the police said yesterday. Tracey Herman, 31, was captured on Tuesday at an apartment in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Pedro Martinez, 22, was arrested at home on Madison Avenue yesterday morning. Ms. Herman and Mr. Martinez were also charged with escape. A police officer and a sergeant were suspended after the two fled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NININGER, EUGENE V., MD
description: NININGER--Eugene V., MD, 84, Psychiatrist and Psychoanalyst, on August 3. A native of Kansas, he was a graduate of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, and served as Commissioner of Mental Health for Westchester County, 1976-1977. An accomplished violinist, he performed with his two sons and daughter in a folk group that played many venues including Folk City and the Lone Star Cafe in Manhattan. His wife of 56 years, Fern, died in 2001. He is survived by his sons James and William, his daughter Ann Grilli, and four grandchildren.

title: The Arts, Briefly; Top of His Class
description: As anticipated, Kanye West, below, vaulted to the top of the Billboard album chart with the debut of "Late Registration" (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam), selling 860,000 copies. This represents the year's second best sales week after the 1.14 million sales of 50 Cent's "Massacre" in March, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Chief among the other top 10 debuts, six of them this week, is the 50 Cent protg and G-Unit member Tony Yayo's "Thoughts of a Predicate Felon" (Interscope) a distant second, with 214,000 copies sold. Brooks & Dunn hit No. 3, a career high, with "Hillbilly Deluxe" (Arista Nashville), while the major-label debut of Death Cab for Cutie, "Plans" (Atlantic), entered the chart at No. 4, well above the peak their previous album, "Transatlanticism," attained -- No. 97 -- when it was released on the indie label Barsuk. GRANTJAMES VARJAS

title: Looper Gives Up Lead, Not Once but Twice
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 7 - If time has not yet run out on the Mets, it certainly has at least one foot out the door. And if the Mets continue their rapid descent through the National League wild-card standings, they can reflect on what happened at Turner Field on Wednesday night as the scene of their demise.

title: Democrats Step UpCriticism of White House
description: Correction Appended

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: A Museum Grows in Golden Gate Park
description: Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron, the Swiss architectural team, designed the new de Young Museum -- opening in San Francisco on Oct. 15 -- to fit into its Golden Gate Park setting and also to invite it inside. A copper shell is perforated and embossed with circles to mimic dappled light. Depending on the time of day, it looks solid or translucent. The ocean air will change the shell's color over time, to pick up the browns, oranges, purples and especially the greenish grays in the park, said Ascan Mergenthaler, a partner at Herzog & de Meuron, which worked with Fong & Chan Architects. (In Europe, he pointed out, copper typically turns dark brown because of acid rain.)

title: Lacking Phone Lines, Rescuers Turn to Ham Radio Operators
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 8 - The 500-pound man on the deck of a shrimp boat along the coast of Gulfport had been lying there for three days and needed medical attention fast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROOKS, VIRGINIA GUARD
description: BROOKS--Virginia Guard, 89, died August 30 after a brief illness. She was a lifelong resident of Pelham. A memorial service will be held September 17 at The Huguenot Memorial Chapel at 1:00PM.

title: Australia's uranium attracts China
More reforms needed in China, OECD says
In Mississippi, History Is Now a Salvage Job
description: BILOXI, Miss. - THE barrel of the Confederate 12-pounder howitzer was missing, and so was the saddle on which Jefferson Davis rode into the Mexican War. Four days after Katrina, Patrick Hotard's face was shadowed with exhaustion and dismay as he surveyed what was left of Beauvoir, the beachside Jefferson Davis home and presidential library, where he is the director. He had just arrived from his refuge in Louisiana, and many of his worst fears were being confirmed as he picked through the bricks, giant wafers of plaster and nylon Confederate flag replicas.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (5) REUNION -- Series premiere. This new ensemble drama chronicles 20 years in the lives of six friends, played by (above, from left) Alexa Davalos, Sean Faris, Will Estes, Dave Annable, Chyler Leigh and Amanda Righetti. The story begins in the present with the funeral of one of the friends, who's been murdered, then flashes back to 1986, when the victim (whose identity is not revealed) and the other friends were graduating from high school. The investigating policeman is played by Mathew St. Patrick,who was Keith on "Six Feet Under."

title: Northwest Suspends Tokyo-New York Nonstop, Citing High Fuel Cost
description: Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would indefinitely suspend its daily flight from New York to Tokyo, blaming the high cost of jet fuel.

title: California Bill on Tax Breaks for Filming Faces Delay
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 - Hollywood's push for government subsidies to keep movie and television production from leaving California may have to wait until next year, after the effort drew stronger-than-expected opposition among state lawmakers and the devastation in New Orleans wiped away an important rationale.

title: Companies find value in hedging China bet
Maybe It Is Time to Fix Blame (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Poe Without the Melodrama, but With a Few Kinks Thrown In
description: With "Usher," a 40-minute version of Edgar Allan Poe's "Fall of the House of Usher," the director Curtis Harrington revisits the subject of his first film, an amateur short made more than six decades ago when he was just a teenager. In doing so, Mr. Harrington -- who has worked alongside the likes of Kenneth Anger, James Whale and Roger Corman, as well as written episodes of television series as diverse as "Baretta" and "Dynasty" -- brings a long and notable career full circle.

title: Before the Flood
description: THE last time a great American city was destroyed by a violent caprice of nature, the response was shockingly different from what we have seen in New Orleans. In tone and tempo, residents, government institutions and the nation as a whole responded to the earthquake that brought San Francisco to its knees a century ago in a manner that was well-nigh impeccable, something from which the country was long able to derive a considerable measure of pride.

title: Letter from Indonesia: Cooperation on terror seems 'one-way street'
Stopping the Buck at City Hall
description: NEW YORKERS are a spoiled lot. They have learned that they have to be, that they have to set the bar high when it comes to their leaders -- much higher than people in some other parts of the country do, as the awful events on the Gulf Coast suggest.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Tennis: Pierce shows off her late-blooming confidence
Our Moral Culture Was Breached, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: You Don't Have to Go to the Hamptons
description: STEFANI GREENFIELD, an owner of Scoop NYC, recently took on another role: host of "Inside the Ultimate Closet," a fashion program on Plum TV, which is broadcast in upscale resort areas like Aspen, Martha's Vineyard, Nantucket, Vail and the Hamptons. If you don't live or vacation in those spots but wish to look as if you did, Ultimatecloset.com offers merchandise from the television series. There are no fall items at the moment (just sandals, beach bags and summery Bohemian-inspired fashions), but Lolita Jaca superlong necklaces with glass, silver and wood beads and a dangling multicolored fringe are an impactful accessory in any season ($325).

title: Polished Primitives in the Dunes
description: Amagansett, N.Y. - CHARLES MILITE'S weekend home, nestled behind the dunes in the Napeague area here, went from empty shell to furnished house in a single day.

title: Custody After Civil Union Pits States and Judges
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 7 - Judges in Vermont and Virginia have different ideas about what is best for Isabella Miller-Jenkins, 3, born to a woman who had a civil union with another woman in Vermont. The relationship ended two years ago. Now each woman says Isabella is her daughter, with one asserting exclusive motherhood.

title: Lots of Talk About Poetry and Music, Lots of Unanswerable Questions
description: Richard Strauss called "Capriccio," his final opera, a "conversation piece for music," an unconventional but apt description. It's a dialectical opera about an aesthetic question: What comes first in opera, the music or the words? Do words determine music, or does music flesh out and give breadth to words?

title: Speaking Soul in the Accents of Jazz
description: For roughly the last decade, since leaping from Blue Note Records to Verve, the guitarist John Scofield has oscillated between sleek, modernistic small-group jazz and gritty electric funk. He has assembled different groups for these purposes and courted noticeably different crowds. (His trio headlines jazz clubs; his berjam band plays the Gathering of the Vibes.)

title: West, Northwest, South and New England
description: WEST

title: After the Storm, the Swindlers
description: Even as millions of Americans rally to make donations to the victims of Hurricane Katrina, the Internet is brimming with swindles, come-ons and opportunistic pandering related to the relief effort in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. And the frauds are more varied and more numerous than in past disasters, according to law enforcement officials and online watchdog groups.

title: Auriemma Stays at UConn
description: Geno Auriemma, who has led the Connecticut women's team to five national championships in 20 years, turned his back yesterday on the W.N.B.A.'s Phoenix Mercury, which is seeking a coach.

title: Alarm Growing on Storm's Cost for Agriculture
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7 - Two weeks from the beginning of harvest season, there is a mounting sense of alarm over a potential financial blow to American farming. Farmers in the breadbasket states rely on barges to carry their corn, soybeans and wheat down the Mississippi River, but cannot be certain that the Port of New Orleans, a crucial link to export markets that was badly damaged by Hurricane Katrina, will reopen anytime soon.

title: Ford Said to Be Ready to Pursue a Hertz Sale
description: The Ford Motor Company is planning to recommend to its board today that it sell its Hertz rental car business to a group of investors led by the Carlyle Group for more than $10 billion, according to executives involved in the deal.

title: The Oil-for-Food Failures
description: The latest report from an independent committee investigating the United Nations' oil-for-food program delivers unsparing criticism of both the management team headed by Secretary General Kofi Annan and the Security Council, of which the United States is a permanent member. It faults Mr. Annan for loose management, his staff for corruption and bungling, and the Security Council members for ignoring Iraqi oil smuggling and failing to restrain the surcharges and kickbacks that they knew Saddam Hussein was using to manipulate the program. The criticism of Mr. Annan, by a committee headed by Paul Volcker, a former Federal Reserve chairman, does not look strong enough to warrant his removal, as Republican critics have urged. But the panel's recommendations for urgent management reform should seize the attention of the world's leaders when they gather this month in New York.

title: Jazz Musicians Ask ifTheir Scene Will Survive
description: New Orleans is a jazz town, but also a funk town, a brass-band town, a hip-hop town and a jam-band town. It has international jazz musicians and hip-hop superstars, but also a true, subsistence-level street culture. Much of its music is tied to geography and neighborhoods, and crowds.

title: IMF gains attentionof Mugabe with threat
In Egypt, voting for president marred by fraud charges
Paid Notice: Deaths   HANSEN, TARA
description: HANSEN--Tara. With profound sorrow, the Horace Mann School mourns the tragic passing of Mr. Tara Hansen '70, devoted husband of Anuradha and beloved and cherished father of Amar '06 & Tarun '03. The family's role model and inspiration in life, his sudden death is a great loss to his family and Horace Mann. His passion, loyalty and belief in Horace Mann's work and mission will never be forgotten. Our thoughts and heartfelt condolences are with the family, Anuradha, Amar & Tarun, during this time of deep sadness. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly Head of School Robert J. Katz '65 Chair, Board of Trustees

title: For survivors, a frustrating search
The Ash May Finally Be Falling From the Gauloise
description: PARIS, Sept. 5 - Dropped in among some routine accounts of the reopening of school and the start of the fall clearance sales was a recent notice that a small piece of French tradition is fading away.

title: Bush's leadership; America and China
In Tree Search, a Step Toward Healing Ground Zero
description: EASTPORT, N.Y., Sept. 7 - The starry leaves on the sweet gum trees are already tinged in crimson.

title: One by One, Reluctant Holdouts Obey Mayor's Order to Leave Their Homes
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 - Mayor C. Ray Nagin has ordered her out, for her own good. But Michelle Loranger does not want to leave her flood-battered city.

title: Maybe It Is Time to Fix Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Margot S. Kruskall, 56, an Expert on Blood Banks, Dies
description: Dr. Margot S. Kruskall, a Harvard hematologist and an expert on blood banks who was an early advocate for patients' donations of their own blood before surgery, a practice propelled by the spread of AIDS in the 1980's, died on Aug. 27 at her home in Dover, Mass. She was 56. The cause was ovarian cancer, her family said.

title: Macabre Reminder: The Corpse on Union Street
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 - In the downtown business district here, on a dry stretch of Union Street, past the Omni Bank automated teller machine, across from a parking garage offering "early bird" rates: a corpse. Its feet jut from a damp blue tarp. Its knees rise in rigor mortis.

title: Designing as Fast as They Can
description: LAST Wednesday around 5 p.m., Chellis Stoddard, a pale young woman in a stretch camisole and jeans, crouched on the roof at 181 Chrystie Street on the Lower East Side, spray-painting yards of mouse-gray lace for her boss, Bryan Bradley, the designer of Tuleh. Ms. Stoddard, a new Rhode Island School of Design graduate, considered herself lucky to be up on a baking roof depleting many cans of white Krylon to create what Mr. Bradley hopes will be a blizzard effect for his spring 2006 collection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANZ, SAMUEL STEPHEN
description: FRANZ--Samuel Stephen. The Franz family mourns the loss of Samuel Stephen Franz, devoted husband to Marilyn Hodor Franz for 47 years, beloved father to Marc, Peter and Eric Franz, proud grandfather to Rachel, Samantha, Zachary, Jake, Aviva and Maxwell Franz. Sam was and is a man of great honor; a man of strength and integrity; a man who delivered joy and comfort to all who crossed his path. He will be missed by all and cherished forever. Consistent with his legacy, in lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to a charity of your choice to assist the survivors of Hurricane Katrina. "Reach for the stars, settle for the moon, walk away with a smile" --this is Sam's mantra and we will all remember it as we gaze upon the stars in search for his guidance. Services were held on September 7, 2005.

title: INSIDE
description: Bombs Kill 16 Iraqis And 4 U.S. Contractors A taxi packed with explosives blew up and killed 16 Iraqis in Basra, and another bomb in the same city killed 4 American contractors. The attacks raised the prospect of sectarian violence on a scale that Basra, Iraq's second largest city, has not seen before. PAGE A12

title: Soccer: Draw keeps Portugal on waiting list
For Agassi, Latest Dramatic Victory Ranks High
description: The better moment for Andre Agassi may be yet to come at this United States Open, yet whatever happens against Robby Ginepri in the next round or perhaps even Roger Federer in the final round, Agassi has already given himself the sort of buzz that validates his decision to keep putting his 35-year-old body through the wringer against the younger, quicker, ever-more-powerful set.

title: Chernobyl's Reduced Impact
description: An authoritative scientific report commissioned by the United Nations has found that the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in rural Ukraine -- the worst nuclear accident in history -- caused far less health and environmental damage than originally feared. The findings offer clues for coping with a major release of radiation from a nuclear plant, whether caused by terrorists or by an accident.

title: Egypt Holds a Multiple-Choice Vote, but the Answer Is Mubarak
description: CAIRO, Sept. 7 - Egyptians voted Wednesday in the nation's first multicandidate race for president, and while Egypt has clearly not yet shaken off decades of one-man, one-party rule, the streets were calm, protesters were allowed to block city traffic and voters could cast a ballot for someone other than Hosni Mubarak.

title: Ebbers Will Avoid Prison While Appeal Is Decided
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, may remain free until an appeals court decides whether to overturn his conviction for leading an $11 billion accounting fraud at the company he helped found, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Looking for Late Gains, Ferrer Invokes Old Theme
description: Seeking to portray himself as a champion of society's most vulnerable citizens, Fernando Ferrer all but returned to the controversial "two New Yorks" theme of his failed 2001 candidacy yesterday, hoping to energize support among low-income and liberal New Yorkers in the waning days of the mayoral primary campaign.

title: Albertsons Posts Profit
description: Albertsons, the grocery chain that put itself up for sale last week, posted a second-quarter profit yesterday that was below the analyst estimates.

title: Town Judge Reprimanded for His Links to Litigants
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 7 - A state judicial commission decided Wednesday to publicly censure a town justice in Westchester County, saying he had improperly done business with people involved in two cases he handled, including one involving the death of a teenager in a drunken brawl at a party in 2002.

title: What killed Arafat? Infection a mystery
Schrder and Putin cementing relationship
Michael Vatikiotis: Debating China's 'peaceful rise'
Security fears keep many bank customers offline
Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Aug. 29 about a third-century Roman mosaic being restored at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, included an erroneous credit. The photograph, of the mosaic's original site in what is now southern Turkey, was by Research Photographs, Department of Art and Archaeology, Princeton University.

title: In Times of Stress, Can Religion Serve as Insurance?
description: FROM layoffs to bad health to killer hurricanes, economic well-being is subject to all sorts of nasty shocks. To protect themselves, people accumulate savings and buy insurance.

title: Can Design Prepare for Disaster?
description: "COULD more have been done?" asked Jan Egeland, a United Nations emergency relief co-ordinator, speaking last Friday of the lack of preparedness for the descent of Hurricane Katrina. "I would say every society in the world is not preparing adequately for catastrophic events."

title: A Bitter Contest for Prosecutor, Scuffle and All

But slowly the production is led in new and significant directions by those who know the most about the people who died.

title: 36 Hours in Panama City, Panama
description: PANAMANIANS joke that the McDonald's franchises and glass skyscrapers make Panama City the "Miami of the South," except that more English is spoken here. But more than a decade and a half after an American invasion leveled part of the city and about six years after United States troops pulled out of the country and ceded control of the Panama Canal, the city is asserting itself as a tourist destination, not just a scenic overpass for an engineered waterway. Fashionable hotels now dot the cosmopolitan skyline. Crumbling colonial homes are being polished into bohemian gems. Emerald rain forests woo eco-tourists. There might even be a Frank Gehry-designed museum in the future, with the hope of sparking a so-called "Bilbao effect" for the port of Balboa. For now, anyway, Panama City hasn't been overrun by tourists. But with daily direct flights from about six cities in the United States, including New York, Newark and Los Angeles, that might not last.

title: The State of Iraq: An Update
description: It was not a good summer in Iraq. After the midwinter bright spots - reductions in violence, greater economic vitality, the famous purple fingers of voters - the situation worsened as the weather warmed. Most worrisome, the constitutional process has failed to bring aboard Sunni Arabs, who remain the core of the insurgency. While Shiites and Kurds wisely compromised on some key points, they favor an oil-allocation scheme that Sunnis fear could deprive them of their fair share of Iraq's natural wealth.

title: Neither the Parents Nor the Kids Are All Right
description: Fox is good at finding the bad in people. "The Simpsons," "Malcolm in the Middle" and "Arrested Development" celebrate narcissists and neurotics without any need to reform them. Even "Married ... With Children," a far more old-fashioned and predictable Fox sitcom, had enough bile and bitterness to overcome the fatigue of the genre.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Lynbrook: Sentencing In Commuter's Death
description: A Freeport man was sentenced yesterday to 15 years to life in state prison for killing a commuter in 2003, the Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon, said. Janny Paez, 21, of 44 Nassau Avenue, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in February for the killing of Anthony Battaglia on Sept. 19, 2003. Mr. Battaglia was robbed, beaten, stabbed and shot as he walked home from the train station, prosecutors said. Four other men were also charged in the case; two have pleaded guilty to robbery and two are awaiting trial, prosecutors said.

title: What Lies Beyond Poetry and Music
description: RICHARD STRAUSS called "Capriccio," his final opera, a "conversation piece for music," an unconventional but apt description. It's a dialectical opera about an aesthetic question: What comes first in opera, the music or the words? Do words determine music, or does music flesh out and give breadth to words?

A FEMA spokeswoman talked unconvincingly about the dignity of the dead. But the bizarre demand, a creepy echo of the ban on news media coverage of the coffins returning from Iraq, is simply the latest spasm of a gutted federal agency.
