title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Official Drops Bid For Governor
description: Secretary of the State Susan Bysiewicz has decided to drop out of the governor's race and run instead for re-election, according to several Democratic associates, who said she provided no reason for her withdrawal. Ms. Bysiewicz, 43, has raised $1.7 million since she announced her campaign last October. Her decision leaves two candidates for the Democratic nomination: Mayor Daniel Malloy of Stamford, who has raised $1.5 million, and Mayor John DeStefano Jr. of New Haven, who has raised $2.5 million. In seeking re-election, Ms. Bysiewicz, who has been secretary of the state since 1999, joins seven Democrats seeking the governor's job. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Agassi goes to the limit, and beyond, to win
Broken Yardstick
description: Washington - THE most widely quoted federal statistic on deprivation and need in modern America is the "poverty rate" -- a measure tracking households with annual incomes below a "poverty threshold" established at the beginning of the Johnson administration's "war on poverty" in the 1960's and adjusted over time for inflation. According to the latest poverty rate estimates -- released by the Census Bureau on Aug. 30 -- the total percentage of Americans living in poverty was higher in 2004 (12.7 percent) than in 1974 (11.2 percent). According to that same report, poverty rates for American families and children were likewise higher last year than three decades earlier.

title: A Time of Tangled Transition in Israel, and in a Family
description: Set in 1981 during the early days of the Israeli settler movement, Joseph Cedar's film "Campfire" has come under fire from religious Jews for its portrayal of a group of early settlers on the West Bank as repressive, self-righteous hypocrites. As Mr. Cedar remarks dryly in the film's production notes, the early settler movement was peopled by "mostly middle-class citizens who used the political atmosphere of the time as an excuse to take advantage of what they considered a good real estate opportunity."

title: The Listings: Sept. 9 -- Sept. 15; ARCADE FIRE
description: Last fall was just about the perfect time for the Montreal band Arcade Fire, above, to arrive on the scene. In a Halloween season full of pre-election anxiety, this little indie rock band's urgent anthems suggested both the fragility and resilience of an embattled bohemian idyll. The hot ticket at last year's CMJ Music Marathon, it offered shows that had the zealous verve of a high school musical theater revue. The yelping frontman Win Butler and the diminutive singer and multi-instrumentalist Rgine Chassagne, who are married, turned confident mistakes into shows of strength. Arcade Fire's debut album, "Funeral" (Merge), a loose suite with no fewer than four tracks titled "Neighborhood," draws on the melodic surge of the Pixies as well as the histrionic punk of the Talking Heads. David Byrne, a fan, has even joined Arcade Fire onstage a couple of times for its cover of his band's "This Must Be the Place." But additional folk instrumentation gives Arcade Fire's music a Northern Gothic feel that sets it apart from the current gaggle of young post-punk devotees. The gravitas of "Funeral," inspired by the deaths of older relatives of several members of the band, somehow never blunts the life-affirming, flailingly danceable thump of songs like "Neighborhood No.3 (Power Out)" or the jerky pogo-stomp of "Neighborhood No.2 (Laika)." But with a group this earnest, there's always room for reverie, as when Ms. Chassagne pays homage to her Haitian roots in "Une Anne Sans Lumire." The sense that whimsy is hard-won amid life's chill made "Funeral" the soundtrack of a wound-licking winter. Arcade Fire now returns triumphantly to CMJ, a year after its auspicious New York concerts, to make Central Park its neighborhood for a night. (5:30 p.m., with Sound Team and Bell Orchestre, Central Park SummerStage, Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street; $30 in advance, $35 at the show; sold out.) LAURA SINAGRA

title: Two Girls With One Goal: They Just Want to Have Fun
description: The yummy Japanese confection "Kamikaze Girls" deserves both a better title and an audience to go with it. Based on the novel "Shimotsuma Story" by the cult writer Novala Takemoto, this unassuming charmer has been saddled with a name that summons up images of fighter pilots self-immolating in the name of family and country. The girls of the film's title mostly just want to have fun (as does the director, Tetsuya Nakashima), which doesn't mean their pretty little heads are empty. It's just that thinking seems more agreeable when you're wearing a frilly bonnet and peek-a-boo knee socks that make grown men cry.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: U.N. Expected To Snarl Traffic
description: Security measures for the forthcoming 60th United Nations General Assembly session will render parts of New York City a "gridlock square," Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. Delegates are expected to begin arriving on Monday for what is scheduled to be the largest meeting ever of foreign heads of state in the city. The police and the Secret Service are expecting 168 heads of state, about twice as many as a typical General Assembly, and more than 50 other delegates and their spouses, Mr. Kelly said. President Bush is scheduled to address the delegates on Tuesday, and to stay overnight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. As a result, streets around the United Nations and the hotel will be closed to vehicular traffic. In addition, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be closed near the U.N. from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. on Tuesday, Mr. Kelly said. The session ends on Sept. 28. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Snyder Faults Morgenthau on Drug Laws
description: In her latest salvo against Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, his Democratic primary opponent, Leslie Crocker Snyder, unveiled a new advertisement yesterday that contends that his office thwarted efforts to change the Rockefeller-era drug laws. These laws, enacted in 1973, impose long mandatory prison sentences on anyone, even a first-time offender, who is caught with a certain amount of drugs. Last year, the State Legislature reduced the minimum sentences for drug offenders. It also allowed those who had been convicted of the most serious felonies and sentenced to the longest prison terms to ask a judge for a new sentence. The commercial, called "Anonymous," is running on Time Warner Cable.

title: The Listings: Sept. 9 -- Sept. 15; MICHAEL FITZGERALD AND JAMES KENNEDY
description: The notion of the divided self takes literal form in Brian Friel's 1964 comedy, "Philadelphia, Here I Come!" Gareth O'Donnell, the play's sensitive protagonist, is a young man readying to leave his home in Ireland for the wilder climes of America. His ambivalence about his impending departure -- about everything, in fact -- is plain to see: there are not one but two Gareths onstage at all times, the public and the private, the real Gareth and the imaginary, tougher-tongued character he'd like to be. In the amiable new revival of the play at the Irish Repertory Theater, Michael FitzGerald movingly embodies the public Gareth, who must face the bruising silence of his emotionally withholding father, the quiet kindness of his lost love, the boisterous indifference of his mates. The febrile James Kennedy (above left, with Mr. FitzGerald) is the leprechaun inhabiting his reeling mind, a teasing presence who distracts Michael with a constant stream of chatter: bits of old movies, fantasies of the glorious future, bursts of bile mocking the banality of his father's conversation. The lively rapport between these wonderfully mismatched actors is the captivating centerpiece in Mr. Friel's tale of a heart torn in two. (Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212)727-2737.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

Shariah Proposal Protested in Canada
description: Demonstrators in Toronto, other parts of Canada and a number of European cities marched to oppose a two-year-old proposal being considered by Ontario provincial leaders to allow the use of Shariah, or Islamic law, to settle family disputes. Traditional Muslims argue that they should have the same rights as Jews and Christians to settle issues like divorce and inheritance among themselves. The provincial Liberal government is split on the proposal, which would make Ontario the first jurisdiction in a Western democracy to make Shariah part of its legal system despite criticism that it discriminates against women. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Broadway Is Going to the Movies via a New Musical Promotion
description: Broadway has tried all sorts of marketing schemes to lure new and younger audiences, from television advertising to early-curtain family nights. Now it's going to the movies. At a cinema near you, songs from "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels" and "Wicked" may already be serenading your trip to the popcorn line.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 - Ten days ago, the water rose to the front steps of their house. Four days ago, it began falling. But only now is the city demanding that Richie Kay and Emily Harris get out.

title: Israelis Kill Palestinian at Settlement
description: Israeli troops shot dead one Palestinian and wounded another after the two cut through a fence at an evacuated Jewish settlement in the southern Gaza Strip, the Israeli military and Palestinian medics said. The shooting was the second time in three days that soldiers have fatally shot a Palestinian who entered one of the settlements, which are off limits to Palestinians. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Senate Democrats Are Shifting Focus From Roberts to Other Seat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - Senate Democrats say the death of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist has eased the pressure on them to oppose the Supreme Court nomination of Judge John G. Roberts Jr. but has set the stage for a more contentious battle over the other vacancy on the court.

title: Wells Revisits Yankees on Spotlight's Brighter Side
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7 - David Wells, all 250 pounds or more of him, was not talking. This is highly unusual. It is snow in the Congo, politeness on the rush-hour IRT, a bargain at the gas pump. "Not interested," he told a reporter from New York.

Vatican Making Effort to Mend Strained Relations
description: Pope Benedict XVI may visit Turkey in November and has invited four bishops from China to take part in a synod next month, both moves that could improve strained relations. Cardinal Walter Kasper, in charge of the Vatican's efforts at Christian unity, said negotiations for the Turkey trip were under way with the Turkish government, which has not issued an invitation. Reuters reported that if some or all of the Chinese bishops are allowed to travel to Rome, their trip will represent a major thaw in relations between the Holy See and China, which does not allow its Catholics to recognize the pope. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Riding on empty
Polishing, and Inflating, Their Records
description: In the final debate before Tuesday's primary, the four Democratic mayoral candidates all agreed last night that they would make building the long-talked-about Second Avenue subway their No. 1 transportation priority. But only C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, went as far as to take credit for reviving the issue.

title: Blank Invoices Detailed in Political Corruption Trial
description: During two hard-fought primary campaigns, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn Democratic chairman, told a political consultant to just send over badly needed supplies like posters and leaflets, saying he would "get someone else to pay for it," the consultant testified yesterday in Mr. Norman's political corruption trial.

description: SCHER--Benjamin. The employees of Scher Fabrics, Inc. mourn the loss of our cofounder, our beloved Mr. Ben, at the age of 104. A gentle, sweet soul, Ben devoted himself to the growth and development of Scher Fabrics from its earliest days until he reached his 90's. His concern for his employees was legendary. This season will be Barber's ninth in the N.F.L., and that is a long time spent eluding tacklers in pro football's most hazardous position.

title: New in Escapes
description: STARTING today, Escapes expands its borders to include weekend travel and real estate outside the United States, including Canada, the Caribbean and Latin America. A new column, Havens, will cover second-home real estate nationally. Coverage of automobiles will remain available in the Automobiles section on Sunday and on the Monday Automobiles page in the Sports section. In its place, Escapes will offer enhanced reporting on participatory sports and adventure travel. Comments are welcome, at escapes@nytimes.com.

Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about the closing of Kepler's, a bookstore in Menlo Park, Calif., that became a hub for the counterculture in the 1960's and 70's, misstated its association with Fred Cody, who ran another bookstore in the San Francisco area. While Mr. Cody was a friend of Roy Kepler, the founder of Kepler's, he did not work at the store. The article also misstated the background of Cody's Books, in Berkeley, Calif. Mr. Cody founded it with his wife, Pat. He was not the sole founder.

title: Corrections
description: A headline with an article yesterday about action by Congress in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina referred incorrectly to an investigation into failures surrounding the government response. The investigation will be bicameral, but its political composition has not been determined and Democrats were not involved in putting the panel together. The article also gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of the director of the Office of Management and Budget, who said $51.8 billion requested for hurricane relief was expected to last "at least several weeks." He is Joshua B. Bolten, not Bolton.

title: Eagles remain the favorite
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (AMC) MOVIES THAT SHOOK THE WORLD: FATAL ATTRACTION -- Series premiere. No, they're not showing Adrian Lyne's 1987 psychological thriller about one man's tiny marital infidelity and all the marriage-threatening, life-threatening trouble it creates. This is the first in a series of nine film-clipand- interview episodes. Asked about the movie's impact, Mr. Lyne (shown above filming the 2002 drama "Unfaithful") says, "Husbands definitely were chastened." Glenn Close, who starred in the film with Michael Douglas, says, with a laugh, "Hollywood loves to see women being brought down." Only a few people in the documentary talk about the most powerful sociosexual influence of the 1980's: AIDS, which had suddenly made casual sex deadly dangerous.

title: Confusion on Debit Card Aid
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 8 - After a day of confusion and complaints, officials of the Federal Emergency Management Agency said Thursday that the agency would not expand a trial program to distribute debit cards worth $2,000 to victims of Hurricane Katrina for immediate living expenses.

title: Sheffield Believes a Quick Recovery Is Likely
description: Gary Sheffield played through shoulder pain last season, and he has continued to play despite knee problems this summer. But Sheffield was out of the Yankees' lineup last night because the injury he sustained Wednesday did not improve overnight.

title: Chirac Discharged From Hospital
description: President Jacques Chirac left the hospital with a clean bill of health, but his doctors said he should rest for 15 days and refrain from air travel for six weeks. Those instructions, his aides later said, mean he will miss a special United Nations session next week.

title: Hope Appears to Take the Night Off for the Mets
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 - Through every rough patch this season, Manager Willie Randolph has maintained an even keel. He has been defiant that the Mets -- his guys -- would come to play, scratch out a victory and begin the day anew, full of hope and faith and optimism. The season, after all, does not end until Oct. 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FLORENCE
description: BERNSTEIN--Florence, died September 7. For many years Florence was the Public Relations Coordinator at The New York Philharmonic, and previously worked as a personal assistant to a number of Hollywood celebrities, including Charles Bronson and Shirley MacLaine. All of her Kaufman family cousins, Jay, Carol and John, Newton, Milton and Shannon, and Robert and Kim, send their deepest sympathies to her twin sister Charlotte and her loving nephews on this sad occasion.$(6$)

title: Arts, Briefly; TV's Summer Staggers To Its Finish
description: These last days of the summer season are displaying the dregs of television. No network was an actual winner on Wednesday night's Nielsen competition, but NBC garnered the most viewers, and Fox delivered the highest adult 18-to-49 ratings. Though NBC led off the night with "Meet Mr. Mom," which drew only an estimated 4.05 million viewers, two repeat episodes of "Law & Order" (8.92 million, then 8.74 million) brought up its average. Fox's measure of victory was due to a 90-minute "So You Think You Can Dance," which brought in 7.56 million viewers, and the largest number of 18-to-49-year-olds. On CBS, Tommy Hilfiger's flop of a reality show, "The Cut," sputtered to a close: only 4.36 million viewers watched Chris Cortez, who had said from the beginning that he revered Mr. Hilfiger, win the design competition. Monday's season finale of "The Closer" on TNT attracted an audience of 6.3 million. It ended its summer run as the top-rated original series on advertiser-supported cable this year, and it has been renewed for a second season. KATE AURTHUR

title: Kayak Fishing
description: THIS fall, get out on the water in a whole new way. Sure, paddling is enjoyable and fly-fishing is all the rage, but if you grab your paddle and your rod, along with some of the latest gear, you might catch more than a view of the foliage. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Crispin Porter & Bogusky Awarded Sprite Assignment

Spending was estimated at $45 million.

title: New Strain of Wheat Rust Appears in Africa
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 8 - Biologists warned Thursday that a virulent new strain of a previously controlled plant disease had emerged in East Africa and could wipe out 10 percent of the world's wheat production if its spread is not halted.

description: "It's like taking a jail and shaking it up in a fruit-basket turnover, so no one has any idea who these people are or why they're here."

title: Dancing With the Devil, Then With a Prosecutor
description: "The Exorcism of Emily Rose," directed by Scott Derrickson from a script he wrote with Paul Harris Boardman, is a horror movie wrapped in a courtroom drama. A priest (Tom Wilkinson) is accused of negligent homicide because a young woman in his care has died after a failed exorcism. For the defense, we have Laura Linney, whose character, Erin Bruner, is an ambitious lawyer with somewhat better taste in liquor than in courtroom attire. For the prosecution, with gray at his temples and a neat little mustache riding his lip, there is Campbell Scott, whose character's steely patience eventually wears thin. "Your honor, I object," he exclaims, as every good courtroom-drama lawyer must. On what grounds? "Well, silliness, for one."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, MILDRED
description: EDELSTEIN--Mildred. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of Mildred Edelstein, a long-standing American Friend known for her enduring dedication to Israel and its people. Along with her late husband, Sidney, Mildred's generous acts of philanthropy enabled the creation of HU's Edelstein Library on the History of Science, as well as the Sidney M. Edelstein's Center for the History and Philosophy of Science, Technology and Medicine. Mildred's memory will exist in perpetuity at The Hebrew University and among a new generation of scholars and leaders for Israel. We extend our sympathies to her daughter, Ruth, and to the entire family. AFHU George A. Schieren, President Ira Lee Sorkin, Chair Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director The Hebrew University Prof. Menachem Magidor, President

title: Briefs: Inquiry targets General Re chief
America's Priciest Getaways
description: SULLIVAN'S ISLAND, S.C. - A SUDDEN rainstorm signals an early lunch hour, and beachgoers head off the expansive stretch of sand toward the center of town. The main drag, all three blocks of it, includes a Kangaroo Express gas station, a dentist's office, a day spa and a handful of restaurants including Bert's Bar, a local pub with the motto "If it hurts, go to Bert's." Across the street, inside Poe's Tavern, known for its burgers and fish tacos, the scene is unhurried and casual, with shorts and T-shirts favored over button-down shirts and slacks.

McSwain Jr., chief of trauma surgery at the New Orleans hospital known as Big Charity, relished watching what he called "water blowing sideways in big slats, like Venetian blinds," from inside his office at the adjacent Tulane University School of Medicine.

title: Ukraine's Orange Flame, Dimmed
description: So ends the Orange Revolution, at least Act I. After months of increasingly nasty disputes, Ukraine's president, Viktor Yushchenko, fired his charismatic prime minister and nominated a caretaker to replace her. The fired prime minister, Yulia Tymoshenko, has said nothing -- yet. But she will. Her fiery speeches and powerful presence were a major factor in the popular uprising that brought Mr. Yushchenko to power last fall, and she is certain to turn these weapons on the president and his new government, especially with elections for Parliament scheduled for March. All that is a serious blow to the hopes and expectations that had been raised for the future of Ukraine, and for reformers in Belarus and other former Soviet republics.

title: EU puts pressure on oil firms
Billions for Vaccines for the Poor to Be Raised in Bond Markets
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - Britain, France, Spain, Italy and Sweden will announce an agreement on Friday to raise almost $4 billion on the bond markets for an enormously expanded use of vaccines across the developing world. The World Health Organization estimates this undertaking will save the lives of five million children over the next decade.

Berger, an influential adviser to former President Bill Clinton who helped shape American foreign policy through the 1990's, was ordered Thursday to pay a higher-than-expected fine of $50,000 but received no jail time for removing and destroying copies of classified documents from the National Archives.

title: Auditor for Schools in Roslyn Is Charged

title: A Mountaintop Retreat With an Artistic Air
description: THE mountaintop hamlet of Cragsmoor clings to New York's Shawangunk Mountains, west of the Hudson River, as tenacious as the dwarf pitch pines native to its landscape. It's a community of winding roads, sweeping views and rustic shingle-style cottages, many built by members of the Cragsmoor Art Colony in the late 1800's. Taking stock in 1906, a local newspaper, The Cragsmoor Journal, found it a "harmonious community active-minded and deeply interested in the best art, literature, drama and music."

Push to Empower Police in Australia
description: Prime Minister John Howard proposed tough new counterterrorism laws, including allowing the police to use tracking devices to monitor suspected terrorists, and expanding police powers to "stop, question and search." Mr. Howard said the measures were a response to the London bombings. The program would also give more power to the country's domestic intelligence agency to search houses and intercept mail; would give the police and intelligence agency access to airline passenger information; and would make it a crime to leave baggage unattended at an airport. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gotti Defense Gets Last Word
description: On the final day before jury deliberations in the racketeering trial of John A. Gotti, the Gambino crime family scion, the judge made the rare move of allowing the defense to have the last word. Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan allowed Mr. Gotti's lawyer, Jeffrey Lichtman, and another defense lawyer, Diarmuid White, eight minutes each to respond to the prosecution's final arguments. The judge said the burden was on Mr. Lichtman to prove that Mr. Gotti withdrew from organized crime after 1999. Later she read 111 pages of jury instructions. Deliberations should begin today. Julia Preston (NYT)

The Listings: Sept. 9 -- Sept. 15; JENNY SCHEINMAN
description: The violin has a long history in jazz, but few conspicuous heroes; for every Stephane Grappelli, there are dozens of horn and rhythm players of greater renown. So it makes sense that Jenny Scheinman, above, has earned her recent accolades in an unforced and roundabout fashion. She's ubiquitous on the indie fringe of New York's jazz scene, appearing every Tuesday at Barbs in Brooklyn (often in a string trio with Carla Kihlstedt, of the exuberantly eclectic Tin Hat Trio) and every Wednesday at the Living Room (backed by the Handsome Band, which she shares with Norah Jones). This month she has interrupted this regular schedule to focus on a special ensemble in celebration of an outstanding new CD, "12 Songs" (Cryptogramophone). It maintains an aura of wistful lyricism and dreamy self-reflection, not unlike the music of Ms. Jones. But the songs are structurally diverse, ranging from the gently twangy "Song of the Open Road" to the circus march "Moe Hawk" to the sepia-tinged border postcard "Satelite." More crucially, the album's septet consists of musicians who, like Ms. Scheinman, playfully apply jazz techniques to many varieties of folk music. Chief among them is the guitarist Bill Frisell, Ms. Scheinman's most visible employer; his replacement in her forthcoming gig at Tonic, one "Moe Hawk," will resemble him uncannily. Also playing are the cornetist Ron Miles, the clarinetist Doug Wieselman and the drummer Mark Ferber -- and, as a bonus, a 16-piece string orchestra studded with the heavyweights Eyvind Kang, Mat Maneri and Dana Leong. Counting Ms. Scheinman, there will be nine violinists onstage. (Monday at 8 and 10 p.m. at Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212)358-7501; cover, $12.) NATE CHINEN

title: Arts, Briefly; Muted Parties
description: Historically, this week is the beginning of the media party season, but its pace and mood will be slowed by the national tragedy on the Gulf Coast. The Forbes annual media party, in which the Forbes family and executives treat working reporters and editors to a ride on the Hudson River aboard a huge yacht, did not take place as scheduled on Wednesday. "It has been a five-year annual party night for competitors and colleagues in the media," said Monie Begley, a spokeswoman for Forbes. "But the events in New Orleans are just too vivid, so not this year." Cond Nast, the publisher of magazines including Vogue and Vanity Fair, had its Fashion Rocks concert scheduled for last night. The company took a different approach, deciding that the show must go on but rechristening it as a benefit. Cond Nast executives said the show, which is held at Radio City Music Hall and includes musical acts from David Bowie to Shakira, right, to Tim McGraw, will now donate all ticket proceeds, about $250,000, to relief efforts for victims of Hurricane Katrina. The Newhouse family owns Cond Nast, but it also owns The Times-Picayune, the daily paper in New Orleans that managed to do some gritty reporting despite having to evacuate its offices, and its foundation has already donated $1 million to the American Red Cross. A taped version of Fashion Rocks is scheduled for broadcast tonight at 9 p.m. on CBS and will now follow the multinetwork telethon to raise money for those affected by the tragedy. "When the events of New Orleans happened, we thought it was important to turn on a dime and use the buzz and awareness that this show creates to galvanize America to donate to the organizations that are working to alleviate the suffering on the Gulf Coast," said Richard Beckman, president of Cond Nast's media group. DAVID CARR

description: "The Outsiders" has long been one of Francis Ford Coppola's least loved films, somewhat of an orphan of both his personal and professional storms. Released in 1983, the film did well enough at the box office, but critics were largely unimpressed, even contemptuous. S.E. Hinton had written her wildly popular book in her sophomore year of high school, and it was published in 1967. Years later, a school librarian wrote to Mr. Coppola and, on behalf of both students and faculty, asked him to turn Ms. Hinton's unvarnished adolescent musings into a film. In 1982, he complied and shot a movie he would describe as "a 'Gone With the Wind' for 14-year-old girls."

title: The Listings: Sept. 9 -- Sept. 15; DAVID NEUMANN
description: In the current economic climate, downtown choreographers (and audiences) don't often have the luxury of encore performances. On Thursday, David Neumann and the Advanced Beginner Group are bucking this disheartening trend with his crowd-pleaser "tough, the tough," which had its premiere in April at the Danspace Project. There is a bit of cast shuffling, including the replacement of Kimiye Corwin by the choreographer's friend and collaborator Adrienne Truscott; Mr. Neumann, above, whose fluid physical presence and intelligent wit always threaten in the scene-stealing department, was one of the highlights of her uneven but engaging "they will take to the highways," also seen last April, at P.S. 122. Cast changes lend themselves to shifts in choreography, but basically "tough, the tough" returns intact. Created in collaboration with the composer Hal Hartley and the playwright Will Eno, this abstract dance, performed in the round, uses text, soundscape and pedestrian movement to explore the organizing principles of routine, from daily life to the Marx Brothers to the changing of the guard along the Pakistan-India border. Like much of Mr. Neumann's work, it examines the brain's relationship to the body in a self-conscious, humorous look at the human animal; in his words, "how we deal with space, what we think we're communicating when we're communicating." Mr. Neumann is often talked about as the reigning funny man of dance. His is a sly, sophisticated humor, more thoughtful than slapstick, and "tough, the tough" represents a maturing of his voice, with dark shadings. While Mr. Neumann rejects interpretations that have linked this piece to events surrounding the Sept. 11 attacks, he does acknowledge a certain apocalyptic whiff in the air. As he says, "Death and disaster are all around, and yet we still have to get up and brush our teeth." (Thursday through Sept. 18, Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212)674-8194.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Approval For A Ground Zero Plan
description: The demolition plan for the severely contaminated former Deutsche Bank building on Liberty Street opposite ground zero was deemed acceptable yesterday by the federal Environmental Protection Agency, clearing the way for scaffolding that will enclose the 41-story tower as it comes down. Stefan Pryor, the president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which acquired the building from Deutsche Bank last year, said, "We will begin deconstruction in the new year and take it down over the course of about 12 months." The structure, badly damaged on Sept. 11, 2001, contains high levels of asbestos, lead, dioxins and other hazardous contaminants. Demolition was to begin last December, but the environmental agency said the draft demolition proposal did not adequately guard against "significant potential for releases of contamination." The number of air-monitoring stations has been increased to 12 from 7, and quality controls have been devised to govern how samples are taken and how data are analyzed and submitted, said Pat Evangelista, the World Trade Center coordinator for the environmental agency. He said that the new plan would be "protective of the area's residents and workers." The development corporation has already awarded cleanup and demolition contracts. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Continental Air Projects Big Loss Because of High Fuel Costs
description: Continental Airlines said today that it expected to post a "significant" loss for 2005 as a result of the record high cost of jet fuel, which is squeezing the beleaguered airline industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, BETTY C.
description: ROSEN--Betty C., 72 of Ridgewood, NJ, formerly of Larchmont, NY, on September 7, 2005. A retired Special Education Teacher in New Rochelle, NY. Survived by husband Stanley, son Stephen, daughter Linda Heinberg, grandchildren Sophie and Simon Heinberg. Services are 1:00pm, Sunday at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt.4, Paramus, NJ.

Cost of Recovery Surges, as Do Bids to Join in Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - With Congress primed to spend billions of dollars on the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, lawmakers and industry groups are lining up to bring home their share of the cascade of money for rebuilding and relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANSEN, TARA
description: HANSEN--Tara. With profound sorrow, the Horace Mann School mourns the tragic passing of Mr. Tara Hansen '70, devoted husband of Anuradha and beloved and cherished father of Amar '06 & Tarun '03. The family's role model and inspiration in life, his sudden death is a great loss to his family and Horace Mann. His passion, loyalty and belief in Horace Mann's work and mission will never be forgotten. Our thoughts and heartfelt condolences are with the family, Anuradha, Amar & Tarun, during this time of deep sadness. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly Head of School Robert J. Katz '65 Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Ruth Built the Steakhouse. Katrina Intervened.
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 8 - It was the steakhouse that Ruth built, a New Orleans institution that sizzled over the last four decades not just as a tourist favorite but also as a popular hangout for the city's power brokers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Lads Who Love Being Thugs and the Lads Who Love Them
description: In "Green Street Hooligans," a feature-length folly about the terrors and self-affirming joys of football (that is, soccer) hooliganism, the young British actor Charlie Hunnam enters in full swagger. A fine-boned beauty who holds the screen with ease, Mr. Hunnam plays his character, Pete Dunham, a full-time teacher and part-time thug, as a sexual predator. But here's the rub: the object of Pete's desire isn't the pretty girl (or boy) next door, but the sneering, shouting and swearing fans across the stadium. Like his equally hopped-up friends, he can't wait to have his way with them.

title: Where's the Governator Now?
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger was a profile in timidity this week when he vowed to veto a pioneering bill authorizing gay marriage in California. The bill, which both houses of the Legislature passed by narrow margins, would expand the definition of marriage to include a civil contract between two people, not exclusively a man and woman. This was an enlightened and fair-minded stand that made California's Legislature the first in the nation to approve same-sex marriages.

title: The French Still Obsess Over Their Gloomy Novelist of Despair
description: PARIS, Sept. 9 - With its customary hype and hope, the annual French literary season known as la rentre littraire opened this week, with no fewer than 663 novelists elbowing for attention. Mostly in vain, it seems. To judge by the French press, Michel Houellebecq is the only writer who counts. And that was before the public had even read his latest novel, "The Possibility of an Island."

description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 9 - Charlie Weis of Notre Dame is 1-0 as a college football coach at a place where Knute Rockne walked and talked. So Weis cannot yet make speeches about great success over great lengths of time.

description: If those five match points tempted her, a steely nerved Kim Clijsters refused to let their loss haunt her. Instead, deep into the third and final set, she dared her top-seeded opponent, Maria Sharapova, to keep striking winners.

description: A former employee of the defunct Drake Business Schools and a friend have been charged with stealing more than $800,000 from one of the campuses, the Queens district attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Man Convicted in '64 Case and Out on Bail Is Rejailed
description: A judge sent Edgar Ray Killen, the former Klansman convicted of the 1964 killing of three civil rights workers in Mississippi, back to prison yesterday, saying Mr. Killen had deceived the court about his health when he asked to be released on bond.

title: Public Advocate Runs Hard Just to Stay Where She Is
description: Early Wednesday morning found Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum out on the campaign trail again, this time at a bus stop in Co-op City in the Bronx. Dutifully, she greeted every commuter walking from the giant apartment buildings, appealing for votes in a far-off corner of the city.

title: In New Orleans as It Did in New York, X Marks the Pain
description: NEW ORLEANS - A CRUDE symbol has surfaced in New Orleans to displace for now the fleur-de-lis, the crescent and the string of beads. It is a large X sprayed with neon-orange paint onto the emptied homes, the violated stores -- even the city buses that litter streets like giant discarded milk cartons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASSER, EMILY J.S.
description: LASSER--Emily J.S. Died September 9, 2005. Wife of Jim, mother of Jonina, Jesse, Josh (and Amishi), and John. Teacher, volunteer fire fighter, writer and exemplar who lived by the principle of tikun olam. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Cancer Support Team, Enrico "Hank" Longo Burn Center, Edgemont School Foundation, Jansen Memorial Hospice or a charity close to your heart. Services at Temple Israel of New Rochelle on Monday at 9:30AM. For information contact the George T. Davis Funeral Home: 914-632-0324.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Import Prices Rose in August As Petroleum Costs Soared Soaring petroleum costs pushed import prices up sharply in August, government data showed yesterday, but other import prices remained quite subdued. The Labor Department said import prices rose 1.3 percent last month; Wall Street had expected a 1.2 percent gain. July's import price numbers were revised down to show a gain of 0.8 percent gain from the 1.1 percent previously reported. Export prices fell 0.1 percent, compared with forecasts for a 0.2 percent increase and a 0.1 percent rise in July. Excluding petroleum, import prices were flat last month compared with a 0.2 percent decline in July and have shown no increase since rising 0.4 percent in April, the Labor Department said. Over the last 12 months, import prices have risen 7.6 percent, reflecting a 42.5 percent rise in the cost of petroleum. Stripping out petroleum, import prices are up 1.8 percent over the last 12 months. (Reuters)

title: A Deepening Gloom About Ground Zero's Future
description: There has been no healing, really. Four years have passed since the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, and the road to recovery at ground zero looks bleaker than ever. A rebuilding effort that was originally cast as a symbolic rising from the ashes has long since turned into a hallucinogenic nightmare: a roller coaster ride of grief, navet, recriminations, political jockeying and paranoia.

title: Boeing Acts to Settle 2 Inquiries
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9 - The Boeing Company is negotiating with federal prosecutors to avoid charges in two separate investigations, expecting to pay a combined $300 million to $500 million, in a move that would allow the company's new chief executive to focus on other challenges, including a week-old strike by 18,000 machinists.

title: Bankruptcy on a Dime? Think Fast
description: FEW words evoke the specter of financial ruin like "filing for bankruptcy." Yet for many Americans with financial problems, the question of whether to file has taken on new urgency.

title: Preparing For Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Patriots Change, but Their Results Don't
description: The rest of the N.F.L. looked at the New England Patriots this summer and engaged in some wishful thinking. Maybe the Patriots, winners of three of the last four Super Bowls, would not be able to cope with the loss of linebackers Tedy Bruschi and Ted Johnson, and the departures of their defensive coordinator, Romeo Crennel, and offensive coordinator, Charlie Weis. Maybe it would all be too much for the Patriots to handle.

description: WEST

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Chirac Discharged From Hospital
description: President Jacques Chirac left the hospital with a clean bill of health, but his doctors said he should rest for 15 days and refrain from air travel for six weeks. Those instructions, his aides later said, mean he will miss a special United Nations session next week. Mr. Chirac, 72, was admitted to the Val-de-Grace military hospital in Paris on Sept. 2 for a "small vascular accident" that impaired his vision. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, CHARLOTTE BREUER
description: KATZ--Charlotte Breuer, 94. Devoted to Sirol (deceased), children Alfred and Deborah Katz, Miriam and Herb Cohen, grandchildren, great grandchildren. Caring, generous, thoughtful, indomitable. A force in so many lives. Graveside service Sunday. Shiva in Riverdale for three days. Contributions to Hatzalah Ambulance, PO Box 181, Riverdale, NY 10471 or Children's Aid Society.

title: Endorsement by Sharpton to Go to Ferrer
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, whose endorsement has been widely sought in the mayor's race, has decided to endorse Fernando Ferrer in hopes of pushing him over the top to victory in Tuesday's Democratic primary election, according to associates of Mr. Sharpton.

title: A Rewarding Use for Reward Miles
description: Herbert Fenster, a lawyer in Denver has given away millions. Genny Smith, a school counselor in Huntersville, N.C., has given away 100,000. And Maura Quinn, a news producer in Chicago, has donated 25,000 -- not dollars, but the miles and points they have accumulated in a variety of rewards programs.

title: Some Ways to Prepare for the Absolute Worst
description: Pam Stegner knows a lot about preparing for an emergency. After all, Mrs. Stegner, a former emergency medical technician in Collins, Mo., has been stockpiling for years now.

title: Weiner, Who Once Imagined a Resurgence, Now Has One
description: When Anthony D. Weiner thinks about the future, he occasionally dwells on the past -- 1977, to be specific, when Edward I. Koch was in last place against a crowded field of better-known Democratic mayoral candidates, only to surge ahead in the primary's final days, beat Mario Cuomo in a runoff and then beat him again to become the city's 105th mayor.

title: Continental Sees Significant 2005 Loss
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it expected to post what it termed a significant loss for 2005, citing the high cost of jet fuel.

title: Abraham Ready to Add New Twist to His Game
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 9 - Reeling from criticism, John Abraham has come up with a new spin.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about German carmakers developing hybrid gasoline-electric cars misstated a word in a quotation about fuel from Michael Blabst, a BMW spokesman. He said: "We recognize that the infrastructure and availability of liquid hydrogen has not developed the way we thought it would two years ago," not "liquid nitrogen."

title: Panel Backs Drug Amid Conflict Concerns
description: Questions about potential conflicts of interest continue to dog the federal drug approval process.

title: How to Help
description: Following are the main groups that the Federal Emergency Management Agency says are organizing aid for those affected by the hurricane. The agency also directs those wishing to give to the Web site networkforgood.org, and a list of such groups is available at nytimes.com/katrina.

title: Agassi, 35 and in Uncharted Waters
description: Andre Agassi has surmounted plenty in his two-decade evolution from shaggy-haired, foul-mouthed youth to follicly challenged champion and spokesman of substance.

title: $250 Million City Program to Promote Charter Schools
description: In the city's most aggressive effort yet to promote the creation of charter schools, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that the city would pay up to two-thirds of the cost of constructing new buildings for them.

title: Synagogue Dispute Clouds Gaza Transfer
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 - The Israeli Army completed the removal of its military equipment from the Gaza Strip on Friday, demolishing the last of its buildings and watchtowers, in preparation for a transfer to the Palestinians on Sunday or Monday.

title: The Necessity of New Orleans
description: AS horrible as Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath have been, the markets and pundits have concluded that the economic fallout won't be so bad.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Seeks Allies to Confront Iran on Nuclear Plans The Bush administration has opened an unusual diplomatic struggle with Russia, China and India to bring Iran's suspected nuclear weapons project before the United Nations Security Council for possible sanctions. PAGE A3

title: Looking Beyond Floodwaters and Seeing Red Ink
description: HURRICANE KATRINA'S effect on the Gulf Coast is distressingly clear. Its damage to the United States economy just started to come into focus this week. The hurricane seems certain to rank as the costliest, if not the deadliest, natural disaster in the nation's history, and economists say that it is likely to affect economic growth, interest rates, insurance premiums, energy costs and taxes throughout the country.

title: The Divide Laid Bare by Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: True to the Bollywood Look, While Defying Traditions
description: Preity Zinta must be the Katie Holmes of the Indian film industry. She is cheerleader-homecoming queen-fraternity sweetheart pretty, so even when her characters are being unkind it's hard not to like her.

title: Advocates for Mentally Ill Defend Housing Program Used by Stabbing Suspect
description: Two days after a baby girl was stabbed in her stroller in Upper Manhattan and a man in a residential housing program for the mentally ill was arrested in the attack, some mental health advocates defended the program, saying there is no better way to help the mentally ill than by integrating them into the community.
