description: New York City public schools showed modest gains in an annual listing of schools needing improvement, the State Education Department said yesterday.

title: Practicing a Gentle Choreography of the Mundane
description: Francesca Selva does not want to set the world on fire, to judge by the American debut program the Italian choreographer presented on Thursday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Ms. Selva is content with quiet exploration of unremarkable themes.

title: STORM AND CRISIS
description: MEMORIES OF 'X' -- For some, the new symbol of New Orleans, a large X on a building, evokes the aftermath of Sept. 11 in New York. PAGE B1

title: U.S. Team Starts Fast, but Falters on Back 9 at Solheim Cup
description: CARMEL, Ind., Sept. 9 - Christina Kim arrived at Crooked Stick Golf Club early Friday morning, a Solheim Cup rookie trying to cheat nervousness with a predawn wake-up call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCE, HENRY III.
description: LUCE--Henry III. On September 8, 2005, age 80, on Fishers Island, NY, of cardiac arrest. He was the husband of Leila Hadley Luce, the father of Lila Frances Luce, Ph.D., and Henry Christopher Luce, stepfather of Arthur T. Hadley III, M.D., Victoria Smitter Barlow, Matthew Smitter Eliott, D.V.M., and Caroline Smitter Nicholson, Ph.D., and brother of Peter Paul Luce. Born in New York City in 1925, he was the elder son of Time Inc.'s late co-founder and editor-in-chief, Henry Robinson Luce, and the late Lila Hotz Tyng. He served in the United States Navy and graduated from the Brooks School and Yale University. With Time Inc. for thirty years, he was the publisher of Fortune and Time, vice president for corporate planning, and a member of Time Inc.'s and Time Warner's board of directors. He was a trustee of Princeton Theological Seminary, the Center of Theological Inquiry, The College of Wooster, Brooklyn Museum of Art, A Christian Ministry in the National Parks, Eisenhower Exchange Fellowships, NewYork Historical Society, United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia, Yale-China Association, and a director of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations. He served as president of the New Museum of Contemporary Art, chairman of the board of China Institute in America, president of The Pilgrims of the U.S., and an elder of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. For forty-seven years, he was a director of the Henry Luce Foundation,serving as president and then as chairman and C.E.O. until 2002. Memorial services will be held in New York City and Fishers Island on dates to be announced. $(6$)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the settlement of a federal lawsuit against Caremark Rx misstated the status of related lawsuits pending against the company. The suits were filed by plaintiffs' lawyers, under state whistleblower laws, in federal district court in Philadelphia. They were not filed by officials in the states.

title: Playing in a European Fishbowl To Faintly Heard Applause
description: Alan Truscott, who died on Sunday, was an excellent bridge player, winning the 1961 European Championship and several American national championships, including the Master Mixed Teams in 1985, the North American Swiss Teams in 1987 and the Mixed Pairs in 1989. He juggled playing with his journalistic duties, not just for The New York Times but also for the International Bridge Press Association, serving as its president from 1981 to 1986. He also found time for family, both his and that of his second wife, Dorothy. He went to the Adirondacks for summers, where children, grandchildren and friends were frequent visitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRIGOSEN, FAE
description: PRIGOSEN--Fae. On September 8. Preceded in death by older sisters and brothers and numerous nieces and nephews. Survived by grandson Eli Hurowitz, MD, his wife Hope Mehlman Hurowitz and their children (Fae's greatgrandchildren Haley Hurowitz and Jonathan Hurowitz).

title: G.O.P. Sees Opportunities Arising From Storm
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 9 - Republican leaders in Congress and some White House officials see opportunities in Hurricane Katrina to advance longstanding conservative goals like giving students vouchers to pay for private schools, paying churches to help with temporary housing and scaling back business regulation.

title: The Divide Laid Bare by Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Driver Charged In Pedestrian Death
description: A car driven by a Wisconsin man whose driver's license was suspended struck and killed an elderly woman in Woodhaven yesterday afternoon as she returned from grocery shopping, the police said. Christina Sullivan, 73, was crossing Atlantic Avenue at 92nd Street with a cart full of groceries, when she was struck about 3:30 p.m. by a brown Dodge S.U.V. driven by Michael Flaugeu, 33, of Green Bay, Wisc., the police said. Mr. Flaugeu was arrested at the scene and charged with driving with a suspended license, they said. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: The Bling and the Bliss, Delivered in a Bespoke Suit
description: IF you ever start itching to find some kind of deeper meaning, try toting a blue velvet box full of rocks custom made by the King of Bling through the Manhattan subway system at rush hour. I can pretty much guarantee that within the first couple of stops, some kind of deeper meaning will find you.

title: Abu Ghraib Unresolved
description: Ever since the world learned of the illegal detentions and brutal behavior at American military prisons, the Bush administration has bet it could outlast public outrage with phony investigations and stonewalling. Just before Congress went on summer holiday, Republican leaders actually yanked the military budget from the Senate floor rather than face two amendments intended to impose the rule of law on the camps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALES, KATHARINE LADD
description: FALES--Katharine Ladd, on September 9, 2005, of Bedminster, NJ. Wife of Haliburton Fales. Mother of Nancy Fales Garrett of Delhi, NY and NY, NY, Hal Fales of Leeds, Mass, Priscilla Fales of Cambridge, Mass, Lucy Fales Evans of Denver, CO, and William E.L. Fales of Carbondale, CO. Sister of Nancy L. Crocker of New Canaan, CT. Grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of two. Memorial Service Wednesday, September 14, 2005 at 3PM in St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone. In lieu of flowers, donations to the St. Luke's Episcopal Church Main St., Gladstone, NJ, 07934 or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 101 E. 70th St., NY, NY. For more info contact Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack. 908-234-0590.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: ABC's Primetime Shows to Speak Spanish

title: 40 Throws And, So Far,No Pain
description: Mike Mussina played catch yesterday, the first time he has thrown since an abbreviated start in Seattle on Aug. 29. The good news for the Yankees was that Mussina felt no pain in his injured right elbow. The bad news was that he is still a ways off from rejoining the team's rotation.

title: Restoring the Light at the End of the Tunnel
description: No corporate executive has a bigger share of the spotlight after Hurricane Katrina's battering of New Orleans than J. Wayne Leonard, chief executive of Entergy, the power company that serves the city and many other areas of Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, PHYLLIS P.
description: LEWIS--Phyllis P., progressive activist, beloved wife and mother, died of leukemia September 9 at 81. Survivors include husband Bob, sons Mike and Carl, grandson Dan, niece Molly Selvin, nephew Peter Selvin and families. Memorial to be announced.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan And India Plan Prisoner Exchange
description: Days before the Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, and the Pakistani president, Pervez Musharraf, are scheduled to meet in New York on the sidelines of the United Nations summit session, their countries announced the planned release of hundreds of prisoners, including fishermen who had strayed into their waters. The exchange of prisoners -- 152 Pakistanis from Indian jails and 435 Indians from Pakistani jails -- is set for Monday and comes as the two countries, nuclear rivals that have fought three wars in the last 55 years, have vowed to resolve their differences, including the vexing issue of Kashmir, a province they both claim. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: S.E.C. May Sue General Re Officials
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the Omaha holding company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, said yesterday that regulators had notified Joseph P. Brandon, the chief executive of a Berkshire subsidiary, the General Reinsurance Corporation, that they planned to file a civil fraud complaint against him in connection with a wide-ranging investigation of insurance industry abuses.

title: Making a Case for Dividends
description: IF you looked up the word lackluster, you might see a chart depicting the stock market's recent performance.

title: Commander Accustomed to Scrutiny and Crises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Vice Adm. Thad W. Allen, who has been put in charge of the federal response to Hurricane Katrina, is known as a steady Coast Guard commander already tested by major crises, including some that drew intense public scrutiny.

title: Connecting the Ancient to the Computerized
description: Mari Kimura had planned to follow the traditional career trajectory for violinists -- performances of standard repertory and some new music -- when a chance conversation made her reconsider. Her interlocutor, on hearing that she was a violinist, asked Ms. Kimura whether she composed, and when the answer was no, he asked her why not. For Ms. Kimura, it was a good question, so she started writing music, including works for violin and computer. And she began collaborating with like-minded performer-composers.

title: Private Aid to Italian Art Costs an Arm and a Leg
description: ROME, Sept. 9 - Italians are so blas about the art all around them that it apparently takes hacking a leg off Michelangelo's "David" or rubbing Jesus out of Leonardo da Vinci's "Last Supper" to get their attention -- and maybe their money.

title: Secrets of the Mummy's Medicine Chest
description: The ancient Egyptians left proof of their scientific prowess for people to marvel at for millennia. Their engineering skills can still be seen at Giza, their star charts in Luxor, their care for head wounds on Fifth Avenue.

title: Bush Honors Public Servants Killed on 9/11
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - President Bush on Friday awarded a Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor to each of the 442 public safety officers who died on Sept. 11, calling them "men and women of uncommon valor and decency and honor."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspected Gang Members Held
description: Federal authorities announced yesterday the arrests of 23 members or associates of a Chinatown gang accused of running illegal gambling parlors in New York City as well as a multimillion-dollar international business in pirated Chinese-made music CD's and movie DVD's. The United States attorney, Michael J. Garcia, said the indictment unsealed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan "effectively dismantles" the Yi Ging gang, named for an alias of Geng Chen, accused as one of its leaders. The indictment names 39 people, charging that the gang routinely used violence against gambling debtors and rivals in the CD business. Gang members destroyed the store of one merchant and beat the 11-year-old daughter of a landlord who refused to sell them property for a gambling parlor, officials said. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a New Orleans couple who prepared dinner in a darkened apartment misstated the man's surname. He is Zackery Bowen, not Brown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RODMAN, PEARL (NEE PENNER)
description: RODMAN--Pearl (nee Penner). On September 7, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Salo Rodman, cherished mother of Carol and Elizabeth. Devoted sister of the late Saul and Samuel Penner, and Tillie Barnett. The world is a colder place without her. Service at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y. Sunday at 1 PM.

title: Lewis E. Platt, 64, Chief of Hewlett-Packard in 1990's, Dies
description: Lewis E. Platt, who rose from an entry-level engineer to become the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, died on Thursday at his home in Petaluma, Calif. He was 64.

title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERAZA, MARGARET MUL HERN
description: PERAZA -- Margaret Mul hern, of Fort Myers Beach, Florida, died Thursday, September 8. She was born April 29, 1910, in County Mayo, Ireland. At the tender age of 16 she emigrated to America and lived in New York City for 65 years. In 1991 she moved to Florida. She had a marvelous love of life and enjoyed a good cup of tea with family and friends. Margaret was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Ruben, and granddaughter, Christina Marie Fey. She leaves to cherish her memory her children, John and Lynn Peraza, Thomas Peraza, Mary Ellen Fey, Margaret and Al Manganelli, and Catherine Ann Peraza; grandchildren, Thomas and Susan Fey, Amy Ruth Peraza, Kimberly Katherine Koren, and Troy and Sandy Emmi; seven great-grandchildren; and two brothers, Jim and Pat Joe Peraza in Ireland. She will be missed by all who knew "Ma, Mom, Grams or Big Margaret." Friends and family will gather in New York at Gleason's Funeral Home, 150th St. and Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY, on Sunday, September 11, between 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, September 12, at 10:45 AM, in the Church of St. Kevin's, 4521 194th St., Flushing, NY. Margaret will be interred with her husband at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to Hope Hospice at Shell Point, 15010 Shell Point Blvd., Fort Myers, FL 33908. Reception to follow at the home of John and Lynn Peraza, 160 E. 38 St, Apt 9A, NYC.

title: Make It an Island
description: Washington - AFTER the victims are interred and public officials held to account for the destruction of a great American city, Congress must determine what to rebuild and what to abandon to the encroaching waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Restore the Marsh
description: Baton Rouge, La. - THE federal government plans to invest more than $50 billion in reconstructing New Orleans and nearby communities. Those funds are welcome. To let New Orleans sink into the gulf would be a tragedy for its residents and for those beguiled by this quirky city on the delta. But to rebuild New Orleans as it was on Aug. 29 would deal a cruel injustice to those who suffered the most in recent days. The question we need to ask is not only how we can restore New Orleans, but also how we can make it safe.

title: Police in Suburbs Blocked Evacuees, Witnesses Report
description: Police agencies to the south of New Orleans were so fearful of the crowds trying to leave the city after Hurricane Katrina that they sealed a crucial bridge over the Mississippi River and turned back hundreds of desperate evacuees, two paramedics who were in the crowd said.

title: 2 Directors Step Down at Morgan
description: Two more Morgan Stanley directors resigned yesterday, further underscoring the intent of the new chief executive, John J. Mack, to remake the firm.

title: Canada Added 28,000 Jobs in August
description: Canada had a net increase of 28,000 jobs in August, bringing its annualized rate of employment gains to 1.5 percent, Statistics Canada reported yesterday. The agency said the rise was mostly a result of 36,000 new full-time jobs created during the month. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: First Topic of Debate: What Was First Topic?
description: During the Democratic primary debate Thursday night on WABC-TV, Fernando Ferrer discussed a breakfast meeting he had had with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg the day after Mr. Bloomberg was elected in 2001.

title: The New Prize: Alternative Fuels
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9 - A week ago, Benjamin Kleber was spending $3.39 a gallon at a gasoline station in Maryland when he noticed an obscure decal on his minivan.

title: R. W. Funk, 79, Creator of Jesus Seminar, Dies
description: Robert W. Funk, founder of the Jesus Seminar, a consortium of Bible scholars who popularized a wave of studies that raised doubts about whether the deeds and sayings attributed to Jesus were historically authentic, died on Sept. 3 at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 79.

title: The Preservation Hall Band, Far From Preservation Hall
description: One by one, the musicians in the Preservation Hall Jazz Band landed at New York airports last night. The stragglers were the drummer, the clarinetist and the trumpet player, who had been missing since Hurricane Katrina flooded New Orleans, their hometown.

title: Preparing For Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEMARCO, MICHAEL J.
description: DeMARCO--Michael J. Of East Hampton, on September 6. Beloved husband of Frances (Bebrauskas). Loving father of Michael of Long Valley, New Jersey, Mariann Wilson of Euless, TX, and Jane DeMarco of Huntington, NY. Dear brother of Lucy Mallardi, Mafalda Williams, Mary Ross and the late Viola DeMarco & Ralph DeMarco. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10 AM, Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton. Interment Most Holy Trinity Cemetery. Memorial donations to American Heart Association.

title: Whiny Notes and Croaks, But Who's Complaining?
description: Alec Ounsworth has a sharp, nasal, quavery voice, and he exults in its every flaw as the singer and songwriter of Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, a New York City band that performed on Wednesday night at Warsaw in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: Court Gives Bush Right to Detain U.S. Combatant
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - A three-judge federal appeals court panel ruled unanimously on Friday that President Bush had the authority to detain as an enemy combatant an American citizen who fought United States forces on foreign soil.

title: The Divide Laid Bare by Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: Unbearable Grief Given Full-Throated Voice
description: Diamanda Galas does what a lot of people want to do and don't: stand up in the middle of a crowd and yell like crazy. In the 1980's she was our princess of the primal scream. If we allowed our discontents to seep out through narrow vents of politeness, Ms. Galas's misery arrived in hot unencumbered blasts.

title: China's President, in Canada, Urges Deepening of Trade Relations
description: TORONTO, Sept. 9 - China's president, Hu Jintao, and Prime Minister Paul Martin spoke Friday of forming a strategic partnership in energy and trade, deepening an economic relationship that is becoming increasingly important to both countries.

title: 'But I Just Want to Know, Where's My Baby?'
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 9 - If she didn't have younger siblings to watch and three of her own small children depending on her, Lakerisha Boyd could do what she feels like doing here in an old motel near the Astrodome.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption about reggae in The Arts on Thursday reversed the identities of two performers. The photograph at the lower right was of Elephant Man and the one to its immediate left was of Sizzla.

title: Plaintiffs Win Round in Lawsuit on Patriot Act
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 9 - A federal judge ruled on Friday that the government cannot continue to bar the representatives of a nonprofit organization from speaking out about the sweeping powers that the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act gives investigators seeking library records.

title: How Do Red Sox Hate Rodriguez? Let's Count the Ways
description: No matter how many times Alex Rodriguez walks onto the same field as the Boston Red Sox, there will always be some intrigue and some tension. Rodriguez was willing to accept contract deferments to save the Red Sox $28 million in a trade, but it was nixed 21 months ago and he, surprisingly, ended up with the Yankees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAHN, PHILIP J.
description: HAHN--Philip J. Born March 31, 1916. He passed away on September 8, 2005 at the age of 89. He was raised in Brooklyn where, as a youth, his intelligence and bright personality quickly shown through. After Pearl Harbor, Phil joined the Army and served in Military Intelligence doing signals work and code breaking. His unit was stationed in Africa, Italy, and Austria over the course of the war. His time in Italy began his love affair with that country. He spoke Italian fluently, traveled often to Rome and was, to his great pride and satisfaction, a Cavaliere of the Italian Republic. After the war, Phil returned home where he joined the family firm of M. Fabrikant & Sons in New York City. An international diamond merchant, Phil traveled widely in the world, visiting Europe, Africa and Asia. Often he would circumnavigate the globe on his business voyages, to his great pleasure and the amazement of his friends and family. Phil was a lover of good food, fine wine, and great art and literature. He was multi-lingual, speaking French and other languages in addition to Italian. Phil was a connoisseur of culture and enjoyed life to its fullest. He contributed to the arts in New York City, supporting Carnegie Hall, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Metropolitan Opera. He was also a generous philanthropist, giving to many charities through his charitable foundation, and he endowed the upkeep of a portion of Central Park. New York City was his true love; it gave him great strength and was the object of his passions. He was devoted to his sisters, his nephews, and their children all of whom will miss him dearly. Phil is survived by his sister and brother-inlaw, Bobbie and Irving Rosenzweig, his nephews Scott and Rick Frishman and their children, and his nephews Paul and Jim Rosenzweig and their children. Funeral services will take place on Sunday September 11, 2005 at 11:30 A.M at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Donations should be made in his memory to a charity of your choice.$(6$)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSEL, MYRA TEICHER
description: RUSSEL--Myra Teicher. Died September 7th of a heart attack. She was two months shy of her 85th birthday. She is survived by her three children, Marjorie, David and Danny, their spouses, Peter, Luba and Keiko, six grandchildren to whom she was utterly devoted, Alexander, Byron, Constantine, Emily, Kevin and Sascha, and her brother Henry and sister-in-law Anne Teicher. Myra lived several lives, all with great intelligence and gusto. She was a lifelong socialist, a machinist during WW II, a loving wife and mother, a college professor, an author and scholar. After her children were grown, she earned an MA at Sarah Lawrence College, then taught literature at Elizabeth Seton College in Yonkers for many years. In retirement, she taught retired NY Public School teachers, selecting a fresh set of books to discuss each year. Her professional specialty was music written to the poems of James Joyce. In her 70's, she rediscovered and published a book of Geoffrey Molyneux Palmer's song settings to "Chamber Music", and she introduced the songs to musicians who performed and recorded them. Myra wrote many scholarly articles, and she attended and presented her work at various James Joyce symposia here and in Euorpe, most recently this past Bloomsday. She will be missed by her family and friends. Contributions in her name can be made to the International Rescue Committee. A memorial service will be held.

title: Arts, Briefly; Kickoff Downs CBS
description: For once, CBS did not win Thursday night in Nielsen's estimates. The upset was due to ABC's broadcast of the N.F.L. season opener, which drew 18.05 million viewers between 9 and 11 p.m. (The ratings for live events are approximate.) At 8 p.m., "N.F.L. Kick-Off 2005" brought in an audience of 11.12 million, also winning the hour in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. Fox had two premieres on Thursday and came in a strong third, behind CBS. "The O.C." began its third season and delivered 7.41 million viewers; "Reunion" started its first and attracted 6.64 million. The good news for "Reunion," the new whodunit, is that it retained a large portion of the "O.C." audience: 89 percent of total viewers and 91 percent of the 18-to-49 demographic stuck around to watch. KATE AURTHUR

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article yesterday about the importance of Egypt's first experiment with a multicandidate race for the presidency misstated Gamal Abdel Nasser's position in 1954, when leaders of the Muslim Brotherhhood tried to assassinate him. At that time, he was prime minister, not president. He became president in 1956.

title: Three Brooklyn Rivals Step Up Their Attacks on Hynes
description: The three challengers in the Democratic primary for Brooklyn district attorney spent yesterday denouncing the incumbent, Charles J. Hynes, in a race that has grown increasingly heated as the Democratic primary approaches.

title: Disconcerting Intimacy, With Hugs and Band-Aids
description: "Open your mouth," a young woman says to each audience member entering in single file to see "Forget Me Not, a New Economy Mass," by Brainard Carey and Delia Bajo, the performance duo Praxis. Then she carefully inserts a sliver of mint wafer and welcomes the arrival with words and a warm squeeze on the shoulder. This mix of disconcerting intimacy, religious reference and refusal to recognize conventional barriers between performers and audience characterizes the hourlong activities of "Forget Me Not," which opened P.S. 122's fall season on Wednesday night.

title: New Orleans Executives Plan Revival
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9 - The New Orleans business establishment-in-exile has set up a beachhead in a government annex here, across the street from the state Capitol. From here, organizations like the New Orleans Convention and Visitors Bureau have begun to plot the rebirth of the city.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (History) THE 9/11 HIJACKERS: INSIDE THE HAMBURG CELL -- They called it "the planes operation." Their leaders were Mohamed Atta (left), Marwan al-Shehhi, Ziad Jarrah and Ramzi Binalshibh. This documentary looks at their transformation from college boys into aspiring religious martyrs.

title: Roberts Meets 3 Senators And Gets a Nod From One
description: Correction Appended

title: The Case for a Cover-Up
description: At last there is a light in the darkness. Washington was slow to respond to Katrina's victims, but now Congress has finally sprung into action. It has bravely promised to investigate the situation.

title: Security Company Closes Baghdad Airport Over Pay
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Saturday, Sept. 10 - The private security company that guards Baghdad International Airport shut down the airport on Friday, saying it had not been paid for the past six months. But the company, Global Strategies Group, announced early Saturday that it had agreed to reopen the airport on Saturday morning after a promise by the Iraqi government to pay half the amount owed.

title: Pity the Poorest While America Waves the Flag
description: AS soon as it became clear that there would be an all-American semifinal match at the United States Open, John McEnroe, the CBS commentator and one of the greatest tennis players this country has produced, said he was happy that there would be an American in the final.

title: Syria Braces for Inquiry in Lebanon Murder Case
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 9 - The senior United Nations investigator in the murder of a former Lebanese prime minister is expected here Monday, a visit that is already roiling the political waters as many here brace for further revelations.

title: Seo Is Impressive, but Gets No Reward
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 - Sometimes this is how fate works.

title: Vietnamese Shrimpers in the Gulf Become Refugees Again
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 9 - As the hurricane raged, Hiep Le pushed with all his might against the cabin door on his father's shrimp boat for hours, trying to keep the wind and water out, and watched as his uncle's boat split in two right next to him.

title: First Game of Series Shows Two Teams Have Big Issues
description: DAVID WELLS, who has always thought of Yankee Stadium as his surrogate home, did not survive the sixth inning there last night, in part because the fielders behind him couldn't throw the ball as straight as Wells did on pitches that Jorge Posada and Alex Rodriguez hit out of the park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTERMAN, SAUL C., M.D., FACS.
description: FUTTERMAN--Saul C., M.D., FACS. Beloved husband of Ruth; devoted father of Rabbi Matthew and Chana, Donald and Shira; adored grandfather of Alon, Yael, Itamar, Nimrod, Yaniv and Maayan; loving brother of Amy Yeminy. A man of compassion and a healer of bodies, he was the retired Associate Director of Surgery at Elmhurst Hospital and Associate Clinical Professor at Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical School. He left his mark in this world by being an unassuming mentsch. He left his mark in the Jewish world by making his synagogue and the Jewish people his priority. He is already sorely missed. The funeral will take place on Sunday at 11AM at Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing.$(6$)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Maplewood: Sex Charges Against Teacher
description: An English teacher at Columbia High School was charged with sexual assault on Thursday for twice having sex with a 16-year-old female student in his classroom in June, the Essex County prosecutor's office said. The teacher, Nelson Trias, 42, was charged with five counts of sexual assault, two counts of criminal sexual contact and other charges. He was released on $50,000 bond and will be arraigned within two weeks, said Mark Ali, director of the prosecutor's child abuse unit. Mr. Trias was placed on a paid suspension by the school district in June. According to school officials and his personal Web site, Mr. Trias was an officer in the Air Force from 1982 to 1988, joined the Reserve after 9/11 and served a tour of duty in Afghanistan. John Holl (NYT)

title: A Predicted Flood
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday misstated the date of the opening program of the "Cantatas in Context" series at St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue at 50th Street. It is tomorrow, not yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the findings of the independent panel that investigated the United Nations' oil-for-food program in Iraq referred incorrectly to kickbacks and surcharges that it said amounted to $10.99 billion in illicit profits for Saddam Hussein. They occurred outside the program; the payments were not connected to it.

title: Raise the Ground
description: Arrowsic, Me. - HURRICANES are a given of nature on the Gulf Coast, and even stronger levees than those breached in New Orleans do not guarantee protection. Fortunately, levees aren't the only solution.

title: Panel Backs Base Closings but Criticizes Plan's Timing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - The military base-closing commission gave its final endorsement on Friday to eliminating or shrinking hundreds of Department of Defense installations nationwide, but it criticized the timing of the closings.

title: From His Stoop in Brooklyn
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a mayoral candidate, has unleashed his fourth television advertisement, "Stoop," for the Democratic primary, the final salvo in a $1.8 million ad campaign that began two weeks before election day.

title: The Turkish Identity
description: Next week, the Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, will address the United Nations here on one of the issues threatening to slow down negotiations to admit Turkey into the European Union -- recognizing Cyprus. But he should also address the question of Orhan Pamuk, the pre-eminent Turkish novelist who has been charged with "public denigration" of Turkish identity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEITZMAN, BARBARA Z. (NEE FORGASH)
description: WEITZMAN--Barbara Z. (nee Forgash). Of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of Haworth, NJ. Mother of Franci Glatz (Al), Seth (Jill Bleemer) and Josh (Michelle Noris). Sister of Norman Forgash (Phyllis). Grandmother of Jason, Emily, Melissa, Abraham and Isidore. Service Sunday 12:30PM, Gutterman - Musi cant, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, NY, NY. Information 1-800-522-0588

title: Program Failed to Monitor 9/11 Workers, Report Finds
description: Thousands of federal workers who helped untangle the wreckage of the World Trade Center may have never been examined or treated for medical problems stemming from the disaster, a Congressional report has found. The report, completed by the Government Accountability Office, said that the federal program that was supposed to monitor the workers was shut down more than a year ago and remains closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, ROBERT A.
description: COHN--Robert A. Died September 8, 2005. Loving husband of Penny, dear father of Douglas and Mitchell. Funeral private.

title: For a Spent Emergency Force, Las Vegas Fails to Dazzle
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 9 - They have been taking long, soapy showers, sleeping like hibernating bears, tossing back a few beers and gawking at the over-the-top architecture here for the last few days.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports section yesterday that listed memorable achievements of tennis players over the age of 35 misstated the year Ken Rosewall won the Australian Open at 37. It was 1972, not 1970.

title: Call Us to Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: Amtrak Raising Fares a Bit and, if You're a Frequent Rider, a Lot
description: Citing the high cost of diesel fuel, Amtrak said yesterday that it would raise its train fares across most of the nation by at least 5 percent this month, but that its most frequent riders would face much steeper increases.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Challenge On Balloting Is Dismissed
description: An appeals court in Columbus unanimously sided with Secretary of State J. Kenneth Blackwell in a case involving out-of-state signature gatherers for four measures on the November ballot. A Republican-backed group opposed to the measures, which deal with election-related matters favored by many Democrats, like legislative redistricting, accused Mr. Blackwell of breaking the law by allowing people from outside Ohio to collect signatures in the state. Dean Murphy (NYT)

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Trapped in the Rubble and Waiting For a Miracle
description: There are myriad stories of heroism from Sept. 11, 2001, some bordering on the miraculous. As we approach the fourth anniversary, the playwright Robert Marese offers "The Fallen 9/11," a mystical tale about a lawyer named Michael Sinclair who was rescued from the bottom of an elevator shaft with the help of New York City firefighters and an assist from Saint Barbara.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BEDDARD, ANITA
description: BEDDARD--Anita. We miss you so and think of you often. You're in our hearts, minds and souls forever. We love you. Michael, Fred & Devon

title: Saturday's Top College Football Games
description: No. 20 Notre Dame (1-0) at No. 3 Michigan (1-0)

title: What! Open a Haunted Restaurant? Pair Run From a Contract
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 9 - The owner of a downtown shopping complex here has filed a lawsuit against restaurateurs who say they cannot honor their lease because the building has a ghost problem.

title: The Son Also Directs
description: LOS ANGELES - After a year of pre-med studies at Skidmore College, Jason Reitman, the son of the film director Ivan Reitman, was sick, had lousy grades and knew what he had to do:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, RUTH (NEE JACOBSON)
description: ROSEN--Ruth (nee Jacobson), died peacefully at home in Tamarac, Florida. on Wednesday, September 7, 2005 at the age 95. The beloved wife of the late Harry Rosen, founder of Junior's Restaurant in Bklyn, NY. Devoted and loving mother of Marvin (Bonny) Rosen and Marcia (Harold) Cohen; cherished grandmother of Ina Friend, Barry (Jamie) Cohen, Andrew (Michelle) Cohen, Sheri Rosen, Beth (William) Bauer, and Jeffrey (Liza) Rosen; adored great grandmother of Matthew & Scott Friend, Reese & Harley Cohen, Ross & Harris Cohen, Casey, Jas min, Avery, & Colin Rosen & Landon Bauer. We want to thank Doreen Taylor for all the love & devotion she gave to our mother & father. Mom, we will all miss you very much. Services Sunday 10:30 am on September 11, at Star of Daivd Memorial Chapel 7701 Bailey Rd., No. Lauderdale, FL., 1-800-456-5252. Donations may be made to Hospice By The Sea, 1531 Palmetto Park Rd, Boca Raton, Fl. 33486.

title: The New Prince of Monaco Confronts His Past
description: MONACO, Sept. 9 - His Serene Highness Albert II, Sovereign Prince of Monaco, Marquis of Baux, sits alone in his mother's old corner office on the top floor of his palace beneath a small crenellated clock tower from which flies the white flag of Monaco.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the findings of the independent panel that investigated the United Nations' oil-for-food program in Iraq referred incorrectly to kickbacks and surcharges that it said amounted to $10.99 billion in illicit profits for Saddam Hussein. They occurred outside the program; the payments were not connected to it. (Go to Article)

title: After Escaping Manhattan, Remaining at Work Across the River
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 9 - The smokers on the promenade of the Morgan Stanley offices here have a clear view across the Hudson River to the unending emptiness where they used to work.

title: Build Diversity
description: Lexington, Ky. - NEW ORLEANS would have marked this past Labor Day with the 12th anniversary parade of the Black Men of Labor, one of the many neighborhood-based social clubs that carry on the African-American parading tradition known as second-lining. These parades feature brass bands and "second-liners," the people who join the procession, dancing, as it winds through the back streets of the city's neighborhoods.

title: Emergency Kit Shopping List
description: Experts recommend keeping a three-day supply of food and water in a container like a duffle bag or waterproof box that is easy to grab during an evacuation. Here is a shopping list for one person; multiply the food and water by the number of people in your family. (Don't forget dry food for the pets.)

title: A Shameful Proclamation
description: On Thursday, President Bush issued a proclamation suspending the law that requires employers to pay the locally prevailing wage to construction workers on federally financed projects. The suspension applies to parts of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida.

title: Wider U.S. Net Seeks Allies Against Iran's Nuclear Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Stymied in its effort to rally a worldwide coalition to press Iran, the Bush administration has opened an unusual diplomatic struggle with Russia, China and India to have Iran's suspected nuclear weapons activities brought before the United Nations Security Council for possible sanctions.

title: U.S. Rejects Cisco Plan on Options
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission threw cold water yesterday on a plan being pushed by Cisco Systems to value employee stock options by selling similar securities to institutional investors. But the agency said other market-based approaches might work.

title: Clash by Diplomats at U.N. Over Reform Bares Divisions
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 9 - Diplomats working on a pivotal document on the management overhaul of the United Nations and updated approaches to terrorism, development and human rights have locked horns just days before it is to be presented to more than 170 world leaders for their endorsement.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the abduction of a 4-year-old boy from a Washington Heights restaurant misspelled his given name. He is Josue Polanco, not Joshua.

title: Preparing For Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: Contesting the Not-So-Virtual World of Politics
description: Video gamers aren't supposed to care about serious stuff like politics. According to stereotype, gamers are supposed to be apathetic, socially challenged slackers who live off their parents and don't care about much beyond where the next bag of Cheetos is coming from.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUSSMAN, HARRIET
description: SUSSMAN--Harriet. Of Lido Beach, N.Y. at age 81 years. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Samuel and Marsha Sussman, Eleanor and Howard Eichner and Bernard and Phyllis Sussman. Dear sister of Lee Cohen and Irwin Kaplowitz. Loving grandmother of William and Kendall, Jennifer and Brian, Jason, Daniel, Alyssa, Aaron and Ben and greatgrandmother of Nicole and Marc. Services Sunday, 9:30AM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Mubarak's Victory Orderly, but Opposition Is Still Angry
description: CAIRO, Sept. 9 - In a lopsided victory, President Hosni Mubarak was declared the winner of Egypt's first multicandidate contest for president on Friday night, with 88.5 percent of the vote, but election officials said turnout was low, at just 23 percent.

title: Fired Ukraine Premier Sees End of 'Orange Revolution' Unity
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Sept. 9 - Ukraine's ousted prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, said Friday that the partnership that led the "Orange Revolution" last year was over and that she would no longer support the man who fired her, President Viktor A. Yushchenko.

title: Ex-Columnist Will Not Be Tried for Taping Call
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9 - A former columnist for The Miami Herald will not be prosecuted for taping a phone conversation with a former politician without his knowledge shortly before the man killed himself, the district attorney said.

title: Blame in New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DANUFF, PATRICIA
description: DANUFF--Patricia. Temple Beth El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Just as it was important that Broadway not remain in the dark after Sept. 11, it's important that we start thinking about the future despite all the very depressing news around us."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, SYLVIA WOHL
description: FELDMAN -- Sylvia Wohl. Dearly loved wife, sister, mother, grandmother, aunt and friend passed away peacefully on September 7, 2005. She will be sorely missed and forever loved by her late husband, Milton; brother, Bernie Wohl; her sons, Leslie and Jeffrey; daughter-in-law, Lori; grandchildren, Alexis, Brittany, Spencer and Morgan; and her dearest lifelong friend, Selma Slater. Funeral service Sunday, September 11, 12:45, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.$(6$)

title: After the Louisiana Deluge, Players Find a Texas Toehold
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 9 - When Jyrell Gaddies, a 16-year-old defensive back, enrolled at Eisenhower Senior High School here this week, he asked the football coach, Daryl Phipps, how many fans the home stadium could hold.

title: After Duty in Iraq, a New Transition to Being the Nonfighting 69th
description: FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 9 - After 12 months of bombs, bullets, scorpions and sweat, Carlo Giordano has a new enemy -- boredom.

title: Hurricane Loss Estimates Differ
description: In a sign of the uncertainty over what insurers will pay for Hurricane Katrina, a risk management firm yesterday released a loss estimate far larger than that of its rivals.

title: Ten Dimes, or the Price of Admission
description: A nice round number, $10,000. A magic number, even. In poker, it buys you a ticket into the Big Time, a chance to win $7.5 million, as Joe Hachem did at this year's World Series. Somewhat less gaudy amounts are also winnable in an increasingly crowded calendar of tournaments on the World Series of Poker Circuit and the World Poker Tour. A few of these events still require "only" a $5,000 buy-in, and the World Poker Tour championship in April requires $25,000, but the fee to all the others remains the iconic $10,000.

title: Schilling, 'Work in Progress'
description: Curt Schilling will make his fourth start since returning to the rotation for the Boston Red Sox today, but the pitcher and the team are still uncertain when or if he will return to being his dominant self.

title: Neigh to Cronies
description: WASHINGTON - I understand that politicians are wont to put cronies and cupcakes on the payroll.

title: Songs in the Key of Politics
description: It was a crowded room and the candidate for City Council was given just a few minutes to work it. "They say we're young and we don't know, won't find out until we grow," his message began.

title: DIRECTOR OF FEMA STRIPPED OF ROLE AS RELIEF LEADER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Under intense pressure to improve its response to Hurricane Katrina, the Bush administration on Friday abruptly removed the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Michael D. Brown, from oversight of the post-storm relief effort, and replaced him with Vice Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a broad attack by Democrats on the Bush administration's handling of the hurricane crisis misstated the action of the White House press secretary, Scott McClellan, in response to e-mails seeking his comment. Two e-mails sent by a reporter carried incorrect addresses. Mr. McClellan therefore was unable to respond; he did not fail to do so.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: When an Establishment Site Opens Its Doors to a Grass-Roots Festival
description: How a grass-roots effort like Dancenow/NYC, a festival of choreographic short takes from emerging, accomplished, gifted and, yes, sometimes witless choreographers, ended up in one of the city's establishment sites for dance is, in part, a lesson in economic change.

title: Flooding Puts Universities in a Bind Regarding Tuition
description: Since Scott S. Cowen, the president of Tulane University, evacuated his New Orleans campus after Hurricane Katrina, he has fought to establish a temporary headquarters, reunite his staff, and get some computers working. Now he is grappling with a ticklish new issue: what to do with the millions in tuition that Tulane has collected for fall classes that are now canceled.

title: Scarcely Heard Question: How God Could Have Allowed Catastrophe to Occur
description: How could God have allowed this to happen? Four years ago, after 9/11, many people were asking that question. They were asking it again after the Indian Ocean tsunami last December. They are not asking it after Hurricane Katrina.

title: Death Toll in New Orleans May Be Lower Than First Feared
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9 - The first organized effort to scour the city for its dead has turned up far fewer bodies than expected, officials said Friday. That raised hopes that the death toll from Hurricane Katrina might be much lower than the 10,000 that the mayor and others had predicted.

title: On Oil Supply, Opinions Aren't Scarce
description: "We're halfway through the hydrocarbon era," my old friend T. Boone Pickens has been saying for the last couple of years. You may remember Mr. Pickens as the most famous corporate raider of the 1980's, but he has spent his life in the oil patch. A geologist by training, Mr. Pickens founded Mesa Petroleum at the age of 26 and ran it for the next 40 years. Now, at 77, he works the oil patch in a different way, running a pair of energy-oriented hedge funds in Dallas.

Mostly in vain, it seems. To judge by the French press, Michel Houellebecq is the only writer who counts. And that was before the public had even read his latest novel, "The Possibility of an Island."

There were mainly two kinds of concertgoers: exuberant women and their not quite so exuberant dates. But there were three kinds of singers.

So when 55,024 voices roared for him as he walked off the mound at Yankee Stadium in the seventh inning last night, Small tugged his cap once, gave a little wave and then tugged the cap again before descending the dugout steps.

Seen from high above Louisiana, the threatening
floodwaters become an eerie canvas  a uniform

title: Moorish Past Finds New Life in a Storied City
description: SITUATED on the rugged foothills of the Sierra Nevada, the southern Spanish city of Granada has long been famed as the site of the Alhambra, the spectacular 14th-century palace built under Moorish rule. Recently, however, Granada has begun showing signs of transformation, thanks to an ambitious campaign by the Andalusian Legacy Foundation to revive Granada's rich Hispanic-Moorish past.

title: Among the Believers
description: Benjamin Kunkel's first novel, "Indecision," published last month, concerns a young man living in Manhattan and trying, as the title suggests, to figure out what to do with his life. He has a B.A. in philosophy and an active, if confusing, romantic life; he gets by on a combination of office work and parental subsidy. In his author's affectionate estimation, offered over a beer on a recent evening at a Brooklyn bar, this young man, whose name is Dwight Wilmerding, is "kind of an idiot." Perhaps, but he may also be - the critical response to "Indecision" suggests as much - an especially representative kind of idiot. His plight, after all, is - for people of his age and background - a familiar one: an alienation from his own experience brought about by too much knowledge, too many easy, inconsequential choices, too much self-consciousness. Bred in a culture consecrated to the entitled primacy of the individual, he discovers that he lacks a self, a coherent identity, maybe a soul. He feels that he could be anyone. "It wasn't very unusual for me to lie awake at night," he confesses, "feeling like a scrap of sociology blown into its designated corner of the world. But knowing the clichs are clichs doesn't help you to escape them. You still have to go on experiencing your experience as if no one else has ever done it."

title: Hotel Puerta Amrica in Madrid
description: THE BASICS  The high-stakes, high-design hotel market in Madrid got at least a dozen new contenders - all in one building - when the $94 million Hotel Puerta Amrica opened two months ago. While the facade is the work of the French architect Jean Nouvel, each of the hotel's 12 floors - from the elevator lobbies down to the blankets and bathrobes - has been conceived by powerhouse architects and design studios, among them Arata Isozaki, Norman Foster, Marc Newson, Ron Arad, Richard Gluckman, Javier Mariscal, Victorio & Lucchino and Zaha Hadid. With public spaces like the Black Tears restaurant designed by Christian Liaigre and the underground garage by Teresa Sapey, the Puerta Amrica can bill itself as "12 floors with 19 stars."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, SHEILA BYRNE
description: MOORE--Sheila Byrne. Of Juno Beach, FL, and Manhasset, NY, on September 9, 2005. Beloved wife of Thomas Joseph Moore. Loving mother of Thomas, Frank, Robert and Mary Jo. Mother-in-law of Lisa, Jennifer and Dennis. Cherished grandmother of Thomas, Bobby, Austin, Elizabeth, Caroline, Joseph and James. Loving sister of Bill Byrne and the late Richard Byrne. May our dear wife, mother and grandmother rest in eternal peace. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, 7-9 PM Tuesday, and 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Wednesday. title: A Lament, With Humor, for the Dance of Time
description: DEPLORING the overemphasis on technique in dance has become a clich sentiment, but that doesn't mean it isn't true. To watch the great solo performer Beverly Blossom is to understand the powerful simplicity with which dance can communicate the essence of life and art in ways that have nothing to do with multiple pirouettes. After a career that began in the 1950's in the modern dance theater of Alwin Nikolais and included the exhilarating downtown multimedia experiments of the 1960's, Ms. Blossom, at 79, knows how to command a stage from the moment she enters. She may simply pause at the side, ease onto a chair or sail about majestically, eyes staring out at her audience from a magnificent, unabashedly ravaged face. It is impossible to look away.

title: The Man Who Would Set Shiite Against Shiite

Fellow clerics are let in first: simple clergy in white turbans and those claiming descent from the Prophet Muhammad in black. Inside, at one end of a narrow whitewashed room with brown cushions laid out along its brown carpet, sits a portly man in his 30's, dressed in a swath of black broadcloth. His beard reaches up his cheeks and a dark widow's peak points down from beneath his own black turban. He glowers, projecting mistrust, even when he briefly smiles.

title: Fra Angelico, the Master of the Golden Halo
description: IN 1984 Pope John Paul II beatified Fra Angelico. He was already the people's choice. His tomb at Santa Maria Sopra Minerva in Rome had long been a shrine. While Botticelli was still an acquired taste, Angelico was the most sought-after early Italian Renaissance painter for collectors, the darling of savvy 19th-century guidebook writers, who bestowed four stars on any site that displayed his golden-haloed gems. The Florentine convent of San Marco, where he was a Dominican friar, became the ultimate Fra Angelico pilgrimage destination: his fresco of an "Annunciation" in one of the tiny, square whitewashed monk's cells epitomizes his austere, light-filled style, with Mary gravely kneeling on a simple low wood bench, hands across her chest, pink-cheeked and so exquisitely slight that she looks immaterial.

title: There's Green, Then There's Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: RUNNING NUMBERS: This week, a new title makes its debut at No. 11 on the nonfiction list: "1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus," by Charles C. Mann. It joins David McCullough's "1776," about another big year in American history, which reclaims the top spot, and Bernard Goldberg's "100 People Who Are Screwing Up America," which is at No. 5. Goldberg's list omits Christopher Columbus, a looming presence in "1491," which argues that pre-Columbian civilization was far more populous and sophisticated than previously thought. Just consider the ancient king of Mutal: "Like most Maya rulers, Chak Tok Ich'aak spent a lot of his time luxuriating in his court while dwarf servants attended to his whims and musicians played conch shells and wooden trumpets in the background." A correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly and Science magazine, Mann traveled widely, and at times hazardously, to research his book. There was the time the fuel gauge jammed on a trip to Mayan ruins in Mexico. "Just as we were landing, the plane ran out of gas," Mann recounted rather breathlessly, on the telephone from his home in Amherst, Mass. "We landed completely silently. And the pilot, in a gesture I had previously only seen associated with the pope, ran out of the plane and kissed the ground." And then there were the bugs. "I learned three things about Amazonian termites," Mann said. "There's a whole lot of them, they're extremely fast, and they bite." GLASS CEILING, GLASS SLIPPER: Five new books enter the fiction list this week: four glossy crime novels ("Point Blank," "Tyrannosaur Canyon," "Vanish" and "Without Mercy") and one book of poems ("Reflections of a Peacemaker") meant to raise money for the Muscular Dystrophy Association. In such a crowded field, it's impressive that some recent debuts are still holding on. They include "The Undomestic Goddess," by Sophie Kinsella, at No. 12 in its sixth week on the list, and "Match Me if You Can," by Susan Elizabeth Phillips, at No. 13 in its third. Both are chick-lit novels about overworked women that appeal to overworked women. In "The Undomestic Goddess," Samantha Sweeting leaves her job as a high-powered London lawyer and heads into the English countryside. When she stops to ask directions at a fancy house, she's assumed to be an applicant for a housekeeping job. One thing leads to another, and Samantha soon discovers the joys of . . . baking. We'll spare you the feminist critique. In Phillips's "Match Me if You Can," the heroine inherits her grandmother's Chicago match-making business and is smitten by her most demanding client. Too bad Chak Tok Ich'aak isn't around anymore. Now he would have been quite a catch. TBR

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 1
description: The evergreen offense of the Colts remains a wonder. Peyton Manning has started all 112 of his pro games and has averaged 263 passing yards a game. Last season, he set an N.F.L. record with 49 touchdown passes. Marvin Harrison is still a gamebreaking receiver, wideout Brandon Stokley is ready after missing the preseason because of a shoulder injury, and the offensive line is top grade. The Ravens will counter with their usual stifling defense, led by Ray Lewis at middle linebacker and Ed Reed at safety. Newcomers like cornerback Samari Rolle and outside linebacker Tommy Polley should help. When the Ravens have the ball, they are far less impressive. They are trying everything to make Kyle Boller a good quarterback; they designated Jim Fassel as the offensive coordinator and brought in Rick Neuheisel, the former University of Washington coach, to all but baby-sit for Boller. If that doesn't work, Jamal Lewis will have to do even more heavy-duty running. The Colts' defense, despite Dwight Freeney's dominance up front, wins no prizes and is hardly healthy. Corey Simon, a late pickup at defensive tackle, may help considerably, but not yet. Ravens Coach Brian Billick said, "We're a better team than we were last year." Maybe so, but the Colts seem on a higher level. Reporter's pick: Colts

We want to thank Doreen Taylor for all the love & devotion she gave to our mother & father. Mom, we will all miss you very much. Services Sunday 10:30 am on September 11, at Star of Daivd Memorial Chapel 7701 Bailey Rd., No. Lauderdale, FL., 1-800-456-5252. title: PERMIT DENIED IN HIGHLANDS
description: The Highlands township of West Milford won a challenge to one of the state's largest developers when New Jersey's commissioner of environmental protection, Bradley M. Campbell, denied a permit for 280 town houses. West Milford is entirely within the area protected by the sweeping Highlands legislation enacted last year, which bars such large-scale developments, but the builder, K. Hovnanian, was eligible for an exemption because it had already secured some permits. Residents and environmental organizations, which maintained that there was not enough drinking water to support the project, were elated when Mr. Campbell turned down the application. Hovnanian said it would appeal immediately. Laura Mansnerus

title: Roberts v. The Future
description: Congratulations to Jeffrey Rosen for his prescient article (Aug. 28). He is right about the kinds of biotechnological and other scientific issues likely to become Supreme Court fodder. But he missed a few. For example, one of the issues that I expect to be decided within the next 10 years is whether there is a constitutional right under the First Amendment (or elsewhere in the Constitution) to conduct scientific research. (This issue could arise, for example, in litigation brought by biotechnologists against laws proscribing therapeutic cloning.) If a "right to research" is indeed found to be lurking between the lines of the Constitution, it would not only open the door wide to human cloning but would also dramatically curtail society's power through democratic institutions to regulate scientific research, as well as technological applications derived therefrom.

description: GARFUNKEL--Leonore, 84, died September 8th, 2005 after a brief illness. Beloved sister of the recently deceased Benjamin Garfunkel. Devoted aunt of Michael Garfunkel, Julie Spencer and Marjorie Derven and sister-in-law of Helene Garfunkel. She was an assistant principal at I.S. 44 in Manhattan before she retired. She was a loving greataunt to Zachary Spencer, Samuel and Rebecca Derven, and Gabrielle and Cecile Garfunkel. She was an active member of the Temple Emanu-El in Long Beach, NY for many years. She will be missed for her colorful stories and participation in all family gatherings. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the Red Cross for the Hurricane Katrina Fund.

Shoot the Piano Player
description: The clich in the critical writing about the French New Wave is that the innovations that once seemed so jarring are now so common that they go unnoticed. But the American critics who were bewildered by the playfulness of the Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai's "Chungking Express" in 1994 could have been the offspring of the American critics who, in 1960, were similarly baffled by Franois Truffaut's "Shoot the Piano Player," perhaps the starting point of free-spirited modern cinema. No New Wave movie contains more of that movement's spirit than "Shoot the Piano Player." There is the loving yet knowing poetic distillation of American genre films (in this case, noir), and the location shooting that builds on the open-air tradition that Renoir and Vigo brought to French film of the 30's. Truffaut adds the innovations that so many American reviewers found off-putting: the abrupt shifts in tone; the movie references and wild throwaway gags; the extraneous encounters that are there solely to express Truffaut's exuberance in moviemaking, in life itself. In musical terms, you could say "Shoot the Piano Player" is the place where the off-kilter wit of a Thelonious Monk solo meets the melancholy of a Sinatra ballad.

Swaying choir singers and rousing piano chords were his accompaniment. But Mr. Nelson was not performing a traditional Christian hymn synonymous with gospel music. He was singing a familiar liturgy, in Hebrew: "Adon Olam."

description: The sky is a brilliant blue and clear, the air unusually warm for September - a sign we are still closer to August than October. A little past 8 a.m. finds me still moving slowly around my Manhattan apartment, stepping over the dirty clothes and half-unpacked suitcases from a two-week beach vacation in the Hamptons and Southern California. My girlfriend, Kathryn, is in the kitchen washing dishes. Neither of us hurry. The Wall Street Journal's offices, where we work, sit directly across the street, making our commute something approximating eight minutes from door to desk.

The laid-back ballad broke radio airplay records this summer, reaching an estimated 192 million listeners in one week. That seems bode well for Johnta Austin, credited as one of the tune's main songwriters (there were 10 in all, including Ms. Carey), especially since he is releasing his own debut CD, "Ocean Drive," through So So Def/Virgin Records on Oct. 25.

The players, pooh-bahs and blue-bloods with good hair and loafers? Here I was, heading across a beautiful bay to an ocean community in late August, the apex of the season, when all manner of somebodies were working other beaches from St.-Tropez to Nantucket, and there wasn't a whiff of elitism anywhere.

This week, the county's Department of Consumer Protection issued subpoenas to 11 gas stations whose prices jumped by more than 60 cents a gallon in one day, from Aug. 31 to Sept. 1. One such offender's price went from $2.85 a gallon to $3.99 over that period. The average price increase in the county during those 24 hours was 30 cents a gallon, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONE, RAFFAELE ANTHONY
description: LEONE--Raffaele Anthony, July 5, 1923-September 5, 2005. "The Great Ralph" left his inscription all over the Bronx neighborhood as a little boy and thus began a family legend, our greatest character. Devoted son and brother, loyal husband of Madeline of 55 years, beloved father of Dr. Frank Leone (Lucy) and the late Adele Leone Monaco (Richard), cherished grandfather of Darsi, Francis, Marietta, Renata, and Joseph. After graduating NYU he transformed his father's manufacturing company into the Raffaele label, dressing the most beautiful women of his time. Upon retirement he worked at his daughter's side as a literary agent, endearing people with his gentle, persistent nature. Ralph loved New York, loved the Bronx; he will be remembered as a man of great intelligence, style and grace, who rarely left the house without his shirt and tie, enormous eyes brimming with life and love. "...we'll be looking at the moon, but we'll be seeing you..."

description: One by one, the fall flowers are opening. And the back-to-school season-opener taking place this week is especially a family affair. Not only is the CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER presenting its paterfamilias, CHARLES WADSWORTH, in its opening night program on Thursday -- accompanying the able young soprano DINA KUZNETSOVA in some of Dvorak's Gypsy Songs -- but the husband-and-wife team of DAVID FINCKEL and WU HAN are performing with the society for the first time in their current role as its artistic directors (as opposed to another of Mr. Finckel's roles, cellist of the Emerson Quartet). Also playing are another husband and wife, EMANUEL AX and YOKO NOZAKI, and some members of the Chamber Music Society's "family" of artist members, like the violinist CHO-LIANG LIN and the violist PAUL NEUBAUER. The program is a carefully constructed essay on Central Europe: in addition to Dvorak, it features music by Bartok, Smetana and Boulanger -- George, not Nadia. 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212)875-5050, $28 to $105.

First, it reunites Gwyneth Paltrow with John Madden, who directed her Oscar-winning performance in "Shakespeare in Love." Second, it is the first of three films opening this fall -- the others are "Jarhead" and "Brokeback Mountain" -- that could propel Jake Gyllenhaal to genuine, 14-carat stardom. Third, like that other Academy Award favorite, "A Beautiful Mind," "Proof" dips into the alien waters of madness and higher mathematics before settling down on the more familiar shores of family drama. And finally, it brings to the screen David Auburn's Broadway hit, which won both the Tony and the Pulitzer Prize in 2001.

title: Val Lewton Horror Collection
description: The Grade-B horror pictures made in the 1940's for RKO by the producer and writer Val Lewton -- several of them in collaboration with the director Jacques Tourneur -- may have been put together on the run and with pocket change. But those are the only things remotely cheap about them. Lewton was as fascinated by monsters as his colleagues over at that other studio, Universal, were. But his monsters tend to walk around in street clothes, with regular, everyday faces: the fact that they could be anyone only reinforces the idea that they could be us. "Cat People" (1942) and "I Walked With a Zombie" (1943), both directed by Tourneur, are horror pictures rewritten to resemble 18th-century seduction verse. Their allure is sensual and unnerving, and their visual poetry alone has a velvety lushness: in "Zombie," whispering slivers of light streak through the slatted blinds of a Caribbean mansion, like fingers reaching out in the darkness; in "Cat People," a troubled young wife (Simone Simon, who has the face of a petulant Persian kitten) stares out her window on a moonlit night, shivering not at the thought of what might be out there, but at what might be inside her. This collection includes those two pictures, as well as the seven others Lewton made for RKO (and a biographical documentary). Together they're a treasure chest of skillful shoestring filmmaking, a sterling example of how much you can accomplish with brains and good lighting. The A-list is for unimaginative overachievers; Lewton understood the melancholy joy of being B. (Warner Home Video, Oct. 4, $59.98) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK THE NEW SEASON FILM/DVD'S

Out of the Small Clubs, Into the Big Time
description: EVER since major jazz labels began to shrink their rosters in the late 90's, the average consumer hasn't really been able to hear what's happening in the small New York clubs. (Maybe contemporary jazz is moving toward a position of having no average consumers, but that's another issue.) Over the last five years, one of the best musicians to make his home in places like Fat Cat and the Up Over Jazz Cafe has been the young pianist Robert Glasper. He has regularly been great, starting out from powerful, precise expositions of theme and then expanding his area of play, always followed closely by his trio. But the grapevine has its limits: unless you're a New York jazz musician, or you hang out with them, you've probably never heard him. "Canvas," which comes out on Oct. 4, is actually his second album, after "Mood," which appeared two years ago on the Spanish label Fresh Sound. The new recording is on the much more visible Blue Note label, and it shows Mr. Glasper doing what he has done, more or less, in those shows, and that is good. There will be time later to build concepts; the main thing is to get a representative sample of his rolling pulse in improvisations, his sputter of ideas within the close watchwork movements of his regular trio, with Vicente Archer on bass and Damion Reid on drums. Mr. Glasper owes a debt to Herbie Hancock, as do most mainstream jazz pianists who came along in the last three decades, and he doesn't hide it in the album's pretty harmonic changes. But laid thickly over any secondary stuff is his own jittery, hip-hop-altered sense of groove. Mr. Glasper's first weeklong residence at a major club in New York -- the Village Vanguard, in fact, which couldn't be better for him -- will finally happen the first week of November. THE NEW SEASON POP/JAZZ

title: He Didn't Wear a Suit, but He Tended to Village Business
description: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON - JUST down the street from my house is St. Matthew's, a church with seating for about 500 people, but on a recent weekday morning, many more were there, hoping to squeeze in. Traffic clogged the downtown; the village hall, the community center and the library were all closed. Even recycling pickup had been canceled. The community had put itself at a standstill not to honor a dignitary or a local politico, but to mourn a 29-year-old Department of Public Works employee.

title: Among the Believers
description: Benjamin Kunkel's first novel, "Indecision," published last month, concerns a young man living in Manhattan and trying, as the title suggests, to figure out what to do with his life. He has a B.A. in philosophy and an active, if confusing, romantic life; he gets by on a combination of office work and parental subsidy. In his author's affectionate estimation, offered over a beer on a recent evening at a Brooklyn bar, this young man, whose name is Dwight Wilmerding, is "kind of an idiot." Perhaps, but he may also be -- the critical response to "Indecision" suggests as much -- an especially representative kind of idiot. His plight, after all, is -- for people of his age and background -- a familiar one: an alienation from his own experience brought about by too much knowledge, too many easy, inconsequential choices, too much self-consciousness. Bred in a culture consecrated to the entitled primacy of the individual, he discovers that he lacks a self, a coherent identity, maybe a soul. He feels that he could be anyone. "It wasn't very unusual for me to lie awake at night," he confesses, "feeling like a scrap of sociology blown into its designated corner of the world. But knowing the clichs are clichs doesn't help you to escape them. You still have to go on experiencing your experience as if no one else has ever done it."

title: Correction Officer Shoots Two, Then Is Killed Fleeing Police

title: Message in a Basket
description: Baskets, made by Tutsi and Hutu women who came together after Rwanda was devastated by the war between their tribes, are for sale at Macy's in New York. Woven with papyrus, banana leaf, sisal or bamboo, the collection, $30 to $80, includes a delicate black-and-ivory version of a centuries-old basket shaped like an acorn and traditionally used by brides for keepsakes ($60), far left. It has been renamed the Peace Basket. "People just imagine Rwanda as being a sad and troubled place, and we wanted to get a positive story out," said Kaliza Karuretwa, a trade counselor at the Rwandan Embassy in Washington, who helped link the women to Macy's (www.macys.com/rwanda): 151 West 34th Street or (212)494-4181. DEBORAH BALDWIN PULSE

title: Three Stars to Outshine Their Broadway Spotlight
description: TURN your ears, for a moment, away from all that star-struck chatter about Julia Roberts making her Broadway debut in a revival of Richard Greenberg's "Three Days of Rain" and consider another movie star in another Greenberg play. That's Jill Clayburgh, who will be appearing in "A Naked Girl on the Appian Way," now in previews and opening on Oct. 6 at the American Airlines Theater in a Roundabout Theater Company production. Now Ms. Clayburgh -- who is not, for the record, the nude abroad of the title -- may no longer have the cash-register cachet of Ms. Roberts. But there was a time, about a quarter of a century ago, when Ms. Clayburgh, too, was Hollywood's reigning It girl.

Van Gogh's Ear successfully distracts patrons from the eponymous grisly image with a fun, relaxing atmosphere. Funky mismatched furniture, bookcases and dim lighting make it seem like an after-hours soiree at a Levitz showroom.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 11-Sept. 17; ART
description: What promises to be one of the more unusual -- and, perhaps, silliest -- happenings of the coming art season will occur on Friday night: the launching of a full-scale realization of Robert Smithson's "FLOATING ISLAND TO TRAVEL AROUND MANHATTAN ISLAND." Based on a pencil drawing that Smithson, the influential earthwork artist, made in 1970 and produced by Minetta Brook, a nonprofit organization, and the Whitney Museum of American Art, where a Smithson retrospective is currently on view, the "island" is a 30-by-90-foot barge loaded with a landscape of dirt, rocks, trees and bushes. A tugboat will tow it over the waters surrounding Manhattan from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., Saturday through Sept. 25. An opening reception will take place at Hudson River Park, Pier 46 at Charles and West Streets, on Saturday evening from 5 to 7. R.S.V.P. to floatingisland@minettabrook.org. For more information call the Whitney at (800)944-8639.

title: With Pain Still Lingering, 9/11 Victims Honored

As it happened, Alexandra Raij and her husband, Eder Montero, both chefs, had been looking to open a Spanish restaurant because, Raij said, "We weren't finding places we liked." So Raij answered the ad.

But despite the gains, blacks still lagged behind whites in combined scores by 219 points and behind Hispanics by 163 points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLEMENTS, H. MILLARD
description: CLEMENTS--H. Millard, on August 29, 2005. The NYU Steinhardt School of Education mourns the loss of H. Millard Clements, Professor Emeritus, global educator and former co-director of the Environmental Conservation Education program. Throughout his 35 year career in the Department of Teaching and Learning, Millard taught his students to incorporate communication technologies, environmental and peace advocacy into their teaching. A founder of YouthCaN, Youth Communicating and Networking, Millard worked with young people to develop online communities and cooperative projects. His goodness, humanitarianism, and steadfast devotion to good causes inspired his students and colleagues. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Phyllis, and family.

The new curlers have the same wide, shallow curve and soft silicone pad of the original, making smoothly swooping lashes a pinch-free possibility for eyes of all shapes and sizes. title: The Crime: Slow Job Growth. A Suspect: Enron.
description: WHILE the economy has enjoyed steady growth and low inflation since the recession ended in the fall of 2001, many companies have been reluctant to add new workers. "Any way you slice the data, employment growth has been disappointing in this recovery," said Lawrence F. Katz, professor of economics at Harvard. The Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group in Washington, concludes that the lag in job growth has caused an "employment deficit" in the United States of 3.2 million jobs.
