title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAHN, PHILIP J.
description: HAHN--Philip J. Born March 31, 1916. He passed away on September 8, 2005 at the age of 89. He was raised in Brooklyn where, as a youth, his intelligence and bright personality quickly shown through. After Pearl Harbor, Phil joined the Army and served in Military Intelligence doing signals work and code breaking. His unit was stationed in Africa, Italy, and Austria over the course of the war. His time in Italy began his love affair with that country. He spoke Italian fluently, traveled often to Rome and was, to his great pride and satisfaction, a Cavaliere of the Italian Republic. After the war, Phil returned home where he joined the family firm of M. Fabrikant & Sons in New York City. An international diamond merchant, Phil traveled widely in the world, visiting Europe, Africa and Asia. Often he would circumnavigate the globe on his business voyages, to his great pleasure and the amazement of his friends and family. Phil was a lover of good food, fine wine, and great art and literature. He was multi-lingual, speaking French and other languages in addition to Italian. Phil was a connoisseur of culture and enjoyed life to its fullest. He contributed to the arts in New York City, supporting Carnegie Hall, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Metropolitan Opera. He was also a generous philanthropist, giving to many charities through his charitable foundation, and he endowed the upkeep of a portion of Central Park. New York City was his true love; it gave him great strength and was the object of his passions. He was devoted to his sisters, his nephews, and their children all of whom will miss him dearly. Phil is survived by his sister and brother-inlaw, Bobbie and Irving Rosenzweig, his nephews Scott and Rick Frishman and their children, and his nephews Paul and Jim Rosenzweig and their children. Funeral services will take place on Sunday September 11, 2005 at 11:30 A.M at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Donations should be made in his memory to a charity of your choice. $(6$)HAHN--Philip J. The employees of M. Fabrikant & Sons, Inc., mourn the loss of our Co-Chairman of the Board, Mr. Philip J. Hahn. Following his distinguished career in the Army during World War II, Mr. Hahn devoted himself to the growth and development of the firm to its status as the worldwide industry leader. He was a titan of the diamond industry who pioneered the early days of the markets in Tel Aviv, Mumbai, and Antwerp where he established manufacturing and trading offices for the firm. He was a positive presence in our New York office until his demise at the age of 89. We mourn his loss, and will miss his wit and wisdom. We extend our condolences to his family. $(6$)HAHN--Philip J. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague. His many years of commitment, dedication and leadership in the diamond industry will be sorely missed. Diamond Manufacturers & Importers Assoc. of America

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOCH, SUSAN DRYFOOS
description: KOCH--Susan Dryfoos. Cherished mother of Peggy Koch Palmer and her husband Briggs S. Palmer Jr., and Kathy Koch Willens and her husband Randall D. Willens, passed away on September 9, 2005, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Adored by many, Susan knew how to be a true friend. She devoted herself to the cause of women and children whose lives were marred by violence. She was the Chair of the Family Violence Divisional Board and a valued member of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. Formerly, Susan worked as a stockbroker, a career she loved. She was an avid bridge enthusiast, a plant lover, and the adoring grandmother of Charlotte and Daniel Willens, and Jordan and Christopher Palmer. She is also survived by her loving nieces, Jennifer Dryfoos and Liz Young, and her sister-in-law Sally Mayer. We will always hold her precious memory in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be sent to the the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 W. 57th St, NYC 10019. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, October 2, at 1 PM. $(6$)KOCH--Susan D. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Susan D. Koch. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family. Patricia Sumergrade, Pres. Richard J. Bronstein, Secy. $(6$)KOCH--Susan D. Sisters always; my love forever. Florrie

title: Passion and the Prisoner
description: It's obvious what women see in men behind bars: most of the murderers and rapists Daphne Merkin cites in her Aug. 28 essay have one key factor in common, and it's not just that they are convicted perpetrators of hideous crimes. They are -- duh -- famous. All it takes in this day and age is national notoriety, whether it's for dismembering young girls or singing badly on "American Idol," to garner yourself a slathering fan club. I doubt that the women who lust after Scott Peterson or the Menendez brothers would find themselves falling for any of the unknown felons in the county jail. Put one of those losers on TV or on the pages of The National Enquirer and he suddenly becomes irresistible.

title: Can't Forget the Motor City
description: Paul Clemens (Lives, Aug. 28) can refer to his "white-trash roots," but I doubt that, say, his father, who sounds like a skilled, hard-working man, would like to be called that. It's astounding that Clemens, a reader of "The Great Gatsby," no less, can be so insensitive when it comes to class prejudice.

title: Le Samoura
description: In Jean-Pierre Melville's end-of-an-era, end-of-a-man noir "Le Samoura" (1967), Alain Delon plays a hit man so good at his job that he has virtually erased himself. He strides through the streets of Paris in a fedora and trench coat -- classic garb that screams "shady character" to anyone who's paying attention -- and yet even after he has committed murder, the witnesses have trouble picking him out of a police lineup. Mr. Delon's face looks as if it has been emptied, as if it were once able to show feeling but has now forgotten how -- or has simply become terrified at the prospect. He could be the Beatles' "Nowhere Man," except that in his noble passivity, he's almost more feminine than masculine -- he's like an old-fashioned vision of a bride, a woman waiting to be completed, but by what? This restored "Le Samoura" includes archival interviews with Melville and Mr. Delon, as well as a reprinted tribute by John Woo, who has cited "Le Samoura" as his favorite movie. That's no surprise, given that Mr. Woo has always been fascinated by gangster codes of honor and by the glimmers of humanity lurking in seemingly coldblooded killers. But in any lineup of iconic hoods, Mr. Delon stands out. At the end of "Le Samoura," he's the bride stripped bare, left holding a gun instead of a bouquet. He finally gets what he's been waiting for: his bridegroom is taking him home. (Criterion, Oct. 18, $29.95) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK THE NEW SEASON FILM/DVD'S

I was drinking Old Cubans, a Champagne mojito that makes you forget what you ever saw in the original. On the other side of the bar, two bartenders discussed the merits of tearing versus snipping. I think we were still on the subject of mint.

title: Movies
description: I HEART HUCKABEES (2004) Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:35 a.m. on Cinemax David O. Russell's messy but adventurous comedy is about good guys and the bad guys who corrupt them. Which is easy because the bad guys have all the money. Jason Schwartzman (above, in suit, with Jude Law) stars as Albert, an environmental activist who agrees to join forces with Huckabees, a generally evil megastore, and regrets it. The villains include Mr. Law as a two-faced store executive, Naomi Watts as his girlfriend (and the Huckabees spokesmodel) and Isabelle Huppert as a nihilistic self-help author whose credo is "Cruelty, manipulation, meaninglessness." Mark Wahlberg plays an angry firefighter who, like Albert, becomes a client of husband-and-wife "existential detectives" (Dustin Hoffman and Lily Tomlin) who cure angst by going through people's garbage.

title: The Makeup Artist
description: Jillian Dempsey, a makeup artist and the founder of Delux Beauty cosmetics, believes in simplifying the face-painting process as much as possible. "My line stands for easy-to-apply, quick but beautiful colors," she said of her collection, a selection of creamy and shimmering eye, lip and skin shades. "I don't have a lot of time to spend on my face, but I want to feel pretty and presentable -- and then get out the door." Ms. Dempsey, who lives in Los Angeles, applies that philosophy to her wardrobe as well. "I might wear something casual and comfortable for work and add a few pieces of Fred Leighton jewelry because my husband likes to give nice anniversary presents," she said. She has been married six years to the actor Patrick Dempsey ("Grey's Anatomy"). Here, Ms. Dempsey wears a silk chiffon blouse ($363) and cashmere vest ($395) by Jovovich-Hawk, a line which is co-designed by the model and actress Milla Jovovich, who is a friend (Barneys, 212-826-8900); Levi's jeans and Christian Louboutin sandals. Other favorite designers include Vanessa Bruno, Chlo and Stella McCartney. "I also love Theory trousers," she said. Jeans are mainstay of Ms. Dempsey's laid-back style. "I just cleaned out my closet, so I only have nine pairs right now. And just like with mascara, I'm unfaithful. I jump from brand to brand." JENNIFER TUNG PULSE: WHAT I'M WEARING NOW

title: No Fixed Address
description: WASHINGTON - THE images of starving, exhausted, flood-bedraggled people fleeing New Orleans and southern Mississippi over the last two weeks have scandalized many Americans long accustomed to seeing such scenes only in faraway storm-tossed or war-ravaged places like Kosovo, Sudan or Banda Aceh.

title: The Cult of The Cycads
description: Never was there a more exciting article about plants than Lauren Kessler's (Aug. 28). It was an edge-of-the-seat story from the first description of the sting operation to the final account of the federal indictments. And along the way, I learned more about cycads and about illegal trafficking in rare plants than I ever thought I wanted to know.

title: Wrong Court for Activism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Henry Adams and the Making of America': Misunderstood
description: HENRY ADAMS AND THE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNAMARA, KEVIN J.
description: McNAMARA--Kevin J. 76, of Rancho Mirage, CA, formerly of New York City and East Hampton, died August 3, 2005. Son of John Francis and Florence Riordan McNamara of Newton, MA. Survived by his life partner and business partner of 23 years, Christopher J. Norman, three brothers, David, Eugene and Owen, and three sisters, Anne Marie, Jane Coughlin and Brenda Millette. Kevin graduated from Boston University with a design degree and was an Air Force veteran. Kevin worked for McMillen and Co. and Parish Hadley before founding his own firm, Kevin McNamara Inc. Inducted into the Interior Design Hall of Fame, one of Architectural Digest's top 100 designers, Mr. McNamara was regarded as one of the top interior designers of the last 40 years. Kevin also cofounded Christopher Norman Inc., which dramatically changed the furnishing fabric industry by weaving elegant, European-style silk in the Far East, thus making silk affordable to the entire interior design market, not just the very rich. Kevin also served as design director for Christopher Norman Inc. Kevin will be remembered for being elegant, wise, generous, charming, for being a true gentleman, for his wit, his personal style and his devotion to beauty and design.

title: 40 Years Later, America Is Studying War Once More
description: Americans, heavy sleepers that they are, are waking up to the news that 2005 is looking a lot like 1965. The art world has been snoozing along with everyone else, which is not to say the 1960's haven't been on its mind. Far-out little objects abound, the equivalents of macram and tie-dye but with a noncountercultural art school pedigree. That flower power grew from toxic fields in Vietnam hasn't had much mention. That was 40 years ago. Ancient history. Bad dream.

title: A Village of Their Own
description: I MOVED to the West Village four months ago in search of a tribe. My husband, Danny, had been murdered by Al Qaeda terrorists in Pakistan in 2002, while I was pregnant and living in India, and because it was a very public murder, I needed a neighborhood with two characteristics seemingly at odds, anonymity and intimacy. After moving within Manhattan four times in two years, I hoped I would find what I was looking for below 14th Street, above Canal and west of Broadway.

title: Behind in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Home of the Italian All-American Bagel
description: PORT CHESTER - THE air here is sweet and yeasty, heavy with the heat of baking and the noise of multimillion-dollar bagel-making machinery. With 90,000 dozen bagels a day being produced, how else would it smell?

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: After the Day Job

title: Charm and Flavor in a Spirited Setting
description: Nyack - LIKE many river towns, this one, at the Rockland County end of the Tappan Zee Bridge, is both a little hip and a little frayed. Its glory days of industry are gone, but Nyack has something few Westchester towns and cities do: a night life.

title: 9/11, Iraq And Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, RALPH K.
description: SMITH--Ralph K. Died in NYC on September 2, 2005 in the Bronx, NY. Born NYC on January 14, 1920, the son of Rose & Julian Smith. He is survived by his daughter Angela & her husband Bill Copeland of Red Oak, TX, three grandchildren, James II, Amanda, & Kristen, and six great grandchildren. His sister-in-law Jocelyn Smith of Colorado Springs, CO. He was a graduate from Wheaton College; he held a Master's degree in Theology and received a Master's degree in Library Sciences from Columbia University. He was a Librarian at Newsweek Magazine for 18 years. A consummate New Yorker, Ralph availed himself of the rich cultural life of the citytheater, opera, ballet, concerts and museum exhibitions. He leaves behind many friends and companions who will miss him greatly and remember him fondly with love. Memorial donations can be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Ave., Bronx, NY 10461. Memorial services will be announced.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Gramercy Penthouse $1,495,000

title: Living With the Dead
description: Oakland, Calif. - AND where do the dead go after they have sucked down their last breaths and drowned in the rafters of their homes? After they have died in the aftermath of fiery explosion? Do they gather, as some believe, together, and ascend to an otherworldly level; or do they remain, watching; or disappear altogether? Do they wait to hear the stories we will tell?

title: MEANWHILE, IN CHINA
description: Expletives and enmity were not the only embarrassments to surface in Microsoft's lawsuit. In other documents, Mr. Lee said Microsoft promised China in 2002 that it would shift jobs there from its headquarters in Redmond, Wash. "At the time of my departure," Mr. Lee said, "Microsoft was on track to outsource 1,000 jobs a year to China."

title: Duty Binds Officers Who Have Gone to Help After Storm
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 10 - On Toulouse and North Rampart Streets in the French Quarter, a Michigan police car nosed behind a New York City Police Department truck parked outside the New Orleans Police Department's First District.

title: When Your College Falls Victim to a Hurricane
description: ABOUT 11 on the Saturday morning before Hurricane Katrina hit, Chris Ilardi moved into the freshman dormitory at Tulane University to start his first year at college. His parents, Terry and Kathy, helped him unpack and set up his new home.

title: After Katrina, Invest in Oil, but Shut Off the A.C.
description: NOW for a few brief thoughts about the catastrophe that is Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath.

title: Another Problem On the Green Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage Children
description: When the Off Broadway Peccadillo Theater Company -- which specializes in American plays that have been largely forgotten by the public -- produces a show, the drama onstage is often not the only thing in the house the playwright brought to life.

title: Baby bulge creates a new niche
Fake Storm Followed by A Real Plan
description: SEPTEMBER is the worst month for hurricanes in Connecticut. So after viewing the victims of Hurricane Katrina and the remnants of New Orleans on television, Gov. M. Jodi Rell decided last week that she did not want to wait to ask the question: Could it happen here?

title: The Once-in-a-Blue-Moon Undertaking
description: IMPORTANT composers leave behind pieces that we should hear but don't know quite what to do with. In music, the orphaned state may involve overweight: instrumental, choral, vocal and sometimes multimedia extravaganzas that require added hiring, box-office worry and extra work for presenting organizations. Brave souls like the Cleveland Orchestra step in from time to time. On Jan. 12 and 14, the orchestra performs Schumann's "Scenes From Goethe's 'Faust"' in Severance Hall.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Upheaval at Arts Center

title: Correction
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about the Prometheus statue in Rockefeller Center referred incorrectly to the sculptor's model. His name is indeed known. He was Leonardo Nole, a native of New Rochelle, N.Y., who worked as a lifeguard before becoming an artist's model.

title: What to Do With FEMA
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, ROBERT A.
description: COHN--Robert A. Died September 8, 2005. Loving husband of Penny, dear father of Douglas and Mitchell. Funeral private.

title: Alphabet City: Bohemian Rhapsody
description: "Rent," the movie, opens in November. And although the swath of Alphabet City immortalized in the rock-opera-turned-film has largely been emptied of artists, bohemians, radicals and immigrants thanks to high rents, the area's diverse ethnic heritage is reflected in many neighborhood restaurants.

title: Man Charged in Companion's Murder
description: A 39-year-old Brooklyn man fatally stabbed his 34-year-old companion yesterday afternoon, while her children were in their Cypress Hills apartment, before he turned the knife on himself, the police said.

title: Sally Hawkins and Chad Loizeaux
description: Sally Hogan Hawkins and Chad Peter Loizeaux were married yesterday at the Church at Point O'Woods in Point O'Woods, N.Y. The Rev. Sennen SanFratello, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCKING, MARIE W.
description: HOCKING--Marie W. On August 31, of Manhattan and Dunewood, F.I. A celebration honoring Marie on Sunday October 2, 2PM in the United Nations Chapel, 777 UN Plaza @ 44 St. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, NYC 10017.

title: After a San Francisco Freeway's Collapse, Growth
description: IN 1992, earthquake-damaged ramps to the old Central Freeway at Franklin and Gough Streets in San Francisco were torn down, opening up views from the heart of Hayes Valley clear to City Hall. The demolition cleared the way for a thriving shopping strip on Hayes Street, once bisected by the freeway and plagued by crime. Simultaneously, residents living in the shadow of the area's other elevated freeway ramp, on Fell Street, lobbied for its removal and replacement by an alternative Parisian-style thoroughfare: the brand-new Octavia Boulevard.

title: On the Cover
description: THIS is the day that television revisits the worst nightmare of our time, but the overall tone of tonight's anniversary specials will not be as bleak as it might have been.

title: Passion and the Prisoner
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Digging Up Dinosaur Bones in the Fossil-Rich Badlands
description: THE gullies and buttes of the Dakotas and Montana are home to the Hell Creek Formation, a rock bed that is one of the richest fossil troves in the world. Laid down by rivers that flowed eastward through swamps to an inland sea that ran from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico, Hell Creek stone dates back to the end of the age of dinosaurs.

title: Remembering 9/11, and Healing Minds in Mississippi
description: On Sept. 11, 2001, Dr. Alan Manevitz headed for ground zero.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MOND, BERTRAND
description: MOND--Bertrand. Sept. 11, 2002. Dear Bert, it's been three years since the tragedy of your murder. I will always miss you and you are forever in my heart. Love, Phyl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUNSICK, GORDON
description: BUNSICK--Gordon. Poly Prep Class of 56 mourns the death of Gordon Bunsick, courageous warrior and key member of Poly's 1955 undefeated Ivy Prep League champion football team. We remember his warmth, wry sense of humor and quick wit. Condolences to his children and grandchildren.

title: Monthly Data, Overtaken by Events
description: ONE economic report after another is due this week. Under normal circumstances, each might provide crucial clues about the direction of the markets.

title: A Show About a Living, Breathing Architect?
description: Correction Appended

title: Meredith Monk Shows How It's Done
description: SQUEAKS and hums and little cries, glottal attacks and grunts: these are part of Meredith Monk's musical idiom. For 40 years, Ms. Monk has devoted herself to music of her own devising, meaning not only that she composes her own distinctively expressive works, but also that she has developed an entirely new technique for performing them.

title: Briefs: Allianz to buy rest of RAS
Paid Notice: Deaths   FINGAR, SOL
description: FINGAR--Sol. The Rubin family extends our heartfelt condolences to Debrah, Joseph, Glenn and Richard upon the passing of our dear friend and business associate Sol Fingar. In the many years we shared together, Sol was always a dynamic personality; a man who deeply loved his friends and family; and a man who was always ready to go that extra mile for anyone who needed his help. Sol will be sincerely missed but always well remembered by all of us whose lives he touched. Richard Rubin

title: Thwarting a Cough, With Decorum
description: THE elderly often complain that proper manners have gone the way of the passenger pigeon, as men no longer doff their caps and as filthy words pepper daily conversation. But executives at InnoZen, a drug maker in Woodland Hills, Calif., believe that decorum is still alive, and that polite people still dread making a scene. That is the inspiration behind the company's Suppress Cough strips, slivers of medicated film the size of soda-can pull tabs.

title: THE NEW SEASON FILM/DVD'S
description: A big hit in 1972 and almost forgotten now, this glossy, soapy, immensely satisfying version of the life of Billie Holiday follows the traditional rise-and-fall course of the showbiz-bio genre. And yet Diana Ross's alternately heartbreaking and terrifying performance (which should have been the start of a great movie career) places that predictable arc in the context of the film's moment in African-American history.

title: Rescuer In Mirror Is Closer Than He Appears
description: THERE is no breakdown lane on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Depending which way you're going, there are three, or four, lanes of traffic moving at 60 to 70 miles an hour. Just beyond them and a four-foot-high railing, there is the Hudson River, 157 feet straight down.

title: A 9/11 Survivor
description: A 9/11 Survivor

title: PHOTO-OP
It Isn't a Train Station, But Codey Has a Legacy
description: Speaking of the peripatetic Mr. Codey, at least one piece of his legacy was cemented last week at a ceremony that saw South Mountain Arena re-christened as the Richard J. Codey Arena at South Mountain.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   O'CONNOR, DIANA (NEE VEGA)
description: O'CONNOR--Diana (nee Vega). Remembering Diana. Beautiful, compassionate, intelligent, determined, loving, kind Diana. You remain in my heart always, "Princess Di". I love you so. Debbie

title: Familiar maverick relishes role of spoiler in German vote
Piazza Is Beaned in His First Game Back in Lineup
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 - Such is life for the Mets these days: Even when they receive a dose of good news, the baseball gods find some way to torture them.

title: In Sagaponack, Rebuff to an Oceanfront Coalition
description: SAGAPONACK became a village this month, when nearly two-thirds of its 464 registered voters went to its one-room schoolhouse and voted overwhelmingly to incorporate. It is the first village formed in Suffolk County since Westhampton Dunes, also in the Town of Southampton, was incorporated in 1993.

title: How to Help
description: Following are the main groups that the Federal Emergency Management Agency says are organizing aid for those affected by the hurricane. The agency also directs those wishing to give to the Web site networkforgood.org, and a list of such groups is available at nytimes.com/katrina.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 28 about Death Cab for Cutie and its new album, "Plans," misspelled the title of the band's previous album at one point. It is "Transatlanticism," not "Translatlanticism."

title: Italian Journalist Abducted in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 10 - Palestinian gunmen forced an Italian journalist from his car and abducted him on Saturday in the central Gaza Strip, according to Palestinian witnesses.

title: The Secret Life of Hanover Square
description: NEW YORK at night is a city of low-key voyeurs and discreet exhibitionists. Not droolers and flashers, but more or less lawful strollers like me, looking for the curtainless window whose occupant pursues some puzzling activity, or by the passing diorama show of apartment and brownstone interiors. In Manhattan this is a pleasure abetted by the tacit cooperation of residents who keep their windows clean and their shades up, affording a view to passers-by even when they don't enjoy one themselves.

title: Toronto
description: WHY GO NOW -- Walking around the bustling streets of Toronto, it seems hard to remember that two years ago it was reeling from the SARS epidemic, creating a virtually tourist-free ghost town. Now, the only epidemic these days is "Lord of the Rings" mania. Having been chosen as the site for the world premiere of the stage adaptation of J.R.R. Tolkien's trilogy, Toronto is bracing itself for the opening in March of the $23 million production at the Princess of Wales Theater. In the first week alone, ticket sales hit $6 million. at $1.17 Canadian to the United States dollar.

title: Ang Lee's gay love story wins top prize in Venice
Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLS, STANLEY
description: WELLS--Stanley, 81, humanitarian, artist, designer, actor, original thinker, entrepreneur, storyteller, entertainer, and general lover of people, passed away on September 8th after a long, courageous 18-year battle with cancer. Stanley was a highly decorated veteran of WWII, having flown over 50 missions. He is survived by his wife Blanche. He was the beloved father of Mitchell, Risa and Amy Wells, beloved grandfather of Jason, Tracey, Michele, Ariana, and Luke. He was also a much loved brother, uncle, cousin, and friend.

title: Mei Ko and Lester Cheng
description: Mei Man Ko, a daughter of Zeng Lan Feng and Sze Kwan Ko of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Lester Cheng, a son of Fao Ieng Chan and Fu Wing Cheng of Brooklyn. The Rev. Ian Cheung, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Evangelical Lutheran Church in Brooklyn.

title: They're Golden, But Not Quite Oldies
description: To the Editor:

title: Fisker's Vision: A Handbuilt Coach With Lots of Horses
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. - THE grandest cars ever did not roll off an assembly line in a state of perfection. With few exceptions, they were "coach built" classics customized down to the smallest details for wealthy customers.

title: The Bridge and the Beyond
description: Correction Appended

title: Put on Your Best Gimme Hat. It's the Upscale Redneck Show
description: AT NBC's presentations to advertisers in May, Kevin Reilly, the president of NBC Entertainment, referred to the network's prize sitcom "My Name Is Earl" as a "redneck" show that was also "upscale."

title: Reviving a Town Around an Arts Center
description: LONG BRANCH - TODD KATZ, the owner of a long-established paint company here, pulls aside the massive door of a building used as storage to reveal -- what else? -- paint cans. Thousands of cans, stacked on racks, some rising 20 or 30 feet toward a vaulted ceiling, which is in pretty bad shape.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Corey Creek's Bold Choices
description: Mr. Bedell made both wines at Bedell Cellars in Cutchogue; the grapes were cultivated at Corey Creek, its sister estate in Southold.

title: A SoHo Loft for Moe the Bartender
description: THE ultraluxury condo tower designed by the architect Santiago Calatrava for a site near the South Street Seaport has been heavily hyped and is being lavishly marketed -- at prices ranging from $29 million to $59 million. But will it ever be built? Its 10 four-story cubic apartments went on sale last month, but the developer has yet to obtain financing to build the tower.

title: Business, Though Not as Usual, Starts Stirring in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9 - Bones broken, vital organs far from functional, the faintest pulse has begun to beat in the battered and beleaguered streets of the Big Easy.

title: STORM AND CRISIS
description: BUSINESSES, BACK TO LIFE -- The vast majority of businesses in New Orleans are locked tight, but there are snippets of economic activity and signs of more to come. PAGE 25

title: Laughing It Off
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Runner-Up Goes the Sitcom
description: It worked for Clay Aiken on "American Idol" and Trista Rehn Sutter on "The Bachelor." Now Kara Saun (above, left), the last aspiring fashion designer eliminated on Bravo's hit "Project Runway," is learning that finishing second in a reality competition can still make you a winner: Ms. Saun has been selected as head costume designer for the coming fourth season of the WB comedy series "What I Like About You."

title: State Colleges Open To Hurricane Victims
description: At the request of Gov. M. Jodi Rell, the State University system has offered free tuition at its schools for the fall semester to students from Connecticut who were enrolled in colleges and universities that have been closed because of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Helping the Poor of New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran resolves to continue its nuclear activities
Also Coming Soon
description: Lost in this year's post-Christmas shuffle, the terrific Turkish-German drama "Head-On" (Tuesday) is one of those rare gutter romances that don't confuse authenticity with grunginess. The "children of Marx and Coca-Cola" finally receive the home video treatment they deserve in Criterion's edition of Jean-Luc Godard's "Masculin Fminin" (Sept. 20). Criterion also brings us a new edition of David Bowie in Nicolas Roeg's sci-fi drama "The Man Who Fell to Earth" (Sept. 27). "Teorema" is not where the wind comes sweeping down the plain, but Pier Paolo Pasolini's drama, with Terence Stamp as an enigmatic stranger who seduces each member of a bourgeois household (Oct. 4). "The Alfred Hitchcock Masterpiece Collection" (Oct. 4) consists of 16 discs, many of them (like "Vertigo") proving the title true. "Rebel Samurai: Sixties Swordplay Classics" (Oct. 4) collects long-unavailable milestones in Japanese cinema, like "Samurai Rebellion," starring Toshiro Mifune. The seminal noir "Kiss of Death," in which Richard Widmark pushes an old lady in a wheelchair down a flight of stairs, makes its debut on DVD. Charlotte Gainsbourg delivers an exquisite performance in one of this year's best films, "Happily Ever After" (Oct. 11), directed by and starring her husband, Yvan Attal. Everyone who loves Johnny Petraglia and movies, rejoice: the Coen brothers' bowling opus, "The Big Lebowski" (Oct. 18), gets the deluxe treatment. When did summer movies last give us a potent piece of political filmmaking? They did this summer with George A. Romero's knockout "Land of the Dead" (Oct. 25). Warner Brothers continues its stellar reissues of MGM classics with a three-disc edition of "The Wizard of Oz" (Oct. 25). Expect lines of geeks to start forming outside video stores right now in anticipation of the Nov. 1 release of "Star Wars: Episode III -- Revenge of the Sith," subsection XVIII, paragraph X, etc. The DVD release of Michael Winterbottom's groundbreaking sex-and-music drama "9 Songs" (Nov. 8) gives the critics who feigned boredom the first time around the chance to feign it all over again. Jacques Rivette's sun-kissed, extra-sensory and epic meditation on the art of storytelling, "Celine and Julie Go Boating" (Nov. 15), comes at last to DVD. "Ran," Akira Kurosawa's pitiless version of "King Lear," arrives from Criterion on Nov. 15. And Dec. 13 brings the DVD debut of Toms Gutirrez Alea's fiercely intelligent "Memories of Underdevelopment," which landed the director in hot water in his native Cuba, and the National Society of Film Critics in hot water with our own government when it tried to honor him. THE NEW SEASON FILM/DVD'S

title: R.V. Owners Skip Camp and Park at Wal-Mart
description: Correction Appended

title: The Next Big One
description: The next killer hurricane that hits Long Island will give far more warning than the last one, which came ashore at Westhampton Beach on Sept. 21, 1938, and scoured the East End like a firehose trained on a sandbox. It shattered houses, scattered boats and trees, opened the breaches that became Shinnecock Inlet and Shinnecock Canal, and killed more than 50 people, none of whom had seen the monster coming.

title: Dangerous Talkers
description: Here's a new road game to play when the children start getting restless in the back seat. Get them to count the number of drivers who have one hand on the wheel and the other holding a cellphone to the ear.

title: Finally, a Grand Slam for Clijsters
description: Kim Clijsters raced from point to point, sliding into leg splits and towing the listless Mary Pierce in her wake, in a hurry to reach a destination that had eluded her like a mirage.

title: Up Front
description: On the fourth anniversary of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, we feature two essays about terrorist fiction. On Page 14, Benjamin Kunkel, an editor at the literary journal n+1 whose first novel, "Indecision," was recently reviewed in these pages, explores the ways in which novelists and terrorists sometimes share a revolutionary fervor. "In the fantasy-nightmare of the terrorist novel, the terrorist was the public symbol maker the novelist wished and failed to be," he writes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROWE, JOHN JAY, JR.
description: ROWE--John Jay, Jr. Died Sunday, August 28 at his home in Amagansett at the age of four score and seven. He and his wife, Diana Cutler, were married in 1941 and spent many years summering in the Devon Colony until he retired and became a full time resident. His family of five children and eight grandchildren will cherish the legacy that he created. Born in Cincinnati, he was the youngest son of Grace Probasco Rowe and John Jay Rowe. He attended Cincinnati Country Day School, Middlesex and Harvard, Class of 1940. He served his country in W.W. II as an Army Captain and spent his career at Procter & Gamble. Best known to the locals as the creator of "Ferryland"--John Rowe was a friend to all; he opened his door and knowledge, wit and a youthful spirit poured out. Our hearts are at half-mast but his wishes were resolute, "Let no moaning be, as I put out to sea." The memorial service will be on Saturday, October 8, at Spring Grove Cemetery, Cincinnati, Ohio, in the Norman Chapel 10:30 AM.

title: Going It Alone in Divorce Court
description: THE mother from North Haven sat in the back of Judge Patricia L. Harleston's wood-paneled courtroom at the New Haven County Courthouse and cried quietly. She was unemployed, she owed more than $2,000 in child support and she had no idea how she was going to defend herself. She said she couldn't afford a lawyer, so she was representing herself at the child support hearing. Meanwhile, the lawyer for the father of her children sat across the room.

title: Last Word on Letters
description: One letter writer in your Aug. 28 issue allowed that nothing he has read "illustrates the twilight of the American Empire more clearly" than Daniel Bergner's Aug. 14 article about private security companies working in Iraq, comparing this development to mighty Rome's demise upon its reliance on Germanic tribes as mercenaries to protect its borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSEL, MYRA TEICHER
description: RUSSEL--Myra Teicher. Died September 7th of a heart attack. She was two months shy of her 85th birthday. She is survived by her three children, Marjorie, David and Danny, their spouses, Peter, Luba and Keiko, six grandchildren to whom she was utterly devoted, Alexander, Byron, Constantine, Emily, Kevin and Sascha, and her brother Henry and sister-in-law Anne Teicher. Myra lived several lives, all with great intelligence and gusto. She was a lifelong socialist, a machinist during WW II, a loving wife and mother, a college professor, an author and scholar. After her children were grown, she earned an MA at Sarah Lawrence College, then taught literature at Elizabeth Seton College in Yonkers for many years. In retirement, she taught retired NY Public School teachers, selecting a fresh set of books to discuss each year. Her professional specialty was music written to the poems of James Joyce. In her 70's, she rediscovered and published a book of Geoffrey Molyneux Palmer's song settings to "Chamber Music", and she introduced the songs to musicians who performed and recorded them. Myra wrote many scholarly articles, and she attended and presented her work at various James Joyce symposia here and in Euorpe, most recently this past Bloomsday. She will be missed by her family and friends. Contributions in her name can be made to the International Rescue Committee. A memorial service will be held.

title: 'God Jr.': In the Game
description: God Jr.

title: The Music of the Spheres
description: MOUNT LAUREL - NFL FILMS is the ultimate connoisseur of the bone-crunching tackle, the impossible fingertip catch, the 50-yard sideline scamper. But, in the end, it doesn't mean a thing if it doesn't have that swing.

title: Dangerous Talkers
description: Here's a new road game to play when the children start getting restless in the back seat. Get them to count the number of drivers who have one hand on the wheel and the other holding a cellphone to the ear. The game will probably be more fun if you don't spoil it by telling the youngsters what a hazard those one-handed drivers really are. Or that you, their harassed chauffeur, must maneuver with extra care and concern because of all those driver-talkers blithely breaking New York State law.

title: 'Theatre of Fish'
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, NOEL
description: SCHNEIDER--Noel. We deeply mourn the passing of Noel Schneider on August 31, 2005, at age 85. Beloved devoted husband of Adele, his wife for more than 55 years; cherished dear father of Adam/ Sandy and Tracy; adored and adoring grandfather of Marna, Lorin, David, and Emma; revered brother of Joan Bodie; esteemed uncle to many nieces and nephews; and treasured by many relatives and longtime friends. He was a gifted, award-winning artist, recognized in Who's Who in American Art since 1973, whose works were beamed abroad by the U.S.I.A.'s Voice of America. He was a proud WWII volunteer veteran who survived more than four years of active service. After his retirement, he earned two associate degrees with honors, in Fine Arts and in Marine Technology. He was loved by all who were privileged to know him, and the memory of his long and wonderful life will live on in our hearts as a permanent tribute and celebration. Donations may be made to Families With Children From China Orphanage Assistance Program (www.fccny.org or P.O. Box 237065, Ansonia Station, New York, NY 10023) or to your chosen charity.

title: Real World: Thailand
description: FRANKLIN PARK - IT must be tough to name a restaurant. You don't want to go with your own name, in case the place flops. You don't want something too distinctive, for fear of ridicule. But you also don't want obscurity -- for fear that your restaurant will go the way of its name.

title: Senator Will Not Ask Roberts to Take a Stand on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - With confirmation hearings for Judge John G. Roberts Jr. set to convene on Monday, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee says in his written opening statement that he does not intend to ask the nominee if he would overturn Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion.

title: Reggaetn Rides the Next Latin Wave
description: COULD this year bring the Latin wave that lasts? The demographics make it seem inevitable: the 2002 census found that one in eight Americans is Hispanic, and a large younger generation is bilingual and bicultural, so it would seem that American pop is bound to bend in their direction. A few years ago, Latin pop seemed ready, with English-language hits by established Spanish-speaking pop stars like Ricky Martin (from Puerto Rico), Marc Anthony (from New York) and Shakira (from Colombia); then it fizzled. But this fall brings another chance, from a familiar face and a fairly new one.

title: Assistance, Incentives And the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: John Adams Thinks Big Once Again
description: BEFORE Pamela Rosenberg leaves her post as general director of the San Francisco Opera at the end of this year, she will deliver a parting gift: the premiere of "Doctor Atomic," a new opera that she commissioned from John Adams about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the Manhattan Project and those anxious weeks in 1945 just before the dropping of the atomic bomb. Peter Sellars directs the production, set to open on Oct. 1, and early glimpses suggest that a truly exciting and important work may be on its way.

title: Dysfunctional Eagles Turn Attention To the Game
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9 - The Philadelphia Eagles will be on national television Monday night, and soap operas will be shown Monday afternoon. The Eagles, who have had their share of melodrama lately, will try to keep the programming mutually exclusive.

title: Helping the Poor of New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: Realistic Idealists
description: LYNN GROSSMAN, a writer in Manhattan who is married to the actor Bob Balaban, comes from a long line of social activists. Her mother joined the civil rights movement, and she herself marched in protest of the Vietnam War. But she said that things had changed by the time her eldest daughter, Mariah, now 27, came of age.

title: In Houston, Pickup Basketball New Orleans Style
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 10 - The toughest pickup games of all can be found on the hot blacktop in the Astrodome parking lot.

title: Sisters, brothers read loved ones' names on fourth Sept. 11 anniversary
Paid Notice: Memorials   MATTHEWS, JUDY
description: MATTHEWS--Judy. A woman for all seasons. She did it all. You are in our hearts forever. Love always, Steve, Howard, Sandy, Dave, Juliette and Little Matty

title: Passion and the Prisoner
description: I wonder, as Merkin was tying up the bow at the end of her essay, admitting to a crush on Gary Gilmore, removed from the eligible list only because he was executed -- does she know that O.J. and Robert Blake are still available?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, SYLVIA WOHL
description: FELDMAN -- Sylvia Wohl. Dearly loved wife, sister, mother, grandmother, aunt and friend passed away peacefully on September 7, 2005. She will be sorely missed and forever loved by her late husband, Milton; brother, Bernie Wohl; her sons, Leslie and Jeffrey; daughter-in-law, Lori; grandchildren, Alexis, Brittany, Spencer and Morgan; and her dearest lifelong friend, Selma Slater. Funeral service Sunday, September 11, 12:45, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St. $(6$)FELDMAN--Sylvia. To our dear Cousins and Uncle Bernie, our heartfelt condolences. To our beautiful Aunt Sylvia, we love you and will miss you very, very much. Elinor Wohl Marty Greitzer Rick, Jane, Robby and Kelly Brickell $(6$)FELDMAN -- Sylvia. My heartfelt condolences to my Cousins Jeffrey, Lori, Morgan, Spencer, Leslie, Alexis and Brittany; and to my dear Uncle Bernie on the loss of my beautiful Auntie, Sylvia. Nancy Drake $(6$)FELDMAN--Sylvia. Our deepest heartfelt condolences to the Feldman and Wohl families. Richard Fabricant David L. Deitz Naomi Glauberman

title: Lindsay Dearborn and Craig Butters
description: Lindsay Hanna Dearborn, a daughter of Angelica Gerry Dearborn of New Canaan, Conn., and Philip Dearborn of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Craig Warren Butters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Butters of Plymouth, Mass. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of Reynolds duPont Jr., a friend of the bride's mother, on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Owning Is Hard
description: THOUSANDS of fledgling landlords are scooping up small multiple-unit dwellings throughout the New York area -- pristine two-families in the Rockaways, for instance, or vintage buildings along Manhattan side streets or in Brooklyn's brownstone enclaves -- but some of them do not quite know what they are getting into.

title: Laughing All the Way From the Bank
description: Sanford I. Weill, who directed the merger of Travelers and Citicorp, calls the combination a "great success" and brushes off those who call it unwieldy.

title: 'Moondust': Down to Earth
description: MOONDUST

title: Yankees Step in the Bucket in an Ugly Loss to Boston
description: George Steinbrenner was agitated as he left Yankee Stadium yesterday, shooing away reporters who wanted to ask him about the ghastly scene he was fleeing. "Get out of here," Steinbrenner said. "Leave me alone."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERN, MARVIN
description: KERN--Marvin. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Sharon Kern-Taub and Donald Kern. Adored grandfather of Matthew Taub. Services today, 12 noon, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 28 about the contemporary art scene in Istanbul misidentified the architect of the Blue Mosque. He was Mehmet Aga, not Mimar Sinan. (Aga was an apprentice of Sinan's.)

title: Laughing All the Way From the Bank
description: ADORNING a conference room wall on the third floor of Citigroup's Manhattan headquarters is an enormous wooden plaque. It bears a likeness of the company's chairman, Sanford I. Weill, and lists every deal he engineered to create what is now the country's largest, most profitable and most influential financial institution.

title: Putting the warlords out of business
Spain Chides Careless Public in Bid to Prevent Forest Fires
description: MADRID, Sept. 10 - As Spain emerges from its worst summer of forest fires in a decade, the government has begun scolding the public for the careless and sometimes malicious behavior that specialists say causes the vast majority of fires here.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 11-Sept. 17; FILM
description: After making successful films in both England ("The Man in the White Suit," 1951) and America ("Sweet Smell of Success," 1957), the director ALEXANDER MACKENDRICK walked away from the movie business in 1969 and took a job as the dean of the film school at the California Institute of the Arts. His lectures have been gathered into a book, "On Film: An Introduction to the Craft of the Director," which is being published this month; to mark the occasion, the MUSEUM OF MODERN ART has been screening all nine of Mackendrick's features, with "MANDY" (1952), certainly the rarest and perhaps the most moving of them all, screening on Sunday at 2 p.m.

title: The Dukes of Hillsborough
description: HILLSBOROUGH - EVERYONE wants to get a peek inside the lives of the rich and famous.

title: New Yorkers Want Action at Ground Zero, Poll Shows
description: Stop talking and start building.

title: A Flair for the Unconventional
description: WHEN I was a teenager living in New Delhi, I read "The Fountainhead" by Ayn Rand and decided I wanted to be an architect. My parents wanted me to be a doctor, but I stood my ground and took the entrance exam to study architecture.

title: Yael Silk and Jordan Fischbach
description: Yael Zipporah Silk, a daughter of Carol Silk of West Orange, N.J., and Mark Silk of Teaneck, N.J., was married on Monday afternoon to Jordan Raphael Fischbach, the son of Janice B. Davidson of Denver and Dr. Marnin Fischbach of Pittsburgh. Rabbi E. Samuel Klibanoff officiated at Mayfair Farms, a caterer in West Orange.

title: 'Henry Adams and the Making of America'
GIRL CAN PLAY ON BOYS' TEAM
description: After an investigation, the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights ruled last week that a Ridgewood basketball league must create a coed program after the organization said that a 12-year-old girl was not eligible to play on a boys' team. The girl, Caitlin Alvaro, applied to play with the boys last October, saying she wanted to use the 10-foot regulation hoop, rather than the 8-foot hoop the girls use. The civil rights division's investigation found that Ridgewood Biddy Basketball denied Caitlin's request "simply because she is a female," said J. Frank Vespa-Papaleo, the division's director. Mr. Vespa-Papaleo said that Biddy must send a letter to all registered girls telling them that they now have the opportunity to play with boys. John Holl

title: See Dick. See Jon. See Jon Run With Dick.
description: Since taking himself out of contention for the governor's race, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey has become, according to some polls, the state's most popular elected official.

title: In Craze for Tunic Blouses, It's See and Be Seen in Sequins
description: When Parveen Hussein Javed opened a tiny clothing store in Astoria, Queens two and a half years ago, she called it Pun Jab Fashions and figured its customers would all be South Asian immigrants like her. But she was in for a surprise.

title: Net Costs
description: Greenburgh - ANDREW CARNEGIE, a Scottish immigrant with no formal education, built more than 1,600 public libraries in the United States. He believed that free libraries promoted a meritocracy, where anyone who wanted to educate himself could get ahead, and that they were places where immigrants could learn about American culture. You can still read "The Great Gatsby" for free. And you can borrow an algebra book or a Harry Potter DVD. But Carnegie would be dismayed to know that the answer to a reference question might cost you.

title: Want a Hedge Fund? Here's Your Homework
description: IF you're thinking about investing in a hedge fund, how can you steer clear of the likes of the Bayou Group, the recently imploded hedge fund company and brokerage firm run by Samuel Israel III?

title: An Out-of-the-Ordinary Tag Sale
description: EILEEN DALY reached into a closet and pulled out a pale blue Roseville primrose-pattern jardiniere and set it upon a matching two-foot tall pedestal. Ms. Daly, owner of Turn the Page Tag Sales, was tagging the pottery for a sale that she is running this weekend at the 15-acre Siena Spirituality Center at Villa Maria in Water Mill.

title: Abu Ghraib unresolved
What Will It Take to Safeguard New Orleans?
description: NEW ORLEANS has long lived with the hurricane protection that it, and the nation, were willing to pay for. Measured against the costs of Katrina's fury, however, better armor may suddenly seem more affordable.

title: Trying to Keep Energy Costs Down
description: WITH the price of oil hovering around $70 a barrel, and the refining and delivery capacity of producers in the Gulf of Mexico hamstrung by the effects of Hurricane Katrina, energy experts predict that the cost of heating homes and apartments will soar.

title: Media barons head to court in war over Australia pay TV's future
Germans See Pain but No Gain as Schrder's Star Dims
description: RSSELSHEIM, Germany, Sept. 10 - To understand why Chancellor Gerhard Schrder seems likely to be forced into retirement after elections next Sunday, one need only visit this endangered car-making town in western Germany where he appeared at a rally the other evening.

title: Questions for Prince Turki Al-Faisal
description: Prince Turki al-Faisal doesn't tell us much; he avoids answering nearly every one of Deborah Solomon's questions (Aug. 28). But here is what the man who represents Saudi Arabia to the United States evidently does believe:

title: What's So Nice About Jeff Daniels Anyway?
description: CHELSEA, Mich. - ON a break last month from shooting "RV," a big-budget comedy starring Robin Williams, Jeff Daniels sprawled on a couch on his screened porch here in his hometown and recalled how he'd won his juicy part.

title: The Lord of the Dance, Born on the 4th of July
description: HE'S baaaaack. Michael Flatley, the prancing king of Irish dance, the man who has been viewed as both a blessing and a curse to the once-obscure art form, is returning with "Celtic Tiger," a Dublin-inflected Vegas review that will undoubtedly draw sniffs from the critics and raves from fans. The title of the show, which carries a lilt of Siegfried and Roy, will likely go over the top and stay there, but that has never been a problem for Mr. Flatley.

title: BASHAW RESIGNS POST
description: The director of New Jersey's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, Curtis Bashaw, submitted his resignation last Tuesday. Mr. Bashaw, appointed to the $137,500-a-year job last year by former Gov. James E. McGreevey, said he was returning to his business as a real estate developer in Cape May, where he has restored several hotels, including Congress Hall. The authority, in addition to overseeing the redevelopment of Atlantic City, distributes revenue from casino taxes to economic development projects around the state. Mr. Bashaw's resignation is effective Sept. 30. Laura Mansnerus

title: Disasters Waiting To Happen
description: MORE than a thousand miles of levees stretch east from San Francisco Bay. They protect the cities and the farmland in the Sacramento-San Joaquin delta of California and keep salt from the bay out of the drinking water of millions of people. But those levees are deteriorating, experts say, raising the odds of a Katrina-like disaster for the nation's most populous state.

title: Scene Stealers: Five Performances to Watch
description: Dina Korzun

title: Ecosystem also takes a beating
Nola Breglio and Jason Heller
description: Nola Keene Breglio, a daughter of Nan and John Breglio of New York, was married there last evening to Jason Richard Heller, a son of Nanette and Stanley Heller of Dallas. Judge Michael B. Mukasey, the chief judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Metropolitan Club..

description: KATZ--Charlotte Breuer, 94. Devoted to Sirol (deceased), children Alfred and Deborah Katz, Miriam and Herb Cohen, grandchildren, great grandchildren. Caring, generous, thoughtful, indomitable. A force in so many lives. Graveside service Sunday. Shiva in Riverdale for three days. Contributions to Hatzalah Ambulance, PO Box 181, Riverdale, NY 10471 or Children's Aid Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODY, GLADYS
description: BRODY--Gladys. Dearly beloved aunt, great-aunt, sister and friend. You were everything to our family. We love you so much. Please rest in peace.

title: Give Me Your Fashion Hungry
description: ROLAND MOURET: Roland Mouret is from Lourdes in the South of France, and made his first pilgrimage to New York City in September 2004 to show his spring collection. "My style is a mix of the English quirkiness, French sensuality and the American laid-back elegance." Roland Mouret Prince of Wales plaid dress, $1,670. At Louis Boston.

description: Robert Patrick

title: SWEET DREAMS
description: A chocolate on the pillow has long been the standard way for high-end hotels to tuck in guests at night. But lately, that ritual offering is being edged out by lots of more attention-grabbing alternatives. Some hotel executives believe that candy has lost its cachet because it's as predictable as a packaged shower cap.

title: It's So Nice to Have Them Back Where They Belong
description: CHEMISTRY counts for a lot, in the theater as in life, but you can never know which combination of artists is going to set off an exciting reaction onstage. It could be the unexpected spark between two actors, or the combination of an adventurous director and a familiar text. This fall, the most potent blends could be well-known actresses paired with unusual material.

title: With a Late Drive, Texas Makes an Early Statement
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 10 - Ever since Southern California blew out Oklahoma in the national title game last season, the biggest question looming over college football was who would emerge as the No. 2 team behind the Trojans this season.

title: Iraqi-U.S. Units Battle to Clear a Rebel Area
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 10 - Thousands of Iraqi and American troops, backed by airstrikes, swept through the northern city of Tal Afar on Saturday, carrying out house-to-house searches and battling insurgent holdouts in the largest military operation in Iraq in months.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ANSELMI, JOSE L.
description: ANSELMI--Jose L. 11/29/49--9/11/04. You will always be remembered and cherished. Bernie

title: Seeing the Blues on the Lower East Side
description: HE has a portfolio of high-profile buildings to his credit, but Bernard Tschumi, the internationally known architect and former dean of the Columbia University architecture school, had never designed a residential structure. So when two developers approached him to create a condominium in New York City, he did not hesitate.

title: Cheryl Berman and Matthew Schechter
description: Cheryl Anne Berman and Matthew Adam Schechter were married yesterday at the Montauk Lake Club in Montauk, N.Y. The Rev. Beth Marshall, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated, with Rabbi Lawrence Siegel taking part.

title: The End User: Next step for Wi-Fi
The Un-U.N.
description: Two years ago, Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, gravely informed the U.N. General Assembly that the organization had reached "a moment no less decisive than 1945 itself, when the United Nations was founded." The world was no longer chiefly menaced by hostility among nations, as it had been then; the U.N. had to adapt to a world threatened by failed states, ethnic hatred, crippling poverty and nonstate actors like Al Qaeda. Annan convened a "high-level panel" to recommend "radical" changes in the U.N.'s structure and culture. Later this week, more than 170 heads of state, gathered in New York for the U.N.'s 60th anniversary, will respond to Annan's challenge. It appears, at the moment, that their answer will be "We're O.K. where we are, thanks."

title: Saints and N.F.L. Can Lead Way in Wake of Storm
description: The human cost of the Hurricane Katrina disaster is still being measured, but the response by those in the world of sports has been revealing, similar in scale and gravity to the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks.

title: Constitutional Lessons, Old and New, on Display
description: PHILADELPHIA - The National Constitution Center has something for everyone: life-size statues of the document's framers, slave shackles beside the Dred Scott display and a copy of the 1962 petition from Clarence Earl Gideon, the Florida drifter whose legal battle won every accused criminal the right to a lawyer.

title: With a Deluge of Claims, Adjusters Work Quickly to Ease the Burden for Homeowners
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 7 - Though the worry on her face said otherwise, Elizabeth Casey was trying to remain upbeat as she told Renee Evans, a State Farm claims representative here, about the damage Hurricane Katrina caused to her house in nearby Pass Christian.

title: Dangerous Talkers
description: Here's a new road game to play when the children start getting restless in the back seat. Get them to count the number of drivers who have one hand on the wheel and the other holding a cellphone to the ear. The game will probably be more fun if you don't spoil it by telling the youngsters what a hazard those one-handed drivers really are. Or that you, their harassed chauffeur, must maneuver with extra care because of all those driver-talkers blithely breaking New York State law.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 11, 2005
description: Weeks

title: AT THE STATE FAIR, AUG. 17, 2005
description: Joan Mason, 72-year-old retiree and great-grandmother from Oskaloosa, Iowa. "We've been camping over 40 years at the fair. We always enjoy the butter cow; my husband usually goes to see the largest boar, the largest steer. I go to a lot of good musical and talent shows. I'm diabetic so I can't have a lot of the great foods like I used to; but that's the one thing lots of people enjoy: the old corn dog. Now they got pork chop on a stick, dip and dot ice cream, pickle on a stick. All three of our children made it this year, and I think all six of our grandchildren, and then the three great-grandchildren. We haven't been to other state fairs, but I'm convinced Iowa is the best. I just don't see how it could get any better." As told to Seth Kugel WHY WE TRAVEL | DES MOINES, IOWA

title: In the Kitchen Despite the Heat
description: By all accounts, it was a successful summer at the Shore. It was very hot, very sunny and very dry. Hotels and rentals filled up, beaches were not closed because of pollution and real estate prices stayed high.

title: Target: Plum Island
description: Old Westbury - FOUR years after Sept. 11, 2001, the United States Department of Homeland Security is finally facing reality. That's right, the agency announced last month that it had decided to replace Plum Island Animal Disease Center with a new federal biological and agricultural defense center at a location yet to be determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASEK, ELIZABETH (BETTY) DODS
description: LASEK -- Elizabeth (Betty) Dods, of Long Island, NY, died on September 6, 2005. A family memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations please to Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice, North Fork, NY.

title: Travis Long and Nicholas Acquavella
description: Travis Laine Long, a daughter of Jeri and Jefferson Long Jr. of Chesapeake, Va., was married yesterday to Nicholas William Acquavella, a son of Donna and William Acquavella of New York. The Rev. Julie Norton, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.

title: When Is a Headache Not Just a Headache?
description: 1. Symptoms The man squinted into the morning mist as he leaned forward to place his ball on the first tee of the golf course. The motion triggered an explosion of pain. "There was a huge bang in my head," he later told the neurologist, the third doctor he had seen in the two months since that Friday morning. "The pain was tremendous," the patient, himself a doctor, said. "I could barely get out of bed the entire weekend."

title: Tune In, Turn On, Dig Art
description: THOSE expecting a contact high from "Ecstasy: In and About Altered States," opening on Oct. 9 at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, will probably not be disappointed. The show promises more than its share of psychedelic colors, environmental light pieces, renderings of recreational pharmaceuticals, mushrooms both painted and sculptured and simulated out-of-body experiences.

title: Hurricane Katrina And Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, NORMAN I.
description: MILLER--Norman I. November 30, 1941--September 8, 2005, in Miami. Services today at Temple Beth Sholom, Miami, FL, 11am. Information: Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 305-531-1151

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCE, HENRY III.
description: LUCE--Henry III. On September 8, 2005, age 80, on Fishers Island, NY, of cardiac arrest. He was the husband of Leila Hadley Luce, the father of Lila Frances Luce, Ph.D., and Henry Christopher Luce, stepfather of Arthur T. Hadley III, M.D., Victoria Smitter Barlow, Matthew Smitter Eliott, D.V.M., and Caroline Smitter Nicholson, Ph.D., and brother of Peter Paul Luce. Born in New York City in 1925, he was the elder son of Time Inc.'s late co-founder and editor-in-chief, Henry Robinson Luce, and the late Lila Hotz Tyng. He served in the United States Navy and graduated from the Brooks School and Yale University. With Time Inc. for thirty years, he was the publisher of Fortune and Time, vice president for corporate planning, and a member of Time Inc.'s and Time Warner's board of directors. He was a trustee of Princeton Theological Seminary, the Center of Theological Inquiry, The College of Wooster, Brooklyn Museum of Art, A Christian Ministry in the National Parks, Eisenhower Exchange Fellowships, NewYork Historical Society, United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia, Yale-China Association, and a director of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations. He served as president of the New Museum of Contemporary Art, chairman of the board of China Institute in America, president of The Pilgrims of the U.S., and an elder of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. For forty-seven years, he was a director of the Henry Luce Foundation,serving as president and then as chairman and C.E.O. until 2002. Memorial services will be held in New York City and Fishers Island on dates to be announced. $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Brooklyn Museum record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed Trustee, benefactor, and great friend Hank Luce, and extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Leila, and his daughter and son, Lila and Kit. The Luce Center for American Art at the Museum stands in his memory, and the Museum's highest honor the Augustus Graham Medal, was awarded to Hank Luce in recognition of his outstanding commitment to the Brooklyn Museum. He will be greatly missed by all. Robert S. Rubin, Chair Arnold L. Lehman, Director $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. The directors and staff of the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc. deeply mourn the passing of their longtime colleague who served as chairman and C.E.O from 1990 to 2002, having been president since 1958. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Leila Hadley Luce, his brother, Peter Paul Luce, his children, Lila Luce and H. Christopher Luce, and other family members. We salute his spirited leadership, unstinting loyalty, and distinctive contributions to American philanthropy. Margaret Boles Fitzgerald, Chair Michael Gilligan, President $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. We mourn the passing of our good friend and president. His record of service in fostering fellowship between Americans, British and all English-speaking peoples, addressing current national and international issues, consistently emphasized enduring historic, cultural, economic, and social bonds. We will miss Hank's leadership, wise counsel and dedication. To his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. The Directors, Officers, staff, & members of The Pilgrims of the United States 122 E. 58th St, NY, NY 10021 $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. China Institute in America sends its deepest condolences to the family and to the staff members of the Luce Foundation of former Chairman of the Board and Trustee, Henry Luce III. Mr. Luce dedicated many generous years of service, fine leadership, and support to China Institute. We acknowledge his passion for China and the Luce Scholars. We will miss him greatly. The Board of Trustees of China Institute in America $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. The Browning School notes with sadness the death of Henry Luce III, Class of 1942. Recipient of Browning's Alumnus Achievement Award, he leaves the legacy of the Henry Luce III Fine Arts Centes. Our thoughts are with his family. James B. Chanos President of the Board Stephen M. Clement, III Headmaster Jeffrey M. Landes '83 President, Alumni Assoc. $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. The Board of Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy mourns the loss of Henry Luce III--a longtime friend and generous benefactor of the Conservancy. We send our heartfelt condolences to Leila and the family. The Board of Trustees Central Park Conservancy A.J.C. Smith, Chairman Douglas Blonsky, President $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. The Council Advisory Board, and Director of the National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts mourn the loss of their esteemed board member and long time supporter of American art. Susan Shatter, President J. Steven Manolis, Advisory Board Chair Annette Blaugrund, Director $(6$)LUCE--Henry III. The 503 Luce Scholars thank you for your life long mentoring and for the year in Asia that changed our lives.

title: The Superintendent On the Bus Goes
description: To increase his presence at the city's schools, Bridgeport's newly appointed superintendent of schools, John J. Ramos Sr., will use a mobile office inside a school bus on some days.

description: THEATRE OF FISH

title: Book Program Founder In West Hartford Dies
description: The vibrant voice of Joelle Pauporte still rang out over her answering machine on Tuesday, a day after she died at home at 36, a victim of breast cancer.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 11-Sept. 17; DANCE
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM and his lithe and personable dancers are famous for adapting unassumingly to the situation at hand. "BATTERYPARKEVENT" is the forthright name Mr. Cunningham has given the piece he has created for the free Evening Stars series, which is held on the lawn of Battery Park just west of the Staten Island ferry terminal. "Batteryparkevent" will be performed only once, and is the Cunningham company's only New York-area appearance for the year. Friday at 7:30 p.m., rivertorivernyc.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALES, KATHARINE LADD
description: FALES--Katharine Ladd, on September 9, 2005, of Bedminster, NJ. Wife of Haliburton Fales. Mother of Nancy Fales Garrett of Delhi, NY and NY, NY, Hal Fales of Leeds, Mass, Priscilla Fales of Cambridge, Mass, Lucy Fales Evans of Denver, CO, and William E.L. Fales of Carbondale, CO. Sister of Nancy L. Crocker of New Canaan, CT, William Ladd, of Massachusetts. Grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of two. Memorial Service Wednesday, September 14, 2005 at 3PM in St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone. In lieu of flowers, donations to the St. Luke's Episcopal Church Main St., Gladstone, NJ, 07934 or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 101 E. 70th St., NY, NY.

title: A Flurry of Horrors, Real and Imagined
description: The easiest, and dullest, way to categorize Byron Haskins and George Pal's 1953 Martian-invasion classic, "The War of the Worlds," is as a fable of cold-war paranoia. But the picture is far too nuanced for that, and its visuals in particular creep into a part of our brains where theory doesn't dare to tread.

title: Briefs: U.S. executive cleared of charges and released
Japan's Rivalry With China Is Stirring a Crowded Sea
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 - In a muscular display of its rising military and economic might, China deployed a fleet of five warships on Friday near a gas field in the East China Sea, a potentially resource-rich area that is disputed by China and Japan.

title: Playing All the Angles in a Wireless Home Network
description: JOSEPH M. GRANT, a lawyer in the Houston suburb of Clear Lake, had little trouble setting up a wireless computer network in his house, which has high ceilings and an open floor plan. "It took less than a day," he said.

title: In Louisiana Shelter, Saints Game Day Offers Diversion
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 11 - There were still two hours until kickoff, but Corey Barbarin was already navigating a digital New Orleans Saints running back across the 40-yard line, thanks to a Xbox game console another evacuee had managed to salvage.

description: Pornified

title: In Complex Office Deals, He's Mr. Big
description: FOR another commercial real estate broker, it would have been the deal of a lifetime. In March, Robert J. Alexander and his team at CB Richard Ellis arranged the $505 million sale of Verizon's headquarters, on the Avenue of the Americas near 42nd Street in Midtown Manhattan, to Equity Office Properties Trust, the nation's largest office real estate investment trust. At the same time, as part of Verizon's consolidation efforts, he helped the company buy the old AT&T headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J., for $100 million. Next, Equity Office hired him and his team to act as leasing agent for the former Verizon headquarters, with 1.1 million square feet of space.

title: Lowering the Barriers for Disabled Visitors
description: ROSANGELA BERMAN-BIELER brings a certain sensitivity to her work as an expert on disability issues in the Caribbean for the World Bank. Ms. Berman-Bieler, who lives in Washington, is also a quadriplegic who relies on a wheelchair. Just getting off a plane in a place like St. Lucia, she said, presents problems because there are no Jetways.

title: Repairing Rent-Regulated Units in a Condo
description: Q. I own an apartment in a prewar condominium with approximately 70 units, and nearly half are rent-regulated apartments owned by the sponsor. I have two questions related to our superintendent. First, I have been told that while he is responsible for fixing problems in the rent-regulated apartments, he has no responsibility to do the same in the apartments of resident owners. Why are we not entitled to these additional services? Second, is our building required by law to employ only superintendents who are union members? Alan Cohen, Manhattan.

A Park Forgotten Could Be Paradise Found

Mayoral Primary Is Down to This: Who Will Vote?
description: The Democratic candidates for mayor will not say so publicly, but this cold political fact keeps them up at night: Not even their $10,000-a-month consultants know who will turn out to vote on primary day, Tuesday. Predictions and polls aside, this race has become a nail-biter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, NORMAN F.
description: LEVY--Norman F. On September 9, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Loving father of Jeanne Levy-Hinte & Francis Levy, Hallie Cohen, Ken Church & Jeffrey LevyHinte. Adoring grandfather of Zeno, Titus, Yunus. You were a beautiful father and inspiration, with an incredible optimism and love of life. You never gave up on anything. You will be greatly missed by your family, your friends and all who knew you. Service Sunday, 1:15 pm, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to charities associated with the New Orleans disaster will be appreciated. $(6$)LEVY -- Norman F. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Norman F. Levy, an outstanding philanthropist and dedicated member of the Board of Trustees. His personal commitment to Mount Sinai was extraordinary and included generous support for rebuilding the hospital, Parkinson's disease, cardiology, scleroderma and innovative programs critical to the growth of science and health care. Norman Levy leaves a legacy of outstanding contributions to Mount Sinai. His generosity, compassion and loyalty to Mount Sinai will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, Francis Levy and Jeanne Levy-Hinte and to the entire famliy. Peter W. May, Chairman Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO $(6$)LEVY--Norman F. The Board of Directors and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are profoundly saddened by the death of our long-serving, devoted, enthusiastic, goodhearted and most generous Director. Norman discovered the theater in the autumn of his life and crammed a lifetime's worth of pleasure in participating in the creation and sustaining of a theater in a relatively brief period of time. He loved our theater and the theater loved him back. All of us will miss his wise counsel, his smile, and his laughter. John B. Beinecke, Chairman Andre Bishop, Artistic Dir Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer Hattie Jutagir, Director of Development $(6$)LEVY--Norman. The Gural family mourns the passing of our much loved friend and partner, Norman Levy. For as long as we can remember Aaron and Norman were a team. He made us laugh, he showed us how to enjoy life and his dedication to his late wife and children were an inspiration to us all. His achievements and philanthropic endeavors over the long years of his life were legendary. He was truly a unique individual and words cannot describe how much he will be missed by Aaron and all of our family. Our hearts go out to Jeannie, Frank and his entire family. Aaron, Jeffrey, Jane, Barbara and Eric $(6$)LEVY--Norman. Newmark & Company mourns the passing of our good friend and valued client, Norman Levy. Norman was a legend and a true visionary in our field. His energy and devotion to his family and the many charitable organizations that he supported was an inspiration to us all. He was truly one of a kind, and all of us at Newmark will miss him greatly. We extend our condolences to Jeannie, Frank and his entire family. Jeffrey Gural and the Newmark family $(6$)LEVY--Norman F. A giant has fallen. Larger than life, he had extraordinary humor, zest and appreciation for living. This brilliant business leader and philanthropist had such humanity. He wanted it said, "He died with a smile." Nachum feivel: our closest friend and guru. Naomi and Maks $(6$)LEVY--Norman F. The passing of Norman F. Levy, my mentor, associate, and friend will be deeply felt by all those who were fortunate and privileged to have known him as I was. Norman L. Brickell $(6$)LEVY--Norman F. To our dearest friend, confidant and partner, you will be sorely missed. Elinor Wohl, Richard J. Brickell and the entire Wohl family $(6$)LEVY--Norman F. To my employer and friend, until we meet again, stay out of trouble. Love, Terry

title: The Storm Next Time

description: The stock market last week had its strongest rally since May, as investors bid up equities in the apparent hope that the damage wreaked by Hurricane Katrina would cause the Federal Reserve to stop raising short-term interest rates.

description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 10 - A Russian space freighter loaded with 2.5 tons of supplies docked with the International Space Station on Saturday.
