title: Planning the Impossible: New York's Evacuation
description: ON New Year's Eve 1999, Fred Siegel writes in "The Prince of the City," his new book about Rudolph W. Giuliani's New York, authorities feared that terrorists would seize on Y2K computer glitches to strike in Times Square. In response, the National Guard was secretly mobilized in Brooklyn "as part of an emergency plan for evacuating Manhattan." As midnight came and went, the computers hummed on, the celebration proceeded flawlessly and officials concluded, Mr. Siegel notes with a tinge of sarcasm, "Gotham was ready for a future emergency."

title: Sitting Pretty
description: The baby sitter in your Style feature (Aug. 28) hardly needs to work at all. Marc Jacobs, Cacharel, Sonia Rykiel, Anna Sui? With prices nearing $600 for a top and $400 jeans, I doubt she needs a $12- to $20-an-hour job.

Rover of New York. The bride's father, who was authorized by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to perform the ceremony, officiated on Coast Guard Beach in North Truro, Mass.

description: The United States has the harshest policies in the developed world when it comes to laws that bar ex-offenders from full participation in civic life. These laws often exclude them from occupations that have no relationship to their crimes, long after they have served their sentences.

description: FOUR years after the terror attack of Sept. 11, 2001, there is not yet a permanent monument at ground zero, nor any sign that plans for one will come to fruition soon. But such monuments are cropping up all over Long Island.

description: FAR from the concert stages of Vienna, New York and Chicago, two music competitions make their debuts this season. One is for violin, the other for piano. Both are in China.

title: For an Airport That's Closed, It's the Liveliest Spot in Town
description: KENNER, La., Sept. 9 - The ticket counters are quiet at Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport. The 40 gates are no longer open to dispatch and receive passengers. The baggage conveyor belt is still. The 174 regular daily departures are down to zero.

But creeping among these mastodons are likable little furry creatures that don't always get noticed. There is something to be prized about the quirky, the odd, the improbable, even the potentially funny, and this fall promises a whole clutch of such oddities.

title: Storm Warnings
description: Floodwaters cut off Wildwood. Absecon Island and Ocean City. Atlantic City had tides 6 feet above normal, with waves 25 feet high under winds that gusted to 84 miles per hour. Wreckage from a 100-foot barge plowed through the center of the Steel Pier In Long Branch, 1,000 feet of boardwalk were carried away "as if it were made of pick-up sticks" In Ventnor, the entire boardwalk was destroyed In Point Pleasant, the Lovelandtown Bridge collapsed into the canal The Passaic River rose, halting train service on the Hudson and Manhattan Line.

title: Correction
description: Correction: American ancestry misidentified the tribal affiliation of Lone Wolf Jackson, his mother and his grandmother. They are members of the Eastern Pequot Tribe, not the Mohegan Tribe. The article also misstated the number of casinos operated by members of the Mohegan Tribe. They operate one casino in Connecticut, not two.

title: The Runners-Up
description: For her documentary series, "Ninth Floor," Jessica Dimmock, a New York native who recently completed the International Center of Photography's program in documentary photography and photojournalism, photographed an apartment in New York's Flatiron district occupied by a group of heroin addicts. The apartment did not have electricity A the only light came from bulbs plugged into outlets in the building's hallway A so Ms. Dimmock used a digital camera to capture the low-light environment.

title: Saint Liam Prevails With Rabbits' Help
description: After Saint Liam lost the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga, the trainer Richard Dutrow Jr. decided to take no chances yesterday in the Woodward at Belmont Park.

title: The True Classic of Terrorism
description: "The Secret Agent," Joseph Conrad's 1907 novel about an anarchist plot to blow up the Royal Observatory at Greenwich -- in fact, a scheme by a secret police agent to stir up a government backlash -- has acquired a kind of cult status as the classic novel for the post-9/11 age. Conrad's villain, the Professor, who never goes out without a glass vial of high explosives in his breast pocket and a detonator in his palm, has been taken to be a prescient portrait of the terrorists who menace our own world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTERMAN, SAUL C., M.D., FACS.
description: FUTTERMAN--Saul C., M.D., FACS. Beloved husband of Ruth; devoted father of Rabbi Matthew and Chana, Donald and Shira; adored grandfather of Alon, Yael, Itamar, Nimrod, Yaniv and Maayan; loving brother of Amy Yeminy. A man of compassion and a healer of bodies, he was the retired Associate Director of Surgery at Elmhurst Hospital and Associate Clinical Professor at Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical School. He left his mark in this world by being an unassuming mentsch. He left his mark in the Jewish world by making his synagogue and the Jewish people his priority. He is already sorely missed. The funeral will take place on Sunday at 11AM at Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing.

title: Katherine Huneke and Thomas Walden IV
description: Katherine Reed Huneke and Thomas Walden IV were married yesterday at the Bay Head Chapel in Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. David J. Woehr, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: In the Shadow of the No. 7 Line
description: For six years, Jeff Chien-Hsing Liao has been riding the No. 7 train, the New York City subway line that connects Times Square in Manhattan to Main Street in Flushing, Queens. Looking out the windows at the densely packed ethnic communities along the six miles of elevated tracks, he has come to think of the train as a kind of river, like those along which ancient civilizations formed.

title: In the Moment
description: SHAUNA SHANE said she had already sketched a tranquil Connecticut River scene that she had intended to paint when a couple entered the park where she had set up easel, canvas and palette on a postcard-perfect late summer Sunday. They inspired her to alter her plans.

title: The Pushcart That God Blessed
description: Before stepping into his pushcart on Remsen Street in Brooklyn Heights, Brauch Yehuda Ganz pulls on a pair of latex gloves, in compliance with the city's food handling regulations. A separate set of rules determines the rest of his attire: navy suit, white shirt, black yarmulke.

title: New Orleans Airport to Reopen for Commercial Flights
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 11 - Officials announced today that they plan to resume commercial flights into and out of Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport on Tuesday, a critical precursor to any reconstruction effort in the flood-ravaged city.

title: Agassi Defies His Age; Federer Keeps On Rolling
description: Super Saturday did not end quite as dreamily as it began for Andre Agassi. There was no reason for him to quibble with the outcome of the first semifinal, as Agassi prevailed in -- what else? -- five sets against his countryman Robby Ginepri to reach his sixth and most unexpected United States Open final at the advanced tennis age of 35.

title: Latin Heartthrobs and the Women Who Love Them
description: One of the yearAs biggest Latin pop tours filled Madison Square Garden on Friday night. This was the New York installment of "Juntos en Concierto," or "Together in Concert." There were mainly two kinds of concertgoers: exuberant women and their not quite so exuberant dates. But there were three kinds of singers.

Recalling Sept. 11, Quietly
description: AMERICANS have memorialized Sept. 11 in ways both monumental and minuscule. The tributes range from the tattoos depicting firefighters and flags that people carry on their arms to the colossal project at ground zero in Manhattan.

title: For Seafood, a Classy White
description: Dry white Bordeaux is one of France's most underappreciated major white wines. Kermit Lynch, a Berkeley, Calif., merchant with a terrific Gallic palate, imports a classy version, the 2004 Chteau Ducasse. Herv Dubourdieu, the winemaker, used mostly smillon grapes and small amounts of sauvignon blanc and muscadelle. Serve this wine lightly chilled, as an aperitif or with risotto primavera, mussels, scallops, trout or halibut. Sea Grape, 512 Hudson Street (10th Street), charges $14. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: The Real Inventory
description: Earlier this summer, I e-mailed my brother a list of the animals we're raising on this farm. I called it an inventory, but it was really a way of acknowledging that perhaps my wife and I have gone too far. There are now five pigs in various stages of growth, and a large, comic parade of ducks and geese that settle onto the lawn like so many ships in a green sea. There are chicks in the basement and chickens in the mulch. And there are the longtime partners in this enterprise, the horses, dogs and cats. My brother -- who has three pigs and four goats himself -- wrote back and said, "Wouldn't it be great to know the real inventory?"

description: Sara Leventhal, a daughter of Donna Leventhal and Mark S. Leventhal of Newton, Mass., was married last evening to Peter Robert Owen Fleiss, a son of Karen Mandell Fleiss and Dr. David J. Fleiss of New York. Rabbi Mark Sokoll officiated at the Boston Harbor Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERAZA, MARGARET MUL HERN
description: PERAZA -- Margaret Mul hern, of Fort Myers Beach, Florida, died Thursday, September 8. She was born April 29, 1910, in County Mayo, Ireland. At the tender age of 16 she emigrated to America and lived in New York City for 65 years. In 1991 she moved to Florida. She had a marvelous love of life and enjoyed a good cup of tea with family and friends. Margaret was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Ruben, and granddaughter, Christina Marie Fey. She leaves to cherish her memory her children, John and Lynn Peraza, Thomas Peraza, Mary Ellen Fey, Margaret and Al Manganelli, and Catherine Ann Peraza; grandchildren, Thomas and Susan Fey, Amy Ruth Peraza, Kimberly Katherine Koren, and Troy and Sandy Emmi; seven great-grandchildren; and two brothers, Jim and Pat Joe Peraza in Ireland. She will be missed by all who knew "Ma, Mom, Grams or Big Margaret." Friends and family will gather in New York at Gleason's Funeral Home, 150th St. and Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY, on Sunday, September 11, between 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, September 12, at 10:45 AM, in the Church of St. Kevin's, 4521 194th St., Flushing, NY. Margaret will be interred with her husband at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to Hope Hospice at Shell Point, 15010 Shell Point Blvd., Fort Myers, FL 33908. Reception to follow at the home of John and Lynn Peraza, 160 E. 38 St, Apt 9A, NYC.

description: Congress has bounded back into post-Katrina Washington full of ideas about controlling gasoline prices and improving the energy picture generally. Some make sense and some are colossally bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIERCE, GERALD G., MD.
description: PIERCE--Gerald G., MD. A retired ophthalmologist died at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida on September 8, 2005 at the age of 74. He resided there since retiring in 1990. He was a graduate of the University of Oklahoma School of Medicine in 1956 and did his internship at St. Vincent's Hospital of the City of New York followed by two years of service in the Medical Corps of the U.S. Navy. Three years of residency in ophthalmology at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary followed a year in basic sciences in ophthalmology at New York University. He practiced general ophthalmology in New York City from 1963 until his retirement in 1990. He was on the staff of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary as an attending ophthalmologist and adjunct professor of ophthalmology at New York Medical College and associate attending ophthalmologist at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a diplomate of the American Board of Ophthalmology and a member and past president of the New York Ophthalmological Society. Before retiring he was a member of the Surgical Advisory Board of the Ophthalmic Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem. Dr. Pierce was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York, the PGA Golf Club of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, the Monmouth Boat Club of Red Bank, New Jersey, Mount Anthony Country Club in Vermont and the Order of Saint John's of Jerusalem. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Belinda, who died in 1992. He was blessed with 2 stepchildren, Lucinda Jewell (Mrs. Peter Donohoe) and Pliny Jewell IV (Elizabeth Paley) and 3 step grandchildren all of the Boston area. He is survived by a brother, Thomas (Marilyn) and a sister Charlotte (Mrs Wm. Lauric) both of the Denver area and six nieces and nephews. A Latin Choral Mass celebrating his life will be conducted at the Holy Ghost Church in Denver, Colorado at the convenience of the family. Cremains will be interred in the family plot in Arlington, Vermont. A toast to his life at your convenience would be appreciated. Life is changed, not ended.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has decided against a proposal to require the use of child safety seats aboard airline flights -- a move that would have forced parents to buy tickets for small children who otherwise could sit in parents' laps. In a statement released by the F.A.A. late last month, Marion C. Blakey, a spokeswoman for the agency, cited safety as the primary concern. "Statistics show that families are safer traveling in the sky than on the road," she said. "If requiring extra airline tickets forces some families to drive, then we're inadvertently putting too many families at risk." Starting Nov. 1, air travelers to the Dominican Republic will be asked to pay a $5 tourist fee on arrival. The fee, which the tourism board called temporary, will be part of the cost of airline tickets. The country already charges a $10 tourist-visa fee to visit the island and a $20 departure tax. Those tariffs will remain in place. AUSTIN CONSIDINE

title: Disney ties China park to better TV access
White House Letter: Political recovery effort calls on black preachers
COLLEGE HIGHLIGHTS
description: No. 2 Texas rallied in the fourth quarter to defeat No. 4 Ohio State, 25-22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEHR, RANDALL
description: BEHR--Randall. Opera Conductor. The operatic and musical community mourn the untimely passing of conductor Randall Behr. An inspired artist, he spoke the language of music with unusual eloquence and grace. Those that had the privilege of working with him marveled at his vast knowledge, keen insight, and detailed approach. He loved music and those who made it with passion. Randall will be remembered for more than his genius; he was a good man. A great friend and mentor, a life cut short, Randall Behr lives on in the many people that were changed by his special presence. We honor him for winning life.

title: Ultra Shabby Chic
description: Can it be? A design-award-winning 283-square-foot kitchen in Midtown Manhattan --built from scratch for well under $5,000? Richard Chambers has found a way: His set design for Ronan Noone's "The Blowin of Baile Gall," opening Tuesday at the Off Broadway Irish Arts Center, depicts a kitchen in exquisite detail -- albeit exquisitely dingy, dilapidated detail. Mr. Chambers rebuilt the set, which won an Elliot Norton Award in Boston, for less money than it costs most New Yorkers to reface their cabinets. Here's how. ERIC GRODE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We're getting shown a lot of love, but we're also getting a lot of stares like we're aliens or something. Am I the only person out here with dreadlocks?"

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 11-Sept. 17; THEATER
description: Last year's rookie of the year -- at least in the world of theatrical production -- had to have been THE NEW YORK MUSICAL THEATER FESTIVAL, which starts its second year this week. Last fall, the festival's inaugural incarnation was a precocious success, spawning commercial runs of, among other shows, "The Great American Trailer Park Musical" (opening Thursday at Dodger Stages) and the oddly titled "[Title of Show]," which starts performances at the Ars Nova space on West 52nd Street on Sunday. (The festival also landed a $100,000 grant from Jujamcyn, the Broadway theater owner, the kind of money that makes fledgling theater organizers so very happy.) This year's three-week party starts on Monday, with more than 30 new tuners including this week's opening trio: "THE BALLAD OF BONNIE AND CLYDE," about, well, Bonnie and Clyde; "IT CAME FROM BEYOND," a campy take on interstellar warfare; and "BUT I'M A CHEERLEADER," a musical version of the 1999 comedy about a "reprogramming" camp for gay teenagers. More wackiness, and even some serious shows, follow in weeks to come. Beginning Monday. Schedule available at www.nymf.org.

title: Elisabeth Levy and Richard Tarlowe
description: Elisabeth Amy Levy, the daughter of Diane Levy and Dr. Michael T. Levy of Manhattan, was married there last evening to Richard Craig Tarlowe, a son of Bonnie Tarlowe and Robert Tarlowe of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein officiated at the University Club.

title: Stepping It Up a Notch in South Norwalk
description: AT a social dinner with friends at Match in South Norwalk I was pleasantly surprised that the restaurant was so much better than when I reviewed it five years ago.

title: Thumbing Nervously Through the Conservative Rulebook
description: IN a simpler time, before they controlled the House, the Senate and the White House, conservatives knew what they believed about the federal government. It was too big, too bloated, too prone to throw money at problems in foolhardy efforts at social engineering. It was almost always wiser to trust the states and local governments -- or better yet, individual initiative and local charities.

title: Credit Hewitt for His Charity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Schrder's legacy
A Little Traveling Music: Songs That Can Transport You
description: AS Dick Clark is fond of saying (so fond, in fact, that he had the phrase trademarked), music is the soundtrack of our lives. It would be tough to find too many music lovers who would disagree: Music has an uncanny ability to attach itself to experiences and places, both real and imagined. And musical pilgrimages are not just limited to fans of Bob Dylan. Here are some artists and songs that might inspire a road trip or two.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH | Lauren Blitzer and Lauren Levin; Fast Friends
description: "HE thinks we're straight," Lauren Levin said to her friend Lauren Blitzer. She was whispering about the overly attentive waiter who had just taken their order at Supper, an Italian restaurant in the East Village where they were dining alfresco on a late-summer evening.

title: Worker's Abduction Brings Heartbreak and Legal Fight
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 8 - The family of Rubn Daro Angustia, a citizen of the Dominican Republic, thought they were blessed when he got a job offer from the Hanover Compressor Company to manage a power plant in a remote area of Venezuela.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLONES, JOHN P.
description: MILLONES--John P. Died September 2, 2005 in Riverdale, NY after a long illness. Beloved husband of Leslie. Admired teacher and mentor at Columbia Grammar & Preparatory School, where he taught Spanish and Latin and kept people laughing for 39 years. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his brother, Peter, his sisters-in-law, Deirdre and Edith, his brother-in-law, Bob Roth, and six nieces and nephews. For those who remember, one last time, "El senor Millones es el hombre mas justo del mundo."

title: Lara Saxman and Nicholai Birnback
description: Lara Elizabeth Saxman was married yesterday to Nicholai Samuel Birnback. Brian M. Kelly, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated at the Boathouse in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: December and 2006
description: December

title: As Recovery Starts, Some Lights Go On, Some Mail Is Delivered
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10 - After nearly two weeks of unrelenting crisis, workers here and across the battered Gulf Coast region began making small but meaningful strides on Saturday in reconnecting power and other utilities, rebuilding highways, delivering mail and restoring a sense of order.

title: Hedy Cerwinka and Gene Mele
description: Hedwig Jody Cerwinka, a coordinator for a nonprofit agency, and Eugene John Mele, a physicist, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Alfred T. Day III performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Shows to Fall For
description: Dates are subject to change.

title: Haunted by a Face on an Album Cover
description: MAKEUP, it would seem obvious, is not something upon which to build a philosophy. Nor, as any architect would tell you, is any foundation that gets washed away at the end of the day. So while you might admire the virtuoso makeup artists -- Pat McGrath, Jeanine Lobell, Bobbi Brown -- who have become celebrities in the last decade, some starting cosmetic lines of their own, you might also pity them. Their work is even more short-lived than a fashion designer's, a flash of inspiration whose half-life can be calculated in hours. What the best makeup artists do is merely suggest: a mood (sullen with a trace of sadness?), an identity (governess turned trophy wife?), a background (Marseille by way of Goa?).

title: Soccer: Trezeguet dazzles for Juventus
Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENFELD, SOLOMON (SAM)
description: SCHOENFELD -- Solomon (Sam). Sweetheart, soul mate, beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Cherished father of Arleen and Michael Hyman, and Paula and the late Frederick Damski. Treasured grandfather of Lawrence and Sheri, Robin and Ricardo, Paul and Laura, Seth and Leah. Adored great-grandfather (G.G. Sam) of Sammy and Sophie, Matthew, Julia, Maya, and Noah, Yosef and Shoshana. Services and interment were held on Friday September 9. You showed us all the true meaning of love and devotion.

title: On Baseball; As Smoltz Starts, Braves Still Look for a Finisher
description: WHEN Atlanta Braves officials met with the veteran pitcher John Smoltz last winter to discuss a change in his status -- from closer to starter -- General Manager John Schuerholz shared his fondest wish. "I told him if we had found a way to clone him, we would have had him starting and relieving," Schuerholz said.

title: Where the Noise Is Not So Joyful
description: At the U.S. Open in Queens for the past two weeks, the sounds of championship tennis have filled the air. There's the thwock of ball on racket, the squeak of shoe sliding on hard court, the slap of smash hitting net.

title: Taking Courses to Get an Edge but Without Getting a Degree
description: The love of art had been a thread running through all of Honey Rodman's personal and professional life. She began her career as a teacher, and taught sculpture, painting and illustration to junior high students in New York for 16 years. Later, while working as a vice president at Time Warner, she and her husband, Jerome Brownstein, delighted in foraging for and buying antiques.

title: Stacy Wakefield and Nicholas Forte IV
description: Stacy Erin Wakefield, a daughter of Merilyn Wakefield and John Arthur Wakefield of Ashland, Ore., was married yesterday to Nicholas John Forte IV, a son of Rosemary Forte and Mr. Forte III of Saddle River, N.J. Jason M. McGill, a minister of the Universal Life Church and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Roberts v. The Future
description: Rosen presents a range of profound issues that judges may well confront in the coming years. How they decide those issues will affect not only our daily lives but also, conceivably, our sense of what it means to be a human being. If the decisions are to enjoy broad acceptance, public confidence in the judiciary is essential. Issue-dominated Senate hearings, however, have the unintended consequence of putting the emphasis on "outcomes," not on fitness to judge.

title: Paperback Row
description: OBLIVION: Stories, by David Foster Wallace. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) These eight stories display Foster Wallace's attention to microscopic detail and taste for philosophical conundrums. The first, "Mister Squishy," conjures a marketing whiz whose mind is so packed with arcane abbreviations and case studies that his personality is crowded out. Another story, "Good Old Neon," relates a high-achieving young man's quest to root out his unhappiness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, PHYLLIS P.
description: LEWIS--Phyllis P. progressive activist, beloved wife and mother, died of leukemia September 9 at 81. Survivors include husband Bob, sons Mike and Carl, grandson Dan, niece Molly Selvin, nephew Peter Selvin and families. Memorial to be announced.

title: Another Anniversary
description: We were going to be married during the weekend of Sept. 15, 2001. It was going to be a small, family thing, with a few friends, and there was a state park where we wanted to have it. Our dog was going to be in the wedding. We're not the most traditional people.

title: These Urban Cyclists Know When to Fold 'Em
description: NEW JERSEY TRANSIT doesn't let riders wheel their bicycles onto trains during peak travel hours. But that's not a problem for Stacey Bhaerman, who on most weekday mornings catches a train to Manhattan from New Brunswick, N.J.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 11-Sept. 17; TELEVISION
description: On the fourth anniversary of the World Trade Center attacks, the words "Let's roll" are heard again. The DISCOVERY CHANNEL is going the dramatic re-creation route with "THE FLIGHT THAT FOUGHT BACK" (Sunday at 9 p.m.), the story of United Airlines Flight 93 out of Newark, on which passengers banded together to stop the terrorists who had hijacked the plane. The documentary balances the re-creation scenes (including an attack with a food cart) with interviews. Relatives of the passengers who died while preventing a greater disaster bring the special some dignity.

title: Working Women On the Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   TRAVERS, WALLY
description: TRAVERS--Wally. May 22, 1957-September 11, 2001. Your love, laughter and smile live on in our hearts. You are loved and missed everyday. Love, Your niece, Patti

title: Feminist Fantasy: Geena Davis in the Oval Office
description: Correction Appended

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 11-Sept. 17; POP/JAZZ
description: SLAVIC SOUL PARTY, a brass-and-accordion Balkan-music band with American jazz grooves led by the percussionist Matt Moran, has developed a reputation for delivering a great time. It's easy to get a piece of it: the band seems to play at least once a week, in small New York clubs like Barbes and Zebulon. This Saturday at BARBES, in Park Slope in Brooklyn, the group celebrates the release of a new album, "BIGGER," as well as a new label operated by the club, Barbes Records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORD, SAMUEL CALDWELL
description: FORD--Samuel Caldwell, 76, died September 3, 2005 at home in Sanibel, FL under loving care of family and hospice. He was born January 23, 1929 in Washington, DC to parents, Samuel Shivel Ford and Elizabeth Caldwell Walker. Sam has been a Sanibel resident for the past 17 years. Memorial services will be held 10:30 AM, Thursday, December 1, 2005 at the Sanibel Congregational United Church of Christ, 2050 Periwinkle Dr., Sanibel, FL. Memorial gifts may be made to the Smithsonian Institution, MRC035, PO Box 37012, Washington, DC 20013-7012. Please visit: www.samuel cfordandgertrudeaford.us

title: Point of Order
description: If the McCarthy era can in no way be said to constitute a bright spot in the history of the Republic, then why does watching "Point of Order," Emile de Antonio's 1963 documentary on the Army-McCarthy hearings, fill you with such -- no other word will suffice -- longing?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 28 in T: Women's Fashion magazine about astrakhan, or Persian lamb, omitted the names of two of the designer labels shown in a photograph. The scarf is by Adrienne Landau; the clutch bag is by Devi Kroell. A picture caption in that issue with an article about 1960's-inspired clothing misspelled the given name of a model. She is Mariacarla Boscono, not Maria Carla. A fashion credit in that issue with an article about shearling misspelled the name of a label. It is AF Vandevorst, not Vandervorst.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: DATEBOOK
description: PARIS Paris will hold its fourth Nuit Blanche, which literally means "white night" but refers to a sleepless night, on Oct. 1 From 7 at night until 7 the next morning, establishments across town, below, will stay open: museums, cafes, movie theaters as well as churches, libraries and swimming pools. And there will be art and lighting displays at famous landmarks like the Htel de Ville.

title: Dangerous Characters
description: The destruction of the World Trade Center transformed the preceding dozen years, since the collapse of the Berlin Wall, immediately into a historical period. It was clear at once that American statecraft, domestic politics and popular consciousness would not go on as before. As for literature, it couldn't matter much at first, in the face of so much murder and alarm. Camus observed that extreme suffering deprives us of the taste for reading, and this may be the more true of extreme fear.

title: After 58 Years, Still Defining Job Loyalty
description: TODAY, on a date that has come to symbolize the way a towering workplace can disappear in an instant, Bob Edgar stands as a beacon of longevity. This month, a month that has shown us that life is neither predictable nor linear, Mr. Edgar is still at the same insurance company, in the same line of work, for the 58th year in a row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARBMAN, JERRY
description: FARBMAN--Jerry, on September 3 at age 91. Preceded in death by his beloved wife Ruth. Devoted father of Caroline (Richard) Norman, Peg (Dick) Wachowski and Ben (Sue) Farbman. Adored grandfather of Judith, Sara, Katie, Beth and Jeffrey. Great-grandfather of Benjamin. Loving brother of Pearl Selter, Rosalind Markson and Estelle Klein. Jerry will be remembered for his generous spirit, sense of humor and his devotion to his family. His was a life well lived.

title: Classical Cleavage
description: As a slogan, "Sex sells" is as familiar as the opening tattoo of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. In fact, many marketers -- and musicians -- might combine the two into "Sex sells symphonies." Cheesecake CD covers and slinky gowns are as much a part of the hawking of classical music as of any other field.

title: Dancing in the Shadows
description: To the Editor:

title: In Recruiting, a Big Push From Small Colleges, Too
description: The players, a jumpy group of 16-and 17-year-old boys from around the country, arrived at the Headfirst baseball camp last month in Ruther Glen, Va., with statistics that stood out. It was not just their batting averages. These were players who scored, on average, 1,300 out of a possible 1,600 on the two-part College Board exam.

title: Another Payday?
description: Back in 1972, Rip Torn gave possibly his finest film performance in "Payday," starring as Maury Dann, a womanizing, substance-abusing country music hellion. Thirty-three years later, Mr. Torn, 74, has popped up in "Forty Shades of Blue," a Sundance prize winner, in which he plays Alan James, a womanizing, hard-drinking R&B producer with a Russian trophy wife. It's as if Maury Dann got older, found his inner soul man and made tons of money. But even though the Film Society of Lincoln Center seems to see a connection -- the two films are paired as part of an "Evening With Rip Torn" on Sept. 21 -- Mr. Torn, interviewed by telephone from a Toronto film location, doesn't see what the fuss is about.

title: Baseball: Yankees fall victim again to Schilling
The Best-Laid Plan: Too Bad It Flopped
description: Among the many achievements of the human race -- Chartres Cathedral, the Mona Lisa -- surely the New Orleans emergency preparedness plan must rank among the greatest, and the fact that this plan turned out to be irrelevant to reality should not detract from its stature as a masterpiece of bureaucratic thinking.

title: Fire Island As Flood Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles McLaughlin, 76, Dies; Brought Park Designer to Life for Readers
description: Charles Capen McLaughlin, who edited the tens of thousands of papers of Frederick Law Olmsted, the designer of Central Park and much more, making Olmsted's remarkable life accessible to both general readers and researchers, died on Sept. 2 at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 76.

title: Cruise Ships Shift Away From the Port of New Orleans
description: By the time Hurricane Katrina slammed into the Gulf Coast, cruise lines had already shifted ships out of ports in New Orleans and Mobile, Ala. Although the damage is still being assessed, it could be a month or more before cruise travel gets back to normal.

title: Hybrid Dreamin': How Much Is That Prius in the Window?
description: For years, many Americans have been giddily oblivious to fuel efficiency, lumbering around in vehicles more suited to desert warfare than to picking up a quart of milk. Drivers of humbler sets of wheels looked on in wonder (and a bit of fear), wondering when rising gas prices would get the attention of S.U.V. owners.

title: Even Venerable Institutions Find a Way to Inspire
description: WHEN Leonard Bernstein, just turned 40, became the first American-born music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1958, he was afire with the conviction that New York must have a major orchestra to match its young, restless and pace-setting civic character. He delivered on his promise. George Szell in Cleveland was a better orchestra builder. But during Bernstein's tenure the Philharmonic became the mission control center for classical music in America.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 14 about Siena, Italy, misstated the location of the closest international airport. It is in Florence, not Pisa. The article also referred incompletely to train service to Siena. Service from Florence may include a change at Empoli, but service from Rome requires a change at Chiusi, not Empoli.

title: Inquiry Is Sought on a Gotti's Union Entry
description: A court-appointed investigator for the carpenters union is urging prosecutors to investigate how Richard Gotti, a brother of the deceased mob boss John Gotti, became a member of the carpenters union to work on a project on the Upper West Side.

title: A Short List for the Major Fall Shows
description: NAVIGATING the art-related hype issuing from museums and art galleries as the fall season approaches can be daunting and exasperating. After the summer doldrums, this is the time museums and galleries treat us to helpings of more serious fare, delivering the year's most worthwhile exhibitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TATE, HENRY MCDONALD
description: TATE--Henry McDonald of New York City and Southold, Long Island, died Sunday, September 4, 2005, in New York City after a long illness. Mr. Tate, 57 years old, was a native of West Hartford, Connecticut and had lived in New York City since 1977. He was a 1971 graduate of North Carolina State University with a BS Degree in Computer Science and received his Master's Degree in Business Administration from Fordham University in 1983. He was a past president of The North Carolina Society of the City of New York, a member of the University Club of New York, The New England Society of the City of New York, and The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Most of his professional life was spent at Bell Laboratories at Holmdel, New Jersey, and he was most recently associated with EMC Corporation in New York. He is survived by his wife, Hope Hall Tate, and three nephews. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Capital Fund, 7 West 55 Street, New York, New York 10019. Friends may call Monday 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell--The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, 3PM at The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Chapel, 7 West 55 Street, New York, New York. $(6$)TATE--Henry. The Officers and Board of the North Carolina Society of NYC mourn the passing of their member and past president Henry Tate. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Hope.

title: Going to War in the Matrix, Middle Earth or the Bronx
description: PERHAPS more than any other medium, video games are dominated by the holiday season. With an average price around $35, games cost more than many books, CD's, museum-admission and movie tickets, so they are often purchased as a gift (though probably as often for one's own self). Though some major games are released while it is still nice outside -- Battlefield 2 hit shelves this summer -- the death of arcade gaming has largely pushed the pastime indoors. And so, most publishers now release their top games when the weather outside turns frightful. In 2004, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas came out in late October and still was the best-selling game of the year.

title: Fast Lane to Broadway Begins in Hollywood
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARAN, SUZANNE
description: MARAN--Suzanne. 6 years gone from us. You are missed and loved each day and are in our hearts forever. Larry, Andy and Caroline

title: Roberts V. The Future
description: Your article seems to suggest that the Supreme Court's most legitimate and effective decisions were merely following the winds of popular opinion. Some of the court's most vital decisions (cases enforcing the voting rights of African-Americans, protecting the rights of prisoners and criminal defendants, holding it unconstitutional to deny interracial couples the right to marry, etc.) have been those in which it stepped in to defend individual rights in political climates in which majority rule at best ignored those rights, and at worst gave majority prejudice the force of law. The suggestion that these rulings have been nothing more than the implementation of popular will is a dangerous disregard of the court's greatest constitutional moments.

title: He Naps. He Sings. And He Isn't Michael Dell.
description: ROUND ROCK, Tex. - THERE'S an established drill, or so it sometimes seems, when a publicly traded company disappoints Wall Street. The chief executive blames high oil prices. Or it's the fault of unforeseen happenings in Asia, or of a software upgrade that didn't go as planned.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Emily Elizabeth Cohen and Benjamin William Cavell misstated the title of one book and the publishing history of another, both by the bridegroom's father, Stanley Cavell. The title was "Pursuits of Happiness: The Hollywood Comedy of Remarriage," not "The Harvard Comedy of Remarriage." Stanley Cavell's other book, "The Senses of Walden," was originally published by Scribner in 1972; it was reissued by the University of Chicago Press in 1992. The report also misstated the location of Boston College Law School, where the bridegroom's mother, Cathleen Cavell, is an adjunct professor. It is in Newton Centre, Mass., not Chestnut Hill.

title: Lost at Tora Bora
description: Well past midnight one morning in early December 2001, according to American intelligence officials, Osama bin Laden sat with a group of top aides -- including members of his elite international 055 Brigade -- in the mountainous redoubt of Tora Bora in eastern Afghanistan. Outside, it was blustery and bitterly cold; many of the passes of the White Mountains, of which Tora Bora forms a part, were already blocked by snow. But inside the cave complex, where bin Laden had sought his final refuge from the American war in Afghanistan -- a war in which Washington, that October, had struck back for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks -- bin Laden munched on olives and sipped sugary mint tea. He was dressed in his signature camouflage jacket, and a Kalashnikov rested by his side. Captured Qaeda fighters, interviewed separately, told American interrogators that they recalled an address that bin Laden had made to his followers shortly before dawn. It concerned martyrdom. American bombs, including a 15,000-pound "daisy cutter," were raining from the sky and pulverizing a number of the Tora Bora caves. And yet, one American intelligence official told me recently, if any one thing distinguished Osama bin Laden on that cold December day, it was the fact that the 44-year-old Saudi multimillionaire appeared to be supremely confident.

title: Hotel Puerta Amrica in Madrid
description: THE BASICS -- The high-stakes, high-design hotel market in Madrid got at least a dozen new contenders -- all in one building -- when the $94 million Hotel Puerta Amrica opened two months ago. While the facade is the work of the French architect Jean Nouvel, each of the hotel's 12 floors -- from the elevator lobbies down to the blankets and bathrobes -- has been conceived by powerhouse architects and design studios, among them Arata Isozaki, Norman Foster, Marc Newson, Ron Arad, Richard Gluckman, Javier Mariscal, Victorio & Lucchino and Zaha Hadid. With public spaces like the Black Tears restaurant designed by Christian Liaigre and the underground garage by Teresa Sapey, the Puerta Amrica can bill itself as "12 floors with 19 stars."

title: The Cult of The Cycads
description: The only time I saw a collection of cycads was in the Santa Barbara, Calif., area, at a vast private garden called Lotusland -- the former owner, Ganna Walska, went through a succession of mostly wealthy husbands and collected flora from all over the world, including cycads from South America, the rarest worth tens of thousands of dollars. I recall seeing five or six of them in the lower garden, and immediately I could sense their ancient roots and almost see dinosaurs munching on them. They are magical, slightly ugly and alluring; I can see why some people become hypnotized by them.

title: Another Victim: Gulf Coast Gambling
description: Beyond New Orleans, one of the areas hit hardest by Hurricane Katrina was the Mississippi Gulf Coast, including Gulfport (below), Biloxi, Bay St. Louis and Ocean Springs. The region was a center for offshore casinos -- a big tourist draw and a boost for the state and regional economies.

title: Shape Sense
description: As the curtain goes up in New York for the spring 2006 women's collections, the authoritative influences of the fall collections that were shown last February reappear and remain vividly in mind.

title: 'Made in Detroit': Your Hometown
description: MADE IN DETROIT

title: Sarah Kanner and Brian Feloney
description: Sarah Elizabeth Kanner, the daughter of Linda B. Kanner and Dr. Steven R. Kanner of Lincoln, Mass., was married there yesterday evening to Brian David Feloney, a son of Lois Ellen Swanson of Osterville, Mass., and Joseph Feloney Jr. of Manchester, Conn. Rabbi Howard Berman officiated at the DeCordova Museum and Sculpture Park. The Rev. Walter Cuenin, a Roman Catholic priest, participated in the ceremony.

title: A Nice Place to Film, but Heavens, Not to Live
description: "THE essential American soul," D.H. Lawrence once wrote, "is hard, isolate, stoic and a killer. It has never yet melted." To judge by a handful of notable foreign films opening this season, it still hasn't.

title: With Time Running Out, Mayoral Candidates Run Faster
description: With the latest polls suggesting that the Democratic race for mayor now has a clear pecking order, the party's four candidates hopscotched the city yesterday to rally supporters and woo undecided New Yorkers as Tuesday's primary election draws near.

title: Famous French Inns Of the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: The Memo That Rehnquist Wrote and Had to Disown
description: AT his confirmation hearings this week, Judge John G. Roberts Jr. will be asked to respond to questions about documents he wrote as a young government lawyer.

title: 'Five Families': Made Men in America
description: FIVE FAMILIES

title: Name by name, victims of 9/11 are remembered
Happy Endings Happen
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LACK, MARGERY
description: LACK--Margery. The Officers, Board of Governors, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Margery Lack, and extend our deepest sympathy to her children JoAnn & Penny, as well as their families. Philip Shapiro, President Joy Leavitt Women's Group President

title: Jessica Scanlan and Brian Bailey
description: Jessica Lee Scanlan, a daughter of Elizabeth Scanlan and Edmund Scanlan of Oak Park, Ill., was married there yesterday to Brian Ernest Bailey, a son of Elizabeth Dee Bailey of West Hartford, Conn., and the late John M. Bailey. The Rev. John P. Boivin performed the ceremony at St. Giles Roman Catholic Church.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 14 about Siena, Italy, misstated the location of the closest international airport. It is in Florence, not Pisa. The article also referred incompletely to train service to Siena. Service from Florence may include a change at Empoli, but service from Rome requires a change at Chiusi, not Empoli.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHAN, BETTY
description: KAHAN--Betty. The YU family is saddened by the passing of Betty (Esther Braina) Kahan, who devoted her life to teaching Jewish children. She was the beloved mother of our alumnus, Rabbi Nathan Kahan, and cherished sister of Zev Binyamin Glueck and Jacob Glueck, a YU Benefactor along with his daughter, Vivian Glueck (and Henry) Rosenberg. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel,President Dr. Norman Lamm Chancellor Morry J Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees

title: 'Moondust'
description: WHEN YOU'VE SHARED a moment with the whole world, it can be hard to know precisely where your memories end and everyone else's begin.

title: Renting for a (Karaoke) Song
description: BRIAN SMITH'S first meaningful karaoke experience was during college, when his best friend's father put him onstage in their basement one day. The father was karaoke crazy, Mr. Smith said, "like I am now, and no one in his family would sing with him."

title: Drinking It In
description: LITTLE CHAPEL ON THE RIVER

title: Gas Tax or No Gas Tax: the Debate Is On
description: IN the days following Hurricane Katrina, Scott Jevarjian of Norwalk saw the price of filling the 50-gallon tank of his Hummer jump by more than $40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAUTMAN, ANDREA DOMINIQUE HOHLWEIN
description: TRAUTMAN--Andrea Dominique Hohlwein, died suddenly at age 44 on September 6, 2005. Beloved wife of Gregory. Devoted mother of Emily Helen, Natalie Siena and Juliet Gabriella. Loving daughter of Hans and Kathryn Hohlwein. Beloved sister of Reinhard Hohlwein and Laura Hohlwein. She received her doctorate in literature from the University of British Columbia. Friends may call Friday, September 16th, 6-8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Service Saturday, September 17th, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell. Interment Oak Cemetery, Sag Harbor, NY.

title: Revising 9/11
description: On the first three anniversaries of Sept. 11, 2001, the nation had the grim luxury of uncluttered memory. We looked back on that day's events as the most terrible thing that could happen on American soil. Today, we are cursed with an unwanted expansion of that vision.

title: Pumped and Plumped
description: Snub-toed pumps are everywhere this fall. Whether because of their blunted shape or their teetering high heels, these shoes have toes that are upturned, invoking a whimsical 40's-era Betty Boopishness. Miu Miu's lavishly embroidered pumps are made of chestnut suede and have a slight platform silhouette; their ski-slope toes are embellished with stone and embroidery detail ($495 at Miu Miu stores). Bettye Muller makes a charming kiltie pump in green or blue suede ($428 at www.searlenyc.com) while Dior exaggerates the snub-toe effect of its pebbled leather pumps with fluffy fur trim atop the foot ($690 at Saks Fifth Avenue). Eugenia Kim's lush scarlet pumps are decorated with cashmere, crystals and a shiny patent leather toes ($485 at Saks Fifth Avenue). And Chie Mihara mixes suede, leather and faux python for a collection of pumps that catches a little air with every step, below, $255 to $265 at Bergdorf Goodman). PULSE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPERY, JOSEPH C.

Ms. Pezzimenti was fresh-faced and toted her own video camera, and she wanted to ask the board's chairman about a controversy over a cellphone antenna.

title: Founding Father Seeks Common Sense
description: NEW ROCHELLE - IN the spring of 1806 William Carver, a blacksmith and veterinarian, left his home in New York City and traveled north to New Rochelle to visit his old friend Thomas Paine, the thinker whose political tract "Common Sense" had inspired the American Revolution 30 years before.

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: I. Seldom has an image so clearly marked the turning of the world. One of man's mightiest structures collapses into an immense white blossom of churning, roiling dust, metamorphosing in 14 seconds from hundred-story giant of the earth into towering white plume reaching to heaven. The demise of the World Trade Center gave us an image as newborn to the world of sight as the mushroom cloud must have appeared to those who first cast eyes on it. I recall vividly the seconds flowing by as I sat gaping at the screen, uncomprehending and unbelieving, while Peter Jennings's urbane, perfectly modulated voice murmured calmly on about flights being grounded, leaving unacknowledged and unexplained -- unconfirmed -- the incomprehensible scene unfolding in real time before our eyes. "Hang on there a second," the famously unflappable Jennings finally stammered -- the South Tower had by now vanished into a boiling caldron of white smoke -- "I just want to check one thing. . .because. . .we now have.. . .What do we have? We don't. . .?" Marveling later that "the most powerful image was the one I actually didn't notice while it was occurring," Jennings would say simply that "it was beyond our imagination."

title: Rebecca Fein and David Luks
description: Rebecca Nina Fein, a daughter of Judith L. Farb and Martin J. Fein, both of Houston, was married last evening to David Shael Luks, the son of Karen Luks and Allan B. Luks of Brooklyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Segal officiated at Tony's, a restaurant in Houston.

title: The Battle Is Joined, but Is the War Already Lost?
description: The trim green awning that wraps around a corner of Delancey and Allen Streets delivers an unmistakable message: Starbucks is coming to the Lower East Side.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: SEATTLE VIA SCOOTER -- Hotel Monaco is putting its guests on motor scooters for a day with the Room With a Vroom package. Rates start at $479 a night, double occupancy, for an overnight stay and use of two scooters (normally $100 each for a full day). The package can be used until Dec. 31 and must be booked five days ahead. For details, (206) 621-1770.

title: Sweet Home, Tennessee
description: Beverly Hills - WHEN "Walk the Line," the film dramatization of the life of Johnny Cash, was in pre-production in 2004, budget concerns dictated that it be shot in Louisiana -- which was offering financial incentives -- rather than Tennessee, where Cash forged his sound, recorded his earliest hits and made his home. But Reese Witherspoon, set to portray his wife June Carter Cash (opposite Joaquin Phoenix), beseeched Gov. Phil Bredesen to make Tennessee more financially attractive to the producers. When he asked why Ms. Witherspoon was campaigning so hard, her response had nothing to do with the fact that she is a $15 million-a-movie Hollywood star. Sitting in an overstuffed striped chair at the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel, Ms. Witherspoon smoothed the hem of her gauzy Alberta Ferretti dress and acted out her response, narrowing her eyes, pursing her lips and letting her high voice slip into its natural Dixie rhythms. "I told him, 'Because ah am a Nashville girl."' It worked.

title: U.S. Olympic Officials Raise Bidding Concerns
description: DENVER, Sept. 10 - United States Olympic Committee officials said Saturday that they wanted to ensure that the International Olympic Committee was not stacking the deck against American cities bidding for the 2016 Summer Olympics before they would commit to entering a city in the bid process.

title: Ramirez Makes Yanks Pay
description: Manny Ramirez wore a blue sleeveless T-shirt with his picture on the back and "Manny being Manny" etched across it at Yankee Stadium yesterday. What else would Ramirez wear? He embraces this simple phrase to define himself as if it were his favorite Scripture passage.

title: War? Turmoil? Try Fantasy Instead.
description: DO we expect too much from our movies, or do we settle for too little? I ask myself this question periodically, especially at this time of year, when the movie industry emphasis shifts, in principle anyway, from the frivolous to the serious. Behind us is another summer of large-scale commercial entertainment, sprinkled with a handful of documentaries and art films, while ahead lies another round of biopics ("Capote"), literary adaptations ("Memoirs of a Geisha") and costume epics ("The New World") intended to dominate the end-of-the-year critics' lists and midwinter awards broadcasts.

title: Wild at Heart? Even That's Debatable
description: GIVE them a little more time before declaring them out of the division race. They are, after all, seven-time winners of the American League East. How much time? How many games? Give them until the outcome of their game with the Red Sox today. Win today or forget about first place and play for the wild card. The way the Yankees have played this season, and continue to play, though, they could find that even their wild-card quest is unattainable.

title: Israeli Cabinet clears way for handover of Gaza to Palestinians
Before the Rise, Before the Fall
description: IN 1966 a young photographer named Danny Lyon moved into a loft on Beekman Street, amid a vast stretch of 19th-century buildings that would soon be razed to make way for the World Trade Center and other Lower Manhattan projects. Mr. Lyon celebrated this depopulated world in an elegiac book, "The Destruction of Lower Manhattan," published in 1969 and reissued a few months ago. "When I made these pictures, I never thought of the future, but only about the past and what was being destroyed by us," he said the other day, adding, "Within days of 9/11, my old title came back to haunt me like a slap in the face." NEW YORK IN FOCUS

In fact, our agency warned us that, as a gay male couple, we might be in for a long wait. This point was driven home when both birth mothers who spoke at the two-day open adoption seminar we were required to attend said that finding good, Christian homes for their babies was their first concern.

And she learned the lesson that helping others is its own reward.

title: The Life and Times of Theater's Life and Times of Jesus
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Long before "The Passion of the Christ" was a twinkle in a certain movie star's blue eye, there was the Passion play. Actually, many Passion plays. Elaborate pageants staged in towns across medieval Europe to inculcate religious feeling in the public by dramatizing scenes from the life of Christ, they formed a significant strand in the DNA of theater history. The most celebrated of these liturgical dramas continues to be presented, once a decade, in the German village of Oberammergau.

title: The Prices! Rising Fast and Still Finding Buyers
description: There are probably more scientific ways to measure the bulge at the upper end of the economy, but the season's hot Prada coat is one way to tell how much disposable income is floating around. The coat is black wool and has jet beading at the lapel and collar. It is fitted, severe, and as chic as widow's weeds. The person who puts one on immediately assumes the sleek and impertinent air of an urban crow. That the price of the coat is around $5,500 has apparently done little to deter sales. Since the first fall shipments, even the Prada stores have had trouble keeping the coats in stock.

description: An obituary Wednesday about Bob Denver, the star of the 1960's television hit "Gilligan's Island," misstated the broadcast history of "Gunsmoke," which was ensured a full-hour slot on Monday nights when CBS canceled "Gilligan's Island" in 1967. "Gunsmoke" had been a full-hour show since 1961; it was not lengthened to a full hour when "Gilligan's Island" was canceled. The obituary also misidentified Mr. Denver's residence. He lived in Princeton, W.Va., not Princeton, Va.

title: McCartney Gets Back, But Not for Nostalgia
description: There's a struggle on Paul McCartney's new album, "Chaos and Creation in the Backyard," and it's one that pays off. On one side is Sir Paul's gift for easy, bubbly melody -- tunes that are so shapely that in the past he has often settled for finishing them as harmless little ditties. On the other side is his urge to experiment with sounds and structures and to recognize some darker thoughts -- a smaller, but still significant part of his song catalog. For this album, on Capitol, Sir Paul chose a producer who favored the experimental side: Nigel Godrich, who has worked with Radiohead and Beck. Sir Paul also lined up his best backup band since the Beatles: himself.

title: A Savage Satirical Sendup of Earnest Aesthetic Artists
description: There is a saying that satire cannot succeed without a true affection for one's victims. "Patience," which opened at the New York City Opera on Saturday, contests that theory. Elsewhere in the Gilbert and Sullivan repertory, law courts, admiralties or Japanese bureaucracies may be mocked, but they are also smiled on and indulged. The Aesthetic and Pre-Raphaelite movements of late 19th-century Britain hit closer to home, and as a writer, W.S. Gilbert shows a contempt for his colleagues that is palpable. Could this explain the unusually savage undertone to the caricatures "Patience" introduces us to?

Paid Notice: Deaths   HAHN, PHILIP J.
description: HAHN--Philip J. The employees of M. Fabrikant & Sons, Inc., mourn the loss of our Co-Chairman of the Board, Mr. Philip J. Hahn. Following his distinguished career in the Army during World War II, Mr. Hahn devoted himself to the growth and development of the firm to its status as the worldwide industry leader. He was a titan of the diamond industry who pioneered the early days of the markets in Tel Aviv, Mumbai, and Antwerp where he established manufacturing and trading offices for the firm. He was a positive presence in our New York office until his demise at the age of 89. We mourn his loss, and will miss his wit and wisdom. We extend our condolences to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKAY, DEAN
description: McKAY--Dean. IBM's first and longtime Vice President of Communications, died September 6, 2005, in Greenwich, CT, of lung cancer, said his son Brian McKay. He was 83. Shortly after Thomas J. Watson Jr. became President and CEO of IBM in 1956, he reorganized the company in anticipation of its probable explosive growth following the introduction of computers. Mr. McKay was put in charge of Communications, responsible for press relations, advertising, internal communications and special events. Mr. McKay was also responsible for IBM's pioneering corporate design program. The company had to make the difficult transformation from an electromechanical company, long well known for its punch card accounting machines, to a leader in the new electronic computer era. A World War II U.S. Navy veteran, Mr. McKay served in the Pacific as a Japanese language translator and interpreter with an intelligence unit of General MacArthur's headquarters. Dean Raymond McKay was born November 13, 1921, in Seattle. He attended public schools in Seattle and was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Washington. He also attended the advanced management program at Harvard Business School. He was a senior vice-president of IBM and a retired member of the Board of Directors of IBM, Conoco, Dupont, MCI, Marsh McLennan, and Nabisco. He is survived by two sons, Brian McKay of Reno, NV, a former Attorney General of the State of Nevada and his wife, Karen; Bruce McKay, a television producer of Garden City, NY, and his wife, Traceyann; and four grandchildren. Services are private. Memorial donations may be sent to Greenwich Hospital, Bendheim Cancer Center, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oracle's Ellison Is Said to Reach Tentative Deal in Trading Case Lawrence J. Ellison, chief executive of Oracle, has reached a tentative agreement under which he would pay $100 million to charity to resolve a lawsuit charging that he engaged in insider trading in 2001, according to lawyers involved in the case. The unusual settlement, which requires the approval of Oracle's board, would be one of the largest payments made to resolve a shareholder suit of this kind, known as a derivative lawsuit. [C1.]

title: Taste and Technology Succeed on the Runway
description: Everybody always wants to know the same thing: What does it take to be a success in American fashion? What combination of luck, brains, money and filthy groveling does it take to create a style that other people will think is worthwhile -- will buy and invest in? It's like the formula for Coke or something. Everybody wants to know. And here, maybe, is the answer: It takes 15 years, a nicotine habit and one genial Hawaiian.

And you know," she adds, "two heads are better than one."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUGH, BRIAN J.
description: HAUGH--Brian J. On September 9, 2005. Loving son of the late John and Mary Haugh. Beloved brother of John, Gerard and Maureen. Loving brother-in-law of Monica and Josephine. Dear uncle of Kerry, Matthew, Clare and John. Cherished companion of Jacqueline Day. Former writer for Star magazine and the Staten Island Register. Member of the Knights of Columbus. Brian loved his family and friends, and had great passion for baseball, the theater and music. Brian's family will receive friends at M. J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, on Tuesday and Wednesday, from 2-5 and 7-9 pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebratred on Thursday, at 11 am, at St. Ann's Church, Staten Island. Interment to follow at Resurrection Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUDETTE, MARY HAGGART
description: AUDETTE--Mary Haggart, 94, on September 6, at Branford, CT. Widow of Charles LaPointe Audette. Survived by three children, Louis and Lianne of New Haven and John of Santa Monica, CA., and two grandchildren.

title: Shielding a Basic Freedom
description: For 69 long days, Judith Miller, a reporter for The New York Times, has been sitting in a Virginia jail as punishment for doing her job. It should be clear by now that keeping Ms. Miller behind bars for refusing to testify in an investigation into how the name of a C.I.A. operative was leaked to another journalist concerns more than one reporter or one news organization or even one prosecutor's investigation. It increasingly endangers one of the pillars of the nation's freedoms: an unfettered press telling the public what is really going on. It is time for those in Congress who talk about freedom so eloquently and so often to stand up for this basic principle.

title: Internet Entrepreneurs Draw a Crowd in China
description: HANGZHOU, China, Sept. 10 - Even before China's annual "Internet summit" got under way here, Charles Zhang, the stylish founder of the Web portal Sohu.com, was holding court in the lobby of the Hyatt Hotel, standing before a crush of reporters and television cameras.

title: What's Congress Going to Sacrifice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun Microsystems Returns to Its Roots to Determine a New Direction
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Sept. 11 - Scott G. McNealy, the chief executive of Sun Microsystems, likes to describe his "iPod moments" -- businesses that could potentially snowball like something thought up by his counterpart at Apple Computer, Steven P. Jobs.

title: Why Boarding School Was Right for Me
description: To the Editor:

description: Devendra Banhart "Cripple Crow" (XL)

title: Tips for Backing Up Outlook Express
description: In my latest e-mail column, I described how you can move your Microsoft Outlook e-mail collection into a more easily backed up folder, like My Documents. Many of you wrote to ask: What about Outlook Express?

U.S. Open: Federer shows special powers to beat Agassi
Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, LOTTE (NEE BAUMANN)
description: MEYER--Lotte (nee Baumann). Of Forest Hills, mourned by family and friends. Services Monday, 12:45 pm, Parkside Chapel, 9860 Queens Boulevard.

title: People
description: Steve Centrillo was named president and chief executive of the flagship New York office of Foote Cone & Belding, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, assuming duties from Lynne Seid, who had been the office's president until she left in June. Mr. Centrillo had been executive vice president and chief growth officer at Interpublic and before that was an executive vice president at Grey Worldwide, New York, part of the Grey Global Group division of the WPP Group, where he worked with Steven Blamer, now the chief executive of Foote Cone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WETHERBEE, DANA A.
description: WETHERBEE--Dana A. 82, of Huntington, former pilot for American Airlines, died peacefully. Born in NYC, WWII veteran, Distinguished Flying Cross, 13 Air Medals. Champlain College. Joined American Airlines 1948, retired 1983, as Director of Flight Eastern Region. Survived by Althea, wife of 55 years, children, James (only astronaut to command five space flights), Lawrence, Jule, Daniel, brother Donald and seven grandchildren.

title: A Duel With Damon, a Dream Revived
description: Mariano Rivera made one of the coolest entrances in baseball in the eighth inning with his 338 1/2-foot trot in from the left-center-field bullpen. By the time the blue door opened, the first few notes of Metallica's "Enter Sandman" were already bouncing from the bleachers to the box seats at Yankee Stadium.

title: The School Year, After Katrina
description: No one yet knows how many children from the gulf disaster zone will have to go to school elsewhere. By one estimate, a quarter of a million children have been displaced from Louisiana, about half from schools that could be closed for as long as a year. The scope of the problem is already clear in Texas, which is bracing for the possibility that it might have to absorb as many as 60,000 new students.

title: In Florida, the Story Is You
description: Journalism is supposed to be all about the five "w's": who, what, when, where and why. Now, a leading Florida newspaper is changing "why" to "y," as in "you."

title: Jets' Defensive Collapse Felt as Bad as It Looked
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 11 - Not until he stood at his locker, fiddling with the cellphone on his belt, did Jets cornerback David Barrett remember the bloody gash on his left middle finger. He stared at it as if it were an illegible note, reminding him to do something he might not otherwise remember.

title: Roundup: Messier retires
Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 1 about a retired firefighter, Thomas A. DaParma, who was charged with offering bribes to two employees of a medical laboratory to dispose of urine samples from his son, Christopher, a firefighter who had tested positive for cocaine use, misstated the son's prior criminal record. He had pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors and a violation. He did not have three felony convictions.

title: Iran Warns the West Not to Use the U.N. to Penalize It
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 11 - Iran's foreign minister warned Sunday of serious consequences if its repeated refusal to suspend sensitive nuclear activities prompted Western nations to submit the case to the United Nations Security Council to consider possible penalties.

title: All the President's Friends
description: The lethally inept response to Hurricane Katrina revealed to everyone that the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which earned universal praise during the Clinton years, is a shell of its former self. The hapless Michael Brown -- who is no longer overseeing relief efforts but still heads the agency -- has become a symbol of cronyism.

title: New Approach From Gap to Cut Down on Clicks
description: Correction Appended

title: Photo guidelines issued for biometric passports
High-School Nostalgia
description: To contradict a popular axiom, nostalgia is exactly what it used to be, only more so. VH-1 specials are already memorializing the 1990's, and the next trend on Broadway seems to be musicals based on film comedies of relatively recent vintage: "Honeymoon in Vegas," "The Wedding Singer," "Legally Blonde."

title: Search Engines Set Out to Find Missing Persons
description: Scores of bulletin boards aimed at finding missing persons have popped up on the Internet since Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast, and two companies have built specialized search engines to help scour them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, NORMAN F.
description: LEVY--Norman F. Norman (dad), thank you for the treasure of a loving family (Frank and Jeanne) and the example of a joyous life and a dignified death. Love, Hallie
