It is the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, not the American Committee.

title: A High School Confidential From the Inside
description: Early in Victor Buhler's documentary "Rikers High," a high school teacher is discussing Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley's novel "Frankenstein." People are afraid of the monster because he looks different, the teacher, identified as Mr. Rodriguez, says. He asks the young men in his class, "Is it rightfully so to be judged by the way you look?" (Economy of phrase is obviously not a priority in this classroom.) When people treat him badly, the monster reacts with anger and "anything in his path gets destroyed."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOCH, SUSAN D.
description: KOCH--Susan D. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledge with great sadness the death of Susan Koch. An extremely dedicated agency trustee, Sue was a member of the Executive Committee and Budget and Finance Committee, Chair of the Family Violence Divisional Board and a long-time Court Volunteer. She was devoted to the work of the agency, respectful and admiring of her fellow trustees and of staff, and deeply committed to the children and families we serve. Her kindness, compassion and generosity leave a wonderful legacy that will continue to inspire us. Sue loved the Jewish Board and the agency loved her in return. Our sincere condolences to her beloved family and cherished friends. Jean L. Troubh, President Joseph S. Kaplan, Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, PhD Exec. Vice President & CEO Paul Levine, Assoc. Exec. Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'KELLY, EUGENE D.
description: O'KELLY--Eugene D. The Board and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Eugene D. O'Kelly, who died on September 10. Gene joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 2003 as a Trustee Fellow and for two seasons served as Co-Chair of the Hall's Corporate Leadership Committee. Gene's warmth, quiet leadership, and considerable business acumen earned him the respect and loyalty of all who worked with him at Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Corinne; to his daughters, Marianne Pearson and Eugenia O'Kelly; and to his entire extended family, including his colleagues at KPMG. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

Some are silly, like the extremely green Kermit the Frog cravat. Some are three decades old. Many feature polka dots, their owner's favorite pattern. One honors the Knicks. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Five Charged In Overseas Gambling Case
description: An investigation of a 2003 firebombing in New Hyde Park has led to the arrest of five men on charges of promoting gambling and enterprise corruption, the Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon, announced yesterday. In a statement, he said that detectives investigating the Aug. 11, 2003, firebombing of Roseanne's Cards Galore discovered evidence of an off-shore gambling operation based in Costa Rica and operated by people in Nassau County, and handling abut $4 million in bets yearly. The firebombing is still under investigation, Mr. Dillon said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Phone Company's Profit Jumps 30%
description: The China Netcom Group , the nation's second-largest fixed-line telephone operator, reported that net income for the first half rose 30 percent after the company cut marketing costs and added more Internet users. Net income rose to 6.36 billion yuan ($787 million), or 0.96 yuan a share, the company said in a Hong Kong stock exchange statement. China Netcom's chief executive, Edward S. Tian, left, is looking to high-speed Internet services to raise profits as China's mobile phone users outnumber fixed-line customers. The company also said it would buy four networks from its parent for 12.8 billion yuan ($1.6 billion) to bolster stalling revenue growth. The company, which is based in Beijing, said it would pay its parent, the China Network Communications Group, 3 billion yuan in cash and settle the balance over five years. China Netcom will also assume debt of about 23.2 billion yuan, it said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 27 about credit scores referred incorrectly to two services available from credit agencies. The Empirica score from TransUnion and the Beacon score from Equifax use a formula developed by the Fair Isaac Corporation and are available only to businesses like mortgage companies. They are not an approximation of the credit scores that TransUnion and Equifax do offer to consumers. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the prices of scores sold. Fair Isaac has sold more than 10 million scores to consumers at various prices -- not just $45, which is the cost for a set of three from the largest credit scoring agencies.

title: Trial of an Assemblyman Focuses on a Ripped Check
description: The prosecution in the political corruption trial of Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. yesterday showed the jury a check for campaign expenses with the signature torn off, to bolster its contention that Mr. Norman had knowingly solicited an illegal amount of money from a lobbying group.

title: Pick as Acting FEMA Leader Has Disaster Relief Experience
description: Correction Appended

title: MEMO PAD
description: MILES MATTER -- Here's an innovative way for highflying business travelers to help make life easier for victims of Hurricane Katrina. At the start of 2005, there were almost 10 trillion frequent-flier miles outstanding in the accounts of 163 million members of frequent-flier programs worldwide, with 112 million of them in the United States, according to Randy Petersen, the frequent-flier-mile guru at WebFlyer.com. Mr. Petersen has created a detailed list of links to airlines, hotels, credit card companies and others that are sponsoring programs that enable members to contribute miles toward hurricane relief efforts. The links, and other information about donating miles, can be found at www.miledonor.com.

title: Tax Bases Shattered, Gulf Region Faces Debt Crisis
description: By destroying houses, businesses and peoples' lives, Hurricane Katrina also destroyed the tax base of the gulf region. Without homes, New Orleans cannot collect property taxes. Without tourists, it cannot collect hotel taxes. And without restaurants and stores, it cannot collect sales taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORNOR, TOWNSEND
description: HORNOR--Townsend, age 78, died on September 11, 2005 at his home in Osterville, Massachusetts. He was the husband of Catherine Childs Hornor, and the former husband of the late Elizabeth Saunders Hornor and the late Barbara Graham Hornor. He was the father of Sally Graham Hornor, Grace Hornor Evans and Townsend Hornor, Jr., and the grandfather of nine. In addition to his wife, children and grandchildren, he is survived by his brother Dewitt, of New York City. A memorial celebration will be held at his house, 239 Eel River Road, Osterville, at 11 A.M. on Friday, September 16. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to The National Marine Life Center, 120 Main Street POB 269, Buzzards Bay, MA 02532.

title: Schrder and Fischer present united front
Mayoral Hopefuls Traverse New York in Primary Race
description: The four Democratic mayoral candidates aggressively courted voters yesterday on the eve of today's primary, with Fernando Ferrer making an appeal to black and Hispanic New Yorkers in hopes of winning the primary and avoiding a runoff, while the three others tried to energize their core supporters to vote in a race where turnout is the big unknown.

title: For Holdouts, Food Rations May Disappear
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 - "They want to starve us out, is what it is," said David Jaurequi.

title: Unexplained Phenomena Lurk Behind New Shows
description: "Supernatural," on WB, is genuinely scary. But there are half a dozen other new dramas designed to make viewers run from the room screaming, including two about aliens from outer space, and at least one sea monster. There is even a remodeled "Night Stalker."

title: Mindful of 9/11, Many Rush to Aid Storm Victims
description: A woman from Queens has organized a clothing drive that stretches into northern New Jersey. A boy from Port Chester, N.Y., has joined students nationwide in collecting backpacks stuffed with pencils and notebooks, and has received 156. A man from New Jersey has driven to New Orleans in a 24-foot-long truck filled with clothing, sanitary napkins and diapers.

title: Tournament With Innovations
description: Everything is up to date in Peru, at least when it comes to soccer for the 16-team under-17 world championships, which begin Friday.

title: Joseph Smitherman, Mayor in Selma Strife, Dies at 75
description: Joseph T. Smitherman, who in more than 35 years as mayor of Selma, Ala., went from ardent support of segregation at the time of the notorious 1965 beatings there to pride in his backing among blacks, died on Sunday in Montgomery, Ala. He was 75.

title: Theatre of Fish: Travels Through Newfoundland and Labrador
World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Consortium Bids $4 Billion for Refiner
description: A consortium led by the Turkish conglomerate Ko Holding and including Royal Dutch Shell made the highest bid of $4.14 billion in an auction for a 51 percent stake in the Turkish oil refiner Tupras. The bid was well above market expectations and amounted to 81 percent more than the market value based on Friday's closing price of 24 new lira. Tupras is the only domestic refiner, with annual capacity of 27.6 million metric tons. It was the second-largest Turkish privatization after the $6.55 billion sale of a 55 percent stake in Trk Telekom this summer and gave a fresh boost to the country's program of selling off some state holdings. Ko Holding has an 80 percent stake in the venture, Shell a 10 percent stake, and two Turkish companies, Aygaz and Opet Petrolculuk, have 7 percent and 3 percent.

title: U.S. plans a 20% cut in Afghan troop level
Actors in Process (and Let Audience Take the Hindmost)
description: "Have fun and make bold choices," the M.C., Betsy Head, repeatedly urges the actors in "The Audition," a curious specimen of what could be called reality theater in which a troupe of game, mostly green performers compete for the approval of the audience and an onstage panel of judges.

title: No Shortage of Blame on the Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 12 - The sun came up Monday morning, just as quarterback Chad Pennington said it would. Receiver Laveranues Coles was awake to greet it, having spent a wakeful night replaying in his mind the three balls he dropped that might have gone for touchdowns in the Jets' 27-7 loss to the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: As Roberts Hearings Begin, Manners Befit the Moment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 - Like weddings, Senate hearings are often choreographed affairs. Monday's opening of the Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge John G. Roberts Jr., set against a backdrop of soaring marble columns and grand crystal chandeliers in a room that has played host to such sessions since the sinking of the Titanic, was no exception.

title: Shakespeare it's not: 'Good Men' of Guantnamo
The Workers, Not the Voters, Do the Waiting
description: In many areas, turnout for Tuesday's Democratic primary in New York City was light.

description: Photographs from today's home page of NYTimes.com.

description: A look at how fresh local ingredients are ruling at some of the best restaurants in Sydney, Australia.

title: Pitch Fever
description: In the lead up to next year's world cup, designers arent the only ones crowding the arena.

title: School of Ghoul
description: Today's art stars find their muse in the devil inside.

title: The Get
Mix Master
description: Michael Macko of Saks Fifth Avenue is hooked on twisted classics.

The New Collectibles
description: Investing for the long haul: Sandra Ballentine on the picks of the season.

title: The Originals
description: Comfortable in their skin, these folks are even more comfortable in their clothes.

title: Outlaw Fashion
description: Plastered in logos, can you still be an outlaw?

title: Mad Togs and Englishmen
description: A new take on flannel, plaid and tweed for this side of the pond.

title: Epic Proportions
description: Sweeping or slender, this season's cut is going to extremes.

title: Olivier's Twist
description: If you want your finger on the pulse, roll up your sleeves. That's because Olivier Rizzo likes it that way. And who is Olivier Rizzo? Just the most influential stylist in fashion. When Rizzo talks, Milan listens.

title: Romanov Holiday
description: A level of luxury not known since the czars. Lenin rest in peace.

title: Eastern Exposure
description: The new bohemia (and its signature clothes) stretches all the way to Krakow.

title: Willie Birch at Luise Ross
Chew on This!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Jefferson Hack | Editor
description: Being the publisher of Dazed & Confused and the editor in chief of Another Magazine means that Jefferson Hack doesnt need to shop. I pick things up from shoots or from going to designers studios, he says. Im not a shopper. That doesnt mean he doesnt like clothes. He does  especially mixing, matching and altering them. Hes particularly fond of his Dior Homme shirt with a cigarette burn in the collar. Hack breaks his no-shopping rule when hanging with Lila Grace, his 3-year-old daughter with Kate Moss. Dad and daughter recently purchased a pair of silver shoes together. For me its an experience, he says. For her its a game.

title: Welcome
description: Welcome to the founding meeting of our book club.

title: Hurricane and Floods Overwhelmed Hospitals
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 - Confusion and desperation permeated the New Orleans hospital system as floodwaters rose, emergency generators failed and dozens of patients died in the three chaotic days after the levees broke, doctors and other witnesses said on Tuesday.

title: Upstairs, Downtown, Idiosyncratically
description: THE tiny restaurant on the top floor of the new Bouley Bakery and Market doesn't operate by the rules and rhythms of most establishments of its kind. It operates by the rules and rhythms of David Bouley.

title: Marc Jacobs Is High School With Money
description: The confetti that 30 minutes earlier had exploded from the ceiling in a silvery rain now lay in clumps on the bleachers. Caroline Kennedy had left with her two daughters. Uma Thurman had come and gone. Robert Duffy, the business partner of Marc Jacobs, stood on the littered runway. He remarked that there were things in Mr. Jacobs's show on Monday night that he had first seen him attempt at the start of his career. "But 15 or 18 years ago we had no money for beautiful fabrics, for embroidery," Mr. Duffy said. "We had, like, five pairs of shoes for a whole show."

title: Morgenthau Wins Race by Big Margin
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, for 30 years the Manhattan district attorney, yesterday beat back his first serious challenger in two decades. His victory assures his re-election, because he has no Republican opponent in the general election.

title: Contract Laborers With Chips on Their Shoulders
description: That most innocuous of diurnal events, the coffee break, proves to be a potential minefield in "The Blowin of Baile Gall," a densely plotted drama by Ronan Noone that opened last night at the Irish Arts Center in a crisp production directed by David Sullivan.

title: First, Kill All the Lawyers? Nah, Give 'Em Therapy
description: The fallen woman used to be a classic American redemption tale. Now it's the fallen lawyer.

title: Reviving a City: The Design Perspective
description: Even as the federal government and local developers push to resurrect New Orleans as quickly as possible in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, some architects and urban planners are contemplating the larger question of what form the city should take - whether restored, reimagined or something in between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHAN, HENRIETTE
description: NATHAN -- Henriette. ELF mourns the death and honors the memory of our beloved colleague, who was an active committee and chapter member of ASID until a few weeks before her death at the age of 91. Contributions may be made to ELF, 1040 First Ave., Box 324, New York, NY 10022. Education Legacy Fund NY Metropolitan Chapter American Society of Interior Designers

title: Entr'acte: Best this, worst that - Britain loves its surveys
EU goal of united front on oil prices falters
U.N. vs. Poverty: Seeking a Focus, Quarreling Over the Vision
description: The United Nations General Assembly meeting today was to have been a rare moment when the quest to relieve the crushing poverty of a billion people took center stage. But so far that goal has been overshadowed by Katrina, the oil-for-food scandal and squabbling over reform of the United Nations itself.

title: Roundup: Bettini wins stage
Egypt closes its border with Gaza
More than 100 killed around Baghdad
Editor of Opinion Pages Resigns at The Los Angeles Times
description: Michael Kinsley, the editorial and opinion editor of The Los Angeles Times, left the newspaper yesterday on what he described as a bitter note after a controversial year in which he experimented with a section normally known for its stodginess.

title: Robot vehicles line up for race in the desert
Baseball: Broussard's bat powers Indians past the A's
Cyber Games' U.S. champs represent electronic elite
Robotic Vehicles Race, but Innovation Wins
description: FLORENCE, Ariz. - Cresting a hill on a gravel road at a brisk 20 miles an hour, a driverless, computer-controlled Volkswagen Touareg plunges smartly into a swale. When its laser guidance system spots an overhanging limb, it lurches violently left and right before abruptly swerving off the road.

title: Firefighting Mistakes Cited in a Report on Three Deaths
description: A Fire Department analysis of a fire in a Bronx building last January in which six firefighters were forced to jump from the fourth floor -- killing two of them -- has found that mistakes, communication failure and unfamiliarity with new equipment may have contributed to the tragedy, say fire officials briefed on its contents.

title: Demand for Gas Fell Nationwide for 2nd Week
description: Demand for gasoline fell nationwide for a second straight week, the government reported today, indicating that record retail prices may have forced some consumers to drive less or conserve fuel in other ways over the week of the Labor Day holiday.

title: Blacks Hit Hardest by Costlier Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Regardless of income levels, blacks were about three times as likely as whites to borrow through more expensive "subprime" mortgages last year, according to a nationwide lending survey released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve.

title: Thais despair over growing insurgency
W.N.B.A. Executive Has Hard Sell on Hands
description: Point guard Donna Orender made every loose ball a scramble for respectability, every shot a chance for recognition, every teammate an accessory to a crusade. She was not afraid to trash-talk, just afraid her paycheck would never come.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,890 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

Europeans balking at new Afghan role
ECB chief cites risk of inflation from oil
In the Delivery Room, How Many Is a Crowd?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Shifting Ad Environment, Rival Publishers Cooperate
description: NEW YORKERS once had a snappy comeback to anyone suggesting that competitors ought to cooperate. "Does Macy's tell Gimbels?" they gibed.

title: Nokia sets its sights on mobile e-mail
Engineers Say a Key Levee Won't Be Set for Months
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Hurricane Katrina washed away a 17-foot-tall earthen levee that had protected St. Bernard Parish, east of New Orleans, from the waters of a shipping canal, and the Army Corps of Engineers said Tuesday that the ravaged parish would be left defenseless against even small storms at least until early next year because replacing the structure would take months.

title: Fliers Start to Take Defensive Action
description: Carrie Charney is flying from New York City to Portland, Ore., next month for her granddaughter's bat mitzvah and then to Baltimore to visit her daughter. But Ms. Charney, a retired insurance claims processor who lives in Bardonia, N.Y., does not seem concerned about bankruptcy filings by Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines that could come today.

title: Today's Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - On Wednesday at 9 a.m., the Judiciary Committee plans to reconvene to finish the first round of questioning of Judge John G. Roberts Jr., with Republican Senators Sam Brownback of Kansas and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma getting 30 minutes each.

title: Bush Tries to Rally a Skeptical U.N. on Terror
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 14 - President Bush faced a skeptical array of world leaders today as he called on the United Nations to step up its battle against terrorism and nuclear proliferation, and recommitted the United States to aiding the world's poorest people.

title: Law Firm Set to Absorb Part of Another
description: Lawyers in the New York office of Coudert Brothers, which announced last month that it would begin to wind down its business, will join Baker & McKenzie.

title: Jets Sign Safety
description: Safety Jeremy LeSueur was signed to the Jets' practice squad yesterday. LeSueur, 24, was originally drafted by the Broncos with the 85th pick in the 2004 draft. A former Michigan player, he spent his rookie season on injured reserve rehabilitating a hernia injury and was released by the Broncos earlier this month. Karen Crouse

title: In This Small Town in Iowa the Future Speaks Spanish
description: Denison, Iowa Searching for the Soul of America Through the Secrets of a Midwest Town By Dale Maharidge Photographs by Michael Williamson. 259 pages. Free Press. $25.

title: O Watercress, Speak to Me: One Man's Paean to Produce
description: AT 3:20 p.m. on a recent Wednesday, Colin Alevras stood in the Tasting Room's tiny subterranean kitchen in the East Village, scribbling notes. "Is that really the time?" he asked, blinking at the clock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZELENKO, NORMAN
description: ZELENKO -- Norman. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP greatly mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Norman Zelenko. Norman was a partner and Of Counsel of Paul, Weiss for over 50 years. We extend our sincere condolences to stepson Rainer Gebber, grandchildren Andreas, Johanna, Nicholas and Sandra, and to all other members of the family.

title: Criminal Charges Against Racing Association Are Dismissed
description: The New York Racing Association's long-running legal battles ended yesterday as a criminal indictment against the organization was dismissed after a favorable report from a court-appointed monitor.

title: Tenants Told to Move Out in Bay Shore
description: More than 100 tenants in the Suffolk County community of Bay Shore were left homeless yesterday after inspectors condemned an apartment complex, citing dozens of code violations.

title: Families at the Bottom
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISZ, JOHN ALEXANDER
description: WEISZ--John Alexander of New York City and Quiogue, L.I. died Sunday, September 11, 2005 at the age of 60. John is the beloved, and already dearly missed, husband of Barbara. He is the devoted and cherished father of Zachary and Zoe, the loving uncle of Barbara Percoco, Eric Mesecke and Keith Weisz, and the caring brother of Michael and Mary Weisz, Dr. Alice Weisz, Christine D'Esposito and Dr. Robert D'Esposito. He was a graduate of Xavier High School in New York City; received Bachelor of Civil Engineering degree from the University of Detroit and Master of Business Administration from Hofstra University. After graduation, he served as a First Lieutenant in the United States Army in Vietnam, for which he received a Bronze Star. He retired three years ago from Clarion Partners, the firm he founded. John always had the unique ability of combining style, dignity, generosity and intelligence with humanity. He was always the gentleman. We will struggle for a long time to adjust to this enormous loss. It was too soon, and he was too young. In repose at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st St, Tuesday, September 13th, 4-8 PM, Wednesday September 14th, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 10 AM Thursday, September 15th at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th St. Memorial donations may be made to The John A. Weisz Scholarship Fund, c/o InnerCity Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, NY, NY 10022, Attention: Anne Reidy.

title: North Korea Talks Resume, Still in a Standoff
description: BEIJING, Sept. 13 - Talks over how to end North Korea's nuclear weapons program resumed in Beijing on Tuesday, but the United States and North Korea showed few signs of settling a dispute over the peaceful uses of nuclear power that broke up previous negotiations.

title: Cricket: The Ashes, back to England
Fields's Run for Mayor Ends Up in 3rd Place
description: C. Virginia Fields's underdog mayoral candidacy came to an end last night as she failed to break out of third place in the Democratic primary election.

U.N. Adopts Modest Goals on Reforms and Poverty
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 13 - The General Assembly unanimously approved a scaled-down statement of goals on Tuesday that Secretary General Kofi Annan said would still give world leaders gathering Wednesday a basis for recommendations to reform the organization and combat poverty.

title: Multiplying in Manhattan: Banks
description: Seemingly as numerous as Starbucks coffee shops -- and sometimes resembling them, too -- new bank branches are popping up across the city on corners, in the middle of blocks and even second-story spaces.

title: Federal Experts to Assess Security at Indian Point
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 13 - The United States Department of Homeland Security on Tuesday began a top-to-bottom review of emergency preparedness and security at the Indian Point nuclear plant in Westchester County. The review is part of a sweeping initiative by the federal government to assess the vulnerability of the nation's infrastructure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISLER, SIMON
description: PREISLER--Simon. Died on September 11th, 2005 in Frankfurt, Germany. Born on October 10th, 1925 in Fancsicovo, Czechoslovakia. He was a survivor of Auschwitz who lived his life to the fullest. Beloved husband of Baba, adored father of Lydia Preisler Shorenstein (Douglas) and Renee Preisler Barasch (Richard) and Beloved Brother of Simcha and devoted Opa to his grandchildren, Brandon, Sandra, Danielle, Emily, Benjamin and Natalie. He will be in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Hurricane Relief Fund at the UJA. Services today, 11:30AM at "Plaza Jewish Community Chapel," 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, MARY
description: BERNSTEIN - Mary, my mother, who died on Sept. 14, 2001, is loved and missed by me forever. Barbara

title: When Food From the Laboratory Leaves a Bitter Taste
description: The heroes and villains in "The Future of Food," Deborah Koons Garcia's sober, far-reaching polemic against genetically modified foods, are clearly identified. The good guys, acknowledged in the film's cursory final segment, are organic farmers along with a growing network of farmers' markets around the United States that constitute a grass-roots resistance to the Goliath of agribusiness and the genetically engineered products it favors.

title: In a Church Garden, a Twist on an Old King Solomon Story
description: Most of us know the Bible tale of how King Solomon settled a dispute between two women claiming to be the mother of the same child. He demanded his sword and said, "Divide the child in two, and give half to the one and half to the other." The first woman renounced her claim; the other told Solomon to proceed. He ordered the child given to the first woman. Putting its welfare first proved she was the true mother.

title: Would-Be Princess Headed to Hospital, Not Jail
description: Antoinette Millard, a Buffalo-born investment banker who posed as a Saudi princess, tried to bilk an insurance company out of a small fortune and stiffed American Express with $1 million in unpaid charges, will spend a year in a psychiatric hospital for her misdeeds.

title: Norman F. Levy, 93, Broker Who Led New York Realty Firm
description: Norman F. Levy, the chairman of the Cross & Brown commercial real estate brokerage of Manhattan from 1976 to 1990, died on Friday. . He was 93 and lived in Fisher Island, Fla.

title: German public banksretool for competition
Miller Loses Mayoral Bid but Vows to Try Again
description: Where congratulations had been expected, there were condolences last night for Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, as his bid for the Democratic mayoral nomination fell far short of what was needed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Northwest and Delta Move Closer To Filing for Bankruptcy Protection Two of the nation's biggest and most troubled airlines, Northwest and Delta, appeared likely to file for bankruptcy protection as soon as today, people briefed on the airlines' plans said. Both airlines have been hit hard by the spike in jet fuel prices this month and by relentless competition. [Page A1.]

title: Forrester Shown as Trustworthy Husband, and Candidate
description: "The Doug I Know," a 30-second commercial for Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican nominee for New Jersey governor, began running yesterday on network and cable television stations in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Aging Nuclear Power Plants May Affect Emissions Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - A proposed agreement among nine Northeast states to cap greenhouse gas emissions from power plants casts a new light on arguments in New Jersey and Vermont about whether the licenses of two aging nuclear plants should be extended.

title: Pakistan arrests 21 militants
Singapore and Katrina
description: Singapore - There is something troublingly self-indulgent and slothful about America today -- something that Katrina highlighted and that people who live in countries where the laws of gravity still apply really noticed. It has rattled them -- like watching a parent melt down.

title: America's forgottenvolunteer corps

description: Grappling with the sensitive issue of how effective a cancer drug must be to merit approval, a federal advisory panel on Tuesday urged rejection of a prostate cancer therapy developed by Abbott Laboratories but endorsed a pancreatic cancer medicine from OSI Pharmaceuticals.

title: Belfast riots erase Northern Ireland's optimism
LG joins other cellphone makers with optimism over demand
Stance on Turks' Cyprus question eludes EU
Rebels Unleash Wave of Attacks in Baghdad, Killing About 150
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 14 - Insurgents staged at least a dozen suicide bombings that ripped through Baghdad in rapid succession today, killing almost 150 people and wounding more than 500 in a coordinated assault that left much of the violence-scarred Iraqi capital paralyzed.

title: Hurricane Relief
description: CHEFS FOR HUMANITY, a nonprofit organization, is auctioning two dozen autographed jackets from chefs including Mario Batali, Bobby Flay and Thomas Keller at eBay through next Wednesday, to benefit Katrina relief organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERMAN, JOSHUA
description: HERMAN--Joshua. Dearest Josh, we'll always love and miss you and remember the good times. Now you'll be skiing the clouds with your Dad. Sandra, Alan, Cliff, Eleanor, Jon and Sondra

title: International funds have the edge
The Lost U.N. Summit Meeting
description: A once-in-a-generation opportunity to reform and revive the United Nations has been squandered even before the opening gavel comes down this morning for the largest assemblage of world leaders ever brought together in a single location. The responsibility for this failure is widely shared. But the United States, as the host nation and the U.N.'s most indispensable and influential member, bears a disproportionate share.

title: Bush Puts Iraq, China and Iran on Agenda
description: For the first time since the Hurricane Katrina crisis, President Bush returned yesterday to dealing with festering global problems, trying to bolster Iraq's president at the White House and then flying to New York to urge President Hu Jintao of China to join him in trying to stop nuclear programs in Iran and North Korea.

title: U.N. Goals: Poor's Best Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Legislature Rejects Gay Marriage Ban
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 - In a sign that the legalization of same-sex marriage has changed the political landscape in Massachusetts, the State Legislature soundly defeated today a proposed constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage and create civil unions, an amendment that lawmakers had voted to approve in a raucous constitutional convention last year.

title: Once Home to Ford, Canadian City Is Losing Auto Work
description: Correction Appended

Paid Notice: Deaths   O'KELLY, EUGENE D.
description: O'KELLY--Eugene D. The Partnership for New York City mourns the loss of Eugene O'Kelly, former CEO of KPMG and member of the Partnership's Executive Committee and Board of Directors since 2003. Gene's commitment to improving the lives and economic wellbeing of New Yorkers helped raise our standard of corporate citizenship. He was one of those rare leaders who was not only respected but also loved by those who had the opportunity to know him.

title: Rewriting Victors' View of Persian History
description: Correction Appended

title: Why the millennium goals matter
Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about a dispute between astronomers over credit for the discovery of 2003EL61, a large icy object in the outer solar system, misstated the term for the identification number assigned by the Internet to every computer. The number, by which American astronomers were able to trace a Spanish group's visits to their Web site before the discovery was announced, is called an IP address (for "Internet protocol"), not IPP numbers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan by the Army Corps of Engineers to award $1.5 billion in contracts for hurricane cleanup misstated the bidding process for a contract received by Kellogg, Brown & Root, a subsidiary of Halliburton. It was awarded by the Navy before the hurricane, after competitive bidding; it was not a no-bid contract awarded by the Federal Emergency Management Agency or the Corps of Engineers after the storm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERROTTA, ROCCO
description: PERROTTA -- Rocco. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Faye and the entire family. Fred H. Weinshank, President

title: Former Yonkers Schools Chief Pleads Guilty to Perjury
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 13 - The former Yonkers schools superintendent, Angelo Petrone, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that he lied and tampered with public documents during an investigation over the hiring of an inexperienced accountant to a $90,000-a-year job.

title: Champions League: Chelsea likes early-season form
Potential U.K. terrorists under watch, official says
A Couple of Swagmen Open Up Their Tucker Bag
description: Tuck Shop, a little spot that specializes in Australian meat pies, has a few words for New Yorkers to learn: chook is chicken, sangers are sandwiches, mash means potatoes and lamington is a jam-filled wedge of cake.

title: Bush support is near lowest ever, poll says
Court Nominee Says Early Career Is No Guide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Judge John G. Roberts Jr. told senators today that the views he expressed as a young lawyer in the administration of President Ronald Reagan are not necessarily a gauge of how he would rule today on issues like voting rights and affirmative action.

title: U.S. May Start Pulling Out of Afghanistan Next Spring
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 13 - Senior Pentagon and military officials are discussing a proposal to cut American troop levels in Afghanistan next spring, perhaps by as much as 20 percent, the largest withdrawal since the Taliban were ousted in late 2001.

title: As Post-Primary Fight Looms, Bloomberg Watches Battle With Glee
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's campaign advisers have spent their summer working hard from the sidelines to make mischief in the Democratic primary. Through news releases, sound bites and whispers to reporters, they have tried to undercut the man they have always expected to face this fall, Fernando Ferrer. They were aiming to force him into a potentially divisive runoff before the general election.

title: A Fatal Incuriosity
description: I hate spending time in hospitals and nursing homes. I find them to be some of the most depressing places on earth.

title: Drawing on Greek Myths to Illustrate a Generation of Tragedy
description: The first in a projected trilogy by the Greek director Theo Angelopoulos, "The Weeping Meadow" tells the story of Greek history from the close of World War I to the aftermath of World War II, not in broad, historic strokes, but through the sufferings of one emblematic, almost mythical family.

title: President Says He's Responsible in Storm Lapses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - President Bush said on Tuesday that he bore responsibility for any failures of the federal government in its response to Hurricane Katrina and suggested that he was unsure whether the country was adequately prepared for another catastrophic storm or terrorist attack.

description: BEIJING, Sept. 14 - North Korea demanded today that the United States and other nations give it money to build a new light-water nuclear reactor before it will end its nuclear weapons program, a condition that appeared to undermine prospects for a breakthrough in the talks here.

title: A Rescue Mission Under Control: Houston Adjusts Well on the Fly
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 13 - If any city in the country was ready for the disaster of Hurricane Katrina, it was Houston.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 - An upbeat Mayor C. Ray Nagin announced on Tuesday that he hoped to reopen four neighborhoods, including the city's central business district and the French Quarter, to residents and business owners in the next few days.

title: In Complex Dance, Roberts Pays Tribute to Years of Precedent Behind Roe v. Wade
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Nowhere were Judge John G. Roberts Jr.'s words framed more carefully -- or listened to more closely -- than on the subject of abortion.

Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCE, HENRY III.
description: LUCE--Henry III. The Writing Center of Marymount Manhattan College notes with sadness the passing of Hank Luce, benefactor and husband of our great friend Leila Hadley. To Leila and the family we extend our deepest sympathy. Lewis Burke Frumkes, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KROLL, LOUIS, DMD.
description: KROLL--Louis, DMD. Devoted husband of Frances (d. 1980). Lou was a kind and decent human being who dedicated his life to caring for others. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the political corruption trial of Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. of Brooklyn misspelled the surname of a lobbyist for the New York State Association of Service Stations and Repair Shops, from whom Mr. Norman is accused of having solicited contributions beyond the state limit. (The same error appeared in an article on Feb. 26, 2000, about a program on Priceline.com that would let customers shop around for gasoline prices.) The lobbyist is Ralph Bombardiere, not Bombardier.

title: Forln reborn in Spanish soccer
When Good Will Is Also Good Business
description: Corporate good will in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina has been anything but run-of-the-mill.

title: 2 Kohlberg Kravis Partners Say They Will Step Down
description: Two senior partners of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company who had been viewed as likely successors to the firm's founders said yesterday that they would step down, raising questions about succession at Kohlberg Kravis, the best-known private equity firm.

title: A Title Series Problem: Filling Backcourt Holes
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn., Sept. 13 - After battling in the regular season for the best overall record and home-court advantage, the Connecticut Sun and the Sacramento Monarchs will meet in a W.N.B.A. finals that could be decided by which team best overcomes the loss of its floor leader.

title: Survivors and Victims of Katrina

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Green Light For Strip Clubs
description: Seattle's 17-year ban on new strip clubs has ended after a federal judge ruled that it was illegal and violated the First Amendment. The judge, James L. Robart of Federal District Court, ruled on Monday that Seattle had effectively created a licensing scheme that restricted the issuing of adult cabaret licenses, amounting to illegal restraint on a legal business. Seattle, which has four strip clubs, tried to justify the ban by arguing that adult dancing was alive and well and that its failure to adopt new legislation was for reasons other than censorship. The city does not plan to appeal the ruling, said Marty McOmber, a spokesman for Mayor Greg Nickels. David Carrillo Pealoza (NYT)

title: Falcons Shadow Owens, and the Result Is Victory
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 13 - On Philadelphia's last offensive play of Monday night's game with Atlanta, Eagles wide receiver Terrell Owens ran down the right sideline, but Falcons cornerback DeAngelo Hall was not just in coverage, he was so tight he was in Owens's shadow.

title: A smokers-only preview of 'Sin City'

description: HAHN--Phil. I. Hennig & Co expresses its sincere condolences to the family and to his employer, M. Fabrikant & Sons. Phil's expertise in the diamond business has led the company to its great success. Richard Hambro, Chairman Dani Shein, Managing Dir

description: BASEBALL

description: NEWBURG--Mort. Beloved husband of Charlene, loving daughters, Janet Smalley and Patricia Stiffman, and their husbands, Thomas Smalley, and David Stiffman, devoted grandchildren, Stephanie Smalley, Andrew and Julia Stiffman. Contributions to Temple Israel of New Rochelle or Arthritis Foundation. For info. call George T. Davis Funeral Home: 914-632-0324.

title: What Jesus' Birth May Have Looked Like
description: Even some conservative Christians are willing to allow that the Nativity scene presented in church pageants and Christmas decorations may not be absolutely accurate. That means the shepherds, three wise men bearing gifts, Mary and Joseph, their baby son (lying in a manger), a couple of angels and maybe a star overhead.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Katrina exposed serious problems in our response capability at all levels of government, and to the extent that the federal government didn't fully do its job right, I take responsibility."

title: Arbitration Panel Recommends 11 Percent Raises for Teachers
description: An arbitration panel recommended raises of 11 percent over three years for New York City's public school teachers yesterday, with the raises tied to lengthening the school day by 10 minutes and curtailing some seniority rights in staffing decisions.

title: TechBrief: Gates seeks programs for Vista OS
EU orders Greek airline to repay aid
News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Savoring Simplicity With a Bit of Meaning
description: Jack Johnson's temperament perfectly matches the ocean he loves so much. He's a pacific guy, a Hawaii-reared surfer turned surf moviemaker turned ultramellow singer-songwriter. And on Monday night, during the first of two sold-out concerts at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park, he spent a few hours murmuring, starting with his introduction, which shall be reprinted here in full: "Hi." About half the show exuded a sleepy charm; the other half was much the same, only without the charm.

title: Out of the Bushes and Onto Center Stage
description: Jackie Onassis once got a court order to keep Ron Galella 25 feet away from her or her children. Marlon Brando once broke his jaw and knocked out four of his teeth. Brigitte Bardot once enlisted some friends to soak him with a hose. Richard Burton's bodyguards once roughed him up and had him tossed in a Mexican jail.

title: In Belfast, rage may be ebbing
Suit Says Wal-Mart Is Lax on Labor Abuses Overseas
description: A labor rights group filed a class-action lawsuit yesterday against Wal-Mart Stores in which apparel workers in Bangladesh, China and other countries assert that Wal-Mart violated its contractual obligations by not enforcing its code of conduct for overseas contractors.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary on Saturday about the coming trip to Syria by the chief of a commission investigating the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister misidentified the commission chief. He is the senior United Nations investigator, a German -- not the chief American investigator.

title: For Russia's Nouveaux Riches, Indoor Plumbing Deluxe
description: Correction Appended

title: A Bonus for Bloomberg
description: The absence of a clear-cut winner in the Democratic primary for New York mayor is likely to benefit the Republican incumbent, Michael R. Bloomberg. News analysis, Page B7.

title: Sydney's Chefs Settle Down but Still Shine
description: Sydney, Australia - THEY'RE not trying quite so hard in Sydney's most admired kitchens these days. Having elevated their city into the ranks of the world's great eating towns, right up there with New York and Paris and London, chefs here have begun to focus on making the most of the magnificent raw materials at their disposal rather than emphasizing the razzle-dazzle of old.

title: European carmakers try hybrids, reluctantly
Henryk Tomaszewski, Leader of the Polish Poster School, Dies at 91
description: Henryk Tomaszewski, whose animated and witty posters for cinema, circus and theater led to the distinctive postwar Polish Poster School style, died on Sunday at his home in Warsaw. He was 91.

title: Incumbent in Queens Is Defeated by Old Rival
description: In a rare defeat for an incumbent City Council member, Allan W. Jennings, a Queens Democrat whose candidacy had been shadowed by recent controversies, lost the party's primary yesterday to Thomas White Jr., Mr. Jennings's predecessor in the Council.

title: Keep the Fabric Up
description: Every museum director and development officer knows that the hardest money to raise is the money that keeps the roof from leaking and the walls from crumbling. Donors like to make contributions that have a certain glamour or clat to them, and museums like to receive them for the same reason. But a director's ultimate responsibility is to make sure that the all-around health of an institution -- its collections, its buildings, its programs and staff -- is better at the end of his term than at the beginning. According to a recent audit of its facilities, that has not been the case at the Smithsonian Institution, which has been led since 2000 by Lawrence Small. This is particularly unfortunate because Mr. Small was hired in part because of the management skills he had displayed in business. All but one of his predecessors as secretary of the Smithsonian were scientists.

title: Briefs: Former prime minister to seek presidency
Top leftist quits run for Polish presidency
Paid Notice: Memorials   HARAN, JACQUES
description: HARAN--Jacques. Eight years have passed. You are always remembered and loved. William

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: The Lincoln Continental Tunnel?
description: The future may not hold, say, the George Washington Mutual Bridge, but the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will explore commercial sponsorship of its properties and nontraditional advertising in its stations and transportation systems. Yesterday, it named Active Public Enterprise Group and aXcess Partners Worldwide, of Atlanta, to develop the sponsorship program and JCDecaux of New York to run the advertising program. The point is to fully tap the "revenues we can be realizing from our facilities," said Kenneth J. Ringler Jr., the authority's executive director. "If it doesn't make sense or isn't in good taste," he added, "we won't do it." David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: The Mets Do the Math: It Doesn't Add Up
description: The buzzword in the Mets' clubhouse these days is "mathematical." It seems that every player has the word on the tip of his tongue when discussing the Mets' dwindling chances of winning the National League wild-card race.

title: Meanwhile: British men finally get their say
Owners of Nursing Home Charged in Deaths of 34
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 - The owners of a nursing home where 34 people died in the floodwaters that inundated the New Orleans area were charged Tuesday with multiple counts of negligent homicide, shortly after a new dispute broke out between the State of Louisiana and the federal government over the retrieval of hundreds of other bodies.

title: Hurricane and Floods Overwhelmed Hospitals
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 - Confusion and desperation permeated the New Orleans hospital system as floodwaters rose, emergency generators failed and dozens of patients died in the three chaotic days after the levees broke, doctors and other witnesses said on Tuesday.

title: After Katrina: A chance to heal America
Marc Jacobs Is High School With Money
description: The confetti that 30 minutes earlier had exploded from the ceiling in a silvery rain now lay in clumps on the bleachers. Caroline Kennedy had left with her two daughters. Uma Thurman had come and gone. Robert Duffy, the business partner of Marc Jacobs, stood on the littered runway. He remarked that there were things in Mr. Jacobs's show on Monday night that he had first seen him attempt at the start of his career. "But 15 or 18 years ago we had no money for beautiful fabrics, for embroidery," Mr. Duffy said. "We had, like, five pairs of shoes for a whole show."

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about hurricane recovery efforts misstated the day Northwest Airlines was scheduled to resume commercial service to the New Orleans airport. It was yesterday, not today.

title: A Rout, Rout, Rout for the Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 13 - To amuse the few fans who come to their games, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays often tweak the Yankees with the pregame music at Tropicana Field. The theme is usually money.

title: No Heat Doesn't Mean No Sweat
description: OCCASIONALLY, even the most carnivorous cooks can find themselves tempted by raw produce. It may seem harebrained to try to one-up vegans by banning from the kitchen not only all animal products, but also all application of heat to any foodstuff, ever. Still, when one has sweated through enough party clothes in enough kitchens, putting the final touches on enough dinner party menus, one may start wondering how much easier a cooking life minus the actual cooking might be. So, fed up with the dry cleaning bills, this confirmed braiser attempted to convert to the uncooked way of life. The first hurdle in a fledgling raw career was outfitting my kitchen and pantry. This might seem simple enough, if you see raw foodism as some kind of pristine 21st century version of noble savagery. But raw food, at least as made by the glamorous authors of a host of recent cookbooks (or as raw foodists might put it, "cook" books), is the farthest thing from straight off the vine. Although the movement dictates no animal products and no heat, we're not talking salad here. Raw foodists have much grander ambitions.

title: INSIDE
description: Baghdad Car Blast Kills 80; Gunmen Execute 17 A suicide car bombing killed at least 80 people when it ripped through a gathering of day laborers waiting for work in one of Baghdad's largest Shiite districts. According to an official with the Iraqi Interior Ministry, 160 people were injured in the blast. In a village north of Baghdad, gunmen abducted 17 men and killed them. PAGE A8

title: Thin Margin for Mayor Puts Runoff Up in the Air
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner promised last night to forge ahead with a campaign to win a Sept. 27 runoff with Fernando Ferrer, his rival who might have narrowly missed winning the Democratic mayoral primary outright.

title: Uncovering the Fireworks Beneath the Courtly Veneer
description: The Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players' concerts at Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church offer an attractive alternative to the slicker productions nearby at Lincoln Center. The musicians are young and vigorous, and they throw themselves into their performances with an abandon that catches the music's inner fire. True, this can lead to dicey intonation at times, and there were moments on Monday afternoon when it did. But if the choice is playing it safe to keep the edges polished or going for fireworks hidden under a courtly veneer, an occasional patch of strident tone is a small price to pay.

title: German vote
Following the Truffles to the Western Edge of Australia
description: Mundaring, Australia - I WAS doubly surprised when I walked into the Loose Box, a small restaurant tucked into a grove of trees in the hills east of Perth, at the western edge of the immense Australian continent -- first, because the place looked as if it had been airlifted intact from provincial France, and second, because of the black object the size of a baseball that Alain Fabrgues, the chef and owner, was juggling in his right hand when he came out of the kitchen to greet us.

title: Sugar and Spice And Prune Hints: How Nice
description: Jacques Torres has introduced Trinitario Treasures chocolate bars, using trinitario cocoa beans from Ghana. He will make the 3.5-ounce bars for the next few months, until his supply of the distinctive small-crop beans runs out.

title: In the Capitol, Nervous Evacuees Fear Biting a Hand That Might Help
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 - Some notions are so entrenched they live on and on, through political and social upheavals, even floods and hurricanes, and that seems to be the case here, in this place with the kind of political history that is inevitably called colorful, at least by those more charitably inclined.

title: GM and Ford trot out new vehicles
Paid Notice: Deaths   SLADE, JOHN
description: SLADE--John. We mourn the loss of a man of great stature and great accomplishments. He left behind the cruelties of pre-war Germany to build a life filled with a myriad of charitable deeds of kindness that benefited the totality of Jewish communal needs. A Benefactor of the Medical Center together with his wife Marianne, an Honorary Board member of the Nation al Women's Division who inspired her husband in his philanthropic activities, we will always remember with warmth and deep appreciation the dedication ceremony of the Slade Building that contains many of our outpatient clinics. The exemplary support provided by the Slades played a critical role in the growth and development of Shaare Zedek. Our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Slade and daughters Barbara and Nicole. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Phil Friedman, Vice-President Sidney Adler, Treasurer Lee Weinbach, Pres Nat'l Women's Div

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Three West Nile Cases Reported
description: Three city residents, two from the Bronx and one from Queens, were recently found to have the West Nile virus, the City Health Department reported yesterday. Health officials said that one Bronx resident, 61, developed a headache and fever on Aug. 16, and that the second, 68, developed symptoms on Aug. 22. Both were hospitalized and are now recovering at home. The Queens resident, 44, became ill on Aug. 24 and is still hospitalized, in stable condition. Health officials said all three probably had been infected in the city. The health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, said residents should eliminate standing water on their property and repair window and door screens to prevent mosquitoes from entering.

title: U.S. meets opposition in call for NATO help

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - As Congress prepares to take its first tentative steps toward evaluating the government response to Hurricane Katrina, Democrats and others are pressing for an independent inquiry, saying lawmakers cannot be trusted to assess their own complicity in the failures.

description: Baton Rouge, La. - Someday, when tiny Ernest Williams Jr. is grown, his mother will tell him the story of his birth.

title: Trying to Resurrect a Favorite Wristwatch
description: I wear, or, rather, wore, a really great Lorus watch. I bought it in Austria five years ago, in an airport shop where I could use up the rest of my Austrian money ($40) so I wouldn't have to exchange it for U.S. dollars. This watch has everything I like: regular numerals, day/date, glow in the dark, sweep second hand, and water resistance so I donAt have to take it off in the shower.

title: You See an Office Tower. Investors See a Condo.
description: Despite all the talk of a real estate bubble, investors are pouring a stream of capital into the New York City market, and as a result prices of commercial properties in Manhattan continue to rise. While some investors are content to collect the income from office space, others are converting office buildings and hotels into condominiums.

Survived by sister Helaine, husband Bernard, daughters Elizabeth and Jan, grandchildren Bettye and Ethan, parents Sylvia and Arthur Rubenstein, nieces and nephews, many friends and colleagues. B.A., M.A. Brooklyn College. Additional graduate work Queens College. 27 year career as elementary school teacher -P.S. 116 in Brooklyn and kindergarten at P.S. 193 in Queens. Ten years as chapter chairman for UFT. Loved beaches, travel, dogs, newspapers. Donations in memory to Amer. Cancer Society.

The suspect, Hamdi Issac, will be extradited to Britain within 10 days, his lawyer said. Officials have said Mr. Issac admitted taking part in the attempted bombings. Brian Wingfield (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Polio Returns
description: In another setback to the 17-year effort to eradicate polio, Somalia has become the 10th polio-free country to be reinfected since late last year. The World Health Organization confirmed that a 15-month-old girl had been paralyzed by the disease in Mogadishu, the capital. In coming months, officials hope to immunize more than 34 million children in the Horn of Africa against polio. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TULLY, MARY ANN
description: TULLY--Mary Ann. Of Port Washington passed away the morning of Monday, September 12, 2005 surrounded by her loving family. 70 years young and full of life she was a long serving board member and fundraiser for Long Island Hospice. Starting as a volunteer caregiver when hospice could only service 8 patients, she helped grow this important community program from its infancy to the thriving, serving and comforting organization now helping people all over Long Island deal with terminal illness. She and her beloved husband and best friend Kenneth celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary this past February. She is the mother to Thomas, Joanne, James, Peter, Kenneth, Alice and Kelly. Grandmother to Daniel, Sean, Taylor, Jamie, Megan, Allison, Andrew, Mark, Nikolas, Christopher, Kara, Brian, William, Kaelin, Colin, Stephen, Jill, Tully, Riley, Logan, and Kegan. Great grandmother to Tyler. Mary ann was someone who touched the heart of everyone she met. She was one of a kind and will be missed very much by all, but especially her loving family, We will never forget you mom. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:30AM at St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Pt. Washington. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY 11797. This would be greatly appreciated by the family, so Hospice can continue their very important work.

title: A Master Class in Obscure Jazz
description: Marian McPartland climbed the stage unsteadily at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, and apologized for her sensible shoes. The pianist, who is 87, explained that she had injured her ankle falling down some stairs; she had a bad knee already. "So now I don't have a leg to stand on," she said. Characteristically, Ms. McPartland played the line not for sympathy but for laughs. Then she turned to the piano and began a solo performance that cast all thoughts of frailty aside.

description: THE tiny restaurant on the top floor of the new Bouley Bakery and Market doesn't operate by the rules and rhythms of most establishments of its kind. It operates by the rules and rhythms of David Bouley.

title: Pakistanis Seize Afghan Militants

title: Judge Backs Case Seeking End of School Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - A federal judge in California declared today, in a ruling that virtually guarantees another long and emotional battle in the courts, that the recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools is unconstitutional.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Traffic on the East Side of Manhattan will be restricted today as more than 170 heads of state and government gather to observe the 60th anniversary of the United Nations.

title: Playing Games With Voting Rights
description: The State of Pennsylvania took a shameful step backward when the State House passed a bill that could potentially deprive tens of thousands of parolees and probationers of the right to vote. Even if the bill fails to be passed by the State Senate -- as many people predict -- it will inevitably suppress the vote in the poor and mainly minority communities where ex-felons tend to live. People in those communities are already confused about their rights under the law, and many who are actually eligible to vote don't do so out of fear that they may be penalized or turned away at the polls.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: A Plan to Limit Chinese Imports
description: Brazil plans to limit imports of Chinese textiles and shoes, which grew more than sixfold in the first seven months of the year. The government probably will impose "safeguards" to protect domestic clothing producers by the end of September, said Dilma Rousseff, chief of staff for President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva. Ms. Rousseff declined to specify the measures that might be introduced. "These, textiles and shoes, are the sectors most harmed by the Chinese," Ms. Rousseff told a news conference in So Paulo. Brazilian imports of textiles and shoes from China, the world's fastest-growing economy, rose to $128 million in January through July, from $23 million in the period last year, after a global quota system was scrapped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALES, KATHARINE LADD
description: FALES--Katharine Ladd. The Board of Directors, Clinical and Administrative Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of Katharine Fales, a beloved Director for 25 years and benefactor of the agency's home care and public health services. Her interest in patient care improved the health and wellbeing of countless New Yorkers. Her commitment to high quality, compassionate health care will be remembered always. We extend our profound sympathy to her family. Douglas D. Broadwater Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHINDLER, FRANYO (MARGA V.)
description: SCHINDLER--Franyo (Marga V.) of Manhattan, died peacefully at home on Monday, September 12. A painter who grew up in Hamburg, Germany, and fled to New York in 1938 where she met her late husband, the art collector, Gustave Schindler, she is survived by her two daughters, Vivian Teich and Nicole Jeffords, her two sons-in-law, Dr. Morton Teich and George Jeffords, and her grandchildren Karina Stern, David Sonnenberg, Marco Sonnenberg, Jofka Forman-Hague, Gabriella Jeffords, Julian Jeffords, as well as nine greatgrandchildren and her loyal caregiver, Inez Richards. Services will be held on Thursday, September 15th at 6:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the hurricane relief fund of your choice.

title: They May Be Seniors but Theyre Still the Stones
description: "Thangyaooh! Thangyaooh! Splendid! Are you feeling good?" Toward the end of the Rolling Stones' concert at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, Mick Jagger did his fascinating preteen girl walk - on his toes, heels almost coming down as an afterthought - to sweep fully across the stage one more time. And a particularly strong version of "Jumpin' Jack Flash" motored up, ending the band's 20th show at the Garden since 1969.

title: Google Gains Researcher; Microsoft Wins Limits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 - Google and Microsoft each claimed victory on Tuesday in the latest round of their bitter court dispute over a top researcher's defection to Google.

Roberts Jr. explained his views and defended his honor with the force and fluidity of an advocate who has argued often before tougher judges than those he faced on the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday.

F.A.A. Alerted on Qaeda in '98, 9/11 Panel Said
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - American aviation officials were warned as early as 1998 that Al Qaeda could "seek to hijack a commercial jet and slam it into a U.S. landmark," according to previously secret portions of a report prepared last year by the Sept. 11 commission. The officials also realized months before the Sept. 11 attacks that two of the three airports used in the hijackings had suffered repeated security lapses.

title: The Hardest Working Man in the Poconos
description: HAWLEY, Pa. - The end of summer prompts a collective exhale from the waitresses and lifeguards at Woodloch Pines, a 1,000-bed resort here in the Pocono Mountains. The families who treat its bungalows and rustic hotel rooms as a temporary summer camp, often for a week at a stretch, have returned home, yielding to the tour buses filled with seniors who will largely serve as its weekday clientele until ski season.

title: The Struggle to Find Life in Ordinary Landscapes
description: The global landscape portrayed in Jem Cohen's visually haunting film "Chain" is an industrial park-cum-shopping mall where the same brand names pop up everywhere, be it Florida, Texas, Berlin, Paris or Melbourne. In this profoundly impersonal suburban climate, two lone women, one an eager corporate beaver, the other a semidropout scrounging on the fringes of society, scuttle through their days. As the movie alternates between the women, who have no connection and who never meet, they muse out loud about their solitary lives.

title: Troops Returning to Duties
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - In a sign that initial rescue efforts after Hurricane Katrina are coming to an end, Pentagon officials said late Tuesday that about 4,000 active-duty troops, two large Navy vessels and three dozen helicopters ordered into the relief effort would return to their regular duties.

title: Hurting From a Beanball, Piazza's Been There Before
description: Three days after being hit on the head by a fastball, catcher Mike Piazza said that he was still hurting but that he would be ready to play tonight.

title: The professor under fire
Senate Rejects Call on E.P.A. to Toughen Emission Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - The Senate narrowly defeated a resolution on Tuesday that would have called on the Environmental Protection Agency to rewrite rules for mercury emissions from power plants. Health and environmental groups say the present rules are too weak.

title: Two Major Airlines Seen Near Filing for Bankruptcy
description: Two of the nation's biggest and most troubled airlines, Northwest and Delta, appeared likely to file for bankruptcy protection as soon as today, people briefed on the airlines' plans said yesterday.

title: UN reform; Keeping the peace
Metro Briefing | New York: West Babylon: Police Seeking Prowler
description: The Suffolk County police are searching for a man wanted for a series of at least 10 break-ins, some involving sexual attacks on girls, the police said yesterday. The most recent attack in a series that began on Aug. 29 occurred yesterday morning in North Amityville, the police said. In each attack, the prowler entered through an unlocked door or window in the early morning. The other break-ins have occurred primarily in the Wyandanch area, Detective Lt. James Maher said. In some cases, the prowler has touched or groped girls before fleeing. In one case he displayed a knife; in two, he was seen fleeing on a bicycle.

title: Decision Time on Iran
description: Brussels - IN November 2003, Iran averted a crisis when it agreed to suspend activities that could one day give it the capacity to produce weapons-grade nuclear material. The International Atomic Energy Agency had discovered an 18-year pattern of noncompliance by Iran with its obligations to report all its nuclear activities, during which time international inspectors could not verify that they were solely for peaceful purposes. Because Iran suspended its most sensitive activities, the agency's board agreed to hold off reporting Iran to the United Nations Security Council. This was understood, in effect, as a quid pro quo: suspension of uranium-enrichment-related and reprocessing activities in return for not being reported to the Security Council.

title: Sheffield Adjusts at Plate for Injury
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 13 - Gary Sheffield learned to compensate for an injury last season, when his left shoulder bothered him so much that he could not reach across the plate for outside pitches. Ever fearless, Sheffield simply stood closer to the plate.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tax Refund Swap for Railroad Stake
description: Kansas City Southern exchanged a Mexican tax refund of 13 billion pesos ($1.2 billion) for the government's 20 percent stake in its Mexican rail unit, settling an eight-year legal dispute and driving up shares 13 percent. The value of the stake acquired by the railroad, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., is 6.2 billion pesos including taxes. The company agreed in the settlement to forgo 6.8 billion pesos of the refund, the Finance Ministry of Mexico said in an e-mail statement. The transaction ends a court battle that stems from a tax overpayment made in the sale of the state-owned railroad in 1997. Kansas City Southern now owns all of a 6,000-mile rail network linking the United States with Mexico's largest ports, Mexico City and the industrial city of Monterrey.

Adored grandmother to ten grandchildren and great grandmother to 29 great grandchildren.

It's usually of concern only to those who really, really care. But when the sommelier is Daniel Johnnes, you have to lift your nose out of the wine glass and take notice.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - In a day punctuated by flashes of hostility and humor, Judge John G. Roberts Jr. on Tuesday acknowledged a constitutional right to privacy and said overturning precedent was a "jolt to the legal system."

description: GOLDBERG--Howard P. Of New York and Fort Lauderdale, FL, died on Sunday September 11. A graduate of CCNY, past senior executive at Federated Department Stores, and past president of both Ohrbach's Department Store and Lillian Vernon, Howard was an innovator in retailing and direct mail. He is survived by his beloved wife Carole Rossant Goldberg, a daughter Jana Anderson, a son Russell Goldberg, son-inlaw John Anderson, grandchildren Katelyn and Lucas Anderson, a sister Eileen Schuman, and a brother Dr. Joel Goldberg; and nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephew. Mr. Kimura was previously at Iso and Blue Ribbon Sushi: 538 Madison Avenue (54th Street); (212)980-5908.

title: A Wine Shop With a Spare Look, Aiming to Spare the Planet
description: Scott Pactor, a former accountant, took a wine course and became an aficionado. Then he turned professional, working at restaurants like Balthazar. Now he has his own shop, Appellation Wine and Spirits, at 156 10th Avenue (19th Street) in Chelsea. He sells some organic wines and others produced with sustainable farming practices and a minimum of herbicides and pesticides. Biodynamic wines, produced according to factors like the earth's rotation and the sun's position, are another important category in this spacious, spare shop, which has 225 labels priced from $7.99 for a sparkling ros from Spain to $165 for a 1996 Hermitage by Chapoutier. When his refrigerator is installed he will carry wines without added sulfites, which must be kept cool; (212)741-9474. FOOD STUFF

title: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Football Conquers
description: The season premiere of "Monday Night Football" led to an easy victory for ABC on Monday in Nielsen's preliminary estimates. The feuding Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles drew a large audience in all the key ratings categories. The season premiere of "Wife Swap" preceded the game. CBS, with a schedule of repeats, placed second among total viewers for the night. New episodes of shows in its Monday lineup make their debuts next week. This Monday was CBS's real goodbye to "Everybody Loves Raymond," which performed well in summer reruns. On Fox, a "Prison Break" double feature -- one a repeat of last week's episode (5.13 million), followed by a new installment (9.12 million) -- held up well against football and put the network in second among 18- to 49-year-olds. In that age group, Fox and ABC tied for No. 1 for the week that ended on Sunday. And for that week, ABC, thanks to several football broadcasts, won among total viewers, ending CBS's 14-week winning streak. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NASH, NANCY THOURON
description: NASH--Nancy Thouron. Died at her home in Morristown, New Jersey on Sunday, September 11, 2005. She was 70. The cause was brain cancer. She was born in Lynchburg, Virginia, grew up in Wilmington, Delaware, resided for several years in New York City and in Brussels, Belgium and lived in Morristown since 1969. Nancy was a graduate of the Tower Hill School, Wilmington, Delaware and St. Timothy's School, Stevenson, Maryland. She received a BA degree from Vassar College in 1956 and a Master of Letters degree from Drew University in 1996. Nancy worked for the American Field Service (now AFS-USA, Inc.) for several years following her graduation from college. Thereafter she devoted herself to family and friends and her interest in art, literature and music. A member and past President of the Shakespeare Club of Morristown, Nancy was a former Trustee and longtime volunteer archivist of the McCullough Hall Museum in Morristown, a long-time volunteer for the Morristown Meals on Wheels program and a member of the Colony Club, New York, NY, the Sakonnet Golf Club, Little Compton, Rhode Island, and the Warren's Point Beach Club, also of Little Compton. She is survived by her husband, Paul LeNoir Nash, her son Andrew Gray Nash and his wife Ann Gullans Nash of Wilton, Connecticut, her daughters Laurie LeNoir Nash and Daphne Thouron Nash, both of New York City and her grandchildren, Jackson Clark Nash, Elizabeth LeNoir Nash and Meredith Gray Nash. She is also survived by her sister, Margaret Thouron Harrell of Wilmington, Delaware. Her brother, George Gray Thouron, Jr., predeceased her. A memorial service will be held at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Morristown, on Friday, September 16 at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to AFS-USA Inc., 198 Madison Avenue, 8th floor, New York, NY 10016 or to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL. 60018, www. abta.org. For information: William A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ.
