title: Elaine Stritch, at 80, Tries Something New
description: Being superhuman is really the opposite of being immortal. For a performer, it means embodying a magnified representation of what it is to be alive and kicking in all its messy Brobdingnagian reality. It is like being Elaine Stritch standing up in front of a packed house at the Cafe Carlyle and urging everyone present to join her in repeating the dreaded word "aging."

title: For Zac Posen, a Refuge From the Runway
description: ZAC POSEN, who will show his spring line of women's day and evening wear tonight at Bryant Park, is a quintessential child of fast-lane New York.

title: Bush Says, 'I Take Responsibility' (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Forever Young
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Stalemate With Union Over Cyprus
description: The 25 members of the European Union failed to agree on a response to Turkey's refusal to recognize Cyprus, a Union member. Turkey expects to start talks on Oct. 3 toward becoming a member itself, but one condition for joining is to recognize all 25 members. Turkey refuses to recognize the Greek-Cypriot government on Cyprus, which represents the whole of the island in the European Union. Turkey supports a Turkish-Cypriot breakaway government in the north. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Investors Rush to Buy Another $4.2 Billion in Google Stock
description: Google raised $4.18 billion in a secondary offering last night, as investors tried to add to their holdings of a stock that has more than tripled since the company's initial offering a year ago.

title: You Can Sit on Your Parks, or Save Them
description: TAMPA, Fla. - ONE day in August Charles Birnbaum, a landscape architect and tireless preservationist, walked among the silent fountains and broken pavers of the Nations Bank Park Plaza, which molders alongside the Hillsborough River here like some kind of ruined paradise garden. Designed only 17 years earlier by Dan Kiley, a renowned modernist landscape architect, this grid of grassy squares, water and palms was built to echo the window patterns and proportions of a neighboring tower designed by Harry Wolf.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Now, If She Can Cut Back On Sweets
description: Maggie, Alaska's only elephant, who has become a cause clbre of animal rights groups because of her cold weather home, will soon begin training to use a giant treadmill intended to help her shed a few hundred pounds and prevent arthritis and other ailments common among elephants in captivity. The 20-foot-by-8-foot treadmill arrived at the Alaska Zoo in Anchorage on Monday. Zoo officials said it would take at least a month to assemble it and to begin training Maggie to use it. Maggie is known for her strong will, as well as for her intelligence, zoo officials said; she has learned to paint and play the harmonica with her trunk. "I think the limit is not her; I think it's us," said Tex Edwards, director of the zoo. "If we figure it out, I think she'll be able to figure it out." Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: EU ambassador finds the positive in Katrina
A Printer Easy to Share With Many Camera Types
description: Until now, Eastman Kodak's snapshot printers have offered easy printing only to owners of Kodak cameras. Two new EasyShare printers open the technology to people who prefer to mix and match brands.

title: Vatican to Check U.S. Seminaries on Gay Presence
description: Investigators appointed by the Vatican have been instructed to review each of the 229 Roman Catholic seminaries in the United States for "evidence of homosexuality" and for faculty members who dissent from church teaching, according to a document prepared to guide the process.

description: In percent

title: Greek Airline Told to Repay State Aid
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 14 - The European transport commissioner, Jacques Barrot, said Wednesday that Olympic Airlines, Greece's national carrier, must repay the government "several hundreds of millions of euros" in state aid it received over the last two and a half years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the appeal of the documentary "March of the Penguins" to political conservatives misspelled the director's surname. He is Luc Jacquet, not Jaquet.

title: A Middleman Who Doesn't Feel Squeezed by China
description: WITH Chinese clothing flooding the United States, Henry Fan foresees a huge shakeout in the Los Angeles garment industry, the nation's largest. "Companies will go to the wall," he said.

title: Exercising That Back Pain Away
description: EVERY morning for nearly a year, Evelyn Castro had to roll out of bed, literally. She would grip the side of the mattress and gingerly ease herself out in a crouch position to avoid sharpening the dull ache in her lower back. Then she would make her way, wincing, downstairs to brush her teeth, stooping so low in front of the sink that she could not see her face in the mirror.

title: Step up terror fight, Bush tells UN
The Missteps That Hampered Miller
description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, had the most money of all the Democratic candidates, a built-in bully pulpit at City Hall and an accomplished legislative record to further his bid for mayor.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: The Importance Of Being An Exorcist
description: Pope Benedict XVI, who often greets religious groups visiting Rome, made a surprising welcome in his general audience: He offered best wishes to a convention of exorcists, whom he encouraged to "carry on their important work in the service of the church." Details of the convention were not released publicly, but exorcism has gained a more prominent role in the Catholic church in recent years. Pope John Paul II, who died in April, oversaw the rewriting of the ritual for exorcisms and reportedly took part in at least one himself, in 2000. Regina Apostolorum, a top Vatican university, is planning this year to offer another course in exorcism to priests; a course last year proved popular with students. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Demand for Gasoline Falls for a 2nd Week
description: Demand for gasoline fell nationwide for a second consecutive week, the government reported yesterday, indicating that record retail prices may have forced some consumers to cut back on their driving over the week of Labor Day.

title: Some Indie Action for Your Selected Short Subjects
description: You're never too young to suffer from gadget lust -- or at least that's what Mattel hopes in introducing a child-size video camera called the Vidster.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (2) SURVIVOR: GUATEMALA -- THE MAYA EMPIRE -- Season premiere. This is the 11th installment of "Survivor," the reality show that made the genre hot five years ago. The competition begins with an 11-mile hike by 16 new castaways with pretty names like Brandon, Rafe, Morgan, Judd, Blake, Brook and Brianna. The only New Yorker is Brian Corridan (right), a 22-year-old student originally from New Milford, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, WILLIAM (''BILL''). RN, LIEUTENANT COLONEL, USAF (RET.)
description: GREEN--William ("Bill"). RN, Lieutenant Colonel, USAF (Ret.) of West Islip, NY and formerly of Brooklyn, NY died on September 9, 2005 at the age of 90. He was born May 10, 1915, the fourth of five children, the only son of immigrant parents, Rose and Louis Green. A graduate of Brooklyn's Boys High School in 1932, he was a life member of its alumni association as well as a member of Mu Sigma fraternity which he served for many years, finally as national president. He graduated from the School of Nursing, Brooklyn State Hospital (class of 1939) and earned his B.S. degree at St. John's University (class of 1951). His distinguished military career of reserve and active duty service began as a private in the medical battalion of Brooklyn's 106th Infantry, NYNG and then as a hospital corpsman in the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps through world War II. Commissioned a first lieutenant in the Medical Service Corps, USAF, he served in the Korean War and in Occupied Japan. In Japan he started collecting antique Japanese woodblock prints known as ukiyo-e, assembling a notable collection eventually given as a gift to Amherst College. His extensive reference library on Japanese art was given to Amherst's Robert Frost Memorial Library. In 1973, he organized the Ukiyo-e Society of America serving as its first president and was eventually awarded honorary membership. Survived by nieces and nephews. Funeral and burial arrangements private. Interment at Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, NY.

title: On Eminent Domain, Supreme Court Workload, End of Life and Consistency
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings yesterday for Judge John G. Roberts Jr., President Bush's nominee for chief justice of the United States. He was questioned by, among others, Senators Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas; Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin; Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware; Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio; Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma; Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York; and Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. The statements were recorded by CQ Transcriptions. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/supremecourt.

title: Flat-Lining Mets Are in Contention for Irrelevance
description: The sky was gray, there were plenty of empty seats and the crowd booed the Mets just about as much as it cheered them.

title: Nominee Is Standing on Precedent, and Setting His Own, With Hearing Responses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Time and again, as he has danced his way around questions on issues like the right to privacy and the right to die, Judge John G. Roberts Jr. has looked to the past, saying he is simply following the precedent of Supreme Court nominees who have come before him and will become his colleagues if he is confirmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARACCI, FRANK
description: CARACCI - Frank. 79, of Maspeth. Beloved husband of the late Josephine, loving father of Joseph and Philip, loving father-in-law of Debora and Yvonne, proud grandfather of Daniel, Christina and Emily. Dear brother of Rose Stone and the late Philip. Brother-in-law of Nancy and William LaMarca. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Spent over 40 years service with public accounting firms in NYC. WWII US Army veteran, served in Europe 1944-1946. Member of the American Legion and Loyal Order of Moose. Graduate of St. John's University School of Business. Family will receive friends at "Leo F. Kearns" 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Our Lady of Hope RC Church, Friday 10:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: In Roberts Hearing, Specter Assails Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Senator Arlen Specter's testy interrogation of Judge John G. Roberts Jr. on the Supreme Court's treatment of Congress may well have left viewers scratching their heads on Wednesday morning, with cryptic references to the "congruence and proportionality test" and to unfamiliar case names like "Lane and Hibbs."

title: Abbott Labs Gets F.D.A. Approval for Stroke Treatment
description: Abbott Laboratories said today that it had received regulatory approval to sell a combination of implanted devices that reduces stroke risk in patients whose neck arteries have been narrowed by a build-up of fatty tissue.

title: Mapping Everything From Eden to the New York Subway
description: The first map in a 1857 atlas created by Edward Quin in England is dated "B.C. 2348," and it is a map that would not be made today: most of the page is taken up with the blackness of a thick cloud. At its center, the darkness is parted in a roiling circle of light. In the distance can be glimpsed a map fragment, which includes two rivers, a mountain and a lake. It is labeled Eden.

title: German voters voice anger and doubt
Cautious in Victory
description: Finally reaching a perch that eluded him for nearly a decade, Fernando Ferrer now has apparently captured the sweetest prize of his political career: the Democratic nomination to become New York's mayor.

title: 'Bit of a standoff' stymies North Korea talks
A Rock Updating of 'The Beggar's Opera'
description: There's a crude old joke that compares the sexual treatment of the first lady by her husband, the president, to his handling of the American people. It can't be repeated here, but suffice to say that the popular conflation of the sexual act with abuse, particularly as practiced by the powerful, is the thrust of "The Banger's Flopera," an ungainly new rock update of John Gay's "Beggar's Opera."

title: 2nd Trial for Merck on Vioxx Begins
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 - Merck's potentially long legal struggle over its painkiller Vioxx edged forward on Wednesday as lawyers presented opening arguments in the second personal injury suit against the drug to reach a jury.

title: Sick and Abandoned
description: It was the stuff of nightmares. Poisonous water moccasins were swimming in the filthy water of the flooded first floor, and snipers, rats and even a 12-foot alligator were roaming the treacherous area just outside the hospital's doors.

title: Stickers Step In Where Wallpaper Is Too Slow
description: Quick peel-and-place decorating, in the form of stickers, was available from many designers at the Maison et Objet fair that ended last week. Most were in the form of colorful silhouettes of flowers, birds and other small shapes to be used as accents. The Vynil line from the Paris company Domestic (above and below) can be used to decorate a wall or a staircase, much like stencils and paint. (The company calls its stickers an alternative to wallpaper.) The composition above is made from the Ramy  l'Oeil collection by Ich & Kar (heart, diamond or spades are available in separate sets, $40 each); the one at left is from Fossil-o-Rama by Pierre Marie ($70). To order: domestic.fr (click on Vynil, and then Commander). CURRENTS: PARIS -- WALL DCOR

title: Multiple Attacks Kill Nearly 150 in Iraqi Capital
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Thursday, Sept. 15 - Insurgents staged at least a dozen suicide bombings that ripped through Baghdad in rapid succession on Wednesday, killing almost 150 people and wounding more than 500 in a coordinated assault that left much of the capital paralyzed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, WILLIAM E.
description: VOGEL--William E. of Morristownship, N.J. on September 13, 2005 at age 68. Loving husband of Lynda M. Baccoli, beloved father of Jane (Richard) Brickell, Wendy Thayer and Allyn Vogel, son of Alice Vogel, adoring grandfather of Robby, Kelly and Kevin. A graduate of Brown University (Class of 1959) and Harvard Business School (Class of 1962). President and CEO of W. S. Vogel Agency, Inc. Funeral services will be held at Bernheim - Apter - Kreitz man Surburan Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, N.J., Thursday, September 15, 2005 at noon. description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 - Israel's highest court ruled today that part of Israel's West Bank separation barrier has imposed major hardships on a group of Palestinian villages and must be rerouted. It marked the second time in 14 months the court has issued such a decision.

description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 - Late Tuesday afternoon, Cleveland Indians General Manager Mark Shapiro sat at his desk in his Jacobs Field office and shuffled through a handful of baby pictures.

description: When most people shop for camcorders these days, they look primarily at models that record onto MiniDV cassettes.MiniDV, ladies and gentlemen, is a terrific format. The tapes are small, inexpensive and available in any drugstore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a front-page article on Aug. 29 about the drafting of Iraq's constitution misstated the name of an Iraqi ethnic group in a comment by the president, Jalal Talabani, on who would benefit from its final approval. He called it a "constitution for Arabs, Sunni and Shiites, for Kurds, for Chaldeans, Assyrians, Christians and Muslims" -- not "Caledonians."

description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 14 - Suddenly, the Jets, some of whom had spoken of Super Bowl visions just a few weeks ago -- think $64 million quarterback, the league's leading rusher, the defensive rookie of the year, Pro Bowl players at center, defensive end and cornerback -- are being cast as a blue-collar team.

title: David Spade, Again Insulting the Hand That Feeds Him
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 - The celebrity funny bone can be quite a sensitive one, and no one knows that better than the comedian David Spade, who earned his share of enemies in the 1990's skewering celebrities during his Hollywood Minute sketches on NBC's "Saturday Night Live." "There were a lot of agents getting word to my agents," Mr. Spade recalled, "and they were saying stuff like: 'Tell him to watch it. He's making a big mistake."'

title: Ophelia Batters the North Carolina Coast
description: SURF CITY, N.C., Sept. 14 - After stalling at sea for a week, Hurricane Ophelia battered the coast of North Carolina on Wednesday, spawning blinding rains that flooded beach communities and left thousands farther inland without power.

title: Beating Rivals, Microsoft's Xbox 360 Is Expected Nov. 22
description: The Microsoft Corporation plans to announce today at the Tokyo Game Show that it will begin selling the Xbox 360, its new video game console, on Nov. 22.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'House': For Fox, Just What The Doctor Ordered
description: "House" rules. The return on Tuesday of the Fox medical series, in which Dr. House (Hugh Laurie) cured a man on death row (LL Cool J, below, a guest star), drew 15.7 million viewers. That catapulted the network into first place for the night in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers and adults 18 to 49. Preceding "House" on Fox was the series premiere of its crime show "Bones," which also delivered high ratings, with an audience of 10.48 million. On the WB, "Gilmore Girls" began its sixth season -- Luke said yes to Lorelai's marriage proposal (yay), but Lorelai and her daughter Rory still aren't speaking (sob) -- and brought in 6.08 million viewers. And the debut of "Supernatural" retained a large part of that audience: 5.49 million watched the new creepfest. The combination put WB behind only Fox for the night in the 18-to-34 demographic it targets and gave the network its highest 18-to-49 ratings in more than a year. NBC rolled out a premiere, too. The 90-minute return of "The Biggest Loser," the weight loss reality series, attracted 7.76 million viewers and helped NBC place second among 18-to-49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

For Confederate Daughters, Hurricane Was a Battle Cry
description: Mrs. Gregory C. Hoch (Corinne), according to her business card, is vice president general for the United Daughters of the Confederacy. The uppermost pin on her sash bears the name James Thomas Weaver, her great-great-grandfather, a Confederate lieutenant colonel who died before the battle of Murfreesboro. She keeps his dress sword on the wall of her home's solarium, in Montclair, N.J.

title: 4th Union Quits A.F.L.-C.I.O. in a Dispute Over Organizing
description: Deepening the split in organized labor, Unite Here, a union that represents apparel, hotel, casino and restaurant workers, announced yesterday that it was quitting the A.F.L.-C.I.O., becoming the fourth union to do so this summer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Battery Park Official Named
description: James E. Cavanaugh, the chief operating officer of the Battery Park City Authority since 2004, has been named president and chief executive of the authority by its board. He succeeds Timothy S. Carey, who resigned on Monday after six years. Mr. Cavanaugh, 51, a Republican, was the supervisor of Eastchester from 1994 to 2003. At the authority, he has overseen daily operations and guidelines for environmentally responsible development. His new salary is $198,398. Mr. Carey will become a part-time special assistant to the board. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Clemens Pitches Hours After Mother Dies
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 14 - Roger Clemens always had the game face to go along with the fastball, the high-and-tight persona to match the high-and-tight heater.

title: Bankruptcy for 2: Storm Broke The Camel's Back; Delta's Filing Was Not Unexpected, But Northwest Had Hoped to Hold Out
description: Late last month, Northwest's chief executive, Douglas M. Steenland, still thought his airline had a chance to avoid seeking bankruptcy protection.

title: Top Officers Are Said to Ignore Complaint Board's Inquiry
description: High-ranking New York City police officers have ignored requests to appear before the city agency investigating charges of police misconduct during the Republican National Convention, according to both an official with a civil liberties group tracking the complaints and a staff member with the agency.

title: Events Force a Quick Rewrite for a Play About a Flood
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 - Floodwaters engulfed the city. A wooden house, submerged to its rooftop, floated like a buoy. The auto repair shop nearby was barely visible. Some trees and telephone poles poked above the water's rim. And an empty raft filled with debris and salvaged possessions floated around aimlessly.

title: How Conservative Is Judge Roberts?
description: It's not surprising that the Senate hearings for Judge John Roberts Jr. are turning out to be about how conservative he would be as the next chief justice of the United States. But there is a twist. It is the Democrats on the Judiciary Committee who want to make sure that he would be conservative in the true sense: respectful of tradition, and not seeking to impose radical new rules. The key question is whether he would stand by established legal precedents on issues like abortion, civil rights, the environment and the power of Congress, or would seek to push the law in a drastically different direction.

title: A Band Rocking in a Zone All Its Own
description: "Thangyaooh! Thangyaooh! Splendid! Are you feeling good?" Toward the end of the Rolling Stones' concert at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, Mick Jagger did his fascinating preteen girl walk -- on his toes, heels coming down almost as an afterthought -- to sweep fully across the stage one more time. And a particularly strong version of "Jumpin' Jack Flash" motored up, ending the band's 20th show at the Garden since 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFROS, ROMAINE
description: EFROS--Romaine. The Officers, National Board of Directors, professional staff and Chapter Members of American Friends of Magen David Adom-ARMDI note with deep sadness the passing of Romaine Efros, a generous and dedicated member of the Emanuel Cellar Chapter of ARMDI for more than 40 years. She was a loyal and ardent friend of Israel and will be deeply missed by all who knew her and benefited from her generosity and warm heart. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to her family. May the memories of her life be as a blessing to her family and all who knew her. Stuart A. Jackson, Chairman Mark D. Lebow, President Daniel R. Allen, Exec. V.P.

title: Job Rules of Carpenters' Union Encourage Corruption, U.S. Charges
description: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to hold New York City's carpenters' union in contempt for changing the union's job referral system without government approval, arguing that the changes will encourage more corruption.

description: AS if to compensate for summer's end, the fall season reliably brings a cache of fresh ideas for the home. This year black is the new white, folk has gone haute, and fusty English style has developed a sense of humor about itself.

title: The Century's First Genocide
Jets Ask to Extend Lease in New Jersey by 10 Years
description: The Jets yesterday gave their firmest indication yet that they would stay in New Jersey, requesting an extension of their lease at Giants Stadium through 2018 and agreeing to meet the terms for building a new stadium sought by state officials.

title: Support for Bush Continues to Drop as More Question His Leadership Skills, Poll Shows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - A summer of bad news from Iraq, high gasoline prices, economic unease and now the devastation of Hurricane Katrina has left President Bush with overall approval ratings for his job performance and handling of Iraq, foreign policy and the economy at or near the lowest levels of his presidency, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: At Time of Epic Storms, Oil Industry Thinks Anew
description: Around the world, offshore oil and gas platforms are generally built to survive without serious damage a so-called 100-year storm -- a hurricane so powerful that it typically occurs only once every hundred years.

title: India Balks at Confronting Iran, Straining Its Friendship With U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 14 - A few months after the United States and India elevated their relationship to a new level with a broad accord, a fresh irritant has disrupted the friendship -- the Bush administration's insistence that a reluctant India join in the confrontation over Iran's suspected nuclear weapons program.

title: Profit jumps 50% for H.K. developer
Hand-Burnished Loops and Curves, Embellished With Gold
description: Lucile Hyacinthe-Lafarge is a cabinetmaker, decorative painter and art restorer whose hand-carved and gilded pieces were on view at Maison et Objet, the annual design and housewares show in Paris, which ended last week. She was one of several artisans whose work provided a welcome balance to the more rapid-design offerings popular this year. Her studio, called L'Astelle (Old French for atelier, or workshop) is in Annecy, a mountainous lake town near Geneva. There, she hand carves the pieces in oak and uses traditional gilding techniques, which involve the application of a glue made from rabbit skin, then covering the piece with sheets of very thin gold. Shown are a mirror (about $1,045), a console table (about $2,700) and a bench (about $11,000); lastelle.fr or 011-33-4-50-45-55-82. CURRENTS: PARIS -- FURNITURE

title: What the Princess Decrees
description: I LOVE New York, and here's why: At 1 p.m. you can be in an Upper East Side restaurant eating a soy burger and talking about private schools and who's getting divorced and what the best yoga studio is and thinking there is nothing new under the sun, and an hour later find yourself in a Harlem brownstone dressed in bias-cut silk charmeuse translating the following sentence into bad French for two tourists: Ask for Egypt, and tell her that Princess sent you.

description: "Believes," a 30-second television commercial for United States Senator Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic nominee for governor in New Jersey, began running yesterday on cable and network stations in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Use of Attention-Deficit Drugs Is Found to Soar Among Adults
description: The use of drugs to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in younger adults more than doubled from 2000 to 2004, and spending on the drugs in the same age bracket, 20 to 44, more than quadrupled, a major prescription management company is reporting today.

title: Fourth Day of Hearings on the Nomination of Judge Roberts
description: The following is the transcript of the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the nomination of Judge John G. Roberts to the Supreme Court, as transcribed by CQ Transcriptions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: High Katrina Loss For Lloyd's
description: Lloyd's of London expects losses related to Hurricane Katrina to amount to 1.4 billion ($2.55 billion), making it the insurance market's costliest natural catastrophe in the past decade. The three-century-old Lloyd's market, which provides insurance through groups of underwriters specializing in particular risks, said the estimate was provisional. Total claims from Katrina, which damaged oil rigs, flooded New Orleans and left hundreds dead, may reach $60 billion, according to Risk Management Solutions. At that level, claims would exceed those of Hurricane Andrew and the Northridge, Calif., earthquake combined. Lloyd's losses from the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks amounted to about $3.3 billion.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about soaps and lotions for babies misidentified the maker of Kiehl's skin care products. It is L'Oral, not Este Lauder.

title: ESPN Increases Budget in a Deal With Baseball
description: ESPN announced yesterday that it would televise Major League Baseball games through 2013 and expand its rights to carry games on new technologies, including a cellphone that it is expected to start marketing next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEINZEN, BRUCE ROBERT, MD.
description: HEINZEN -- Bruce Robert, MD. Of Plandome, New York. Husband of Clare Heinzen, father of Jerome, Barbara, Thomas and Nancy, died at home 11 September 2005. He was an attending surgeon when North Shore Community Hospital opened in 1953 in Manhasset and continued there in private practice until he retired in 1989. Best remembered as a dedicated teacher and doctor, Bruce Heinzen inspired many with his plain honesty and personal care. A service will be held at home on Saturday, 17 September 2005. Please ring the family for details on 516627-1527. Memorial gifts to Adventures in Learning, High Street, Manhasset 11030, tel: (516) 365-7131.

title: Energy Prices Pushed Inflation Up in August
description: Higher energy prices took a sizeable bite out of consumers' wallets in August as inflation rose and negated the value of wage increases, the government reported today.

title: Other Views: Seattle Times, Daily Star, Kathimerini
ON THE STREET: THEN
description: LABOR Day may have been upon them, but in the summer of 1990 fashion die-hards clung to the faded remnants of the season, whisking around town in breeze-catching, ankle-length skirts that were tiered, whimsically patterned or pleated in the manner of a Grecian nymph. Today their spiritual sisters are just as stubborn, flaunting flounced, multitiered, kaleidoscopically colorful peasant skirts, each a languid reminder of a summer holiday, and a wistful metaphor for hanging on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISLER, SIMON
description: PREISLER--Simon. We mourn the passing of a generous and noble man. His worldly charm and intellect inspired us all. Our sympathy to Baba, Renee, Richard, Lydia, Doug, and his six grandchildren. Karen and Howard Weiss, Harriet Stein, Blanche Weiss and the Children

title: MetroStars Sign Player
description: The MetroStars announced the signing yesterday of Daniel Garipe, a 24-year-old defensive midfielder from Argentina, after a monthlong courtship. Garipe had been training with the MetroStars since mid-August, but the completion of a deal had been delayed because he was unable to obtain a visa.

title: Senate Panel Discusses Need for Central Authority in Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Leading senators and former state and local government officials who have supervised the recovery from natural disasters agreed Wednesday that a single government official with emergency powers should be put in charge of reconstruction efforts after Hurricane Katrina.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Middle East, Asia, Africa, The Americas
description: EUROPE

title: Hopeful Words: On Taking Responsibility
description: When President Bush addresses the country from New Orleans tonight, he will have the opportunity to build on the good beginning he made earlier this week, when he took responsibility for the federal government's failures in responding to Hurricane Katrina. In an administration that has hated to acknowledge that it ever does anything wrong, it was refreshing to hear Mr. Bush freely admit that Katrina demonstrated that there is a question about whether the nation is really prepared to respond to a terrorist attack or another natural disaster. It is only by squarely acknowledging past failure that the country will be able to do better in the future.

title: EU fails to agree on stance for Cyprus question
More Deaths Confirmed in Homes for the Aged
description: A day after Louisiana officials charged the owners of a nursing home in the deaths of 34 patients there, the owners of two other nursing homes confirmed yesterday that an additional 13 patients died in their homes in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. State officials also said they were investigating the deaths of 14 patients at yet another nursing home in New Orleans.

title: At FEMA, Disasters and Politics Go Hand in Hand
description: "AS we are all aware," James Lee Witt told Congress in April 1996, when he was director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, "disasters are very political events."

title: Bridge; Honors Club to Be the Host Of Two Charitable Events
description: Honors Bridge Club will be the host of two charitable events on Sept. 25: a two-session Calcutta event ($250 per pair plus the auction) and a two-session regular duplicate ($150 per pair), playing identical deals, starting at noon and 4:45 p.m., all proceeds going to the Fresh Air Fund. Free food will be served before each session at the club, at 115 East 57th Street in Manhattan. Details are available at (212)230-1230.

title: Faulty Airport Security
description: To the Editor:

title: New Generation of Afghan Voters Is Finding Its Voice
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 11 - Late in the afternoon here the streets are full of young men, pouring out of private classes that teach English and computer skills or that offer the chance to catch up on years of missed schooling during two decades of war. With books under their arms, the young men jump on their bicycles or head home on foot across the dusty roads and parks.

title: Asbestos Fund Bars 9 Doctors
description: Correction Appended

title: Bush Says, 'I Take Responsibility'
description: To the Editor:

title: Padres Are Looking Good, Although Their Record Isn't
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 - Armando Benitez should have had Barry Bonds touch his glove in the ninth inning Wednesday afternoon. Benitez, the San Francisco Giants' closer, could not find the strike zone with a two-run lead, so he could have used some good luck in trying to lock up a storybook sweep of the San Diego Padres.

title: Reader Responses
description: Following are responses to Damon Darlin's "Some Ways to Prepare for the Absolute Worst."

title: Living It Up at Full Volume
description: SOMETIMES it all runs together, the 180 shows, 70 in tents and the rest in showrooms and garages and art galleries and an armory, and the dozens of parties, one in a bowling alley and one in a space that was an infamous sex club not so long ago and one on a penthouse terrace with a pool that Samantha on "Sex and the City" once dived into naked.

title: Court Nominee Says His Record Shows He Is No Ideologue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - Judge John G. Roberts Jr., the prospective chief justice of the United States, tried today to win over wary Senate Democrats who questioned the depth of his commitment to minority rights and to candor.

title: E.P.A. Struggles to Determine Extent of Hazards in Sludge
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The magnitude and geographic sweep of the pollution left by Hurricane Katrina is so enormous that the Environmental Protection Agency is struggling to determine what the worst hazards are, where they are and what can be done about them, the agency's administrator said Wednesday.

title: How to Turn Your Old Laptop Into a Digital Video Recorder
description: Many new multimedia notebooks include built-in television tuner cards and software that let them double as digital video recorders. But you don't have to buy a whole new laptop just to record your favorite shows.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: The Sunni world turned upside down
Charges Are Dismissed in Boating Crash That Killed L.I. Girl
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y., Sept. 14 - A criminal charge of boating while intoxicated was dismissed Wednesday in Suffolk County District Court against a Long Island man who was driving one of the boats involved in an Aug. 17 collision in Great South Bay that claimed the life of Brianna Lieneck, an 11-year-old Deer Park girl.

description: Bringing Linux To a Home PC

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about hurricane damage to a DuPont chemical plant in DeLisle, Miss., misstated the residence of Paul Stewart, who said he was concerned about whether chemicals had escaped. He lives in Bay St. Louis, across the bay from the plant, not across the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULDRINI, FREDERICK P.
description: BULDRINI--Frederick P. of Island Park, NY on September 13, 2005 in his 89th year. Beloved husband of Dolores. Loving father of Frederic F. and George. The family will receive friends Thursday 2-5 & 7-9 PM at the Christopher T. Jordan Funeral Home, 302 Long Beach Road, Island Park, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 9:15 AM at Sacred Heart Church, Island Park, NY. Private cremation will follow.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: College President To Step Down
description: Arthur E. Levine said yesterday that he would step down as president of Teachers College at Columbia University on July 1, after 12 years in the job. When Mr. Levine took office in 1994, the college had run up deficits in 7 of the previous 10 years. He stabilized the college financially, refurbished its aging physical plant and built a new residence hall. Under his leadership, the college recently raised $155 million in a capital drive, and annual giving has risen to $27 million, from $6 million in 1994. Mr. Levine, 57, said he planned to take a sabbatical and then return as a professor. The college plans a national search for his successor. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRISTIN, KAREN (AKA KAREN A. JOHNSON)
description: KRISTIN--Karen (aka Karen A. Johnson). Of New York City. Dancer/choreographer/ teacher. Passed away at home on September 5, 2005. She is survived by mother Phyllis, brothers Ted and Bob, and sister Mary Kay. She will be greatly missed by family, extended family and friends. Memorial service Saturday, October 1, 1:30 PM at Tillman Chapel, 777 U.N. Plaza, at 1st Ave. and 43rd St.

title: Detention of Iraqi Employees Angers Western News Media
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 14 - On April 5, Abdul Ameer Younis Hussein, an Iraqi cameraman for CBS News, was struck in the thigh by an American sniper's bullet while filming the aftermath of a suicide bombing in Mosul. As he recovered in a military hospital, the Americans arrested him. They later said the film in his camera suggested he was working for insurgents.

title: Areas Isolated After Storm Make Do
description: BROOKLYN, Miss., Sept. 14 - Hours after the wind stopped howling but days before outsiders showed up, Amanda Williams had cooked up the 300 pounds of venison that was stored in her deep freezer, scavenged some paper plates from the store across the street and set up a table in her front yard to begin feeding this town just north of Gulfport.

title: Going for a Waterless Dip With Roller Skaters, Bikers and Superstars
description: Scale -- huge, imposing, daunting scale -- is what defines Nomie Lafrance's site-specific performance piece "Agora," and what ultimately undercuts its impact. Still, this hourlong dance experiment and community fiesta generates considerable good will. So much so that it has already been extended to Oct. 1.

title: The German elections: Enough is enough, again
Corrections
description: A brief report in the Observatory column of Science Times on Sept. 6 about a study of the effects of road salt on streams in the Northeast referred incorrectly to those that were found to be about one-quarter as salty as seawater. They are suburban-urban streams, not rural ones.

title: For the Gulf Coast, a Rehabilitation Effort
description: THE National Trust for Historic Preservation plans to announce an initiative today to send damage assessment teams to the Gulf Coast region to survey neighborhoods and report on what can be saved, according to Richard Moe, president of the trust.

title: Trickle-Down Fashion
description: APART from the invasion of celebrity designers and the skyrocketing prices of luxury goods, fashion at the beginning of this decade will be remembered for bringing design to the masses, thanks to the high-minded styling efforts of the likes of Target and H&M, which have upped the ante for discount stores across the country. Several of them decided that Fashion Week, now regarded as a marketing opportunity for all sorts of products not remotely appropriate for the racks of Bergdorf Goodman, was the way to alert customers to the possibility of finding a designer bargain at J. C. Penney or Wal-Mart.

title: 50's Pinup Lives Again at Toronto Film Festival
description: TORONTO, Sept. 14 - The closer the 30th Toronto International Film Festival inches toward its Saturday close, the more difficult it becomes to classify this sprawling, exhausting event. With 256 features from 60 different countries in the program -- including a whopping 109 world premieres -- the festival has become something of an endurance test for attendees. With so many movies on tap, festivalgoers are sometimes forced into making difficult choices, deciding, say, between watching Charlize Theron play a mineworker fighting sexual harassment in Niki Caro's "North Country," or Gretchen Mol frolic in her birthday suit in Mary Harron's "Notorious Bettie Page," a frothy entertainment about the 1950's pinup.

title: Thursday's Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The Judiciary Committee plans to reconvene at 9 a.m. on Thursday to finish questioning Judge John G. Roberts Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASSER, KENNETH J.
description: LASSER -- Kenneth J. Of Scarsdale and Palm Beach, died Tuesday, September 13. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis, his three sons, Larry, Steve and Mike, and their wives, Michelle, Roberta and Ellen, and by his five grandsons, Seth, Ethan, Joe, Jon and Jacob, and by Seth's wife, Jamie. Graveside services will be held Sunday, September 18, at 1 PM at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne.$(6$)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Wielding Ax Shot, Police Say
description: A police officer shot and wounded a 21-year-old man who had used a fire ax to try to hack his way into his family's apartment last night, the police said. The man, identified by his brother as Alfonsa Wilson, was arguing with his mother about a telephone bill in the fourth-floor apartment at 265 Ocean Avenue in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens before he went to the basement and got the ax, the police said. He began hacking at the metal door, breaking a lock. Family members called 911, and when officers arrived, he threatened them with the ax, police officials said. One officer, who was not identified, shot the man once in the stomach. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in stable condition. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 24 about an effort to find the wreck of a Dutch slave ship that broke apart 239 years ago after a revolt by the slaves referred imprecisely to the beach at Struis Bay where archaeologists are searching. While it is on the protrusion of land that is South Africa's southernmost point, it is not the southernmost point; that is Cape Aghulas.

title: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Backs an Anemia Drug
description: A federal advisory panel recommended approval yesterday of Celgene's drug Revlimid, a chemical cousin of thalidomide, as a treatment for a potentially fatal blood disorder.

title: Kentucky Governor Ousts 9 Officials as Scandal Widens
description: Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky demanded the resignation of nine senior state officials yesterday, asked the chairman of the state Republican Party to step down and abolished a constituent service program in response to a widening investigation into patronage in his administration.

title: Arts, Briefly; Louisiana Orchestra Regroups
description: The Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra, based in New Orleans, will play a special benefit concert in Nashville on Oct. 4 at Andrew Jackson Hall in the Tennessee Performing Arts Center. The Nashville Symphony said it would play host -- literally. Nashville players and staff members will put up the Louisiana musicians, who have spread out across the country after fleeing Hurricane Katrina and the flooding. Nashville players will fill in for any Louisiana players who cannot make it. For those who can, American Airlines will fly them in for free. Alan D. Valentine, president and chief executive of the Nashville Symphony, said: "The Nashville Symphony and our entire city has been moved by the heartache and suffering of the people of New Orleans. Reuniting our colleagues at the Louisiana Philharmonic and providing them with a forum to play together again will be an incredibly enriching experience for us all. This performance will certainly transcend all traditional definitions of a benefit concert." The proceeds will go directly to the Louisiana orchestra. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 21 about a video made by a group of peacekeepers that satirizes the American response to the war in Kosovo referred incorrectly to Bob Rivers, who wrote the parody song in 1999. He is a talk show host in Seattle, not a disc jockey.

title: S.I. Yanks Win First in Series
description: Kyle Larsen went 3 for 4 and Jason Stephens allowed one run over five and two-thirds innings last night as the Staten Island Yankees defeated the host Auburn Doubledays, 6-1, in the opening game of the best-of-three title series in the New York-Penn League.

title: In the Quarter, a Pool Serves as Gathering Place, Respite and Bathtub
description: NEW ORLEANS - Behind the closed doors of a courtyard on Burgundy Street, next to a fallen pear tree and a collapsed wall, the famed bon temps of the French Quarter survive in a 30-foot aquamarine oval that looks like a mirage amid Hurricane Katrina's carnage: a swimming pool.

title: Investigative Adventures in Unemployment
description: Bait and Switch The (Futile) Pursuit of the American Dream By Barbara Ehrenreich 237 pages. Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $24.

title: Gordon and Rivera Grind Down Devil Rays
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 14 - A couple of weeks ago, Jorge Posada walked around the Yankees' clubhouse and gave every teammate a T-shirt with a two-word command on the front: Grind It.

title: Militants play police role in portion of Gaza Strip
Mother of Boy Killed at Playland Plans Suit, Saying Ride Lacked Warnings
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 - The mother of a 7-year-old boy who was killed on a boat ride at Playland Amusement Park in August notified Westchester County on Wednesday that she planned to file a lawsuit claiming that the ride at the county-owned park was unsafe and that her son should never have been allowed on it alone.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Baidu Skids On Analyst Ratings
description: Shares of Baidu.com, China's most-used Internet search engine, plunged 28 percent after analysts from two firms that managed the company's initial public offering said the stock was overpriced. The shares, which closed Wednesday at $81.32, have a "fair value" around $27 to $45, Anthony Noto, a Goldman Sachs analyst, wrote in a note to clients. Mr. Noto started coverage of the company with a rating of underperform. Baidu's stock had more than quadrupled since its initial offer Aug. 5 on expectations that it could maintain its lead in China over Google, the world's biggest search engine company and No.2 in China. Competitive pressure and the possibility of copyright infringement and increasing regulation by the Chinese government create risks for Baidu, Mr. Noto wrote. "We are not able to justify the current valuation of the stock, even when evaluating more aggressive scenarios," he wrote. A Piper Jaffray analyst, Safa Rashtchy, also started coverage with an underperform rating, saying the shares would decline to $45 because the current price is "unsustainable."

title: Mothballs Come to Mind
description: AT the conclusion of Fashion Week tomorrow night, when several extravagant events are planned to celebrate the Herculean feat of making it through some 180 runway shows over 10 days, the real partying should be taking place at the European fabric mills that specialize in silk chiffon. From the looks of the many collections that made liberal use of the breezy, gauzy fabric that evokes memories of grandmother's closet, their proverbial ship will be coming in.

title: Enduring Influence of a Tastemaker
description: COLEFAX AND FOWLER, the firm that Nancy Lancaster owned and operated with John Fowler for more than 20 years, is still a highly regarded source for design services and antiques in London (011-44-20-7493-2231). The company offers more than 200 fabrics and 100 wallpaper designs in London and in New York (through Cowtan & Tout, 212-647-6900). Cotton and viscose blends include, left, from top: Kentmere, Tarn and Thirlmere. Curtain and upholstery fabrics include silk Willowherb Stripe, shown banded by Herb Stripe, left; the chair, photographed at the company's main London showroom at 39 Brook Street, is covered in Florentine, a silk velvet. Fabrics start at $125 a yard, and wallpaper starts at $125 a roll (to the trade). An interior design division, Sibyl Colefax & John Fowler, also sells antiques, from small decorative pieces of china ($50) to 18th-century four-poster beds ($60,000). Information on antiques: www.colefaxantiques.com. Information on fabric and wallpaper: www.colefax.com. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Aceh rebels hand over weapons
North Korea Demand on Reactor Creates Standoff at Nuclear Talks
description: BEIJING, Sept. 15 - North Korea stuck doggedly today to its demand that the outside world build it a new nuclear reactor before it dismantles its nuclear weapons, leaving six-nation negotiations here on the verge of collapse.

title: Aides Testify in Assemblyman's Trial
description: Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. personally asked one of his district workers to fax a bill for about $2,500 in campaign expenses to an Albany lobbyist, yet did not follow the usual office channels for reporting that bill to his campaign treasurer, his aides testified yesterday in his political corruption trial.

description: TESHER--Ariel. 20 years old. Beloved daughter of Lynn Epsteen-Tesher and Dr. Martin Tesher on September 13, 2005. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Ariel's memory may be sent to the Pediatric Psychopharmacology Program, Mass. General Hospital Development, 165 Charles River Plaza, #

title: Lawmakers Push for More Data on Heart Devices
description: Two federal lawmakers said yesterday that they planned to increase their scrutiny of how the Food and Drug Administration monitors the safety of critical medical devices like heart defibrillators and pacemakers once they are on the market.

title: Girardi Declines a Chance to Manage Italian Team
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 14 - Joe Girardi, the Yankees' bench coach, recently passed up a chance to gain his first managerial experience. Girardi, a possible candidate to manage the Yankees some day, declined the job leading the Italian team in the World Baseball Classic, the 16-nation tournament in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'KELLY, EUGENE DESMOND II.
description: O'KELLY--Eugene Desmond II. September 10, 2005. Funeral service Saturday, September 17, 2005 at 2 PM at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Eugene O'Kelly Cancer Survivors Fund, Schwab Fund for Charitable Giving, 101 Montgomery Street, San Francisco, CA. 94104.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Ill Woman Released From Detention
description: A terminally ill Bronx woman was temporarily released from detention late Tuesday while an immigration judge decided whether to reopen her deportation case. Today, two City Council members, Bill de Blasio and Kendall Stewart, are expected to introduce a resolution citing the case and urging federal immigration officials not to pursue deportation when it causes extreme hardship to the immigrant, relatives or community members. The woman, Andrea M. Mortlock, 41, a legal permanent resident since 1979 who is in the last stages of AIDS, was ordered deported to her native Jamaica based on a 1987 conviction for selling cocaine. In a petition to the Organization of American States' Inter-American Human Rights Commission, which is reviewing her case, she called deportation "tantamount to a death sentence" because she could not get proper treatment in Jamaica. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

He called it a "constitution for Arabs, Sunni and Shiites, for Kurds, for Chaldeans, Assyrians, Christians and Muslims" - not "Caledonians." (Go to Article)

description: LEVY--Norman F. The Officers and Directors of Konigsberg Wolf & Co., P.C. mourn the loss of Norman F. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNHAUSER, KENNETH R.
description: KORNHAUSER--Kenneth R. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Kenneth R. Kornhauser, a treasured leader whose profound commitment to the Jewish community was evident in his boundless dedication to the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, the Suffolk Association for Jewish Educational Services, and the Suffolk Y Jewish Community Center. Kenneth's efforts strengthened our ability to serve those in need, making an indelible impact on millions of lives. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Ann; his children: Craig; Evan, and his wife, Lindsay; his father, Martin; his sister, Janet, and her husband, Harvey Fine; his parents-inlaw, Faye and Joseph Morris; and the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.$(6$)

title: Corrections
description: Excerpts by CQ Transcriptions yesterday from the confirmation hearings for Judge John G. Roberts Jr. misstated a word in a comment by Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, who questioned the judge about his work on extending the Voting Rights Act during the Reagan administration. In referring to Congress's amendment of the act, Senator Feingold spoke of reinstating a discrimination standard to prevent "dilution" of votes, particularly those of minority voters -- not "delusion" of votes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTOW, MIRIAM FURST
description: OSTOW--Miriam Furst. 85, September 14, 2005. Wife of Mortimer, mother of Robin, Jerry, Abigail and Rachel. Mother-in-law of Carmen, Arthur and Brian. Grandmother of Natascha, Rachel, Todd, Micol, Naomi, Joseph, David, Nurit, Sarah, Ilana, Micah and Hannah. Associate Director of Conservation of Human Resources, Columbia University for 35 years. President of Histadruth Ivrith. Member of Board of Overseers, List College, Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Founder of the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale. Funeral services Friday 11 AM at Plaza Community Chapel, 91 Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva at home Saturday evening through Wednesday evening. Donations: Jewish Theological Seminary.$(6$)

title: NASA Facility in the Region Is Spared Grave Storm Damage
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 - Beyond the plant gates, many homes and commercial buildings have been reduced to confetti, matchsticks and mud. But to drive through the guarded gates of NASA's 832-acre Michoud Assembly Facility here is to enter a more normal world -- a place that simply went through a bad storm.

title: Mayor Plans to Reopen Parts of New Orleans by Weekend
description: New Orleans "will breathe again," beginning this weekend.

title: Nest Egg or One-Armed Bandit?
description: TO look at them now, Warren and Kimlyn Preis appear to have hit the real estate jackpot. They paid $425,000 for their current house in Chicago in 1998, and today, Mr. Preis said, it is worth more than double that.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about planned events that were interrupted by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, misidentified the university attended by a woman with the screen name Kaytay, who met a young man while waiting for her first class and described the encounter on her Web site. It was the University of Michigan, not New York University.

title: Fresh-Cut Wood With a Mind of Its Own
description: Ernst Gamperl is an artist with a studio on Lake Garda in Vesio di Tremosine, Italy. He uses a process called greenwood turning, using unseasoned wood, to create his vases and vessels. He turns oak and sycamore from a forest near his former workshop in Munich, using a lathe and chisels to create vessels with walls only an eighth of an inch thick. They change shape as the wood dries, shrinking more in some areas than in others, making the outcome somewhat unpredictable. "I like to play with the possibilities that the wood offers," Mr. Gamperl said. The pieces, $1,200 to $2,000, include urns about two feet tall, below left, and columnal vases about three feet tall, below right in background. The collection will be available in mid-October in Coral Gables, Fla., at Luminaire, 2331 Ponce de Leon Boulevard, (800)645-7250 or luminaire.com. CURRENTS: PARIS -- CARVING

title: Playoffs First, Future Second to Cashman
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 14 - The most pressing question around the Yankees is whether the team will make the playoffs. The second biggest source of intrigue might be whether Brian Cashman wants to remain the general manager.

title: Flights of Imagination
description: IRVINE, Calif. - Five F-14 fighter planes from the VF-103 Jolly Rogers carve through the sky over Nellis Air Force Base. "Single left-hand roll," calls the flight leader, Frank Ferrante, better known as Trapdoor. On his cue, the planes peel off in unison, barrel-rolling over the desert.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Settlement for Slain Woman
description: The Tacoma City Council on Tuesday unanimously approved a $12 million settlement in a wrongful-death suit filed by the family of a woman who was killed by her police chief husband in April 2003. The city will pay $1 million; the rest will come from insurance, the city said. The Council also agreed to name the new Pierce County domestic violence center after the slain woman, Crystal Brame, who was shot and killed by her estranged husband, David, before he committed suicide in front of their two children. David Carrillo Pealoza (NYT)

title: Out of the Chase, Gordon and Earnhardt Make Changes
description: Jeff Gordon and Dale Earnhardt Jr., two of the most popular drivers in Nascar, are undergoing major changes to their race teams after failing to make the field for the coming Chase for the Nextel Cup.

title: Deal for Ukraine Company Renews Charges of Abuse
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Sept. 14 - In the last weeks of Leonid D. Kuchma's scandal-tarred presidency, an American company reached an agreement with his government to take control of a state-owned chemical factory in eastern Ukraine under terms that have been criticized as secretive and suspiciously generous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEMETRIOU, PETER T.
description: DEMETRIOU--Peter T. Of Lloyd Harbor on September 11 at age 55. Survived by wife Irene, sons Theodore, Michael & daughter Chrisanthi, mother Joanna Demetriou & sister Evan De Francesco. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, in-laws and friends. President of Peter Demetriou & Sons, Inc. and ex-MFH of Smithtown Hunt. Visiting hours September 15, 2-9PM at Fairchilds, 15-70 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. 516-627-2000.

title: Downtown and Midtown

Inside the snug boutique, top, you can slide your feet into designs by Charles Jourdan, Yves Saint Laurent, Stuart Weitzman and Andrew Geller in sizes 5 to 11. At 85 Hester Street, between Orchard and Allen, (917)250-3268.

title: U.S. airlines file for bankruptcy protection
Elaine Stritch, at 80, Tries Something New
description: Being superhuman is really the opposite of being immortal. For a performer, it means embodying a magnified representation of what it is to be alive and kicking in all its messy Brobdingnagian reality. It is like being Elaine Stritch standing up in front of a packed house at the Cafe Carlyle and urging everyone present to join her in repeating the dreaded word "aging."

title: A Maori-Modern Fusion Takes a New York Stage
description: Black Grace made a largely unheralded United States debut in August 2004. Based in Auckland, New Zealand, the company was unknown to most Americans. But by the end of a weeklong engagement at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshires, Black Grace was playing to vociferously enthusiastic, soldout houses. Now it is about to take on New York City, with a season that opens tomorrow at the New Victory Theater.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "People here are used to doing for themselves. They didn't wait for FEMA or the parish to do it for them."

title: It's Bluetooth for the Ears: A Hearing Aid Takes Calls
description: For hearing-aid users, digital cellphones have not been a big advance; they create electronic interactions that often lead to irritating buzzing and feedback. The ELI hearing aid from Starkey Laboratories (starkey.com) uses the Bluetooth wireless technology now included with many cellphones to avoid interference by, in effect, moving the telephone into the hearing aid.

title: INSIDE
description: President's Job Approval Ratings Hit a Low Point President Bush's job approval ratings are suffering, a New York Times/CBS News Poll found. Just half of respondents said they approved of the president's handling of terrorism, and 6 in 10 said Mr. Bush did not share their priorities for the country. Over all, 41 percent of respondents approved of Mr. Bush's performance in office, while 53 percent disapproved. Those figures are equal to the worst ratings Mr. Bush has ever received.

title: Times Co. Buys TV Station
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy KAUT-TV in Oklahoma City from Viacom. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: More From the Verizon Files
description: Today's mailbag brought even more feedback from my rant last week about Verizon's excruciating 12-second outgoing voicemail message, which I calculated earns the company over $1 million a year:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trump Loses A Bid To Block Sale
description: Justice Richard B. Lowe III of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday rejected Donald J. Trump's request for a preliminary injunction against his Hong Kong partners, whom he has accused of intentionally selling the Trump Place and Riverside South development on the West Side for half their true value. While the ruling does not end his claims against his partners, it permits them to collect the proceeds from selling the property, 77 acres between 59th and 72nd Streets. The partners, a consortium of Chinese investors, sold the development this year to Extell Development Company and the Carlyle Group for $1.76 billion. Mr. Trump, whose share of the sale is 30 percent, had sought to prevent his partners from investing the proceeds in another real estate project. Mr. Trump's lawyer, Marc Kasowitz, said he was disappointed by the ruling. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Turmeric in the Freezer
description: Turmeric in the Freezer

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Ex-Schools Official Charged
description: A former Long Island school board president was charged yesterday with grand larceny. Charles Reinhardt, 63, was charged with double-billing $1,423.77 for trip expenses for an education conference in 2003, according to the Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon. Mr. Dillon said Mr. Reinhardt charged the expenses to the Bellmore-Merrick Central High School District, where he was the board president, and also to the North Bellmore Union Free School District, where he was a board member. He repaid the money after investigators questioned him about the reimbursements, and he no longer serves on either board. Mr. Reinhardt was released after his arraignment in Nassau's First District Court in Hempstead, said his lawyer, Stephen P. Scaring. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Making the Desert Bloom With Architecture
description: In a powerful reminder that big-name architects have become big business, the casino operator MGM Mirage has enlisted a celebrity roster -- Rafael Violy, Lord Norman Foster, James KM Cheng, Cesar Pelli, Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates -- to design various parts of a $5 billion, 66-acre development in the heart of Las Vegas.

title: Massachusetts Rejects Bill to Eliminate Gay Marriage
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 - In a sign that the legalization of same-sex marriage has changed the political landscape in Massachusetts, the legislature soundly defeated a proposed constitutional amendment on Wednesday to ban gay marriage and create civil unions, an amendment that lawmakers gave preliminary approval to in a raucous constitutional convention last year.

title: Her Best Friend Was a Pig, Till a Grifter Came to Town
description: One of the bothersome aspects of digital video, particularly when used in fiction films, is its encouragement of a vrit shooting style that some filmmakers believe makes their fictions more "real." Too often, though, this results in messy, undisciplined shots from weird angles and scenes that wobble as if captured from atop a mound of Jell-O. And just because you have the ability to shoot a scene from behind your protagonist's left earlobe -- as happens in "Piggie" -- doesn't mean that's the best way to make your narrative resonate.

title: Northwest, Southwest, South and Washington
description: NORTHWEST

title: Bush Says, 'I Take Responsibility'
description: To the Editor:

title: Protestants Say Anger and Alienation Are Fueling Riots in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 14 - Every morning this week, the broken glass and burned-out cars have quickly disappeared from the streets here after the previous night's rioting by Protestant mobs.

title: Northwest's Timing Made U.S. an Unsecured Creditor
description: By filing for bankruptcy yesterday, Northwest Airlines expects to make the federal government an unsecured creditor for a $65 million contribution to its pension fund that was coming due today. Had Northwest delayed the filing by even one more day, the government would have had a stronger claim on the money.

title: To Stand Out in a Crowd: Don't Shout (Mick Excepted)
description: The American spring collections have not been strong on subtlety. It is as though designers fear the unexpected shading, the perfectly placed seam. But on Tuesday in Chelsea, far from the noise of the tents in Bryant Park, Narciso Rodriguez took a brilliant risk. He spoke in a whisper.

title: Freewheeling on the New Lightweight Fold-Ups
description: FOLDING bicycles, light enough to carry on trains or planes and small enough to store in tiny spaces, have long been popular with commuters. But as their quality has improved, some cyclists are shelving their standard road bikes and using folders for morning rides and weekend cruises. They're also packing them into hard-shell suitcases (avoiding the airlines' roughly $80 "bike fee") to take along on business or family trips.

title: Newell to Cut 5,000 Jobs and Close Plants in Restructuring
description: Newell Rubbermaid, which makes some of the country's best-known consumer products, said today that it would cut 5,000 jobs and close a third of its 80 manufacturing plants by 2009 in an effort to focus on its most profitable and promising items.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Unipol Bid For Bank Advances
description: Compagnia Assicuratrice Unipol's bid for Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Italy's sixth-largest lender, was approved by Italy's market regulator, Consob, clearing the main hurdle to completing the purchase. Unipol's 5 billion euro ($6 billion) offer document will be sent to Banca Nazionale and made public Thursday, Unipol said in a statement to the stock exchange. The bid is still subject to approval by the Bank of Italy and by the Italian insurance regulator, Isvap. "The probability that the takeover will be approved by the other authorities is quite high," said Patrizio Pazzaglia, an investment director at Bank Insinger de Beaufort, which oversees about $330 million in assets. Unipol's takeover of Banca Nazionale would create Italy's fourth-biggest financial services company. The bid blocked a rival offer by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain.

title: Monarchs Follow Leader to Victory in Finals Opener
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn., Sept. 14 - The Sacramento Monarchs spent Wednesday morning practicing how to defend the free-flowing offense that the Connecticut Sun played so effectively during the regular season.

title: On a Border in Crisis, There's No Bolting a Busy Gate
description: JOSEFA ORTIZ DE DOMNGUEZ, Mexico - If it were up to Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, this tiny village, known more commonly as Las Chepas, would be bulldozed to the ground.

title: Global Poverty, Anemic Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Highs and Lows for Fields, but No Regrets
description: The party got off to a rocky start.

title: Indie-Rock Festival Tries to Keep Up
description: New York's rock clubs are being taken over this week by by what, exactly?

title: Buyers look to clean up after storm
Turning Mere Beauties Into Glossy Goddesses
description: JOSEPHINE RHODIN, a 16-year-old model from Sweden, looked like just another fresh-faced Scandinavian blonde until she arrived Sunday night at the TriBeCa showroom of Alice Temperley, a British fashion designer making her New York debut this week. Then Charlotte Tilbury, a British makeup artist with flame-red hair and a passionate personality to match, set about changing this teenager's style.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about chain stores that allow free overnight parking for recreational vehicles included one company erroneously. Costco says it does not allow overnight parking in its lots.

title: Drinking Glasses for Flowers, From the Human Pantry
description: Vases made of stacked shot glasses and tumblers, some dating to the 1920's, are the work of Laurence Brabant, a glass artist in Paris. Ms. Brabant started out as a textile designer, but after displaying her stretched-latex artwork at "Skin Tight," an exhibition in New York in 1999, she said, she decided to shift her attention from art to craft. "I wanted to create a real project, not an art piece," she said. "I am attracted to transparency and fragility; glass made sense as a medium." Ms. Brabant uses a special adhesive that is activated by ultraviolet light and drills through the bottoms of the glasses to give the vases depth. They are one of a kind, about six to eight inches tall, and can be ordered from the artist at about $25 to $50; her e-mail address is laurence.brabant@free.fr. CURRENTS: PARIS -- CRAFTS

title: A craze forDisney chic sweeps Hong Kong
Father's Ideals Forged Life in East for German Candidate
description: TEMPLIN, Germany - Half a century ago, the Rev. Horst Kasner made an extraordinary decision: He packed up his young family and moved from democratically governed Hamburg, West Germany, to this small town in the Brandenburg countryside, then the heart of Communist East Germany.

title: IPod's Law: The Impossible Is Possible
description: APPLE says its iPod music player and iTunes music store have 74 and 85 percent of their worldwide markets. But according to Gene Munster, a Piper Jaffray analyst, the end is near. "Nobody can sustain an 80 percent market share in a consumer electronics business for more than two or three years," Mr. Munster told CNN. "It's pretty much impossible."

title: The First Lady of English Country Style
description: WITH its shocking-pink lettering and dramatically cropped cover photograph of a youthful, tiara-topped woman in going-to-see-the-king garb, "Nancy Lancaster: English Country House Style" by Martin Wood, is arguably the best-looking book to hit the coffee table since "Bright Young Things" was published in 2000.

title: At Frankfurt Auto Show, a Reluctant Embrace of Hybrids
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 14 - This was the week that Europe's reluctant auto industry bowed to the popularity of hybrid technology, with a skein of announcements by leading German carmakers that they would follow Toyota's lead in developing these dual gasoline-electric engines.

title: Family Name in Brooklyn Loses Clout With Defeat
description: In Brooklyn, a borough with no shortage of political dynasties, the Boyland family name has been one of the most enduring. But in Tuesday's primary election, the family's electoral record suffered a rare blemish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALIS, LEONARD, M.D.
description: MALIS--Leonard, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of an outstanding colleague, surgeon, and teacher. Dr. Malis devoted four decades of expertise and service to the institution. He served as Chairman of the Department of Neurosurgery for 20 years. In the 1960's, he performed the first micro-neurosurgical procedure and pioneered the first superficial temporal middle cerebral bypass procedure. He also taught the first micro - neurosurgical course in the United States. His historical clinical achievements will continue in the many lives he touched. Dr. Malis will be remembered for his brilliant talent and innovation in the field of Neurosurgery. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Michael T. Harris, MD, President Vicki Lopachin, MD, Vice President Amy J. Weinstein, Administrator$(6$)

title: Paul Kellogg to Quit as Head of City Opera
description: Paul Kellogg said yesterday that he would retire as general and artistic director of the New York City Opera at the end of next season, in 2007, citing his age and the burdens of trying to attract new funds and new audiences.

title: Proof of salt in ancient China
North Korea Sets New Demand for Ending Arms Program: Money to Buy a Civilian Reactor
description: BEIJING, Sept. 14 - North Korea demanded on Wednesday that the United States and other nations give it money to build a new light-water nuclear reactor before it will end its nuclear weapons program, a condition that appeared to undermine prospects for a breakthrough in the talks here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUCKER, ISIDORE R.
description: TUCKER--Isidore R. Devoted husband of Ray May. Loving father of Lenore, Janine, and Abby. Cherished grandfather of Elliot, Alexander, Robin, Jason, and Simon. Beloved brother of Anna and Jack. Dear uncle to his nieces and nephews. A wise and respected attorney, a kind and generous friend to many, and a true gentleman. Services Thursday September 15, 2005, 11:30AM at The "RiversideNassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: Can famous mooncakes go green?
World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Serbian War Crimes Suspect Surrenders
description: A Serb accused of burning alive up to 140 Muslim civilians during the 1992-95 civil war is in police custody after five years on the run, Bosnian Serb police officials said. The man, Sredoje Lukic, a former member of White Eagles, a paramilitary group, is to be transferred to the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague, the police said. His cousin Milan Lukic, who is jointly charged with taking part in some of the same killings, is in prison in Argentina, awaiting extradition to the Netherlands. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Expecting Trouble: The Book They Love to Hate
description: WHEN newly pregnant women visit Brigham Obstretrics and Gynecology, a practice affiliated with Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, they are handed a sheaf of primers on prenatal tests, morning sickness and the like. The tone is calm and brisk, but a page of recommended books carries a warning: "*WE * DO * NOT * RECOMMEND * 'What to Expect When You're Expecting."'

description: Q. I'd like to trade my miniblinds for curtains. What's fresh and not too expensive?

description: SMITH--Irving. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Irving Smith, associated with The Times from January 1947 until retiring in May 1979.

description: Arlen Specter -- Welcome to Day 3 of the confirmation hearings of John Roberts. I'd like to take this opportunity to remind the nation of what a wonderful job I'm doing chairing this committee, and I'd like to let the ranking member tell me so.

title: John H. Slade, 97, an Institution at the New York Stock Exchange, Dies
description: John H. Slade, a former star athlete in Germany who fled the country in the 1930's and over the next seven decades established a career as a prominent investment banker on Wall Street, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97 and was believed to be the oldest active member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Times Names Survey Editor
description: Janet Elder, the deputy editor of The Times's news surveys department, was appointed the newspaper's editor of news surveys and election analysis on Tuesday.

title: Lehman Brothers Earnings Surged 74% in Quarter
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings said yesterday that third-quarter profit surged 74 percent to a record, beating analysts' estimates, as revenue from equity underwriting and trading almost doubled.
