title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERN, MARVIN
description: KERN--Marvin. The Trustees and staff of the Riverdale Y mourn the loss of our former treasurer, longtime trustee, and esteemed advisor. Marvin was a "mensch". We will miss his devotion to our agency. May his wife, Florence, and children Donald and Sharon be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. January Akselrad, President Judy Kaufthal, Chair Simon Jaffe, Exec. Dir.

title: In Surrogate Races, 1 Win, 1 Recount
description: Kristin Booth Glen, a former dean of the City University School of Law, won the Democratic Party primary on Tuesday night for the powerful if little-known post of Manhattan surrogate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERRIN, ILENE (NEE WOLBERG)
description: FERRIN--Ilene (nee Wolberg). Loving, devoted and adored wife of David, sharing 35 years of marriage and sharing one another's hearts. Sister-in-law of Marie Victor and Norma Fernandez. Loving daughter of Sylvia and Henry (deceased), and sister of Phil (deceased). Aunt to Richard and Jeffrey. Served for ten years as co-President of the Long Island Chapter of the American Liver Foundation. Her life was an extraordinary example of love, grace, dignity and resiliency. She was cherished by all who knew her. She graced the lives of so many, and left us all too soon. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to TRIO (Transplant Recipient International Organization), Manhattan Chapter, PO Box 122, Throgs Neck Station, Bronx, NY 10465 or to LILAC (Long Island League to Abolish Cancer), C/O Elly Rosen, 11 Cedar Drive South, Old Bethpage, New York 11804. Services today, 12 Noon, at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Two Airlines, Delta and Northwest, File for Bankruptcy Court Protection Northwest, the nation's fifth-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection, a step taken simultaneously by Delta Air Lines, the country's third-largest carrier. The twin filings -- whose coincidence was not planned, the airlines' chief executives said -- mean that half the seats on flights in the United States are offered by airlines operating under court protection. [Page C1.]

title: With Government on TV, Citizens Play Their Parts
description: THE televisions -- the sound turned off, the closed captioning struggling to get "stare decisis" spelled properly -- hung over the prospective jurors inside State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The screens carried the images of serious United States senators and a confident Judge John G. Roberts Jr. discussing the future of the country's highest court.

title: For Zac Posen, a Refuge From the Runway
description: ZAC POSEN, who will show his spring line of women's day and evening wear tonight at Bryant Park, is a quintessential child of fast-lane New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KINGMAN, ELEANORA BLOOD
description: KINGMAN--Eleanora Blood, of Millburn, NJ, wife of the late Barclay A. Kingman, mother of the Rev. Perry A. Kingman, Elizabeth K. Costello and Daniel R. Kingman. Also survived by six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Stephen's Church, 119 Main St., Millburn, NJ on Friday, September 16, 11AM, where a Rite of Christian Burial will be offered. For info contact: The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, Maplewood, New Jersey.

title: A Queen of Pop Is Ready for Roseland, but Not to Sing
description: ON Monday, with her spring 2006 fashion show just four days away, Gwen Stefani careered around her showroom in downtown Manhattan like a wayward billiard ball. One minute she was instructing her patternmaker where the ruffles should go on a chiffon evening dress; the next, listening intently with Zaldy, her head designer, to a few bars of music she had written for the show. Then at last she peered over the shoulder of Andrea Lieberman, her creative director and longtime stylist. Ms. Lieberman was making 11th-hour adjustments to a willowy and pleasingly disjunctive ensemble, composed of a wisteria-patterned chiffon dress, a snug cardigan printed with a chain-link design and a gnarly-looking knitted Rastafarian cap.

title: Voters Want Nominee's Say on Major Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Americans say that senators voting on Supreme Court nominees should consider the candidates' positions on issues like affirmative action and abortion before voting on whether they should be confirmed, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: U.S. forces reduced on Gulf Coast
Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Stones Back With a 'Bang'
description: The Rolling Stones entered this week's Billboard chart at No. 3, selling 129,000 copies of "A Bigger Bang" (Virgin), according to Nielsen SoundScan. The band, performing tonight at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., has seen 44 of its releases make the Billboard 200, with the last 23 reaching the Top 5. Kanye West remains at No. 1 with "Late Registration" (Roc-A -Fella/Def Jam), which includes the hit "Gold Digger," currently No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart. Jumping an impressive 33 positions to No. 2 is 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Shady/Aftermath/Interscope), reissued this week as a combination CD/DVD, while the Black Eyed Peas' "Monkey Business" (A&M/Interscope) moved up two slots to No. 4, and "The Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/IDJMG) by Mariah Carey stayed solid at No. 5. Returning to the Top 10 were Green Day's "American Idiot" (Reprise/Warner Bros.) at No. 8, and Young Jeezy's "Let's Get It: Thug Motivation 101" (Corporate Thugs/Def Jam/IDJMG) at No. 10. GRANT JAMES VARJAS

title: That Finely Engraved Personal Touch
description: THE other day our mailman delivered a postcard from Yellowstone, a thank you note for a birthday present and four billion catalogs, bills and credit card offers. Guess which we read first?

title: BROWN LEADS IN WHITE PLAINS
description: Mark Brown, a former two-time New York State Open titlist, registered a five-under-par 66 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead in the Met P.G.A. Championship at Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Bernie Beglane

title: The Saints Are Now America's Team
description: AS the Saints, running hand in hand, were loudly cheered during the introductions last Sunday at their season opener in Charlotte, N.C., one fan held up a sign: "New Orleans, We Love You -- 363 Days a Year."

title: New Nightlife in the 16th Arrondissement
description: The usually sleepy 16th arrondissement has a new boutique hotel, Htel Sezz, with interior design by Christophe Pillet, who also designed the furniture. (Unica Home has a version of the Meridiana desk chair, on left; $385 at unicahome.com.) He put the bed in the middle of the room with a desk doubling as a headboard (and translucent vaselike desk lamps doubling as reading lights) and drawers tucked under the mattress -- like a deluxe camp site, said the owner, Shah Kalaidjian. The 27 rooms range from a tiny, Parisian-style 200 square feet to twice that size (about $310 to $740). Amenities include flat-screen televisions, WiFi access and marble bathrooms (behind glass walls for a voyeuristic touch). A Champagne bar is in the lobby. Htel Sezz is at 6 Avenue Frmiet, 011-331-56-75-26-26 or hotelsezz.com. CURRENTS: PARIS -- HOTELS

title: City Seems Locked Into Holding a Runoff Election to Which No One Will Come
description: If New York City holds an election, and nobody actually votes in it, will the election actually occur?

title: Judge Rules Reciting Pledge in Schools Is Unconstitutional
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 - A federal judge in Sacramento ruled Wednesday that reciting the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools was an unconstitutional endorsement of religion, once again igniting a firestorm over the appropriateness of the pledge's reference to "under God."

title: State Senator Captures the Democratic Nomination for Mayor
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 14 - A state senator trying to become the first African-American mayor of this city won his party's primary on Tuesday, setting up a general election race between two veteran politicians vying for a chance to reverse the region's long decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HESS, DANIEL
description: HESS--Daniel, died on September 14 of Lung Cancer. Best friend and husband for 48 years of Susanne Hess. Extraordinary father of Debra Hess and Linda Van Kesteren. Amazing Appa to Alexa, Morgan and Nicolette. Brother of Betty Shain-Kovenetsky. Father-in-law of Rene Van Kesteren. The world is a much sadder place without him. Funeral services Friday, 1 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Donations in Danny's memory may be made to the Mount Sinai Hospital or the Lung Cancer Alliance, 888 16th St, NW, Suite 800, Washington, DC 20006.$(6$)

description: How to explain what iZ is? It's a crab-eyed, three-legged robotic thing that its makers hope will catch on as a kind of pet rock that actually rocks.

title: Bush to Focus on Vision for Reconstruction in Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - President Bush is to pledge in an address to the nation from New Orleans on Thursday night that the federal government will provide housing assistance to victims of Hurricane Katrina and also help reimburse the states for costs they have absorbed in taking in evacuees, a White House official said Wednesday.

title: The Lighter Side of Taxidermy
description: Animals dominated last week at the annual French design show Maison et Objet, with birds and trophy heads making more than a few appearances. Some pieces evoked a luxury hunting lodge; others were send-ups of the clichs of taxidermy. A porcelain parrot, above, about three feet tall ($14,000), is from Meissen, the German company. It was originally produced in the 1750's; the one shown is from a limited 2001 edition. Along with other Meissen pieces, it is available in Williamsburg, Va., at Binns of Williamsburg, 435 Duke of Gloucester Street, (757)229-3391. A stylized wooden moose head ($299), above center, is from Vlaemsch, a Belgian company, and is by Augustin Scott de Martinville, a Swiss designer, who said he "wanted something light to stress the heavy drama that is usually associated with the killing of an animal and the stuffing of its head"; it is available from gnr8.biz. Console tables with a canine profile, called Sultans ($225 each), left, are made with kraft paper and resin laminate by Ibride and designed by Rachel and Benot Convers. The tables will be in Hollywood next month, at Lost and Found, 6320 Yucca Street, (323)856-5872. Sock puppet-like animal heads ($310 to $500), above right, are by Anne-Valrie Dupond for Edgar le Marchand d'Art, a Paris gallery. The figures, made of found textiles, are hand sewn and mounted on corrugated paper shields. They may be ordered from the gallery by e-mail: edgar@edgarlemarchanddart.com. CURRENTS: PARIS -- DESIGN

title: Robinson's Heart (and Soul) Belong to the Devils
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 14 - Larry Robinson is back as the coach of the Devils, but two players who were the cornerstones of their three Stanley Cup championships -- Scott Stevens and Scott Niedermayer -- are gone. As goaltender Martin Brodeur put it Wednesday, this season is the start of a new era.

title: Artists Defying Labels Just by Speaking About Art
description: "Modern art is a gift," the artist Matthew Ritchie says in "Art:21," PBS's forum for artists of the 21st century. "Take it or leave it." Obviously many of these visionaries have been hard at work for more than the last five years. Still, their recent manipulations of ink and glass and gouache and, lately, pixels amount to a new frontier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHINDLER, FRANYO (MARGA V.)
description: SCHINDLER--Franyo (Marga V.), of Manhattan, died peacefully at home on Monday, September 12. A painter who grew up in Hamburg, Germany, and fled to New York in 1938, where she met her late husband, the art collector Gustave Schindler. She is survived by her two daughters, Vivian Teich and Nicole Jeffords; her two sons-in-law, Dr. Morton Teich and George Jeffords; and her grandchildren, Karina Stern, David Sonnenberg, Marco Sonnenberg, Jofka Forman-Hague, Aaron Teich, Alyson Teich, Gabriella Jeffords, and Julian Jeffords, as well as nine greatgrandchildren, Max, Jakob, Maya, Noah, Ella, Rachael, Hannah, Tovi and Elian, and her loyal caregiver, Inez Richards. Services today, September 15, 6:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a hurricane relief fund of your choice.

title: Buying abroad: Learning to make the numbers work
Commission Criticizes Storm Response
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The members of the 9/11 commission criticized the Bush administration and Congress on Wednesday for "minimal progress" in enacting many of the panel's year-old recommendations to bolster domestic security agencies and their ability to respond to terrorist attacks and natural disasters like Hurricane Katrina.

title: For Passengers, a Weary Feeling of Bankruptcy Fatigue
description: Air travelers reacted to yesterday's bankruptcy filings by Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines the same way they greeted earlier decisions by United Airlines and US Airways to seek Chapter 11 protection: with resignation.

title: Gillette Is Betting That Men Want an Even Closer Shave
description: LET regulators worry whether Gillette's proposed merger with Procter & Gamble poses antitrust problems. Let investors worry about how that merger will affect the fused companies' stocks. The people at Gillette have a far more immediate challenge: persuading men that they need to buy yet another new shaving system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERIZA, SUZANNE MARY
description: HERIZA--Suzanne Mary. May 3, 1962--September 14, 2005. A long time resident of New York City and born and raised in Denver, CO, Suzanne passed away after a long fight with breast cancer at her family home in Denver surrounded by friends and family. Survived by her loving family: mother, Sharon Heriza; father Bob Heriza (Judy); brothers Brian (Kimberly), Jeff (Jacqueline, Kristin, Robert) and Chris (Stacy); grandmother Mary Heriza and many aunts, uncles and cousins. A celebration of her life will be held on Friday, at 4:00 PM in Washington Park, Colorado. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Metro Denver or Gilda's Club in NYC.

title: U.S. and European Reluctance to Cut Farm Subsidies Weighs on Trade Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - With three months left before a crucial deadline in global talks to reduce trade barriers, top negotiators for the United States and the European Union were still far apart on Wednesday on reducing the elaborate protections for their own farmers.

title: A Glass Jaw Can Be a Matter of Heart
description: Correction Appended

title: Murder Case Called a Tale of 3 Worlds
description: Correction Appended

title: Where Musical Refugees Can Thicken the Gumbo
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Sept. 10 - The rich musical culture of New Orleans, where so much of American music finds its taproot in the African-inspired sounds of jazz, blues and rock, has been tossed to the four winds. Some musicians, many of whom fled Hurricane Katrina without so much as their instruments, have headed west to Austin, Tex., or Los Angeles, others have gone north to Chicago, New York or Atlanta.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union City: Toddler Is Hit By Car And Dies
description: A 15-month-old girl was killed yesterday afternoon and her nanny seriously injured when the nanny pushed the girl's stroller out from between two cars stopped at an entrance to the Bergen Turnpike and a passing car struck it, the Union City police said. The girl, Katherine Mercado Mosquera, was pronounced dead at the scene, and the nanny, Grace Beliz, 65, was taken to Jersey City Medical Center, where she was in serious condition, Detective Sgt. Nichelle Luster said. The driver of the car that hit the stroller, Alejandro Rodriguez, was not charged with any wrongdoing. Sergeant Luster said officers were investigating the accident. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a power failure in parts of Los Angeles used an incorrect given name in some copies for the mayor, who said that most of the city quickly returned to normal. He is Antonio R. Villaraigosa, not Anthony.

description: EUROPE

title: The real letdown; Lackluster leadership
Paid Notice: Deaths   ZWEIG, HARRIET
description: ZWEIG--Harriet. On September 11, heart and soul of husband Sol, married for 59 years. Beloved mother to Peter and his wife Linda (who became a daughter). She was exceptionally proud of her lovely accomplished granddaughters Julie and Lea. As a teacher in New York for 35 years she was unbelievably loved by both pupils and parents. Memorial service in the Pines of Boca Lago Country Club, Florida on Friday, September 16 at 11 AM.

title: Hopeful Words: On Helping the Poor
description: Let's face it: most Americans wouldn't know a Millennium Development Goal, a Monterrey Consensus or a Doha round if all three jumped out and hit them in the head. But those phrases have life-or-death importance to more than two billion people around the world who survive on barely anything. And yesterday at the United Nations, President Bush used them in front of the world.

title: Reports Detail Elements That Turned Fires Into Catastrophes
description: As flames enveloped the Bronx apartment, whipping around the room where Lt. Curtis Meyran stood with his men on a cold, windy Sunday morning in January, the lieutenant seemed not to realize the level of danger. A voice on his radio asked if the flames had reached him; he answered that there had been a "slight extension" -- meaning that the fire had grown, and gotten closer, but not by much.

title: Caution on Turkey
Texas Executes Woman
description: Frances Newton, convicted of murdering her husband and their two children in 1987, was executed last night in Huntsville, Tex.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Vote Tallies To Be Released
description: The highest court rejected appeals to delay the release of the results of Sunday's general election by two weeks. The objections were raised after one district in Dresden was forced to postpone its ballot until Oct. 2 when a candidate died. A preliminary official result from the count in 298 districts will now be published either late Sunday or early Monday, the federal election commission said. A final official result will be published two and a half weeks later. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Silence in a Quarter Haunted by Its Own Old Spirit
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 - Backlighted by the moon, taking a meandering path down the middle of Bourbon Street around 1 a.m. Wednesday, the silhouette seemed to recall the hedonism here before Hurricane Katrina silenced the jazz, blackened the windows and closed the clubs.

Brown recalls, he placed frantic calls to his boss, Michael Chertoff, the secretary of homeland security, and to the office of the White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr.

description: In the network race to find another "Lost," NBC went underwater and came up with "Surface." But the problem with sea monsters is that they are not that scary: they live deep down in a vast ocean, and we don't.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Talks Rejected
description: Fifteen groups of relatives of 9/11 victims, allied as the Take Back the Memorial movement, said yesterday that they would not meet with Peter H. Woodin, a professional mediator who was named last week to help break the political impasse at ground zero. The groups have charged that the International Freedom Center planned for the cultural building on the memorial quadrant would detract from the memorial. In a statement, they said that the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and Gov. George E. Pataki had created "yet another deaf and redundant 'process' from which they are removed" and were "wasting time and resources that could be better spent addressing other compelling problems." The corporation said it was disappointed that Take Back the Memorial representatives were not "willing to engage in meaningful discussions." David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: China Proposes Compromise in Stalled Korean Nuclear Talks
description: BEIJING, Sept. 16 - China proposed a new compromise solution to the North Korean nuclear standoff and gave participating countries one day to accept or reject the offer, but there were mixed signals today about whether the United States and North Korea were prepared to come to terms.

title: A Tolerant Man's Obsession With Fanaticism
description: To observe the tenor Neil Shicoff's thrilling performance of the final aria from Fromental Halvy's 1835 opera "La Juive" ("The Jewess") at the Vienna State Opera is to watch a singing actor shoot the moon. As he builds the aria, "Rachel, quand du Seigneur," into an explosion of anguish that ends with the character's collapsing on the stage, the rare fusion of life, art and political passion may leave you shaken.

title: The questions of the hour
The Front-Runner in Germany Runs Scared
description: MAINZ, Germany, Sept. 15 - Three days before an election that has become unexpectedly suspenseful, Angela Merkel turned up on Thursday in this ancient city on the Rhine with a blunt message: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder has failed, and his government ought to be thrown out.

title: Legislator Resigns Amid Federal Inquiry
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 15 - A veteran state senator who is under federal investigation resigned here on Thursday morning in a fiery speech on the steps of City Hall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 5 about the 75th anniversary of the founding of a Russian Orthodox church in Jordanville, N.Y., near Utica, gave an erroneous name in some copies for a neighboring town. It is Richfield Springs, not Richfield Fields.

title: ABN Appears to Gain a Foothold in Italy
description: MILAN, Sept. 15 - ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, was set Thursday to become the first foreign buyer to crack Italy's impenetrable banking sector, winning a nine-month takeover battle that has led to calls for the country's central bank chief to resign.

title: An odd couple (he's the passive, she's aggressive)
Film in Review; Venom
description: Eden (Agnes Bruckner, who was outstanding in Karen Moncrieff's "Blue Car") is the prettiest girl in her small Louisiana town and she can't wait to get out. That's why her dreamy boyfriend, Eric (Jonathan Jackson, who got his start playing Lucky Spencer on "General Hospital"), has broken up with her. Rather than going to Louisiana State University, as they had discussed, Eden secretly applied to Columbia University, was accepted and will soon be leaving for New York.

description: All that stood between the Mets and their third victory this month were three outs. They are, of course, the hardest outs to get, and that task has seemed to become much more difficult when the Mets and their closer, Braden Looper, are trying to get them.

description: The National Center for Health Statistics released the government's most comprehensive survey of American sexual practices and reproductive health yesterday, delving for the first time into such sensitive areas as the prevalence of oral sex among teenagers and same-sex activity among adults.

description: Marian McPartland climbed the stage unsteadily at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, and apologized for her sensible shoes. The pianist, who is 87, explained that she had injured her ankle falling down some stairs; she had a bad knee already. "So now I don't have a leg to stand on," she said. Characteristically, Ms. McPartland played the line not for sympathy but for laughs. Then she turned to the piano and began a solo performance that cast all thoughts of frailty aside.

Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTOW, MIRIAM FURST
description: OSTOW--Miriam Furst. 85, September 14, 2005. Wife of Mortimer, mother of Robin, Jerry, Abigail and Rachel. Mother-in-law of Carmen, Arthur and Brian. Grandmother of Natascha, Rachel, Todd, Micol, Naomi, Joseph, David, Nurit, Sarah, Ilana, Micah and Hannah. Associate Director of Conservation of Human Resources, Columbia University for 35 years. President of Histadruth Ivrith. Member of Board of Overseers, List College, Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Founder of the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale. Funeral services Friday 11 AM at Plaza Community Chapel, 91 Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva at home Saturday evening through Wednesday evening. Donations: Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: The Listings: Sept. 16 -- Sept. 22; 'BIRD BRAIN'
description: It all started five years ago with some pigeons in Brooklyn. Since then, Jennifer Monson has followed the migration patterns of gray whales, ospreys, ducks and geese, presenting free, outdoor site-specific dances, workshops and panels on conservation along the way. On Monday, Ms. Monson gives her first New York performance in more than two years. This Bessie-Award winning choreographer is turning Dance Theater Workshop inside out with "Bird Brain" in an effort to create a habitat that offers urbanites a taste of her nature-driven dances. From 6:30 to 7:30 p.m., audience members supplied with building maps can follow a series of "trails" through the workshop's theater, past a terrace performance by local students, stairwell happenings and a janitor's closet that has been transformed into a wetland. They will then travel through the dressing room to reach the main theater, where Bob Braine and Leslie Reed have used hundreds of five-gallon buckets full of various plant species to create a movable forest of vegetation for the premiere of "Flight of Mind" (above). Four dancers, including Ms. Monson, will perform this contemplative distillation of her "Bird Brain" projects, shifting the buckets to invoke different environments in which the nonpresentational, ambient dance will unfold. The composers David Kean and Kenta Nagai will perform Mr. Kean's soundscape of noises, taken from the dancers and the building itself. On Monday night, naturalists, artists and conservationists will take part in "Moving Ecologies," a post-performance discussion of the urban landscape. (Monday through Sept. 24, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)924-0077.) CLAUDIALA ROCCO

title: U.S. and EU reconcile over glass of wine
Court Says West Bank Barrier Must Detour by 5 Arab Villages
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 - Israel's highest court ruled Thursday that part of Israel's West Bank separation barrier had imposed major hardships on Palestinian villagers and must be rerouted. It was the second such decision by the court.

description: The government has arrested two Eritrean employees of the American Embassy in Asmara, declining to specify the charges. The police arrested two other Eritrean employees of the embassy in 2001 and have yet to charge or release them. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; For NBC, Crime Pays
description: For its last Wednesday of summer repeats, NBC's crime double feature -- "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" at 9 p.m. (9.10 million) and "Law & Order" (9.72 million) -- did the job, bringing the network a victory in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers. Over the summer, "Law & Order" has consistently beaten "CSI: New York" among all viewers, though the two New York mysteries have shared the 18-to-49 spoils more equally. The Wednesday at 10 p.m. time slot will be an even more interesting battle beginning next week, when new episodes of the two crime franchises make their debuts, along with a third competitor, ABC's science-fiction series "Invasion." This Wednesday, NBC nearly prevailed among the 18-to-49 audience also, but Fox squeezed out a victory there when "So You Think You Can Dance" brought in 8.01 million viewers. But "Dance" failed to lift the series premiere of Fox's "Head Cases," in which Chris O'Donnell, above, plays a broken-down corporate lawyer. It delivered 6.39 million viewers and was fourth among 18-to-49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

title: Relief Ship Released in Somalia
description: Gunmen who held a ship with United Nations food relief for nearly three months released the vessel and 940 metric tons of rice donated for the country's 28,000 tsunami victims. Piracy is common along Somalia's coastline but this was the first instance of a hijacking of a ship working for the World Food Program. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8:30 P.M. (11) TWINS -- Series premiere. Sara Gilbert, the endearingly sardonic Darlene on "Roseanne," and Molly Stanton (above left, with Ms. Gilbert), a seductive blonde from the daytime soap "Passions," must have become twins the same way Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny DeVito did in the film of the same name. One young woman has a brain and an engineering degree; the other is a lingerie model. In this sitcom from the creators of "Will & Grace," both women are set to inherit the family underwear business from their parents (Melanie Griffith and Mark Linn-Baker).

title: It's Not Easy Making Art That Floats
description: The island of Manhattan was formed over the course of more than 500 million years, shaped by metamorphic pressure, erosion, continental drift, glacial deposits and rampant real estate development.

description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 15 - From the beginning of his tenure -- now in its fifth year -- Coach Herman Edwards has struggled to find the answer to a seemingly simple question: How do the Jets get off to a good start?

title: Appointment at Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company appointed Jason L. Rapp yesterday as vice president for strategy and operations at its Web site nytimes.com. Mr. Rapp, 36, has served as executive director of corporate planning since 2004, working on acquisitions, investments and strategy development.

title: Newell Rubbermaid to Cut 5,000 Jobs
description: Newell Rubbermaid, whose products include Calphalon cookware and Rubbermaid containers, said yesterday that it would cut 5,000 jobs and close a third of its 80 manufacturing plants by 2009 to focus on its most profitable and promising items.

title: Guns Are Evil. Everybody Should Have One.
description: "Lord of War," a misfire of a political satire about the international gun market, opens with a killer scene: Nicolas Cage standing on a veritable carpet of bullet casings. Mr. Cage's character, Yuri Orlov, is a gunrunner who has placed untold weapons in untold numbers of hands. Now, surrounded by gutted buildings and dressed to impress, a cigarette burning between his fingers, Yuri looks straight into the camera and wonders aloud how he can furnish everyone in the world with a gun to call his very own.

title: Misconduct and accounting errors at Interpublic

It was September, and following the pattern of the last 10 years Mr. Yann, a Manhattan-based public relations executive, was taking his ease at a rented home on Nantucket.

She is survived by her three bereft children, Michael Kempster (Linda) of Andover, MA, Barbara Zerzan (Tony Velez) of Brooklyn, NY, Victor Kempster (Katterli) of Los Angeles, CA; her grandchildren, Jessica (Josh), Nick, Sophia, Micala, Elena and Sasha, and greatgrandson, Rex. She is also survived by her loving brother, Victor Edelstein (son Eric); companion, Giulianna Piccoli; and her children and grandchildren. Lorry (Mom, Bunkie, Buba and Super Buba) was a beautiful, honest and loving person with very close and devoted friends, intelligence and humor. She was married to the late Dr. Stephen Wells Kempster. She also enjoyed many years as part of the Rudolph Steiner School Community. She was our anchor and will be deeply missed and forever cherished.

description: As the first step in creating a unified four-block campus, Baruch College plans to renovate its original home, 17 Lexington Avenue, at 23rd Street, now called the Lawrence and Eris Field Building. A wedgelike glass atrium with a twisting staircase is to be added to the facade in the $250 million project. Kathleen Waldron, Baruch's president, said yesterday that work would begin in 2008. The architect, Gordon Kipping of G Tects, will be collaborating informally with Frank Gehry. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Tooth and Claw
National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Governor Overruled On Pill Bill
description: The State Legislature voted to override Gov. Mitt Romney's veto of a bill to make the so-called morning-after pill more widely available. The 176-to-16 vote was widely expected since the measure, which allows some pharmacists to dispense the pill without a prescription and requires hospitals to offer it to rape victims, had passed by veto-proof margins in July. When taken within a few days after sex, the pill, which the Food and Drug Administration considers a contraceptive, can interfere with ovulation or fertilization or can sometimes prevent a fertilized egg from being implanted in the uterus. Mr. Romney, a Republican, said he vetoed the bill because he believed that the pill's ability to prevent implantation meant that it was sometimes used as an abortion pill. Pam Belluck (NYT)

description: The next time Amtrak officials decide to spring a hefty fare increase on their most loyal customers, they may want to pass along an early warning to the members of Congress among them.

title: Brooklyn
description: BROOKLYN should need no introduction: ancestors of as many as one in four Americans are said to have once called it home. But New York's most populous borough -- with about 2.5 million residents representing more than 90 ethnic groups -- has always been shadowed by its glamorous neighbor across the East River. Thriving a century ago, Brooklyn fell off the map around the time the Dodgers went Hollywood. Now it's back. Over the last decade or so, a new generation of immigrants in search of affordable rents have brought youthful energy to the patchwork of distinctive neighborhoods. Progress, both good and bad, can be seen in strands of new parks that will eventually share space along the waterfront with towering high-rises and a new cruise-ship terminal, and the possibility of a new basketball stadium looms near downtown. A weekend is hardly enough time to take in the borough's many sides, so try to see as much of today's Brooklyn as you can -- while you still can. NICK KAYE

title: The Nuclear Waste Site in Utah
description: While few people outside Utah were paying close attention last week, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission authorized the licensing of a private storage plant for spent nuclear fuel rods on an Indian reservation some 50 miles southwest of Salt Lake City. Utah's outraged political leaders pledged to use every legal and political trick available to block the project even though, as representatives of a very conservative state, they supposedly abhor bureaucratic or judicial interference with private corporate decisions. Their contention -- that the storage site, backed by a consortium of eight utilities, would pose a safety hazard -- seems overblown. If the project should clear all of the remaining regulatory, legal and commercial hurdles, it could provide a useful interim storage site while the nation seeks a more permanent burial site deep underground.

title: The Stars of Texas
description: IF you think you might arrive after sunset at the Astronomers Lodge in the Davis Mountains of West Texas, put fresh batteries in your flashlight. Without them, you may not be able to find your room. The rule in this mountain guesthouse and its environs is darkness, darkness, darkness. Except, that is, for the light from the stars -- and the more thousands on display any given night, the better.

title: Solving for X: Is She Crazy or a Math Mastermind?
description: It's funny how movies about smart people often play so dumb. Take the terribly serious film adaptation of David Auburn's much-admired, prize-laden Broadway play, "Proof." This contemporary drama concerns the daughter of a famous dead mathematician struggling to come to terms with both her father's legacy and her own troubled mind. Fearful that she has inherited his madness, Catherine may instead have inherited his genius, and it's this tension -- is she ring-a-ding nuts or just brilliant -- that is meant to fuel the story's professed suspense, making it something of a psychological whodunit.

Mr. Kozlowski, who was convicted of grand larceny, falsifying business records, securities fraud and other charges, is to be sentenced in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan and, unless he is granted bail, could be whisked off to Rikers Island to be processed. He faces a prison sentence as long as 30 years.

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Secretary Of State Announces Resignation
description: Randy A. Daniels, New York's secretary of state, announced yesterday that he would resign on Sept. 23, a move an aide said was tailored to let him devote himself more firmly to exploring a run for governor next year. "By stepping down, Randy Daniels is moving closer and closer to making a decision to run for governor," said Robert H. Ryan, the senior adviser to Mr. Daniels's exploratory committee. He said Mr. Daniels, 53, a Bronx Democrat turned Republican, would tour the state in the next few weeks but would wait until after the November elections to make a formal announcement about his plans. Mr. Daniels submitted his resignation on Wednesday in a one-page letter to Gov. George E. Pataki, who appointed him secretary of state in 2001. In a statement yesterday, Mr. Pataki praised him as an "energetic and innovative leader." Al Baker (NYT)

The American Folk Art Museum just opened an "emerging talent" show, its first, titled "Obsessive Drawing." Frankly, the idea sounded like a sop thrown to a Babes-in-Chelsealand art moment. But "emerging," as it turns out, is relative.

title: National Briefing | Washington: President Approves Base Closing Plan
description: President Bush gave his approval to a plan for closing 22 major military bases and sent it to Congress. Mr. Bush made no changes in the plan as approved by the independent base closing commission, which last month voted to keep open five bases the Pentagon had wanted to shut and to reduce operations at seven others on the closing list. That reduced the number of closings at large installations to 21, from 33. More than 800 installations will be eliminated, shrunk or given new missions if the blueprint goes through. David S. Cloud (NYT)

The Democrats portrayed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as a true Republican presiding over a city that caters to the wealthy as the middle class and the poor increasingly struggle to get by.

title: Documentary Examines a Cuban Classic
description: In 1962, a team of Soviet cineastes and intellectuals, led by the eminent director Mikhail Kalatozov and including the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko, traveled to Cuba to make an epic film about that country's recent revolution. After two years of collaboration with local actors, writers and technicians, they produced "I Am Cuba," which displeased both the Cuban public and the Soviet authorities. The movie languished in obscurity until 1995, when Francis Ford Coppola and Martin Scorsese helped bring it to the attention of American audiences. By then, in the wake of Communism's collapse, it could be hailed as a lost classic of a strange, fraught historical moment -- a "Bolshevik hallucination," in the words of the film critic J. Hoberman.

title: Family Values With Mogul Price Tags
description: THE best way to tell if it's a happening weekend in Aspen is to drive past the airport, three miles west of town on Highway 82 in the Colorado Rockies. During the busy season, dozens of private jets flank the tarmac like limousines at the Oscars, waiting to whisk their owners to the next exotic destination. This display of riches is the first thing people see when they arrive in town, whether they fly in from somewhere across the country or drive up from Denver, three and a half hours away.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MALIS, LEONARD I. MD.
description: MALIS--Leonard I. MD. When the definitive history of neurosurgery is written, a significant portion will be devoted to the contributions of Leonard I. Malis. Dr. Malis was born in Philadelphia in 1919. After receiving a medical degree from the University of Virginia in 1943, he served as captain in the Medical Corps and by the end of WW II was the head of his hospital's neurological unit. After leaving the army, he did his neurosurgical training at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. He completed a fellowship at Yale University and returned to Mount Sinai as an assistant attending neurosurgeon, assuming the chairmanship of the Department of Neurosurgery in 1970. Dr. Malis was a pioneer in microneurosurgery, introducing the operating microscope to neurosurgery in New York. With his brother Jerry, he developed some of the earliest state of the art surgical instruments and techniques which are still in use today. Dr. Malis retired as Chairman of the Mount Sinai Department of Neurosurgery in 1991 but continued as Professor of Neurosurgery until 1994 and as Professor Emeritus until his death. His clinical and academic legacy will enrich the practice of neurosurgery for generations to come. The Department of Neurosurgery at Mount Sinai will miss Dr. Malis as a teacher and colleague, but his presence will be noted in in operating rooms daily. We offer our condolences to his family and many friends. Kalmon D. Post, M.D. Leonard I. Malis M.D./ Corinne and Joseph Graber Professor, Chairman, Department of Neurosurgery Mount Sinai School of Medicine$(6$)

title: The Listings: Sept. 16 -- Sept. 22; VISION ARTISTS FOR NEW ORLEANS
description: The Vision Festival, a vibrant grass-roots endeavor that marked its 10th season in June, has long been a gravitational center for jazz's far-flung avant-garde. Its focus is social and political as well as aesthetic -- a reflection of the guiding principles of its director, Patricia Nicholson, whose husband, William Parker, is the scene's most prominent bassist. This benefit concert took shape as Ms. Nicholson fielded post-Katrina inquiries about the whereabouts of Edward (Kidd) Jordan, a saxophonist, educator and patriarch of the New Orleans jazz scene who has also been a Vision Festival favorite. (Mr. Jordan had evacuated his house near the 17th Street Canal the night before the levee breach.) Ms. Nicholson wasted little time organizing an evening featuring a roll call of festival-affiliated artists. The resulting line-up will include John Zorn's Masada, featuring the trumpeter Dave Douglas; an expanded incarnation of Mr. Parker's Little Huey Creative Music Orchestra; solo performances by the trumpeter Bill Dixon and the pianist Muhal Richard Abrams; and Vision Festival staples like the poet Amiri Baraka, the pianist Matthew Shipp and the saxophonist Charles Gayle. Mr. Jordan, above, will play in a group with the drummer Clyde Kerr, another displaced New Orleans musician. Even the celebrity interlopers will reflect a downtown disposition: the actor Steve Buscemi shares M.C.-ing duties with Ms. Nicholson and the poet Steve Dalachinsky; Elvis Costello and Deborah Harry reprise their collaboration with the Jazz Passengers; and Yo La Tengo reunites with the free-jazz ensemble Other Dimensions in Music. (Tuesday from 5:30 p.m. to midnight, Orensanz Center for the Arts, 172 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212)529-7194; www.visionfestival.org. Admission is $30; donations of canned food, water, diapers, and clothing will also be accepted.) NATE CHINEN

title: Oktoberfests
description: LET'S face it. Wine tastings and sake bars have their merits, but a hoot and a holler they're not. You're dying for a beer -- just a nice, cold, frothy mug, a wooden bench and some good old-fashioned hedonism. Enter the Oktoberfest -- that glorious 16-day excuse to eat, drink, dance and frolic to heart's content. This month, millions will descend on an open field in Munich to celebrate at the original stomping grounds of King Maximilian, whose wedding reception for his son began the tradition of Oktoberfest in 1810.

title: A Journey Inspired by Family Becomes One of Forgiveness
description: The title of Liev Schreiber's "Everything Is Illuminated," adapted from the best-selling novel of the same title by Jonathan Safran Foer, refers to the way the past casts a glow of understanding onto the present. A less charitable interpretation is also possible. The film, more emphatically than the book but in keeping with its spirit, suggests that even the darkest page of history can be bathed in a glow of consoling, self-congratulatory sentiment. Taking place in Ukraine (though filmed mainly in the Czech Republic), "Everything is Illuminated" is a gentle comedy of understanding and forgiveness played in the shadow of the Holocaust.

After all, it's not as if the subjects that raise middle-class hackles have changed so very much in the 55 years since George Bernard Shaw died, leaving mountains of plays (more than 50, and their prefaces and postscripts) and essays and pamphlets and treatises and letters and reviews to rumble on in an ardent and exasperated eternity.

title: A Wonderful Afterlife, but Must Share Bath
description: "Just Like Heaven," directed by Mark Waters from a script by Peter Tolan and Leslie Dixon, is a metaphysical second-chance comedy, the kind of movie in which the laws of time and space are bent to give characters access to self-knowledge unavailable in ordinary circumstances. The genre has a long and varied history, going back at least to "It's a Wonderful Life" and including "Ghost," "Big" and the many versions of "Heaven Can Wait." These movies always risk a certain sentimentality, but at their best -- "Groundhog Day," "All of Me," Mr. Waters's splendid remake of "Freaky Friday" -- they leaven teary lesson-learning with a whimsical delight in the ridiculous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, WILLIAM PIERCE, MD
description: SMITH--William Pierce, MD passed peacefully on September 8, 2005 at home in Saratoga, CA. He was born and raised in Canajoharie, NY. He graduated Valedictorian from Yale University in 1947 after serving our country as an Air Force Captain in WWII. He flew 50 missions in a B-24 as lead squadron pilot. He graduated in medicine from Columbia University in 1953 and completed his residency at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was a physician at Henry Ford Hospital until 1995 and spent much of that time as Medical Clinic 1 Division Head. He was a revered member of the clinical faculty of the University of Michigan Medical School. He was the loving father of the late Deborah H. Smith and Rebecca Smith-Coggins, MD. He is survived by his daughter Rebecca, son - in - law Dwain L. Coggins, MD, three grandsons and brother Barton P. Smith, MD. In lieu of a formal service, friends and family are asked to join in silent reflection and prayer at 8AM Pacific Time on Saturday, September 24, 2005. For information contact Darling Fischer Chapel of the Hills, Los Gatos, CA.

Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDERMAN, I. WARREN
description: RUDERMAN--I. Warren. 85, crystal research pioneer. Of Demarest, died August 29, 2005, at the age of 85. The second child of Jack and Mollie Ruderman, he was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1920. At an early age he fell in love with chemistry--an affair lasting throughout his life. In 1940 he graduated from City College with a B.S degree. He earned his M.S. at NYU and Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, and received a PhD from Columbia University in 1949. He worked cooperatively with other scientists on the Manhattan Project, and continued collaborative scientific research for many more years. He combined his scientific talents with business acumen starting a series of advanced technology research and development corporations. In 1956 he founded Isomet, dedicated to the research and production of acousto-optical devices utilized in laser instrumentation. He left Isomet in 1973 and formed a new corporation, Inrad, again specializing in laser optics. In collaboration with Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, he pioneered the science of creating very large crystals to focus laser light to achieve the extremely high temperatures necessary to generate fusion. After retiring from Inrad in 2000, he started a research company in conjunction with Cornell University to investigate the use of laser light for treatment of vocal cord tumors. His many scientific awards include election as a Fellow in the NY Academy of Science, and membership in Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Xi, the American Physical Society, the American Chemical Society, and the Optical Society of America. He was awarded 18 U.S. and foreign patents, authored numerous scientific articles and gave invited chemical and physical society lectures in the U.S., Europe, China, and Japan. In 1943 he met his other lifelong love, Carol Schmied, a master's candidate at the Columbia School of Social Work and in 1945 they married. He and Carol raised four children and have 12 grandchildren. They celebrated their 60th anniversary in June of this year. In addition to his scientific achievements he led a balanced life of civic and family interests. He was a trustee of the Demarest Baptist Church. He played tennis with the "Tenafly Monday Night Irregulars." He enjoyed travel, gardening, theater, music, and visiting with devoted children and grandchildren. He touched many lives, and those who knew him will always remember his warmth, wit, and intelligence. He is survived by his wife Carol, his children Genevieve, William, Clifford, and Barbara, his sister Florence, and his 12 grandchildren. He will be sorely missed by his family, his many friends, and former co-workers and colleagues. Memorial service 3 PM Saturday, October 1, Demarest United Methodist Church, 109 Hardenburgh Avenue. Memorial donations may be made to the Tenafly Nature Center, 313 Hudson Avenue, Tenafly, NJ 07627.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Lennon' to Close
description: In a major disappointment for fans of the Beatles and Broadway biographies, "Lennon," a new musical based on the life of John Lennon, will close on Sept. 24 after only 49 performances at the Broadhurst Theater. The musical, produced with permission of Yoko Ono, Lennon's widow, was written and directed by Don Scardino and starred a cast of nine actors, each of whom embodied Lennon at different moments of his life. The show received poor reviews during an out-of-town run this year in San Francisco and didn't fare much better with New York critics after opening at the Broadhurst on Aug. 14. After Labor Day, sales faltered badly, with the show playing to less than 40 percent of capacity last week. The production is expected to lose most of its $7 million capitalization cost. 'I Am Cuba'
description: Born in 1903, Mikhail Kalatozov came of creative age in the Soviet film industry in the 1920's, its most heroic period. Although he apparently suffered his share of indignities, he survived well enough to continue making films, earning international plaudits with "The Cranes Are Flying" (1957). And so it came to pass that his survival instincts and talent took him to the Caribbean, where soon before Cuba pointed its Soviet missiles at the United States, he set his sights at that tiny island nation. What emerged from this sojourn was "I Am Cuba" (1964), above, a black-and-white wonderment that tells the story of the revolution with squealing trumpets, restless drums and astonishing cinematography. It is a story told with everyday heroes laboring in smoky dance halls and dusty fields, and with villains like Batista and the United Fruit Company. Mostly, though, it is a story told with a camera as deliriously liberated as the Cuban people would prove enslaved. Long unseen outside of Cuba and the Soviet Union, it was rediscovered in the early 1990's and subsequently released here to great critical acclaim. Ten years later, fresh prints have been struck with new subtitles and done away with the original Russian overdub. The impulse to strip the translation from the sensuous imagery is understandable, if perhaps unfortunate. What gives "I Am Cuba" such resonance, after all, isn't just that camera and those bodies in restless motion, but also the strange convergence of this nominal ideal with that alien accent. In 1962, you imagine, the voice of the Soviet Union reverberated through Havana as loudly as that of Fidel Castro. (Today through Sept. 29 (excluding Sept. 24), Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Sixth Avenue, South Village, (212)727-8110.) MANOHLA DARGIS Critic's Choice

Justin, played by a slight, hollow-cheeked young actor named Lou Pucci, lives in a nondescript suburban house (in Beaverwood, Ore.), with his eccentric, wistful mother, Audrey (Tilda Swinton), his distant, disapproving dad, Jack (Vincent D'Onofrio), and a younger brother (Chase Offerle) who shows up from time to time to give Justin strange looks. Justin must also contend with the tedium of school and the torment of adolescent lust, whose object is an idealistic classmate named Rebecca (Kelli Garner).

title: The Listings: Sept. 16 -- Sept. 22; TOM BURCKHARDT: 'FULL STOP'
description: Known until now for eclectically layered abstract paintings, Tom Burckhardt has produced a big surprise for his current exhibition: a walk-in cartoon of an artist's studio, above, made of tan corrugated cardboard and black paint. The construction calls to mind Red Grooms's animated environments, but Mr. Burckhardt's humor is quieter and mysteriously somber. Much of the entertainment value is in the transformation of objects into all kinds of cardboard forms, with details added by brush and black paint. The tabletop on saw horses, the crumpled paint tubes, the art postcards tacked to the wall, the art books on the book shelves, the pressed-tin ceiling, the paint-splattered floor: everywhere you look there are details to examine. It is as if a Midas-like character with a cardboard touch had paid a visit. The installation is also a nostalgic comment on the mystique of the modern artist's studio. Mr. Burckhardt has planted art historical references throughout: the brushes in a Savarin coffee can allude to Jasper Johns; the pot-bellied stove is from Edward Hopper's studio; the record player replicates one owned by Willem de Kooning; and the shoes are Jackson Pollock's. An empty canvas stands on the easel, a blank screen waiting to receive the artist's visionary projections. Even if you don't get all the references, you may still have a sense of the studio as a kind of scared anachronism, a place frozen in time as our digital age plunges headlong into the virtual future. (Caren Golden, 539 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212)727-8304, through Oct. 15. ) KEN JOHNSON

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: County Bans Parking Near Ranch
description: The McLennan County Commission banned parking alongside 23 miles of road near President Bush's ranch at Crawford, but stopped short of prohibiting camping on the right of way. During Mr. Bush's vacation in August, Cindy Sheehan, the mother of a serviceman killed in Iraq, staged a 26-day protest of the war on one such area. Thousands of supporters and opponents of the conflict converged on the road, frequently jamming traffic. Commissioner Ray Meadows said the ordinance, which was passed Tuesday, was meant to protect the public and not to suppress political dissent. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Approves Construction Rules
description: The City Council passed legislation yesterday that would require any major building construction or renovation paid for with city capital funds to adhere to "green standards," which include using renewable energy sources and conserving materials. Council leaders said the law would affect $12 billion in planned construction projects, including $5 billion for new schools. The Council also passed a law to increase fines on stores that lock workers in against their will as a way to prevent thefts, and another one that strengthens human rights protections for city residents. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARREN, ROSALIND AMES
description: WARREN -- Rosalind Ames died peacefully in her home surrounded by family and friends after a courageous battle against cancer. She is survived by beloved husband Eugene, loving daughters Shawn Crowley and Jennifer Medwin, caring sons-in-law Steve Medwin and Bill Crowley, cherished grandchildren Ryan Beres and Jessica Medwin, Catherine and Kiera Crowley, caring best friend Mary O'Brien and devoted friend Jenny Ruff. Roz arrived in New York City from Philadelphia at the age of 16 to begin an extraordinary twenty-three year modeling career. Admired and respected in her industry for honesty, integrity and strong character. Roz was one of the reigning queens of the 50's & 60's on Seventh Avenue. She worked for all of the top designers in her day: Charles James, Halston, Anne Klein, Ben Zuckerman, Geoffrey Beene, Kasper, and Molly Parnis. Charles James insisted that all Saks mannequins be patterned after her figure. Roz was selected by Eleanor Lambert to be the opening and closing model for the prestigious Coty Awards. She was Mr. Goodman's first choice of models at Bergdorf Goodman fashion shows. Roz showed privately for Jacqueline Kennedy and The Duchess of Windsor and was a personal favorite of Lady Bird Johnson. Roz left a lasting impression on those who met her. She had the unique ability to combine style, dignity, and generosity with humanity. Fiercely independent and determined, she was a woman before her time. Many will remember her for the intensity with which she applied herself in various Upper Westside gyms over the years, exercising, spinning, and ultimately daily yoga. She succeeded on her own terms, never compromising her integrity and commanding the respect of those with whom she worked. A discerning judge of character, Roz was a friend for life for those lucky and deserving people who she chose to embrace. At the same time, Roz always had a special place for those less fortunate than her, and her love of animals was profound--not only the lucky animals who shared her home over the years, but also the many dogs she knew by name in the park. Even in the midst of her struggle with cancer, she would gather the strength to walk to Central Park to feed the birds. Roz will be deeply missed by all her family and friends. She will remain in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) at 11:30 AM on Sunday, September 18th. Donations in her mamory may be made to the ASPCA, Hospice of New York, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer (Thoracic Oncology Department).

Goss, the C.I.A. director, to declassify and make public an internal agency report that criticizes his predecessor, George J. Tenet, and others for lapses on terrorism in advance of the Sept. 11 attacks.

World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Judge Frees Dissident Ecologist
description: A judge has freed an ecologist who had been held for 10 months on murder charges that international human rights and environmental groups have said were trumped up. The ecologist, Felipe Arreaga, 56, served nearly a year in jail in Zihuatanejo before being exonerated on charges he had taken part in the killing of the son of a powerful local landlord. Mr. Arreaga had crusaded for years to stop illegal logging on the Pacific coast and had been a thorn in the landlord's side. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Thursday about the 50th anniversary of the publication of "Lolita" made an incorrect reference in discussing Vladimir Nabokov's efforts to keep his manuscript out of the hands of the postal authorities. The United States Postal Service did not exist until 1971; its predecessor in the 1950's was the United States Post Office Department.

A seventh candidate was shot dead Friday in the country's restive south, and on Thursday a roadside bomb killed an Afghan interpreter working with the American military and a blast wounded two Canadian peacekeepers on patrol.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Financier Gets 18 Months
description: A Virginia financier was sentenced to 18 months in prison for running an illegal money-transmittal business that sent nearly $5 million to Iran, Pakistan and Afghanistan. The defendant, Rahim Bariek, 46, was also ordered to forfeit $32,343 after pleading guilty to a single criminal count. Two months after the Sept. 11 attacks, he had testified before Congress about the importance of business people following American law to operate hawalas, or informal money-exchange systems common in many Islamic countries, but the federal authorities say he did not have a proper license to do so. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

Dance forms a major part of the festival, and of the linked Philly Fringe (the difference being that in Live Arts the performers are selected, or "curated" in contemporary parlance, while in the fringe the performers select themselves -- come one, come all).

title: Italian Police Arrest Fugitive Crime Leader in Naples Gang War
description: ROME, Sept. 16 - The Italian police seized the head of a major crime family in Naples on Friday, in an arrest the authorities said they hoped would put an end to a yearlong gang war that had been responsible for the deaths of some 50 people.

title: At the Mercantile Library, Contemporary Classical Performers Lean Perilously Close to Pop
description: The name Meet the Composer Inc. pretty well sums up this national organization's mission. Founded in 1974, it presents the public with opportunities to meet and hear works by living composers. Intimate spaces where audiences can have personal exchanges with composers are particularly suited to its mission. Meet the Composer has found another such site at the Mercantile Library in Midtown Manhattan, which has supported the creation and appreciation of fiction since 1820. Called MTC @ The Merc, this new series was inaugurated on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEMPSTER, LORRAINE (EDELSTEIN)
description: KEMPSTER--Lorraine (Edelstein). Died peacefully after a brief illness in Norwalk, CT on September 10th surrounded by her family. She is survived by her three bereft children, Michael Kempster (Linda) of Andover, MA, Barbara Zerzan (Tony Velez) of Brooklyn, NY, Victor Kempster (Katterli) of Los Angeles, CA; her grandchildren, Jessica (Josh), Nick, Sophia, Micala, Elena and Sasha, and greatgrandson, Rex. She is also survived by her loving brother, Victor Edelstein (son Eric); companion, Giulianna Piccoli; and her children and grandchildren. Lorry (Mom, Bunkie, Buba and Super Buba) was a beautiful, honest and loving person with very close and devoted friends, intelligence and humor. She was married to the late Dr. Stephen Wells Kempster. She also enjoyed many years as part of the Rudolph Steiner School Community. She was our anchor and will be deeply missed and forever cherished.
