title: Security is prime concern for Afghanistan election
Paid Notice: Deaths   WISELY, SISTER BERNADETTE DE LOURDES, O. CARM (''MOTHER BERNADETTE'')
description: WISELY--Sister Bernadette de Lourdes, O. Carm ("Mother Bernadette"). Died on September 13, 2005 at Teresian House in Albany, NY. Joining the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and Infirm when the Community was only in its infancy, Mother Bernadette quickly became the trusted assistant to the Foundress of the Congregation. Mother M. Angeline Teresa and pioneered the concept of "resident-centered care". She became an advisor to many individuals and organizations and was a founding member of the American Association of Homes for the Aging and the first woman President of the National Council on the Aging. She was also on the National Advisory Committee for the White House Council on the Aging where she helped to set trends for eldercare that are still recognized today. Mother Bernadette published many articles in professional journals and was the author of two books, "Where Somebody Cares", and "Woman of Faith". Throughout her long life Mother Bernadette has been an inspiration to many, both among her fellow Religious and those many friends and associates who have also shared in the Vision and Mission of Mother M. Angeline Teresa.

title: Brooklyn Politician's Defense Gets Boost in Trial
description: A former state election official said yesterday that a system in which a business executive divides contributions to candidates through more than one account is perfectly legal in New York, giving a boost to the defense in the trial of Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr.

title: Seeking Office by Shedding Taliban Past
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Sept. 16 - For a man so seemingly intent on turning back time, there could be no better symbol than the one that Maulavi Qalamuddin has chosen for his campaign for Parliament: a clock.

title: Amid the Muck, a Man With a Plan
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 15 - The Palmetto Apartments, a cluster of two-story buildings where 120 low-income families lived before Hurricane Katrina, is a grim sight. By now, the water, which had been more than six feet deep in the buildings, has retreated. Left behind are battered walls, mud-caked rooms, warped wood floors and mold climbing toward the ceilings. The grounds, still swampy, smell like a fetid barnyard.

title: A Step Closer to Embracing Bold Sounds
description: For all its success, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has long been criticized as a staid institution that plays it safe. So there was much anticipation when it opened its 37th season on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall with a promising new pair of artistic directors in place: the cellist David Finckel, best known as a member of the Emerson String Quartet, and the pianist Wu Han. These exploratory artists, who happen to be married to each other, have thought outside the box and undertaken projects as recording producers, educators and administrators. Concertgoers will have to wait until next season, though, to see what kinds of programs they have in mind, since their appointment came after the current season was planned.

title: Friend Says Defendant Admitted Role in Killing
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALIS, LEONARD, M.D.
description: MALIS--Leonard, M.D. He was a giant in medicine and a great humanist. He improved, brightened, and enriched our lives and those of so many others. How lucky we were to have his friendship for some six decades. He will be in our memories always. The Linsky Family

title: Clues to a Hedge Fund's Collapse
description: A six-page note threatening suicide written by the chief financial officer of the Bayou Group, a hedge fund company accused by prosecutors of conducting a $300 million fraud, appears to answer in sometimes gripping detail the questions that have consumed Bayou's investors since it imploded a month ago.

title: Homeowners Face 4.3% Rise in Tax Rates
description: Homeowners in New York City, already facing rising home heating costs this winter, will have to contend with a second major cost increase: a sharp and unexpected rise in property tax rates required by state law, city officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCE, HENRY III.
description: LUCE--Henry III. The Board of Directors of the Milton B. Rosenbluth Foundation wishes to express profound sorrow at the loss of our Board member, Henry Luce III. He was generous and caring and will be greatly missed. We extend heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Leila and family. Michael A. Rosenbluth, MD Helen Tucker, Chairman, Board of Directors

title: Paying Attention to Means
description: When Schoenberg described John Cage as more inventor than composer, he probably had a whole generation of creative tinkerers in mind. Artistic engineering by people like Cage and his colleagues no longer occupies the high ground it did half a century ago, music having reverted to kinder, simpler connections with music's past and its popular-music present. But some experimenters hold on, and the Interpretations series at Merkin Hall is giving them time before the public.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Weapons Arrest At City Hall
description: A 48-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested at City Hall for possession of an imitation pistol and a forged gun permit, the police said. They said that the man, Peter Concepcin of Ocean Parkway, approached officers at the gates of City Hall around 1 p.m. and volunteered his gun permit. When the gun permit turned out to be fake, the officers found the fake pistol tucked under his belt and arrested him. He was charged with criminal possession of a weapon and criminal possession of a fraudulent instrument. The police said Mr. Concepcin did not appear to be emotionally disturbed. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Undecided German voters wooed
Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKLEY, MAC
description: BERKLEY--Mac, 98, of Aventura, Fla. Beloved husband of Ruth and the late Fay, loving father of Doris and Bobby, five grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Funeral services at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, on Sunday, September 18, at 12:30 PM.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Hallmark) JULES VERNE'S MYSTERIOUS ISLAND -- (2005). Kyle MacLachlan stars in Verne's Civil War-era tale of travelers in a hot-air balloon who find themselves in a land of giant animals. They also find the infamous Captain Nemo (Patrick Stewart, left).

title: Nations redouble their efforts against bird flu
Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Friends Killed Within 24 Hours
description: A 21-year-old man, Avery Frederick, was shot twice in the head and killed around noon yesterday while standing in front of 97 Lott Avenue, near the corner of Bristol Street, in Brownsville. The police said they were investigating whether Mr. Frederick's death was connected to the killing of his friend Anthony Manns, 22, who was shot in the chest and killed on Thursday afternoon as he stood by his car a half-block from where Mr. Frederick was later gunned down. Witnesses to Mr. Manns's killing said the fatal shots had been fired from a green minivan. Mr. Frederick's father, Paul Frederick, said his son had recently been released from jail after serving time for possession of a large amount of cocaine. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the conductor Hermann Michael on Wednesday misidentified the German state that includes his birthplace, Schwbisch Gmnd. It is Baden-Wrttemberg, not Bavaria.

title: Sir Hermann Bondi, 85, Is Dead; Theorized on the Universe
description: Sir Hermann Bondi, an astronomer and mathematician whose ideas about cosmology shaped an important theory about the origin of the universe, and who later became a leading science adviser to the British government, died last Saturday in Cambridge, England. He was 85.

title: Controller Steals Show at Game Fair
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 - Nintendo, maker of the GameCube video console, has surprised the industry with its answer to the increasingly high-tech consoles of its rivals: a simple, one-handed controller that players can also swing like a sword or a golf club.

title: An Island of Calm in Boston's Sea of Doubt
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 - David Ortiz does not let the importance of any at-bat unnerve him, does not let the intensity of any situation distract him and does not let himself envision anything except a blissful outcome. To Ortiz, the more complicated the scenario, the more relaxed he feels.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Cabbie And Brother Shot Dead
description: A taxi driver and his brother were shot and killed early yesterday morning after picking up a passenger near the Ironbound, a section in the city's East Ward, the police said. The driver, Johnny Infante, 41, who worked for Ecuamerican Sedan Limo, and his brother, Edgar Infante, 52, were on their way to 12th Avenue about 12:45 a.m. when the shooting occurred on South Ninth Street, the police said. Edgar Infante was pronounced dead at the scene. His younger brother died shortly after at University Hospital in Newark. Both were natives of Ecuador. The authorities said Johnny Infante was teaching the streets to his brother, who also wanted to drive a cab. Investigators said they believed that robbery was the motive. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The schedule note in Weekend yesterday with a television review of "Just Legal," a new WB series, misstated the day it will run. It will be Mondays, not Fridays.

title: In 4-Year Anthrax Hunt, F.B.I. Finds Itself Stymied, and Sued
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - Richard L. Lambert, the F.B.I. inspector in charge of the investigation of the deadly anthrax letters of 2001, testified under oath for five hours last month about the case.

title: An uproar in Italyderails gay union hopes
Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Herms, belle of the ball, denies liaison
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television highlight entry on Aug. 23 for the 1996 film "Bastard Out of Carolina," on Lifetime, misspelled the given name of the director. She is Anjelica Huston, not Angelica.

title: France bans flights by Cameroon Airlines
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about job losses at auto plants in Windsor, Ontario, misstated the locations of Toyota and Honda in Canada. They are a couple of hundred miles to the east of Windsor, not west.

title: Mayor Vetoes Health Care Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a City Council bill yesterday that would require large stores to provide a minimum level of health care to their workers.

title: World Briefings: Middle East, Asia, Europe, Americas, Africa
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Accounting for the Smithsonian's Disrepair (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wraith's Sordid Hometown Visit
description: Who let David Lynch into "Our Town"? Judith Thompson, that's who. Certainly her play "Lion in the Streets," the first New York production for a group out of Montreal called the Alternate Theater, seems like a merging of those two worldviews, injecting a creepiness and voyeurism into domestic nostalgia.

title: A Frustrating Week at the U.N. for the White House Team
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - After weeks of trying to rally international support to confront Iran over its nuclear program and to reform the United Nations, the Bush administration has had an unusually frustrating week, rebuffed by crucial partners and also by a coalition of poor countries increasingly resentful of American power.

title: Briefcase: For Katrina victims, credit crises loom
Private firms drive China's growth
Plan Will Pay 90% of Costs For Students Hit by Storm
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - The Department of Education announced a plan on Friday to pay 90 percent of the educational costs of students and schools affected by Hurricane Katrina for one year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Stabbed In Subway Stairwell
description: A 46-year-old man was assaulted by three men in the stairwell of the 176th Street subway station on the No. 4 line shortly after 8 p.m. last night, the police said. The men approached the victim and asked him for money. After he refused, they stabbed him once in the abdomen. He was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx and was expected to survive. No one has been arrested. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. pornography looks to go mobile
Four Companies Are Hired to Help With Debris
description: The Army Corps of Engineers reviewed 22 proposals before awarding up to $4 billion in hurricane cleanup contracts yesterday to four companies with a directive that much of the work be subcontracted to small businesses in the Mississippi Gulf region.

title: Criminal boss is captured in Italy
Out of Katrina's Wake, Victims Find Aid in Harlem
description: Using a model developed to help bereaved families after 9/11, New York has turned one floor of an old Harlem welfare office into a welcoming center where several hundred Katrina storm survivors are finding one-stop disaster assistance.

title: Bush voices 'same goal' with Putin after talks
U.S. worries about the toll Iraq is taking, poll finds
Arts, Briefly; Another Garbo Role
description: Greta Garbo would have been 100 years old on Sunday. In honor of the occasion, she will be playing a leading lady in the mail, thanks to a new 37-cent stamp, to be released Sept. 23 in New York by the Postal Service. A postage stamp of a similar design is being issued simultaneously by Garbo's native Sweden. Both stamps bear an engraved design by Piotr Naszarkowski, in which the portrait is rendered by finely etched lines suggesting the nuances of shadow and light, rather than a continuous-tone photograph. The engraved design is based on a photograph by Clarence Sinclair Bull, taken during the filming of "As You Desire Me" in 1932. Garbo died in 1990. MATTHEW HEALEY

title: Some Middle-Class Residents Who Evacuated Say They Lack Faith in Federal Aid
description: Patty Rome and Rick Pfalzgraf say they do not have much faith that the federal government will help people like them, the largely middle-class victims of Hurricane Katrina who left the city and its suburbs on their own and have since dispersed across the country.

title: Going to the Hospital? Don't Forget to Pack a Nurse
description: A FEW years ago, a friend having major surgery was advised to hire a private nurse to be at her bedside in the hospital.

title: Financier Shifts His Focus to Auto Parts
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16 - Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the man who recently built up and then sold North America's largest steel maker, has set his sights on the auto industry.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the Moscow Journal article on Wednesday, about the profusion of luxurious restrooms in Moscow restaurants, misstated the name of the establishment in the heart of the city, just around the corner from the Kremlin. It is Cafe Freud, not Cafe 5. (Go to Article)

title: Stanley Burnshaw, Poet, Editor and Critic, Dies at 99
description: Stanley Burnshaw, a consummate man of letters who was not only a poet, critic, translator, editor, publisher and novelist, but also skilled at setting type by hand, died yesterday on Martha's Vineyard. He was 99.

title: Off the Charts: Schrder's future turns on jobs
Entry Level: The hidden problems of huge windfalls
Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Several dehydrated contestants vomited loudly and often during the brutal premiere of the 11th edition of CBS's "Survivor" on Thursday night. But not Stephenie LaGrossa, below, one of two popular cast members from the previous season -- the other is Bobby Jon Drinkard, whose eyes rolled back in his head on camera -- who were brought back to compete again. The debut drew 17.78 million viewers, which was down from the beginnings of previous seasons but still helped CBS win the night among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. CBS was No.1 during the 9 p.m. broadcast of President Bush's speech. The preliminary Nielsen estimates for the live event showed ABC in second place, trailed by NBC and Fox. After that, CBS stayed in first place with a "CSI" repeat. Week 2 of Fox's "O.C." -- Marissa's been kicked out of school -- drew 6.04 million viewers and put Fox in second place, although a distant one, in the 18-to-49 demographic for the night. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HESS, DANIE
description: HESS--Danie. Danny, dining in New York will never be the same without you. My love goes out to Susanne, the children and grandchildren. Elaine Litvack

title: In New Yoga Classes, Poses and Prayer
description: HAMILTON, Mass. - When Cathy Chadwick instructed her three yoga students to move into warrior position, she did not remind them to watch their alignment or focus on their breath. Instead Ms. Chadwick urged them to concentrate on the affirmation each made at the beginning of class after she read aloud the prayer of St. Theresa of Avila.

title: Chrysler Aims to Outdo Ford in Canadian Labor Talks
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 16 - DaimlerChrysler Canada is seeking greater concessions from workers than Ford obtained in its labor settlement this week, the head of the Canadian Auto Workers said Friday.

title: Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: An Impeccable Gentleman Lawyer's Disintegration
description: A good musical grabs us at first listen. That's almost a definition, or a job description, of this essentially populist form. Ed Dixon's "Richard Cory," in its premiere at the New York Musical Theater Festival, comes off instead as the sort of subtly shaded chamber piece that might attract a specialized audience with repeated hearings, like a Bruckner symphony or a Britten opera.

title: Summer of My Discontent
description: ALL semester long I had thought about the approaching summer vacation with mixed feelings. On one hand I was elated at the prospect of seeing my seven siblings and ten half brothers and sisters, but on the other, I was apprehensive about being back in Africa. The year was 1990. I had left Ghana nearly two years earlier to attend high school at the Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan and I was nervous about facing my father whose dream of my becoming a lawyer or banker or a diplomat with the United Nations was being shattered by my desire to be a writer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLADE, JOHN
description: SLADE--John. It is with sincere regret that we at the New York City office of American Express Tax & Business Services, Inc. mourn the passing of our loyal client, John Slade. Wall Street has lost one of its brightest stars. From his leadership at Bear Stearns to his generosity toward the New York community, John will always be remembered as a model for living life to the fullest and achieving the highest levels of personal and professional success. We send our deepest sympathies to the Slade family. Joseph V. Falanga, CPA on behalf of American Express Tax & Business Services, Inc.

title: Despite Ejection, Yankees Avoid Dejection
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16 - Randy Johnson's snarling, scowling persona serves him well sometimes. It keeps teammates, coaches and reporters at a safe distance. It intimidates opposing hitters. It may help him focus on harnessing his Hall-of-Fame ability.

title: On Beauty
Paid Notice: Memorials   HART, FRANCES MASON
description: HART--Frances Mason.September 17, 2004. Always in our hearts with love, Judy, Lanny, Heather, Greg

title: Investing: Bubble talk on housing
ViewPoints: China's president goes prospecting
Spotlight:What's next for Euronext?
Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSSBARD, HELEN
description: GROSSBARD--Helen. On Sept. 16, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Dr. Lionel (Janet), Dr. Stephen (Elizabeth) & Dr. Elliott (Elayne). Darling grandmother of Doctors Michael and Sarah Jane Grossbard, Doctors Caren & Scott Solomon, Dr. Jeremy Grossbard (Adrienne) and Jessica Grossbard, and Sylvie & Joseph Grossbard. Doting great-grandmother of Will, Katie, Dan, Lily and Lucy. Service Sunday, 9:45 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN--Gladys. In our hearts forever. Your Children and Grandchildren

title: Miller Gave Raises in Last Weeks of Race
description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, gave about $100,000 in merit raises to 20 members of his Council staff in the final weeks of his mayoral campaign, Council officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Harvard and Penn Are Standing Tall
description: The eight Ivy League colleges produce more United States presidents than World Series most valuable players. They are big on Nobel Prizes, ambassadors, bank presidents and chairmen of the board.

title: Iraq's Costs Worry Americans, Poll Indicates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - With Hurricane Katrina already costing the federal government tens of billions of dollars, more than 8 in 10 Americans are very or somewhat concerned that the $5 billion being spent each month on the war in Iraq is draining away money that could be used in the United States, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Death Toll Exceeds 800, as Recovery Continues
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 16 - The official death toll in Louisiana has more than tripled in the past week, jumping to 579 on Friday from 154 last Saturday. Officials attributed the steep increase to receding floodwaters, a full-strength recovery effort and the addition of counts from parishes beyond the most affected areas.

title: Business Briefs
description: US Airways Allowed to Leave Bankruptcy And Merge With America West Airlines A federal judge yesterday approved the plan by US Airways to exit bankruptcy and merge with America West Airlines Inc. Judge Stephen Mitchell of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Virginia signed off on the deal, which will create the fifth-largest domestic airline by passenger volume. US Airways said the merged company would have $2.5 billion in cash, including restricted amounts. It will fly as US Airways and be based at America West headquarters in Tempe, Ariz. Private investors will own 52 percent of the merged airline after committing more than $565 million. Investments by suppliers and vendors increase the merger value to more than $1.5 billion. Shareholders of America West receive 37 percent of the new company and unsecured creditors get 12 percent. (Reuters)

title: Man Accused of Molesting Boys Draws a Church Group's Fire
description: A former official in the Catholic diocese on Long Island who was barred from priestly duties after being accused of molesting boys is prominently listed on the pastoral staff of a Great Neck, N.Y., parish.

title: Evidence Grows That Canada Aided in Having Terrorism Suspects Interrogated in Syria
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 14 - A judicial inquiry here is turning up evidence that Canadian police and intelligence agencies solicited and used information that was obtained from at least four Canadian citizens under torture by foreign intelligence agencies.

title: Officials Prepare for Partial Return of Residents
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 - Officials have set up nine checkpoints around the city and stepped up police and National Guard patrols in preparation for the thousands of business owners and residents who are expected to return to the central business district and two other neighborhoods on Saturday.

title: Also Trying to Sell a Cup of Kindness
description: SINCE Starbucks exploded onto the national coffee scene a decade ago, the company has been growing at an over-caffeinated pace. The company says it wants to leap from 10,000 stores to 30,000 worldwide eventually, roughly the number of outlets McDonald's now has.

title: Maker of Heart Devices May Expand Release of Malfunction Data Beyond F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - A representative of the nation's biggest maker of heart devices, Medtronic, said Friday that it was considering making available to doctors and patients some of the data about product malfunctions that it regularly provides to federal regulators.

title: Air travel plays, on the ground

description: Over and Out

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tour Bus Kills Cyclist
description: A Chinatown souvenir-shop owner was struck and killed by a tour bus as she rode her bicycle in downtown Manhattan at 9:45 yesterday morning on her way to renew her vendor's license, her daughter and the police said. The bus left the scene of the accident, the intersection of Water Street and Gouverneur Lane, the police said. They said the driver might not have been aware of striking Jen Shao, 65, who owned a shop on Mott Street. Investigators said that they were still searching for the bus and its driver last night. An investigator said that after the collision, witnesses reported seeing Ms. Shao fall under the rear wheels of the bus. The victim rode her blue bicycle often, according to her daughter, Cong Cong Hu, in part because cycling was easier for her than walking. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Apocalyptic Vignettes, Violent Yet Intimate
description: It's limitless, all right. But the muddled three-hour epic by Josh Fox, a Brooklyn-based experimental writer and director of dreamscapes like "The Bomb," doesn't exactly inspire joy. Exhaustion is more like it.

title: Going (Down) by the Book
description: NEW ORLEANS - When President Bush spoke from Jackson Square on Thursday night, across the Mississippi River a few men sitting next to a trailer watched him on a television powered by a generator. They listened respectfully, but they were not exactly dazzled.

title: Insuring a Fair Recovery
description: After the government, no group will be more essential to the rebuilding of the Gulf Coast than private insurers. At least one estimate of the final price tag has soared past the $125 billion mark, with insurers' portion of the bill climbing as high as $60 billion. The companies will be trying to help their customers, while worrying about their own bottom lines at the same time. It's important to make sure their judgments are fair -- both for the sake of the hurricane victims and the taxpayers, who will pick up much of the tab the insurers don't pay.

title: The envy of Europe
Tennessee Is in Town, and Florida's Coach Is on Edge
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 16 - Florida Coach Urban Meyer says that every loss takes 10 pounds off his frame and a year off his life. A piercing migraine sets in, and he becomes so insufferable that visiting family members have been known to leave town to avoid his company.

title: China Proposes a Deal to End North Korean Nuclear Standoff
description: BEIJING, Sept. 16 - China proposed a new compromise solution to the North Korean nuclear standoff and gave the countries involved in the talks one day to accept or reject the offer, but there were mixed signals on Friday about whether the United States and North Korea were prepared to come to terms.

title: Ramirez Is Plunked and Boston Wins in 10
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 - The bases were loaded with one out in the 10th inning and Manny Ramirez was staring at an interesting defensive alignment. The Oakland Athletics were playing five infielders and two outfielders, so Ramirez could snare a lot of empty green if he could just rocket the ball to the outfield.

title: Tales of Love at Battery Park, Some Even True
description: Battery Park on Wednesday night was thick with rumors of rain: If not now, then tomorrow, surely; in Jersey it's raining a little, did you know? The wind scurried leaves along the grass. No matter. A good-size pool of the curious and the faithful gathered for the opening of "Evening Stars," a series of free dance performances on the Battery Park lawn, presented by the Joyce Theater and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, that runs through tonight.

title: A World of Dreams With a Burst of Spirit
description: Glen Rumsey has kept travel and dream journals for much of his life, including the years he toured with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company in the 1990's. The journals are the basis for his new "ignored in my heaven," performed by the Glen Rumsey Dance Project on Thursday night at Location One in SoHo as part of the gallery's Creative Atelier series.

title: Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: West, Northwest, Southwest, Plains, Midwest, South, and Science and Health
description: WASHINGTON

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,893 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Government Money Will Flow to Gulf Coast, but Will Fundamental Change Follow?
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 16 - The flip side of disaster is always opportunity. After the flood comes the promise of manna and lofty pledges from on high about not only money but also a new social order. So with breathtaking speed, the political dialogue here has gone past panic and the blame game to an anxious focus on the anticipated windfall from Washington.

title: Briefly: IMF and EU warn on growth
Bush Rules Out Raising Taxes for Gulf Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - President Bush said Friday that rebuilding the Gulf Coast would "cost whatever it costs," that he would not raise taxes to pay for the recovery and that at least some of the expense would have to be offset by budget cuts in other programs.

title: A One-Woman Show of Dance, With Words From the Heart
description: "It all boils down to a few clichAs, and here they are," the solo performer Beverly Blossom says at the start of her new show, "The Incomplete Lament of an Old Dancer." But the 79-year-old Ms. Blossom is nothing if not an original, and there are few clichAs in her short program of gestural dances and cryptic speeches, which opened Thursday night at the Baruch Performing Arts Center in Manhattan. Rather, she weaves together a curious combination of personal history, cultural history and broad humor, animated by an artistry acquired over a lifetime of performance.

title: The End User: Mind what you sign
Stocks: Upgrades bolster Big Board shares
Bush in New Orleans: The Speech, and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: In Person and on TV, Saints Visit the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 16 - The National Football League has lifted the New York-area television blackout for Monday night's game between the Giants and the New Orleans Saints.

title: $200 Million Is Pledged for Higher Education in Africa
description: Encouraged by a rising tide of democracy in Africa, six major American foundations announced yesterday that they would spend $200 million over the next five years to strengthen higher education in seven African countries.

title: A Parent Trying to Save Her Children (and Turn a Profit)
description: If ever a time was ripe for a revival of "Mother Courage and Her Children," Brecht's epic play of war and profit, it would seem to be now. In an effort more commendable for its intention than its execution, the Jean Cocteau Repertory has mounted a staging that fails to capture either the tragedy or the comedy of the play, let alone the ironies of war.

title: And the Film Deal Goes to . . . an Outsider
description: A new crop of movie entrepreneurs tested their wares at the Toronto International Film Festival over the last week, and several had cause to be pleased with the results.

title: FEMA, Slow to the Rescue, Now Stumbles in Aid Effort
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORD, JOHN J.
description: FORD--John J. On September 15. Beloved husband of Terry. Devoted father of Tara Ford Spiegel. Cherished brother of Martin and Kitty Riley, and the late Andrew and Peter. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, on Saturday, 7-9 pm, and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 10 am, St. Ignatius Loyola. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Bank chief in Italy off EU hook?
The Water's Fine. Don't Come In.
description: DELHI, N.Y., Sept. 12 - The graceful obelisk in front of the Delaware County office building here solemnly commemorates the noble sacrifices of Catskill Mountain men during the Civil War.

title: Saturday's Top College Football Games
description: No. 13 Miami (0-1) at No. 20 Clemson (2-0)

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: A Face Seen and Unseen on the Subway
description: YOU might look past him as you sat across from him on the subway. If you briefly paused to study his face, you might wonder about his life's story -- What have those eyes seen? -- before turning to search the car for someone more interesting. Then, when you returned your gaze to his seat, he would be gone, assumed into the human blur of New York City.

title: It's a Start (Sort Of) for Mussina
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16 - No, Joe Torre explained, he had not spoken with Mike Mussina as of late Friday afternoon. "I don't talk to the starters on the day they pitch," said Torre, the Yankees' manager.

title: In New York Cribs, Jeff and Lisa Give Way to Ahmed and Chaya
description: In the last several years, New York City has had more baby girls named Fatoumata than Lisa, more Aaliyahs than Melissas, more Chayas than Christinas. There have been more baby boys named Moshe than Peter, more Miguels than Jeffreys, more Ahmeds than Stanleys.

title: Herms Selects a Nonfamily Member as Chief Executive
description: The Herms fashion house has promoted Patrick Thomas to sole chief executive, the first person outside the Dumas family to run the company in its 168-year history. Mr. Thomas, 58, served as co-chief executive with Jean-Louis Dumas, 67, a member of the family that owns 75 percent of the company. Mr. Dumas said that he would retire in January. Thomas Crampton (IHT)

title: Disney on Parade
description: WASHINGTON - The president, as he fondly recalled the other day, used to get well lit in New Orleans. Not any more.

title: A paparazzo's take oncelebrity 'hype'
Europeans get 'a bit of protection' at gas pump
Putting the Squeeze on a Bubble
description: WHEN Alan Greenspan warned that the stock market was displaying signs of "irrational exuberance," share prices collapsed -- four years later. Now the Federal Reserve chairman says he can glimpse similar frothiness in housing prices. Does that mean that investors who have benefited from sharp rallies in sectors tied to real estate, not to mention homeowners, will get a free pass for four years?

title: Cheney Faces Surgery Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - Vice President Cheney will undergo surgery next week to repair a weakness in a blood vessel behind his right knee, his spokesman confirmed on Friday.

title: From Artist in a Helmet to Nice Guy at His Worst
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 16 - James Reed resembles a cartoon character on the field, his 285 pounds of bulk balancing on feet as nimble as a ballet dancer's.

title: Far From Home, He Hit Just the Right Note
description: The telephone receiver lay on a desk. A 7-year-old girl, daughter of the pianist, twirled about. Satoru Ohashi was playing his horn: Several choruses of "Struttin' With Some Barbecue." Then a ballad, "I Can't Get Started." Finally, some chord changes from "I Got Rhythm."

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Thousands Pour Into Egypt
description: At least 5,000 Palestinians broke through Egyptian and Palestinian Authority lines on the Gaza border again, pouring into Egypt in defiance of government attempts to stop them, The Associated Press reported. The Palestinian Authority and Egypt have promised to stop the flow but failed, prompting increasing anxiety and criticism from Israel, which handed over control of the border on Monday. Palestinians threw stones at their own security forces and then overwhelmed Egyptian police officers who had put down barbed wire and tried to beat them back. "They look like they're running a system which has neither law nor order, neither organization nor authority," an Israeli Defense Ministry official, Amos Gilad, told Israel Army Radio. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: The wit and wisdom of Geoffrey Beene
As Ferrer Gains Support, Bloomberg Chooses to Withhold Some
description: On the day that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton endorsed the mayoral candidacy of Fernando Ferrer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg broke with the Republican White House and said he opposed the Supreme Court nomination of Judge John G. Roberts Jr.

title: Visit to Jailed Client Ends in Lawyer's Arrest
description: Being a criminal defense lawyer has its privileges. There are the lucrative hourly fees, occasional television appearances, identification cards that allow lawyers to bypass lengthy courthouse security lines and that golden rule known as attorney-client privilege.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the trial of a Hmong refugee accused in the killing of six Wisconsin hunters referred incorrectly to Terry Willers, who was shot. He was wounded, not killed.

title: The Normality of Gay Marriages
description: There's nothing like a touch of real-world experience to inject some reason into the inflammatory national debate over gay marriages. Take Massachusetts, where the state's highest court held in late 2003 that under the State Constitution, same-sex couples have a right to marry. The State Legislature moved to undo that decision last year by approving a proposed constitutional amendment to ban gay marriages and create civil unions as an alternative. But this year, when precisely the same measure came up for a required second vote, it was defeated by a thumping margin of 157 to 39.

title: An Evangelical Comic Provokes Holy Laughter
description: BRENTWOOD, Tenn., Sept. 14 - In his study in suburban Nashville, Brad Stine was working out a routine about intelligent design. The bit was in its formative stages, but Mr. Stine, a born-again Christian, felt the topic had potential. "I'm trying to find elements of evolution that are suspect," he said, ramping up into character. "Like, if it took a billion years for a bug to develop camouflage, what did he do in the meantime -- hiii-iiide?" He sneered the last word into two escalating syllables.

title: Forget Star Chef; Think Professional Eater
description: Anthony Bourdain, a chef turned writer turned television host, has a large, delicate and elastic mouth, which is a handy thing given that it is his primary instrument. For years, it served as a testing ground for the food he cranked out all over Manhattan and finally at Les Halles, the classic bistro on Park Avenue South in Manhattan. His pie hole was also a portal for the many chemicals -- principally, but hardly limited to, beverage alcohol -- that kept him going in his cooking days.

title: The Union That Can't Throw Straight
description: DID you hear the one about the football player who offered to play injured if his team would guarantee his 2006 salary? True story. The player is Matt Birk, a Harvard graduate and four-time Pro Bowl center for the Minnesota Vikings. Last season, despite three hernia operations and chronic pain, he played in most of his team's games. As this season began, though, he had a torn labrum in his left hip -- a painful injury that was a direct consequence of coming back too quickly from last year's ailments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILL, CAROL
description: HILL--Carol. Died September 9, 2005 in NY. AFTRA-SAG. Actress, TV Weather girl, Interviewer. Instructor: Announcer Training Studios, Kingsborough, Brooklyn College, John Jay. MS in Speech & Theatre, Brooklyn College 1973. Beloved friend.

title: Premium for Basic Medicare Increasing 13% Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - The Bush administration announced on Friday that the basic Medicare premium would shoot up next year 13 percent, to $88.50 a month, mainly because of the increased use of doctors' services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTOW, MIRIAM
description: OSTOW--Miriam. The Jewish Theological Seminary community mourns the death of Miriam Ostow, a member of our Albert A. List College of Jewish Studies Board of Overseers. A graduate of JTS and Columbia University, where she served as Associate Director of the Eisenhower Center for the Conservation of Human Resources, Miriam was a leader and scholar. As a longtime friend of JTS, she tirelessly supported the Jewish community with a compassionate nature and sharp intellect. Miriam was the lifelong partner to her beloved husband, former Professor of Pastoral Psychiatry at JTS, Dr. Mortimer Ostow. May all her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: Not All N.H.L. Players Happy With Leadership
description: TORONTO, Sept. 15 - The appointment of Ted Saskin as executive director of the National Hockey League Players' Association is being challenged by a group of veteran players, and the escalating controversy threatens to divide the players just as they return to the ice after the cancellation of last season because of a lockout.

title: Israel to Disrupt Palestinian Vote if Hamas Runs
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon vowed Friday to withhold Israeli cooperation from Palestinian legislative elections in January if candidates from the militant group Hamas take part.

title: Walking Back to Houston With Anna or Waingro
description: As hole cards in no-limit hold'em, an ace with a king is one of the thorniest hands to play without bleeding your stack or draining it down to the felt. You may be fingering the two highest unpaired cards, but your hand is an underdog to even a lowly pair of deuces -- an underdog, in fact, to every pocket pair. Kings, for example, are a 70 percent favorite over A-K, aces a whopping 92.6 percent, while aces beat deuces only 80 percent of the time. Yet players routinely fold deuces before the flop but raise with A-K.

title: Martnez Makes Sure Runs Are No Issue
description: With the Mets' season slipping away, one of the only things that can draw fans to Shea Stadium on a dreary September night is a certain 5-foot-11, 175-pound right-hander who has been known to do some special things with a baseball.

title: Giants and Jets Have 10 Days to Work Out a Stadium Deal
description: It is now up to the Giants and the Jets whether there will be a new stadium complex in the Meadowlands.

title: Accounting for the Smithsonian's Disrepair
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Basic Medicare Premium To Jump 13% Next Year The Bush administration announced that the basic Medicare premium would rise 13 percent next year, to $88.50 a month, mainly because of the increased use of doctors' services. Many beneficiaries will pay an additional premium for the new prescription drug benefit, expected to average $32 a month. PAGE A8

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Moscow Journal article on Wednesday, about the profusion of luxurious restrooms in Moscow restaurants, misstated the name of the establishment in the heart of the city, just around the corner from the Kremlin. It is Cafe Freud, not Cafe 5.

title: A Latin Beat on Behalf of Bloomberg
description: An advertisement for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg featuring a song sung by the trombonist and salsa musician Willie Coln, will begin running this weekend on Spanish-language broadcast and cable stations.

title: A Band That Won't Ask, Are You Ready to Rock?
description: The independent rock at the core of the CMJ Music Marathon, the four-day convention and showcase that ends tonight, isn't so much a musical style as a constellation of business practices and a coalition of cult followings. And the New Pornographers, who played a packed Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, sum up indie rock's self-conscious joys.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Dna Tests Reviewed
description: An independent review of the state's central crime laboratory, prompted by its botched DNA testing in a capital murder case involving a retarded defendant, found that the laboratory did not make technical errors in its handling of DNA in 123 other cases, Gov. Mark Warner's office said. But Peter Neufeld, co-director of the Innocence Project, said the review was deeply flawed because the panel did not review trial transcripts to determine whether laboratory analysts had distorted test results in sworn testimony. Mr. Warner ordered the review in May because of mistakes by one of its top analysts in the case of Earl Washington Jr., who came within days of execution but has since had his sentence commuted. James Dao (NYT)

title: Smithson's Floating Sculpture
description: We do all remember that Manhattan is an island. Yet it can seem, especially from its middle blocks, like a Gulliver of an island -- tied down by Lilliputian bridges and tunnels, so tightly shackled to the mainland that it no longer stands apart in the imagination. Even at the water's edge, the scale of Manhattan is large enough to hide its separateness -- a problem in perspective. From the Hudson water line, New Jersey looks almost as circumnavigable as Manhattan itself, or it would if you didn't know that New Jersey was the continent, true and proper. But now we will all have a chance to contemplate the island-ness of our island city, thanks to "Floating Island to Travel Around Manhattan Island" by Robert Smithson.

title: Aspiring Starter Will Take Any Role
description: At 6 feet 5 inches and 220 pounds, and boasting a fire hose of a right arm, Aaron Heilman looks like he could have played football at his alma mater, Notre Dame. It would have prepared Heilman well for his role in the Mets' bullpen, where he is the team's version of a backup quarterback.

title: Gadgets of the week: Hearing aid for cellphone calls
A Virtuosic Exploration of the Origins of Modern Guitar
description: Few guitarists have played more contemporary music than David Starobin, both on record and in the concert hall. But every now and then, Mr. Starobin steps back to look at the modern guitar's early 19th-century roots. Since the early 1990's, he has made several superb recordings of works by Mauro Giuliani, an Italian guitarist and composer who spent much of his career in Vienna, and Fernando Sor, a Spaniard who spent his most productive years in London and Paris. On Wednesday evening, Mr. Starobin devoted a recital at the Manhattan School of Music to variations and character pieces by both.

title: In New Orleans, Businesses Take First Steps Back
description: As New Orleans struggles to get back on its feet, the city's employers will play a major role. In some areas, it could be months before business returns to normal. But many employers, particularly the biggest ones in some crucial industries, are already beginning to reopen and bring employees back, often helping them find housing and supplying transportation. Here is an overview of employment in the city and in the center of tourism, the French Quarter.

title: Bomb rocks Beirut suburb
Don't Push Syria Away
description: Damascus, Syria - BASHAR AL-ASSAD would have been the first Syrian president in 40 years to visit the United States had he attended the United Nations summit meeting in New York this week as planned. And it could have been an opportunity for two countries that have notably tense relations to talk. Instead, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice delayed his visa, excluded him from a meeting of foreign ministers to discuss Lebanon and Syria, and had a United Nations investigator arrive in Damascus at the time of his departure. Boxed in, Mr. Assad canceled his plans.

title: Roll Over, 'Cats.' The Real Thing Is Here.
description: The manager of the coffee shop in Midtown was sorry, but he could not let Yuri Kuklachev and his entourage come in; the New York City Department of Health does not allow animals in restaurants. In Mr. Kuklachev's hand was a cat carrier containing Marusa, his favorite cat. He had brought her to New York, along with 25 other cats, on the nine-hour trip from Russia to perform in the Moscow Cats Theater here, and he was not about to be deterred by details. After repeated promises to keep the carrier under the table and well out of sight, everyone was allowed to sit down.

title: The Paintings of Bascove
description: Her love affair with bridges began in Philadelphia, where the artist who calls herself Bascove grew up.

title: The Odd Couple: Paul Simon and Dr. Irwin Redlener
description: Think of it as the perfect marriage of hip and square: Paul Simon, the singer-composer-guitarist who can still rock you into a sweet thundering oblivion (I saw him perform just a few months ago), and Irwin Redlener, the dedicated, cerebral physician who refuses to let go of the thought that good people and hard work can change the world.

title: Welcome
description: What can you do on the Web that you cant do in print? A lot. Theres still no substitute for traditional newspapers, but adding online material can really enhance the overall product.

title: The Laws of the Jungle
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Poor Planning and Corruption Hobble Reconstruction of Iraq
description: NAJAF, Iraq - In April, Najaf's main maternity hospital received rare good news: an $8 million refurbishment program financed by the United States would begin immediately. But five months and millions of dollars later, the hospital administrators say they have little but frustration to show for it.

title: At Oxford, Academe's Quads and Gargoyles for the Precollege Set
description: Correction Appended

title: A Few Soft Wedge Shots by the Zipper
description: YEARNING to play golf in Times Square, bask on a lawn there, take an outdoor shower? Luxury housing is now being built in the city's frenetic vortex.

title: Connecticut Sun Back in the Finals
description: The Connecticut Sun has reached the Women's National Basketball Association championship finals for the second consecutive year. The third game of the best-of-five series against the Sacramento Monarch is scheduled for Sunday in Sacramento.

title: PARC NATIONAL DES VOLCANS, JULY 10, 2005
description: Ronnie Taffet, 54, from Manhattan, a vice president at Macy's. "The gorillas normally just do their thing: they eat and hang out as if you weren't there. What was so amazing with this young gorilla was that he looked at me and I looked at him for what seemed like minutes. He locked eyeballs with me. I want to believe that it was because he knew that I loved him, that he knew I was such a fan of his species. He was sort of sitting there, and he stared at me, and then he stood up and pounded his chest, like he was showing me 'I'm the boss, let's keep this straight.' It was just amazing. Even the guides were blown away. I had the biggest smile. I just couldn't believe that we were connecting like that." As told to Seth Kugel WHY WE TRAVEL: RUHENGERI, RWANDA

title: The Forgotten Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Shares
description: When my 15-year-old daughter and I are in the car, we vie for control of the radio. My solution has been to divide the time 50-50; however, she insists that this is not fair, since I control the radio when she is not in the car. Hence, I owe her more time. What's the ethical way to share the radio? Flix Alfonso Pea, Reading, Pa.

title: Ninth Avenue: Curtain Up
description: As the new season begins on Broadway, so does the same old congestion on the adjacent side streets. Things are a little less hectic over on Ninth Avenue, where small, stylish restaurants are opening every month.

title: No Cause to Sue School
description: A federal judge ruled last week that the parents of a Syosset boy who was suspended from school over a creative writing assignment had no valid cause to sue the school district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLANCY, CAROLE MARIE
description: CLANCY--Carole Marie. 62, of San Jose, California died on September 5 at Stanford University Medical Center, Stanford, CA. after a long battle with breast cancer. Ms. Clancy, a broadcast and newspaper journalist, was an Executive Producer for NBC TV, shaping the initial "Live At Five" television newscast format on WNBC TV in New York. She was awarded an Emmy for a docutmentary production in 1984. Most recently, she was the editor of the Silicon Valley/San Jose, CA. business journal. During her ongoing battle with cancer, Ms. Clancy was particularly moved by young children being treated for the disease. She used her observations as the foundation of a childrens book "Hat Tricks" about children dealing with their own treatments or those of a family member. Ms. Clancy was preceded in death by her mother, Margaret Ann Clancy. She is survived by her father Jay Burton Clancy and stepmother Corinne Clancy of Hilton Head Island, SC. Two sisters Jill Roller and Susan Clancy. A nephew Ryan Roller and brother-in-law Bill Roller all of Basking Ridge, NJ.

title: I'll See Your High G and Raise You an A Flat
description: Correction Appended

title: Close Encounter of the Human Kind
description: With the first busloads of Katrina refugees about to arrive in San Antonio, the call went out for physician volunteers, and I signed up for the 2 a.m. to 8 a.m. shift. On the way, riding down dark, deserted streets, I thought of driving in for night shifts in the I.C.U. as an intern many years ago, and how I would try to steel myself, as if putting on armor.

title: The Paparazzi Don't Come Around Anymore
description: JERSEY CITY - ON a routine workday five years ago, Maria Pignataro might have dined in view of the Eiffel Tower, traveled across the Atlantic on a private jet and made her way home in a limo hired by her client, Elizabeth Taylor. Yes, that Elizabeth Taylor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, RITA
description: GOLDBERG--Rita on September 15, 2005. Beloved wife of Melvin. Loving mother of Hal and Carrie, Lonny and Debra. Dear sister of Arlene and Irving. Adoring Nana of Justin and Carly. We love you so much. You will always be in our hearts. God bless you in Heaven. Service Friday, 11:15 AM at "The Riverside", 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: THE TRAIN OF THE FUTURE
description: New Jersey Transit officials offered commuters a glimpse of their train-riding future in Newark last Wednesday, and it was not drab, rigid or strictly horizontal. But what clearly was most appealing to all who beheld it was that it would eliminate the chance of spending more than an hour a day pressed between two strangers. "The middle seat is gone," cheered Maxine Marshall, who commutes from Plainfield to Jersey City. Well, it is not gone yet. The gleaming vehicle, unveiled at Newark Penn Station, was a prototype of New Jersey Transit's first bilevel passenger car, which will not be in service for at least a year. There are only two seats on each side of the aisle. The railroad plans to start running the first batch of 100 cars in late 2006 to ease crowding on its trains into and out of Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. Those trains are rapidly approaching full capacity during rush hours. The most comfortable way to squeeze more people onto each train is to add a second level, said Jack Lettiere, the state's transportation commissioner and chairman of New Jersey Transit. A typical 10-car train will have 1,375 seats, or about 225 more than on a comparable train today. Patrick McGeehan

title: MEMORIES OF SIENA
description: To the Editor: Having visited Siena twice, we found Pableaux Johnson's portrait of his sojourn there bringing to mind our visit to its virtually hidden synagogue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPKIN, JACK L.
description: POPKIN--Jack L. age 87. A true gentleman loved by all who knew him, for his integrity, generosity and kindness. Established Jack L. Popkin Co. in 1947. He will be dearly missed by all, especially by his wife Rita, his children and his grandchildren. Services today 10am at "Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer" 114-03 Queens Boulevard (Cor 76th Road) Forest Hills, NY.

title: THE BANKRUPTCY BARRIER
description: When Northwest Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection last Wednesday, James P. Womack, a manufacturing specialist and author, was on one of its flights. "I actually flew through bankruptcy yesterday," he said Thursday, phoning from aboard a delayed flight in Boston. "I thought there would be a bump or a shudder but there actually was nothing at all."

title: Realistic Goals at U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Christina Pino-Marina and Chris Hughey
description: Christina Pino-Marina, a daughter of Randee Kay Pino-Marina and Nestor Pino-Marina of Vienna, Va., was married yesterday to Phillip Christopher Hughey, the son of Patricia E. Mullins Hughey of Jacksonville, N.C., and Phillip W. Hughey of Peckville, Pa. The Rev. J. Carlyle Gill performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Picturesque West Side Block of the Tall and the Short
description: Correction Appended

title: Wary of 'Hotshot' Youngsters? Then Steer Clear of Radjabov
description: My good friend of many years Alan Truscott, known to New York Times readers as the bridge columnist, and I had a rivalry going for at least two decades. It wasn't in bridge; I played the game for relaxation between serious chess rounds. I was not up to playing against a champion. And Alan never embarrassed me by inviting me to play. Before he came to the United States, he was an English national chess master, but we never crossed swords in that game either; players of that rank do not challenge grandmasters.

title: TERRYCLOTH ON THE WAY OUT?
description: To the Editor: In "What's Over/What's Next" (Aug. 7), Terry Trucco claims that terrycloth bathrobes are on the way out in the hotel industry. We, along with most of our five-star hotel clients, disagree.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Titanic Memorial Lighthouse, now at the South Street Seaport Museum in Manhattan, misstated the number of people on the Titanic when it sank in 1912. There were more than 2,200, not 1,500.

title: The Industry: The Gambler
description: It takes a rock-solid stomach to open a restaurant. According to Brian Buckley, a New York restaurant analyst, for every two restaurants that open in Manhattan, only one will still be operating in two years' time. One man who seems to be undeterred by those odds is Rick Camac, the managing director for several eateries in progress: Adiletto's, an upscale pizzeria with branches in the West Village and Midtown, and Fatty Crab, a Southeast Asian bistro that's set to open this Monday on Hudson Street.

title: The Scarlet in Singapore
description: THE BASICS -- Idiosyncratic restoration projects are all the rage in Singapore. The Scarlet, for instance, was a row of Chinese merchants' houses dating from the 1860's and a 1920's Art Deco building before its $35 million conversion into a voguish 84-room boutique hotel. At the entrance, a tall amiable doorman in scarlet-collared black livery escorts visitors under the Venetian crystal chandelier to the low-ceilinged lobby and bar area. Gilt mirrors, high-backed velvet chairs and bronze Ert-esque statuettes establish the Scarlet's Moulin Rouge-bordello-meets-Deco-chic mood. One-word names for the bar (Bold), restaurants (Breeze, Desire) and five suites (Splendour, Passion, Opulent, Lavish and Swank) also play on the come-hither theme.

title: Cleanup of Forge River
description: Crews began cleaning up duck-farm residue and other pollutants last week at the headwaters of the Forge River, once a popular fishing stream in Moriches and Mastic, whose waters this summer were murky gray, foul smelling and littered with dead fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERVEY, SANDRA HOPE SEIDEL
description: GERVEY--Sandra Hope Seidel, died September 4, leaving three children, Joshua, Ben and Jennifer; sister, Ethel Seidel Maloy; three grandchildren, and dear friends, Richard Gardner and Vicky Rosenblatt. 480-551-0551.

title: For Native Americans, Buying Has Become Easier
description: SPOKANE, Wash. - ON his way to a traditional Native American dance competition a few weeks ago, Rodney Abrahamson, a police officer with the Bureau of Indian Affairs, stopped off at a title company to sign the papers refinancing his home mortgage. It was a satisfying stroke of the pen.

title: Killing Time
description: While plenty of celebrities boast of their eco-friendly Priuses, there are some alpha A-listers who would rather accessorize with a bolt-action rifle. The British shoot-'em-up director Guy Ritchie has taken aim at everything from wild boar to clay pigeons. Kurt Russell tracks game and then donates his quarry to charity. And the N.R.A. rocker Ted Nugent likes bagging and cooking wild game so much that he penned a cookbook, "Kill It & Grill It."

title: New Trust Lets Coles Share Secret
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 16 - If you want to plug into Laveranues Coles's inner life, borrow his iPod.

title: That's the Way the Tree Falls
description: DO you feel that success has eluded you? You're not alone. All too often, even when fortune smiles on some lucky or worthy devil, he can see only what is missing, cataloging only the empty spaces between the stuff.

title: North Korea Talks Extended To Discuss Chinese Proposal
description: BEIJING, Sept. 17 - Sparring continued Saturday over North Korea's conditions for dismantling its atomic weapons program, with the six nations negotiating over North Korea's nuclear program agreeing to extend the talks to a sixth day.

title: Symbol of a Sweeter Past Has a Murky Future
description: If Red Hook, Brooklyn, has a skyline, the abandoned Revere Sugar factory at Richards and Beard Streets may well be the neighborhood's Chrysler Building, its distinctive conical silo jutting out from the old waterfront to be seen for miles around.

title: So What Do You Call A Stand-In for Codey?
description: Years from now, this may only be remembered as the answer to some New Jersey-centric trivia question. Nonetheless, Asembly Speaker Albio Sires was clearly relishing his role as the acting governor. Or would that be the acting acting governor?

title: In the Amazon, Where Our Sister Was Slain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICODEMUS, RICHARD T.
description: NICODEMUS--Richard T. Investment advisor, died September 14, 2005 at age 80. Founded Nicodemus & Sherwood with partner of 30 years Deborah Sherwood. Decorated WWII veteran, musician, conservationist, and farmer. Survived by wife Elisabeth; sisters Anne, Fairlie and Jane; children Sigrun, Morli, and Christopher; and five grandchildren. Send donations to Peconic Land Trust, P.O. Box 1776, Southampton, NY 11969 or St. George's Society of New York, 216 E. 45th St., Ste. 901, NY, NY 10017. Service Monday, September 19, 11 AM, St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A National Perspectives article last Sunday about adobe houses in Mesilla, N.M., misstated the registration of 416 historic buildings there. They are registered with the New Mexico Historic Preservation Division, not the National Register of Historic Places. The article also misidentified the previous owner of the Fountain House, a large adobe there. It was owned by Albert Jennings Fountain, not his grandfather Col. Albert Jennings Fountain.

title: Cycling: It's September, Spain and Heras
Free Election, No Freedom From Fear
description: Afghans are set to elect a National Assembly and 34 provincial councils today after a campaign plagued by violence and intimidation. Last week, Human Rights Watch said in a report that candidates had faced threats from insurgents in the south who include former Taliban fighters, and from warlords who were candidates. Women running for office have been particular targets, and the election law allows losing candidates to take the seats of winners who die in office or resign (this is called the "assassination clause" because of the temptation it raises). Here are excerpts of some accounts from witnesses, as they appear in the report. MARC D. CHARNEY

title: Giving Them What They Want
description: With the flap over "memogate" still fresh at CBS, your writer missed a perfect opportunity to elicit opinions on the duties and responsibilities of news reporting from the head of a broadcast network. What we got instead was a plan to redecorate the house with no mention that it may be burning to the ground.

title: A Golden Rule: Enrollment for All
description: SEAN O'NEIL, 4, clung to his mother outside the Stanwich School in Greenwich several days after the family had fled their New Orleans home. Asked why he seemed sad, Sean, who is attending kindergarten at the school, burrowed his head into his mother's hip and said, "Because we lost our world."

title: Life in the Shelters: Isolated and Perilous
description: PUNTA GORDA, Fla., Sept. 17 - In a part of the world where palm trees, lush grasses and other flora thrive, the neighborhood just east of this small city is an anomaly, with its chalky gravel roads and barren landscape. Identical white mobile homes are lined up like barracks across a 90-acre site, which is devoid of color but for the red stop signs and green street markers that crop up between the bleak rows.

title: Hurricanes Hold On to Win in 3rd Overtime
description: CLEMSON, S.C., Sept. 17 - Miami 36, Clemson 30

title: The Curveballs That Life Throws
description: THE last time I saw Brian Dykstra, he was at the tiny Triad Theater in New York, doing an exhilarating one-man show that was mostly about what was wrong with the Bush administration.

title: Braves Repel Woes, and Mets, Yet Again
description: With every division title, the Braves have developed a force field of a mystique that lets them overcome misfortune.

title: Refugee Groups Reaching Out to Victims of Hurricane
description: Correction Appended

title: DataBank; Stocks Slip on Worries Over Effects of Katrina
description: The stock market gave up ground last week on concerns that the economy may be slowing and inflation rising in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

title: It's Unfair to Give Short Shrift to Hewitt
description: It's Unfair to Give

title: Poor Planning and Corruption Hobble Reconstruction of Iraq
description: NAJAF, Iraq - In April, Najaf's main maternity hospital received rare good news: an $8 million refurbishment program financed by the United States would begin immediately. But five months and millions of dollars later, the hospital administrators say they have little but frustration to show for it.

title: Political Science
description: Since Galileo was forced by religious literalists to repudiate his own scientific experiments showing the earth circled the sun, perhaps we should feel some sympathy for the presidential science adviser, John H. Marburger III, a middle-manager hoping to salvage some semblance of reality-based thinking in the White House.

title: A Thriving Market, And a Community Pillar
description: CLIFTON - TO drivers zipping by on the Garden State Parkway, the beige-brown shingled sign for Corrado's Family Affair stands out just as much as it did when James Corrado and his three sons opened their produce market here 30 years ago. From the ground, though, it's clear that Corrado's has become something more. The store remains family owned by "the triumvirate" -- the brothers Peter, Joey and Jerry -- and managed by 8 of their 17 children. But the enterprise has expanded into a mini-empire that takes in 23 acres along the Crooks Avenue border that separates Paterson and Clifton.

title: Meredith Ullman and Richard Weintraub
description: Meredith Ullman, a daughter of Judith Ullman and Dr. Julian Ullman of Chicago, was married last evening to Richard Peter Weintraub, the son of Linda Weintraub and M. Douglas Weintraub of New York. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

title: For one family, elections give hope
Statistical Twins Are Separated by Triples
description: With every beguiling arc he shoots into the San Francisco night, Barry Bonds -- who returned to the Giants' lineup Monday after missing the first 142 games of the season with a knee injury -- steps closer to Babe Ruth on the career home run list. Ruth had 714 homers, second to Hank Aaron's 755. Bonds homered Friday night to push his total to 704.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page picture in this section last Sunday with an article about a dispute over the sale of historic documents by the Thomas Paine National Historical Association Museum in New Rochelle showed the Thomas Paine Cottage, adjacent to the museum. The cottage is managed by the Huguenot and New Rochelle Historical Association, a separate entity not involved in the dispute. The picture should not have appeared.

title: What Wasn't Said Is Focus as Italy Debates Gay Rights
description: ROME, Sept. 17 - The two faces of Italy -- one that is increasingly secular and the other that is still deeply influenced by the church -- collided this week in a noisy electoral debate that left one thing clear: Italy, it can safely be said, will not legalize gay marriage any time soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, MARY DUER
description: BROWN--Mary Duer. 74, landscape watercolorist died September 14, 2005 at her home in Bethesda, MD. after a long battle with breast cancer. Mrs. Brown was a native of New York City and Middleburg, VA. She was a graduate of the Foxcroft School, Middleburg, VA and The School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. She summered in Bass Harbor, ME. She was a member of the Southern Watercolor Society, Midwest Watercolor Society and Kentucky Watercolor Society. She painted for The Coast Guard Arts Program. She was a member of the Colony Club, NY, the Salmagundi Club, NY, the Sulgrave Club, Washington, DC and a former member of the Blue Hill Troupe, NY. She is survived by her husband, Stanley N. Brown, Jr., two daughters, Catherine Stanton of NYC, Starr Sears of Washington, DC, a son, Henry Brown of NYC, a brother, Beverley Chew Duer of NYC and five grandchildren. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center 1275 York Ave. NY, NY 10021.

description: Q. Your boss has begun to display a pattern of irrational behavior, and it is putting a strain on people in the office. What should you do?

title: Caylee Yerkes and Michael Ribeiro
description: Caylee Yerkes, a police officer, was married yesterday to Michael Ribeiro, a repair technician. Canon Thomas P. Miller performed the Episcopal ceremony at Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: HAWAII IN THE FALL -- The Outrigger Hotels and Resorts are offering reduced prices for fall at two condominium properties on the big island, Hawaii, and on Oahu, through Dec. 21. For instance, for as low as $219 a night (down from $325), guests can stay in a two-bedroom, two-bathroom condo at the year-old Outrigger Fairway Villas on the Kohala Coast of Hawaii. At the Outrigger Luana Waikiki, on Oahu a studio unit without a kitchen is as little as $115 a night (reduced from $210) or a one-bedroom suite with kitchen for as low as $195 a night (usually $325). All prices exclude 11 percent tax. For details, call (800) 688-7444 or see www.outrigger.com.

title: Aging, Frail, and Refugees From the Hurricane
description: COLUMBIA, La., Sept. 15 - The frail residents of the Wynhoven Health Care Center fled New Orleans and the havoc of Hurricane Katrina for a high school gymnasium, where they spent four nights sleeping on the floor with just inches between them. Then they endured a 10-hour bus ride to this rural outpost in northeastern Louisiana more than 200 miles from home that might as well have been the far side of the moon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLBROOK, LEE S.
description: HOLBROOK--Lee S., 40, of Yarmouth, ME died suddenly Saturday September 3, 2005. The beloved daughter of Holly G. Holbrook of Yarmouth and David D. Holbrook of NYC. Lee was born March 24, 1965 in Mount Kisco, NY. Lee graduated from Millbrook School in Millbrook, NY and went on to Curry College in Milton, MA, where she received her degree in Early Childhood Education. She taught in the Portland Maine Public School System before opening her own pre-school and daycare center, the Holbrook Center in Freeport, ME. An avid horsewoman, Lee moved to Yarmouth in 1992 and opened Royal River Farm, an equine boarding and training facility. She became an integral part of the Yarmouth community, sharing her time and talents not only with the horse community but also with many other people and organizations. In addition to her parents, Lee is survived by a sister, Helene H. Downs and her family in Charlottesville, VA; and a brother, Christopher C. Holbrook and his family in Greenwich, CT. Many cousins, nieces, nephews, aunts and uncles will also miss Lee dearly. Lee was a special woman with an extremely generous spirit. Her easy laugh and kindness towards all living creatures will be missed by all who had the honor to know and love her. Services were private. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Millbrook School, Millbrook, NY 12545.

title: A Golden Rule: Enrollment for All
description: SEAN O'NEIL, 4, clung to his mother outside the Stanwich School in Greenwich several days after the family had fled their New Orleans home. Asked why he seemed sad, Sean, who is attending kindergarten at the school, burrowed his head into his mother's hip and said, "Because we lost our world."

title: Inky-Fingered Fanatics
description: When folks absolutely must have their nibs tweaked, Richard Binder is often their go-to guy. His skills as a nibmeister have made him famous in the somewhat esoteric but exuberant fellowship of American fountain pen aficionados. People who turn to him because their vintage Parker 51 seems to be writing too dry or too wet, or because they want the nib of their Pelikan 600 reground into an oblique or a stub, boast thereafter that their pens have been "Binderized."

title: Message: I Care About the Black Folks
description: Correction Appended

title: Mixed results mean businesses face a more uncertain world
A New Mix: Anime and Guilt
description: A Japanese scientist agonizing over the terrible experiments he performed during World War II? You may not find him in a Japanese history text, but you will in the anime series "Tetsujin 28." The show, which makes its American debut on DVD on Tuesday, features three professors wracked by guilt over wartime research that produced, in the words of one of them, "things that should never have been brought into this world."

title: Insurgents assassinate Iraqi lawmaker

description: WATMAN--Pearl. Zabar's & the Zabar family mourn the passing of our much loved cousin and former Controller, Pearl Watman for her many years of hard work and dedication. She was truly a unique individual and words cannot describe how much she will be missed. Our hearts go out to her daughters Andrea and Joy, grandsons Benjamin and Sam and family.

description: Elizabeth Daphna Heyman, a daughter of Ronnie F. Heyman and Samuel J. Heyman of New York, is to be married today to David Scott Winter, the son of Susan R. Winter and Benjamin J. Winter, also of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the bride's parents' summer house in Greens Farms, Conn., with Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman participating in the ceremony.

title: The Statesman
description: At 1:45 in the morning one day this past July, Bono, the lead singer for U2 and the world's foremost agitator for aid to Africa, was in a van heading back to his hotel in Edinburgh from Murrayfield Stadium; he had just performed in, and expounded at, a concert designed to coincide with the beginning of the summit meeting of the major industrialized nations, held nearby at the Gleneagles resort. Despite the hour, practically everybody in the van was on a cellphone. The bodyguard in the front seat was calling the hotel to see if a huge crowd would still be camped outside hoping to catch a glimpse of their world-straddling hero. (Roger that.) Lucy Matthew, the head of the London office of DATA, Bono's policy and advocacy body -- the acronym stands for Debt AIDS Trade Africa -- was whispering to some contact in the States. And Bono, who had been conferring 12 hours earlier at Gleneagles with President George Bush, Prime Minister Tony Blair and Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, was sharing an anxiety attack with a friend. The leaders of the G-8, as the group is known, were going to offer far less in aid and trade to developing nations in Africa than the activists had led their followers to expect. Thousands of bright-eyed young recruits to the cause were going to go home in disgust.

title: Will Arnett: Hollywood Squares
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. - TO do well at comedy and poker, you better have mastered the art of the deadpan expression. And Will Arnett, one of the stars of "Arrested Development," the deft, mock-documentary television series about rich people behaving blithely and the adult children of shopaholics, has got the straight face down pat. On that Fox show, which is up for 11 Emmys tonight, Mr. Arnett plays George Oscar Bluth, known as Gob, an incompetent magician who tools around Newport Beach on a Segway and, oops, blows up the family yacht when he means only to make it disappear.

title: Using Fireplaces to Save on Energy
description: MILLIONS of Americans have built-in hedges against higher home-heating costs already installed in their living rooms: fireplaces. But turning an ordinary fireplace into an efficient source of heat takes some work.

title: A Bushian Laboratory
description: On Oct. 5, 1999, George Bush went to the Manhattan Institute and delivered the most important domestic policy speech of his life. In what was mostly a talk about education, he made it quite clear he was no liberal. But he also broke with mainstream conservatism as it then existed.

title: On a Night With No Winner, Schrder Acts the Part
description: BERLIN, Sept. 18 - On an election night that produced no winner, Chancellor Gerhard SchrAder provided an uncanny facsimile of one, bounding to the stage to raucous applause, his hands clasped above his head in a victory gesture.
