title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, HYMAN
description: GOLDSTEIN - Hyman. Of Cortlandt Manor, NY, died on Friday, September 16, 2005. He was 87 years old. Hy was born on April 15, 1918, in New York City to Louis and Rebecca Goldstein. He served his country for five years in the US Army during WWII. Hy was a Rockland County resident from 1959-1979 before moving to Westchester County. He owned and operated a fur store in White Plains for 25 years before retiring. Hy is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Sylvia (nee Gozansky); his children Diane Love and her companion John, Myrna Schoen and her husband Edward, David Goldstein and his wife Linda, and his grandchildren, Adam Schoen and his wife Kristan, Jessica Schoen, Jenna, Bryan and Jason Goldstein. A funeral service will be held Monday, September 19, at 9:30 AM at Temple Beth El, 415 Viola Road, Spring Valley, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of David and Linda Goldstein, 8 Neva Court, Suffern, New York, Monday thorugh Thursday evening. Donations may be made in the name of Hy Goldstein to the Desmoid Tumor Research Foundation.

title: Corrections

It is "America Starts Here," not "America Stops Here."

title: Michael Sonberg and Andrew Austin
description: Justice Michael R. Sonberg and Andrew D. Austin are to affirm their partnership today at the Penn Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum is to lead the commitment ceremony.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: This week, two big institutions -- the METROPOLITAN OPERA and the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC -- lumber into the new season with conservative, patron-friendly opening-night programs. The Met gets things started on Monday with a high-wattage gala performance featuring PLCIDO DOMINGO, SUSAN GRAHAM, BRYN TERFEL, ANGELA GHEORGHIU, DENYCE GRAVES and others singing selected acts from "LE NOZZE DI FIGARO," "TOSCA" and "SAMSON ET DALILA." And in what may be the highlight of the Met's first week, Mr. Terfel returns on Friday for a reprise of his title role in Verdi's "FALSTAFF." JAMES LEVINE conducts both nights. Monday at 7 p.m., Friday at 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000.

title: The New Boss
description: If John G. Roberts Jr. is confirmed as William H. Rehnquist's successor on the Supreme Court, the country will have not only a new chief justice but also a new political entity: the Roberts Court. We speak easily of the Rehnquist Court or the Warren Court, managing to identify those complex institutions with a single individual. But how does a chief justice put his stamp on the court?

title: Unsafe Behind Bars
description: Sag Harbor - LAST month, Victoria Ruvolo appeared in Suffolk County Court to request leniency for the teenager who nearly killed her when he threw a 20-pound frozen turkey that smashed into her car's windshield. She embraced the 19-year-old, Ryan Cushing, as he sobbed: "I'm so sorry, I'm so sorry. I didn't mean it." Ms. Ruvolo whispered: "It's O.K. I just want you to make your life the best it can be."

title: The Remix; Book Smart
description: The Upper East Side may have lost The Paris Review, but its literary luster will be restored when Glenn Horowitz and John McWhinnie open a rare bookstore and gallery -- JohnMcWhinnie@GlennHorowitzBookseller -- on 64th Street this fall. McWhinnie (right) has made Horowitz's East Hampton shop a black hole for design-minded weekenders for seven years. For this new venture, he has curated over 2,000 rare and first-edition tomes on 20th-century literature, art, photography and design, with pulp fiction thrown in -- "my own anti-canon," he explains. "The goal is to show the productions of an elite art culture with their popular counterparts: Jackson Pollock besides James Dean, Frank Stella with Robert Crumb, Robert Frank against Nobuyoshi Araki." Cultural ephemera will range from a prototype of the drafting desk that Marcel Breuer gave to Walter Gropius to a porcelain beatnik figurine that declares, "It's

title: A California Murder Case Raises Troubling Issues
description: ORINDA, Calif., Sept. 15 - Susan Mae Polk was 15 when she visited a therapist, 16 when they had sex, 25 when they married and 44 when she killed him.

title: A Piece of the Pie
description: Few investment houses would advocate sinking money into a Broadway musical. But that's what Fidelity Investments is doing -- sort of. The Boston-based brokerage firm recently announced its sponsorship of the Broadway revival of "Sweeney Todd," a scaled-down import from London starring the Tony Award winners Michael Cerveris and Patti LuPone. The Boston Pops and Boston Ballet have benefited from Fidelity's largess in the past, but Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler's 1979 masterpiece about a revenge-crazed barber slicing his way through Victorian London? "This was a highly acclaimed musical, and we felt it was a good community partnership," said Vin Loporchio, a Fidelity spokesman.

description: While I don't doubt your survey, which showed very few articles about the problems of poverty and the levees, surely The Times can't cover everything everywhere (it is, after all, The New York Times, despite its national and international interests).

title: Kerry Davenport and Kevin Fitzgerald
description: Kerry Stryker Davenport, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Junius Clay Davenport III of Plandome, N.Y., was married last evening in Manhasset, N.Y., to Kevin Gerard Fitzgerald, a son of John J. Fitzgerald of Limerick, Ireland, and the late Kathleen Thornhill Fitzgerald. The Rev. James E. Brown Only officiated at the Congregational Church of Manhasset.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; FILM
description: The police raid in June on MONDO KIM's in the East Village, part of the Kim's Video empire, raised a host of questions about the ethics of movie love. As DAVID HUDSON, keeper of the blog GreenCine Daily (http://daily.greencine.com/), put it nicely, "To what degree is some level of piracy acceptable, maybe even necessary, for a culture to flourish?" Given the precarious state of theatrical distribution for foreign-language and nonstudio films in particular, it is a question every serious moviegoer needs to deliberate. This issue will be an unavoidable part of the program on Wednesday when some Mondo Kim's employees serve as guest curators at the ANTHOLOGY FILM ARCHIVES. Presumably, no bootlegs will be on tap, but it is a good guess that the unannounced selections will be very special indeed. 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212)505-5181.

title: Has the Sky Stopped Falling at Disney?
description: Burbank, Calif. - ON April 4, 2003, Glen Keane, one of the Walt Disney Company's most respected animators, summoned about 50 of his colleagues to a third-floor conference room on the lot here to discuss the war brewing at the studio. Disney's animators had settled into two opposing camps: those who were skilled in computer animation and those who refused to give up their pencils.

title: Lawyers Put On a Show. Isn't That Redundant?
description: If you were going to break a leg Wednesday evening, there were few places better suited than the stage of NJPAC, where a litigious audience of dandily attired attorneys cheered on the New Jersey Law Journal's "Celebration of Lawyers in the Arts."

title: 2005 Volkswagen Jetta
description: FIVE years ago, residential streets in the happening neighborhoods of big American cities seemed thick with Jettas. Volkswagen had just redesigned the compact sedan, its best-selling model, and a clever advertising campaign infused with indie-rock riffs connected to urban attitudes so successfully that the car became something of a cultural totem among artists, 20-something hipsters and plenty of other downtown denizens.

title: The Enemy Within
description: LOUDON, N.H., Sept. 17 - A year ago, Carl Edwards raced here in a stark white Ford that had the aesthetic appeal of a refrigerator. Edwards's goal was to lure a corporate sponsor with deep pockets and bright logos.

title: Denise Lobo and Stephan Rothe
description: Denise Ann Lobo and Stephan Erno Rothe were married on Friday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Mahwah, N.J. Bishop Anthony Lobo of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Islamabad-Rawalpindi, Pakistan, an uncle of the bride, officiated, with the Rev. James White, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: The Accidental Design of Rolin Jones's Career
description: LIFE has been on fast-forward these days for Rolin Jones. The other evening, he attended a preview of his play "The Intelligent Design of Jenny Chow" -- a high-intensity, fantastical drama about an adopted girl who builds a flying android alter-ego named Jenny Chow to search for her birth mother. (It opens the Atlantic Theater Company's 20th season tomorrow.) "I'm in a really festive mood," he said. "The technical part of the show is really complex, but last night was a really big leap for everybody."

title: A Supreme Challenge for a Proxy-Fight Pro
description: Institutional Shareholder Services dispenses plenty of advice to shareholders about how to vote in proxy fights, but its chairman, Robert C. S. Monks, is broadening his advice-giving to the political arena.

title: Chris Rock Hates Everybody's Fussing
description: LOS ANGELES - CHRIS ROCK is pleased that "Everybody Hates Chris," the UPN comedy series that's kind of, sort of, but not-quite based on his less-than-idyllic adolescent years in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, is making its debut Thursday at 8 p.m. But he would have preferred that it not be preceded by the kind of critical superlatives and anticipatory hype usually reserved for the crowning of emperors.

title: The Remix; TREND SPOTTING - LUSTER FOR LIFE
description: Pearls for men? Don't sneer. The successor to pink -- last year's counterintuitive choice for the aggressively masculine -- has arrived. The pop star Usher upped the ante in March when he appeared on the cover of L'Uomo Vogue wearing a pearl brooch amid his more familiar diamond ropes, and a pearl ring in the pictorial. And Tom Meyers, whose oxidized sterling chains sell at Barneys New York under the TEM label (left), has added freshwater pearls to a unisex collection that blurs the gender divide. As he put it, when describing his inspiration, think Marc Bolan as an 18th-century viscount, with necklaces looping once around the neck, like the long scarves of the period. Ridiculous? Maybe. But not so long ago, diamond studs for studs also seemed unlikely. MARK JACOBS

title: Graphic Material
description: Squeezed into a gold leather bikini, her skin painted the same shimmering hue, the statuesque starlet Margaret Nolan (41-23-37) stood still while scenes from the just-finished James Bond movie "Goldfinger" were projected onto her curves. The shoot was long and meticulous, the brainchild of the graphic designer Robert Brownjohn. A golf ball was made to disappear between her gilded breasts; the license plates from Bond's Aston Martin DB5 were another playful gag. And to think that the Bauhaus had come to this.

title: Wicketts Remedy
A onetime Talib hopes for votes
The Remix; The Anti Lad Mag
description: Don't you hate it when the help needs help polishing the family silver? The Chap, a London magazine, comes to the rescue. With useful information for the posh wannabe -- like how to avoid disgracing yourself over a dry sherry with the dowager Marchioness of Cholmondeley; the semiotics of the mustache; and the definitive guide to servants -- the magazine takes itself about as seriously as the press would Elizabeth Hurley's doing Shakespeare. And its neo-Victoriana has made the jump from the printed page to the sports arena, with the Chap Olympics, held annually in Regent's Park. Events include the cucumber-sandwich discus and quill throwing, but neither is as competitive as the fight for elbowroom at the bar. HENRY CONWAY

title: Roberts Drops Hints in 'Precedent' Remarks
description: Judge John G. Roberts Jr. declined to answer direct questions about abortion at his confirmation hearings last week. But that does not mean he said nothing about whether he would overrule Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision that established a constitutional right to abortion, if he becomes chief justice.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, September 18th, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, September 19th, 10AM, at St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79th St., NYC.

description: You would expect the last thing a been-there-done-that, time-compressed New Yorker needs is another expensive private club. But if the success of a certain British import to the meatpacking district is any indication, the city's beau monde is convinced that membership has its privileges.

title: Afghans Turn Out to Vote Despite Scattered Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 18 - Afghans flocked to the polls today to vote in the country's first democratic parliamentary elections in 35 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALGER, ELIZABETH JOYCE (NEE CANNON)
description: ALGER--Elizabeth Joyce (nee Cannon), 78, of Leonia, NJ, previously from Toronto, Ontario, died peacefully on Saturday, September 10, 2005. Devoted wife of Dr. Ian E. Alger. Beloved mother of Derek, Wendy, Timmy and Penny. Loving grandmother of Olivia Leigh Hucker, Jonathan Russell Hucker and Katy Anne Kohut.

description: HOINESS--Donald, age 83, of Northfield, MN, teacher, tenor. Memorial service Friday, October 7, 2005, at Ft. Snelling Chapel, Minneapolis. Benson & Langehough, 507-645-5123.

title: Under Din of Abortion Debate, an Experience Shared Quietly
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. - At Little Rock Family Planning Services, the women filed in without making eye contact, a demographic that remains unrecognized.

title: Raf
description: The damp, persistent chill had ended, and by noon in Westende, a community of high-rise apartment buildings on the coast of Belgium, the temperature had risen to 65 degrees. At cafe tables along the boardwalk, middle-aged women opened the tops of their blouses, while down on the beach, pinkish bodies, plumped by their Lycra casings, lay between the canvas windbreaks.

title: A Supreme Challenge For a Proxy-Fight Pro
description: Institutional Shareholder Services dispenses plenty of advice to shareholders about how to vote in proxy fights, but its chairman, Robert C.S. Monks, is broadening his advice-giving to the political arena.

title: Blue Plate Special: Bouncers and Dress Codes
description: BY day Chelsea Square is an ordinary diner, serving up souvlaki, gyros and burgers to a mix of elderly neighborhood residents, families and workers. The pace is leisurely; the television is on mute. But late at night, especially on weekends, Chelsea Square becomes a most unlikely party hot spot, with a reputation as the hip-hop diner.

title: Mad Togs and Englishmen
description: A new take on flannel, plaid and tweed for this side of the pond.

title: Julie Myers and John Wood
description: Julie Lyn Myers, a daughter of Kathleen D. Sinzheimer of Overland Park, Kan., and the late Charles R. Myers, was married yesterday to John Frederick Wood, the son of Elizabeth Wood and Robert A. Wood of Clayton, Mo. The Rev. Lyndon C. Shakespeare, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church, Georgetown, in Washington.

title: Help for Aging Parents, and for Yourself
description: ELINOR GINZLER knows that her parents were lucky -- and that she was, too. Her mom died in her sleep at the age of 73 -- "20 years too early, but she died the way she wanted to," Ms. Ginzler recalled. Her dad died at 83 -- and, even though he had battled cancer for five years, he did not suffer much. "The last time it recurred, they gave him three to six months," Ms. Ginzler said. "He died three weeks later, and he died in his own home."

title: Accountability for Syria
A Wimp on Genocide
description: President Bush doesn't often find common cause with Cuba, Zimbabwe, Iran, Syria and Venezuela. But this month the Bush administration joined with those countries and others to eviscerate a forthright U.N. statement that nations have an obligation to respond to genocide.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Two photographs on Page 3 of the Travel section today, with the Datebook column, are reversed. The rowers should appear with the report about the Head of the Charles Regatta in Cambridge, Mass., and the people looking at books with the report about a literature festival in Cheltenham, England.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; ART
description: When Charles IV became king of Bohemia in 1347, he had visions of transforming Prague into a cultural center that would rival Paris and Rome. His two sons, Wenceslas IV and Sigismund, also promoted culture in their capital city. As a result, the profusion of artists and artisans who created panel paintings, goldsmiths' work, illuminated manuscripts, sculpture, silk embroideries and stained glass during the 14th and 15th centuries was extraordinary. Few of these riches had ever traveled to New York before the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART's exhibition of some 160 works, "PRAGUE, THE CROWN OF BOHEMIA, 1347-1437," which opens to the public on Tuesday.

title: Movies
description: THE INCREDIBLES (2004) Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz Pixar's Oscar-winning animated film has a message about mediocrity, and it's a lot like Ayn Rand's in "Atlas Shrugged." Bob Parr (the voice of Craig T. Nelson) used to be a superhero, as did his wife (Holly Hunter), a k a Elastigirl. Now they live in the suburbs, she takes care of their three children, and he spends his days in a cubicle processing insurance claims. Occasionally he and his friend Lucius (Samuel L. Jackson) put on their old uniforms and prove they're special, as Mr. Incredible and Frozone (above, with Elastigirl). The movie would have been more interesting if it had stuck with the difficulties of mundane middle-class life for demigods, but this is an action film, so the Incredibles have to save the world. The voice of their favorite fashion designer, Edna E. Mode, belongs to Brad Bird, who wrote and directed.

title: Barbara Loewenthal and David Podwall
description: Dr. Barbara Loewenthal, the daughter of Martha and William Loewenthal of Tampa, Fla., is to be married this afternoon in Lawrence, N.Y., to Dr. David Podwall, a son of Marcia and Arthur Podwall of Smithtown, N.Y. Rabbi Elliot T. Spar is to officiate at Temple Israel of Lawrence, with Rabbi Abraham Axelrod taking part.

title: On Baseball; When the Record Reads
description: A .500 won-lost record has different meanings to different teams. It is, to be sure, a mediocre record, no matter one's perspective, but depending on a team's position, whether in previous seasons or in the current standings, it can be good, bad or indifferent.

title: Travel Industry Gears Up to Help Storm Victims
description: Many hotel, airline and cruise ship companies reached out to Gulf Coast victims immediately after Hurricane Katrina. Once it became clear that many would need assistance for months, some in the travel industry created programs with a more long-term impact -- including ways for their customers to help through frequent flier and loyalty programs.

title: Guantnamo Prisoners Go on Hunger Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - A hunger strike at the prison camp at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has unsettled senior commanders there and produced the most serious challenge yet to the military's effort to manage the detention of hundreds of terrorism suspects, lawyers and officials say.

title: Their Hearts and Minds?
description: David Rieff (Sept. 4) describes our current conflict with jihadism as a "contest between modernity and antimodernity." But the word "modern" doesn't explain anything. Brutality and terrorism are as "modern" as democracy and civil rights. Though vilified by the religious right to the point that it can't be mentioned without a smirk, the better label would be "secular humanism." A product of the Enlightenment, it is now under siege abroad and undervalued at home.

description: Joanna Perlman, a marketing and public relations specialist, is to be married this evening to Adam L. Barsky, a deputy secretary to Gov. George E. Pataki of New York. Rabbi Alvin Kass, a New York Police Department chaplain, is to officiate at the Essex House in New York.

description: GLEN COVE - It may be on austerity, but the Glen Cove School District has 10 more teachers this year than last, and its budget is only $75,000 smaller than the one voters rejected in May.

description: SOUTH BOUND BROOK - ASBESTOS nearly killed this borough. Twenty years ago, when the GAF factory closed after damages were awarded to victims of asbestosis linked to products like the roof tiles that were manufactured there, South Bound Brook looked doomed too.

description: The Urban Studies column last Sunday, about the view of the Brooklyn Bridge from the N train, referred incorrectly to the point at which the train emerges from a tunnel to cross the Manhattan Bridge. The tunnel is under Brooklyn, not under the East River.

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: Americans have learned to live with an uncomfortable sense of acceptance of poverty. It feels vaguely ill mannered to even mention it. We all know that our society has pockets of wretched poverty, but even progressive citizens manage to live day to day without discussing this fact out loud. Talking about poverty seems so outdated, so L.B.J.-ish, so nave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BARBANELL, JUNE
description: BARBANELL--June. A blink of an eye, an eternity, one year. Now I know the meaning of a broken heart. Arthur

description: IN the predawn darkness, John Ficke picks up his coffee, then rounds up fellow commuters for the 60-mile drive from Torrington to Fairfield.

title: Complex Casanova
description: Fugitive, socialite, grifter, self-made millionaire: truly a man of parts, Casanova combined some of the most compelling archetypes of fiction into a best-selling life. A Forrest Gump of the Enlightenment, he was present during many of the key moments of late-18th-century history, encountering Voltaire, Mozart, Rousseau and Benjamin Franklin along the way, as well as Pope Clement XIII, Louis XV, Madame de Pompadour and Catherine the Great. If he hadn't existed, an Italian director would have invented him.

description: Correction Appended

title: Snow Man
description: High-altitude style on a freeskiing sensation.Thanks to 23-year-old Jon Olsson, finding stylish ski gear is no longer an uphill battle. Olsson's flair on the slopes -- he holds the record for Winter X-Games medals and was this year's World Superpipe champion -- is matched only by his candy-colored ski togs. Which must be why his fellow Swede J. Lindeberg tapped him as the face of Lindeberg's new skiwear collection, Future Sports. Olsson prepares for altitude slickness in a J. Lindeberg lamb's-wool hat, $295, fur-trimmed jacket, $1,295, polo, $69, belt, $110, and pants, $69. All at J. Lindeberg, 126 Spring Street and Saks Fifth Avenue. Grooming by Elisabeth Lovgren. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

title: Portraits of American Paradises, Mostly Lost
description: THE "perfect society" may be a figment of the idealist's imagination, but from the early years of the republic, many Americans have tried to give those ideals a tangible form, organizing their lives and those of their neighbors in a variety of social experiments.

title: Crowds in Class and Study Hall
description: GREENLAWN - The warnings from the Harborfields School District administration last June were unusually dire. Opposing the school budget would not just mean fewer extracurricular activities, voters were told; academics would be cut, too.

title: Recipe for an Instant Town: Find Land, Add Trailers
description: In his speech Thursday about recovery efforts along the Gulf Coast, President Bush said the government's goal was to get hundreds of thousands of evacuees out of shelters by mid-October.

title: Glancing Back Wistfully at a Yiddish Yesteryear
description: FOR Molly Picon, a star of Yiddish theater, it all came down to chutzpah -- that tough-to-translate combination of nerve, audacity, grit and attitude. At least that's the view of her playwright biographer, Rose Leiman Goldemberg, who says she recognizes the quality, because she has a dose of it herself.

title: The Remix; Time Is Money
description: Nothing gets the horologically obsessed wound up like a tourbillon. The tourbillon -- which means "whirlwind" in French and was invented in 1795 by Abraham-Louis Breguet -- is essentially a revolving cage that houses a watch's escapement and balance wheel. It rotates one revolution a minute, counteracting the effects of gravity and movement on accuracy. Blancpain's 1735 model has every bell and whistle and costs $779,000. Patek Philippe's Minute Repeater Tourbillon clocks in at a cool half-million. Comparatively speaking, the Breguet Skeleton Tourbillon (pictured here) is a bargain at $122,900. So, why not wear your complexity on (or near) your sleeve? SANDRA BALLENTINE

title: 2 Parents + 2 Boys + 2 Weimaraners = 1,000 Square Feet
description: HERE'S how Tim Hall described the domestic fandango that erupts on a typical morning in the 1,000-square-foot, third-floor walk-up he shares with his wife, Kimberly Hall; their sons, Ethan, 3, and Graham, nearly 2; and two leggy Weimaraners, Gretel and Wilma:

title: Rough Rider
description: I see a lot of clothes that pretend to have a history: jeans that have been sanded and scrubbed by some guy in Long Beach, Calif., to make them look as if they have a past; T-shirts that have been ripped and repaired, as if they've suffered. But my motorcycle jacket -- a black leather Belstaff Montana jacket with a snap-down touring collar, to be exact -- has lived more, seen more, survived more, than I have. In the early 1950's, Che Guevara wore a Belstaff on the motorcycle trip through Latin America that turned him into a radical. Belstaff outfitted T.E. Lawrence for his travels in Arabia, Steve McQueen for the movies and the pioneering aviators of the 1930's for unknown adventures. These days, even the Dalai Lama wears one. As a writer, my work has taken me through the alleys of Cairo, floods in Rangoon and the back streets of Rio. I've also shot photographs in the sand dunes of the Sahara and on the peaks of the Himalayas. I don't have time to change with the fashions, and I don't have space for fussy, complicated clothes. I need classics that will be with me forever. I like clothes in which I can see the desert in a crease at the elbow or Highway 1 in Vietnam in a scuff on the shoulder. I don't mind if my clothes look worn or beaten up, as long as they are real and well made. I don't want somebody else living for me; that, I can do myself. George Clooney, a serious biker and Belstaff fanatic, calls his jacket "classic and cool, the perfect combination between tradition and innovation." That sounds about right to me, too.

title: Business Owners Start to Return to New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 - Business owners and some residents slowly returned to parts of this storm-struck city and surrounding communities early Saturday, prying back plywood and stepping over ruined steeples on the first day of a staggered re-entry scheduled to move ZIP code by ZIP code, parish by parish.

title: Still a Circumnavigator
description: I WAS the oldest of six children. From my father I learned not to be afraid to take on challenges. He had me pick up a paper route as soon as I was big enough to pull a wagon. My father was in the Navy, so we moved around a bit in my early years. Then he worked for Union Carbide, in marketing. My family spent most of that time in Chicago. When I was in high school, we moved to New Jersey.

title: The Remix; Stag Party
description: These days, a man's home is his hunting lodge. Freemans restaurant ignited the trend: the eatery's take on dark floors and dead animals sent people into the woods (and onto eBay) for stuffed geese, driftwood and antler coat racks. Scott Morrison, a co-owner of the denim company Earnest Sewn, hired Taavo Somer, a co-owner of Freemans, to outfit his compound in upstate New York, now a modern-country mix complete with a bar featuring a stack of backlit logs. Casey Storm, the costume designer for Spike Jonze, furnished his midcentury modern house in Los Angeles with dyed sheepskin rugs, woodsy paintings and a menagerie that includes an albino wallaby (above).

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: WOUNDED. By Percival Everett. (Graywolf, $23.) An appealing air of menace hangs over the action in Everett's latest novel, a modern-day western where the cowboys and Indians get along and the real threat comes from the neo-Nazis in the hills. The narrator is John Hunt, a laconic black horse trainer in Wyoming, whose natural reticence has grown more pronounced since his wife's death in an equestrian accident: now John's only regular social contact is with the ex-con uncle who lives on his ranch. But as much as John wants to mind his own business, he's confronted by bigotry and its consequences when a ranch hand is accused of killing a young gay man -- the victim, like Matthew Shepard, "strung up like an elk with his throat slit." This isn't a mystery, and the murder quickly recedes from the story, but not before setting in motion a chain of events that leaves John fearing for his own safety and questioning the sexual and racial politics of just about everybody he knows. Like more traditional westerns, "Wounded" isn't big on psychological depth -- the villains might as well twirl handlebar mustaches -- and Everett has abandoned the madcap humor he favored in earlier books, but his acerbic intelligence remains on display, and the result is an unsettling look at intolerance and its logical end in violence. "There are plenty of stupid, narrow-minded people around," John tells a visitor. "They're not hard to find. There are a lot of ignorant people, a lot of good, smart people. Is it different where you come from?"

title: Building the Great Firewall of China, With Foreign Help
description: In April 2004, a few weeks before the 15th anniversary of Beijing's massacre of protesters in Tiananmen Square, the top-ranking staff members of The Contemporary Business News in Hunan were called into a meeting. An editor read a message from the Communist Party's propaganda department warning that protests or media coverage of the anniversary would not be tolerated as June 4 approached. Though the message was routine, the reporters were warned not to take notes.

title: Carlyn Ross and Alan Schlechter
description: Carlyn Jacqueline Ross, a daughter of Francine C. Ross and Dr. Steven W. Ross of Oak Brook, Ill., is to be married today to Dr. Alan Daniel Schlechter, the son of Susan and Bruce D. Schlechter of New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein is to officiate at the Central Park Boathouse in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOAG, JOHN WARNER, B. ARCH.
description: HOAG--John Warner, B. Arch. (Univ. of Toronto 1955); Fellow, Royal Architectural Institute of Canada (1984); Order of da Vinci (1987) and Honorary Membership (2004) both granted by the Ontario Association of Architects. Born February 21, 1930 in Brantford, Ontario, predeceased by his parents John Arliss Hoag and Kathleen Warner Hoag, and infant brother Peter. Died on September 11, 2005 at South Muskoka Memorial Hospital in Bracebridge, Ontario. Husband of Sarah Mansfield Dunn from New Rochelle, New York, father, friend and greatest supporter of their children Hannah Margaret Hoag (Omer Rashid) and Matthew Warner Hoag. Survived by his brother, William Arliss Hoag (Patricia James Hoag) of Oakville, Ontario and their children and grandchildren, his cherished cousin Doris Chatham of Mill Valley California, and brother-inlaw, Tom Dunn of Boston, Massachusetts. He was an outstanding father, husband, son, brother, and uncle. John was a good friend to many, a mentor, a raconteur, and a bon vivant with a love for anything relating to France. John worked in architectural firms in London, and Boston before joining, for a decade, Skidmore, Owings and Merrill of New York. While living in New York, John had enjoyed being a member of the Mendelessohn Men's Chorus. In 1966 John returned to Canada and worked for Marani, Rounthwaite & Dick in Toronto prior to joining the University of Waterloo (Ontario). He was at Waterloo for 25 years, until retirement as the Architectural Program Administrator for Co-operative Education. He maintained a small private practice in Ontario which completed a major commission in Boone, North Carolina; a project in Galt, Ontario received an Award of Merit from Heritage Cambridge. John was very active in the architectural profession and in his church. He held many leadership positions and was known for his sense of fairness and professionalism. John was Chairman of the Committee on Church Architecture for the Presbyterian Church in Canada when it won a Premier's Award for Accessibility (1986) for a handbook of standards and accessibility guidelines for church architecture. A funeral was held at Rosedale Presbyterian Church, 129 South Drive Toronto (M4W 2S3) on Saturday, September 17, at 11:00 A.M. For information Humphrey Funeral Home, A.W. Miles Chapel, in Toronto, please call #

title: When the Voters Spoke
description: Politicians yammer, but voters are succinct. The elections last Tuesday were a striking reminder of the power of the voter's voice -- the simple yes or no, in or out, that reduces months of political doublespeak to a heap of irrelevance in a single night.

The dog run, the city's first official run when it opened in 1990, is the site of a social life and gossip scene so vibrant that dog owners compare it to everything from a church congregation to a high school lunchroom to an even friendlier version of the neighborhood bar.

But with 153 world leaders leading their entourages around town and 180 fashion shows showing off the latest looks and streets blocked off and traffic inching along in fractional increments, was it her fault that she was late for work every day last week?

title: EL TOVAR'S LEGACY
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Check In/Check Out" on Aug. 7, about El Tovar, the lodge in the Grand Canyon: Fred A. Bernstein wrote that it is a "down-to-earth building resembling a three-story log cabin." That modest description misses the point.

title: A Ringside Seat for Murrow Versus McCarthy
description: WITH the success of "Ocean's Eleven" and "Ocean's Twelve," George Clooney's Danny Ocean has become the king of the caper, a guy who finds a tiny weakness in the system and exploits it for his own ends. But even Danny would have to marvel at Mr. Clooney's most recent second-story job. Using the leverage of his stardom and the connections developed over his years in the business, Mr. Clooney has actually managed to make and distribute a black-and-white film about issues of historic and civic moment. "Ocean's Thirteen" it ain't.

title: Sony's Unlikely Mogul, at the Crossroads
description: WHEN Sir Howard Stringer was anointed the unlikely emperor of the Sony Corporation in March, it was one for the history books, and in a few ways. For one -- and much noted at the time -- Sir Howard is the first foreigner to run Sony, the global electronics and entertainment colossus based in Tokyo. For another, he intended to telecommute mainly from his base in New York, while still finding time to visit his family in Oxfordshire, England, at regular intervals.

title: Comeback Thriller, but Irish Lose the Fight
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 17 - A few minutes after Jason Teague of Michigan State high-stepped into the end zone to give the Spartans a 44-41 overtime victory over Notre Dame on Saturday, most of the Fighting Irish players had left the field, and the marching band was carrying off its suddenly silent instruments.

title: Their Hearts and Minds?
description: Instead of trying to explain the United States to the Islamic world, Karen Hughes would be better advised to listen and to try to understand why so many Muslims detest such policies as invading Muslim countries, surrounding the Arab world with military bases, not acting as an impartial broker in the Israeli-Arab dispute. Looking at others' points of view, as Robert McNamara belatedly learned, is the better part of wisdom.

title: Must Future Court Nominees Match Qualifications of Roberts?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - Judge John G. Roberts Jr. has not done any favors for the next Supreme Court nominee.

title: Laugh Lines: Sept. 11-17
description: Reacting to criticism that the federal government does not respond quickly enough in times of emergency and crisis, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff today unveiled what he called "a color-coded apathy alert system" that will warn the public of just how sluggish the government's response will be.

title: Law Requires Homeless Children Have Access to Public School
description: REGARDLESS of whether Connecticut welcomes them, any children displaced by Hurricane Katrina who come here must be educated here. That is because of a federal law called the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act that ensures homeless children have access to public school educations.

title: The Zone; Shredding the Rad
description: Speed down Route 7, and Vermont troopers will write you a ticket faster than you can say "Green Mountain State." But that's no deterrent to a growing number of New Yorkers willing to drive about eight hours (four each way) to "surf the white winter wave." Eight years ago, when I started Milk, a fashion photography studio in Chelsea, most of my colleagues would rather have gone clubbing in Poughkeepsie than hit the slopes. But lately, everyone I know -- from supermodels to photographers to messengers -- has been making the trek. And looking the part.

title: Mean Boys
description: Being a native of New Jersey -- the home of Jon Bon Jovi, the first gay governor and, of course, the Sopranos -- I know about guys with bad hair and attitude. But what the Garden State does better than any other is the shopping mall. I, my friends, am a scion of the Shopping Mall State.

title: Miami Wins in Triple OT
description: The No. 13 Hurricanes squandered a 10-point lead in the fourth quarter but beat No. 20 Clemson in the third overtime, 36-30. Miami avoided starting a season 0-2 for the first time since 1978.

description: SO, how did the bell on Dizzy Gillespie's trumpet become bent?

title: Foot Noted
description: I have a good friend who is something of a clotheshorse. Actually, given his 40 or more trench coats, 70 pairs of chinos and Levi's, dozens of watches and hundreds of dress shirts -- not to mention the fact that every time he buys shoes, he splurges on two pairs -- he is definitely more of a stallion.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; DANCE
description: There is no denying that the annual New York Dance and Performance Awards, known as the BESSIES (after the master teacher Bessie Schonberg Varley), are a lovefest for the downtown dance crowd. But the event (Sunday at the Joyce Theater) is also an always-entertaining glimpse of people who are usually just names on a program. This year two charismatic elders, CARMEN DE LAVALLADE and GUS SOLOMONS JR., will hand out the awards, which are often described as the dance world's equivalent of the Oscars. At 5 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-0800; $15.

title: Dangling Particles
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - SCIENCE plays an increasingly significant role in people's lives, making the faithful communication of scientific developments more important than ever. Yet such communication is fraught with challenges that can easily distort discussions, leading to unnecessary confusion and misunderstandings.

title: Alice Barzun and Brendan McLean
description: Alice Lowell Barzun, a portfolio manager, was married yesterday to Brendan Mor McLean, a cinematographer. Canon Borden C. Purcell performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Oak Leaf, Ontario.

title: Oscar the Grouch, Wicked Wit and All
description: MADISON - THE poet W.H. Auden wasn't far off. Commenting on Oscar Wilde's plays, all written in the three years before the playwright's sensational trials and imprisonment for the crime of "gross indecency" in his affair with young Lord Alfred Douglas, he wrote that Wilde had created "a verbal universe in which the characters are determined by the kind of things they say, and the plot is nothing but a succession of opportunities to say them."

title: 30 Die in Car Bomb Blast in Busy Baghdad Market
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 17 - Terrorists drove into a crowded public marketplace on the southeastern outskirts of Baghdad, got out of their car and used a remote-control device to detonate a bomb hidden inside, killing at least 30 people on Saturday evening, according to initial reports from the Interior Ministry.

title: Alison Fargis and Michael Buckley
description: Alison Katherine Fargis and Michael Buckley were married last evening at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Mark W. Hummell, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: 'National Pastime'
description: When British soldiers in Afghanistan and southern Iraq wanted to befriend the locals, they played a soccer match. On Christmas Day, 1914, British and German soldiers in the First World War trenches did the same thing. For nearly 100 years soccer has united a divided world-apart from the world's hyper-power, the United States. You can buy a McDonald's Big Mac on the Champs-ElysAes and anything from anywhere in the world on Fifth Avenue, but American sporting culture and the world soccer culture do not mix.

title: Questions for Jonathan Kozol
description: I would have thought that Jonathan Kozol's issue with private schools was not so much that they sap parent dedication from public schools; after all, what's the point of parent dedication if public schools are not good in themselves? I would have thought the point was that only public schools embody the American dream of an equal education for all, teaching American values unfettered by constraints of religion or class.

title: Swirling Currents On a Private Label
description: Ruth Crawford Seeger: Violin Sonata, Piano Pieces, Two Ricercari and Other Works Continuum, directed by Cheryl Seltzer and Joel Sachs. Naxos 8.559197; CD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVY, MARGARET TRASK
description: DAVY--Margaret Trask. Of Beacon Hill, formerly of Manhattan, September 10, 2005. Beloved wife of Samuel J. Loving mother of Melissa Trask Davy of Pittsburgh, formerly of Watertown, MA. Caring mother-in-law of Stefano Falconi. Devoted grandmother of Alessandra Claire and Francesca Genevieve Davy-Falconi. Sister of the late Walter J. Trask. Aunt of Walter J. Trask III. Visitation will be held in Story Chapel, Mt. Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, MA, Monday, 11:30 to 1:30, followed by a funeral service at 1:30. Relatives and friends kindly invited. A memorial service will be held in October. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Margaret's memory to WGBH Annual Fund, PO Box 200, Boston, MA 02134. For information, William T. Hickey & Son, Cambridge, MA.

title: Jocelyn Hayes and Bradford Simpson
description: Jocelyn Hayes, the daughter of Regina McDonnell Hayes and Jeffrey L. Hayes of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' vacation home in Brewster, Mass., to Bradford Simpson, the son of Peggy and Dhale Simpson of Little Rock, Ark. The ceremony was led by David Pryor, a former governor and United States senator from Arkansas who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Ramirez's Stroke Rekindles Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 - With Manny Ramirez, there is no need to be surprised anymore. Anything can happen. Something usually does. He has spent parts of the last five weeks playing and acting as if he would rather be polishing his car, but when Ramirez swings, there is always a chance something exciting will happen.

title: Renee LaJeunesse and Eric Snyder
description: Renee Marie LaJeunesse, the daughter of Pearl and Norman LaJeunesse of Arundel, Me., was married yesterday to Eric James Snyder, a son of Carol and James Snyder of Lindenhurst, N.Y. The Rev. Renald Labarre, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Church in Biddeford, Me.

title: NOW IT CAN BE TOLD
description: One might think that there would be few secrets to reveal about someone who named his memoir after his most public embarrassment. But not so with Phil Dusenberry, the former chairman of BBDO North America and source of many memorable ad campaigns.

title: 'L'chaim' in 1,659 Ways
description: Daniel Rogov's 2006 edition of "Rogov's Guide to Israeli Wines" (Toby Press, $19.95) is indispensable for fans of Israel's fast-growing industry. Mr. Rogov, Israel's leading critic, rates 126 wineries and 1,659 kosher and nonkosher wines, through 2004. His 10 top producers are Golan Heights Winery (Yarden, Katzrin, Gamla labels), Castel, Flam, Margalit, Yatir, Galil Mountain, Saslove, Amphorae, Recanati and Carmel. His "fastest-improving" include Carmel, Barkan, Sea Horse, Tabor, Dalton, Zauberman, Gush Etzion, Segal and Tishbi. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Forgetting Reinhold Niebuhr
description: THE recent outburst of popular religiosity in the United States is a most dramatic and unforeseen development in American life. As Europe grows more secular, America grows more devout. George W. Bush is the most aggressively religious president Americans have ever had. American conservatives applaud his "faith-based" presidency, an office heretofore regarded as secular. The religious right has become a potent force in national politics. Evangelicals now outnumber mainline Protestants and crowd megachurches. Billy Graham attracts supplicants by the thousand in Sodom and Gomorrah, a k a New York City. The Supreme Court broods over the placement of the Ten Commandments. Evangelicals take over the Air Force Academy, a government institution maintained by taxpayers' dollars; the academy's former superintendent says it will be six years before religious tolerance is restored. Mel Gibson's movie "Passion of the Christ" draws nearly $400 million at the domestic box office.

title: The Get; Premium Cable
description: TUNE INTO THESE SUPERPLY CLASSICS.

title: Fame Cuts the Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Remix; Power Suiting - Hickey Freeman's New Home
description: Hickey Freeman is taking the classic American suit into the 21st century. The company's clothes have adorned the men of New York's financial district since 1899, but stock traders had to trek up to Fifth Avenue to have them tailored. No more.

title: Preparing for an Attack On the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: After Hung Jury, 4 Who Poured Blood at Upstate Army Center Face U.S. Trial
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Sept 14 - On the verge of America's invasion of Iraq, four left-wing activists went into the vestibule of their suburban Army recruiting center and poured vials of their blood, about four ounces each, onto the walls, windows and American flag.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; THEATER
description: "THE BIG TIME" has to be the only musical opening this year that began as an Oliver Stone film project. The project, about lounge singers who save a cruise ship from hijackers (it was originally conceived as a satire of the Steven Seagal vehicle "Under Siege"), was shelved after the Sept. 11 attacks. But its original screenwriter, the playwright DOUGLAS CARTER BEANE ("The Country Club"), has revived it -- sans Mr. Stone -- and added songs by DOUGLAS J. COHEN ("Boozy: The Life, Death and Subsequent Vilification of Le Corbusier and, More Importantly, Robert Moses"). Now THE DRAMA DEPT. production of "The Big Time" looks to be the most exciting entry of the NEW YORK MUSICAL THEATER FESTIVAL. It features direction by CHRISTOPHER ASHLEY ("All Shook Up") and a cast including the Tony winner DEBBIE GRAVITTE ("Jerome Robbins's Broadway") and the singular JACKIE HOFFMAN ("Hairspray"), who promises to steal a few scenes as one of the terrorists. Running at the Lion Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212)352-3101.

title: Meredith Ballew and Jonathan Bing
description: Meredith Hunter Ballew, who heads a New York City business and cultural development organization, was married last evening to Assemblyman Jonathan L. Bing of New York. Rabbi Andrew Vogel Ettin officiated at Fearrington House, an inn and resort in Pittsboro, N.C., with the Rev. Ronald E. Gonia, a United Methodist minister, taking part.

title: To Many in the Amazon, Government Comes on a Boat
description: CAAPIRANGA, Brazil - Some arrived alone in canoes or small motorboats, while others came as entire communities, crowded aboard double-decker vessels. At a remote bend in the river in the heart of the Amazon jungle, their destination lay at anchor: a riverboat that functions as a floating government office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENOWITZ, BEN
description: BENOWITZ--Ben. 97, September 16, 2005. Beloved husband for 68 years of Lillian. Brother of Phil. Father of Paul, Larry and Martin. Father-in-law of Sondra and Brooke. Grandfather of Scott, Isaac, Miriam and Daniel. Ben will be remembered for his warmth, humor and love of family. Funeral September 18, 10:45 am, Parkside Chapels, 2576 Flatbush, Brooklyn. Shiva at home Sunday to Wednesday. Donations in Ben's memory may be made to UJF.

title: An Allegory Unfolds in the Air
description: CLOVE GALILEE floats 16 feet above the stage at the NYU Skirball Center, her legs cycling gracefully, her voluminous white dress billowing. She is rehearsing her starring role in Mabou Mines' latest theatrical extravaganza "Red Beads," most of which takes place in midair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTEIN, IRVING SAMUEL
description: WEINSTEIN--Irving Samuel. On Friday, August 26, 2005, after a long illness, in Palm Desert, CA. A respected principal of several electrical contracting companies in NY during his 50-year career. Veteran of WWII, long-term member of the Masonic Order and a Shriner. Will be deeply missed and mourned by family and friends. Services at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Queens, September 29 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Los Angeles Shriners Hospital, 3160 Geneva St., LA, CA 90020.

title: The Remix; Fit for a King
description: For most men, knowing how to choose a tailor and buy a custom-made suit remains as mysterious as the appeal of low-rider jeans. Enter Thomas Mahon, one of Savile Row's youngest tailors, and possibly its grooviest. He put his money where his mouse is with www.englishcut.com, offering advice for those who go the bespoke route. Mahon, a graduate of Anderson & Sheppard who has padded the shoulders of Prince Charles, Bryan Ferry and Graydon Carter, offers the following pointers.

title: Corrections
description: The Sunday Serial, a work of fiction that begins with Chapter 1 today on Page 46 of The Times Magazine, refers imprecisely to a military designation received by the main character, Carl Webster, during World War II. It is an honorable discharge from the Navy, not an honorary discharge.

description: LEHMANN--William H. 89, died on September 11, 2005. Widower of Ebba, survived by his sons Greg and Bill. Beloved for his wit, wisdom and compassion. He was a dignified gentleman who will be sorely missed.

description: Correction Appended

title: Now on Animal Planet: Downward Dog (Literally)
description: WHO is Animal Planet for, exactly? The answer seems obvious: It's for people who love animals. After all, the channel is chockablock with cute kittens and freaky crocodiles, tail-chasing dogs and backyard bugs. And yet the impression one comes away with is not exactly that of a loving representation of our animal brethren. Animal Planet shows exhibit such a strange mixture of anthropomorphism and indignity you start to get the impression that its viewers, on some level, probably without even knowing it, dislike animals. As with Lennie and his puppy in "Of Mice and Men," the fawning adulation here is tempered by less honorable urges.

title: Wary of High-Voltage Batteries, Rescuers Study Up on Hybrids
description: SIXTEEN may become a vitally important number for firefighters to keep in mind. That's how many feet from a Prius that Toyota says its electronic key must be taken to be certain the hybrid power train will not be able to start.

title: Defining Beauty Through Avedon
description: RICHARD AVEDON honored women. For nearly half a century, taking photographs for the top two fashion magazines in the world, Harper's Bazaar and Vogue, women were the subject and the target of his insistent, yet sympathetic gaze. From the models in his fashion tableaux to his later, unembellished portraits of artists, writers, intellectuals, socialites and hardscrabble workers in the American West, his regard for the fully realized individual remained constant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MURPHY, BOB
description: MURPHY--Bob. THE VOICE OF SUMMER is silent, but, oh, it plays in our hearts. Happy Birthday.

Restaurateur Adds to His Lineup
description: TOM SCHAUDEL, Long Island's restless restaurateur, has opened yet another worthy restaurant. His latest, Angelfish in Long Beach, joins Coolfish in Syosset, his flagship restaurant; Thom Thom in Wantagh, a steak and sushi place with an Asian spin that made its debut about a year ago; and the recently opened Rockfish in Huntington, which Mr. Schaudel compares to a fish shack.

title: Lafayette Hopes, and Fears, It Will Become the New New Orleans
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Sept. 15 - With its strong Cajun traditions, Mardi Gras celebrations and drive-through daiquiri bars, this southern Louisiana city has long sparred with New Orleans for the right to call itself a capital of relaxed revelry, the arts and French-influenced folkways.

title: Rethinking the Runoff
description: Call it the run-on primary. The results of last week's election to choose a Democratic challenger to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have politicians, the public and good-government groups pondering whether a process envisioned as a vehicle for electoral reform needs fixing or has even run its course.

title: Evelyn Y. Davis and James Patterson
description: Evelyn Y. Davis, the corporate shareholder activist, and James E. Patterson, a retired government official, were married on Wednesday in Arlington, Va. Gerald E. Williams, a lawyer and Virginia civil magistrate, performed the ceremony in his office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, ALEXANDER AKA SANDER
description: KATZ--Alexander aka Sander. 92, September 16, 2005, two days shy of 68th wedding anniversary to his beloved Nina. Devoted father to Patricia (David Bogaisky), Susan (Edward Flinn) and Janet (George Samuels). Loving grandpop to Soraya, Jeremy, Michael, Emily, Daniel and Michael S. Brother of Herbert and Gloria Brooks. His family was the center of his life. We will miss him. Services Sunday at Sinai Chapel, Fresh Meadows, NY, 1:15 pm.

description: WASHINGTON - AT the opening of the United Nations last week, President Bush said the United States could get much more done building coalitions than acting as the world's Lone Ranger.

title: David Cronenberg's Body Language
description: At the Cannes Film Festival this past May for the premiere of his new film, "A History of Violence," the director David Cronenberg got into some trouble for announcing that with this, his 15th feature film, he had sold out. "I've been waiting for years to sell out," he told a scrum of journalists. "It's just that nobody offered me anything before now." He was joking, of course, but over his 30-year career, the director of "The Fly," "Dead Ringers," "Crash" and a dozen other profoundly disturbing films has accrued the kind of hyperdevoted fan base that tends not to find that kind of talk funny at all. The news that the 62-year-old Cronenberg had apparently broken the compact never to change in any way caused his fans to light up the Internet with cries of mourning and condemnation. "You have to watch what you say," he admitted to me recently, "just because they're so passionate. If nobody cared what you said, then it wouldn't be an issue."

title: BOULDER, COLO.: TWO HANDS PAPERIE
description: Three blocks west of the Pearl Street pedestrian mall in Boulder, Colo., where tourists shop for Southwestern souvenirs or watch street performers, is Two Hands Paperie, a trove of paper-related products and gifts. It caters to paper and book lovers, as well as writers seeking artistic journals to inspire their muse.

title: John J. McMullen Dies at 87; Ex-Owner of Devils and Astros
description: John J. McMullen, who brought the National Hockey League to New Jersey in 1982, then presided over Devils teams that won two Stanley Cup championships, died Friday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 87.

title: Gathering, Between Tragedy And Peril
description: Hastings-on-Hudson - IT was the annual neighborhood block party, and everything looked normal. The weather was perfect for late summer -- bright sunshine with just a hint of coolness in the air. Sawhorses had been set up to block traffic. Tablecloths fluttered in the light wind; held down by dishes of pasta salad, fruit salad, chicken wings and a selection of pies and cakes. Neighbors stood in clusters and caught up with news; older residents sat at card tables and caught the late afternoon sun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIFFIN, GERALD W.
description: GRIFFIN--Gerald W. died peacefully on Wednesday, September 14, with his family at his side. The cause was complications from hip surgery. Gerry was born to Esther and Charles Griffin on July 9, 1927. He grew up in Flatbush, Brooklyn. His love of sports earned him basketball scholarships to high school and college and he graduated from St. John's University in 1950, after serving briefly in the military. Gerry earned his law degree in 1953 from St. John's Law School and began his legal career at the firm of Milbank Tweed. He later joined the firm of Cooper & Dunham, becoming a named partner in 1963, and remained with that firm for 43 years. His practice focused on litigating patent, trademark and copyright disputes. Gerry is survived by his wife Roberta, brother Charlie, children, Lisa, Beth, Patricia and Gerald and grandchildren, Riley, Jack, Daniel and Brennan. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave in Manhattan on Tuesday, September 20 from 7-9pm and Wednesday, September 21, from 2-5pm & 79pm. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Thursday, September 22, at 11:30am.

title: Jennifer Rudin and Glen Pearson
description: Jennifer Anne Rudin, a daughter of Marcia Rudin and Rabbi James Rudin of New York, is to be married today to Glen R. Pearson, a son of Carolyn and Rodney Pearson of Altadena, Calif. Rabbi Gary Greenebaum is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton, Huntington Hotel and Spa in Pasadena, Calif. The bride's father and sister, Rabbi Eve Rudin, are to participate in the ceremony.

description: One man was killed and another wounded in a shooting early yesterday outside a Brooklyn apartment building, the police said. The identity of the gunmen was unknown, they said.

description: Much newsprint and air time were squandered in the first half of the "decade before the storm" on revelations of sexual impropriety in the Oval Office and the inconsequential ripples from the Whitewater scandal.

title: Ashley Deeks and Michael Flowers
description: Ashley Stewart Deeks and Michael Patrick Flowers, both lawyers for the United States in Baghdad, were married yesterday in East Orleans, Mass., at the weekend home of the bride's parents, Susan Deeks and Peter Deeks of New Vernon, N.J. The ceremony was led by Aaron P. Karczmer, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: UN sleuth puzzling out Hariri assassination
Fueling Car and Home
description: Like everybody else in this country, New Yorkers have been agonizing over every costly trip to the gas station. But consumers here have more than their cars to worry about. The cost of keeping houses warm in the Northeast this winter is expected to hurt worse than the price at the pump.

title: Extreme Makeover: Museum Edition
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio - IT would seem embarrassing for any architect, let alone one as prominent as Peter Eisenman. You design a museum -- your first large-scale work, a breakout project whose exterior scaffolding design, a virtual celebration of impermanence, sets the architecture world buzzing. Within just a few years, however, cracks start to show. Quite literally: the skylight leaks. The glass curtain wall lets in too much light, threatening to damage delicate artwork. The interior temperature swings by as much 40 degrees some days.

title: The Talk
description: Toff Toff / (taf, tof) / n. / (chiefly British slang) An elegantly dressed man, often with a trust fund and affected manners; this season, a dominant motif in men's fashion, as designers from Burberry to Hickey promenaded enough gentlemanly tweeds, plaids and crisp Anglo-tailoring to rival a hunting party at Madonna's estate.

description: A woman accidentally backed her vehicle into her 13-year old son on Staten Island early yesterday, killing him, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARGAND, ANNABELLE ROD MAN
description: ARGAND -- Annabelle Rod man. Annabelle Rodman Argand, born in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and later residing in Maplewood, NJ, Jerusalem, Israel and Madison, WI, died Saturday, September 3, in Madison. She was 90 years old. Since 1945 a prominent presence in Hadassah and National Women's League, she was also a needlework artist on Judaic and biblical themes recognized by the Wisconsin Arts Board and the Smithsonian Institution. She is survived by her son Dr. Robert, of San Carlos, CA, a daughter Trudy (Harvey) Barash, of Madison, WI, four grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Memorials may be made to the Beth Israel Center Second Chance Fund (in support of families who require low cost housing), 1406 Mound St., Madison, WI 53711. Mrs. Argand often used the Yiddish expression. "You can't dance at all the weddings with one tuchus." But she came close. For more detail, www.madison.com (obituaries, 09/05/2005).

title: Judging a Band by Its Covers
description: Buying "Tiny Dancer"? Would you prefer the original Elton John, the Ben Folds or the Tim McGraw? "Smells Like Teen Spirit"? Can we interest you in Tori Amos or Paul Anka?

title: What's in the Belly Of the Beast? Gravel
description: Officials at the Maritime Aquarium in Norwalk recently discovered that the bulges inside the stomachs of some of its sand tiger sharks is gravel from the bottom of the tank, a scientist there said last Tuesday. John Lenzycki, a marine biologist and the assistant curator of animals, said the gravel was identified through digital X-rays of a female shark.

title: Germans seemingly said 'Nein' to sweeping reforms
Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: Perhaps The Times should cover poverty better, but the newspaper exists in a country that looks to the side rather than face the reality of poverty.

title: 'Zarqawi'
description: The image went around the world. On September 6, 1970, two airplanes, one from Swissair and the other from TWA, were hijacked and forced to land at the so-called "Revolutionary" airport, a disused military facility at Zarqa, in Jordan. Three days later, a British plane was diverted to this same airport. Once the passengers were let go, two Palestinian terrorists, Wadi Haddad and Layla Khalid, blew up the cabins. This first dramatic gesture on the part of the PFLP triggered the onset of Black September, the fierce repression undertaken by King Hussein against the Palestinian fedayeen who had taken refuge in Jordan.

title: Parental Guidance
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Psst: Want to Know My Net Worth?
description: APRIL was a stellar month for Jim Wang, 25, a software engineer who has kept a scrupulous record of his struggle to save for a down payment on his first home.

title: Sentencing Angelo Petrone
description: Before he lost his job, Angelo Petrone, the disgraced former schools superintendent in Yonkers, would proclaim with great emotion how much he loved the schoolchildren whose futures he was hired to nurture and protect. The yearly act of gutting his his own school budget, threatening to throw teachers out of work while eliminating art, music and sports programs, tore at Mr. Petrone's heart, which overflowed with indignation at the tightwads in Albany who made such suffering necessary.

title: Christopher Goeken and Glenn Magpantay
description: Christopher Scott Goeken and Glenn Duque Magpantay, lawyers in New York, affirmed their partnership yesterday. Sabrina Sojourner, a friend of the couple, led the commitment ceremony at the Times Square Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Giving Them What They Want
description: Lynn Hirschberg writes that "news stories are often dark" and that Leslie Moonves "would like to find a way to make them light" ( Sept. 4). If you wonder why many of us rarely watch the major networks these days and instead turn to cable, it is precisely because of this lack of respect for viewers.

title: Epic Proportions
description: Sweeping or slender, this season's cut is going to extremes.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Democrats question Roberts on his candor
Sideline Acrobats
description: Cheerleading is, in the popular imagination, the soft, sweet stuff of fall afternoons -- the bright colors and big smiles, the irony-free heartland enthusiasm, the sideshow aspect of exhorting players and crowds by way of pompoms and short skirts. But the truth is that cheerleaders, at the college level at least, happen to be serious athletes. The University of Kentucky squad, whose current members are featured in the following photographs, is the best in the country, having won the national championships of the Universal Cheerleaders Association 14 times since 1985. To watch them in training or competition (or at play in a lake) is to see acrobatic artistry at a literally sky-high level -- the women soaring through the air, the men hoisting them up on single upturned palms.

title: Melanie Lopes and Ryan Lumelleau
description: Melanie Leigh Lopes, a daughter of Rita and Henrique Lopes of Ridgefield, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Ryan Alexander Lumelleau, a son of Loretta and John Lumelleau of Mission Hills, Kan. Msgr. Edward V. Wetterer performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Les Femmes on the East Side
description: ANY play that has a rich-boy character named Dicky Mayhew automatically endears itself to me. Add to that a fabulous all-white Art Deco-inspired set and a couple of bouncy, dancelike but not quite dancing entrances, and any number of flaws fade into the gleaming woodwork.

title: What a Hurricane Can Teach
description: MAMARONECK - SHOULD people be allowed to loot?" Joan Spedafino asked her fourth graders at F.E. Bellows Elementary School here, as they sat pensively on their classroom rug to consider her question in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. One pupil argued that it was all right since people in New Orleans had no money, while another held that "the stores won't have stuff for people who are paying."

title: Pentagon Construction Boom Beefs Up Mideast Air Bases
description: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar, Sept. 15 - Even as the Pentagon is mulling plans to begin reducing the number of American combat troops in Iraq and Afghanistan next spring, the military has more than $1.2 billion in construction under way or on the drawing board to upgrade 16 air bases throughout the Middle East and Southwest Asia.

description: JESSI KLEINMAN of Bellmore was filled with anticipation when she arrived in New Orleans on Aug. 24 with her father, mother and brother, three days before freshman orientation was set to begin at Tulane University.

Jones made his way to one of the soaring windows in the studio he has been occupying over Times Square and changed his clothes, concealing no part of his fabled musculature from public appreciation.
