description: POLAK--Ernest H. Of Tucson, AZ, died on September 12, 2005 leaving his loving wife, Ghislaine; two sons, and five grandchildren. His long life was devoted to scientific research and development.

title: Hotel Rooms of Their Own
description: With the number of women traveling solo rising, several hotels have designated floors or wings only for women who are guests. The hotels have enhanced security with peepholes and chains on the doors and, in some cases, surveillance cameras in the hallways. Generally, only waitresses provide room service for these rooms, and often the members of the engineering and housekeeping staff are women.

title: Ferrer, His Candidacy Assured, Campaigns in Brooklyn
description: Fernando Ferrer began the first real weekend of the general election campaign quietly shoring up support among backers of his former rivals for the Democratic nomination, while Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continued efforts to make inroads into Mr. Ferrer's own base of Hispanic voters.

title: Columbia Wins Its Season Opener
description: Columbia is a long way from a successful year, but the Lions can rest assured that this season will be no worse than last year. Columbia, 1-9 in 2004, won its season opener, 23-17, last night at Fordham.

title: Will Katrina Make the Fed Slow Down?
description: WITH few economic reports due this week, the Federal Reserve has the stage pretty much to itself. But even if the calendar were full, it would be hard to deflect traders' attention from the first formal opportunity to gauge the Fed's thinking on interest rates and the economy since Hurricane Katrina.

title: Girding for a New School Year, One With Less Room to Move
description: Last Wednesday, parents arrived in droves to drop off their children at Holy Cross Elementary School, a low, many-windowed building on a quiet street in Harding Park in the eastern Bronx.

title: Girls and Boys, Meet Nature. Bring Your Gun.
description: GREEN MOUNTAIN NATIONAL FOREST, Vt. - Chomping wad after wad of Bubblicious Strawberry Splash gum and giggling as she tickled people's necks with a piece of grass she pretended was a spider, Samantha Marley could have been any 9-year-old girl.

title: The Key to Google's $10 Million Man
description: SAN FRANCISCO - IN the public tug of war over Kai-Fu Lee, a computer scientist at Microsoft who defected to Google, a Seattle judge ruled last week that Google can have him, but said he could not work on search and speech technologies, two of his specialties.

title: C.E.O. CATFIGHT
description: As skirmishes between corporate titans go, this was the equivalent of Cher slapping Nicolas Cage in "Moonstruck."

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: As a former resident of New York, and an occasional visitor to New Orleans, I had noted the romantic flavor of the Times articles you mentioned. Frankly, it's hard to fathom. The poverty was perhaps not as stark as in areas like Biloxi, Miss., but poverty, class and race were all pretty well entwined in the Big Easy, and any walk through any part of the city would have made it obvious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSSBARD, HELEN
description: GROSSBARD--Helen. On Sept. 16, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Dr. Lionel (Janet), Dr. Stephen (Elizabeth) & Dr. Elliott (Elayne). Darling grandmother of Doctors Michael and Sarah Jane Grossbard, Doctors Caren & Scott Solomon, Dr. Jeremy Grossbard (Adrienne) and Jessica Grossbard, and Sylvie & Joseph Grossbard. Doting great-grandmother of Will, Katie, Dan, Lily and Lucy. Service Sunday, 9:45 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: New opposition leader aims at Japan's charter
Heavy Metal Gets an M.F.A.
description: YOU might not have known it from looking at the audience, but when the Chicago instrumental band Pelican performed at the Knitting Factory in late July, it was playing metal.

title: J. Calvin Jureit, Inventor Who Transformed Home Building, Dies at 87
description: John Calvin Jureit, the inventor of the Gang-Nail connector plate, a simple-to-use connecting device for roof trusses that helped revolutionize the home-building industry in the 1950's and make housing much more affordable, died Sept. 9 in Stuart, Fla. He was 87.

title: In the Mediterranean, a Quiet Haven, Sort Of
description: UNDER a cloudless Cypriot summer sky that matched the cerulean Mediterranean below it, two warring tribes met in pursuit of the perfect Jet Ski. Against a backdrop of luxury hotels and archaeology, the protagonists of this unlikely stand-off found themselves in neutral territory a mere 45-minute flight from their battle-weary homelands. "Gil, from Israel, meet Ahmed, from Palestine," said a smiling Panos, the burly water sports instructor-cum-Middle East mediator who'd clearly witnessed such encounters before. Pausing before the rippling waves awaiting them, each warmly extended one hand to the other. "If we can't shake hands here," the Israeli observed to the Arab, "then where will we ever be able to shake hands?"

title: Life's Illusions, Recalled Just So
description: PURCHASE - THE ability of contemporary artists to redeem weakly obvious ideas is emphasized, celebrated even, perhaps contrary to the curator's intentions, in "Acting Out: Invented Melodrama in Contemporary Photography" showing at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College.

title: Corrections
description: Two photographs on Page 3 of the Travel section today, with the Datebook column, are reversed. The rowers should appear with the report about the Head of the Charles Regatta in Cambridge, Mass., and the people looking at books with the report about a literature festival in Cheltenham, England.

title: Indian Point Siren Failures Set Off a Storm of Protest
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y., Sept. 16 - When some warning sirens for the Indian Point nuclear power plant failed to go off during a test on Wednesday, the wail from elected officials and residents was perhaps even louder than the emergency-notification system itself.

title: THE NEW BELFAST
description: As someone who travels to Belfast, Northern Ireland, frequently, I believe that Stuart Emmrich captured the flavor of the "new" Belfast very well in "Belfast Is Ready for the Party to Begin" (Aug. 21). But in an otherwise excellent report, several of Mr. Emmrich's observations call for clarification.

title: From Artist to Muse and Back to Artist
description: Berkeley, Calif. - WHEN the film version of Steve Martin's best-selling novella, "Shopgirl," opens next month, audiences will see just how much of himself Mr. Martin put into the adaptation: he wrote the screenplay, produced the film and stars as Ray Porter, a wealthy older man who enters into a relationship with a shy, depressed clerk (Claire Danes) who spends her days selling gloves at an elegant Beverly Hills department store and her nights making art at her small dining table.

title: Nature and Nurture, Squaring Off Again
description: CARMEL - ON a stifling hot September morning, Cindy Katz was visiting to one of the last undeveloped patches of land in this hamlet just north of Westchester. Looking out at 37 acres of wetlands and thick forest, she trained her eyes on a deer as it bounded into view near a row of fallen trees. In a split second it was gone, beneath the arc of a steep hill that ends at the west branch of the Croton River, a pristine stream with trophy-size trout that flows into the Croton Falls reservoir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGLINCHEY, ANNE
description: McGLINCHEY--Anne, formerly of Bay Ridge, died September 12, in Farmington Hills, MI. She worked as a victims advocate and was Director of Manhattan Court Dispute Referral Center. Make donations to NYC Zonta Club.

title: Georgia's Shame of a Voting Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Scolds Careless Public: You Can Prevent Forest Fires
description: MADRID, Sept. 17 - As Spain emerges from its worst summer of forest fires in a decade, the government has begun scolding the public for the careless and sometimes malicious behavior that specialists say causes the vast majority of fires here.

title: Governor of Illinois Is Pressed on Scandal
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17 - For two days in a row, Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich was bombarded with questions from reporters this week about whether he was "Public Official A," the unidentified person accused of directing a kickback scheme involving state pension investments.

title: An Urban Landmark in Manhattan Grows by 46 Stories
description: Like the pharaohs, William Randolph Hearst liked big. Gaudy wasn't bad, either. In his eyes, action -- boisterous and ambitious -- was king. The denouement was best left to others.

title: The Get; The New Collectibles
description: Rattle and Roll: These silver-and-enamel cuff links will lead you into retail temptation. They are $325 at Alfred Dunhill, 711 Fifth Avenue.

title: Gunmen Kill Kurdish Member of Parliament in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 18 - Iraqi officials announced today that a Kurdish member of Parliament was fatally shot by gunmen north of capital, as hundreds of Shiite militia fighters blocked off streets in the southern city of Basra to demand the release of three members being held by British forces.

title: Dealing With Dealers
description: What is wrong with an unequivocal opposition to crystal meth? You ran a harrowing article on the life of a family whose teenage son was hooked on this devastating drug. ("My Addicted Son," by David Sheff, Feb. 6). Maybe the Ethicist should read it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Too Much of a Mystery
description: John Roberts failed to live up to the worst fears of his critics in his confirmation hearings last week. But in many important areas where senators wanted to be reassured that he would be a careful guardian of Americans' rights, he refused to give any solid indication of his legal approach. That makes it difficult to decide whether he should be confirmed. Weighing the pluses and minuses and the many, many unanswered questions, and considering some of the alternatives, a responsible senator might still conclude that he warrants approval. But the unknowns about Mr. Roberts's views remain troubling, especially since he is being nominated not merely to the Supreme Court, but to be chief justice. That position is too important to entrust to an enigma, which is what Mr. Roberts remains.

title: Catherine Earthman and Thomas Polk
description: Catherine Calhoun Earthman and Thomas Salvage Polk were married yesterday in Nashville. The Very Rev. Kenneth Swanson officiated at Christ Episcopal Church Cathedral.

title: More Services at the Real Estate Office
description: BETH NOBLE was three months pregnant in July when she and her husband found a house in Smithtown that they wanted to buy. The seller was ready to move to Florida, so when the Nobles' offer was accepted, the couple hoped they could close on the house quickly.

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: Re "Covering New Orleans: The Decade Before the Storm" (Sept. 11):

title: Q & A
description: Are there package tours that cross the Antarctic Circle? -- Katherine Lin, Flushing, Queens

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRESSLER, BERNARD
description: BRESSLER--Bernard. Died peacefully on Saturday morning, September 17. Bernie was the beloved husband of Teresa, father of Lisa Berg and Jeanette Bressler, grandfather of Adam and Joshua Berg, father-in-law of Michael Berg, future father-inlaw of Steven W. Perlsweig, and brother of Martin. He was 77 years old. He was a veteran of the US Navy in World War II and graduated from Rutgers University in 1948, and in 1952 from Harvard Law School, magna cum laude, where he was a member of the Law Review. Bernie was a founding senior partner in the New York, New Jersey and Florida law firm of Bressler, Amory & Ross and has written and co-written a number of legal works including the New York Lawyers Manual and the Tax Annotations for Nichols Encyclopedia. At the time of his death Bernie was the Director and Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the New Jersey Public Interest Law Center, which successfully litigated the issue of racial profiling by the New Jersey State Police. Over the years he was active in a number of charitable activities, including Area Chairman for the United Jewish Appeals and for the United Negro College Fund. He also served as a Trustee of the Summit Civic Foundation, the South Street Theater Company and the Community Theater of Morristown. Bernie was a member of the Lotos Club in New York and the Park Avenue Club in Morristown. Funeral services will be at Temple Sinai, 208 Summit Ave., Summit, NJ, on Tuesday, September 20, at 11 am, with interment at the Workman's Circle Cemetery, Route 33, Freehold, NJ. Donations may be made to the Bernard Bressler Fund at the Morristown Memorial Hospital in honor of Dr. Steven Papish.

title: The Remix; Pitch Fever
description: 1. David Beckham (a) may hold the title of soccer's No. 1 fashion plate, but recently some other players have been earning peacock status. Giorgio Armani chose Kak, the Brazilian forward for A.C. Milan, for his spring jeans campaign, while A.C. Milan's Ukrainian striker, Andriy Shevchenko (European Footballer of the Year in 2004), has been promoting Emporio Armani's sunglasses (b).

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I would expect a lot of premature mortality. Their experience is unimaginable."

title: To the City's Bridges, Billets-Doux
description: HER love affair with bridges began in Philadelphia, where the artist who calls herself Bascove grew up. Driving over the Benjamin Franklin Bridge, she recalls, gave her "a profound sensation of suspension, moving from one world to another, and being in neither." She began painting them in Paris, and when she moved to New York, she lived on East 62nd Street "where the Queensboro presides over the neighborhood." That became her first New York bridge; Bascove, who now lives in the East 50's, went on to paint dozens.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-18-05: CONSUMED; Collective Bargain Hunting
description: Nearly a half-century later, consumers still make the most of technology to battle high prices. One example of what has changed, and what hasn't, is the Web site FatWallet.com. Founded in 1999 as a hobby by a Web developer named Tim Storm, it now has 370,000 registered users and about 30 employees. FatWallet performs three functions. As an "affiliate" of various online retailers (including Staples, Dell and Target), it earns a small commission on sales it makes through its site, which it splits with its users in a "cash back" program. It also has an area where online coupons and special sales are announced. But the most interesting -- and potentially subversive -- thing is the forums section. There, consumers themselves have tracked down bargains and decided to share them with others. Some of these users are definitely "deal-hunting addicts," Storm says, and their forum interactions are "the heartbeat of the site."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLAKEMAN, IRENE
description: BLAKEMAN--Irene. Our hearts are connected forever. We love you Mom. Joan and Janet

description: LASUS--Helen, on September 15, 2005, of Pound Ridge, NY. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Robert, Richard and Howard. Loving sister of Bernard Marcus and Frances Entin. Funeral services will be held on Monday, September 19 at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY at 10AM. Interment, Glenville Cemetery, Greenwich, Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLADE, JOHN
description: SLADE--John. It is with sincere regret that we at the New York City office of American Express Tax & Business Services, Inc. mourn the passing of our loyal client, John Slade. Wall Street has lost one of its brightest stars. From his leadership at Bear Stearns to his generosity toward the New York community, John will always be remembered as a model for living life to the fullest and achieving the highest levels of personal and professional success. We send our deepest sympathies to the Slade family. Joseph V. Falanga, CPA on behalf of American Express Tax & Business Services, Inc.

title: Further With Feiner
description: Greenburgh and Paul Feiner are not through with each other yet . Barring a surprise when voting machines are checked tomorrow, the apparently unsinkable Mr. Feiner, the town supervisor, has just survived his first primary election challenge in a dozen years, squeaking past Bill Greenawalt by 173 votes. He plans to run in November for his eighth term, chastened but unopposed.

title: New Zealand Leader Ahead in Voting
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sunday, Sept. 18 - Prime Minister Helen Clark will begin talks with other parties to form a coalition government after her Labor Party held a slender plurality over the main opposition National Party in the election on Saturday.

title: The Get; Pinstripe Wizards
description: These jackets tilt the deal in your favor.

title: Energy Tax to Be Cut
description: With energy prices soaring after Hurricane Katrina, Suffolk County is moving to roll back part of a four-year-old tax on home energy bills in time for the winter. The move would reduce the tax by a percentage point, to 1.5 percent, for six months beginning Dec. 1, costing the county about $13 million.

title: Corzine Finds $185,000 Doesn't Go Far Enough
description: In giving up his Senate seat to run for governor, Jon S. Corzine cast himself as an outsider. What he did not need, though, was the chairman of the formidable Bergen County Democratic organization calling him an outsider -- as in, "we do not look kindly upon someone who's outside the county trying to exert influence in a local race."

title: Cover Artist
description: For most New Yorkers, riding the subway during rush hour is about as pleasant as a trip to SoHo on a Saturday. But for the artist Karel Funk, it was a valuable source of inspiration. "I could see so much about the people standing next to me -- whether they were wearing contact lenses or had dandruff -- but I still knew nothing about their lives," he says. "I became interested in portraits that show everything but reveal very little. That's when I thought about painting sporty jackets and hoods: they are universal but anonymous."

title: Peacocks
description: Some of the men attending Fashion Week had more interest in what they wore than the women the shows were mostly for. While the women took shelter in understatement, sharp dressers appeared in both classic and uncharted combinations. Several dandies wore a different ensemble every day. ON THE STREET

title: Comings and Goings
description: Correction Appended

title: Tech Support
description: Clockwise from top left: Lexar JumpDrive Lightning flash drive Tired of carrying around discs, or worse, e-mailing yourself work from home? Flash drives that are small enough to wear as a pendant are everywhere, but this stainless-steel model is the only one you'll actually try it with. $140 for one gigabyte; $280 for two gigabytes. Go to www.lexar.com.

description: Taryn Siegelberg, a daughter of Charlene and Robert Siegelberg of Manhattan, was married last evening to Michael Laurence Feinberg, a son of Diane and Kenneth R. Feinberg of Bethesda, Md. Cantor Richard Botton officiated at the Loft@47 West Street in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MICH, ISABELLA TAVES
description: MICH--Isabella Taves. Born September 20, 1905, Lincoln, Nebraska; died June 25, 2005, New York, NY. Tuesday would have been her 100th birthday. B.S. 1926, Northwestern University, summa cum laude, and Phi Beta Kappa. She became a journalist and then wrote for Colliers, Cosmopolitan, McCall's, Today's Woman and Look magazines. She authored articles, short stories, several non-fiction books and novels. Devoted wife of the late Daniel D. Mich, former executive editor of Look Magazine. They traveled the world, meeting the great men and women of the mid-20th century. Dog lover extraordinaire, she bred and showed Dalmatians. A cherished and devoted friend, she is deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAMMELL, WEBB
description: TRAMMELL - Webb. Sep tember 15, 2005. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Philip. Devoted brother of Ghislaine Morris. He was a retired Lieutenant Commander in the Navy and former Rockefeller Foundation assistant treasurer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, September 21, 10:30 am, at the Church of St. John the Martyr, 250 East 72nd St. Interment to follow later at Arlington National Cemetery.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 17 - Warlords, drug lords, and former Communist and Taliban officials are joining professors, businessmen and poets as candidates in Afghanistan's first parliamentary elections in 35 years on Sunday.

title: Kings and legends of ancient Persia
The Talk; Short Story
description: Back in the 1980's, when Pee-wee Herman wore suits that were several sizes too small, everyone in their big-shouldered baggy suits thought he looked hilarious. Who knew he was a style icon in the making? But the short, almost shrunken jackets crowding the fall 2005 runways have other historical antecedents that predate Pee-wee's arrival on his bicycle.

title: The Remix; Dressing Downtown
description: Adam Kimmel's debut collection already has the support of downtown demimondains like Norman Reedus (below) and Hope Atherton, who model his workmanlike men's wear in the label's promotional material. But the publicity-shy 26-year-old prefers to focus on his clothing rather than his models. Kimmel says he was inspired by the utilitarian style of the Abstract Expressionist Willem de Kooning: "He was a man's man. It was a beautiful life lived so simply." This translates into tailored industrial cotton, coarse canvas lined with fox and a sweatshirt tuxedo. Kimmel also loves the jumpsuit, a signature piece, in which de Kooning, a serial overalls-wearer, would surely have made a splash. Available at Bergdorf Goodman. MARK JACOBS

title: Up From the Country, Patron Saints of the Road
description: SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 16 - Little does the National Football League know that everybody's new favorite team could really be a bunch of squirrel eaters.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 17 - Warlords, drug lords, and former Communist and Taliban officials are joining professors, businessmen and poets as candidates in Afghanistan's first parliamentary elections in 35 years on Sunday.

title: Talking in the Dark
description: When was the last time you heard a "busy tone" on a telephone? Probably not for years. Our phone system is so robust, our mobile phones are so ubiquitous and voice mail and e-mail are such reliable backups that instant, unhindered access to friends, colleagues and relatives has come to seem a right and not a privilege. Indeed, if you include instant-messaging, blogs and cellphone text messages, you might think we're living in the golden age of communications.

title: Duomo Vogue
description: Renaissance men never go out of fashion, but their clothes are another matter. This season, however, princely velvets and jackets turned up at Gucci, Miu Miu, Calvin Klein and Armani; Alexander McQueen evoked 16th-century painterly tops; and designers as diverse as Valentino and Hedi Slimane found common ground in capes that could have been salvaged from a musty palazzo.

title: A Glass House, Room for Guests
description: Best thing about being single: You get to date a lot of women. I am a lover of freedom. If anyone nags me, I say, "Hey, if I wanted to be nagged, I'd get married." That pretty much ends that discussion.

title: Giving Them What They Want
description: After a week of viewingwrenching (and often outstanding) television news coverage of Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, I find that Moonves's comments present both an absurd and alarming view of what he sees as the future of the "CBS Evening News." Broadcast news is not, and never was, intended to be entertainment.

title: Codey Leaving a Mixed Bag as His Legacy
description: WEST ORANGE - SO Richard J. Codey gets a phone call one recent evening.

title: Negative Capability, Dude
description: To the Editor:

title: A Commoner's Rowdy Ride to the White House
description: A BIOGRAPHER of Benjamin Franklin and Theodore Roosevelt, H.W. Brands has shifted his lens westward to tell the life of Andrew Jackson. His subject is well chosen -- a president generally ranked as significant yet one whose story is not widely known.

title: Concrete Worker Is Killed in Brooklyn
description: A worker at a Brooklyn construction company was killed yesterday afternoon when his head became wedged between a massive block of concrete and the metal cable being used to hoist it onto a flatbed truck, the police said.

title: Yoga, Y'all
description: I must begin here by saying that I am not picky about my yoga. Even as yoga has become to 21st-century America what, say, automobiles were to 20th-century America (something everybody has, but the wealthy have the fanciest), I have not succumbed to yoga snobbery. It is not necessary for me to perform my poses in studios designed by Frank Gehry while balancing on a mat spun from the finest bacteria-resistant Tibetan unicorn pelt.

title: Goodbye to All That
description: I SOMETIMES think about a friend of mine, a woman who skedaddled out of here years ago, and who now lives in Philadelphia, where she's doing very well, thank you very much. "Me and New York," she has said. "We were like partners in a bad marriage. We loved each other at least I loved it but we couldn't live together."

title: Amid Ruins of Home, Sorrow and Solidarity
description: GULFPORT, Miss. - THE Caravan of Hope arrived here at 6 p.m. Thursday. For Clarence Weatherspoon and several other professional basketball players, that was when the full force of Hurricane Katrina's tragic impact became real.

title: Letters
description: RUFUS PORTER'S MURALS

title: Bulking Up, Slimming Down
description: HOLBROOK - Last year, the two teachers on cafeteria duty at Hiawatha Elementary School would have been watching 150 third and fourth graders, not 180, according to Jill Gierasch, the school's principal. There would have been an aide in every kindergarten class, not two shared by four classes. An adult monitor would be at the front entrance five days a week, not three.

title: Colombian President in New Jersey, Where the Voters Are
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 15 - When Colombia's president, lvaro Uribe, arrives for a town hall meeting on Sunday at the Ritz theater, in the heart of this working-class port city, he will no doubt feel right at home.

title: North Korean talks are extended
Iranian Leader Refuses to End Nuclear Effort
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 17 - In an unyielding address before the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday afternoon, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran rebuffed attempts to rein in his country's nuclear program, railing against the United States as an aggressor and restating a compromise proposal that had already been rejected.

title: Corrections
description: A line is omitted on Page 13 of the Travel section today at the end of an article about visiting the Napa Valley inexpensively. It should read, "Total spent: $262.49."

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: County's Orphans Of the Storm
description: ROCHELLE and Kai So and their children left New Rochelle two years ago to escape the high cost of living in Westchester. Hurricane Katrina has escorted them back, the poorer for their efforts.

title: Putting Aside Personal Travail to Tend to the Dead
description: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss. - The Edmond Fahey Funeral Home is one of a handful of peculiar buildings in Hancock County these days, peculiar in that it is still standing. All around lie piles of wood and brick, massacred trees and half-standing houses and yet, in the lobby the other day stood a man patiently perfecting the Windsor knot of his tie.

title: Ruth Farbman, 92, Aide to Mayor Wagner, Dies
description: Ruth Farbman, a former aide to Mayor Robert F. Wagner who was prominent in New York City civic affairs during the 1950's and 60's, died on Sept. 2 in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: Looking for a House and a Turret
description: A VICTORIAN mansion -- that's the kind of home Cynthia von Buhler was holding out for. Was it possible?

title: LIVES IN ART: A View From Both Sides of the Camera; Turning Dress-Up Into Fine Art
description: SAG HARBOR - GROWING up in Huntington Harbor in the 1960's, Cindy Sherman didn't know that she lived only a couple of miles from the home of Arthur Dove, the pioneering Modernist painter. Nor was she aware of the burgeoning art world in New York City. Even today, she is hard-pressed to pin down the genesis of her artistic impulse.

title: Manga for Girls
description: Walk into almost any chain bookstore and you're likely to find a teenage girl sprawled on the floor reading manga -- thick black-and-white comic books by Japanese authors. Graphic novels, including manga, have been popular with American boys for years now. But, to the surprise of publishers, "shojo" comics (or manga for girls) have become one of the hottest markets in the book business. Two publishers -- Viz Media, which is Japanese-owned, and Tokyopop, an American company -- have been the leaders in the American manga market, which has more than doubled since 2002, helped along by a $5 billion business in related animated films, TV series and licensed products like dolls and action figures. Del Rey, in the Random House Publishing Group, has become the first New York publisher to enter the shojo market in a big way (in partnership with Kodansha in Japan). Last year, Del Rey sold a million copies of its first 16 releases combined. Next year, it plans to bring out close to 85 manga titles, most of them aimed at teenage girls.

title: Time Is Money
description: Nothing gets the horologically obsessed wound up like a tourbillon. The tourbillon -- which means ''whirlwind'' in French and was invented in 1795 by Abraham-Louis Breguet -- is essentially a revolving cage that houses a watch's escapement and balance wheel. It rotates one revolution a minute, counteracting the effects of gravity and movement on accuracy. Blancpain's 1735 model has every bell and whistle and costs $779,000. Patek Philippe's Minute Repeater Tourbillon clocks in at a cool half-million. Comparatively speaking, the Breguet Skeleton Tourbillon (pictured here) is a bargain at $122,900. So, why not wear your complexity on (or near) your sleeve?

title: Style; Black Magic
description: Fall's most amazing silhouettes conjure a couture revival, as designers peer back into Cristbal. Pouf!

title: 'The Holding': Haunted in Canada
description: THE HOLDING

title: The Supreme Court's Private Life
description: PRINCETON, N.J. - WHEN John Roberts, President Bush's nominee for chief justice of the Supreme Court, told the Senate Judiciary Committee last week that "the right to privacy is protected under the Constitution in various ways," some saw this as contradicting a memo he wrote while serving in the Reagan administration in which he referred to the "so-called 'right to privacy."' The confusion may stem less from Judge Roberts's lack of candor than from the political and legal morass brought on by a string of dubious decisions by the Supreme Court over the last 40 years.

title: Bravest Gone South to Answer the Call
description: YONKERS - IT was close to noon and the bus was waiting. The black-and-yellow sign up top, which usually announces destinations like White Plains or Peekskill, said "Not in Service." That wasn't quite right, it seemed, given that these 26 Yonkers firefighters were about to head down South, ready to help whoever needed it.

title: Awash in Inequity
description: Q. As a renowned scholar of African-American history, a field that some say you virtually invented, how do you think Hurricane Katrina has altered our view of race in this country? The tragedy is that Katrina changed our view at all.

title: Canadian agencies linked to torture use abroad
JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Shag Rugs. Definitely, Shag Rugs.

title: Political Science
description: I was disappointed that Daniel Smith devoted only two sentences, in his Sept. 4 article, to the issue of "intelligent design." Here is a classic case of the administration ignoring not just decades of scientific research (as with global warming or stem cells) but also a century and a half of careful, documented scientific research in biology and geology. Evolution is truly the idea that makes the rest of biology make sense.

title: The Great Rock 'n' Roll Swindle
description: Music is inextricably linked with fashion. History shows that rock 'n' roll was born in 1947, at the time of Christian Dior's New Look. Unwanted and banned in the 40's, it was forced to go underground. But the moment rock 'n' roll started to cut its teeth on popular culture was the moment when every James Dean look-alike danced with an adolescent girl dressed head to toe in crinoline skirts and padded bras: the Hollywood High version of the New Look. That look, meanwhile, found a rival in the birth of prt--porter by Dior's successor, Yves Saint Laurent. It was the dawn of the 60's, and youth stopped imitating its elders and took on an identity of its own, taking over and changing fashion forever.

title: The Get; Heavy Necking
description: Fall's longer scarves come with fringe benefits.

title: High: Napa Valley on $1,000 a Day
description: Before us lay a bonbon, ensconced on a half shell. We considered the bonbon, debated it, conceptually analyzed the bonbon. We were perplexed, our hard-worn sense of self and confidence plummeting as we tried in vain to decode the elusive yellow powder -- clearly a curry of some sort -- covering the bonbon.

title: A Moveable Feat
description: White Plains - FOR many years, the Long Island Expressway was known as the world's longest parking lot. But several years ago, the Cross Westchester Expressway, also known as Interstate 287, assumed that title. The expressway runs from Interstate 95 in Port Chester through White Plains to the Tappan Zee Bridge, where it merges with the New York Thruway, or Interstate 87.

title: The Zone; Spare Parts
description: The lane dividing car and driver just got narrower. In a nod to the luxurious early days of motoring, when Louis Vuitton made custom "transport baggage" for Rolls-Royce, carmakers are taking their brands off-road with watches, clothing and leather goods.

title: The Remix; School of Ghoul
description: Gallerists and collectors may be optimistic about the booming art market, but some artists are tapping into a darker mood for inspiration. These modern-gothic artists -- whose works are being snapped up by fashion insiders -- champion a sinister, surreal side of culture, celebrating drugs, death metal and even the occult. For these morbid angels, death becomes them. Below, a sampling.

title: Boy, 9, Shot in Head in Bronx Building
description: A 9-year-old boy was shot in the head early yesterday morning when gunfire broke out inside a Bronx apartment building, the police said. The boy, identified by a relative as Kevin Whitfield, was in stable condition last night at Harlem Hospital Center a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: The Get; Getting the Boot?
description: Look down for consolation.

title: Dealing With Dealers
description: "What's the morality of narcking on the neighbors?" Perhaps it's time for a new Ethicist. In his Sept. 4 column, we are to deliberate on all the polite ways to encourage our neighborhood crystal-meth dealer to tone down any overt "nuisance" behavior so that we might avoid blowing the whistle and exposing him to inflexible and ineffectual criminal codes! In weighing the costs and benefits to the community at large of preserving the right to sell crystal meth without censure, I believe the decision is clear: "Doing nothing" is the worst possible alternative.

title: Swirling Currents On a Private Label
description: Richard Rodney Bennett: 'The Mines of Sulphur' Vocal soloists; Glimmerglass Opera Orchestra, conducted by Stewart Robertson. Chandos CHSA 5036; two CD's.

title: RUFUS PORTER'S MURALS
description: To the Editor: "In the Steps of Rufus Porter, Yankee Original," by Sam Hooper Samuels (Aug. 7), created great excitement in our little town of Bridgton, Me., population 5,000. Rufus Porter spent some of his boyhood years in Bridgton.

title: The Get; Capital Gains
description: Style Map - Washington, D.C. Poor Washington. Unquestionably the world's most politically powerful 60-odd square miles, the District of Columbia has chafed under its reputation as a hopelessly bourgeois backwater among glitzier capitals -- a blue suit among ball gowns. Now several neighborhoods are challenging the District's bad rap as First Frump, and none more convincingly than the 14th Street corridor, a blazing stretch of storefronts that, after decades of neglect, is fast becoming home to some of the city's edgiest art and commerce. MARK GLAZE

title: 'Class Matters': Money Changes Everything
description: Class Matters

title: 'The Purchase of Intimacy'
description: In the parish of Catahoula, Louisiana, during the 1840s Samuel Miller lived on his plantation with Patsy, his mulatto slave and sexual partner. In 1843, as Miller fell ill with dropsy, he sold the land and his slaves to Hugh Lucas, settling for nine promissory notes of $3,000 each, to be paid yearly. In April 1844, Miller, who was in declining health, left Louisiana with Patsy for St. Louis, Missouri. Before leaving, Miller gave the promissory notes to William Kirk, asking him to "keep them for Patsy's benefit" since "he intended to have her emancipated, and that he wanted the notes to enure to her benefit" (Cole v. Lucas, 2 La. Ann. 1946, 1948 (1847)). The previous year, Miller had granted Kirk power of attorney, authorizing him to emancipate Patsy.

description: THEATER

description: To the Editor:

title: The Highs and Lows of Going It Alone
description: Cary McWilliam, a freelance modern dancer and teacher in Manhattan who earns about $23,000 a year, loves the freedom of leaping from one job to the next, unbeholden to any single employer. But that same independence takes a toll on her finances and her nerves.

title: A BAR IN MARSEILLES
description: To the Editor: "Going to Marseilles," by Julia Chaplin (Aug. 14), mentions the Bar de la Marine with little comment other than referring to a "jumped-up D.J." But Bar de la Marine is the central location of the Marcel Pagnol "Fanny" trilogy. Americans may remember it in the 1961 film "Fanny," with Leslie Caron, Charles Boyer and Maurice Chevalier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASHBURN, STANLEY JR.
description: WASHBURN--Stanley Jr. October 6, 1908--September 11, 2005. Born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, he graduated from Yale in 1931. During WWII, he was a pilot with cargo-carrying Air Transport Command. Shortly after, he organized the American Airship Company and co-piloted the 120 foot long non-rigid airship. His corporate career followed as System Promotion Director for Pan Am World Airways. Stanley invented the "bongo board" and wrote countless published articles and books. He is remembered by his devoted wife AnnaBell, daughter Nancy, son Brodie, four grandchildren, one great grandchild and beloved nephews Tyler and Thomas Leinbach. A memorial service will be held on October 8 at 11 AM at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue at 60th Street.

title: Down-Home Comfort With an Upscale Bent
description: SAUGERTIES - JUST a few years back, those looking for adventurous dining typically left this bucolic Mayberry of a town for nearby Woodstock, which is considered more exciting, or even Manhattan.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 18, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 28 about deals made to persuade tenants to move from rent-regulated apartments referred imprecisely to inheritance rights for those apartments in New York City. A family member can take over an apartment only after having lived with the tenant for two years before the tenant moves out -- or one year, if the tenant is elderly or disabled. While such apartments can be passed along, they cannot literally be conveyed like heirlooms.

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: As a native Louisianian who lived in New Orleans for more than 12 years and who now lives in New York City, I believe that a national newspaper needs to be not only more vigilant in its reporting on other parts of the country, but also more comparative.

title: Keren Schweitzer and Jason Lippmann
description: Keren Schweitzer, a flutist, and Jason William Lippmann, a cellist, were married yesterday. The Rev. Kimber Lee Wilkes, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Westlake Village Inn in Westlake, Calif.

title: Some Lessons Are Not Textbook Examples
description: MAPLEWOOD - IT would be a mistake to say that Mark Terenzi lives for moments like this.

title: 'My Name Is Joaquin, and I Am an Actor'
description: After Joaquin Phoenix shoots the final scene of a film, as he did last September when he finished portraying Johnny Cash in Walk the Line,' he falls into a state of confusion and loneliness. "It was really hard for me to leave that movie," Phoenix recalled, as he smoked a cigarette in the garden of the restaurant of the Chateau Marmont in Hollywood. "I was angry and hurt and felt abandoned. I didn't know what to do. To play Cash, I had learned a whole new way of functioning in the world, and suddenly, I couldn't rely on that anymore. You go into a space of not having a routine to your day, of not knowing what you're going to say, and it's like, who are you? What are you? It's so easy to have a drink to just feel O.K. about being nothing."

title: Puff Dada
description: Stephen Burks laughs a lot, which is most unusual for a designer. Unlike many of his young peers, whose expressions range from self-consciously serious to grim, Burks seems downright happy-go-lucky. In photographs, he's often smiling broadly or captured in midlaugh. But don't let the carefree exterior fool you. Burks is a driven man.

title: Sabrina McLaughlin and Ramsey Smith
description: Sabrina Louise McLaughlin and Ramsey Douglas Smith were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: INSIDE
description: 30 Die When Car Bomb Strikes Baghdad Market Terrorists detonated a bomb hidden inside a car in a crowded Baghdad market, killing at least 30 people, according to initial reports from the Iraqi government. The attack came on the fourth day of an insurgent offensive aimed at Iraqi Shiites, which has killed more than 200 people and wounded more than 600. PAGE 12

title: On a Night With No Winner, Schrder Acts the Part
description: BERLIN, Sept. 18 - On an election night that produced no winner, Chancellor Gerhard SchrAder provided an uncanny facsimile of one, bounding to the stage to raucous applause, his hands clasped above his head in a victory gesture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARREN, ROSALIND AMES
description: WARREN -- Rosalind Ames died peacefully in her home surrounded by family and friends after a courageous battle against cancer. She is survived by beloved husband Eugene, loving daughters Shawn Crowley and Jennifer Medwin, caring sons-in-law Steve Medwin and Bill Crowley, cherished grandchildren Ryan Beres and Jessica Medwin, Catherine and Kiera Crowley, caring best friend Mary O'Brien and devoted friend Jenny Ruff. Roz arrived in New York City from Philadelphia at the age of 16 to begin an extraordinary twenty-three year modeling career. Admired and respected in her industry for honesty, integrity and strong character. Roz was one of the reigning queens of the 50's & 60's on Seventh Avenue. She worked for all of the top designers in her day: Charles James, Halston, Anne Klein, Ben Zuckerman, Geoffrey Beene, Kasper, and Molly Parnis. Charles James insisted that all Saks mannequins be patterned after her figure. Roz was selected by Eleanor Lambert to be the opening and closing model for the prestigious Coty Awards. She was Mr. Goodman's first choice of models at Bergdorf Goodman fashion shows. Roz showed privately for Jacqueline Kennedy and The Duchess of Windsor and was a personal favorite of Lady Bird Johnson. Roz left a lasting impression on those who met her. She had the unique ability to combine style, dignity, and generosity with humanity. Fiercely independent and determined, she was a woman before her time. Many will remember her for the intensity with which she applied herself in various Upper Westside gyms over the years, exercising, spinning, and ultimately daily yoga. She succeeded on her own terms, never compromising her integrity and commanding the respect of those with whom she worked. A discerning judge of character, Roz was a friend for life for those lucky and deserving people who she chose to embrace. At the same time, Roz always had a special place for those less fortunate than her, and her love of animals was profound--not only the lucky animals who shared her home over the years, but also the many dogs she knew by name in the park. Even in the midst of her struggle with cancer, she would gather the strength to walk to Central Park to feed the birds. Roz will be deeply missed by all her family and friends. She will remain in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) at 11:30 AM on Sunday, September 18th. Donations in her mamory may be made to the ASPCA, Hospice of New York, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer (Thoracic Oncology Department).

title: In a Sea of Black, Starlight
description: Amid this fall's wardrobe of darks and neutrals, accessories are lifting the gloom and infusing some glamour with a sizable dose of sparkle and shine. Whether in stone-trimmed ballerina flats, custom-crystalled iPod cases, demure rhinestone bobby pins or full-on sequined shrugs, shoppers can find glitter galore, even in the current forward pitch and tumble toward basic black.

title: Giving Them What They Want
description: Here's a radical suggestion: get rid of all the pretty faces on the news and show lots of meaningful footage -- the Euronews model. Use voice-overs.

title: Burlesque in Disco Style
description: GOING out to clubs these days often feels more like a stint on Rikers Island than a place to unwind and have a cold drink: bouncers who yell and boss, checkpoints at every raised platform, and reserved tables guarded like the jewelry counter at Tiffany's. Happy Valley, a new three-level club on an unfashionable, trash-heaped block of East 27th Street -- but actually a much cooler stretch than the street's more touristy western end in Chelsea -- is the antithesis of the usual cruel-to-be-kind experience.

title: Yakking (and Shaving!) While Driving
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Details Final Days of Pope John Paul II
description: ROME, Sept. 18 - The Vatican has published a meticulous account of Pope John Paul II's final days, vividly describing his last hours and providing an official chronology of his death.

title: The Get; Mix Master
description: 1. Michael Macko, the men's fashion director at Saks Fifth Avenue, takes the all-American style that his store is known for and gives it a twist, whether it's a bespoke suit in a boldly subversive stripe or a preppy button-down mixed with plaid trousers and a bright Charvet tie. "I'm a classicist, but I love a contemporary spin on things," he says. He's pictured here in a Ralph Lauren cashmere and wool suit ($1,450), Borrelli shirt ($390) and Charvet silk tie ($130).

title: Color War
description: IT takes something bizarre to grab a New Yorker's attention. And bizarre it was: row after row of actors' head shots, the kind that adorn the walls of New York's pizza parlors, delis, comedy clubs and theaters. But these pictures, on display at a Los Angeles playhouse, were not in black and white as they traditionally are in New York. They were all in color.

title: Lawmakers in Many States Look to Suspend Gas Taxes
description: Lawmakers in more than a dozen states and the District of Columbia are requesting special sessions or are already weighing proposals to suspend gasoline taxes because of price surges attributed in part to damage to refineries from Hurricane Katrina.

title: The Disaster Behind the Disaster: Poverty
description: IN the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, people watching images of poverty along the Gulf Coast may have wondered, "How many poor places like this are there in this country?" The easy answer is, quite a few.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARISH, JULIAN I., M.D.
description: BARISH--Julian I., M.D., 88, passed September 14, 2005, at home. Pioneer in adolescent psychiatry, founder of the Psychiatric Center for Adolescents, former president American Society for Adolescent Psychiatry, chairman of Adolescent Psychiatry Group at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Beloved husband of the late Judith Sophian Barish. Dearly loved by children Rick & Tricia and Greg Speckert; sister June Silverman; cousins Lester, Ruth, Leonard & Shirley Oberman; nieces & nephews Jan Maslow, Deane Fox, Mark, Doug & Todd Sophian; Betty Ray May; other family & friends, Fernando & family, Arami, Pamela, Jon, Naomi and so many more. The most caring, selfless person, he will be deeply missed. Service Tuesday, September 20, 6:30 pm, at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St, NYC, 212289-2221; visitation 5-9 pm.

title: ...But Keep the Fuel Tax
description: New York City's taxi drivers are not alone in agonizing over every costly trip to the gas station. Anyone who drives a car is hurting. But higher gasoline prices are not the only consequence of rising global prices for crude oil, tighter supplies of natural gas and the bottlenecks caused by Hurricane Katrina. The cost of keeping houses warm in New york and other Northeastern states is expected to hurt worse than the price at the pump.

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: I lived in New Orleans, and it was my observation that poverty there was almost totally ignored by those in the white community to the point that they never ventured into areas where the black population lived; the only black people many of those well-off folk knew or spoke with may have been their maids. It was like two parallel worlds, not unlike what I have seen in undeveloped countries.

title: Johnson Regrets Ejection
description: TORONTO, Sept. 17 - Randy Johnson has experience apologizing for angry outbursts. He did it in January, a day after confronting a television cameraman on a Manhattan street and shoving his camera. He did it again Saturday, a day after he was ejected in the second inning for arguing balls and strikes.

title: A Door-to-Door Scam For Hurricane 'Victim'
description: A citizen's call to the state police in Prospect recently foiled a scam that had an unidentified man falsely collecting money for a young girl he said was a victim of Hurricane Katrina.

Amy Shavell and Daniel Vatner

Ware, of Manhattan, two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A.B., B.S., M. Engr., Columbia University, twotime All-American water polo player. Co-founder, Agroceres, Brazil; founder, Ware Chemical Corporation. Sculptor, painter; member, Westport Arts Center. His humor, creativity, and wisdom will be greatly missed by all.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; POP/JAZZ
description: Usually, organizing a benefit concert is a thankless task. You start with some widely admired cause or some especially pressing need, and you add a lineup of stars who find themselves in tricky positions: at a benefit, they ignore the night's theme at their peril. But they acknowledge it at their peril, too. Think of some of the performers at Live 8, trying valiantly to find links between African poverty and the songs in their repertory.

title: With Gas Prices Soaring, Lawmakers Are Flinching
description: New Jersey's available transportation money is barely flowing now, a whorl closing in on a drain. If the disappearing Transportation Trust Fund is not pumped up before next summer, it will have next to nothing to buy New Jersey Transit cars or repave the state's highways, half of which are rated "unacceptable."

title: Space Oddity
description: Vito Acconci is cleaning up his act. The 65-year-old renegade artist turned architect has trimmed his mad-scientist's tousled hair so that he looks almost clean-cut. He still wears a uniform of head-to-toe black, but he no longer removes it in public. And he's scaled back the cigarettes, from two-and-a-half packs a day to just one. Perhaps this is what happens when an inveterate troublemaker famous for masturbating in a gallery has a second act designing, among other things, a children's playground.

title: Weekend Warriors
description: ELIZABETH - THERE is no scoreboard. No bench. No yard markers. In truth, there is not even enough grass. Veterans Park, which sits hard by the Arthur Kill on the edge of this largely blue-collar town, is home to the New Jersey Terminators.

description: HILL--Carol. Died September 9, 2005 in NY. AFTRA-SAG. Actress, TV Weather girl, Interviewer. Instructor: Announcer Training Studios, Kingsborough, Brooklyn College, John Jay. MS in Speech & Theatre, Brooklyn College 1973. Beloved friend.

title: Ankara's Citadel District, Renewed
description: TELL your taxi driver "Kaleici" (kah-leh-ee-chee) if you want to be dropped off in the high main square of the oldest district of Ankara. Phrygians, Romans, Byzantines, Seljuk Turks, and Ottomans once lived by this hill topped with citadel walls. Now, with the increasing presence of tourist-friendly businesses and attractions, you'll find as many women with cameras as wearing headscarves among those eyeing hazelnuts and chickpeas at the square's open-air market.

title: A Touch of Class
description: Ever since street style beat out the carriage trade, aristocrats have been totally out of fashion. Although a cool guy might aspire to a sharp suit worn by a music icon like Sean Combs or Usher, he would never yearn for the kind of boring blue-blood blazers worn by Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn in "Wedding Crashers."

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?
description: Perhaps you are right. The Times may have not done its readers right by ignoring the poverty of New Orleans. Reporting is one thing. Effective city management is another.

title: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?

title: My Dinners With Andrew
description: I WAS in my favorite restaurant again, everything in its place except for the empty seat across from me. I never minded eating alone, though I'd long experienced shared meals, especially really great ones, as the ultimate intimacy.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 18 -- Sept. 24; TELEVISION
description: The glut of fall premieres is here, as the networks dump dozens of new and returning shows before us. And on cable, Season 3 of "NIP/TUCK" starts this week (FX, Tuesday at 10 p.m.). The 90-minute episode is likely to thrill fans: Christian (JULIAN McMAHON) has survived his encounter with the Carver, a serial mutilator and rapist, but is even more of an emotional disaster, and is unable to work. And Sean (DYLAN WALSH) has his own problems. Julia (JOELY RICHARDSON) wants a divorce, and his son Matt (JOHN HENSLEY) is reeling after his affair with his life coach (FAMKE JANSSEN), whom he doesn't even know (yet) is a transsexual.

title: Penguin Family Values
description: The news that emperor penguins are exemplars of self-sacrifice, marital fidelity and steadfast parenting has brought joy to many religious conservatives, who see the brave birds in the documentary "March of the Penguins" as little Christian beacons of family and faith.

title: Keeper of the Flame
description: Josette Balleydier rolls up to her fluorescent-lighted Formica desk at the S.T. Dupont factory in France as if it were a Steinway grand. She pulls on a pair of white felt gloves, thinks for a moment and casts her eyes across rows of silver cigarette lighters filling a Styrofoam tray. "Attends," she whispers, bringing the first lighter to her ear and flipping back the lid. "Alors! Le cling!" Lighter No. 1 passes the test.

title: For an Art Moderne Theater, a Struggle Over Act II
description: When readers of a movie industry publication called Theatre Catalog scanned the 1941 edition for a listing for the two-year-old Trylon Theater in Forest Hills, Queens, they learned it was a "striking and modern" cinema named for a World's Fair monument, complete with a stone and glass tower that lit up Queens Boulevard at night.

title: My Hair Coach
description: You've had a trainer, a therapist, a life coach and a personal concierge. It's time to move on to the next vanity experience, one that will give you fodder for dozens of dinner-party conversations to come. It's time to track down the hair coach, the New York City hairdresser known for her uncommon consultations with extra hold.

The stabbing followed a violent argument in which the man hit his wife's mother, according to the police.

Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, WILLIAM BREWSTER
description: LEE--William Brewster, of Rochester, NY, died peacefully on September 15, 2005 after an amazing life of nearly 84 years. He is survived by his wife Nancy Hodge Lee, his children Christey Lee Robinson and W. Brewster Lee and his wife Victoria West, and his grandchildren Taylor T. Robinson, Elizabeth B. Robinson, W. Brewster Lee III and Victoria H. Lee. He was a graduate of Westminster School, Yale University '44W and Cornell Law School. During World War II he was a pilot in the 390th Bomb Group (H) of the United States Army Air Corps Eighth Air Force and participated in thirty missions over occupied France and Germany. He was later assigned as a pilot to the Service and Ferry Commands of the Army Air Corps in Europe and the United States. After the war he joined the law firm now known as Nixon Peabody LLP in which he later became a partner. He retired in 1985. He was a former member of The Country Club of Rochester where he served as President and Chairman. Donations may be made to the Rundel Library Foundation, 114 South Avenue, Rochester, NY 14604.

title: Perry Lafferty, 87, Former TV Producer, Dies

title: Pushkin and St. Petersburg: Recommended Reading
Up Front
description: In an essay beginning on Page 12, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. looks at Reinhold Niebuhr's relevance in our era of renewed religiosity. Schlesinger first encountered Niebuhr at Harvard University's Memorial Church in the winter of 1940-41. He was 23; Niebuhr was 48. It was a time of heated political debate between internationalists and isolationists. "The last thing I felt I needed was a dose of evangelical religion," Schlesinger recently recalled. But Niebuhr, probably the period's best-known theologian, spoke with passion, and his eloquence swept Schlesinger away. "I came to understand that original sin, a proposition I was prepared to accept not as revealed truth but as powerful metaphor, undermined absolutist pretensions and set sharp limits on human wisdom and aspiration," Schlesinger said. Before long, the two men had become close friends and firm political allies through the Americans for Democratic Action, the most influential organization of anti-Communist liberals in the 1950's and early 60's. Founders and charter members included Eleanor Roosevelt, John Kenneth Galbraith and Ronald Reagan.

title: Death to the Crusade
description: IN a quiet courtyard near Istanbul's Grand Bazaar, patient merchants smoke unfiltered cigarettes and tend their stalls in the Secondhand Book Bazaar, or Sahaflar Carsisi. On this site, once the publishing center of the Ottoman Empire, customers have been buying manuscripts for 500 years, and books since 1732, after Ibrahim Muteferrika, an Ottoman diplomat, set up a printing press in Constantinople. A bust in the courtyard honors him, even though his improvements came over the objections of the scribes and illuminators who dominated the information industry of the day. Their presence is still felt here. I recently picked up an old Ottoman map of North America with antique calligraphy I cannot even begin to decipher.

title: Playing His Own Revival
description: When the pianist and composer Keith Jarrett takes the stage at Carnegie Hall on Sept. 26, he will be without what he calls his "safety net" -- the bassist Gary Peacock and the drummer Jack DeJohnette, his partners in the Standards Trio, who have performed with him during his recovery from chronic fatigue syndrome over the last several years. Much of Mr. Jarrett's fame comes from his solo improvisational concerts, which meld his jazz and classical interests. His latest album, a two-CD set called "Radiance," is taken from two shows in Japan in 2002 that signaled a return to the format, and the Carnegie Hall concert will be another important step along that road. From his home in New Jersey, Mr. Jarrett, 60, recently spoke by telephone with Thomas Staudter about his recovery and about reclaiming his solo career.

title: The Remix; VANITY PRESS - GROW YOUR OWN GRAPES
description: Producing a cult cabernet requires a sizable outlay of time and money. But thanks to a new invitation-only club in Napa, Calif., 375 wine lovers can become part-time vintners. The Napa Valley Reserve, located on about 80 acres of prime growing land, is the pet project of H. William Harlan, the proprietor of Harlan Estate (a bottle of its 2001 Napa Valley red recently went for $750 at auction). It operates on the same principle as, say, a private golf club: for an initiation deposit of about $150,000, members get a nonequity stake in the estate and the chance to make their own boutique blend under the auspices of the label's winemaking team. The degree of involvement is up to the individual: you can visit your vines once a week or once a year, and you can opt to learn the whole vine-to-wine process or just collect your case allotment (up to 75) of prized juice each year. And, of course, what you put on the label is up to you. SANDRA BALLENTINE

title: Inside the List
description: MASON-DIXON: In a week when the death toll of the horrific Gulf Coast flood continued to rise, a new Civil War title arrived at No. 10 on the fiction list: "The Widow of the South," by the first-time novelist Robert Hicks, a music publisher and manager in Nashville. It's the fictional story of the real-life Carrie McGavock, who turned her Tennessee plantation house into a makeshift hospital for Confederate soldiers after the bloody Battle of Franklin in 1864, which left nearly 2,000 dead. McGavock had almost 1,500 of the bodies buried in her own private cemetery on the Carnton plantation, hence her nickname. In spite of some negative reviews, the book has been selling briskly, and Warner Books set its print run at 250,000. The novel is featured by the Military Book Club and the American Compass Book Club, a conservative mail-order outfit, and it has also received a lot of attention in the Southern press. The Tennessean speculated it might do for the Carnton plantation what "Gone With the Wind" did for Atlanta: increase tourism. "The house itself was used as a makeshift hospital, and bloodstains are clearly visible on the floors upstairs," The Tennessean advised would-be visitors. "There are those who think this residence is home to spirits, some more civil than others. The grounds are lovely and well worth a leisurely stroll." If you don't mind the ghosts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, BENJAMIN M., M.D.
description: STEIN--Benjamin M., M.D. Born March 11, 1911 died August 21, 2005. Loving and devoted to both his wife Claire, and son Douglas, he lived a life of dedication to his family, to his profession and to his country, serving in World War II as a physician in England, Normandy, and Germany where he opened the first American Hospital after the war. In 1957 the Board Certified Radiologist purchased Brunswick Hospital in Amityville and developed it into the largest privately owned Hospital Center in the United States. He provided the latest technology for patient care and opened the first privately owned MRI facility in New York State. His concern for his staff and their advancement was so appreciated that every attempt to unionize his institution was defeated. Beloved and respected by all, may he rest in peace.

Seen from the heights of the modest hill named Victoria Peak-from the summer residence of the governor of the Crown Colony of Hong Kong-the prison must have looked very fine. "If the sun were ever to shine," said Annie to the Portuguee, "the glass would probably glitter. It would look like a necklace of diamonds, Lorenzo. Or a big margarita, in a square cup."

title: Getting Religion
description: One morning this past June I found myself sitting in a coffee shop across from Rockefeller Center, teaching an astonished friend how to sing the old gospel hymn "How Great Thou Art." We had just come from a press conference for the Greater New York Billy Graham Crusade, which we were going to attend that weekend in Queens. My friend, who grew up in Brooklyn and once attended a yeshiva, was looking forward to this as an anthropological expedition. He thought of me as a secular Manhattan writer, like himself, which I suppose I am. He hadn't quite understood that for me our little trip would also be a kind of homecoming.

title: THE ORIGINALS
description: Jefferson Hack - Editor Being the publisher of Dazed & Confused and the editor in chief of Another Magazine means that Jefferson Hack doesn't need to shop. "I pick things up from shoots or from going to designers' studios," he says. "I'm not a shopper." That doesn't mean he doesn't like clothes. He does -- especially mixing, matching and altering them. He's particularly fond of his Dior Homme shirt with a cigarette burn in the collar. Hack breaks his no-shopping rule when hanging with Lila Grace, his 3-year-old daughter with Kate Moss. Dad and daughter recently purchased a pair of silver shoes together. "For me it's an experience," he says. "For her it's a game."

title: Paperback Row
description: UP FROM ZERO: Politics, Architecture, and the Rebuilding of New York, by Paul Goldberger. (Random House, $14.95.) "Up From Zero" is a vivid tale of the long, complex and still unfinished struggle over what should go up in the place of the World Trade Center. Goldberger, a Pulitzer Prize-winning architecture critic, recounts the trade center's emergence in Lower Manhattan; describes three years of proposals and counterproposals for rebuilding the 16-acre site; and introduces the full cast of politicians, developers, architects and city planners competing to shape "the most challenging urban-design problem of the 21st century."

description: LEVY--Norman F. On behalf of the Board of Directors, volunteers, consumers and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, we offer our heartfelt condolences to the family of Norman F. Levy. Norman Levy was a longtime friend and supporter whose very presence, along with his daughter Jeanne Levy-Hinte and their many friends, graced our annual Humanitarian Awards dinners. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Martin C. Hausman President Edward R. Matthews Executive Director Ronald J. H. Napal Chief Development Officer

title: A Mansion Unmatched, a Future Unknown
description: Among the dingy buildings of West 14th Street -- the scarred brownstones stripped of cornices, the utilitarian concrete-and-glass boxes -- the brick Greek Revival town house on the street's north side near Seventh Avenue stands out like a trumpet blast. Its black doors, bearing the address in gold leaf, almost glow, and a cast-iron balcony sets off the parlor windows, which stretch from the floor nearly to the 14-foot ceiling.

title: Wooing Customers With All That's Organic, and Trying to Turn a Profit
description: HOW do you build a business in a field that is, by its nature, allergic to "business"? That is the conundrum facing organic-food entrepreneurs on Long Island.

description: EVEN though ski resorts may be havens for steely-nerved daredevils, they are not immune to the jitters. In the post-9/11 tourism environment, resort owners frequently discounted lift tickets and lodgings at the last minute, rather than face revenue charts resembling the downward slopes of their mountains.

title: Even the Sunflowers Are Illuminated
description: LIEV SCHREIBER has earned an Obie, a Tony and reams of praise for his performances in plays by Mamet, Pinter and especially Shakespeare; he has also directed several stage productions. Now, having acted in 29 movies, including last year's remake of "The Manchurian Candidate," Mr. Schreiber, 37, adds filmmaker to his rsum. His adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer's tragicomic novel "Everything Is Illuminated" opened here Friday. Shot in the Czech Republic, it tells the story of Jonathan, a young American Jew (Elijah Wood) who travels to Ukraine to find the woman who saved his grandfather from the Holocaust.

title: Contributors
description: Rineke Dijkstra The photographer Rineke Dijkstra rarely works on commission. So it's fitting that her assignment for this issue was to shoot the designer Raf Simons (Page 190), who rarely agrees to be photographed. "He trusted me," Dijkstra says. Her series of awkward, scantily clad teenagers on beaches landed her shows at the Museum of Modern Art, the Guggenheim and the Tate. Fans who can't catch a retrospective of her work, which is now traveling through Europe, can pick up the accompanying book, "Rineke Dijkstra Portraits: Retrospective" (above and left, center). "I feel a bit young for a retrospective," she says, laughing. "But it's nice to have everything together and see the connections." This is especially poignant for subjects she has shot over extended periods of time, like Almerisa (far left), a Bosnian refugee, now 18, whom Dijkstra met when Almerisa was 6. Dijkstra claims her subjects almost never turn her down when approached. "It's mostly young people -- they're always curious."

title: East Hampton Airport Getting an Upgrade
description: WITH corporate and charter jets and helicopters rattling windows and prompting complaints to the manager's office, East Hampton Airport on summer weekends sometimes seems as busy as La Guardia Airport.

title: Often Hidden, North Fork Barns Get a Close-Up
description: MARY ANN SPENCER has spent the last five years counting barns. The inventory she undertook, sponsored by the Old House Society of Cutchogue, turned up 734 barns in the Town of Southold alone. Ms. Spencer is also a photographer; many of the barns, shown off against the vivid, dramatic East End light, can be seen her new book, "The Barns of the North Fork" (Quantuck Lane Press, $39.95).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALEXANDER, ''GEORGIE''
description: ALEXANDER--"Georgie" With deepest sorrow we announce the loss of our beloved Georgie on August 29, born September 18, 1918. Daughter of John and Sadye Gelernter. A true New Yorker, her life was filled with love of the arts which she inspired in everyone whose life she touched. Graduate of Newark State Teachers College, she began teaching art at Russell Sage JHS and went on to produce and broadcast art programs at Ch-13 and NYCE. She brought artists into the public schools as creator/co-founder of "Studio in a School," retiring in 1986 as Director of Art for NYC schools. Georgie will be remembered by her nieces and nephews and all who knew her for her warmth, generosity and youthful spirit. Survived by her devoted daughter, Jane Alexander-Perry and loving sister, Jacqueline Levinson. A memorial will be held at 3 PM, September 25, at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC

title: After Fears of a New Menace, Old Faces Return

description: WARREN--Roz. Your leaving has created a void which can never be filled. I shall forever miss the sound of your voice, your great laugh and your sense of humor. Arts, Briefly; A Strong Finale For 'Rescue Me'
description: The season finale of "Rescue Me" on FX on Tuesday brought in the series' highest ratings since its debut in July 2004. Nielsen estimated that 3.8 million viewers watched Denis Leary's character sink further into misery: 2.4 million of those were adults in the 18-to-49 demographic. On Lifetime, "Ambulance Girl," an original movie broadcast on Sept. 12, delivered 4.8 million viewers, and was cable's most-watched program that day. For the week that ended on Sept. 11, ESPN's Sunday football broadcast -- the Indianapolis Colts' victory over the Baltimore Ravens -- was the No. 1 advertiser-supported show on advertiser-supported cable by a mile. It drew an audience of 11.25 million, and helped ESPN place third in primetime for the week. TNT was No. 1 among cable channels on the strength of "The Closer" finale and Nascar. And Fox News was second: 11 of the 20 most popular shows of the week were on that cable news channel. KATE AURTHUR

title: Much to Do Before Checking Into Prison
description: The rapper Lil' Kim has been in a whirlwind of photo shoots, business meetings, public appearances and autograph signings for the past few weeks. "Naked Truth," the fourth album in her more than decade-long career, is due in stores on Sept. 27, and in the manner of any artist eager to catapult to the top of the charts, she has been marketing herself aggressively. But unlike other acts whose CD's will have their debut that day, Lil' Kim has had to worry about something more grave and perhaps more life-altering than the possibility of mediocre sales figures: prison.

title: More Horrible Than Truth: News Reports

But the media's willingness to report thinly attributed rumors may also have contributed to a kind of cultural wreckage that will not clean up easily.

title: Innocence Abroad
description: Madison, Wis. - "LOOKING at foreign law for support is like looking out over a crowd and picking out your friends," Judge John Roberts told the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday, responding to a question from Senator Jon Kyl about Supreme Court justices citing foreign law as they interpret the Constitution. "Foreign law, you can find anything you want. If you don't find it in the decisions of France or Italy, it's in the decisions of Somalia or Japan or Indonesia or wherever."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies After A Fire
description: A 38-year-old man died of a heart attack after a fire started in the kitchen of his Starrett City apartment yesterday morning, the Fire Department said. The man was identified as Eric Rosado, of 1325 Pennsylvania Avenue. The fire began shortly before 2:30 a.m., apparently in a trash can, the Fire Department said. Mr. Rosado was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead at 3:45 a.m., the police said. It was unclear what started the fire but it did not appear to have been set, and the flames were contained to the kitchen, neighbors said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLANCY, CAROLE MARIE
description: CLANCY--Carole Marie. 62, of San Jose, California died on September 5 at Stanford University Medical Center, Stanford, CA. after a long battle with breast cancer. Ms. Clancy, a broadcast and newspaper journalist, was an Executive Producer for NBC TV, shaping the initial "Live At Five" television newscast format on WNBC TV in New York. She was awarded an Emmy for a docutmentary production in 1984. Most recently, she was the editor of the Silicon Valley/San Jose, CA. business journal. During her ongoing battle with cancer, Ms. Clancy was particularly moved by young children being treated for the disease. She used her observations as the foundation of a childrens book "Hat Tricks" about children dealing with their own treatments or those of a family member. Ms. Clancy was preceded in death by her mother, Margaret Ann Clancy. She is survived by her father Jay Burton Clancy and stepmother Corinne Clancy of Hilton Head Island, SC. Two sisters Jill Roller and Susan Clancy. A nephew Ryan Roller and brother-in-law Bill Roller all of Basking Ridge, NJ.

At Abu Dhabi Gas Industries' technical training center, a small cluster of buildings atop one of the country's richest onshore oil and gas fields, instruction starts with the basics: Come to class on time. Pay attention. Don't expect a promotion unless you've earned it.

title: One Father, Back in Court, Indefatigable
description: Michael Newdow, the doctor who does not want his daughter to say "under God" when she recites the Pledge of Allegiance in school, has managed to get his cause back into the federal courts. Mr. Newdow is certainly tenacious, but his lawsuit is a misguided distraction from real challenges to the First Amendment.

title: In Petition to Government, Tribe Hopes for Return to Whaling Past
description: NEAH BAY, Wash. - The whaling canoes are stored in a wooden shed, idle for the past six years. They were last used when the Makah Indians were allowed to take their harpoons and a .50-caliber rifle and set out on their first whale hunt since the late 1920's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, RAYMOND J.
description: HOROWITZ--Raymond J. 89. On September 18, 2005. Beloved by his daughter Judy Babcock and his late wife Margaret, and loving brother of Edith King. His career as a an attorney was punctuated by decades of wise counsel and thoughtful action. A pioneer art collector who promoted and appreciated scholarship in the field of American Impressionism, and along with Margaret, formulated a premiere collection. A caring friend, always ready with a willing ear. There will be a memorial occasion to be announced at a later date.
