The network's "Lost" was the top drama series, and CBS's "Everybody Loves Raymond" was best comedy. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

title: U.S. to head to Moon for $104 billion
Paid Notice: Deaths   PARKER, TONI TRENT
description: PARKER--Toni Trent. Author who dedicated herself to encouraging the publication and distribution of quality books for minority children, died peacefully at home, Friday. Parker helped create a series of widely acclaimed guides to books for minority students and a not-for-profit organization, Kids Cultural Books, which conducts book festivals around the country to encourage literacy. Parker was herself the author of six children's books. She is survived by her husband, Barrington Daniels Parker Jr., a judge on the Second Circuit Court of Appeals; their daughters, Christine, Kathleen, and Jennifer; her mother, Viola Trent; and sisters, Kay Holloway and Judy Scales-Trent. Her funeral service will take place Monday, 4 pm, at First Presbyterian Church, 1101 Bedford Street, Stamford.

title: SAP purchase to raise retail offerings
It Isn't Easy Being a Genius
description: Boston - LET me begin by making something very clear: I'm not a genius. Tomorrow, 25 people are going to find themselves making similar protestations -- at least most of them are -- after the MacArthur Foundation announces its latest class of fellows for its so-called genius award. And as someone who once received one of those awards, here's a little insight into what the new fellows experienced over the last few days and what they're going to have to deal with.

Touching Up Some Famous Faces (No Scalpel Required)
description: By the time they got to Elton John, the rock star's right ear was completely severed. At first, Christopher J. Gargiulo thought he could heal the tear by simply applying a little pressure and gliding his thumb across the top of the ear.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 18 - Many saw them as one of the elite teams in the N.F.L., and so the Jets, however subconsciously, changed to conform to this highfalutin image.

description: FELL--Freda. The Brotherhood Synagogue extends condolences to our Chairman of the Board, Alan Fell, and his family, on the passing of his mother. She was courageous, energetic, and a loving wife, mother and grandmother.

description: WHEN some of Silicon Valley's best minds pool their collective intelligence and millions of dollars to create a Web site for people who want to read about and buy everything in Lindsay Lohan's closet, you know the Internet industry is ready to party again.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about boxers' ability to withstand punches to the jaw misstated the nationality of Corrie Sanders, who knocked down Wladimir Klitschko four times in five minutes during their fight in 2003. He is South African, not Australian.

title: A Good-Natured Show in the Shadow of Turbulent Times
description: Ellen DeGeneres is to awards shows what Jon Stewart is to political satire -- better at it than most. Standing out among all the flowing chiffon and plunging dcolletage in a black tuxedo and black silk shirt, Ms. DeGeneres quickly and matter-of-factly acknowledged the victims of Hurricane Katrina, and then put that tragedy on hold for the evening. Noting that she had been the host of the show in 2001, which was delayed twice after Sept. 11, she paused and added, "Be sure to look for me next month when I host the North Korean People's Choice Awards."

description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. - Joseph Kieta can still hardly believe his good fortune.

description: The meek better move to the end of the line. Chefs will inherit the earth. They have their product lines, publishing contracts and reality shows. Their empires traverse oceans. Their antics pepper gossip columns.

But Giambi may not be able to return as a designated hitter, because Gary Sheffield says he has felt no improvement in his injured left leg.

description: TORONTO - VERNON WELLS is a major league baseball player. He is also like a lot of baseball fans around the United States: he doesn't hate the Yankees, but he derives a special pleasure from making the team with baseball's largest payroll squirm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, BETTY GOLDFARB
description: KATZ--Betty Goldfarb. Of NYC, NY passed away peacefully on Monday the 12th, 2005 surrounded by her children. Beloved wife, loving mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Beloved sister. Services were held Tuesday. Information: "Gutterman Musicant" 800-522-0588.

title: A Company Looks to Wean Computers Off the Wires
description: While snaking cables are still a long way from becoming the buggy whips of the 21st century, a Silicon Valley technology company recently said that it had developed a wireless technology that might hasten their obsolescence.

title: Verdi Onstage and Domingo on the Podium
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 18 - The Washington National Opera enters middle age looking as healthy as it ever has. Fifty years ago there was no real company and no real season. Operas were put on one by one if someone found a way to pay for them. Sets were borrowed. A place at the Kennedy Center added legitimacy in 1971. An independent opera house in an old department store building was planned 10 years ago but proved impractical. Selling the property, however, put a lot of money in the company's bank account.

title: Briefs: Minister sparks outcry with immigration remark
The Colts Get Defensive, and Manning Doesn't Mind
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 18 - The Indianapolis Colts are not publicly expressing any concern that their high-powered offense has been slowed in the first two games of the season. Even with quarterback Peyton Manning having his third-worst game in his N.F.L. career on Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, the Colts are 2-0.

description: Back in March, this column turned up a candidate for the city's public advocate position who was something of a mystery man. The candidate, Michael E. Brown, had not been seen by any of his five rivals on the campaign trail. Officials of the Campaign Finance Board had not gotten a single piece of paper from him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUM, SAMUEL
description: BLUM--Samuel. Born on July 15, 1908, Sam grew up in Leipzig, Germany. In 1932 he moved to Paris, where he met Simone Padawer. They married on June 19, 1938, and on April 12, 1940, they came to New York City, where they have lived ever since. He was the president of United Feather and Down until his retirement, a member and trustee of Park East Synagogue for more than 50 years, and a founder and board member of Alyn, a hospital for disabled children in Jerusalem. Sam played bridge every afternoon for decades at the Regency Whist Club. A successful businessman on two continents and fluent in several languages, he was known for his ever-present smile, eternal optimism and impeccable appearance. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Simone; his son, Bentley; his daughter, Micheline; his sonin-law, Michael; his granddaughters, Megan and Jessica; his grandson-in-law, Edward; and his great-grandchildren, Noah and Charlotte. Services will be held at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, on Monday, September 19, at 12 pm. Family visiting hours will be at his home, 130 East 67th Street, following services, and Tuesday through Thursday after 3 pm. Donations can be made to Alyn, 51 East 42nd Street, NYC, or Park East Synagogue.

title: A Triptych With Two Leading Men at the Met's Opening
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its season on Monday night, which meant a traditional gala evening of people-watching, celebrity-spotting (Sean Connery was unmistakable in the general manager's box) and, for patrons who paid the top ticket price of $1,000, a post-performance dinner on the grand tier. Oh, and there was also opera, of course, a sampling of the season to come, with performances of Act I of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro," Act II of Puccini's "Tosca" and Act III of Saint-SaAns's "Samson et Dalila," all conducted by the Met's music director, James Levine.

New Orleans Museum, Under Lock and Guard
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 - It is a jarring sight: Two burly men carrying M-16 assault rifles on the marble steps of the New Orleans Museum of Art. Nearby, a sergeant from the Oregon Army National Guard, wearing dog tags, a brown T-shirt and camouflage pants, wields a leaf blower as if it too were a weapon. Any visitors had better be prepared to show some identification and provide a good reason for being here.

But even back then, Mr. Menendez was openly ambitious about it.

Afghan Voters Take Next Step to Democracy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 18 - Undeterred by threats from Taliban insurgents and saboteurs, millions of Afghans voted Sunday in the country's first free legislative elections in more than a quarter of a century. It was the last formal step toward Afghanistan's transition to a democratic government after the American-led military ouster of the Taliban nearly four years ago.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Just Like Heaven' Leads at the Box Office
description: An old-fashioned romantic comedy with a contemporary metaphysical twist opened just strongly enough to knock the reigning horror film from the top of the box office this weekend. "Just Like Heaven" (DreamWorks), starring Reese Witherspoon, right, and Mark Ruffalo, took in $16.5 million in estimated ticket sales. Directed by Mark Waters, the film features a lonely architect who comes to love the woman who haunts his San Francisco apartment. But "The Exorcism of Emily Rose" (Sony), held up well at No. 2 with a drop of only 49 percent from the previous week (horror films usually drop 60 percent in their second week), with $15.3 million in ticket sales, for a cumulative gross of $52 million. Two other films opened in the top five this weekend: "Lord of War" (Lions Gate), starring Nicolas Cage as an arms dealer who faces his conscience, was No. 3 with $9.2 million, and the low-budget thriller "Cry Wolf" (Rogue Pictures) was at No. 5 with $4.5 million. Flanked by those two openers at No. 4 was "The 40-Year-Old Virgin" (Universal), in its fifth week with $5.8 million and cumulative sales of $90.6 million. Heralding the beginning of the Oscar-screening season, a few films opened in limited release, including "Proof" (Miramax), starring Gwyneth Paltrow, Anthony Hopkins and Jake Gyllenhaal ($200,868 in eight locations), and "Separate Lies" (Fox Searchlight), starring Tom Wilkinson, Emily Watson and Rupert Everett ($23,209 in two locations). CATHERINE BILLEY

title: If the Children Can Drink Uncola, What About Unbeer?
description: Kidsbeer, a Japanese soft drink bottled and formulated to look like beer, may soon be available throughout Europe, but watchdogs of underage drinking say they will fight any effort to ship it to the United States.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Killed By Father's Vehicle
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed last night when her father, who was allegedly drunk, accidentally ran over her in front of their home, the police said. The driver, Robert Abreu, was apparently unaware that his daughter had stepped in front of his S.U.V. as he was driving in front of his house on West 31st Street in Coney Island around 10:20 p.m., the police said. He was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated. His daughter was taken to Coney Island Hospital, where she was pronounced dead. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Richer Nations Seek Protection From Bird Flu
description: ROME, Sept. 18 - As World Health Organization officials repeat warnings about the potential for a deadly bird flu pandemic, wealthier countries are redoubling efforts to buy an experimental vaccine and antiviral drugs in the hopes of protecting their citizens from infection.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed Outside Laundry
description: A 23-year-old man was shot in his car outside a 24-hour laundry on Saturday night, the police said. The man, Keston Clouden, had gone to the laundry, at 928 Mother Gaston Boulevard, to help his mother, Debra, wash clothes. He was shot about 10:30 p.m. after he went back to his car. Mr. Clouden, who lived with his family on Mother Gaston Boulevard and worked at a nearby auto repair shop, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center by his father and was pronounced dead a short time later, the police said. His family said he immigrated from Trinidad seven years ago. No one was arrested in the case yesterday, the police said. Jess Wisloski (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Thursday about "Rooms," a musical at the 45th Street Theater with lyrics and music by Paul Scott Goodman, referred imprecisely to a production of his musical version of "Bright Lights, Big City" in Philadelphia. That production, scheduled to open next year at the Prince Music Theater, will not be its premiere. That occurred in New York in 1999.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bystander Shot On Subway
description: A woman riding a C train was shot in the foot during the robbery of a man in a subway car on Saturday night, the police said. The shooting occurred on a northbound train at the Shepherd Avenue station shortly before 11:30 p.m., the police said. A 16-year-old boy with a small-caliber rifle was attempting to rob a 37-year-old man, and when the man grabbed for the gun, it fired, striking the woman in the foot. The boy fled with the man's cellphone, which the police later found at the station, along with the rifle. The woman was treated at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center and released. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: News Analysis: Electorate puts off hard decisions
Doctors Join to Promote Electronic Record Keeping
description: He is a self-described techie, but that did not help Dr. Eugene P. Heslin harness the wonders of electronic medical records. The technology seemed too complicated and expensive for a small medical group like his six-doctor family practice in rural upstate New York.

title: The Painted Drum
The Search for a Few Good Bands Out of 1,000
description: It's a terrible time to try to become a rock star. Major labels are obsessed with hit singles and quick profits, and don't nurture talent because small independent labels will do it for them. Radio stations are in a stranglehold of consolidation and payola. Internet file-sharing may be making it harder to turn a hit into a sales blockbuster, while consumers have so many choices that they have grown fickle. It's hard for something out of the ordinary to get a hearing, and nearly impossible to get a second chance.

In a Parking Lot, Under a Tent and Amid the Chaos, Sunday Goes On
description: GRETNA, La., Sept. 18 - Sunday morning came again to New Orleans, and thousands were still gone from that barren landscape of piebald-mud-caked and things-out-of-place. In some quarters only cinderblocks and tires remained, odd remnants of homes become landing zones. On Canal Street, breakfast was coffee and oatmeal and little besides.

title: Stern Words From the Preacher at the President's Side
description: WASHINGTON - At first glance, T.D. Jakes is not an obvious fit with the buttoned-up Bush White House. As the founder of the Potter's House, a 30,000-member megachurch in southwest Dallas, he is a multimillionaire businessman, novelist and playwright. He also happens to have played himself in the R-rated movie version of his best-selling book, "Woman Thou Art Loosed," the story of a woman raped as a girl by her mother's boyfriend.

title: Wright's Bad Luck Part of Yankees' Rough Day
description: TORONTO, Sept. 18 - Jaret Wright has pitched nine years in the major leagues, about as many as his father did, and he does not scare easily. Wright understands that a pitcher is a target as soon as he releases the ball, but he also knows the odds. Being hit by projectiles twice in a month is awful luck.

title: Potential for Ukraine
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed After Celebration
description: A man celebrating his wife's birthday in Williamsburg early yesterday was shot and killed after an argument with an acquaintance, the police and witnesses said. The man was identified as Harry Macias, 34, of College Point, Queens. Witnesses told the police that several men fled the scene of the shooting, in front of 19 Hope Street, in one or two vehicles and the police briefly closed the Williamsburg Bridge while searching for the men, but didn't find them. Mr. Macias and his wife had gone to a sports bar on Marcy Avenue about 4 a.m., and left soon after without incident, the bar manager said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Amid a Strong Start, Vanderbilt Finds Believers
description: Vanderbilt's chancellor, Gordon Gee, stood on a chair amid the celebration of a comeback victory at Wake Forest on Sept. 1 and gazed down at a changed team.

title: Return to Practicality Begets Simple Elegance
description: Among the thousands of people converging on Bryant Park last week to see the new spring clothes was a young woman named Surelys Galano. An academic from California who was eager, as she said, "to make the transition from science to fashion," Ms. Galano had crashed the J. Mendel show and was sitting in the second row, behind Stan Herman, the president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America. Taking a rsum out of her handbag, Ms. Galano said she was surprised in one way by the shows. "They're not as creative as I had expected," she said. Mr. Herman let out a loud whoop.

title: Mansour Armaly, 78, Leader of Early Study of Glaucoma, Dies
description: Dr. Mansour F. Armaly, an ophthalmologist and researcher who led an early national study of glaucoma and discovered an unusually high incidence of the disease among family members of those who had it, died Aug. 19 at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington. He was 78.

title: Counting a City's Death Toll in Orange Paint
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 - The orange paint next to the front door told what happened inside the little white house on Mendez Street after the floodwaters came. Along with the date, 9-17, there was this: "2-D," for two dead.

title: Rapping for a Hometown in Hurricane Crisis
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18 - "I lost my house," said one victim of Hurricane Katrina, although this particular victim was equipped with some wildly refractive ornamentation and, more importantly, a very loud microphone. The crowd fell silent. "I lost my cars," he continued. "But it ain't about me." Then, without pausing to acknowledge the absurdity, he delivered an exuberant, bare-chested ode to the shiny rims on the wheels of vehicles he no longer had.

title: Iraqi Working for Times Is Killed, Relatives Say
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 19 - An Iraqi journalist and photographer working for The New York Times in Basra was found dead early this morning in Basra after being abducted from his home by a group of armed men wearing masks and claiming to be police officers, relatives said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, HENRY
description: KAPLAN--Henry. Television and stage director Henry Kaplan died Wednesday, September 14 at the age of 79. His television and stage credits included over 25 years with ABC-TV's "All My Children" as well as "Dark Shadows" and "The Doctors." His stage credits included "Any Wednesday," "P.S. I Love You" and "The White House." Mr. Kaplan also directed for Granada Television in London as well as many shows for London's West End.

title: Narrow Defeat Looks Like Victory to Ebullient Schrder
description: BERLIN, Sept. 18 - On an election night that produced no decisive winner, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder provided an uncanny facsimile of one, bounding to the stage to raucous applause, his hands clasped above his head in a victory gesture.

title: Despite the Storm, Louisiana Says the Alligator Hunt Must Go On
description: KAPLAN, La., Sept. 15 - After guiding his skiff through the marshes of Vermilion Parish as the sun rose in southern Louisiana, Raywood Stelly spotted his prey. A seven-foot alligator, lured from the muddy embankment, gnawed on putrid meat offered on a hook. Mr. Stelly drew his handgun and shot the alligator in the back of its head.

title: New CD's
description: The Bad Plus"Suspicious Activity"'(Columbia)

title: 'Huge hole' remains in pact, analysts say
Business gives voice to anxiety
Dolphins Turn Human and Trouble Ensues
description: Since the show follows the fortunes of a school of dancing Brazilian river dolphins, it should be noted that the new musical "Miracle Brothers" does indeed flow like a river -- a winding, muddy, very long river in a dry season. Kirsten Childs's thickly whimsical poperetta about race relations in 17th-century Brazil features, as the script puts it with typical metaphoric zeal, "twists and turns of fate more kinky than Afro-Brazilian hair."

title: 154 Patients Died, Many inIntense Heat, as Rescues Lagged
description: If some of those who died in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina have been described as stubborn holdouts who ignored an order to evacuate, then these citizens of New Orleans defy that portrait: The 16 whose bodies were wrapped in white sheets in the chapel of Memorial Medical Center. The 34 whose corpses were abandoned and floating in St. Rita's Nursing Home. The 15 whose bodies were stored in an operating room turned makeshift morgue at Methodist Hospital.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: , Lancaster, Pa., for branding and communications. There had been no previous agency. Spending has not been determined.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8:30 P.M. (2) HOW I MET YOUR MOTHER -- Series premiere. Young Ted (Josh Radnor) feels pressured to meet the right woman and settle down. Robin (Cobie Smulders, above, with Mr. Radnor) may be the one, but he declares his love too early. She also throws a drink in his face, but for a good cause. Neil Patrick Harris and Alyson Hannigan play characters important to Ted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEMPSTER, LORRAINE (EDELSTEIN)
description: KEMPSTER--Lorraine (Edelstein). Died peacefully after a brief illness in Norwalk, CT on September 10th surrounded by her family. She is survived by her three bereft children, Michael Kempster (Linda) of Andover, MA, Barbara Zerzan (Tony Velez) of Brooklyn, NY, Victor Kempster (Katterli) of Los Angeles, CA; her grandchildren, Jessica (Josh), Nick, Sophia, Micala, Elena and Sasha, and greatgrandson, Rex. She is also survived by her loving brother, Victor Edelstein (son Eric); companion, Giulianna Piccoli; and her children and grandchildren. Lorry (Mom, Bunkie, Buba and Super Buba) was a beautiful, honest and loving person with very close and devoted friends, intelligence and humor. She was married to the late Dr. Stephen Wells Kempster. She also enjoyed many years as part of the Rudolph Steiner School Community. She was our anchor and will be deeply missed and forever cherished.

title: North Korea Says It Will Abandon Nuclear Efforts
description: BEIJING, Monday, Sept. 19 - North Korea agreed Monday to end its nuclear weapons program in return for security, economic and energy benefits, potentially easing tensions with the United States after a two-year standoff over the North's efforts to build atomic bombs.

title: Once Upon a Time, No One Wanted This Place
description: They chuckle at the thought that they are millionaires or even close. After all, they chose careers and lifestyles guaranteed to keep them humble, then found themselves the inadvertent beneficiaries of Manhattan's giddy real estate spiral.

title: Gunmen Kill a Lawmaker in an Attack Near Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 18 - A Kurdish member of the Iraqi National Assembly was fatally shot in an attack north of the capital on Saturday night, Iraqi officials said Sunday. In the southern city of Basra, hundreds of Shiite militia fighters blocked off streets to demand the release of three militia members being held by British forces.

title: U.S. and Allies Seek Iran Resolution at U.N.
description: The United States and its allies said yesterday that they would push for a resolution critical of Iran from the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency, although the body might not refer the country to the Security Council for sanctions.

title: Toni Trent Parker Dies at 58; Promoted Black Children in Books
description: Toni Trent Parker, an author who helped advance the cause of books featuring African-American children, died on Thursday at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 58.

title: Ruth Farbman, Aide to Mayor Wagner, Dies at 92
description: Ruth Farbman, an aide to Mayor Robert F. Wagner who was prominent in New York City civic affairs during the 1950's and 60's, died on Sept. 2 in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINRIB, SIDNEY
description: WEINRIB--Sidney. On Friday, September 16, 2005, of McLean, VA, longtime resident of Roslyn, NY. Sidney was a pioneer in the optical retail industry and former president and CEO of Sterling Optical. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Weinrib; father of Donna Acker and her husband, Larry, Jeri Taylor and her husband, Michael, and the late Rene Henry and her husband, Paul; brother of Margie Bryant; grandfather of Samantha Thompson and her husband, Jeff, Adam Rudginsky, Ben and Marty Acker, Joshua, Lucy and Holden Taylor; great-grandfather of Annabelle. Graveside service will be held at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY, on Tuesday, September 20th, at 1 pm.

title: Newcomer Helps Glavine Beat Braves
description: Anderson Hernandez was strolling through the Mets' clubhouse on his way outside to stretch early yesterday morning when something moved him to glance at the lineup.

title: Don't push Syria away
The Subsidy Dance
description: To the Editor:

title: Patara Journal; A Congress, Buried in the Sand, Inspired One on a Hill
description: Correction Appended

title: News Analysis: Do all countries have the right to develop atomic energy?
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENOWITZ, BEN
description: BENOWITZ--Ben. 97, September 16, 2005. Beloved husband for 68 years of Lillian. Brother of Phil. Father of Paul, Larry and Martin. Father-in-law of Sondra and Brooke. Grandfather of Scott, Isaac, Miriam and Daniel. Ben will be remembered for his warmth, humor and love of family. Shiva at home Sunday to Wednesday. Donations in Ben's memory may be made to UJF.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, IDA PEIKEN
description: MILLER--Ida Peiken. Formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, and Lake Worth, FL, recently of Huntington Beach, CA, died Sunday, at 94. Services Tuesday, Boynton Beach, FL, Sinai Memorial Chapel. Her husband, Henry J. Miller died in Florida two years ago. She leaves behind two children, Mrs. Susan Spiritus of Newport Coast, CA, and Dr. Frederick Miller of Denver, CO, and four granddaughters, Margo and Lisa Spiritus and Joanna and Rachel Miller.

title: Tragedy in Black and White
description: By three to one, African-Americans believe that federal aid took so long to arrive in New Orleans in part because the city was poor and black. By an equally large margin, whites disagree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, KOHLER, MAXINE F.
description: STEIN-KOHLER--Maxine F. 71, on September 17, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Stein-Kohler, loving sister of Gloria Kaplan, caring aunt of Richard and Robin Kaplan, and devoted and cherished friend to many who will miss her dearly. Funeral service Monday, September 19, at 1 pm, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either the American Cancer Society or the Central Park Conservancy would be appreciated.

title: Baseball: Ramirez powers Red Sox over A's
Taking Full Responsibility
description: President Bush didn't say the other night how he would pay for his promise to rebuild the Gulf Coast states. Allow us to explain: Every penny of aid approved by Congress so far and all subsequent aid -- perhaps as much as $200 billion -- will be borrowed, with most of it likely to come from Asian central banks and other foreign investors. That means additional interest of about $10 billion a year indefinitely. The bill will hit current and future taxpayers in the form of higher taxes or cuts in government programs, or both.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Two Brothers Shot and One Dies
description: A man was killed and his brother wounded in a shooting in Olinville on Saturday night, the police said. The man, Tsishon Freeman, 23, was found shot to death in a second-floor hallway at 711 Magenta Street about 10:30 p.m., the police said. His brother, identified as Delshawn Walker, 18, was discovered shot and wounded at a different address, 715 Rosewood Avenue, a short time later, but the police said yesterday that the men had been shot together at the Magenta Street address. Mr. Walker was listed in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center yesterday. There were no arrests yesterday, and the police did not disclose a motive. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: After bumpy first half, Thai outlook brightens
For Hurricane Relief, Connections Count
description: Backstage at the Bryant Park tents, Sarah Ferguson and Kelly Osbourne had their arms twined around each other and were hopping around like 4-year-olds. Dressers flew around, hanging the entire immediate future of Seventh Avenue fashion on garment racks. Janice Dickinson, the superannuated supermodel, sat in a makeup chair regaling the stylist Tom Pecheux with random snippets from her memoir as he reapplied Ms. Dickinson's lipstick for the fourth time in less than an hour.

title: Browsing the Site, Not Watching the Show
description: This August, MSNBC.com drew the most visitors of any news Web site, receiving 26.6 million unique hits, according to Nielsen/NetRatings. The site has been first among news sites four times since March by this measure, beating stalwarts like the Web sites of CNN and The New York Times. (Ranked by raw page views, MSNBC.com was third this August, below CNN.com and Yahoo News. The difference in rankings suggests that CNN.com and Yahoo News readers view more pages per visit, but the MSNBC site gets more visitors over all.)

title: Marsalis Leads a Charge for the Cradle of Jazz
description: Correction Appended

title: For Better or for Worse
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Faces of Amsterdam
description: A portrait of a city through its people.

title: The Originals
description: A tireless, curious, exuberant, irrepressible bunch.

title: A Sicilian Slice
description: Who better than to show you around than Dolce and Gabbana, the fashion guys who made Sicily their signature?

title: Kabul's Reawakening
description: The people of Kabul, Afghanistan, are embarking on yet another heroic effort: tourism.

title: The Get
description: Point and shoot, hood dreams, suitcase serenade.

title: Welcome
description: One aspect of my column has been to look for resonance between the news and the culture  high, low, pop and not. Id love to hear from readers proposing their own connections and debating each other about their meaning; the most intriguing takes would be posted on this page. Harking back to my days as a theater, movie and TV critic, Id also like to open up a vein of pure cultural dialogue  primarily by readers but sparked by some questions, interjections and opinions of my own. The hope is to feature some thinking, conversation, cultural finds and laughs that are not tied to the usual left/right, hate Bush/love Bush, blue/red polarities of a newspapers opinion pages.

title: Welcome
description: It may sound odd to welcome you to On The Ground when were all hovering here in the mists of cyberspace. But welcome anyway. This is a newer version of KristofResponds, the blog Ive been keeping since the Iraq war.

title: Our Dear Leaders
description: The new nuclear deal with North Korea is hot stuff, and President Bush gets credit for gradually becoming more flexible with regard to Kim Jong Il. Bush started off in 2001 by refusing to have anything to do with North Korea, but then that approach failed so catastrophically that he has since then gradually come around to a more sensible and flexible approach similar to that of the Clinton administration. Five wasted years, but, hey, thats better than a wasted decade.

title: Earl's Real Name Is Second Chance and Redemption
description: Offbeat and utterly charming, "My Name Is Earl" is about a search for redemption after a fall from grace - NBC's fall from grace.

title: Many Women at Elite Colleges Set Career Path to Motherhood
description: Cynthia Liu is precisely the kind of high achiever Yale wants: smart (1510 SAT), disciplined (4.0 grade point average), competitive (finalist in Texas oratory competition), musical (pianist), athletic (runner) and altruistic (hospital volunteer). And at the start of her sophomore year at Yale, Ms. Liu is full of ambition, planning to go to law school.

title:
Ex-Tyco Executives 
Get 8 to 25 Years in Prison
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International who was convicted of looting the company of $150 million, was sentenced yesterday to 81/3 to 25 years in a New York State prison, the latest corporate figure to be handed a lengthy prison term in a corruption case.

title: The Beginning of the End for the Knicks
description: Jeff Van Gundy had ventured headlong into the path of a hulking, headstrong center once before, and perhaps he should have known the futility of such gestures when he tried to reroute Patrick Ewing's course five summers ago.

title: From Google to Noodles: A Chef Strikes Out on His Own
description: Redwood City, Calif. - LIKE many employees at Google, Charlie Ayers profited handsomely when the company went public in August 2004. Selling some of his Google shares enabled him to quit his job and follow other passions.

title: Attacks Kill 9 Americans in North Iraq as Tensions Build in South
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 20 - Insurgents have killed nine American troops and security officers in four attacks across Iraq, including a suicide-bomb blast that took the life of a State Department security official and three security contractors as their diplomatic convoy left the regional United States embassy office in Mosul.

title: Does This Story Hold Water?
description: Dear readers: Thank you so much for all of your responses to my no-longer-waterproof-watch story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUM, SAMUEL
description: BLUM--Samuel. The American Friends of ALYN Hospital is deeply saddened by the death of Samuel Blum, who, with his beloved wife Simone, founded our organization. Sam was a lifelong supporter of the handicapped children who are treated at ALYN Hospital in Jerusalem. Sam remained a valued Board Member until his death; his financial advice, passion and commitment to our work will be greatly missed. The ALYN family offers condolences to Simone, our Chairman Emeritus, and her entire family. We are grateful that the Blum Family has asked that donations in Sam's memory be directed to ALYN. Minette Brown, President American Friends of ALYN Hospital, NY, NY

title: Pentagon Blocks Testimony at Senate Hearing on Terrorist
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - The Pentagon said today that it had blocked a group of military officers and intelligence analysts from testifying at an open Congressional hearing about a highly classified military intelligence program that, the officers have said, identified a ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks as a potential terrorist more than a year before the attacks.

title: From FEMA to WEMA
description: SLIDELL, La. - I don't think Washington needs any more czars. But if President Bush feels compelled to put someone in charge of rebuilding the Gulf Coast, let me suggest a name: Lee Scott.

title: A Late Start Isn't Stopping Gator Harvest
description: KAPLAN, La., Sept. 15 - Hurricane Katrina flooded New Orleans and killed hundreds of people across the Gulf Coast region. The storm left a million others at least temporarily homeless. But where Louisiana's alligators are concerned, the hunt must go on.

title: Fighting to Get in on the Next Little Thing
description: San Francisco - FOUR months to six months. Only a year or two ago, that was how long start-up companies generally had to cajole, fret and act nonchalant while waiting for venture capitalists to part with money -- if they proved willing to write a check at all. Even during robust times, the period between a first pitch meeting with a venture capitalist and financing typically spans three months.

title: About That March
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Soaring Force in American Ballet: Hispanics
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 19 - Hispanic dancers have long graced American stages, but their presence, which was once notable, is fast becoming the norm -- a fact that was evident at the 10th annual International Ballet Festival here this weekend. It's hard not to think that today's crop of top Latin stars will eventually have an effect on American ballet. In some ways, they already have.

title: The Great Chorale of the Avian World
description: All Shook Up

title: Khodorkovsky Appeal Delayed Again
description: An appeal of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky's conviction on charges of tax evasion and fraud was delayed for a second time because of arguments over the lawyers representing him and his improbable attempt to register as a candidate for a parliamentary seat later this year. Mr. Khodorkovsky's lawyers have accused the court of hurrying consideration of the appeal. If the conviction is upheld, he will be ineligible to run. Prosecutors have, in turn, accused hom of prolonging the deliberations. His principal lawyer, Genrikh Padva, has missed two hearings, citing hospitalization for an undisclosed illness. The appeals court ordered three other lawyers to argue his case today, but Mr. Khodorkovsky refused. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Iran Sets Price for Raising Nuclear Issue With U.N. Council
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 20 - Iran's chief nuclear negotiator said today that Iran would stop allowing inspections of its nuclear facilities and restart uranium enrichment if the United States and its allies use the "language of threats" and refer Iran to the United Nations Security Council.

title: Merkel scrambles to shore up her support
British armored vehicles crash into Basra jail walls, freeing two Britons
Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDERSON, DAVID C.
description: ANDERSON--David C. Journalist, writer, Quaker. A Memorial Meeting will be held Saturday, September 24, 4 PM. Brooklyn Meeting House, Religious Society of Friends (Quakers) 110 Schermherhorn St., corner of Boerum Place, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to: Mary McDowell Center for Learning, 20 Bergen St. Brooklyn, NY 11201; Coalition to Stop Gun Violence 1023 15th St., NW, Suite 600 Washington, D.C. 20005; Columbia Land Conservancy, P.O. Box 299 Chatham, NY 12037.

title: INSIDE
description: Little Difference Found In Schizophrenia Drugs A study that compared drugs used to treat schizophrenia has confirmed what many psychiatrists long suspected: newer drugs that are highly promoted and widely prescribed offer few if any benefits over older medicines that sell for a fraction of the cost. The study looked at four new-generation drugs, called atypical antipsychotics, and one older drug. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1

title: Rebuilding the Gulf: No New Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Start-Ups a Leg Up, for a Slice of the Pie
description: LOS ANGELES - THE aha! moment came for Hal Bringman in 1999 when the online music pioneer MP3.com went public and its value soared, for a time, to nearly $7 billion -- making millionaires, at least on paper, of its founder and investors.

title: Manning Shows Improvement and More Confidence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19 - After the Giants' season-opening victory over the Arizona Cardinals last week, quarterback Eli Manning said he was pleased that they had scored 42 points, but he was not satisfied with his performance. He appeared out of sorts at times and completed fewer than half of his passes.

title: German Federation Admits to Nazi Past
description: With the World Cup in Germany less than a year away, that country's soccer federation last week released a 300-page report in book form that confirmed what many people had long believed -- the DFB, as the federation's initials are rendered in German, enthusiastically supported the Nazi regime from 1933 to 1945.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about mistakes by the Federal Emergency Management Agency after Hurricane Katrina referred incorrectly to the area being overseen by the agency's federal coordinating officer, William Lokey. It also misstated the amount of ice that had been delivered to the region by Friday. Mr. Lokey oversees Louisiana, not the three-state region. Relief workers delivered 177.6 million pounds, not tons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORADEI, ROSE (CLARA)
description: MORADEI--Rose (Clara), 87, of Bank Street, NY, died September 3rd in Calvary Hospital. Born in Swartswood, NJ, she was the daughter of the late John and Maria (Negro) Clara. She graduated from Newton High School, Newton, NJ in 1937 and was Office Manager for Dr. John Marshall Hoag, in New York City for over 30 years. Her weekends were spent in Pawling, NY where she has left many admirers and friends. She is survived by a sister, Helen Losey of Goshen, NY and eight nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to the Pawling Free Library, Broad St, Pawling, NY.

title: ABC's Lens Doesn't See Big Picture
description: The impulse to turn last night's "Monday Night Football" doubleheader on ABC and ESPN into a National Football League telethon for hurricane relief was a kind and well-intentioned one. But through the first half and into the third quarter, the execution was faulty.

title: No Joke: Egyptian Comedy Promotes Peace With Israel
description: CAIRO, Sept. 19 - Egyptian movie audiences are not accustomed to laughing about the Arab conflict with Israel, or to seeing Israeli diplomats portrayed as regular folks living next door.

title: Controlling Quality: The Hard Road to Building a Brand
description: WHEN Craig and Randy Rubin started Hi-Tex Inc. in November 1993, they never intended to open a factory. "Our charter was no bricks and mortar," said Ms. Rubin. The business, in West Bloomfield, Mich., was set up, she added, to be a branding and a technology company.

description: To the Editor;

title: World Briefings: Americas, Asia, Africa, Middle East, Europe
description: AMERICAS

title: The Slow Flow of Russian Oil
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19 - For five years, the managers of Russia's richest oil fields in western Siberia increased output by 14 percent annually, overcoming decades of Soviet neglect by repairing leaks, replacing pumps and charting better geological maps.

title: Snow Defends Bush's Economic Policy
description: A strong economy will allow the federal government to help the victims of Hurricane Katrina and rebuild the Gulf Coast while continuing to reduce the budget deficit, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said this morning.

title: Racketeering and Fraud Trial Begins for Illinois Ex-Governor
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 19 - All the potential jurors recognized the defendant -- the white hair, the big glasses, the gruff face. One admired his moratorium on executions in the state. Another expressed disdain for any politician who uses a position for personal gain. A third said he found the defendant "forgetful and unprepared."

title: Oprah, No Diva She, Accepts Herms Apology on the Air
description: Oprah Winfrey is not a diva. At all. No way. She is so adamant on that point that she brought the head of Herms USA onto her talk show yesterday to admit it and apologize in front of a national audience.

title: Two Large Unions Reach Agreement to End Feud
description: Two of the nation's largest unions -- the service employees and the state, county and municipal employees -- agreed yesterday to end a long-running feud by pledging not to raid each other's memberships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONFELD, BENJAMIN
description: BRONFELD--Benjamin. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Benjamin Bronfeld, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Marc Goldberg, President

title: The Crime and the Time
description: The cries for blood have certainly quieted since the recent corporate crime spree first made headlines with the disasters at Enron and WorldCom. Some cried foul when Bernard Ebbers of WorldCom and John Rigas of Adelphia Communications got sentences that meant those white-haired white-collar criminals would probably die in prison. Tomorrow night, Martha Stewart's version of the reality show "The Apprentice" will have its premiere amid her burst of postprison popularity.

title: A Dry Place to Study
description: John Sexton, the president of New York University, was planning to teach one class this semester, but added a second one to handle some of the 100 Hurricane Katrina evacuees who have landed at N.Y.U. for the term.

title: About That March
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMPF, WILLIAM I.
description: KAMPF -- William I. The Union for reform Judaism mourns with profound sorrow the sudden death of Bill Kampf, of St. Paul, MN, a member of its Board of Trustees since 1997 and, since 2004, the president of the Union's Great Lakes Council. In a variety of roles, Bill served the Union with great devotion. We extend deepest condolences to his wife, Janet, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may Bill's memory be for a blessing. Robert M. Heller, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President

title: Students Protest Use of Metal Detectors in Their Bronx School
description: Complaining that they were being treated like inmates, some 1,500 students from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx marched nearly two miles to the borough's Department of Education offices yesterday to protest the use of metal detectors at the school and not being allowed off campus during lunch.

title: Up From Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: Tips for Managing the Nuts and Bolts Like the Big Guys
description: SMALL-BUSINESS owners must often juggle the same complex accounting, legal and management issues that large corporations do without nearly the same resources or staff. "There are so many factors involved, and the interplay between the personal and business complicates things even further," said James A. Seidel, an executive at RIA, which provides small-business advice. While there is no substitute for hands-on experience, here are some tips that can help out small companies:

title: The Claim: Older People Are the Worst Drivers
description: THE CLAIM -- Older people are the worst drivers.

title: Gotti Jury, Reporting Impasse, Is Ordered to Keep Working
description: The jurors in the federal racketeering trial of John A. Gotti, the prince of the Gambino crime family, told the judge yesterday that they were deadlocked on the charges against him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IVANHOE, SYLVIA
description: IVANHOE--Sylvia, on September 14, 2005. Beloved wife of Morris (Scotty). Loving mother of Nora Freedman, Linda Jacob and Robert Ivanhoe. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear brother of Armand Knopf. Services and interment will be held today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, DANIEL
description: GREENE - Daniel. October 17, 1912 to September 17, 2005. Beloved father to Karin Grouf, Sherri Greene, Ron Greene and Ken Greene. Grandfather of Caitlin Greene and Ryan Greene. Brother to Syliva Piven, brother-in-law to Fred Hill and father-in-law to Diane Greene. Close friend to Phyllis Harnik and Jon Grouf, and uncle to Peter, Mark, Jacqueline and Ellen. Blessed with a quiet mind, he was always content and enjoyed everything he did and was liked wherever he went. He joins his wife Dorrit Greene after 61 years of marriage. Now they may both rest in peace together. Funeral services private.

title: Navigation Systems: Obsolete Before Their Time?
description: KAREN GREENWELL says she can get lost in her own backyard. Which is why Ms. Greenwell, a clinical researcher in Blue Bell, Pa., always insists on renting a car with an onboard navigation system.

title: New DVD's
description: Masculin Fminin

title: Should Roberts Be Confirmed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukraine Plunges Deeper Into Political Turmoil
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 - Ukraine plunged deeper into political turmoil today when the Parliament rejected President Viktor A. Yushchenko's choice to be prime minister and the country's top prosecutor announced the opening of criminal investigations into allegations of corruption among the president's aides.

title: House Bill Would Limit U.S. Power to Protect Species
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - The chairman of the House committee overseeing natural resources introduced a bill Monday that would make it more difficult for the federal government to set aside land it deems crucial to the health of endangered species.

title: To Bed or to Bar?
description: Ben Cukier, a New York investment banker, favors Starwood's W hotels. "They have really comfortable beds, really comfortable rooms and a hip atmosphere," the 33-year-old Mr. Cukier said. "They always have a great bar and a good lobby where you can hang out and read a book."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: British Army Storms Basra Jail to Free 2 Soldiers From Arrest
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 19 - Two British soldiers working under cover were arrested Monday in the southern city of Basra and then freed as a British armored vehicle blasted through the wall of their jail after an angry crowd began rioting outside, an Interior Ministry official said.

title: Rule Changes Are Proposed for Fisheries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - The Bush administration on Monday proposed using market-based incentives to govern saltwater fishing in certain areas, a tradable ticket to fish designed to impose order in waters prone to overfishing.

title: Blast at British Embassy in Croatia
description: A bomb exploded at the British Embassy in Zagreb, the capital, causing minor injuries to a security guard. Prime Minister Ivo Sanader said there was no clear motive for the bombing but suggested that it might be linked to Croatia's application to join the European Union. Britain is the current president of the union and is one of several member countries that have opposed Croatia's membership until it arrests its main war crimes fugitive, Gen. Ante Gotovina. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: File-Sharing Services Seek Pact With Record Studios
description: At least five online file-sharing companies have started trying to reach an accord with the music industry to convert the free trading of copyrighted music on their networks to paid services, according to several recording industry and file-sharing executives.

title: Staying Small, Going Global: How Uncle Sam Can Help
description: THE government wants to help the little guy sell more goods not just in America but around the world. And many loan-guarantee and insurance programs exist to give small businesses more incentives to push their products abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRESSLER, BERNARD
description: BRESSLER--Bernard. Bressler, Amery & Ross mourns the death of its founding partner, Bernard Bressler. Bernie was a brilliant man who, second only to his family and many good friends, revered the law. After graduating from Harvard Law School in 1949, where he was an editor of the Harvard Law Review, Bernie's practice focused on counseling a wide range of entrepreneurial businesses in fields such as technology, biotechnology, publishing and public relations. Above all, he was a teacher who, with patience and generosity, loved to explore complex legal and all other intellectual issues with all. He also taught us how to deal with serious illness, and death, directly and with strength and dignity. We will miss him deeply. Funeral services will be held at Temple Sinai, Summit Avenue, Summit, NJ on Tuesday, September 20, at 11 AM. The family will be sitting shiva that evening (only) at 7 PM at the Clubhouse of the Moore Estate, Woodland Road, Morris Township, NJ. The family has requested that any gift be sent to a fund that will be established in Bernie's name, The Bernard Bressler Fund at the Carol Simon Cancer Center of Morristown Memorial Hospital in honor of Dr. Steven Papish, Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07962-1956.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Donald S. Harrington, 91, Liberal Crusader, Dies
description: The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, a Unitarian minister who crusaded for social justice and was the public face of New York's Liberal Party in its heyday as a candidate for public office and its titular state chairman, died on Friday in Romania. He was 91.

title: Just Sports Business as Usual If the Saints Go Marching Out

title: A Flourish, and Lil' Kim Goes From Star to Inmate
description: Just hours after sipping Cristal Champagne and downing shrimp, chicken and fried rice at Mr. Chow, the rapper Lil' Kim began serving a one-year sentence for perjury at the Federal Detention Center in Philadelphia yesterday.

title: Quebec Rules Against Wal-Mart in Closing of Unionized Store
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 19 - Quebec's labor relations board has rejected Wal-Mart Canada's claim that it closed a unionized store in that province for economic reasons, saying instead that there was evidence the store might reopen.

title: Miscellany
description: Iando, Paris, which specializes in search engine marketing, was acquired by Media Contacts, Barcelona, Spain, the interactive division of MPG, part of Havas. Terms were not disclosed. Andres Menajovsky, who founded Iando, becomes director for search and performance at Media Contacts France. For a year, Iando will be known as Iando, a Media Contacts company, and after that it will be absorbed by Media Contacts.

description: Bees are deadly.

title: Across the Gulf Region, Getting a Handle on What Comes Next; Considering a detour to keep her hopes afloat.
description: HOUSTON - ALICE TRAN recently spent $60,000 to buy and make improvements on her second small business in Jefferson Parish, La., just across the Mississippi River from New Orleans. She opened the business, a karaoke bar called Club Hawaii, two months ago. Then came Hurricane Katrina.

title: Greed, It Turns Out, Isn't So Good
description: MANY years ago, when we both toiled for The New York Post, a colleague passed the time one night telling me about corruption trials that he had covered in New Jersey, a state graced with an ample supply of government officials caught with their hands in the till.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Lawyer in Investors' Suit Freed
description: Zhu Jiuhu, a lawyer arrested for helping to organize one of the largest class-action lawsuits ever brought against the government, was released from custody, one of his attorneys said. He had been held for nearly four months in western Shaanxi Province because of his work representing thousands of disgruntled investors who contend that the government illegally seized their private oil wells in 2003 and cheated them by paying compensation far below market value. The suit has yet to go to trial. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Ex-White House Aide Charged in Corruption Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - A senior White House budget official who resigned abruptly last week was arrested Monday on charges of lying to investigators and obstructing a federal inquiry involving Jack Abramoff, the Republican lobbyist who has been under scrutiny by the Justice Department for more than a year.

title: Fed Raises Rates Again, by a Quarter Point
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Saying that Hurricane Katrina was unlikely to pose a "persistent threat" to the economy, the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates this afternoon for the 11th time in a row and signaled that more rate increases are on the way.

title: OPEC Offers Extra Oil; Hurricane Dominates Market
description: VIENNA, Sept. 20 - Oil prices slipped today in regular trading following some predictions that the direction of Hurricane Rita might be shifting away from America's heartland of oil and gas. Meanwhile, OPEC formally agreed to lift all restrictions on its oil sales for the next three months, in a move aimed at further reassuring markets still on edge over the security of energy supplies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, RAYMOND J.
description: HOROWITZ--Raymond J. 89. On September 18, 2005. Beloved by his daughter Judy Babcock and his late wife Margaret, and loving brother of Edith King. His career as a an attorney was punctuated by decades of wise counsel and thoughtful action. A pioneer art collector who promoted and appreciated scholarship in the field of American Impressionism, and along with Margaret, formulated a premiere collection. A caring friend, always ready with a willing ear. There will be a memorial occasion to be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS--Ruth. September 20, 1998. Jordana is engaged. Holland is a joy. Miss you, Joyce, Jason, Greg, Jordana

title: It's Wild vs. Domestic Sheep as Groups Lock Horns Over Grazing Area
description: Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep are believed to have once numbered 1,000 or so, but after they dwindled to about 100 they were listed as a federally endangered species, in 1999.

title: $4 Million Fine for Office Depot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - Office Depot, the office supplies retailer, has paid $4.75 million to settle charges that it sold office products to the federal government that were made in countries that do not have reciprocal trade agreements with the United States, the Justice Department said on Monday.

title: Eastern frustration played big role in German election
Bush Aide Will Lead Hurricane Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - President Bush has named Frances Fragos Townsend, his domestic security adviser, to lead an internal White House inquiry into the administration's performance in handling Hurricane Katrina, Scott McClellan, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said Monday.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 - Behind padlocked gates on Rue Conti in the French Quarter, the ghosts of 306 years were waiting in wax.

description: The Lion at Theater Row 410 West 42nd Street Tickets: (212)352-3101 Wednesday at 8 p.m.Performances on Thursday and Saturday are sold out.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about home sellers who do not use real estate agents referred incorrectly to former rules that are at the center of an antitrust lawsuit brought by the Department of Justice against the National Association of Realtors. The association allowed members to block customers' Internet viewing of certain property listings on the Multiple Listing Service -- not a brokerage firm's access to the M.L.S. itself. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the cable network that carries "Sell This House." It is A&E; HGTV runs a similar program on staging homes.

title: West, Plains, Midwest, South and Mid-Atlantic
description: WEST

title: U.S.-Korean Deal on Arms Leaves Key Points Open
description: BEIJING, Sept. 19 - After a tense weekend of heated debate within the Bush administration, the lead American negotiator with North Korea made one last call to Washington at noon on Monday, Beijing time, and then signed a statement of principles that committed North Korea, in black and white, to give up "all nuclear weapons and existing nuclear programs."

title: F.E.C. Sues Republican Group Over Political Contributions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - The Federal Election Commission filed suit Monday against the Club for Growth, a well-funded Republican group, in an effort to force the organization to comply with limits on political contributions.

title: Afghan Electorate's Message: The Provinces Need Public Works and Restoration of Order
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 19 - The winners and losers of the landmark Afghan elections on Sunday will remain a mystery for another several weeks, but whoever makes it to the legislature will quickly be tested against the universal axiom of parliamentary democracy: that all politics is local.

title: Feeling some heat, Merkel fights for top job
Rights Report Details Uzbek Crackdown After Uprising in May
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19 - The government of Uzbekistan, stung by the outcry in the West over its bloody suppression of a prison break and anti-government demonstration in May, has engaged for months in a ferocious crackdown against those who have tried to expose the brutality, says a report released Monday by a prominent human rights organization.

title: Art Is Long, Book Parties Are Short
description: Art Is Long, Book Parties Are Short

title: Honey Bruce Friedman Dies at 78; Entertainer and 'Lenny's Shady Lady'
description: Honey Bruce Friedman, a former nightclub entertainer who in 2003 helped win a posthumous pardon for her ex-husband, the comedian Lenny Bruce, on a 39-year-old obscenity conviction, died on Sept. 12 at a hospital in Honolulu. She was 78 and a Honolulu resident.

title: Students Receive Fewer A's, and Princeton Calls It Progress
description: Princeton University significantly reduced the number of A's it gave out last year, according to a report released yesterday by the university, but it still wants to do more.

title: Google testsa WiFi link
Across the Gulf Region, Getting a Handle on What Comes Next; A sample in her suitcase and no doubts about going home.
description: NEW ORLEANS - BY the time Bobbie Bedney realized it was time to go, it was almost too late. As she left the house in the Seventh Ward with her niece and son and tried to get away from the flood, the water was above her waist and then up to her neck. But she got unexpected help from a man who had been looting an electronics store. He reached out to grab Ms. Bedney's niece with one hand, carrying her along as he pulled a floating trash can filled with boxes of high-tech goods with the other hand. "I had to laugh," she said.

title: NASA's Back-to-the-Future Plans
description: NASA has finally unveiled its plans for carrying out the ambitious space exploration program that was announced by President Bush in January 2004 but left vague and undefined ever since. The proposed new space vehicles look like a sensible way to put astronauts and cargo into space after the shuttle fleet is retired and will be built to facilitate landings on both the Moon and Mars. Michael Griffin, the new administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, deserves credit for putting real flesh on what had been little more than an aspiration. Unfortunately, the new plan lacks the pizzazz to inspire public support and will be operating under budget constraints that make delays or overruns likely.

title: Nigerian Anglicans Break With Canterbury
description: Angry over other Anglican churches' tolerance of homosexuality, the Anglican Church of Nigeria has deleted from its Constitution all references to "the See of Canterbury," the British "mother" church that links Anglican churches worldwide into a global communion. The step further institutionalizes the division over homosexuality between Anglican churches in most of the developing world and those in Britain, Canada and the United States. The Constitution of the Nigerian church, led by Archbishop Peter J. Akinola, above, says it will now be in communion only with churches that "maintain the historic faith, doctrine, sacrament and discipline." The Nigerians said the change would allow them to reach across geographic boundaries and provide "worshiping refuge to thousands in the U.S.A." who have refused to accept the 2003 decision of the Episcopal Church USA to ordain an openly gay bishop in New Hampshire. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Liz Claiborne Hires Executive from CNBC
description: Liz Claiborne, maker of Dana Buchman and Sigrid Olsen clothing, named the chairman of CNBC, Pamela Thomas-Graham, president of its flagship brand.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot
description: A 21-year-old man was shot last night in the Prospect-Lefferts Gardens section, the police said. The shooting occurred about 11 p.m. at 728 Rogers Avenue, near Lenox Road. The man, whose identity was not released by the police, was taken to Kings County Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.

title: British Police Believe Tapes Show Bombers in Practice Run
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 - Less than two weeks before they attacked London on July 7, three of the four suicide bombers traveled to the city for what appears to have been a practice run, the police said today.

title: Cash Now, Questions Later
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 19 - In the period that some simply call "before," employees working at the Liberty Bank and Trust Company headquarters, a six-story glass box in eastern New Orleans, sat at brand-new workstations in a building they had occupied only this past spring.

title: Nobody Knows, So Round the World She Goes
description: MURIEL was a bit undressed on Saturday morning, her propellers and outboard wings detached as mechanics prepared her 70-year-old twin engines for a journey back through time, back through a cloudy course over the Pacific in search of the answer to the most frequently asked question in aviation history: What happened to Amelia Earhart?

title: Earl's Real Name Is Second Chance and Redemption
description: Offbeat and utterly charming, "My Name Is Earl" is about a search for redemption after a fall from grace -- NBC's fall from grace.

title: An Honest Victory
description: Cambridge, Mass. - AUTHORITY can be delegated; responsibility cannot. President Bush's speech last week accepting responsibility for the federal government's slow response to Hurricane Katrina was commendable, if overdue. Though it has been derided by some as political expediency, the president's acknowledgment was a necessary first step in rebuilding the Gulf Coast and preparing for the next disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MIHALY, JOHN, JR.
description: MIHALY--John, Jr., on September 17, 2005. Loving husband of Kathleen, beloved father of John III. He enjoyed a long career as a purchasing agent for the Penn Central Railroad and various hotels including The Palace, The Drake and The Rihga Royal. Friends may call at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm Tuesday. Mass of the Divine Liturgy Burial, St. Nicholas of Myra Byzantine Catholic Church, White Plains, Wednesday September 21, 10am.

title: Space Vision: The Experts Split Again
description: The nation eagerly accepted President John F. Kennedy's challenge in 1961 to put men on the Moon. But President Bush's plan to return humans there and then voyage onward to Mars is dividing space experts and generating skepticism about its feasibility.

Brooklyn Girl Killed by Car Driven by Father, Police Say
description: It had been a merry all-day party in the Bronx, a Dora-the-Explorer-themed birthday bash on a balmy Sunday on the eve of 3-year-old Jalien Abreu's first day in school.

title: Remedy for Sleep Apnea May Lift Depression's Veil
description: Fatigue, irritability, lack of concentration and loss of interest in enjoyable activities are common symptoms of depression. But they are also symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea, and a new study suggests that physicians may confuse the two.

title: White House Said to Shift List for 2nd Court Seat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - The White House is reshuffling its short list of potential Supreme Court nominees with a new emphasis on finding someone who will hold up under the pressure of what is expected to be fierce confirmation battle, several Republican allies close to the process said on Monday.

title: Ex-Tyco ExecutivesGet 8 to 25 Years in Prison
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International who was convicted of looting the company of $150 million, was sentenced yesterday to 81/3 to 25 years in a New York State prison, the latest corporate figure to be handed a lengthy prison term in a corruption case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINCUS, STANLEY
description: PINCUS--Stanley. On September 18, 2005 of New York City. Beloved husband of Joni. Devoted father of Matthew and Amy. Loving brother of Irving Rubin, Zena Starr and the late Sylvan Rubin. Services Wednesday 12 Noon at "Gutterman's" 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: Little Difference Found in Schizophrenia Drugs
description: A landmark government-financed study that compared drugs used to treat schizophrenia has confirmed what many psychiatrists long suspected: newer drugs that are highly promoted and widely prescribed offer few -- if any -- benefits over older medicines that sell for a fraction of the cost.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Germany: Exel Sells for $6.7 Billion
description: Deutsche Post, faced with the loss of its German mail delivery monopoly, agreed to buy Exel for 3.7 billion ($6.7 billion) to become the world's largest manager of warehouses and inventories as global trade expands. Deutsche Post, Europe's biggest postal service, will pay 1,244 pence in cash and stock for each Exel share, Klaus Zumwinkel, chief executive of Deutsche Post, said in London. The acquisition will add modestly to earnings in 2006 as the German company seeks new markets before its mail monopoly runs out. Deutsche Post is based in Bonn and Exel in Bracknell, England.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column yesterday about the Bessie awards for dance misstated the title of a trilogy by the choreographer Ralph Lemon that was performed in part at the ceremony. It is "Geography Trilogy," not "Geometry Trilogy."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: OPEC Is Set to Raise Limit on Extra Oil Output But Prices Surge as Hurricane Threatens Gulf OPEC delegates said that the group planned to allow its members to provide up to 2 million barrels a day of extra crude oil "if the market needs it." But oil traders brushed aside the move and instead sent oil prices higher today on worries of another possible hurricane. [Page C1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZWICK, JOSEPH
description: ZWICK - Joseph. Passed away peacefully September 19, 2005. Beloved husband and best friend of Harriet. (nee Baumholtz). Adored father of Michael and Marjorie. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Harry. God be with him.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 31 about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina misattributed a statement about the severity of flooding in New Orleans. It was Senator David Vitter, a Louisiana Republican, who said, "I don't want to alarm anyone that New Orleans is filling up like a bowl" -- not Michael D. Brown, who was director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Britain: LogicaCMG Is Buying Unilog
description: LogicaCMG, Europe's third-largest computer services provider, agreed to buy the French software company Unilog for 930 million euros ($1.13 billion) and said it would sell shares to help pay for the purchase. LogicaCMG said in a statement that it would offer 389 million ($703.5 million) of shares to existing shareholders. LogicaCMG, which is based in London, will pay 73 euros cash ($89) for 67.7 percent of publicly held Unilog shares, and a combination of cash and stock for the rest, held by Unilog managers. LogicaCMG told investors last month that it needed to be bigger to make a profit. Unilog is based in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAGER, DOROTHY
description: SAGER--Dorothy. On September 17, 2005. Beloved and loving wife of 64 years of Irving. Adoring mother of Tony and cherished grandmother of Jessica and Diana. Service and interment private. Contributions in her memory to UJA Fund for Hurricane Katrina Victims would be appreciated.

title: Mixed Messages as the Auto Show Season Begins
description: If the press preview days of this year's Frankfurt International Motor Show proved anything, it is that auto companies need to search high and low to meet car buyers' conflicting demands for more power, luxury and miles per gallon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charges Against Actor Dropped
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan agreed yesterday to drop the charges against the actor Christian Slater, left, if he stays out of trouble for six months. Mr. Slater, who was charged in May with groping a woman on an Upper East Side sidewalk, did not speak to reporters as he left Manhattan Criminal Court. But his lawyer, Eric Franz, said, "The case is dismissed, and we are very pleased with the outcome." In a previous court appearance in July, Mr. Slater rejected a plea deal that would have required him to perform three days of community service in exchange for pleading guilty to second-degree harassment. Mr. Slater, 36, was originally charged with sexual abuse in the third degree and disorderly conduct. At the time of his arrest, on May 31, the actor was appearing in "The Glass Menagerie" on Broadway.

title: Beltran Can Only Hope That He Has Hit Bottom
description: One of the telling moments of Carlos Beltran's season came in the fifth inning of Thursday's game against the Washington Nationals. The bases were loaded with one out, and the Mets trailed, 4-1, when Beltran strode to the plate to face Livn Hernndez.

title: Senate Panel Hears Concerns About Eminent Domain Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee listened sympathetically today to people who face the loss of their homes or their churches to make way for economic development.

title: The alchemy of art-world heavy metal
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about Senator Jon S. Corzine's preferred candidate for a New Jersey Senate seat misstated the given name of the person shown with Mr. Corzine and gave an outdated title for him. He is Robert Del Tufo, not Peter; and he is a former New Jersey attorney general, not the current one.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Germany: Siemens to Cut Jobs
description: Siemens, Europe's biggest engineering company, will eliminate 2,400 jobs at the German computer services division and replace the unit's head as part of a plan to weed out unprofitable businesses and revive the stock. The cuts at Siemens Business Services will help save 1.5 billion euros ($1.8 billion) in two years, Klaus Kleinfeld, the chief executive, said in a conference call with analysts. Adrian von Hammerstein, head of the division, will leave, and Siemens will cut the unit's German offices to 20, from 60. The company also plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs at Siemens Communications. Siemans is based in Munich.

title: Audit Details School Waste in Hempstead
description: A new state audit blames officials of the dysfunctional Hempstead school district on Long Island for "uncontrolled, inappropriate and wasteful spending" in recent years.

Beloved brother of Mary Lyons, Catherine Soyars, Geraldine Mirando and Patrick Lyons. Loving uncle of seven nieces and nephews. Mass Thursday 10 AM, Church of St. Anne, 35 Dartmouth St., Garden City.

description: SAVODNIK--Marvin. "Mickey", 71, September 17, 2005. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Beth and Scott. Father-in-law of Cary and Dominique. Brother of Irwin. title: Ex-President of Mexico Charged in Massacre
description: For the second time, a special prosecutor has asked a judge to issue an arrest warrant for former President Luis Echeverra, this time in connection with the massacre of student protesters in 1968 that fueled an era of social unrest. Last year, the prosecutor, Ignacio Carrillo Prieto, sought genocide charges against the former president in the killings of two dozen protesters in 1971, but the courts later threw out the charges, saying there was not enough evidence. Now the prosecutor's office seeks to charge Mr. Echeverra, who is 83, and several other former officials with the massacre in the Tlalteloco housing project in 1968, in which soldiers killed dozens of students. At the time, he was the interior minister and controlled the country's spy and security forces. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Muscular Men With Balloons and a Bunny
description: The New Victory Theater on Friday was full of delightedly shrieking children (and more than a few adults) ushering in its 10th anniversary season. Onstage, a troupe of muscular, charming New Zealanders known as Black Grace also happened to be celebrating 10 years, and doing it in style with the company's New York debut.

title: Many Women at Elite Colleges Set Career Path to Motherhood
description: Cynthia Liu is precisely the kind of high achiever Yale wants: smart (1510 SAT), disciplined (4.0 grade point average), competitive (finalist in Texas oratory competition), musical (pianist), athletic (runner) and altruistic (hospital volunteer). And at the start of her sophomore year at Yale, Ms. Liu is full of ambition, planning to go to law school.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Boats To Be Added To Patrol Ports
description: The New Jersey State Police will add new patrol boats to bolster harbor security at the Port of Camden and the Port of New York and New Jersey, Acting Gov. Richard E. Codey announced yesterday. Four 28-foot patrol boats, as well as bomb detection and surveillance equipment, will be purchased with a $2.5 million grant from the Department of Homeland Security, Mr. Codey said in a statement. The money will also be used to purchase specialized equipment for state police divers and bomb disposal equipment for use at the ports.

title: At Vioxx Trial, Witness Says Short-Term Use Posed a Risk
description: Merck & Company's painkiller Vioxx may cause heart attacks with just one dose, a University of Michigan researcher said at the second product liability trial over the drug, challenging the company's assertion that only long-term users are at risk.

description: The possibility was too rich for Bubba Crosby to consider. For two seasons, the Yankees had pounded a harsh reality into his psyche. Crosby was fast enough to pinch-run, and dependable enough to play outfield in the late innings. But Crosby was not a hitter.

She was 65.

title: A Shop for Riders Hooked on Wheels
description: PHILADELPHIA - MATT HEITMANN encountered frustration in the software consulting business, yet he endured his most teeth-gnashing experiences when he tried to outfit himself for the amateur bike racing that he loves.
