Mayor Suspends Flow of People to New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 - Under pressure from President Bush and with a new storm threatening the Gulf of Mexico, Mayor C. Ray Nagin suspended on Monday his controversial plan to allow people to return to this vulnerable city.

title: Lining Up to Be Raped?
description: Our close ally President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan visited the U.S. last week and fretted aloud about a surprising problem: The "easiest way" for Pakistani women to make money is to get raped, he said, so they're lining up to be raped and thus making him look bad.

National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Wrongful Arrest Case Settled
description: The City of Chicago agreed to pay $6.2 million to settle a wrongful arrest lawsuit brought by a boy who was charged with the murder of 11-year-old Ryan Harris in 1998. The boy, who was 8 at the time, and a 7-year-old boy confessed after a police interrogation, but charges were dropped after medical experts said the boys could not have produced semen found in the victim's underpants. A Chicago man, Floyd Durr, was later charged with the killing; he is awaiting trial. Last week, the City Council ordered city lawyers to settle the case. The other boy settled a wrongful arrest suit with the city earlier this year for $2 million. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

Turkey's Parliament Meets on Terrorism
description: Opposition parties mustered enough votes to convene a special session of Parliament to address a recent escalation of bomb attacks around the country. A sanitation worker was wounded yesterday when a bomb went off in a central Istanbul park, and two people were killed and 10 wounded in an explosion on a bus in the Mediterranean resort of Manavgat on Sunday night. No one claimed responsibility for those attacks. In July, a bomb on a minibus in the Aegean resort of Kusadasi killed five people. Kurdish separatists are suspected in that attack.

title: Lottery Numbers

title: Diplomacy at Work
description: For years now, foreign policy insiders have pointed to North Korea as the ultimate nightmare, the ongoing worst-case scenario for an international crisis: a closed, hostile and paranoid dictatorship with an aggressive nuclear weapons program. Very few people could envision a successful outcome. And yet North Korea agreed in principle this week to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, return to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, abide by the treaty's safeguards and admit international inspectors.

But a leased 350-kilowatt generator kept its refrigerators humming, and no inventory was lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, SANDRA
description: FELDMAN - Sandra. Died September 19 after a courageous battle against breast cancer. Beloved wife of Arthur Barnes, sister of Larry Abramowitz and Helen Berliner, stepmother to David and Donna Marie Barnes, and grandmother to Alex and Tatum Barnes. She was also our leader, mentor, colleague and friend at the United Federation of Teachers. She was our president from 1986 to 1997, when she became president of our parent union, the American Federation of Teachers, and served until July, 2004. Her dream was always to improve society through education, labor, social justice and political action--and that is her legacy. Sitting at the feet of Bayard Rustin when she was 17, and later, under the tutelage of Albert Shanker, she learned about justice, civil rights, organizing, protests and, most of all, how improving public education can be a major force for social change. She pioneered a legion of programs such as Dial-A-Teacher and Teacher Centers to help students and teachers alike. Since February 2004, when Sandy found out she had a relapse, she fought mightily--as mightly as she always fought to help make a difference in our lives, and in the lives of the thousands of people we represent and the hundreds of thousands of children and others we serve. Those who knew her well know how hard she worked and how much she sacrificed so others would have social justice and economic opportunity. She was a giant and will be hugely missed. Randi Weingarten, President, and the 155,000 Members of the UFT

title: Simon Wiesenthal, Nazi Hunter, Dies at 96
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the death camp survivor who dedicated the rest of his life to tracking down fugitive Nazi war criminals, died today at his home in Vienna. He was 96. His death was announced by Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean and founder of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hicksville: Oil Spill Closes Lanes On L.I. Expressway
description: The eastbound lanes of the Long Island Expressway were closed from Exit 40 to Exit 41 for much of yesterday after an oil tanker flipped while entering the highway, the Nassau County police said. The accident occurred at 9 a.m. near Exit 41, causing traffic tie-ups all the way to the Queens border for much of the day. The tanker contained home heating oil, which spilled onto the roadway. The eastbound lanes were reopened shortly before 5 p.m., except for the right lane, which needed repairs, according to the police. The truck driver, Elvin Fernandez, of Brentwood, was taken to Nassau University Medical Center with a minor shoulder injury. He was issued six citations for equipment violations, the police said.

title: U.S. Details Charges Against Student Linked to Plot Against Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - An American student in Saudi Arabia who is charged with plotting to assassinate President Bush told Saudi interrogators that "I came up with the idea on my own" because he wanted to be "the brain, the planner" for a terrorist operation, American prosecutors said in a court filing made public on Monday.

description: Eating soy may help prevent bone fractures in postmenopausal women. A large study of more than 24,000 women suggests that soy protein is especially helpful to bone health in the first few years after a woman reaches menopause.

title: OPEC Set to Open Oil Taps Full Blast
description: VIENNA, Sept. 19 - OPEC delegates said Monday that the group planned to allow its members to provide up to two million barrels a day of additional crude oil if the market needs it. But oil traders brushed aside the move and instead sent oil prices higher on worries of another possible hurricane.

title: Taking Minority-Owned Businesses Under Their Wing
description: FOUR years ago, Group O Direct, which handles rebates and other fulfillment aspects of customer promotions, was a $4 million-a-year company that barely turned a profit. Michael J. De La Cruz, its vice president for sales and marketing, said that bigotry -- the company is owned by Mexican-Americans -- accounted for some of the problem. But the bigger part was that Group O Direct, though it had been around since 1974, did not know how to navigate corporate shoals.

title: Almost Before We Spoke, We Swore
description: Incensed by what it sees as a virtual pandemic of verbal vulgarity issuing from the diverse likes of Howard Stern, Bono of U2 and Robert Novak, the United States Senate is poised to consider a bill that would sharply increase the penalty for obscenity on the air.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Backs Transportation Bond
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has urged voters to approve a $2.9 billion transportation bond in November, saying the money would pay for highway repairs and mass transit improvements. Nearly 60 percent of the money would be used for energy-efficient improvements, such as railway work, the governor said in a statement released Sunday. If voters approved, $1.45 billion would be dedicated to Metropolitan Transportation Authority projects, including the Second Avenue subway, a rail line between Manhattan and Kennedy Airport, and a Long Island Rail Road connection at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Schools Chief Urges Teacher Pay Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein on Monday called for sweeping changes to the way teachers are paid and said that the creation of signing bonuses, pay differentials and merit raises would be a top priority in a second term of the Bloomberg administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISELY, SISTER BERNADETTE DE LOURDES, O. CARM. (''MOTHER BERNADETTE'')
description: WISELY--Sister Bernadette de Lourdes, O. Carm. ("Mother Bernadette"). The Board of Directors, staff, volunteers and supporters of the Catholic Health Care System of the Archdiocese of New York (CHCS) mourn the death of Mother Bernadette, who inspired the Carmelite Sisters of the Aged and Infirm with her charismatic leadership. Mother Bernadette's pioneering concepts of care for the elderly guide the management of the System's three facilities overseen by the Carmelite Sisters: Mary Manning Walsh Home, Manhattan; Carmel Richmond Healthcare & Rehabilitation Center, Staten Island; and Ferncliff Nursing Home, Rhinebeck. Her development of the "resident-centered care" model continues as inspiration for the management of the System's four additional facilities: Kateri Residence and Terence Cardinal Cooke Health Care Center, Manhattan; St. Vincent de Paul Residence, Bronx; and St. Teresa's Nursing Home, Middletown. Mother Bernadette's legacy can be witnessed every day in the System's holistic approach to care, and her dynamic vision will continue to inspire the pacesetters of eldercare philosophy. Karl P. Adler, M.D., Chairman

title: From Macdonald, tropical glitz; at Elspeth Gibson, easy sweetness

title: North Korea demands a nuclear reactor
Foer Takes Opera Plunge in a Berlin Warehouse
description: BERLIN, Sept. 19 - With a libretto by the novelist Jonathan Safran Foer and music by seven composers, each of whom scored a section, "Seven Attempted Escapes From Silence" has an odd structure for an opera. The story and the staging of the piece, which had its premiere on Wednesday at the Staatsoper here, are just as unusual. The plot involves prisoners who have lost the power of speech; they sing, but only their guard uses recognizable words. And the production, with multiple directors, includes a recording of Mr. Foer reading stage directions that aren't followed.

title: Reporter Working for Times Abducted and Slain in Iraq

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Suit Tries To Block Voting Law
description: A consortium of voter's rights groups has filed a federal lawsuit seeking to block the state's new law requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification before casting a ballot. It argues that the law is unconstitutional and creates an unnecessary and undue burden for students, as well as for those who are poor, disabled or elderly. On Aug. 26, Georgia became the second state, after Indiana, to require a photo ID as an absolute condition for admission to the polls. The suit was brought by the American Civil Liberties Union, Common Cause, the League of Women Voters, the Georgia Legislative Black Caucus and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Brenda Goodman (NYT)

title: Up From Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Emmys Draw a Crowd
description: With 27 awards, HBO once again won the most Emmys on Sunday night. But the popularity of nominated shows on the networks, like "Lost" and "Desperate Housewives" on ABC, and CBS's "Everybody Loves Raymond," made this year's broadcast of the awards ceremony the most watched since the 2002 program. Nielsen's preliminary estimates for the live show indicated that 18.6 million viewers watched. Last year's program brought in only 13.8 million. CBS easily won the night in all key demographics. Friday's lineup featured the debuts of two new series. CBS's "Threshold" was the first of the networks' fall science-fiction series to have its premiere, and the results were mixed. It drew 8.42 million viewers and won among the 18-to-49 group but was not strong enough to bring the network a victory for the night among total viewers. NBC was No. 1 in that category, with a two-hour "Dateline" and a repeat of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit." The new WB sitcom "Twins" brought in a mere $3.14 million, but it placed second among women 18 to 34, one of the network's target demographics. KATE AURTHUR

title: What's a Shut-In to Build? A Robot
description: Jennifer Marcus, ensconced in the messy fortress of her bedroom, clicking away at the keyboard and refusing to take out the garbage, is a suburban mom's worst nightmare, for sure. But the feisty heroine of "The Intelligent Design of Jenny Chow," a new play by Rolin Jones, isn't beaming instant messages to her girlfriends, retailing gossip about boys or news of shoe sales. She's swapping technospeak with rocket scientists, hellbent on creating her very own android.

title: Denying Access to the Ballot
description: It has been clear since 2000 that the election system is in serious need of reform. But the commission led by James Baker III and former President Jimmy Carter has come up with a plan that is worse than no reform at all. Its good ideas are outweighed by one very bad idea: a voter identification requirement that would prevent large numbers of poor, black and elderly people from voting.

title: Up From Disaster (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMZAN, RUTH
description: KAMZAN - Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Abe. Mother of Morton and Colleen, Alex and Irene, Richard and Ellen. Grandmother of Joshua, Jenna, Jessica, Elizabeth, Robert, Alyssa and Jordan. Services Tuesday, 11am at "Gutterman's Inc", 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Up-Front Preferences
description: UP-FRONT PREFERENCES -- In-flight comfort, specifically amenities like seats that can lie flat for sleeping, is the most important factor in choosing an airline for international business-class travel, according to a survey of more than 500 business fliers by 1stAir Inc. That is not good news for international carriers based in the United States. Their business-class products are generally viewed as inferior to those on foreign airlines like British Airways and Cathay Pacific. In all, 70.5 percent of those polled said they preferred the premium cabins on foreign carriers to those on domestic ones.

title: Palestinian President Says Gaza-Egypt Border Needs International Deal
description: The border between the Gaza Strip and Egypt will not be reopened until there is an international agreement, said the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas. Palestinian and Egyptian security officers gained control of the border on Sunday, halting the uncontrolled flow of people across the frontier that followed the departure of Israeli troops last week. "We want to act as a state, as a responsible authority," Mr. Abbas said in Gaza City. "Until we reach an agreement, we should be patient." Greg Myre (NYT)

title: The Orioles' Collapse: Let's Count the Ways
description: ONCE upon a time -- earlier this season -- the Baltimore Orioles peeked at the schedule and thought they would come to Yankee Stadium the third week of September and play some meaningful games. They are at Yankee Stadium in the third week of September, and they are playing meaningful games, but they are meaningful only to the team they are playing. The season ceased to have meaning for the Orioles, at least significant meaning, in a maelstrom of unappetizing events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, ARTHUR
description: SMITH--Arthur. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Arthur Smith, associated with The Times from November 1967 until retiring in January 1991.

title: Dancers Rev Their Engines for Celebrity 'Dance-Off'
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 - It's a shame that the four-time world heavyweight boxing champ Evander Holyfield got the hook midway through ABC's surprise summer hit, "Dancing With the Stars." Because Tuesday night's "Dance-Off" special -- a rematch between the last two couples standing -- looks to be a memorable fight.

title: NASA Planning Return to Moon Within 13 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - Combining an old concept, existing equipment and new ideas, NASA gave shape on Monday to President Bush's promise to send humans back to the Moon by the end of the next decade.

title: Martin, the Jets' Ironman, Has a Dented Right Knee
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 19 - "As far as injuries go," said Coach Herman Edwards, beginning his news conference Monday the way he always does. Edwards's voice remained steady, his face expressionless. There was nothing in his delivery to convey the weight of the words that were about to follow.

title: Mr. Butkus Goes Back to High School
description: McKEES ROCKS, Pa. - Dick Butkus -- the model of the furious, ferocious middle linebacker, the former Chicago Bear who once smashed footballs and bodily fluids out of unsuspecting running backs -- was grumbling. He was muttering. Who would want to annoy this guy? These teenagers, players on loan to him, were irritating him by missing assignments and failing to play hard enough. It was enough to make the bristles of his crew cut revolt. These youngsters were not doing their jobs.

title: Ferrer Is Likely to Get Backing of Workers in Health Care
description: With the Board of Elections poised to certify Fernando Ferrer as the Democratic nominee for mayor, 1199/S.E.I.U., the influential health care workers' union, is set to throw its considerable weight behind Mr. Ferrer's candidacy today.

title: You Have All the Answers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sideline Acrobats
description: The raw power and athletic grace of the country's best cheerleading squad.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Vintage hardware -- period knobs, hinges or door knockers -- can be the great finishing touch in a renovation project.

title: Currents
description: Shopping New Orleans' treasures in spite of the floods, music unleashed, a tweak for design by way of Ikea and more.

title: Fly Girl
description: Tweed and waders have a certain lure. This fall, take the bait.

title: Norman Mailer Receives National Book Medal
description: Correction Appended

title: Exploring the Mysterious Aftermath of a Different Hurricane
description: The suspense that ABC had hoped for with "Invasion," its skillful new body-snatcher series, has been undermined by menaces beyond the network's control. In the wake of Hurricane Katrina, the opening episode's terrestrial forms of terror prove far scarier than extraterrestrial ones. An immense hurricane hits South Florida! And oh, yeah, some aliens use it as a shield to invade the United States.

title: A Perky Warrior Singing the Pentagon Blues
description: Throughout the chest-pounding, inept new NBC series "E-Ring," Benjamin Bratt must run around the Pentagon like Theseus in the labyrinth. "Hey, fellas!" he says, by way of salute to passengers on an up escalator that he's running down. "How's it hangin', fellas?" he later asks a collection of men with far more stars and bars than he.

title: Soccer: World players choose their own Dream Team
3 London bombers made dry run
Fed raises U.S. rates despite hurricane
It's 'My N.H.L.,' and Peter Puck Has Left the Building
description: The National Hockey League is about to answer a question vital to its future: How do you market a brand severely damaged by a season-long lockout?

title: Interpublic Proxy to Include Proposal to Sell Company
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York said yesterday that it would place a shareholder proposal to sell the company on the proxy for the 2005 annual meeting, after the Securities and Exchange Commission denied a request by the company to exclude the plan.

title: EU agrees on key point for Turkey
Katrina's Children Find New Schools, and Fears
description: HOUSTON - DAVE SCHRANDT is in charge of registering homeless children for the Cypress-Fairbanks school district, and when he really gets cranked up, he can fill out the six forms to enroll a hurricane evacuee in 15 minutes.

title: Red Sox Find a Way to Beat Up on the Devil Rays
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 20 - On the brink of falling out of first place for only the second time since June 24, the Boston Red Sox pushed aside questions about their list of injuries, the depth of their pitching, the pressures of defending a world championship, and they did what they do best.

title: People: John Mellencamp, Christian Slater, Simon Russell Beale
National Briefing | Washington: Pentagon To Resume War Crimes Trials Of 4 Detainees At Base In Cuba
description: The Pentagon said it was planning to resume hearing motions in the war crimes trial at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, of David Hicks, an Australian who is facing terrorism charges. The trials of four detainees, including Mr. Hicks, left, were abruptly suspended last year when a federal judge ruled that the trials violated domestic law and international treaty obligations. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit overturned that ruling in July, and the issue is now before the Supreme Court. The actual trial of Mr. Hicks might begin in November.

title: Iraqi Police Protest British Raid on Jail
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 21 - Iraqi police officers led an angry demonstration today in the southern city of Basra to protest a British raid on an Iraqi police station earlier in the week, as Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari made a joint appearance in London with Britain's defense secretary to try to defuse tensions over the incident.

title: Correction
description: Credits last Wednesday with pictures of foods from Iceland misstated the surname of the photographer. She is Bara Kristindottir.

title: Evacuees of One Storm Flee Another in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 20 - Hurricane Rita prompted a mandatory evacuation of this city's public shelters on Tuesday, emptying them as quickly as they had filled just three weeks ago and sending still-dazed survivors of Hurricane Katrina packing off to Arkansas, to the bus terminal, to the airport and, for some who considered themselves lucky, to paid and furnished apartments here in the Houston area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASEL, THEODORE
description: BASEL--Theodore, on September 20, in Rhode Island. Burial Friday, 1:30pm in Montefiore Cemetery, Queens.

title: Attack Source of Militancy, Karzai Urges U.S. Coalition
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 20 - President Hamid Karzai questioned Tuesday the need for major military operations in Afghanistan, saying that airstrikes were no longer effective and that the United States-led coalition should focus more on shutting off the flow of militants.

title: A Migration Across a Stage and Through a Building
description: This will have to be more of a road marker than a review. Unfortunately, the road is coming to an end. This week's performances of Jennifer Monson's "Bird Brain" events, titled "Flight of Mind," which began on Monday night at the Dance Theater Workshop, represent the culmination of at least the New York portion of this five-year project, although there may be a tour and more environmental forays.

title: Army Truck Driver Is Killed by Roadside Bomb in Iraq
description: An Army truck driver who had lived in the Bronx and Queens after immigrating from Surinam died on Saturday after a roadside bomb exploded near his Humvee during an escort mission in western Iraq, the Department of Defense said yesterday.

title: Simon Wiesenthal Is Dead at 96; Tirelessly Pursued Nazi Fugitives
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLADE, JOHN
description: SLADE--John. The World Union for Progressive Judaism records with sadness the death of John Slade, our good friend and generous benefactor. His love for the Jewish people and commitment to Jewish values was wisely recognized and admired. John was our World Union International Humanitarian Award honoree in 1992. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Marianne, his daughtersand their families. Steven Bauman, Chairman Rabbi Uri Regev, President

title: Fresh Start, With Chain Saw and Foie Gras
description: ABITA SPRINGS, La. - "WE'VE got 19 on the books for tonight, and we're hoping for a few walk-ins if we're lucky. Does everybody know the menu?"

title: Writers Sue Google, Accusing It of Copyright Violation
description: Three authors filed suit against Google yesterday contending that the company's program to create searchable digital copies of the contents of several university libraries constituted "massive copyright infringement."

title: Islanders and Rangers Give Glimpse of Season to Come
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Sept. 20 - If first looks mean anything, the Rangers and the Islanders lived up to their billing Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum, where the Islanders won, 5-1, in the metropolitan area's first N.H.L. action since April 2004.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Plums and Pumpkins: Autumn's Lush Bounty Arrives
description: Correction Appended

title: From Trappist Monks, Heavenly Brew
description: FOR single-minded devotion to quality, purity and tradition, the Trappist monks of Belgium are hard to match, especially when it comes to ale.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Lease

title: Ford gears up hybrid lineup
Briefly: War critic complains after police halt rally
World Briefing | Middle East: Hariri Inquiry Moves To Syria
description: In a heavily guarded motorcade with helicopters overhead, Detlev Mehlis, the head of a United Nations inquiry into the Beirut car bombing that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in February, crossed the Lebanon-Syria border to begin interrogating Syrian officials. He is expected to interview Ghazi Kanaan, the interior minister who until 2002 was the chief of Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon, and Rustum Ghazali, his successor.

title: It isn't easy being a genius
Schools in Norfolk, Va., Get $500,000 Prize for Student Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - The public schools in Norfolk, Va., which over the last seven years have steadily narrowed a wide gap between white and black students in reading and mathematics scores, have won this year's Broad Prize, a $500,000 award to the urban school district making the greatest strides in student achievement.

title: Lennar Corporation Beats 2nd Quarter Estimates
description: The Lennar Corporation, one of the nation's largest home builders, said yesterday that it earned more than $2 a share in its fiscal third quarter, more than analysts had estimated, as the housing market expanded at a record pace. It will release its earnings next week.

title: Mets Put Crimp in Marlins' Wild-Card Push With 12th-Inning Rally
description: Manager Willie Randolph scrunched his lips toward his nose. He squinted. He shook his head dismissively. He shifted in his chair.

title: Picking a Guitarist, Fluent in Monk and More
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - The organizers of the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition compare it to the Van Cliburn and Tchaikovsky competitions, appropriately lofty benchmarks for what is heralded as America's classical music. The other useful parallel, "American Idol," goes as tactfully unacknowledged as an elephant in the room.

title: Unswayed by Storm, Fed Raises Key Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Saying that Hurricane Katrina was unlikely to pose a "persistent threat" to the economy, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates on Tuesday for the 11th time in a row and signaled that more increases were on the way.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some copies on Monday, with a sports article about the Carolina Panthers' victory over the New England Patriots, was published in error. It showed Stephen Davis, a running back for the Panthers, in their season opener against the New Orleans Saints. (In the correct picture, Chad Brown of the Patriots -- No. 98 -- is trying to tackle Davis.)

title: Briefly: Dutch stock-sale duty to vanish
Briefs: Gazprom confirms Sibneft talks
Dictators without borders, The other stalemate
Roundup: Woods is set to get his pairing for Cup
Democrats Say Relief Effort Needs Independent Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Congressional Democrats said on Tuesday that the arrest of a former senior White House budget official involved in organizing the federal response to Hurricane Katrina demonstrated the need for an independent investigation of the government's reaction to the disaster, especially since the official is married to a leading Republican Congressional aide.

title: Singing Into the New Orleans Night
description: Correction Appended

description: To the Editor:

title: Cycling: Question of synergy - Championships draw top riders
People: Norman Mailer, Madonna, Kirstie Alley
Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, PATRICIA
description: FRIEDLANDER--Patricia. On September 19. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Loving Mother of Patricia Schumaecker, Scott, Chris & Tom Friedlander. Sister of Elizabeth Pautz. Also survived by eight grandchildren & two great-grandchildren.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (4) THE APPRENTICE: MARTHA STEWART -- Series premiere. In this spinoff from Donald Trump's series, Ms. Stewart (right) welcomes 16 job candidates and sets them to work on a children's book. One team goes wild with the story line. The other surrenders all to a focus group.

title: A Top Lieutenant of Lord Black Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charge
description: A former Chicago Sun-Times publisher pleaded guilty to a federal fraud charge yesterday and agreed to cooperate with a Justice Department investigation of Conrad M. Black, his former boss at Hollinger International.

title: Rare Bottles, Chosen by a Sommelier
description: Jean-Luc Le D, who left his job as sommelier at Daniel at the end of last year, has opened a wine shop, Le D's Wines, 600 Washington Street (Morton Street), in Greenwich Village, (212)924-6999. It's a simple but spacious shop, temperature-controlled, with dark wood racks and bins for what Mr. Le D said are about 600 labels, many from small, artisanal producers. Prices run from about $7 to "the sky's the limit," he said. There are hard-to-get wines, like Peter Michael from California, and a large assortment of sakes.

title: Sheffield Provides Power as Yanks Tread Water
description: This was why the Yankees kept playing Gary Sheffield. When their pitching fell apart last night, it took a sensational effort by Sheffield to save them.

title: Man Accused of Suffocating His Half Sister
description: Prosecutors told Sima Parsy yesterday that it was her son who had murdered her daughter last month, and as she sat in a Staten Island courtroom she did not hide her misery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ultimatum From Teachers' Union
description: The New York City teachers' union last night issued an early October deadline for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to offer them a new contract. The current contract expired in May 2003. At a delegates' meeting, the union, the United Federation of Teachers, adopted a resolution calling for both sides to use the recommendations issued by an arbitration panel last week as a framework for a deal. But the delegates said that if the mayor did not offer a pact by early next month, they would hold a vote to authorize a strike, or to endorse Mr. Bloomberg's Democratic challenger, Fernando Ferrer, or both. It is illegal for teachers to strike in New York. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Exploring the Mysterious Aftermath of a Different Hurricane
description: The suspense that ABC had hoped for with "Invasion," its skillful new body-snatcher series, has been undermined by menaces beyond the network's control. In the wake of Hurricane Katrina, the opening episode's terrestrial forms of terror prove far scarier than extraterrestrial ones. An immense hurricane hits South Florida! And oh, yeah, some aliens use it as a shield to invade the United States.

title: Political footwork from Bill T. Jones
Guatemalan Woman Freed After Kidnapping Ordeal
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 20 - A 22-year-old woman from Guatemala was raped and held captive in a motel for 14 hours last weekend by two men, including one who had paid thousands of dollars to have the woman smuggled into the country last year. Jeanine F. Pirro, the district attorney, made the announcement in a news conference here on Tuesday.

title: Admirer of 'Lolita'
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: BUDDAKAN -- The Toronto chef Susur Lee, below right, will be the consultant at the New York branch of Stephen Starr's restaurant Buddakan. Mr. Lee, a native of Hong Kong, worked in France and Singapore and won acclaim at his hole-in-the-wall in Toronto called Lotus, which closed in 1997, and, since 2000, at the elegant restaurant Susur there. He will be working with Angelo Sosa, formerly of Yumcha, and Michael Schulson. The original Buddakan in Philadelphia is pan-Asian, but the one in the meatpacking district, to open in November, will be more thoroughly Chinese.

title: Tropical storm prompts partial Keys evacuation
Test results of drugs are now online
World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Arrest In Blast At British Embassy
description: A Croatian security guard who was the only person wounded Monday in an explosion at the British Embassy in Zagreb, the capital, was arrested after admitting that he had planted the bomb. Interior Minister Ivica Kirin said the police had ruled out any involvement by a terrorist group but gave no explanation for a motive.

title: Qualcomm bumps up forecast for quarter
Pentagon Bars Military Officers and Analysts From Testifying
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - The Pentagon said Tuesday that it had blocked several military officers and intelligence analysts from testifying at an open Congressional hearing about a highly classified intelligence program that, the officers have said, identified a ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks as a potential terrorist a year before the attacks.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: City Charges Woman Who Posed As Evacuee
description: A 43-year-old woman was charged with defrauding the City of Mason and St. Vincent's Catholic Charities by falsely claiming to be a hurricane evacuee and accepting charity. The police said the woman, Kim Horn, arrived in Mason more than a week before Hurricane Katrina hit. Ms. Horn, of Leesville, La., is charged with larceny by fraud. She received assistance and a house with reduced rent after claiming to be an evacuee, said Martin Colburn, the city manager for Mason, 15 miles south of Lansing. Ms. Horn could face five years in prison if convicted. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERN, JOEL S.
description: KERN--Joel S. Funeral Service on Thursday September 22 at 1PM at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua, New York.

title: Bonds Testifies With His Bat, Only With His Bat
description: WASHINGTON - THE scent of persecution acts as smelling salts for Barry Bonds. He is never more wired than when put down, never more alert than when doubted, never more defiant than when booed.

title: Tesco's profit jumps, but share price slips
Canine flu worries U.S. dog owners
Auto Workers And Chrysler Reach Deal In Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 20 - Reflecting the struggling state of North American automakers, the Canadian Auto Workers reached a tentative agreement with DaimlerChrysler Canada early Tuesday that eliminates about 1,600 jobs and offers only limited wage and benefit gains.

title: European Commission Shortens Time That Phone and Internet Records Must Be Kept
description: Seeking to break a four-year impasse, the European Commission offered a compromise on anti-terrorist legislation yesterday that would require telephone network operators and Internet service providers to keep records of phone calls and Internet traffic for a shorter amount of time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GERSON, IVAN D.
description: GERSON--Ivan D. "A unique man." You are gone so long, we miss you so, dear Ivan. Hugs, Mom, Dad and Adrienne.

title: They Sang Bach, So Who Needs a Debate?
description: It wasn't broke, exactly, but you can't really blame Carnegie Hall for tinkering with its annual choral workshop. Through most of the 1990's -- when the founding director, Robert Shaw, was still around to preside -- the public performance that crowned the event was often a highlight of the New York season. In recent years, with mixed leadership, the results, too, have been mixed, producing few revelations.

description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Sept. 18 - Richard Scruggs picked his way through the ruins of his once-handsome four-bedroom home, no more than 50 yards from the edge of the Gulf of Mexico.

Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about the campaign for a New York City Council seat in East Harlem misstated the margin by which the incumbent, Philip Reed, defeated Felipe Luciano, his Democratic primary opponent, in 2001. It was about 1,000 votes, not 200. This correction was delayed by a reporting lapse.

description: The Response of the Press: The Press Responds

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Researchers File For Biotech Grants
description: Almost 100 biotechnology companies and research institutions have filed letters with New Jersey's Commission on Science and Technology saying they plan to apply for grants to do stem cell research, the commission said yesterday. They will be competing for $5 million in grants of up to $300,000 each. The grants are part of the state's bid, led by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, to become a major stem cell research center. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Iraq may be years from returning to peak oil output, ex-minister says
Locations: Melting Woks
description: Chinese Mirch (Chinese-Indian), 120 Lexington Avenue (28th Street); (212) 532-3663.

title: Canadian auto workers agree to more job cuts
Orange focuses on business users
Arts, Briefly
description: Poet Rebuffs Laura Bush

title: Putting the Shimmy Back on Bourbon Street
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 - Three weeks ago, Britni Carrubea escaped Hurricane Katrina "with nothing but the clothes on my back." Now, she is back at work on what was the only operating stage on Bourbon Street, without the clothes on her back.

title: As Game Goes Global, Presidents Cup Comes of Age
description: GAINESVILLE, Va., Sept. 20 - Two days before the start of competition at the Presidents Cup, a caravan of American players raced a caravan of International players through streets and suburbs named for Civil War trails.

title: INSIDE
description: New Warning From Iran Over the Nuclear Issue Iran's chief nuclear negotiator warned that the country would resume enriching uranium and restrict United Nations inspectors from critical information if the United States and its allies referred Iran to the Security Council over its nuclear program.

title: Avidly Seeking Wireless Clues From Google
description: Google, with deep pockets and seemingly boundless ambition, keeps marching steadily beyond Internet searching into new markets like e-mail, advertising, book searches, a satellite map service, instant messaging and telephony. Where next?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about refugees from foreign countries who empathize with the plight of victims of Hurricane Katrina misstated the title of Judy Rogers of Nah We Yone, a nonprofit agency in New York that helps African immigrants. She is executive director, not a co-director.

title: A son's new convictions, and an academic's lack of them
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Stelco Shares Drop on Restructuring Plan
description: Shares of Stelco, an insolvent Canadian steel maker, plunged 62 percent after an agreement was reached on a restructuring plan that would result in the cancellation of company stock. The stock closed at 28 Canadian cents. An agreement was reached with the province of Ontario on employee pension contributions, Stelco said. The company, which is still negotiating with bondholders, said the province would invest 100 million Canadian dollars ($85.4 million) in the plan and make fixed payments through 2015. Stelco, based in Hamilton, Ontario, agreed to increase its upfront contribution to 400 million Canadian dollars, from 200 million Canadian dollars. "There is insufficient value to provide recovery to existing shareholders," the company said. "The existing shares will be effectively canceled."

title: Presenting Political Boss as Manager of Details
description: The ghosts of past political bosses hang like stale cigar smoke over the gleaming new state courtroom in Brooklyn where Clarence Norman Jr., the Democratic county leader, heir to long and fabled lines of political power brokers, is charged with violating campaign finance laws.

title: Avon Cuts Its Earnings Forecast
description: Shares of Avon Products fell yesterday after the company cut its 2005 earnings forecast late Tuesday. Shares of Avon fell $3.60, or 12 percent, to $27, below the previous 52-week low of $30.50 set on Tuesday.

title: Move to Reinstate Multiple Sclerosis Drug
description: Biogen Idec Inc. and the Elan Corporation said yesterday that they would seek federal regulatory approval to resume sales of the withdrawn Tysabri drug for multiple sclerosis.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the Red Cross response to Hurricane Katrina misspelled the given name of the organization's vice president for response operations, who said that for safety's sake shelters were not opened in flood-prone areas. He is Armond T. Mascelli, not Armand. (Go to Article)

title: In Bush's Trail, Scarred Ground
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - When people refer to battlegrounds in presidential races, they are usually not thinking of airport runways. But those people probably have not heard of Runway 4/22 at the airport in Las Cruces, N.M.

title: Recipe: Red Pepper Soup
description: Total time: 45 minutes

title: U.S. to Inspect Small Leak From Fuel Pool at Indian Point
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced yesterday that it was inspecting a small radioactive leak from a spent-fuel pool at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in northern Westchester County.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Outsize Treats Without the Calories
description: An indulgent fantasy is translated into realistic but oversize sculpture in a new exhibit, "How Sweet It Is!," at Hammer Galleries, 33 West 57th Street, (212)644-4400. Boxes of chocolates, danish and ice cream pops are rendered as giant sculptures by Peter Anton, using wood, wire, paint and plaster. Mr. Anton, whose works are always inspired by food, interjects a touch of whimsy. Some of the chocolates in the boxes are missing or have been nibbled, with evident tooth marks. The ice cream pops are half-eaten. The sculptures will be on display through Oct. 8. FOOD STUFF

title: Katrina, the Mississippi River and the Risks of the Coming Harvest
description: In 1953, a young documentary filmmaker named Charles Dee Sharp traveled down the Mississippi River, shooting still photographs for a film he never made. One of Sharp's pictures -- recently published by the Center for American Places in a book called "The Mississippi River in 1953" -- is a color shot of rows of new red cornpickers awaiting shipment in Moline, Ill. Behind them the surface of the river looks like a sheet of mercury. Those cornpickers, long since antiquated, could harvest only two rows of corn -- in the cob -- at a time. They were scaled to much smaller farms and lower yields than you find in the Midwest these days, where fields are now harvested by enormous combines that shell the corn as they pick it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JABLON, FLORENCE R.
description: JABLON--Florence R. of South Palm Beach, FL, died peacefully at home on September 5, 2005 surrounded by her children, Judy, Peter, Marc, and Jill. She will be remembered as a vibrant woman, devoted wife of the late Sydney, proud and supportive mother to her four children and their spouses, loving grandmother to Jessica, Julie, Adam, Johanna, Jonathan, and Stephanie, and loyal friend to many. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., W. Palm Beach, FL 33407.

title: Tests find avian flu can't spread easily
World Briefing | Europe: France: Cash Incentives To Have Third Babies
description: France, which has a birthrate of 1.9 children per couple, among the highest in Europe, plans to announce benefits this week to encourage families to have children, including an increased monthly grant for women who take time off from work to have a third child.

title: Attacks in Iraq Kill 9 Americans, Including State Dept. Aide
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 20 - In one of the most lethal stretches for Americans in Iraq in recent months, nine soldiers and security officers were killed in four attacks in the past two days.

title: I.M.F. Cites U.S. Debt in Dangerous Global Imbalances
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The United States is posed for slower growth next year, and its rapidly rising foreign indebtedness is at the heart of dangerous global imbalances, the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: Surfing France's annual avalanche of books
Paid Notice: Deaths   DREYER, HARVEY
description: DREYER--Harvey. Extraordinary husband of 58 years to Doris, loving father of Susan (Paul) Harris, Marcie (Peter) Maynard and Ellen (Jim) Yanda, doting grandpa of Laura, Melanie, Hilary, Marielle and Aaron. Survived by brother, Len Goldreyer, inlaws, Muriel and Sam Zuckerman. Lived 82 wonderful years full of love and laughter. A deeply kind, thoughtful and caring man to family, friends and all mankind. Services Thursday, September 22, 10 AM, Plaza Chapels, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Remember Me? We Were So Close About 15 Minutes Ago . . .
description: Sleek, attractive and ultimately vapid, "Novo" applies to sex and love the concept of short-term memory loss used to such acute dramatic effect in Christopher Nolan's "Memento." Eduardo Noriega, a handsome Spanish actor with puppy-dog eyes, is Graham, a photocopy worker at an anonymous corporation who is afflicted with a severe memory disorder after an accident. Because he can't remember what he was doing 15 minutes earlier, each time he makes love to a woman it is "the first time."

title: Abortion in the Lives of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Flow: Rail freight: Europe's challenge
Paid Notice: Deaths   WIESENTHAL, SIMON
description: WIESENTHAL--Simon. The Anti - Defamation League mourns the passing of Simon Wiesenthal, a hero in the fight to bring justice to the millions of Holocaust victims and an impassioned voice of conscience against anti-Semitism and all forms of prejudice. A 1988 recipient of ADL's Jabotinsky Award for "courageous leadership," his life, which epitomized the Biblical injunction, "Remember, do not forget," is his legacy to all of us. Barbara B. Balser National Chair Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Trying to Resurrect the Body of a City Buried in Sludge and History
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 - There were military and police vehicles on the ground and enough helicopters to wear grooves in the sky, all of them run by men and women seeking to secure this city's present and future. Amid them moved an unlikely caravan of people seeking to preserve its past.

title: Indians Got It Together When Hafner Returned
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 - The pitch from Chicago's Mark Buehrle that hit Cleveland's Travis Hafner in the face July 16 was one that got away, an 86-mile-an-hour sinker that did not sink much as it neared home plate.

title: Yahoo's mess of pottage
EU closes in on talks for Turkey
Mark Bittman
description: The author of the Minimalist column and the new book, "The Best Recipes in the World," is answering reader questions on cooking global cuisine.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Israeli Envoy Leads Assembly Session
description: Dan Gillerman, Israel's ambassador to the United Nations, became the first Israeli since Abba Eban 52 years ago to preside over the General Assembly when he took the president's chair to introduce the Israeli foreign minister, Silvan Shalom. Mr. Gillerman was elected one of the Assembly's 21 vice presidents this year as a delegate from the regional bloc that Israel belongs to, the West European and other states group, which also includes Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United States. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Design Shortcomings Seen in New Orleans Flood Walls
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 - Along the Mississippi River and Lake Pontchartrain, great earthen levees were ample to hold off much of the surging water propelled by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Heat Is On for Baseball to Toughen Drug Policy
description: Almost five months after Commissioner Bud Selig sent a letter to the players union detailing a plan for a stricter policy on performance-enhancing substances in Major League Baseball, he is still waiting for a formal response.

title: Northern Exposure
description: AFTER receiving copious amounts of food aid for 10 years, North Korea has asked the United Nations and other relief agencies to close their Pyongyang offices and withdraw their monitors by the end of the year. Such hostility may seem strange from a country whose citizens are starving. But in fact the reasoning is obvious: the more contact the relief agencies' monitors have with North Korean citizens, the more information on the country's human rights situation might leak to the outside world. What is not obvious, however, is why the South Korean government -- which also provides food aid -- is abetting North Korea's shameless attempt to mask its crimes.

title: Codey Plans Stricter Limits on Smoking
description: NEWARK, Sept. 20 - With its smoky casinos where cigarettes are more common than jackpots, New Jersey has found tobacco a difficult habit to kick. Efforts to outlaw smoking indoors have stalled in the State Legislature for years, even as New York and other states have made such bans commonplace.

title: Shares Fall After the Fed Says Rate Increases Will Go On
description: Stocks erased a rally and continued sliding yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate for the 11th consecutive time and indicated that its "measured" pace of increases would persist despite the economic damage of Hurricane Katrina.

title: EU closing in on talksfor Turkish membership
Celebrity: Hollywood, seen through the smoke
Intel to Offer Chips to Save Battery Power
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 - The Intel Corporation, the largest semiconductor maker, announced on Tuesday a new manufacturing process to make chips for cellphones and other mobile devices that use far less power than is currently possible, thus helping extend battery life.

title: Germany and the Battle for Reform
description: The big news from Germany's elections on Sunday was what did not happen: Angela Merkel, the right-wing candidate who had a free fall from a 20-point lead, did not become the first woman chancellor. The incumbent, Gerhard Schrder, was not driven into retirement, as his opponents had hoped. And Germans did not give either a governing majority. Still, they delivered a message: economic reform should move forward. The three parties that support reforms got 80 percent of the vote. All they have to do is agree on how to govern.

title: Goldman Posts 84% Gain in 3rd Quarter
description: The Goldman Sachs Group reported an 84 percent gain in third quarter earnings yesterday, driven by significant gains in stock and bond trading as well a surge in revenue for services offered to hedge funds.

title: Deep Flaws, and Little Justice, in China's Court System
description: ANYANG, China - For three days and three nights, the police wrenched Qin Yanhong's arms high above his back, jammed his knees into a sharp metal frame, and kicked his gut whenever he fell asleep. The pain was so intense that he watched sweat pour off his face and form puddles on the floor.

title: New Orleans watches the skies
Manila issues warning on anti-Arroyo protests
World Business Briefing | Europe: Violation of W.T.O. Sugar Ruling Is Seen
description: Australia, Brazil and Thailand accused the European Union of planning to increase sugar shipments, in defiance of a World Trade Organization ruling that the bloc illegally subsidizes such exports. The European Union may start selling as much as two million metric tons of surplus sugar without export aid as early as October to avoid adding to its stockpile, the three governments said. That would raise the bloc's annual sugar exports to 7.2 million metric tons, or 7.9 million short tons, compared with an average 5 million metric tons, or 5.5 million short tons. Under W.T.O. rules, the European Union is entitled to export no more than 1.273 million metric tons of sugar with aid to compensate for a lower price on the world market.

title: In the name of the car
Craving Hyphenated Chinese
description: NEW YORKERS always think they know the real thing when it comes to Chinese food. Forty years ago it was egg rolls, chop suey and drinks with paper umbrellas. Then it was General Tso's chicken and sesame noodles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAUNDERS, LEROY N.
description: SAUNDERS--Leroy N., retired NYPD, formerly of Durham, N.C., on September 18. Survived by his wife Marion, and children Richard, James, Allison, Oscar and Meena, mother Irene Sanders, three sisters, four brothers, two grandchildren. Memorial service: Friday, September 30, 2:30PM at the UN Chapel, 777 UN Plaza at 44 St. Memorial gifts: Boys & Girls Harbor, 1 E. 104 St, NY, NY 10029.

title: Bush's Waterlogged Halo
description: Following President Bush's speech in New Orleans, many U.S. papers carried the same basic headline: "Bush Rules Out Raising Taxes for Gulf Relief." The president is planning to rely on "spending cuts" instead to pay for rebuilding New Orleans. Yeah, right -- and if you believe that, I have some beachfront property in Biloxi I'd like to sell you. The underlying message of all these stories is that the Bush team sees no reason to change course in response to Katrina.

title: Poet Rebuffs Laura Bush
description: Protesting the war in Iraq, the poet Sharon Olds, winnerof a National Book Critics Circle Award and professorof writing at New YorkUniversity, has rebuffed an invitationfrom Laura Bush, the first lady, to attend thefifth National Book Festival onthe National Mall in Washingtonon Saturday. Noting thatthe event, sponsored by the Libraryof Congress, includes adinner at the library and abreakfast at the White House,Ms. Olds, in a letter on the Website of The Nation (thenation.com/doc/20051010/olds), saidshe found the invitation appealing."But I could not facethe idea of breaking bread with you," she wrote in a letterto Mrs. Bush. "I knew that if I sat down to eat with you, itwould feel to me as if I were condoning what I see to bethe wild, highhanded actions of the Bush administration.. . . So many Americans who had felt pride in our countrynow feel anguish and shame, for the current regime ofblood, wounds and fire. I thought of the clean linens atyour table, the shining knives and the flames of the candles,and I could not stomach it."

title: An Antiques Haven Updates Itself
description: Hudson, N.Y. - For the last 20 years, this city, about two hours up the Hudson River from Manhattan, has been known as a thriving antiques center. At its peak, it was home to as many as 70 dealers selling just about any category of good old things.

title: In-flight cellphone use to be tested on 2 airlines
Past of Democrat in Forrester Ad Is Attacked
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20 - State Democratic officials said on Tuesday that one of the Democrats appearing in an anticorruption commercial for the Republican candidate for governor, Douglas R. Forrester, was fired as a court clerk in Essex County after being accused of stealing money from court deposits and was, for a time, a Republican.

title: The crime and the time
A trigger for asthma: It's all in the dust
Museum Names New York Director
description: Correction Appended

title: When the Landlord Is Muslim
description: As rising crude oil prices leave many Middle Easterners flush with cash, much of their money is being invested in real estate, both in the United States and abroad.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about the start of a civil trial to determine whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is liable for the deaths and injuries suffered in the 1993 terrorist bombing at the World Trade Center misstated the date of the attack. It was Feb. 26, not 23.

title: Norman Mailer Receives National Book Medal
description: Correction Appended

title: OPEC Drops Cartel Role and Says Pump All You Can
description: VIENNA, Sept. 20 - Oil prices slipped Tuesday on signs that the direction of Hurricane Rita was shifting away from America's energy heartland and OPEC formally agreed to lift all restrictions on its oil sales for the next three months, in a move aimed at further reassuring markets still on edge over the security of energy supplies.

title: With Information on Bodies Hard to Come By, Relatives of Victims Wait in Anguish
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 20 - The worst part is the images they cannot blot out. A sister, trapped in rising water without an ax. A brother's body left in a bathtub by the road in hopes that it would not be overlooked. A father, blind and lame, struggling to swim in a flooding nursing home. An old woman, alone with her cats.

title: Briefly: Court muffles challenge to antiterrorism act
Yushchenko hit again with political setbacks
Opponents Share Hour of Unkind Words
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20 - Displaying the kind of zest that has often been missing on the campaign trail, Douglas R. Forrester and Senator Jon S. Corzine attacked each other over property taxes, ethics and their records on Tuesday night in the first debate between the two men who want to be New Jersey's next governor.

description: HOENE--Burkhard In memory of Burkhard Hoene. Though a year has passed, we still miss you more than words can ever say...and we remember the good times. Brian, Lavinia and Ophelia

Paid Notice: Deaths   LEIDERMAN, HOWARD
description: LEIDERMAN - Howard. 60, on September 20, 2005 after a courageous battle with brain cancer. Beloved, wonderful husband of Ronni. Devoted father of Alissa and Darren. Father-in-law of Howard and Marni. Loving grandfather to Sarah, Aaron, Hayden and Avery and step-dad to Nora, and Sara. A brilliant, accomplished artist and illustrator, Howard was an uncannily funny man, a non-comformist who knew how to get joy out of life. He saw the glass half full and ran with it. Howard you led us all; you are irreplaceable. We love and miss you already. Services Wednesday, 11:00 AM, Temple Beth-El in Great Neck.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I'm not too sure if his heart is as big as his head."

title: At Least Some Can Wake Up and Smell Coffee in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 - Ever since Hurricane Katrina uprooted his family, his home and his daily routine, Larry Zehnder, a quality assurance manager at the Folgers coffee plant here, has been missing a familiar smell. But this week, as dozens of coffee cans rolled off a partly restored production line, the aroma of fresh roasted beans reassured him that a recovery was on the way.

title: New Orleans's Heart Beats Strongly in New York
description: On a typical night in New Orleans, Clarence Frogman Henry could be heard in a Bourbon Street club singing his 1956 hit, the one where he proves he can sing like a girl or a frog. On Tuesday night, Mr. Henry cooed and croaked it at Madison Square Garden, and suddenly there was poignancy in the songAs title: AAinAt Got No Home.A

title: Jets' Martin Expects to Play
description: Jets running back Curtis Martin should be ready to play Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars. A magnetic resonance imaging examination of Martin's right knee was negative.

title: Telethon Raises $5 Million
description: Fans watching the National Football League telethon for Gulf Coast hurricane relief Monday night pledged $5 million to the Bush-Clinton Katrina Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGELSTEIN, CHARLES
description: VOGELSTEIN--Charles. Died September 14, 2005 at the age of 79. Widower of Norma, beloved father of Lynn, brother of Henry and Susan Vogelstein and Stanley Weiss, father-in-law of John Foster, devoted uncle of Steven and Barbara Vogelstein, David Vogelstein and Vivian Sherman, Andrew and Francesca Weiss, and dear friend of Frances Cave and the Habachy family. Born in Hamburg, Germany in 1925, Charles emigrated with his family to the United States in 1939 and worked as a mens wear and textile designer before entering the Columbia University School of Architecture. Following graduation, Charles worked as an architect for more than 40 years, principally as a partner with the firm of Oppenheimer, Brady & Vogelstein. Charles was committed to peace, equality, and social justice. We will miss his sweet smile, unconditional love, and quiet strength. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 9, 2005, at 2pm at The NY Society for Ethical Culture located at 2 West 64th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Manhattan Country School, 7 E. 96th St., NY, NY 10128; Planned Parenthood of NYC, 26 Bleecker St., NY, NY 10012; or The Association for Help to Retarded Children-NYC Foundation, 200 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10003.

Times Company Announces 500 Job Cuts
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it would cut its work force by 500 employees, including 45 in The Times's newsroom and 35 in the newsroom of The Boston Globe.

title: War Protesters Ask Jurors to Heed Their Consciences
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 20 - Four left-wing Catholic war protesters who threw vials of blood inside a military recruiting center to object to the impending United States invasion of Iraq in 2003 likened their actions to those of historic figures like Susan B. Anthony and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Arts, Briefly; Networks Vie for Eyes
description: Monday was the official start of the fall television season, and, as expected, "Monday Night Football" brought ABC a victory in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. But of greater significance is reaction to the networks' new scripted offerings. CBS placed second in Nielsen's estimates, but its overall schedule was down in comparison with last year, when "Everybody Loves Raymond" anchored the 9 p.m. hour. "Two and a Half Men," now in that "Raymond" slot, drew 15.23 million viewers; one year ago, "Raymond" brought in more (17.99 million). In the new lineup, the debut of the series "How I Met Your Mother" delivered an audience of 10.65 million, and that of "Out of Practice" 13.39 million. And though "CSI: Miami" was significantly down from its 2004 premiere, it was the most-watched program of the night, with 18.61 million viewers. Against heavy competition, NBC was the No.3 network, with solid sampling of its three one-hour shows. The premiere of "Surface," which features inscrutable sea creatures, attracted 10.9 million viewers and beat CBS in the 8 p.m. hour among 18-to-49-year-olds. "Las Vegas" (12.41 million) and "Medium" (12.45 million) also held up well for NBC. But the news for Fox was not good. Though "Prison Break" continued to perform well, with 7.81 million viewers, the premiere of "Kitchen Confidential" brought in only 4.32 million. And one night after winning an Emmy for comedy writing, "Arrested Development" drew 4.58 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNLAVY, FRANCINE ALESSI
description: DUNLAVY--Francine Alessi, 95, died 29 January 2005. A talented linguist and teacher, she was preceded in death by her husband, Alfred R. Dunlavy, and is survived by a daughter and son-in-law, Patricia and Peter Valenti; grandson, Marco Valenti; granddaughter and grandson-in-law, Christine and Justin Shreve. Burial service 22 September at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY, at 10:00 am.

title: Glaxo settles in fraud case
A Perky Warrior Singing the Pentagon Blues
description: Throughout the chest-pounding, inept new NBC series "E-Ring," Benjamin Bratt must run around the Pentagon like Theseus in the labyrinth. "Hey, fellas!" he says, by way of salute to passengers on an up escalator that he's running down. "How's it hangin', fellas?" he later asks a collection of men with far more stars and bars than he.

title: Bait and Switch
Kate Moss Is Dismissed by H&M After a Furor Over Cocaine
description: In a move with little precedent in the fashion industry, Kate Moss, one of the world's most recognizable models, was dismissed from a planned advertising campaign yesterday after executives said she had admitted to recently using cocaine.

title: Residents Leave Gulf Coast Area as Storm Grows
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 - Hurricane Rita brushed past Key West on Tuesday and was forecast to strengthen into a major hurricane later in the week, prompting residents and rescuers to begin evacuating this feeble city, as well as parts of Louisiana and Texas.

title: Turning African Danger Into Safe Entertainment
description: Hollywood has a formula, not foolproof but entrenched, for turning a political message into a commercial film: take a likable hero, add a romance, then telegraph an unobjectionable idea, something like, "Let's feed starving children." Lately, a new twist has been added: latch on to Africa. The subject may be arms dealing in Liberia, as in the new Nicolas Cage movie, "Lord of War"; big, bad drug companies in Kenya, as in the current "Constant Gardener "; or the dictatorship of the fictional not-quite-Zimbabwe that Nicole Kidman's character flees in the recent flop "The Interpreter." But the common strategy in these and several other films is to take a hot-button African issue and spin it into easy-to-swallow entertainment. Fleeing from the truly political and divisive ground of "Fahrenheit 9/11," these movies begin with safe opinions, then sugar-coat them.

title: Premier Rejected in Ukraine; Political Stalemate Hardens
description: Correction Appended

title: Old Cuisines Pair With Big Names
description: TWO cuisines that were underrepresented in the bumper crop of restaurants to open in coming months were Chinese and Spanish. But a couple of prominent restaurateurs and a big-name chef are making up for it.

A Storm Survivor, Political Reputation Intact
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 20 - Hurricane Katrina has given the nation a new political celebrity, the mayor of beleaguered New Orleans. And like they say with pride here about most everything, Mayor C. Ray Nagin is just plain different.

title: Thousands flee storm aiming at Texas coast
Lost Love, Lost Time and the Guest Metaphysician
description: Who's married and who's divorced. Who has kids and how many. Are you still in touch with the old gang? The chatter that perfumes the air in "The Pavilion," Craig Wright's play about time's winged chariot and the dreams it grinds into dust, is largely what you would expect at a small-town high school reunion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOGAN, HARRY
description: MOGAN--Harry. Of White Plains, N.Y. Died on Monday, September 19, 2005. He was 85 years old. Harry was born on February 6, 1920 in Vienna, Austria, and served in the U.S. Army overseas during World War II. Beloved husband of Marietta, loving father of James and Dr. Glen Mogan and Lynn Cesaria, dear father-in-law of Claire and Diane, caring grandfather of Jacqueline, Jeffrey; Grant, Craig, Douglas; Bradley, Caroline and Jesse. Great-grandfather of Isaac. Service Wednesday September 21, 2005, 11AM at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made in the name of Harry Mogan to UJA.

Paid Notice: Memorials   TANNOR, SOLOMON
description: TANNOR--Solomon. Hadassah, The Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. mourns the passing of Solomon Tannor, beloved husband of Norma, of blessed memory, cherished father of Merrill, Robert and Erica, Evan and Ilene and loving grandfather of Amanda, Samantha, Bradley, Jaymie and Cole. As a Guardian of Life, Sol was a generous benefactor of Hadassah, devoted to Israel and the Jewish people. His legacy will live on through the programs he supported at the Hadassah Medical Organization. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. June Walker, National President

title: German Rock Meets Underground Hip-Hop
description: Two pop fringes intertwine in 13 & God, the group that headlined Irving Plaza on Monday night. It's an alliance between the Notwist -- a German band that started out playing punk, turned to electronica, and now mingles the buzzes and clicks of minimal techno with quietly melodic rock songs -- and the hip-hop group Themselves from the San Francisco Bay Area artists' collective (and label) Anticon, which prizes complex electronic soundscapes and free-associative lyrics.

title: London Bombers Visited Earlier, Apparently on Practice Run
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 - Less than two weeks before they attacked London on July 7, three of the four suicide bombers traveled to the city for what appears to have been a practice run, the police said Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REED, SAMUEL
description: REED--Samuel. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 953 Fifth Avenue Corp mourn the loss of Samuel Reed, a longtime resident and Board member. Mr. Reed passed away on Saturday, September 17, 2005. The Board and shareholders wish to express their sympathy to his family, Annette de La Renta, Beatrice Niven, Eliza Bolen, and Charles Reed. He will be sorely missed by all.

Indonesia Wary but Reassured on Avian Flu Death
description: HONG KONG, Sept.21 - A woman's death from avian influenza in Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, has caused considerable alarm there, but genetic tests performed in Hong Kong on samples of the virus from the woman showed today that it had not yet mutated in ways likely to make it more of a threat to people.

title: French jazzman's life on 2 tracks
A Work Covering Two Stages, With Clouds as a Backdrop
description: For his "Batteryparkevent," Merce Cunningham chose not to use the proscenium stage set up for the companies taking part in the Evening Stars series of free performances in Battery Park last week. Rather, he chose not to use it for dancing. On Friday night, five composers -- Takehisa Kosugi, David Behrman, Marina Rosenfeld, George Lewis and John King -- sat before a table of instruments on the stage as 14 dancers dressed in inky blue body tights filed past them, down stairs and onto two stages placed well apart amid the large and expectant crowd who had braved the forecast rain. (It mostly held off, although the performance -- the company's only New York appearance for the year -- was briefly interrupted to wipe down the stage shortly after the start.)

title: Funk, Blues, and Jams That Were Big and Easy
description: On Tuesday night, Radio City Music Hall played host to one of two hurricane-relief concerts called, "From the Big Apple to the Big Easy." (The other was held simultaneously at Madison Square Garden, and was reviewed by Jon Pareles.) The stars were Dave Matthews, the Neville Brothers, and a dozen more. And the show started as soon as you hit the lobby: jazz wafted down from the mezzanine as concertgoers found ways to look festive (shiny beads) and feel festive (plastic cups).

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Separatist Rebels Gun Down 11 Soldiers
description: In the deadliest such incident in recent months in the country's troubled northeast, at least 11 Indian soldiers were killed and 5 wounded in a rebel ambush in Manipur State, the army said. The soldiers were returning to their base when guerrillas began firing at them from a hilltop about 20 miles from the state capital, Imphal. An ethnic separatist group claimed responsibility.

description: Energy companies stepped up evacuations of offshore platforms and rigs and rushed to secure refineries along the Texas coast today as they braced for Hurricane Rita, which was upgraded to a Category 5 storm this afternoon and is packing winds of 165 miles an hour.

title: Comparing Schizophrenia Drugs
description: A government-financed study has provided the strongest evidence yet that the system for approving and promoting drugs is badly out of whack. The study compared five drugs used to treat schizophrenia and found that most of the newest, most heavily prescribed drugs were no better than an older drug that is far cheaper. The nation is wasting billions of dollars on heavily marketed drugs that have never proved themselves in head-to-head competition against cheaper competitors.

title: Mussina Ready to Pitch, but Rust Might Show
description: Bubba Crosby spent much of yesterday reliving the greatest game of his major league career. In his locker, he had the Yankees' lineup card and a video from Monday's victory over the Baltimore Orioles, which Crosby ended with a home run. He did several interviews and took many congratulatory calls from friends and family.
