title: Ah, I Remember It Well, at 95
description: No one knows better than Kitty Carlisle Hart that the golden age of "American musical thea-tah," as cultural grande dames are wont to call it, was peopled with dreamers and madmen as driven, ambitious and unstable in their way as subsequent generations of rockers and hip-hoppers. She knew them all.

title: A Boy Grows in Brooklyn, With a Voice-Over
description: Comedians are angry people. Everybody knows that. And that is why "Everybody Hates Chris" on UPN is such a surprise. Chris Rock's new series, a memoir that he narrates, paints an affectionately wry portrait of a 13-year-old growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn.

title: Inviting the Past to Your Doors
description: HARDWARE can be the great finishing touch in a renovation project, and for homeowners who are restoring an old house or apartment, the right touch is often a period knob, hinge or door knocker. Charles Lockwood, author of "Bricks and Brownstone" (Rizzoli, 2003) and a specialist in restoration, pointed out that "19th-century New Yorkers were very proud of their hardware" -- all the more reason to seek out the right replacements, whether originals or reproductions. But a house does not have to be old to be flattered by a period piece. Vintage hardware can also enrich a modern white box.

title: William S. Bartman, 58, Art Patron, Is Dead
description: William S. Bartman, an art patron and the founder of a nonprofit publishing company and exhibition space, died last Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 and a Manhattan resident.

title: Closer... Closer... Whoa! That's Plenty Close Enough
description: While easily stowable digital cameras have become as popular as cellphones, the zoom abilities of most have not improved much over time. The new Coolpix S4 from Nikon is different. At just 4.4 inches wide and 1.4 inches thick, this stylish six-megapixel camera -- with a swiveling lens that shoots with 35-millimeter quality -- is small enough to carry in your pocket. And its 10x optical zoom can amplify subjects more than three times as much as any other camera in its class, making it ideal for amateur paparazzi or parents at school sports events.

title: The New Orleans Shotgun: Down but Not Out
description: Correction Appended

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Giant Ape Climbed Here. And She Was Why.
description: IT is a silent tribute to the beauty who screamed her way to fame in the clutches of a giant gorilla in love, created by a fan who collected stacks of movie memorabilia.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (9) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- "Everyone Hates the Pilot." The comedian Chris Rock narrates this new sitcom about Chris Rock, an adolescent in Brooklyn in the 1980's. The series premiere is set on the first day of school, during which Chris (Tyler James Williams, right) has to deal with a bully and makes a new friend.

title: Vatican to ban gays seeking priesthood
Warnings of decline in growth within EU
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: In an Oil Squeeze, Attention to the Alternatives
description: The steady climb in oil prices, followed by Hurricane Katrina's disruption of the petroleum markets, has forced a 1970's mood of sobriety on American consumers. With gasoline at the pump hovering around $2.80 a gallon in much of the country, energy conservation is back in vogue, and the small businesses that dominate the renewable-energy industry are on a bit of a roll.

title: Everything Is Everything (Then There's Mother and the Birds)
description: Philadanco commissioned three works for its 35th anniversary. One of them, thankfully, was by Ronald K. Brown. His "For Mother" saved this Philadelphia repertory company's program Tuesday night, when it opened the Joyce Theater's fall season.

title: INSIDE
description: Splitting With Leader, Democrat Backs Roberts Democratic divisions over Judge John G. Roberts Jr. spilled out into the open as the senior Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, said that he would vote to confirm Judge Roberts as chief justice, putting himself at odds with the Democratic leader, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada. PAGE A22

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a recipe with the Fall Cook column in the Dining section yesterday, for Plum Crumble, misstated the number of plums to be used in Step 2. It is 12, not 2. A corrected recipe will appear in the section on Wednesday.

title: Tenure, Turnover and the Quality of Teaching
description: TEACHER quality has become a highly politicized issue. In November, Californians will vote on Proposition 74, which weakens tenure rules for kindergarten through 12th-grade teachers. Not surprisingly, Republicans and Democrats are lined up on opposite sides of the issue, with debate focusing on the impact of the proposition on teacher quality.

title: Tacky Track Lighting
description: Q. My rental apartment has tacky track lights. I don't want to rip them out, but I'd like to replace the fixtures. What can you suggest?

title: Committee's Top Democrat Will Vote Yes on Roberts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Democratic divisions over Judge John G. Roberts Jr. spilled out into the open on Wednesday, when the senior Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee announced he would vote to confirm Judge Roberts as chief justice, a move that puts him at odds with the Senate's Democratic leader.

title: Lawyer of Ex-Official Sees Coercion in His Arrest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - A lawyer for David H. Safavian, the former White House budget official arrested this week, accused the Justice Department on Wednesday of trying to coerce Mr. Safavian into cooperating with a criminal investigation of Jack Abramoff, the once-powerful Washington lobbyist.

title: Kidnapped Soccer Coach Rescued in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 21 - The federal police on Wednesday rescued Rben Omar Romano, the coach of one of Mexico's most popular soccer teams, who was kidnapped two months ago by armed men in broad daylight.

title: Senior Shiite Cleric Plans to Endorse Iraqi Constitution
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 22 - Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, will issue a religious order for Shiites to vote in favor of the newly drafted constitution in a referendum planned for Oct. 15, one of his aides said today.

title: National Briefs
description: WEST

title: A Lion of the Courtroom Hears His Critics Roar
description: David Boies is a star in the courtroom, but his back-office operations are causing some headaches.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HART, SYLVIA ADES
description: HART--Sylvia Ades, September 20, 2005, beloved wife of Walter Hart, Jr. and also the late Reuben Ades. Cherished mother of Jane and Paul Ades, and Diane Leibling. Loving stepmother of Linda Adler and Walter and Diane Hart. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Devoted sister of the late Lillian Schwartz Kraut, aunt and great-aunt. Services Thursday, 1pm, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury NY.

title: Senior Brazil Legislator Quits, Further Weakening President
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21 - The speaker of the lower house of Congress resigned Wednesday in disgrace, the highest-ranking casualty in a widening corruption scandal that has paralyzed Brazil for nearly five months and shows no signs of easing.

title: How to Make a Hotel Room Homey? Take Your Own Wallpaper
description: Personalizing the look and feel of one's PC can make an otherwise impersonal machine feel like home. Why give that up just because you are working in a cybercafe halfway around the world? Some new flash memory drives due out next month will let users transport not just their files, but also programs and even that desktop image of dogs playing cards to another computer.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday and in some late editions on Sunday about Donn Clendenon, a star for the Mets in the 1969 World Series, misstated the inning in which they scored two runs to take a 5-3 lead in Game 5 against the Baltimore Orioles and win the championship. It was the eighth, not the ninth.

title: NATO Reports All 26 Nations Are Aiding Iraq With Training
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 - European countries have overcome their differences with the United States over Iraq, and all 26 members of NATO now provide training and equipment to Baghdad, the secretary general of the group said this week.

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: Skin Deep; When It's Hair, You Can Be Too Thin
description: AS Joan Denton flipped through her son's wedding album two years ago, something caught her eye, and it wasn't the beaming groom or the radiant bride. It was the sight of her own scalp. "I realized I could see through my hair to the top of my head a little bit," said Ms. Denton, 59 , of Eatontown, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday and in some late editions on Sunday about Donn Clendenon, a star for the Mets in the 1969 World Series, misstated the inning in which they scored two runs to take a 5-3 lead in Game 5 against the Baltimore Orioles and win the championship. It was the eighth, not the ninth.

title: New Dog Flu Virus, Deadly and Contagious, Is Detected in 7 States
description: Correction Appended

title: Man, 24, Killed by Gunman After Spilling Drink at a Club
description: A patron who accidentally spilled his drink on a woman in a Bowery nightclub yesterday morning was shot to death on the sidewalk across the street, the police said. A second round of gunfire struck a man who was asleep in a doorway, wounding him in the leg.

title: Government Rests Case Against War Protesters
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 21 - Four anti-war activists who spilled blood at a military recruiting center before the American invasion of Iraq were portrayed by a federal prosecutor on Wednesday as religious zealots who routinely destroy government property yet have mostly evaded consequences.

title: In Place Where the Hungry Are Fed, Farmers May Starve
description: NIAMEY, Niger, Sept. 21 - The images coming out of this impoverished, West African nation have been unrelentingly grim: hungry children with stick-thin arms and swollen bellies, mothers carrying babies hundreds of miles to look for food after a poor harvest and high prices put local staples out of reach. A few months ago, those images prompted a torrent of food aid from Western donors.

title: Nepali king promises national elections
Killings exacerbate tensions in Thai region
Paid Notice: Deaths   DREYER, HARVEY
description: DREYER--Harvey. Extraordinary husband of 58 years to Doris, loving father of Susan (Paul) Harris, Marcie (Peter) Maynard and Ellen (Jim) Yanda, doting grandpa of Laura, Melanie, Hilary, Marielle and Aaron. Survived by brother, Len Goldreyer, inlaws, Muriel and Sam Zuckerman. Lived 82 wonderful years full of love and laughter. A deeply kind, thoughtful and caring man to family, friends and all mankind. Services Thursday, September 22, 10 AM, Plaza Chapels, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Hunger Strike by Detainees Goes to Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Lawyers for a group of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, have asked a federal judge to assume oversight of the military's management of a hunger strike there, asserting that the government has been concealing the full scope of the problem.

title: Allen Still Has His Job, and Says He'll Do Better
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 21 - Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said Wednesday that left cornerback Will Allen had not lost his job. But Coughlin did not shut off the lights and turn on a projector to buttress his announcement.

title: Lights Go Out on the Marlins in the 8th and 9th
description: The Mets are suddenly playing as if the pennant were on the line. With a 5-4 victory over the Florida Marlins last night, they have won four of five games and two consecutive series.

title: Ferrer Campaigns With Green and Criticizes Bloomberg
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Democratic nominee for mayor, campaigned for the first time yesterday with his former political archnemesis, Mark Green, while also unveiling his first television commercials against his new rival, Michael R. Bloomberg, one of which suggested that the Republican mayor had failed to tackle poverty in the city.

title: After This Summer
description: On some fundamental level, the coming of autumn, which begins early this evening in the East, signals a shift in mood that is almost too deep to explain. Today is the midpoint between solstices, when day and night are exactly equal. In that narrow sense, the arrival of fall is merely an astronomical marker, just one point on Earth's annual orbit around the Sun. But it is also the beginning of the season when change feels most palpable to us. In early September, it's still possible to pretend that the summer light is holding its own.

title: Ruling on utility merger seen as victory for EU competition chief
Chevrolet Buys Out 'Tonight Show' Time
description: Chevrolet Buys Out

title: Planting Big Wet Ones on the Face of Cuba
description: Castro does not, in fact, get smooched in "Kissing Fidel," the new play by Eduardo Machado, an Intar production at the Kirk Theater. But virtually everyone else does in the course of this confused and overwrought comedy about a family of Cuban-Americans mourning in Miami. Before flying off to Havana to pursue an unlikely embrace with the dictator, the play's central character, a collection of neuroses loosely held together by a black suit and stylish eyeframes, will plant sloppy kisses on the lips of not one, but two of his male cousins. And his aunt. And his father.

title: Bush Compares Responses To Hurricane and Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - President Bush on Wednesday for the first time linked the American response to terrorism and its response to Hurricane Katrina, declaring that the United States is emerging a stronger nation from both challenges, and saying that terrorists look at the storm's devastation "and wish they had caused it."

title: Music Unleashed: The Hard Drive Spins And Notes Float Free
description: Saitek, a London company that makes video-game and computer accessories, is offering a wireless stereo speaker unit that requires no complicated setup and can broadcast music from computers up to 100 feet away. About 13 by 3 by 4 1/2 inches and shaped vaguely like a banana, the unit, called the A-250, runs on four AA batteries or regular house current and has a small transmitter that plugs into a USB port on a computer. The unit is compatible with both PC's and Macs and uses a 2.4-gigahertz radio frequency, playing high-fidelity music files and Internet radio transmissions. It includes track buttons, allowing a user to skip or repeat pieces from a distance. It comes in glossy black or cream and can also be wired to an iPod or a CD player. It costs about $130. Stores: saitek.com.

title: Errors in Timing: Start of Fall and of Spades
description: The Long Island Fall Regional took place last week in Smithtown. Yes, somebody should explain the seasons to the organizers, since fall does not officially start until 10:23 p.m. tonight. Maybe they expected an autumnal feel to the air, but that didn't happen either.

title: Israel Security Aide Now Expects More Attacks From West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 21 - The director of Israel's Shin Bet security service said Wednesday that armed Palestinian factions were increasingly likely to initiate attacks from the West Bank rather than from the Gaza Strip after Israel's withdrawal from Gaza.

title: Treading More Lightly With Color Underfoot
description: Embroidered throw pillows, rugs in vivid patterns and striped velvet throws fill a new SoHo boutique owned by Kate's Paperie, the downtown emporium, and Company C, a home furnishings company. "Color and texture are the critical points where Kate's and Company C mesh," said Sandra Cohen, the shop's director, top right. The inventory, well edited and well priced, includes throw pillows ($30 to $60); area rugs, up to 10 by 14 feet, in tufted or hooked wool ($59 to $2,995); and accent rugs in jute (from $58). "Europeans have always been uninhibited about eye-catching rugs," Ms. Cohen said. "Now it's finally hitting the American market." She added, "When people are under stress, color is uplifting." The boutique, Company C at Kate's Paperie, is at 88 Prince Street (Broadway); (212)941-9816.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Former School Official Is Arrested
description: The former director of facilities for the Paterson Public School District was charged yesterday with extorting $78,000 in cash and home improvements from district contractors, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. James M. Cummings Jr., 58, was arrested at his home in Andover. He was director of facilities for the district from 1998 until 2003, prosecutors said. In a written statement, Mr. Christie said Mr. Cummings's indictment followed four guilty pleas by other people arising from the investigation of corruption in the Paterson school system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NUGENT, JOHN D. (''DREW'')
description: NUGENT--John D. ("Drew") b. 1941, cherished husband of Charlotte, beloved father of Josh and Edie, brother of Nelle, son of Evelyn Nugent Bailey and the late John P. Nugent, July 30 after a long illness. A celebration of his life will be held on Sunday, September 25, at 3 PM, in Inwood Park, on the peninsula near the flagpole, entrance on 218th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family would deeply appreciate contributions in Drew's name to RTPPC, c/o Dr. Howard Scher, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Dispute Over Downed Russian Jet Continues
description: A week after a Russian fighter jet crashed in Lithuania, the countries were still arguing over the fate of the wreckage and the pilot. The plane flew 130 or so miles into the airspace of Lithuania, a NATO member, before the pilot ejected and the plane plunged into a field. Russia cited a mechanical problem and called Lithuania's detention of the pilot "incomprehensible." In protest, Russia's Foreign Ministry canceled an economic conference with Lithuania scheduled for today. Lithuania, meanwhile, said that the pilot had denied the Su-27 jet was armed with missiles but that a Russian delegation later acknowledged that it was carrying four air-to-air missiles. Lithuania said it would hold the pilot until its investigation was complete.

title: Emerging From the Haze
description: This 30-second spot is the first English-language general election ad for Fernando Ferrer, the Democratic nominee for mayor. It began running yesterday on broadcast and cable networks. (The campaign also released a Spanish-language ad using a segment of his speech to supporters on primary night.)

title: Still Sheltered, Evacuees Add Novel Touches
description: HOUMA, La., Sept. 21 - Eloise Juneau does not need a calendar to tell how long she has been living in a shelter. Any mirror does just fine. Her blond hair has turned silvery at the roots, a reminder that it has been almost four weeks since she has been able to dye it.

title: Faulty Levees
description: The official explanation for the collapse of some of the flood walls protecting New Orleans has been that Hurricane Katrina simply overwhelmed the system. But reports yesterday in both The Washington Post and The New York Times suggested that Katrina might not have been as powerful as advertised and that the real culprit was the system itself -- flood walls so poorly constructed that they were easily breached.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, SANDRA
description: FELDMAN--Sandra. We extend our heartfelt condolences to our sisters and brothers in the American Federation of Teachers over the death of their inspired leader Sandra Feldman. Sandy was a powerful advocate for teachers and students. In New York, and later in Washington, she was an effective champion of adequate school funding and decent standards for classroom teachers. She used her union's political power for the betterment of our nation's children, and we honor her for it. Dennis Rivera, President George Gresham, Secretary Treasurer 1199SEIU, New York's Health & Human Service Union

title: Nepal's King Promises Elections as Protests Continue
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 22 - With thousands of protesters on the streets of Katmandu in Nepal's version of a Prague spring, the government of King Gyanendra this week promised to hold elections and described its commitment to democracy as "unflinching."

title: Ah, I Remember It Well, at 95
description: No one knows better than Kitty Carlisle Hart that the golden age of "American musical thea-tah," as cultural grande dames are wont to call it, was peopled with dreamers and madmen as driven, ambitious and unstable in their way as subsequent generations of rockers and hip-hoppers. She knew them all.

title: Oil and Gas Prices Rise Again as Rita Approaches Texas Coast
description: Houston, the nation's energy epicenter, emptied of people as businesses from large oil refineries to small stores shut down in anticipation of Hurricane Rita.

title: Deal May Be in Offing to Acquire Troubled Payment Processor
description: A rival company in the payment-processing and data security business is close to making an offer to acquire CardSystems Solutions, a move that would allow CardSystems, the small processor at the center of one of the nation's biggest data breaches, to continue handling cardholder transactions but could put new management at the helm.

title: A Tweak for Design By Well-Knowns By Way of Ikea
description: Beginning Oct. 7, Ikea will introduce "PS 2006," a collection of 39 home products from 28 designers, who were asked to use new approaches to design and materials but given no formal restrictions. Hella Jongerius, whose conceptual, perforated and stitched porcelain vases command thousands of dollars, here offers a simple stoneware version (without her usual yarn embroidery) called Jonsberg, for $39.99. The Ellan chair (above, also $39.99), by Chris Martin, rests squarely on the floor during a meal and then allows the user a comfortable postprandial shift without straining the rear legs. The chair will be available in black by Oct. 15, and in turquoise and white at the end of October. The products will be at ikea-usa.com and at Ikea stores, (800)434-4532.

title: Lawmakers Try to Get Grip On Curbing Medicaid Fraud
description: ALBANY, Sept. 21 - State Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Republican from Long Island, bore down on a top aide to the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, at a legislative hearing on Wednesday. Citing statistics from other states, the senator asked why New York was not recapturing more of the fraudulent payments streaming out of its $44.5 billion Medicaid program.

title: Planned Move of Fish Mart Delayed Again
description: The Fulton Fish Market's long-awaited move to the Bronx, which was scheduled to take place over the coming weekend, has been delayed again, this time by a lawsuit that seeks to prevent the fish wholesalers from unloading their own shrimp, porgies and cod.

title: A Rare 'Manon' Sighting
description: Correction Appended

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harvard Allows Recruiters
description: Harvard Law School will allow military recruiters back on its campus after barring them last semester. Harvard chose to bar the recruiters after a federal appeals court ruled that if universities believed the military's "don't ask, don't tell" policy on gay men and lesbians violated their antidiscrimination policies, they could prohibit recruiting without losing federal money. The appeals court ruling has been stayed pending a decision by the Supreme Court, which is to hear the case in December.

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: From "The Star-Spangled Banner" Tradition to Schmaltzing With Waltzes
description: Orchestras in America may be struggling, but the New York Philharmonic must be doing something right. The Philharmonic opened its season on Wednesday night with a gala program conducted by Lorin Maazel, and patrons voted their approval with their pocket books. A record $3.1 million was raised on this single night, with 1,000 people attending the posh dinner after the post-performance dinner. Moreover, an official from the Philharmonic said, new subscriptions are up 32 percent.Mr. Maazel, who begins his fourth season as music director, is clearly satisfying some segments of the public. Still, the first half of the program offered a reminder of why Mr. Maazel, for all his brilliance, can be an exasperating conductor.

title: The House That Turned Into a Potboiler
description: FRANKLIN, Tenn. - A FEW years ago, in the midst of a fairly active midlife, Robert Hicks, a rotund man who wears red dotted glasses, set about to write a novel. Plenty of people embark on this quest all the time of course, believing that they have something profound to say about the human condition, or certain that they will make lots of money with which to buy a nice house. But Mr. Hicks was someone with no pronouncements to make, someone who owned a nice house. It was another house, though, that drove him to the joyful tortures of composing fiction.

title: Picture window: Price halved for New Zealand fishing spot
Senate Panel Endorses Roberts's Nomination as Chief Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - The Senate Judiciary Committee strongly endorsed Judge John G. Roberts Jr. today to be the next chief justice of the United States, sending the nomination to the full Senate for confirmation next week.

title: Some in the Audience Might Want Special Glasses
description: To be cool and cognizant, and on the right side of critical opinion, experts will tell you this: if everyone loves something, there must be something wrong with it. The argument will get you a long way in some circles but, at the end of the day, not far enough. Consider, for example, the young Chinese pianist Lang Lang, who helped the New York Philharmonic and Lorin Maazel open their regular subscription series at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night.

title: U.S. Discloses Moves to Stop Piracy of Intellectual Property
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 - Carlos M. Gutierrez, the commerce secretary, announced on Wednesday a series of initiatives aimed at curbing the global trade in pirated and counterfeit goods, a problem that American businesses say is costing them $250 billion a year.

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Culture in Which Children Are Taught to Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Patara Journal article on Monday, about an archaeological excavation of the Lycian League parliament building in Patara, Turkey, referred incorrectly to the ancient Greek historian who wrote "The Persian Wars," which mentions Patara as a port used by the Persians in the fifth century B.C. He was Herodotus, not Thucydides. The article also misspelled the name of the wife of the Roman emperor Hadrian, who accompanied him to Patara in the spring of A.D. 131, according to evidence uncovered at the excavation site. She was Sabina, not Sabine.

title: Simplicity in a Remote, at a Less Complicated Price
description: In an attempt to create remote controls that can run all of a household's electronics with a minimum of buttons, many companies have turned to display screens. Unfortunately, many companies have also used these displays to expand the number of functions on the remotes, at times leading to more confusion than convenience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACHRACH, DORIS (NEE MAYDIN).
description: BACHRACH -- Doris (nee Maydin). Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving sister of Phyllis Weingarten and Deanna Bernstein. Adored aunt of Robert, David and Beth, and great aunt to their children. Services Friday September 23rd, 2pm at "Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial" Chapel, 76th Rd & Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY In lieu of flowers donations to NARAL Pro-Choice NY or International Center of Photography, NYC would be appreciated.

title: Matchmaker, Matchmaker
description: Except for collectors of pitiful nightclub scenes -- the sitcom kind, with music dubbed later, in which everyone tunelessly shuffles around in an overlighted room -- "Love, Inc." is unlikely to captivate anyone. This UPN comedy, which has its premiere tonight, was originally conceived as a vehicle for Shannen Doherty, but after filming a pilot and finding the results unfunny, the network dropped Ms. Doherty and reshot with Busy Philipps of "Dawson's Creek." Without the freaky, capricious Ms. Doherty, the show has lost its negligible reason for being.

title: In a New Documentary, Latino Ballplayers Finally Get Their Due
description: "Viva Baseball," a new documentary about the history and the struggles of Latino ballplayers to be accepted as major leaguers, arrives at a moment when their influence in the sport is undeniable.

title: Suit Details Bayou Founder's Explanations of Unpaid Personal Loan
description: Among the many questions still swirling around the collapse of the Bayou Group, a $300 million hedge fund, is why did so many Wall Street professionals and institutions believe Bayou's founder, Samuel Israel III, was a successful, well-connected money manager with an honorable reputation?

title: When Sun Protection Factor Is No Longer a Factor
description: With summer ending it's time for lounging and entertaining to move indoors. The Conran Shop will help out with a 20 percent discount on all upholstered furniture (except Herman Miller and Knoll) from Saturday through Oct. 10. The 43-inch-wide Sleeper Sofa, by Niels Benson, a designer in Vancouver, British Columbia, starts at $2,200 as shown above (previously $2,775). The Talk modular sofa, from Conran's Content collection, starts at $4,520 (previously $5,650). The shop is at 407 East 59th Street; (866)755-9079 or www.conran.com.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 11 about planned events that were interrupted by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, misstated the location of Fiterman Hall, the 15-story satellite building of the Borough of Manhattan Community College that had undergone a $65 million renovation and was scheduled to open in October 2001. It was just north of the World Trade Center, not south. (By the end of Sept. 11, 2001, the hall was buried to the third floor in the debris from the 47-story building next door, 7 World Trade Center. It remains closed.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANTELMAN, JOAN PAUER
description: ANTELMAN--Joan Pauer, 71. Died September 21. Survived by son Bruce (Maria), daughter Ilene, and brother Stanley Pauer (Edith). Resident of Hallandale Beach, FL. She was born in Brooklyn and attended Bryn Mawr and Brooklyn colleges. A homemaker in Clifton, N.J., and a bridge Grand Master, she then became a computer programmer and a teacher of bridge. Services Friday, 12:45PM at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 20955 Biscayne Blvd, Aventura, FL.

title: Orioles' Roberts to Miss Six Months
description: Brian Roberts did not expect to see Bubba Crosby in his hospital room around midnight after Tuesday's game. Roberts was medicated, with his left elbow in a splint and six months of recovery ahead of him after a collision with Crosby hours before. But he did not kick Crosby out of his room.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANT, ELEANOR BEERS
description: GRANT--Eleanor Beers, on September 20, 2005 of Manhasset and Southampton, NY. Long time NYC educator and founding member of the Congressional Glaucoma Caucus Foundation. Loving wife of Stanley J. Bud Grant. Devoted mother of William R. (Kimberly) and grandmother to Emily C.; step-mother to six; step-grandmother of 19 and also survived by countless family and friends. Calling hours at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Thursday evening 7-9pm and Friday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Saturday, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset, 9:45am. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering NYC or St. Ignatius Retreat House, Manhasset, NY.

title: All eyes on nesting season: Turtle tours on the rise
On The Street: Then
description: THEY may fancy themselves the standard-bearers of stylistic eccentricity, flaunting Mohawk haircuts, Ramones T-shirts and glad rags pilfered from the attic trunk, but teenagers today don't have a thing on their brashly freewheeling predecessors. In the fall of 1987 that earlier generation of rule-breakers routinely flipped convention on its head, whipping up disjunctive combinations undreamed of in that day.

title: World Briefing | Asia: More Than 1,000 Missing In South Asia Storms
description: Dozens of people were killed and more than 1,000 were reported missing in fierce storms that have swept across the coast of the Bay of Bengal this week. In Bangladesh, 1,000 people, mostly fishermen, were reported missing. In the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, the authorities said 56 people were dead and hundreds were missing.

title: Two NYRA Officials Fired in Latest Scandal
description: Braulio Baeza is a Hall of Fame jockey who won 3,140 races in his career, including the 1963 Kentucky Derby aboard Chateaugay. But yesterday the sport that propelled him to fame left him embroiled in legal trouble after he was charged with misreporting jockeys' weights in his job as the New York Racing Association's assistant clerk of scales.

title: Senators Accuse Pentagon of Obstructing Inquiry on Sept. 11 Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Senators from both parties accused the Defense Department on Wednesday of obstructing an investigation into whether a highly classified intelligence program known as Able Danger did indeed identify Mohamed Atta and other future hijackers as potential threats well before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Rock and Country, Partners in Marketing
description: On Monday night, the remarkably durable 1980's band Bon Jovi became the first group to play the Nokia Theater, a notably uncozy new rock club in Times Square. The concert was a masterpiece of cross-promotion, designed to advertise the club, the club's sponsors, the band, the band's new album ("Have a Nice Day," released by Island Def Jam Records) and also, finally, America Online, which broadcast the performance at aol.com.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Security Minister Dies In Helicopter Crash
description: The minister of public safety, Ramn Martn Huerta, was killed when his helicopter crashed in mountains near Mexico City, President Vicente Fox announced on national television. The federal police chief, Toms Valencia, also died in the crash, he said, as did seven others on board. The cause of the crash was unclear, and the authorities said there would be an investigation. The officials were flying from the capital to an induction ceremony for new guards at a maximum-security prison about 35 miles west of Mexico City. Mr. Martn, 48, was one of Mr. Fox's closest aides and had been leading the government's fight against a wave of drug-related violence that has already left more than 1,000 people, including dozens of police officers, dead across the country this year. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREUND, SERENA L.
description: FREUND--Serena L. On September 20, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Max Freund. Loving mother of Elizabeth Green and Alice Gottlieb. Cherished grandmother of Robert, David, Geoffrey, Eric and Caroline and greatgrandmother of seven. Fond sister-in-law of Bunny and Joan Lewis and also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services were private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Child Development Center Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, 120 W. 57th St., New York, NY 10019.

title: At Morgan, a Sense of Inertia
description: For John J. Mack, bigger has always been better.

title: Castle in Ruin, on a River That Nearly Was
description: BEACON, N.Y. - As John Cronin sails toward the ruins of Bannerman's Island in the broad belly of the Hudson River, he sees a symbol of the challenges facing the waterway where he has spent much of his adult life.

title: Toms Has More on His Mind Than the Presidents Cup
description: GAINESVILLE, Va., Sept. 21 - When David Toms tried to walk into the White House with his Presidents Cup teammates and competitors for a dinner Tuesday night, an alarm sounded.

title: This Doll Has an Accessory Barbie Lacks: A Prayer Mat
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 21 - In the last year or so, Barbie dolls have all but disappeared from the shelves of many toy stores in the Middle East. In their place, there is Fulla, a dark-eyed doll with, as her creator puts it, "Muslim values."

title: Shopping New Orleans' Treasures, In Spite of the Floods
description: Eleven antiques dealers in New Orleans are still in business, online if not in person. A Web site, 1stdibs.com, will ship their wares directly to consumers by the end of November. "The inventory was on Magazine Street and the French Quarter," said Michael Bruno, a founder of the site (below, at its home page), which as of Tuesday were dry. Soniat House Antique Galleries, in the French Quarter, is offering a 17th-century French bracket with a carved wood angel, 20 inches high, 16 1/2 inches wide and 9 inches deep ($10,300), left. The site usually charges a 20 percent commission, but it has reduced that to 5 percent. Rodney Smith, an owner of Soniat House, said that they are hoping to reopen their store Oct. 5.

title: Hoping to Start Over, but Feeling Displaced
description: You may think of jazz when you think of New Orleans. Or maybe the blues, or zydeco. But hip-hop, too, has become such a part of the city's culture that Loren Fourous was able to make a living from it, as the founder and president of a glossy quarterly called Da R.U.D.E. Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAMLOK, DWIGHT G.
description: MAMLOK--Dwight G. On September 20. My sweet beloved husband of 58 years left me too soon. He was the most sensitive human being, wrote the beautiful poetry for my song cycle "The Andreas Garden", short stories on a variety of subjects, and what a great sense of humor, despite the hard times of living during the Nazi era. He supported me in every way, helped in my musical and human development. He was so positive and courageously fought through his gruesome illness, cancer of the jaw.

title: Gaming the Price of Leadership
description: Never underestimate the brazenness of incumbent politicians determined to sneak unfair rule changes into the game. Incumbent treachery is under way in the Senate, where Republicans are using a big spending bill as cover to try to gut campaign donation limits and give themselves an eight-to-one spending advantage over election challengers.

title: Publicis and Rival, Aegis, Discussing Takeover Bid
description: London - THE Publicis Groupe has approached a competitor, the Aegis Group, to discuss a possible takeover bid valued at around 1.56 billion, or about $2.8 billion, people close to the companies said yesterday.

title: Come Sail Away in the Netherlands Or Take a Turn in Sweden
description: Two striking new buildings are helping to shape redeveloped waterfronts in Sweden and the Netherlands. The Turning Torso, left, by the Spanish architect and engineer Santiago Calatrava, spirals 623 feet above a former industrial district in the Swedish city of Malmo, replacing a crane that used to tower nearby. It sits on the strait that separates Denmark from Sweden and is the tallest residential building in Sweden.

title: Supersize Strollers Ignite Sidewalk Drama
description: ONE recent evening during rush hour on a Washington subway, Jose Rivas found himself cornered by a giant stroller, with no clear path of escape. "She saw us," Mr. Rivas, 33, said of the woman pushing the buggy. "She looked at us. She was basically like: 'You better find a way to get out. It's not my responsibility."'

title: The Case of the Servant With the Fur Collar
description: Why was she wearing fur?

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ISAAC STERN
description: ISAAC STERN July 21, 1920-Sept. 22, 2001 FIDDLER

title: An abbey austereno more
A Minimalist Adrift in a Sea of Acclaim
description: Hiroshi Sugimoto knows a thing or two about staying calm. His seascapes emit scarcely a ripple; his movie theaters not a single flicker. In fact, Mr. Sugimoto's photographs are so void of agitation that, until you put your face right up against them, it can seem as if there's nothing happening at all.

title: That Sexual Researcher Again, This Time Played for Laughs
description: You can pretty much figure out the difference between the film "Kinsey" and the musical "Dr. Sex" -- two biographical treatments of the groundbreaking sex researcher Alfred Kinsey -- from their titles. In the film, Liam Neeson offered a nuanced portrait of the soft-spoken and highly logical scientist. The musical, a harmless and derivative piece of fluff, is about a good-time guy who likes to party at gay clubs and crack wise like a Catskills comic.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Son of Cool
description: IN high school the cool rich girls wore Esprit. They styled their blond hair in the slightly asymmetrical bob that could pass for Flock of Seagulls hip or, secured with a barrette, still look appropriate at the country club. They got cars for their 16th birthdays. They dated guys who said they were from Europe.

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, LUCILLE G.
description: COHEN--Lucille G. On September 20, 2005. Beloved and devoted aunt to Richard Jay and Hope, great-aunt to Lindsey Heather and Ashley Brooke, and to her extended family, Ruby and Franklin, Phyllis, Lawrence and Barbara, Jason, Lynn, Andrew, Ivan, Steven and Tony. Services to be held Friday, September 23, 2005 at 9:30AM at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Boy Grows in Brooklyn, With a Voice-Over
description: Comedians are angry people. Everybody knows that. And that is why "Everybody Hates Chris" on UPN is such a surprise. Chris Rock's new series, a memoir that he narrates, paints an affectionately wry portrait of a 13-year-old growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn.

title: Correction
description: The Critical Shopper column on Aug. 11, about the Kitson store in Los Angeles, misstated the origin of a crystal-covered cellphone that the actress Lindsay Lohan was shown carrying in a celebrity magazine. It was not made or sold by Kitson.

title: CUNY Signs a Deal to Expand Educational Opportunities for Mexican-Americans
description: Mexicans and Mexican-Americans account for fewer than 2,000 of the 200,000 undergraduates at the City University of New York. But they are one of the fastest-growing ethnic groups in New York. Yesterday, CUNY's chancellor signed an agreement with Mexico's consul general in New York to try to expand educational opportunities for this group.

title: Voters' Remorse on Bush
description: Maybe, just maybe, the public is beginning to see through the toxic fog of fantasy, propaganda and deliberate misrepresentation that has been such a hallmark of the George W. Bush administration, which is in danger of being judged by history as one of the worst of all time.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Shrank in August
description: Japan's trade surplus shrank 80 percent in August as rising crude oil prices increased the cost of imports to the country, the Ministry of Finance said today.

title: Techbrief: EU role limited on HP layoffs
A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: Flavors of peace: A couscous fest
Reading the Body to Ease Aches And Prevent Injury
description: UNTIL Jerilynn Jenderseck underwent a new fitness assessment called Body Map she wasn't able to pinpoint her body's weak spots. But after her exam showed that she arched her lower back and often shifted her weight to her right leg to compensate for her weaker left one, her personal trainer added targeted drills to her workouts.

title: Anger Grows in Basra After British Raid
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 21 - Waving pistols and assault rifles, Iraqi police officers led an angry anti-British demonstration in the southern city of Basra on Wednesday, and the provincial council voted unanimously to stop cooperating with British forces in the area until Britain apologized for storming a police station to free two of its soldiers.

title: Assemblyman Calls Failure to Report an 'Oversight'
description: Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., who is being tried on charges that he violated campaign finance laws, admitted yesterday that he had failed to tell his campaign treasurer about thousands of dollars in campaign contributions that he had solicited from a gas station lobby. But, he said, his failure had been an "oversight."

title: Celebrity Blessing
description: COMMON wisdom would hold that the higher a designer builds anticipation for a first runway appearance, the further he or she will fall in the event of a fashion flop. But that does not seem to hold true for celebrity designers. Gwen Stefani is the latest example of a pop star who attempts a career in clothing design, generates magnificent preshow buzz, then falls short of a real breakthrough on the runway, all without alienating her retail customers.

title: Time Warner Head Says AOL Is the Company's Future
description: The chairman of Time Warner, Richard D. Parsons, said yesterday that improving the company's America Online Internet business was a priority as he tries to bolster the share price -- signaling a tweak in strategy and a belief that the stigma of the AOL-Time Warner merger is finally a thing of the past.

title: At L.S.U., a 60-Minute Timeout
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 21 - The flag on the parade ground at Louisiana State flies at half-staff in memory of the victims of Hurricane Katrina. The field house is still being used as a special-needs shelter. Displaced F.B.I. agents from New Orleans plan to move into the Sigma Nu fraternity house.

title: Among Democratic Activists, Little Indecision on Roberts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - While many Democratic senators are still wrestling with their vote on Judge John G. Roberts Jr.'s nomination as chief justice of the United States, Democratic activists -- in advocacy groups, policy organizations, the party apparatus -- do not seem nearly as torn.

title: If Only the Hall Closet Could Store as Much
description: Of the more than 30 million wireless routers shipped worldwide in the last year and a half, more than 80 percent ended up in homes, where they are mostly used to share Internet access. But they can handle other duties as well, and with the popularity of music and video downloads, storage may be the next frontier.

title: Kerry and Edwards, 2005
description: John Kerry and John Edwards ran for office together and they lost together, and they both gave major speeches about Katrina this week, but there the similarity ends. The two men might as well live in different worlds.

title: Amtrak Reports Steady Ridership Despite Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Amtrak will end its fiscal year in a few days with "no measurable impact on our ridership" from the brake problem that sidelined the Acela fleet this year, the chairman of the railroad's board told Congress on Wednesday.

title: Delta Says It Plans Another $3 Billion in Cost Cuts
description: Delta Air Lines, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week, said today that it plans to cut another $3 billion in costs, including more pay and benefit reductions for all its employees, including its chief executive.

title: The Afghan Difference
description: Afghanistan and Iraq were both invaded by United States-led forces, which overthrew outlaw regimes. Both have new constitutions, guided by the same American diplomat. Both have foreign armies of significant size on their sovereign soil. But Iraq is careering toward civil war, while Afghanistan has just completed an encouragingly inclusive parliamentary election. Iraq cannot even begin to talk about defending itself without American troops. Afghanistan is already saying it's time for the United States to cease major military operations on its territory.

title: Formula One: School of hard knocks and university of Ferrari
A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: The IMF has lost its influence
New Vatican Rule Said to Bar Gays as New Priests
description: ROME, Sept. 21 - Homosexuals, even those who are celibate, will be barred from becoming Roman Catholic priests, a church official said Wednesday, under stricter rules soon to be released on one of the most sensitive issues facing the church.

title: Red Cross and Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: We'll Even Throw in Half a Pack of Life Savers
description: We'll Even Throw In Half a Pack of Life Savers

title: Workers Trying to Rescue Pets Abandoned in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 - Up North Claiborne Avenue five dogs ran as a pack between the smashed houses under dead power lines, through that twisted junkscape of lumber and tin, toilets in the silt, a wall marked "Possible Body" and the headless Virgin Mary with arms outstretched. The dogs neither fought nor growled. Among their number were a German shepherd, a beagle and a yellow Labrador.

title: Director Zigs From Stars to Nonactors in a New Film
description: TORONTO - "Is it inappropriate for the director of 'Ocean's Twelve' to go to Belpre, Ohio?" Steven Soderbergh asked recently, during the Toronto International Film Festival. The director was here for the premiere of his latest film, "Bubble," a drama about working-class characters swept away by jealousy and murder and driven by forces they cannot wholly articulate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about science museums that train staff members and volunteers to respond to visitors' challenges to evolutionary theory misstated the name of one where a tour company offers escorted visits for creationists. It is the Denver Museum of Nature and Science, not Science and Nature.

title: Studies Find Flu Vaccine and Antiviral Drugs Fall Far Short
description: ROME, Sept. 21 - Just as governments around the world are stockpiling millions of doses of flu vaccine and antiviral drugs in anticipation of a potential influenza pandemic, two new surprising research papers to be published Thursday have found that such treatments are far less effective than previously thought.

title: And Now, a Few Words From Johnson's Catcher
description: John Flaherty had the same conversation with the home-plate umpire Larry Vanover last night that he has with every umpire who is behind him when he catches Randy Johnson. It is Flaherty's protection against the possibility of a temper tantrum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE LEEUW, BARBARA
description: De LEEUW--Barbara. On September 9, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Loving mother of Michele Silverman (Seth) and Marc De Leeuw (Christine). Adoring grandmother of Victoria, Samantha and Joshua. Devoted sister of Herb Haber. Barbara graduated from Erasmus High School, Brooklyn College and Columbia University School of Social Work. She spent 26 years as a social worker at the League for the Hard of Hearing, devoting herself to the needs of the hearing impaired. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Donations may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing.

title: To Find a Doctor, Mine the Data
description: Correction Appended

title: Iraqi Pilgrim Site Imagines Itself as Shiite World's Vatican City
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASCH, ARTHUR
description: ASCH--Arthur. Of Short Hills, N.J. Beloved husband of thelate Virginia M. Devoted father of Cathy Asch and Roger and his wife Leslie Asch. Loving brother of Jerome and the late Seymour Asch. Dearest uncle of Andrea Rupp; most precious grandfather of Nicholas and Joshua. Funeral Services will be held at Temple B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave, Short Hills, N.J. on Friday, September 23rd at 1pm. For information, please call BernheimApter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (1 - 888 351-4414).

title: Asia Freight Aided Profit in Quarter, FedEx Says
description: The FedEx Corporation, the package shipping company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose and earnings for the full year would be higher than forecast because of growing exports from Asia and an expanding economy.

title: Bush Firm on Iraq Policy as Antiwar Forces Plan Protest
description: President Bush said today that even though Hurricanes Rita and Katrina had dominated national attention and resources in the last few weeks, "our focus on defending our country remains undiminished" and that he had no intention of heeding critics' calls to withdraw American troops from Iraq anytime soon.

title: Hotels by the generation: Bed or bar?
A Jade's Rapid Decline
description: A Jade's Rapid Decline

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LONG, REV. JOHN F., S.J.
description: LONG--Rev. John F., S.J. Beloved brother of Stephen, Bernard, Ralph, Lorraine Roell, Charles and Gerald. Survived by 25 loving nieces and nephews. Reposing on Friday at America House Jesuit Community, 106 West 56 St. (Manh.) 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be on Saturday at Fordham University Church (Bronx) at 3:30 PM. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: Chevrolet Buys Out 'Tonight Show' Time
description: The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation has bought all the commercial time during "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC tonight. The 17 minutes Chevrolet is buying will be devoted to comedy segments about the new Chevrolet HHR sedan. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Barbie pushed aside in Mideast cultural shift
Women, as seen by the sensitive lens of Avedon
Turning Venice Into Savannah on Stilts
description: The City of Falling Angels By John Berendt 414 pages. The Penguin Press. $25.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VACCHIANO, WILLIAM
description: VACCHIANO--William. The entire Juilliard community mourns the passing of William Vacchiano, one of the longest serving faculty members in the history of the School. He was a member of the trumpet faculty from 1935 to 2002, and his students went on to perform in most of the major orchestras around the world. A person of impeccable musical integrity and great humanity, he was revered and loved by his students and friends. We send our deepest condolences to his entire family. He will be deeply missed. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: Teenagers Shop For Art of the Deal
description: GABY Yosca can stretch a dollar like a bungee chord. Last weekend, during an hourlong shopping expedition at a Salvation Army store in downtown Manhattan, Ms. Yosca, a 15-year-old sophomore at the Dalton School, worked with a budget that was modest but elastic enough in her expert hands to accommodate four dresses, an aqua-tinted tank top, a brown corduroy blazer, two silk shirts, two belts, a pocketbook and a volume on makeup. "I scored," she gloated as she watched the cashier ring up her haul for a grand total of $62.50. Scooping it up, she glanced at her mother, Susan Yosca, who stood waiting outside flashing her a thumbs up.

title: Faster U.S. Aid Unlikely
description: A Bush administration proposal that sought to deliver a portion of American food aid more quickly and at lower cost to starving people around the world appears headed for defeat in Congress, though there is still a narrow chance a scaled-down version will survive in the Senate.

title: G.I.'s Role in Detainee Abuse Is Starkly Contrasted at Retrial
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 21 - The court-martial of Pfc. Lynndie R. England, accused of abusing Iraqi detainees in Abu Ghraib prison, opened Wednesday with her lawyer saying she became involved in the mistreatment because she had "an overly compliant personality" that "left her open to the suggestions of others."

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: The Dark Side of the Moon
description: Correction Appended

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: S.& P. Puts JetBlue on Credit Watch as Its Earnings Weaken
description: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services placed JetBlue Airways on credit watch with negative implications yesterday, meaning that its debt ratings could be cut.

title: When Crisis Strikes, an Orderly Exit?
description: HURRICANE KATRINA'S deadly toll on nursing home residents could never have been predicted by reading Louisiana's licensing regulations, which are more elaborate than most. They require the "evacuation of residents to a safe place" during an emergency, a "plan for coordinating transportation services," the "delivery of essential care" and the assurance that "the resident's family or sponsor is notified."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a street musician in New Orleans misstated her surname at two points. She is Marguerite Smith, not White.

title: Where Disorder Once Reigned, Efficient Evacuation Now Rules
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 - Catching a bus at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center to evacuate for Hurricane Rita is a breeze.

title: Selling Dreams and Drugs
description: Correction Appended

title: Ford Plans to Build a Lot More Hybrids
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 21 - The Ford Motor Company plans to increase production of hybrid electric vehicles tenfold, to 250,000 vehicles annually, by the end of the decade, executives said Wednesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Deal Is Reached to Put Toilets on City Streets
description: After more than a decade of false starts, New York City officials announced yesterday that they had selected a company to remake the city's jumbled streetscape by providing aesthetic order to its thousands of bus shelters and newsstands and, perhaps most intriguing, installing 20 freestanding public toilets on city streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, STUART
description: RUBIN--Stuart. Passed away on September 16, 2005. Beloved son of Dean and Bea Rubin.

title: A Long Night and an Eclectic Playlist From a Veteran Act
description: "Welcome to what is going to be an extremely long show tonight," said Elton John, at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday. And then he explained how it was going to work. First he would play songs from "Peachtree Road" (Universal), his 2004 album. For this, he almost apologized: "I know itAs difficult to listen to new songs." Then he would play all the songs from "Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy," the beloved album he released 30 years ago. And then? "Then weAre going to get to the jukebox," he said.

title: A Culture in Which Children Are Taught to Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, Martha Fires Someone, but Pink Slip Is Scented
description: She could have been brisk and exacting. But Martha Stewart was a much sweeter boss on her version of "The Apprentice" than Donald Trump on "The Apprentice" or, for that matter, than she ever seemed to be as founder and chief executive of Martha Stewart Omnimedia.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about warnings by Vice Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard against prematurely moving residents back to New Orleans omitted the name of the television program on which he said he was capable of giving the city's mayor "very good counsel." It was "Fox News Sunday," on Fox Broadcasting.

title: Verizon and Disney in Deal
description: Verizon Communications has signed a deal with the Walt Disney Company to carry ABC, Disney and ESPN TV channels on its new television system, the companies said yesterday. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Hornets to Play at 2 Sites
description: The New Orleans Hornets announced yesterday that they would play 35 home games this season in Oklahoma City and 6 at the Pete Maravich Assembly Center in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Roundup: Abducted coach freed in Mexico
I.M.F. Warns of Imbalance in World Consumption
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The United States is likely to experience slower economic growth next year, and its rapidly rising foreign debt is at the heart of dangerous global imbalances, the International Monetary Fund said Wednesday.

title: G.O.P. in House Plans Inquiry Despite Democrats' Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - House Republicans plan to proceed with a special investigation into the government response to Hurricane Katrina despite resistance by Democrats who say they will not take part and are demanding an independent inquiry.

title: Final Toast to an Owner Who Defined Integrity and Held Firm Views
description: ABOVE all else, John McMullen was a man of his word. If he said something, if he took a position on something, he could be counted on to stick to it. He did not go back on his word. The same cannot be said of many other owners I have encountered in baseball the past 35 years.

title: Fine Old Plasterwork and Water Don't Mix
description: CYPRESS, Tex. - WATER is the enemy of plaster. Earl A. Barth, the 83-year-old master plasterer of New Orleans, knows this deep in his heart. And so he waits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGRADE, JAMES F.
description: McGRADE--James F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James F. McGrade, associated with The Times from October 1955 until retiring in April 1989.

title: Refineries and Rigs Shut Down for Storm
description: Energy companies stepped up evacuations of offshore operations and rushed to secure refineries on the Texas coast yesterday as they prepared for Hurricane Rita, which was upgraded to a Category 5 hurricane packing winds up to 165 miles an hour. The storm appeared to be headed for the heart of the nation's oil industry.

title: Official Says Iraqi Oil Production Still Lagging
description: LONDON, Sept. 21 - Big oil companies have no concrete plans to develop Iraq's oil industry, Issam al-Chalabi, a former Iraqi oil minister, said Wednesday. It will be several years before the country can hope to return to its 1979 production peak and probably a decade before it can pump the amount suggested by its reserves, he said.

title: Monarchs May Claim Crown, but W.N.B.A. Is Biggest Winner
description: The Sacramento Monarchs and the Connecticut Sun were seconds away from going to a decisive fifth game in the W.N.B.A.'s first best-of-five finals.

title: Is There Hope for MPEG-2
description: Last week, I described my unhappiness with the new generation of tapeless camcorders--the ones that record onto mini-DVD discs, tiny hard drives or memory chips. Many of these models record video in something called the MPEG-2 format.

title: Aha! Video Straight to a Computer
description: EVERY now and then, humanity wakes up, looks at itself in the mirror and realizes that it's been wasting a lot of effort doing things the old way just for the sake of tradition. From the caveman who first put a bunch of rolling logs under something heavy, to the genius who packed four times more orange juice onto a truck by condensing it first, history is filled with "Aha!" moments that propel society forward.

title: Sony to Cut Jobs and Products to Revitalize Electronics Maker
description: TOKYO, Sept. 22 -The new head of Sony Corporation, Sir Howard Stringer, unveiled a turnaround plan today that will cut 10,000 jobs, shed unprofitable products and centralize decision making at the struggling, sprawling Japanese electronics giant known for its Walkman portable music players and PlayStation game consoles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, MURRAY
description: ROSENBERG -- Murray. Passed away Tuesday September 20, 2005, beloved husband of the late Anne, adored father of Linda Rosenberg, and Judy & Rabbi Carl Wolkin, cherished grandfather of Joshua & David Wolkin. Murray is survived by his brother, Leo, and brothers-in-law Abe Feldman, and Robert Lambert. Devoted uncle of nieces and nephews. A true mensch in both words and deeds. Donations may be made to the East Meadow Jewish Center, East Meadow, NY 11554. Graveside services will be held Friday September 23rd 10 A.M. at Wellwood Cemetery. For info call 631-249-2300.

title: Matters of How Many and How Much at the Sept. 11 Memorial
description: IF you build it, and they come, will you have room enough?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,901 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSZMANN, FRANZI
description: GROSZMANN--Franzi. Died at the age of 100. She was good to us and we loved her. Daughter Lore Segal; grandchildren Beatrice and Jacob Segal; great-grandsons Benjamin and Isaiah; and brother Paul Stern and his sons, Peter and John.

title: Let's Do Dinner (Ulterior Motive for Dessert)
description: The most interesting thing about "Loudmouth Soup," the second feature film from the director Adam Watstein, is the story of its production: the film was shot in a single night, from 6:30 p.m. to 2:30 a.m., with seven actors, eight cameras (one for each actor, plus a floater), no second takes and no script.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge's Pay Will Continue Despite Charges
description: Correction Appended

[Page C1.]

title: Senate Panel's Debate on the Confirmation of Judge Roberts
description: SPEAKERS:U.S. SENATOR ARLEN SPECTER (R-PA)CHAIRMANU.S. SENATOR ORRIN G. HATCH (R-UT)U.S. SENATOR CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IA)U.S. SENATOR JON KYL (R-AZ)U.S. SENATOR MIKE DEWINE (R-OH)U.S. SENATOR JEFF SESSIONS (R-AL)U.S. SENATOR LINDSEY O. title: National Briefing | Washington: Plea For Intervention In Detainees' Hunger Strike
description: Lawyers for 11 Kuwaiti detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, have asked Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of Federal District Court to assume oversight of the military's management of a hunger strike there. The strike, a protest against conditions at the camp and long confinement without trial, began last month. The military issued a statement Wednesday that referred to it as a "voluntary fast." According to the statement, 36 detainees were participating, and 16 were in the camp hospital and being fed through nasal tubes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RASKIN, SYLVIA
description: RASKIN--Sylvia. September 20 at 96 years of age. Beloved wife of the late David J. Raskin. Mother of Zelda Andrews and Jane Del Bianco. Grandmother of Michael Andrews, Peter Andrews and Jennifer Felsenfeld and great-grandmother of David Andrews. Sister of Martin Danzig, the late Evelyn Mittelman and the late Albert Danzig. Services private.

title: Judge Approves $3.56 Billion Settlement for WorldCom Investors
description: A federal judge approved legal settlements yesterday that will give $3.56 billion to WorldCom investors who say that they were defrauded by banks and the accounting firm Arthur Andersen.

title: 7 composers and a 1st-time librettist
Sturgeon Stocks Are in Decline Around World, Survey Reports
description: Sturgeon, the fish that produce black caviar, are severely depleted or threatened with extinction almost everywhere in the world, researchers are reporting today.

title: Metro-North Will Schedule Latest Trains Even Later
description: The suburbs are not so sleepy anymore, at least not in the eyes of officials of the Metro-North Railroad.

title: Sports of The Times; San Diego Pride Demands That Manning Eat Dirt
description: East Rutherford, N.J. - SUBPLOTS are following Eli Manning around. In the Giants' opener against Arizona, the other quarterback was Kurt Warner, his mentor last season. Against the Saints, he had to oppose his hometown team. And Sunday night against the Chargers in San Diego, he will be going against the team he didn't want to be drafted by in the city he didn't want to play in -- if he and his Giants teammates can hear the signals in the din at Qualcomm Stadium.
