title: A Noted Poison Pen Starts a Hedge Fund Hiring Showdown
description: Daniel S. Loeb, a hedge fund manager who has become as famous for his poison pen as for his investment performance, is at it again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKETT, LOUIS K.
description: BECKETT--Louis K. Died on September 20, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Isabelle and the late Ruth. Adored father of Angelica Joyce Smith. Cherished father-inlaw of Fred Smith. Beloved grandfather of Timothy and Gregory. Loving great grandfather of Ella Renata. Services Thursday, 1 PM graveside at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Gunmen Storm a Bronx Home, Leaving 3 Dead
description: Three assailants burst into a Bronx apartment late Tuesday, bound the hands of the four adults they found inside, and then fatally shot three of them -- two men and a young mother whose 2-year-old son was sitting next to her, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALKER, DONALD A.
description: WALKER--Donald A. Distinguished Professor of Physics at SUNY New Paltz. Died on September 15, 2005. A nuclear physicist and computer specialist, he graduated from Queens College and Oregon State University where he received his Ph.D. in 1968. An Air Force veteran of the Korean War, he had many interests in addition to science. As a young man, he studied trumpet with William Vacchiano. Survived by his wife Maureen, children Daniel and Katharine and his brother Henry J., he was pre-deceased by his twin brother David S. Services 2PM Saturday, September 24, at the Reformed Church in New Paltz.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Earl' Lifts NBC's Spirits
description: NBC has been hoping that the comedy "My Name Is Earl" will help the network out of its slump, and for at least one night, it did. In its 9 p.m. slot on Tuesday, the premiere of the heavily promoted "Earl" drew 14.94 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Along with the debut of the seventh season of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit," which brought in an audience of 16.35 million, "Earl" helped carry the night for NBC in total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. Sandwiched between those shows, "The Office" posted disappointing results, with 9.16 million viewers and a 33 percent decline from "Earl's" 18-to-49 rating. Elsewhere in the morass of network premieres, CBS's "NCIS" attracted 14.69 million viewers (good), and ABC's "According to Jim" drew 7.88 million (not so good). CBS also featured two finales of its summer reality offerings, "Big Brother" (8.46 million) and "Rock Star: INXS" (7.9 million), for a third place finish in total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds; Fox was No. 2 in those categories. Also of note, ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" rematch, also known as the revenge of John O'Hurley, above (with Charlotte Jorgensen), didn't fare well against the increased fall competition. The results of the danceoff will be announced on a half-hour show tonight. Tuesday's episode delivered a disappointing 10.78 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paris wine bars thinking 'petit'
Need Answers? Ask Anybody
description: Correction Appended

title: 5 Killed, 23 Wounded, by 2 Bomb Blasts in Pakistan City
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 22 - Two bomb blasts hit the eastern city of Lahore today, killing at least 5 people and wounding at least 23, police officials said.

title: Molly Yard, Advocate for Liberal Causes, Dies at 93
description: Molly Yard, for more than half a century an outspoken advocate for liberal causes, who came to national prominence as president of the National Organization for Women in the late 1980's, died yesterday at a nursing home in Pittsburgh. She was 93 and had resided most recently in Arlington, Va., and Washington.

title: On a Secret Quest, Stalking the Wild Orchid
description: BROWNS MILLS, N.J. - WHEN Neill Heath, a conservationist and fund-raiser employed by the Nature Conservancy, handed me a neatly folded bandanna one afternoon last month, I assumed it was to wipe my sweaty brow in the 95-degree heat. In fact, it was meant as a blindfold. Along with six other guests of the conservancy, I was required to cover my eyes for rides between locations in the heart of the Pine Barrens, in south central New Jersey, where rare blooming orchids had been spotted. The intention, of course, was to keep their whereabouts a secret, thereby protecting them from poachers.

title: New Shops in New York
description: STARTING Tuesday and through October, Self Magazine will operate the Self Center -- a 14,000-square-foot spa, lounge, and retail space offering discounted massages, facials, reflexology and nail treatments. A portion of the proceeds from each service (provided by Oasis Day Spa) will be donated to CFDA Foundation/Fashion Targets Breast Cancer. Customers will receive goodie bags, subscriptions to Self and on certain days other freebies like blowouts (Oct. 8 and 15) and private mammography screenings (by appointment on Sept. 27). More information and a complete schedule of events can be found online at Self.com, where visitors can click on "Self Center." At 461 Fifth Avenue, corner of 40th Street, (212)286-2878.

title: Focus for Supreme Court Pick Is Said to Be on Diversity
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARLT, PAUL T.
description: ARLT--Paul T. died on September 20th at age 91 in Rye, NY. He leaves his wife of 65 years MacClaire, a daughter Ronay Menschel, son-in-law Richard Menschel, and grandchildren Charis and Ryan Drant, and Sabina and Celene Menschel who loved him and to whom he was devoted. Born in the Bronx, graduate of Townsend Harris High School and Colgate University, Paul was a painter, political cartoonist, and graphic artist for 70 years. A longtime resident of Washington, DC, he studied at the Corcoran Gallery of Art and The Phillips Collection art schools. A Marine Corps combat artist in WWII, he worked for the State Department under the Marshall Plan from 1948-51. From 1951-56 he was a syndicated political cartoonist for the New York Herald Tribune. In the 1960's he was commissioned by NASA to witness and paint aspects of the Gemini and Apollo space missions. In watercolor or oil, his work depicted the beauty of nature, the drama of events, and the goodwill of people. In later years he explored the politics and architecture of Washington, DC and the landscape of Nantucket. His work is in the collections of the Museum of the City of New York, and The Phillips Collection and the National Air and Space Museum in Washington DC. Services will be private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Museum of the City of New York or The Phillips Collection.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Patara Journal article on Monday, about an archaeological excavation of the Lycian League parliament building in Patara, Turkey, referred incorrectly to the ancient Greek historian who wrote "The Persian Wars," which mentions Patara as a port used by the Persians in the fifth century B.C. He was Herodotus, not Thucydides. The article also misspelled the name of the wife of the Roman emperor Hadrian, who accompanied him to Patara in the spring of A.D. 131, according to evidence uncovered at the excavation site. She was Sabina, not Sabine. (Go to Article)

title: Amid Drug Use Reports, 2 More Brands Drop Kate Moss
description: Two global luxury brands became the latest companies to sever ties with the model Kate Moss over concerns that her reported involvement with illegal drugs would tarnish their appeal to consumers.

title: Possible Conflicts for Doctors Are Seen on Medical Devices
description: As an assistant professor at the Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center in Shreveport, Dr. William Overdyke oversaw operations to replace worn-down knees. From 2000 through the middle of 2001, whenever a patient needed an artificial knee, he or the residents he supervised implanted one made by Sulzer Medical, state documents show.

title: Weary and Diminished, Red Sox Curse Their Lot
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 21 - The Red Sox seemed too tired to play the part of the defiant second-place team, and too worn out to show much despair after a numbing loss. After playing for 30 straight days, they just wanted to get to Baltimore for a one-day rest and not think too much about being behind the Yankees in the American League East for the first time since July 18.

title: Democrat who Backs Bloomberg Played Role in Bribery Scandal
description: Among the organizers of Democrats for Bloomberg, a new group working to create bipartisan support for the Republican mayor, is a businessman who figured in a bribery scandal involving Donald R. Manes, the Queens borough president who killed himself in 1986.

title: Ukraine Gets Prime Minister After Deal Between Rivals
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 - President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine won parliamentary approval of a new prime minister on a second vote today after striking a deal with his bitter rival in last year's disputed presidential elections.

title: Trying to Revive the City That Care Forgot
description: On Tuesday night, Radio City Music Hall played host to one of two hurricane-relief concerts called "From the Big Apple to the Big Easy." (The other was held simultaneously at Madison Square Garden.) The stars were Dave Matthews, the Neville Brothers, and a dozen more. And the show started as soon as you hit the lobby: jazz wafted down from the mezzanine as concertgoers found ways to look festive (shiny beads) and feel festive (plastic cups).

title: Bank of New York Selects Concept Farm
description: The Bank of New York has named the Concept Farm in New York as its agency of record, to handle assignments with billings estimated at $15 million.

title: Man Held After Botched Robbery
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21 - A tense hostage drama in the basement of a jewelry store ended peacefully on Wednesday night when a man claimed to have a grenade surrendered after holding the store's owner hostage for hours, the police said.

title: Senate Leader Explains His Sale of a Stock That Then Plummeted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Senator Bill Frist offered an explanation on Wednesday for the timing of his sale in June of his stake in HCA, the giant hospital company that his family founded, as its shares reached a peak and began a steep slide.

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All' (11 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Physical Culture; Lighter, Stronger, Farther
description: JUST in time for autumn leaf-peeping trips to the mountains, a new crop of hiking boots has arrived to handle whatever trails you follow. Unlike boots of old -- which often required a long and painful break-in period -- today's styles are designed to feel broken in. That does not mean every boot will suit every foot or every type of hiking though. It's up to you to choose the right one.

title: After the Runway: Reality
description: ON Tuesday morning, as Francisco Costa, the women's designer at Calvin Klein, was about to greet customers at Neiman Marcus in Beverly Hills, Lynwood Holmberg was getting into a taxi in Manhattan. Ms. Holmberg is the women's fashion director at Mario's, a boutique in Portland, Ore., with a sister shop in Seattle, and like a lot of retailers this week she is in New York to choose what her customers will be wearing next spring.

title: Rolling Rhythms to Beat the Bayou Blues
description: On a typical night in New Orleans, Clarence Frogman Henry could be heard in a Bourbon Street club singing his 1956 hit, the one where he proves he can sing like a girl or a frog. On Tuesday night Mr. Henry cooed and croaked it at Madison Square Garden, and suddenly there was poignancy in the song's title: "Ain't Got No Home."

title: Often, Tolls Don't Show True Picture
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 21 - The death toll from Hurricane Katrina passed 1,000 on Wednesday, with Louisiana reporting 799 fatalities and Mississippi 219. But the seeming precision of the numbers raises the question of which deaths can truly be attributed to the storm.

title: Boston Scientific Settles With an Ex-Partner
description: Boston Scientific has agreed to pay its former stent-making partner, Medinol, $750 million to end the bitter legal battles in this country and abroad that arose from the breakdown of their relationship. Boston Scientific will also return its 22 percent stake in Medinol, a privately held company that is based in Tel Aviv and is controlled by its founders, Judith and Kobi Richter.

title: Country Girl
description: Berlin - IT'S complicated: Angela Merkel is an East German. I'm an East German too. Nevertheless, last Sunday I didn't vote for Mrs. Merkel, the Christian Democratic Union's candidate for chancellor. But now, like many Germans, I'm upset by her poor showing.

title: A Revived Debate: Babies, Careers, 'Having It All'
description: To the Editor:

title: Con Artists Trick Rescuers Into Giving Up Personal Data
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 21 - The three-card monte dealers are gone from Bourbon Street, but fraud lives even in an abandoned New Orleans, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: Freedom Museum Is Headed for Showdown at Ground Zero
description: The International Freedom Center, a proposed museum that is facing expulsion from ground zero under pressure from angry relatives of 9/11 victims, will make a forceful new appeal today to stay at the World Trade Center site.

description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Bauman, 83, Who Hit 72 Homers as Minor Leaguer, Dies
description: Joe Bauman, who hit 72 home runs in 1954 playing for a minor league team in Roswell, N.M., setting a single-season record for professional baseball that stood for nearly half a century, died Tuesday at a hospital in Roswell. He was 83.

title: Build Your Own Lego Masterpiece, Virtual Brick by Virtual Brick
description: Snapping Lego bricks together has been a childhood ritual for 50 years, but now Legos have found a way to click into the technological world -- and back again. The Lego Group, based in Denmark, recently opened an online Lego Factory (legofactory.com), where Lego enthusiasts can design projects with free 3-D software and then order a kit to build the model.

title: Seeking luxury and high-end value? Head to the Highlands
Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTER, VICTOR
description: FUTTER--Victor, 86, died peacefully at home in Manhasset, Long Island, on September 21, 2005. Beloved husband of Joan for 62 years, loving father of Jeffrey, Ellen and Deborah, father-in-law of William Cohan and Susan Sommer and cherished grandfather of Jillian, Allison, Claire, Anne, Elizabeth, Theodore and Quentin. He was an esteemed lawyer, author and lecturer dedicated to public service and numerous not-for-profit organizations and activities, but above all an adored and devoted husband, father and grandfather. He will be forever treasured, admired and remembered. The funeral is private and a memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Victor Futter Fellowship For Public Service at Columbia Law School. The family of Victor Futter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIESENTHAL, SIMON
description: WIESENTHAL--Simon. The Conscience of the Holocaust. Because of your efforts, the world is a better place. The six million Jews who perished in the Holocaust were not forgotten, and all those who have suffered persecution since have had your voice as their champion. Your courage and dedication to the cause of justice will always be our inspiration. On behalf of our 450,000 member families, our most sincere condolences to your family. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, September 27 at 7PM at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue. Due to security considerations, you must call 212-370-0320 to attend. The Simon Wiesenthal Center Rabbi Marvin Hier, Dean and Founder Larry Mizel, Chairman Nelson Peltz, Co-Chairman Rhonda Barad, Eastern Director

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: U.S. Forces Must Pay More
description: On a visit, Russia's defense minister, Sergei B. Ivanov, agreed to provide Kyrgyzstan with $3 million in military aid and equipment and said Russia wanted to keep its air base at Kant. President Kurmanbek S. Bakiyev said the United States would have to increase payments to keep using Manas Air Base for refueling missions and for transporting troops and equipment to and from Afghanistan.

title: Plane Lands Safely in Los Angeles After Landing Gear Becomes Stuck
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 - A JetBlue airliner whose front landing gear became stuck at a 90-degree angle after takeoff landed safely Wednesday night after circling the skies over Los Angeles for nearly three hours. Many of the 140 passengers watched live coverage of their plight on television monitors embedded in the backs of seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, WILLIAM JAY, M.D.
description: LEVIN--William Jay, M.D. Of Englewood, NJ on September 20. Beloved husband of SallyJo O'Brien. Cherished son of Morton and Doris Levin. Devoted father of Julia Jaye Levin. Dear brother of Frayda Levy, Melissa Levin, Mindy Levin and the late Jackie Shani. Loving uncle of Sigal, Advah, Lilach and Shachar. Services "Gutterman-Musicant" 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ, Friday, 10:30 AM.

title: U.S. Deliberating Whether to Retry Gotti After Jury Deadlocks on Racketeering Charges
description: A day after federal jurors in the trial of John A. Gotti, the prince of the Gambino crime family, returned a deadlocked verdict on the main racketeering counts against him, federal prosecutors declined to say whether they would try him again on the charges.

title: Gulf Hurricane of Top Strength Menaces Texas
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 21 - Hurricane Rita attained the strongest storm designation on Wednesday as it barreled toward the Texas coastline, forcing the evacuation of as many as a million people from this island city and other Gulf Coast communities along an arc from Corpus Christi to New Orleans.

title: New Web Site to Track Clinical Drug Trials
description: GENEVA, Sept. 21 - A trade group for the global drug industry said Wednesday that it would start a Web site meant to help doctors, patients and investors keep track of clinical drug trials.

description: To the Editor:

title: Memorializing Saul Bellow With Levity and Substance
description: The body is subject to the forces of gravity, says a character in one of Saul Bellow's stories. But the soul is ruled by levity. One would expect a memorial service for Mr. Bellow, who died in April at age 89, to have a degree of levity, and indeed the service at the 92nd Street Y yesterday afternoon did. But there were also the melancholy strains of tradition and reminders of Mr. Bellow's deep sense of his Jewishness.

title: School Janitor Is Arrested Over $13,000 in Phone Calls
description: A part-time custodian at a Manhattan high school was arrested yesterday and charged with using a school telephone to make more than $13,000 in calls to relatives in the Dominican Republic, city investigators said.

title: A Girl Caught in an Eternal Family Triangle
description: A woman floats through the air in pale silk robes that drift and wave. Her legs and arms are outstretched, her head is aloft and long hair streams down her back.

title: Searching for Beads, Finding a Jewel
description: I SHOULD have suspected something was up when Clementine approached her father instead of me to discuss her impending eighth birthday. But at the time I was distracted by plans for a four-day trip I was about to take.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Lawsuit On Canadian Drugs Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit the state filed against the Food and Drug Administration last year after it rejected a state plan to import prescription drugs from Canada. The judge, William K. Sessions of Federal District Court in Burlington, ruled that the plan violated import law and could not be carried out under the 2003 Medicare prescription drug law. Vermont, which has not decided whether it will appeal, was the first state to file such a lawsuit.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'The People's Champ' Overcomes Kanye West
description: In a week when seven albums made their debut in the Top 10, it was the Houston rapper Paul Wall's that took the No. 1 spot. According to Nielsen SoundScan, more than 176,000 copies of Mr. Wall's "People's Champ" (Atlantic) were sold, besting the 165,000 of Kanye West's "Late Registration" (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam), which dropped to No. 2 after two weeks at the top of the chart. The San Diego rockers Switchfoot entered the chart at a career-best No. 3 with "Nothing Is Sound" (Columbia), while Trisha Yearwood's "Jasper County" (MCA Nashville) came in at No. 4. Jumping into the No. 5 spot in its first week is the Pussyfoot Dolls' "PCD" (A&M/Interscope), featuring the hit single "Don't Cha," currently at No. 2 on the singles chart. "Chaos and Creation in the Backyard" (Capitol), Paul McCartney's first album of new material since 2001, became his 45th release to reach the Top 10, arriving at No. 6, and Damian Marley, a son of Bob Marley, made his debut at No. 7 with "Welcome to Jamrock" (Universal). GRANT JAMES VARJAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AWAD, ROSE (NEE AZRAK)
description: AWAD--Rose (nee Azrak). Born May 23, 1914, died peacefully on September 17, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Dewey. Beloved and loving mother of Claudette Razook, Carole Hunt, Douglas Awad and James Awad and the late Joan Elias. Cherished grandmother of 15 grandchildren and 18 great grandchildren. Rose devoted her life to her husband, family and extended family and friends, held a position of respect and was deeply loved by all. She had an extraordinary sensitivity and compassion for all those she loved, and all those loved were embraced by her kindness. Rose was an extraordinary cook and was quick to share her talents with her favorite charities, particularly the Ladies Aide Society and St. Mary's Orthodox Church in Bay Ridge where she was a prominent and devoted parishioner. She has left her impact on her progeny, who will carry on her principles, moral values and love forever. She will be sorely missed. Family will receive friends from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm on Tuesday, September 27, 2005. at the Herbst, Traska, Waldeck Chapels, 7614 4th Ave, Bklyn, N.Y.(valet parking). Funeral liturgy at 10am on Wednesday, September 28, 2005 at St. Mary's Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Blvd, Bklyn, N.Y. Interment to follow at Green-Wood Cemetery. Donations may be sent to St. Mary's Orthodox Church 8100 Ridge Blvd, Bklyn, N.Y. 11209. For information 718745-1600.

title: Backup Is Ready if Martin Can't Play
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 21 - If anyone is still wondering why it is such a big deal whether the injured Curtis Martin is able to start for the Jets on Sunday against Jacksonville, consider the team's regular-season record since he joined the club:

description: Manually Adjusting Windows AutoPlay

title: Gothic Treasures
description: An adventurous show of objects at the Metropolitan Museum helps us discover that the High Gothic of Prague is not the Gothic we find elsewhere.

title: Shopping: Planting Bulbs
description:
By LESLIE LAND
To garden is to battle frustration: rain doesnt come, deer come in droves. But planting bulbs is a different story. Spring flowers are just about guaranteed, absolutely no expertise is required, and there are all sorts of clever new tools to make a simple task even easier.

title: Guild v. Google
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Land Disputes in Brazil
description: The conflicts over land ownership that led to the death of an American nun are intensifying.

title: More on TimesSelect
description: I have some reservations about discussing the whole issue of TimesSelect here. First, because I had no role in the decision-making, which was a matter for company executives. And, second, because it seems a bit petty to debate Times policy instead of larger issues like, for example, genocide in Darfur. But so much of my mail is coming from readers who are furious with me and The Times that I think its appropriate to air it.

title: Not Some Science Fiction Future
description: Garreaus book is packed with telekinetic monkeys, Schwarzenegger mice built like steers, with necks bigger than their heads, a man who can send e-mail with his thoughts, vaccines that guard against acute pain for a month at a time, and memory and longevity pills. There are pressing questions about which of these technologies we should embrace, which ones we can stop, which ones we ought to stop  and how to tell the difference.

title: Partners in Travel
description: Ive had quite a few readers asking about my contest to choose a travel partner or two for an upcoming trip. (This is kind of a secret, to be disclosed next month or so, but I mentioned it a few items ago on this blog.)

title: Arrest in Killings of 2 Who Dared to Rob the Mob
description: In the annals of New York City crime, few undertakings were more ill-advised, foolhardy and just plain dangerous than the one that prosecutors say was chosen by Thomas and Rose Marie Uva, a young married couple from Queens.

title: With an Agent and a Part, He Just Needs a Line Now
description: Network sitcoms try to be lovable. The humor on HBO is founded on hate.

title: She Sees Dead People, and Offers Them a Sympathetic Ear
description: When it comes to death, CBS be not proud. The network's mawkish new series "Ghost Whisperer" posits itself as an hourlong grief-counseling session that benefits the living and the dead. A young newlywed keeps hearing from spirits who have not crossed over into some otherworldly zone of solace, and only with her message-delivery skills can the mourners and the mourned get on with their lives - or deaths, as the case may be.

title: 36 Hours in Point Reyes, Calif.
description: SINCE 1962, when President John F. Kennedy established the Point Reyes National Seashore, this triangle of land north of San Francisco has welcomed myriad travelers: elephant seals, elk, herons, humans. It's one of those rare places that's both open to outsiders and deeply protective of itself. From Point Reyes Station, the tiny town that sits outside the park's eastern edge, an unscathed landscape stretches out in marshes, tide pools and old pine forests, in pristine beaches and pastures broken at the ocean by granite bluffs. Unlike neighboring Bolinas, where residents tear down street signs to deter tourists, Point Reyes has no airs of exclusivity. Hiking, horseback riding, kayaking and clamming are just some of the activities that attract day-trippers, as well as checking out restaurants and browsing bookstores. Every year, hundreds of bird species pass through, as do more than two million people - a fitting mix for a place that lies beneath the Pacific Flyway, a great artery of aerial migration, and on Highway 1.

title: Manna From Hollywood: Charity Begins on TV
description: With "Three Wishes," the Christian rock star Amy Grant moves beyond singing about the Almighty. Her new NBC reality show sets her up to actually play God.

title: A Detective Used to Finding Killers and Losing Partners
description: The pilot of Fox's "Killer Instinct" - a title that recalls the days of witless "Fatal Attraction"-derived movie-naming - begins with a murderer's-eye camera breaking into a San Francisco apartment. Blackhearted preparations are made around a sleeping woman. Spiders can be seen crawling on her skin - one, then more, then dozens. Finally, she's immobilized, and the bad person stands over her.

title: Let Other Doctors Save Lives; These Specialists Create Them
description: "Inconceivable," which starts tonight on NBC, is a cerebral, macabre drama about a glamorous fertility clinic. It's impressively produced, but it will make you queasy. The show spends not a minute on ideological controversies surrounding this brave-new-world reproductive science - the surrogates, egg transfers, sperm samples - but there's something in it that's just too unstable to serve as a backdrop for primetime drama. Betrayal and vanity may suit the characters on "Nip/Tuck," FX's marvelously creepy drama about plastic surgery. Around the delicate creation of human life, however, it's worth saying: more reverence is in order.

title: Start-ups don't wait long for venture capitalists
Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTER, VICTOR
description: FUTTER--Victor. The President and Board of Trustees of Barnard College are saddened to learn of the death of Victor Futter, esteemed attorney and law professor, father of former Barnard President and Trustee, Ellen Futter. We extend our deepest sympathies to Ellen and her family. Anna Quindlen, Chair of the Board Judith Shapiro, President

title: S.E.C. Looks at Company's Retaliation on Analysts
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the Altera Corporation, a California chip maker, over its retaliation this year against Wall Street analysts who were less than bullish on the company's shares, the company said yesterday.

title: The Seasons; After the Fall
Gas Natural presses its Endesa bid

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 6 in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 23 - An assailant wearing a suicide belt killed six people waiting for buses in central Baghdad during a lunchtime attack today, the latest bloodshed in what American officials have said will be a period of heightened violence before the national referendum in three weeks on a new constitution. The attack appeared directed at Shiite workers, a favored target of the Sunni Arab insurgency.

title: Arrest in Killings of 2 Who Dared to Rob the Mob
description: In the annals of New York City crime, few undertakings were more ill-advised, foolhardy and just plain dangerous than the one that prosecutors say was chosen by Thomas and Rose Marie Uva, a young married couple from Queens.

title: A Justice as Parade Leader
description: Justice Antonin Scalia of the United States Supreme Court will serve as grand marshal for the Columbus Day Parade in Manhattan this year, the parade's organizers said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YARD, MOLLY
description: YARD--Molly. In tribute to Molly and the Student League for Industrial Democracy. Herbert Robinson

title: Corrections
description: A capsule summary on the first sports page on Monday misidentified the winner of the National Football League game between Cincinnati and Minnesota. It was the Bengals, not the Vikings.

title: Roller-Skating Their Troubles Away, 70's Style
description: A drowsy comedy about a handful of kids grooving and roller-skating, "Roll Bounce" has heart and good vibes but little else to recommend it. Directed by Malcolm D. Lee, who did marginally peppier work with "Undercover Brother," this bland family fare stars the young rapper Bow Wow (n Shad Gregory Moss) as Xavier, X for short, the most talented member of a roller-skating gaggle of friends. In the summer of 1978, when "Three Times a Lady" and "You're the One That I Want" were top of the pops, X and his buddies live on the South Side of Chicago, where they glide and bop to the disco beat.

title: Senate Rejects Bush Bid to Ease Delivery of Food To Poor Nations
description: A Bush administration proposal that sought to get food to starving people more rapidly and efficiently was rejected by Senate leaders yesterday, but the Canadian government announced that it was increasing the use of the same technique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUTZ, RONALD S.
description: STUTZ--Ronald S., 70, of Miami, Fla., Bayside, N.Y. and Roxbury, N.Y. Died peacefully on September 20, 2005 in Miami. Retired from teaching at Jamaica High School. He will be sorely missed by his loving wife Linda and by many cousins and friends. Graveside services on Sunday, September 25 at 3PM at Congregation B'nai Israel Cemetery in Fleischmanns, N.Y. Contributions may be made in his memory to Congregation B'nai Israel, Fleischmanns, N.Y. 12430.

title: Stringer tries to rein in Sony
Higher oil prices could be fillip to plane makers
Just When Airlines Thought Things Couldn't Get Worse
description: In April, the chief executive of Southwest Airlines, Gary C. Kelly, asked employees to prepare a business plan based on oil prices at a level then unimaginable: $55 a barrel. Little did Mr. Kelly know that his nightmare price then would be welcome now.

title: Sense of crisis deepening in beleaguered Indonesia
When It's Any Port in a Storm, It's Good to Have More
description: He doesn't want to, but sometimes Bruce Morrow has no choice. There are no public restrooms nearby, and one of his twin sons desperately needs one. So Mr. Morrow, 42, who lives in downtown Manhattan, escorts the 6-year-old to a gap between two parked cars.

title: Voting Reform Is in the Cards
description: WE agreed to lead the Commission on Federal Election Reform because of our shared concern that too many Americans lack confidence in the electoral process, and because members of Congress are divided on the issue and busy with other matters.

title: 10 Palestinians Dead in Blast at Hamas Weapons Parade
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 - A Palestinian pickup truck carrying rockets exploded today at a large Hamas rally as the group paraded its weapons through a densely packed refugee camp in the Gaza Strip. At least 10 Palestinians were killed and dozens were injured, Palestinian medical officials said.

title: Along the Hudson, a Storybook World
description: Along the Hudson, A Storybook World

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Stricter Water Monitoring Ordered
description: A Federal District Court judge ordered the city's Department of Environmental Protection yesterday to review and update the methods it uses to monitor and report on the quality of the city's drinking water. The department has been on probation for more than four years and under supervision by a federal monitor for violating federal environmental laws and contaminating the city's water supply in the late 1990's. The order, by Judge Charles L. Brieant, comes two weeks after a department employee pleaded guilty to falsifying water quality records at a Westchester County monitoring station, a federal crime and a violation of the department's probation. Under terms of the court order, the department will also have to develop procedures to ensure that its managers do not keep workers from cooperating with investigators. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inwood Woman Is Stabbed To Death
description: A 21-year-old woman died yesterday after she was stabbed repeatedly inside her Inwood apartment, the police said. The woman, who was identified by her sister as Cheyenne Patricio, was found by her mother around 9 p.m., lying in a pool of blood, said the sister, Cristina Semorile, 31. Ms. Patricio was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Allen Pavilion, where she died. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: For Bank of America, Next Target Is Europe
description: Correction Appended

title: Dancing Terrorists, on a Cruise Ship
description: The Lion at Theater Row 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton Tickets: (212)352-3101 Through Wednesday.

title: Adaptable banditry plagues South Africa
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Teterboro: Airport To Add Runway Barriers
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has approved the construction of soft-concrete arrester beds to help stop small planes that skid off the ends of runways at Teterboro Airport. The first, which will cost $11 million, is scheduled to be in place at the end of Runway 6 by the spring, said William DeCota, the Port Authority's director of aviation. A second arrester bed, which will cost $9 million, is planned for Runway 19 after an adjacent road is moved to make room for it. The Port Authority also approved spending $3 million to repair an arrester bed at Kennedy International Airport that has stopped three runaway planes. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Miles of Traffic as Texans Heed Order to Leave
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 22 - Heeding days of dire warnings about Hurricane Rita, as many as 2.5 million people jammed evacuation routes on Thursday, creating colossal 100-mile-long traffic jams that left many people stranded and out of gas as the huge storm bore down on the Texas coast.

title: Mediocrity Is Early Line In the N.F.C. North
description: In the N.F.C. North, mediocrity has spread like a virus.

title: Storm Raises Fears onWeak New Orleans Levees
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22 - As the outer bands of Hurricane Rita raked past with gusty winds and showers, water began seeping into the shattered and empty Lower Ninth Ward through makeshift dike repairs on Thursday, and the Army Corps of Engineers expressed concern about just how reliably a weakened levee system could protect this devastated city against a tidal surge along Lake Pontchartrain.

title: Berlusconi shaken as his financechief quits
An Artist of Many Styles Who Reclaimed Old Secrets
description: Most famous designers have a distinctive, identifiable style, but not Frederick Carder (1863-1963), the founder of Steuben Glass Works in Corning, N. Y. From 1903, when he founded the company, until 1932 he produced more than 8,000 designs, in styles ranging from Art Nouveau to Art Deco to neo-Classical.

title: After a Year Leading C.I.A., Goss Is Struggling, Some Say
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - A year after taking charge of the Central Intelligence Agency, Porter J. Goss is still struggling to rebuild morale and assert leadership within an institution shaken by recent failures and buffeted by change, current and former intelligence officials and members of Congress say.

title: All the Talking Is Nearly Done for Randolph
description: THE ritual of access and accountability has played out, day after day, month after month, across the seasons, late winter to early fall, from Florida to Flushing, in cities all over the country.

title: M.T.A. Security Plan Will Cost $130 Million More, Hevesi Says
description: Fortifying the city's transportation infrastructure against potential threats will cost $721 million, or $130 million more than the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's initial estimate of $591 million, officials said yesterday.

title: American University Chief Is Investigated Over Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - In the next few weeks, the board of American University will decide the future of its longtime leader, Benjamin Ladner, who has become the latest college president to be investigated over the nature of his spending.

title: A Retired Judge Is Killed Crossing the Street
description: Paul P.E. Bookson, a retired New York State judge and a past president of the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side, died last night after he was struck by a motorcycle while crossing a street in downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: No Arrest for Ex-President of Mexico
description: A federal judge refused to issue an arrest warrant against former President Luis Echeverra in connection with a massacre of student protesters in 1968. On Monday, a prosecutor filed charges of genocide against Mr. Echeverra for the massacre, in which soldiers fired on student protesters, killing dozens, but the judge said there was insufficient evidence for the charge. Mr. Echeverra, now 83, was interior minister in 1968, and president from 1970 to 1976. In July, another judge ruled that Mr. Echeverra could not be charged in the killings of two dozen protesters in 1971. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: New Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Planting Bulbs
description: TO garden is to battle frustration: rain doesn't come, deer come in droves. But planting bulbs is a different story. Spring flowers are just about guaranteed, absolutely no expertise is required, and there are all sorts of clever new tools to make a simple task even easier. LESLIE LAND

title: Crime in South Africa Grows More Vicious
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 22 - On most big-city freeways, a commuter headache is a fender-bender and a line of rubberneckers. This big city is, ah, different.

title: Drug Treatments for Schizophrenia
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivera, a Retiring Type, Brushes Away the Hype
description: The third question about the Cy Young award was floated to Mariano Rivera, and he decided it was time to talk about the broomsticks. To explain his polite indifference to winning the personal pitching award, Rivera had to discuss what role broomsticks played in his life and his career.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about efforts by residents of Chebeague Island in Maine to secede from the town of Cumberland misstated the island's size. It is more than 1,860 acres, not 200.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Pernod Ricard Profit Drops
description: Pernod Ricard, the world's second-largest liquor company after Diageo, reported an unexpected drop in first-half profit because of higher advertising spending and currency-hedging costs linked to the $13 billion takeover of Allied Domecq. Net income fell to 157 million euros ($192 million) from 169 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Pernod makes Wild Turkey bourbon and Mumm champagne, and is based in Paris. Pernod raised marketing spending by 13 percent in the half to win clients in fast-growing markets like China and shore up sales in France, where demand is dropping.

title: Corrections
description: Correction Appended

title: After Katrina's Lesson, Bush Is Heading to Texas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Under intense pressure to show that he has learned the practical and political lessons of Hurricane Katrina, President Bush planned on Thursday to pack his foul-weather gear and head to Texas on Friday ahead of Hurricane Rita, trying to make clear that he is directing an all-out federal effort to cope with the storm.

title: New Jersey Med School Board Faces Ethics Charges
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22 - New Jersey's ethics commission received a formal complaint Thursday charging that five members of the governing board of the state's embattled medical school work for companies that do business with the school and are violating the state's conflict of interest law.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PERRY, ALAN S.
description: PERRY--Alan S. 3/27/23-9/23/95 We miss you. Love, your gals: Nancy, Chrissie, Liz and Mimi

title: Freedom or Not?
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation will soon decide whether ground zero will continue to include an International Freedom Center, or whether families of some 9/11 victims will be able to censor those plans. Yesterday, the Freedom Center submitted a report that specified in greater detail how it would be run and what it hoped to present in the way of programming. This became necessary when Gov. George Pataki capitulated to a misguided outcry from critics who fear that the center's main task will be to present anti-American views of 9/11.

title: Rooting for Bibi Is Rooting for Israel
description: Next Monday, Israel and the whole Middle East will witness a hugely important election. Ostensibly it is a vote over when the Likud Party should hold its primary. But it actually is a vote over who will lead Likud into the next election -- Prime Minister Ariel Sharon or his challenger, Bibi Netanyahu. If I could vote, there is no question whom I would cast my ballot for: Bibi. Yes, pray for Bibi to crush Mr. Sharon and drive him right out of the party. That's where Mr. Sharon belongs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about a new museum of emigration in Bremerhaven, Germany, referred incorrectly to its uniqueness. Other such museums exist in Europe, including at least one in Ireland.

title: EU report spurs battle over budget for regional aid
Aide says cleric will tell Shiites to pass charter
Water Pours Over Levee, Flooding Dozens of Blocks in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 23 -The force of approaching Hurricane Rita has torn through levees still under repair for damage from Hurricane Katrina 24 days ago, sending water cascading into the hardest-hit neighborhoods of the city this morning, quickly submerging cars and flooding empty homes wrested from their foundations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOULKS, EVELYN (LYN)
description: FOULKS--Evelyn (Lyn) September 19, 2005. 84. Beloved sister and aunt. Alfred University, Cleveland School of Art, Traphagen School of Fashion. Well known jewelry designer. Preceded in death by her husband Horace "Bud" Foulks. In addition to brothers Arthur and Donald Collins, Mrs. Foulks is survived by 12 nieces and nephews, numerous great nieces and nephews, many friends and her precious poodle BoBo. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC, Wednesday September 28 from 2:005:00 P.M. and 7:00-8:00 P.M. Service at Frank E. Campbell at 8:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the North Shore Animal League.

title: Referendum will test Swiss-EU relationship
Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWTON, MARTHA E.
description: LAWTON -- Martha E. Malkames. Age 56, of Mahopac, NY, on September 22, 2005. Survived by her father, husband, brother, sister, eight children and 2 two grandchildren. Visiting today 3-8 pm, Joseph J. Smith Funeral Home, 692 Rt. 6, Mahopac. Funeral Saturday, 9:45 am, Sacred Heart Church, Monroe, NY. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANDER, NOEL
description: MANDER--Noel. 93, the pipe organ builder, died September 18, 2005. Mander founded NP Mander in 1936, but shelved it for the duration of WWII during which he fought. After the war Mander restored his firm and eventually, the reputation of the British organ building tradition. He went on to build and restore fine instruments around the world, including those of St. Paul's Cathedral and Canterbury Cathedral. He was much loved.

title: U.S. on Front Lines and in Backwaters
description: Imperial Grunts The American Military on the Ground By Robert D. Kaplan 421 pages. Random House. $27.95.

title: Sony Plans 10,000 Job Cuts
description: TOKYO, Sept. 22 - Sir Howard Stringer, the new chief executive of the Sony Corporation, unveiled a turnaround plan Thursday that would cut 10,000 jobs, shed unprofitable products and centralize decision-making at the struggling, sprawling Japanese electronics giant, known for its Walkman portable music players and PlayStation game consoles.

title: Houston, You Have a Problem
description: Facing a potentially devastating hit from Hurricane Rita, the Houston-area economy ground to a halt yesterday as more than four million residents evacuated the city and other nearby coastal areas on clogged highways, which were made worse by motorists stranded as gasoline ran short.

title: THE CHURN
description: People

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Coretta King Returns Home
description: More than five weeks after suffering a stroke and heart attack, Coretta Scott King, 78, widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., went home from the hospital. Mrs. King will continue to work with a physical therapist for three hours a day, six days a week, as she tries to regain her speech and the use of her right arm, her doctor said. After her stroke on Aug. 16, Mrs. King lost most of the motor functions on her right side. Brenda Goodman (NYT)

title: Pleasing All Tastes, From Patriotic to Schmaltz
description: Orchestras in America may be struggling, but the New York Philharmonic must be doing something right. The Philharmonic opened its season on Wednesday night with a gala program conducted by Lorin Maazel, and patrons voted their approval with their pocketbooks. A record $3.1 million was raised on this single night, with 1,000 people attending the posh dinner after the performance. Moreover, an official from the Philharmonic said, new subscriptions are up 32 percent.

title: Italy Extradites London Bombing Suspect
description: A suspect in the failed July 21 bombings in London was extradited from Italy and charged with a variety of offenses, including attempted murder and possession of explosives. The suspect, Hussain Osman, left, a 27-year-old Briton of Ethiopian descent who is also known as Hamdi Issac, is accused of trying, and failing, to blow up a train on the London Underground at Shepherd's Bush, on a day when three other would-be bombers also set bombs that failed to explode. Three other suspects in the aborted attacks are being held at the Belmarsh high-security prison in London. Mr. Osman was arrested in Rome a week after the bombings and fought British efforts to extradite him, saying that he would not get a fair trial. He is to appear before magistrates at Belmarsh today. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: The Pegu Club
description: I knew the pleading look. I'd seen it before. Not just on her face but on the faces of other friends who had trudged with me to so many cursed destinations and, upon finding a charmed one, wanted to be able to keep it to -- and for -- themselves.

title: Arts, Briefly; Country Pays For a City Visit
description: Correction Appended

description: NEW YORK

title: Fleeing Town, in a Manner of Speaking
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 22 - Rafael Lara had been creeping along Interstate 10 for only four hours, an eyeblink compared with the 12 or more hours some had been struggling to flee Hurricane Rita. "I'd feel a lot better about that," Mr. Lara, 30, a Houston firefighter, said Thursday, "except we're still only four miles from our house."

Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIRKER, DR. LOTHER
description: ZIRKER--Dr. Lother, on September 21, 2005. Husband of Johanna (nee Bronner). Father of Dr. William Zirker (Elayne DeSimone). Grandfather of Aaron and Jacob Zirker. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Friday, 12 noon, from Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Queens, NY. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY. Shiva observed at the home of Dr. William Zirker and Elayne DeSimone. For information contact Goldsteins Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks, Phila.

2nd Banana Whose Taste Is Irresistible
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 - Just as there has never been another lead character on television quite like Larry David -- it would be hard to imagine Ralph Kramden or Ray Barone picking up a prostitute to qualify for the carpool lane to Dodger Stadium -- there has never been a sidekick quite like Jeff Greene, the fictional Mr. David's fictional manager.

title: Khodorkovsky Appeal Rejected
description: A panel of three judges rejected most points of an appeal by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon and political opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin. The ruling, which came at the end of a one-day hearing, threw out minor convictions and reduced Mr. Khodorkovsky's nine-year sentence by a year but upheld the most serious charges of fraud and tax evasion. It also effectively ends his jailhouse campaign for a seat in Parliament. Platon Lebedev, Mr. Khodorkovsky's co-defendant and partner, had his sentence cut to eight years from nine. Anton V. Drel, one of Mr. Khodorkovsky's lawyers, said it had not yet been decided whether to pursue further appeals in other courts, including the European Court for Human Rights in Strasbourg. Andrew Kramer (NYT)

title: Baker Adds Another Dimension to the Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 22 - The first time it happened, Chris Baker wondered if one of the Miami Dolphins players had his signals crossed. But as last Sunday's game wore on, it became apparent that the Dolphins were purposefully deploying an extra linebacker or safety to shadow Baker, the Jets' tight end, like a pickpocket.

title: Manna From Hollywood: Charity Begins on TV
description: With "Three Wishes," the Christian rock star Amy Grant moves beyond singing about the Almighty. Her new NBC reality show sets her up to actually play God.

title: Agency Calls on Frist About Timing of Stock Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - A spokesman for Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, said Thursday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had contacted Mr. Frist's office about the sale in June of his shares in HCA, the giant hospital company founded by his family.

description: Correction Appended

description: A front-page credit on Wednesday with the picture of Simon Wiesenthal, the death camp survivor who dedicated his life to tracking down fugitive Nazi war criminals, misspelled the surname of the photographer. He is Ed Alcock.

title: West Presses for Nuclear Agency to Rebuke Iran, Despite Russian Dissent
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - The United States and Europe sought support Thursday for a tough new resolution they are circulating at the International Atomic Energy Agency accusing Iran of "noncompliance" with treaties governing its nuclear program but not immediately referring the matter to the United Nations Security Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FROIMSON, ALFRED
description: FROIMSON--Alfred. September 21, 2005 from cancer. Loved and mourned by family and friends. Memorial September 26 at Cedarpark, NJ.

description: KENNEDY -- Elizabeth, 101, on September 17, 2005. Sadly we say goodbye to our Mimi. She was loved and admired by all who knew her. Her greatest pleasure was her family to whom she gave more love than could be imagined. We will love you forever . Anne, David, Sarah and Elizabeth Griffin

title: Embattled Commissioner of F.D.A. Resigns
description: Lester M. Crawford resigned as the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration this afternoon, telling his staff that at 67, he is ready to retire.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Truck Fire Snarls Bridge Traffic
description: A pickup truck caught fire last evening on the George Washington Bridge, making it necessary to close the upper level for more than an hour and snarling the evening commute for thousands of drivers, the authorities said. No one was hurt, but the 1998 Dodge pickup, which belongs to Andrew Iverson, 36, of Jay, Maine, was destroyed. Mr. Iverson, an unemployed truck driver who was returning home from Tallahassee, Fla., was halfway across the upper level about 6 p.m. when he noticed smoke coming from his truck and jumped out. Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said that all lanes were reopened and traffic was fully moving by 7:25 p.m. As for Mr. Iverson, he said he would be moving again "as soon as I get a rental car." Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Oracle Profit Flat in First Quarter; Database Business Slowed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 - The Oracle Corporation, the software maker, said Thursday that its first quarter profit was flat because of sluggish growth in the company's database business.

title: Art in Review
description: Jim IsermannDeitch Projects18 Wooster Street, SoHoThrough Oct. 15

title: Hamas Leader Guilty in Two Deadly Attacks
description: A court convicted a Hamas leader of masterminding the suicide bombing at the Park Hotel in Netanya during Passover in 2002 that killed 29 people. The defendant, Abbas al-Sayed, 39, was also found guilty of orchestrating a suicide bombing in 2001 that killed five people at a shopping mall in the city. Prosecutors said he bought weapons and organized bombings with money from Hamas leaders abroad. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (4) INCONCEIVABLE -- Series premiere. Life at a fertility clinic has its crises. Tonight's involve a dead soldier's frozen embryos and a tiny mistake with a surrogate birth. Angie Harmon (left) and Jonathan Cake star as glamorous reproductive specialists.

description: DREYER--Harvey. You and yours have always been a special and loving part of our lives. We will miss you so much. Thanks for our wonderful memories. Hilda and Bob Abramson

description: To the Editor:

title: For Hotelier, Crisis Is Another Word for Opportunity
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 21 - For the first few days after Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans, F. Patrick Quinn III did what he could to help the displaced. He carted food and water to guests stranded at a hotel he owns on the edge of the French Quarter. He even ventured out on a dinghy to help a stranger in a futile attempt to rescue the man's brother, stranded in a flooded section of the city.

title: Briefly: Senate passes huge bill on food and agriculture
Star Parties
description: DARK sky. In the age of light pollution, it's the elusive dream of astronomers, few of whom live near unadulterated night skies these days. "We are turning the night into day," said Robert Gent, president of the Astronomical League, the world's largest federation of amateur astronomers. That has a growing number of amateur astronomers and star enthusiasts gathering in remote settings to enjoy the stellar beauty of dark skies -- from the polar caps and dust storms of Mars to the luminescent Andromeda galaxy.

title: In the O.C., a Walkable Island With Neighbors Nearby
description: NO one is more surprised about the price of property on Balboa Island than the people who own homes there. These days, a modest cottage in the middle of the island starts at $1.5 million. A home right on the bayfront runs at least $3.3 million -- and that's a tear-down. But what else would you expect for property in the middle of Newport Harbor in Orange County, Calif. -- the real-life "O.C."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the stabbing deaths of a woman and two children in Jersey City misspelled the surname of the Hudson County prosecutor at one point in some copies. He is Edward J. De Fazio, not De Fabio.

title: Once Disaster Hits, It Seems Never to End
description: A masterpiece of indirection and pure visceral thrills, David Cronenberg's latest mindblower, "A History of Violence," is the feel-good, feel-bad movie of the year. The story of a seemingly average American family almost undone by cataclysmic violence, the film takes place in a surreal and mercilessly brutal land, Anytown, U.S.A., that has been repeatedly soaked in blood only to be repeatedly washed clean. The great kick of the movie -- or rather, its great kick in the gut -- comes from Mr. Cronenberg's refusal to let us indulge in movie violence without paying a price. The man wants to make us suffer, exquisitely.

title: Editorial Observer: Changing the Rules for the Team Sport of Bread-Winning
description: There were hints over the years that my friends and I should have noticed. While it was desirable, in an era of equal rights, for men to cook dinner for their girlfriends or wives, taking out the garbage was often called "a man's job," and you, the women in our lives, wouldn't touch the stuff. And when it was time to get out the rat poison or squash the spider, many of you turned to us as the big strong hunters. That was a particular source of confusion because women have been encouraging men of my generation to wax their chests and moisturize, to dress up in designer clothes and carry squishy mats to yoga classes. We are no longer the household spear carriers.

title: Is the World Suffering From Too Much Martha?
description: IT is not yet clear how well Martha Stewart's new television shows will do, but one thing has become apparent: since the shows began to air, a lot of investors in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia have been selling.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Mining Investigation
description: The National Assembly of Venezuela will open an investigation into mining companies operating in the country, after a vow by President Hugo Chvez to regain control of the industry. Deputy Pedro Jimnez Flores said in a statement on the National Assembly's Web site that members would travel to the southeastern state of Bolvar next week to inspect mining operations and evaluate the conflict between small miners and Crystallex in the Las Cristinas tract, the country's largest gold deposit. The inquiry comes two days after Mr. Chvez said the country intended to end mining concessions to foreign companies and create a state-owned agency to exploit Venezuela's mineral reserves.

title: In One Ohio Town, a Fading Sport Is Still King, for a Day
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 - The traffic on Route 23 started to back up early Thursday, with cars inching their way into the Delaware County Fairgrounds to witness this year's running of the Little Brown Jug. In the world of American sports, it was an amazing sight to behold, for here were tens of thousands of people gathering to see, of all things, a harness race.

title: China Lectured by Taiwan Ally
description: BEIJING, Sept. 22 - China's leaders may have felt they had no better friend in Taiwan than Li Ao, a defiant and outspoken politician and author who says that Taiwan should unify with Communist China.

title: Senate panel strongly backs Roberts
Math Scores Statewide Show Gains in 4th Grade
description: The number of fourth graders performing at grade level in math increased markedly across New York State this year, with the biggest gains in Yonkers and New York City. But the number of eighth graders scoring at grade level declined slightly statewide, ending four years of steady gains in New York City.

title: Briefly: Political parties vow to boycott elections

title: Louisiana Lawmakers Propose $250 Billion Recovery Package

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Indictments Of Chicago Officials
description: Five current or former Chicago officials, two with personal ties to Mayor Richard M. Daley, were indicted on federal fraud charges and accused of rigging hiring and promotions in city departments. All five were charged with mail fraud; one was also charged with making false statements to federal agents. Since January 2004, 36 people have been indicted in the investigation; 23 have been convicted. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Dickensian Deprivations Delivered From the Gut
description: Roman Polanski's last movie, "The Pianist," which was widely hailed as a return to form, was also an intensely personal movie for the director. Adapted from someone else's autobiography, the movie, about a Polish Jew struggling to survive the nightmare of Naziism, nonetheless dealt with experiences painfully close to Mr. Polanski's own life. The same might be said about his wonderful new adaptation of Charles Dickens's "Oliver Twist," a novel that has been brought to the screen many times before, but never with such a dark intensity of feeling.

Blackhearted preparations are made around a sleeping woman. Spiders can be seen crawling on her skin -- one, then more, then dozens. Finally, she's immobilized, and the bad person stands over her.

So far, we've heard some good ideas and some terrible ones, but none address the huge scale of the problem.

Ms. Sheehan and her supporters also announced a $1 million antiwar advertising campaign starting this week in major newspapers and on television. Elisabeth Bumiller (NYT)

title: The Listings: Sept. 23-Sept. 29; THE WHITE STRIPES
description: With his rusty holler, old-timey leanings and relentless lone-guitar attack, Jack White, above, has established himself over the last five years as the retro-rock bandleader to beat. But the White Stripes's latest album, "Get Behind Me Satan" (V2), reveals the falsetto-screeching frontman's country blues shtick to be more versatile than he'd previously let on. The first single, "Blue Orchid," seemed to aim for the straightforward appeal of the band's previous rockers, like "Seven Nation Army." But the balance of Mr. White's new songs veer off in poppier directions. Over the reliable cymbal smashes laid down by the drummer (and his ex-wife), Meg White, he now displays previously undisclosed piano chops. And on numbers like the strutting "My Doorbell," he even sprinkles some funk. The psychedelic-pop-tinged "Forever for Her (Is Over for Me)" suggests 70's confections without letting up on the band's trademark surly stomp. The album's title doesn't make it clear whether the White Stripes are recruiting the Devil or shoving him aside. But judging by the dark view of romance expressed on ominous tunes like the marimba-driven "Nurse" and the cabaret-country "I'm Lonely (but I Ain't That Lonely Yet)," the recruitment seems more likely. Still, the sing-along "Little Ghost" provides some lighthearted graveyard humor with its jug-band plea for a pretty phantom to "scare me up a little bit of love." The opening act is the indie rockers the Shins, who may not "change your life," as Natalie Portman's character in the movie "Garden State" promised, though their ethereal pop has been known to alter an evening or two for the better. (Tomorrow and Sunday at 7 p.m., Keyspan Park, 1904 Surf Avenue, Coney Island, Brooklyn, (718)449-8497; $45.) LAURA SINAGRA

description: KAUFMAN--Sidney, 88, September 21, 2005. Of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Ilene, Carolyn and Steven. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: School Bus Employees Arraigned
description: Two employees of a school bus company were charged with child endangerment yesterday after leaving a 5-year-old disabled boy alone on an unlocked bus on Tuesday morning, the authorities said. After picking the boy up in the morning, a driver and a matron were supposed to drop him off at Public School 118 in Hollis, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. But about 10:15 a pedestrian on 55th Street in East Flatbush, near the home of the driver, Ezekial Jeremiah, heard the boy crying aboard the bus. He was strapped into a third-row seat, calling for his mother. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Jeremiah, 43, and the matron, Lillian Ortiz, 50, were arraigned yesterday in Queens Criminal Court and released on their own recognizance. They could each face up to one year in prison. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Six Die in Two Blasts in Pakistan
description: Bombs strapped to two bicycles left at a public park and a shopping district in Lahore, Pakistan's second-biggest city, killed six people and wounded 30, according to officials and reports in the local media. No one claimed responsibility for the blasts. While police officials speculated that the intention was to cause panic in the city, security across the country was stepped up. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Correction
description: The 36 Hours column on Sept. 9, about Panama City, misidentified an ingredient in the savory breakfast roll known as carimaola. It is made with mashed yuca, a starchy tuber also known as cassava -- not yucca, a type of agave.

description: CURRAN--Marylyn. 64 of Bayville, NY died suddenly on September 20th. Devoted daughter, wife, mother, grandmother, Teacher, Hearing Officer, Burn Center Nurse, Honorary FDNY Medical Officer and Friend. Survived by mother Mary, Husband Jim, daughters Gwendolyn, Pamela (James), and Merrilee (Thomas). Grandchildren, Katie, Allison (deceased), Sasha, Sophie, Heidi and Dylan. Active participant in all activities associated with The New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation. She was our anchor and guiding light and will be deeply missed and forever cherished. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Allison P. Henry Art Fund c/o/ Portledge School, 355 Duck Pond Road, Locust Valley, NY 11560 www.portledge.org

title: Kill the Light, Save a Bird
description: Tourists have always flocked to see the bright lights of New York City, but starting this week, the city is dimming parts of its renowned skyline to ward off one group of visitors: migratory birds. The Chrysler Building, Rockefeller Center, the Citigroup Center, the Morgan Stanley Building and the World Financial Center are among the high-profile high-rises that have agreed to requests from the city and the Audubon Society to dim or turn off nonessential lighting at midnight.

description: A first-place team took the field to start the game at Yankee Stadium last night, and although that had once been a regular occurrence on September nights in the Bronx, the home fans finally enjoyed celebrating something unusual in the atypical 2005 season.

title: At the Gothic Crossroads of Prague
description: TO keep us happy, museums tend to give us what we think we want, which basically means what we already know. When they don't do this, though, we get an adventure. "Prague: The Crown of Bohemia, 1347-1437" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is an adventure. It's one of those shows you go to not at all sure what you're in for, and when you find out, you're floored, because it's so beautiful, and so familiar, and so strange.

title: Joint Trial for 9 Srebrenica Suspects
description: Judges at the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague have decided to hold a group trial for nine of the highest-ranking officers of the Bosnian Serb Army who are charged in the mass killing of prisoners at Srebrenica in 1995, the court announced. It said the trial would avoid duplication, ensure consistency and lessen the hardship for witnesses. One of the nine suspects, Zdravko Tolimir, is still on the run, but the other eight are in custody. No trial date was announced. Marlise Simons (NYT)

description: MOST of the time, the Katahdin Stream Campground in Baxter State Park in Maine is a simple cluster of tent sites and picnic tables. But for hundreds of northbound through hikers around this time of year, the little plot of land becomes a somewhat more meaningful place: the final staging area in their 2,175-mile journeys on the Appalachian Trail.

A young newlywed keeps hearing from spirits who have not crossed over into some otherworldly zone of solace, and only with her message-delivery skills can the mourners and the mourned get on with their lives -- or deaths, as the case may be.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Gives To 9/11 Memorial
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to contribute $3 million to the Tribute Center, the temporary 9/11 memorial that is scheduled to open in the spring at 120 Liberty Street, near the World Trade Center site. The center's Introductory/Orientation Gallery will be named for the Port Authority, and Port Authority employees will lead tours of the site from there. Supporting the center "is in line with our mission of revitalizing Lower Manhattan and redeveloping the World Trade Center site," said James Connors, a Port Authority executive. title: World Briefing | United Nations: High Death Rates For Muslim Children
description: Islamic states account for the highest child mortality rates, with 4.3 million children under the age of 5 dying each year from preventable disease and malnutrition, 60 percent before their first birthday, according to a report from Unicef and the 57-nation Organization of the Islamic Conference. The report found the worst deprivation in sub-Saharan African countries. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VACCHIANO, WILLIAM
description: VACCHIANO--William. The entire Juilliard community mourns the passing of William Vacchiano, one of the longest serving faculty members in the history of the School. He was a member of the trumpet faculty from 1935 to 2002, and his students went on to perform in most of the major orchestras around the world. A person of impeccable musical integrity and great humanity, he was revered and loved by his students and friends. We send our deepest condolences to his entire family. He will be deeply missed. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: Hunting for a Child No One Believes Is There
description: In my next life, I want Jodie Foster to be my mother. (Sorry, Mom.) In her last two major films, David Fincher's "Panic Room" and the new thrill-free thriller "Flightplan," from the German director Robert Schwentke, this awards-bedecked actress has played the world's most ferocious single mother who, forced to protect her only daughter, swats bad men like flies. In between these two films, Ms. Foster delivered a gemstone performance in Jean-Pierre Jeunet's "Very Long Engagement," as a married woman who turns to a stranger to become pregnant. In the film she made before "Panic Room," the independent scrap "The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys," she played a Catholic nun, Sister Assumpta.

title: Facing His Irish Recruits, Willingham Drives Ahead
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 21 - Tyrone Willingham's makeup -- he calls it his wiring -- prevents him from dwelling on the past. He will not second-guess or revisit what he cannot change.

description: BATON ROUGE, La. - After 18 years of military service on active duty and in the Louisiana Air National Guard, Staff Sgt. Michael Sorjonen thought the mission sounded routine: rescue a handful of people from the roof of a two-story Holiday Inn.

title: Yonkers Enlists Badillo to Investigate School Finances
description: YONKERS, Sept. 22 - After months of controversy over finances in the city schools, Mayor Philip A. Amicone announced on Thursday that he would bring in a high-profile consultant, Herman Badillo, to do a top-to-bottom examination of how the school system spends its money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARLT, PAUL T.
description: ARLT--Paul T. died on September 20th at age 91 in Rye, NY. He leaves his wife of 65 years MacClaire, a daughter Ronay Menschel, son-in-law Richard Menschel, and grandchildren Charis and Ryan Drant, and Sabina and Celene Menschel who loved him and to whom he was devoted. Born in the Bronx, graduate of Townsend Harris High School and Colgate University, Paul was a painter, political cartoonist, and graphic artist for 70 years. A longtime resident of Washington, DC, he studied at the Corcoran Gallery of Art and The Phillips Collection art schools. A Marine Corps combat artist in WWII, he worked for the State Department under the Marshall Plan from 1948-51. From 1951-56 he was a syndicated political cartoonist for the New York Herald Tribune. In the 1960's he was commissioned by NASA to witness and paint aspects of the Gemini and Apollo space missions. In watercolor or oil, his work depicted the beauty of nature, the drama of events, and the goodwill of people. In later years he explored the politics and architecture of Washington, DC and the landscape of Nantucket. His work is in the collections of the Museum of the City of New York, and The Phillips Collection and the National Air and Space Museum in Washington DC. Services will be private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Museum of the City of New York or The Phillips Collection.

title: Ex-Pharmaceutical Executive Sentenced to 8 Years in the Beating Death of His Wife
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22 - A former professor and pharmaceutical executive who was found guilty of beating his wife to death and then staging a car accident to cover it up was sentenced on Thursday to eight years in prison.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Lost' Draws a Crowd
description: Now that we know part of what is down the mysterious hatch on ABC's "Lost" -- a menacing fan of the Mamas and the Papas with a communications system whom Jack (Matthew Fox, below) had met before being stranded on the island -- we can all wonder why we didn't guess such an obvious answer. Just kidding. Wednesday's season premiere of the Emmy-winning drama produced even more intriguing questions than it answered, and it drew a large audience of 23.09 million, and a dominant share of 18-to-49-year-olds. ABC easily won both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic in Nielsen's estimates. "Lost" also helped the debut of "Invasion" win the 10 p.m. hour, with 16.88 million viewers. NBC's opener of "Law & Order's" 16th year also did well in that time slot, with 13.11 million viewers. But the network's other debuts earlier in the evening were weaker: "E-Ring" delivered an audience of 9.39 million, and "The Apprentice: Martha Stewart" performed surprisingly poorly, attracting only 7.65 million. On UPN, "America's Top Model" was back, with 4.72 million viewers, and a second-place finish for the night among women 18 to 34, one of its target demographics. And finally, CBS also featured two season premieres, "Still Standing" (7.03 million) and "Yes, Dear" (7.37 million). KATE AURTHUR

title: Bus Carrying Elderly Storm Evacuees Explodes Near Dallas
description: WILMER, Tex., Sept. 23 - A bus carrying elderly evacuees from an assisted living center in Houston was rocked by multiple explosions on its way to Dallas early this morning, killing at least 24 elderly residents.

title: Why His Peers Say Kozlowski Got Off Easy
description: L. DENNIS KOZLOWSKI, whose excesses damaged the reputations of everything from shower curtains to ice sculptures, is on his way to a New York State prison for at least seven years. He is lucky that his sentence was not determined by a jury of his peers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HESSE, HENRY H.
description: HESSE--Henry H. Died on September 20, 2005. Beloved father to Michael, Susanne and Elena. Loving husband to Marion. Graveside services Monday, September 26, 1pm, Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Edwards Funeral Home, 914-693-3330

title: Theodore Barber Dies at 78; Was Major Critic of Hypnosis
description: Theodore X. Barber, a psychologist who became a leading critic of hypnosis after his scientific studies concluded that the power of suggestion often worked nearly as well, died on Sept. 10 at a hospital in Framingham, Mass. He was 78 and lived in Ashland, Mass.

title: Where's the Party? Scottsdale!
description: WHEN Steve G. Bernath, 32, an engineer from San Jose, Calif., visited a friend in Scottsdale two years ago, he expected a sleepy community full of "golf fanatics and blue-haired women," he said. But a weekend of clubbing quickly changed his mind. "I was in awe actually as far as the night life," he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEDER, EILEEN
description: BEDER--Eileen. Died on September 21 joining Abner, her love of 46 years on the second anniversary of his death. She began a career at Merrill Lynch, leaving to raise a family. Resuming her career, she became a certified financial advisor and, finally, a Vice President at Ryan Beck. Her true life's work, however, was as mother, sister, aunt, cousin, friend and grandmother. Her smile, warmth, generosity and love will be missed.

title: Vexed by Rivalries and Deficits, Italy's Economy Minister Quits
description: MILAN, Sept. 22 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's government was thrown into disarray Thursday as his economy minister, Domenico Siniscalco, resigned after failing to oust Italy's discredited central bank chief, Antonio Fazio.

title: Newly Crowded Homes and Towns Strain at the Seams
description: BATON ROUGE, La. - The Wal-Mart off Interstate 10 here is no longer open 24 hours a day. It needs to close at 10 p.m. to restock the underwear, salad greens and soap being snapped up by the dozens by new residents, inconveniencing those who are long accustomed to doing their shopping at night.

title: Ukraine Parliament Approves New Premier After Rivals' Deal
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 - President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine won parliamentary approval of a new prime minister on Thursday on a second vote after striking a deal with his bitter rival in last year's disputed presidential elections.
