description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Daniel Pearl Music Days
description: The Daniel Pearl Foundation will present the fourth annual Daniel Pearl Music Days, a global network of performances sharing the theme harmony for humanity, from Oct. 1 to 10. Both the foundation and the music days celebration were formed in honor of the journalist Daniel Pearl, who was kidnapped and killed by terrorists in Pakistan while he was on assignment for The Wall Street Journal in 2002. Mr. Pearl was a classically trained violinist, an avid fiddler and a mandolin player. There is no financial or fund-raising aspect to the celebration, and anyone can participate by dedicating a prescheduled musical concert or song, or by organizing a special event that includes a statement or program note in support of tolerance and harmony for humanity. Last year's event included more than 400 concerts in 39 countries, and this year the reach will expand even further as it includes a new Internet component. A Web-based collection of words and music, e-Stage, will include a dedicated Internet radio station broadcasting for the entire month of October with symphonic tributes, bluegrass salutes, jazz jams, youth and student recordings and music from a variety of Music Days participants. The station will also feature some of the diverse music of the event's honorary committee members, who include Sir Elton John, Yo-Yo Ma, Barbra Streisand and Herbie Hancock. Information: www.music-days.org. STEVEN McELROY

title: He's Got to Put It All Down in a Letter (to His Gun)
description: Thomas Vinterberg, the director of "Dear Wendy," and Lars von Trier, its screenwriter, collaborated previously on the Dogma 95 manifesto, now marking its 10th anniversary, which set out to revitalize cinema by imposing a set of strict and arbitrary rules -- a "vow of chastity" -- on filmmakers. Mr. Vinterberg went on to direct "The Celebration" (1998), the only Dogma movie made so far with a legitimate claim to greatness. Mr. von Trier has moved on to other provocations, most recently a trilogy, of which two parts ("Dogville" and "Manderlay") have been completed, set in imaginary American small towns.

title: Senator Frist's Stock Sale

For years, Mr. Frist assured critics that there was no conflict of interest because his HCA money was held in a blind trust.

The Listings: Sept. 23-Sept. 29; MATTHEW MORRISON
description: Because of certain genetic disadvantages -- a square jaw, muscular build and a gleaming white smile -- Matthew Morrison is doomed to play the sort of romantic leading men who show up for a ballad or two in every Broadway musical and are inevitably upstaged by the more tortured and less attractive star. Being handsome, believe it or not, has its drawbacks, although Mr. Morrison, the Broadway heartthrob of the moment, has so far made the most of it. He burst on the scene in "Hairspray," playing Link Larkin, a hip-swiveling singer whom every teenage girl swoons over. Three years later, he was once again the object of lust, but in a more challenging role as the Italian hunk in "The Light in the Piazza." This Tony-nominated turn showed off his vocal and acting range as well as his strutting charm, and made people think that he might be more than just a pretty face. Now comes the real test, when Mr. Morrison makes his straight-play debut in Richard Greenberg's "Naked Girl on the Appian Way," a frothy comedy in which the author of "Take Me Out" seems to be channeling his inner Neil Simon. Playing a good-looking (of course) and somewhat slow adoptee oblivious to any of life's troublesome complications, Mr. Morrison (above, with Jill Clayburgh) delivers some of the show's funniest lines with the athletic ease that is his trademark. At one point, his character, somewhat randomly, says that he always imagined that his real parents were gymnasts, whom he describes without a trace of irony or mean-spiritedness as "these really nice, smiley thin people who were just always springing." Moments later, he bounds offstage with a leap, making you actually believe that it could be true. (American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212)719-1300.) JASON ZINOMAN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Ex-Boyfriend Sought In Woman's Beating
description: A 25-year-old woman was in critical but stable condition at St. Barnabas Hospital last night after being severely beaten in her apartment, and the police said they suspected her former boyfriend. Around 11 a.m., when the woman, Lillian Reyes, returned to Hoffman Street in the Belmont section during a lunch break from her job at a nearby bank, she encountered her ex-boyfriend, Rafael Nuez, 31, who beat her and fled, the police said. A little later, Mr. Nuez's brother called Ms. Reyes's father and told him to check on her. With the help of a police officer, Ms. Reyes's father entered the apartment shortly before 1 p.m. and found her. She and Mr. Nuez have a 3-year-old son. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Renewing Spirits, Mostly His Own
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22 - In the list of necessary figures required for the near-term recovery of New Orleans, a cabaret performer would seem to rank low.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Police Mistreatment Of Gay Men Is Called Common
description: Police mistreatment and harassment of gay men, bisexuals and transsexuals is common across the United States, a study by Amnesty International, the human rights group, found. Offenses include verbal and physical abuse, inappropriate body searches, beatings and rapes, and failure to protect people in holding cells, according to the study. The report focused on Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and San Antonio. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Delta to Cut $3 Billion More, in Both Paychecks and Planes
description: Delta Air Lines, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week, said yesterday that it planned to cut another $3 billion in costs, partly by reducing the pay and benefits of all its employees, including its chief executive.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ridership Record For New Jersey Transit
description: The average number of commuters riding New Jersey Transit's buses and trains rose more than 5 percent to 800,900 in the year that ended on June 30, the transit agency said yesterday. More than one-third of the additional trips -- 12,850 -- were on buses going in and out of New York City. Another 8,400 were on the light-rail systems along the Hudson River and in the Camden area, as well as the Newark subway. George D. Warrington, the agency's executive director, attributed the record level of ridership to improved service, a strong economy and the rising price of gasoline. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

The Listings: Sept. 23-Sept. 29; JOHN COLTRANE'S 79TH-BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION
description: The legacy of John Coltrane, above, has not suffered in the nearly four decades since his death. But this year has been more salutary than most, thanks to two newly unearthed live recordings: a 1957 Carnegie Hall concert with Thelonious Monk (issued late last month on Blue Note) and a pair of 1965 quartet sets at the Half Note (due in mid-October on Verve). Coltrane, who would have been 79 today, was not only a titan of the tenor and soprano saxophones, but also one of jazz's great paradigm-shifters; the most remarkable thing about the new albums is that each captures him in transition. It's fitting, then, that this weekend offers several birthday tributes, each pointing toward a different phase of his career. At Birdland, the spotlight is on Joe Lovano, a saxophonist indebted to the hard-charging, elliptical logic of Coltrane's late-1950's style; also on hand is a superb rhythm section consisting of Steve Kuhn on piano, Lonnie Plaxico on bass and Andrew Cyrille on drums. The Stone welcomes Rashied Ali, the fiery drummer who joined Coltrane's group a handful of months after the Half Note sessions; he offers testimony to Coltrane's questing late period, along with the bassist Reggie Workman (another former Coltrane bandmate), the trumpeter Roy Campbell, the saxophonist Louie Belogenis and the pianist Andrew Bemkey. And at the Cornelia Street Caf, George Garzone, whose exploratory tenor playing probably hews closest to the Half Note era itself, joins Joe Cohen on guitar, Kermit Driscoll on bass and Pete Zimmer on drums; as a bonus, it's Mr. Garzone's birthday, too. (Joe Lovano plays tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11, Birdland , 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212)581-3080; cover, $40, with a $10 minimum. Rashied Ali plays tonight at 8 and 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, www.thestonenyc.com; cover, $20 for one set, $30 for both sets. . George Garzone plays tonight at 9, Cornelia Street Caf, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212)989-9319; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum.)

title: A Photographer Captivated by Wax and Fragments From the Past
description: The title of the show at the Japan Society sounds just a little pretentious: "Hiroshi Sugimoto: History of History." But what it describes is a very personal, whimsical exhibition by this well-known Japanese photographer that incorporates his own work with artifacts that he has collected over the years, particularly from East Asia and Japan.

title: Let Other Doctors Save Lives; These Specialists Create Them
description: "Inconceivable," which starts tonight on NBC, is a cerebral, macabre drama about a glamorous fertility clinic. It's impressively produced, but it will make you queasy. The show spends not a minute on ideological controversies surrounding this brave-new-world reproductive science -- the surrogates, egg transfers, sperm samples -- but there's something in it that's just too unstable to serve as a backdrop for primetime drama. Betrayal and vanity may suit the characters on "Nip/Tuck," FX's marvelously creepy drama about plastic surgery. Around the delicate creation of human life, however, it's worth saying: more reverence is in order.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Labor Leader To Be Host Of Cable Show
description: The New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Regional News Network have agreed to broadcast a new 30-minute, twice-monthly talk show, "Working New York," which focuses on issues affecting workers and their families. Denis Hughes, left, the president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has nearly two million members, will be the host. The show will be broadcast on RNN at 10 p.m. on the first and third Wednesdays of each month. Regional News Network reaches more than 5 million households in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: At Abuse Trial, Two Accounts of Why G.I. Was in Photos

England, on trial for joining in the mistreatment, did almost anything he asked, current and former members of their unit testified Thursday.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Court Denies Access To Records
description: The state's highest court has ruled that a man seeking his confidential adoption records because they would help him further his Mormon faith is not entitled to them. The man, whose name was not disclosed in the Supreme Court's ruling, contended that his interpretation of Mormon beliefs made it necessary to know about his parents and ancestors. The court ruled it could not unseal the records based on the "subjective interpretation of his religion." Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: A New Head Start Bill
description: The House voted largely along partisan lines, 231 to 184, to approve a bill that strengthens the Head Start program for preschoolers by increasing the involvement of states, parents and sponsors. More Democrats said they would have voted for the bill had it not included an amendment that allows religious groups that sponsor Head Start programs to hire workers based on their beliefs. Supporters of the amendment said it protected religious freedom. Opponents argued that it discriminated against otherwise qualified applicants. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

Arts, Briefly
description: Storm Cancels Concerts Cultural events began falling victim to Hurricane Rita yesterday as it swirled on 150-mile-an-hour winds west-northwest across the Gulf of Mexico, with forecasters predicting that it would make landfall on Saturday in Texas or southwestern Louisiana. The Houston Symphony canceled concerts today, tomorrow and Sunday, when the pianist Yefim Bronfman was to be the guest soloist in a performance of Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3 on a program that also included Tchaikovsky's "Voyevoda" and Symphony No. 6, "Pathetique." Separate outdoor concerts this weekend by the touring British bands Coldplay (whose Chris Martin is above) and Oasis and the American band Journey were also canceled, the BBC reported. The Cynthia Woods Mitchell Pavilion near Houston, where the performances were to take place, said the action was taken for reasons of safety in the face of the hurricane.

description: Oprah Winfrey said yesterday that she was expanding her highly influential television book club to include the works of contemporary authors, reversing a policy of choosing only classic novels and once again offering authors and their publishers the hope of huge sales resulting from her picks.

title: Prints That Helped Europe Discover Its Great Artists
description: The art-alert today are so used to thinking of "prints" as originals that it takes refocusing to remember that they were also once valued as reproductions, a means of copying other artists' works. In fact, from the early 16th century to the beginning of the 19th, widely circulated prints in a variety of techniques were the only means of acquainting a broad public with original works whose ownership rested in the hands of the church and other wealthy patrons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, MARTHA COLLINS
description: JOHNSON--Martha Collins. 91, of Heath Village, Hackettstown, NJ, died on September 19, 2005. Born in Pittsburgh she graduated from Greenwich Academy and Vassar College. In her long career as educator, she was Head of the Lower Schools of Low-Heywood, Stamford, CT, Bedford Rippowam, Bedford, NY, Brookside (now Montclair Kimberley Academy) in Montclair, NJ (1962-73) and interim head of Far Brook School in Short Hills, NJ in 1979. At Heath Village she founded a tutoring program connecting senior residents with students, leading to her election to the Hackettstown Senior Citizen Hall of Fame in 1997. She leaves three children, Elizabeth Glaeser Chaitman of NYC, Edward Bayne of Concord, MA, and Sarah Bayne, of Los Gatos, CA, six grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. A memorial Service will be held at 2 PM on September 30 at Heath Village, Hackettstown, NJ.

title: A Long Night of Saving the Favorites for the End
description: "Welcome to what is going to be an extremely long show tonight," Elton John said at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday. And then he explained how it was going to work. First he would play songs from "Peachtree Road" (Universal), his 2004 album. For this, he almost apologized: "I know it's difficult to listen to new songs." Then he would play all the songs from "Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy," the beloved album he released 30 years ago. And then? "Then we're going to get to the jukebox," he said.

title: Brazil's Lofty Promises After Nun's Killing Prove Hollow

Seven months after the American nun who organized the settlement was shot to death, the conflicts over land ownership that led to her killing not only remain unresolved but are intensifying, Roman Catholic church leaders and peasant residents here maintain.

title: INSIDE
description: Crime in South Africa Grows More Vicious South Africa's rates of carjackings, murder and armored-car attacks have fallen sharply, but the remaining violent crime is not only ever more spectacular, but ever harder to rein in. Every time the police find a way to thwart criminals, the criminals invent ways around it, or find easier targets. PAGE A4

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Suit Filed Against Sony BMG
description: The merger that created Sony BMG Music Entertainment, the world's second-largest record company after the Universal Music Group, was challenged in a European Union court by a group representing independent music companies. A case brought by Impala, a trade group based in Brussels for the European independents, was heard by the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg. Impala says the merger, approved last year by the European Commission, curtailed competition in the music industry by reducing the number of "major" music companies to four from five. The union approved the merger between the music units of Sony and Bertelsmann after blocking a merger proposed in 2000 between the EMI Group and Warner Music.

title: Saudi Minister Warns U.S. Iraq May Face Disintegration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi foreign minister, said Thursday that he had been warning the Bush administration in recent days that Iraq was hurtling toward disintegration, a development that he said could drag the region into war.

title: Michael deCourcy Hinds, Reporter, Dies at 58
description: Michael deCourcy Hinds, a former national correspondent for The New York Times, died on Monday at the NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 and a Manhattan resident.

title: For Pay Toilet Company, Progress Is Sometimes Slow
description: The Spanish advertising company that is paying more than $1 billion to put toilets, bus shelters and newsstands on New York City streets has never before installed a street toilet in this country, though it has built more than a hundred of them in Spain and Latin America in the past decade.

title: Blurred Line for the Ground Zero Museum

title: The Danger Next Door

But now that progress is threatened by an increasingly violent insurgency that uses Pakistan as a staging area for attacks. Unless the United States and Pakistan take steps to eliminate this sanctuary, the security situation in Afghanistan will continue to deteriorate and undermine the country's fragile democracy.

title: Can You Hear Me Now? Avoiding the Weekend Disconnect
description: SANDY FELDMAN knows firsthand the technological roadblocks that a picturesque rural retreat, like Salisbury, Conn., can hold. His cellphone only works in certain areas of town. Getting high-speed Internet access at his house was a six-month ordeal that involved digging under the road, cutting a trench through his yard and shutting off power to the house twice. But that's nothing compared to the hassle of trying to get his BlackBerry to work.

title: The Listings: Sept. 23-Sept. 29; JEANINE DURNING
description: Ms. Durning looked like a wren commandeering gale-force winds in her 2003 "Part One Parting." But she inspired trust -- just grab a few pinfeathers and go along for the ride. An analogous faith was necessary to enter the fraught worlds of several mysterious women in a program of Ms. Durning's choreography five years earlier. And her 1996 "Solo With Armour" had a similarly enticing inscrutability. Ms. Durning's new multimedia "out of the kennel into a home" (above) -- with music by Jules Maxwell, text by Keith Reddin and video by Jason Akira Somma -- sounds like her latest exploration of unchartable provinces of the mind and heart. This evening-long piece, inspired by the memoirs of escape artists and prisoners, burrows into the nature of mental and physical confinement. It takes the theme literally enough to push off the stage and into the street and a truck that is parked there. One of the great pleasures of Ms. Durning's dances is her own faith in the power of unassuming emotionally (and physically) propulsive movement to express quite complex notions. She has performed with David Dorfman and Lance Gries, two modern-dance choreographers who understand how powerfully eloquent pure movement can be. Ms. Durning adds a distinctively female lack of adornment to the mix, in dances that have grown steadily more authoritative and thought-provoking over the 15 years she has been at it. The latest dance looks like quite a departure from the past, but it is hard to imagine that her distinctive, if quiet, voice will not come through. (Ms. Durning and her dancers will perform Wednesday through Oct. 1 at 7:30 p.m. at Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: 15 Palestinians Dead in Blast at Hamas Weapons Parade

description: A few readers (probably Pakistanis) have asked about the Pakistani-U.S. free trade zone that I proposed in the process of scourging Musharraf a couple of days ago. This is something that I proposed in one of my first columns, way back in 2001 when I was a beneficiary of 9/11 and got this gig. My version of it is that Pakistan, Afghanistan and the U.S. would all be united in a free-trade area, like our zone with Jordan or with Central American nations. If we can encourage manufacturing and exports in Pakistan and Afghanistan (other than heroin), then theyll be more stable and well all be better off.

Bookson. As President of Congregation K'hal Adath Jeshurun, he dedicated himself to ensuring continued religious life at the 118-year-old house of worship. With his devoted and beloved life Tova, he embraced the Project as long-term partner in transforming this National Historic Landmark into a Jewish heritage center for future generations. Learned, dynamic, determined, kind, he'll be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences to the entire family. Michael Weinstein, Chairman Roberta Brandes Gratz Founder Lorinda Ash Ezersky President Amy E. Waterman Executive Dir.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Religious Schools To Register
description: Leaders of federations representing more than 13,000 madrasas, or religious schools, agreed to register with the government by Dec. 31, Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz said. They also agreed to submit annual financial reports but do not have to disclose the names of donors. A visit by one of the suspects in the London subway bombings of July 7 to a Pakistani madrasa focused renewed attention on them, and President Pervez Musharraf vowed to identify and isolate those that breed militancy. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Samurai, Drugs, a Failed Revolution and a Sick Health System
description: The 43rd New York Film Festival started last night with George Clooney's "Good Night, and Good Luck," and will wrap up on Oct. 9 with Michael Haneke's "Cach." Between now and then, dozens of new shorts and features from all over the world, along with some recovered treasures from the past, will remind New Yorkers that, even in the age of Netflix and Video on Demand, we live in one of the world's great film cities. The growth of the nonstop, worldwide festival circuit has made New York both more and less special. Most of the movies the festival shows have been seen elsewhere, and will open theatrically (at least in New York) before too long. But the fact that they have been curated by a committee of eminent critics confers undeniable cachet, and the absence of prizes and the din of deal-making give it an air of decorum and seriousness. What follows is a critical guide to the first weekend, one of five covering the festival. A.O.SCOTT

Arts, Briefly; Viewers Love 'Chris'
description: "Everybody Hates Chris," the new UPN comedy based on the childhood of Chris Rock, right, was, in fact, beloved in its debut on Thursday. It attracted an estimated 7.58 million viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic beat the first half of an hourlong premiere of "Joey" on NBC. It was the most-watched sitcom in the life of UPN, but the rest of the network's schedule didn't fare as well. "Love, Inc.," another new comedy, lost a large part of the "Chris" audience. Meanwhile, on NBC, there was further evidence that "The Apprentice" franchise is imploding. One night after the new Martha Stewart edition drew lower than expected ratings in Nielsen's estimates, the premiere of the fourth season of the Donald Trump version brought in the series's fewest viewers: only 9.38 million. In the same 9 p.m. hour, CBS's "CSI" returned and delivered an audience of 28.29 million. The pilot episode of "Criminal Minds," a mystery that will normally be broadcast on Wednesdays opposite ABC's "Lost," attracted 19.82 million. CBS was No.1 over all in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

A listen to the tapes of President Lyndon B. title: The Sex Appeal of Cards, and Vice Versa

Cut to a beautiful woman going all-in against a handsome stud sitting behind a big stack. The stud calls her bet and, after making meaningful eye contact, raises one chip. With no chips left, the woman tosses a Kimono condom -- still in its wrapper, of course -- toward the pot, boldly reraising him. As three shlubs look on, the stud shoves the rest of his chips in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANGANELLI, RAYMOND MICHAEL
description: MANGANELLI -- Raymond Michael, wonderful husband, father, grandfather, and brother, died on September 21st at his home in Hillside, New Jersey, surrounded by his family. Dr. Manganelli was born on January 15, 1921, in Elizabeth, New Jersey, to Louis and Concettina Manganelli. He graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School in Elizabeth, N.J., and then earned a B.S. degree from The Ohio State University. He married Filomena Rotolo on June 17, 1945; they recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary with their family. After working at the Schering Corporation, he went on to have a distinguished 57 - year career at Rutgers University as a Professor and later as a Professor Emeritus. Dr. Manganelli received his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Environmental Science at Rutgers, and became a pioneer, an educator, and an innovator in the fields of Air, Water, and Noise Pollution Studies. He was in the forefront in developing cutting-edge environmental education programs and in performing and publishing state-of-the-art research, and had the unique ability and distinguished record of successfully predicting where the demand for information and instruction would develop. There are many examples of his pioneering efforts. In the early 1950's, he was the first in the United States to develop a Graduate level Air Pollution Training Program. He was a pioneer and an early innovator in the study of noise pollution as it relates to health in the workplace. Many of the most prominent professionals in the United States working in the Environmental field from 1950 to the present were students of Dr. Manganelli. Dr. Manganelli was appointed to the New Jersey Clean Air Council by every Governor for the last 40 years, and served for the entire time as a Council member and for a time as its Chair. He has received numerous honors, awards, and citations for this service and for his distinguished accomplishments and service to many professional organizations, including the United States Environmental Protection Agency; the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection; the Air, the Water, and the Noise Pollution Control Associations; the American Industrial Hygiene Association; and Rutgers University. Dr. Manganelli's devotion to teaching and advising generations of undergraduate and graduate students earned him numerous teaching awards and led to the formation of several scholarships in his name, among them the Raymond M. Manganelli Scholarship awarded each year since 1992 at Rutgers University. Dr. Manganelli led a life characterized by a colleague at Rutgers as "remarkably balanced." His passions included his family, Rutgers, Civil War history, 6mile-per-day jogging, educational and environmental issues, things Italian, and Ohio State football. Dr. Manganelli was an active member of Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church of Union, N.J. He is survived by Filomena, his beloved wife of 60 years; son and daughter-in-law, Dr. Raymond L. and Cathy Manganelli of Manhasset, N.Y.; daughter and son-in-law, Alida and Larry Karas of Hillside, N.J.; four grandchildren, Thomas and Christopher Manganelli, and Michael and Nicole Karas; a brother, Michael Manganelli; and sisters, Emily Davis and Dorothy Sutherland, and their families, as well as the family of his late sister, Margarita King. The Funeral will be from McCracken Funeral Home, 1500 Morris Avenue, Union, on Monday at 8:30am. Funeral Mass at Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church (corner of Morris Avenue and Suburban Road in Union) at 9:30 am. Interment will be at Fairview Cemetery in Westfield, N.J. The family will receive friends at the McCracken Funeral Home on Saturday, 2-4 & 7-9 pm, and Sunday, 15pm. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to the "Raymond M. Manganelli Scholarship Award," The Rutgers University Foundation, Winants Hall, 7 College Avenue, New Brunswick, New Jersey 08901-1261.

description: To the Editor:

title: Saturday's Top Games
description: No. 21 Iowa (2-1) at No. 8 Ohio State (2-1) NOON, ABC (Regional) Each of these teams has sustained a non-conference loss -- Iowa on the road to Iowa State and Ohio State at home to Texas -- and a loss in this one makes a national title impossible and a Big Ten title unlikely. Iowa quarterback Drew Tate had a huge game in last season's 33-7 drubbing of the Buckeyes, and Ohio State will be out for revenge. Iowa's victories have come against Ball State and Northern Iowa, and neither of those teams has anywhere near the talent level of the Buckeyes. Ohio State quarterback Troy Smith will need a big game, and the Buckeyes have to try to get their star receiver Ted Ginn Jr. more involved. Both of these teams feature excellent linebacking corps, and this game could become a defensive struggle.

title: Art of the Internet: A Protest Song, Reloaded
description: Some songs have all the luck. They lead double, even triple lives, meaning everything to everyone, and meaning it passionately.

title: Movies on TV
description: CLOSER (2004)Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:45 a.m. on Cinemax Julia Roberts smiles less. Jude Law wears glasses (which serve only to make him look sexier). Natalie Portman takes off her clothes. Clive Owen smolders. Mike Nichols's powerful romantic drama is based on Patrick Marber's Tony Award-winning play, which ran on Broadway in 1999, with Natasha Richardson and Ciaran Hinds among the leads. In London, a photographer, an obituary writer, a stripper and a dermatologist meet in odd ways (e.g., a man pretends to be a woman on the Internet), fall in love, flirt, fight, curse, change partners and betray one another more than once. Emotions don't get much rawer than theirs. Characters don't get much needier. The movie stops one scene short of the play's unhappy ending.

title: World Briefings: Europe, Asia, Africa, Americas
description: EUROPE

title: 'Commander in Chief': Geena Davis as President
description: CREATE a show about the first female president of the United States, as Rod Lurie has done with the new drama "Commander in Chief," and right away you have a pivotal decision to make: does she come into the White House through the front door, by getting elected, or through the back, by inheriting the office?

title: Truckful of Rockets Explodes at Hamas Rally in Gaza, Killing 15 and Injuring Dozens
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Sept. 24 - A pickup truck carrying rockets exploded on Friday at a large Hamas rally as the group paraded its weapons through a densely packed refugee camp in the Gaza Strip. At least 15 people were killed and dozens were wounded, Palestinian medical officials said.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 7 about a Marine unit in Ohio that has suffered a rash of deaths in Iraq misspelled the surname of one of those killed. As a reader informed The Times this week, he was Lance Cpl. Eric J. Bernholtz, not Bernholz.

title: A Bunch of Wild and Crazy Receivers
description: Breathtaking receptions are a near certainty and outrageous antics are a strong possibility tomorrow when Terrell Owens of the Eagles and Randy Moss of the Raiders face off in Philadelphia.

title: Turkish court's ban of Armenian conference is circumvented
News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Suspended College President Offers to Accept Lesser Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - Benjamin Ladner, the president of American University, who has been suspended pending an investigation of expenses that he charged to the college, has agreed to accept a more modest contract if the board votes to return him to office, his lawyer and several board members said on Friday.

title: Democrats Press Justice Dept. Nominee Anew
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - Senate Democrats pressed Friday for more answers from President Bush's nominee for deputy attorney general about his relationship with Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist, but the White House strongly defended its nominee.

title: Seminar on 1915 Massacre of Armenians to Go Ahead
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 23 - After a Turkish court's decision to cancel an academic conference on the killing of hundreds of thousands of Armenians during World War I, the conference's organizers said Friday that the event would go ahead at a new location on Saturday. The organizers were encouraged by a wave of support from the European Union and senior Turkish government officials.

title: A Photo Show on a Pogrom 50 Years Ago Is Itself Attacked by a Mob
description: ISTANBUL - Tucked away for more than 40 years, the 120 black-and-white photographs hanging in a gallery here have the stark appearance and potential emotional impact of evidence presented in a legal proceeding.

title: One Passionate Prodigy Takes On Another
description: To be cool and cognizant, and on the right side of critical opinion, experts will tell you this: if everyone loves something, there must be something wrong with it. The argument will get you a long way in some circles but, at the end of the day, not far enough. Consider, for example, the young Chinese pianist Lang Lang, who helped the New York Philharmonic and Lorin Maazel open their regular subscription series at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night.

title: The City of Falling Angels
Floods Reclaim Neighborhoods That Are Already Ravaged
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 23 - The waters returned to the Lower Ninth Ward on Friday, but this time, there was little left for them to destroy.

title: Day of Jitters for Companies Even as Worst Fears Ease
description: Energy prices tumbled yesterday and share prices edged up as Hurricane Rita appeared to weaken, stirring hopes that the storm will cause less damage than expected to refineries and other energy operations along the Gulf Coast.

title: Doing Executive Time
description: SHOULD white-collar criminals receive harsher sentences than street thugs or drug peddlers?

title: U.S. Orders Ford to Retest a Former Dumpsite in New Jersey
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has ordered the Ford Motor Company to retest a former chemical dumpsite in Ringwood, N.J., to determine how contaminated it still is, even though Ford cleaned it a decade ago and the federal agency gave it a clean bill of health at the time.

title: Merkel reaches out to Green Party
Harold Friedman, 82, Chemist Who Studied Electrolytes, Dies
description: Harold L. Friedman, a chemist who studied the structural and thermodynamic properties of liquids, in work that has relevance to both oceanography and human physiology, died on Sept. 16 at the Long Island State Veterans Home in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 82.

title: Exxon Mobil Back at No. 1 in Market Value, Even as It Shrinks Shares
description: EXXON MOBIL is back on top, and for the first time is worth more than $400 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Street Scene section of Business Day yesterday comparing Bank of America's performance in Europe with that of Citigroup was mislabeled. The number represented corporate and investment banking net income for the two banks, not net income over all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, ROSE
description: STERN--Rose. 90, died peacefully on September 22. Wife of the late Bernard Stern.Sister of Lester Kaye. Mother of Evan and Louis Stern. Devoted grandmother of Jonathan, Jennifer, Russell, Mark & Douglas. Great-grandmother of Michael, Rachel, Isabella, Zachary, Matthew, Hannah & Jake. You were a class act. We love you and will miss you.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Aug. 27 about Ward Marston, who restores old phonograph records, misstated the date of the creation of his Marston label. It was 1997, not two years ago. The article also referred incorrectly to Enrico Caruso's recordings, which Mr. Marston has restored. Caruso sang into a recording machine horn, not a microphone. (He died in 1921, and microphones were not used for commercial recordings until 1925.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ANN F.
description: COHEN--Ann F. Died on Thursday, September 22, 2005 A graduate of City College of New York, she was an accountant as well an active volunteer in many civic and Judaic organizations. Her strength, warmth, wisdom and humor will be deeply missed by her daughter, sonin-law and grandchildren as well as a devoted extended family and many lifelong friends. Services Sunday, September 25th at 10:30 AM at Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 91st St. in New York. Shiva at 245 East 80th Street, NY. Memorial contributions to Solomon Schechter Day School, 26 Buena Vista Road, West Hartford, CT 06107.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Alcoa Forecasts Shortfall in Quarterly Earnings, Blaming Higher Costs for Material and Energy Alcoa said its third-quarter earnings will fall far short of Wall Street's expectations, setting off a 6 percent decline in its share price yesterday. Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum maker, said late Thursday that third-quarter inome from continuing operations should be between 27 cents and 31 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial were expecting a 43 cent-per-share profit when Alcoa announces financial results on Oct. 10. Alcoa blamed lower aluminum prices and higher costs, particularly in energy and raw materials. Seasonal weakness in Europe and automotive markets also hurt business. Alcoa also said Hurricane Rita's impact would hurt third-quarter results. The company, based in Pittsburgh, was forced to close its Point Comfort, Tex., alumina refinery and the Lake Charles, La., anode plant because of the hurricane. (AP)

title: Stormy Spins in a Vortex
description: WASHINGTON - Stormy was testy.

title: Why utilities are shining so brightly now
Finding Desire for Movement in Wyeth's 'Christina's World'
description: Tamar Rogoff's new "Christina Olson: American Model," which opened on Wednesday at Performance Space 122, is first of all a tour de force for the young film and television actress Claire Danes. Ms. Danes has the rare gift of stillness, and her soft-voiced recitation of brief passages from biographies of Christina Olson and Andrew Wyeth is almost as dynamic as her dancing in this evocation of the look and life of Olson, the woman depicted in Mr. Wyeth's most popular painting, "Christina's World."

title: The Slap of Luxury
description: EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 21 - The latest addition to college football's most luxurious locker room sits underneath the three 60-inch plasma television sets.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 - After a first season in which it attracted an estimated 24 million viewers every week, helped resuscitate ABC and won six Emmy Awards, "Desperate Housewives" resumes its crooked suburban soap opera on Sunday night.

title: Artistic stillness that draws a crowd
Hijackers Back Down on Deal
description: Gunmen who seized a ship carrying relief food off the coast of Somalia on June 27 continue to hold the ship, its 10-man crew and 850 tons of rice despite an announcement last week that the hostage crisis had been resolved. The hijackers had agreed to end the crisis last week in a deal struck with the World Food Program. But the agency said the hijackers had issued fresh ransom demands. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Thursday showing fighting in August 2004 around the Imam Ali mosque in Najaf, Iraq, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Tyler Hicks of The New York Times.

description: GAINESVILLE, Va., Sept. 23 - As the sky turned dark above the Robert Trent Jones Golf Club, Jack Nicklaus kept his sunglasses on and his hands in his pockets.

title: Debt Deal for Poorest Nations Moves Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - The United States moved closer on Friday to a final deal with other industrialized nations on wiping out about $18 billion in debt owed by the world's poorest nations.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Thursday about President Bush's plans to resume human exploration of the moon misstated the date of the Apollo 11 lunar landing. It was July 20, 1969, not July 16.

title: Animosity in Italian camp at IMF talks
A Long Wait for Public Toilets
description: It is much too soon to celebrate, but the Bloomberg administration has finally selected a company to install 20 public toilets in New York City. If this seems laughable in a city of 8 million residents plus 40 million tourists a year, having 20 new high-tech public toilets by 2007 would certainly offer an improvement over having zero. And if the users, the city and the neighbors like them, maybe someday there will be enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, MELVIN
description: WEISS--Melvin. On September 21, 2005. Beloved husband for 48 years to Felicia. Loving father and father-in-law of Stephanie and Stephen, Peter and Jennifer. Devoted and adored grandfather of Alex, Emily, Charlotte and Spencer. For 75 years, Mel cared deeply for his family and friends, sharing his love and laughter. He was the sweetest, kindest and most generous man to all whose lives he touched. He will be forever missed. Services Sunday, September 25th, 11:45 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave

title: INSIDE
description: Rockets Explode at Hamas Rally in Gaza, Killing 15 As Hamas paraded weapons through the crowded Jabaliya refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, a pickup truck carrying rockets exploded, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens. Palestinian officials held Hamas responsible for what appeared to be an accident, while Hamas blamed Israel. PAGE A6

description: CURLEY--Thomas F. Age 80. Beloved father, grandfather, husband, teacher. Survived by wife Sarah, son Mark, daughter-in-law Mary Ellen, grand-daughters Anastatia and Oona. Memorial service at Xavier High School, 30 W. 16 St, New York, N.Y. October 1 at 4PM.

New Jersey Couple Wins $258 Million in Mega Jackpot
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept 23 - What to do with a piece of paper worth $258 million?

title: A Miniature Gate in Hot Pursuit of a Miniature Central Park
description: It is not an easy job, towing 150 tons of conceptual art around Manhattan all day. There are tides and wind currents to negotiate. There are ferries and container ships and police boats to avoid. And then there is the precious cargo itself, not exactly your average garbage scow: "Floating Island," designed by the artist Robert Smithson, who died in 1973, is a kind of waterborne jewel-box version of Central Park, built on a barge, with live trees and shrubs.

title: Samurai, Drugs, a Failed Revolution and a Sick Health System
description: The 43rd New York Film Festival started last night with George Clooney's "Good Night, and Good Luck," and will wrap up on Oct. 9 with Michael Haneke's "Cach." Between now and then, dozens of new shorts and features from all over the world, along with some recovered treasures from the past, will remind New Yorkers that, even in the age of Netflix and Video on Demand, we live in one of the world's great film cities. The growth of the nonstop, worldwide festival circuit has made New York both more and less special. Most of the movies the festival shows have been seen elsewhere, and will open theatrically (at least in New York) before too long. But the fact that they have been curated by a committee of eminent critics confers undeniable cachet, and the absence of prizes and the din of deal-making give it an air of decorum and seriousness. What follows is a critical guide to the first weekend, one of five covering the festival. A.O.SCOTT

title: Briefcase: Oil and storms sap urge to shop
World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Bomb Wounds Dozens At Cafe
description: A bomb exploded in a crowded outdoor cafe in the northeastern city of Vitebsk, wounding at least four dozen people, some critically, news agencies reported. The bombing was the second this month in the city, near the Russian border. Officials said the motive behind the latest explosion -- caused by a bomb planted in a flower bed late Thursday night -- was not clear, but they appeared to rule out terrorism. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Fund-Raising for Ferrer Gets Off to Slow Start
description: Fernando Ferrer yesterday reported raising $303,675 during the most recent campaign finance filing period, a somewhat slow start to a fund-raising effort that many experts say must be unusually robust if Mr. Ferrer is to be financially competitive in his race against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: In 'Little History,' a scholar revealed
Hurricane Rita comes ashore
Paid Notice: Deaths   STUTZ, RONALD S.
description: STUTZ--Ronald S., 70, of Miami, Fla., Bayside, N.Y. and Roxbury, N.Y. Died peacefully on September 20, 2005 in Miami. Retired from teaching at Jamaica High School. He will be sorely missed by his loving wife Linda and by many cousins and friends. Graveside services on Sunday, September 25 at 3PM at Congregation B'nai Israel Cemetery in Fleischmanns, N.Y. Contributions may be made in his memory to Congregation B'nai Israel, Fleischmanns, N.Y. 12430.

title: Including Indians in Colonial History
description: STILLWATER, N.Y., Sept. 17 - All appeared as it should to those who regularly attend re-enactments of colonial life. At a hillside camp teeming with canvas tents, an apple pie and a pork roast cooked in pots heated by coals. Women used looms to weave. Men fired cannons.

title: Gadgets of the week: Tiny but zoomy
Today's Lesson: Rethink College Funds
description: Correction Appended

title: A Million Little Pieces
description: THE United Nations summit meeting last week should be the last of its kind. It allowed world leaders, once again, to over-promise and under-deliver on behalf of an organization that few of them genuinely wish to equip for success. With the failure of its member states to agree on meaningful reform -- even after Rwanda, Bosnia, Iraq and the oil-for-food scandal -- it is time for a new approach.

title: Competence Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Convert Guilty Of Terror Charges
description: A jury convicted a British man of terrorism-related offenses, including possessing a 20-page instruction manual, written in his own handwriting, explaining how to fire mortars. The man, Andrew Rowe, 34, who officials said converted to Islam in the 1990's and was connected to Al Qaeda, was also found guilty of possessing a notebook containing codes to identify airports, airline crew, army bases, weapons and explosives. The jury failed to reach a verdict on a further charge, that Mr. Rowe had tried to enter Britain from France with explosives concealed in his socks. Mr. Rowe, a resident of London, denied the charges, arguing that his mortar manual was meant to impress women. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: With Fans in the House, Boston Finds Its Footing
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 - The fans wearing their Varitek jerseys and Nixon T-shirts and Big Papi-sized smiles started filing into Camden Yards when the gates opened at 6 p.m. sharp on Friday, and the parade continued through the early innings of Boston's game against the Orioles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, STELLA
description: COOPER--Stella. 95 of Rye and Palm Beach died September 22, 2005. Loving wife for 68 years of Ted Cooper. Devoted mother (and mother-in-law) to Paulette Cooper (Noble) and Paul Noble of Palm Beach and New York. She was articulate, intelligent, interesting, compassionate, charitable, generous and vivacious. Graveside services 1 p.m. Sunday at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Donations to Mazon. For information contact Zion Funeral Home, 914-381-1809.

title: Reliving the Heyday of Kansas City Swing
description: It is the beginning of the second year for Jazz at Lincoln Center's new home at Columbus Circle, but the 18th year since the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra became the institution's resident jazz band. The second statistic is the more meaningful.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bomb Scare At Airport
description: The Manchester airport in the north of England all but closed for several hours after a man carrying a briefcase ran through a security checkpoint and headed toward an area where airplanes were parked, the authorities said. The man, whose name has not been released, was subdued with a stun gun. Bomb disposal officers carried out a controlled explosion on the briefcase but said later that it contained no explosives -- only clothes, papers and a passport. The man is now in custody and undergoing psychiatric evaluation. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Investing: Betting on Germany
Tax Court Lifts Secrecy, Putting Some Cases in New Light
description: Robert O. Kazary, a lawyer in Maryland, panicked when he opened his mail last month and found a report from the United States Tax Court that said his client did not qualify for a tax exemption -- the opposite of the court's final ruling in 1996.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Club Owners File For Bankruptcy
description: The owners of a nightclub in West Warwick where 100 people died in a 2003 fire have filed for bankruptcy. The owners, Jeffrey A. and Michael A. Derderian, who are brothers, filed papers stating that they and their company, Derco, could not satisfy present and future debts, said Jeffrey B. Pine, a lawyer for Jeffrey Derderian. The filing is expected to halt the brothers' trial next week in the state worker's compensation court on charges that they did not fully compensate the families of four employees killed in the blaze. Mr. Pine said the brothers each had personal assets up to $50,000 but debts that could exceed $100 million. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Mimi Lives, as Bohme Hits Performance 1,166
description: Three days after opening its new season, the Metropolitan Opera wheeled out its popular production of "La Bohme" on Thursday night. It was the 1,166th performance of the work in the Met's history. That is a staggeringly high number, but then again, "Bohme" has become more than just one opera among others -- it is a kind of ritual, an anthem. It is as if the season hasn't really begun until the consumptive lady sings.

title: Yahoo turns Hollywood as media rivals watch
A new Moscow erases the old (and history)
Briefly: U.S. urges IMF action on yuan
China adjusts its currency rules
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a government crisis in Ukraine referred incorrectly to an American company involved in a disputed investment in a Ukrainian chemical factory, which is at the center of an investigation into government corruption. The company, the IBE Trade Corporation, is the parent, not a subsidiary. The subsidiary, Worldwide Chemical, now operates the factory under a joint operating agreement with the government.

title: Giambi's Back Is Tender, but It Won't Keep Him Out
description: Jason Giambi missed his second start in a row last night with back spasms, but the injury did not seem serious. In fact, Giambi said he was fine and that he could have started. He seemed surprised when reporters told him he was not in the Yankees' starting lineup.

title: The Death of Mr. Lazarescu
description: Directed by Cristi Puiu 3 p.m. today and 8:30 p.m. Sunday, Alice Tully Hall

title: It's Not Her Father's Playboy
description: In the era of bachelor-oriented magazines like Maxim, Details and Stuff, the notion of stealing your father's Playboys sounds, well, antiquated.

title: As Injuries Mount, Boxing Looks Within
description: On the surface, the crisp jabs and hooks in a boxing match cause skin to ripple, sweat to sprinkle and knees to buckle. Inside the cranium, the sight looks like this: the brain sloshing, veins stretching and cells spewing out chemicals.

title: All Work and No Play Makes Katrina a Surprise
description: New Orleans - IT wasn't that they lacked a car, or the money, or even the will to get out of New Orleans in time. Cecil Person and his two brothers were simply too busy working.

title: Friends, and Then Some, Honor a Socialite
description: Nan Kempner, the New York socialite known as much for her wit as for her celery-thin figure, had her last party yesterday, at Christie's. Peter Duchin played, Champagne was served, the fellow who designed Camilla Parker Bowles's wedding hat flew in from London. The consensus was it was an event that Ms. Kempner, who once said she would attend the opening of an envelope, and who died of emphysema in July, would have very much enjoyed -- excepting the early hour of 10 a.m., which was ghastly.

title: Doctors With Ties to Device Makers
description: While health reformers are struggling to curtail undue influence by drug companies on the prescribing practices of doctors, a comparable problem has surfaced in the field of medical devices. An article by Reed Abelson in The Times on Thursday reveals that many surgeons have ties to manufacturers, ties that are often not revealed to their patients or to hospitals. These connections raise questions as to whether some doctors are choosing devices primarily for the good of their patients or primarily for the benefit of their own bank accounts.

title: Lessons of Katrina, Realities of Rita
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Insurers Set to Offer New Medicare Drug Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - In a major step to cut drug costs for older Americans, the Bush administration announced on Friday that 10 companies would offer prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries in all parts of the country, while many other insurers would sell coverage in specific states, for premiums averaging $32 a month.

title: The ECB: Villain, or a savior of Europe?

title: Gulf Coast Insurance Expected to Soar
description: The cost of insurance for homes and businesses is expected to rise sharply in the Gulf Coast states because of Hurricane Katrina, and even more so with Hurricane Rita, industry experts said yesterday. Policyholders far from the battered coastline are also expected to face higher premiums.

title: Expecting the Worst, Hoping for a Little Better
description: AMERICA'S energy industry prepared to take another one on the chin this week as Hurricane Rita skittered across the Gulf of Mexico and bore down on the refineries and chemical plants along the Texas coastline. Millions of people fled before the storm -- or tried to, at least, until freeways clogged hopelessly.

title: Report Says Bush's Tax Cuts Will Cause Some to Pay More
description: Over the next 10 years, Americans will not receive nearly $750 billion in tax cuts sponsored by President Bush because the cuts will be offset by the alternative minimum tax, a new report by Congressional tax specialists shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, SANDRA
description: FELDMAN--Sandra. The U.S. Fund for UNICEF notes with sadness the passing of Sandra Feldman, an honorary board member and lifelong advocate for children. Ms. Feldman's extraordinary leadership, courage and tenacity brought opportunity and dignity to countless children, families and communities. She will be deeply missed.

title: 'Katrina Effect' Pushed Texans Into Gridlock
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 - At 9:30 a.m. on Wednesday, with Hurricane Rita gathering strength and aimed at Texas, Mayor Bill White of Houston ordered mandatory evacuations from low-lying sections of the city while urging voluntary evacuations from flood-prone neighborhoods and mobile homes.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE INCREDIBLES -- (2004). The Parrs are not your typical suburban couple. They're actually Mr. Incredible and Elastigirl (above) -- superheroes forced, in an age of mediocrity, to live among the dull masses. But things will change. This Pixar production won the Oscar for best animated film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTER, VICTOR
description: FUTTER--Victor. We are saddened by the passing of our classmate and former Director and express our deepest sympathy to his wife Joan and the family. Victor's wisdom and energy will long be remembered. Tullio J. Borri, President Society of Columbia Graduates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOSINSKY, ESTHER
description: SOSINSKY--Esther. Died September 22, 2005. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and Debra Sosinsky, devoted sister to Murray Sims. Services Sunday 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue corner 91st Street, NY, NY.

description: Call it a blind date. Shawn Chacon knew nothing about playing in New York. The Yankees knew very little about Chacon. Yet somehow, since Chacon and the Yankees got together in July, their relationship has been pure bliss.

title: Drop the Debt
description: In July, the world's richest nations agreed to cancel about $40 billion in debt owed to international lenders like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund by 18 of the world's poorest countries. It is a long-overdue step that would allow countries like Mozambique, Ghana, Nicaragua and Bolivia to spend about $1 billion more per year on schooling and health.

title: Bus Stop Blast Kills 6 Iraqis; 3 G.I.'s Die in Other Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 23 - An attacker detonated an explosive belt on Friday at a crowded bus stop in central Baghdad and killed six people, the latest bloodshed in what American officials have predicted will be a period of heightened violence before the national constitutional referendum in three weeks.

description: A 20-year-old Fordham University student was raped early yesterday in the vestibule of her Bronx apartment building by a man who threatened her with a metal pipe, the police said.

title: A Jazz Guitarist With a Light, Though Commanding, Touch
description: "Unspeakable," which earned Bill Frisell a Grammy for best contemporary jazz album this year, doesn't bear many of the sonic hallmarks of a jazz recording. But it is wholly characteristic of Mr. Frisell, a broad-minded jazz guitarist with a taste for thoughtful twang. And it's recognizably a product of Nonesuch Records, which is also home to Ry Cooder, Emmylou Harris and the Kronos Quartet.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Khodorkovsky Lawyers Pressured
description: A day after a court rejected an appeal by the former oil executive Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russian prosecutors announced they would seek to disbar eight of his lawyers, citing tactics that a spokeswoman said "were close to criminal" during the appeal of his conviction on charges of fraud and tax evasion. A Canadian lawyer on his defense team, Robert Amsterdam, said security officials had rousted him from his hotel room early yesterday and ordered him to leave the country. Genrikh Pavda, Mr. Khodorkovsky's principal lawyer, who was not among those accused of misconduct, called the prosecutors' step "complete nonsense," saying the lawyers were simply acting to protect their client's rights. The appellate court upheld his conviction, but overturned some charges and reduced his prison sentence by a year, to eight years. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Fast Long Island Evacuation? Impossible
description: If a huge natural or man-made disaster ever struck Long Island, there would be several local, state and federal plans in place to help people, according to officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Evacuating the island, however, is not one of them.

title: Barring Gays From the Priesthood
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing That New Deal Religion
description: Hurricane Katrina set off a 1930's nostalgia craze in Washington, with liberals pining for F.D.R. and conservatives promising their own New Deal. But after looking at polls and talking to people now coping with Hurricane Rita, I don't see this craze spreading beyond the Beltway.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a government crisis in Ukraine referred incorrectly to an American company involved in a disputed investment in a Ukrainian chemical factory, which is at the center of an investigation into government corruption. The company, the IBE Trade Corporation, is the parent, not a subsidiary. The subsidiary, Worldwide Chemical, now operates the factory under a joint operating agreement with the government. (Go to Article)

title: The Road Map to School Peace
description: Since the State Legislature gave him direct control of the city's school system, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has created clear lines of authority and cut back a sprawling, ineffectual bureaucracy. But further progress toward a first-rate public school system will require a respectful relationship between the city and the union that represents its 80,000 teachers. Unfortunately, that relationship is probably worse than it has been in decades.

title: For 3 Little Millionaires, a Series of Painful Events
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23 - Even in Greenwich, the $15 million to $18 million fortune they stand to inherit stands out as serious money. And yet few would trade places with them. They are 11-, 8- and 5-year-old siblings who have endured nearly as much tragedy in their short lives as the waifs of the Lemony Snicket stories who lurch from crisis to crisis.

title: Hurricane Rita
description: Hurricane Rita roared into the Gulf Coast, lashing Texas and Louisiana with driving rain, flooding low-lying regions and sparking fires.

title: Stock Certificates
Corrections That Deserve Greater Prominence
description: My Sept. 25 Public Editor column in The New York Times suggests that more errors deserve to be considered substantive and published under the Corrections heading on Page A2. The corrections below, which have been published in the For the Record category during the past 30 days, are among those that I think deserved the greater prominence that the Corrections label would have given them in the paper.

title: Music: Berlin
description: The fall of the wall turned Berlin into one of the most musically endowed cities in the world. With double the musical wealth, it has four major symphony orchestras, a prominent early-music ensemble and three opera houses, which have orchestras that present their own symphony concerts. That is seven major orchestras, plus all the chamber music concerts they spawn, along with committed audiences, a population to whom classical music really matters and a deep cultural connection with the art form. But with the city's hard-pressed finances, contraction is possible in the future, so going sooner rather than later is a good idea.

title: The Reawakening
description: When you're looking for the perfect city to visit for a week or so, Kabul is probably not the first place that comes to mind. Travel to Afghanistan is firmly discouraged by the State Department, which warns prospective tourists about kidnapping, assassination, land mines and what the government's official advisory rather swashbucklingly refers to as "banditry." Even getting there can be risky: a Kam Air flight crashed into a mountain just southeast of Kabul in February, killing all 104 passengers. But Kabul was where I wanted to go.

title: Rome Has Culture and History, Sure. But Don't Forget the Gelato.
description: Correction Appended

title: Warsaw
description: WHY GO NOW As a tourist destination, Warsaw has been long overshadowed by other post-Soviet East European capitals like Prague and Budapest. But Poland, a new member of the European Union, has one of its fastest-growing economies, and the city bustles with energy of change: glass skyscrapers spring up next to dingy Communist-era apartment blocks; cafes overflowing with elegant crowds abut traditional pierogi bars and newly arrived Asian takeout places; bankers and stockbrokers flow out of the former Communist Party's headquarters for their lunch break.

title: Rock It to Me
description: The roadies are fussing with my mike. Is this the right height? Would I be more comfortable sitting? "O.K., rock star," they joke, making the most of my anxiety. How about the lights? Hmm? Are they in my eyes? It's bad enough that the audience is chuckling along with the gag: two well-known rock gods playing stagehands for me, a relative amateur. Next, I have to play for them.

title: James Agee: Journalist, Critic, Novelist, Screenwriter
description: Correction Appended

title: After Life
'Girl Sleuth': Whodunit?
description: Melanie Rehak's amiable and thorough new book begins and ends with appeals to the reader. Her first sentence is direct: "Grab your magnifying glass, because this is a mystery story." Her last line is more of an entreaty. "There are fighting days still ahead of us," she writes, "and we're going to need her." The "her" is Nancy Drew, the fictional teenage detective whose authorship and enduring popularity are the subjects of "Girl Sleuth." The "us" in the sentence is women.

title: Modern Art: London
description: Over the last decade, a couple of square miles of the East End of London have become the beating heart of Europe's contemporary art scene. That's where some 80 galleries have opened and many young artists now live. It is also where European collectors and dealers now head to discover what's new. Unlikely as it sounds, Hackney is where it's happening.

title: Lots of Choices, Lots of Room on French Slopes
description: THERE was something missing.

title: Dining: San Sebastin
description: I thought about London, where the turnover in restaurants is faster than in other European cities, and the Fat Duck, the international gastronomic darling of the moment, is just a short drive or train ride away. But the pound is a punishing currency, and who really longs to taste the fruits of the English soil or talks of English wine?

title: Gastro Hub
description: Surveying the country's restaurants in 1976, the food writer Waverley Root and his co-author, Richard de Rochemont, sniffed, "Chicago has not developed restaurants which have left their mark on history, unless you count the collective mark of its steakhouses." In 2005, eating in Chicago is almost painful: to choose one superb restaurant is to reject a dozen others.

title: Clubbing: Glasgow
description: The first thing you need to know about clubbing in Glasgow is that the city is tougher than you are. Forget the trappings of the clichd night out dancing in Manhattan, with its V.I.P. rooms and designer labels, women in $300 sandals, lines of limos in the Meatpacking District and "secret" Lower East Side nightspots. Glasgow laughs at all that.

title: Uncle Walt, Parlez-Vous Franais?
description: "Cheese! It's hailing cheese!" We cover our heads. Our 8-year-old, Thor, cowers beneath us - his parents, Astor and Speedie, and me, a surrogate brother, sister, wannabe parent - as we form a shield between him and the miniature cubes pounding down on us. This is France, so it was only a matter of time till the cheese blasted us; we didn't expect it at the Tour de France, though.

title: Design: Copenhagen
description: It lacks the buzz and hype of London and the familiar ring of Bilbao. But Scandinavia's Oresund region, which includes the Danish capital, Copenhagen, and Malmo in southern Sweden, has - at least for the moment - taken Europe's center stage for new architecture.

title: A Sicilian Slice
description: Dolce & Gabbana is as synonymous with Sicily as old ladies in veils and young Romeos on scooters. Since founding the label in 1985, the designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have mined the island for inspiration with the zeal of latter-day Viscontis. They have made stylistic allusions to its sartorial traditions - ecclesiastic and aristocratic - named one of their fragrances after it and used it as the backdrop for some of their most memorable advertising images. They have also frequently vacationed there, spending two weeks every summer de-stressing on the secluded island of Stromboli and dancing under the mirrored balls in the bustling resort town of Taormina. "We love Sicily," says Dolce, a native Sicilian. "It is the perfect place to just relax - eat, read and not worry about the stress of work. And we always come back with so many ideas. It is very magical."

title: Corrections
description: The Long Island Journal column last Sunday, about Aaron D. Twerski, the new dean of the Hofstra University School of Law, included a university incorrectly among those where he has taught. He has been a visiting law professor at the University of Michigan, Boston University and Cornell; Brown has no law school.

title: 'Hot Animal Love': Beastie Boys and Girls
description: HOT ANIMAL LOVE

title: Support My Local Businesses
description: It's no secret that I've had a longstanding love affair with Sweden. I fell for Stockholm the first time my grandmother took me there in 1983: I considered completely transplanting myself when I spent a glorious week there with my friends Claes and Christina in the summer of 1996; toyed with the notion of citizenship when I rented a summer house in Stockholm's southern archipelago in 1998; and ended up bagging the ultimate souvenir -- a Modernist bungalow, complete with its own island -- in late 1999.

title: REMEMBERING NICE
description: To the Editor: "Going to Nice" (Sept 4) brought rich memories of when, as an infantry G.I. from the 75th Division, I spent a week there in April 1945.

title: New York Bookshelf: Nonfiction
description: KING OF THE JEWS By Nick Tosches Ecco ($25.95, hardcover)

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: In his long list of cities afflicted by terrorist attacks since 9/11, Danner curiously mentions no Israeli cities, like Jerusalem or Tel Aviv. On the other hand, he labels Menachem Begin as someone who "used terror with great success," noting that Begin's Irgun bombed the King David Hotel, killing 91 people, "most of them civilians." For the record, the King David was serving primarily as the command center of the British Mandatory Government in Israel. The Irgun alerted the British authorities to the pending explosion and urged that the building be evacuated.

title: Even Geraldo Deserves a Fair Shake
description: ONE of the real tests of journalistic integrity is being fair to someone who might be best described by a four-letter word.

title: Hurricane Slams Into Gulf Coast; Flooding Begins
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., Sept. 24 - Hurricane Rita, with an eye 20 miles wide and wind gusts of almost 150 miles per hour, slammed into the Gulf Coast before dawn on Saturday, causing far less damage than officials had feared but raising new concerns as its torrential rain and storm surges caused widespread flooding across much of the region.

title: Fourth-Grade Math Scores Rise
description: SCORES on standardized math tests by fourth graders in Westchester increased this year, while eighth graders' scores declined slightly, according to data released on Thursday by the State Education Department. The math exams were given to all New York fourth- and eighth-grade students last spring.

title: In Atlantic City, The Republican Folds
description: Come November, there will be at least one sure bet in Atlantic City.

title: Briefly: Fazio kept from giving speech
'Mothering the Mother' During Childbirth, and After
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 - Loretha Weisinger tickled the tummy of 1-month-old Kejuan Kelly, then twirled his tiny blue bootie on her finger. She cooed and cradled him, all the while softly lobbing questions at his young mother.

title: Virulent Dog Virus Hits Area Kennels
description: OSSINING - A NEW strain of influenza that began infecting dogs in Florida early last year has recently struck hard in the Westchester area, forcing the temporary closure of two kennels after more than 100 dogs being boarded there became ill, veterinary officials say.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; FILM
description: It would be an overstatement to suggest that without KILLER FILMS, the New York-based production company founded by Christine Vachon and Pamela Koffler, there would be no American independent film movement. But how influential would that movement be today if films like "Happiness," "Boys Don't Cry" and "Far From Heaven," produced by the company, hadn't been made?

title: Mets a Step Closer to Leaving Cellar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - As last season came to a close, Cliff Floyd said there wasn't "any light at the end of the tunnel" for the Mets. As this season heads into its final week, despite the team's battle to climb out of last place in the National League East, Floyd said progress had been made.

title: 'Fortune's Formula'
description: The story starts with a corrupt telegraph operator. His name was John Payne, and he worked for Western Union's Cincinnati office in the early 1900s. At the urging of one of its largest stockholders, Western Union took a moral stand against the evils of gambling. It adopted a policy of refusing to transmit messages reporting horse race results. Payne quit his job and started his own Payne Telegraph Service of Cincinnati. The new service's sole purpose was to report racetrack results to bookies.

title: No Pandering
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 3
description: New England Patriots (1-1) at Pittsburgh Steelers (2-0) 4:15 p.m.

title: Long Island's Muslims And Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Megan Henry and Keith Shugarman
description: Megan Anne Henry and Keith David Shugarman were married yesterday evening in Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Gid Montjoy IV performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church.

title: Evicted in Islip
description: The Islip Town Supervisor, Peter J. McGowan, is guilty of something, although it's hard to know of what, exactly, with an inquiry just begun and his government shut tight as a clam. It could be that he grotesquely abused his power. Or maybe he was just inept or out of touch, kept in the dark by misbehaving underlings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JEFFER, MEDWIN B.
description: JEFFER--Medwin B. 88, of Lake Worth, Fla., on September 21, 2005. Beloved husband of Marilyn and the late Eleanor; father of Susan and Dr. Mattis Fern and Peter and Haya Jeffer; grandfather of Jacqueline, Steven, Allison and Scott; great grandfather of Ben, Emily, Max, Samantha and Jack. Founder of Jeffer Funeral Homes with his father Irwin and brother Alvin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINHA, SURYA PRAKASH
description: SINHA--Surya Prakash. July 30, 2005. Leaves wife Jessica, child Sonya. Legal scholar, first U.S. Indian law professor.

title: Beds, Baths and Beyond
description: So you want to throw a house party at your estate, but all your family bequeathed you is debt? Then join the young jet-setters bored with boutique hotels who are leading the Rothschild lifestyle (sans the inheritance taxes) and organizing over-the-top fetes in private homes available for short periods. It's never been easier to invite 20 or more friends to, say, an island near Mykonos (www.fivestargreece.com), an ultramod clifftop party pad in Ibiza (www.worldlocations.com) or a rustic-luxe hacienda in Seville. And not only do these extreme rentals provide the perks of a five-star hotel, but they can also be much more affordable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALEXANDER, GRACE GEORGE
description: ALEXANDER -- Grace George. The Board of Directors, staff, and artists of Studio in a School note with sorrow the passing of Georgie Alexander. A tireless and dedicated advocate for children and the arts, Georgie was instrumental in helping to choose the artists and teachers with whom Studio initially worked and has continued to be supportive both in spirit and financially. Studio is as much Georgie's legacy, as it is anyone's. We extend our sympathies to her daughter Jane and to her entire family. Agnes Gund, Founder Richard Roob, Chairman Thomas Cahill Executive Director The Studio in a School Association, Inc.

title: Steven Schack and George Gustines
description: Steven Todd Schack and George Gene Gustines celebrated their partnership in a commitment ceremony yesterday in New York aboard the Lexington, a motor yacht. Gordon W. Arnold, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, and the boat's captain, officiated.

title: Cycling: Boonen gets world title in big sprint
THE WALLS OF BELFAST
description: To the Editor: Although Stuart Emmrich recognizes in "Belfast Is Ready for the Party to Begin" (Aug. 21) that Belfast is an up and coming -- and frequently misunderstood -- city, he mischaracterizes the role of its murals.

title: A City at Sea
description: AS we read about the effects of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita on the Gulf states, we have to wonder if the same thing could happen to the metropolitan region. Scarily, it could.
