description: JAMES AGEE

title: Bloomberg Keeps His Name Off Rebate Checks
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is giving up something Democrats have long described as an unfair perk of his incumbency: the prominent inclusion of his name on the $400 property-tax rebate checks that the city sends out to homeowners.

title: The New Normal: Wary but Resilient
description: AT the Colosseum in Rome, authorities have introduced airport-style metal detectors as part of an array of new counterterrorism measures that also include closed-circuit television cameras and movable metal crowd control barriers.

title: White House Letter: A celebration of books beset by a war's reality
Deal Is Reached to DropDebt of 18 Poor Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - Finance ministers from around the world reached agreement on Saturday on a plan to wipe out as much as $55 billion in debt owed by impoverished countries.

title: India Outsources a Bollywood Film
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia - A BOOMING film capital, this Pacific city has played host to aliens in "The X-Files," a clone of Arnold Schwarzenegger in "The 6th Day" and Jackie Chan fighting all comers against a mountainous skyline that was supposed to double for New York in "Rumble in the Bronx."

title: From Brazil and Portugal: True to Tradition
description: TARRYTOWN - DINERS have come to expect the unusual from restaurant kitchens no longer restrained by ingredients and styles of a region or country. The world is their pantry, and many chefs are eager to try flavor combinations unheard of until now.

title: Music: Berlin
description: The fall of the wall turned Berlin into one of the most musically endowed cities in the world. With double the musical wealth, it has four major symphony orchestras, a prominent early-music ensemble and three opera houses, which have orchestras that present their own symphony concerts. That is seven major orchestras, plus all the chamber music concerts they spawn, along with committed audiences, a population to whom classical music really matters and a deep cultural connection with the art form. But with the city's hard-pressed finances, contraction is possible in the future, so going sooner rather than later is a good idea.

title: Lucite coffee tables and African tribal masks
description: On the surface, Brussels seems fairly boring: It is clean and the headquarters of the European Community, and has a lot of restaurants uniformly serving artery-clogging moules-frites and beer. But the interior designers and vintage-furniture aficionados, who routinely trek in from Europe's more fashionable capitals nearby, know better.

title: Soft Landing
description: Sweaters to keep him cozy for the long haul. THE GET

title: An Authoritative Voice From the Archives
description: THE only way it could have been better would have been for Henry to hit the very first pitch, the one thrown by Gerald Ford.

title: Another Order To Go
description: AFTER 116 years, Lenox is breaking the china.

title: The Dermatologist
description: In Manhattan's fashionable circles the dermatologist Patricia Wexler is known as the connoisseur of great skin. Just ask her patients Vera Wang and Donna Karan. To improve her own appearance Dr. Wexler heads straight for Fifth Avenue.

title: Mosey On Down to the General Store (but Do It While You Can)
description: In a Chelsea neighborhood becoming ever-so-sleek and franchise-infested, a little video store called Alan's Alley has become a modern-day trading post. Beyond the expected assortment of videotapes and DVD's, some of them quite esoteric, the store also sells old furniture, Fiesta Ware and the works of a local potter.

title: Empowering Iran
description: It's a great time to be an Iranian theocrat. American military power has removed your most dangerous foreign enemy, Saddam Hussein. American diplomatic strategy has delivered the lion's share of Iraqi political power and oil wealth to the Shiite religious parties you've financed and armed for years and which are now your grateful dependents. Russia, China and the nonaligned movement have been blocking any strong international action to slow down your rush to develop nuclear weapons technology. What's more, you've finally worn down and outmaneuvered those pesky reformist clerics who kept arguing for overtures to the Great Satan in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACHRACH, DORIS
description: BACHRACH--Doris.You will always be in my thoughts on the holidays. Barbara Epstein

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: SCOTLAND BY TRAIN -- The Scottish Freedom Pass from Britrail offers travelers a 25 percent discount off train (and even ferry, bus and subway) travel until Dec. 31. Adults pay $161 (children half price) for a pass that can be used any four days of an eight-day period for standard-class train travel within Scotland. There's also a pass good for use 8 days in a 15-day period for $210. Among the benefits of the pass is that it can be used as well between Berwick-Upon-Tweed (England's East Coast) and to Carlisle (on the West Coast). It is also honored on the Caledonian MacBrayne and Strathclyde ferries to Scottish islands, as well as on some buses and on the Glasgow subway. For more details call (866) 274-8724 or see www.britrail.com (after reaching "passes" category for Scotland, click forward to "low-season" tab).

title: China Sets New Media Restrictions, This Time for the Internet
description: BEIJING, Sept. 25 - China on Sunday imposed more restrictions on the news media, designed to limit the news and other information available to Internet users, and sharply restricted the scope of content permitted on Web sites.

title: 'New York Night'
A Health Care Disaster
description: KILN, Miss. - In the richest country in the world, a man named Eugene Johnson is going blind in a homeless shelter, because his eye medicine washed away in Hurricane Katrina and he can't afford to buy more.

title: First phase of Aceh pact completed
Independence Party: The Mouse That Roared
description: NASSAU Republican leaders trumpeted it as a significant victory when their candidate, Donald Clavin, outpolled the incumbent Democrat, Howard Weitzman, in the Sept. 13 Independence Party primary for county comptroller.

description: Correction Appended

description: Governor M. Jodi Rell has ordered an inquiry on whether to close a state office building at 25 Sigourney Street in Hartford, where workers are complaining of health problems.

Tick Numbers Are Up In Old Lyme and Lyme
description: The number of ticks in Old Lyme and Lyme was up by about 80 percent from 2004, said Kirby C. Stafford III, vice director of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven, last Monday. The station was testing the ticks for Lyme disease, which Dr. Stafford said generally infects 15 to 20 percent of ticks.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about young politicians in the city misstated the age of Theodore Roosevelt when he was elected to the Assembly in 1881. He was 23, not 24.

title: Movies
description: CLOSER (2004) Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:45 a.m. on Cinemax Julia Roberts smiles less. Jude Law wears glasses (which serve only to make him look sexier). Natalie Portman (above right) takes off her clothes. Clive Owen smolders. Mike Nichols's powerful romantic drama is based on Patrick Marber's Tony Award-winning play, which ran on Broadway in 1999, with Natasha Richardson and Ciaran Hinds among the leads. In London, a photographer, an obituary writer, a stripper and a dermatologist meet in odd ways (e.g., a man pretends to be a woman on the Internet), fall in love, flirt, fight, curse, change partners and betray one another more than once. Emotions don't get much rawer than theirs. Characters don't get much needier. The movie stops one scene short of the play's unhappy ending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, SYLVIA
description: LEWIS--Sylvia. Passed away peacefully at home on September 24, 2005, after many years of illness. Predeceased by her husband Mac. She is survived by her daughters Hili and Mir, her brother Eddie Rauch and her nieces. We will be thankful forever to Lynette Farquharson for all her devoted care. Graveside service at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY, on Sunday, September 25, at 1 pm.

title: A Quotidian Corner of Fairfield County
description: IN 1981, Danbury, Conn., said goodbye to bumper cars and prize pigs once and for all, as the 160-year-old agricultural carnival known as the Danbury Fair packed up its tent poles for good.

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: While I greatly respect Mark Danner's thorough analysis, I'd like to point out that many soldiers and marines returning from Iraq are positive about the difference they are making and the support among the average people there. Not all, but an overwhelming majority of the vets I've spoken to or read online have much to say, with specifics, about the desire for democracy on a very local, basic level. The sense is not quite parades and flowers, but still a recollection of much appreciation and support, punctuated by some very bad guys (often from out of the country) with bombs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTER, VICTOR
description: FUTTER--Victor. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend and Director Emeritus Victor Futter. Vic was a great leader of Greenwich House as a member of the board for 20 years, providing invaluable counsel, leadership and support in numerous ways. We will miss his wisdom, expertise in nonprofit governance, and the infectious enthusiasm with which he recruited Board members. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Joan; his children, Jeffrey, Ellen and Deborah; and his entire family. George A. Davidson, Chair Board of Directors Roy Leavitt, Executive Director & CEO Greenwich House, Inc.

title: In This 'Culture War,' Culture Is the Winner
description: It's bad enough for Citigroup that Bank of America has surpassed it as the No.1 issuer of credit cards. But is Citigroup falling behind in classical music, too?

title: Corrections
description: An annotated film listing in the New Season issue on Sept. 11 for "Ballets Russes," opening on Oct. 26, omitted a credit. Dayna Goldfine was Daniel Geller's co-director.

title: Benefits
description: Songs Over Supper

title: And the Other Video? 'Weekend at Bernie's'
description: On Tuesday night at 8 p.m., many were watching the Yankees trying to leapfrog over the first-place Boston Red Sox. (That didn't happen until the next night.) Stragglers were making their way home on New Jersey Transit. And those less fortunate were watching the televised gubernatorial debate.

title: The Gulf Will Rise Again
description: BILOXI, Miss. - ON Aug. 17, 1969, Hurricane Camille roared onto the Gulf Coast with winds of more than 200 miles an hour, only the second Category 5 storm to hit the mainland United States. It killed 143 people in Mississippi, and 201 more in flooding in central Virginia.

title: The Classicist
description: This past June in New York, in the days before he was presented with the award for international designer of the year by the Council of Fashion Designers of America (C.F.D.A.), the fashion world's equivalent of an Oscar for Best Picture, Alber Elbaz was not rejoicing. The award was a validation of sorts, a long-overdue acknowledgment of his talent and the work he had done since 2002 at Lanvin, the long-moribund French couture house that he has rejuvenated. But the attention and accolades, though welcome, made Elbaz both giddy and anxious. The giddiness was largely for show, a part of the cuddly, jovial image that Elbaz puts forth, especially in social situations. He is a small, round man, and he nearly always wears a black suit with trousers that are much too short, a silk bow tie knotted loosely at his throat and black rectangular glasses that set off the softness of his face. Elbaz understands the power of fashion, how clothes can create a personality, real or otherwise. This gift for artifice extends to his own sartorial choices. While he appears to be playful and a bit theatrical (and he can be), Elbaz is mostly thoughtful and distinctly aware of the vagaries of his chosen business. Now 44, he has worked in fashion for nearly 20 years, including, for 2 of them, as the chief designer of women's wear at Yves St. Laurent, and he knows that being chosen by a group like the C.F.D.A. means that you will, inevitably, be discarded in favor of another. "Being a designer is not about being a star -- I didn't work for the eight seconds when you get a prize," Elbaz told me over lunch at Chanterelle in TriBeCa the day before the awards ceremony. "For me, there is nothing scarier than being of the moment. Because the moment ends."
