title: Antiwar Rallies in Washington and Other Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - Vast numbers of protesters from around the country poured onto the lawns behind the White House on Saturday to demonstrate their opposition to the war in Iraq, pointedly directing their anger at President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Hard Bigotry of No Expectations
description: Throughout his campaigns in 2000 and 2004, George W. Bush talked about "the soft bigotry of low expectations": the mind-set that tolerates poor school performance and dead-end careers for minority students on the presumption that they are incapable of doing better. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said recently that this phrase attracted her to Mr. Bush more than anything else.

title: Israel launches new strike on Gaza strip
Kate Zernike and Jonathan Schwartz
description: Kate Zernike and Dr. Jonathan D. Schwartz were married yesterday in Essex, Conn. Patricia Bruder Debrovner, an adjunct leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Essex Yacht Club.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph on Aug. 28 in T: Women's Fashion magazine, with an article about the writer Maria Bell's experiences as a Los Angeles socialite, was published in error. The photograph showed the actress Maria Bello, not Maria Bell.

title: Parents, Be Thankful for Small Favors: They Pay for the Gas
description: It's simply not true that all of today's young people were born with a key to a silver BMW in their hands. For some, it was merely to a blue Toyota.

title: A Campaign to Remember
description: Beyond a few aging political junkies, I suspect there aren't many New Yorkers for whom the name Samuel J. Silverman triggers instant recognition. Yet for a brief moment some 39 years ago, Mr. Silverman, an accomplished state judge who died in 2001, was a figure of national note, having been drafted against his better judgment to play a key role in Senator Robert Kennedy's 1966 campaign to clean up the patronage trough also known as New York City's Surrogate's Court.

title: Baryshnikov Takes His Building for a Test Run
description: IN boutique hotels and trendy restaurants, this would be the soft opening. Mikhail Baryshnikov's new Baryshnikov Arts Center will officially open in November, offering a highly equipped, multipurpose space for all kinds of artists -- playwrights, multimedia creators and choreographers, students and stars -- to come together to work and collaborate, or simply to hang out, exchanging thoughts and ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRAND, JOSHUA M.
description: BRAND--Joshua M., 62. September 17th, 2005. Beloved husband of Mercedes, son of Marion Orgel, father to Monica, Debbie, Jeff and Kenny, and brother to Andrea, David, and Carol. A man of great energy, he dedicated his life to family and friends.

title: Early Practice Turns Into Victory on Fifth Avenue
description: Shortly after dawn yesterday, when many were enjoying a weekend sleep-in, Craig Mottram of Australia was running down Fifth Avenue, right in the middle of the road. A little later, Carmen Douma-Hussar of Canada was doing the same.

title: The Ick Factor
description: Today's scholarly linguistic dissertation deals with embodied cognition. (That should clear the room of readers searching for the prurient, offensive and scatological.)

title: Elizabeth Avedon and Matthew Atkinson
description: Elizabeth Cox Avedon and Matthew Rogers Atkinson were married yesterday at St. Mark's Church in Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Amilcar Figueroa, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: At the Fiesta Bowl, the Final Frame
description: THE Lehman High School students filed down Westchester Avenue wearing gigantic T-shirts and jostling and shouting in the September sun. It was Monday afternoon, the school day was over, and their path home took them under the elevated 6 train, past two-family brick houses or wooden ones with vinyl siding, and just in front of New Fiesta Bowl, where the neon signs were dark.

title: Eat, Memory: Line of Sight
description: A couple of years ago I placed an ad for a line cook. And there was a guy who, according to his rsum, should have been right up my alley. He held a grill position in a busy seafood joint at the shore; he had studied philosophy and political science; and he had about four years of experience in the industry. I was looking forward to meeting this guy, with whom an after-work conversation over beers might be possible, and who had just enough years in the industry to still have something to learn, but not so few that he would need to be taught everything. I called him up and we had a pleasant phone exchange. I liked his voice, his manner; he was intelligent and articulate. I invited him in for an interview the following day.

title: Hokies Show Yellow Jackets Something Special in Blowout
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Sept. 24 - VIRGINIA TECH 51, GEORGIA TECH 7

title: Bargain Fares in Europe? Well, Not Exactly
description: A $1.28 air fare from London to Venice? Can it be true? Many American vacationers in Europe might be tempted by the wondrously cheap fares offered by European budget airlines like Ryanair and easyJet.

title: Funny About the News
description: Q: How will your new late-night show, "The Colbert Report," be different from Jon Stewart's, "The Daily Show," on which you have appeared for years as a fake senior news correspondent? The character will not change. He's the exact same guy from "The Daily Show," and he has just been promoted into the host's chair. We're trying to establish a persona here. He's a well-intentioned, poorly informed, high-status idiot.

title: 'The Shame of the Nation': Separate and Unequal
description: THE SHAME OF THE NATION

title: This Story Sadly Appropriate for Children
description: LONDON - "THE history of the world is, sadly, not a pretty poem," the art historian E.H. Gombrich wrote in his first book, a history primer for children, published in German in 1936. "It offers little variety, and it is nearly always the unpleasant things that are repeated, over and over again."

title: Answered Prayers: How 'Capote' Came Together
description: AROUND two years ago, a classic Hollywood pitch meeting was ending. In the Santa Monica offices of the now-defunct United Artists, a director with nothing more impressive than a low-budget documentary under his belt, a first-time screenwriter, a producer and an actor listened for a yes.

title: Walk this Way
description: After making New York neighborhoods approachable for more than 125,000 tourists, the audio-walking-tour company Soundwalk is tackling an even tougher city. With the CD guide "Varanasi: The City of Light," visitors will gain much-needed insight into this ancient Indian holy center (also known as Benares), which is visited each year by millions of Hindu pilgrims who come to be purified in the Ganges, or to die. "For foreigners, it's filthy, noisy, smelly, there are people dying everywhere - it's a living paradox," says Eddie Stern, the director of the Ashtanga Yoga New York, and a co-producer of the project. "We want to help people penetrate such a confusing place."

title: 4 Nights Only!
description: This might be a good tag line when you take your online dating on the road. Most profile-based Web sites (like Nerve or Yahoo) allow you to sort by ZIP code, so you can contact the ones that make your hot list. Or if you believe it's better to let them come to you, you can create an alternate profile for yourself as a resident of the city that you plan to visit. A Craigslist posting practically guarantees success, but with blatant come-ons like "Show me your ... city," it might be better to pay to advertise.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: ONE DANGEROUS LADY. By Jane Stanton Hitchcock. (Miramax, $23.95.) Hitchcock showcases the swankiest dwellings in New York and the Caribbean as backdrops to her second suspense novel featuring Jo Slater, a wealthy woman who's been both the toast and the roast of Manhattan. When Jo's friend Russell Cole goes missing from his yacht in Barbados, New York society converges on the island to entertain his shady but glamorous would-be widow. Family members attribute Russell's absence to "something called Dissociative Fugue Disorder," a straight-out-of-a-soap-opera form of amnesia that causes him to wander from home and temporarily lose his identity. But Jo and her friend Larry, a novelist who writes about "low crime in high places," aren't so sure. Soon after the widow tells Jo they're "sisters under the skin" (which creeps Jo out considerably), people start to die. Hitchcock's cast entertains rather than stimulates, but they're so bitchy and droll we can hardly complain.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday about privacy rights and the Constitution misstated the initial of the president of the State University at Albany. He is Kermit L. Hall, not Kermit T.

title: Heather Betz and Susan Hazeldean
description: Heather Lynn Betz and Susan Victoria Hazeldean affirmed their partnership in a commitment ceremony yesterday at the River Caf in Brooklyn. The Rev. Gale Jones, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

title: S.U.V.'s, Cellphones And Selfishness
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE WEB
description: Bookstalls outside the Botanical Garden in Madrid, hand-carved pipes in Rome and Georgian homes off St. Stephen's Green in Dublin, above. Correspondents of The New York Times in nine European cities, from Richard Bernstein in Berlin to John Tagliabue in Paris, share their favorite places to eat, shop or just go for a walk at nytimes.com/travel.

title: 1:34 A.M. She Agreed To A Nightcap. Where To Go?
description: Los Angeles: the Prince This Rat Pack-era steakhouse of the fake-English variety has been taken over by Koreans, who have wisely not updated the dcor (they did add techno-pop music, shoju and squid pancakes to the mix). 3198 West Seventh Street; (213)389-1586. New York: Angel's Share Behold the perfect cocktail bar: soft lighting, no parties larger than four, a velvet-couched salon and a flawless litchi martini. If you can't close at this place, you are not a closer. 8 Stuyvesant Street, Second Floor; (212)777-5415. Paris: the Hemingway Bar Clubby and classic, this oak-paneled room offers backgammon tables and the expertise of its fabled bartender, Colin Field, who will gladly make you a $492-euro sidecar. Hotel Ritz, 15 Place Vendme; 011 33 1 43 16 30 30. THE TICKET

title: Megan Kultgen and Anthony Bovino
description: Megan Elizabeth Kultgen, a daughter of Candy and David Kultgen of Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, and Austin, Tex., was married yesterday to Anthony Joseph Bovino, a son of Karyn and George Bovino of Carmel, N.Y. The Rev. Anthony Sorgie performed the ceremony at Emmaus Catholic Church in Austin.

title: In This 'Culture War,' Culture Is the Winner
description: It's bad enough for Citigroup that Bank of America has surpassed it as the No. 1 issuer of credit cards. But is Citigroup falling behind in classical music, too?

title: The Broken Contract
description: A contract of citizenship defines the duties of care that public officials owe to the people of a democratic society. The Constitution defines some parts of this contract, and statutes define other parts, but much of it is a tacit understanding that citizens have about what to expect from their government. Its basic term is protection: helping citizens to protect their families and possessions from forces beyond their control. Let's not suppose this contract is uncontroversial. American politics is a furious argument about what should be in the contract and what shouldn't be. But there is enough agreement, most of the time, about what the contract contains for America to hold together as a political community. When disasters strike, they test whether the contract is respected in a citizen's hour of need. When the levees broke, the contract of American citizenship failed.

title: Clap Your Hands Say Yeah: Ready to Gloat at the Reunion
description: PHILADELPHIA - "WE'RE the kind of guys that everyone carried around on their shoulders in high school," Alec Ounsworth, the scrawny 27-year-old frontman of the band Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, said with more than a hint of sarcasm.

title: With an Eagle and an Ace by DiMarco, It's All Tied
description: GAINESVILLE, Va., Sept. 24 - Where there was noise at Robert Trent Jones Golf Club, there was Chris DiMarco and his homemade swing, knocking golf shots on a string and carrying the United States team through an autumn afternoon.

title: DONALD, IS THAT YOU?
description: For a man never at a loss for words -- or a chance to promote himself -- it is little surprise that Donald J. Trump is now hawking ring tones to cellphone users, for a fee.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: 'Small Towns, Black Lives'

title: Screech and Tell
description: We went to Newfoundland for many reasons. For one thing, we had never heard anything much about it, and by "we," I mean me; my 13-year-old daughter, Billie; my stepson, Harper Simon; my friend Kim Painter; and my photographer and friend, Meg Ryan, who took along her assistant, Learka Bosnak, and her photo assistant, Dan Hallman.

title: With Friends Like These, She Wrote a Book
description: WHEN Rosanne Kalick learned she had a second form of cancer, she remembered, one acquaintance's response was, "If anyone should have this, it's you." A co-worker said, "Don't you know you're ruining everyone's Thanksgiving?" And a friend offered this salve: "You know, hospice is wonderful."

title: Topics of The Times: Leave It to Cleaver
description: Excuse me, but what is so all-fired hard about peeling garlic? Mark Bittman is completely dismissing one of cooking's greatest pleasures.

title: Internet Sites Are Making China More Accessible
description: Want to sample Sichuan dishes in Southwest China after climbing the Great Wall in the North? There's no need to call a travel agency. As China becomes increasingly popular with Western travelers, Internet sites that offer searches in both Chinese and English could make planning travel inside China considerably easier and cheaper from outside the country.

title: Hughes, New U.S. Envoy, Makes First Diplomatic Effort
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25 - Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes arrived today in Egypt on her overseas debut as President Bush's "public diplomacy" envoy and denounced Islamic militancy, defended administration policies in Iraq and said that the slow response to Hurricane Katrina was regrettable but not racist.

title: Doubts About Roberts, Expressed One Volunteer at a Time
description: White Plains - ANYONE driving by the County Center here on the afternoon of Sept. 12, the day Judge John G. Roberts Jr. began testifying before Congress in Washington, might have seen about a dozen well-dressed women standing at intervals on the sidewalk, each holding a sign bearing a fragment of a message. They were volunteers for Planned Parenthood, and the first woman's sign, in bright pink and blue, read, "Judge Roberts." A little farther down the line, the next read, "Answer." Still farther was: "The ?'s" There followed brightly colored signs on choice, safety, privacy and women's health.

title: The Politics Of Upper Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Amanda Flug and Samuel Davidoff
description: Amanda Diane Flug and Samuel Bryant Davidoff were married last evening at the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington. Judge Stefan R. Underhill of Federal District Court in Connecticut officiated.

title: STORM AND CRISIS
description: THE OIL INDUSTRY -- The storm damaged oil refineries, but it did not cause the widespread destruction of the energy infrastructure that some had feared. PAGE 34

title: Lauren Gard and Adam Kaszycki
description: Lauren Gard and Adam Kaszycki are to be married today. The Rev. Donald R. Williams, a United Methodist minister, is to perform the ceremony in Ocean City, N.J. The couple will be known as Mr. and Ms. Gard.

title: Ads That Catch the Eye Or Make Card Tables
description: I'VE been commuting on Metro-North for 20 years, and I can't recall ever being influenced by an advertising poster on the train. Despite hundreds of hours spent staring at these advertisements, I have yet to buy a BMW, attend the United States Open or pick up a special seasonal beverage at Starbucks.

title: In Long Beach, $1 Million Condos
description: LOOKING down recently from the unfinished terrace of a new condominium seven floors above the Long Beach boardwalk, signs of summer held fast: hesitant swimmers cowered before crashing ocean waves, joggers trickled by and one man on a big-wheeled skateboard coasted along the beach pulled by an attached sail.

title: The Blame Game Over Dead Fish
description: Looking onto Alley Creek from Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, visitors are greeted by a slow stream of fish carcasses mixed in with the current. More of the fish, a pale species known as bunker or menhaden, are washed up on the shore, the smell reminiscent of a bait shack without air-conditioning.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in the New Season issue on Sept. 11 about the ABC series "Commander in Chief" starring Geena Davis misstated the surname of her character at one point. She is Mackenzie Allen, not Adams.

title: The Minimalist On the Bespoke Bicycle
description: LOOK around your average minimalist apartment, and it is easy to see why the spartan style gives some people the chills. Where's the stuff? Where's the warmth? Where's the love?

title: Why Time Warner Has Fallen in Love With AOL, Again
description: TECH'S most notorious dead man walking may be AOL. Many years have passed, however, since commentators first voiced the opinion that AOL's days were numbered (1994), that commercial online services were doomed (1995), that the more it blended with the surrounding Web, the greater the likelihood that it would lose its reason for being (1996).

title: Bombing suspect extradited to Spain
Rieslings Arise Near the Falls
description: Cave Spring, an Ontario boutique, has mastered Canadian riesling. The winemaker Angelo Pavan makes graceful versions, thanks to the soil and climate of the Niagara Peninsula, which lies between Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. His 2004 semidry ($10.99) and 2004 reserve ($14.99), both redolent of peaches, resemble Mosel rieslings from Germany. The 2004 Indian Summer Select Late Harvest (half bottle, $19.99) is a tangy dessert white. Chelsea Wine Vault, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), carries them.

title: Red Sox Stitch a Victory With Patchwork Bullpen
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 - No matter how many home runs Manny Ramirez or David Ortiz hit over the next week, the fate of the Red Sox' playoff chances rests squarely on the American League's most combustible bullpen.

title: Trading Spaces, and Deferring the Taxes
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LING, ALFRED S.C.
description: LING--Alfred S.C. 77, on September 13, 2005. A graduate of Princeton University, the University of Illinois (MS, Physiology) and at he University of Maryland (MD and Ph.D, Pharmacology). Following his residency in internal medicine at the Pennsylvania Hospital, he joined Rockefeller University Faculty and was Senior Physician at Rockefeller Hospital. He retired as Vice President for Clinical Research for Wyeth Research. He served his Princeton Class of 1949 as Class Agent and President. He leaves his wife, Helen; his children, Dr. Geoffrey Ling of Maryland, Dr. Douglas Ling of New Jersey, and Karen Lee Ling, Esq. of New York; and five grandchildren.

title: Take a Hike
description: THIS summer, the nation grieved in advance for Brennan Hawkins, an 11-year-old Boy Scout lost in the Utah wilderness. But the boy was rescued four days after he disappeared, and his searchers might have found him earlier -- had he not run from them. His family had taught him to avoid strangers, and he was afraid of being abducted.

title: From Inside Out, A Museum Remix
description: NORTHPORT - THE picturesque brick building with the steeply pitched roof on Main Street has been home to the Northport Historical Society Museum for 31 years. The building, on the National Register of Historic Places, had become something of a museum piece itself, its interior hardly altered from the time of World War I until early this year, when the society began a major renovation.

title: Whether It's Half Full or Half Empty, It Again Ends Up All Trojans
description: EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 24 - It was a testament to the dominance and the efficiency of Southern California that it could play well for little more than a half Saturday against 24th-ranked Oregon and still win by 32 points.

title: AT THE WALL OF PEACE, AUG. 31, 2005
description: Bae Yun Jin, 40, a businessman from Gwangmyeong, Korea, with his wife, Oh Soon Hwa, also 40, a shopowner. "I visited Paris to attend the Maison & Objet fair and spend two days sightseeing with my wife. The city is too big to appreciate in such a short time. We visited -- or strolled -- the Louvre, Champs-Elyses, Arc de Triomphe, Versailles, March aux Puces and Montmartre. I had traveled to Paris twice before, but I did not recognize that wall. When I saw the word 'peace' in Korean and English, I guessed that the other languages had the same meaning. Our country has a sad history of war between people of the same race, and we still live in tragic division. So, I hope that the word of peace engraved on the wall comes to Korea and unifies the peninsula again in the near future."

title: Gastro Hub
description: Surveying the country's restaurants in 1976, the food writer Waverley Root and his co-author, Richard de Rochemont, sniffed, "Chicago has not developed restaurants which have left their mark on history, unless you count the collective mark of its steakhouses." In 2005, eating in Chicago is almost painful: to choose one superb restaurant is to reject a dozen others.

title: Where Armies Must Be Built, It's Slow (Iraq) and Even Slower (Afghanistan)
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan - American and international efforts to train Afghanistan's security forces began in 2002, about a year before a similar program for Iraqi soldiers and police officers. Yet the Afghan model seems to have lagged behind the troubled Iraqi program.

title: Beginning Oct. 1, Stop Talking and Drive
description: The state police are preparing to enforce a new law that, starting on Oct. 1, prohibits using a hand-held cellphone while driving.

title: Paperback Row
description: NUCLEAR TERRORISM: The Ultimate Preventable Catastrophe, by Graham Allison. (Owl/Holt, $15.) Disagreeing with those who think a terrorist nuclear attack is unavoidable, Allison, a Harvard scholar, calls for bolder measures to reduce the nuclear threat (rounding up the world's fissile material, for example). In THE PERSIAN PUZZLE: The Conflict Between Iran and America (Random House, $15.95), Kenneth M. Pollack addresses the United States' relationship with a country that has supported terrorism and may have pursued nuclear weapons.

title: Shut-Down Carousel Going to Cooperstown
description: The Empire State Carousel, handmade by 1,000 volunteers over 20 years to celebrate the history and culture of New York State, is moving from a location at the Holtsville Ecology Center and Animal Preserve in the Town of Brookhaven to the Farmers' Museum in Cooperstown, a carousel spokesman said.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; TELEVISION
description: With MARTIN SCORSESE as director, "NO DIRECTION HOME: BOB DYLAN" (Monday and Tuesday, 9 p.m., Channel 13) is not going to be your average music documentary. One of Mr. Scorsese's many talents is the ability to evoke a past era (in this case, 1961-66) viscerally. So the film, punctuated with long-ago, previously unseen performances, isn't just about Mr. Dylan, now 64. It's about what he meant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOUGLASS, WILLIAM ANGUS
description: DOUGLASS--William Angus. Died peacefully on September 19, at home, with his wife Stephanie, son Doug, daughters, Tory and Fiona, by his side. A graduate of Yale '51, he and college friends founded Careers, Inc, in 1951. Since 1970 he divided his time between UK and USA. A service will be held on October 11, at Presbyterian Church, New Canaan. In lieu of flowers donations to IRC or Doctors Without Borders.

title: In This Storm, White House Tries to Take New Tack
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 24 - As he emerged Saturday morning from the "battle cab" deep inside the Northern Command's headquarters in Colorado Springs, President Bush caught sight of a famous image of himself: with bullhorn in hand at ground zero on Sept. 14, 2001.

title: Vesper Mei and Mark Bellermann
description: Vesper Mei, a daughter of Elaine and Peng-Siu Mei of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday to Mark Richard Walter Bellermann, a son of Ayer Bellermann of Oyster Bay, N.Y., and Peter Bellermann of Sherman, Tex. Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Stamford, Conn., officiated at the home of Frances R. Storrs, a grandmother of the bridegroom, in Oyster Bay.

title: Reviving New Orleans clings to Big Muddy
Stephanie Sweet and Daniel Ingersoll
description: Stephanie Frederick Sweet, a daughter of Kirk and Carol Sweet of Lake Forest, Ill., was married there yesterday evening to Daniel Wright Ingersoll, a son of Margaret and Jon Ingersoll of Moorestown, N.J. The Rev. Jay Sidebotham, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Spirit.

title: A Dog's Death
description: I am a pediatrician who frequently treats children with kala-azar, a disease transmitted to humans from dogs by sand flies.Treatment of dogs and humans is painful, prolonged and not very effective. Euthanizing infected animals is the best way to curb the spread of the disease. A stray dog, Lisa, established herself outside our house, and we fed her daily.When kala-azar was diagnosed, we reluctantly euthanized her. Ethical?

title: That's a Lot of Zeros
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR - WHEN was the last time you popped into the bank to deposit $99,999,999, filling out one of those generic triplicate slips at the counter without your name printed on it? Never? Apparently your neighbor has, because Chase's blank deposit form features 10 empty boxes next to the word "Total." That's eight yawning spaces for "dollars" and two for "cents," all clamoring to be noticed in eye-popping green ink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, NORMAN I.
description: MILLER--Norman I., 63, September 8, 2005, in Miami. Survived by life partner, Jose Garcia; former wife, Alice Ostrove Miller, and her life partner, Fran Levey; mother, Sylvia; brother, Joe. Predeceased by sister, Barbara Friedman, and father, Louis. Graduated from Horace Mann, Tufts and George Washington. Services were held.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 25, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Benefits of Caffeinated Drink for Children Are Source of Debate
description: The company's marketing materials describe the drink as a way to kick-start the morning for children as young as 4. The company Web site, adorned with a picture of an elementary school wrestler and a gymnast, says its drink can help a child "develop fully as a high-performance athlete" and fill nutritional gaps "in a sport that is physically and mentally demanding."

title: Gansevoort's Owners Plan to Export Its Meatpacking District Style
description: Following up on the trendy Gansevoort hotel in New York's Meatpacking District, the hotel's developers have decided to build two more -- in Los Angeles and in Miami Beach.

title: Not Just the Humidity, It's the Heat, Too
description: Summer is finally over, sort of, although it would be hard to tell. This has been the hottest September since the National Weather Service began keeping records in 1872.

title: Weather Suits Mosquitoes Fine
description: THE recent rain and hot muggy weather has mixed up an alluring soup for mosquitoes infected with West Nile virus to breed and bite, state health officials said this past week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We're going back to the drawing board. With an earthquake or a major terrorist attack, we'd obviously have no warning. We haven't looked at mass evacuation or temporary housing for hundreds of thousands of people."

title: CLASS ABOVE ALL
description: His work as an investment banker is well known -- his boutique firm holds a high-profile conference for media moguls every summer in Sun Valley, Idaho -- but Herbert A. Allen's philanthropy is all low-key.

title: A Raw Deal
description: THIS used to be a festive time in New York. In September, just as New Yorkers moved back from their summer homes and as the first hint of fall was in the air, all the city newspapers would announce jubilantly that the oyster season had opened.

title: Sally Inc.
description: IT was a hot wet Wednesday, altogether too swampy for anything but the briefest outdoor interlude, so the tour of Sally Hershberger's prodigious penthouse balcony quickly came to what is so often the point: real estate.

title: Presidents Cup Golf: 2 years later, teams still as close as ever
'26a': Sister, Sister
Factoring In the Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Cover
description: CREATE a show about the first female president of the United States, as Rod Lurie has done with the new drama "Commander in Chief," and right away you have a pivotal decision to make: does she come into the White House through the front door, by getting elected, or through the back, by inheriting the office?

title: A million little pieces
Looking More Compelling: A Power System of One's Own
description: MIAMI - UNTIL recently, an approaching hurricane or tropical storm would force Martin Schleifer to shut down his small advertising agency in Coconut Grove, Fla. "Every time a storm came, it would be a mad dash to prepare," he said on Monday, as Hurricane Rita loomed ominously offshore. "Losing power essentially put us out of business."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.H.L.

title: And the Neighbors Said, We Knew Them When
description: When Bob Domina supports a baseball team, he doesn't go halfway. Mr. Domina, a boyish, garrulous social worker from the St. George neighborhood of Staten Island, has season tickets to both the Yankees and their local minor-league affiliate, the Staten Island Yankees. He is president of the minor-league team's booster club. And at one point this past season, he found himself in Costco, loaded down with toilet paper and cleaning supplies, in the midst of a grocery run to help the young players furnish their apartments.

title: Take a Hike
description: THIS summer, the nation grieved in advance for Brennan Hawkins, an 11-year-old Boy Scout lost in the Utah wilderness. But the boy was rescued four days after he disappeared, and his searchers might have found him earlier -- had he not run from them. His family had taught him to avoid strangers, and he was afraid of being abducted.

title: SMOKING LEGISLATION
description: With its smoky casinos where cigarettes are more common than jackpots, New Jersey has found tobacco a difficult habit to kick. Efforts to outlaw smoking indoors have stalled in the State Legislature for years, even as New York and other states have made such bans commonplace. But Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey has taken aim at the tobacco industry, and if he gets his way during the last few months of his term, New Jersey may become much less friendly to those looking to light up. Last Tuesday, Mr. Codey said he would introduce legislation to raise the state's legal age for buying tobacco products to 19 from 18, a move that comes weeks after he signed into law a statewide ban on smoking in college dormitories -- the first of its kind in the nation.

title: City Received a Near-Record Number of Visitors in 2004
description: A cheap dollar, safe streets and a calendar packed with cultural events proved a compelling mix for international travelers in 2004, drawing 31 percent more foreign visitors to New York City than in the previous year, according to a report released yesterday by the city's tourism office.

title: Canada Still Has Mulroney to Kick Around
description: IT'S Canada's Nixon moment. "The Secret Mulroney Tapes: Unguarded Confessions of a Prime Minister," the edited transcripts of hundreds of hours of interviews with the former conservative prime minister Brian Mulroney (who served from 1984 to 1993), has revealed a foul-mouthed, insecure man with an enemies list that sprawls from Vancouver to Halifax.

title: Don't Blink. You'll Miss the 258th-Richest American.
description: THE latest Forbes 400 list of the richest people in America has just hit the newsstands. The idea for the Forbes 400 -- rather than, say, 300 or 500 -- was inspired by Mrs. Astor's 400, the definitive list of New York high society in the 1890's. It's rumored that Mrs. William Backhouse Astor Jr. limited her social list to 400 because only 400 people could fit into her ballroom, but that may not be true. In any case, they had to be the right 400 people. As her escort, Ward McAlister, explained to reporters in 1888: "If you go outside that number, you strike people who are either not at ease in a ballroom or else make others not at ease."

title: Hurricanes Don't Have Much to Swagger About, Except the Score
description: MIAMI, Sept. 24 - Late in the first quarter of Miami's 23-3 victory over Colorado on Saturday, Hurricanes safety Brandon Meriweather began dancing on the field after driving his shoulder into the helmet of Colorado receiver Evan Judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCE, HENRY III.
description: LUCE--Henry III. The New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony, Kenneth Klein, Music Director, remembers its benefactor Henry Luce III with great appreciation and fondness. Thank you for the lovely concerts at Wychwood and the New York Historical Society and for the interesting conversations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHAPIRO, ELSIE
description: SHAPIRO--Elsie. September 27, 1992. Remembered with love.

title: Passing Through
description: After the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, the Chinese Ministry of Education began sending future students of Beijing University, a hotbed of pro-democratic protest, into the military for a year. So in 1991, at the age of 18, instead of beginning studies, I entered the army. There, along with 1,500 other students, I spent hours in formation training and even more time being lectured on the inevitable demise of capitalism and the victory of Communism.

title: You Don't Say
description: Not long ago an important producer I know was screening an almost finished cut of a movie that none of us thought too good. Did we offer criticism? Of course not.

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: That was a brave choice to use Mark Danner's article as your cover article on Sept. 11. It was exhilarating to read something so clearheaded and unsentimental on the anniversary. But you are making consistently brave decisions at the magazine. And you are combining courage with rigor: Peter Maass's article on oil comes to mind, and Jeffrey Rosen's about the next set of questions the Supreme Court will face. These articles, and Danner's, share a boldness, a willingness to imagine the future not purely as a continuation of the present. Bravo!

title: Focus Pocus
description: Say 'Cheese' (and ditch the film). THE GET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ILIFF, ELOISE ANNE
description: ILIFF--Eloise Anne. On September 16, 2005 at St. Vincent's Hospital, Manhattan. Actor, artist and teacher died after a short illness. Survived by two daughters, Emily Paine and Rachel Paine-Wilson and three grandchildren, Sebastian, Lydia and Joshua Wilson. Services October 2.

title: The Ticket; 200 Boylston Street: Where Your Pet Picks Up For You.
description: Unattached dog owners might want to high-tail it to Boston -- recently nominated as the third most dog-friendly city in North America and the second-best for singles - and position pups in the lobby of the Four Seasons. Within minutes, a crowd of international dog-loving businessmen will be kneeling at your feet, valets will approach you to offer walks in the Public Gardens, and waiters will arrive with silver trays laden with home-baked dog biscuits and Evian. Lap it up! www.fourseasons.com/boston. ANN MARIE GARDNER

title: To Reach Beyond Our Lonely Planet (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sicilian Slice
description: Dolce & Gabbana is as synonymous with Sicily as old ladies in veils and young Romeos on scooters. Since founding the label in 1985, the designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have mined the island for inspiration with the zeal of latter-day Viscontis. They have made stylistic allusions to its sartorial traditions -- ecclesiastic and aristocratic -- named one of their fragrances after it and used it as the backdrop for some of their most memorable advertising images. They have also frequently vacationed there, spending two weeks every summer de-stressing on the secluded island of Stromboli and dancing under the mirrored balls in the bustling resort town of Taormina. "We love Sicily," says Dolce, a native Sicilian. "It is the perfect place to just relax -- eat, read and not worry about the stress of work. And we always come back with so many ideas. It is very magical."

title: Early Damage Estimates for Rita Much Lower Than for Katrina
description: Damage caused by Hurricane Rita as it swept across parts of Texas and Louisiana on Saturday was perhaps only one-seventh as severe financially as the devastation that Hurricane Katrina inflicted on Mississippi and eastern Louisiana, according to initial estimates by insurance experts.

title: A Troubling Leak
description: The seepage has been slow, showing up only in trace amounts. But given enough time, we hope, measurable quantities of common sense may find their way through hairline cracks in the reinforced skulls of officials at Entergy Nuclear Northeast and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, and they will realize that local leaders and a jittery public deserve complete, accurate and timely information about problems at the Indian Point nuclear plant.

title: The Analysts vs. the Insiders
description: INSIDERS are aggressively buying shares of their company's stock while Wall Street analysts are downgrading it. As a potential investor, what should you do?

title: Those Aren't Just Sandals, Darling, They're Destiny
description: THEY'RE Stella McCartney black patent-leather pumps with a vertigo-inducing four-and-a-half-inch heel, in case you're wondering. When a movie has a title like "In Her Shoes" and is based on the best-selling chick-lit novel about a pair of shoe-obsessed sisters, you can't really expect the opening close-up to be of the film's other stars, Cameron Diaz and Toni Collette. That Ms. Diaz wears the to-die-for heels during an athletic if anonymous sex act in a public restroom only adds to their allure. As Ms. Diaz's character says a few scenes later, shoes like that "should be living a life of scandal and passion."

title: To Reach Beyond Our Lonely Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: The High- Performance Hybrids
description: "Hold on to your hat!" Jim Burns shouted as he slammed the accelerator to the floor. With a high-pitched whine, the electric motor behind my seat burst into action, and "the Enigma" -- an experimental red sports car in which I was riding shotgun -- bolted forward, pressing me back into my leather seat. In about three seconds we were whipping through the San Diego State University campus at 50 miles an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNES, MARY THAW DILWORTH
description: BARNES--Mary Thaw Dilworth, died September 19 in Pittsburgh, PA. Daughter of John Crossan and Helen Thaw Thompson Dilworth. Wife of the late Richard Langley Barnes, mother of four and grandmother of seven. Graduated from Vassar College 1936 and the University of Pittsburgh Law School 1939. One of the first 100 women lawyers in the state of Pennsylvania. A member of the Pennsylvania State Civil Service Commission 1963-86, Chairman 1982-86, appointed to Federal Women's Prison Board 1953-61 by President Eisenhower, head of Allegheny County Census 1960, on the Boards of the Urban League, the Home for Aged Protestant Women, Western Pennsylvania Hospital and the Pennsylvania Citizens Council. A special advisor to the 1970 Commission on Public Opinion, a liaison to the National Institute for Aging, and a Council member of the National Institute for Child Health & Development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: LEVIN--William, M.D. The administration, colleagues, staff and patients of Terence Cardinal Cooke Health Care Center mourn the passing of our beloved ENT specialist, Dr. Bill Levin. The skill and caring attention that he brought to each patient in his work here will be sorely missed. We extend our heart-felt sympathy to his wife Sally and daughter Julia. Anthony J. Lechich, M.D. Medical Director Mark F. Mazzella, Exec VP

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: In Eight Colors: Hush Your Mouth
description: It started with a dozen T-shirts, emblazoned with bright red stop signs. Now the shirts come in eight colors and three styles, all with the same basic message: Stop snitching.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about school districts that are on contingency budgets referred incorrectly to Hewlett-Woodmere. Though it has always won voter approval, in several recent years it did so on a second or third try after an initial proposal was rejected; the district did not have a record of never having lost a budget vote before this year.

title: Stony Brook University Closer to Campus Deal
description: Stony Brook University cleared a major hurdle in its planned takeover of Southampton College's 80-acre campus when the SUNY trustees voted unanimously in Albany on Tuesday to negotiate a purchase price with the campus's owner, Long Island University.

title: THE FACE OF AMSTERDAM
description: When it comes to Rembrandt and van Gogh, the Dutch are about evenly split, but as for flowers, the rose is vastly more popular than the national symbol, the tulip. Almost everyone rides a bike to work, except in extreme weather. The Dutch favor a touch of spice in their food -- Indonesian and Surinamese dishes are popular. And while the country's colonial past lends an exotic note to the cuisine, you're still never far from the typical favorites: herring, bread and cheese. Ann Marie Gardner

title: Pimp My Prius
description: Driving a hybrid can satisfy more than your conscience. With a little help from the flourishing car-customization business, it's an easy matter to add a bit of style -- some blue racing stripes, beige leather interior -- to an otherwise anonymous Prius. Or fully surrender to your id, and you could perhaps end up with the car on the opposite page.

title: The East in the West
description: The East in the West

title: The Opera That Chooses the Nuclear Option
description: JULY 16, 1945. The gadget, as the scientists are calling it, has been hoisted up its tower. Gen. Leslie Groves, the Army commander of the Manhattan Project, is beating up on the weatherman. Thunderheads have materialized from nowhere, threatening to set off the blast too soon. "The test will proceed as scheduled," Groves insists. "I demand a signed weather forecast. I warn you, if you are wrong, I will hang you."

title: Afraid of Being on Your Own? That's Healthy (and Also Useful)
description: Like many people who entertain the notion of leaving secure jobs to start their own businesses, Clive Rousseau remembers exactly when, in late 2003, those thoughts began to surface. For more than three years, he had been working at BuffSpa, a nail salon at Bergdorf Goodman, where his pedicures had helped him amass a devoted clientele.

title: COASTAL BLINDERS
description: To the Editor: "Highway 61, Visited" (Sept. 11) by Steve Dougherty, concerning Bob Dylan's roots in small-town Minnesota, should have had a different headline -- "Look New York! There's a State Called Minnesota!"

title: China Allows Visit by Democracy Advocates From Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 25 - Hong Kong's chief executive led all but one member of the city's legislature across the border to mainland China today, starting a two-day trip that marks the first time Beijing authorities have let in prominent Hong Kong advocates of democracy since the Tiananmen Square killings on June 4, 1989.

title: Melville
description: He was born on August 1, 1819, into good circumstances. But his parents lacked the money to stay there, and so they turned, at no small cost to their dignity, to their elders for help. On his mother's side, the benefactor was Maria's father, Peter Gansevoort, a towering man (six foot three in an age when six-footers were rare) famous for having commanded the defense of Fort Stanwix, an outpost guarding the trade route from the Great Lakes, during the British siege of 1777. There is a tendency today to think of the Revolutionary War as a dispute among bewigged gentlemen who sent men into battle with inaccurate guns to the martial music of fife and drum; in fact, it was a brutal war whose combatants literally tasted sweat and blood flung from the bodies of their enemies as they slashed at each other with bayonets. It was not uncommon for wounded soldiers to be stabbed through and left to bleed to death "like sieves," or to have their brains dashed out with "barbarity to the utmost" by the musket butts of the advancing enemy. Melville was to write about this war in the novel Israel Potter, in which he described the Yankee defenders at Bunker Hill gripping their muskets by the barrel and beating back the British assault by "wielding the stock right and left, as seal-hunters on the beach, knock down with their clubs the Shetland seal."

title: 'The World on Sunday': Pulitzer's Prize
description: THE WORLD ON SUNDAY

title: Design: Copenhagen
description: It lacks the buzz and hype of London and the familiar ring of Bilbao. But Scandinavia's Oresund region, which includes the Danish capital, Copenhagen, and Malmo in southern Sweden, has -- at least for the moment -- taken Europe's center stage for new architecture.

title: As Test Scores Jump, Raleigh Credits Integration by Income
description: RALEIGH, N.C. - Over the last decade, black and Hispanic students here in Wake County have made such dramatic strides in standardized reading and math tests that it has caught the attention of education experts around the country.

title: Art as Roadside Attraction
description: AFTER five years of living in the high desert near Joshua Tree National Park in California, the artist Andrea Zittel has begun to toy with the idea of turning her home into a roadside attraction. "I've taken a lot of road trips and have always loved those places where you have to pay 75 cents to see carved stones or U.F.O.'s," she said. "Besides, I'm so close to the highway that it just seems right."

title: The Ticket; One Hundred Ninety-Nine Potential Mates On The Chicago Architectural Cruise, And Other Interesting Tourist Attractions
description: Los Angeles

title: THE WALLS OF BELFAST
description: To the Editor: Mr. Emmrich shrugs off Belfast's historic Titanic connection with a single throwaway line. The ship, he writes, "was built here, in a building that is being turned into a museum."

title: Tackling Big Issues, Not Just Small Ones
description: To the Editor:

title: There's a Bit of Magic In This 'Night'
description: NO one is saying there are too many productions of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" these days. I'm just pointing out that the Long Wharf's, which opened on Sept. 14, is the third one I've reviewed in the last six months.

title: The Sins of the Seminaries
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind. - THIS week, teams of examiners, led by Edwin O'Brien, archbishop for the United States military, are beginning a visitation of all 229 Catholic seminaries in the United States. Judging by press accounts, the effort is all about uncovering and expelling homosexuals -- a purge, simply put.

title: Sarah Min and Matthew Pincus
description: Sarah Min, a magazine editor, and Matthew Storrs Pincus, a music publisher, were married yesterday in Southampton, N.Y. Judge Barbara Wilson of Southampton Town Court officiated at the weekend house of the bridegroom's family on Ram Island.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: CLEARED FOR TAKEOFF. FULL SPEED AHEAD. NOTHING BUT BLUE SKIES FROM NOW ON.

title: The King of Geek T.V. Gets a Big-Screen Comeback
description: WHEN Fox canceled "Firefly" after 11 episodes in 2002, the show's creator, Joss Whedon ("Buffy the Vampire Slayer," "Angel"), vowed he would not rest until he continued the story. On Friday, Universal Pictures will release "Serenity," the movie version of this science fiction/western hybrid, in which a group of space smugglers stumble upon a galaxy-wide coverup. The regular cast of the television series revive their roles, led by Nathan Fillion as Capt. Mal Reynolds. Mr. Whedon spoke with Kate Aurthur about sequels, about going from television to movies, and about finding closure.

title: Dogs Cough, and Owners Worry
description: AS leading veterinarian virologists announced that a new canine influenza virus was spreading across the country, Connecticut veterinarians, and kennel and dog owners, said last week that they have been worrying for a while about an unusually persistent and contagious cough in dogs this year, particularly in puppies. The illness, they said, mimics the symptoms of kennel cough, a common, highly contagious canine illness. But this year's cough spreads more rapidly and makes the dogs sicker.

title: (Wall) Street Art
description: BACK when people actually kept stock certificates, before assets were reduced to a collection of bits and bytes, those documents were adorned with intricate engravings that joined allegorical figures to symbols of industry and familiar landmarks. On its certificate even the workaday Alexander's store was accompanied by a classical-looking beauty. As much protection against counterfeiting as they were fine art, the images were applied to steel plates by engravers who worked in anonymity. To Mark D. Tomasko, they were artists who deserve recognition, and more than 70 engraved stock certificates, bonds and the like from his collection are on view in a show called "New York on Steel," through November at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street, at Nassau Street. The stock exchange repealed engraving requirements for certificates in 2001; paper money is now the last bastion of this vanishing art. NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK IN FOCUS

title: 'That 90's Band' Tries Again
description: Correction Appended

title: A Mixed Message for Ferrer in Primary Voting Patterns
description: Fernando Ferrer won the mayoral nomination by doing better among non-Hispanic whites and West Indian blacks than he did four years ago, but fewer voters from his Hispanic base turned out than in 2001, analyses of voting patterns from the Sept. 13 Democratic primary show.

title: Correction
description: The Dining Out review on July 31, about Jackson & Wheeler, in Pleasantville, referred incorrectly to the restaurant's entertainment schedule. It can be found on the Web at jacksonandwheeler.com; music is not typically presented on Wednesdays. A letter dated Sept. 6 from the restaurant's owner alerted The Times to the error.

title: Business Owners Set to Return
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 24 - Business owners can return to the dry neighborhood of Algiers and the central business district in New Orleans as soon as Monday, Mayor C. Ray Nagin said on Saturday, resuming his plan to repopulate the city even as strong winds from Hurricane Rita blew dust and debris down the streets. The mayor predicted that residents could return home to some areas as soon as the end of the week.

title: A SECOND ACT
description: In the eyes of federal prosecutors, Raymond J. Ruble is a leading promoter of abusive tax shelters. But this being America, that hasn't stopped him from continuing to work as a tax lawyer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 28 about cultural change in Moscow referred incorrectly to social conditions during the Soviet era. Beggars were rare on the Metro then, and the wide social gulf was between the powerful and ordinary citizens, not between the superrich and the rest of the population.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 28 with an article about the MTV executive Van Toffler, which mentioned criticism MTV received for its coverage of the Live 8 concerts on July 2, referred imprecisely to the event at which Bono was shown. It was the final Live 8 concert in Edinburgh on July 6, not one of the July 2 concerts.

title: Help Wanted: Lo Pay, Hi Expenses
description: WHEN John W. Caracciolo, president of the Morey Organization in Garden City, needed a new general manager two years ago for the three radio stations his company owns on Long Island, he asked the manager of his company's station in suburban Philadelphia to consider a transfer and promotion to the job.

title: Comfort to the Enemy
description: October 1944, Okmulgee, Okla. U.S. Marshal Carl Webster has returned to his hometown to check out a German P.O.W. camp named Deep Fork, where one prisoner, Willi Martz, has just hanged himself and another, Jurgen Schrenk, keeps escaping and then turning himself in.

title: Warsaw
description: WHY GO NOW -- As a tourist destination, Warsaw has been long overshadowed by other post-Soviet East European capitals like Prague and Budapest. But Poland, a new member of the European Union, has one of its fastest-growing economies, and the city bustles with energy of change: glass skyscrapers spring up next to dingy Communist-era apartment blocks; cafes overflowing with elegant crowds abut traditional pierogi bars and newly arrived Asian takeout places; bankers and stockbrokers flow out of the former Communist Party's headquarters for their lunch break.

title: BackTalk; What Would Red Have Thought, And Written?
description: Today is the 100th anniversary of the birth of my father, Red Smith, the former sports columnist for The New York Times.

title: U.S. Praises Vote To Report Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - The Bush administration praised the International Atomic Energy Agency's vote on Saturday to report Iran to the United Nations Security Council over its nuclear program but also acknowledged the uncertainty of the road ahead.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Premiere for a Score

title: On Gramercy Park, an Old-Fashioned Girl
description: THE Parkside Evangeline, a single-room-occupancy women's residence of the sort you might find in a Truman Capote story, opened in 1963 in a slender 17-story brick building opposite Gramercy Park. In a photograph taken not long after its opening, two uniformed workers from the Salvation Army, which runs the residence, stand surrounded by a group of women with shiny hair and prim dresses, some looking as if they just stepped off the bus from Duluth.

title: Imagine 20 Years of This
description: It is possible to build a hurricane-proof house. But perhaps the best of the lot -- a dome-shaped creation made with tons of poured concrete and anchored with steel pilings -- looks like something from a bad sci-fi movie.

title: After the Storm, Salvaging a Life
description: IN the days after Hurricane Katrina, Tory Johnson sat at home in Manhattan, watching the devastation on TV. Like the rest of us, she felt helpless and horrified. Like so many of us, she wrote a check to a charity. Like very few of us, she got on a plane, flew to Houston, and vowed to personally mend some tattered lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREYER, KENNETH
description: FREYER--Kenneth. 81 of Northampton, MA of lung cancer on September 19, 2005. Devoted husband of Joanne for 54 years. Loved by daughter, Alice Bonner, son, Glen, son-in-law Matt Bonner, grandsons Daniel and Ryan. During WW II, Ken served in the Merchant Marine from 1942 to 1946 and was a member of the library staff at Queens College, NYC from 1954 to 1986. Cremation will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIESENTHAL, SIMON
description: WIESENTHAL--Simon. The Conscience of the Holocaust. Because of your efforts, the world is a better place. The six million Jews who perished in the Holocaust were not forgotten, and all those who have suffered persecution since have had your voice as their champion. Your courage and dedication to the cause of justice will always be our inspiration. On behalf of our 450,000 member families, our most sincere condolences to your family. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, September 27 at 7PM at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue. Due to security considerations, you must call 212-370-0320 to attend. The Simon Wiesenthal Center Rabbi Marvin Hier, Dean and Founder Larry Mizel, Chairman Nelson Peltz, Co-Chairman Rhonda Barad, Eastern Director

title: 'Melville': The Novel as Big as a Whale
description: MELVILLE

title: Chainsaw Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Scores Remain High On State Math Tests
description: SCORES on standardized math tests by fourth graders across Long Island rose modestly this year, while eighth graders' scores declined slightly, according to data released on Thursday by the State Education Department.

title: Refineries Escape Major Damage, but Gas Prices May Still Rise
description: TEXAS CITY, Tex., Sept. 24 - Hurricane Rita caused some damage to oil refineries near the Texas-Louisiana border and raised the prospect of gasoline shortages and higher prices during the arduous process of restarting refineries all along the Gulf Coast. But it did not cause the widespread destruction of the energy infrastructure that some had feared.

title: The Ticket; 4 Ways To Infiltrate Mostly Male (And Female) Vacation Spots.
description: Male Operatives

title: Vice President Has Procedure for Aneurysms in His Knees
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - Vice President Dick Cheney successfully underwent medical procedures to repair aneurysms in arteries behind both knees on Saturday, his office said.

title: Letters
description: Taking Stock of the Forever War

title: Clubbing: Glasgow
description: The first thing you need to know about clubbing in Glasgow is that the city is tougher than you are. Forget the trappings of the clichd night out dancing in Manhattan, with its V.I.P. rooms and designer labels, women in $300 sandals, lines of limos in the Meatpacking District and "secret" Lower East Side nightspots. Glasgow laughs at all that.

title: 'The Conservative Mind'
description: To the Editor:

title: Michelle McNamara and Patton Oswalt
description: Michelle Eileen McNamara was married yesterday to Patton Oswalt at Cicada, a restaurant in Los Angeles. Maureen McNamara Stratton, a Universal Life minister and a sister of the bride, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, MARY ELIZABETH
description: LEWIS--Mary Elizabeth, 81, of NYC, died September 23, 2005 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Retired Director of Health at St. Bernard's School in Manhattan, where she devotedly nursed 30 years of boys. She leaves her children, Alfred B. Lewis III, Anne H. Lewis, and Katherine R. Lewis; her grandchildren, Paul, Elizabeth, Katie, Caroline, Olivia and Colin; her brother, Thomas Sullivan; and 11 nieces and nephews. Memorial service at St. Bernard's, 4 E. 98 St., on Friday, September 30, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Bernard's School in memory of Mary Lewis.

title: Merlot Makers Form Alliance
description: COMPLETING a process begun in the summer of 2004, five producers have formed an organization to promote Long Island merlot, the red that is considered the region's flagship wine.

title: Hanging On, and Saluting the Past
description: ASK bus or subway riders born after 1980 to explain the etymology of the word "straphangers" and they may respond with a mystified shrug. Leather or fabric loops, designed to be grasped by standing passengers, have largely disappeared from American public transportation systems; sweat and skin oils quickly deteriorated the straps, and their constant replacement became a budgetary drain. Today's straphangers must settle for wrapping their hands around cold metal versions -- or, in many cases, a stationary bar.

title: The Ticket; 894 Pages To Talk About With Your Seatmate.
description: "Me Talk Pretty One Day," by David Sedaris Nothing could communicate more clearly your taste for irono-snarky humor. Wear a Bright Eyes T-shirt, leave the "Harold and Maude" DVD poking out of your bag and prepare to be talked to by women who customize their own clothing. Further reading: anything by JT LeRoy.

title: White Sox Fans? Say It Ain't So
description: If George Steinbrenner can lord it over the Yankees from Florida, there's no reason why Eddie Einhorn, vice chairman and a co-owner of the Chicago White Sox, can't take care of business from New Jersey.

title: After Life
GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Still Outraged, And for Good Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rich Are Different. So Is a Certain Rock.
description: When the two neo-Classical-style residential towers of 15 Central Park West begin to rise next summer at the site of the old Mayflower Hotel, the complex will have something in common with the Empire State Building that goes beyond its commanding location and scale. It will be clad entirely with Indiana limestone, the material of choice for many of New York's greatest landmarks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Protecting the Innocent

title: Something Like Motherhood
description: I'M driving my niece and nephew to the Museum of Science. At the end of our outing, when I take them home, their father -- my brother John -- will tell them that their mother's latest cancer treatment has failed and that she will die. But for now my niece, who's 9, rifles through my glove compartment and discovers a tampon. She tears open the wrapper, ejects the tampon and begins swinging it by the string.

title: Walk This Way
description: After making New York neighborhoods approachable for more than 125,000 tourists, the audio-walking-tour company Soundwalk is tackling an even tougher city. With the CD guide "Varanasi: The City of Light," visitors will gain much-needed insight into this ancient Indian holy center (also known as Benares), which is visited each year by millions of Hindu pilgrims who come to be purified in the Ganges, or to die. "For foreigners, it's filthy, noisy, smelly, there are people dying everywhere -- it's a living paradox," says Eddie Stern, the director of the Ashtanga Yoga New York, and a co-producer of the project. "We want to help people penetrate such a confusing place."

title: A City of Many Pasts Embraces the Future
description: IN the recently published first volume of memoirs, "Istanbul: Memories and the City," Orhan Pamuk describes how a 1950's childhood among Europe-yearning cosmopolitans in the crumbling ruins of the Ottoman Empire helped to shape him as a writer. The key, he said, is to understand the concept of huzun.

title: TV Highlights
Paid Notice: Deaths   HAIGH, ANDREW D.
description: HAIGH--Andrew D., 74, of Bolton Landing, NY, died on September 17th surrounded by family and friends. An accomplished jazz musician; an educator and librarian. He worked at the libraries of Smith and Bard Colleges and at the University of Massachusetts. He was a loving husband, a devoted father and a great friend. He is survived by his children, Liz Haigh and her husband John Knoblock of Truckee, CA, William and his wife Jennifer of Potsdam, NY. He was predeceased by his wife, Stella E. Wheeler, on August 25th. Funeral services and burial will be private. Those wishing to send a remembrance in his name may do so to the Oncology Department, Glens Falls Hospital, Glens Falls, NY 12801 or to the Ida D. Haigh Scholarship Fund of Smith College in Northampton, MA 01063. He will be greatly missed.

title: China Plans Bigger Voice For Voters In Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 24 - In the summers of 2003 and 2004, hundreds of thousands of protesters filled the streets here to call for the direct election of Hong Kong's chief executive and the entire legislature. But the demand was quickly ruled out by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMGARTEN, JAMES
description: BLUMGARTEN--James. Of South Salem, NY, September 24, 2005. Writer by profession, he defined "gentleman," and was truly a man for all seasons. His family and friends will mourn his loss. We love you, Gumps. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service at a time and place during the month of November will be announced.

title: Embracing Traditions or Turning Them on Their Heads
description: Jenny Scheinman

title: Tiana Wimmer and Warren Leiden
description: Tiana Givens Wimmer and Warren Robert Leiden were married yesterday in Mount Tamalpais State Park in Mill Valley, Calif. Steven Ladik, a friend of theirs, who was named a deputy commissioner of civil marriage by Marin County, officiated.

title: Lots of Choices, Lots of Room on French Slopes
description: THERE was something missing.

title: Art In Action|Paris After Hours
description: Those arriving in Paris on Oct. 1 will find the perfect remedy for jet lag. Nuit Blanche, the fourth annual all-night free art party, transforms the city into a cross-cultural wonderland, as contemporary artists show work in venerable spaces. Last year, revelers happily queued in the dark for magical pairings like a Bill Viola video tableau screened in the Madeleine, a Maurizio Cattelan wax figure of John F. Kennedy in a casket placed in the cole des Beaux Arts and a dance party set to Buster Keaton montages in front of the stock exchange. As Parisians walk and ride free bicycles from venue to venue, the energy is so high that it's no wonder the idea has spread to Rome, Brussels and Montreal. This year's lineup will be announced shortly: go to www.parisinfo.com for details, or buy a copy of Zurban when you arrive. The only problem is finding a restaurant that's open after midnight. Try Au Pied de Cochon near les Halles, or Caf Charbon near the Bastille.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Consolation Prize Brings Larger Reward
description: BUD SELIG is not the type of person to say, "I told you so."

title: Ashley Chamberlain and David Myers
description: Ashley Mabry Chamberlain, a daughter of Gerry Chamberlain and James Chamberlain Jr. of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married yesterday evening to David Keith Myers, a son of Jacqueline Myers and Dr. Stanley J. Myers of River Vale, N.J. The Rev. Michael Lindon, a minister of the Full Gospel Baptist Church, officiated at the Island Cove Marina and Resort in Harrison, Tenn.

title: With Higher Prices, Many More People Are House Poor
description: BECAUSE of the nationwide surge in housing prices, many middle-income families just can't afford the average house price anymore. But they are buying anyway, and making due by cutting household budgets and tightening belts in myriad ways.

title: Letters
description: Chainsaw Outrage

title: To Reach Beyond Our Lonely Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: The March
The Education Gap
description: Especially in these days after Katrina, everybody laments poverty and inequality. But what are you doing about it? For example, let's say you work at a university or a college. You are a cog in the one of the great inequality producing machines this country has known. What are you doing to change that?

title: Yanks Go Marching Game by Excruciating Game
description: The final days of the regular season have become a delicate march for the Yankees because every pitch, every play and every misplay could spoil their day and maybe ruin a lot more. Every game is precious now, each one a miniature drama in a journey that seems destined to end in dramatic fashion.

title: Through the Blur: Photographs From Abu Ghraib
description: SELDOM has a news media image been so troubling and disturbing as that of an Iraqi prisoner standing on a rickety wooden box, his face hooded, with wires hooked to his hands. He was told he would be electrocuted if he fell down.

title: Penguins help lead way in documentaries' surge
Boutique Plus
description: Tokyo's Claska hotel is a vision of the future. In 2003, a collective of artists, designers and architects reimagined what a hotel could be, and the result is a mixed-use facility in the quiet neighborhood of Meguro. The nine guest rooms, ranging from minuscule to palatial with prices starting at less than $100, are located on the fourth and fifth floors. The rooms share a stripped-down aesthetic, with nods to Danish and industrial Modernism. The second and third floors are devoted to office and gallery space, used for art and fashion shows and D.J. events. The lobby houses a good Pan-Asian restaurant (complete with a hopping bar), as well as a bookstore and a pet-grooming boutique called DogMan. Only in Tokyo can you get plastered while you watch some dude with dreadlocks trimming a schnauzer. Go to www.claska.com.

title: Tonic Water
description: Borba The idea of a drink with astonishing, near-magical powers has been around for a long time: from the Fountain of Youth to 19th-century patent medicines to modern-day "energy" drinks. So a new line of "infused water beverages" that claims benefits like "firming," "skin calming" and even "age defying" might sound a little strange, but it shouldn't. What is most unusual about Borba -- the brand name of this drink line -- is that it is sold not through grocery or health-food stores (or medicine shows) but in the cosmetics department of Nordstrom and in the beauty-products chain Sephora and the like. And Borba's inventor did not come from the food-and-beverage world, but from a background in makeup and skin care.

title: Bring Back Warren Harding
description: THERE are no coincidences. On Monday, as L. Dennis Kozlowski was slapped with 8 to 25 years in jail for looting Tyco International of some $150 million, the feds were making their first arrest of a high-ranking member of the Bush administration. The official was David Safavian, the chief of White House federal procurement policy who once worked for Jack Abramoff, the sleazy Republican lobbyist whose disreputable client list, in another noncoincidence, included Tyco. While it's an accident of timing that Mr. Safavian was collared at his suburban Virginia home just as Mr. Kozlowski was sent to the slammer in New York, the two events could not better bracket a corrupt era worthy of the Gilded Age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, JACQUELINE
description: ROSENTHAL--Jacqueline. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Jacqueline Rosenthal, who together with her beloved late husband, John Rosenthal, set an example of philanthropic leadership imbued with compassionate generosity and the spirit of klal Yisrael. Their commitment enabled us to enrich Jewish life and learning in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to their children: John Paul Jr., Laura, Lisa, and Ronald; to their grandchildren; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: The City of Falling Angels

I had made plans, months before, to come to Venice for a few weeks in the off-season in order to enjoy the city without the crush of other tourists.

description: Q. Is there any way a homeowner can sell his home but retain the right to remain in it for as long as he lives? Is it possible for him to receive an income stream from the buyer even though he is still living in the house? Andrew Rotstein, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: The Surfacing column on Aug. 14, about Tirana, Albania, referred imprecisely to the country's history. While there were Greek colonies along its coast, Albania itself was never a Greek colony. The history was called to The Times's attention in mid-August by a reader, whose message was delayed when it reached a vacationing staff member. This correction was further delayed for discussions with the reader and the writer.

title: QUICK BITE: Fort Lee; A Chain Restaurant Unbound
description: Chain restaurants in northern New Jersey are a dime a couple of dozen and, more often than not, you can expect nothing short of absolute mediocrity in both the food and the service. Very rarely you may find individual establishments that do an exceptional job.

title: Storms Stretch Safety Net for Black Colleges
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 24 - After Hurricane Katrina hit, there was six feet of water in the library at Xavier University. There is a beached boat on a campus made that much soggier by the wind and rain from Hurricane Rita. There is a waterlogged chapel, floors as slimy and slippery as river moss, with chairs and Bibles and plants strewn willy-nilly and a statue of the Virgin Mary perched on a pedestal overlooking it all.

To critics who questioned the value of going where 12 men have gone before -- and of sending astronauts when machines might do -- the agency said that a return to the Moon was a crucial first step on the way to Mars and beyond.

But a new device called D-Scriptive makes it possible to enjoy the experience even if you can't see it, by delivering real-time narrations to sight-impaired theatergoers. In the past, that service was performed live by individual narrators, but the process was cumbersome and all but prohibitively expensive.

This man is the essence of evil, and the picture was almost Christ-like, suggesting that he is the victor. I shuddered to think that the wives and children of my friends who lost their lives that day will have to see that picture on their kitchen tables.

title: Naked Ambition
description: "Why be given a body," Katherine Mansfield asked, "if you have to keep it shut up in a case like a rare, rare fiddle?" My rare fiddle was first exhibited to a mixed audience in Marin County, Calif., circa 1991, on a nude beach north of the Golden Gate Bridge where leering men failed miserably to impersonate sunbathers. If you didn't mind being addressed while your breasts were scrutinized, it was a fantastic place to go. I also discovered, on the city side of the bridge, the Osento Bath House for Women, which, with its multiculti sister vibe, offered a serene, almost utilitarian clothing-optional experience. But I, the budding naturist, craved something in between the total pervfest and the total perv refuge, a place where a sensual yet risk-free frisson stirred the waters, as when naked men and women, strangers all, share a single, often slimy-bottomed wooden hot tub.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; ART
description: Musical instruments can offer art not only for the ear, but for the eye. The vivid shapes and forms of the string, wind and percussion instruments in "SOUNDS OF THE SILK ROAD: MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS IN ASIA" at the MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS, BOSTON come from a civilization that produced the earliest known musical instruments in the world. The more than 100 objects on view -- most from the museum's own awesome collection -- cover a geographical range from Japan in the East to Turkey in the West. They range from a small, ornately decorated dung-dkar, a Tibetan trumpet that started out as a seashell, to a full gamelan orchestra (an ensemble in which bronze gongs and other metallophones predominate) from Java.

title: Hong Kong democrats finally see mainland

title: Haight Crime
description: IT isn't easy, being the moral compass for your race and generation during the convulsive era of the Watts riots in Los Angeles, and CINNAMON KISS (Little, Brown, $24.95) finds Walter Mosley's conscientious private eye, Ezekiel (Easy) Rawlins, sorely tempted to stray from the path of virtue. Driven by the hokiest of plot contrivances -- the need to come up with $35,000 to send his adopted daughter to a Swiss clinic for the treatment of a rare blood disease -- Easy almost allows himself to be recruited for an armed robbery masterminded by his best friend, Raymond (Mouse) Alexander. But there's no real danger of that kind of backsliding from Easy, who has come a long way since 1948, when he returned from World War II (in "Devil in a Blue Dress") to find himself, along with the rest of his friends from the old neighborhood, at a moral crossroads. Unlike the entrepreneurial Mouse, who took up crime for the status, power and wealth denied him by a racist society, Easy plays mainly, if not exclusively, by the rules, a brave choice for "a black man in a country that seemed to be teetering on the edge of a race war." By 1966, when "Cinnamon Kiss" takes place, he has too much at stake -- an honest job, a loving woman and children, the respect of his community -- to blow it all on some risky criminal enterprise.

title: A Horse Farmer Takes Manhattan
description: AS the eldest of four children, Henry Decker was starting to worry he would inherit a horse farm.

title: Reading From Left to Right
description: AT the beginning of "Just Like Heaven," Elizabeth Masterson, a medical resident played by Reese Witherspoon, leaves work after more than 24 straight hours of emergency-room duty and drives out into darkness and pouring rain, then promptly smashes head-on into a truck. If you haven't already seen the movie, it will spoil nothing to tell you that the accident, discreetly shown as a "Six Feet Under"-style whiteout, is not fatal. After all, what romantic comedy in its right mind would kill off Reese Witherspoon in the first act? And "Just Like Heaven," which opened last weekend to a solid $16.5 million box-office take is, in more than one sense, a movie very much in its right mind. Elizabeth survives, but the film itself provides the latest evidence that the myth of a monolithically liberal Hollywood is dead.
