title: Keeping Watch on Pit Road
description: As the final 10 drivers continue their pursuit of the Nextel Cup championship today at Dover International Speedway in Delaware, a group of volunteer firefighters from Baldwin, N.Y., will have some of the best seats in the house. Twice a year, they are among the 75 or so firefighters who provide protection for the weekend of racing at Dover.

title: Freedom Center in Doubt
description: In fall 2001, not long after hundreds of makeshift hospital beds had been set up at Chelsea Piers to receive injured survivors from the World Trade Center -- beds that were never used -- Tom A. Bernstein, president of Chelsea Piers, envisioned reclaiming ground zero with the power of an idea.

title: The Pain in Spain
description: It took 31 years, but the Ashram -- which describes itself as the "smallest, roughest, toughest, leanest, meanest, sweetest health retreat on the planet!" -- has found a second home on the Spanish island of Majorca. Famed for its spartan weeklong boot camps in the Santa Monica, Calif., mountains, it attracts a power crowd that includes C.E.O.'s and Oprah Winfrey, and often boasts a one-year waiting list of hundreds. "We have had many opportunities to expand, which we have always resisted," says Catharina Hedberg, the upbeat Swedish co-owner. During a test run in Sller, Majorca, the first two months were booked in five days, she says, "so we decided to stay." The grueling Ashram formula (roughly 1,200-calorie vegetarian menus, rigorous uphill hikes and no more than 13 guests a week, who pay on average $550 a day to share rustic accommodations) hasn't changed, although, according to Hedberg, "we added some sea kayaking, and the last night's special meal is vegetarian paella." Majorca's fall season is already filled, with 200 hopefuls on the waiting list, but there are still a few spaces left for next spring. For information, go to www.theashram.com.

title: Shirting
description: As summer became fall, many women found the perfect transitional look, the white shirt. For day there are cotton variations with pleated and ruffled sleeves and for evening, silk taffeta, a standout at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera, above right. For a party, one wearer wrapped a $25 H&M design with a pink cummerbund. The many lantern sleeves recall Hubert de Givenchy's first collection in 1952. As a young designer with little money, he made a group of inexpensive cotton eyelet separates, at left with hats, that startled the rigid Paris couture. One woman, right with narrow skirt, re-created that look last week in New York. ON THE STREET

description: THEATER

title: View Point | From The Top Of The Rock
description: For more than 50 years, the observation deck on the 70th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza was a stellar New York City attraction. First opened to the public in 1933, it was designed to resemble the upper decks of an elegant ocean liner with a spectacular view. In the 1949 movie musical "On the Town," Gene Kelly, Frank Sinatra and Jules Munshin, sailors on leave, alight here on a joyous tour of the city. It was closed in 1986 for the expansion of the Rainbow Room. On Nov. 1, after a $75 million renovation by Tishman Speyer, the deck, now called the Top of the Rock, will reopen.

title: Housing From the Amen Corner Creates a Stir
description: Correction Appended

title: Ethnic Majority
description: O.K., Grant Avenue in San Francisco can be a lot of fun. The main drag of that city's Chinatown is noisy and jolly, with crowds of shoppers and fun-seekers. But it's tourist Chinatown. The Chinatown that people actually live in, with $5 haircuts and mom-and-pop stores selling exotic brands of toilet paper, is tucked away nearby, as close to the Middle Kingdom as you can get without a ticket to Shanghai.

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: The whole world empathized with the United States on Sept. 11, 2001; good will toward America was at its zenith in the weeks following the attacks. But U.S. credibility evaporated when we launched a war of choice against Iraq, diverting attention, resources and troops from Afghanistan and the hunt for bin Laden. Unlike bin Laden and his imitators, American recruitment officers are having trouble meeting their quotas of new recruits. American youths are not soft or unwilling to fight, but perhaps they are unwilling to die for nonexistent weapons of mass destruction, domino theory, war profiteers, a neoliberal free-market economy in Iraq, Israel, oil and empire.

title: 'A Woman in Berlin'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tree Stumped
description: California's Pygmy Forests

title: Art Born of Outrage in the Internet Age
description: IN the 18th century, songwriters responded to current events by writing new lyrics to existing melodies. "Benjamin Franklin used to write broadside ballads every time a disaster struck," said Elijah Wald, a music historian, and sell the printed lyrics in the street that afternoon.

title: Poland's Voters Are Likely to Shift to the Right in Sunday's Election
description: WARSAW, Sept. 23 - In Poland's first free parliamentary elections 14 years ago, dozens of political parties competed in the country's chaotic introduction to modern democracy. Only one received more than 12 percent of the vote.

title: Anne Pluta and Jeffrey Zeeman
description: Anne Marie Pluta, a daughter of Helen and Richard Pluta of West Brookfield, Mass., was married last evening to Jeffrey Howard Zeeman, the son of Rita and Roger Zeeman of Edgewater, N.J. Cantor Robert S. Scherr officiated at the Lord Thompson Manor, a country inn in Thompson, Conn.

title: Megaplex Plan In Putnam County
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Top: A Hip-Hop How-to
description: TEN days ago Kevin Liles, the executive vice president of the Warner Music Group and one of the most powerful African-Americans in the record business, dropped by a television studio in Midtown Manhattan to visit Lil' Kim, one of his company's artists. She was taping a show for Black Entertainment Television, and he needed to tie up some loose ends before she headed off to prison for a year and a day to fulfill her sentence for perjury.

title: Housing Plans Nudged For Chance at More Jobs
description: THE lot on the western end of downtown Stamford faces a parking lot, and the constant drone of traffic on I-95 is unavoidable. The site was going to be developed into housing for lower-and middle-income residents, units designed to meet the growing need for more affordable housing in a growing city.

title: On Baseball; Good Scheduling, Thanks to Good Pennant Races
description: THE last time the Yankees played the Red Sox in the last series of the regular season was in 1996. The last time the Chicago White Sox and the Cleveland Indians concluded a season against each other was in 1993. In neither case did the season-ending series have an impact on the outcome of the races for playoff spots.

title: It's All Tied Up Approaching the Wire
description: At the beginning of yesterday's game against the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium, Jaret Wright gave up a single to right field, a single to left field, a single to center field and a single in the infield to fall behind by a run.

title: On His Own, in Bellmore
description: HAL GOLDMAN has achieved the goal of most young chefs: he has opened his own place, where he is both chef and owner. The restaurant is Jackson Landing in Bellmore, named for its location on the Jackson Canal. This site was last home to Michael's on the Water, but it is probably best remembered as Villa Doria, a longtime Bellmore favorite.

title: So You Think You're Ready to Own a Home?
description: YOU don't want to be a real estate tycoon. You aren't interested in buying something and selling it four months later for a $15,000 profit.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; POP/JAZZ
description: Current country music, with its arena-pop trappings and happy-talk songs, revisits the music's old honky-tonk spirit like a suburbanite at a theme park. But there are still some diehards who savor the idea of a honky-tonk as a place for hell-raising, heartbreak and down-home hybrids.

title: Underestimating Fielding Is a Silly Mental Error
description: In left field for the Chicago White Sox, Scott Podsednik spent the first half of this season doing a fine imitation of a Frisbee-catching dog. When a flying object came his way, Podsednik usually snared it before it could touch the ground.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Most music is best heard standing alone, free from history and political context. But JEAN SIBELIUS's "KULLERVO" is inseparable from its circumstances. Sibelius's music has faded in and out of prominence since his death in 1957, but COLIN DAVIS is an active fan, and he will be doing us a favor next Friday night when he and the LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA bring "Kullervo" to LINCOLN CENTER.

title: Rock It to Me
description: The roadies are fussing with my mike. Is this the right height? Would I be more comfortable sitting? "O.K., rock star," they joke, making the most of my anxiety. How about the lights? Hmm? Are they in my eyes? It's bad enough that the audience is chuckling along with the gag: two well-known rock gods playing stagehands for me, a relative amateur. Next, I have to play for them.

title: Showdown for German chancellery
The Ticket; 37 Ways To Meet Your Lover
description: In the air, on the ground and sailing far, far away, including, but not limited to: clever cruises ... pickup props ...perfect nightcaps ... gay destinations ... CHRIS ISENBERG

title: Gaga for Dada
description: There are many reasons Zurich belongs on your to-do list. You can visit your money, and other people's too, since much of the world's gold reserves lies in vaults beneath Zurich's swank shopping street, the Bahnhofstrasse. You can check out the twin towers on the Grossmnster, founded by Charlemagne; set your watch to a clock with the largest face in Europe; buy dreary but ecologically smug Freitag bags; maybe run into Tina Turner rolling on the river. If not, there's sustenance in chocolate truffles, accompanied by the best hot chocolate in the civilized world, at Confiserie Sprngli -- which is as much fun to say as it is to visit (pronounced sch-PROON-gli).

title: 'Lovesick Blues': Long Gone Daddy
description: Lovesick Blues

title: TIRELESS, CURIOUS, EXUBERANT, IRREPRESSIBLE BUNCH
description: Jeff Probst | Television Host

title: Go Ahead and Drive Less, if You Can
description: DETROIT - FOR three straight weeks, Americans have been buying less gasoline than they did a year ago. Consumption is dropping at a rate not seen since drivers were waiting in gas lines back in the early 1980's. And people are turning to mass transit in record numbers in some cities.

title: 'A Woman in Berlin'
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: Mark Danner's article was brilliant, devastating (Sept. 11). It reminded me of several great articles in the 60's and 70's that had national implications. I hope this does also.

title: Takeout Takes Off
description: Add in-flight dining to the list of things you're better off doing yourself. Only seven hours separate J.F.K. and Charles de Gaulle airports, but they begin with dinner and end with breakfast. Here are some menu suggestions, culled from the neighborhood stores and gourmet counters of New York, that will have even Parisian passengers dropping their plastic knives in envy.

title: Bombings and Gun Battle Kill at Least 25 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 25 - A suicide bomber swerved his sedan across a highway median and detonated it alongside a police convoy in southeast Baghdad today, in the worst of several attacks and gun battles that left at least 25 people dead and dozens wounded, Iraqi officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An annotated film listing in the New Season issue on Sept. 11 for "Ballets Russes," opening on Oct. 26, omitted a credit. Dayna Goldfine was Daniel Geller's co-director.

title: The Real Estate 'Queen' in Her Hive
description: YOU can see the twin towers of the Eldorado, across Central Park from the west-facing windows in the dining room of Barbara Corcoran's three-bedroom Park Avenue apartment, lording it over the foamy tree line and the steely reservoir below. It's a view that's a gift -- this iconic piece of the Manhattan skyline -- and just the right accouterment for the self-styled queen of New York real estate.

title: The Band Just Wants to Have Fun
description: AS with most birthday parties for 1-year-olds, the guest of honor didn't really know what was going on. A Brooklyn band, Have Her Home by Ten, was celebrating its first anniversary last weekend with a prom-themed all-nighter at the Bitter End, the legendary Greenwich Village bar where Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen played as they were hitting the New York scene. Tough acts to follow.

title: To Reach Beyond Our Lonely Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: This Band Was Your Band, This Band Is My Band
description: MEMBERS of the British rock band Queen thought they'd never tour again after Freddie Mercury, their flamboyant lead singer, died of an AIDS-related illness in November 1991. Big hits like the camp opera "Bohemian Rhapsody" and the rock-swing "Crazy Little Thing Called Love" seemed uniquely suited to Mercury, who carried them with just the proper mix of kitsch and bluster.

title: Swiss vote to easestrictures on foreign workers
Mandelson extends olive branch on subsidies
Up for Grabs: The Shiite Keystone of Iraq
description: THE funnel-shaped southern region of Iraq contains energy, water and strategic wealth without parallel anywhere else in the country; in fact, some analysts think Iraq would not be a viable nation without it.

title: INSIDE
description: Speaking Up Against War Thousands of protesters gathered on the lawns south of the White House to demonstrate against the war in Iraq. The speakers included Ralph Nader, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Cindy Sheehan, who had held a protest near the president's home in Texas. PAGE 26

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSPAN, PHYLLIS
description: GREENSPAN--Phyllis. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Phyllis Greenspan, beloved wife of Murray H. Greenspan, lifelong leaders of the Jewish community whose boundless generosity and devotion profoundly impacted millions of lives. Phyllis' deep commitment to our Women's Campaign and Murray's service as chair of our Malverne Jewish Center Campaign strengthened our ability to care for those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Murray; to their daughters: Ellen Sklover; Marsha Kalson, and her husband, Michael; Barbara Harari, and her husband, Rob; to their grandchildren; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Austerity Budgets, So Called
description: To the Editor:

description: THE EMMYS: THREE GUESSES

title: 'Girl Sleuth': Whodunit?
description: GIRL SLEUTH

title: Where the Merry-Go-Round Never Stops
description: FROM Exit 53 of the Long Island Expressway, the carnival beckoned like an oasis, a magical paradise twinkling in the midafternoon sun. Colorful umbrella-shaded cars on a slowly revolving Ferris wheel peeked over the fairgrounds at the edge of the Suffolk Community College campus in Brentwood. Thrill rides rose and dropped, spun and twirled. An enormous gondola known as Pharaoh's Fury swayed to and fro, gathering momentum with each swing.

title: A New Condo for a Prolific Actor
description: THE actor Samuel L. Jackson and his wife, the actress LaTanya Richardson, paid $4.8 million in July for an apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that had been owned by the former N.B.A. basketball player Greg Anthony and his ex-wife, the novelist Crystal McCrary Anthony.

title: Fruit Cocktail Season
description: IT'S fall. And in addition to its being the season of fresh opportunities for your social life -- refreshed by the summer, being your personal best, aka serious dating -- fall is the season for prickly cactus pears. The pears, which are the fruit of the Opuntia cactus, are in the markets now (in Mexican groceries, they're called "tunas"), and they're showing up in New York as cocktails, including the Chilango at La Esquina in NoHo and a blood-red caipirinha at Barmarch in east SoHo.

title: Corrections
description: A table of primary election results last Sunday misstated preliminary figures in the three-way Republican contest for supervisor of Shelter Island. The leader, with 179 votes cast at the polls, was Arthur R. Williams, not Alfred J. Kilb; Henry Bowditch had 178 and Mr. Kilb 173. Final results, reflecting absentee ballots also, were not available when this section went to press.

title: S.U.V.'s, Cellphones And Selfishness
description: To the Editor:

title: Fern Schad and Alfred Moses
description: FERN MAGONET SCHAD was leading a very full life, divided between her homes in Manhattan and Southampton, N.Y. She went to the opera, ballet and the theater, and often visited galleries, sometimes with friends, at times by herself.

title: Five Quicker Picker-Uppers
description: Carry any one of these items, and conversation will start no matter what the language. THE TICKET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOULKS, EVELYN (LYN)
description: FOULKS--Evelyn (Lyn) September 19, 2005. 84. Beloved sister and aunt. Alfred University, Cleveland School of Art, Traphagen School of Fashion. Well known jewelry designer. Preceded in death by her husband Horace "Bud" Foulks. In addition to brothers Arthur and Donald Collins, Mrs. Foulks is survived by 12 nieces and nephews, numerous great nieces and nephews, many friends and her precious poodle BoBo. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC, Wednesday September 28 from 2:005:00 P.M. and 7:00-8:00 P.M. Service at Frank E. Campbell at 8:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the North Shore Animal League.

title: In the Wake of the Storm, Rage and Redemption
description: THE worst may not be over for most of the evacuees from New Orleans. And the best may lie ahead, too. Being uprooted suddenly and violently, and not knowing when you will be able to return -- or even if there will be anything left to reclaim -- is as awful a shock as life can dole out.

title: Clinton Says She Opposes Freedom Center
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has announced her opposition to the International Freedom Center, joining a growing list of critics who fear that the planned museum would distract from the solemnity of ground zero.

title: Shopgifting
description: Zo Sheehan Saldaa routinely returns merchandise to stores. But that doesn't mean she collects a refund.

title: Israel Strikes in Gaza After Hamas Rocket Fire
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, Sept. 25 - Israel carried out airstrikes in the Gaza Strip early Sunday and gathered ground forces just outside Gaza's borders, while the defense minister threatened a forceful response to an overnight rocket barrage by the Islamic faction Hamas.

title: There's 'Sis' and 'Bah,' but 'Boom' Is a Menace
description: YESTERDAY, as on other fall Saturdays, student musicians around the country performed in their school marching bands, revving up football fans with classics like "When the Saints Go Marching In" and the theme from "Hawaii Five-O."

title: An Uprooted Underclass, Under the Microscope
description: UNEXPECTEDLY, the country is embarking on a broad experiment: Will moving the poor out of New Orleans help them rise?

title: How to Sell a Mustang (or Anything Else)
description: IT is a basic truth that much of the world of business is the territory of selling. Selling touches almost every corner of the world of economics, but it is rarely discussed in business magazines and the business sections of newspapers. Still, every scrap of paper you hold in your hand was sold. So were your morning fruits and cereals and meats, and so were your bathrobe and your slippers, not to mention your home and your car.

title: Silver-Haired and Lionhearted, Bridgeport Crime Patrol Succeeds
description: CHARLES ROSS, 73, is determined to protect the residents in Bridgeport's Harborview Towers. So when he saw a young girl approach a white van that he said looked suspicious, he called the police, who discovered that the girl, 7, had been buying crack cocaine for her grandmother. The grandmother was arrested. When Mr. Ross recognized a man at Harborview from a wanted poster hanging in the local police precinct, he notified the police and the man was arrested.

title: TV Highlights
description: Sunday, September 25

title: As for the World of Heated Pools but No Playgrounds, Show Me to the Gate
description: "YOU have all hardwood floors in here," the saleswoman was saying, leading me through one of the condos at Horizons at Mount Arlington. "Upgraded cabinets. Granite countertops."

title: TANZANIAN PARADOX
description: To the Editor: As a Tanzanian I am always pleased to read positive coverage about my country. So I looked forward to reading "Tanzania at 15 M.P.H." (Sept. 4), about two journalists who cycled across the country. How strange that it should have appeared so soon after Hurricane Katrina struck the Gulf Coast.

title: Officer's Car Strikes Girl From Bronx, Killing Her
description: A 12-year-old Bronx girl was struck and killed Friday night by a car driven by an off-duty police officer, according to the police. The killing was accidental, the police said, adding that the girl, Virginia Verdree, darted into the street 30 feet from a crosswalk.

title: Kathleen Iger and Jarrod Cushing
description: Kathleen Pamela Iger, a daughter of Kathleen Susan Iger of New York and Robert A. Iger of Los Angeles, was married last evening to Jarrod Alan Cushing, a son of Mary-Anita Crean of Watertown, Conn., and Alan Clarke Cushing of Duluth, Ga. Frank R. Camera, a justice of the peace in Bristol, R.I., officiated at the Blithewold Mansion, Gardens & Arboretum there.

title: It's Foolish to Try the Offbeat Against a Far Stronger Player
description: In my Sept. 4 column, I reported that Joel Benjamin was given the trophy on tiebreak points after tying for first place in the 106th United States Open Championship in Phoenix. But I have since learned from Gerry Dullea, the acting director of publications for the United States Chess Federation, that there was some mix-up and that the trophy should have gone to Vadim Milov of Switzerland. Everything else remains unchanged; the title still belongs to both players.

title: A Light Load
description: As fall brings shorter days and longer nights, L.L. Bean has come up with an ingenious antidote to the dangers of walking home from school in descending darkness. The company's new nylon Illuminex book packs ($34) are trimmed with an electroluminescent wire (powered by a battery pack in the front pocket) that can be activated to emit either a bright steady light or a flash, ensuring students better visibility. The company has also designed a messenger bag ($59, both at www.llbean.com) for college students who want to see and be seen. PULSE

title: Tree Stumped
description: A hike through the pygmy forests of Northern California, where the century-old trees can be a foot and a half tall, is enough to argue the case for Lilliputian travel. Why suffer the pomp and bloat of resort culture when you can be a towering presence in the serene woodlands off the Mendocino coast? "It looks like a munchkin forest," says Renee Pasquinellian, an ecologist with the State Parks office, who compares the phenomenon, which occurs naturally, with bonsai trees, which are stunted by man. But there is mystery surrounding this anomaly. "No one has figured it out," says Teresa Sholars, a professor at the College of the Redwoods. It's believed that the very poor quality of the soil, due to extreme age and lack of nutrients, makes pygmies out of trees that would grow tall elsewhere. With its elevated boardwalk, Van Damme State Park offers the best vantage from which to puzzle over the pygmy canopy. The more remote, less trafficked pygmy forest at the Jug Handle State Reserve requires a several-mile hike up the Ecological Staircase Trail, which begins on a grassy coastal bluff with an ocean view and leads through a dramatic transition from redwoods to the little guys.

title: Budgets and Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining: San Sebastin
description: I thought about London, where the turnover in restaurants is faster than in other European cities, and the Fat Duck, the international gastronomic darling of the moment, is just a short drive or train ride away. But the pound is a punishing currency, and who really longs to taste the fruits of the English soil or talks of English wine?

title: The Reality of Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: You Can Wake Up, The Debate Is Over
description: TRENTON - If you left the state early this summer and happened to miss the first debate on Tuesday night between Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester, here is a recap of what you missed: not much.

title: Immigrant Entrepreneurs Are Saving Main Street
description: SOME immigrant laborers and the contractors who hire them still congregate in the Dunkin' Donuts parking lot near the Freeport railroad station, even though the village has had a special hiring site for day laborers -- a trailer set up by Catholic Charities in an industrial part of town -- for three years.

title: Where the Mild Things Are
description: EDISON - THE comic strip "Mutts" is a throwback. Its daily tales of Earl the dog and Mooch the cat ooze an archaic innocence (and sometimes an anarchic knowingness) that would not have been out of place in a Sunday comics supplement from the 1920's. It's easy to imagine Earl and Mooch rubbing panels with classic strips like George Herriman's "Krazy Kat" or E.C. Segar's "Popeye."

title: 'Codes, Precepts, Biases, and Taboos' and 'Into It': The Double
description: CODES, PRECEPTS,

title: Fly Girl
description: Tweed and waders have a certain lure. This fall, take the bait.

title: 'Vita': Exile on Prince Street
description: VITA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVITT, STACY
description: LEVITT--Stacy. 17 years ago we parted in the dentist's office. Miss you, Sweetie. Mommy and Michael

title: Love for Sale
description: THE Visa card functionary had called and I needed money badly. Three good jobs I'd been called in to interview for in the past three months had gone to other people, but not before my hopes (and my interest rate) had been raised. I looked around my apartment for the few valuable things I owned that would fetch a quick dollar in New York's bazaar.

title: Ouch! A Director's Parting Shot
description: IT is not every day that shareholders get a peek inside the corporate boardroom to see how effectively -- or not -- their representatives, the directors, are overseeing management. That's why the four-page resignation letter from Michael P. Berry, an independent director at Corinthian Colleges, is so riveting. It describes a compliant board that sits comfortably in the pocket of Corinthian's management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEISTER, JACK B.
description: MEISTER--Jack B. 78, Morristown, NJ. Adored by his wife, Lucille, and daughters, Andrea and Barbara. CCNY grad, WWII Navy vet, inventor, engineer, business owner. Respected for his integrity, ingenuity, talent and vision. Loved for his sense of humor and generous, sensitive spirit, his photography and poetry show-cased his soul. He loved travel, the arts, his home in Nantucket, crabcakes and, most of all, his family. Thank you, Jack, thank you, Daddy, for being the best, most loving husband and father in the world; for protecting, supporting, caring for and believing in us. Thank you for never letting us down, your strength and wisdom and the roses. We will always be proud of you and we love you with all our hearts.

title: FEWER A's AT PRINCETON
description: Princeton University significantly reduced the number of A's it gave out last year, according to a report released by the university, but it still wants to do more. Roughly 41 percent of the grades given in undergraduate courses last year were A-pluses, A's or A-minuses, down from 46 percent the previous year and 48 percent the year before that. In April 2004, the Princeton faculty set a goal of 35 percent. The school year that ended in May was the first year under the policy. "We are all very proud of our faculty for committing themselves to this very bold initiative," said T. Kyle Vanderlick, the chairwoman of the chemical engineering department and a member of the committee that reported on the changes in grading. "And we were delighted with the progress we have made."

title: The Un-Colas
description: Not everyone would like to buy the world a Coke. In the past few years, a rash of local colas has emerged in response to Coca-Cola's world dominance. So, the next time you're globe-trotting, try an indigenous cola, whether it's organic, pro-Muslim or honey-sweetened.

title: How to Pitch the Military When a War Drags On?
description: THE camera tracks a mother's field of vision as she hovers over a checkbook and a calculator lying on her kitchen table. She looks up as her daughter, a young African-American woman, sits down to speak with her.

title: Signposts for a Songwriter
description: Dennis Linde has been a remarkably successful songwriter for a remarkably long time, from Elvis Presley's "Burning Love" in 1972 to Alan Jackson's current witty hit, "The Talkin' Song Repair Blues." Between those two came "Goodbye Earl," an infamous success for the Dixie Chicks in 1999 that was a dark-humored masterpiece about spousal abuse.

title: Another Deal, Another Tax Break
description: WHAT'S a job worth these days? State officials looking to bring the Royal Bank of Scotland to Stamford said they thought jobs at the bank were worth about $87,000 each. That's how much the state offered in tax credits to lure the bank to Stamford. To some, that sounds like an expensive gamble. To others, it's a bargain.

title: Protecting Pets in a Disaster
description: AMONG the countless stories of personal tragedy produced by Hurricane Katrina, some of the most compelling were accounts of residents who refused to evacuate their homes because they would not leave their pets behind.

title: The Reawakening
description: When you're looking for the perfect city to visit for a week or so, Kabul is probably not the first place that comes to mind. Travel to Afghanistan is firmly discouraged by the State Department, which warns prospective tourists about kidnapping, assassination, land mines and what the government's official advisory rather swashbucklingly refers to as "banditry." Even getting there can be risky: a Kam Air flight crashed into a mountain just southeast of Kabul in February, killing all 104 passengers. But Kabul was where I wanted to go.

title: Forgiven, or Banished? A Rabbi Who Erred Awaits His Fate
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR - THE legal case of Rabbi Steven Kane was closed on Sept. 14. The misdemeanor charges against him for possession of marijuana were dropped. For driving with ability impaired by drugs, he received a citation and paid a $400 fine. The incident is a mark on his driving record -- nothing more than a traffic violation.

title: Mop Tops for Youths Keep Barbers at Bay
description: AFTER years, boys in Westchester seem finally to have had it with military-style buzz cuts. From elementary to high school, the hirsute look is, well, growing. And while many parents seem resigned, if not amused, by the return of styles from their own youth, area barbers are anything but pleased.

title: Tobias Schneebaum, Chronicler and Dining Partner of Cannibals, Dies
description: Tobias Schneebaum, a New York writer, artist and explorer who in the 1950's lived among cannibals in the remote Amazon jungle and, by his own account, sampled their traditional cuisine, died on Tuesday in Great Neck, N.Y. He was in his mid-80's and a longtime resident of Greenwich Village.

title: 'The March': Making War Hell
description: THE MARCH

title: The Testable Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: In Peekskill, It Takes a Community
description: PEEKSKILL - I give my parking tickets to the police and they cover them," Alison Levy said, pulling her car to a halt at the foot of a "No Standing" sign in Peekskill, close to a group of youths painting a psychedelic doodle on a concrete wall beneath the Route 9 overpass. "This project can only really happen because everyone in town is helping out."

title: The Walls Long Island Loves/Hates
description: TOM AND ALICE SHEEHAN have what you could call a love-hate relationship with the towering concrete wall meant to hold back the noise of Sunrise Highway from blasting through their yard in Bohemia. She likes it, but while he doesn't quite hate it, he's certainly not a fan.

title: 'My Detachment': Noncombat Fatigue
description: MY DETACHMENT

description: Correction Appended

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Editors' Choice
Davis Cup Tennis: Slovakia and Croatia, the unlikely finalists
THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; THEATER
description: Surely New York theater can beat the Lifetime Movie Network at its own game. That, anyway, would seem to be the implicit challenge behind the selection of plays opening this week devoted to what publicity copywriters love to describe as "women at the crossroads."

title: In Paris, a Bevy of Wine Bars Go au Naturel
description: OVER the last few years, a collection of new bars dedicated to wines made with minimal intervention has made an appearance in Paris. Run by wine enthusiasts who are nearly evangelical about the natural wine movement, the 20 or more bars  vins have personalities as distinctive as the products they showcase.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FEINMEL, SIDNEY
description: FEINMEL--Sidney. Brother, mentor, forever in my heart. Mychal

title: The Proof Is in the Spoofing
description: HERE'S a curious paradox for you: The most inviting introduction to the new season on Broadway may well be Gerard Alessandrini's merciless evisceration of the last one, in the re-tooled, consistently riotous latest edition of "Forbidden Broadway."

title: Small-Screen Sundance
description: Terence Gray was trying to come up with a clever way to pitch shows to television executives when he started an Off Off Broadway troupe called Brownstone Productions in 1994 to perform two unproduced sitcoms he had written with Jon Dell'Olio. It didn't work, but it did encourage Mr. Gray to create the New York Television Festival, which makes its debut on Wednesday and runs through Oct. 3 at several Manhattan locations.

title: 'Super Mario' Has a Super Headache
description: IN 1976, Mario J. Gabelli, then a red-headed 34-year-old research analyst, took one of his regular trips to Branford, Conn., to meet with Frederick J. Mancheski, then chairman and chief executive of Echlin Inc., an auto parts company he covered. But on that visit, Mr. Gabelli had something to sell: himself.

title: In Southern Louisiana, Storm Pushes Gulf Waters Into Communities
description: HOUMA, La., Sept. 24 - Five bayous in low-lying Terrebonne Parish fan out like fingers of a hand, one that squeezed thousands of people in a watery grip on Saturday in the wake of Hurricane Rita.

title: Swisstel Krasnye Holmy in Moscow
description: THE BASICS -- Moscow suffers from a dearth of modern hotels. In response, the city's autocratic mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov, has overseen a boom in hotel construction, involving himself in plans and designs with a sense of style not universally admired. The newest hotel, Swisstel Krasnye Holmy, opened in July and represents Mr. Luzhkov's new Moscow: brash and elitist, staggeringly expensive and, for now, still rough around the edges. A sleek glass and metal cylinder rising 34 stories above the city, it is also a conspicuous addition to a skyline dominated by Stalin's seven towers. A month after it accepted its first guests, much remained unfinished, including the fitness center, the pool, an Italian restaurant and what will be the hotel's greatest attraction: a bar inside an inverted glass bowl on the 34th floor.

title: Admirers of Fallen 9/11 Hero Disdain the Vatican's Likely Plan to Bar Gays as Priests
description: The Rev. Mychal F. Judge, the Fire Department chaplain who died in the rubble of 9/11, was, and still is, one of the most widely loved Roman Catholic priests in New York City's recent history.

title: None Of The Above
description: TRENTON - AND here most people assumed that the race for governor involved two self-sufficient oligarchs -- Senator Jon S. Corzine, the Democrat, and Douglas R. Forrester, his stern Republican rival. Yet like ghosts hovering on the fringes of this year's race, there are a handful of independent candidates clamoring to be heard, often with great persistence and ingenuity but little success.

title: A Community Worries About a Loss of Community
description: Richard C. Wade, 84, sat at a corner table at Trellis, the only full-service restaurant on Roosevelt Island, tarrying over a bottle of wine and a plate of fries. "You'll never see this again," he said with a sigh as he pointed a knobby, liver-spotted finger out the window at Main Street.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: Contributors
description: DOMENICO DOLCE AND STEFANO GABBANA For this issue, the Italian designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana (near right), who are celebrating the 20th anniversary of their company ("10 Years of Dolce & Gabbana," center right, marked the 10th anniversary), played tour guides for their favorite vacation spot, Sicily. The photographs (Page 106) reveal why they make sure to venture there at least twice a year. They find it magical, Gabbana says, because of the "patchwork of the culture: the Arabs, the Vikings, the Carthaginians, the Greeks -- you name it, they were there." They also cherish the atmosphere for its sharp contrasts: "the arid with the overvegetation, the colors with the darkness, the joy and the tragedies." Sicily's influence can work its way into their collections in numerous ways. Here, far right, it is the embroidery. Their home in Stromboli is not only on a volcano, it's an island on an island, which is, Gabbana says, "the maximum of freedom.

title: Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: Danner's article was thought-provoking. Pakistan's backing of Taliban and Qaeda remnants in Pakistan and Afghanistan has profound significance for the war on terror. Pakistan's implicit complicity in letting bin Laden operate from an unknown hideout and the 51 percent approval rating of bin Laden among Pakistan's masses have serious political and strategic ramifications for the broader Middle East. Qaeda-inspired Islamist groups are potential future claimants to power in Saudi Arabia, the land of the two holiest Muslim cities, Mecca and Medina. If these Qaeda-affiliated political groups come to power in Saudi Arabia, they will be beholden to Pakistan's energy-poor and nuclear-rich military. Imagine the reach of bin Ladenism in such a situation: it is probably the worst-case scenario for the free world.

title: Under The Hood
description: In the marriage of form and function, form generally rules the roost. Not so with the perpetually wait-listed climate control hoodie by DDC Lab, in which utility roundly eclipses and to a certain extent enhances the garment's style. The athletic hoodies for men and women are made of nylon and polyethylene. Imagine scuba suits fused with Tyvek Fed Ex envelope paper with a hint of Lycra thrown in. The result: a resilient bi-stretch fabric with admirable thermal and wicking qualities, fray-proof raw edges and the ability to keep body temperature at a constant state of comfort. In addition, the hoodie's waist pockets are made from antimicrobial material and the inner chest cellphone pocket is constructed of antiradiation fabric. Oh, and it looks nice, too. Available in gray, indigo, mauve and black heather; $320 for women's, $370 for men at DDC Lab in New York, (212)414-5801. PULSE

title: The Domestic Goddess at the Height of Her Power

Television has featured plenty of moms, but few true matriarchs, so when Roseanne signed on for this comedy and found out it was to be called "Life & Stuff," she blanched, then protested, then prevailed. "Roseanne," which had its premiere in 1988, was a hit almost immediately, most likely thanks to its star's primary innovation: making radical television by rendering the mundane with grace and uncommon insight.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Baltimore has joined Philadelphia as the second city in the United States served by the London-based Big Bus Company. The open-top, double-decker buses, which also operate in London and Dubai, will allow visitors to hop on and off at tourist attractions all over the city between 9:30 a.m. and 5 p.m. A 24-hour ticket costs $25. Donald C. Fry, president of the Greater Baltimore Committee, a regional business association, said that one of the biggest challenges to citywide tourism had been providing tourists with transportation to attractions away from the Inner Harbor -- like the Maryland Zoo, Edgar Allen Poe's grave and the Baltimore Museum of Art. Amtrak has indefinitely postponed a fare increase that was to begin Sept. 20 in response to rising fuel costs. It had announced earlier that it would raise fares by 5 to 7 percent on trains nationwide, including along the Northeast Corridor, where trains run on electricity. Discounts on monthly passes, currently 70 percent, were also to be whittled down to 50 percent. Tracy Connell, an Amtrak spokeswoman, said, "Amtrak will be conducting briefings with some public officials and other interested groups before they make a final decision on the fares." Hong Kong Disneyland opened this month, with thousands of early arrivals waiting outside the gates on opening day. The 310-acre property joins Tokyo Disney Resort as the company's second destination in Asia. AUSTIN CONSIDINE

"Our scientists and engineers will overcome obstacles to taking these cars from laboratory to showroom," he continued, "so that the first car driven by a child born today could be powered by hydrogen and pollution-free."

title: The Ticket; Twenty-Nine Pounds Is All It Takes For The Hottest Boys' Night Out In Eastern Europe.
Color My World
description: When I travel, I always take my Winsor & Newton watercolor kit, which is the size of a pack of cigarettes when folded up. I bought my first one in the 1980's. It was handy to bring on trips, and I packed it into a leather pouch along with a couple of brushes, a pencil, an eraser and paper. At the time, I was filling notebooks the size of credit cards with tiny pictures. The notebooks have become a little bigger, but the kit is still the same. Its plastic hinge is now cracked and held together with duct tape, and I have a backup set that stays open on my desk. Painting keeps me occupied in those moments when travel can be aimless and even disorienting. Mainly it is a way to register at least some of the new impressions of a foreign place, when its thrilling barrage can sometimes overwhelm you. Recording a scene with paint rather than film sinks you more deeply into your surroundings. You have to look a little harder and a little longer. And you end up with a memento. When I look through my sketchbooks, they bring back moments that I would otherwise have completely forgotten. Most of my watercolors are done quickly -- out the window of a train in the Tsavo desert; through the windshield of a car driving through a Wyoming blizzard; before the sunbathing subject gets up to take a swim. Sometimes I have longer to look and time to kill -- peering out an airplane window while trying to render the grid on the ground as we circle before landing; sleepless in a hotel room in Omaha; on the shore in Maine, where I know I've been a long time when I notice how far the shade under that granite rock has traveled. TIMELESS

Up Front
description: IN his review of Jonathan Kozol's latest book, "The Shame of the Nation," beginning on Page 12, Nathan Glazer indicates his sympathy for Kozol's idealism, his goals of integration and greater equality, but questions how we get from here to there, indeed whether it's even possible. It's a classic Glazer performance. For decades now, he has busied himself with removing the stars from the eyes of idealists, awakening well-intentioned dreamers to morning-after realities. An early editor of Commentary magazine; for 30 years the editor, with Irving Kristol, of The Public Interest; the author of such books as "Affirmative Discrimination" and "The Limits of Social Policy," Glazer has often been labeled a neoconservative. But he has always been a skeptic and pragmatist rather than an ideologue, and he is not afraid to change his mind. While he was an opponent of affirmative action in the 1970's and 80's, he later came to believe that some kind of policy was necessary to maintain minority representation in higher education, and in 2003 he joined in a friend-of-the-court brief defending the University of Michigan in a case that led to a Supreme Court endorsement of some affirmative action policies. As the documentary filmmaker Joseph Dorman has said of Glazer, "He is a happy party of one."

title: Boys' Night Out
description: Twenty-Nine Pounds is all it takes for the hottest boys' night out in eastern europe. One if by land, two if by EasyJet. Lured less by perfectly preserved medieval spires than by cut-rate flights, cheap booze and rumors of relaxed sexual mores, British bachelors are flocking to Tallinn, Estonia, which is rapidly becoming the hottest "stag night" destination in Europe. Early pub closings have long driven the British to go elsewhere for their prenuptial benders. But in recent years, most of the favorite destinations have grown tired of these vomiting visitors. Many of the bars and hostelries in Dublin, Amsterdam and Barcelona have adopted "no stag or hen night" policies, driving bachelors to the Baltics. Vilnius and Riga, the capitals of Lithuania and Latvia, are waiting in the wings whenever Tallinn's had enough. EasyJet began offering London-Tallinn returns from A40 ($72) last October, and tour operators like Tallinnpissup.com offer to organize a "medieval lesbian stripper show and meal" for as little as A29 ($52) a person.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 25 -- Oct. 1; DANCE
description: You have two chances to catch the ADITI MANGALDAS DANCE COMPANY, first at City Center's FALL FOR DANCE festival on Wednesday, when the Indian company will give a 20-minute preview of its Kathak-inspired work, and then the full United States debut at ASIA SOCIETY on Thursday and Friday, with the premiere of "Footprints on Water." Either way, expect explosive speed, virtuosic footwork and complicated, lively rhythms from the five dancers and three musicians, led by the choreographer and principal dancer, Ms. Mangaldas. 8 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Midtown, (212)581-1212, $10. 8 p.m., Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212)517-2742, asiasociety.org, $20.

Taking Stock of the Forever War
description: Like Mark Danner, I remember the feeling of "unimaginability" immediately after Sept. 11. After Katrina, however, the loss of the towers and 3,000 people that day is not the same tragedy it was. However uncomfortable it may make some feel, the hurricane connects us to the rest of the world (we have become the third world and refugees), whereas Sept. 11 isolated us.

title: The Twilight World of the Iraqi News Stringer
description: WE were investigating a terror cell responsible for beheadings and assassinations. Although it was my first job with this Iraqi stringer, he was proving quite efficient in his various roles as translator, reporter and "fixer," or facilitator: He had worked through a good friend, he said, to score us an interview with an Iraqi government intelligence source who would illuminate the workings of the cell from the inside.

title: Elizabeth Carloss and Sean Riley
description: Dr. Elizabeth Ann Carloss, a daughter of Barbara and Harry Worthington Carloss of Paducah, Ky., was married there last evening to Sean James Riley, the son of Joan and James Kevin Riley of Pearl River, N.Y. The Rev. David Riley, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Broadway United Methodist Church of Paducah, with the Rev. David Comperry, a Methodist minister, taking part.

title: Topics of The Times: Fountains of Garlic
description: Some front-page news was mislaid in Wednesday's paper. It ran on Page 3 of the food section. It was the discovery by Mark Bittman, who writes the Minimalist cooking column, of the Fountain of Garlic, an overlooked source of fistfuls of cloves ready to roast, stew, slather and serve -- with no peeling. He threw out the old garlic-preparing equation -- quantity plus ambition divided by time -- that limited the number of cloves I was willing to crush and peel for any meal to about six. Mr. Bittman suddenly raised it to 40, 50 or even more.

title: Hey Ho Let's Go (to Berlin)
description: In the East Village, the battle to keep CBGB from being bulldozed rages on, but in Berlin the cultural legacy of New York's punk scene has recently been enshrined for the ages. On Sept. 15, The Ramones Museum Berlin -- billed as the world's first Ramones museum -- opened to the public. A project of a die-hard German fan, Florian Hayler (above), it houses more than 300 photographs, records, news clippings and other memorabilia. That includes an unwashed pair of jeans owned by the guitarist Johnny Ramone, the drummer Marky Ramone's sneakers and an autographed black leather jacket.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROTH, IDA
description: ROTH--Ida. September 26, 2000. Our beloved "Granny". Five years in a world without you. Forever in our hearts. Diane and Larry

Inside is the gravesite of the Lubavitcher grand rebbe, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, who died in 1994, leaving no successor.

title: Better Safe Than Wet
description: SAN ANTONIO - WHEN my friend Amy asked her 9-year-old son, Eli, what lessons he had learned from Hurricane Katrina, she, being a rabbi, no doubt expected some noble reflection on self-sacrifice and good deeds. "Don't live on the Gulf Coast," is what Eli told her, and Amy did not have the heart to tell him the exact location of his hometown, Houston.

title: Knit to Fit
description: The latest quick-knit kit from the Swedish yarn entrepreneur Suss Cousins yields a colorful Peruvian-wool scarf nearly six feet long and as skinny as a necktie. With its three-inch width and chunky single stitch, the scarf offers instant gratification for novice knitters, said Ms. Cousins, who opened a store, Suss Design NYC, this month in NoLIta. Do-it-yourselfers like Julia Roberts frequent her store in Los Angeles, Ms. Suss said, because in Hollywood "people have to wait around a lot, and it's better than standing outside smoking." The kit ($29) comes in a choice of colors and has an instructional DVD; www.sussdesign.com. The store is at 281 Lafayette Street, at Prince Street, (212)226-1848. DEBORAH BALDWIN PULSE

title: Prominent National Democrats Rally Around Ferrer
description: As Fernando Ferrer met with voters in Brooklyn and the Bronx, his campaign prepared yesterday to announce the support of the former Democratic Senate leader Tom Daschle and Howard Dean, the Democratic Party chairman.

title: Corrections

title: On the Avenue, Fifth Avenue, the Architects Attract Us
description: STAND in an open area in Central Park and glance around. Just about everyone seems to be looking in one direction -- at the twin-towered panorama of Central Park West, certainly one of the grand attractions of New York City. Few people turn toward the corresponding vista along Fifth Avenue, even though the facades on the east side of the park present an equally interesting sweep of architecture, complete with spires, riddles and even a witty aside by one of the masters of the architectural riposte.

title: Last-Ditch Protests at a Cathedral Short on Cash
description: In the shadow of the country's largest cathedral, the Gothic hulk of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, is a strip of dry grass and weeds dotted with lonely granite slabs. On the other side of the cathedral's manicured campus, known as the Close, are a bare-bones playground and a few parking spaces sheltered by a thicket of trees. Though the lots don't look like much, for the past five years, they have stood at the center of a highly contentious debate.

title: A Pan-Asian Galaxy

So, when I heard about a restaurant named Wasabi, I wondered: Is it another sushi place? Is it best in small doses? Does the food there make you feel as if fire is coming out your nose?

title: Serge Lang, 78, a Gadfly and Mathematical Theorist, Dies
description: Serge Lang, a leading mathematical theorist who became better known for his academic jousts with nonmathematicians on social and political issues than for his work in geometry and the properties of numbers, died Sept. 12 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EGE, HANS A.
description: EGE--Hans A., The Board and staff of The Bay and Paul Foundations are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague Hans A. Ege and extend our sympathy and condolences to his wife, Else, and daughters, Elizabeth and Tina. Hans became a director of the foundation nearly twenty years ago and has honored us throughout this period with his wisdom, leadership, and patriotic devotion to both his adopted United States and native Norway. Synnova Bay Hayes, President Frederick Bay, Executive Director

title: China's Leader, Ex-Rival at Side, Solidifies Power
description: BEIJING, Sept. 24 - Three years after becoming China's top leader, Hu Jintao has solidified his grip on power and intimidated critics inside and outside the Communist Party with the help of the man once seen as his most potent rival.

title: Showering Together
description: Halfway through our move from Philadelphia to Austin, we stopped the van in Tennessee so Regina could have a baby shower. That's a somewhat coy and lame way of saying that she grew up in Nashville and that her mother and best friend still live there. So of course that's where she was showered, not that it made the experience any more fun for me. While I believe that dads should actively participate in every aspect of their children's lives and their partners' pregnancies, there's still something totally absurd about the idea of the "couple's shower." It was Regina who had the "Baby Bargains" book. She knew what she wanted and what we needed, and her judgment served as Talmud in our house. My only priority was hanging up a poster of Johnny Cash in the nursery.

Nuclear Agency Votes to Report Iran to U.N. Security Council for Treaty Violations
description: VIENNA, Sept. 24 - Iran's showdown with the West over its nuclear ambitions entered a new, more volatile phase on Saturday, as the board of the International Atomic Energy Agency voted to report the country to the United Nations Security Council for violating its obligations under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

title: Alonso drives into record book
Inside the List
description: RUSHDIE'S LIST: The winner of this year's Man Booker Prize will be announced on Oct. 10 in London, and among the novels no longer in contention, surprisingly to some, are Salman Rushdie's "Shalimar the Clown," Ian McEwan's "Saturday" and J. M. Coetzee's "Slow Man." The omission of Rushdie's novel from the contest's shortlist seems particularly startling -- if only because the Booker's chief judge this year, the critic John Sutherland, reviewed "Shalimar the Clown" in The Evening Standard not long ago and said that it displays Rushdie "writing at his best." There's not much consolation for Rushdie on this week's best-seller list, where "Shalimar the Clown" does not appear. (You can find it instead on the hardcover fiction extended list, available online, where it makes its debut at No. 18.) None of Rushdie's first three novels, "Grimus" (1975), "Midnight's Children" (1981) and "Shame" (1983), made the Times list. His commercial breakthrough was "The Satanic Verses," which spent nine weeks at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list in 1989, knocking off a Danielle Steel confection called "Star," after Ayatollah Khomeini of Iran declared that Rushdie had been "sentenced to death." Since that time, each of Rushdie's novels has made the list in hardcover -- "The Moor's Last Sigh" for four weeks in 1996, "The Ground Beneath Her Feet" for one week in 1999 and "Fury," also for one week, in 2001. Rushdie won't take home the Man Booker this year, but he's already got that competition more or less licked -- in 1993 "Midnight's Children" won what was called the "Booker of Bookers" for the best novel in the 25-year history of the award.

description: Five people were killed across the city yesterday in unrelated cases, three in Queens and one each in Brooklyn and the Bronx, according to the police.

title: DATEBOOK
description: SEYCHELLES This trilingual island nation in the Indian Ocean celebrates its creole culture with the Festival Kreol Oct. 22 to 30. Events are scattered across the country's three main islands: Mah, Praslin and La Digue. The docket includes live music, traditional cuisine, raft races, a fashion show, a forum on the Kreol language, Kreol disco, dominoes and even a coconut-tree climbing contest. There will also be several competitions for children, including an academic quiz, an art contest and a Kreol songwriting competition.

title: On Edge of Dusk, a Celebration Dawns on the U.S. Team
description: GAINESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 - They had squeezed the last light from the day and absorbed every counterpunch thrown before the two teams sat around the 18th green of Robert Trent Jones Golf Club and observed a private conversation between a golfer and his caddie.

title: 5 Die in Afghanistan as Copter Crashes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 25 - Five American soldiers were killed Sunday when their Chinook military helicopter crashed in the mountains of southern Afghanistan, the United States military said. The helicopter went down southwest of Dai Chopan, a mountainous district of Zabul Province and one of the most turbulent areas of the country, where groups of Taliban militants have continued their insurgency. The chief spokesman for the American-led forces in Afghanistan, Col. James Yonts, said there had been no reports of hostile fire, but in comments to news services, a Taliban spokesman, Abdul Latif Hakimi, said the Taliban had shot the helicopter down.

description: BEIJING, Sept. 25 - China on Sunday imposed more restrictions intended to limit the news and other information available to Internet users, and it sharply restricted the scope of content permitted on Web sites.

By disarming, the I.R.A. would remove what has been considered one of the largest and most stubborn obstacles to lasting peace in the British-controlled province of Northern Ireland.

title: Attacks in Iraq Kill 16, Including 5 Teachers
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 26 -A group of armed men burst into a primary school in a town south of Baghdad today, rounded up five teachers, marched them to an empty classroom and executed them, a police official said. All of those killed were Shiite.

title: A Legacy in Immigration
description: Early in his administration, President Bush promised to tackle America's unsafe and unfair immigration system. That was before Sept. 11, before Afghanistan, before Iraq, before Katrina and Rita, so most people figured there was no more room on the president's platter for 11 million illegal residents of this country. But in recent days, administration officials have resumed their scheduled briefings with business leaders and thinkers and members of Congress to remind them that the White House is serious about fixing America's broken immigration policy.

description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico - Vctor Javier Garca still has a dozen marks across his abdomen and genitals from the burning cigarettes the police used to torture him into falsely confessing to being a serial killer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 19 about refugees in a camp in Romania who fled Uzbekistan after it put down an uprising in the city of Andijon misstated a conclusion by Human Rights Watch. Its report quoted a former detainee who said police officials had told him that the government detained 4,200 people after the episode, and the report said it was reasonable to assume that the number of detainees may have reached into the thousands. The report did not conclude, however, that 4,500 survivors and their relatives had been arrested. (Go to Article)
