title: Grade Deflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Urges Action on Detainee Abuse
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, confirmed that an Army captain had recently reported new allegations of detainee abuse in Iraq to his Washington staff, and he said it was essential for the military and Congress to crack down on such misconduct.

title: Human Drama Unfolds the World Over
description: The 43rd New York Film Festival continues with Noah Baumbach's latest, "The Squid and the Whale," one of the highlights of this year's Sundance Film Festival, and selections from the Czech Republic ("Something Like Happiness") and from Poland ("I Am"). Also on tap is "Greeneland: Graham Greene and the Cinema," an illustrated lecture about the British novelist's long and fascinating affair with the seventh art. ("What I object to," wrote Greene, "is the idea that it is the critic's business to assist films to fulfill a social function. The critic's business should be confined to the art.") In addition, look for a reprise of Steven Soderbergh's latest, "Bubble," and two screenings of "Capote," Bennett Miller's already justly lauded film starring Philip Seymour Hoffman as Truman Capote. A full review of that film will appear in The Times tomorrow. Essential viewing can be found in the festival's sidebar program "The Beauty of the Everyday: Japan's Shochiku Company at 110," dedicated to the great Japanese film studio. Among the treasures on view are early films from the auteurs Heinosuke Gosho, Yasujiro Shimazu, Hiroshi Shimizu Yasujiro Ozu, Mikio Naruse and Kenji Mizoguchi. You can see more details about this valuable series online at www.filmlinc.com/wrt/showing/shochiku.htm. MANOHLA DARGIS

title: World Bank head urges trade pact for the poor
A Museum Sheds Light on a Hard-Driving Star
description: STEVE McQUEEN, the actor, racecar driver and discerning collector, is having what many of his peers would consider a career year, appearing on television; in books, theaters and music videos; and in several forms of advertising. Not bad for someone who has been dead for 25 years.

title: Polish center-right parties face coalition talks
Sharon Faces Leadership Vote Forced by Political Opponents
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 26 - Ariel Sharon narrowly won a crucial vote on today in his right-wing Likud party, fending off a challenge from his main rival, Benjamin Netanyahu, who is seeking to oust him as party leader and prime minister.

title: Rebuked, Even Sued, a Board Remains in Place
description: Hollinger International's prominent independent directors, including Richard N. Perle, Henry A. Kissinger and James R. Thompson, remain in their paid positions more than a year after several were censured for their conduct in an internal company report.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
On U.S. visit, Dalai Lama wins applause and laughs
Make opium legal, report tells Afghans
Grievance About a Policeman, Then a Deportation Hearing
description: Waheed Saleh says he was smoking a cigarette outside a doughnut shop at the rough edge of Riverdale in the Bronx when a police officer handed him a summons for disorderly conduct. He protested, he says, and the officer yelled at him to go back to his own country.

title: Oprah Winfrey to Back 'Purple'
description: Correction Appended

title: A Conflicted Mind Onstage: To Betray or Not to Betray?
description: For the first four scenes of "George Saunders's Pastoralia," two dirty, grunting prehistoric humans silently waste away the day inside a cave, biting their toenails, banging sticks on stones and wrestling with each other like animals. Then one of them -- a cave woman with a mess of tangled hair -- sees her food on a spit and says disgustedly, "I'm so tired of roast goat I could scream."

title: Leading Hartford's Force Like a New York Cop
description: HARTFORD - They sat stiffly on metal folding chairs in a scuffed church basement, listening to the man in the uniform trying to reassure them.

title: Broadcaster Wounded by Bomb in Lebanon
description: A prominent Lebanese broadcaster was critically wounded when a bomb exploded under her car seat.

title: Easing Foreign Workers' Way in Switzerland
description: Swiss voters supported a referendum in favor of easing restrictions on Eastern European workers, helping to temper the country's image as an alpine fortress at the center of Europe.

title: With Westbrook's Help, the Eagles Limp to a Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 - In a game featuring Terrell Owens and Randy Moss, the best receiver on the field was Brian Westbrook.

title: Violence threatens Mideast summit
Spend/Thrift: Lord, won't you buy me a Mercedes-Benz
J.C. Penney Decides T-Shirts With Beer Logos Are for Men
description: The back-to-school sales push did not turn out to be happy hour for J. C. Penney. In the company's Aug. 28 sale circular that was inserted in Sunday newspapers across the country, a "Back to School 2005" logo is superimposed on a T-shirt promoting Guinness beer. It's next to other T-shirts with the logos of Budweiser, Miller and Corona beers and Crown Royal whisky on them.

title: With Disarming Humor, the Dalai Lama Tackles Weapons and War
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 25 - The two bald monks, a combined 181 years in age, seemed oddly out of place as they sat in the bleachers of Rutgers Stadium awaiting the Dalai Lama on Sunday.

title: At Google, the Workers Are Placing Their Bets
description: Like all search engines, Google helps people sort through information from the past. But a new service, being used inside the company, tries to forecast the future.

title: Storms Cast Spotlight on Energy's New Reality
description: The vast energy complex spread along the hurricane-battered Gulf Coast apparently escaped serious damage in the latest storm. But for an industry still reeling from the impact of Hurricane Katrina, the recovery will be long and arduous, leaving global energy markets at the mercy of other natural disasters -- or unforeseen twists in unpredictable oil-producing countries like Nigeria and Iran.

title: A Quiet Departure for Eisner at Disney
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 - When Michael D. Eisner leaves the Walt Disney Company for good on Friday, there will be no grand send-off or congratulatory party. Mr. Eisner, who served as chief executive for more than two decades, has agreed only to a one-page retrospective in the company newsletter, according to Disney executives.

title: Hong Kong Delegation Visits Mainland
description: Hong Kong's chief executive, Donald Tsang, led all but one member of the legislature across the border to mainland China, starting a two-day trip that was the first time the authorities in Beijing had let in prominent Hong Kong advocates of democracy since the Tiananmen Square killings in 1989.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Monitor says IRA is disarmed
A Waking Nightmare
description: When I asked Gail Siles how the whole thing had affected her psychologically, she said, "Don't ask me now. It's too early." But in a later conversation, during which she seemed on the verge of tears, she said, "Listen, everybody's depressed and kind of still in shock. Everybody who's been through this thing. It's hard to believe it happened."

title: Paying Homage to the Era of Housewifely Slogan-Writing
description: A NEW film from DreamWorks seeks to return moviegoers to a time when milk was delivered to the doorstep, toys came inside cereal boxes and advertisers gave away cars, appliances, trips and cash to consumers who won contests writing jingles, slogans and advertisements.

title: He Said. She Said. And Then What Did the Therapist Say?
description: For years, George Gurley has chronicled his alcohol-fueled, socialite-offending nights on the town in The New York Observer. But starting in early August, he has been venturing into more perilous territory: couples therapy. In the process, he has made something of a minor celebrity of his therapist, Dr. Harold W. Selman, who practices on the Upper East Side.

title: Storm's impact on oil expected to be limited
To Stand Out, a British Daily Gets Just a Little Smaller
description: LONDON, Sept. 25 - It is still too early to predict how The Guardian's brash, expensive transformation into a midsize newspaper will play out in the long run. But asked to critique the new format the other day, Robert Thomson, editor of The Times of London, reached for an elegant put-down.

title: Paul T. Arlt, Artist and Cartoonist, 91, Dies
description: Paul T. Arlt, a cartoonist for The New York Herald Tribune who also spent decades in Washington creating paintings of the powerful, died on Tuesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 91.

title: Spain sentences alleged Qaeda chief for 9/11 role
CURRENCIES
Man Waiting at S.I. Bus Stop Is Killed in Hit-and-Run Crash
description: A van struck by a speeding car was propelled onto a sidewalk in Staten Island yesterday morning, killing a man waiting for a bus, the authorities said. The car's driver then left the scene on foot, they said.

title: At Least 25 Are Killed in Day of Violence Across Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 25 - A suicide bomber swerved his sedan across a highway median and detonated it into a police convoy in eastern Baghdad on Sunday. It was the worst of several attacks and gun battles that Iraqi officials said left at least 25 people dead and dozens wounded.

title: Confronting Racial Inequality, Here and Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Convicts Syrian of Conspiracy in 9/11
description: MADRID, Sept. 26 - A Spanish court today convicted a Syrian man of conspiring to commit the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks in the United States, and found 17 other men guilty of belonging to or aiding a Spanish cell of Al Qaeda under his command.

title: New Level of Competition: When a Supplier Gets Into Its Customers' Business
description: Business competition on the Web just got more interesting.

title: Waters Recede, Leaving a Trail of Frustration
description: HOUMA, La., Sept. 25 - When Michael and Haley Rich evacuated their mobile home along Bayou Grand Caillou ahead of Hurricane Rita, they left by car. On Sunday, they returned by boat.

title: Roberts Debate Opens as Bush Weighs Next Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - With speculation already focusing on President Bush's next Supreme Court choice, the full Senate began debate this afternoon on the confirmation of Judge John G. Roberts Jr. as chief justice of the United States.

title: A makeover for Indian city 'disjointed in time'
Israel Orders Army to Quell Rocket Fire; Hamas Ends It
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 25 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said Sunday that he had given the military free rein to act against Palestinian factions firing rockets at Israel. Hours later, the militant group Hamas announced that it was halting all attacks from the Gaza Strip.

title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Military jury convicts soldier in Iraq prison abuse case
'Falstaff' With All the Details in Place
description: Verdi's rich "Falstaff" pours out ideas in a fast-moving stream of glinting music. In James Levine's hands at the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening, the score emerged from the first notes as burnished, full-bodied and warm as the title character himself. Then Dr. Caius (Peter Bronder in his Met debut) took the stage and began singing in a strong, firm tenor.

title: Top Algerians Prefer Amnesia to Accountability on War
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 25 - Emerging from years of civil war that left more than 100,000 dead and thousands more unaccounted for, Algeria is not alone in the world as it tries to figure out how to get beyond a brutal past. History is filled with wrenching stories of neighbors killing neighbors in nations divided along ideological, ethic and religious lines.

title: Group of 7 urges China to free the yuan further
Re-emerging After a Strange Silence
description: Fiona Apple, the soul-baring singer who hasn't released an album since 1999, wishes she had a more compelling explanation for her absence. "The truth is that I haven't been doing anything that interesting," she said, shrugging one afternoon late last week. "I got off the road last time and I just felt like not writing and not doing anything for a long time."

title: Young Pro With the Marks of a Romantic Old Pro
description: Dario Vaccaro is an almost frighteningly proficient choreographer. He has been making dances for only a few years, but the three pieces the Dario Vaccaro Dance Project presented on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo could have been the work of an old pro. Each was well made and engaging, with cogent movement and dramatic themes. What was largely missing from the Joyce SoHo evening was a sense of the artist behind the dance.

title: I.R.A. Disarmament Is Complete, Commission Reports
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 26 - The Irish Republican Army has completely and permanently dismantled its weaponry, according to the agency that oversees paramilitary disarmament in Northern Ireland, finally ending the era in which one of Europe's oldest guerrilla organizations killed more than 1,700 people in waves of assassinations, bombings and guerrilla warfare.

title: Relieved Texans Returning Home as Storm Fades
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 - Tens of thousands of evacuees began returning to Houston on Sunday and workers repaired battered levees enough to keep water from flowing into twice-flooded New Orleans, as Hurricane Rita's sputtering remnants spread up the Mississippi Valley and into the Midwest.

title: In the Loop: Serenity, Freakouts and Craft
description: The White Stripes, in general, are proof that a craftsman's trust in his materials sets him into a greater loop of trust. When the system's really working, the craftsman trusts his craft; those who behold the craft trust the craft and the craftsman. It keeps going around and around, and even if the craft's unstated rules seem inexplicably to change, the beholders keep trusting.

title: Ex-Roslyn School Chief Admits Stealing $2 Million
description: The former Roslyn schools superintendent, a once-revered figure whose academic credentials and contacts with Ivy League admissions offices seemed to make him the ideal guardian of a wealthy district's aspirations for its children, pleaded guilty today to stealing $2 million from the school system over a period of six years, and agreed to pay it back.

title: Those Who Inspire Are Memorialized in Romance Tales
description: The "More Than Words" award, which the romance publisher Harlequin presents to five women annually, is in many ways typical corporate largess. The honorees, founders of inspiring community organizations, each receive a $10,000 check for their programs, and the publisher occasionally sponsors fund-raising and other events for the causes.

title: Delta's Woes Won't Stop a Party for Its Magazine
description: Why let a pesky thing like bankruptcy spoil a good party? That's the attitude Pace Communications is taking with the cocktail reception it will be the host of tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art to observe the redesign of Sky, the in-flight magazine of Delta Air Lines, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Sept. 14.

title: Justice Within Limits
description: CHICAGO - THE trial of Saddam Hussein will have the same structure as a certain type of detective novel: we know who did it, and we know how it will all end; the only mystery is how we will get there. The defendant will be found guilty of crimes against humanity -- but will he be able, in the process, to discredit the Iraqi government and strengthen the hand of the insurgency? Unless the Iraqis and their American advisers pay close attention to the politics of the trial, the answer may well be yes.

title: Johnson Puts 'I' in 'Team' to Win, and Take Points Lead
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 25 - Kyle Busch nuzzled next to Jimmie Johnson's rear bumper before the tense final restart late Sunday afternoon, determined to swerve around Johnson, his Hendrick Motorsports teammate, and steal a race that meant much more to Johnson.

title: New CD's
description: Gretchen Wilson"All Jacked Up"(Epic)

title: Editorial Observer: Justice Breyer Proposes a New Path for the Post-Rehnquist Court
description: In law school, I took a yearlong administrative law course from Stephen Breyer. Many people find "ad law," the law of agencies and government regulation, fairly dull. But Justice Breyer, who was not yet on the Supreme Court, could barely contain his enthusiasm. He talked animatedly, week after week, about subjects like Congress's decision to mandate air bags in new cars. At the end of every class, we made a point of checking how much chalk there was on his suit, since he tended to back into the blackboard in his excitement over topics like "agency nonacquiescence."

title: Dubai bourse starts a quest for global economic role
Patriots winin last second
Briefly: Cabinet endorses bills for postal privatization
Despite Flaws vs. Steelers, Patriots Can Rely on Vinatieri
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 - Tom Brady approached the locker room door and bellowed the obvious.

title: Going Deep for Digital
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 - Last March, executives from the Walt Disney Studios approached the visual-effects wizards at George Lucas's company, Industrial Light & Magic, with an audacious request. Could they convert the forthcoming Disney animated film "Chicken Little" into 3-D?

title: Golf: Lifelong wait ends in 4 seconds
Frustrated Americans in China
description: Two innocents abroad learn the limits of American idealism - or the limits of their own, at least - in "No Foreigners Beyond This Point," Warren Leight's wistfully funny new play about the difficulty of doing good in a society rigged to accommodate only more cynical transactions.

title: World Bank: Debt Relief Plan Approved
description: The World Bank's policy-making committee endorsed a sweeping plan to wipe out billions in debt owed by the world's poorest countries, most of them in Africa, clearing the way for debt relief to begin early next year.

title: Iran Threatens Ban on Nuclear Inspectors
description: Iranian leaders criticized the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency's resolution to report Iran to the Security Council for violations, and they threatened to ban inspectors from visiting Iranian nuclear sites in retaliation.

title: Memorabilia of Kennedy Are Headed to Auction
description: A lot of Camelot - the Camelot of John F. Kennedy, not of Arthurian legend - has been squeezed into a warehouse in East Harlem. There, in a bright, white room in the basement, a crew of auction house employees born after Kennedy was assassinated is scrambling to prepare for an auction in December.

title: If Yanks Have a Shot, Rivera Is the Reason
description: Correction Appended

title: Center-Right Parties Leading in Polish Parliamentary Election
description: International Herald Tribune

title: Slowly Starting to Return, Evacuees Find a Road Less Traveled
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 25 - As they pulled into the Shell station just off Interstate 45 on Sunday, Ta and Rachel Samuel were feeling hugely relieved.

title: On the Mall, 2 Events Speak Volumes
description: WASHINGTON

title: As Population of Yellowstone Grizzlies Grows, Further Protection Is Up for Debate
description: BOZEMAN, Mont. - By all accounts the turnaround of the Yellowstone grizzly is an all-too-rare success story of the Endangered Species Act.

title: Mantra for New Orleans: 'We Will Swing Again'
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 - In many American cities, indigenous culture is a bonus amenity, an add-on to the business and civic functions of the metropolis. Here, though, the first and last conversation you have will be about where you went, what you ate, who you heard play. The people who make music, who perform cabaret - and those who pour the whiskey that accompany the shows - are precisely the point here, and they play big for their size. If there is no show, there is no New Orleans.

title: Faking the Katrina Inquiry
description: As the nation reels from Rita's devastation along the Gulf Coast, any hope for a thorough investigation of government's gross mismanagement of Katrina is quietly ebbing away behind the political levees of Washington. The White House and Republican-controlled Congress, resisting popular support for an independent, nonpartisan commission, remain determined to run self-serving, bogus investigations.

title: Find the Brownie
description: For the politically curious seeking entertainment, I'd like to propose two new trivia games: "Find the Brownie" and "Two Degrees of Jack Abramoff."

title: Mayor Accuses His Opponent of Wavering on Education Policy Over the Years
description: Beginning an aggressive new phase in his re-election campaign, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came out swinging yesterday at his Democratic rival, Fernando Ferrer, accusing him of wavering on education reform and missing opportunities to fix the system.

title: Hong Kong activists praise dialogue
Poles shift to right invoting for Parliament
Phantom Constituents in the Census
description: A longstanding quirk in census rules counts incarcerated people as "residents" of the prisons where most are held for only a short time, instead of counting them in the towns and cities where they actually live. This practice was scarcely noticeable 30 years ago, when the prison population was insignificant. But with 1.4 million people in prison today, this padding of electoral districts' population figures shifts political power from the densely populated urban areas where most inmates live to the less populated rural districts where prisons are often built.

title: Vice President Goes Home After Knee Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 - Vice President Dick Cheney went home from a hospital here on Sunday morning, a day after doctors performed procedures to repair aneurysms in arteries behind both his knees.

title: A Story Better Told in Print
description: NEW ORLEANS - LAST week at the Sheraton Hotel in downtown New Orleans, a mix of contractors, journalists and security people sat in the bar, reminiscing about Katrina and speculating about Rita, the storm of the moment.

title: After the Deluge, a City Begins to Stir
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 - Through the nights the pretty lights squint and the leftover winds cuss the city of the gone. The hotel marquees cast brand names to no audience. Comes the stillness.

title: Iraqi Police Academy Attacked by Bombers
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 26 - A suicide bomber detonated his car at the gates of the police academy today, killing at least seven people and wounding 30 in the second attack in as many days on the Iraqi police. On Sunday, a suicide bomber swerved his sedan across a highway median and detonated it into a police convoy in eastern Baghdad.

title: Bush Mulls Recovery Plan as Evacuees Begin Long Journey Home
description: President Bush said today that he was considering naming a federal "czar" to oversee the reconstruction of the Gulf Coast after the one-two punch of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, but only after he heard more from state and local officials about how they would like to see their communities rebuilt.

title: Lost Somewhere Between the Kennedys and the Rat Pack
description: Correction Appended

title: Jets Jarred by Injuries to Pennington and Fiedler
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 25 - If a single image can sum up a game or, for that matter, September - it was that of the Jets backup quarterback Jay Fiedler being brought to his knees from the pain searing his right shoulder after throwing a 16-yard pass to Justin McCareins in the fourth quarter on Sunday.

title: VW's unlikely white knight: Porsche
Hamas calls cease-fire after 3 days of attacks
2 killed as typhoonpounds Hainan Island
Try and Try Again
description: PRINCETON, N.J. - FOR these crimes," wrote Hannah Arendt during the Nuremberg trials, "no punishment is severe enough. It may well be essential to hang Gring, but it is totally inadequate."

title: Historical Perspective
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Works from 'Slavery'
description: A forthcoming exhibition on slavery at the New-York Historical Society may draw crowds or controversy.

title: Homes of Hurricane Victims
description: Mississippi has confirmed 220 deaths and publicly identified about 95 victims, allowing the first detailed glimpse into the lives that were lost in Hurricane Katrina.

title: Readers Respond to The Big Uneasy
description: Maureen Scott, Kansas City, Mo., writes: There are some of us that believe that government is a social contract between the people and their representatives to do what is best for the welfare of the nation. The people trust that competent leadership is one of the values that government embraces when appointing those leaders. Having said that, I would say that our government at all levels has failed the people in providing the most basic of human needs: safety and security. The question remains: What will they do to remedy it, and how soon will it take? I will be watching the calendar to see how this administration responds, and measure their steps to correct this problem. Incompetency, in the Katrina episode, was a cold-blooded killer.

title: What Are You Up to Now, Desperate 20-Somethings?
description: In the season premiere of "Desperate Housewives," a neighbor with a drinking problem asks God for a sign. The bottle of liquor in her hand is promptly shattered by a bullet. The show's narrator (Brenda Strong as the deceased Mary Alice Young) says, "God may work in mysterious ways, but he isn't particularly subtle."

title: Accidental President With a Feminist Twist
description: This is a fall season that asks viewers to swallow the implausible, from alien invaders on the CBS science fiction series "Threshold," to sea monsters on NBC's "Surface."

title: A Consolidation at Cond Nast Gives Magazines One Overseer
description: Cond Nast announced yesterday that it would consolidate its magazine units, bringing its Advance Publications magazines under the umbrella of Cond Nast Publications.

title: Corrections
description: Part of a byline was misspelled on Sunday on an article in some copies about the death of two people in the crash of an ultralight airplane in New Jersey. The reporters were Jennifer 8. Lee and Nate Schweber.

title: WellPoint Near Deal to Acquire Big Rival
description: WellPoint, the giant health insurer, is near a deal to acquire WellChoice, the largest health insurer in New York State and the parent of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, for about $6.5 billion in cash and stock, according to executives close to the negotiations.

title: A Devil's Garden, Tended by Ants
description: Detox for Killer Lakes

title: Using History as a Guide, but Skipping the Details
description: One of the most poignant passages in E.L. Doctorow's new novel "The March" quotes a letter of condolence from Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman to Gen. William J. Hardee after Hardee, like Sherman, lost a son named Willie. "How unnatural is this age when, in violation of God's grand stratagem, the young are unbodied of their souls before the old," Sherman writes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Hutchison Telecommunications Expands
description: Hutchison Telecommunications International of Hong Kong, which offers mobile phone services from India to Israel, said that its Indian venture had agreed to buy two units of BPL Communications for $1.15 billion. Hutchison Essar, a venture with Essar Teleholdings of India, agreed to buy BPL Mobile Communications in Mumbai and BPL Mobile Cellular, which serves three western and southern states. The purchase will add 2.8 million clients to the more than 12 million the venture has now.

title: Arts, Briefly; Tiger Woods Brings Golf to Central Park
description: It is the fantasy of perhaps every New York City golfer who has lugged clubs onto a commuter train or sat in traffic on the way to a course in the suburbs: wouldn't it be great to just tee it up in Central Park? Tiger Woods was in Manhattan yesterday to spread the message that the dream has become (virtual) reality in his new video game, "Tiger Woods PGA Tour 06." The game, published by Electronic Arts, hit stores last week. In addition to a dozen real layouts, including St. Andrews in Scotland, it includes an 18-hole course set all around Central Park. For instance, the spot in the Sheep Meadow where Mr. Woods posed for photographers yesterday (above right; at left, an image from the game) is on the eighth hole, a dogleg-left par 4. "I think a course in the park is a great idea," said Connie D. Long, 40, a television director and avid golfer who passed the media scrum on a break from work. "I would like to hit across the big pond and land the ball in a martini glass at the cafe over there." D.J. Powers, an associate producer of the game, said he would take the idea under advisement.

title: Rice Visits Haiti Ahead of Elections
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 27 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice visited the poorest nation in the Americas today to urge Haitians to vote in the first elections since Jean-Bertrand Aristide was ousted last year and spirited into exile on an American military jet.

title: Houston Bids Hurricane Goodbye
description: HOUSTON BIDS HURRICANE GOODBYE -- Flights at Houston's two major airports, disrupted Friday and into the weekend by the threat of Hurricane Rita, were back to normal yesterday. Continental Airlines, which has its largest hub at George Bush Intercontinental, said it was operating a full schedule yesterday with the resumption of Continental Express and Continental Connection flights. Houston Hobby was also back on track. Most airlines eased penalties for ticket cancellations and rebookings.

title: Gunmen in Iraq add teachers to target list
Asia oil subsidies bring windfall to smugglers
Gas Stations Violated Pricing Law, New Jersey Says
description: Correction Appended

title: Cronies at the Till
description: The first results are in on who is set to profit from the Katrina cleanup, and -- surprise -- many of the firms winning major contracts have big political connections. Congressional investigators are already looking into AshBritt, a Pompano Beach, Fla., company with ties to Mississippi's governor, Haley Barbour -- the former chairman of the Republican National Committee. AshBritt has nabbed $568 million in contracts for trash removal. Questions have also been raised about the political connections of two other major contractors: the Shaw Group, and Kellogg, Brown & Root, a subsidiary of Halliburton. Both companies have been represented by Joe Allbaugh, President Bush's former campaign manager and the former head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency -- although Mr. Allbaugh says he does not help any of his clients obtain federal contracts.

title: Ugly Princess, Beautiful Soul and Air Guitars
description: Love at first sight is fine, but how about love at first "schmutzer"? That's what a diffident, bespectacled inventor, Clyde (Jamie McGonnigal), calls the lint-roller he presents triumphantly to a princess (Meredith McCasland) near the climax of "Isabelle and the Pretty-Ugly Spell."

title: U.S. Says It Has Killed No. 2 Qaeda Operative in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 27 - A man wearing a belt of explosives under his clothing walked into a crowd of recruits gathered outside a police compound northeast of Baghdad today and detonated his payload, killing seven and injuring 23 in a spray of burning metal, police officials said.

title: Istanbul's crosscurrents of past and future
Present at the Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Retrial Begins for Officer in Killing
description: Six months after a jury failed to agree on his innocence or guilt, Police Officer Bryan A. Conroy went on trial again yesterday, accused in the fatal shooting of a West African immigrant during a raid at a Chelsea warehouse in May 2003.

title: It's a Deal. Take It and Be Happy.
description: FEW people in New York work a tougher room than William Beaman. As a settlement officer in the parking ticket adjudication unit in Jamaica, Queens, Mr. Beaman faces a steady stream of drivers clutching parking summonses that they hope to convince a judge were wrongly issued.

title: Evolution Lawsuit Opens in Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 26 - Intelligent design is not science, has no support from any major American scientific organization and does not belong in a public school science classroom, a prominent biologist testified on the opening day of the nation's first legal battle over whether it is permissible to teach the fledgling "design" theory as an alternative to evolution.

title: The Gulf will survive
Union deal sends shares of Boeing up sharply
Plenty of Fan Support, Just Not for the Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 - In a city where Cal Ripken Jr. took a victory lap, where Eddie Murray's number is on a plaque and where Earl Weaver used to kick dirt on home plate, a chant rose from the mezzanine, loge and box seats on a drizzly Monday night at Camden Yards.

title: Brazil Land Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside Google, employees try 'betting' on the future
German confidence up - before vote
Cycling: Young American leaps the pond
Paid Notice: Memorials   FERBER, STEVEN
description: FERBER--Steven. 2/17/61-9/27/97. We miss you and love you. Love, Mom, Family and Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTER, VICTOR
description: FUTTER--Victor. Columbia College and the Office of Alumni Affairs and Development mourn the passing of Victor Futter, College Class of 1939. Mr. Futter served as President of the College Alumni Association from 1972-74. He was a dedicated supporter of the College and received the President's Cup in 1999. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Joan; children, Jeffrey, Deborah and Ellen, former president of Barnard College, and his seven grandchildren. Derek A. Wittner, Dean, Collumbia College, Office of Alumni Affairs and Development

title: Stroller Moms Retort, We're Not Bulldozers
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (7) COMMANDER IN CHIEF -- Series premiere. Geena Davis (below) plays the first woman to become president of the

title: Grading the C.E.O. Speech
description: Correction Appended

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Church Acts Against 11 Priests
description: Cardinal Francis George, the archbishop of Chicago, announced that he had prohibited 11 priests accused of sexual misconduct with minors from engaging in public ministry, presenting themselves as priests or acting as agents of the archdiocese. The announcement came two years after 14 priests in the archdiocese were accused of misconduct and removed from ministry while the Vatican reviewed their cases. Cardinal George determined that 11 of the priests had committed sexual misconduct. Two accused priests are facing canonical trials over the accusations, and one accused priest has died. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Q & A
description: Helpful Slime

title: When Loss Is Compounded
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Conducts 4th Day of Airstrikes in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 - Israeli aircraft carried out missile strikes in the Gaza Strip for a fourth straight day today, and Israel's defense minister said he was skeptical of a pledge by Palestinian factions to stop attacking Israel from Gaza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINK, JUDITH
description: FINK--Judith. Beloved mother of Jennifer (Avi) Gelboim, devoted friend to all. She lived her too short life to the fullest and will be sorely missed. Graveside services Tuesday. Contributions to St. Barnabas Hospice, Livingston, NJ.

title: Congress Can Smell Drugs in Baseball, and Fear in Selig
description: COMMISSIONER Bud Selig wants to make sure that Congress won't have him to kick around anymore. He's so intent on avoiding a repeat of his March 17 drubbing by grandstanding members of Congress that he won't accept the heck of a good compromise the baseball players union has proposed for stiffening steroids suspensions.

title: Check Those Subtitles
description: To the Editor:

title: Haves, Have-Nots and College
description: To the Editor:

title: West, Southwest, Midwest and Washington
description: NORTHWEST

title: Spain Issues First Prison Sentence for 9/11
description: MADRID, Sept. 26 - A Spanish court on Monday sentenced a Syrian man to 27 years in prison for conspiring to commit the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and leading a cell of the terrorist network Al Qaeda in Madrid. The sentence is the only one to date in connection with the attacks.

title: Fehr Offers to Toughen Penalties for Steroids
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 - For the second time in less than a year, the players union has agreed to reopen baseball's collective bargaining agreement with the owners and strengthen the testing, and penalties, for steroid use.

title: A Fresh Reminder of Sept. 11
description: Not down near bedrock in the depths of ground zero. Not across the waters of Upper New York Bay at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. But 536 feet in the sky over Lower Manhattan -- that is where construction workers have found what may be the newest evidence of 9/11's appalling human toll, four years after the fact.

title: Human Beings 2.0
description: A newspaper's most important function is to comfort troubled readers with horror stories from far away. Every day we strive to remind you: Hey, things could always be worse.

title: Vegans, Keep Out: It's Hunting Season
description: CONCORD, Mich. - Ted Nugent is not an evolution guy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about President Bush's call for greater energy conservation referred incorrectly to the administration's efforts regarding higher fuel economy standards for automakers. While the standards for cars have stayed the same, the administration has indeed raised one standard - the one for light trucks, which covers sport utility vehicles, vans and pickups - to 22.2 miles a gallon in 2007 models from 20.7 in 2004 models. It has also proposed increases that the White House expects to raise the standard to 24 miles a gallon for 2011 models of light trucks. (Go to Article)

title: Letters
description: Aural, and Actual, Pollution

title: Consumer Confidence and New Home Sales Decline
description: Hurricane Katrina's devastating toll and high energy prices sent consumer confidence to its lowest level in more than two years this month, while new home sales fell sharply in August, according to two reports released today, raising some concerns about the economy's health or at least consumers' perceptions of it.

title: Ferrer's Case for a 'Greater' City
description: This 30-second spot is the second English-language ad in the general election for Fernando Ferrer, the Democratic nominee for mayor. It began running yesterday on broadcast and cable channels and is part of a modest, roughly $130,000 ad campaign for the week.

title: Thinking hybrids
Linking of Languages May Speak Volumes
description: Linguists have devised a new way of linking languages, which they say has allowed them to reconstruct a network of the languages spoken in islands near New Guinea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIDGWAY, THOMAS JR.
description: RIDGWAY--Thomas Jr. 91, beloved husband of Jane Pope (Akers) Ridgway, who died in his summer home in Newport, Rhode Island, on September 5, 2005. He was born in Philadelphia, PA, on May 9, 1914. He was the son of the late Thomas and Edith Ridgway. A memorial service will be held in St. Columba Berkeley Memorial Chapel, Vaucluse Avenue in Middletown, Rhode Island, on Wednesday, September 28, 2005, at 12 noon. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Call Memorial Funeral Home, 375 Broadway, for information. Newport. www. Memorialfuneralhome.com

title: Roberts Debate Starts, but Outcome Is Clear
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - The Senate opened formal debate Monday on the nomination of Judge John G. Roberts Jr. to be chief justice of the United States, as President Bush signaled that he was considering a woman or a member of a minority to fill the Supreme Court seat of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who is retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORRELL, GENE
description: FORRELL--Gene. The Board of Directors of Musicians Foundation Inc. mourn the loss of Gene Forrell who has served as a Director for many many years. His support, insight and imagination will be sorely missed for he always put the needs of musicians first. Anne B. Stern, President Hans E. Tausig, Vice-Pres.

title: Italy's Edison accepts takeover price
Police Chief Abruptly Resigns in New Orleans
description: The police superintendent of New Orleans, Edwin P. Compass III, abruptly resigned today, four weeks after Hurricane Katrina put the city under water and into chaos, with people who had stayed behind left for days to fend for themselves amid reports of looting and lawlessness.

title: City and Correction Officers' Union Reach Tentative Deal for 10.25 Percent Raise
description: The union representing the city's 8,300 correction officers said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement on a retroactive 27-month contract with wage increases of 10.25 percent over that period and terms similar to those awarded to city police officers in June.

title: New Orleans's Literary Gumbo of Jazz, Myth and History
description: The story of New Orleans jazz is as much mythology as history. That's probably because the facts themselves were so extraordinary. No city in the United States has housed more nationalities and religions or has had more racial, social and sexual divisions or interminglings.

title: A Children's Book of Aspirations, With Songs
description: How many ways can a show go wrong? "Uncle Jed's Barbershop," a muddled musical memory play inspired by Margaree King Mitchell's children's book, offers an unfortunate illustration. Most of its good ideas are poorly executed, and its bad ideas are realized half-heartedly. Even the talented cast looks baffled and exhausted by show's end.

title: U.S. and China drift through textile talks
Editors' Notes
description: The TV Watch column on Sept. 5 discussed broadcast journalists' undisguised outrage at the failings of Hurricane Katrina rescue efforts. It said reporters had helped stranded victims because no police officers or rescue workers were around, and added, "Fox's Geraldo Rivera did his rivals one better: yesterday, he nudged an Air Force rescue worker out of the way so his camera crew could tape him as he helped lift an older woman in a wheelchair to safety."

title: I.R.A. Destroys What It Says Were the Last of Its Weapons
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 26 - The Irish Republican Army has completely and permanently dismantled its weaponry, the agency that oversees paramilitary disarmament in Northern Ireland said Monday, signaling the end of an era in which the group killed more than 1,700 people in assassinations, bombings and guerrilla warfare.

title: Brown puts emphasis on reforms in Britain
Justices Agree to Review Campaign Spending Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - The Supreme Court opened a new chapter today in the long-running debate over the role of money in politics by agreeing to decide whether Vermont's strict limits on campaign spending and contributions are constitutional.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Murder-Suicide In Hair Salon
description: The ex-boyfriend of a Park Slope hair stylist shot her and turned the gun on himself in the back room of her salon yesterday morning as customers waited out front, the police said. The gunman, Jorge Peguero, 54, a bodega owner, took Vinicia Baez, 43, a co-owner of Dolores and Alex Hairstyles, at 318 11th Street, into the shampoo room, shot her several times, then killed himself, the police said. Ms. Baez died a short time later at New York Methodist Hospital. Friends described Mr. Peguero as a controlling ex-boyfriend who was jealous that Ms. Baez, a single mother of two grown children, had started exercising and was dating again. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: Agreeing Only to Disagree on God's Place in Science
description: It was on the second day at Cambridge that enlightenment dawned in the form of a testy exchange between a zoologist and a paleontologist, Richard Dawkins and Simon Conway Morris. Their bone of contention was one that scholars have been gnawing on since the days of Aquinas: whether an understanding of the universe and its glories requires the hypothesis of a God.

title: Blair, in Labor Speech, Aims at Reinforcing His Dominance
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 27 - In a keynote speech intended to reinforce his political dominance, a pugnacious Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged today to keep British troops in Iraq and to "remain the strongest ally of the United States."

title: Haves, Have-Nots and College
description: To the Editor:

title: Forrester Suggests Corzine Donations Helped Win Black Ministers' Backing
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26 - A group of influential black ministers gathered on Monday to endorse Senator Jon S. Corzine for governor. But the announcement turned unexpectedly into a contentious forum on race, politics and money as the ministers demanded that the Republican candidate, Douglas R. Forrester, apologize for what they said were insensitive remarks.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We can all pitch in."

title: Old Foes, Pope and Dissident, Meet to Find Shared Ground
description: ROME, Sept. 26 - The two old and eminent theologians -- once friends, then not -- met again over the weekend. One of them, the Rev. Hans Kng, had been barred from teaching Catholics in 1979 for questioning the pope's infallibility. The other, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, reportedly played some role in that barring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORCORAN, JOHN W.
description: CORCORAN--John W. Of NYC, Rye and Windham, NY. On September 25. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Elise Dobi, Laura, Sanford and Pamela Corcoran. Cherished grandfather of five loving grandchildren. Former Vice-Chairman of Donaldson Lufkin and Jenrette. A graduate of Dartmouth College and Harvard Business School. Family will receive friends Wednesday 79 PM and Thursday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 65 East 89th St. Interment to follow at the N. Hardyston Cemetery, Hardyston, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to Spence Chapin Services, Attn: Linda J. Wright, 6 E. 94th St., NY, NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AINSLIE, RUTH
description: AINSLIE--Ruth. The Board of Directors, staff and members of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association are saddened by the death of our dear friend and colleague, Ruth Ainslie. We will miss her intelligence and insight as well as her energy and style. We express our deepest sympathy to her family.

title: Modeling Korean unification
Paid Notice: Deaths   KASSAL, SAMUEL Z., DDS
description: KASSAL--Samuel Z., DDS. Died September 25. Survived by his wife, Winifred; father of Leslie and Drew; stepfather of Randee and Gary. Brother of Bentley and Stanley. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINBERG, SYLVIA
description: WEINBERG--Sylvia. Beloved mother of Richard and Robert. Devoted grandmother of Laura, Matthew and Perry. Loving mother-in-law of Barbara and Laurie. Services at Plaza, 630 Amsterdam Ave, September 27, at 10 am.

description: SPEAKERS:

title: News Analysis: In Polish coalition, an uneasy partnership
Putin Won't Rule Out Third Term in 2008
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27 - President Vladimir V. Putin told Russians today that his five years in power had brought stability and prosperity so that "people can plan their lives" after the country's period of wrenching post-Soviet chaos.

title: Stroller Moms Retort, We're Not Bulldozers
description: To the Editor:

title: Roundup: Millar's comeback
Stop Stalling on Affordable Housing
description: The gargantuan task of finding permanent housing for the hundreds of thousands of people displaced by Hurricane Katrina will require a policy shift in Congress, which has spent the last several years savaging federal housing programs. A good first step would be to pass the Federal Housing Finance Reform Act, a new oversight bill for the federally backed mortgage giants, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

title: Report calls for legalized Afghan opium
INSIDE
description: Private Convicted in Abu Ghraib Prison Abuse Pfc. Lynndie R. England was convicted of joining in the Abu Ghraib prison abuse when she posed next to detainees who had been stripped and put into humiliating poses. An earlier effort by Private England to plead guilty in a deal with prosecutors was rejected by the judge in May. PAGE A12

title: Haves, Have-Nots and College
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Nashville Newcomer
description: Great American Country, the Scripps-owned cable television channel that carries the Grand Ole Opry and competes directly with Viacom's Country Music Television, will relocate its corporate operations to Nashville from Denver. Country Music Television is already in downtown Music City; Great American Country currently has a small office on Music Row, a mile north of downtown. The announcement is welcome news for country music, which lost a valuable broadcast partner in 2000 when the Nashville Network left the city and eventually became Spike TV. The formal announcement was made at a news conference yesterday featuring the mayor of Nashville, Bill Purcell, and Gov. Phil Bredesen of Tennessee.

title: Police Chief Abruptly Resigns in New Orleans
description: The police superintendent of New Orleans, Edwin P. Compass III, abruptly resigned today, four weeks after Hurricane Katrina put the city under water and into chaos, with people who had stayed behind left for days to fend for themselves amid reports of looting and lawlessness.

title: Former FEMA Chief Blames Local Officials for Failures
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - The former head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency admitted today that he had made mistakes in responding to Hurricane Katrina. But he strongly defended the agency and himself, and asserted that the disaster had been compounded by internal Louisiana politics.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Friday, about Richard Thomas, now appearing in "A Naked Girl on the Appian Way" on Broadway, misstated the surname of the director. He is Doug Hughes, not Hayes.

title: Youth Expected to Admit Role in Boy's Death
description: NEWARK, Sept. 26 - The teenage cousin of a 7-year-old boy whose death spurred a systemic overhaul of New Jersey's child welfare system is expected to plead guilty on Tuesday to a charge related to the child's death, the teenager's lawyer said Monday.

title: Towers Were Unsafe in '93, Jury Is Told
description: The last thing Jan Gilhooly remembers after parking his car was the blinding flash followed by a huge orange fireball. A violent rush of air sent him hurtling 60 feet across the floor of the World Trade Center's basement garage, he said, collapsing his lungs and leaving him unconscious.

title: A Steadfast G.M. Faces Strike By Union in Canada Tonight
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 26 - General Motors and the Canadian Auto Workers made some progress in contract negotiations on Monday, but the company's continued demands for job cuts and reduced work breaks left open the prospect of a strike on Tuesday.

title: A Lithuanian Soprano Creates Her Own Ariadne
description: Since 1993, when she first sang the title role of Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" at the Metropolitan Opera, the soprano Deborah Voigt has pretty much owned the role at the house. But Ms. Voigt has other challenges on the horizon now. So the company brought back its alluring Elijah Moshinsky production of this Strauss favorite on Saturday afternoon with the Lithuanian soprano Violeta Urmana.

title: Merkel sets conditions for talks on a coalition
Spain finds Qaeda cell chief guilty in 9/11 plot
Clueless Jason Meets His Fate
description: "Medea" is not exactly his play, but let's begin with a word of appreciation for Lawrence Winslow, whose portrayal of Jason in the Classical Theater of Harlem's jolting version of Euripides' masterpiece provides something not often associated with the grisly tale: humor.

title: Bush may pick a woman for next court position
Editors' Notes
description: A front-page article yesterday reported on the awarding of billions of dollars in federal contracts to help rebuild the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina. The article said many contracts had been awarded without bidding or with limited competition, and it cited two major contractors whose political connections have already raised questions among government officials about the potential for favoritism or abuse.

title: GM bends a bit, but union in Canada is not satisfied
Women and Men: We Had a Deal!
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Survives Effort by Rival to Hasten Vote
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 26 - Ariel Sharon narrowly won a crucial vote on Monday in his right-wing Likud Party, fending off a challenge from his main rival, Benjamin Netanyahu, who was seeking to oust him as party leader and prime minister.

title: If It Simply Hurts Too Much to Cry...
description: When Jodi Borrello registered her 10-year-old daughter for fifth grade in their adopted home, Port Barre, La., the school administrator happily showed her where to catch the bus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCAVEY, VINCENT M.
description: McAVEY--Vincent M. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Vincent M. McAvey, a Veteran member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Robert J. Reilly, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, ROY
description: MOORE--Roy, Author/Photographer of "Reflections on Greece" and Co-Author/Photographer with his wife Alma of "Thomas Jefferson's Journey to the South of France," died September 23 in NYC. Born in Virginia, he practiced his profession of travel and fashion photography in America and Europe. He is survived by his wife, his son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Gretchen Moore of Veazie, ME, his grandson, Demian Moore of Washington, DC, and his granddaughter, Tanya Moore of Miami Beach, FL. He was predeceased by his daughter, Melinda Moore. Droll, funny and feisty, he was deeply loved and will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Remembrances may be contributed for Stem Cell Research.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Louvre II Architects Named

title: 'Fire Bell' in the Night
description: The most important decision we'll make in the aftermath of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita isn't whether to rebuild New Orleans. It's how to tackle global warming.

title: Cases to Be Reviewed in the New Session
description: The following is a list of cases that will be reviewed in the new term, the Supreme Court on Tuesday:

title: Fierce Typhoon Batters Southern China
description: A typhoon with winds topping 125 miles an hour swept across the Chinese resort island of Hainan, according to state media. It claimed at least nine lives, knocked out power to most of the island's eight million people and flooded rice paddies. State media said it was the strongest typhoon to hit Hainan since 1973. The storm, which earlier caused a deluge of rain and at least 18 deaths in the Philippines, moved inland across southern Guangdong Province and was expected to inundate Vietnam with heavy rains.

title: With Storms Behind Them, Gulf Residents Begin Piecing Their Lives Together
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26 - The lights came back on in the French Quarter on Monday, and residents streamed back across the Mississippi River to neighborhoods in Algiers. For the first time since Hurricane Rita compounded the devastation of Hurricane Katrina, glimmers of optimism began coursing through this battered and largely deserted city as Gulf Coast residents in Texas and Louisiana tried to put their lives back together.

title: French police arrest 9 suspects in antiterror sweep
How Many Pages in Google? Take a Guess
description: In the bitter war of words between Google and Yahoo over search-engine index size, Google has decided to give its latest answer in the form of a question.

title: From Bloomberg, a Focus on Leadership
description: This 30-second advertisement for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is running on all major broadcast stations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LUBIN, CAROL RIEGELMAN
description: LUBIN--Carol Riegelman. A Service in celebration of the life of Carol Riegelman Lubin will be held Sunday, October 2 at 3 PM at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, New York City.

title: Bizarre and Infamous Join Scholarship in an Archive of Psychology
description: AKRON, Ohio - Just 45 minutes from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, half an hour from the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton and two blocks from the Inventors Hall of Fame in this city's downtown is an attraction like no other.

title: Mayor Moves Closer to Deal on Teachers
description: As New York City and the teachers' union returned to the negotiating table yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg weighed in with unusually pointed comments about the contract talks, saying that he wanted a deal nailed down within two weeks or that the sides should accept a compromise recently proposed by arbitrators.

title: Half a Step Forward to Rein In Iran
description: Correction Appended

title: TechBrief: Hutchison expanding in India
Paid Notice: Deaths   FROST, JOSEPH
description: FROST--Joseph. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz Rabbi Emeritus Harry S. Katz, President

title: Clouds Part, Giving Yanks a Clear Path to First Place
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 - By the later innings Monday night, the Baltimore Orioles' outfielders started diving all over the grass at Camden Yards, robbing the Yankees of hits. In those moments, the Orioles looked like a hustling, energetic team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICULESCU, BARBU DR.
description: NICULESCU--Barbu Dr. September 25, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Katherine. Devoted father of Rena Crisp and her husband William. Cherished grandfather of Peter. Longtime trusted companion of Ceclia Lavor. Funeral services private.

title: Stock Sale Was Planned Months Before Plunge, Frist Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - Senator Bill Frist on Monday defended his sale of stock in his family's hospital company at the June peak in its price, saying he had first sought legal and ethical advice about divesting the shares two months earlier.

title: Study Shows Migration to U.S. Follows Trend
description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, migration to the United States peaked in 2000 and has declined substantially since then, even taking into consideration signs of a fresh upturn in 2004, according to a new year-by-year analysis released today by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: What Are You Up to Now, Desperate 20-Somethings?
description: In the season premiere of "Desperate Housewives," a neighbor with a drinking problem asks God for a sign. The bottle of liquor in her hand is promptly shattered by a bullet. The show's narrator (Brenda Strong as the deceased Mary Alice Young) says, "God may work in mysterious ways, but he isn't particularly subtle."

title: Nude is cool for hot new talent
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a decision by a consortium to sponsor applications to build two nuclear reactors misstated the location for which one company, Entergy, is planning a third application. It is the company's River Bend plant, near St. Francisville, La., not its Waterford plant, near Taft, La.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: A 'Main Event' in Old New York
description: It is called a trading book. In meticulous, spidery notations, it reveals just how the sloop Rhode Island, owned by Philip Livingston & Sons, New York merchants, traded rum, tobacco and cheese for guns, cloth and ivory in 1749.

title: Big-Name Novelist, Small-Town Murders
description: In 1959, a newspaper article about the murder of the Clutter family in the tiny town of Holcomb, Kan., caught the eye of the novelist Truman Capote. He spent most of the next half-dozen years following the case, which ended with the execution of Dick Hickock and Perry Smith and the subsequent publication of "In Cold Blood," Capote's best-selling mutation of the true crime potboiler into bona fide literature.

title: Bush Selects General to Run Spy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - President Bush has nominated Maj. Gen. Michael D. Maples of the Army to be director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, the first time in decades that someone who is not a career intelligence officer has been picked to lead the agency.

title: Women and Men: We Had a Deal!
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate Says He Was Offered a Quid Pro Quo to Exit the Race
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 26 - A third-party candidate in the race for Westchester district attorney said on Monday that he had been approached by a person with ties to the Republican candidate, Janet DiFiore, and asked to bow out of the race in exchange for a job in Mrs. DiFiore's office, should she win.

title: Women in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: If Parks Offer Free Internet, Why Can't Costly Hotels?
description: I'M no cheapskate, but I watch costs carefully even when I'm traveling on the company dime. And I'm here to tell you, I am getting fed up with being charged $9.95 or more in an expensive hotel for broadband Internet service. Lots of business travelers tell me they feel the same.

title: Briefly: Thales denies allegations of bribe payments to Iraq
Briefly: Benedict holds talks with outspoken critic
Jets' Pennington Out for Rest of the Season
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 26 - The Jets' worst fears were realized Monday when they learned that Chad Pennington tore the rotator cuff in his surgically repaired right shoulder during Sunday's 26-20 overtime loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars and would be lost for the season.

title: Turmoil at the Drug Agency
description: The surprise resignation of Lester Crawford as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration was announced late Friday, just as Hurricane Rita threatened the shoreline in Texas, a time calculated to minimize attention. Given that Dr. Crawford, a veteran agency official, had been promoted to the top job only two months ago and had given no hint of wanting to quit, his sudden departure bore all the signs of a forced resignation. His stated reason, that at age 67 it was time to step aside, sounds preposterous. An administration spokeswoman called it a personnel issue. One official cited Dr. Crawford's failure to disclose all financial information before confirmation, a charge his wife, Catherine, denies.

title: 'Frankenstem' stalks the vineyard
Formula One: With pressure on, Alonso responded
Famine risk as North Korea recoils
Paid Notice: Deaths   SZOLD, MYRON ROBERT
description: SZOLD--Myron Robert, age 70. Beloved husband of Pam. Loving father of Seth (Susan) Szold and Jennifer (Jon) Bohnert. Devoted grandfather of Tom, Lexie, Charlie and Daniel. Fond brother of Terry (Stan) Kulesa. In lieu of flowers donations to: Szold Scholarship Fund at Oberlin College, Bosworth Hall, 50 West Lorain St. Oberlin, OH 44074. Interment Private. Veterans Funeral Service 800/844-0203.

title: Mayoral Battle, Round 2: Rivals' Allies Enter Ring
description: The 2005 mayoral campaign slid into negative politicking for a second straight day yesterday, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Fernando Ferrer both turned to Hispanic allies to trade fire on education issues, and Mr. Ferrer accused the mayor of unleashing "attack dogs" on him.

title: The Vatican and gays; German leadership
Virgo Offers a Peek at the Violent History of the Galaxies Next Door
description: In a telescope or in ordinary pictures that capture a cosmic instant, the 2,000 or so galaxies of the Virgo cluster glow like pearly city-states, isolated and smug agglomerations of starlight. But astronomers know these galaxies are really buzzing about like bees confined by gravity in a hive some 10 million light-years across, careering back and forth at 500 miles a second, banging into one another and splashing stars and gas across space.

title: U.S. Weapons, Foreign Flavor
description: Before the Iraq war, one of the Pentagon's biggest concerns was that American troops would face unknown biological and chemical threats. But when the order came in to step up production of two-piece protective suits, the Pentagon had to look overseas to get all the parts -- even to countries that opposed the war.

title: Cost of Defective Rail Ties Weighs on M.T.A. Finances
description: The concrete railroad ties the Metropolitan Transportation Authority bought eight years ago were supposed to last 50 years. But the authority's two commuter railroads are already tearing up tracks to replace them at a potential cost of almost $125 million, New York's comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bus Companies To Stop Idling Motors
description: Three private companies have agreed that the 1,000 school buses they operate in New York City will no longer be allowed to keep their motors idling within a block of public school buildings and to limit idling in urban depots , according to a settlement announced yesterday by the state attorney general's office. The companies, United Tom Tom Transportation, Jofaz Transportation and Rainbow Transit, also agreed to a self-monitoring program and to penalties totaling $61,425 for violating city and state laws prohibiting excessive idling. The settlement also covers Henderson Bus Corporation, which operates 649 school buses in Nassau County, and County Coach Corporation, which has a fleet of 60 school buses in Westchester County. Diesel emissions are considered a serious pollutant and a major contributor to one of the city's biggest health issues--the high rate of asthma, especially in children. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: A Few Cigarettes a Day Can Kill, Too
description: Smokers who hope to avoid serious illness by limiting their intake to a few cigarettes a day may be making a big mistake.

title: World Briefings: Middle East, Europe, Asia, Americas
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Gambling With History
description: Washington - THE mere mention of Gettysburg conjures up images of beautiful, rolling Pennsylvania farmland and stone monuments commemorating the soldiers who fought there 142 years ago. Nearly two million tourists visit Gettysburg each year to pay tribute to the place where, as Abraham Lincoln said, this nation was given "a new birth of freedom."

title: Red Sox-Yanks a Cure for an Assortment of Ills
description: It is obvious by now that Yankees-Red Sox games provide ratings booster shots for any network that carries them.

title: New Shining Path Trial in Peru
description: Ten months after his retrial collapsed in chaos, Abimael Guzmn, leader of the leftist guerrilla movement Shining Path, went on trial again on charges of fueling a terror war that killed tens of thousands of Peruvians in the 1980's and 90's. A secret military tribunal convicted Mr. Guzmn after his capture in 1992, but the country's top court ruled the conviction unconstitutional two years ago, ordering a civilian retrial. That proceeding fell apart last November, when Mr. Guzmn and his fellow defendants began chanting Communist slogans in court. This time, cameras and tape recorders have been banned from the heavily guarded court. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: The Claim: Thumb Sucking Can Lead to Buck Teeth
description: Correction Appended

title: Indonesia begins new round of polio shots
The March
Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIDMAN, EDITH SHIVITZ
description: MAIDMAN--Edith Shivitz at home in Nyack on September 25, wife of the late Irving, mother of the late Bart and Matthew. Survived by Rebecca, Ellen and Robert (Ros lyn) Maidman; five grandand eight great grandchildren; and brother David (Florence) Shivitz. Service at Congregation Sons of Israel, 300 N. Broadway, Upper Nyack, NY (845) 358-3767 on Thursday at 10AM. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Memorial donations to Rockland County, Henrietta Szold Chapter of Haddasah, 900 Rt 45, New City, NY 10956.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Emergency Radio Contract
description: The Pataki administration has entered into a $2 billion contract to establish a statewide radio network to connect public safety agencies from Niagara to New York City. The contract, to design, deploy, operate and maintain an advanced digital radio network over the next 20 years, was signed on Sept. 19 with M/A-Com, a subsidiary of the Bermuda-based company Tyco International. The system, which will require the construction of some new radio towers, will replace several outdated radio systems. The system is expected to be completed in about five years, said Victoria B. Dillon, a company spokeswoman. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Cool Reception for Porsche-VW Link
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 26 - The chief executive of Porsche, Wendelin Wiedeking, said two weeks ago at the Frankfurt Motor Show that his company had two options for growth: sell more sports cars, which would mean competing on price, or try to break into the broader luxury market, building on the success of its Cayenne sport utility vehicle.

title: Accidental President With a Feminist Twist
description: This is a fall season that asks viewers to swallow the implausible, from alien invaders on the CBS science fiction series "Threshold," to sea monsters on NBC's "Surface."

title: Judge Sets Gotti's Bail at $7 Million
description: John A. Gotti, the Gambino crime family scion who avoided conviction for racketeering in a trial that ended last week, came closer to leaving prison yesterday when a judge ruled that he could be released on $7 million bail. But she also ordered a new trial to begin Feb. 13 on the three charges against him that left the jury deadlocked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, DANIEL
description: GOLDSTEIN--Daniel. 78 of Boca Raton formerly of Woodmere, died at home on September 26 after a long illness, surrounded by his family. Dan was a devoted husband to Arlene for 42 years and a loving father to Carrie and David Gamsey, Debbie Kahn, Karen and Jeff Miller. He was adored by his grandchildren, Brian, Robyn, Stephanie, Katie and Melanie. Born in the Bronx Dan played football and basketball at City College. He was a champion paddleball player as well as a loyal Giants and Knicks fan. For over 25 years he was general manager of Milton Paper Company. A true and caring friend, he will be missed by all. Services Wednesday 11am at "Boulevard-Riverside", 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Setting the nuclear myth to music
World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Management Shift at Nestl
description: Nestl said that its chief financial officer, Wolfgang Reichenberger, left, was stepping down to run a 500-million-euro venture capital fund as part of its strategy to expand into higher-margin nutritional products. The company also took the unusual move of going outside the company for a successor, hiring Paul Polman, a former head of Procter & Gamble's European business. The appointment created speculation the company is looking for a successor to Peter Brabeck-Letmathe, who has been chief executive since 1997. Mr. Reichenberger will step down at the end of the year to run the new fund in a partnership with Inventages Venture Capital Investments, based in Switzerland. Tom Wright (IHT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Hurt In Beating Dies
description: A 25-year-old woman who was severely beaten in her apartment last week died yesterday, the police said. The police are seeking the woman's ex-boyfriend, Rafael Nuez. The woman, Lillian Reyes, had returned to her Hoffman Street apartment in the Belmont section during a lunch break from her job at a nearby bank, the police said, and encountered Mr. Nuez, 31, the father of her 3-year-old son. He beat her and fled, leaving her with severe head injuries, the police said. Her father found her almost two hours later. She died at St. Barnabas Hospital. Mr. Nuez is 5 feet 8 inches tall, 200 pounds, with black hair and brown eyes, and he drives a 2000 Chevrolet Cavalier with New York plates DHG3184, the police said. Anyone with information about him is urged to call (800) 577-8477. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN CLIEF, ANTHONY S.
description: Van CLIEF--Anthony S. The Board of Directors and staff of the Brookdale Foundation Group are deeply saddened by the loss of Anthony S. Van Clief, the husband and best friend of Mary Ann Van Clief, Vice President of the Brookdale Foundation, on Sunday September 25. Tony will forever be remembered for his charm, wit, warmth, his fabulous Italian cooking, his love of golf, and his unparalleled devotion to his wife, Mary Ann. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mary Ann, children Tami and Dite, and their spouses, brother, Elwood, and mother-in-law, Mama May Andersen. If so desired, memorials may be made to the Bright Side Manor, 300 Teaneck Rd., Teaneck, NJ . Stephen L. Schwartz, President

title: Urging Quicker Action on Finances, Codey Names Two to Board of Medical School
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26 - Urging New Jersey's state medical school to speed up its efforts to tighten the financial regulations that permitted tens of millions of dollars in questionable spending in recent years, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey announced nominees on Monday to fill two vacant seats on the board of trustees.

Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISS, ROBERT
description: HEISS--Robert, 67, on September 25th, 2005. Dearest husband of Nelly Szlachter. Cherished father of Carla, Andrea and Daniel and fatherin-law of Olen and Ben. Adoring and adored grandfather of Maxwell and Alexander. Loving brother of Jonny and true friend of Carmen. Esteemed physician who was loved by all who were privileged to know him. Services Tuesday, 11:45 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Jury Considering the Fate of Brooklyn Party Leader
description: Prosecutors described Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. as a "favorite son of Brooklyn" who had betrayed the public trust as the political corruption case against him went to the jury yesterday.

title: Jazz and Classical Rhythms Mingle in a Modernist Stream
description: Since it was founded by Joel Sachs in 1993, the New Juilliard Ensemble has become a useful part of New York's new-music world, performing not only at the Juilliard School but also at the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden series, and serving as a boot camp for Mr. Sachs's other New York new-music ensemble, Continuum. Mr. Sachs has used his connections with composers around the world to procure new music for the group, to the tune of more than 40 works in its first dozen years. Five more scores will be added to its cache this season, but since the Juilliard School is celebrating its centennial, Mr. Sachs devoted the ensemble's first concert, on Saturday evening at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, to revisiting works written for the group over the last decade.

title: Requiring a Voter ID
description: To the Editor:

title: A Still Midlife, With Crisis
description: David, an immigration lawyer very close to making partner, says he is absolutely brilliant at filling out forms. Played by Jason Pugatch, who has the Midwestern good looks of Will Ferrell, he has accepted boredom as his lot in life. Christopher Kyle's "Safety Net," a thoughtful midlife-crisis drama that touches on everything from the racial prejudices of the liberal elite to the nature-nurture debate, is a portrait of a man going through the motions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fearing Economic Damage From High Fuel Cost Bush Urges Measures to Conserve Energy With fears mounting that high energy costs will crimp economic growth, President Bush called on Americans to conserve gasoline by driving less. He also issued a directive for all federal agencies to cut their own energy use and to encourage employees to use public transportation. "We can all pitch in," Mr. Bush said. "People just need to recognize that the storms have caused disruption," he added, and that if Americans are able to avoid going "on a trip that's not essential, that would be helpful." [Page A1.]

title: Ex-Employee Kills Himself After Shooting 3 in Factory

title: Devils Trade Friesen
description: The Devils traded left wing Jeff Friesen to the Washington Capitals yesterday for a third-round pick in next year's draft. By trading the 29-year-old Friesen, the Devils were able to drop below the league-mandated salary cap of just under $39 million before Oct. 5, the start of the regular season.

title: Russia Lifts Arrest Warrant for Ukrainian Ex-Premier
description: Russian prosecutors said they had withdrawn their arrest warrant for Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister, after she voluntarily appeared in Moscow over the weekend and agreed to give evidence. President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine dismissed Ms. Tymoshenko, who was one of the leaders of the Orange Revolution, as prime minister this month amid internal divisions. She is suspected in Russia of bribing Russian military officials in the mid-1990's, when she was chief of Ukraine's energy monopoly. Russian television reports suggested that Russian authorities might have decided to unite forces with Ms. Tymoshenko in an effort to undermine Mr. Yushchenko. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Gulf Currents That Turn Storms Into Monsters
description: A month ago, Kerry Emanuel, an atmospheric scientist who has spent decades studying how hurricanes reach their peak strength, "had this terrible feeling of dread" when he saw that Hurricane Katrina's track in the Gulf of Mexico would carry it right over an oceanographic phenomenon known as the loop current.

title: Prevention: What Amplified Music Is the Loudest? All of It
description: If you are heading out for a concert, you should consider taking a pair of earplugs.
