title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISLOCKY, NICHOLAS W.
description: VISLOCKY--Nicholas W. The Board of Trustees, officers and staff of The Green-Wood Cemetery mourn the loss of our dear friend and Superintendent, Nicholas W. Vislocky. With passion, commitment and good humor he served Green-Wood for more than 34 years, five of those years as its Superintendent. His many contributions to the beauty of the Cemetery and his abiding love of GreenWood will be deeply missed. We extend our condolences to his wife, Marie, and to his children, Lisa and Nicholas. The Board of Trustees of The Green-Wood Cemetery

title: George Archer, 65, Winner of Golf's Masters in 1969, Dies
description: George Archer, the 1969 Masters champion, who was once the tallest player on the PGA Tour and maybe its best putter, died Sunday at his home in Incline Village, Nev. He was 65.

title: The I.R.A. Finally Risks Disarmament
description: A singular opportunity in the bloody strife of Northern Ireland is at hand with word from an independent monitor that the Irish Republican Army has in fact scrapped its hidden arsenals of war weaponry. Vast amounts of murderous tools from the modern Troubles have been rendered unusable and sealed away, according to John de Chastelain, the retired Canadian general who spent the last seven and a half years laboring to make the balking leaders of the I.R.A. deliver on the disarmament promise of the Good Friday peace accord.

title: Football, and a Sense of Normalcy, Returns
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 26 - When Tom and Jeannie Darling evacuated the Lakeview section of New Orleans ahead of Hurricane Katrina, they took all the important stuff: baby pictures, memorabilia from Louisiana State's shared national championship of 2003 and their 2005 season tickets.

title: Sharon fends off Netanyahu in leadership challenge

description: LEWIS--Mary. You gave our boys your kindness, competence and comfort and all of us your friendship. We love you dearly and will miss you deeply. Adam and Squire Families

title: Former Chief of the F.D.A. Wasn't Fired, His Wife Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - Catherine W. Crawford, the wife of Lester M. Crawford, who resigned abruptly as commissioner of food and drugs last week, said on Monday that he had stepped down voluntarily and "was not fired."

title: IRA destroys all its arms
Storm Victims May Face Curbs On Bankruptcy
description: When Congress agreed this spring to tighten the bankruptcy laws and crack down on consumers who took on debt irresponsibly, no one had the victims of Hurricane Katrina in mind.

title: More Rita victims sought
Scientist Recommends Isolation for Animals Showing Signs of Canine Flu
description: With a new, highly contagious canine flu spreading, dogs that are coughing should be kept at home for up to two weeks, a scientist who first described the illness said yesterday.

title: Reforms in Time, Bush Envoy Is Told
description: Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes, pressing her campaign to promote democracy and improve the American image in the Middle East, won a commitment from the Egyptian prime minister, Ahmed Nazif, to ease emergency restrictions on political freedoms in the next session of the Parliament, her chief aide said. The aide, Dina Powell, said Mr. Nazif had told them that President Hosni Mubarak could not lift the restrictions on the rights of assembly and protest without replacing them with an anti-terrorism law he would seek to get passed. The emergency laws were imposed in 1981 after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat and have been used since to arrest suspected extremists. The United States has repeatedly called for them to be lifted. Ms. Hughes, the administration's top envoy for public diplomacy, also met with "opinion leaders" friendly to the United States but critical of some American policies and then flew to Saudi Arabia for meetings with officials and women's groups today. Steven R. Weisman (NYT)

title: In a Midair Free Fall, Try to Just Laugh It Off
description: AS the plane taxied down the runway, the man across the aisle from me chattered away to the people next to him. I began reading. Once in the air, his row mates shut their lights off. Barely pausing, he turned to me and kept up his monologue for the rest of the flight. The moment the plane landed, he fell silent. As he headed for the exit, he looked back at me.

title: Chef and Developers Cancel Columbus Circle Restaurant
description: Nearly two years after it was announced that he would become the final star in the constellation of top chefs at the Time Warner Center, Charlie Trotter and the building's retail developers have decided to cancel plans for him to open a seafood restaurant there.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Deal for Yellow Pages Publisher
description: Eniro of Sweden, the biggest Nordic yellow pages publisher, agreed to buy Findexa of Norway for 7.9 billion Swedish kronor ($1 billion) from investors including the Texas Pacific Group. Findexa is Norway's dominant yellow pages publisher. Texas Pacific bought Findexa, Norway's dominant yellow pages publisher, in 2001, took it public last year and is now selling its remaining stake.

title: First Giant Squid Captured in Wild (on Film, That Is)
description: For decades, scientists and sea explorers have mounted costly expeditions to hunt down and photograph the giant squid, a legendary monster with eyes the size of dinner plates and a nightmarish tangle of tentacles lined with long rows of sucker pads.

title: Hazards: Alligator Attacks Increasing (Don't Pick One Up)
description: There are any number of ways to be bitten by an alligator, but some are more reliable than others, a paper by an epidemiologist in North Carolina reports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELSHMAN, BRUCE
description: FELSHMAN--Bruce, on September 26, 2005, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Tanya, Caron and Robert. Cherished grandfather of eight. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday, 79pm. Funeral service 8pm, Tuesday evening, at the funeral home. Interment Wednesday, All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lazard Hires Morgan Stanley Banker
description: Lazard said that it had hired Riccardo Pavoncelli, a longtime Morgan Stanley banker, to bolster its European cross-border deal-making team. Mr. Pavoncelli, an Italian count, has been with Morgan Stanley's investment banking group since 1988, most recently as head of its business in Italy. He was previously co-head of the group's telecommunications practice and head of its European debt capital markets team. Morgan Stanley said that it had named Dante Roscini, 46, head of investment banking in Italy. In June, Lazard's Italian head of investment banking, Gerardo Braggiotti, left the firm after a dispute with its chairman and chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein. The 48-year-old Count Pavoncelli is married to Cosima, the daughter of Claus and Sunny von Blow. He will be based in London. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Lynndie England found guilty in abuse of Iraq detainees
We Never Told Our Father He Had Cancer
description: Though we saw him as fearless, my father died without being told he had cancer.

Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBUD, DR. LEON
description: EISENBUD--Dr. Leon. Our love for you will remain alive. Elsa and Sid LaPook and Family

Reluctant Soldier Bares His Illusions of War
description: My Detachment A Memoir By Tracy Kidder 192 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: Demotion of a Prosecutor Is Investigated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - The Justice Department's inspector general and the F.B.I. are looking into the demotion of a veteran federal prosecutor whose reassignment nearly three years ago shut down a criminal investigation of the Washington lobbyist Jack Abramoff, current and former department officials report.

title: Private Found Guilty in Abu Ghraib Abuse
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 26 - Pfc. Lynndie R. England, a 22-year-old Army file clerk whose smirking photographs came to personify the Abu Ghraib prison scandal, was convicted Monday of joining in the abuse when she posed next to detainees who had been stripped and put into humiliating poses.

title: Five Teachers Slain in an Iraq School
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 26 - Armed men dressed as police officers burst into a primary school in a town south of Baghdad on Monday, rounded up five Shiite teachers and their driver, marched them to an empty classroom and killed them, a police official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDRETH, EDWARD SWAIN
description: LANDRETH--Edward Swain. On September 26, 2005 at age ninty-two. Retired Executive Vice President of Sterling Products International. Beloved husband of Betsy Landreth. Loving father of Elizabeth Newhouse, Ted Landreth, Ann Gund, and Barbara Landreth. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth Wagley, John Wagley, Jonathan Landreth, Audrey Viola, Alexander and Gregory Pasternack, and great grandfather of Ava Landreth and Isabel Viola. Services at Saint James Episcopal Church, Bristol, PA, Thursday September 29th, 11:30 A.M. Donations in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Bush Wants to Consider Broadening of Military's Powers During Natural Disasters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - President Bush said Monday that he and Congress should immediately begin discussing whether to amend federal law so the military could take responsibility right away in natural disasters like Hurricane Katrina.

title: DVD Fight Intensifies: Microsoft and Intel to Back Toshiba Format
description: Microsoft and Intel are throwing their full weight behind one side in the long-running battle over the format for the next generation of high-definition DVD's.

title: Forced Marsh
description: IN the wake of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, there has been much talk of rebuilding Louisiana's coastal wetlands and barrier islands. This proposal, which could cost an estimated $15 billion, has been advocated by Louisiana scientists, engineers, politicians and environmentalists alike, who explain that the state is suffering the highest rate of land loss in the nation and imply that restoring this land would reduce the damage from future storms.

title: After the Hurricanes, the Inner Storm for Children
description: Once the water recedes, mud is hauled away and families are reunited with those who survived Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, most of the displaced residents will be focused on finding new places to live and work. But it will be equally important to pay attention to the effects of these vast disruptions on the mental health of children whose lives were torn apart.

title: Don Adams, Television's Maxwell Smart, Dies at 82
description: Don Adams, who played Maxwell Smart in the 1960's sitcom "Get Smart," combining clipped, decisive diction with appalling, hilarious ineptitude, died on Sunday at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 82.

title: Implant Program for Heart Device Was a Sales Spur
description: By January, about 80 cardiologists nationwide completed an evaluation run by the Guidant Corporation of one of its products, an improved electrical component, known as a lead, that connects an implanted cardiac device to the heart.

title: Baidu faces new suit on copyrights
In Heeding Health Warnings, Memory Can Be Tricky
description: In briefing consumers on health risks, public health campaigns often rely on a catchy strategy: they list the myths about a behavior or product, then follow up those misconceptions with the truth.

title: Many Don't Wash Hands After Using the Bathroom
description: Most people say they wash their hands after using the bathroom. But a new study suggests that many of them are not telling the truth.

title: Many Try, but in Vain, to Return to a Devastated Parish
description: CHOUPIQUE BAYOU, La., Sept. 26 - David Reeves drove his pickup down a country road littered with pine trees snapped as easily as matchsticks, electric wires tossed spaghettilike across the asphalt, and a variety of roadkill: armadillos, raccoons, nutria, dogs. Then he arrived at the roadblock here at the Intercoastal Waterway, where he waited on Monday.

title: Patterns: Red Sox Fever and the Lonely Emergency Room
description: How dedicated are Red Sox fans? Let's just say that according to a new study, when a big game is on television, Boston emergency rooms see a lot less business coming through the door.

Trial of 4 War Protesters Upstate Ends With a Mixed Verdict
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 26 - Jurors handed four antiwar activists a mixed verdict on Monday, apparently deciding that pouring human blood on walls, windows and an American flag at a military recruiting station to protest the Iraq war was neither Gandhi-like nor a "slippery slope" to the kind of destruction caused by violent extremists.

title: French rail strike called as part of Oct. 4 protests
Americana, Unabashedly Romantic
description: Leon Botstein didn't invent thematic programming, but he hopped onto that bandwagon when the notion was hot, and has ridden it well into its twilight. These days, the thematic labels Mr. Botstein slaps on his programs invite argument too easily to be of much use, even as marketing tools: the stretches of empty seats at the American Symphony Orchestra's first concert of the season, on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, suggested that ticket buyers have become numb to their supposed appeal.

title: Rainout Forces Red Sox to Alter Pitching Order
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 - Curt Schilling was wearing his white uniform pants, a red and blue cap and black cleats about three hours before he was scheduled to toss a pitch for the Boston Red Sox. He had not yet pulled on his jersey like baseball's version of Superman, but he looked ready to soar.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CASIN, HARRIETTE M.
description: CASIN--Harriette M. You are the angel glow that lights a star. Happy birthday, Mother. Love, Wendy and Daniel

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a test of the world's highest-resolution videoconferencing system referred incorrectly to one piece of equipment. The video data will be fed over a high-speed network to a Sony video projector, not a camera.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Housewives' Still Popular
description: The start of the second season of "Desperate Housewives" on Sunday night led ABC to victory in Nielsen's estimates of total viewers and adults 18 to 49. "Housewives," with Alfre Woodard, below, which drew 28.17 million viewers, was sandwiched between "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (16.27 million) and "Grey's Anatomy" (19.53 million), which also won their hours. CBS benefited from a long National Football League spillover into prime time and came in second for the night. NBC's Sunday lineup made its fall debut and included the relocated "West Wing," which moved to Sunday at 8 p.m. from Wednesday at 9 and drew an audience of 8.85 million. That number was significantly down from its season premiere last year (12.27 million) and was only slightly better than the debut of the now-canceled "American Dreams" a year ago (8.61 million) in the 8 p.m. Sunday slot. NBC placed third in viewers, its average boosted by "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" (10.33 million) and "Crossing Jordan" (13.16 million).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Ahold Names Chief Financial Officer
description: Royal Ahold, the Dutch owner of supermarket chains like Giant, has appointed John Rishton chief financial officer. Mr. Rishton, the chief financial officer of British Airways, will start Jan. 1, a spokesman said. Mr. Rishton succeeds Hannu Ryopponen, who left to join Stora Enso, the world's biggest paper maker, after reviving Ahold.

title: Corzine Stays on Theme: Affordability in New Jersey
description: "Affordable," a 30-second television commercial for United States Senator Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic nominee for governor in New Jersey, began running last weekend on cable and network stations in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Right-Wing Victors Face Tough Talks in Poland
description: Two center-right parties prepared for talks to form a new government together after a victory in parliamentary elections on Sunday. Fighting the country's endemic corruption, which helped cause the rout of former Communists in the voting, is an issue that the two parties -- Law and Justice, which, with 90 percent of the vote counted, had 27 percent, and Civic Platform, which had 24 percent -- should be able to unite behind, but their alliance is expected to be more sorely tested on economic policy. Law and Justice won over left-leaning voters with bitter attacks on Civic Platform's plan for a flat tax. Yesterday, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the Law and Justice leader poised to become the next prime minister, promised lower taxes but ruled out the flat tax. His party's victory in the parliamentary vote was a potential gain for his twin brother, Lech, the party's candidate in the presidential election on Oct. 9. Graham Bowley (IHT)

description: Lawrence J. Ellison's tentative settlement of an insider trading case hit a snag yesterday, when a California judge questioned why the company that Mr. Ellison heads, the Oracle Corporation, should pay legal fees to the lawyers who brought the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOONEY, DONALD J., SR.
description: MOONEY--Donald J., Sr., formerly of Rowayton, CT. Died September 15. He was 79. Rose to Executive VP of Equitable Life Assurance Society of US, youngest VP in company history, founding president/CEO of country's first variable life insurance company, founding president/CEO of Equitable Life Japan. Saw combat in Pacific Theatre during WWII as US Army artillery spotter, and MP in post-war Tokyo. Earned Purple Heart and Bronze Battle Star. Native of Schenectady, NY, settled in Bellevue, WA following retirement. Loving husband, father, grandfather, and devoted to his garden. Survived by wife Noriko Mooney of Bellevue, WA, sister Kathleen Carrese, Ballston Lake, NY, sons Donald, Jr., Thomas, and daughter Christina of Cincinnati, daughter Leslie of Phila., seven grandchildren. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association of Washington, 1271 30th Ave NE, Ste 101, Seattle, WA 98125.

title: As China assesses toll, typhoon hits Vietnam

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 26 - Afghanistan, the world's biggest producer of opium and its derivative, heroin, acknowledged Monday that it had considered licensing its vast illicit crop and using it to produce opium-based medicines, though it ruled out such a move in the immediate future.

title: Manning's Performance a Plus; Defense's Lapse Is a Concern
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 26 - When Coach Tom Coughlin sat down Monday morning to view videotape of the Giants' game against the Chargers a day earlier, he saw that quarterback Eli Manning had played the best game of his professional career -- and under unusually challenging circumstances. And still the Giants lost, 45-23.

title: Iran Warns of Retaliation for Vote on Its Nuclear Activities
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 27 - Iran warned today for the first time that it might retaliate economically against countries that voted in favor of a European-sponsored resolution calling for possible Security Council punishment of the Iranians for their nuclear enrichment activities.

title: Bucs' Williams Runs Like Fine-Tuned Machine
description: He is called Cadillac, but it is his nickname, not his persona. The last thing Carnell Williams reminds people of is a big, brassy show car, the snazziest ride on the road.

title: Nominee to Lead Public Broadcasting Promises to Pursue Balance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - Cheryl F. Halpern, a major Republican fund-raiser selected Monday to be the next chairwoman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, vowed to continue to encourage "objectivity and balance" in public television and radio.

description: The first time he was within a long goal kick of Scotland, Vladimir Romanov was 2,000 miles from home, serving on a Soviet attack submarine that was on patrol clandestinely in waters off the Scottish coast during the cold war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, FLORENCE
description: HOFFMAN--Florence of Delray Beach, Florida passed away on September 25, 2005 90 years young. Dynamic, creative and full of life even in the most difficult times. Beloved wife of the late Milton for 64 years. Devoted mother of Sue & Lew; Jim & June. Loving grandmother of Billy, John, David, & Michelle and proud great-grandmother of Alexander, Nicholas & Margaux. She will live on with us forever in her beautiful sculpture. Her indomitable spirit, courage and dignity will be remembered always with admiration and love. Private services in Florida.

title: Small Will Get Start; Wright Is Sent to Bullpen
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 - Jaret Wright and Aaron Small pitched last Saturday. Wright gave up seven runs and got three outs. Small allowed no runs and got 20 outs. For Yankees Manager Joe Torre, starting Small the next time through the rotation was an easy decision.

title: Wal-Mart Shows Hilfiger Interest
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest retailer, indicated yesterday that it might be interested in acquiring the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, the clothing company, executives close to the talks said.

title: Quotas: much ado, little gain
Urie Bronfenbrenner, 88, an Authority on Child Development, Dies
description: Urie Bronfenbrenner, an internationally renowned psychologist and authority on child development who in the mid-1960's helped found the federal Head Start program, which aids poor preschool children and their families, died on Sunday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Nestl surprises with new finance chief and a fund
Clarence Norman Is Guilty of Illegal Campaign Contributions
description: Clarence Norman Jr., the leader of one of the largest Democratic party organizations in the nation, was found guilty today of soliciting illegal campaign contributions, representing a stark fall from grace for the son of a prominent Brooklyn minister who grew up to practice law and become the ultimate insider in New York's political system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONARD, JOSEPH W.
description: LEONARD--Joseph W., 83. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, friend, died peacefully on September 26. Private gathering to be held. Donations may be made to Dept. Anat. Sci. at SUNY Stonybrook, LI 516444-3111. Please mention in memory of Joseph Leonard.

title: In Louisville, a Measured Police Response
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. - Shadowy figures slip in and out of dark alleys for blocks around Eastern Star Baptist Church in this city's crime-weary West End, brazenly offering to sell drugs or confronting those who scurry past.

title: Germany's electoral drama: Replies to reader questions
Trusts like the Senate leader's can't be truly 'blind'
At the Vatican, Exceptions Make the Rule
description: Rome - THE forthcoming Vatican document on gays in seminaries will unleash a wrenching debate about Catholicism and homosexuality, but one thing it is certain not to mean is that in the future there will be no gays in the priesthood. The continued presence of gays in the priesthood will be the product not just of difficulties in enforcement, or the dishonesty of potential candidates, but also of design.

title: Portrait of Mississippi Victims: Safety of Home Was a Mirage
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 23 - Most of the victims were in their 60's or older. Nearly all drowned. Their bodies were found inside or just outside their destroyed houses.

title: Al Qaeda aide killed in Iraq, U.S says
A Little Clock Mismanagement: Mix-Up Added Time in Pittsburgh
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers must have felt as if their 23-20 loss at home to the New England Patriots on Sunday went on forever. They were almost right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLESINGER, RUTH AINSLIE
description: SCHLESINGER--Ruth Ainslie. The officers, Board and staff of the YWCA of the City of New York express great sadness at the loss of Ruth Ainslie, Board Member and ardent supporter of YW programs. Her interest and involvement with our girls' and women's programs invigorated the staff and opened new doors for the YW. Her wise, calm perspective was always valued; she will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to her husband, children, and her many friends. YWCA-NYC Grace Richardson President, Board of Directors Constance A. Tate Board Chair Rennie Roberts Chief Executive Officer

title: European mutual fund fees are double those in U.S.
Mets Frustrate Another East Rival
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 - As dim as the Mets' postseason chances have looked over the last two weeks, Manager Willie Randolph has still acted as if they had a shot. A small one, he conceded, but a shot.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 19 about refugees in a camp in Romania who fled Uzbekistan after it put down an uprising in the city of Andijon misstated a conclusion by Human Rights Watch. Its report quoted a former detainee who said police officials had told him that the government detained 4,200 people after the episode, and the report said it was reasonable to assume that the number of detainees may have reached into the thousands. The report did not conclude, however, that 4,500 survivors and their relatives had been arrested.

title: A New Russia Leaves the Old in the Dust
description: MOSCOW - Emilie Souptel keeps the door to her restaurant locked and, lifting a small lace curtain to peer out, will not open it to anyone who frightens her.

title: Making Music, Quite Literally, With Their Feet
description: The first clue that Natya Dance Theater was ready to take the stage at Peter Norton Symphony Space on Saturday night was not the sight of dancers wrapped in saris, but the luminous tinkling of bells. While it sounded as though a pack of reindeer were primed to bound up the aisles with a sleigh in tow, the truth was that the nine female dancers of the troupe, which specializes in the bharata natyam form, had strapped bells -- called shalangai -- to their ankles and were ready to make music with their feet.

title: Ex-Schools Chief Pleads Guilty to Huge Theft
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., Sept. 26 - The former Roslyn schools superintendent, a once-revered figure whose academic credentials and contacts with Ivy League admissions offices seemed to make him the ideal guardian of a wealthy district's aspirations for its children, pleaded guilty on Monday to stealing $2 million from the school system over six years.

title: Which of These Foods Will Stop Cancer? (Not So Fast)
description: Correction Appended

title: No Toe Shoes but, Yes, Goofy Innocence and Rigorous Sensuality
description: By now, everyone who is interested in dance or even mildly curious about dance knows the drill: six evenings, five companies or artists per evening, $10 a ticket anywhere in the 2,750-seat City Center. It's Fall for Dance, which made a big splash in its debut run last year and now seems to have become something of a marker at the outset of a new season of dance.

title: Amro in Deal to Control Italian Bank
description: MILAN, Sept. 26 - ABN Amro, the largest bank in the Netherlands, succeeded Monday in prying open Italy's almost impervious banking market with an agreement to buy 39 percent of Antonveneta, a midsize bank in northeastern Italy, for 3.2 billion euros ($3.86 billion).

title: Today's Home Page Images
description: Photographs from today's home page of NYTimes.com.

title: It Might Come in Handy
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Optimism in Tough Times
description: Question from David O. Levine, Lebanon, N.J.: Its a rough day in the news. There have been a lot of them lately. Today: the photo of the busload of seniors being incinerated, shown on the front page of The Times and The Post, the levee bursting in New Orleans again, our dithering, corrupt, incurious president. And of course, theres much more. So tell me please, on the BAD days, where do you look for inspiration and to see that its all going to be O.K.?

title: Sharons Political Capital
description: Question from Jason L. Gravitch, Simsbury, Conn.: Aside from Ariel Sharon, is there any other politician in Israel with the political leverage or ability to execute a further withdrawal from West Bank settlements? I am aware of his plans to hold on to the largest population centers, but as for the others scattered throughout the West Bank they must hold many times the magnitude of people involved in the Gaza evacuation. Is it your opinion that Sharon possesses the political capital to carry out this evacuation as well? And in this age where Sharon is the last living giant of Zionism (Ben Gurion, Begin, Meir, Dayan, etc.), is there anybody else in the political landscape who commands the respect and trust that Sharon can?

title: When Music Drives Home Words of Protest
description: The PBS documentary "Get Up, Stand Up" replays the history of protest songs as delicately as it can, without favoring the protestors or those whom they opposed. But slowly and methodically, the show, ably narrated by Public Enemy's Chuck D, explains how these voices shaped American attitudes about race, sex and the rights of individuals.

title: On the Case, a Crack Team of Tic-Ridden F.B.I. Agents
description: As the pop-culture fascination with serial killers has grown, audiences have learned to pick up telltale signs: friendlessness, shiftiness, cruelty to animals at a young age. Then there are the damaged detectives, whose flaws help them solve crimes, like Clarice Starling, with her morbid anxiety in "The Silence of the Lambs," or Monk, with his obsessive-compulsive disorder. "Criminal Minds" goes further, and displays a host of tics and quirks of murderers and capturers alike.

title: Mr. President, Conservation Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Narrowly Avoids a Water Crisis
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 27 - In what officials called Houston's own "Apollo 13" brush with disaster, hundreds of thousands of area residents and area oil refineries and chemical plants came within two days of running out of water after Hurricane Rita disrupted power to a pumping plant.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ferry Company Plans Fare Increase
description: Higher fuel prices are pushing up fares on some New York Waterway ferry routes between New Jersey and New York. Port Imperial Ferry Corporation said that starting Monday, it would raise fares by 25 cents, to $5.75 each way, between Weehawken or the north end of Hoboken and the dock at West 38th Street in Manhattan, while a trip from Weehawken to the World Financial Center or Pier 11 in Lower Manhattan will be $7.75. The increase will not apply to Waterway's commuter routes that start or end at the south end of Hoboken or in Jersey City. Those routes are controlled by the BillyBey Ferry Company. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Rice Visits To Support Elections
description: Under extraordinary security precautions, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urged Haitians to vote in the first elections since Jean-Bertrand Aristide was ousted last year and spirited into exile on an American military jet. She also warned the interim government that the elections for president and Parliament on Nov. 20 "must be open and inclusive and fair." The Bush administration has invested heavily -- but cautiously -- in the Haiti elections, committing $400 million to the country since last summer.

title: Old, Hurt, Mediocre and in Contention
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 27 - San Francisco Giants Manager Felipe Alou tells a story about a track meet he attended 50 years ago in Mexico City that somehow pertains to this season's so-called race in the National League West.

title: Officer Criticizes Detainee Abuse Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - An Army captain who reported new allegations of detainee abuse in Iraq said Tuesday that Army investigators seemed more concerned about tracking down young soldiers who reported misconduct than in following up the accusations and investigating whether higher-ranking officers knew of the abuses.

title: G.M. and Canadian Union Reach a Deal
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 27 - General Motors of Canada and the Canadian Auto Workers reached a three-year contract late Tuesday, narrowly avoiding a strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORCORAN, JOHN W.
description: CORCORAN--John W. Of NYC, Rye and Windham, NY. On September 25. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Elise Dobi, Laura, Sanford and Pamela Corcoran. Cherished grandfather of five loving grandchildren. Former Vice-Chairman of Donaldson Lufkin and Jenrette. A graduate of Dartmouth College and Harvard Business School. Family will receive friends Wednesday 79 PM and Thursday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 65 East 89th St. Interment to follow at the N. Hardyston Cemetery, Hardyston, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to Spence Chapin Services, Attn: Linda J. Wright, 6 E. 94th St., NY, NY 10128.

title: Legendary Monster of theDeep Is Captured on Film
description: For decades, scientists and sea explorers have mounted costly expeditions to hunt down and photograph the giant squid, a legendary monster with eyes the size of dinner plates and a nightmarish tangle of tentacles lined with long rows of sucker pads.

title: Kentucky Annexes Canada, And Minds Its Manners
description: Phillips Union Whiskey might be just a trifle too easy to drink. By blending Kentucky bourbon and smooth Canadian whiskeys, Dean Phillips, the president of Phillips Distilling, a family company in Minneapolis, has tamed the muscular richness of the bourbon. The combination trades well-defined character for extremely pleasant 80-proof appeal, straight up in a snifter or on the rocks. But the cloying vanilla and cherry versions are suitable only for afternoon tea. Phillips Union Whiskey is $24 to $30 for 750 milliliters at 67 Wine and Spirits, Astor Wine and Spirits, New York Wine Exchange and Cabrini Wines. FOOD STUFF

title: Income Down From 1999, Tax Data Show
description: The total income of Americans in 2003, adjusted for inflation, was 4 percent smaller than in 1999, new tax return data showed yesterday.

title: Iran Issues a Counterthreat
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 27 - Iran warned Tuesday for the first time that it might retaliate economically against countries that back a resolution calling on the Security Council to punish Iran for its nuclear enrichment activities.

title: Cleveland Pulls Back From the Edge
description: Correction Appended

title: Baseball Union Comes a Long Way
description: HAS the Baseball Hall of Fame requisitioned Rafael Palmeiro's earplugs? These artifacts belong in a prominent showcase at the Hall as the best example that baseball is finally getting serious about drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORN, GORDON N.
description: KORN--Gordon N., CPA, died at his home in Riverhead, NY. He was sixty-eight years old. Mr. Korn was a former Senior Partner of the accounting firms M.R. Weiser of Lake Success, NY and Lopez, Edwards, Frank & Company. He was a member of the New York State Society of CPA's and the AICPA. During this time, he lectured his peers on his expertise in stock brokerage accounting. He obtained his degree in accounting from Brooklyn College and was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School in New York City. He served in the Army in the late 1950's and was stationed in the United States. He is survived by his wife, Brenda, whom he married in 1958, his sons, Lawrence and Jeffrey, and his grandchildren, Elana, and Alexander.

title: Gunfire Exchanged After Attempted Robbery of East Side Watch Store
description: Two men tried to rob a watch store at East 56th Street and Second Avenue yesterday afternoon, then traded gunfire with police officers before escaping down the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in a pickup truck, the police said.

title: An arts center almost as flexible as the man for which it's named
Despite the celebrity flash, a quiet gracefulness emerges
Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about President Bush's call for greater energy conservation referred incorrectly to the administration's efforts regarding higher fuel economy standards for automakers. While the standards for cars have stayed the same, the administration has indeed raised one standard - the one for light trucks, which covers sport utility vehicles, vans and pickups - to 22.2 miles a gallon in 2007 models from 20.7 in 2004 models. It has also proposed increases that the White House expects to raise the standard to 24 miles a gallon for 2011 models of light trucks. (Go to Article)

title: Blair Tells His Party He Will Keep Troops in Iraq
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 27 - In a keynote speech intended to reinforce his political dominance, a pugnacious Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged Tuesday to keep British troops in Iraq and to "remain the strongest ally of the United States."

title: 2 Plead Guilty In Child's Death In New Jersey
description: NEWARK, Sept. 27 - It was one of New Jersey's most gruesome child abuse cases, a 7-year-old boy's mummified body stuffed into a plastic container only a few feet from where his two starving brothers were kept in a locked basement with a bucket for a toilet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about allegations of detainee abuse by soldiers near Falluja, Iraq, misstated the designation of the military unit that is the focus of a report by Human Rights Watch and the subject of an Army criminal investigation. It is the First Battalion, 504th Parachute Infantry, of the 82nd Airborne Division -- not the First Brigade.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wards Island: Man Killed In Homeless Shelter
description: A 45-year-old resident of a homeless shelter on Wards Island stabbed a fellow shelter resident to death yesterday morning, the police said. The victim, who was not identified, died of his wounds at Harlem Hospital Center. Andre Miller was arrested in connection with the stabbing, which occurred shortly before 7 a.m. at the 953-bed Charles Gay Center. A knife, which apparently passed unnoticed through metal detectors at the entrances, was recovered at the scene, a Department of Homeless Services official said. The official said Mr. Miller spent a few nights in the shelter every month and had a history of drug use. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (9) VERONICA MARS -- Season premiere. Having determined last season who murdered her best friend, Veronica (Kristen Bell, right) tries to get out of the part-time private eye business and become just another ordinary high school student. Then her pal Wallace (Percy Daggs III) is thrown off the basketball team because of a positive drug test. And he swears he hasn't used any drugs.

title: Israeli Military Launches Strikes on Targets in Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 - Israel launched renewed airstrikes in the Gaza Strip today, while the Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas announced plans to meet President Bush next month in a hopes of calming tensions in the Mideast.

title: Symptoms of Withdrawal: A Memoir of Snapshots and Redemption
Israel and Arabs Exchange Fire in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 - The Israeli Air Force and Palestinian factions again exchanged fire in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday. Palestinian groups made a joint pledge to halt their attacks, but the Israeli defense minister, Shaul Mofaz, dismissed the announcement. He said Israel was not prepared to call off an offensive begun in response to Palestinian rocket fire from Gaza since Friday.

title: Wilkens Denies He Was Asked to Go
description: Lenny Wilkens appeared taut as he departed the Knicks eight months ago, dressed somberly in a dark blue suit and reading awkwardly from a prepared statement intended to mask his frustration.

title: Pataki Bars Museum From World Trade Center Memorial Site
description: After a summer of furious and steadily rising criticism, Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that he was evicting the proposed International Freedom Center museum from its place next to the World Trade Center memorial site. With that, the center declared itself to be out of business.

title: Israel fires missiles into Gaza for the 4th day
The Little Engine That Could
description: ATLANTA - WE'VE learned a lot about evacuating cities in recent days, much of it deeply troubling. But if the failures of New Orleans and the gridlock of Houston show anything, it's that we urgently need a third way out of cities, something other than flying or driving. Fortunately, there is such a way: passenger rail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OJEDA, RIOS, FILIBERTO
description: OJEDA-RIOS--Filiberto, 72. Shot to death by FBI on September 23, 2005. Puerto Rican patriot, freedom fighter, musician, cook, and friend. "It's the life of a rebel that he chose to live, it's the death of a rebel that he died." Todo Boricua Machetero! Un abrazo. Ron Kuby and Marilyn Vasta

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about executives' public speaking at conventions gave a misspelled surname in some copies for an adviser at the Vistance Group, who commented on a slowdown in the activity. He is Ed Trissel, not Trissell.

title: Keith Jarrett: Alone Again (Naturally)
description: No living jazz pianist has wrung more drama from the solo recital than Keith Jarrett. His vaulting, improvised concerts -- melodic marathons, gleaming with significance -- brought him international acclaim in the 1970's, along with a sizeable audience. His album "The Kln Concert" (ECM), issued 30 years ago, ranks among the best-selling solo piano recordings of all time.

title: AIDS Drugs for Africa
description: The United States has awarded a $77 million contract to a consortium that will help manage the flow of AIDS drugs to Africa, American aid officials announced yesterday.

title: H&M drops Moss from campaign
Orders for Durable Goods Show Sharp Increase for August
description: Orders for durable goods showed a surprisingly robust recovery in August, the government reported today, with computers and primary metals leading a rise that followed a sharp drop in July.

title: It's Mets, Not Phillies, Who Play as if Their Season Depended on It
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 - If the Houston Astros emerge from the survival-of-the-fittest competition also known as the National League wild-card race, their manager, Phil Garner, should consider sending the Mets some of his playoff share, or, at the very least, some gourmet fruit baskets.

title: Ferguson needs some new silver
Saints Lose Safety to a Torn Rotator Cuff
description: Jay Bellamy, the New Orleans Saints' starting strong safety, will miss the rest of the season with a torn rotator cuff. He had started 115 consecutive games since 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, DANIEL
description: GOLDSTEIN--Daniel. 78 of Boca Raton formerly of Woodmere, died at home on September 26 after a long illness, surrounded by his family. Dan was a devoted husband to Arlene for 42 years and a loving father to Carrie and David Gamsey, Debbie Kahn, Karen and Jeff Miller. He was adored by his grandchildren, Brian, Robyn, Stephanie, Katie and Melanie. Born in the Bronx Dan played football and basketball at City College. He was a champion paddleball player as well as a loyal Giants and Knicks fan. For over 25 years he was general manager of Milton Paper Company. A true and caring friend, he will be missed by all. Services Wednesday 11am at "Boulevard-Riverside", 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Greece may use satellites to monitor home construction, migration
There's more bad news for Kate Moss
Recipe: Killer Kugel
description: Adapted from Tina Wasserman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, FLORENCE
description: HOFFMAN--Florence of Delray Beach, Florida passed away on September 25, 2005 90 years young. Dynamic, creative and full of life even in the most difficult times. Beloved wife of the late Milton for 64 years. Devoted mother of Sue & Lew; Jim & June. Loving grandmother of Billy, John, David, & Michelle and proud great-grandmother of Alexander, Nicholas & Margaux. She will live on with us forever in her beautiful sculpture. Her indomitable spirit, courage and dignity will be remembered always with admiration and love. Private services in Florida.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor And The Freedom Center
description: Saying that the International Freedom Center planned for the World Trade Center site had become "very controversial," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he had instructed his appointees to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board to carefully read the center's new report on how it would operate. "Then we'll discuss it and try to come to some resolution," the mayor said. The center was intended to put 9/11 in the context of the world's history of freedom but it has faced criticism that it would detract from the memorial and deprive the memorial museum of space. Speaking of exhibitions planned for the center, Mr. Bloomberg said, "Some things you might want to put elsewhere." David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: On the Case, a Crack Team of Tic-Ridden F.B.I. Agents
description: As the pop-culture fascination with serial killers has grown, audiences have learned to pick up telltale signs: friendlessness, shiftiness, cruelty to animals at a young age. Then there are the damaged detectives, whose flaws help them solve crimes, like Clarice Starling, with her morbid anxiety in "The Silence of the Lambs," or Monk, with his obsessive-compulsive disorder. "Criminal Minds" goes further, and displays a host of tics and quirks of murderers and capturers alike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VLAMIS, STEVE ''STAMATIS''
description: VLAMIS--Steve "Stamatis" on September 26. Born in Andros, Greece, in the village of Aprovatro, November 2, 1914. He moved to Athens at age 11 to begin his lifetime career in the food business. At 21, he entered the Greek Navy. After his service tour, he joined the Merchant Marine service as Chief Cook. In the late 30's, he debarked his ship in Galveston, Texas, making his way to New York City and his first restaurant job in America. A few years later, while managing an Upper East Side tavern, he met his future wife, Anne Dalechek, whom he married shortly after. They were married 65 years. Together they opened Steve's Restaurant, a luncheonette that became a mainstay in the neighborhood, famous for its home cooking from WWII years until 1988 when Steve retired to spend more time with his family. He also owned Cafe Taurino, a favorite Italian nightspot under the Queensboro Bridge. He was a loyal supporter and parishioner of Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 337 East 74th St, Manhattan, where church services will be held. His greatest gifts to his family was his love of life and learning, his stoicism, his compassionate and forgiving nature, his life-schooled wisdom, and rugged independence. He is survived by his son Anthony, daughter Susan, and grandson Steven Alexander Vlamis. Friends may call Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st St.). Funeral service Thursday, 11AM, Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: Arctic Ice Cap Shrank Sharply This Summer, Experts Say
description: The floating cap of sea ice on the Arctic Ocean shrank this summer to what is probably its smallest size in a century, continuing a trend toward less summer ice that is hard to explain without attributing it in part to human-caused global warming, various experts on the region said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARR, ABBEY KISSEL
description: STARR--Abbey Kissel of Far Hills, NJ, died on Monday September 26, 2005. She was born February 28, 1917 in New York City to William Thorn and Frances Dallet Kissel. Mrs. Starr attended Brearley School in NYC, and was a lifelong resident of Holland Road, Far Hills, NJ. She was a longtime member and Past Chairman of The Clarence Dillon Public Library Board of Trustees. Mrs. Starr was the wife of the late Louis Starr, mother of Frances Starr Todd, and the late Dillwyn Thorn Starr, mother-in-law of Elizabeth Starr, grandmother of Mary Todd Ganzenmuller, Christopher Bray Todd, Christopher Parrish Starr, and Elizabeth Abbey Starr, and sister of William Thorn Kissel, Jr., and the late Peter F.F. Kissel. Memorial service at the Lamington Presbyterian Church, 300 Lamington Road, Bedminster, NJ on Saturday October 1 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Clarence Dillon Public Library, 2336 Lamington Road, Bedminster, NJ 07921, The Raptor Trust, 1390 White Bridge Road, Millington, NJ 07946, or Planned Parenthood, 196 Speedwell Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: 'The Bourgeois Lady Is Finished,' Miuccia Prada Says
description: MILAN, Sept. 27 - Their names might be evergreen, but the talent and faces of Italian fashion are not fresh, and that has become evident as the spring 2006 collections open. Whereas Paris has produced at least half a dozen new names in half a dozen years and in almost as many languages, Italy has managed a scant two -- Marni and Dsquared -- in the 20 years since Dolce & Gabbana disturbed the peace with its Sicilian hussies.

title: Australian Leaders Defend Expanded Antiterror Laws
description: JAKARTA, Sept. 28 - A day after Australia's federal and state leaders called for "draconian" laws to give the police powers to search, arrest and detain terror suspects, officials said the measures were needed because of possible terrorist sleeper cells in the country.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Cleanup Of River
description: A five-year effort to restore the health of a river that flows into Chesapeake Bay has begun, state and federal officials announced. The plan, expected to cost $19.4 million, will focus on the Corsica River, which flows into the bay from Centreville on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, said Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. It will seek to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution, plant underwater grass essential to the waterway's health and restore oyster beds. These steps in turn should result in the river's being removed from the Environmental Protection Agency's list of "impaired-waters," Mr. Ehrlich said.

title: Shop Owners See Where a Storm of Scavenging Left Its Mark
description: Most business owners in the French Quarter of New Orleans were lucky.

title: Texas Tea From a Russian Sea
description: YUZHNO-SAKHALINSK, Russia - Just north of Japan and across the Pacific from California, a long-forbidden Siberian island is about to join the global energy map.

title: DeLay's Remarks
Paid Notice: Deaths   FUTTER, VICTOR
description: FUTTER--Victor. The Board of Trustees and the Bank Street College community join together to express our sorrow at the death of Victor Futter. We extend our sincere sympathy to his daughters, Trustee Deborah Futter and former parent and longtime friend Ellen. Perhap Victor's proudest association with this institution was that of beloved grandfather of School for Children students Quentin and Theodore, and alumnae Anne and Elizabeth. Our hearts go out to the entire Futter family, and we wish them strength in this time of sorrow. Augusta Souza Kappner, President Sue Kaplan, Chair of the Board

title: French police retake ship from unionists
Workhorse reaches a milestone
Corzine No Longer Holds Shares in Goldman Sachs, Adviser Says
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27 - It took Senator Jon S. Corzine two decades to work his way to the top of Goldman Sachs and accumulate company shares that in 2001 were valued at $270 million. But now, all that he has left in the company is -- well, nothing.

title: Israel expands offensive against Palestinian militants
Mr. President, Conservation Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Says Board Effort on Evolution Was Resisted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 27 - Science teachers at the high school in Dover repeatedly resisted the school board's efforts to force them to teach creationism on equal footing with evolution in biology class, according to a former teacher who is among those challenging the board in a landmark trial.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,912 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: 3 Arrested in Killing of Businessman With Whom Abramoff Feuded
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - The police in Fort Lauderdale announced Tuesday that three men had been arrested in the 2001 gangland-style murder of a prominent Florida businessman there, a killing that occurred in the midst of a bitter, well-publicized dispute with the Washington lobbyist Jack Abramoff.

title: With the return of womanliness, fashion begins to grow up
Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Bishop Sued Over Discipline
description: Six conservative Episcopal churches that have clashed with their bishop over his support for gay clergy members sued the bishop in Federal District Court yesterday. The Episcopal bishop of Connecticut, Andrew D. Smith, left, has taken steps toward defrocking one of the churches' rectors and threatened to do the same with the other five after all six stopped paying diocesan dues in protest. The suit charges Bishop Smith and the diocese with violating the churches' leaders' First Amendment rights to religious freedom.

title: Juan Valdez and the Gecko Are Consumer Favorites
description: Four advertising characters and slogans have been named to the Madison Avenue Walk of Fame after a vote by consumers.

title: Nightmare for African Women: Birthing Injury and Little Help
description: KATSINA, Nigeria - Dr. Kees Waaldijk began surgery shortly before 10 a.m. one recent Saturday in a cement-walled operating room in this city near Nigeria's northern border. More than five hours later, orderlies carried the last of four girls to the recovery ward. In the near-90 degree heat, Dr. Waaldijk's light blue surgical garb had turned dark with sweat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMONS, LEO M.
description: SIMONS--Leo M. On September 22, 2005, at age 76. He will be lovingly remembered by wife Nancy (nee Irausquin); children Pamela and Grant; their mother, Sonia Simons; daughter-in-law Sunisa Simons; grandchildren Emily, Nicole, Julia & Scott Simons; sister Lillian Greenberg and brother - in - law William Greenberg; niece Janet Greenberg and nephew Michael Greenberg. He was a mechanical engineer, formerly with Ramseyer and Miller, Inc., and Russell Design Associates. Burial was held on September 25. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Assoc.

title: Dreaming of Bras for the Modern Woman
description: MAIDENFORM ladies are dreaming again.

title: Pringles, Double-Wides and Wal-Mart Gags in Bulk
description: So, how many elastic-lunged, Broadway-caliber divas stuffed into hot pants and heels can you fit into a double-wide trailer, and still have room for the big-screen TV set? The answer's about five, according to "The Great American Trailer Park Musical," the bright but flimsy new show that opened last night at Dodger Stages. That leaves enough room for the La-Z-Boy and a big ol' baritone, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARSHALL, MELVIN
description: MARSHALL--Melvin. March 10, 1922--September 26, 2005. Mel lived his life by offering the benefit of the doubt, he put his wife and children first. He was a man for whom family meant everything and whose life could only be measured as a fabulous success. Noted raconteur, his booming voice and jovial nature were well known and well loved. He will live on in the hearts and memories of his wife Edith & his children Jeremy and Jennifer and Bill and Sabrina, his adored granddaughters Julian & Cameron and beloved grandsons Max and Simon as well as his extensive extended family and friends. A celebration of his life is planned for November. We will be at home for callers Wednesday-Saturday.

title: Steps to Limit Global-Warming Gas
description: Capturing and storing the carbon dioxide generated by power plants and factories could play an important role in limiting global warming caused by humans, says an international climate research group associated with the United Nations.

title: When Music Drives Home Words of Protest
description: The PBS documentary "Get Up, Stand Up" replays the history of protest songs as delicately as it can, without favoring the protestors or those whom they opposed. But slowly and methodically, the show, ably narrated by Public Enemy's Chuck D, explains how these voices shaped American attitudes about race, sex and the rights of individuals.

title: Celebrated Hostage Gave Crystal Meth to Captor
description: Ashley Smith, who was held hostage in her apartment in March by the man now charged with murder in the Atlanta courthouse shootings, was hailed as a hero after she disclosed how she had persuaded her captor to surrender, partly by reading to him from the spiritual best seller "The Purpose-Driven Life."

title: CALENDAR
description: Hurricane Relief

title: Guilty in Murder
description: A Brooklyn man was convicted of murder in the 2003 death of a 19-year-old Fairfield University student.

title: Honoring the Dead at Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: As Natural Gas Prices Rise, So Do the Costs of Things Made of Chemicals
description: In one sense, chemical industry executives should be sighing with relief. Hurricane Katrina damaged some of their plants, but repairs are proceeding quickly. Hurricane Rita left barely a physical mark. For the next few months, orders will drop but, the executives say, demand will probably ratchet up quickly as rebuilding along the Gulf Coast begins.

title: Honoring the Dead at Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

description: A Gratuity Will Be Added To Parties of Four or More

title: Harry Heltzer, 94, Inventor of Reflective Signs, Dies
description: Harry Heltzer, who began at the 3M Company as a $12-a-week manual laborer, invented one of the company's most profitable products and rose to be its top executive, died on Sept. 21 at his home in Lenoir, N.C. He was 94.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Private Gets 3 Years for Iraq Prison Abuse
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 27 - Pfc. Lynndie R. England, a 22-year-old clerk in the Army who was photographed with naked Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison, was sentenced on Tuesday to three years in prison and a dishonorable discharge for her role in the scandal.

title: Jury Finds Brooklyn Man Guilty of Student's Murder
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about a truck accident on Staten Island in which three highway workers were injured misspelled the name of the street where it occurred and the model name of the truck, and misidentified the neighborhood. It was on Slosson Avenue, not Slossan -- in Castleton Corners, not Todt Hill. The truck was a Ford Explorer Sport Trac, not Track.

title: Supreme Court Takes On Spending Limits for Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - The Supreme Court opened a new chapter in the long-running debate over the role of money in politics on Tuesday by agreeing to decide whether Vermont's strict limits on campaign spending and contributions are constitutional.

title: Honoring the Dead at Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Writers Union Fires Its Executive Director
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 - A week after new leaders swept into office at the Writers Guild of America West, promising a more aggressive posture in organizing and negotiating with Hollywood employers, the guild has fired its executive director, saying he had resisted its change of direction.

title: Feting an unsung fashion hero
U.S. Envoy's Message Falls Flat Again, This Time in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 28 - Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes, seeking common ground with leading women's rights advocates in Turkey, was confronted instead today with anguished denunciations of the war in Iraq and what the women said were American efforts to export democracy by force.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Leaders Agree On Antiterror Laws
description: Australia's seven state and territorial premiers agreed to tougher counterterrorism laws sought by Prime Minister John Howard, but only after Mr. Howard agreed to a review of the laws after five years and a "sunset clause" that will have them expire after 10. The laws, which must still be enacted by federal and state parliaments, would allow the authorities to detain terrorist suspects for up to 14 days without charge and give the police greater powers to search people at venues like sporting events.

title: Ever Since A.D. 270, the Need to Get Away From It All
description: ZAFARANA, Egypt - Men have retreated to the desert for centuries in search of God, drawn by the quiet and the isolation, by a feeling of divine presence in the barren landscape.

title: U.S. bank to pursue wealthyJapanese
Antiterror plan on data rejected by EU assembly
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Downtown Alliance Picks Leader
description: The Alliance for Downtown New York yesterday named Eric J. Deutsch, of Brooklyn, as its new president, succeeding Carl Weisbrod. Besides managing the Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District, the city's largest, the president of the alliance often serves as a spokesman and advocate for downtown, which is still recovering from the effects of 9/11. Mr. Deutsch, 38, who has been president and chief executive of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation since 2002, is scheduled to take his new post in November. In July, Mr. Weisbrod became executive vice president of Trinity Church and president of Trinity Real Estate. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Two People Killed in Train-Car Collision in Connecticut
description: A southbound Amtrak high-speed train crashed into a car on the tracks in Waterford, Conn., today, killing a woman and her grandson and seriously injuring her granddaughter, according to a local official, Paul B. Eccard.

title: Soldiers seize ship from striking workers
Paid Notice: Deaths   FARIDANY, NANA
description: FARIDANY--Nana. Died September 23, of cancer. Longtime administrator and spiritual heart of the Carmel Bach Festival. A formidable inquiring intellect, passionate horsewoman, gifted pianist, draftsman and painter, crack gardener and brilliant, loyal, accepting friend. Beloved wife of Lawrence Crapo, daughter of Nancy Morrow, sister of Melissa Lofton, mother of Francesca Faridany and Lucy Faridany, mother-in-law of Stephen Wadsworth Zinsser.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Race For Prosecutor Heats Up
description: The Democratic candidate for Westchester district attorney, Tony Castro, sharply criticized his Republican opponent yesterday over accusations that her husband promised a third-party candidate political favors in exchange for backing out of the race. The allegations against the candidate, Janet DiFiore, came to light on Monday when Anthony J. DeCintio Jr., who is running on the Right to Life ticket, said Mrs. DiFiore's husband expressed concern about her chances against him in the November election and asked him to drop out of the race. Mrs. DiFiore's husband, Dennis Glazer, confirmed that he spoke to a friend who later called Mr. DeCintio and urged him to leave the race, but he denied offering any favors in return, as has Mrs. DiFiore. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Judge John G. Roberts Jr.'s views on libel law attributed a critique of a Supreme Court decision to him erroneously. Mr. Roberts did criticize the decision, New York Times v. Sullivan, in a 1985 memorandum. But a separate unsigned 30-page critique that was among the papers released from his years as a lawyer in the Reagan administration was not his; it was written by Bruce Fein, who was general counsel for the Federal Communications Commission in the Reagan administration. A corrective article appears today, on Page A20.

title: A bustling Warsaw catches up
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Another Killing In Ciudad Jurez
description: The partly clad body of a woman who appeared to have been strangled was found in an old soccer field in Ciudad Jurez, which has been plagued for more than a decade by the unsolved murders of more than 350 women, including at least 90 raped and killed in similar ways.

title: TechBrief: A more mobile Intel
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLESINGER, RUTH AINSLIE
description: SCHLESINGER--Ruth Ainslie. No longer can we enjoy your earthly presence, but your spirit and lively intelligence live on in Erin and Patrick, your best accomplishments. On this your birthday, we celebrate a life well lived and we mourn for you, a wonderful compassionate woman and a loving mother whose life ended too soon. Love, Jean and Ellen

title: Stop and go for Swiss banks in China
Early tally puts rivals of Karzai in the lead
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on Monday about donations by Billy Joel to educational institutions and arts groups misidentified the source of the account. It was PlaybillArts.com, not its affiliated publication Playbill.

title: Overnight, the world was safer
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: In a Mountaintop Vineyard, History and Mystique Reign
description: SARATOGA, Calif. - YOU don't so much drive to Mount Eden Vineyards as hang on for dear life. The narrow dirt road twists through hairpin turns as you ascend the Santa Cruz Mountains, a hilly coastal range that rises above this prosperous Silicon Valley community like islets over an ocean of suburbia.

title: The Scopes Trial, Echoed in Dover, Pa.
description: To the Editor:

title: VW opts for home production
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BlackBerry With Intel Inside
description: Research in Motion said it would use a new chip from Intel for its next generation of BlackBerry wireless e-mail devices and phones. The new chip, code-named Hermon, will use very little power and work on networks using a cellular standard being developed that will offer very-high-speed Internet connections. Some earlier BlackBerry models used Intel processors, but they were modified versions of obsolete personal computer chips. The announcement by Research in Motion, which is based in Waterloo, Ontario, came a day after Palm and Microsoft said they would co-develop the next Treo wireless e-mail device.

title: A raw deal:New York's oysters
14 in a row: Braves win the NL East
Suffolk Requires Big Stores to Help With Health Care
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Sept. 27 - Responding to pressure from unions and their supporters, the Suffolk County Legislature voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to require retailers like Wal-Mart, BJ's Wholesale Club, Target and Kmart to contribute to their nonunionized employees' health insurance. The law is one of the few efforts in the country to impose such workplace rules on the warehouse-style stores.

title: Two-Year-Old Mall Fetches a Premium Price
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 22 - Barely two years after it opened, the Source at White Plains, a gleaming four-story shopping center that cost $96 million to build and is home to Fortunoff, Whole Foods Market and Cheesecake Factory, has been sold.

title: As a Stern Teenager, She's Not Such a Stretch
description: SAN DIEGO - A high school can be like a battlefield, with weapons checked by metal detectors, and no place suggests this more than the set of "Veronica Mars." A few minutes west of downtown, jets from Miramar Air Force Base streak overhead, and the landlord who rents a soundstage to "Mars," a scrappy UPN drama now in its second year, leases out the adjacent property for military maneuvers on arid terrain. Blank rounds pop in the distance.

title: Arts, Briefly; Benefit in Central Park
description: Ivan Neville, Cassandra Wilson, Lou Reed, below, and Laurie Anderson are among more than 20 popular musicians scheduled to perform today at a marathon festival at SummerStage in Central Park to support programs that provide health care for musicians in the New Orleans area. "When you think of New Orleans you think of being at an outdoor music festival like Jazzfest, and SummerStage is sort of our equivalent to that in New York City," said Peter Shapiro, the event's executive producer. Admission is free, with a $25 suggested donation. Doors open at 4 p.m.; the show begins at 5:30 and ends at 10. Other scheduled performers include Allen Toussaint, Dr. John, Drive-By Truckers, Christian McBride, J Mascis, Soulive and Rob Wasserman. SETH SCHIESEL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, BENJAMIN
description: LEVINE--Benjamin, age 92 years, died peacefully September 26. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude. Devoted father of Michele (Dr. Alvin Morrison), Dr. Myron (Suzanne) Levine, and Carol. Loving grandfather of David, Orin, Joanna, Rachel, Joshua and Rebecca. Adored greatgrandfather of Monica, Noah, William, Quinn, Abigail, Jessica and Abraham. Professor Emeritus in Biology at Nassau Community College, Dr. Levine was an accomplished artist and author of "The Universe and You." Longtime resident of Long Beach, NY. Services will be at "Gutterman's," 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, Thursday, 12:15, September 29.

title: How Coke Came to Be Kosher
description: Marcie Cohen Ferris knows about the South of kosher barbecue contests, African-American cooks who can keep kosher and the inventors of recipes like dirty matzoh dressing. As she writes in "Matzoh Ball Gumbo: Culinary Tales of the Jewish South" (University of North Carolina Press, 2005), "Southern and Jewish cultures have mixed at the dinner table for more than four centuries." The book, which goes on sale on Oct. 10, is a blend of research and real people chronicled by Ms. Ferris, who is an American studies professor at the University of North Carolina and associate director of the Carolina Center for Jewish Studies. The tales -- insightful, funny and occasionally heartbreaking -- come complete with recipes, including one for her mother's Rosh Hashana jam cake. But not all the stories concern cooking. Here is an excerpt from the chapter "Too Jewish in Atlanta":

title: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $2.4 million 545 West 45th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues Manhattan

title: Discrimination in Head Start
description: House Republicans have an alarming plan for Head Start, the early childhood program for some of the nation's most impoverished children and their families: They want to give religious groups that sponsor local Head Start programs license to discriminate by not hiring otherwise qualified individuals who do not share a particular religion.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Governor Plans To Head Baptist Center
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee will become director of a planned center for education and public policy at his alma mater, Ouachita Baptist University at Arkadelphia, when he leaves office in January 2007, the university announced. Mr. Huckabee, a Republican, has said he is considering a run for the presidency. As lieutenant governor, Mr. Huckabee became governor upon the resignation, in 1996, of Jim Guy Tucker, who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy in a Whitewater-related trial. Mr. Huckabee, 50, subsequently won two four-year terms as governor but by law cannot seek re-election.

title: A Bloomberg Critic Who Shows Not His Face, but Bush's
description: It happened again yesterday. Someone in a George W. Bush mask, holding a sign and standing by silently at a public appearance by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. This time, the sign said, "Say It Again Mike."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALIK, EDWARD L.
description: KALIK--Edward L., 79, died September 22. The World War II veteran was born and raised in New York. Since 1966, he lived in St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands. He is survived by his wife, Margaret; daughters, Barbara Kalik and Linda Spaisman; sister, Irene Zeidman; stepdaughter Kathy Lindsay; stepson James Curran; grandchildren Amy and Mark Spaisman; step-grandchildren Sean and Ryan Curran; sister-in-law, Joanne Kalik and many other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his brother, Irwin Kalik. Services will be at 2:45 P.M. Friday, September 30 at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, N.J.

title: Leiter May Win Role From Embree
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONARD, JOSEPH W.
description: LEONARD--Joseph W., 83. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, friend, died peacefully on September 26. Private gathering to be held. Donations may be made to Dept. Anat. Sci. at SUNY Stonybrook, LI 516444-3111. Please mention in memory of Joseph Leonard.

title: New Stadium for Giants and Jets Hits Snags
description: The chances of the Giants and the Jets making football history by building a two-team stadium in the Meadowlands dimmed this week, with the teams at odds over everything from the shape of the stadium to the amount of retail space at the proposed complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRINBLAT, MAGDALENE (DALIA ENTIN)
description: GRINBLAT--Magdalene (Dalia Entin). Beloved wife of 67 years of Arthur and cherished aunt of many nieces and nephews, died on September 27 after a short illness. Private funeral.

description: NEW YORK

description: In percent

title: Voluptuary in a Velvet Glove
description: Rarely does anyone see peaches labeled by type: yellow, white, local and doughnut are usually as far as it goes. But the Indian blood peach, a velvet-skinned late-season variety, is worth seeking. Its burgundy flesh, shading to gold, is deeply flavored and juicy.

title: Breakaway Unions Start New Federation
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 - Seven unions founded a new labor federation on Tuesday, creating a rival to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. that promised to unionize hundreds of thousands of workers and to pressure the Democratic Party to pay far more heed to workers' concerns.

title: BT Group takes aim at an Internet phone rival
Interior Secretary Says U.S. Will Push Search for Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said Tuesday that after the two destructive gulf hurricanes that battered the nation's energy heartland, the Bush administration would intensify its push to expand energy development on public lands including the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and in the nation's coastal waters.

title: When Rockers Show Classical Chops
description: With "a Ira," his new opera about the French Revolution, just released on a Sony Classical recording, Roger Waters joins a parade of rock stars who apparently harbor dreams of tuxedos and podiums. Sir Paul McCartney has written a handful of orchestral and choral works, large and small. Stewart Copeland, of the Police, beat Mr. Waters to the punch with his own opera, "Holy Blood and Crescent Moon." Billy Joel has recorded an album's worth of piano pieces, and Elvis Costello, with a ballet behind him, has written an opera as well.

description: Correction Appended
