title: Internet Grows as Factor in Used-Book Business
description: In barely a decade, online booksellers have grown to account for two-thirds of the market for general-interest used books, a trend that calls into question the future of brick-and-mortar stores devoted to used books, according to a study financed by the publishing industry and released yesterday.

title: Time to Pause the Laugh Track
description: LOS ANGELES - Tonight, on a Studio City soundstage here, James Burrows will direct the first episode of the eighth and final season of NBC's "Will & Grace," and to him the whole setup will look a bit like home.

title: Dissecting Two Rebels of the Arts
description: When artists imitate one another, it isn't only the sincerest form of flattery. Nor is imitation necessarily a symptom of a lack of original ideas, though the recent histories of Broadway and Hollywood might lead you to think so. As the Wooster Group demonstrates with wit, warmth, humility and, yes, sincere flattery in "Poor Theater," the troupe's tribute to kindred creative souls, imitation can be a hopeful attempt to crawl into the skin of someone else and see how it fits. This is not, for the record, always a comfortable activity.

title: Star TV buys into network in Indonesia
INSIDE
description: From Gucci, a New Leader's Vision In Milan, Frida Giannini's first major show for Gucci may seem tame after the collections of her predecessor, Tom Ford. But maybe these changes reflect young women's attitudes. A review by Cathy Horyn.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III. (Go to Article)

title: Playing Favorites After Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: In Egyptian desert, cells of earliest monks
Where Nevsky sank the Teutonic invaders
U.S. to Ban Imports of Beluga Caviar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 - The United States Fish and Wildlife Service will begin banning imports of beluga caviar and other beluga products from the Caspian Sea on Friday, after caviar-exporting countries in the region failed to provide details of their plans to conserve the fish, which is listed internationally as a species threatened with extinction.

title: Jets and Giants Near Deal on New Jersey Stadium
description: In a sudden turnabout after weeks of jostling, name-calling and bitterness, the Jets and the Giants were close yesterday to signing a 50-50 partnership agreement to finance and build a football stadium in the Meadowlands, the first of its kind for teams in the National Football League, according to executives involved in the negotiations.

title: Briefly: Landslides and floods leave 57 dead in north
Romance Made Electric; Some Makers Move to Revive Beloved Battery-Run Cars
description: DETROIT, Sept. 28 - Alexandra Paul, a former star of "Baywatch," is not a satisfied General Motors customer -- to put it mildly.

title: Voting, Poverty and ID's
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Bars Freedom Center at Ground Zero
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, NORMAN M.
description: MILLER--Norman M., 80 years old, died on September 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Joyce for 54 years. Devoted father of Ellen and Alan, Mark and Susie, and Sharon and Alan. Doting grandfather of Carly, Jonathan, Branden, Harry, Benjamin and Toby. Services Friday, 11 AM, at "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: The St. Petersburg Philharmonic Opens at Carnegie With Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky
description: At the end of its opulent renovation in 1986, Carnegie Hall asked itself what purpose its main hall and principal artistic asset best served. Would it become a generator, a creator of its own music, or would it be a destination?

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Thursday describing weight-loss drugs, with an article about diet doctors, misidentified the company that is seeking federal approval for over-the-counter sales of Xenical. It is GlaxoSmithKline Consumer Healthcare, a United States marketing partner of Roche, the drug's maker. Roche itself did not apply.

title: Suicide bomber in Kabul kills 9 Afghan soldiers
No Toe Shoes, but Goofy Innocence and Quiet Sensuality
description: By now, everyone who is interested in dance or even mildly curious about dance knows the drill: six evenings, five companies or artists per evening, $10 a ticket anywhere in the 2,750-seat City Center. It's Fall for Dance, which made a big splash in its debut run last year and now seems to have become something of a marker at the outset of a new season of dance.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: German retailers are hit
Guilt by Association
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Brooklyn Bayou
description: TELEVISION executives must be wondering whether reality hasn't eclipsed reality programming. In the aftermath of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, and the epic displacements they caused, episodes of "Survivor" seem superfluous at best.

title: Playing Favorites After Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: EU talks on Turkey threatened by disputes
Roy D. Blunt: Effective Behind the Scenes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - Just after House Republicans elected him their new leader on Wednesday, Representative Roy Blunt, now the second most powerful man in the House, told a story about a carved stone bust he keeps in his office. The statue depicts someone who had been in the Capitol around 1815, Mr. Blunt said, but nobody knows who it is.

title: Senate Roll Call on Roberts Nomination
description: The 78-22 roll call by which the Senate voted to confirm John Roberts as the 17th chief justice of the United States.

title: Comely Lamp Cords
description: Q. I hate plastic lamp cords. Is there an alternative?

title: Ford to Offer Fire Shields For Town Car Limousines
description: DETROIT, Sept. 28 - Ford Motor, acknowledging for a second time that fuel tanks in some of its large sedans pose an increased risk of explosion in rear-end collisions, offered Wednesday to provide protective fire shields to owners of Lincoln Town Car stretch limousines.

title: For Tiny Tasks, Big-League Design
description: CHILDREN need a place to work, too, even if their idea of work involves a flat surface and a purple crayon. This season's assortment of scaled-down tables and chairs includes enough whimsy to spice up any child's room, yet some of the latest children's tables are sleek and simple enough to be used as side tables by adults.

title: A Patchwork Quilt For the Floor
description: Often old rugs that are beyond repair have patches that are still in good condition and begging to be saved. The new Fragments collection of patchwork carpets, like the one below, is a happy solution. ABC Carpet & Home uses segments cut from antique and vintage rugs to make the patchworks. Some are from flat-weave kilims and others are from pile carpets. The patches are chosen based on color rather than pattern and the result is akin to a crazy quilt. The rugs come in many sizes. A 7-by-9-foot rug is $1,999, one 8 by 10 feet is $3,999, and a room-size carpet, 12 by 19 feet, is $9,999. Custom sizes and colors are also available at ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212)473-3000. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: RUGS

title: Kensington Notebook Power Adapter
description: Everyone wants a powerful but light laptop. But no matter how light the laptop, the extra stuff in the computer bag -- CD/DVD drives, a mouse, a U.S.B. hub -- adds ever more to the weight. The most common complaint is about AC adapters, commonly known as bricks, which weigh as much as a pound. But unless something goes wrong with the adapter, most never think about replacing it.

title: BMW Narrows Search To Four Finalists
description: BMW of North America in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., has narrowed to four finalists a review for the BMW national creative account, with spending estimated at $70 million to $80 million. The account had been handled for a decade by Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, which resigned as the review began in June.

title: Yankees-Red Sox Finale: Of Arms and the Date
description: IF the Yankees and the Red Sox go to Sunday to decide the winner of the American League East, the Yankees will win because the Yankees always beat the Red Sox on Oct. 2 when first place is at stake in the final game.

title: Delay Is Indicted in Texas Case and Forfeits G.O.P. House Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority leader and a driving Republican power in Washington, was forced to step aside from his leadership post on Wednesday after a grand jury in Texas indicted him on a charge of conspiring to violate election laws in his home state.

title: When the Water Came in at the Watering Hole
description: GULFPORT, Miss. - Everyone who stayed for Hurricane Katrina has a story, and Johnny Fleming's story begins in a bar. That is not particularly odd in Gulfport. Bible Belt Mississippi, local residents will tell you, stops at Interstate 10.

title: Tips: Buying into golf communities
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8:30 P.M. (4) WILL & GRACE -- Live season premiere. Yes, the producers have decided to start the final season with a live broadcast, in hopes that it will be "electric and angerous," as James Burrows, the episode's director, says. Grace (Debra Messing) is on the verge of having an affair with a married man (Eric Stoltz, above, with Ms. Messing). Will (Eric McCormack), who has just learned that Karen's husband, Stan, is still alive, is working for that mysterious job-finder (Alec Baldwin), who wants Karen (Megan Mullally). And Jack (Sean Hayes), bless his heart, is having fun with his own television talk show.

title: None for Me. I'm Driving.
description: None for Me. I'm Driving.

title: BT strikes at Internet phone rivals
Dutch Railway Apologizes for Deporting Jews
description: The Dutch national railway company apologized for the first time for its role in deporting thousands of Jews to Nazi concentration camps in World War II.

title: Waiting for the Next Generation
description: Waiting for the Next Generation

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: Near Miss for 2 Jets on a Las Vegas Runway
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - An America West passenger jet taking off from Las Vegas missed hitting an Air Canada jet by about 100 feet last Thursday night, according to a preliminary report, because a controller in the tower confused two planes and issued conflicting instructions.

title: For Republicans, a Swelling Sea of Troubles
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - This is not what the Republicans envisioned 11 months ago, when they were returned to office as a powerful one-party government with a big agenda and - it seemed - little to fear from the opposition.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Conviction for Banker's Murder Appealed
description: Nancy Ann Kissel, sentenced to life in prison in Hong Kong after being convicted of murdering her husband, a Merrill Lynch investment banker, lodged an appeal, her lawyer, Simon Clarke, said. Ms. Kissel was found guilty of killing her 40-year-old millionaire husband, Robert P. Kissel, and hiding his body in a roll of carpet in a storeroom in their luxury apartment block. A jury found her guilty of murder on Sept. 1 after a 66-day hearing that captivated Hong Kong's media with tales of drug-taking, violent sex and affairs.

title: A Mogul Who Would Rebuild New Orleans
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 28 - Many of the business elite of New Orleans seem preoccupied these days by what some here simply call The List -- the chosen few Mayor C. Ray Nagin is expected to name on Friday to a commission to advise him on the rebuilding of the stricken city. Almost certain to make the grade is the real estate mogul Joseph C. Canizaro, the man best known for bringing high-rises to the New Orleans skyline.

title: Goods, Yes; Services, Not Necessarily
description: I HAVE spent both the best and the worst shopping days of the last year at Century 21, the celebrated discount department store at the lip of the basin where the World Trade Center once stood. The best was a day in the spring, shopping for everything but women's clothing. The worst was a day in early autumn, shopping for everything, including women's clothing.

title: Kodak Misses Targets but Says Its Digital Moment Will Come
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which has missed its earnings targets for three quarters, said yesterday that earnings were likely to be disappointing for the rest of the year.

title: Palestinians Vote as Offensive Widens in West Bank
description: Palestinians held municipal elections in more than 100 communities in the West Bank, with the contests mainly between candidates linked to the Fatah movement of the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, and those with ties to the Islamist faction Hamas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARISH, JULIAN MD
description: BARISH--Julian MD. Was a Past President of the American Society for Adolescent Psychiatry. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues in the Society. Stephen B. Billick MD, President, ASAP

title: Signs of Hope in Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing Favorites After Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: China's golf empire is a family affair
Endgame Remains Uncertain for Struggling Favre and Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 28 - The tour guide stopped his sightseeing group near the long tunnel leading to Lambeau Field, a few steps from the sign that reads, "Play Like a Champion." While most of the dozen or so people stared at the goal posts and lush grass, two men turned away to gawk at a familiar player with a graying buzz cut and razor stubble, jogging down another tunnel to the Packers' practice facility.

title: Palestinian Leader to Meet Bush on Israeli Strikes
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 - Israel renewed airstrikes in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, while the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, announced plans to meet President Bush next month in hopes of calming tensions.

title: Accounts
description: Perry Ellis International, New York, named Margeotes Fertitta Powell, New York, part of the MDC Corporation, to handle its advertising, which had been handled by Lloyd & Company, New York. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Everything Is Illuminated
description: ALEXANDER LERVIK, a Swede, knows about the gloom of long dark winters. So, as a designer striving to bring light to dim spaces, he has come up with illuminated versions of products that never glowed before: a door handle fitted with a light-emitting diode, or L.E.D., that shines bright red when the door is locked, and an illuminated children's swing.

title: Return to Victorian splendor
Do-It-Yourself Facial Peels
description: Correction Appended

title: Ferrer Focuses on Housing Costs
description: This 30-second commercial is the third English-language advertisement in the general election for Fernando Ferrer, the Democratic nominee for mayor. It will begin running today on broadcast and cable channels, as part of a modest, roughly $130,000 ad campaign for the week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teacher Faces Rape Charge
description: A physical education teacher at a Brooklyn high school was charged with statutory rape yesterday after a student came forward and said she had a sexual relationship with him for two years, the police said. The teacher, Lawrence Major, 45, of Rochdale Village in Springfield Gardens, Queens, taught at Paul Robeson High School in Weeksville, the police said. The police said the sexual relationship with the student, now 16, began in 2002, when she was 14. Mr. Major will not be allowed to be return to work while the case is pending, said Kelly Devers, a Department of Education spokeswoman.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Disturbed Tops Bon Jovi
description: For the second week in a row, seven new albums have entered the Billboard top 10, according to Nielsen's SoundScan. The rock band Disturbed grabbed the No.1 spot, selling 239,000 copies of "Ten Thousand Fists" (Warner Brothers), left, its second chart topper after the 2002 platinum "Believe." Bon Jovi made its debut at No.2 with 202,000 copies sold of it ninth album, "Have A Nice Day" (Island), pushing Kanye West to No.3 with "Late Registration" (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam). "So Amazing: An All Star Tribute to Luther Vandross" (J Records), featuring Stevie Wonder, Usher, Fantasia and others came in at No.4, and Barbra Streisand had the 28th top-10 album of her career with the Barry Gibb collaboration "Guilty Pleasures" (Columbia), in at No.5. Last week's No.1, Paul Wall's "People's Champ" (SwishaHouse/Asylum), fell to No.9, suffering a 60 percent slide in sales. GRANT JAMES VARJAS

title: Agency Takes a Preliminary Step to Revoke a Genentech Patent
description: The Patent and Trademark Office has taken a step toward revoking a Genentech patent that was expected to bring hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties each year until 2018.

title: Turkish Women, Too, Have Words With U.S. Envoy (on Iraq War)
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 28 - Under Secretary of State Karen P. Hughes, seeking common ground with leading women's rights advocates in Turkey, was confronted instead on Wednesday with anguished denunciations of the war in Iraq and what the women said were American efforts to export democracy by force.

title: Out of Africa: Modern Wares With Echoes of Colonial Days
description: Now that Hollywood is treating Africa like a big discovery, stores seem to be turning there, too. The Cane chair, made in Malawi of bamboo and reed, right, and the steel Profile Cut table from Cape Town, above, are part of an African collection at the Conran Shop assembled by its creative director, Polly Dickens. "They're not fussy, and although they have an African feel they're not crafty or brown bread," she said, describing the chair ($450) as refined yet comfortable and the table ($3,950) as straddling two worlds because the steel is cut with a laser. The table is good for a nomad, she said, because it comes packed flat. A strong nomad: it takes four people to lift it. The Conran Shop is at 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (212)755-9079; www.conran.com. DEBORAH BALDWIN CURRENTS: FURNITURE

title: Some Comic Romantic Antics of the Backstage Variety
description: Go figure. "In the Wings," a new comedy by Stewart F. Lane at the Promenade Theater, has enough clichs in it to drown the best actor. Yet Marilyn Sokol, portraying the biggest clich of them all, the meddling Jewish mother, manages to draw genuine laughs, and lots of them. She's not around long enough to salvage the proceedings, but the skill is something to admire.

title: The Designated Hitter
description: In 1989, a young Republican congressman named Tom DeLay dreamed of climbing to a position of power in the House of Representatives. He hitched his wagon to Ed Madigan, who was running to be party whip. But another ambitious young Republican, Newt Gingrich, stood in the way. DeLay ran Madigan's campaign and Gingrich ran his own, and the contest was so brutal that after Gingrich won, DeLay and Gingrich reportedly didn't speak for two years.

title: Roundup: Celta Vigo player banned for doping
Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: In Scotland, a golfer's paradise
Fresh Help With Cool-Weather Plantings
description: Salvias, butterfly bushes and deer-resistant epimediums are just a few of the stars at the Home Garden Center, which opens tomorrow at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. On weekends, Sonia Uyterhoeven, the gardener for public programs (inset, on right), and other experts will be on hand to answer questions from visitors. The sessions, covering garden design, holiday decorations and everything in between, will continue indefinitely, said Todd Forrest, the associate vice president for horticulture and living collections at the garden, remaining outdoors "unless it's brutally cold." The center has two acres of display gardens packed with fall-blooming perennials like Winston Churchill, a compact red aster, above right, and Heavy Metal, an upright blue switch grass (shown near the gazebo). Deep winter will bring out fragrant witch hazels and daphnes. Information: (718)817-8700 or nybg.org. ANNE RAVER CURRENTS: GARDENS

title: Currencies: Dollar's climb ends amid profit-taking
Jailed Pedophile Guilty in 1998 Murder of Boy, 12
description: A man described as a classic sexual predator who is already serving time for sexually abusing a dozen teenage boys was found guilty yesterday of the kidnapping and murder of a 12-year-old Yonkers boy found buried in a shallow grave in Dobbs Ferry more than six years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed In Robbery
description: A man fired two shots into a parked car during a robbery attempt yesterday in Bensonhurst, the police said, accidentally killing his accomplice, who was standing outside the passenger side, and injuring a man in the driver's seat. The accomplice, Gregory Dorismond, 24, was fatally shot in the chest about 1:45 a.m., the police said. The man in the driver's seat, Azmat Mushtaq, 19, was taken to Lutheran Medical Center, where he was listed in critical condition with a gunshot wound to the head, the police said. Mr. Mushtaq and a 20-year-old passenger, whom the police did not identify, had picked up two women nearby and driven to 2045 84th Street, where the shooting occurred, the police said. The police were trying to learn if the women had helped set up the two men. The gunman escaped. Fernanda Santos (NYT)

title: After the Love Is Gone
description: I broke up with Bill a long time ago. It's always hard to remember love -- years pass and you say to yourself, was I really in love or was I just kidding myself? Was I really in love or was I just pretending he was the man of my dreams? Was I really in love or was I just desperate? But when it came to Bill, I'm pretty sure it was the real deal. I loved the guy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLESINGER, RUTH AINSLIE
description: SCHLESINGER--Ruth Ainslie. Our dearest friend who was taken so quickly. The twinkle in her eye and smile on her face said it all. If only we could give you a "mulligan" to keep you here. You will be in our hearts and minds forever. With love, Diane and Arthur

title: First, Birds. Then Stars?
description: To the Editor:

title: Locking in That Shaven (or Unshaven) Look
description: THE two-day beard is a modern classic. Both virile and casual, it bespeaks a man who needn't bother to shave every day.

title: Finland Again Ranks First Among Global Competitors
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28 - Nordic countries remain more competitive than those of any other region, while Japan and the major economies of Europe have become less so, the World Economic Forum said Wednesday in its annual study.

title: Indonesian Risks Fury by Cutting Subsidy on Fuel
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 27 - President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono of Indonesia is frequently portrayed as cautious and indecisive. But near the end of his first year in office, his government is cutting fuel subsidies, a politically perilous step certain to bring street demonstrations and give ammunition to his political opponents.

title: Irish Eyes Are Burning Bright, Irish Feet Are Stepping Light
description: Leather pants, chesty blondes, flag-waving bravado. "Celtic Tiger" is almost entirely a vehicle for Michael Flatley's ego. Depending on your feelings toward Mr. Flatley, the Lord of the Dance, this is very good or very bad.

title: Judges Frees Man Jailed for '86 Murder, Citing Ex-Officer's Misconduct
description: It seemed bad enough when Louis J. Eppolito, a highly decorated former New York City detective, was indicted in March on charges of being a killer on the payroll of the Lucchese crime family.

title: Nordic countries top competitiveness ranking
Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, DANIEL
description: GOLDSTEIN--Daniel. Rest in peace dear friend. We will never forget you. All our love to Arlene and family. Silvia and Marvin

title: California Wildfires Spread to 17,000 Acres
description: OAK PARK, Calif., Sept. 29 - More than 3,000 firefighters from throughout California battled a 17,000-acre wildfire along the borders of Los Angeles and Ventura Counties today, aided by calm winds and moderate temperatures.

title: If It's Fall, Why Can't I Wear My Boots?
description: KIDS are back in school, the last of the ross have left the table, and Starbucks is offering lattes spiced with pumpkin flavoring, but for much of the Northeast, it just doesn't feel like fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an arts symposium in which Justice Antonin Scalia defended the government's right to deny funds for art of which it disapproves referred incorrectly to a debated grant by the National Endowment for the Arts. It was given to the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia for a traveling exhibit of the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe, not to Mapplethorpe himself.

title: Playing Favorites After Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Tested Campaign Tool Led to Conspiracy Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - The indictment of Representative Tom DeLay on Wednesday put the Republican National Committee in an uncomfortable spotlight, saying a top political aide to President Bush was the funnel through which $190,000 in improper donations passed in 2002.

title: TechBrief: U.S. debut delayed for HD-DVDs
Top Officials Told to Testify in Muslims' Suit
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that former Attorney General John Ashcroft, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other top government officials will have to answer questions under oath in a lawsuit that accuses them of personally conspiring to violate the rights of Muslim immigrants held in a federal detention center in Brooklyn after 9/11.

title: Photoshop Elements 4.0
description: Photoshop Elements 4.0 hit the shelves this week with a score of improvements, including some that make it easier to find pictures of people you want and easier to edit out people you don't.

title: Doggedly Slipping Into Jeans as a Microphone Scrapes
description: Take a girl and her microphones, drop her into a handsome industrial space with a few friends and you have DD Dorvillier's enchanting new "No Change or 'freedom is a psycho-kinetic skill,"' which opened on Tuesday night at Context Studios, presented by her Human Future Dance Corps. It doesn't hurt that Ms. Dorvillier, who sprang like an exotic little weed from the hard pavement of New York's downtown dance scene in the 1990's, has a wonderfully unruly imagination and a sly sense of humor.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Two Killed In Shooting
description: Two people were killed and one person was seriously injured in a shooting yesterday at a Newark social club, the police said. The shooting occurred shortly after 2 a.m. at the SJMJ Democratic Social Club on Avon Avenue, said Detective Todd McClendon. Two of the victims, Jessie Young, 44, and Cynthia Corbett, 46, both of Newark, were pronounced dead at the scene. A third person, Yusef Muhammad, 45, also of Newark, was shot once in the head and was listed in critical condition at University Hospital, Detective McClendon said. The police said the shooting appeared to have followed a dispute over money. John Holl (NYT)

title: Taking Witness Stand Seen as Brooklyn Leader's Slip
description: Wearing one of his tailored dark suits with a yellow patterned tie, Clarence Norman Jr., the boss of the Brooklyn Democratic Party organization, took the witness stand before his case went to the jury on Monday.

title: New York and Milan
description: AS if the scent of sugary cupcakes wafting from Magnolia Bakery in the West Village were not sweet enough, perfumer Bond No. 9 will open next door to the bakery tomorrow. The new shop (below) will be the company's fourth perfumery in Manhattan. As at the other stores, customers will be able to choose among 25 scents or mix blends of their own. The newest scent, a unisex eau de parfum aptly named Bleecker, will not be available until Nov. 1. But there is another reason to visit the store tomorrow: the first 100 customers will receive free Magnolia cupcakes. At 399 Bleecker Street, (212)633-1641.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASKAWY, THELMA
description: LASKAWY--Thelma. On September 25, 2005, at age 87. She is survived by her beloved husband, Benjamin; cherished son, Philip; loving daughter-in-law, Patricia; grandsons, Michael and Thomas; and great grandsons, Kieran and Eli. Services will be private.

title: Michael Crichton, Novelist, Becomes Senate Witness
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - His last book, "State of Fear," was published more than nine months ago, but the reviews were still pouring in on Wednesday, even as Michael Crichton folded his 6-foot-9-inch frame into a seat to testify before the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works.

title: Koizumi's new party
Roberts overwhelmingly approved as U.S. chief justice
Briefs: No military action against Iran, Straw says
Big Hands on the Little Hands
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Sept. 23 - The little-old-watchmaker-guy stereotype is wrong on three counts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: The Night Life of Bees
description: THERE are 18 precious days until the spelling bee final, and Josh Malamy will not waste a single one. He is boning up on Latin and Greek roots and studying the 794 pages of Scripps National Spelling Bee word lists on Spellingbee.com. Among the obscure words he recently memorized were "chrysochlorous" (a greenish-gold color) and "choumoellier" (an Australian vegetable). He is reluctant to share another for fear of giving his competitors an edge.

title: 'Will & Grace' Goes Live, And So Does a Commercial
description: A commercial offering a humorous salute to the pitfalls of live television is scheduled to raise the curtain tonight on the first live episode of the sitcom "Will & Grace" on NBC.

title: Natural Gas Prices Set Record, Pointing to Costly Winter
description: Natural gas prices set a new record today, presaging higher heating bills for a majority of Americans this winter as well as soaring costs for industrial manufacturers of such products as plastics and chemicals.

title: Cycling: Young American dreams of European success
Defying Terror, Filmgoers Attend a Festival in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 28 - In what was perhaps as much an act of defiance as a leisurely way of spending an afternoon, more than 300 Iraqis walked into a theater this past Saturday, and without metal detectors or security guards, sat down and watched a movie.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Hacker Sees University Records
description: The University of Georgia is advising more than 2,400 current and former employees that a hacker might have gained access to their names and Social Security numbers through an unprotected computer server, the university said. Last year, a hacker gained access to credit card information of 32,000 students there. The authorities say they are not aware of any misuse of that information.

title: Carlyle sees opportunity in 'big, fat' German firms
Youthful Sound From Young Interpreters
description: As part of its celebration of its 45th season, Young Concert Artists has decided to freshen up its image by moving from its longtime home, the 92nd Street Y, to the bright new Zankel Hall. It may be a savvy change. The audience on Tuesday evening at the season-opening performance, by the Jupiter String Quartet, seemed younger than Young Concert Artists audiences at the Y tended to be, and the hall looked nearly sold out. But Zankel's rental fees are considerably higher, and corners must be cut: when Susan Wadsworth, the organization's founder and director, spoke from the stage before the performance, she said she was saving $3,000 by not using a microphone.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Rams Respect Struggling Giants' Defense
description: The Giants' defense, thoroughly embarrassed on national television four days ago, is still licking its wounds. The healing process, ideally, would include an opponent Sunday that was flat-footed and needed a compass to locate the end zone.

title: A Faustian bargain for 'Cold Blood'
Umpire Revels in the Calls, and in Getting Them Right
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 - On Monday night at Camden Yards, Bruce Froemming, baseball's senior umpire, was at third base for a game that was delayed nearly two hours by rain, not to mention by Oriole pitchers who walked 10 Yankees. It plodded along and ended after midnight.

title: A Normal Political Crisis in an Abnormal Country
description: ROME, Sept. 28 - Pretty much every adult Italian has now called for Antonio Fazio to step down as governor of the Bank of Italy. Yet he has glued himself to his chair, despite pleas from the prime minister on down, despite setting off another crisis for a wobbly government, despite comments on the issue from a leading opposition politician that invariably begin, "In a normal country ."

title: A New Shop for Those Whose Taste Runs to Tenement Style
description: At the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, top left, recreated rooms poignantly depict the living conditions of struggling immigrant families from the 1860's through the 1930's. Now visitors can buy period antiques and collectibles in the museum's renovated shop, Recollections, which opens today. The merchandise -- rounded up at auctions, antiques fairs and estate sales, and from donors -- includes some items from the 1940's and 50's and "balances authenticity and salability," said Melanie Stern, the shop director (top, on right). It was gathered with the help of the museum's curator, Pamela Keech (on left). With its pressed tin ceiling and reproduction 1920's wallpaper, Recollections sets the mood for such tenement furnishings as a treadle sewing machine in an oak cabinet, made around 1900 ($300), left; old irons ($25 to $75); and Morgantown glass and chrome stemware ($25 each), right. Furnishings from the hardworking kitchens of another time include a vintage oak icebox ($750) and a 1930's Hamilton Beach mixer with two original yellow glass bowls($250). An early 1900's linen tablecloth has an embroidered German inscription, which translates as "only a mother knows what love means" ($200). The shop entrance is at 90 Orchard Street, (212)387-0341. Information on museum tours: tenement.org. ERNEST BECK CURRENTS: MUSEUMS

title: 4 Philippine militants were on bombing mission, officials say
THE GREAT STINK
I.P.O. Lawsuit Reinstated
description: Credit Suisse First Boston, the Goldman Sachs Group, Merrill Lynch & Company and other investment banks must defend a lawsuit claiming they participated in an industrywide scheme to rig initial public offerings, an appeals court said.

title: Bush Reported Near to Nominating Judge
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - President Bush is close to naming a successor to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor and could announce his choice this week, Republicans close to the White House said Wednesday.

title: High Visibility Training
description: AS the days shorten and darkness descends on outdoor workouts, roadside runners, walkers and cyclists are well advised to wear reflective clothing. In the past this meant resorting to neon orange vests or glow-in-the-dark wristbands. But now makers of athletic clothing are working reflective details into their garments, ideally in subtle ways. At night these accents reflect car headlights, improving the visibility of the exercisers in traffic. Yet by day the clothes are not overly flashy. STEFANI JACKENTHAL

title: Fannie Mae Shares Plummet on Reports of New Violations
description: Shares of Fannie Mae, the nation's largest source of money for home loans, tumbled yesterday after Dow Jones said that investigators had found "new and pervasive accounting violations" at the company.

title: Algerians vote in controversial referendum
Taking the Fall for Fashion
description: MILAN - IT is a cautionary fashion fable, told, as it must be, in images, a parable of now you see her, now you don't. Two weeks ago most major fashion magazines carrying advertisements for the new fall accessories from Christian Dior featured a pair of Russian-looking lace-up boots lined with woolly shearling and a matching purse slung over the shoulder of a beautiful woman with wide-set eyes, a leonine blond mane and a look so markedly vacant she seemed lost in, well, let's say reverie.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Catalonia steps up to challenge Spain
Roberts Is Sworn In as Chief Justice of U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - John G. Roberts Jr. was confirmed as the 17th chief justice of the United States today in a formality that intensified speculation over who will be President Bush's next Supreme Court nominee.

title: Students Discover Economics in Its Natural State
description: WHY do the keypad buttons on drive-up cash machines have Braille dots? It is an interesting question, since the patrons of these machines are almost always drivers, none of whom are blind. The answer, according to my former student Bill Tjoa, is that because A.T.M. producers make keypads with Braille dots for their walk-up machines anyway, it is cheaper to make all machines the same way. The alternative, after all, would be to hold two separate inventories and make sure that each machine went to the right destination. If the Braille dots caused trouble for sighted users, the extra expense might be justified. But they do not.

title: Winemaker Open to Bids
description: Vincor International, Canada's biggest wine maker, said yesterday that it would seek other takeover bids after rejecting an unsolicited $900 million buyout offer from a larger rival, Constellation Brands.

title: In a Melting Trend, Less Arctic Ice to Go Around
description: The floating cap of sea ice on the Arctic Ocean shrank this summer to what is probably its smallest size in at least a century of record keeping, continuing a trend toward less summer ice, a team of climate experts reported yesterday.

title: TriBeCa School's Squeaky Wheels Get Some Peace
description: First, plans called for a new apartment building behind Public School 234 in TriBeCa. Then, there were plans for a second, with 162 units, next to it. Parents panicked, saying that the cacophony of construction sounds was going to make thinking, much less learning, impossible inside the school.

title: Suicide Bomber on Motorbike Kills 8 Afghan Soldiers and a Civilian
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 28 - A suicide bomber on a motorbike drove into a convoy of Afghan soldiers boarding minibuses outside their training base on the edge of Kabul on Wednesday afternoon and detonated his explosives, killing 9 people in addition to himself and wounding 28, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Taliban warns of more suicide attacks
Paid Notice: Deaths   ARLT, PAUL T.
description: ARLT--Paul T. The Board and staff of the Public Art Fund note with sadness the death of Paul T. Arlt, father of Ronay Menschel, board member, colleague and friend. We send our condolences to Ronay and the entire family. Susan K. Freedman, President

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Prize for Ann Beattie

title: Military Leaders Bring Mixed Message on Iraq to Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - An array of top American military leaders sought today to reassure Congress about progress in Iraq, but they made clear that American troops could begin withdrawing next year only if the country remained on its democratizing track and Syria and Iran stayed out of their neighbor's affairs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Widow Sues Over Firefighter's Death
description: The widow of a Fire Department lieutenant killed in a fire in January filed a wrongful-death lawsuit in State Supreme Court yesterday, seeking unspecified damages from the city and from the owners of the apartment building where the fire broke out. The widow, Jeanette Meyran, charged that illegal partitions in the building blocked access to a fire escape, and that the Fire Department was liable because at the time of the fire it was no longer supplying firefighters with safety ropes that might have saved the life of her husband, Lt. Curtis W. Meyran. He and another firefighter died when they jumped from fourth-floor windows of the building. The department would not comment on pending litigation.

title: More division on North Korea atomic resolution
Shortcutto China's interior
Playing Favorites After Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LUBIN, CAROL RIEGELMAN
description: LUBIN--Carol Riegelman. A Service in celebration of the life of Carol Riegelman Lubin will be held Sunday, October 2 at 3 PM at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, New York City.

title: Mount Eden, historic but unsung
Soccer: Ronaldinho strikes again for Barcelona
Corrections
description: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day last Thursday about Web sites that provide informal research help misstated the given name of a Google executive commenting on one of them, Google Answers, and a correction in this space on Friday misspelled her surname. She is Marissa Mayer, not Melissa Meyer.

title: Tehran warns of economic retaliation
New Austerity for German Car Industry
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 28 - The German auto industry, saddled with some of the highest labor costs in the world, is embarking on a stringent belt-tightening campaign, prodded by a pair of German ex-colleagues who made their names with an even tougher austerity drive in the United States.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about residential architecture in New Orleans misattributed the phrase "do no harm." It is from Hippocrates' work "Epidemics," not from the Hippocratic oath.

title: A Suspect Is in Stable Condition After the Police Fire 77 Shots
description: Officers fired 77 shots early yesterday at a gunman they were pursuing through two housing projects in East Harlem, the police said. But only three bullets struck him, and he was in stable condition at a hospital last night, they said.

title: U.S. envoy gets earful from Turkish women
Germany edges ever closer to a coalition
Cut-Rate Homes For Middle Class Are Catching On
description: NOVATO, Calif. - Janice Quinci likes nice things: fashionable clothes, dinner out with her husband, a private school for her daughter. With a household income in the six figures, Ms. Quinci can pretty much enjoy it all.

title: Tony Hawk HelmetCam
description: Dude, Tony Hawk wants to skateboard with you -- virtually, that is. With the new Tony Hawk HelmetCam digital camera strapped on, weekend athletes can record their own daring trips down the road or on the piste, and then intercut the images with stock video of the professional skateboarder's daredevil feats that is included with the product.

title: Ex-Chrysler stars lead the attack on German labor costs
A Parmalat trial, but no change to law
After Hurricane Katrina, a Bank Turns to Money Laundering
description: GULFPORT, Miss. - The scene would make a mob boss proud: workers in a windowless hallway scoop armfuls of grimy cash out of plastic garbage bags and sling them into a washing machine. Others fill the dryers and iron the clean bills. Nearby, a half-dozen women count the freshly pressed bills and bundle them into thousand-dollar wads.

title: Commerzbank had flaws in detecting laundering
Leather Jackets for Butterfly Chairs
description: The original butterfly chair was designed in 1938 by Antonio Bonet, Jorge Ferrari-Hardoy and Juan Kurchan, architects in Le Corbusier's office. That chair, with a leather cover, is in the Museum of Modern Art design collection, while mass-market versions, with canvas covers, have become staples of dorm rooms. For those who have outgrown canvas, Precision Leather Crafter in Westbury, N.Y., which also does upholstery and repairs, will make a custom leather cover (from $850); precisionleather.com or (516)997-7000. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?

title: Yanks Count on Wang's Cool Amid Heat
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 - It was 3:30 p.m. Wednesday, and Chien-Ming Wang was already in full uniform. He was one of the first Yankees in the clubhouse, and the Fox network needed him for a promo. It was yet another example of something that seemed implausible six months ago.

title: President? No, thanks. Roberts prefers court
Corrections
description: The About New York column yesterday, about an imagined conversation with God at a Manhattan diner, referred incorrectly to the Bible to which the thickness of the menu was likened. It is the King James Version, not St. James.

title: The Big House Can't Break the Clubhouse
description: SO another political leader has been found guilty of wrongdoing, Clarence Norman Jr. He was convicted in Brooklyn on Tuesday of violating campaign finance laws, which has to have shaken the borough's clubhouse Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: Marlins Have Look of Dead Men Walking to the Finish
description: MIAMI, Sept. 28 - Death did not visit the Florida Marlins suddenly. First there were two weeks when the playoff-contending Marlins collapsed down the stretch. When the end came, it still shocked. The Marlins died young and talented, a team of great potential.

title: Messy Start by Arroyo Leads to Setback for Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28 - Bronson Arroyo knew that he was being removed from the game in the fourth inning after a woeful performance. But Arroyo still slid his right foot across the pitcher's rubber several times to tidy up the area he was vacating. It was the least he could do.

title: So Many Voids and Singletons, and So Many Bidding Options
description: Distributional deals usually generate wild bidding with no one sure who can make what. Then, as advised in this column before, it is normally better to be the declaring side, especially when you have a double fit.

title: Released After 6 Years, Gotti Goes Home Under High Bail
description: John A. Gotti, the Gambino crime family prince who avoided conviction on racketeering charges in a trial that ended last week, left federal prison yesterday on $7 million bail and returned to his spacious Long Island home, where he will be under house arrest awaiting a new trial in February.

title: A Modernist Office Seeks Protectors
description: In Los Angeles, a 1987 office interior by the architect John Lautner, who died in 1994, is threatened with demolition. It has a black slate desk cantilevered from a slate wall, above, and a copper wall, right. Loeb & Loeb, a law firm with three floors in the building (at 10100 Santa Monica Boulevard), takes over the lease today and may gut the office, the only one by Lautner to survive intact, according to Duncan Nicholson, the secretary of the John Lautner Foundation, a preservation group. Members of the Los Angeles Cultural Heritage Commission, which advises the City Council, visited the office last week and will vote Oct. 19 on whether to recommend that the council take up the cause. Other possibilities include auctioning the furnishings or finding a museum to buy them, Mr. Nicholson said. The building's owners and Loeb & Loeb declined comment. ELAINE LOUIE CURRENTS: INTERIORS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Raids Aim At Islamic Radicals
description: The police arrested 38 men suspected of involvement in Islamic extremism in raids across the western state of Hesse. The state's interior minister, Volker Bouffier, said the action was intended to pre-emptively combat "criminal Islamic structures." In the raids, at Internet cafes, discount telephone call shops and snack bars in 20 towns and cities, including Frankfurt, 500 officers interrogated more than 1,000 people. Of those arrested, Mr. Bouffier said, 33 had no valid residence permits and 3 had been sought in connection with other offenses. The action came days after France said it had arrested nine men near Paris who were suspected of being part of an Islamic cell planning terrorist attacks there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRIN, HOWARD SCOTT
description: KRIN--Howard Scott, on September 27, 2005. Beloved husband of Karen. Cherished son, brother and uncle. Funeral service Thursday, 1:30PM at "Gutterman's Inc." 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Move To End U.N. Nuclear Checks
description: Parliament voted to fast track a bill that would end inspections of the country's nuclear sites by the International Atomic Energy Agency in retaliation for the agency's resolution to report the country to the United Nations Security Council for violating the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. It could be a few weeks before the bill is prepared and approved. Later, hundreds of university students pelted the British Embassy with rocks and tomatoes to protest Britain's role in drafting the atomic energy agency's resolution, the ISNA news agency reported.

title: Competing with clients, FedEx goes online
DaimlerChrysler cuts German workforce
Three Car Bombs in Iraqi City Kill at Least 62
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 29 - Three pickup trucks packed with explosives detonated in quick succession this evening in a town north of Baghdad, killing at least 62 people and injuring scores of others in the latest of a string of increasingly deadly attacks aimed at Shiite civilians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSKOW, CONNIE B. (NEE BAIN)
description: MOSKOW--Connie B. (nee Bain). Age 62. Beloved wife of Michael of 38 years. Loving mother of Robert (Holly), Eliot (Veronica) and Lisa (Michael) Kimelman. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin, Gabriel, Jacob, Madeline and Sylvia. Devoted daughter of Gladys and the late George. Dear sister of Fabienne Bain. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Connie Moskow Breast Cancer Research Fund, c/o Northwestern Memorial Foundation, Attn: Steve Falk, 676 North St. Clair Suite 2050, Chicago, IL 60611 or your favorite charity. Service Thursday, 1 PM, at the Weinstein Funeral Homes, North Shore Chapel, 111 Skokie Blvd, Wilmette. Interment Memorial Park Cemetery, Skokie. 847-256-5700.

title: Strike expected to snarl traffic across country
Maazel Leads the Philharmonic in Carter, Mozart and Strauss
description: The New York Philharmonic has its hands full with what it is calling its focus on Elliott Carter this season. With one hand, it is patting itself on the back for programming more than a single work by one of this country's greatest living composers; with the other, it is assuring its subscribers that for all the self-congratulation, there won't be much: just four works, spread out between now and June.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SLADE, JOHN H.
description: SLADE--John H. A Service in Celebration of the Life of John H. Slade will be held Friday, September 30th at 10:30 AM at Congregation Emanu-El at 1 E. 65 Street, New York City.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Sept. 21 about "Blind Date" by Bill T. Jones credited the set imprecisely. While it was designed by Bjorn G. Amelan, the video projections were designed in collaboration with Peter Nigrini.

title: Abuse of Electroshock Found in Turkish Mental Hospitals
description: PARIS, Sept. 28 - Turkey's psychiatric hospitals are riddled with horrific abuses, including the use of raw electroshock as a form of punishment, according to a human rights report issued in Istanbul on Wednesday, just days before Turkey begins formal talks to join the European Union.

title: E*Trade to Buy BrownCo From J.P. Morgan for $1.6 Billion
description: E*Trade Financial said today that it would acquire BrownCo, a division of J.P. Morgan Chase, for $1.6 billion in cash, in a bid to get access to the firm's affluent and active-trading customers.

title: Ford to Cut Parts Suppliers in Bid to Reduce Costs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 - In its latest move to cut costs, the Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to drop half the companies supplying it auto parts like seats and instrument panels.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Slows to a 12-Year Low
description: Britain's economy expanded at its slowest annual pace in more than 12 years in the second quarter, reinforcing expectations that the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, will have to scale back plans to increase spending. Britain, Europe's second-largest economy after Germany, grew 1.5 percent from a year earlier, instead of the 1.8 percent estimated on Aug. 26, the Office for National Statistics said in London. It was the smallest gain since the first quarter of 1993. Record oil prices, the end of a property boom and rising unemployment dampened consumer spending in the first half as manufacturing entered a recession.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 22 Charged In Drug Case
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have charged 22 people, including two inmates at a federal prison in Pennsylvania, with conspiring to smuggle cocaine into the United States through the Howland Hook Marine Terminal on Staten Island and ports in San Francisco and Oakland, Calif. Four of the 22 were arrested in Colombia and are awaiting extradition to the United States. Prosecutors said two inmates controlled the operation while serving long sentences for drug crimes at the Federal Correctional Complex in Allenwood, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARR, MARILYN B.
description: CARR--Marilyn B. Died September 28, 2005. Beloved wife of Robert, mother of Meredith, grandmother of Abigail. Cherished by friends and relatives. A highly respected travel agent, founder of Linden Travel Bureau, school volunteer for many years. Services will be held on Friday, September 30, at 11:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Arctic ice: Going, going ...
Orders for Durable Goods Recovered Strongly in August
description: Orders for durable goods showed a surprisingly robust recovery in August, the government reported yesterday, indicating that the manufacturing sector was picking up its pace after a sharp drop in July and before Hurricanes Katrina and Rita devastated the Gulf Coast.

title: Yankees Rebound From Start to Finish to Take East Lead
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 - The Yankees had done their part to take over first place by themselves. They had edged the Baltimore Orioles, 2-1, on Wednesday night, getting the kind of steely pitching that had deserted them in a blowout loss the night before. Now, all they needed was a loss by the Red Sox in Boston.

title: GIs ready for spike in attacks, Bush says
Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about the National Football League's effort to create a home-field atmosphere for the New Orleans Saints misstated the name of the New Orleans police superintendent, who was to take part in the coin toss at a game with the New York Giants. (The error also occurred in numerous articles between Sept. 3 and Sept. 14.) The superintendent, who announced his retirement on Tuesday, is Edwin P. Compass III, not P. Edwin Compass III.

title: Briefs: Munich Re raises claims forecast
The Military Issues Order to Shape Up
description: ASK Airman Amanda Powell, who works in finance at Eglin Air Force Base in Fort Walton Beach, Fla., about her memories of boot camp, and she will smile proudly and reply, "I was in the top of my flight, fitness-wise."

title: Playing Favorites After Katrina (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Baltimore Mayor Announces His Candidacy for Governor
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 - Mayor Martin O'Malley, whose tough anticrime message helped propel him to two decisive election victories in Baltimore, began his campaign for Maryland governor on Wednesday evening, saying the state had gone "adrift" and needed new leadership.

title: Republicans See Signs That Pentagon Is Evading Oversight
description: Correction Appended

title: Hope for Korea
Paid Notice: Deaths   CORCORAN, JOHN
description: CORCORAN--John. We are all saddened by the loss of our good friend and music lover, John Corcoran, and we wish to extend our heartfelt sympathy to Susan and the rest of the family. Lyric Chamber Music Society of New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REIN, RUTH LICHTER
description: REIN--Ruth Lichter. Former owner of Crest Dance Studio in Queens, died on September 25, 2005 in West Palm Beach, FL. Funeral services, 11:30 AM, September 30, Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills.

title: Looper's Shoulder Ailed Him All Season
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 - It came too late to make much of a difference for the Mets, and it certainly came too late for their frustrated fans, but reliever Braden Looper reluctantly revealed before Wednesday's 16-6 loss to the Phillies that he had been pitching since the end of last season with inflammation in his right shoulder and that it would require surgery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about necklaces and bracelets said to enhance athletic ability misstated the academic standing of Dr. Clayton Everline, who wears a titanium necklace. He is a second-year resident, not a third-year resident, at St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark. This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: What Did Bill Frist Know and How?
description: DID Senator Bill Frist violate insider trading laws when he sold his stake in HCA Inc., the hospital chain that his father helped found?

title: Nora Kerr, 61, a New York Times Editor, Dies
description: Nora Kerr, a longtime editor at The New York Times and a former editor of its Sunday Travel section, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 61 and a Manhattan resident.

title: 29 Killed in Attack on Darfur Camp
description: Armed men on horses and camels attacked a refugee camp in the Darfur region, killing 29 people and raising concern that the volatile area was plunging further into violence, the United Nations said.

title: This Retro-Rock Doesn't Come in a Tidy Package
description: Is the reign of the neat freaks coming to an end? From retro-rock to new-new wave, many of the biggest alternative bands of the past few years have devoted themselves to tidiness: sharp sounds, arch attitudes, precise songs. The Strokes, Franz Ferdinand, Bloc Party, the Killers -- a fistful of bands from the United States and Britain have paid tribute to old styles by neatening them up.

title: Corzine Makes Property Taxes a Rallying Cry
description: Correction Appended

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Kissing Fidel" and "No Foreigners Beyond This Point."

title: Quality or Quantity
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Recycled
description:
Creating attractive items for homes or fashion using everything from recycled glass to
used bicycle tire tubes, some designers are proving that twice-used can look twice as good.

title: The Heat Is On
description: The calendar says autumn, but the temperatures are saying flip-flops.

title: Incompetence in the Bush Administration
description: Joseph Moosman, Karlsborg, Sweden, writes: Many thanks for your recent column on cronyism [Find the Brownie]. I hope your challenge is picked up and carried forward.

title: When Friendly Fire Becomes a Battle of Good and Evil
description: People are always so happy at the beginning of disaster movies.

title: Senate Confirms Roberts as 17th Chief Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Judge John G. Roberts Jr. became the 17th chief justice of the United States on Thursday, taking the oath of office during a brief but emotional White House ceremony just hours after the Senate, with its Democrats evenly divided, voted overwhelmingly to confirm him.

title: 36 Hours in Durango, Colo.
description: IN Durango, where red-rock buttes and flat-top mesas jut against the sharp peaks of the Rockies, the atmosphere of the Old West is well preserved. On Main Avenue, window displays bristle with cowboy boots and turquoise jewelry, frontier-style saloons feature waitresses in period costume, and the old steam engine on the Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad hollers as it rolls into the station. But walk a block from Main, and you'll find today's Durango, home of world-class mountain bikers, road cyclists and kayakers, where sun-kissed locals in visors and sunglasses kick back with pints of microbrewed beer - then head back out to indulge their adrenaline-charged exuberance for outdoor adventure.

title: Mexico Fears Its Drug Traffickers Get Help From Guatemalans
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 - The Ministry of Defense reported this week that a feared organization of hit men that was started by corrupt officers of the Mexican military had forged an alliance with deserters from an elite Guatemalan military unit to help the Mexicans fight for control of drug-trafficking routes across the United States border.

title: Born to Consume, No Matter What the Cost
description: Clotheshorses, shopaholics, kleptomaniacs and teenagers desperate to pierce their navels: these are among the female consumers of varying age who sprawl across the screen in Henry Jaglom's comedy "Going Shopping." The movie, written by Mr. Jaglom and Victoria Foyt, who stars as the owner of an upscale urban boutique called Holly G's, for which she designs many of the high-priced dresses, is a mostly all-girl yakfest; the men skulk guiltily around its margins.

title: A Teenager's Phantasmagoric Journey to Her Own Identity
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by Fairchild Publications to close Vitals Man and Vitals Woman magazines misstated the timing of an increase in the advertising circulation base for Domino, a shopping magazine published by Cond Nast Publications, the parent of Fairchild. It will increase to 450,000 from 400,000 in January; the announcement was made in August.

title: Balancing Wild Passion With Cool Restraint for a Requiem
description: Lincoln Center can rightfully claim truth in advertising. This season's Great Performers series began on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall with a truly great performance: Colin Davis conducting the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus in Verdi's Requiem Mass.

title: Big margin questioned in Algeria
Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Sept. 21 about the National Book Foundation's choice of Norman Mailer to receive a lifetime achievement award misstated his position and tenure at Dissent magazine. He was a member of the editorial board from 1955 to 1991, not editor from 1952 to 1963. (The magazine was founded in 1954.)

description: Attractions

description: NEW YORK

title: Senate Confirms Roberts as 17th Chief Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Judge John G. Roberts Jr. became the 17th chief justice of the United States on Thursday, taking the oath of office during a brief but emotional White House ceremony just hours after the Senate, with its Democrats evenly divided, voted overwhelmingly to confirm him.

title: Election Reform Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Roberts, sworn in, is joining a Supreme Court in transition
Book Report: The business of soccer (not)
Investing: Too late to buy gold?
Paid Notice: Deaths   GODLEY, ELIZABETH MCCRAY
description: GODLEY--Elizabeth McCray. The Friends of Bassett and the medical staff and administration of Bassett Healthcare mourn the passing of our friend, colleague and member of the Friends' board of directors. Her support for the Friends of Bassett and the patients and families served by Bassett Healthcare was unwavering. Mrs. Godley and her late husband, Ambassador George McMurtrie ("Mac") Godley, supported many of Bassett's regional initiatives that continue to benefit thousands of patients and families throughout central New York. Following the Ambassador's death, Mrs. Godley's generosity helped establish Bassett's Critical Care Complex, the Bassett Heart Care Institute and the Mithoefer Center for Rural Surgery. Mrs. Godley was the quintessential woman of action. We are most honored that she gave so much of her time, experience and support to advance rural health care in our region. We send our deepest condolences to her family. She will be deeply missed. William F. Streck, M.D. President and C.E.O., Bassett Healthcare Charles T. The Listings: Sept. 30 -- Oct. 6; SCOTT DUBOIS AND LOREN STILLMAN
description: For much of jazz's history, and particularly since the dawn of the Marsalis era, up-and-comers have been elevated according to their command of the jazz tradition. But "the jazz tradition" is a fluid concept these days, encompassing not only blues and bebop but also the jangly polyphony of Ornette Coleman, the enigmatic lyricism of Wayne Shorter and the folk idioms of far-flung locales. Loren Stillman, a saxophonist, and Scott DuBois, a guitarist, are two examples of younger artists with this broad-minded definition of the music, and each has begun to make waves. Last week, Mr. DuBois, above left, took part in the semifinals for the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition; Mr. Stillman, above right, was a semifinalist in 2002. They have several more things in common: exploratory yet melodic sensibilities, serious compositional ambitions and the tutelage of the saxophonist David Liebman. Naturally, the two musicians work together, in Mr. DuBois's longtime quintet; the other members are the saxophonist Jason Rigby, the bassist Thomas Morgan and the drummer Mark Ferber. "Monsoon," an album released last year on the Soul Note label, weighs this ensemble's cohesive looseness against the complex subtleties of Mr. DuBois's compositions. Similar tensions inhabit the music of Mr. Stillman, whose fourth solo album, "It Could Be Anything" (Fresh Sound New Talent), will be available in late October. Two nights after playing with Mr. DuBois, Mr. Stillman will lead a quartet featuring the guitarist Ben Monder, the bassist Eivind Opsvik and the drummer Ted Poor, each a bandleader in his own right. (The Scott DuBois Group plays Sunday at 9:30 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212)929-9883; $5. The Loren Stillman Group plays Tuesday at 10 p.m., Bowery Poetry Club, 308 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, (212)614-0505; $8.)

title: The Listings: Sept. 30 -- Oct. 6; 'ARIANE ET BARBE-BLEU'
description: The most famous creation of the composer Paul Dukas was most famously played by Mickey Mouse, who appeared as the Sorcerer's Apprentice in the original Disney film "Fantasia." It is slightly odd that Dukas should be associated with a cartoon icon, since he was an eminently serious composer: one reason that he's not better known is that he was so self-critical that he destroyed much of his own work. One piece that did survive was his major opera, "Ariane et Barbe-Bleu," which had its premiere at the Opra-Comique in Paris in 1907. Its dense, luminous score has historically won the approval of musicians, and its female lead has been played by some of the 20th century's great sopranos (including Germaine Lubin and Geraldine Farrar). But it has never caught on with the public even as much as, say, Debussy's "Pellas et Mlisande," another setting of a Maeterlinck play, and certainly not as much as Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle," another operatic version of the same folk tale. Now New York City Opera is giving at least some of the public a rare chance to hear the work (for those who weren't around for its Met performances in 1911 and 1912), in a new production. Many of those involved are new to the company, among them Paul-mile Fourny, the director; Louis Dsir, the set and costume designer (see the design above); the soprano Renate Behle, replacing Carol Vaness, who had to withdraw for health reasons, as Ariane; and Leon Botstein, the conductor, president of Bard College, and a passionate defender of less-known music. His conducting skills, unfortunately, don't match his passion, but this is still a work well worth hearing. (Thursday night at 7:30, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212)875-5570; remaining tickets, $25 to $95.)

title: 36 Hours in Durango, Colo.
description: IN Durango, where red-rock buttes and flat-top mesas jut against the sharp peaks of the Rockies, the atmosphere of the Old West is well preserved. On Main Avenue, window displays bristle with cowboy boots and turquoise jewelry, frontier-style saloons feature waitresses in period costume, and the old steam engine on the Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad hollers as it rolls into the station. But walk a block from Main, and you'll find today's Durango, home of world-class mountain bikers, road cyclists and kayakers, where sun-kissed locals in visors and sunglasses kick back with pints of microbrewed beer -- then head back out to indulge their adrenaline-charged exuberance for outdoor adventure. title: The 'Outsider' Art of 'Junebug'
description: In Phil Morrison's film "Junebug," a Chicago art dealer (Embeth Davidtz) travels South to research the work of a self-taught artist named David Wark (Frank Hoyt Taylor, above.) The paintings attributed to the fictional Wark -- strange, visionary tableaus of racial and sexual violence during the Civil War, painted with acrylic, ink and house paint on found surfaces, including plywood, linoleum and book covers -- were actually made for the film by a Brooklyn-based artist, Ann Wood. What is it like for a trained painter to be commissioned to produce work that deliberately invokes that of an untrained, or "outsider," artist? In an interview, Ms. Wood recalled her working process for the film: "Phil and I spent a lot of time together looking at things -- nave art and Civil War photography and the murals at Pompeii -- and experimenting during the week or so before he went to North Carolina to begin filming. The first few attempts weren't successful, but in each step of the process, we solved a problem or found a piece of the puzzle. Phil's got a giant imagination." She acknowledged the influence of well-known outsider artists like Howard Finster, Horace Pippin and Henry Darger on the "Junebug" paintings. She said of Darger: "There are some obvious similarities -- the uniformed soldiers, violence and weird sexuality but what I love about them, am inspired by, and refer to them for is composition."

World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: 29 Killed In Attack On Darfur Camp
description: Armed men on horses and camels attacked a refugee camp in the Darfur region, killing 29 people and raising concern that the volatile area was plunging further into violence, the United Nations said. The attack, which took place Wednesday at the Aro Sharow camp in northwest Darfur, forced several thousand people into the countryside, where Arab militias known as janjaweed have been attacking black African villagers since early 2003 in a campaign the United States government has deemed genocide. Continuing peace talks in the Nigerian capital have not yet reached a deal. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Railway Apology For Deporting Jews
description: The Dutch national railway company apologized for the first time for its role in deporting thousands of Jews to Nazi concentration camps in World War II. It acknowledged that it had collaborated with the Nazi occupiers by deporting 107,000 Dutch Jews, or 70 percent of the country's Jewish community, to camps in Germany and Poland. "On behalf of the company and from the bottom of my heart, I sincerely apologize for what happened during the war," the company's chief executive, Aad Veenman, said. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Corrections

She was his mistress. (His second wife was Carol Orchard, who did not commit suicide.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERR, NORA
description: KERR--Nora. 62, on Tuesday, September 27, 2005. Born in Cairo, Egypt on November 19, 1943. After the war she and her family moved to the United States where she grew up in suburban New Jersey. She attended Rutgers, The State University and William Paterson University of New Jersey, before leaving for a variety of writing positions at New Jersey radio stations. She eventually was hired by the Bergen Record, and, in December, 1975 by the New York Times. Among the positions she held at the Times were Travel Editor, Regional News Editor, Styles Editor, Westchester Weekly Editor, Magazine Part II Editor, and most recently, Assistant Editor in Culture News. Survivors include her husband, Gordon T. Thompson of NYC, her son, Andrew Kerr-Thompson of NYC, her sister, Jacqueline Kerr Harrold of Benton, PA. Services will be at 10:30 AM, Saturday, October 1, at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street.

title: Sand, Water, Intrigue and a Lot of Suntans
description: In the soggy adventure "Into the Blue," the supertoned, ultratanned actors Paul Walker and Jessica Alba spend much of their screen time submerged in the sapphire depths of the Bahamian archipelago. All this splish-splashing serves this throwaway entertainment on two counts: for one thing, with their mouths plugged, the actors are spared the painful work of delivering the unspeakable dialogue. More important, these underwater interludes strip away any pretense that a flick like this exists for any reason except to show a couple of hotties shimmying about in as few clothes as is PG-13 permissible.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Environment At Risk, Watchdog Says
description: The commissioner of the environment, Johanne Glinas, said in a report that the country's drinking water, national parks and oceans were not being adequately protected. The report by Ms. Glinas, who oversees environmental matters for the auditor general, said the government, which has often pledged to make the environment a priority, "suffers from a chronic inability to see its own initiatives to completion." In response, the environment minister, Stphane Dion, acknowledged that the government could do more. Colin Campbell (NYT)

A Letter From the Shores of Iraq
description: Umm Qasr, Iraq - To reach the headquarters of the Iraqi Navy in the port of Umm Qasr, my U.S. Navy escort and I had to drive in from Kuwait. We were met at the border by two jeeps with the Royal Marines who escorted us to Umm Qasr at dusk. Even though this is the safest part of Iraq, we had to be outfitted in body armor, and the Royal Marines had their automatic weapons loaded and ready. They kept every civilian car we passed, every kid on a bicycle, in their sights, just in case one was a suicide bomber.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Mayor Will Not Seek New Term
description: The mayor of Washington, Anthony A. Williams, said he would not seek a third term, bowing out of a crowded field for next year's Democratic primary. Five candidates have already entered the race. Mr. Williams's leadership since taking office in 1999 had impressed large parts of the city, particularly in the predominantly white northwest quarter. But his record was not without tarnish. His re-election campaign was fined $277,700 in 2002 for submitting thousands of fraudulent signatures on nominating petitions. John Files (NYT)
