description: Seven students at John F. Kennedy High School were arrested yesterday and charged with rioting during and after a protest over reductions in the school's guidance staff, the police and city education officials said. About 200 seniors protested the elimination of four of the school's 10 guidance counselor positions, said Keith Kalb, a spokesman for the Department of Education. The cuts were a result of a reduction in the number of students at Kennedy, he said. Officials said that three students were arrested inside the school building, including one who struck a school safety agent with an umbrella. Four others were arrested outside the school. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

The Listings: Sept. 30 -- Oct. 6; MOVEMENT RESEARCH
description: Carla Peterson received one of the most rousing ovations at this year's Dance and Performance Awards (known as the Bessies) when she won a special citation for "guts and gumption in directing Movement Research." The audience of choreographers, performers, presenters and others within the New York dance world knows what a vital and intelligent role that organization plays in fostering the creation of process-oriented, investigative movement like that of K.J.Holmes, above. If you want to see how choreographers think about, develop and explore emerging aesthetics in dance, head over to Dance Theater Workshop any Sunday over the next two months, where, for the 14th season, artists chosen by a rotating panel of their peers will show works-in-progress. On this first Sunday, Jonah Bokaer, Heather Kravas, Kiyoko Kashiwagi and Melanie Maar will present their ideas; Ms. Maar is currently an artist-in-residence at Movement Research, a title held last year by both Ms. Kravas and Mr. Kashiwagi. The focus here is on exploration, not end result, with the artists performing anything they choose within a 5-to-15 minute period. While the work can incorporate other art forms, don't expect a lot of high-tech bells and whistles; as the name indicates, it's all about the movement. There's no admission, but neither are there reservations for the limited-seating showings, so arrive early. Doors open at 7:45 for 8 p.m. performances. (Sundays in October and November, starting this weekend, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)598-0551.)

title: Arts, Briefly; Old or New, 'Lost' Wins
description: ABC easily won Wednesday's Nielsen competition in all the key ratings measurements, with a new episode of "Lost" drawing 22.6 million viewers at 9 p.m. That episode was preceded by a repeat of its season premiere from last week and, in discouraging news for the other networks, this rerun beat all five of their offerings during the 8 p.m. hour. NBC's "Apprentice: Martha Stewart" (6.22 million) was among the vanquished, sinking further from its weak debut last Wednesday. But ABC's "Invasion" didn't benefit from the strength of "Lost" nearly as much as it should have. It delivered 12.97 million viewers and was weaker in the second half-hour than the first, which is never a good sign. NBC's "Law & Order" roundly beat "Invasion" in total viewers (14.73 million), but more important, it did better than the season premiere of CBS's "CSI: New York" in both viewers (13.12 million) and adults 18 to 49. Before that, CBS's "Criminal Minds" made its time period debut opposite "Lost" and managed to place a very distant second, with an audience of 10.56 million. Fans of UPN's critically beloved "Veronica Mars" can feel some relief. In the hour after "America's Next Top Model" (4.46 million, No. 2 in women 18 to 34), the opener of Season 2 of "Veronica" (3.15 million) had its biggest viewership and demographic numbers ever.

description: MOSS--Chester C. (Chet), 84, died September 29, 2005. Loving husband of Shirley (Star), devoted father of Ronnie, Nancy and Barbara. Dear father-in-law of Andrew Segal. description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 - Ford said on Thursday that it planned to cut in half the number of companies supplying it major auto parts, like seats and instrument panels. It was the latest cost-cutting initiative by the financially troubled automaker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTENBERG, MICHAEL
description: WITTENBERG--Michael. The Board of Directors and staff of The Manhattan Theatre Club express our deepest sympathy to the family of Michael Wittenberg, husband of our beloved friend and board member Bernadette Peters. He will be sincerely missed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bank of Italy Council Votes to Keep Chief
description: The council of the Bank of Italy, the country's central bank, voted to retain the bank's governor, Antonio Fazio, and refused to call a special meeting that would have been necessary to remove him. The council rebuffed calls from the prime minister and the current and former finance ministers for Mr. Fazio's ouster because of accusations that he favored an Italian bank's bid for Banca Antonveneta over an offer by ABN Amro Holding. The council is the only body with the power to remove the chief of the Bank of Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICE, JOEL KEY
description: RICE--Joel Key. Passed away on Friday September 23 at NY Presbyterian Hospital. He was born in Applachicola, FL, the son of Rob Roy and Clara Buzhardt Rice. A small private service was held at St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: Arts, Briefly; Country's Biggest Stars Featured in Rare Video
description: On Oct. 14, Viacom's Country Music Television will broadcast previously unseen video of Johnny Cash, Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings and Kris Kristofferson. Jennings died in 2002; Cash in 2003. The video, shot by the Los Angeles-based record producer and bassist Don Was, comes from the final 1994 recording session of the Highwaymen, the quartet that included all four country music icons. Their first hit as a band was "Highwayman" (1985), a No. 1 country single written by Jimmy Webb.

title: Court Allows Tobacco Suits in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 29 - A ruling by the Supreme Court of Canada opened the door Thursday for the province of British Columbia to sue tobacco companies in an effort to recover the cost of smoking-related health care.

title: House Jockeying Begins For Leadership Positions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Representative Tom DeLay's fall from power under criminal indictment in Texas quickly touched off intense political jockeying among House Republicans on Thursday as they sensed that Mr. DeLay's troubles could create a rare opportunity to win a spot in the party leadership.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Principal In Fraud Attempt Is Removed
description: New York City education officials said yesterday that they were reviewing the case of a Manhattan high school principal who urged parents to falsify income information on school lunch forms, apparently to increase government aid to the school. The principal, Maurice Collins, of A. Philip Randolph Campus High School, was removed this month after officials learned he had written to parents that "the lower you estimate your income, the better for the school budget." A report from investigators released yesterday found that Mr. Collins sent copies of the letter to his superiors, but they said they did not read it closely. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Housing for Storm's Evacuees Lagging Far Behind U.S. Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - After Hurricane Katrina left hundreds of thousands of people homeless, the Federal Emergency Management Agency signed contracts for more than $2 billion in temporary housing, including more than 120,000 trailers and mobile homes. But the agency has placed just 109 Louisiana families in those homes.

title: Audit Assails the White House for Public Relations Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 - Federal auditors said today that the Bush administration had violated the law by purchasing favorable news coverage of President Bush's education policies, by making payments to the conservative commentator Armstrong Williams and by hiring a public relations company to analyze media perceptions of the Republican Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, HOWARD J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSS, WILLIAM J.
description: MOSS--William J. The Officers and Trustees of The Flagler Museum are saddened by the death of their longtime friend and colleague who, with brilliant mind and clever wit, served the Museum safely for 28 years as Secretary, Treasurer and Trustee. His consummate insight, leadership, friendship and charming sense of humor cannot be replaced. We express our deepest sympathy to Casey, his loving wife of 58 years, his nine children and 18 grandchildren. Bill, we will miss you. The Flagler Museum might well not exist today and be the strong institution that it is were it not for your foresight, dedication, steadfast support and lasting leadership. George Matthews, President Robert Hanke, Vice-Pres. William Matthews, Treasurer Thomas Kenan, Secretary

title: Peterson May Be Lost for Season With Back Injury
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 29 - Giants cornerback Will Peterson said Thursday that he could miss the rest of the season with a fractured vertebra, an injury similar to the one that cost him the final 11 games of 2003, putting a struggling defense in an even tougher bind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKNOW, MURIEL
description: JACKNOW--Muriel. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of our devoted friend Muriel Jacknow of Farmington Hills, MI. A past member of the ATS national and East Central Region Boards, Mrs. Jacknow and her late husband, Dr. David Jacknow established the annual David and Muriel Jacknow Prize for Excellence in Teaching. They contributed to various Detroit chapter and regional projects which funded Technion research, dormitories and laboratory equipment, and hosted meetings in their home. Mrs. Jacknow was also active in the ATS chapter in Sarasota, FL. We extend our condolences to her daughters Lisa Elias and Amy Jacknow, her son, Dr. Alan D. Jacknow, her grandchildren, and the entire Jacknow family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Scott Leemaster, Detroit Chapter President Matthew T. Engelbert, East Central Region Director

title: Steve Marcus, 66, Saxophonist Who Blended Jazz and Rock, Dies
description: Steve Marcus, a jazz saxophonist who was an early exponent of the style that came to be known as fusion, died on Sunday at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 66.

description: Boston - WHAT do you say when the front office sends you a pitcher four days before the end of the season? Thank you, or what took you so long?

Booths selling pricey pumpkin-theme dust-catchers. And, of course, weigh-offs. But some civic festivals are more creative with this humble all-American fruit.

Brown as the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, referred incorrectly to Mr. Brown's longtime friendship with Joe M. Allbaugh, a former campaign adviser to President Bush who recommended Mr. Brown for the job. While they have known each other for decades, they did not attend college together.

title: New Jersey Chemical Leak Disrupts Morning Commute
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 30 - A chemical leak at a swimming pool chemical plant in Kearny, N.J., this morning snarled the morning commute by closing the Pulaski Skyway and had local officials warning of potential health risks to residents with respiratory problems.

title: Scruffy Space Cowboys Fighting Their Failings
description: It probably isn't fair to Joss Whedon's "Serenity" to say that this unassuming science-fiction adventure is superior in almost every respect to George Lucas's aggressively more ambitious "Star Wars: Episode III -- Revenge of the Sith." But who cares about fair when there is fun to be had? Scene for scene, "Serenity" is more engaging and certainly better written and acted than any of Mr. Lucas's recent screen entertainments. Mr. Whedon isn't aiming to conquer the pop-culture universe with a branded mythology; he just wants us to hitch a ride to a galaxy far, far away and have a good time. The journey is the message, not him.

title: Abdirahman Is Set to Compete
description: Abdi Abdirahman of Tucson, Ariz., in the midst of a successful year, has joined the field for the New York City Marathon on Nov. 6. Earlier this month, Abdirahman set an American record of 58 minutes 42 seconds for 20 kilometers. This year, he has also won national tiles at 10 kilometers and 10 miles and finished second in the national 8-kilometer championship. He made his marathon debut in New York last year, placing 14th in 2 hours 17 minutes 9 seconds. Frank Litsky

description: Hedge funds are not meant to be for everyone. But that has not stopped Christian Baha from using the mass media to promote his fund.

title: School Bus Carrying About 50 Overturns in Bronx
description: A full-length yellow school bus with nearly 50 passengers on board overturned in the Bronx late this morning, injuring an undetermined number of children. None of the injuries were currently thought to be serious, said a New York City Fire Department spokesman, who did not know what school the students were from.

title: Americans Plan Rome Trip Over Ban on Gay Priests
description: Responding to reports that the Vatican may be close to releasing a directive to exclude most gay candidates from entering the priesthood, leaders of Roman Catholic men's religious orders in the United States are planning to travel to Rome to voice their objections in person.

title: The Way It Is
description: Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. He sold all his stock in HCA, which his father helped found, just days before the stock plunged. Two years ago, Mr. Frist claimed that he did not even know if he owned HCA stock.

title: DeLay Goes on Radio and TV to Proclaim Innocence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Representative Tom DeLay went on a media blitz on Thursday, a day after his indictment on charges of conspiracy in his home state, Texas, angrily proclaiming his innocence and saying that Democratic leaders in Congress were working with a Democratic prosecutor in Texas to try to destroy his career.

title: Unconventional Perspectives on American History and the Irish Troubles
description: Both Neil Jordan's "Breakfast on Pluto," the centerpiece of the New York Film Festival, and Lars von Trier's "Manderlay" stretch the traditional boundaries of what we think of as epic films. The hero/heroine of Mr. Jordan's sprawling comedy is a male transvestite; the heroine of "Manderlay," the second part of Mr. von Trier's United States trilogy, is a gangster's idealistic daughter whose grand do-gooder schemes inevitably backfire. The movies are political in opposite ways. Mr. Jordan's radically apolitical protagonist, Kitten, mirrors the absurdity of war (the Irish troubles). "Manderlay" is an allegorical tract about racism in America that asks uncomfortable questions about slavery and its legacy that no major American filmmaker would dare address so boldly. Both are important films. STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Salesman Charged In Theft At Hospital
description: A Queens man has been arrested in connection with the theft of roughly $750,000 from Jacobi Medical Center, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday. Brian Lew, 31, of Little Neck, was charged with second-degree grand larceny, prosecutors said. In a statement, Mr. Spitzer said that Mr. Lew, a salesman of surgical implant materials, received commissions based on false invoices for medical supplies.

title: Insurers' Merger Plans Raise Questions About an Expected Windfall for New York State
description: Two of the region's biggest health insurers, Health Insurance Plan of New York and Group Health Inc., announced yesterday that they planned to merge, raising new questions about an expected multibillion-dollar windfall for New York State from HIP's planned conversion to a profit-making company.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot On Way To Subway
description: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot in East New York yesterday morning as he walked to the subway, the police and his relatives said. The man, Robert Bynum, 25, was shot several times by an unknown gunman on Warwick Street not far from his home, and was pronounced dead at the scene. Mr. Bynum, who had three children, was on his way to his job loading trucks at a warehouse in Queens. The police said they did not know the motive for the shooting, which occurred about 7 a.m. A man who was in the area said he heard a voice saying, "I didn't do anything, I didn't do anything," then five or six gunshots, and an automobile speeding off. Relatives said that his wife and children had fled in fear. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Two Charged In Fatal Shooting
description: Two Newark men were arrested yesterday in connection with a shooting on Wednesday that left two people dead and one person wounded at a Newark social club. The two men, David Jackson, 20, and John Thompson, 25, surrendered separately after investigators identified them as suspects in the shootings at the SJMJ Democratic Social Club on Avon Avenue, said Detective Todd McClendon of the Newark police. The police said that the men, who are charged with murder and other offenses, have a record of assault and robbery. John Holl (NYT)
